Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe news of my father\u2019s passing is impossible to fathom,\u201d he wrote. \u201cThey say he committed suicide. I still can\u2019t believe this.\u201d\n\nFor decades, Mr. Seyed Emami taught sociology at Tehran\u2019s Imam Sadegh University, a hard-line institution where the cadres of the Iranian establishment are trained. He said it was his duty to teach students his opposing views. In his spare time, he organized popular camping trips for Tehrani youths to the outskirts of Iran.\n\nOther environmentalists associated with Mr. Seyed Emami\u2019s organization remain behind bars. Mr. Tahbaz, the Iranian-American businessman, is a board member of the Persian Heritage Wildlife Foundation, and was quietly arrested by intelligence agents while visiting the country.\n\nSeveral local employees and volunteers of the foundation were also arrested, though it is unclear why. Mr. Tahbaz has been accused by hard-line Iranian news outlets of plotting to sell hunting permits, something that seems highly implausible, people close to the foundation say.\n\nThe detention of Mr. Tahbaz adds to a long list of dual nationals arrested in Iran, most of them by the intelligence service of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps. Family members of two Iranian-Americans sentenced for spying, Baquer and Siamak Namazi, a father and son, say Iran is effectively holding them hostage in order to make a prisoner exchange.\n\nIn 2003, an Iranian-Canadian photographer, Zahra Kazemi, died in Evin prison after she was detained while taking photographs. Her death led to a downgrading in relations between Canada and Iran.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere is currently no Canadian embassy in the country and there are no official diplomatic relations between the two nations.", "title": "He Fought for Iran\u2019s Environment and Was Arrested. Now, He\u2019s Dead.", "authors": ["Thomas Erdbrink"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Nacho fries! Tuscani Pasta! Chicken Alfredo! Posters and sales pitches for Taco Bell\u2019s latest menu additions cover the windows of a store on a busy Manhattan block.\n\nAt a nearby Chipotle, however, the signage was more subdued: \u201cNow Open,\u201d it read simply.\n\nThe posters are a stark illustration of the deep divides between the two low-priced Mexican-food chains. Fast food \u2014 its stream of new menu items, its marketing, its reliance on franchisees \u2014 is in Taco Bell\u2019s DNA, while Chipotle has used a simple menu to build a fleet of company-owned stores.\n\nIt\u2019s a gulf that Taco Bell\u2019s chief executive, Brian Niccol, will have to bridge when he moves to Chipotle next month. Credited with reversing Taco Bell\u2019s fortunes, he must now apply those successes in an entirely different environment, as Chipotle struggles with a plunging stock price and a string of health issues that have hurt its image.", "title": "He Led a Turnaround at Taco Bell. Can He Do It at Chipotle?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Back in New York, he dropped salaried jobs in favor of flexible freelance gigs in fashion and advertising that would support his own work. With his magnetically reticent personality, he moved with ease through the overlapping countercultural spheres that comprised the downtown avant-garde, from Judson Dance Theater to the Warhol Factory and the nascent gay movement. He was around for the 1969 Stonewall Rebellion. And when, in its wake, his then-lover, Jim Fouratt, became a founding member of the Gay Liberation Front, Hujar contributed to the cause the only way he knew how, with a photograph \u2014 of GLF members staging a protest march for his camera. It remains one of the signature images of the time.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Hujar himself had no interest in activist politics. By this point, he was 35 years old, struggling professionally, cash-poor, but rich in downtown connections. The world he cared about was the one he could view, edit, speak to and shade through his camera. And in the \u201970s and early \u201980s, that\u2019s what he did by initiating his own personal golden age of portraiture.\n\nA few of his portraits of famous figures \u2014 the singer Peggy Lee, for example \u2014 may have been a product of freelance assignments. Most others were self-assigned. Some were of high-profile personalities like Susan Sontag. But the fame of most of his sitters extended little farther than a few blocks downtown. Occasionally he would shoot \u201con location,\u201d as he did in the case of the Warhol transgender superstar Candy Darling (born James Lawrence Slattery), who, dying of cancer at 29, vamped for him in her hospital bed. But generally, people came to his Second Avenue studio.\n\nPhoto\n\nThey included such protean theater figures as Charles Ludlam and Robert Wilson; the poets John Ashbery and Anne Waldman; critics like Vince Aletti and Fran Lebowitz, who were also close personal friends; and drag performers like Jackie Curtis and later \u2014 repeatedly \u2014 the endlessly versatile Ethyl Eichelberger. Hujar referred to his favored sitters as people who were \u201cchic, but in a dark kind of way.\u201d Whatever their darkness, he made them glow with sumptuous black-and-white chiaroscuro. And he made even the edgiest figures \u2014 a man tying his limbs into knots, a woman locked in a body cast \u2014 look relax and softened.\n\nTo create this effect, he used a technique that could easily have been lifted from therapy. He asked many of his 1970s portrait subjects, male and female, clothed and nude, to pose lying down on his bed, where they seem to be drifting toward asleep, or just waking up, or lost in post-coital trance. And nowhere is a sense of tenderness and vulnerability more evident than in Hujar\u2019s photographs of animals that he encountered in the wild or on farms belonging to friends.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe would slowly approach cows or sheep or birds, talking softly, conversationally, calming them into stillness. He seems to have regarded the animal portraits \u2014 along with his several portraits, early and late, of children \u2014 as, in some sense, self-portraits. They certainly feel like images understood from the inside: emblems of innocence threatened. Yet more than even the most composed of his human subjects, Hujar\u2019s animals seem self-controlled and self-contained. They have the inviolate dignity of bodhisattvas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA few of these photographs, along with several of the prone human portraits, appeared side by side in the only book Hujar published in his lifetime, \u201cPortraits in Life and Death,\u201d which arrived, with an introduction by Sontag, in 1976. And intermingled with those pictures were some of his shots of corpses from the Palermo catacombs. The book got a mixed reception. Some people hated it. They thought the combination of living and dead, human and animal, was perverse and grotesque. I loved it, still do.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt demonstrates that each of Hujar\u2019s photographs is a stand-alone object, masterfully conceived and printed, complete in itself. Yet the work overall is the product of a single complex, difficult sensibility. It shares a pervasive and insistent atmosphere of otherness, and \u2014 this comes through only gradually \u2014 a spirit of level-eyed fortitude in the face of damage. (The same point is made in the show, organized by the Morgan\u2019s curator of photographs, Joel Smith, which replicates the book-like, edge-to-edge hanging of 70 disparate pictures in vertical pairs that Hujar created for his 1986 solo show at Gracie Mansion Gallery.)\n\nAnd damage did come, with the emergence of AIDS. Many of the people in Hujar\u2019s photographs \u2014 Eichelberger, Ludlam and Wojnarowicz lead a long list \u2014 died as a result of the disease, which makes the show itself a portrait in life and death. Hujar, who remained little known to the art world at large while the reputations of near-contemporaries like Robert Mapplethorpe soared \u2014 received his diagnosis in 1986. He put down his camera in despair and never worked again. He died a year later, at 53.\n\nIn a way, the Morgan has picked up the thread of his art for him. Its exhibition catalog, with essays by Philip Gefter, Steve Turtell and Mr. Smith, gives the first full account of his life. And the museum itself has acquired a substantial chunk of his work \u2014 more than 100 lifetime prints and thousands of contact sheets \u2014 for its permanent collection. In the process, a venerable institution has refreshed itself, and a resistantly singular artist has become the Classic he always was and will always be.", "title": "He Made Them Glow: A Maverick\u2019s Portraits Live On", "authors": ["Holland Cotter"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "But insurance brokers, gay-rights advocates and staff at medical clinics said in interviews they had heard of numerous such cases. H.I.V. specialists say the denials endanger men\u2019s lives by encouraging them to drop PrEP if they need life, disability or long-term-care insurance.\n\nBy contrast, health insurance companies usually cover PrEP, which the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention endorsed in 2014 for anyone at substantial risk of H.I.V., which includes any gay or bisexual man who might have sex without a condom with anyone of unknown H.I.V. status.\n\nThe denials turn the insurance industry\u2019s risk-management standard on its head: men who do not protect themselves can get policies, while men who do cannot.\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t make any sense,\u201d said Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, and perhaps the nation\u2019s best-known AIDS doctor. \u201cIt ought to be the other way around.\u201d\n\nDr. Robert M. Grant, the AIDS researcher at the University of California, San Francisco, who led the clinical trial that established the value of PrEP, said such denials \u201creally are silly \u2014 it\u2019s like refusing to insure someone because they use seatbelts.\u201d\n\nMoreover, advocates argue, the practice singles out gay men for discriminatory treatment. Women, for instance, are not denied coverage if they use birth control pills or get the vaccine against human papillomavirus, which can cause cervical cancer. Yet like Truvada, use of these drugs suggests an active sex life, with the accompanying risks.\n\nAnd insurers routinely cover applicants with actual diseases controlled by medications, including diabetes, epilepsy, high blood pressure and bipolar disorder.", "title": "He Took a Drug to Prevent AIDS. Then He Couldn\u2019t Get Disability Insurance.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBoom.\n\nA star is dead.\n\nOn Sept. 20, 2016, Victor Buso, an amateur astronomer in Rosario, Argentina, was checking out the new camera on his telescope by taking pictures of a nearby spiral galaxy when a star within it went off in a supernova explosion.\n\nWithin hours, and prompted by Mr. Buso\u2019s good fortune, professional astronomers around the world trained their big telescopes on the galaxy, known as NGC 613, about 80 million light-years from here in the constellation Sculptor. It was a rare instance in which astronomers were able to see the beginning of a supernova, when one of the most massive stars in the universe ends its life in one of the most violent events nature can cook up.\n\nMost supernovas are far away and don\u2019t call attention to themselves until their funeral pyre explosions are well underway. In this case, astronomers were able to record what they call the \u201cbreakout,\u201d when a shock wave radiating from a star\u2019s core, which has probably collapsed into a black hole, reaches the surface of the poor star and brightens it catastrophically.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like winning the cosmic lottery,\u201d said Alex Filippenko, in a news release from the Keck Observatory in Hawaii, where Dr. Filippenko, of the University of California, Berkeley, has been tracking the supernova.\n\nThe astronomers, who reported their findings on Wednesday in Nature, said the original star had probably been about 20 times as massive as the sun, but had blown most of that mass off into space before the decisive explosion began.", "title": "He Took a Picture of a Supernova While Setting Up His New Camera", "authors": ["Dennis Overbye"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cFootball Destroyed My Husband\u2019s Mind\u201d (Sunday Review, Feb. 4):\n\nI read Emily Kelly\u2019s poignant essay as someone who was paralyzed 30 years ago while making a tackle in a college football game, and as the son of a Hall of Fame linebacker suffering from neurological disease caused by the thousands of hits he endured playing in college and professionally.\n\nSo while I have always loved football, I know the dangers.\n\nThere are steps to mitigate the risks, especially among youths. Now that there is considerable evidence of a relationship between head trauma in children and future neurological problems, contact football should be banned for those under 14.\n\nUntil such a ban, we need to enact national concussion assessment and intervention protocols; require parents or guardians to sign an authorization outlining the risks and potential consequences of playing tackle football; ensure that schools and leagues have liability insurance to cover the costs of catastrophic injuries; and mandate safety education and training for all involved in youth sports.\n\nWe can never reverse the devastating medical conditions that Rob Kelly and thousands of others are now confronting. But we can offer a better prognosis for our sons and daughters who play football and other sports.", "title": "Opinion | Head Trauma and Football", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Courtney Webb and Ryan Spencer were dating for less than eight months before they decided to take the plunge.\n\n\u201cMy parents were like, \u2018Whoa, are you sure you\u2019re ready to get married? This is moving along really, really fast, but if you\u2019re happy, we\u2019re happy,\u2019\u201d said Ms. Webb, 29, who lives in Manhattan and is a founder of TriMix Fitness, a fitness studio in Greenwich, Conn.\n\n\u201cI guess you could say we\u2019ve had a whirlwind romance,\u201d she said. \u201cBut I\u2019m someone who has become used to moving along pretty quickly.\u201d\n\nMs. Webb, who is hoping to qualify as a skeleton athlete at the 2022 Olympic Games in Beijing, has indeed been moving along rapidly the past few years. In fact, she has taken hundreds of other whirlwind plunges, each aboard a one-person sled that sends her soaring down and around a twisted icy track \u2014 sometimes for more than a mile \u2014 at speeds of up to 85 miles per hour.", "title": "Headfirst With a Helmet, and Headlong Without", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "One of the biggest challenges is helping patients access quality mental-health services and counseling both for the addiction issues and the almost always present untreated mental-health issues. The opioid addiction is never the only problem. But mental-health care, especially for those on Medicaid, is challenging to access. Hours are too often limited to days, when people are at work (and many of my patients can\u2019t afford the unpaid time off that may lead to job termination). The other challenge is funding. Mental-health care and medical care for addiction is expensive. Medications that prevent withdrawal symptoms and block the high (or do one or the other) are excellent for tools for reducing the chance of relapse, but at an out-of-pocket cost of $500 to $700 per month, it is too expensive for many patients. Patients can end up buried under mountains of debt simply because they were responsible and sought treatment for their addiction. Medicaid does a bit better, but when patients bounce off of Medicaid because of a slight increase in income, it can put patients\u2019 sobriety in peril because their benefits for counseling, doctor visits and medication suddenly vanish until, again, that deductible is met. And access to mental-health care can be a serious challenge for Medicaid patients. Sarah Butler, Physician Assistant (Certified), Livonia, Mich.\n\nOur system perpetuates the problem. Patients expect that they will get prescribed opioids because in large part they will. If they don\u2019t, they might respond poorly to the question, \u201cWas your pain well-managed in the hospital?\u201d on patient satisfaction surveys. Reimbursement is in part based on the results of these surveys. They dominate our every interaction with patients. I recently broke a bone and both in the E.R. and in the M.D. office, was offered opioids as a first-line pain medication. I declined, aware that alternating acetaminophen and ibuprofen, and icing and elevating were better, evidence-based options for acute pain like a broken bone. Dolores Flanagan, Nurse, San Francisco\n\nA Lack of Empathy\n\nMany healthcare professionals noted that the way society stigmatizes addicts can jeopardize their recovery prospects.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe emphasis on the opioid epidemic speaks to a societal problem with empathy. As many publications have noted, when the addiction epidemic was concentrated in brown and black communities, it was a law enforcement problem. Now that addiction has moved to the suburbs, it is a public health issue, as it always should have been. Addiction is defined as a chronic, relapsing disease. Many have done bad things as a consequence of their addiction, but that doesn\u2019t mean they are irredeemable. We have known for quite some time now that addiction changes the brains of those who fall to its prey. We need to do a better job at using pharmacotherapies to treat addiction. Diabetics take medicines to address the changes of their disease process, yet in some treatment centers want addicts to go \u201ccold turkey\u201d or accuse them of \u201cswitching one addiction for another.\u201d Shannon Dingle, Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner, Bronx\n\nThe misconception about opioid use is the belief that it\u2019s a choice. There has been so much research that links opioid addiction with attachment disorder. So you have people who have suffered from poor parental bonding getting hooked on opioids often at the hands of the medical community; they go to jail, lose their jobs, children, freedom, and when they get out they can\u2019t get jobs, they have no emotional support and they blame themselves for their vulnerability. Why wouldn\u2019t they? The rest of the world blames them. No wonder they go back to using drugs. Addicts need love, support, connection. That\u2019s why they got addicted in the first place \u2014 not having these things. We need to have compassion. And, we need to understand and respect addiction more generally. Dr. Rebecca Jones, Dermatologist, Brattleboro, Vt.\n\nBurning Out\n\nThe emotional tollf required to take care of certain patients has overwhelmed some health care workers.\n\nI started as a therapist treating women in a major city, and over the course of a 10-year career wound up running multiple state-funded women\u2019s residential addiction programs there, with the purest of intentions to provide help for what I know to be mostly traumatized women. I got burned out and left my job about a year and a half ago because I couldn\u2019t deal with addicts anymore. They turn treatment on its head \u2014 it becomes a sort of \u201cgame on\u201d when they enter programs and proceed to break every rule, in a giant game of distraction, which invariably leads back to relapse. It\u2019s an exhausting and grim business treating addicts because one can\u2019t help but conclude in the end that most of them don\u2019t really want to change. It\u2019s been heart-wrenching for me to become so disillusioned with the whole thing. Name Withheld, Licensed Mental Health Counselor, Brooklyn\n\nI am a doctor, with a brother who was a heroin addict for 10 years. With my help, he got clean twice, both times by leaving the country for a while and getting out of his environment. However, he never admitted that he was an addict, never went to rehab and never changed his addictlike sociopathic behavior. We have not had a relationship for a very long time, and we never will again. I know it is not politically correct to say this, but opioids, narcotics, meth and all these drugs change people in very substantial ways, and it\u2019s a minority who are ever truly rehabilitated. I think we should put our medical efforts into the patients we may truly be able to help. Being an addict can be a choice, and they will get better only if they are really ready to. Meanwhile, I, personally, will not allow them to waste my time. Name Withheld, OB-GYN, New York\n\nRecovery Is Possible\n\nBut as rampant as opioid addiction has become, there have been stories of hope too.\n\nThe biggest misconception about opioid abuse is that folks cannot get better. I saw with intensive outpatient treatment over a year with Suboxone that miracles do happen. I saw folks get better and become productive members of society. I saw them turn around and give back to other addicts. I saw their families heal with them. But the investment of resources is significant. They also need continuing care for many years \u2014 less frequent treatment but they still need to attend groups at least once a week sometimes for years and continue on their Suboxone. Christine, Licensed Clinical Social Worker, Syracuse", "title": "Health Care Professionals Share Their Stories About Opioid-Addicted Patients", "authors": ["Alice Yin"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAt a moment when living composers \u2014 especially women \u2014 struggle to get their works performed, few would have predicted that a half-hour TV show would emerge as a key showcase for their work. But \u201cMozart in the Jungle,\u201d the daffy Amazon comedy whose fourth season began streaming on Friday, has become an unlikely destination to hear new music.\n\nHere is a taste of some of the recent pieces featured on the show, which is set in a fanciful version of the New York classical music world and stars Gael Garc\u00eda Bernal, Bernadette Peters, Malcolm McDowell and Lola Kirke. The works were performed on Tuesday at National Sawdust, the striking performance space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, which itself has a cameo in the season.\n\nCaroline Shaw\n\nCaroline Shaw, a composer, violinist and singer, won the Pulitzer Prize in 2013, when she was 30 \u2014 and has gone on to have her work performed by some of classical music\u2019s major artists and collaborate with Kanye West. She appears as herself in the fourth season of \u201cMozart\u201d: Ms. Kirke\u2019s character, who leads an ensemble devoted to works by women, serenades Ms. Shaw outside her apartment and gets permission to premiere this piece, \u201cHi,\u201d in a conducting competition. (Ms. Shaw conducts it here.)\n\nMissy Mazzoli\n\nThe composer Missy Mazzoli won wide acclaim for her opera \u201cBreaking the Waves,\u201d based on the dark psychosexual film by Lars von Trier, and just premiered a new opera, \u201cProving Up,\u201d at the Kennedy Center in Washington. She composed this piece, \u201cImpromptu,\u201d for the show\u2019s third season, where it was presented as a work by Mr. McDowell\u2019s character, the aging but rebellious maestro Thomas Pembridge.\n\nNico Muhly\n\nNico Muhly, whose Hitchcockian opera \u201cMarnie\u201d will be performed at the Metropolitan Opera next season, wrote a made-for-TV aria for the third season of \u201cMozart,\u201d in which he also had a cameo. On the show, Mr. Garc\u00eda Bernal\u2019s character, a conductor, flies to Venice to lead a diva\u2019s comeback concert. He persuades the singer to try something new: a Muhly aria based on the \u201cLong Island Lolita\u201d tabloid case in which a teenager named Amy Fisher shot the wife of her lover, Joey Buttafuoco. It is sung here by the soprano Susanna Phillips, currently appearing in \u201cLa Boh\u00e8me\u201d at the Met.\n\nPaola Prestini\n\nPaola Prestini co-founded her first production company, VisionIntoArt, while still a student at the Juilliard School, and went on to become the artistic director of National Sawdust. She is currently collaborating with Robert Wilson on an opera-theater work based on Hemingway\u2019s \u201cThe Old Man and the Sea.\u201d This is an excerpt from her piece \u201cListen, Quiet,\u201d which is performed in season four of \u201cMozart\u201d at a chaotic party in which Mr. Garc\u00eda Bernal\u2019s character, distraught, gives away his possessions. (The cellist here, Jeffrey Zeigler, who used to play with the Kronos Quartet \u2014 and is married to Ms. Prestini \u2014 is part of an ensemble\u2019s worth of musicians with cameos in the party scene.)", "title": "Hear How \u2018Mozart in the Jungle\u2019 Became a New-Music Showcase", "authors": ["Michael Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "When my children were little, if they complained about aches and pains, I\u2019d sometimes rub some moisturizer on them and tell them the \u201ccream\u201d would help. It often did. The placebo effect is surprisingly effective.\n\nMoisturizer is cheap, it has almost no side effects, and it got the job done. It was a perfect solution.\n\nOther treatments also have a placebo effect, and make people feel better. Many of these are dangerous, though, and we have to weigh the downsides against that benefit.\n\nLots of Americans have chest pain because of a lack of blood and oxygen reaching the heart. This is known as angina. For decades, one of the most common ways to treat this was to insert a mesh tube known as a stent into arteries supplying the heart. The stents held the vessels open and increased blood flow to the heart, theoretically fixing the problem.", "title": "Heart Stents Are Useless for Most Stable Patients. They\u2019re Still Widely Used.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Despite these complications, what\u2019s clear is that even though Congress didn\u2019t kill the estate tax, the new limits come close.\n\n\u201cThe estate tax used to cover a lot more people even in recent decades, up to 2 percent of all estates. Now we\u2019re down to less than one-tenth of 1 percent,\u201d said Chuck Marr, director of federal tax policy for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington. \u201cThe estate tax is hanging on by a thread.\u201d\n\nAccording to IRS figures, 12,411 estates filed Form 706, United States Estate (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Tax Return, for 2016. Of those filers, fewer than half \u2014 5,219 estates \u2014 owed anything, paying $18.3 billion on assets of $108 billion, for an effective tax rate of 17 percent. Even among estates valued at more than $50 million, 133 managed to avoid paying any estate tax.\n\nIf the new exemption had been in place that year, it would have trimmed those estate-tax bills by an amount between $2.3 billion and $6.2 billion. No more than 2,204 estates would have exceeded the individual $10 million baseline exemption in 2016. And under the new $20 million baseline exclusion for married filers, the tax would have hit just 911 estates.\n\nBesides the generous exemption, the estate tax always has provided another big benefit to inheritors: Those assets are passed on at their market value at the time of death. This allows stocks, real estate and other holdings that may have appreciated to be sold with no tax ever paid on those gains.\n\nThat\u2019s the prime reason that anyone with an estate valued between the old and new exemption limits needs to consider rewriting his or her plans to bring the maximum amount of assets back into the estate. The problem is that one vehicle that\u2019s often used is an irrevocable trust, which, as the name implies, isn\u2019t easily reversed.\n\n\u201cEvery estate planner has a handful of files where we now want to bring those assets back into the estate to get that step-up in basis, but it\u2019s not that easy,\u201d Mr. Jenney said. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to petition the probate court, show that circumstances have changed, go to court and terminate the trust.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother time bomb in older estate plans could lurk in trusts that move assets out of the estate to future generations, called generation-skipping transfers. These transfers are taxed in coordination with the estate tax and gift tax and count toward the estate tax exemption amount. Often, those trusts use a formula that automatically removes the maximum exemption amount from the estate and places that money in the trust, said Melissa Langa, managing partner of Bove & Langa in Boston.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIf you had an $11 million estate before the new act, $5 million would go to the trust for future generations, $6 million would be held for the spouse, and that would have been a great plan,\u201d Ms. Langa said. \u201cNow it might be that all $11 million is held for the benefit of the children and grandchildren and the spouse is left with nothing.\u201d\n\nAn added sting for families forced to rewrite their estate plans (a process that can cost between $2,000 and $10,000) is that unless the work is a business expense, they can\u2019t deduct that cost. The new tax law eliminated the allowance for tax preparation fees.\n\nBut it\u2019s the sunset provision of the new law that creates the most potential problems, according to estate planners, many of whom are unimpressed with the hasty, late-December tax-law rewrite.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re lucky it\u2019s as tame as it is, because the legislation is just idiotic,\u201d said James Spica, an estate tax specialist with Dickinson Wright in Detroit. \u201cI don\u2019t think there even was a handful of people working on it who understand how it works.\u201d\n\nMr. Spica pointed out that the estate of a spouse who died under the older, lower exemption would benefit if the surviving spouse died between now and the end of 2025. Estates of any amount pass untaxed to a spouse and are taxed only after the surviving spouse dies. So even if the first spouse died when the estate exemption was $11 million for a couple, that estate enjoys a $22 million exemption \u2014 but only if the surviving spouse dies before Dec. 31, 2025.\n\nMeanwhile, someone who dies today under the $22 million exemption could see that allowance cut in half if the surviving spouse passes away in 2026, when the exemption drops back to the earlier limit.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019ll get half the benefit if the second spouse dies outside this new regime,\u201d Mr. Spica said.\n\nAnother issue Congress left hanging concerns how to handle gift taxes after the higher exemption expires. Because the tax on large gifts works in concert with the estate tax, the estate of someone who gives away more than the lower exemption could be hit with a \u201cclaw back\u201d tax bill for several million dollars when the law reverts to the lower limit, said James Blase of Blase & Associates in St. Louis.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf you make a very large gift before 2026 and die afterward, there\u2019s absolutely no law,\u201d Mr. Blase said. \u201cCongress left it totally up to the I.R.S. to issue regulations, and that\u2019s a big deal. There\u2019s a lot of uncertainty.\u201d\n\nThe one place where estate-tax certainty does exist is within the very wealthiest families, who continue to face a 40 percent maximum tax rate on their estates.\n\n\u201cFor the uber-wealthy, a $5 million change in the exemption doesn\u2019t really make a difference,\u201d Ms. Langa said, adding: \u201cIt\u2019s a huge thing for people in the $10 million to $20 million range, but if you\u2019re in the $200 million range, it\u2019s a drop in the bucket.\u201d", "title": "Heirs Inherit Uncertainty With New Estate Tax", "authors": ["Brian J. O Connor"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "A version of this article appears in print on in The International New York Times", "title": "Opinion | Heng on Trump\u2019s China Policy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "A couple of weeks before the premiere, Ms. Ahuvia spoke about the work\u2019s evolution. Below are edited excerpts from that conversation.\n\nWas folk dancing a big part of your life growing up?\n\nIt became a bigger part of my life when we moved back to Florida. It was one way of staying connected to Israel. My mom had been a folk dancer, semiprofessionally. We went to weekly gatherings at the JCC [Jewish Community Center], and when we moved to Hawaii, joined another gathering there.\n\nVideo\n\nWhat inspired this piece?\n\nBefore this piece I made a solo that was returning to the dances in a more emotional way; it was more about my relationship to them. I talked at the time about making these dances and songs face the Nakba, which is what Palestinians call the founding of the state of Israel. [Nakba is the Arabic word for \u201ccatastrophe.\u201d] How could I hold onto my heritage and also this other reality? I wasn\u2019t really looking at how the dances were constructed. This piece came out of wanting to investigate that more deeply.\n\nI knew the dances were an integral part of this Zionist enterprise, and you could see that in a liberatory way or see some of the colonial mechanisms in it. I was looking for a way to communicate that.\n\nOne issue you explore is cultural appropriation, how the pioneers of Israeli folk dance, mostly Eastern European women, drew from social dance forms like Palestinian dabke.\n\nIt\u2019s well-documented that these women went to Palestinian villages and watched them dancing and felt they held the steps for what new Israeli dances could be. And so they borrowed steps and wrote new music and created dances that were directly synchronous to the new music, and in this way it becomes a new Israeli dance.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis was their way of participating in the nation-building and what for them was this revolutionary moment. I don\u2019t think that cultural exchange is bad, but I think it\u2019s about the context of whose narratives get told and seen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou also look at the popularity of Israeli folk dance among Christian Zionists. Did you know about this phenomenon before starting your research?\n\nOur family friends are Christian Zionists, so it wasn\u2019t a surprise. But I figured out it was much larger in scope than I realized. I was looking for videos of basic steps being taught, and the first websites to pop up were almost always Christian.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhere does the title come from?\n\nI went to the Israeli embassy in New York to renew my passport, and the security guard asked me, in Hebrew, \u201cEverything you have is yours?\u201d Because I was working on this piece, it really stuck with me.\n\nIs it risky showing this work at a Jewish-affiliated organization like the 14th Street Y?\n\nIt\u2019s a little risky. I don\u2019t know who\u2019s going to come, and last year when I did a work-in-progress showing [at the Y], there was some tension about the content of the work. But they pride themselves on being a place that\u2019s politically open, where artists can say what they want to say.", "title": "Her Roots Are Tangled in Folk Dance and Israel", "authors": ["Siobhan Burke"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "It started years earlier, the older woman told her. Almost every night, she would get these crazy fevers. First came bone-rattling, shaking chills; she couldn\u2019t get warm even under a pile of quilts. Then suddenly she would be roasting hot, with sweat pouring off her. Her temperature would spike to 102 or 103. And her whole body would hurt, right down to her bones. She popped Tylenol constantly just to keep her fever down.\n\nThen an hour after the fever hit, she would start to feel sick and throw up until she had nothing left in her. This happened almost every night.\n\nDuring the day, she felt weak and tired, and her bones hurt. It made any movement painful. Her doctors called it fibromyalgia. She also had a rash. Hives, the doctors told her. It didn\u2019t itch, but no one could figure out why she had it. And, her daughters added, she had no appetite. The very thought of food made her want to vomit, the older woman told May. She\u2019d lost over 80 pounds this past year.\n\nA Deep Dive Into the Records\n\nMay could see how the patient\u2019s clothes, eyes and even skin looked a couple of sizes too large. Otherwise her exam was uninformative. She didn\u2019t have a fever, and she didn\u2019t have a rash. May told the patient she would go through the stack of records and come up with a plan.\n\nReviewing them, May saw that the patient had a persistently elevated white-blood-cell count. Normal is under 10; the patient\u2019s was at nearly 20 \u2014 and had been for a couple of years. CT scans showed enlarged lymph nodes throughout her body. These findings could be from a chronic infection. Or from a cancer. But her hometown doctors found neither.\n\nPhoto\n\nOverlooked Possibilities\n\nMay decided to think about illnesses that her first doctors hadn\u2019t tested for. The woman needed to be checked for H.I.V.; patients over 55 are thought to make up a quarter of all cases \u2014 diagnosed and undiagnosed \u2014 and they are much less likely to be tested for it. Another possibility was syphilis, called the great imitator for its variable presentation. And given her persistent gastrointestinal problems, May would look for celiac disease. She also sent off a test to look for a type of blood cancer called multiple myeloma, which attacks the blood and bones and is seen in patients over 50.\n\nMay waited anxiously as the results came back. It wasn\u2019t H.I.V. It wasn\u2019t syphilis or celiac disease. The patient didn\u2019t have multiple myeloma either, though that test, which measures levels of one part of the immune system known as antibodies, was abnormal; one antibody, known as IgM, was high. May referred the patient to an infectious-disease specialist, who found no infection. The oncologist found no cancer. And the dermatologist merely confirmed what May already knew \u2014 the patient had hives, and it wasn\u2019t clear why. She presented her puzzling patient to every smart doctor she knew when she walked down the hospital hallway and at educational conferences. Yet after seven months of testing and referring and discussing, May was no closer to a diagnosis than she was on Day 1.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA Doctor Puts It Together\n\nIt was part of May\u2019s weekly routine to check the patient\u2019s chart for any new consultant notes or test results. One afternoon she was surprised to see an 11-page note from a pathology resident who, as far as she knew, was not involved in the case. It was a meticulous summary of all the patient\u2019s symptoms as well as the many tests performed so far. He went on to suggest that she had a disease May had never heard of \u2014 Schnitzler syndrome. It was, as the resident described it, a rare and poorly understood immune disorder.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Schnitzler syndrome, according to current thinking, the most primitive part of the immune system \u2014 a type of white blood cell known as the macrophage \u2014 goes wild and instructs the body to act as if it is infected. The body responds with fever and chills, a loss of appetite, flulike body aches, hives and high levels of one specific type of antibody: IgM. Exactly why and how this occurs is still unknown.\n\nThe disorder was first described in 1972 by the French dermatologist Liliane Schnitzler, who subsequently identified five patients with hives, episodes of prolonged fever, bone pain and enlarged lymph nodes. These symptoms, plus an elevated level of IgM, Schnitzler proposed, defined a new disease.\n\nCurious About Unsolved Cases\n\nMay didn\u2019t know the resident who proposed the diagnosis, Dr. Forest Huls, but she\u2019d heard of him. Huls, although still in training, had a reputation for finding cases that stumped others and figuring out the diagnosis. \u201cWhen I see people suffering and I know that if I took the time and effort, I could figure it out,\u201d he told me, \u201cthen I have to do something.\u201d He looks for unexplained pathological findings \u2014 in this case, the high level of IgM.\n\nHuls hadn\u2019t heard of Schnitzler syndrome, either. He came upon it by using the database PubMed to look for a disease that matched the patient\u2019s symptoms. He made a list of her symptoms and abnormalities. To get the full picture, he combed through her earlier electronic medical records, now archived in an old electronic warehouse, and found that her symptoms had started maybe a decade earlier. Then he looked for a disease that fit. It took hours before articles on this strange disorder began to appear. As he read, he suspected that she had it.\n\nMaking the Case\n\nAfter reading Huls\u2019s note, May looked up Schnitzler syndrome. Doctors\u2019 descriptions of patients with the disorder matched her patient exactly.\n\nIt was an important diagnosis to make, in part because there is now a very effective treatment. When the woman\u2019s insurance company refused to pay for the new and very expensive drug, May appealed to the manufacturer, which agreed, after several months, to provide it. Once she started taking it, the shaking chills and fever disappeared. So did the nausea and vomiting, the hives and bone pain.\n\nLooking back at her life with this illness, the patient can barely recognize herself. Before her illness, she\u2019d prided herself on her get-up-and-go and her disinclination to sit still. All those years stuck on the sofa and ultimately in bed, too sick, too weak and in too much pain to move, seemed like a chapter in someone else\u2019s life.\n\nAs for Huls, he is finishing up his fellowship at the hospital this summer. Wherever he ends up, he is certain he will find new cases to challenge his curiosity, cases he hopes to solve.", "title": "Her Various Symptoms Seemed Unrelated. Then One Doctor Put It All Together.", "authors": ["Lisa Sanders"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMany of these smaller utilities have just a handful of people who are charged with managing the entire system,\u201d said Manuel P. Teodoro, a political scientist at Texas A&M University who has studied the challenges facing small and rural water utilities.\n\nHe noted that this research suggests one possible strategy for improving water quality in rural areas: States might provide aid to help smaller water utilities merge and consolidate into larger systems that are better able to comply with complex safety rules. California has been exploring such an approach.\n\nDr. Allaire and her co-authors also found that water systems that serve minority and low-income communities were more likely to violate federal standards around coliform bacteria, which frequently accompany disease-causing pathogens. Their research also showed that privately owned utilities had fewer violations than publicly owned utilities, and that larger water systems tended to have fewer violations than smaller systems.\n\nThe whole point of tracing these patterns, Dr. Allaire said, was to help policymakers understand which parts of the United States might require additional scrutiny or assistance in meeting national water quality standards. \u201cOtherwise,\u201d she said, \u201cwe have no systematic way to identify problems and set priorities.\u201d\n\nThis new study may understate the full extent of problems with the nation\u2019s drinking water systems, said Kristi Pullen Fedinick, a scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group that conducted its own nationwide survey of Safe Drinking Water Act violations last year.\n\nState governments are largely responsible for implementing federal water-quality standards, and the quality of monitoring and enforcement can vary significantly. Some states have cut back on budgets for their drinking water programs, and many communities focus on tracking just a handful of key contaminants like coliform or disinfectant byproducts. That means potential violations involving other contaminants, like lead, may go underreported.\n\n\u201cOn a national scale, we know that there\u2019s a huge amount of underreporting,\u201d Dr. Fedinick said.\n\nIn recent years, the E.P.A. and Justice Department have often been reluctant to penalize states or municipalities that fall behind on enforcement or reporting. The federal government can, however, provide technical assistance and funding to water utilities that are struggling with health violations.", "title": "Here Are the Places That Struggle to Meet the Rules on Safe Drinking Water", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The list is a reminder of how the biggest gains in virtual currencies have been reaped by a small number of early adopters \u2014 despite the early promises that virtual currencies could democratize the financial system and spread wealth more evenly.\n\nNearly all of the people on the list either helped found virtual currencies or have been involved with them for years. Recent efforts to quantify the inequality among Bitcoin holders have found that it is significantly higher than in even the most stratified countries, which may sting many people who recently rushed into virtual currencies and are now sitting on losses.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor early virtual currency adopters like the people on the Forbes list, the recent price declines are not catastrophic. The price of Bitcoin is still up 600 percent from a year ago, and up 70,000 percent from when the Winklevoss twins began buying in 2012.\n\nIdentifying the richest people in the secretive and paranoid virtual currency realm is far from easy; some of it is guesswork. Mr. Lubin, whom Forbes pegged as the second-wealthiest person in the virtual currency universe, illustrates the difficulties. He told the magazine that he had begun selling his Ethereum tokens, known as Ether, last year to fund his business, ConsenSys. Because Forbes could not verify his holdings, the magazine put his wealth at between $1 billion and $5 billion before the most recent price declines.\n\nThe New York Times Explains...\n\nThe normal Forbes billionaires list is easier to compile because the richest people in the world generally have most of their wealth tied up in stock holdings, which usually have to be disclosed for big public companies. With virtual currencies, it is not necessary to disclose your identity, and the system was created by people who were interested in protecting financial privacy.\n\nMany large holders of virtual currencies are loath to acknowledge their holdings for privacy and security reasons, and many people who are rumored to have giant Bitcoin stockpiles are not on the Forbes list.\n\nPerhaps the most notable omission is Satoshi Nakamoto, the mysterious creator of Bitcoin, whose identity has been guessed at many times but never confirmed. Researchers have guessed that Satoshi, as the creator is known, most likely amassed about one million Bitcoins during the network\u2019s first year, when few other people were mining new tokens. Those Bitcoins would now be worth around $7 billion.\n\nPhoto\n\nOthers have publicly claimed to have large holdings without verifying those holdings. Brock Pierce, a former child actor and the leader of a virtual currency community in Puerto Rico, has said he would donate $1 billion of his virtual currency fortune to charity, but Forbes said, \u201cHe refuses to provide documentation that proves he has anywhere near that much money.\u201d The magazine estimated Mr. Pierce\u2019s wealth at between $700 million and $1 billion.\n\nThe list suggests that inventing virtual currencies can end up being less lucrative than investing in them. The magazine estimated that the inventor of Ethereum, Vitalik Buterin, is less wealthy than two early investors, Mr. Lubin and Anthony Di Iorio, who had previously managed his family\u2019s patio-door business in Canada.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd while three big holders of Ripple\u2019s token, XRP, are on the list, the inventor of the digital token, Jed McCaleb, is not.", "title": "Here Are the World\u2019s Virtual Currency Billionaires (or at Least They Were)", "authors": ["Nathaniel Popper"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "But the outreach is necessary and courageous. Mr. Moon, elected last year on a promise to improve ties with North Korea, will deserve credit if his efforts help reduce the North Korean threat.\n\nOne good sign is that Mr. Moon has persuaded key foreign officials to attend the Olympics opening ceremony and thus be in proximity in case diplomatic fairy dust creates an opportunity for interaction. Not only are Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan and Vice President Mike Pence expected to show up, but also two senior North Korean officials: Mr. Kim\u2019s sister, Kim Yo-jong, the first immediate member of the North\u2019s ruling family ever to set foot in the South, and Kim Yong-nam, the country\u2019s nominal head of state.\n\nOn Saturday, Mr. Moon plans to host the North Korean delegation for lunch with the goal of restoring a high-level dialogue between the two countries after a hiatus of more than two years and of opening the door, maybe later this year, to a meeting between himself and Mr. Kim.\n\nAt a minimum, the lunch provides an opportunity for Mr. Moon to make clear directly to the North Korean leaders the risks and costs of failing to ease tensions, fueled mainly by the North\u2019s accelerated push to develop its arsenal of nuclear warheads and the missiles with which to deliver them. North Korean officials have a hard time reading political signals from Washington, so frank discussions are crucial.\n\nWhether Mr. Pence or Mr. Abe are open to even a brief discussion with the North Koreans is unclear. They have taken a much tougher stance against North Korea than Mr. Moon, creating a dangerous gap among the allies. En route to South Korea, Mr. Pence sent mixed signals, suggesting on Monday that he might be open to a meeting, then on Wednesday announcing plans to impose the toughest sanctions yet on the North over its nuclear and missile programs.", "title": "Opinion | Here\u2019s Hoping the Winter Games Lead to a Thaw in Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThere\u2019s a potentially ideal merger partner for the $104 billion Goldman Sachs. The Wall Street firm\u2019s chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, told shareholders on Tuesday that it was already having some success turning around its stumbling fixed-income, currency and commodities trading unit. But buying $56 billion Bank of New York Mellon could be a better fix \u2014 if only the asset-management and custody specialist weren\u2019t in a different league.\n\nIf the two were to combine, Goldman would get hold of more than $33 trillion in assets under custody and supervision \u2014 think clearing, cash management, global payments and the like. Goldman may be able to sweet-talk Bank of New York Mellon clients into sending more trades its way.\n\nJPMorgan and Citigroup already use similar businesses to great effect, helping to explain why their F.I.C.C. traders rake in twice as much revenue or more. The match could also help Goldman meet Mr. Blankfein\u2019s goal, laid out in September, of broadening its reach with both investors and corporations.\n\nMarrying Bank of New York Mellon also would reduce Goldman\u2019s reliance on trading. The F.I.C.C. unit, for example, would account for just 11 percent of revenue, down from 17 percent. A union would also more than double assets under management to $3.4 trillion and take that division\u2019s share of the top line to more than 45 percent. On top of that, if Goldman could cut as much as 20 percent of its target\u2019s expenses, those would be worth some $17 billion once taxed and capitalized \u2014 enough to justify paying a 30 percent premium to Bank of New York Mellon\u2019s current market value.\n\nThis bank dating-app math may, however, obscure real-world compatibility issues. First, Bank of New York Mellon may not relish losing its independence, and Charles W. Scharf took over as its chief executive only last summer. Second, some of the firm\u2019s customers may balk at the idea of Goldman\u2019s having even broader access to their business and data.\n\nFinally, as much as banks\u2019 mood about regulation has brightened in the past year, allowing two systemically important financial institutions \u2014 one in trading, the other in clearing and custody \u2014 to hook up has been taboo for a decade. That may be changing. For now, Goldman can browse, but it could be too soon to swipe right.", "title": "Here\u2019s an Idea for Goldman: Buy Bank of New York Mellon", "authors": ["Antony Currie"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe prevalence of both genital and oral herpes simplex virus infections has declined steadily since 2000. Still, roughly half of middle-aged Americans are infected.\n\nHSV-1, or oral herpes, causes cold sores around the mouth and face, and sometimes genital sores. HSV-2, genital herpes, is sexually transmitted, and causes sores around the genitals, buttocks and anus. HSV-2 can sometimes cause mouth sores as well.\n\nBoth types of herpes are transmitted by direct contact with an infected person; some infected people have no symptoms.\n\nOral herpes is usually acquired early in childhood or adolescence from nonsexual contact with saliva. It can be spread to the genitals through oral sex. Genital herpes is spread by vaginal, anal or oral sex with an infected person.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven when there are no symptoms, the herpes virus continues to live in the body and can be reactivated to cause outbreaks. There is no cure for herpes, but antiviral medicines can help to reduce the severity and duration of outbreaks of both oral and genital herpes.", "title": "Herpes Is Slowly Retreating, but the Infection Remains Common", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Arthur Jones, a Holocaust denier described as a Nazi by the Illinois Republican Party, is poised to win the Republican primary in the state\u2019s Third Congressional District. He is running unopposed, all but guaranteeing he will soon be the official Republican candidate for the House of Representatives.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no way in the world they can knock me off the ballot,\u201d said Mr. Jones, 70, who has unsuccessfully sought the nomination five times. His campaign website has a section devoted to conspiracy theories about the Holocaust, which he called \u201cnothing more than an international extortion racket.\u201d\n\nThe Republican primary in the district, a Democratic stronghold that includes part of Chicago and its southwestern suburbs, is on March 20. A spokesman for the Illinois Republican Party said it had difficulty recruiting anyone to run against Mr. Jones because \u201cit is a very Democratic district.\u201d\n\nThe final deadline for certifying primary candidates passed last month, but the spokesman said the party would consider lending its support to an independent or write-in candidate. That deadline is in June, according to the State Board of Elections.", "title": "He\u2019s a Nazi, Republicans Warn, but He\u2019s Their Likely Nominee for Congress", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Increasing blood sugar levels are associated with cognitive decline, a long-term study has found.\n\nResearchers assessed cognitive function in 5,189 people, average age 66, and tested their blood sugar using HbA1c, a test that accurately measures blood glucose levels over a period of weeks or months. (The finger-prick blood test, in contrast, gives a reading only at a given moment in time.) They followed the group for up to 10 years, tracking blood glucose levels and periodically testing cognitive ability. The study is in the journal Diabetologia.\n\nThere was no association between blood sugar levels and cognition at the start of the study. But consistently over time, scores on the tests of memory and executive function declined as HbA1c levels increased, even in people without diabetes. The study controlled for many other variables, among them age, sex, cholesterol, B.M.I., education, marital status, depression, smoking, alcohol consumption, hypertension and cardiovascular disease.\n\nThis is an observational study that does not prove cause and effect, and the lead author, Wuxiang Xie, a researcher at the Peking University Health Science Center, said that the underlying mechanism is still unknown.\n\nStill, he said, \u201cDiabetes-related microvascular complications might be, at least in part, the reason for the subsequent cognitive decline. Future studies are warranted to reveal the precise mechanisms.\u201d", "title": "High Blood Sugar Levels Tied to Memory Decline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "FRIDAY PUZZLE \u2014 One way to know whether you are getting better at solving \u2014 that\u2019s a question I'm asked quite often \u2014 is when your preference for certain days of the week moves toward the weekend puzzles.\n\nI\u2019ve gone on record as saying that my favorite solving day is Thursday, because I love the tricky bits and the pranks and the wordplay, and that still holds true. I\u2019m a Thursday junkie. But that doesn\u2019t mean that I don\u2019t appreciate a nice, smooth Monday or a \u201cfight me\u201d Friday; different puzzle days of the week have different charms.\n\nBrendan Emmett Quigley, who offers his puzzles on his own indie website as well, returns with a puzzle that honestly made me wonder if my new favorite day might be Friday. There is so much good stuff in this grid: I INSIST, the fabulous debut of EMPHASIS MINE, SETS A GOAL, LATE CALL, PORTRAIT GALLERY, SQUAT JUMP (and please take a moment to note the Scrabbly goodness in the center of this grid), BOOK PROPOSAL, LAZY BONES, LE MONDE, ON A DATE, SLAYED and more. It\u2019s a clean grid that feels like a walk through a modern art museum: Every time you turn a corner, there is something neat to look at.\n\nAnd let\u2019s talk about the clues. This one hit all the right notes. As a solver who is a woman, I appreciated seeing Ayaan Hirsi ALI \u2014 regardless of what you might think of her political views \u2014 in the puzzle as opposed to the usual Muhammad ALI. No disrespect to the boxing icon, but it was nice to see a common entry clued that way. To be fair, cluing ALI as the boxing champion would be too easy for a Friday, but there are many ALIs out there, and it\u2019s nice to see the constructors and editors branching out. And let us all take a moment to enjoy the correctly spelled \u201cDoctor Who\u201d clue at 46D, celebrating the arrival of the first woman Doctor, played by the actress JODIE Whittaker. Finally, I note with relief that the entry LOLITA is clued neutrally and factually as \u201cLiterary nickname for Dolores.\u201d Nicely done.", "title": "High-Minded Sort", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Baylosis was among dozens of rebel leaders who were released from prison in 2016, during the leadup to the peace talks. He had been serving a sentence for murder and rebellion.\n\n\u201cThe government has again focused its efforts on the prosecution of peace consultants,\u201d Ms. Palabay said. \u201cInstead of working to resolve the roots of the armed conflict by way of pursuing peace talks, the Duterte regime has instead resorted to fascist reprisals.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Palabay also said the arrests were illegal because both men had been covered by an agreement guaranteeing rebel negotiators immunity from arrest. But Mr. Duterte\u2019s spokesman, Harry Roque, said that agreement was no longer valid because the talks had been suspended.\n\n\u201cThe president is not interested to talk peace to those who do not sincerely desire peace,\u201d said Mr. Roque, who is not related to Mr. Baylosis\u2019 aide.\n\nA small group of activists protested Thursday morning outside the national police headquarters in Manila, where the men were being held, demanding that they be freed.\n\nThe Philippines\u2019 Communist insurgency began in 1969, making it one of the longest-running conflicts in Asia. Over the decades, tens of thousands of people have been killed in the fighting. The Philippine military says the New People\u2019s Army currently has about 5,000 fighters.\n\nMr. Duterte, an authoritarian who often calls himself a leftist, began moving toward peace talks with the rebels soon after taking office in 2016. In college, Mr. Duterte was a student of Jose Maria Sison, the founder of the country\u2019s Communist Party, who now lives in self-imposed exile in the Netherlands.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Sison initially welcomed the peace overtures, but he later called Mr. Duterte a \u201choodlum\u201d and a coward for backing out of the talks.\n\nThe detention of Mr. Baylosis and his aide came two weeks after a Manila court issued arrest warrants for three other rebel consultants involved in the talks, who had been released from prison in 2016 along with Mr. Baylosis. The three, none of whom have been apprehended, had been serving sentences for murder in connection with killings committed in the 1980s.\n\nMr. Duterte\u2019s government labeled the New People\u2019s Army a terrorist organization soon after halting the peace talks. The United States has long given it that designation, but past Philippine governments have resisted doing so in hopes of encouraging negotiations.", "title": "High-Ranking Communist Rebel Is Arrested in Philippines", "authors": ["Felipe Villamor"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "As a little thrill to shake up the torpor of the speeches, several well-known athletes, including Lindsey Vonn and Pita Taufatofua, the Tongan taekwondo Olympian who competed in cross-country skiing and appeared shirtless and well-oiled for the fourth consecutive Olympic ceremony, posed with Bach and made a heart gesture with their hands.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nBeijing 2022 Takes the Stage\n\nSkaters scooted around the stage leaving luminescent trails that formed patterns, and eventually the logo of the 2022 Games. Giant illuminated pandas roller-bladed around. And then, at least according to the guidebook, the pandas flew back to Beijing through the internet.\n\nPhoto\n\nK-Pop Takes a Turn\n\nTime for K-pop! The national anthem of Greece. The flag of Greece was raised. The Olympic anthem. The Olympic flag was lowered and handed over to the mayor of Beijing, host of the 2022 Games. The national anthem of China. And that meant it was time for a segment devoted to Beijing. Yes, with pandas!\n\nPhoto\n\nVisual Spectacle and Some Math\n\nNext a somewhat abstract look at time. Some base 60 numbers were projected. It was a bit hard to understand, but the ceremony guidebook clarified: \u201cWhen the number becomes zero, the people of the future break free from the existing time and space, and arrive at a world no longer bound by gravity.\u201d And \u201cThe Axis of New Time set a new orbit of time in motion, and despite the fluid nature of the orbit, it reformulates itself by discovering and creating a new order.\u201d Thousands of moving lights and dancers made for a fine visual spectacle if not a crystal clear one.\n\nPhoto\n\nCross-Country Medalists Share the Stage\n\nTraditionally a victory ceremony or two is held at the closing ceremony. Here it was the men\u2019s and women\u2019s mass start cross-country races. Marit Bjoergen of Norway accepted her mind-boggling eighth gold medal and Iivo Niskanen of Finland his second. Thomas Bach of the IOC was on hand and was introduced for a second time as a former fencing gold medalist. In English and French. In French, fencing is \u201cescrime.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nNorth Korea and South Korea Carry Their Own Flags\n\nRather than carrying the unified flag that was seen throughout the Games, South and North Korea each carried in their own flag: speedskater Lee Seung-hoon carried South Korea, and Kim Ju-sik of pairs figure skating, carried North Korea.\n\nOn the stage, a mournful and reflective moment; a tribute to those who have died, led by a turtle and giant puppets. The puppets were kkoktu, used at funerals to guide the dead to the next world. Marchers carried dandelion seeds, symbolic of life arising from death. Turtles are said to carry messages from humans to the gods.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Parade of Flags, Minus One\n\nNext up was the parade of flags, with each nation carried by one of its own Olympic heroes. Except for Russia, whose flag has been banner non grata at the Games. Ester Ledecka (Czech Republic), Jessie Diggins (U.S.), Marit Bjoergen (Norway), Ireen Wust (Netherlands) and Javier Fernandez (Spain) are among those who earned the honor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd then came the mass of athletes, entering in no particular order rather than strictly by nation as in the closing ceremony. This entry was scheduled to take 20 minutes, although at other Olympics it has often gone on much longer. There were a record 2,920 athletes at these Games.\n\nThe Canadian delegation marched in on a high, with many athletes wearing their medals around their necks. They had their best Winter Olympics performance ever \u2014 winning 29 medals in total, 11 gold. You\u2019ll notice less athletes in the closing ceremony than you did in the opening ceremony. Many athletes \u2014 and most of the biggest name athletes \u2014 travel back home after their events. But the last event of the Olympics concluded just 3 hours before the closing ceremony. So if you see any athletes limping just a little, they may have participated in this afternoon\u2019s 30 kilometer cross-country skiing race.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nA Blending of Traditional and Rock Music\n\nJang Sa-ik and a group of children got the South Korean national anthem assignment. The anthem was accompanied not by an orchestra but by a single marimba, a xylophone-like instrument. And then Yang Tae-Hwan, 13, completely shredded Vivaldi\u2019s the Four Seasons (Winter, naturally) in a rock guitar arrangement, as performers in glowing suits cavorted. Eighty traditional Korean instruments, geomungos, a kind of zither, were then mixed with the rock \u2014 the meeting of old and new. A prayer pagoda rose from the stage to cap the opening number.\n\nPhoto\n\nA Colorful Introduction and a Handshake\n\nIn a colorful intro, young skiers and skaters on wheels dashed onto the circular stage that filled the pentagonal stadium. There was heavy use of light projections on the stage. President Moon Jae-in of South Korea and Thomas Bach of the I.O.C. arrived and shook hands with Ivanka Trump among others. They were presented with snow globes by two children. Their significance? They were each born on July 7, 2011, the day Pyeongchang was awarded the Games.\n\nIt was 35 degrees in the Pyeongchang Olympic Stadium. That\u2019s tropical compared to the low teens from the opening ceremony here. Attendees were still given a bag with a seat warmers, hand warmers and toe warmers. The ceremony is expected to be two hours long, after all.", "title": "Highlights and Photographs From the 2018 Winter Olympics", "authors": ["Victor Mather", "Motoko Rich", "Talya Minsberg"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "On Tuesday, teenagers from the school, gripping pillows and sleeping bags and carrying doughnuts and candy, packed a grocery store parking lot in Coral Springs, Fla., to begin the more than 400-mile journey to Tallahassee.\n\nTheir goal: convincing lawmakers to pass a slate of gun control bills in a state that has been among the friendliest to firearm owners in the nation.\n\nMany had come straight from the funeral of one of the dead. They hugged their parents goodbye and loaded backpacks into the bellies of three buses. Dozens climbed aboard.\n\nIn a telephone interview from the bus, Sarah Chadwick, 16, a junior, said the social media response to the students had been overwhelming, but she wanted everyone to know: \u201cWe see your support, we see what you\u2019re doing.\u201d\n\nThe students felt they had the \u201cbest voices to listen to right now,\u201d along with other survivors of shootings, and that Twitter had allowed them to reach more people than they would have thought possible, she said.\n\n\u201cWe have stuff to say, and we won\u2019t be silenced after a matter of days, or even weeks,\u201d she said.\n\nBy the seventh hour of the trip, students on the bus had become aware of Mr. Clooney\u2019s donation and the supportive remarks made by other celebrities.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut as they strategized in the back of the bus, some worried that Mr. Clooney\u2019s star power and liberal activism would swallow their voices and push conservatives away.\n\n\u201cThe minute they don\u2019t see our faces anymore, and they just see the Hollywood elite, they\u2019re going to stop taking it seriously,\u201d said Chris Grady, 18, a senior with a mop of curly hair.\n\nMr. Grady said he had enlisted in the Army a few months back, but that the attack at his school had made him think hard about whether that was the path he wanted to take.\n\n\u201cAs it stands right now, the real danger is at home, not abroad,\u201d he said. \u201cSo this is where I want to be \u2014 right at the heart of the movement.\u201d\n\n\u201cI wasn\u2019t sure what I wanted to study,\u201d he continued. \u201cAnd now for sure I\u2019ll be getting my degree in political science.\u201d\n\nFinally, around 10 p.m., the three buses of students from Stoneman Douglas High rolled into the parking lot of a Tallahassee high school. They had arrived.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cOh. My. God,\u201d said one teenager, peering out the bus window. \u201cIt\u2019s so many people.\u201d\n\nA crowd of people from Leon High had gathered in front of the red brick building to support and cheer the Stoneman Douglas group.\n\nIn the morning, the students will break into groups and meet with some 70 elected officials. Gov. Rick Scott is expected to give them two hours.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMallory Muller, a Stoneman Douglas High student, hugged a teddy bear to her chest.\n\n\u201cThe whole bus ride here I was very anxious,\u201d she said. \u201cYou have the nervousness about \u2014 what happens? And kind of scared for your own safety.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe know what we\u2019re doing tomorrow is big,\u201d she went on, \u201cso I think there is that buildup tomorrow, too. That pressure.\u201d\n\nStudents elsewhere in Florida march in a spontaneous show of support.\n\nBefore marching south toward Stoneman Douglas High, dozens of students from West Boca Raton High School first gathered in the courtyard of their school for a peaceful protest \u2014 17 minutes of silence for the 17 victims \u2014 but then someone opened a door and walked out, and others followed, a videotape of the scene aired by WPTV showed.\n\n\u201cEverybody started walking,\u201d one student told the news channel. \u201cIt felt like half the school was walking.\u201d\n\nAs the students walked south on U.S. Highway 441, sheriff\u2019s deputies lined the road to direct traffic and keep them safe, but did not interfere. The distance between the two schools is about 10 miles.\n\nThe march from Boca Raton surprised Broward County officials, who said they had heard nothing about the protest. Todd DeAngelis, a spokesman for the city of Parkland, said the authorities abruptly assembled an escort by law enforcement and organized water stations on a day when the temperature was in the low 80s.\n\nHundreds of mourners, including military, honored a J.R.O.T.C. member at his funeral.\n\nIn a rare honor, the United States Military Academy offered the member, Peter Wang, 15, the realization of a lifelong dream: admission to West Point, posthumously. The academy said it was extending the offer in recognition of his \u201cheroic actions\u201d during the shooting.\n\nMr. Wang was last seen holding a door open at Stoneman Douglas High so that others could escape, Ernie Rospierski, a teacher who survived, told CBS News.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRelatives of Mr. Wang, a cadet in the school\u2019s Junior Reserve Officers\u2019 Training Corps program, described him as modest and not interested in status, but eager to serve and help others.\n\nAt his funeral on Tuesday, the military mourners acknowledged him as one of them. They came in echoes of the uniform that he had once proudly worn: Marine and Navy dress blues, high school R.O.T.C. members in their dress uniforms, others wearing camouflage fatigues. Veterans were in attendance, as well.\n\n\u201cWe came down to represent,\u201d said Jeff Colopy, vice commander of American Legion Post 157 in Margate, Fla., to \u201cpay tribute to one of our fallen comrades. In our eyes, he was military.\u201d\n\nLying in an open coffin in the small chapel at Kraeer Funeral Home and Cremation Center in Coral Springs, with a military honor guard at either end, Mr. Wang wore his uniform. A line of mourners stretched out of the chapel, with scores more waiting under a tent outside.\n\nMr. Wang was one of three Junior R.O.T.C. cadets who were killed in the shooting; the others were Martin Duque, 14, and Alaina Petty, also 14.\n\nThe shooting suspect, Mr. Cruz, had also been a member of his school\u2019s Army Junior R.O.T.C., and had \u201cexcelled\u201d in air rifle marksmanship contests with other schools in the area in a program that was supported by a grant from the National Rifle Association Foundation, according to The Associated Press. He was wearing his maroon Junior R.O.T.C. emblem polo shirt when he was arrested after the shooting, The A.P. reported.\n\n\u201cWe all have those shirts,\u201d Angelyse Perez, an 18-year-old senior and a company commander, told The Washington Post. \u201cWe\u2019re never wearing them again. We\u2019re going to destroy them all.\u201d\n\nProtests ripple out across the nation.\n\nAt rallies across the country on Monday and Tuesday, students made pleas for gun control and declared that while they might not be old enough to vote, they were old enough to change society.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA crowd of students stood on the steps of the squat, red brick public library in Toms River, N.J., on Monday, a school holiday, to express their solidarity with the fallen Parkland students and teachers.\n\nIn Chicago, students from the South Side, where gun violence has been a problem, began organizing to demand gun control legislation.\n\nIn Battle Creek, Mich., dozens of students walked out of Harper Creek High School on Tuesday to protest gun violence in schools.\n\nAnd in Bakersfield, Calif., about a dozen students and 80 adults joined a protest on Monday. \u201cListening to how worried my mother was dropping me off Friday morning after the shooting was one of the worst things I\u2019ve had to listen to in a while,\u201d Lucy Brown, a member of the Bakersfield High School Young Democrats Club who helped organize the protests, told bakersfield.com.\n\nSome states are considering \u2018red flag\u2019 laws.\n\nThe Florida shooting has renewed attention on state laws that allow a judge to remove weapons from people deemed dangerous, known as \u201cred flag\u201d laws. The measures are frequently supported by Democrats, but opposed by many Republicans and gun rights advocates.\n\nState Representative Arthur O\u2019Neill, a Republican from Connecticut, one of only five states to have such laws, has said he would write to legislative leaders in other states to urge them to adopt similar laws. \u201cUnfortunately, this law is not as widely known as it should be,\u201d Mr. O\u2019Neill said last week in a statement.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, State Senator Daylin Leach on Tuesday announced that he was proposing red flag legislation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.
