Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "How Good Were the Paydays for Bank Chiefs \u2026 and Shareholders?: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Sure, I had had bouts with depression before, especially in winter. Seasonal affective disorder was first given a name in 1984 by Dr. Norman E. Rosenthal and his colleagues. I was a toddler then, but even when I was in grade school I knew what it was. My father always called it \u201cbaseball\u2019s off-season,\u201d saying the worst part of the year was the stretch from the final World Series game to the first day of spring training, a time when most of our six-member family would be folded into a long, black mood.\n\nI had gone to college in Tampa, which sidestepped the issue for a little while, but as an adult, in winter, I would fold again. So I set up a double-edged solution: I would sign up for a long spring race (from 10 miles to a marathon), which meant that I was exercising (always a useful tool against depression). It also meant that I would run long miles in the middle of the day, and soak up as much sun as I could in New Jersey in January, February and March.\n\nBut this year was different. I knew that I would never get my head above water if I stuck it out through another New Jersey winter. That\u2019s why, with no pet to care for, no house to pay for and a transportable job as a freelance writer, I opted out of the season and headed south.\n\nRunning still played a part in my treatment. I chose an easy running schedule to train for the Daytona Beach Half Marathon: no speed work, no hills, just plain old miles four days a week. On cooler \u2014 for Florida \u2014 days, I\u2019d run in the late morning, my skin tanning and highlights streaking through my hair two weeks in. For long Saturday morning runs, I would start before dawn and watch the sunrise along with drinkers and smokers and tourists. I\u2019m sure I ended up in the background of a lot of their photos.\n\nEvery day, I drove my newly adopted dog to a dog park one town over, where she would run around sniffing other dogs while I turned my face to a warm, welcoming sun, then drive home humming to whatever Top 40 hit was on the radio. I felt like I was a flower unfurling its petals at dawn. I started smiling again. I started flirting again.", "title": "How I Became a 37-Year-Old Snowbird", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "I told myself I would never fall down the \u201cwife trap rabbit hole.\u201d\n\nMy mother and father both worked outside the home, but like many women of their generation, my mother was in charge of keeping the home and caring for the children on top of her paying job. When my boyfriend and I moved in together, I made sure not to take over the housekeeping. We both cooked and cleaned and knew how to operate the washing machine. Home maintenance was either a joint effort or jointly neglected.\n\nLike so many egalitarian efforts, our domestic parity was lost once we had a baby. Everyone probably has a story of how it happened to them. In our case, my husband fell into a depression. On top of that, our 2-week-old baby needed surgery for a stomach condition called pyloric stenosis, and he came out of the operation weak and underweight. Along with the love I gave him, I went into a tough-broad-who-gets-everything-done mode. But I never came out of it.\n\nAnd so our patterns formed. I took care of the baby. I took care of the house. As my son grew older, I managed everything: food, medical appointments, preschool reconnaissance, after-school activities, birthdays and wardrobe and transportation. We had a second child and we constantly renegotiated the terms of our labor division because neither of us wanted to be stuck in those stereotypical roles. But though my husband had emerged from his depression and I from my tough broad mode, we never got our gender equality groove back despite our efforts.\n\nThen, two years ago, my husband took a job in Luxembourg, where the lingua franca is French. He\u2019s fluent in French, whereas on a good day, I speak it like a 5-year-old. Suddenly, the entire dynamic between us changed.", "title": "How I Solved the Gender Labor Imbalance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "It would have been possible to just write a story about this clumsy attempt to salvage diesel\u2019s declining reputation. But Jim Yardley, the editor on the story, pushed me to broaden the scope and use the monkey experiments as a window into the ways in which automakers have tried to influence the scientific debate about diesel, as well as the methods they use to exert political influence in Berlin and Brussels.\n\nThat broader story took a lot more reporting. Pinning down how the automakers used the studies to influence public policy was difficult. Environmental groups and lobbyist watchdog organizations told me that when corporations sponsor research, they rarely wave the studies around publicly. Rather, their front organizations manage to get the studies published in scientific journals, obscuring who paid for the research. The findings enter the bloodstream of the body politic, subtly influencing the debate.\n\nThe front organization that commissioned the monkey experiments and others related to diesel is the European Research Group on Environment and Health in the Transport Sector, known by its German initials E.U.G.T. To assess the group\u2019s impact on the debate, I obtained a list of its other studies.\n\nI discovered that some of the research had been cited by reputable organizations, including an arm of the British government. One study commissioned by the E.U.G.T., which cast doubt on whether traffic restrictions in cities led to cleaner air, influenced the judges in a court case in Austria to reject a suit by citizens of Graz who were pushing for the creation of a low-emissions zone in the city.\n\nI\u2019ve certainly had some tense conversations with auto companies and their representatives during the last couple of years. But they reacted fairly calmly when I asked them about the monkey research. Volkswagen, Daimler and BMW all distanced themselves from the experiments. After the article was published, all three companies took action against midlevel employees who had been responsible for overseeing the work of the front organization, relieving them of their duties pending internal investigations.\n\nThe carmakers\u2019 low-key response to my questions about the monkeys indicates that they may have underestimated what the article\u2019s repercussions would be. I know I did. I thought the story would make a splash, but I didn\u2019t expect it to become the top story in German media for several days; for German Chancellor Angela Merkel to weigh in with an expression of condemnation; and for the German Parliament to hold a debate on the issue.\n\nWhy the outrage over the fate of 10 macaque monkeys when Volkswagen had already pleaded guilty to conspiracy to violate the United States Clean Air Act and other charges? After all, we already knew that diesel exhaust has caused hundreds of thousands of people to die prematurely, and that Volkswagen and other European carmakers took advantage of weak enforcement to mislead the public about how much pollution their vehicles produced.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI think the explanation is this: Until the 10 monkeys became part of the story, Volkswagen\u2019s fraud had no identifiable victims. When people die from lung cancer or heart attacks after breathing air polluted by diesel cars, it\u2019s impossible to point the finger at any one carmaker. The ill effects are cumulative and may take years to manifest themselves.\n\nThe 10 unfortunate monkeys, forced to breathe exhaust so that Volkswagen and the others could sell more cars, provided the scandal with its first specific casualties. They crystallized public frustration with the auto companies\u2019 behavior.\n\nAs the magazine Der Spiegel wrote in an editorial, \u201cThe faces of our animal relatives opened our eyes to the unscrupulousness of this industry.\u201d\n\nIn Germany, the monkey experiments may prompt action that watchdog groups have been seeking for years. Political leaders, fearful that their longtime acquiescence to the auto industry has become a liability, are talking about forcing all lobbyists to register and disclose their contributions to politicians, as they must already do in the United States. There are increasing calls for car companies to retrofit old diesels with better emissions equipment. And during the debate in Parliament, several representatives spoke of a need for \u201cculture change\u201d in the industry, a hint that they may push automakers to change their management.\n\nIn the days following the publication of my article, the No. 1 question readers asked was what happened to the monkeys \u2014 the answer to which I can now at least partly provide.\n\nAccording to the Albuquerque lab, the 2014 experiments did not kill them, and they were returned to the general population of primates kept by the lab. Their fate since then is unclear \u2014 a spokeswoman for the lab said it shares information about the medical conditions of its animals only with government regulators. But it is safe to say they are among the most influential nonhuman primates in German history.", "title": "How I Uncovered Volkswagen\u2019s Rigged Monkey Experiments", "authors": ["Jack Ewing"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "BLUE MOUNTAINS, Ontario \u2014 To become a Canadian citizen, immigrants must swear allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, prove their proficiency in English or French and demonstrate that they understand the symbolic significance of the hallowed maple leaf.\n\nBut the road to becoming Canadian, to truly feel this northern land\u2019s cultural identity in one\u2019s breakable bones, is a journey that increasingly propels immigrants down a gentle slope suitable for beginners: the snow-dusted bunny hill.\n\nEager to embrace the Canadian way of life, or simply to assuage the cabin fever that accompanies the long frigid months, many immigrants are jamming on their ski boots and hazarding a go at their adopted nation\u2019s quintessential winter pastime.\n\n\u201cIn winter there\u2019s nothing else to do,\u201d said Mahendran Arumugam, who moved to Canada in 2014 from the sweltering Indian state of Tamil Nadu. \u201cThere\u2019s no point complaining about snow, so you better start enjoying it, and what better way than to start skiing.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike other immigrants, Mr. Arumugam, 32, an internet technology worker, was learning to ski at the Blue Mountain ski resort, a picturesque skein of alpine trails about 100 miles north of Toronto.", "title": "How Immigrants Become Truly Canadian: On the Ski Slopes", "authors": ["Dan Levin"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Since his 2015 debut as Finn, a major new character in \u201cStar Wars: The Force Awakens,\u201d this cheeky Londoner has used his charm and talent to become a global celebrity. In addition to his work in \u201cStar Wars,\u201d he has played serious roles in films including \u201cDetroit\u201d (earning him a comparison to \u201ca young Sidney Poitier\u201d in The Washington Post), and in the theater, at London\u2019s Old Vic.\n\nPhoto\n\nNow, he is at the forefront of what he describes as a \u201cmovement\u201d of young British actors, many from African backgrounds, who are becoming household names. And this month, he becomes the face of a second sci-fi franchise, with the opening of \u201cPacific Rim Uprising,\u201d a monster film with giant robots, which he also produced.\n\nIn person, Mr. Boyega is built like a bullet and is seemingly always in motion. Handsome and self-assured, he bears a resemblance to a younger Denzel Washington and exhibits the same antic humor as Kevin Hart. His mix of onscreen talent and offscreen ambition, as a producer, has drawn admiration from old hands in the industry. Harrison Ford, his \u201cStar Wars\u201d co-star, described Mr. Boyega as being \u201cbold, confident and complicated, with intelligent ideas.\u201d\n\nMr. Boyega seemed pleased by the description, and reiterated that the two are \u201cbest friends,\u201d a shtick he often uses in interviews, spawning countless memes and news articles about their \u201cStar Wars bromance,\u201d as Mashable put it.\n\nMr. Ford politely debunked the hype around the friendship (\u201cI hardly know the man,\u201d he said, wryly), but he did manage to impart a few lessons in A-list attitude. During a publicity shoot involving both men and Daisy Ridley, who portrays the film\u2019s heroine, the photographer asked Mr. Boyega to step to the side so Mr. Ford could have the center position.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHarrison was just like, \u2018See that, kid? I\u2019m the star,\u2019\u201d said Mr. Boyega, doing an impression of Mr. Ford that sounded like the gravelly voice-overs heard in Hollywood trailers. \u201cAnd I said to him, \u2018Yeah, mate, you ain\u2019t going to be the star when you get stabbed by Kylo Ren,\u2019\u201d referring to the villain who kills off his character, Han Solo, with a light saber.\n\nSo, did Mr. Ford feel that he was passing the \u201cStar Wars\u201d baton to Mr. Boyega with his departure from the series?\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know that I thought of it that way at all,\u201d Mr. Ford said, sounding very much like Mr. Boyega\u2019s impression. \u201cI was there to die. And I didn\u2019t really give a rat\u2019s ass who got my sword.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Boyega\u2019s parents are Nigerian immigrants, and he grew up in Peckham, a modest neighborhood of South London. His father is a Pentecostal minister, and Mr. Boyega remains religious.\n\nThe name of his production company, UpperRoom, has a double meaning: It is a reference to the location of his childhood bedroom (\u201cWhere I planned long-term goals, where I got dumped. That\u2019s where I became king. That\u2019s where I became slave. Everything\u201d) and intended in a biblical sense, as a place where people come together in unity.\n\nAsked whether faith also informs his dating life, he said: \u201cYeah, she\u2019s got to be Christian.\u201d\n\nAnd has the future Mrs. Boyega turned up yet?\n\n\u201cNah, still waiting,\u201d he said, in between mugging for the camera at the Annroy photo studio.\n\n\u201cMy bank account\u2019s doing all right, but if I have money and a relationship, I\u2019d have, like, 39.99,\u201d he said, delivering the punch line in his South London accent as \u201cfuh-ey noin noiny-noin.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs a boy in school, Mr. Boyega struggled to find his niche after failing with soccer and the cello. But a knack for plays prompted him to start training at the nearby Theatre Peckham, where he played a trickster leopard in an adaptation of the Caribbean folk tale \u201cAnansi the Spider\u201d and also appeared in a production of \u201cShrek.\u201d\n\n\u201cI wasn\u2019t Shrek, I wouldn\u2019t put myself through that,\u201d he said. \u201cI played Donkey for the comic relief. I found that I would gain more fans doing that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs an aspiring thespian, he would wait outside the stage door of the Royal Court Theater to ask the actor Daniel Kaluuya (an Oscar nominee for his role in \u201cGet Out\u201d) for advice. And at London\u2019s Identity School of Acting, Mr. Boyega trained with Letitia Wright (a star of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d).\n\nMr. Boyega\u2019s breakout role came in 2011, with \u201cAttack the Block,\u201d a comedic low-budget sci-fi thriller about aliens invading a public housing development very much like his own. \u201cIt was Steven Spielberg mixed with the \u2019hood,\u201d he told The New York Times that year. \u201cI thought 50 Cent wrote it.\u201d\n\nFrom there, it was only a few years before he was running lines with Lupita Nyong\u2019o, whom he met on the set of \u201cStar Wars.\u201d She got a dose of his comic relief up front.\n\n\u201cI remember, he immediately teased me about my uncombed hair, moments after we met,\u201d she said. \u201cI was stunned that he had the audacity to do so, not conforming to social norms of making a good impression.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Boyega burst out laughing at the memory. \u201cO.K., it was the morning time, and she was looking a bit rough,\u201d he said, barely suppressing his giggles. \u201cI think that, being a good person, you should be honest: \u2018Are they going to touch up your hair,\u2019 you know?\u201d\n\nNonetheless, Ms. Nyong\u2019o declared herself charmed. \u201cI was impressed by his honesty, even in jest, and I knew we would be good friends at that point,\u201d she said.\n\nUnderneath all the chumminess, it is not lost on Mr. Boyega that he is part of a new wave of British black actors receiving respect and acclaim in the industry.\n\n\u201cFor me it feels like a big movement,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s the first time seeing my peers who I\u2019ve gone through drama school with, seen at auditions, secure roles in good quality TV and film. And I am inspired by that right now.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven Mr. Ford, once he had had time to think about it, came around to the notion that Mr. Boyega may represent the future. \u201cIf he is the new replacement for Han Solo, he\u2019s brought a uniqueness to it,\u201d he said.\n\nAnd then, like a final blaster shot before the spaceship door closed, Mr. Ford said: \u201cI do think he\u2019s got bigger ideas than that. And better ideas than that.\u201d\n\nAs the photo shoot was wrapping up, Mr. Boyega remembered that he had been in that studio before. Indeed, a coffee-table book nearby contained a picture of him from 2013 that had been taken there.\n\n\u201cYou look so young,\u201d said his groomer, Natalie Abizadeh.\n\nHis entourage gathered around the book for a long moment, until Mr. Boyega wrinkled his nose and ran a censorious finger along the image of his untidy hairline. \u201cI couldn\u2019t afford a haircut,\u201d he said.", "title": "How John Boyega Went From \u2018Star Wars\u2019 Stormtrooper to Sci-Fi Producer", "authors": ["Ben Widdicombe"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "LIGHTS UP And then I go out there and hope for the best \u2014 hope for some inspiration, and for new things to happen.\n\nGOALS I do have different goals every show. I\u2019ll say, I\u2019m going to be as loose as possible. Or, I\u2019m going to keep this show as intimate as possible. Then comes a Friday night show where I know people are going to be rowdy, and I\u2019m going to go out there and be as rowdy as them.", "title": "How John Leguizamo, Actor, Spends His Sundays", "authors": ["John Leland", "Sunday Routine"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "I find it hard to describe your scores, and I mean this in a positive sense. The influences are varied and ever-present, but subtle and elusive.\n\nThat\u2019s a huge compliment. I feel like I\u2019m enthralled to the same three composers all the time: Messiaen, Penderecki and Bach \u2014 well, Bach and Vivaldi. I love Baroque stuff. I\u2019ve got such patchy knowledge of so much other music. It\u2019s a childish way of looking at things, but I will listen to Penderecki and think about how that kind of thing can be done with modern music, or how Messiaen\u2019s modes can work in the structure of Bach chorales. It feels like a really ugly cross-pollination.\n\nUgly?\n\nIt\u2019s like you\u2019ve got a bunch of beautiful animals in a room, crossbreeding into something revolting. But that\u2019s partly because there is so much in between that I don\u2019t understand or have never studied or don\u2019t know enough about. I\u2019ve got such patchy music education I have to just obsess on what I know. Maybe that\u2019s what everybody does.\n\nThe breadth of what you know comes through in \u201cPhantom Thread.\u201d\n\nThe principal thing was to make sure the emotion was sincere. I was so scared of it being pastiche. In a way it goes back to my first audition for a youth orchestra. I\u2019d never heard the real thing. I\u2019d been in small orchestras that couldn\u2019t play. Suddenly here\u2019s this room of 17- and 18-year-olds, and I\u2019d never heard this noise, and I\u2019ve never forgotten it. I still feel like, when I\u2019m doing film stuff, I\u2019m chasing that same fix. I know that eventually, after these months of work on paper, I know that eventually there will be a day, or if I\u2019m lucky two days, with an orchestra to record it all.\n\nPhoto\n\nHaving said that, the first stuff I sent to Paul he said was all too dark. Like the first two pieces I sent him, on the piano, he said that it sounds like you are telling the story already, that you\u2019re giving away what\u2019s going to happen.\n\nThe first piece from the soundtrack album, \u201cPhantom Thread I,\u201d begins with these eerie, hazy high strings. Then this alluring theme starts, and a hint of what could be a Bach chorale prelude filters through. Was that Bach-like element conscious?\n\nThat started with trying to work out what music could be used to describe the character of Reynolds [the designer]. I said to Paul, we should think about what music he would have listened to. I sold Paul the idea of Reynolds being into Glenn Gould, that Reynolds listened intensely to all those recordings. It was a good excuse to work on a slightly neurotic Bach-piano-style piano music, which seemed to fit him. And then Paul asked for it to be bigger and bigger and bigger. So eventually we did it with a full orchestra.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the piece from the film \u201cSandalwood I,\u201d I heard Steve Reich stuff, and also Debussy.\n\nThings leak into my head, I suppose. But I\u2019m constantly stumbling with this stuff. I will spend weeks and weeks on the piano, and things start to be satisfying, and then you realize later where they\u2019ve been stolen from.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe harmonies in \u201cThe Tailor of Fitzrovia\u201d suggested to me a composer you haven\u2019t mentioned: Britten. Are you a Britten fan at all?\n\nLots of it was coming from Paul as well as from Daniel [Day-Lewis, who plays Reynolds]. We talked about music in Britain in the \u201950s, and did lots of research, and among all this slightly twee, pastoral, folksy stuff, Britten really stood out for having the darkness to it.\n\nSo Daniel Day-Lewis gave input for the music?\n\nHe talked about Thomas Tallis a lot. How can music sound English and still be Romantic? One piece, \u201cAlma,\u201d for string quartet and piano, is the most English of everything. I\u2019m not sure why. It just has that kind of harmony to it. I feel like it\u2019s the closest we got. I\u2019m lucky Paul used it in a very tender, romantic moment in the film, at the New Year\u2019s Eve party.\n\nThe film also includes excerpts from pieces by Debussy and Schubert and more. Were these your choices?\n\nThose are Paul\u2019s. He\u2019s always done this. He knows his stuff. He pretends not to.\n\nThen there\u2019s that lush piece, \u201cHouse of Woodcock.\u201d That, to me, is the 1950s, the mellow, quasi-jazzy, quasi-posh music.\n\nIt was called \u201cBill Piano\u201d for ages, because it was from listening to lots of Bill Evans. Such pretty music, which sounds like an insult, but it\u2019s really isn\u2019t.\n\nIs it hard to balance all this work with Radiohead, which releases albums only occasionally but is, for example, doing a substantial American tour this summer?\n\nRadiohead seems to be slowing down. You know, Thom [Yorke] is doing great music by himself. And Ed [O\u2019Brien] is currently recording a record on his own. At the same time, every time I write a new piece of music, in my head it\u2019s headed for a Radiohead song; that\u2019s where my head really is.", "title": "How Jonny Greenwood Wove the \u2018Phantom Thread\u2019 Score", "authors": ["Anthony Tommasini"]} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI had to convince her of the power we had in radio in Miami,\u201d Mr. Thomas said in an interview. \u201cWe were going to go to places people didn\u2019t want to go.\u201d This included Opa-locka, a town marred by gang violence and political corruption whose residents she interviewed. \u201cWe had Lou Dobbs on and Marco Rubio,\u201d Mr. Thomas said, laughing, referring to the conservative Fox Business Network host and the Republican Florida senator. \u201cShe loved to debate.\u201d\n\nIn 2011, Ms. Reid was named managing editor of theGrio.com, a news and analysis website aimed at an African-American audience. (By then she was also writing op-ed columns for The Miami Herald and appearing as a commentator on cable news.) Chris Witherspoon, now a correspondent for the movie ticket seller Fandango.com, was rewriting news briefs for the site when she arrived. \u201cJoy said, \u2018You are way too fabulous to be behind your desk,\u2019\u201d he recalled. She promoted him to entertainment editor.\n\nWhen the singer Whitney Houston died in 2012, MSNBC called Ms. Reid to speak about it on camera, Mr. Witherspoon said. \u201cJoy said, \u2018I think you should do it,\u2019\u201d he recalled. He did so for a week and went on to appear on other talk and news shows. Ms. Reid, he said, \u201cgave me my voice when I didn\u2019t have one of my own.\u201d\n\nDespite a hectic schedule, Ms. Reid makes time for an extended family. \u201cShe is very girlfriend-y,\u201d said Jacque Reid, a television personality who is not related to Joy but has been close with her for a long time. She remembered a party her friend, who lives in Brooklyn, had in December. There were some celebrities, sure. \u201cShe also had the women who helped raise her, her cousins and their children. Those are the V.I.P.s in her life.\u201d\n\nMs. Reid got her television break in 2014 when she was hired by MSNBC to create a daily show called \u201cThe Reid Report.\u201d It was short-lived, though, canceled the next year because of poor ratings (along with Ronan Farrow\u2019s). \u201cIt was stressful because it was daily,\u201d Ms. Reid said. \u201cThere was a lot more management eyes on us. And when it ended, you know, it was not fun. But it did enable me to do something I hadn\u2019t done in my career, which was to actually be a field reporter.\u201d\n\nMany of her stories focused on race in America. In 2015, she went to Mississippi to investigate the death of a man found hanging from a tree, suspended by a bedsheet, which some people said could have been a lynching. \u201cI literally have never had an experience where I felt almost like I was waking through a haunting,\u201d she said. \u201cYou could just feel the ghosts of Mississippi past everywhere you went.\u201d", "title": "How Joy Reid of MSNBC Became a Heroine of the Resistance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "One hopes Buruma is persuaded to reprise his half of this performance at New York Review holiday parties. He\u2019s a self-deprecating man, the butt of every joke he tells. At the end of this performance his only job was to catch the dancer in his arms. To stunned silence in the audience, he dropped her.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn another performance, Buruma stood onstage amid flying pork cutlets, a drag queen, a \u201cdog god\u201d and actors fighting over a placenta in a plastic bag. His role was to wear a leather cowboy hat and exclaim, on cue, \u201cI am the Midnight Cowboy!\u201d\n\nBuruma also appeared in not one but two Suntory whiskey ads, as if presaging Bill Murray\u2019s sarcastically avuncular role in \u201cLost in Translation.\u201d In one of these ads he appeared alongside Akira Kurosawa, the director of \u201cRashomon\u201d and \u201cSeven Samurai.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBuruma was, in other words, half male ing\u00e9nue and half avant-garde Zelig during his Tokyo years. He was a bonhomous lurker. His memoir describes his intellectual and sexual coming-of-age.\n\nHe fell in with a group of Western gay men, including the film historian Donald Richie, who were sexual exiles, able to live more freely in Japan than in the United States or England.\n\nThey were Buruma\u2019s charons into a raffish world of erotic cabarets and sex shows and carnival acts. The scenes flicker past as if lit by strobe lights: women urinating into plastic umbrellas held aloft by happy club patrons; sex in toilet stalls and in movie theaters; a girl who bites the heads off chickens; a man known as the Human Pump for his intricate regurgitation abilities.\n\n\u201cI cannot imagine wanting to immerse oneself in another culture,\u201d Buruma writes, \u201cwithout feeling a sensual pull.\u201d His own sexuality was still up for grabs. He had a Japanese girlfriend when he first moved to Tokyo.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe dated other women, including nude dancers and a jazz singer \u201cwho belted out Peggy Lee numbers late at night for my benefit \u2014 why Peggy Lee, I don\u2019t know.\u201d In his pursuit of ravishment there were men as well.\n\nBuruma casts an emollient eye over the multiple and overlapping ways that he felt like an outsider in Japan. He often received special treatment as a gaijin, but just as often it was made clear to him that he would never get as close to this culture as he wanted.\n\nHis own personality kept him between worlds. \u201cHovering on the fringes was where I liked to be, neither in nor out, neither one thing nor another, semidetached, a born fellow traveler, a male fag hag, an observer in the midst of sympathetic strangers.\u201d\n\nBuruma is a keen observer and the owner of a well-provisioned mind. There are smart little junkets in this book into everything from Japanese movies (Buruma became a film critic for The Japan Times) to the country\u2019s tattooing culture to its female elevator operators, about whom he made a documentary film.\n\nHis prose is unflaggingly good. The experimental theater director Ritsaert ten Cate, for example, \u201chad a face like an unmade bed: hooded eyes, loose cheeks, lips like two cuts of liver.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBuruma worked as an assistant to Magnum photographers while in Tokyo, and took his own photographs as well, many of which are printed in this book. You sense him in this memoir, like a photographer working in a darkroom, burning his memories here and dodging them there.\n\nThere\u2019s a good deal of dodging, one senses, in the area of his sexual experience, his desire to be both moth and flame. \u201cA Tokyo Romance\u201d is about Buruma\u2019s desire to live life up to his nostrils, and clearly he has.\n\nFor a book that is largely about extreme experience, in terms of art and life, he is perhaps overly discreet about his own emotions and behavior. Whenever you sense he is about to open a door, he instead drops you at the curb.\n\nIt was P. G. Wodehouse, of all people, who asked, \u201cWhat\u2019s the use of a great city having temptations if fellows don\u2019t yield to them?\u201d Buruma did his share of yielding. He filed everything away.\n\nWhen he returned again to live in the West, his time in Tokyo led to magazine work and his first book contract. \u201cJapan,\u201d he writes, \u201cwas the making of me.\u201d", "title": "How Life as a Foreigner Helped Shape a Man of Letters", "authors": ["Dwight Garner", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "For most of his 67 years, Kelly, a retired four-star Marine general who projects the weary asceticism of a TV cop perpetually two weeks from retirement, might have been out of place among Mar-a-Lago\u2019s bronzed faces and gilded trimmings. But by mid-February, this was one of the few rooms where he could still expect such a warm reception. Back in Washington, the scandal surrounding his handling of abuse claims against a top aide, Rob Porter, hummed through its second week \u2014 an unusual longevity in a White House where news of a Trump lawyer\u2019s pre-election hush payment to a porn star had come and gone without great consequence. More surprising still was how quickly, and unshakably, the crisis attached itself to Kelly, whose sins \u2014 praising the aide too forcefully before his departure, purportedly sitting on the allegations for months without acting \u2014 felt airlifted from an era of more traditional Washington cover-ups. Kelly held onto his job through the weekend, which did not initially seem like a given. But Trump had already been musing privately about possible replacements.\n\nEven among Trump critics, Kelly once inspired uncommon sympathy. While other high-level officials, like Jeff Sessions and Rex Tillerson, had invited doubts about how long they could possibly tolerate working in the administration, Kelly\u2019s responsibilities seemed uniquely masochistic: He was the chief disciplinarian in a famously undisciplined White House. \u201cYou never run into somebody like Trump in the military,\u201d Panetta told me. \u201cThey\u2019d usually get kicked out.\u201d The job itself was premised on a paradox: If Trump weren\u2019t Trump, Kelly\u2019s position would be bearable. And if Trump weren\u2019t Trump, you would not need a John Kelly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow, Kelly\u2019s struggle has grown lonelier \u2014 informed, even before the Porter affair, by yawning cracks in his once-broad base of support. Some of Trump\u2019s deepest skeptics had convinced themselves, despite a career\u2019s worth of counterevidence, that a well-traveled military man might temper the president\u2019s instincts, particularly on immigration. Then there were Kelly\u2019s friends, who had already worried that the job was bending Kelly to its will, and not the other way around.\n\nShortly after Election Day, Senator Tom Cotton, the Arkansas Republican, went to Trump Tower to see the president-elect. Trump was preparing to staff his cabinet, and he asked Cotton, an Iraq war veteran, to name the best general of this generation. Cotton chose Kelly. \u201cThe president didn\u2019t know about General Kelly and asked me to tell him more,\u201d Cotton told me. In December, Trump nominated Kelly to run the Department of Homeland Security.\n\nUnlike many prospective additions to the administration, Kelly had stayed out of the 2016 campaign. In an interview with Foreign Policy that July, he said he would be willing to serve in either a Trump or a Clinton administration but made plain his distaste for the \u201ccesspool of domestic politics.\u201d \u201cTo join in the political fray, I don\u2019t think it convinces anyone,\u201d he said, chiding fellow military leaders who had lined up behind candidates. \u201cIt just becomes a talking point on CNN.\u201d\n\nHis confirmation process was mostly incident-free, specked with the kind of John Wayne dialogue that had dazzled Trump from the start. Before Kelly\u2019s Senate hearing, an aide who helped him prepare, Blain Rethmeier, noticed the general had neglected to attach a flag pin to his lapel. \u201cBlain,\u201d Kelly told him, declining the pin, \u201cI am an American flag.\u201d He was confirmed on Inauguration Day, 88 votes to 11. \u201cA great choice,\u201d Senator Chuck Schumer, the Democratic leader, said at the time.\n\nKelly grew up in Boston\u2019s Brighton section, the Catholic-school-educated son of a postal worker; fellow Marines later joked that his accent required a Boston-to-English translator. In his own telling, he was shaped by two forces in the neighborhood: men who had worn the military uniform \u2014 his father, his uncles, everyone on the block \u2014 and the ubiquitous drug use among his peers. \u201cHe would claim that growing up in South Boston, he lost most of everybody he grew up with to drugs,\u201d Adam Isacson, the director of defense oversight at the Washington Office on Latin America, told me, recalling meetings with Kelly when he led the United States Southern Command. \u201cIt was part of his persona.\u201d\n\nBy the time the Iraq war began, Kelly, by then a three-decade veteran of the corps, had become the first Marine promoted to brigadier general in an active combat zone in over half a century, according to the Marines. On Barack Obama\u2019s first trip to Iraq as the presumed Democratic nominee in July 2008, Kelly rode with him in an armored truck across Anbar Province. His career advanced rapidly during Obama\u2019s first term, and in 2012, he was named to head the Southern Command (\u201cSouthcom\u201d), charged with overseeing United States military operations in Central and South America and the Caribbean.\n\nUnder Obama, Kelly \u2014 a typically conservative Marine, friends say \u2014 was nominally tasked with steering the country toward policies he often abhorred. After officials pushed the repeal of \u201cdon\u2019t ask, don\u2019t tell,\u201d Kelly seethed. \u201cMarines will die from this,\u201d he told colleagues at the Pentagon. (The Trump White House disputes this.) He was also a fierce defender of the status quo at Guant\u00e1namo Bay, which fell under his command, publicly criticizing efforts to close the facility and chafing at media accounts that humanized those being held there. When some detainees began a hunger strike during Obama\u2019s second term, Kelly feared that the issue was being framed too sympathetically. His charges were instructed to call the act \u201clong-term nonreligious fasting\u201d instead.\n\nBut perhaps Kelly\u2019s most instructive experiences at Southcom involved the scourge of trafficking \u2014 drugs, weapons, people. From command headquarters, just outside Miami, he tracked narcotics production in Colombia and Guatemala. At a forum in 2015, Kelly recalled meeting an official from Customs and Border Protection who oversaw some 200 miles of the Mexico-Texas line. \u201cI asked her how much cocaine she got last year. She said, proud as she could be, \u2018642 pounds,\u2019 \u201d Kelly said. \u201cThat\u2019s pocket litter to me. I got 191 metric tons last year.\u201d He also charted the rise of MS-13, an international criminal gang that had become a security threat across Central America.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKelly seemed to see immigration almost entirely through the prism of security \u2014 paralleling Trump\u2019s campaign, which nodded to the zero-sum economic view of immigration prominent on the right for years, but dwelled far more on blood-and-guts anecdotes of violent crime by immigrants. Although Southcom\u2019s area of responsibility does not include Mexico, this did not discourage Kelly from holding forth on the country, making claims that, according to Obama-administration officials, sometimes contradicted the intelligence of Northcom, the Pentagon command covering Mexico. At the height of the Ebola scare of 2014, he suggested publicly that the disease would spark a stampede across the border, incensing White House staff members who thought he was stoking panic. \u201cIf it breaks out, it\u2019s literally, \u2018Katie, bar the door,\u2019 \u201d Kelly said. \u201cAnd there will be mass migration into the United States.\u201d\n\nAs he assumed control at Homeland Security, Kelly implied that his views on immigration were more nuanced than Trump\u2019s, infused with compassion for a region whose leaders he had come to know personally. In preconfirmation testimony, Kelly accused the United States of \u201cignoring what our drug demand does to the people of Central and South America,\u201d whose countries had devolved at times into \u201cnearly failed narco-states.\u201d He positioned himself as a moderate voice in sessions with lawmakers, casting doubt on the wisdom of a massive border wall. Speaking to a group of Democrats last year, he suggested that undocumented immigrants without a serious criminal footprint would not be enforcement priorities. \u201cHe said, \u2018I\u2019m the best thing to happen to DACA recipients,\u2019 \u201d Representative Nanette Diaz Barrag\u00e1n, a California Democrat, told me.\n\nThe benefit of the doubt lasted nine days. On Jan. 29, Trump signed an executive order barring entry to the United States by residents of seven predominantly Muslim countries, inciting large protests at airports across the country \u2014 and a backlash against Democrats who had voted to confirm Kelly, whose department was left to carry out the order. Kelly told angry lawmakers that responsibility for the chaos was \u201call on me.\u201d In reality, according to an exhaustive Inspector General\u2019s report released early this year, Kelly and his team were caught almost entirely off-guard. He told investigators that \u201che had assumed that White House staff had proactively engaged Congress and other stakeholders\u201d before the order was signed, according to the report. Publicly, Kelly cheered the spirit of the measure, arguing that a federal court order blocking the ban was preventing the nation from doing \u201call that we can to weed out potential wrongdoers from these locations.\u201d Privately, he faulted the execution. \u201cThat\u2019s not going to happen again,\u201d he told the White House.\n\nAt the same time, Kelly was making good on a signature Trump campaign promise. Immigration officers arrested more than 140,000 people in 2017, a sharp uptick. \u201cWe questioned the fact that many of these arrests were taking place when parents were dropping off their children to go to school,\u201d Representative Nydia Vel\u00e1zquez, a Democrat from New York who met with Kelly at the time, told me. \u201cHe didn\u2019t back down.\u201d\n\nBy then, most Democrats had seen enough. \u201cHe\u2019s disappointing to me,\u201d Schumer decided by February of last year, suggesting in an interview that Kelly was probably \u201cregretting going in.\u201d\n\nKelly betrayed no second thoughts in public. He also began taking on duties that appeared to be outside his jurisdiction. When news broke that Trump\u2019s son-in-law, Jared Kushner, worked to establish a secret communications channel with Russian diplomats during the transition, it was Kelly who defended the effort on television as \u201ca good thing.\u201d In May, addressing a private breakfast with former diplomats and foreign-policy experts, Kelly said he had suggested to Tillerson, the ever-beleaguered secretary of state, that he could \u201ctake care of Central America\u201d while Tillerson confronted first-order headaches like North Korea, according to a person in the room. (A White House spokesman disputes this account.)\n\nIt was no secret, by then, that Trump had grown disenchanted with his first chief of staff, Reince Priebus, who presided over a team consumed by squabbling factions, endless leaks and overbroad walk-in privileges for presidential face time. (During one Oval Office meeting Trump had with New York Times reporters in April, no fewer than 20 people came and went.) In an interview with The Times last December, Kelly said that he told Trump around this time that he did not believe the president \u201cwas being well served by the staff\u201d in some respects. A month and a half later, Kelly recalled, Trump called and said, \u201cI need you to be chief.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKelly set out first to slay the meandering, oversize meetings he loathed. \u201cI see these people,\u201d he used to tell staff members at Homeland Security, after returning from the White House. \u201cI don\u2019t even know who they are or what they do.\u201d Almost immediately, he sought to institute new rules: Meetings were to be tight, targeted and surprise-free. Once, Vice President Mike Pence showed up for one unexpectedly. \u201cYou guys have the meeting,\u201d Kelly grumbled, walking off, according to a White House official who witnessed the exchange.\n\nFor decades, the White House chief of staff\u2019s mandate has been a kind of tough love \u2014 the capacity to close the door to the Oval Office and tell the president what he does not want to hear. \u201cAbove all, you are the honest broker of information,\u201d Chris Whipple, the author of \u201cThe Gatekeepers,\u201d a history of White House chiefs, told me. True to this template, Kelly clamped down on the free flow of information to Trump, who once rifled through Breitbart articles and conspiracy-stuffed printouts with impunity. Some executive riffraff was expelled altogether. \u201cHe fired me like a gentleman,\u201d says Anthony Scaramucci, who lasted 11 days as communications director and scolds anyone who suggests it was 10. Those who dared attempt an unsanctioned chat with the president could expect a Kelly follow-up: \u201cYou want to be chief of staff?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe early purges, which included the exits of the advisers Stephen K. Bannon and Sebastian Gorka, restored a measure of good will toward Kelly among Democrats. But again, Kelly\u2019s kinship with Trump on immigration was underestimated. \u201cPart of that is the Marine in him, part of that is the Irish guy in Boston who believes that in the end, you really do have to abide by the laws,\u201d Panetta, a friend of Kelly\u2019s, told me. \u201cI think that\u2019s what\u2019s coming out now.\u201d\n\nIn November, as Homeland Security was set to extend residency permits for tens of thousands of Hondurans living in the United States, Kelly made an 11th-hour plea to the department\u2019s acting secretary to reconsider the move. When the administration debated lowering the annual cap on refugees \u2014 should it stay at 110,000? Fall to 50,000, the minimum recommended by Defense and State Department officials? Land somewhere in between? \u2014 Kelly offered his take: If it were his call, he said, the number would be between zero and one. The administration settled on 45,000.\n\nEven as Kelly has driven out the most flamboyant West Wing agitators \u2014 Scaramucci, Omarosa Manigault Newman, Bannon, Gorka \u2014 it has not gone unnoticed that Stephen Miller, the 32-year-old senior policy adviser and Trump\u2019s nativist id on immigration policy since the campaign, has thrived on Kelly\u2019s watch. \u201cHe turns out to have been more hawkish than I might have expected,\u201d Mark Krikorian, the executive director of the hard-line Center for Immigration Studies, told me of Kelly. \u201cIt\u2019s a pleasant surprise.\u201d\n\nIn January, several Senate moderates believed they were close to securing Trump\u2019s support for a compromise measure protecting the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers, in exchange for border-security funding and other policy adjustments. Trump invited some of them to a televised summit at the White House, where he told them he would approve any legislation they brought him. \u201cI\u2019m not going to say, \u2018Oh, gee, I want this, or I want that,\u2019 \u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ll be signing it.\u201d He even assured Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, that he welcomed a stand-alone bill protecting the Dreamers from deportation \u2014 anathema to the negotiating position of Republicans in Congress, some of whom rushed to dissuade him at the table.\n\nKelly sat silently through the televised session. But after about an hour, when the cameras were dismissed and the meeting began in earnest, he unburdened himself in what four attendees described as a caustic scolding. \u201cYou\u2019ve been fiddling around for years on immigration,\u201d he told lawmakers. The time had come, he said before leaving in a huff, to \u201cdo your job.\u201d Attendees were handed a document labeled \u201cMUST HAVE\u2019S,\u201d outlining the administration\u2019s demands: billions in border-wall funding, an end to \u201cextended chain migration\u201d and a move toward a \u201cmerit-based system\u201d for legal immigration. These were requirements long pushed by Kelly and Miller and likely to sink any deal with Democrats.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s this?\u201d Trump asked, according to three people present, eyeballing the list of what were ostensibly his own policy directives. He suggested the papers were unhelpful and could be disregarded. Lawmakers left the meeting unsure if the president knew his own administration\u2019s position, or if he was even responsible for it.\n\nDays later, a bipartisan group of senators led by Dick Durbin of Illinois and Lindsey Graham of South Carolina thought again that they could sell Trump on their plans, only to be thwarted anew. This time, they did not conceal their frustrations with Kelly in particular. \u201cI don\u2019t think he was well served by his staff,\u201d Graham said of the president to reporters at the Capitol. And Kelly, he said, was \u201cpart of the staff.\u201d\n\nIn another meeting with Hispanic congressional Democrats later in January, Kelly made the case once more for a \u201cmerit-based system\u201d for legal immigration. Members reminded him what he was asking of them. \u201cHe\u2019s saying this to 25 members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus!\u201d Representative Luis Guti\u00e9rrez, an Illinois Democrat, told me. \u201cMy mom came with a fifth-grade education. Someone stood up and said to him, \u2018So you don\u2019t think we should even be here?\u2019 We\u2019re the children of those parents. And we\u2019re members of Congress.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKelly\u2019s active role in immigration policy, Whipple told me, was highly unusual for a chief of staff, setting Kelly apart from even otherwise partisan warriors like Dick Cheney, who served as chief to Gerald Ford, and Rahm Emanuel, the first to hold the position under Obama. \u201cThis is abnormal,\u201d Whipple said. \u201cHe\u2019s been more partisan than almost any chief of staff I can think of.\u201d\n\nIt took a mass shooting and another round of Russia intrigue to elbow speculation about Kelly\u2019s job status, post-Porter scandal, temporarily out of the news. \u201cTrying to keep below the radar particularly after the Porter issue and my involvement was so inaccurately covered,\u201d Kelly told me in an email, declining an interview. But his standing has not necessarily rebounded. This fate seems to flow, in part, from the heightened initial expectations of him. But it also speaks to his shortage of allies in Trump\u2019s inner circle. Rivals, sensing a power vacuum, are wasting no time, spawning a succession of leaks and counterleaks that evoke the Priebus-era West Wing.\n\nToday Kelly holds the support of two incongruous constituencies: those who cheer him on immigration and those who assume, despite the strikes against him, that he is preventing catastrophes no one can see. But this base is shrinking. \u201cOne Donald is bad enough,\u201d Reines, one of the last Democratic holdouts, tweeted as Kelly cycled through conflicting explanations of the Porter timeline in February. \u201cWe don\u2019t need two.\u201d\n\nOlder friends have greeted recent events with a deeper despair. Some war buddies, eager to publicly support Kelly when he took the job, have begged off entirely. \u201cI\u2019d prefer not to talk anymore about him,\u201d Mark Hertling, a retired three-star general who served with Kelly in Iraq, told me, \u201cgiven what I\u2019ve seen lately.\u201d\n\nFor John Allen, a retired four-star general who has known Kelly since the late 1970s and endorsed Clinton in 2016, the first distress signal seemed to come in October. Trump had upset the widow of La David T. Johnson, an Army sergeant who was killed in an ambush in Niger, by telling her that her husband \u201cknew what he signed up for.\u201d Defending himself afterward, Trump falsely accused Obama of not contacting the families of fallen troops at all, adding (truthfully) that Obama did not call Kelly when his son First Lt. Robert Kelly was killed in Afghanistan in 2010.\n\nKelly, who had long avoided discussing his loss in detail, confirmed as much from the lectern of the White House briefing room. \u201cIt must have been enormously painful for him,\u201d Allen told me. \u201cJohn is very private in his grief.\u201d But Kelly went on to accuse Frederica Wilson, a Florida congresswoman who knew the widow and listened to Trump\u2019s phone call with her, of making self-aggrandizing remarks years earlier. A video from the time quickly proved him wrong, but Kelly never apologized. To friends who had winced often at Trump\u2019s conduct, but never Kelly\u2019s, it was agonizing to watch.\n\nIn the months since, Trump and Kelly have found new reasons to grow sick of each other. Even before the Porter maelstrom began dominating Trump\u2019s cable-news diet, the president had been smarting for weeks over Kelly\u2019s suggestion to Fox News that the president had \u201cevolved\u201d on his wall demands. Both episodes stirred latent frustrations with Kelly\u2019s imperious style, which had grated on Trump. \u201cHe\u2019s a free spirit,\u201d Roger Stone, Trump\u2019s longtime informal adviser, said of the president. \u201cNobody handles Donald Trump. Nobody manages him. He resents those who try.\u201d Trump has been floating Gary Cohn, his economic adviser, as a possible replacement.\n\nBut on immigration, Kelly\u2019s legacy, such as it is, may already be secure. His tumble has coincided with what was supposed to be a period of congressional progress on the issue \u2014 testing the priorities of a president who would still like a wall but thrills at the prospect of any signing ceremony. After appearing inclined at times toward an agreement with Democrats before Kelly helped reel him back, Trump has by now wholly convinced them that he is not to be trusted to cut a deal. Once held up as the administration\u2019s most credible cross-aisle emissary, Kelly has instead become the figure \u2014 even more than Miller, from whom Democrats expected nothing less \u2014 most closely associated with White House intransigence. \u201cHe\u2019s not a martyr, and he\u2019s not a hostage,\u201d Juliette Kayyem, a former assistant secretary at Homeland Security under Obama who has worked with Kelly and who initially cheered his addition to the administration, told me. \u201cJohn Kelly is not saving us.\u201d\n\nThere is a favorite book of Kelly\u2019s that he has said he rereads at key moments of his career. It is \u201cThe General,\u201d a 1936 novel by C.S. Forester, set among British forces around World War I. Principally, it is about a commander unable to meet the moment. \u201cHe is a brave guy, a dedicated guy, a noble guy,\u201d Kelly said of the protagonist, Herbert Curzon, in a collection of book recommendations by military leaders published last year, \u201cbut a guy who in the end has become a corps commander \u2014 a three-star general \u2014 and when presented with an overwhelming German attack couldn\u2019t figure out how to deal with it because he\u2019d never developed himself intellectually.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOutmatched by his circumstances, Curzon resolves, at least, to fall on his terms. \u201cHe didn\u2019t know the great lessons of the great master, if you will,\u201d Kelly said, \u201cand then he just decided one day to go down to his horse, grab his sword, and attack \u2014 with the intent of dying.\u201d", "title": "How Long Can John Kelly Hang On?", "authors": ["Matt Flegenheimer"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s not a terribly useful tool right now,\u201d said Alan Blinder, a Princeton economist and former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. \u201cFor it to be useful you have to have at least a little confidence you know the number. You don\u2019t need to know it to two decimal places, but within a reasonable range. If your range is 2.5 to 7, that doesn\u2019t tell you anything.\u201d\n\nIn the mid-1990s, when Mr. Blinder was at the Fed, he and Janet Yellen, then a Fed governor, tried to persuade the chairman Alan Greenspan that interest rate increases were needed because the unemployment rate was quickly falling below estimates of Nairu in the 6 percent and higher range.\n\nMr. Greenspan won the argument, as he almost always did at the Fed in that era. And with hindsight it seems he was correct. Unemployment kept falling through the late 1990s, and reached as low as 3.8 percent in the spring of 2000, without evident flares of inflation pressure.\n\nIndeed, the jobless rate in the United States has now fallen below 4.5 percent just three times since 1970 \u2014 the late 1990s, 2006-2007, and in the last year. In none of those times did inflation flare up (and in the current expansion, it hasn\u2019t flared up yet).\n\nLooking abroad is instructive, too. Each country has a distinct labor market that probably implies a different natural rate of unemployment. But it is striking that in Germany and Japan, joblessness levels have fallen in the last couple of years below estimates that officials in those countries have generally considered their Nairu \u2014 without inflation taking hold.\n\nThat tells some officials here, charged with making policy in 2018, that the sensible strategy is to see just how low joblessness can go without causing problems.\n\n\u201cWe have to have humility\u201d about where the natural rate of unemployment really is, said Neel Kashkari, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. \u201cUltimately we\u2019re trying to assess supply and demand in the market for labor, and we can start by looking at the price. The price of labor has not been growing very quickly, and we\u2019ve been seeing job creation far in excess of what we need to keep up with labor force growth.\u201d", "title": "How Low Can Unemployment Really Go? Economists Have No Idea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "With billions of dollars in commercial time at stake, content providers, and especially media companies that own expensive sports rights, have raced to keep up. Scripted programming can have a long shelf life and be sold over time in a variety of ways, but the vast majority of sports is watched live, which means broadcasters need to capture every viewer possible and figure out how to count them.\n\nThe catch is that they aren\u2019t yet in agreement on how to do that.\n\n\u201cIn order for the industry to move forward, we have to coalesce around a single-source approach,\u201d said Cary Meyers, head of ESPN\u2019s consumer-research division, where the network is working directly with Nielsen on a live audience metric that would be a different version of TAD.\n\nNBC appears unwilling to take any chances with the Winter Games, particularly after facing an unexpected decline in traditional, or \u201clinear,\u201d TV ratings in Rio, when it had to offer free commercial time to advertisers to meet its ratings guarantees. Streaming surged during that period.\n\nLinda Yaccarino, NBC Universal\u2019s head of ad sales, has been a vocal critic of Nielsen in recent years, saying that the measurement company\u2019s methods don\u2019t accurately count all the new ways people are watching its shows. Network complaints have grown louder as the legacy media companies battle falling ratings and new competition for ad dollars from the likes of Facebook and YouTube, which is owned by Google.\n\nNielsen ratings for traditional television are based upon averaging every minute of viewing by a representative panel. NBC combines Nielsen\u2019s measures for its television channels with Adobe\u2019s measurement of streaming data to form TAD.\n\nAdvertising technology is changing constantly, and Nielsen has to carefully decide when a metric is ready for mainstream adoption. Megan Clarken, Nielsen\u2019s president of United States media (and at one time an Olympic-qualifying long jumper), said that a decade ago the company faced pressure to enter mobile measurement. If it had done so, Nielsen would have been pushing ultimately useless metrics to measure viewing on BlackBerry phones.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat we do as a company is we watch for that activity, that evolution,\u201d she said, \u201cand what we aim to do is not be ahead of it, but be with it, and certainly not behind it.\u201d\n\nWhile analysts said it was smart of NBC to push its own metric for the Games, it is also the right move for Nielsen to proceed carefully as it develops an industry standard for tracking viewers across a \u201cdizzying array\u201d of consumer devices in the digital world, said Dave Morgan, the founder and chief executive of Simulmedia.\n\n\u201cEverybody in the digital video industry is pretty much in agreement that 30 to 40 percent of the ad impressions that are delivered out there don\u2019t really exist,\u201d said Mr. Morgan, whose firm works with brands on targeted TV ads. \u201cYet nobody would say 30 to 40 percent of TV\u2019s viewing audience doesn\u2019t exist. So I think Nielsen is very, very afraid of going into a Wild West environment where it is wide open to fraud and bots.\u201d\n\nAccording to Nielsen, while measuring authentic digital viewing is difficult, it is no more difficult than doing so for television. But despite the ambiguity of the measuring sticks, advertisers don\u2019t want to miss an opportunity to impress a mass audience over 17 days.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t necessarily want to sit on the sidelines because, \u2018Hey \u2014 funky measurement,\u2019\u201d said Gibbs Haljun, managing director of media investment at GroupM, the media-buying arm of WPP. \u201cThat sort of defeats the point of what they\u2019re trying to do.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile NBC sees a strong need for better measurement of non-television viewers, especially in sports, it won\u2019t necessarily be rolling out TAD across the NBC universe. The Olympics are a unique property, with thousands of hours of programming playing out on broadcast and cable channels, unlike a hit drama like \u201cThis Is Us,\u201d which would never be shown across a broadcast and cable channel simultaneously.\n\nThe Olympics is the perfect petri dish for audience measurement,\u201d said Mr. Lovinger of NBC. The network\u2019s traditional television ratings during the Rio Games were down 15 percent compared with the London Games four years earlier, and since the network had made separate linear and digital ratings guarantees for Rio, it was left \u201cwithout the ability to manage delivery across the Games,\u201d Mr. Lovinger said.\n\n\u201cYou look at the Olympics in Rio and you look at the kind of decline in linear television viewing and the supplement of digital viewing, either simultaneous or delayed, and it is obviously a material difference,\u201d said David Cohen, president of North America at Magna Global, a major ad-buying firm.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo far, TAD seems to be doing its job. Across the first four nights of the Olympics, ratings for NBC only were down 15 percent from the comparable nights in Sochi four years ago. But the total audience was down just 7 percent. NBC said it is meeting its ratings guarantees, and has begun selling extra ad inventory that it had held back in case of falling short.\n\nMr. Haljun said that the timing is right for NBC\u2019s metric this year, but doesn\u2019t see it as a long-term solution.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re at this weird point where people agree there needs to be a certified third-party number that\u2019s comparable across networks,\u201d Mr. Haijun said.\n\n\u201cBut we\u2019re in the early days of getting there,\u201d he added. \u201cPeople are doing different things and have disagreements on the best way to do this.\u201d", "title": "How Many People Are Watching the Olympics? NBC Uses a Tricky Head Count", "authors": ["Kevin Draper", "Sapna Maheshwari"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "After decades of postmodern politics, they long for grand narratives, on both sides. Call it solidarity in partisanship \u2014 a longing for clear lines that cut across policy issues, rather than a wet blanket of consensus that covers over sociopolitical fractures.\n\nBut is it what voters want, too?\n\nIt is conventional wisdom that the consensus politics of Ms. Merkel, Mr. Schulz and their generational peers strengthened the political fringes, especially the far right. That\u2019s not entirely true, though: Polls show that Germans, even if they\u2019re tired of Ms. Merkel, still value consensus.\n\n\u201cGermans are generally oriented toward compromise, not polarization,\u201d said Andrea Wolf, a board member of Forschungsgruppe Wahlen, a major German pollster.\n\nThough Ms. Merkel\u2019s poll numbers dipped during the refugee crisis, they have rebounded. \u201cI doubt that the policy approach of the younger generation of policymakers is what voters really want,\u201d Ms. Wolf said. \u201cIt\u2019s possibly rather just what they want.\u201d\n\nReal politics always consists of bullet points. You want to lift up the lower middle classes? You have to pass tax relief, restructure social security contributions, bolster the education budget \u2014 which is what the next grand coalition will vow to do, if the negotiations are successful.\n\nThe challenge for German politicians, moving forward, will be to come up with a narrative big enough to create a sense of direction, of being based on values more fundamental than raising the gross domestic product a few percentage points, but avoiding the sort of utopian visions that German voters rightly distrust.\n\nIf they succeed, they could set free a new era of political energy. If they fail, we could see a dark turn toward the sort of fractured, incoherent politics haunting the rest of the world, full of holes that the far right can move through. There\u2019s a trap, however. In raging against the slow and boring politics of compromise, the members of the new generation are joining the very populist chant they are setting out to defeat.", "title": "Opinion | How Millennials Are Changing German Politics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "At the 2010 Vancouver Games, Nagasu was only 16 when she finished a surprising fourth. She thought she deserved a top-three finish. So she looked to the 2014 Sochi Games as another chance for the podium.\n\nBut Nagasu \u2014 famously, and heartbreakingly for her \u2014 was passed up for the United States team that year, even though she finished third at the United States nationals. Three Americans not named Mirai Nagasu went to Sochi instead, chosen by a committee considered the skaters\u2019 body of work that season, not merely their performance at nationals.\n\nNagasu cried almost nonstop in the weeks and months after being passed over. She blamed herself for being lazy. She felt as if her chance at an Olympic medal had vanished. She considered hanging up her skates, wondering if her very public journey as a skater who was brilliant but erratic was worth it. At 14, she was the second-youngest skater ever to win a United States championship, and then things grew complicated when her body started changing.\n\nWhat pulled her back into skating was an April 2014 trip to Colorado Springs to visit a friend, Agnes Zawadzki. Zawadzki was training with Tom Zakrajsek, a coach who once worked with one of Nagasu\u2019s biggest competitors, the 2010 Olympian Rachael Flatt.\n\nNagasu had always admired Flatt\u2019s consistency, because it had always been Nagasu\u2019s weakness. She took a few sessions with Zakrajsek and decided that the 2018 Olympics could be within her reach. She asked Zakrajsek to coach her, and packed up her Honda Civic for her new life in Colorado.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe daughter of Japanese immigrants, Nagasu had wanted to move out of her parents\u2019 house in Arcadia, Calif., when she was a rebellious 17-year-old. But her mother, Ikuko, and her father, Kiyoto, would not allow it. This time, they were supportive.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo Mirai Nagasu packed up her childhood bedroom, leaving the pink Miss Smiley comforter and most everything else behind.\n\n\u201cYour room will always be here, just like it is in case you need an escape,\u201d Ikuko Nagasu told Mirai before she drove away. \u201cI promise I\u2019m not going to make it a sewing room.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Colorado Springs, Nagasu lived with a host family and learned how to cook for herself. After many failed attempts, she mastered meatloaf and baked desserts for her friends at the rink. She adopted her first of three dogs, took college classes and began dating Darian Weiss, an actor, and their relationship grew serious. She eventually moved into her own house.\n\nTo help pay the bills, she got a job that was far different from when she worked at her family\u2019s restaurant, where as a little girl she was paid in quarters for washing dishes. She became an \u201cice girl\u201d for the Colorado Avalanche during the 2015-16 hockey season, and her task was to clean the ice with a shovel while wearing a tiny skirt and crop top.\n\nLiving a real life, an adult\u2019s life, outside of the rink has helped her focus inside the rink even more. In her sport, that\u2019s usually a foreign concept.\n\nPhoto\n\nNagasu was rejuvenated by Zakrajsek\u2019s technical help but also by his pep talks. On Saturdays, he brings his skaters in for sports concepts classes, where he plays clips from inspirational movies or gives motivational lessons.\n\nAs for Nagasu\u2019s experience with missing the 2014 Games, Zakrajsek said they had spent about five minutes on it in the past four years. There was too much ahead of them, they decided, to look back and wallow.\n\nAhead of them was something bigger: a triple axel. It\u2019s a jump that only two female skaters \u2014 Mao Asada and Midori Ito of Japan \u2014 had landed at the Olympics.\n\nAt Nagasu\u2019s age, though, learning a new jump was virtually unheard-of. The conventional wisdom in skating is that young girls learn to jump, and that women only refine what they learned as young girls. But the jump garners a tremendous number of points because of its difficulty. So she trained and trained, and last summer she finally landed it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cShe\u2019ll do triple axels after triple axels until Tom has to drag her off the ice,\u201d said Vincent Zhou, who finished sixth last week in the Olympic men\u2019s singles event. \u201cShe\u2019s incredible. She will skate 17,635 long programs and then do a short program every single day. She\u2019s the hardest worker I know.\u201d\n\nIn last week\u2019s team event, Nagasu nailed her long program, including landing the triple axel. It helped the United States team win the bronze.\n\n\u201cI knew in my heart this day would come,\u201d she said.\n\nThis week, in the singles, she said she believes she can land it again. Maybe then she\u2019ll let herself fade away \u2014 a woman at the top of a girls\u2019 sport, and one with at least one Olympic medal around her neck.", "title": "How Mirai Nagasu Grew Up and Got Back to the Olympics", "authors": ["Juliet Macur", "Sports Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "The way we use \u201centitled\u201d feels less strange when you consider that its two meanings have slightly different origins. Once upon a time, \u201centitlement\u201d was, quite literally, something granted by a higher authority: A \u201cnoble\u201d person pleased the sovereign, perhaps by acquiring land or fighting bravely, and in return the sovereign bestowed upon him special rights and privileges, perks not afforded to a commoner, including the right not to have their estate expropriated by the crown. \u201cEntitlement\u201d was a recognition of service, a promise of specific legal benefits. In some cases it came with an actual title, like the feudal \u201cbaron.\u201d\n\nSomething similar has been true in the United States, where \u201centitlements\u201d refers to government benefit programs not subject to budgetary discretion \u2014 assistance that the state was obligated, on levels both legal and societal, to provide to all eligible citizens. According to the linguist Geoff Nunberg, it was sometime after the publication of \u201cThe Culture of Narcissism,\u201d an influential 1979 book by Christopher Lasch, that a certain negative connotation began to spread. Legitimate \u201centitlement\u201d and an illegitimate sense of entitlement merged. You might now be an entitled person: someone whose privilege leads to arrogance, snobbery and rudeness, someone who expects to be waited on, provided for, deferred to.\n\nThis was an unfortunate development for those who depended on entitlement programs, who were increasingly cast as undeserving \u2014 people who \u201cchose\u201d to be poor, via laziness and lack of responsibility, and yet felt \u201centitled\u201d to governmental support. Even before Lasch\u2019s book, Ronald Reagan, during his first run for president, held up an actual career criminal \u2014 a con woman, identity thief and suspected kidnapper believed to have bilked the government of untold thousands of dollars \u2014 as a symbol of excess, conjuring around her a world of fantastical \u201cwelfare queens\u201d: enemies of the bootstrapping individualist spirit of America, coddled and demanding and overly dependent on programs they were, in fact, legally entitled to use. The apotheosis of this concept was laid out by Mitt Romney in 2012, when he declared that 47 percent of voters were dependent on the government, saw themselves as victims and believed \u201cthat they are entitled to health care, to food, to housing, to you name it. That that\u2019s an entitlement.\u201d It was not his job, he argued, to care about such people, whom he\u2019d \u201cnever convince\u201d that they should \u201ctake personal responsibility and care for their lives.\u201d\n\nOf course, it did not escape American voters that as the very wealthy scion of a very powerful family, Romney was the epitome of an \u201centitled\u201d man in the original, feudal sense; his entitlement was hereditary. And he was, above all, in a position to make influential judgments about what others had, what others wanted, what people deserved or did not.", "title": "How Much Is Anyone \u2018Entitled\u2019 To, in the End?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "The commission oversees hundreds of millions of dollars in revenues and prizes a year.\n\n\u201cWhen somebody wins a public lottery of $560 million, there is a public interest in knowing who the winner was, and that it is a fair and equitable process,\u201d John J. Conforti, an assistant attorney general representing the lottery commission, told the court.\n\nThe state gave little credence to the argument that identifying Ms. Doe would jeopardize her safety, saying that any risk could be managed by engaging a security detail. Ms. Doe\u2019s lawyers said they were already lining up bodyguards.\n\nMost states view the names of winners of significant prizes as a matter of public record, though a few permit winners to keep their identities private. Some states, including New Hampshire, allow trusts and not just individuals to claim winnings.\n\nFor almost two hours Tuesday, Judge Charles Temple of the Hillsborough County Superior Court heard arguments in the case, which has made headlines around the world for the eye-popping size of the prize and for an \u201cif only\u201d twist in Ms. Doe\u2019s plight.\n\nWhen Ms. Doe realized she had the winning ticket, she followed the instructions on the ticket and on the lottery commission\u2019s website to \u201csign the ticket.\u201d\n\nIf only she had talked to a lawyer first, she might have avoided the entire issue. She could have set up a trust that would sign the ticket, claim the prize and be the public face of the winner, rather than Ms. Doe personally. But lottery officials say the chance to do that ended when she signed her name.\n\nMs. Doe\u2019s lawyers \u2014 Steven M. Gordon and Billy Shaheen, high-powered attorneys in the state \u2014 said the ticket and state\u2019s website were misleading because they did not explain that by signing a ticket, winners give up their anonymity. Nowhere, they said, does the website advise the winner \u201cthat there is an option for a trust to claim a prize.\u201d", "title": "How Much Is Your Privacy Worth? A Lot, if You\u2019ve Won $560 Million", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Clearly anticipating an extremely lengthy and profitable run, ATG not only paid for the Lyric\u2019s renovation, but made it financially worthwhile for the Cirque du Soleil show \u201cParamour,\u201d which had cost $25 million, to move out.
