It\u2019s not like playing an hour of basketball, but you definitely do feel it. Often Griffin and Gemma will jump in and do some situps or jumping jacks with me. Gemma will sometimes get on my back for the push-ups.\n\nFace Time\n\nI prefer shaving oil to shaving cream. I find that I\u2019ve got dry, sensitive skin, so that tends to protect my skin better. Dermalogica has a great one. Then I use the Bumble & Bumble Curl Conscious Defining Cr\u00e8me on my hair. I don\u2019t spend a lot of time.\n\nSneakerhead\n\nI grab a pair of jeans, a crew-neck navy sweater and Air Max 1s and I\u2019m good to go. I\u2019m into sneakers, but also more into just Nike as a brand, frankly. I love how they have scaled with integrity. I believe they have had a really positive impact on culture, whether it\u2019s women in sport or equality of all sorts of types.", "title": "How Warby Parker\u2019s Neil Blumenthal Disrupts His Daily Routine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOn Monday, The New York Times published its first augmented reality feature. The article, written by John Branch, includes four AR moments and is a preview of the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea.\n\nReaders are able to meet world-class Olympic competitors \u2014 the figure skater Nathan Chen, the big-air snowboarder Anna Gasser, the short-track speed skater J.R. Celski and the hockey goalie Alex Rigsby \u2014 midperformance. Through your phone, the room around you looks just as it is, except the athlete is in it with you.\n\nPhoto\n\nAugmented reality allows us to bridge the digital and physical worlds; graphical elements can be superimposed on your immediate environment. The Olympics project \u2014 a major collaboration among the newsroom, design and product staffs that I led, as The Times\u2019s director of immersive platforms \u2014 demonstrates one of AR\u2019s richest benefits: deepening the explanatory value of visual journalism. Scale, for example, is incredibly difficult to represent on your phone screen. By conjuring athletes as if they were in the room, scale is conveyed by the context of your surroundings.\n\nAnother advantage is the mode of interaction we provide. Instead of the abstractions of pinch-to-zoom or swipe or click, we simply ask readers to treat the graphic as a physical object. If you want to see the form from another angle, you simply walk around to that area. If you want to see something up close, simply lean in to that spot. News becomes something you can see, literally, from all sides.\n\nPhoto\n\nBringing the four Olympians into augmented reality required finding a technique to capture them not just photographically, but also three-dimensionally, creating a photo-real scan that can then be viewed from any angle.\n\nPhoto\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe asked each athlete to demonstrate his or her form at specific moments. Nathan Chen held a pose showing exactly how he positions his arms tightly to his body during his quads to allow his incredible speed of rotation. Alex Rigsby showed us how she arranges her pads to best guard the net from a puck traveling at 70 miles per hour.", "title": "How We Achieved an Olympic Feat of Immersive Journalism", "authors": ["Graham Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHealth food\u201d as a path to dietary salvation has long flourished in America, going back to John Harvey Kellogg\u2019s legendary sanitarium in Battle Creek, where Americans paid to have yogurt administered to both ends of their alimentary canal. A somewhat more hedonic version of health food appeared in 1950s Los Angeles. \u201cHealth seekers\u201d could find fresh unprocessed foods \u201cstill charged with their life force\u201d at restaurants like the Aware Inn, the Health Hut and, a bit later, the Source. (It was on the patio of the Source on Sunset Boulevard where Woody Allen broke up with Diane Keaton in \u201cAnnie Hall\u201d after ordering a plate of mashed yeast.) These were restaurants with gurus, and they introduced Americans to such culinary novelties as juicing, alfalfa sprouts and the late, unlamented chocolate substitute called carob.\n\nAround the same time a rather more austere regime of dietary salvation entered the countercuisine via the small but highly influential fad of macrobiotics, or, as it was often called (for no apparent reason), \u201cZen macrobiotics.\u201d Imported from Japan in the early \u201960s, this rigorous, science-free culinary practice demanded of adherents that they scrupulously balance the yin and yang in their diet; for many followers this came down to eating little more than (yang-y) brown rice and tamari, a diet responsible for several cases of scurvy and a handful of deaths. Yet the macrobiotic fringe seeped into the mainstream, introducing Americans to Asian flavors (soy sauce) and methods (stir frying) as well as to eating seasonally and organically, while helping to stigmatize processed foods like refined grains and sugar.\n\nIf Kauffman\u2019s story has a hero, it is Frances Moore Lapp\u00e9, the writer who most galvanized the counterculture just as it was beginning to think of eating as a political act. In 1969, Lapp\u00e9, 25, burrowed into the stacks of Berkeley\u2019s agricultural economics library hoping to learn if Malthusian predictions of mass starvation (recently popularized by Paul Ehrlich in \u201cThe Population Bomb\u201d) were true. What she discovered, and told the world about in her 1971 best-selling book, \u201cDiet for a Small Planet,\u201d was that the problem \u201cwasn\u2019t how much food the earth could produce, it was what we did with it\u201d \u2014 which was to feed much of it to animals, nature\u2019s least efficient machine for converting sunlight into edible protein. A far better machine? The humble soybean, which she convinced a generation \u201ccould save the world.\u201d Enter William Shurtleff, who, inspired by Lapp\u00e9, went to Japan and returned as the Johnny Appleseed of tofu.\n\nPhoto\n\nLapp\u00e9 had composed a powerful proof of exactly how the personal is political. Summarizing the message she brought to millions of Americans, Kauffman writes, \u201cShopping and cooking \u2026 were political acts, hopeful acts, whose cumulative impact would be felt around the world.\u201d The arresting idea that what someone in Ann Arbor chose to eat had implications for hunger in Bombay made vegetarianism a moral imperative for many in the counterculture.\n\n\u201cThen came the real struggle,\u201d Kauffman writes, of making vegetarian food \u201cdelicious.\u201d But in time hippie chefs rose to the challenge, usually by raiding other food cultures for flavor, as Mollie Katzen did so effectively in her \u201cMoosewood Cookbook\u201d (three million copies sold since publication). In time, the counterculture rescued vegetables from centuries of mistreatment by Anglo-American cooks.\n\nThe third current shaping hippie food flowed directly from counterculture politics, with its critique of capitalism and romantic notions about preindustrial life. Especially after 1970, when untold numbers of hippies fled a souring scene in the city for a fresh start in the country, figuring out how to feed themselves without depending on the Man became paramount. (America\u2019s rural population increased by more than 10 percent during the 1970s.) Rejecting a chemical agriculture that was fatally linked to the Vietnam War by Monsanto and Dow, hippie farmers with no training had to puzzle out how to grow food without pesticides or fertilizers. Many failed, but a handful went on to develop the sustainable practices now enshrined in the federal definition of \u201corganic food,\u201d which has become a $50 billion industry.\n\nBut for the hippies it wasn\u2019t enough to grow the food differently; it had to be sold and distributed differently, too, which meant networks of buying clubs and co-ops and farmer\u2019s markets. Except for the farmer\u2019s markets, which continue to thrive, these alternatives to capitalism have not fared nearly as well as the types of food they sold. Grocers like Whole Foods eventually co-opted the co-ops, reducing what had been a radical idea to a cool retail vibe.\n\nCapitalism\u2019s genius for absorbing and integrating every challenge to it is on vivid display in this thoroughly absorbing history. Behind familiar brands like Stonyfield (now a subsidiary of Lactalis, a French dairy company) or Cascadian Farm (now part of General Mills) stand hippie ideals as well as pioneering organic farmers. As Gene Kahn, the hippie-farmer founder of Cascadian Farm, told me, somewhat ruefully, after he sold his company to General Mills, \u201cEverything eventually morphs into the way the world is.\u201d True enough, and yet the world is also changed in the process. Hippie foods may have been absorbed into the mainstream, and to an extent hippie farming too, but the big hippie idea about food \u2014 that our eating has moral, ethical and political implications \u2014 has lost none of its power, and continues to feed a movement.", "title": "How We Got From Twinkies to Tofu", "authors": ["Michael Pollan", "Jonathan Kauffman"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAcross a range of responsibilities, we simply expect much more of boards of directors than ever before,\u201d Mr. Powell said in a speech in August. \u201cThere is no reason to expect that to change.\u201d\n\nThis account is based on interviews with six people involved in or briefed on the negotiations, representing both the bank and the Fed, who were not authorized to speak publicly about regulatory matters.\n\nWells originally got into trouble in 2016 for charging millions of customers for bank accounts they did not want and for auto insurance they did not need. The bank was repeatedly penalized and fined by regulators.\n\nExecutives had convinced themselves last year that they were out of the woods, according to the people familiar with their thinking, who were not authorized to speak publicly about interactions with regulators. But that illusion was shattered in September, when Ms. Yellen said the bank remained under investigation.\n\nIn early January, Wells officials heard from the Fed that the central bank planned to impose stiff new penalties. Executives were furious that the proposed sanctions seemed more draconian than those imposed on banks that nearly cratered the global economy a decade earlier, according to people familiar with the thinking of top bank executives.\n\nThen, on conference calls and face-to-face sessions in Washington, the negotiations began.\n\nOne crucial participant was Wells\u2019s general counsel, C. Allen Parker. His advantage was that he was new to Wells, not part of what one bank adviser called the \u201cancien r\u00e9gime.\u201d He joined last spring after more than two decades at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, the white shoe law firm where he had been the presiding partner.\n\nAnother was Elizabeth A. Duke, a former Fed governor, who became chairwoman of Wells\u2019s board in January, well after the account-opening scandal came to light.", "title": "How Wells Fargo and Federal Reserve Struck Deal to Hold Bank\u2019s Board Accountable", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cShe found me through Lena Dunham\u2019s Instagram,\u201d Ms. Dwyer said, gesturing to Deanna DiCroce, who had arrived for her appointment (a butterfly tattoo) on a recent Saturday. Ms. Dunham\u2019s \u201cGirls\u201d co-star Jemima Kirke, a client who lives in the neighborhood, had recommended the shop.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d been to a bunch of places in the East Village and didn\u2019t leave with the best vibes,\u201d Ms. DiCroce said. \u201cIt\u2019s intimidating.\u201d\n\nMargot Pascal, a leather goods designer, is another Nice Tattoo client. She has two tattoos from earlier experiences at mostly male parlors. \u201cAt some other places I often felt judged because of my tattoo design,\u201d Ms. Pascal said. \u201cI ended up going with an artist who was a nice, shy guy. But the place, the vibe \u2014 no love.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s more, because some tattoos may require disrobing, a woman can feel especially vulnerable with male artists. \u201cEven apart from the question of safety, some women prefer female artists for the same reason they choose female doctors,\u201d Ms. Mifflin said. \u201cThe interaction is intimate.\u201d\n\nRobert Boyle, a founder of Nice Tattoo, said that Nice wasn\u2019t intentionally positioned as an all-female tattoo parlor. \u201cAfter we started to understand the implication of providing an alternative space for female artists, it became a position we felt was culturally important,\u201d he said.", "title": "How Women Are Rethinking the Tattoo Parlor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Lorin Stein, the editor of The Paris Review, informed the magazine\u2019s board that he had been named. After an investigation conducted by the law firm Debevoise & Plimpton, he resigned on Dec. 6. The next week, The New Yorker said it had parted ways with its Washington correspondent, Ryan Lizza. (CNN put Mr. Lizza on leave from his job there as a commentator, reinstating him the next month, after a company investigation \u201cfound no reason\u201d to keep him off the air.)\n\nThe list was still having an impact in late December, when BuzzFeed fired Adrian Carrasquillo, a White House correspondent, and the National Geographic did the same with the photojournalist Patrick Witty (who has also worked for The Times).\n\nMr. Witty, in a written statement, denied the accusations against him, although he acknowledged that he might have acted inappropriately. \u201cI am saddened to think that I in any way have contributed to or reinforced the imbalance of power between men and women in my industry,\u201d he said.\n\nThe rest of those named on the list who lost jobs declined to comment.\n\nSome of the men whose names appeared on the document but did not end up suspended or fired said the list had nonetheless affected their professional and personal lives.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s so na\u00efve to think that just because no one has spoken out, that means that there aren\u2019t any false accusations,\u201d said a man who agreed to discuss the document only if his name was not used, because he did not want to draw further attention to his appearance on the list. \u201cIt just means that the men that have been falsely accused are petrified.\u201d\n\nMs. Donegan said she was not aware of any false accusations and believed that the document\u2019s disclaimer was sufficient in expressing reasonable doubt.\n\nOn the surface, the list did not to raise any legal issues, according to David A. Schulz, a First Amendment lawyer who is a lecturer at Yale Law School and has represented The Times. Ms. Donegan, he said, \u201chas a right to collect information and organize it in a useful way.\u201d Those who contributed to the document would be at risk only if someone named on the list sued for libel, he added.", "title": "How a Crowdsourced List Set Off Months of #MeToo Debate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "For a quick six minutes in the new film \u201cRed Sparrow,\u201d Jennifer Lawrence is a ballerina.\n\nIt\u2019s hard won. Transforming Ms. Lawrence into a credible ballet dancer \u2014 a Bolshoi prima, no less \u2014 required a dance dream team, which came in the form of the talented choreographer Justin Peck; Ms. Lawrence\u2019s handsome partner, the Ukrainian dancer Sergei Polunin; and her dance double, the stellar American Ballet Theater principal Isabella Boylston.\n\nBut first, Ms. Lawrence needed a teacher. Kurt Froman, a former member of New York City Ballet who worked with Natalie Portman and Mila Kunis on \u201cBlack Swan,\u201d may not be on a non-dance fan\u2019s radar, but he was the coach that people in ballet and Hollywood knew could make Ms. Lawrence spring into dancing shape.\n\n\u201cI love feeling like an ambassador to my art form,\u201d Mr. Froman said in an interview. \u201cIn the past when you saw dance misrepresented, you\u2019d get this kind of cringe, because you\u2019d feel like, God, if only someone had suggested something a little more legitimate they could have pulled this off.\u201d\n\n\u201cRed Sparrow,\u201d which opens on Friday, may not be a dance movie, but ballet \u2014 its single-mindedness \u2014 permeates it. In this dark spy thriller, directed by Francis Lawrence and based on the 2013 novel of the same name by Jason Matthews, Ms. Lawrence plays Dominika Egorova, a Russian ballerina who has to retire from the stage \u2014 and here comes a spoiler, which is easier to read about than to watch \u2014 after her partner leaps into the air and crashes onto her leg. It\u2019s a career-ender.", "title": "How a Dance Dream Team Turned Jennifer Lawrence Into a Ballerina", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "The Weinstein Company declined to comment. In announcing its bankruptcy plans on Sunday, the company\u2019s board said in a statement, \u201cWhile we recognize that this is an extremely unfortunate outcome for our employees, our creditors and any victims, the board has no choice.\u201d The studio also made public a sharply worded letter that it sent to Ms. Contreras-Sweet and Mr. Burkle on Sunday that blamed her for failing to \u201ckeep your promises\u201d about interim funding.\n\nIt was in November when Ms. Contreras-Sweet first sent a letter to the board outlining her proposal. \u201cI will be chairwoman of a majority-female board of directors,\u201d she wrote. \u201cWomen will be significant investors in the new company and control its voting stock.\u201d She also proposed creating a fund for victims and establishing a mediation process for reaching settlements.\n\nAfter failing to find other buyers who would keep the studio intact \u2014 Lionsgate, Shamrock Capital Advisors, Killer Content and the Qatari company beIN Media Group were among those considering various pieces \u2014 the board entered into exclusive negotiations with Ms. Contreras-Sweet\u2019s group in late January.\n\nMost of the studio\u2019s all-male board had quit in early October. Those who remained were Mr. Weinstein\u2019s younger brother, Bob Weinstein; Tarak Ben Ammar, a Franco-Tunisian financier and film producer; and Lance Maerov, an executive at the advertising giant WPP Group.\n\nBy Feb. 10, a Saturday, the two sides were finalizing a deal. The Weinstein brothers, who jointly own about 42 percent of the company, would receive no cash from the sale. Other equity holders would also be wiped out. Bob Weinstein, who had been running the studio since the firing of Harvey Weinstein in October, would step down. According to two people briefed on the talks, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss a private process, the Weinstein Company and Ms. Contreras-Sweet\u2019s group were set to formalize the agreement that coming Monday.\n\nThen came a curveball.\n\nIn a phone call on the evening of Feb. 10, two lawyers who work for Eric T. Schneiderman, New York\u2019s attorney general, told Ms. Contreras-Sweet that they had reviewed the proposed deal and wanted to discuss three major concerns, according to the people briefed on the talks. Those were adequate compensation for victims, protections for the studio\u2019s remaining employees and no financial rewards for studio executives who enabled or perpetuated Mr. Weinstein\u2019s misconduct. (Mr. Weinstein has denied ever engaging in \u201cnon-consensual sex.\u201d)", "title": "How a Deal to Sell the Weinstein Company Fell Apart", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "California voters eliminated traditional party primaries in 2010, replacing them with the top-two system at the urging of Arnold Schwarzenegger, then the Republican governor, and other moderates. They argued that a primary open to all voters would lead to political moderation by candidates who, in theory, could not win by appealing only to the base of their party.\n\n\n\nThe voter initiative was vigorously opposed by Democratic and Republican leaders who warned that it would force candidates to invest time and money in debilitating primaries and runoffs and could lead to general elections where a major party would be kept off the ballot.\n\nIt is far from clear whether the top-two system \u2014 which has been adopted in some form by four states so far \u2014 has lived up to its promise of good government reform or created the kind of one-sided general elections that so concerned party leaders. That happened in California in a congressional race in 2012, in which the general election choice was between two Republicans in a district with a Democratic edge, and in last year\u2019s Senate race, in which no Republicans were on the general election ballot.\n\nIndeed, in the middle of this heated battle, it is still a matter of dispute whether the change has made much of a difference at all. Thad Kousser, a professor of political science at the University of California, San Diego, suggested that so far it had not. \u201cWe haven\u2019t seen big shifts in the Legislature,\u201d he said. \u201cIt hasn\u2019t changed California politics radically.\u201d\n\nThe stakes now are particularly high. Mr. Issa\u2019s seat is one of seven congressional seats that Democrats are targeting to flip in California this year. It is one of two where the Republican incumbent is not running again, which otherwise would have probably assured a straight runoff between the sitting Republican and a Democratic challenger. (The other is Representative Ed Royce\u2019s to the east.)\n\nDemocratic leaders are moving to winnow the field, steering contributions to favored candidates, moving to award the state party endorsement to one person and warning candidates who might have embarrassing chapters in their professional or personal lives of the kind of scrutiny and political attacks that come with entering public life.\n\nBut any attempt by the party to interfere is complicated by the strains between establishment Democrats and the more liberal wing of the party, which have been on particular display in this state. Democratic leaders are wary of coming across as old-school bosses stampeding the concerns of grass-roots activists.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMy job is not to tell people they can\u2019t run,\u201d said Eric C. Bauman, the state Democratic leader, who has been trying to trim the field to, ideally, he said, two Democrats. \u201cIt\u2019s not to push people out of races. But to try to help good candidates look to see if they have other options they could run for and make an equally important contribution.\u201d\n\nMr. Bauman said the current circumstances had confirmed what have been his criticisms of the top-two method from the beginning.\n\n\u201cThat denies people an opportunity to vote for a candidate who represents their interests,\u201d Mr. Bauman said. \u201cIt creates that danger that we could end up with so many Democrats that we split the vote so badly that we get aced out of a spot in November.\u201d\n\nGiven California\u2019s status as the leading edge of Democratic efforts to take back the House, the situation is a top concern of national Democrats.\n\n\u201cWe plan on having a Democrat running in both races this November,\u201d said Daniel Sena, the executive director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. He said the committee was hoping this could be accomplished quietly but was prepared to move more aggressively \u2014 such as by steering financial contributions to favored candidates if it looked as if Democrats might be running themselves to defeat.\n\n\u201cWe still reserve the right to get involved,\u201d he said. \u201cRight now we are preserving the right to invoke military options and spend money as we see fit.\u201d\n\nThis is a problem not only for Democrats. There are four Republicans running in Mr. Issa\u2019s district and six in the Royce district. But Republicans have a registration edge in both districts, making it less of a threat for them, officials in both parties said.\n\nWhen the top-two system was first put on the ballot, leaders of both parties opposed it. And in 2016, after two Democrats emerged from a crowded primary to run for the United States Senate seat eventually captured by Kamala D. Harris, a Democrat, one of the losing Republicans, Tom Palzer, a retired city planner, started his own initiative campaign to repeal the system.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhen you go to the ballot box and two people are from one party, you don\u2019t have a choice,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t care if it\u2019s two Republicans, two Libertarians. We need healthy parties, and we need competitive parties in the State of California. I\u2019m a Republican. If the top two were Republican, that wouldn\u2019t be right.\u201d\n\nBut other Republicans, after watching the problems the system has caused Democrats, have reconsidered their position and opposed an effort to persuade the state party to back Mr. Palzer\u2019s effort. They argued to party members that repealing it would \u201crescue Democrats from their brutal and costly infighting.\u201d\n\nJim Brulte, the state Republican chairman, said it was unclear what the party would do if Mr. Palzer\u2019s initiative gathered enough signatures to appear on the ballot.\n\n\u201cWhen the top two was on the ballot, every political party in California opposed it,\u201d he said. \u201cThe party has not taken a position on a repeal and will not take a position on it unless there\u2019s an actual initiative.\u201d\n\nChristian Grose, a professor of political science at the University of Southern California, who is writing a book on the system, said that by his count, there had been 159 congressional votes in California since the system was put in place, and the outcome that party leaders had feared happened in only one congressional race. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t mean it couldn\u2019t happen,\u201d he said. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to overstate it. It seems like empirically we just haven\u2019t seen that happen.\u201d", "title": "How an Abundance of Democratic Candidates Could Help the G.O.P. Hold the House", "authors": ["Adam Nagourney"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Last year, Lucy Dacus almost crumbled under the staggering load of anticipation.\n\nA rising singer and songwriter with a new record deal and an intensifying air of next-big-thing-ness, Ms. Dacus was forced to weather real life \u2014 including health issues, mounting personal responsibilities and the ambient stress of political turmoil \u2014 while also focusing on what had all of a sudden become her job. In Nashville last March, she made her second album \u2014 the first with any expectations attached, the one that is supposed to change her life. Then she had to wait for it to come out.\n\nDuring that uneasy downtime, Ms. Dacus thought a lot about what her emotionally raw and intimate new work might mean to people \u2014 the album, \u201cHistorian,\u201d is out March 2 on the storied independent label Matador \u2014 and also about what it meant to make music her career.\n\nAt a time of immense technological and aesthetic change in the industry, Ms. Dacus, based in Richmond, Va., is a timeless model: a guitar-based, album-oriented songwriter with a big, unadulterated voice and tattooable lyrics. But as she prepared to take the ambitious jump from local band to national act, opener to headliner, amateur to professional, Ms. Dacus, 22, was grappling with what it\u2019s like to be a winner of that lottery and a product of the hype machine that keeps modern indie rock humming.\n\n\u201cI never considered a career in music because it was too unattainable,\u201d she said, just a few years removed from dropping out of film school and taking a seasonal job as a photo editor for yearbooks and class pictures. \u201cI just didn\u2019t believe it was possible.\u201d", "title": "How an Indie-Rock Star Is Made in 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s how a linebacker\u2019s death became part of that debate.\n\nA Roadside Tragedy\n\nEdwin Jackson, a linebacker from Atlanta, was the Colts\u2019 third-leading tackler of the 2016 season before sitting out 2017 with an injury. He was riding in an Uber car driven by the crash\u2019s second victim, Jeffrey Monroe, who was from nearby Avon, Ind.\n\nThe car had stopped along the side of Interstate 70 in Indianapolis so Mr. Monroe could get out to help Mr. Jackson, who was sick, when Manuel Orrego-Savala\u2019s Ford truck drove onto the emergency shoulder and plowed into them, the Indiana State Police said. He struck both men, heaving one of their bodies into the highway\u2019s center lane.\n\nWhen a state trooper saw the wreckage on the side of the road shortly after, he headed toward the crash, hitting the man lying in the middle of the highway in the process, the police said. (The police did not say which man the trooper struck.)\n\nMr. Monroe, 54, and Mr. Jackson, 26, were pronounced dead at the scene. Mr. Orrego-Savala was arrested as he tried to flee on foot.\n\nThe state police said that Mr. Orrego-Savala was living in the United States illegally, having been deported to Guatemala twice before. He had been convicted of driving under the influence in California in 2005, and his record also showed \u201cmany other\u201d misdemeanor convictions and arrests in Indiana and California, said Nicole Alberico, a spokeswoman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement, the federal immigration agency.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI.C.E. has formally asked the county jail where Mr. Orrego-Savala, who was using the alias Alex Cabrera Gonsales, is being held to continue detaining him for federal immigration agents. But before he is deported again he is likely to be prosecuted locally for causing the fatal crash, and federal prosecutors said on Tuesday that they had charged him with illegally re-entering the country after being deported.\n\nA Growing List\n\nThe Trump administration regularly highlights crimes committed by immigrants, especially those who came here in ways Mr. Trump has vowed to curtail. Last week, Mr. Trump used the biggest stage available \u2014 the State of the Union address \u2014 to warn of the dangers of MS-13, a gang associated with young Central American migrants, drawing criticism that he had, once again, made immigrants out to be little more than criminals.\n\nVideo\n\nBesides a border wall and other measures to discourage illegal immigration, the president wants to curb two forms of legal immigration. He wants to end the diversity visa lottery, which offers people from countries that do not normally send large numbers of immigrants to the United States a chance at a green card, regardless of whether they have special skills or relatives in the United States. The president also wants to restrict family-based immigration, the system that has given millions of visas to relatives of American citizens and permanent residents, in favor of a more merit-based system.\n\nIn January, the administration released a report purporting to show that the vast majority of people convicted of international terrorism-related charges since Sept. 11, 2001, were foreign-born. It took pains to highlight cases in which such people came to the country through the diversity visa lottery or because they were related to an American citizen or legal resident. But parts of the report were misleading, and Democrats and others who support immigration were quick to dismiss it for its political tinge.\n\nLast week, in a news release that began with the words, \u201cOur current immigration system jeopardizes our national security and puts American communities at risk,\u201d the White House listed 15 people accused or convicted of terrorism-related crimes who it said had arrived either through the diversity visa lottery or family ties.\n\nThe list included two others whose immigration records Mr. Trump amplified on Twitter: Akayed Ullah, a Bangladeshi-born immigrant who tried to detonate a pipe bomb in the New York subway in December, and Sayfullo Saipov, an immigrant from Uzbekistan who killed eight people in a bike lane on the West Side of Manhattan in October.\n\nWhat Research Shows\n\nSeveral studies, conducted over many years, have concluded that immigrants are less likely to commit crimes than people born in the United States, and much less likely to be in prison than those born in the United States.\n\nHomeland Security officials have estimated that about 1.9 million noncitizens living in the country, whether legally or illegally, have been convicted of criminal offenses. About 820,000 of those people may be in the country illegally, including about 300,000 with felony convictions, according to the Migration Policy Institute, a research group that has opposed Mr. Trump\u2019s proposals to cut immigration.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nExperts say the evidence does not show that immigrants are more dangerous than native-born Americans. Among men ages 18 to 49, immigrants were one-half to one-fifth as likely to be incarcerated as those born in the United States, according to census data, though that proportion rises significantly when only federal inmates are counted. Yet about one-third of noncitizen federal inmates are serving time only for immigration-related offenses, such as slipping back into the country after being deported.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut for those who support restricting immigration, another question is whether current immigration laws leave the country vulnerable. Opponents of the diversity visa lottery often cite a report the State Department\u2019s inspector general issued in 2003, which concluded that the program could be granting green cards to spies, criminals and terrorists.\n\nAn Emotional Pull\n\nDuring the presidential campaign, Mr. Trump spoke of family members of people killed by unauthorized immigrants, arguing that their relatives would still be alive if immigrants were not allowed to come illegally to the United States in the first place. Mr. Trump made the case of Kathryn Steinle, who was shot to death by an undocumented immigrant in San Francisco in 2015, into a byword for the dangers of unchecked immigration. After the man who shot her, who claimed it was an accident, was acquitted of manslaughter in November, Mr. Trump renewed his call for the wall.\n\nSome of the most vocal family members have continued to press their cause in Washington, where one such group, Advocates for Victims of Illegal Alien Crime, was meeting with several members of Congress on Tuesday. They said they were planning to mention Mr. Jackson\u2019s death in their conversations.\n\nMary Ann Mendoza, the mother of a police officer killed in a drunken-driving crash with an unauthorized immigrant in 2014, said the group was trying to reach Mr. Jackson\u2019s family to offer support.\n\n\u201cWe want to let them know that we are a group of people at AVIAC who have experienced the same sort of loss they have,\u201d she said. \u201cThey can join us in our fight.\u201d\n\nMr. Jackson\u2019s roommate, Chad Bouchez, who said he had been out with Mr. Jackson the night he died, told CBS News that he did not believe Mr. Jackson would have wanted his death politicized.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think Edwin would have judged anyone on where they were from or anything else,\u201d he said.", "title": "How an N.F.L. Player\u2019s Death Turned Into a Political Exhibit", "authors": ["Vivian Yee"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "UPDATE: Air France has announced that the strike has ended.\n\nThousands of Air France passengers all over the world faced disruptions to their itineraries today, following a labor strike involving the carrier\u2019s pilots, cabin crew and ground staff.\n\nAccording to a representative from Air France\u2019s office in Paris, 28 percent of its employees went on strike on today, which forced the airline to cancel 25 percent of its flights scheduled for the day. Long-haul flights are the most affected: the airline plans to operate only 50 percent of those scheduled to depart from Paris. However, Air France will still operate 75 percent of its medium-haul flights to and from Charles de Gaulle Airport and 85 percent of its short-haul flights.\n\n\u201cI know of many Air France passengers who have had to rearrange their itineraries by leaving a day earlier or later or have had to reschedule their trips all together,\u201d said Henry Harteveldt, a travel industry analyst and the founder of Atmosphere Research Group. he said. Mr. Harteveldt also said that Air France is one of the largest European carriers to Africa, and fliers with Air France tickets to and from the continent may find themselves stranded.\n\nTo add confusion to an already aggravating situation, Michael Holtz, the owner of SmartFlyer, a global travel consultancy specializing in airlines, said that Air France has several code share partners such as Delta Air Lines, Korean Air and Aeromexico. This could potentially mean that passengers who have purchased their tickets through those airlines may be scheduled to fly on a plane operated by Air France. \u201cYour ticket could say Delta, but if you\u2019re flying out of Paris or another city where Air France operates, you might actually be scheduled to take an Air France plane and find yourself grounded,\u201d Mr. Holtz said. \u201cConversely, if you bought an Air France ticket, you could be flying on a plane operated by one of its partners and not at all be impacted by the strike.\u201d (Travelers can find a list of Air France\u2019s partner airlines on its site.)", "title": "How the Air France Strike Could Affect Travel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "So the other difference now is sobriety. After some relapses with opiates, Kelley has been clean for eight years, she said, and the partying that dogged other band members has subsided. Seeing Kim \u201cdescend into a kind of pop star abyss of drugs and unreliability at the height of her success was pretty depressing,\u201d Mr. Albini wrote, \u201cand that whole deal could have turned out almost infinitely worse, but she came back from the precipice, built a substantial body of work and is making some of her most stunning music right now in full maturity.\u201d\n\nFor the first time, a melody came to Kim in a dream. She said she woke with \u201ca dude in my head, singing,\u201d sounding like the synthy \u201880s hit \u201cTainted Love.\u201d She lost the synth, and the dude, and it became the title track for \u201cAll Nerve,\u201d which careens from plaintive to forceful over an insistent rhythm section. After the spacey explorations of \u201cMountain Battles,\u201d this album is shorter, punchier. Kim didn\u2019t have a grand explanation for the shift: \u201cThe fact that we\u2019re playing, is where the meaning is,\u201d she said.\n\nBut reuniting post-drugs can also be fraught, said Patty Schemel, the drummer for Hole, who chronicled her own addiction and recovery in a recent memoir, \u201cHit So Hard\u201d (Da Capo Press). \u201cIn my band, getting back into the same room, that old dynamic comes back,\u201d Ms. Schemel said. Musically, too, crutches may remain. \u201cWriting songs, if you\u2019re hitting a wall and you\u2019re not just finding it, getting high kind of helps, in your mind,\u201d she said, \u201cand so you want to fall back into those habits.\u201d\n\nIn a second interview without Mr. Macpherson and Ms. Wiggs, the Deal sisters talked about their old ways. Hearing a song arrangement, \u201cSometimes I think, God, if I could just smoke a nice joint and listen to this, critically, I would be able to identify any inauthentic moments better,\u201d Kelley said. \u201cThen I sigh and think, I don\u2019t know if that\u2019s really true or not. Me wishing for an easier way to do something, doesn\u2019t necessarily make something true.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nKim recalled making music, around 1999, after taking hallucinogenic mushrooms. \u201cI was never a hallucinogen person,\u201d she said, \u201cbut these mushrooms were incredible. And I have a tape of my art that I created and it\u2019s like an hour, 90 minutes, of me going \u2014\u201d She made a low, indistinct moan. Took a breath. Continued low, indistinct moaning.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKelley laughed and said, \u201cSee, if you give that to me, and I smoke a big fat joint \u2014\u201d\n\nKim finished her thought: \u201cYou tell me what the authentic part of it is.\u201d She laughed. It sometimes takes the two of them to piece together one story from their heyday. \u201cOpening the doors of perception,\u201d with drugs, Kim said, \u201cyou can really only open the door once. It doesn\u2019t need to keep getting reopened all the time. That was something that I realized.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe \u201cLast Splash\u201d lineup reunited in 2013, on a 20th anniversary showcase for the album. The last time they\u2019d toured, the Deals would be absent until moments before they were due onstage, Ms. Wiggs said, and would disappear again afterward. \u201cIt was pretty alienating,\u201d she said. (She had enough downtime at Lollapalooza to learn how to six-pin juggle.)\n\nWith sober bandmates, performing \u201cwas so delightful, because they were so present, and they\u2019re delightful people when they\u2019re present,\u201d Ms. Wiggs said. \u201cIt\u2019s super fun to hang out with them.\u201d\n\nOn their tour bus, they joked and marveled at the enthusiasm of their fans. \u201cWe were in D.C. last night,\u201d Mr. Macpherson said. \u201cIt was a theater and nobody sat. I would\u2019ve sat.\u201d\n\nThe women in his band, in unison, pointed out the obvious: \u201cYou were sitting!\u201d\n\nThe Deals and Mr. Macpherson live within a few miles of each other in Dayton, Ohio, their hometown; they get together to watch ballgames, and their state loyalty runs deep: on the bus, Kim wore socks emblazoned with a picture of Johnny Bench, the Cincinnati Reds Hall of Famer. Ms. Wiggs drove west from her home in Brooklyn for rehearsals in Kim\u2019s basement. \u201cAll Nerve\u201d was recorded nearby, in Dayton, Kentucky and at Mr. Albini\u2019s studio in Chicago. (Their tour for it begins in Los Angeles in April.)\n\nEven after all these years, there were revelations in how they did things: Kim\u2019s recording process, \u201cit\u2019s not going to make sense to me,\u201d her sister said. \u201cHer process is her process, and I can either join her, or I can say \u2018no, thank you,\u2019 and split. That was huge for me, to understand all that.\u201d", "title": "How the Breeders Finally Learned to Get Along", "authors": ["Melena Ryzik"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "And some are former residents of the \u201cJungle,\u201d the camp near Calais, France\u2019s main ferry port for travel to Britain, that became a symbol of the global migration crisis in 2015, home to migrants from the Middle East, Africa, Afghanistan and elsewhere.\n\nWhen the French government closed the camp in October 2016, evacuating thousands and offering to resettle them around the country, many made their way to Brussels, another international transit hub. Over the summer, tents and makeshift shelters appeared in Maximilian Park. Migrants who might once have headed for Calais continue to arrive in the city, hoping to journey onward.\n\nMr. Khater certainly does not want to stay in Belgium. \u201cI am afraid here,\u201d he said, \u201cbecause I don\u2019t have an education, I don\u2019t have money, I don\u2019t speak French.\u201d\n\nMost important, he added, \u201cBelgium doesn\u2019t understand the politics of Sudan; if I ask asylum here, Belgium may send me back to Italy immediately, or worse, even to Khartoum.\u201d\n\nEuropean Union law requires migrants to apply for residency or asylum in the first country in the bloc they reach. In the past three years, tens of thousands of Sudanese have crossed the Mediterranean by boat, landing in Italy, Greece or Spain. Most applied for asylum, and only a few hundred have been deported, according to the International Organization for Migration.\n\nMany Sudanese, however, seek to move on, in secret and without papers, to Britain. Often that involves camping for months near bus stops, truck stops, train stations or seaports.\n\nSo what do countries owe such transitory migrants? Belgium\u2019s state secretary for asylum policy and migration, Theo Francken, has argued that the state cannot take responsibility for those who do not claim asylum.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis reasoning is that if Belgium allows a few hundred migrants to reside illegally on its territory, it could attract millions of others, potentially plundering Belgium\u2019s generous social security system.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSeeing unauthorized migration rise in Brussels last summer, the Belgian government ordered a series of heavy-handed raids on informal camps and homeless shelters. Those raids \u2014 along with falling temperatures \u2014 have largely succeeded in breaking up camps in public parks, and received wide popular support.\n\nEven so, hundreds of Belgian families have reacted by inviting migrants into their homes. (Last month, the government proposed police raids on the houses of citizens suspected of sheltering unauthorized migrants.) Medical charities are providing food, clothes and assistance, and volunteers have set up shelters like the one where Mr. Khater sleeps, in a former office building. The total cost of sheltering one migrant is about 10 euros per night, organizers estimate.\n\nThere have been several demonstrations against the government policies, and about 3,000 people formed a human chain around migrants at the Gare du Nord last month to prevent a police raid.\n\nThe crackdown has also exposed Belgium to the possibility of rebuke on human rights grounds.\n\nIn September, the government invited Sudanese officials to help identify and expel people in the country illegally who did not want to apply for asylum. Ten Sudanese were subsequently sent to Khartoum, and accounts quickly surfaced that at least three had been abused upon their return.\n\nThe Belgian government ordered an investigation of the allegations. It concluded earlier this month that Brussels had not done enough to assess the risks faced by those deported, and warned that migrants who had not applied for asylum still had the right to be protected from torture.\n\nThe report said it was impossible to establish whether the abuses had taken place.\n\nAt the Gare du Nord, Mr. Khater and several fellow travelers showed wounds and scars that they said had been inflicted by the Belgian police. One had a dislocated thumb, another a fresh cut across his jaw, yet another a stitched eyebrow. Several had open wounds. All said they knew Sudanese men who had recently been deported to Khartoum and then dropped out of contact.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWhy aren\u2019t the police kind to us?\u201d Mr. Khater asked. \u201cI am running for my life. I did do nothing wrong. I don\u2019t understand the politics here.\u201d\n\nMr. Kassou, the shelter organizer, agreed that \u201ccertain officers in certain towns, not all police\u201d could be \u201cpretty violent with migrants.\u201d \u201cWe very regularly have people who enter with wounds, even bites from police dogs,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSarah Frederickx, a spokeswoman for the Belgian police, said that officers treated transitory migrants in \u201ca very empathic and humane way.\u201d That being said, she added, \u201cit is possible that during certain operations, for instance when people fiercely resist police actions, officers use force, but in proportion.\u201d\n\nMany aspects of what is happening are familiar, according to Johan Leman, an emeritus professor of anthropology at the Catholic University of Leuven who is an expert on Belgian migration policy and has worked with migrants in Brussels for decades. \u201cIrregular migration from Africa to Europe isn\u2019t new,\u201d he said. Tough return policies have existed in Europe since the 1980s, and the continent experienced a refugee crisis in the 1990s after the breakup of Yugoslavia.\n\n\u201cWhat is new,\u201d he said, \u201cand what I have never seen before in Europe to this extent, is, first of all, that ministers are pounding their chests, saying, \u2018Look at me, how many people I have deported now.\u2019 And secondly, that people are being deported back to a country of which we manifestly know that the government is violating human rights \u2014 I am thinking of Sudan here.\u201d\n\nSudan\u2019s president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, is wanted by the International Criminal Court for trial on charges of war crimes and genocide.\n\nWhen police officers arrested several Sudanese migrants, including three minors, around the Gare du Nord last year, Mr. Francken, the state secretary for asylum policy, described the operation on Facebook as a \u201ccleanup.\u201d After a public outcry condemning the remark as xenophobic, he offered his apologies to the prime minister, who did not accept them.", "title": "How the E.U.\u2019s Migrant Crisis Reached the Streets of Brussels", "authors": ["Milan Schreuer"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019re into the analytics as much as he is,\u201d defensive back Jaylen Watkins said.\n\nThe Eagles have empowered Pederson to make decisions rooted in instinct or math, or both. They understand that what may seem a foolish move in the short term may enhance their chances of winning \u2014 as that fourth-down call against the Giants did. In a call that was likely to fail, Pederson identified that the upside of going for it outweighed the downside of failing.\n\n\u201cHe can do whatever he chooses to do, but when you have the resource of data, why not?\u201d the Eagles\u2019 owner, Jeffrey Lurie, said Monday night at the Super Bowl\u2019s opening festivities in St. Paul. \u201cIt\u2019s kind of a no-brainer.\u201d\n\nThat is also how Frigo and his colleagues at EdjSports feel about using quantitative analysis in the N.F.L., which has yet to fully adopt it. EdjSports would not divulge how long it has worked with the Eagles or how many other teams are clients, though the logos adorning the walls of its office \u2014 of the Lions, Saints and Steelers, among others \u2014 offer a hint. Contractual obligations prevented EdjSports from sharing data that could compromise its relationship with the Eagles, but Frigo said many of Philadelphia\u2019s decisions have aligned with EdjSports\u2019s recommendations.\n\nThose recommendations derive from a model drawing on years of play-by-play data, churning it through hundreds of thousands of simulations \u2014 sometimes more \u2014 to determine the decision that most boosts a team\u2019s likelihood of winning, a metric EdjSports calls GWC, for Game Winning Chance. Because the model cares only about producing the most wins on average, it tends to favor unorthodox moves.\n\nLooking at a chart, Sean O\u2019Leary, one of EdjAnalytics\u2019s founders, noted how it\u2019s mathematically defensible for a team on its first possession of overtime to go for it on fourth-and-1 at its own 10-yard line; not that a coach, facing public pressure to adhere to football norms, ever would.\n\nBut fourth downs are embedded with opportunity for those keen to exploit it. Frigo said that on fourth down alone, teams on average give up anywhere from two-thirds to three-quarters of a win over a season on what Edj classifies as high-confidence mistakes \u2014 that is, decisions that EdjSports\u2019s model has deemed with certainty to be an error. The worst offenders might lose as much as a game and a half.\n\nUsing the Patriots, who are not an EdjSports client, as an example, Frigo cued up on a screen one of the company\u2019s postgame reports, which allow a team to evaluate its decision-making. The report of New England\u2019s A.F.C. championship victory against Jacksonville revealed that Bill Belichick, perhaps the best coach in history, committed four of those high-confidence errors when he elected to punt instead of going for it. To Frigo, those mistakes confirmed coaches\u2019 susceptibility to conservative thinking from a purely game theory standpoint.", "title": "How the Eagles Followed the Numbers to the Super Bowl", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201dIf they had overturned that I don\u2019t know what would have happened to the city of Philadelphia,\u201d he said with a smile.\n\nPhiladelphia\u2019s defense, which relied on superb play by its line all season, spent most of the game generating very little pass-rush, but when the game was on the line Graham burst through for the sack, and Derek Barnett recovered the ball for a turnover that essentially decided the game.\n\n\u2014\n\nDo you want exclusive sports news, highlights and analysis from a rotating cast of New York Times journalists delivered to your inbox once a week? Click here to receive our weekly Sports newsletter.\n\n\u2014\n\nOn one final drive, Brady drove his team 40 yards, but it was too little too late, and he lost in a Super Bowl for just the third time in eight tries.\n\nThe effort put forth by Foles in the last two games will certainly raise questions as to his status for next season, as he is currently expected to go back to being a backup to Carson Wentz. While the Eagles will assuredly want to stick with Wentz, Foles may seek a trade so he can start somewhere else, though he said all week that he had no plans to demand such a move.\n\nHere\u2019s how the Philadelphia Eagles won their first championship:\n\nPhoto\n\nEagles settle for a field goal on first drive.\n\nIt was like watching a replay of the N.F.C. championship game, with Nick Foles repeatedly succeeding on third down and simply marching down the field into the red zone. A few attempts into the end zone fell incomplete, but Jake Elliott came out and his 25-yard attempt sailed through the uprights to give the Eagles an early 3-0 lead.\n\nAfter a brief delay caused by the lights being too dim for kickoff, Stephen Gostkowski kicked off to Corey Clement who took the ball to the Philadelphia 26-yard line. A pair of quick completions from Nick Foles to Nelson Agholor picked up a combined 6 yards and on third down he rolled out to his left before completing a 17-yard pass to Alshon Jeffery that gave the Eagles a first down.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA run by LeGarrette Blount went nowhere, with the big running back knocked backward for a 1-yard loss, and a Foles pass to Torrey Smith fell incomplete, setting up another third down, which Foles, after waiting for something to develop, converted with a 15-yard pass to Smith.\n\nFoles found his favorite target, Zach Ertz, for a 7-yard gain then Jay Ajayi had a pair of short runs, the first of which picked up a first down. Foles sold a nice pump fake and then hit Clement for a 16-yard catch-and-run that put Philadelphia on New England\u2019s 5-yard line.\n\nBlount went up the middle to the 2-yard line, but a false start penalty by Ertz moved the ball back to the 7. Foles overthrew Agholor in the end zone, setting up a third-and-7, and an attempt to Jeffery also fell incomplete, setting up Elliott for the short field goal.\n\nDrape: Foles to Jeffery for the first 3rd down conversion showed a couple of things: Coach Doug Pederson trusts him, and Foles can extend plays with his legs. Then, he gets 3rd-and-11 and throws an even better pass to Torrey Smith. The Eagles did everything but get 7 on that drive. Elliott draws first blood, 3-0 Eagles. All in all, Foles looks sharp.", "title": "How the Eagles Won Their First Super Bowl Title, Drive by Drive", "authors": ["Benjamin Hoffman", "Joe Drape"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "For decades, the N.R.A. has used its sway in Washington to preserve the A.T.F. in its limited capacity. It has aggressively lobbied against nominated directors and pushed Congress to enact restrictions on how the bureau spends money to curtail its ability to regulate firearms and track gun crimes. One funding provision, for example, forbids the A.T.F. from using electronic databases to trace guns to owners. Instead, the agency relies on a warehouse full of paper records.\n\nIt is beneficial to the N.R.A. to have a smaller agency like the A.T.F. in charge of gun regulation, one senior bureau official acknowledged, rather than a larger, more politically powerful agency like the F.B.I. that can more effectively demand additional resources from Capitol Hill.\n\nThe gun lobby is one of the most potent political forces in Washington, doling out tens of millions of dollars each election cycle to lawmakers and campaigns to steer the political discourse on gun regulation. The N.R.A. reported spending the most amount of money in its history in 2016 working to support Mr. Trump and the Republican Party, and its backing has come under renewed scrutiny in the gun debate that has taken shape in the days since the shooting in Parkland, Fla.\n\nThe president, in turn, has courted gun advocates, vowing to defend firearm owners and the N.R.A. In a tweet on Thursday morning, Mr. Trump called the organization \u201cGreat People and Great American Patriots.\u201d\n\nThe A.T.F. rose to prominence in the Prohibition era with its takedown of Al Capone. In the decades since, its mission has been tailored toward gun violence and trafficking. More recently, the bureau has had its share of troubling episodes. It was infamously involved in the 1993 siege at a Branch Davidian compound in Texas in which 75 peopled were killed, and during the \u201cFast and Furious\u201d scandal two decades later, the bureau lost guns across the Mexican border, which were later recovered at crime scenes. Agents also used a multimillion-dollar slush fund meant to pay informants to instead pad their own pockets, The New York Times revealed last year.\n\nPhoto\n\nUnder President Barack Obama, the White House considered eliminating the A.T.F. The proposal, a direct affront to the N.R.A., would have transferred all its law enforcement authorities to the F.B.I., a former senior Obama administration official said. The plan was largely abandoned, however, after the 2012 school shooting in Newtown, Conn.\n\nThe N.R.A. opposed the nomination of Andrew Travers, whom Mr. Obama selected to lead the agency in 2010. Mr. Travers was never confirmed. The N.R.A. did not take a position on the agency\u2019s last and only director confirmed by the Senate, B. Todd Jones, who led the A.T.F. from 2011 to 2015.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe support enforcement of the laws on the books and A.T.F. efforts to apprehend and prosecute violent criminals,\u201d said Jennifer Baker, a spokeswoman for the N.R.A. \u201cWe have and will continue to oppose political appointees looking to enact an anti-gun agenda through the regulatory process making it more difficult for law abiding citizens to exercise their constitutional rights while criminals continue to break the law.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAn official at the Justice Department said the administration was interviewing potential A.T.F. directors but did not know when that might result in a nomination. The White House has confidence in the acting director, Thomas E. Brandon, the official said, who was not authorized to speak publicly about the matter.\n\nMr. Brandon, who has served in that capacity since 2015, is thought of highly among the A.T.F. work force, agents said. But even his most ardent supporters acknowledge that a Senate-confirmed director, handpicked by the president, would be better positioned to be an advocate for the agency.\n\nThere is no indication that Mr. Brandon will be nominated to permanently lead the bureau.\n\n\u201cA.T.F. works diligently with the resources that we have,\u201d said a bureau spokesman, Joshua Jackson. \u201cAnd like any agency, we could always use additional resources.\u201d\n\nThe A.T.F.\u2019s own 52-page budget proposal for the current fiscal year describes an agency on the cusp of a resource crisis. That document is separate from the White House budget proposed last week, which lays out the administration\u2019s broader priorities for the fiscal year that begins in October.\n\nIn describing its own shortages, the A.T.F. says it remains unable to fulfill even basic regulatory responsibilities, including inspections of firearms dealers \u2014 something the bureau says presents a \u201csignificant risk to public safety.\u201d\n\nThe A.T.F. is also bracing for the departure of nearly a fifth of its roughly 2,500 special agents. Of them, 499 are at least 50 years old, according to the budget proposal, and face mandatory retirement at 57.\n\nLast year, 141 agents retired from the A.T.F., Mr. Jackson said, and only 117 were hired. An additional 24 agents left the bureau for other reasons.\n\nStill, as ranks thin, the A.T.F. is being tasked to lead some of the Trump administration\u2019s most lauded violent crime initiatives. A team of agents was sent to Chicago over the summer to help the city combat gun violence, and the bureau is leading crackdowns on the MS-13 criminal gang, which Mr. Trump has vowed to \u201ceradicate.\u201d", "title": "How the N.R.A. Keeps Federal Gun Regulators in Check", "authors": ["Ali Watkins"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "In \u201cSelf-Made Man,\u201d a new book published by the Cato Institute, the lawyer Timothy Sandefur argues that Douglass\u2019s essential legacy lies in his advocacy of liberty, individualism and private property and free enterprise. The radical abolitionist who risked all to use words and politics to free an entire people from slavery was, to Mr. Sandefur, only \u201ca radical for individualism\u201d and never concerned with \u201cthe interests of the collective.\u201d\n\nTo believe that, one has to ignore most of Douglass\u2019s career, especially his life as an abolitionist, his ferocious attacks on the poison of racism and his brilliant analysis of how lynching emerged from the evils of white supremacy. Douglass believed that freedom was safe only within the state and under law.\n\nDouglass did preach self-reliance for his fellow blacks: He argued that the freed slaves should be given their rights, protected and then \u201clet alone.\u201d But he never employed that \u201clet alone\u201d dictum without also demanding \u201cfair play,\u201d and security against terror and discrimination. Conservatives have cherry-picked his words to advance their narrow visions of libertarianism.\n\nDouglass, the greatest American abolitionist, also happened to be a Republican in a century when that party stood for using government to free people. The right\u2019s effort to get right with Douglass is born of sincere beliefs but also shows a movement\u2019s need for a famous black voice. Were he alive, Douglass would most likely laugh, and warmly welcome the debate.\n\nAt the unveiling ceremony for the statue of Douglass in the United States Capitol in 2013, congressional Republicans proudly wore large buttons that read, \u201cFrederick Douglass Was a Republican.\u201d Douglass\u2019s descendants who were there, as well as scholars like me with, shall we say, different training, smiled and endured.\n\nWhose Douglass? Which Douglass? Dead, allegedly alive or in his literary work? These are modern questions rife with meaning. But we cannot contain Douglass within such circumscribed limits.\n\nAt the height of the national debate over slavery in 1857 he wrote: \u201cPower concedes nothing without a demand. It never did and it never will. Find out just what any people will quietly submit to and you have found out the exact measure of injustice and wrong which will be imposed upon them,\u201d and added, \u201cThe limits of tyrants are prescribed by the endurance of those whom they oppress.\u201d Douglass\u2019s understanding of power could never confine him to advocacy of individualism alone.", "title": "Opinion | How the Right Co-Opts Frederick Douglass", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "That description is close to the kind of locomotion that Dr. Jayne and his graduate student, Steven J. Newman, analyzed in a recent issue of the Journal of Experimental Biology.\n\nUnlike most snake forms of movement, this one involves moving in a straight line, with no bending. It is not swift, as Kaa\u2019s progress was in Kipling\u2019s \u201cJungle Book,\u201d but it is eerily liquid. Slyly, slowly, the snake flows without bending.\n\nThe motion had not escaped students of snakes. A scientist named Hans Lissmann described it about 70 years ago and produced a hypothesis about what muscles the snakes used to propel themselves, and how those muscles acted.\n\nLissmann, Dr. Jayne said, \u201cdid some classic work\u201d on \u201crectilinear locomotion,\u201d (scientific language that suggests why the world needs poets).\n\nDr. Jayne said, \u201cWe had an extremely good idea of all of the movements,\u201d and Lissmann hypothesized how the muscles might work. \u201cBut what we were really lacking were any direct observations of how the muscles work,\u201d Dr. Jayne said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTo do those observations, Mr. Newman inserted fine wire electrodes in the snakes\u2019 muscles to record their activity, something like the way sensors record heart activity in an electrocardiogram.\n\nWhat the scientists found was that Lissmann was mostly right, but not exactly so. Here\u2019s how it works:\n\nAs the snake is moving forward, a muscle in its belly skin shortens the skin and stays tensed. Then a muscle running forward from the tip of one rib to the skin tenses to pull the skeleton and body forward over the skin.\n\nAnother muscle that runs toward the tail from the middle of a rib to the skin pulls the skin forward.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLissmann did not expect the skin muscle to stay tensed, and he thought the skin muscles did the work of pulling the body forward, whereas it is the muscle running from the tip of a rib to the skin.\n\nWhy do the details matter? Scientists and poets alike want to get things right, whether it\u2019s a matter of the precise word or the electrical activity of the muscle.\n\nAnd in terms of practicality, the makers of soft, snakelike robots meant to find their way through nooks and crannies without troublesome legs to snag on obstacles, might find the exact nature of the motion useful, as snakes have for millenniums.\n\nInterestingly, Dr. Jayne said, the slow, liquid crawl he and Mr. Newman studied seems to be used more by the heavier snakes \u2014 boas and pythons.\n\nLike Kaa.", "title": "How the Snake Pours Its Way Across the Ground", "authors": ["James Gorman"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The scene was both sickeningly familiar and shockingly new \u2014 seven bodies, riddled with bullets, sprawled on the floor of a garage on Chicago\u2019s North Side. As Americans today grow increasingly numb to persistent mass shootings, such a crime now might not even make the front pages. But on Feb. 14, 1929, Chicagoans were appalled enough to give it an enduring name \u2014 \u201cthe St. Valentine\u2019s Day Massacre\u201d \u2014 and it remains a powerful example of how to check gun violence with proactive reform.\n\nNinety years ago, Americans felt as helpless to stop the slaughter as many do today. Chicagoans had seen gang killings before, in the bootleg battles that brought Al Capone to power, and they knew the drill. The police would issue indignant statements and roust a few gangsters, but no one would be arrested, much less prosecuted or convicted. Soon enough, just like today, it would all happen again.\n\nYet the scale of this crime prompted a different response. Newspapers nationwide printed photos of the carnage, forcing Americans to consider the costs of Prohibition. Many had seen Capone, whose organization was behind the killing, as a folk hero \u2014 a self-made millionaire, giving the people what they wanted. But he soon picked up a new and enduring nickname: \u201cPublic Enemy No. 1.\u201d\n\nStill, the causes of the massacre went beyond a single mobster. Other cities had speakeasies and bootleggers without open warfare. What made Chicago different were the longstanding alliances between government and gangsters. The massacre, observed The Chicago Tribune, was \u201cthe culmination of the use of criminals by politicians and of politicians by criminals. This mutuality of service and profit made twins of politics and crime.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | How the St. Valentine\u2019s Day Massacre Changed Gun Laws", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "The Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show will be conducted for the 142nd time beginning Monday, but its origins and how it received its name are not widely known.\n\nThe competition, which is billed as the World\u2019s Greatest Dog Show, has cultivated a strong following since it opened in 1877 in New York at Gilmore\u2019s Garden, which later became known as Madison Square Garden. At its inception, the show had over 1,200 dogs entered, and the judges decided on a winner over a three- or four-day period.\n\nLast year, the show had close to 3,000 dogs from all 50 states entered in the competition. The show is now judged over two days.\n\nThe show and its name sprang from a hotel that has now been gone for more than a century.\n\nIn the 1870s, a group of men met regularly at the Westminster Hotel near Union Square, according to historical accounts. They had such an affinity for the hotel and its bar, as well as for dogs, that they decided to name the show after it.", "title": "How the Westminster Dog Show Got Its Name", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cNo Way to Measure Students,\u201d by Molly Worthen (Sunday Review, Feb. 23), criticizing \u201ca bureaucratic behemoth known as learning outcomes assessment\u201d:\n\nLearning assessment in higher education is simply an effort to document that students have indeed learned something. More work for faculty? You bet. It\u2019s a lot harder than giving out the As, Bs and Cs that have been the traditional measure of student success. But it\u2019s also far more meaningful for students, parents, policymakers and employers.\n\nAs higher education costs climb and student borrowing increases, it should come as no surprise that colleges and universities are under more pressure to demonstrate what students have gained. Thanks to the work of many dedicated faculty members and accreditors, colleges and universities are providing a richer and more complete picture of student learning than in the past. This is important and worthwhile.\n\nSure, we can always do better. But the demand that colleges assess learning will not slacken. One hopes faculty members will lend a hand to these efforts.\n\nTED MITCHELL, WASHINGTON\n\nThe writer is president of the American Council on Education.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nKudos to Molly Worthen. As a professor in the University of California system, I can attest to the accuracy of her report. Over the past 10 years precious state resources have been transferred from classroom instruction to administration. Class size is growing, and more students are unable to take the courses they need to graduate on time while well-paid \u201cassessment\u201d experts are hired to do work that is often misguided and useless.", "title": "Opinion | How to Assess What Students Have Learned", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "New York Fashion Week\n\nShow sites are smaller, we hear, but even if you didn\u2019t make the guest list this season, there are plenty of ways to take part in the festivities surrounding New York Fashion Week.\n\nOn Thursday, Rebecca Taylor will collaborate with Tilt Brush by Google, a cool VR tool that allows users to \u201cpaint\u201d in a 3-D space, on an immersive installation that will take over her entire meatpacking district store.
