At 230 Elizabeth Street.", "title": "How to Be Part of Fashion Week Without the Invite", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "After the last down is played and a new Super Bowl champion hoists the Lombardi Trophy on Sunday, the focus of the National Football League will turn to another prize: the sale of one of its 32 teams. The winning bidder will pay a huge sum for a property that is as close to a guarantee of fame and fortune as there can be.\n\nJerry Richardson, a former professional football player who made his fortune in the food service business, is putting the Carolina Panthers up for sale after the season ends. He has owned the team since 1993, when the N.F.L. added it to the league. But last year, allegations of sexual and racial harassment against him surfaced, and amid a team investigation, Mr. Richardson announced that he would sell the team.\n\nThe next owner of the Panthers will have to be incredibly wealthy. N.F.L. ownership rules say that only individuals can buy a team \u2014 so no corporate partnerships or funds \u2014 and that the general partner has to put up at least 30 percent of the purchase price, which runs into the hundreds of millions of dollars. The buyer is also limited in the amount that can be borrowed.", "title": "How to Bid for the N.F.L.\u2019s Biggest Prize: Team Ownership", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Create speed bumps\n\nIt\u2019s amazing how often we pick up our phones \u201cjust to check\u201d then look up 20 minutes later wondering where the time has gone. I call these \u201czombie checks,\u201d and they\u2019re nearly guaranteed to be unsatisfying or make you feel like you\u2019re wasting your life.\n\nOne solution is to create \u201cspeed bumps\u201d: small obstacles that force you to slow down and make sure that when you do check your phone, it\u2019s the result of a conscious choice. Put a rubber band around your phone as a physical reminder to pause, or set a lock screen image that asks you to confirm that you really want to proceed.\n\nPay attention to your body\n\nWhen you notice that you\u2019re in the midst of a phone spiral, ask yourself: What\u2019s your posture like? How\u2019s your breathing? Is whatever you\u2019re doing on your phone making you feel good? Do you want to be using it right now? The more tuned in you are to your own experiences in the moment, the easier it will be to change your behavior.\n\nPractice trial separations\n\nLeave your phone at home while you go for a walk. Stare out of a window during your commute instead of checking your email. At first, you may be surprised by how powerfully you crave your phone. Pay attention to your craving. What does it feel like in your body? What\u2019s happening in your mind? Keep observing it, and eventually, you may find that it fades away on its own.\n\nUse technology to protect yourself from technology\n\nTime-tracking apps like Moment, Quality Time and (OFFTIME) will measure how much time you\u2019re spending on your screen. (Be prepared to be horrified.) Freedom and Flipd let you block your access to problematic apps and websites when you want to take a break (Flip\u2019d also lets you create friendly challenges with other people to see who can spend the most time offline.) Apple now has a \u201cDo Not Disturb While Driving\u201d mode that sends customizable automated text message responses so that you can step away from your phone without worrying that you\u2019ll leave someone hanging. Lilspace does the same for Android, and displays a timer on your lock screen showing you how much time you\u2019ve managed to stay unplugged (a strangely motivating feature).\n\nUse the sight of other people on their phones as a reminder of your own intentions\n\nRight now, the sight of someone else pulling out his or her phone on the elevator probably makes you want to check yours as well. But with practice, you can transform this into a cue for a new, healthier habit. When I see other people reach for their phones, I try to use it as a cue to take a deep breath and relax. (I\u2019m successful most of the time.)\n\nGet existential about it\n\nIf all else fails, consider your own mortality. How many people on their deathbeds do you think are going to say, \u201cI wish I\u2019d spent more time on Facebook\u201d? Keep asking yourself the same question, again and again and again: This is your life. How much of it do you want to spend on your phone?", "title": "How to Break Up With Your Phone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "To join Global Entry you must complete a comprehensive online form about your travel history, have an in-person interview with a customs official, be fingerprinted, and pay a $100 application fee (good for five years). It\u2019s the most seamless way to move through customs: You simply stop at an automated passport control kiosk, identify yourself with your passport and finger biometrics, and tap a screen to answer a few questions. (Note: Global Entry is not strictly for United States citizens, nationals and lawful permanent residents; passport holders from Argentina, Colombia, Germany, India, Mexico, the Netherlands, Panama, the Republic of Korea, Singapore, Switzerland, Taiwan and Britain may also apply.) But a number of travelers (Americans and Canadian visitors) have been discovering a free program called Mobile Passport Control \u2014 the use of which has increased threefold from fiscal year 2016 to 2017.\n\nWhile not necessarily as quick as Global Entry, Mobile Passport Control still saves users the time and hassle of filling out a paper declaration form. And it doesn\u2019t require any sort of advance approval or interview. Rather, it works through a free Customs and Border Protection app for iOS and Android called Mobile Passport and can be used at about 25 airports (in cities that include New York, Houston and Chicago), as well as at Port Everglades in Fort Lauderdale, Fl a.\n\nTo use the Mobile Passport app, users create a profile by adding their passport information (along with the passport information for each family member traveling with them). Then, when their flight lands at a participating airport, they follow signs to a designated fast Mobile Passport Control lane, open the app and answer five questions about their trip (on behalf of their entire family), submit it, and then receive a receipt with an encrypted bar code. When they reach the Customs and Border Protection officer in their lane, they show their passport, scan the bar code on the receipt, and go on their way.\n\nWhile the Mobile Passport app is not as comprehensive or ubiquitous as Global Entry (Global Entry is at more than 50 airports, while Mobile Passport is at fewer than half that), Customs and Border Protection says they are complementary programs. As veteran Global Entry members know, at certain times of the day and at particular airports there can be a line for the kiosks. Or a kiosk may not be working, slowing up an ordinarily smooth process. For that reason, Customs and Border Protection suggests having both programs so that whenever possible, you have the option of choosing the shorter line.\n\n(For those interested in enrolling in Global Entry, some credit cards offer statement credits to customers who charge the fee to their cards, like Chase Sapphire Reserve, Citi Prestige and certain American Express cards.)", "title": "How to Bypass Airport Lines With the Tips of Your Fingers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMany nursing home residents are unaware of their rights. So when these individuals face the threat of eviction, legal advocates say, many of them do not even realize they have the right to challenge their discharge.\n\nBelow is a list of several of those rights under federal law along with tips from lawyers and advocates who work on behalf of nursing home residents:\n\n\u25a0 Before a nursing home discharges or transfers a patient who wants to stay in the home, it must send a written discharge notice to the resident, the resident\u2019s designated representative and the state\u2019s long-term-care ombudsman.\n\nNotices are supposed to be issued 30 days before the planned discharge (and should provide contact information for the local ombudsman, or advocate, who can provide assistance).\n\n\u25a0 A person facing eviction from a nursing home can appeal the discharge and demand a hearing, and the home cannot discharge or transfer the person while the appeal is pending.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u25a0 The nursing home cannot make residents leave if they are waiting to get Medicaid.\n\n\u25a0 If a nursing home contends that it cannot meet a patient\u2019s needs, it must document the specific needs that cannot be met and explain how it tried to meet them. This requirement is meant to prevent nursing homes from arbitrarily discharging residents they should be able to care for.", "title": "How to Challenge a Nursing Home Eviction Notice, and Other Tips", "authors": ["Tara Siegel Bernard", "Robert Pear"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Just Chill\n\nLow-key head-to-toe red? She shared some of her best tips for a wallet-friendly trip to Vegas that doesn\u2019t skimp on luxury.\n\nTiming Matters\n\nFirst, avoid visiting Las Vegas during citywide conventions. Hotel occupancy is higher, which limits your chances of booking a great room, as are nightly rates for hotel rooms all over the city. Las Vegas Tourism\u2019s official site has a calendar of upcoming conventions you should keep an eye on.\n\nIn general, hotel rates are the lowest in July and August because the city\u2019s hot weather keeps the crowds away. \u201cIf you love hanging out by the pool, these are great months to visit because many of the resorts have fantastic pools,\u201d Ms. Daitch said. He envisioned a menu that was nostalgic \u2014 \u201cThe best feedback to hear is \u2018I grew up eating this,\u2019\u201d he said \u2014 but not hidebound by tradition, and his partners agreed.\n\n\u201cI think there\u2019s a third culture,\u201d Mr. Chen said, that arises when children are raised in a culture different from their parents\u2019. \u201cWe see it as more of a remix, rather than, \u2018Hey, this is authentic.\u2019 It gives you a license to create.\u201d\n\nBy August, the three men had made it through the first round of pitches to the museum. Not according to Annette Lang, a New York City-based certified personal trainer. \u201cYou can actually maintain and even improve your fitness level when you\u2019re on the road,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd, you don\u2019t have to bother with a gym to do it.\u201d\n\nMs. Lang naturally has plenty of tips on how to get some exercise while you travel. Here are some of the ones she offers her clients when they tell her they\u2019re leaving town.\n\nExperience Your Environment Through Activity\n\nThink about how you can include some activity on each day of your getaway, Ms. Lang said. If you\u2019re in an urban destination that has a bike share program, for example, consider renting a bike for an hour or two, and take a ride along a waterfront or other scenic part of town.\n\nWhen visiting sites with scenic viewpoints at the top, such as on the observation deck of a building or the roof of a cathedral, climb the stairs to the top, if that\u2019s an option. Even a few minutes of stair climbing will boost your heart rate, and you\u2019ll be rewarded by great views at the end of your journey.", "title": "How to Fit in Exercise While You Travel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "The idea that a league like the N.H.L. gets to decide what \u201cits\u201d players do is hardly an immutable law of nature. Soccer is even more commercial and lucrative than hockey, yet its rules work in the opposite way: Teams are obliged, by dictate of FIFA, the International Federation of Association Football, to cough up their stars when they\u2019re summoned by a national team for a tournament. The leagues may not like it, but there is no danger of a World Cup without players like Neymar and Lionel Messi.\n\nClearly, soccer has figured out the better system. The players want to play; the fans want to watch; there is nothing as uplifting and inspiring as international competition between the best of the best. Since 1998, when professional players were admitted, Olympic hockey has consistently been spectacular and exhilarating.\n\nBut the N.H.L. sees itself as a business first and foremost, and it cannot see any profit in Olympic hockey. Moreover, the league has a competing interest: It helps run another international tournament, the World Cup of Hockey, which has so far failed to achieve anything near the popularity of Olympic hockey. Weaker Olympic hockey serves the N.H.L.\u2019s purposes, even if it is bad for everyone else.\n\nWhat might be done? There are a few possible solutions. Despite the notion that the N.H.L. \u201cowns\u201d its players, contracts of involuntary servitude remain illegal in the United States and Canada, and the star players have considerable individual bargaining power. Players like Crosby and Ovechkin should negotiate for a provision in their contracts (or at least reach an informal understanding) that clarifies that the player, when requested by his national Olympic team, would be \u201cloaned\u201d to the team if he wanted to be. Ultimately, the right to play at the Olympics could become part of the collective agreement between league and players.\n\nAnother possible solution is a \u201cnational duty\u201d rule like the one that FIFA has, which the Canadian Parliament, legislatures in hockey-loving states like Minnesota and New York and perhaps even the United States Congress would enact. Such a law would require that notwithstanding any contract, athletes be excused from their jobs when requested by a national team. This would resemble existing laws that require employers to give members of the military reserves leave for their duties.\n\nOnce upon a time, the problem with Olympic hockey was its ban on professional athletes, a rule that, though motivated by a noble ideal of amateurism, kept out North America\u2019s best players and thus made the Soviet teams dominant. Matters have come full circle, for it is now not suspicion of profit that hurts Olympic hockey, but too much attention to it.", "title": "Opinion | How to Fix Olympic Ice Hockey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMake sure the person whom you think wronged you is the person who wronged you,\u201d says Charles L. Griswold, a philosophy professor at Boston University. Forgiveness means abandoning anger, and that can be long, hard work \u2014 possibly a lifetime\u2019s worth. So before you embark, clearly identify perpetrator and transgression, and make sure the situation calls for forgiveness and not something else, like mercy.\n\nDespite a seemingly endless supply of self-help and religious literature that urges bountiful forgiveness, be careful about offering it up willy-nilly. \u201cDon\u2019t act in a way that condones or enables further wrongdoing,\u201d Griswold says. But take action. Studies find that anger, vengefulness and all the negative ruminations that come with not forgiving can damage the human organism, especially the heart. Indeed, so-called forgiveness interventions (essentially practice sessions) have successfully reduced symptoms in patients with coronary artery disease, chronic pain and even drug addiction.\n\nResearchers disagree about exactly what constitutes forgiveness (though they concede that it involves \u201creducing unforgiveness\u201d). While many theologians and philosophers think it can be unilateral, Griswold holds that forgiveness should be bilateral: For a victim to truly let go of his or her anger, the perpetrator must first admit responsibility. You can ask for an apology, he says, but you won\u2019t always get one. Both parties should use direct and specific language. \u201cClarity is of the essence,\u201d Griswold says. \u201cIf you fudge what it is that you\u2019re doing, the process hasn\u2019t been successfully completed.\u201d And if the person who mistreated you is dead, has disappeared or is just an unrepentant jerk? \u201cYou have to find other ways to put aside your anger,\u201d Griswold says.\n\nMany religions teach forgiveness, but being devout is not required. Griswold has written about forgiveness in secular contexts because he believes that forgiving is one way our species can express true moral virtue. Humans hurt one another in tiny and immense ways, over and over, but we have also worked out this simple \u2014 yet sometimes profoundly difficult \u2014 act to free one another from some impact of that harm.", "title": "How to Forgive", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "There\u2019s a familiar refrain heard in living rooms around the world during the Olympic Games: \u201cI could do that.\u201d Eye rolls usually follow. But if you are watching the Games and wondering if you can follow in the footsteps of those athletes, here\u2019s a way to get started.\n\nFirst, you\u2019ll have to check your ego at the door. You most likely will not be able to nail a chicken salad grab (yes, that\u2019s really what it\u2019s called) on the halfpipe or do a double full twist as an aerial ski jumper. With a humble approach, you can start chasing down your own Olympic, or recreational, dreams.", "title": "How to Get Started With Olympic Winter Sports", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Traveling to a foreign country can be daunting if you don\u2019t know the local language, and while Fran\u00e7ois Thibault, the cellar master and co-founder of Grey Goose, speaks only French, his job requires constant travel around the world. \u201cOver the years, I\u2019ve learned how to navigate foreign countries with limited verbal communication,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Thibault has a number of tips to help travelers manage in a destination when they don\u2019t speak the native tongue, based on his own experience. Here are a few of them.\n\nDownload a Language Translation App\n\nTraveling in foreign countries has become much easier in the past few years thanks to the many foreign language apps which translate words on the spot. Mr. Thibault tends to rely on Google Translate and suggests that travelers find an app that works for them. Ideally, find one that specializes in the language you need to translate especially if the language uses a character set you\u2019re not familiar with, or have difficulty pronouncing.\n\nBut take note: in Mr. Thibault\u2019s experience, these apps work best when you\u2019re trying to decipher something in writing, like a restaurant menu or a street sign, rather than in the midst of a conversation.", "title": "How to Get by in a Country Where You Don\u2019t Know the Language", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cListen,\u201d says Ben Cohoon, a forester who hoots for owls in his job managing timberland in Northern California. First, figure out which owl species are in your area, and find field recordings of their vocalizations online. Owls say more than just \u201choo, hoo\u201d: Spend several days just listening to their calls, memorizing their whistles, cackles, grunts and groans. Once you know their repertoire, go outside. Try hooting around dusk; owls tend to be nocturnal.\n\nCohoon mostly calls northern spotted owls, which in 1990 were listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act. The federal government then began requiring owl surveyors like Cohoon to hoot before allowing trees to be harvested. If an owl called back, in many cases the trees around it had to be left standing. New rules curtailed logging in the Pacific Northwest, setting off a clash between loggers and conservationists that came to be known as the Timber Wars (a bumper sticker from the era read \u201cSave a Logger, Eat an Owl\u201d).\n\nCohoon vocalizes differently in the spring, when he knows the birds are looking for mates, than in the early summer, when they\u2019re vociferously defending their owlets. Once he locates an owl, he shuts up. \u201cDon\u2019t bother them,\u201d he says. No response doesn\u2019t mean no owls. \u201cMaybe they got harassed by a bunch of Steller\u2019s jays earlier in the day and just don\u2019t feel like talking,\u201d Cohoon says. Or maybe you don\u2019t sound right; Cohoon has trained dozens of people, and sometimes they simply can\u2019t get the pitch and cadence. \u201cIt\u2019s kind of like singing,\u201d he says. Hooting humans are no longer required; as of 2011 the United States Fish and Wildlife Service advises that northern-spotted-owl surveys be conducted using recordings of real owls.\n\nProceed with caution \u2014 when you hoot for owls, you can inadvertently alert predators to their whereabouts, make them worry for their young, give them false hopes for finding a mate or even lure fledglings away from their parents. Cohoon suggests you leave communicating with vulnerable owls to the pros. Instead, hoot for more aggressive and common species, like the barred owl or the great horned owl, which has a booming voice and tends to be chatty. \u201cThey\u2019ll call all night long,\u201d he says.", "title": "How to Hoot Like an Owl", "authors": ["Malia Wollan"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Parents should also be on the lookout for sepsis, a life-threatening complication caused by the body\u2019s overwhelming attack against an infection. The condition is characterized by fever or chills, extreme pain or discomfort, clammy or sweaty skin, confusion or disorientation, shortness of breath, and a high heart rate.\n\n\u201cThe trick with the flu is that it happens very quickly,\u201d said Dr. Flor M. Munoz, associate professor of pediatrics and infectious diseases at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. \u201cYou have to be really paying attention. Things can progress within 48 hours or so.\u201d\n\nSymptoms that call for immediate medical care are if a child\u2019s breathing becomes labored, and he or she is taking fast, shallow breaths or feels chest pain or pressure; if the child\u2019s lips turn blue or purple; if he or she is less responsive than usual; if the child\u2019s skin becomes clammy; or if the child refuses to eat or drink or has diarrhea and is vomiting, raising the risk of dehydration.\n\nIn general, if a child is particularly irritable, is sleeping too much, seems confused, dizzy or not mentally alert, and not acting like his or her usual self, parents should seek medical help. Severe vomiting and seizures are also danger signs.\n\nConcerns for Babies and Toddlers\n\nFor children under 2, parents must be vigilant about making sure their child is getting enough fluids, and watch for urine that becomes dark in color, a sign of dehydration that calls for immediate medical care. Other symptoms to watch for in infants are trouble breathing, inability to eat, significantly fewer wet diapers than normal and crying without producing tears.\n\nIbuprofen or acetaminophen can be used in older children, but acetaminophen is the preferred drug for fever in infants. It should be used only in appropriate doses, as instructed on the package (aspirin should never be used in children).\n\n\u201cFor a baby under 1, there\u2019s a lower threshold to see the doctor,\u201d Dr. Munoz said. \u201cI would be willing to wait a little longer on a 12-year-old who can tell me how he feels, but for a baby that age, it\u2019s hard for a parent to know what\u2019s going on. You have to watch them very carefully and be attuned to changes.\u201d", "title": "How to Know When a Child\u2019s Flu Turns Serious", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "After I settled onto a treatment table, the acupuncturist Samantha Story took a look at my skin and said I was dehydrated and needed to \u201ctill the soil.\u201d She inserted at least two dozen needles in my face, another 10 or so in my scalp and a few on my d\u00e9collet\u00e9 and legs and hands, which were pain free to the point of being imperceptible.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe needles target tension and strain \u2014 physical and mental \u2014 and promote good circulation to result in, one hopes, a lifting and smoothing and sculpting effect. Ms. Story removed the needles after half an hour and performed gua sha, which is a facial massage using a jade tool that looked vaguely like a comb.\n\nI couldn\u2019t afford the eight to 10 regular treatments recommended for best results, so I\u2019ll never know if facial acupuncture really can have lasting effects. But for a few hours I did think I had firmer looking skin and more defined cheekbones.\n\nI did know that I could have sat for several hours of someone massaging my face, so I decided to double-down on my next treatment, with Thuyen Nguyen of FaceXercise, a facialist who has a cultish, word-of-mouth following (Michelle Williams, Uma Thurman, Cindy Crawford, who usually come to him through makeup artists or hairstylists or friends) for his Instant-Lift Facial Ultimate Workout.\n\nAdding to the under-the-radar vibe is that Mr. Nguyen works out of a small, dark treatment room in Aqua, an underwater cycling studio in TriBeCa. My mind was luxuriously blank for 50 minutes as he washed my face using his own charcoal-based face cleanser; he then rubbed with a facial oil and did lymphatic drainage massage to get rid of water retention and puffiness. He has soft, strong fingers that move quickly and precisely around the eyes and jawline. When he wasn\u2019t massaging me, he was kneading me or doing rolling motions or using tiny facial cups.\n\nEvery once in a while he would impart some wisdom, like \u201cevery pore is a sphincter,\u201d or note that he was applying a face mask made with Manuka honey, and I would make some kind of affirmative noise and then go back to a place of wordless ecstasy as he worked on my skin. At the end he applied his own multivitamin serum and a cream, before massaging my neck and scalp and feet.\n\nMy fine lines were no longer visible, and my skin looked so good that a friend later asked me what highlighter I was using when I wasn\u2019t wearing any makeup. But these were mere bonuses after the pleasure of the treatment.\n\nAs I was leaving, I told Mr. Nguyen I was about to fly to Asia and asked what I could do to preserve my skin during long-haul flights. \u201cWhen you remember, just squeeze your skin to get the circulation going,\u201d he said. \u201cMassage is the youth serum in a bottle we\u2019re all looking for.\u201d I might believe him.", "title": "How to Lift Your Face With 2 Hands, 30 Needles and No Knives", "authors": ["Marisa Meltzer", "Me Time"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "What is it? The tweak aims to increase the likelihood that a failing bank would be forced into bankruptcy, rather than into a resolution process overseen by the government. The difference might seem insignificant, especially since the current regulatory procedures for winding down a bank, introduced by the Dodd-Frank Act of 2010, are stringent and mimic bankruptcy. But the Treasury Department believes that an actual bankruptcy would be preferable. It would make the process of restructuring a failed bank more evenhanded and predictable, according to the Treasury. In turn, investors in the big Wall Street firms, and anyone doing business with them, would become more aware of the losses they could suffer if those firms crashed.\n\nBut didn\u2019t the financial crisis of 2008 illustrate the grave dangers of allowing a large bank to go into bankruptcy? The disorderly collapse of Lehman Brothers into bankruptcy set off a panic across the global financial system, according to most analyses of the period. And that is why the Dodd-Frank Act set up a way for regulators to seize a large bank and restructure it in a controlled manner, known as the orderly liquidation authority. As with bankruptcy, it envisions making creditors the new owners of a restructured firm. But it added a feature to limit panic. Under Dodd-Frank, regulators can lend to the failed bank. Such a backstop could prevent a further run on the bank. Its customers and creditors would see that the seized bank had sufficient funds to pay them. The government lending mimics the loans that banks make to bankrupt companies.\n\nHow much of this does the Treasury want to do away with? Not much at all. It recommends using the Dodd-Frank resolution framework \u201cas an emergency tool for use in extraordinary circumstances.\u201d But that\u2019s how the backers of Dodd-Frank saw the process, too. Crucially, the Treasury also wants to keep the emergency government loan. But the Treasury\u2019s proposal does introduce an important and innovative change. It calls for a special type of bankruptcy regime for large financial firms, called Chapter 14. This new regime envisions having a set of specialist judges, working with regulators in the United States and around the world, who could plan for and oversee the bankruptcies of large banks.\n\nWould Chapter 14 work in a crisis? Much depends on whether the customers and creditors of the failing bank yank their money, intensifying the run and spreading fear through the system. The Treasury argues that changes since the crisis mean banks have more cash on hand, and banks can now hold off for a short time on paying claims on financial instruments called derivatives (recall, such claims were particularly debilitating for Lehman.) Also, banks must now have detailed plans to put themselves into bankruptcy, though the Treasury last year suggested changes that might make that planning less stringent. Notably, the Treasury hopes to make Chapter 14 effective by deploying a method for restructuring a failed bank that regulators already expect to use under the orderly liquidation authority.\n\nThis approach rests on turning pre-existing debt owed by a bank\u2019s holding company into new equity at the subsidiaries where the bank does all its business. The theory: If a reassuringly large amount of new equity were created at the subsidiaries, the banks\u2019 creditors and trading partners would feel protected and not withdraw. Indeed, the Treasury says this would eliminate the incentive for counterparties to run.\n\nEliminate is a strong word. In the heat of a crisis, when the scale of a bank\u2019s losses is not known, making it hard to know how much new equity is needed, creditors and trading partners may just head for the exits, crippling the bank. Even so, Aaron Klein, a fellow at the Brookings Institution, said it made a lot of sense to enshrine this formal wind-down procedure in bankruptcy. \u201cWhy wouldn\u2019t you want to make bankruptcy better?\u201d he said.\n\nAnd there\u2019s a big reason it might work. Under post-crisis rules, banks must earmark billions of dollars of debt that would be used for creating new equity in a resolution. Put another way, Dodd-Frank has made it possible for the Trump administration to pursue a favored policy goal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nSnap just lost nearly $2 billion in market value.\n\nShares of the social media company tumbled 7.4 percent Thursday after Kylie Jenner tweeted that she no longer opens Snapchat.\n\nThe tweet comes as Snap faces growing criticism from users over the redesign of its app. So far nearly 1.5 million people have retweeted a petition asking Snap to revert to the old version, CNBC reported.\n\nEarlier this week analysts at Citi became the latest to downgrade the stock over the negative reaction.\n\nMark May of Citi wrote:\n\n\u201cWhile the recent redesign of its flagship app could produce positive long-term benefits, the significant jump in negative app reviews since the redesign was pushed out a few weeks could result in a decline in users and user engagement, which could negatively impact financial results.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe new tax law is having implications beyond America\u2019s borders.\n\nEuropean banks with significant operations in New York and other parts of the United States have seen multi-billion dollar hits on their results in the fourth quarter as a result.\n\nChanges in corporate tax rates have forced European lenders \u2013 and their American counterparts \u2013 to recognize so-called deferred tax assets at the end of last year.\n\nBut, the pain is expected to be short term as most banks, including Barclays and UBS, anticipate the tax rate for their United States operations will be lower future.\n\nAs earnings season edges toward a close, here is the impact on some of Europe\u2019s largest lenders:\n\n\u2022 Barclays reported an annual loss of 1.9 billion pounds, or about $2.7 billion after it took a series of charges, including \u00a3900 million related to tax changes in the United States. \u201cGiven the group\u2019s substantial U.S. operations, this is expected to result in a reduction of the group\u2019s effective tax rate in 2018 and future periods to mid-20 percent,\u201d the bank said on Thursday.\n\n\u2022 Credit Suisse reported a loss of 2.13 billion Swiss francs, or about $2.3 billion, in the fourth quarter, driven primarily by 2.23 billion francs in income tax expenses related to the reassessment of its deferred tax assets.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Deutsche Bank reported a full-year loss of 497 million euros, or about $612 million. John Cryan, the Deutsche Bank chief executive, said: \u201cOnly a charge related to US tax reform at the end of the year meant that we had to post a full-year after-tax loss.\u201d\n\n\u2022 HSBC reported a pretax profit of $17.2 billion for 2017, but took a charge of $1.3 billion to reflect a reevaluation of its deferred tax balances.\n\n\u2022 Soci\u00e9t\u00e9 G\u00e9n\u00e9rale said its profit was dragged down in the quarter after it was hit by restructuring charges related to its French retail banking network and the impact of tax reforms in France and in the United States.\n\n\u2022 UBS fell to a loss in the fourth quarter as a result of a writedown of 2.87 billion francs on deferred tax assets.\n\nKeep an eye out for Standard Chartered when it reports its annual results next week.\n\nThe bank, which is based in Britain, but makes most of its money in Asia, has been recently touting its ability to serve the North American market.\n\n\u2014 Chad Bray\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat does it take to become a protected whistle-blower?\n\nAccording to the Supreme Court, in an opinion written by Ruth Bader Ginsburg, it requires telling the Securities and Exchange Commission, not just your bosses. More from Andrew Ackerman of the WSJ:\n\nThe case stems from a lawsuit filed by a would-be whistle-blower, Paul Somers, who says he was fired from Digital Realty Trust in 2014 after complaining internally about accounting irregularities, among other matters. Mr. Somers argued he was protected by Dodd-Frank even though he didn\u2019t report the alleged problems to the S.E.C.\n\nPeter Henning\u2019s take\n\nThe Supreme Court, in an opinion by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, rejected that reading of the statute. It applied a simple analysis: \u201cCourts are not at liberty to dispense with the condition \u2014 tell the S.E.C. \u2014 Congress imposed.\u201d By not reporting his suspicions to the S.E.C., he lost the protection afforded whistle-blowers.\n\nNewell adds new directors as it fights with Starboard Value\n\nThe maker of Sharpie markers and Elmer\u2019s glue said today that it was adding three new directors amid its fight with Starboard. They are:\n\n\u2022 James Craigie, the chairman and former C.E.O. of Church & Dwight, the maker of Arm & Hammer\n\n\u2022 Debra Crew, the former C.E.O. of Reynolds American, the tobacco company\n\n\u2022 Judith Sprieser, a former C.E.O. of Transora, a services provider for packaged goods companies (who will be nominated at the company\u2019s upcoming annual meeting)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat Newell said of the move:\n\nThese actions are part of Newell Brands\u2019 ongoing refreshment process on behalf of shareholders designed to build a board with the best mix of skills, expertise and experience to support the Newell Brands\u2019 leadership team in accelerating shareholder value creation.\n\nWhat it didn\u2019t say: That this was a response to Starboard, which has criticized Newell\u2019s management team \u2014 and is seeking to replace the company\u2019s entire board.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nAre the risks of a recession rising?\n\nRay Dalio, the founder of Bridgewater Associates, the world\u2019s biggest hedge fund, thinks so.\n\nLast week, Mr. Dalio said: \u201cThe risks of a recession in the next 18-24 months are rising.\u201d\n\nNow he says there is a 70 percent chance of one before the next presidential election in 2020, according to Reuters.\n\nDuring an appearance Wednesday at the Harvard Kennedy School\u2019s Institute of Politics, Mr. Dalio said:\n\n\u201cI think we are in a pre-bubble stage that could go into a bubble stage ... The probability of a recession prior to the next presidential election would be relatively high, maybe 70 percent.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Broadcom-Qualcomm battle is getting more bitter\n\nBroadcom didn\u2019t walk away after Qualcomm raised its takeover bid for NXP Semiconductor, but it did lower its own proposal by $3 a share, to $79. Why? Because the new NXP offer transferred $4.10 per Qualcomm share to NXP investors.\n\nQualcomm responded that the move \u201cmade an inadequate offer even worse,\u201d and argued that the NXP deal couldn\u2019t have gotten done at the original price of $110 a share.\n\nLooks like we\u2019re headed to a showdown at Qualcomm\u2019s annual meeting on March 6.\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 As online streaming booms and 5G gets closer, is now the time for Charlie Ergen to sell Dish Networks? A new study by the McKinsey Global Institute suggests that rising consumer demand, as well as what companies produce and which tech they use, drives productivity improvements.\n\nMore from Peter Eavis\u2019s correspondence with Jaana Remes of McKinsey, one of the study\u2019s authors:\n\nImportant new technologies can often take well over 10 years to have a big impact on productivity, she adds. The optimistic take, though, is that we can in the coming years expect to see big benefits as companies further automate, and introduce artificial intelligence.\n\nIn other macro news: Prepare for interest rates to rise, Jay Powell said. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "How to Liquidate a Failing Bank: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Mindfulness practices have taught her to accept the distractions.\n\n\u201cFor shooting, you need to remove any kind of emotion from what you\u2019re doing,\u201d she says. \u201cThere\u2019s my target, here\u2019s my trigger, this is my process, now I\u2019m going to make the shot.\u201d\n\nFocus on the task, not the results. One of the most vulnerable moments is when a biathlete has hit four targets and is about to take the last shot. \u201c\u2018If I hit this, I\u2019ll win the gold medal\u2019 \u2014 as soon as you have that thought, you\u2019re definitely going to miss it,\u201d Egan says. \u201cThat extra push or desire to win is not only not helpful, it\u2019s counterproductive. You have to eliminate that from your mind and focus on the task.\n\nJust ask Martin Fourcade, the world\u2019s top biathlete, who missed the shot that would have guaranteed him the gold medal in the final round of shooting in the 15-kilometer mass start race on Sunday. Being Fourcade, he won anyway in a photo finish, but hitting one more target would have made his triumph a whole lot easier.\n\nEgan says her strategy is to replace goal-oriented thoughts (\u201cI have to hit this last shot\u201d) with cue words that help her focus on the things that will get the job done. Words like form, breathing, trigger and follow-through. \u201cYou have to eliminate all of that noise in your mind,\u201d Egan says. \u201cI have to use some kind of process-oriented word about how to shoot well.\u201d\n\n\u201cEven if you\u2019ve only done mini-golf, you can understand the concept of following through,\u201d she says.\n\nCompete against yourself, nobody else. \u201cIf you\u2019ve ever been to a biathlon race, you get to the last shooting stage and so many people are missing \u2014 the pressure is on,\u201d Egan says. \u201cEven the best athletes in the world are subject to the last-stage meltdowns.\u201d\n\nThe key to biathlon is focusing on your own process and tasks and not being distracted by the potential outcome or how others are performing. \u201cI think that is a principle that applies to really everything,\u201d Egan says. \u201cI think such a big part of this is focusing on what you are doing. You have to let go of how everyone else is doing, and focus on your own work.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf you can do that,\u201d she adds, \u201cyou\u2019re going to have a performance you can be proud of, whether it\u2019s giving a presentation at work or a piano recital or biathlon.\u201d", "title": "How to Manage Stress Like an Olympic Biathlete", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Are there any programs that track phone cellular data usage by individual app?\n\nA. Third-party apps often use easy-to-read graphics to break down your phone\u2019s cellular data consumption so you can see just which programs are burning through your bytes. Data Usage for Android and iOS as well as My Data Manager (also for Android and iOS) are among the options, and your wireless carrier may have its own data-tracking app. However, depending on your device, you may not need extra software.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn iOS 11, open the Settings icon on the home screen and tap Cellular. Scroll down to the Cellular Data section to see the total amount of data used in the current period noted above a list of apps. (The \u201ccurrent period\u201d is measured between the times you hit the Reset Statistics button at the bottom of the screen \u2014 which can be at the beginning of your billing period or whenever you feel like it.)\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the list, you can see the amount of data each app has used. If you want to stop an app from pulling down data over the cellular connection, tap the button on the right side of the screen to restrict its network activity to a Wi-Fi connection.\n\nThe steps for checking your data usage in Android varies based on the operating system and device maker. In several versions, start by opening the Settings app, choosing Network & Internet, then tapping Data Usage and Mobile Data Usage. To see how much an app is eating, tap its name in the list to see its total use, its foreground use and its background use. Android 7.0 and later has a Data Saver mode that can help save megabytes on a limited plan.", "title": "How to Monitor Cellular Data Use for Apps", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "In computer-speak, this \u201copening up\u201d would involve something called an open application programming interface. This is a common software technique that allows different programs to work with one another. For instance, Uber uses the open application programming interface of Google Maps to get information about a rider\u2019s pickup point and destination. It is not Uber\u2019s own mapping algorithm, but rather Google\u2019s open application programming interface, that makes it possible for Uber to build its own algorithms for its distinctive functions.\n\nThe government should require social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter to use a similar open application programming interface. This would make it possible for third parties to build software to monitor and report on the effects of social media algorithms. (This idea has been proposed by Wael Ghonim, the Egyptian Google employee who helped organize the Tahrir Square uprising in 2011.)\n\nTo be clear, the proposal is not to force companies to open up their algorithms \u2014 just the results of the algorithms. The goal is to make it possible to understand what content is fed into the algorithms and how the algorithms distribute that content. Who created the information or advertisement? And to what groups of users was it directed? An open application programming interface would therefore threaten neither a social media platform\u2019s intellectual property nor the privacy of its individual users.\n\nMedia watchdog groups have long been able to assess the results of the editorial decisions of newspapers and television. Whether those stories express the left, right or center of the political spectrum, they are openly available to independent organizations that want to understand what is being communicated.\n\nExtending this practice to social media would mean that a watchdog group could create software to analyze and make public whatever information from the platforms it might consider important: the demographics of the readership of a certain article, for instance, or whether a fake story continued to be widely disseminated even after being debunked.", "title": "Opinion | How to Monitor Fake News", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDon\u2019t fight it,\u201d says Alexus Kwachka, a commercial fisherman from Kodiak, Alaska, who still gets seasick even after 30 years of traveling between the Bering Strait and the Gulf of Alaska. \u201cGo to the rail and puke as soon as you can.\u201d Do so over the leeward side of the boat, facing downwind. Don\u2019t feel ashamed. For Kwachka, it helps to keep the mood light. He tells the crew he\u2019s going to \u201clook for Buicks,\u201d vomits over the side and then sneezes. \u201cThat seems to reset things,\u201d he says.\n\nScientists don\u2019t entirely understand how motion sickness is triggered or why humans and other animals (fish included) experience it. They do know it stems in part from sensory conflict, like discord between visual input to the brain and signals sent from the parts of the inner ear responsible for balance. Some research suggests that facing forward and focusing on a distant point on the horizon can minimize symptoms. Because the placebo effect on seasickness is particularly strong, the prevention measures you believe in are more potent. Kwachka has seen people try everything from chewing ginger root to wearing special bracelets. If you do feel ill, fresh air helps. Drugs, too, but the sedative effects of most anti-motion pharmaceuticals are incompatible with making your livelihood at sea. The most effective treatment is exposure; militaries in many countries run weekslong motion-sickness desensitization programs.\n\nGenerally, the more lurching and vertical the motion, the worse you\u2019ll feel. On a few occasions, though, Kwachka has been out in truly perilous storms with 40- and 50-foot ocean swells. In those conditions, adrenaline is likely to override everything else. \u201cIf your life is in jeopardy, seasickness is the last thing you\u2019re focusing on,\u201d he says. As is true of most things, your psychological state matters: While nearly every human is susceptible to motion sickness, people prone to anxiety and neuroticism are more so. Discussing your symptoms may worsen them, while calm breathing can have the opposite effect. Try to relax. \u201cAs a species we want to be in control of just about everything,\u201d Kwachka says. \u201cOn the water you need to let go.\u201d/\u2022/", "title": "How to Overcome Seasickness", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Stripling also suggested that getting into amateur or HAM radio is helpful, especially for times when traditional communication networks are down. Finally, don\u2019t forget old-fashioned rendezvous points. If you have no communications at all, it\u2019s critical to have a spot everyone knows to meet up just to make sure everyone is safe.\n\n2. Learn about the hazards and most likely disasters in your area. Not every region is prone to the same types of disasters. If you live on the coast, make sure you talk about plans for coastal storms and flooding. If you live in the Midwest, make sure you\u2019re all on the same page about tornadoes and catastrophic storms. Western state residents may want to talk about mudslides and wildfires. Everyone should probably discuss things like terrorism or other man-made disasters. In every case, people respond better in an emergency if they\u2019ve talked about possible threats before they occur.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s also incredibly important to understand that disasters don\u2019t impact people equally \u2014 they tend to exacerbate existing vulnerabilities,\u201d Mr. Stripling said. \u201cSo you need to understand the vulnerabilities in your neighborhood \u2014 things like poverty, housing discrimination or unequal transportation access \u2014 since these elements often point to where the worst consequences will occur.\u201d\n\n3. Understand your neighborhood and how your neighbors can help one another. If everyone is going to rely on one another, think about what is convenient and makes sense for each person. \u201cMaybe one neighbor runs a store and could help stock food supplies for the whole team, and another has a vacation home or relative\u2019s house that could serve as a rendezvous point,\u201d Mr. Stripling said. \u201cThe neighbor who lives within walking distance of the school could be in charge of kid pickup if transportation goes down. Or someone owns an S.U.V. or boat that could help evacuation procedures. Everyone brings something to the table \u2014 and the more diversity your team has, the more powerful it will be.\u201d\n\nIdeally, everyone in your community will be willing to pitch in with their own unique skills, abilities and perspectives to help everyone stay safe and protected. Additionally, while everyone should pool resources in a way that makes sense, you should all be willing to back one another up, even if it doesn\u2019t seem like a particular role is your best fit. If the neighbor responsible for kid pickup is out of town when a blizzard hits, someone else should be ready to step in. Best of all, the closer and more tight knit you are before a disaster, the more you\u2019ll be willing to cover the gaps when one happens.\n\nBe ready before help arrives\n\nMost of us are taught that in an emergency, first responders like police officers, emergency medical personnel and firefighters will be the first ones to get there and help victims. In reality, bystanders and neighbors are usually first \u2014 and in the best position to help save lives \u2014 especially after a disaster significant enough that it may take time for those emergency workers to arrive.\n\nMr. Stripling suggested reading the Federal Emergency Management Agency\u2019s \u201cUntil Help Arrives\u201d program and sharing it with your community group. Similarly, he pointed to the New York City Health Department\u2019s Bystander Training Course as another useful resource even for people who don\u2019t live in New York.", "title": "How to Prepare Your Community for a Disaster", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe only way to extricate paper from lamination is to use lots of solvents to dissolve the plastic,\u201d Ms. Oey said. \u201cSome stiffer laminations, we don\u2019t know how to get off, and it doesn\u2019t protect the document. The lamination itself can ruin a document beyond repair.\u201d\n\nNot only is the lamination process itself likely to harm delicate papers, it also places undue stress on objects that can cause them to tear, yellow or become brittle prematurely.\n\nFor items like papers and fragile documents, the best thing you can do is to control the environment they\u2019re stored in, said Maureen Callahan, an archivist for the Sophia Smith Collection at Smith College.\n\n\u201cWater and vermin are the greatest enemies of paper,\u201d Ms. Callahan said. \u201cFolks also often store family records in basements or attics, where heat and humidity can fluctuate wildly and where water is more likely to enter.\u201d\n\nYour best bet? Ms. Oey said it\u2019s a clean, dark space, like the top of a linen closet.\n\nWith items like printed photographs and albums, making things clean and neat will go a long way.\n\n\u201cNeatness for photographs is almost as important as storage,\u201d Ms. Oey said. Very important photographs can be stored in high-quality paper folders (check to make sure they are acid free and lignin free) or in good plastic sleeves like Mylar. But an important caveat to remember: not using a sleeve is preferable to a cheap one that will scratch.\n\nEvery conservator who spoke to The Times recommended cardboard boxes over plastic bins for storage, because they don\u2019t breed mold as easily and dry out quicker. But if you want to get fancy, the best option is to buy acid-free archival boxes, online or from vendors like the Container Store. They can be a bit pricey, but hold up best against moisture and mold.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd just as important as knowing what to do is knowing what not to do.\n\n\u201cAll conservators would agree with me when I say we have seen miles and miles of terrible sticky tape,\u201d Ms. Oey said.\n\nSo remember: No tape (it sticks). No paper clips or staples (they can rust). Definitely no lamination. And absolutely no plastic bins that can fill up with water.\n\nOther strange heirlooms (wedding dresses, record collections and more)\n\nFamily archives can include all sorts of strange ephemera. Maybe your grandmother had an extensive record collection, or there\u2019s a box of photo slides sitting in your garage that you have no idea what to do with.\n\nWhatever the case, individual items like these don\u2019t have any catchall rules besides common sense. But Ms. Oey encourages individuals with archiving goals they don\u2019t know how to accomplish to seek out experts who are available.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMost major collecting services have resources on their website about preservation no matter what you\u2019re trying to preserve. There are expert tips easily accessible for audio and visual materials, furniture, paintings, historical silver, even individual digital film types.\n\nMost libraries have an online reference system called Ask a Librarian that allows individuals to talk to preservationists who can advise them on how to best take care of the strange item, or point them toward an expert who can provide assistance, or help them find a conservator who might mend the item (though that can get pricey). A great place to start is the Library of Congress website.\n\nAnd that old wedding dress that\u2019s still in the closet? It\u2019s best to let a professional preservationist handle it, experts said. The Association of Wedding Gown Specialists has a list of guidelines and recommendations on its site. (Though, if you still want to go it alone, the same rules apply: Have a professional clean it, then store it in an acid free box in a cool, dark space away from water.)\n\nDigitizing those love letters and printed photos\n\nJust as with paper archives, the most important part of archiving digital files is storage.\n\n\u201cHow you store your files and where will always be the most important form of preservation anyone can do,\u201d Ms. Oey said. Computers, for example, are not safe in and of themselves. Anything important to you should never have only one digital file.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe key with digital archiving, archivists say, is duplication. Every important file should have three copies. Ideally, those three copies should be stored on at least two different storage media. Ms. Levenick said that she personally uses a 3-2-1 method for backing up: three copies, two different media and at least one away from home. For example, you might store two digital wedding albums on your desktop and in a cloud based storage.\n\nThe first step to a good digital practice is high resolution photographs. Ms. Oey recommends snapping photos of your items in good (preferably natural light). \u201cIf you have a nice digital camera like an SLR, that\u2019s great, but honestly an iPhone [or other smartphone] will work just fine.\u201d (Any smartphone camera will do.) You can also use a service to do this for you for 60 cents a pop.\n\nThe second step is storing those files just as safely as the original documents. While your digital photographs aren\u2019t going to get soaked through by a burst pipe, keeping them in well-maintained environments is equally important.\n\n\u201cIf you are using physical storing, you need to regularly migrate off one hard disk and onto another,\u201d Ms. Oey said. That includes hard drives, flash drives, CDs and anything else. \u201cDoing this every three to five years on average will keep your files safe and up to date.\u201d\n\nOnline storage solutions can be weird and confusing, but luckily there is already a handy and thorough guide on Wirecutter, a New York Times company that reviews and recommends products, to help you choose.\n\nDigitizing audio, video and everything else\n\nAudio and video preservation are often neglected by family archivists because they are more technical than common sense, but they are no less important.\n\nAudio recordings \u2014 like reel-to-reel, cassette, mini-tapes from answering machines \u2014 can be easily translated to digital form as MP3 files, but not in a high enough quality to replace the original recording. Several archivists said that you could spend anywhere from $400 to $40,000 digitizing audio, and that letting a vendor handle it is definitely the way to go (unless you want to make a hobby of digitization).\n\nBut if you have a large collection, it\u2019ll be more expensive. Many vendors charge around $15 to digitize a cassette. The Association for Recorded Sound Collections has a list of vendors and plenty of resources on preserving physical sound and digitizing it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPreserving video follows much of the same rules. The trend is toward storing video in digital formats instead of carrier-dependent formats. Again, if you want to make a hobby of it, there\u2019s plenty of info to dive into. The Institute of Museum and Library Services has a thorough detailing of all the trials that go into digitizing video and deciding how to do it.\n\nBut for those who just want their videos safe, vendor help is the way to go. Most video conversion vendors will charge you around 20 cents per foot for 8mm, Super 8mm and 16mm film conversion.\n\nTurning to other heirlooms, vinyl records, for example, can be particularly dangerous and easy to destroy, so it\u2019s recommended that you take those to a local vendor. As with every other kind of archiving, if you have something weird or uncommon, it\u2019s probably best to call an archivist and grab some specialized tips.\n\nDo your best, but don\u2019t archive everything\n\nPreventive care of heirlooms is always easier than trying to repair a broken item.\n\n\u201cDeath and decay is inevitable, and not everything is worth saving,\u201d Ms. Callahan said. Curation, everyone agreed, is maybe the most important part of archiving.\n\n\u201cBe discriminating,\u201d she said, adding that if record-keeping becomes overwhelming \u201cyou\u2019re far less likely to go through them, and folks from the next generation probably won\u2019t know what to make of them.\u201d", "title": "How to Preserve Your Family Memories, Letters and Trinkets", "authors": ["Kelsey Mckinney"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cFlorida Shooting Suspect Displayed Flashes of Rage and Other Warning Signs\u201d (front page, Feb. 16):\n\nEvery time there is a mass shooting, and a suspect is identified, endless media attention is devoted to examination of the alleged perpetrator\u2019s behavior and demeanor before the tragedy. The implication seems to be, if only people had paid attention, the carnage somehow could have been prevented. The truth is, there will always be angry young men, and angry older men, and women, too.\n\nAnd, although very few of us are potential mass murderers, who among us has never felt \u201cflashes of rage\u201d? I feel one every time I read another gun-rights advocate piously offer \u201cthoughts and prayers\u201d to relatives and friends of the victims of assault weapon violence.\n\nDAVID ENGLISH, ACTON, MASS.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn response to the news that President Trump is going to visit the high school in Parkland, Fla., to offer his condolences, the obvious question is, \u201cIs President Trump capable of empathy?\u201d In his responses to tragedies like these, he seems to be going through the motions, feigning feelings through words that don\u2019t seem to be his own, likely written by his staff.\n\nIt is impossible to imagine Mr. Trump overcome by emotion and breaking down in tears, as President Obama did in talking about Sandy Hook. The only emotions he shows are rage and affront, at imagined slights to his own stature. He shows no feeling for anyone else\u2019s suffering. He should just go golfing, and stop pretending to care.", "title": "Opinion | How to Prevent Future Mass Shootings", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Scott Pruitt, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, suggested this week that climate change might not be a danger for humanity.\n\nDuring an interview Tuesday with KSNV television of Las Vegas, Mr. Pruitt said that rising global temperatures are \u201cnot necessarily a bad thing\u201d and that \u201chumans have flourished\u2019\u2019 during times of warming trends. His comments represent a new wrinkle in Mr. Pruitt\u2019s history of questioning the established science of climate change.\n\nAt the E.P.A., Mr. Pruitt has championed the elimination of policies intended to mitigate climate change. He also has long expressed doubt about the role of humans in rising global temperatures, despite the scientific consensus that human activity is the dominant cause of climate change.\n\nHis recent comments go a step beyond some of his previously stated views, some scientists say.\n\n\u201cI do think how Mr. Pruitt talks about climate tells us something important about how folks on the right view climate,\u201d said Joseph Majkut, director of climate policy at the Niskanen Center, a libertarian think tank that advocates conservative solutions to climate change. Mr. Majkut cited in particular the search for what he referred to as \u201ccounter-narratives.\u201d", "title": "How to Read Between the Lines When Scott Pruitt Talks About Climate Science", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "I tell my story a lot. I tell the story of how I wasn\u2019t always blind. I tell the story of how I lost my vision while serving in Afghanistan, by stepping on an I.E.D. I tell the story of how I put my own injury into perspective by considering the greater sacrifice of my fallen comrades, and how I owed it to them to make the most of my escape from death.\n\nI tell the story of how I did that by winning a gold medal in swimming at the Paralympics on the first anniversary of the loss of my vision. And after I tell it, people often thank me. They tell me that it\u2019s an incredible story, and that I\u2019m a good storyteller. They tell me how inspiring it is to see how I\u2019ve overcome my blindness.\n\nBut that\u2019s not my whole story.\n\nIt\u2019s part of it, I suppose \u2014 in many ways, I have overcome my blindness. Five years after losing my sight, I have a rewarding job teaching leadership at the Naval Academy, a lovely house on a creek in historic Annapolis, Md., a loving family and a number of truly deep friendships. My quality of life is very high. Day to day, week to week, I don\u2019t find that my blindness is an obstacle.\n\nWhat I haven\u2019t been able to overcome is how others perceive me and treat me differently now because of my blindness, or how I so often feel as if I\u2019m on the outside listening in on the lives of others.", "title": "Opinion | How to Really See a Blind Person", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cRussia at Work on U.S. Midterms, Spy Chiefs Warn\u201d (front page, Feb. 14):\n\nThe continued political and economic success of our democracy depends on a well-founded belief in the integrity of our election system. Therefore, the Russian attempt to undercut our confidence in electoral integrity is an existential threat.\n\nRussian efforts will, if left alone, become ever more sophisticated and effective. Unfortunately, President Trump is concerned only about what he thinks the Russians can do for him in what he hopes will be his campaign to hold on to the presidency.\n\nIf the Republicans are not yet ready to start impeachment proceedings, the least they can do is pass a congressional resolution calling on the president to demand that all Russian electoral interference cease immediately, backed by an order requiring, in the face of noncompliance, the immediate removal of all Russian diplomats from our country.\n\nCyberwarfare against our electoral system is war. Better to recognize that now and act accordingly. It is not time to react militarily, but it is past time to react effectively. Russia must be isolated from the family of nations.", "title": "Opinion | How to Respond to Russia\u2019s \u2018Cyberwarfare\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Another super-easy trick: Bolt the door. \u201cLocking the door closes it all the way to seal it against the weather stripping,\u201d said Brittany Bailey, a licensed contractor and founder of PrettyHandyGirl.\n\nPlug up drafty holes\n\nIf you\u2019ve tackled the door and windows and still feel a draft, use this test to find the source: Wet your hand with water, then talk a walk around the room. Drafts can come from unexpected spots, like near the plumbing under the kitchen sink, around electrical sockets, from non-working fireplaces, and more \u2014 basically, any place that leads outside.\n\nFor out-of-the-way spots, Ms. Bailey recommends filling the gaps with expanding spray foam, an easy project that your landlord should be grateful for. (Bonus: It\u2019ll keep out bugs and other critters.) For electrical sockets, Mr. Lipford suggests fitting a pre-cut gasket behind the outlet cover. If you have a drafty decorative fireplace, cut a piece of foam core to fit the back or opening to block the cold air.\n\nPut down area rugs\n\nIf your floors feel cold, put down a rug. It sounds simple, but it\u2019s more helpful than you may think. \u201cNot only will a rug keep your feet from feeling cold, but it actually add a layer of insulation,\u201d Ms. Bailey said. In especially chilly rooms like the bathroom, kitchen or ground-level spaces, add a rug with a rug pad underneath it, too. \u201cDouble the insulation!\u201d\n\nGet the hot air flowing\n\nIf you have central heating, it only works if there\u2019s a free flow of heat into your rooms. If you don\u2019t have air returns in each room, keep your doors open so your heating unit can warm your entire space efficiently.\n\nIf you find one room consistently cooler than others, adjust the vents redirect more heat to flow into the room.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGive your radiator an assist\n\nA hack to get a little more heat from your radiator: Tape a piece of aluminum foil behind the radiator to reflect heat into the room instead of into the wall. \u201cIt sounds gaudy, but it works well and you\u2019ll never see it,\u201d Mr Lipford said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd resist turning your radiator into a bookshelf: Heat rises, so you\u2019re blocking the most natural pathway of warm air.\n\nRearrange the furniture\n\nWith any kind of heating system, make sure you\u2019re not physically blocking the heat from getting into the room. \u201cI can\u2019t tell you how many times a tenant has complained that the heat\u2019s not working, and I find out that there\u2019s a sofa on top of the vent,\u201d said Mr. Manfredini.\n\nMove your furniture away from air vents and radiators so they have room to breathe. Even if your living room furniture isn\u2019t blocking vents, consider scooting everything toward the center of the room in wintertime. \u201cIt\u2019s always going to be colder around the perimeter,\u201d Mr. Lipford explained.\n\nCirculate warm air\n\nIf you have high ceilings and a ceiling fan, switch the fan to run in reverse during the winter. On a low setting, the fan will create a mild updraft that pushes the warm air down from the ceiling back into the room. \u201cThis costs pennies a week,\u201d said Mr. Lipford.\n\nTurn down the thermostat\n\nWhile some apartment buildings operate on a single thermostat, single-family rentals and newer apartment buildings tend to let renters control (and pay for) their own heat, said Mr. Lipford. So take my dad\u2019s advice: Put on a sweater!\n\nLearning to live in a chillier space is a surefire way to save on your energy bill. The Department of Energy recommends setting your thermostat at 68 degrees in the winter for maximum energy savings. If you can lower your home\u2019s temperature an additional seven to 10 degrees for eight hours a day (as in, when you\u2019re sleeping or at work), you can save up to an additional 10 percent on your energy bill.\n\nThere is a threshold, though: Don\u2019t turn the heat down more than 10 degrees if it\u2019s only for a few hours, because it\u2019ll take too much energy to heat your space back up. If you can, automate it with a smart or programmable thermostat. \u201cSomething like 60 percent of homes now have programmable thermostats, but many people still don\u2019t use them,\u201d Mr. Manfredini said. If you don\u2019t, you may be able to install an inexpensive model yourself. (Just get permission first or save the old one to reinstall when you move.)\n\nSpot-heat zones you use most\n\nFor nighttime, turn down the heat and outfit your bed with a cozy down comforter or heated mattress. Wirecutter, the New York Times product review site, recommends the Snowe Down Comforter for a durable, well-priced comforter and the Sunbeam Premium Quilted Mattress Pad for even more warmth.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf you have a room that always feel chilly, warm it with a space heater while you\u2019re using it. \u201cThese use about the same amount of energy as a refrigerator, but that\u2019s much less energy than warming up the whole house to make one room feel comfortable,\u201d said Mr. Manfredini.\n\nWirecutter\u2019s pick for the best space heater is the Lasko 754200 Ceramic Heater. Just be sure to use the same precautions with a space heater as you would with a lit candle: Never run it while you\u2019re sleeping, don\u2019t leave the room when it\u2019s on and use caution when kids are around.\n\nAdd humidity\n\nThe same way humidity can affect the \u201creal-feel\u201d outside temperature in summertime, adding humidity to cold air makes it feel warmer inside. Moisture in the air holds onto heat better, keeping it warmer longer, and making it feel warmer on your skin, too. Wirecutter recommends the Honeywell HCM-350 Germ-Free Cool Mist Humidifier as the most effective, leakproof and easy to maintain option.\n\nUse nature to your advantage\n\nEspecially in the winter, when the sun is low in the sky, you can get a lot of heat through south-facing windows. During the day, open curtains or blinds, then close them at night to keep that warm air in. Consider thick, lined curtains for extra insulation at night. \u201cThey don\u2019t have to be thermal, just thick enough to block a draft,\u201d said Ms. Bailey.\n\nFinally, the next time you\u2019re looking to move, ask the landlord what the average energy bill is before you sign the lease. In Mr. Lipford\u2019s experience, the cost can vary by almost $100 a month even in similarly-sized homes, depending on how energy efficient they are.", "title": "How to Save Money and Energy Heating Your Apartment", "authors": ["Ayn-Monique Klahre"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "The United States delegation has jackets with battery-powered heating elements. Concern about cold conditions prompted the Italian team, which was 59th in the parade of nations at the opening ceremony, to advise its athletes to skip the entertainment portion of the ceremony.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the first time we decide this,\u201d said Danilo Di Tommaso, deputy chief of mission for Italy. \u201cVancouver was covered. Sochi was not cold. Torino was beautiful. In the recent past, we didn\u2019t have this problem.\u201d\n\nSome cross-country and biathlon athletes have been spotted holding a whistle-like gadget in their mouths as they ski. The device is a respiratory heat exchanger.\n\nAluminum coils inside of it capture the heat from an athlete\u2019s breath. When the athlete sucks in cold air, the air is warmed by the residual heat so it feels less cold going into the athlete\u2019s lungs. The Czech biathlete Eva Puskarcikova has been photographed using it. A team spokesman said it helped her breathing during the event. But the gadget looks odd, like a hunting whistle, and sometimes icicles made of saliva form on the end of it.\n\nIn 1988, University of Wisconsin researchers studied the device, called a Lungplus, when used by 91 subjects in various cold-weather conditions. Over all, Lungplus users reported more comfort breathing in very cold temperatures. The researchers noted that Lungplus breathing at minus 15 degrees Celsius received similar scores, in terms of comfort, as regular breathing in 20 degrees Celsius, according to the research published in Applied Ergonomics.\n\nThe Norwegian athletes, who are accustomed to very cold weather, have adopted several strategies to stay warm in Pyeongchang, according to the team\u2019s chief medical officer, Dr. Mona Kjeldsberg. Members of the Alpine team and support crew use heated socks while they wait to compete, she said. Most wear wool undergarments and use tape and buffs to protect exposed skin on the face. To stay warm, \u201chot chocolate from Norway is a favorite,\u201d she said.\n\nDespite the bitter cold, the wind chill and temperatures in Pyeongchang have not dropped low enough to create serious concerns about hypothermia or frostbite for the athletes, experts say. (Frostbite risk becomes significant if the temperature drops below minus 13 Fahrenheit, or minus 25 Celsius.)\n\nDuring competition and training, most athletes will generate enough heat to keep their internal body temperature at a comfortable level. Between events, athletes will need to keep moving to maintain deep body temperature. One mistake athletes and spectators can make is to focus on warming hands and feet, which often feel cold first, rather than warming the rest of the body.\n\n\u201cAn old mountaineering adage is, if you want to keep warm hands, wear a hat,\u201d Dr. Tipton said.\n\nAthletes do best when they keep their head and torso warm. That\u2019s because the body\u2019s first defense against cold is to shut down blood flow to the extremities, essentially sacrificing the hands and feet to maintain the temperature of the heart, lungs and brain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe temperature of the hands and feet, however, dominates a person\u2019s perception of thermal comfort. In other words, the athletes may feel colder than they actually are.\n\nFor elite athletes, feeling cold can affect performance in several ways. The discomfort becomes a distraction. Hands and feet can become numb and lose motor function \u2014 a problem for biathletes who stop midrace to fire guns. Then there is something called \u201ccold-induced diuresis\u201d \u2014 as the body concentrates blood flow to key body parts, blood pressure rises and urination increases. That can lead to a corresponding loss in blood volume \u2014 a hazard for endurance athletes.\n\nAnd if athletes get cold enough to begin shivering, that can spell real trouble. When shivering is induced in a research setting, the study subject typically feels extremely tired after the experiment and the next day as well, Dr. Tipton said, since it causes \u201cmuscles to work against each other in asynchronous fashion.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWarm drinks do little to warm the body, but holding and sipping a hot beverage in the cold do offer psychological benefits.
