View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShe said Mr. Pacelle had \u201cdone nothing wrong.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhich red-blooded male hasn\u2019t sexually harassed somebody?\u201d she added. \u201cWomen should be able to take care of themselves.\u201d On Friday, Ms. Brunson resigned from the board.\n\nBut some people who worked with Mr. Pacelle said they believed the board had erred by not firing him.\n\nAlison Schiebelhut, 36, an employee since 2010, said in an interview that she had a consensual relationship with Mr. Pacelle from 2002 to 2003, when she was an intern at the Humane Society. She then returned to the organization in 2010 to do legal and policy work.\n\nOn more than one occasion after 2010, she said, Mr. Pacelle summoned her to his office and pressured her for sex. She said she refused and once tried to placate him with a hug. After hugging her goodbye, he turned her around, pushed her over his desk and rubbed his genitals against her, she said.\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018I\u2019m going to elbow you really hard right now if you don\u2019t stop,\u2019\u201d she recalled. \u201cI stood up for myself, and then he just went and sat down. He never hit on me again.\u201d\n\nMs. Schiebelhut, who said she spoke this week to the law firm investigating Mr. Pacelle, said she did not report the incidents to her superiors at the time, but was confident they would have taken action had she done so.\n\nPeggy Kokernot Kaplan, a former chairwoman of an advisory council for the Humane Society, said in an email that she had learned of sexual harassment at the organization after she stepped down in 2014.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI also heard so many undercurrents from women afraid to speak up for fear of retaliation if they pursued work with another animal organization, or they simply didn\u2019t feel their voices would be heard if they did speak up,\u201d she said.\n\nLate Friday, Kitty Block was named acting president and chief executive of the Humane Society. Ms. Block, a lawyer, is currently president of Humane Society International, the global affiliate of the Humane Society of the United States.\n\nOne women\u2019s group applauded the decision but said that questions remained about the leadership of the animal welfare group.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s good that he\u2019s gone, but we have to question this board and the culture of the Humane Society,\u201d said Toni Van Pelt, president of the National Organization for Women.\n\nMs. Van Pelt said the board members needed to apologize to the women who were harassed and ask Mr. Pacelle to do the same.\n\n\u201cI think this is not the end of this story for the Humane Society with the way this board voted,\u201d Ms. Van Pelt said.", "title": "Humane Society C.E.O. Resigns Amid Sexual Harassment Allegations", "authors": ["Julie Bosman", "Matt Stevens", "Jonah Engel Bromwich"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "While Hardaway has had his rocky moments this season, missing 20 games because of a stress injury in his left leg, he has provided the Knicks with the scoring power they hoped he would bring and has shown he\u2019s capable of handling a larger role. The Knicks have played like a 48-win team when he is on the court, according to the statistical analysis website Cleaning the Glass, and a 28-win team when he sits. Entering Friday night, he was 11th among small forwards in real plus-minus, an advanced statistic that estimates a player\u2019s affect on a team\u2019s performance.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s taken on the role of one of the players we can build with,\u201d Coach Jeff Hornacek said.\n\nHardaway\u2019s return to the Knicks was both a surprise and a reflection of what his exile from New York had done for him. His journey was bookended by two phone calls from two Knicks executives, two years apart. In between, Hardaway Jr. had to change the player he was.\n\nHis first tenure with the Knicks ended on the night of the 2015 N.B.A. draft. He was with two teammates watching the event at Clyde Frazier\u2019s Wine and Dine \u2014 the Midtown Manhattan restaurant owned by the Knicks legend Walt Frazier \u2014 when he received a call. Hardaway stepped outside to take it, only to hear Phil Jackson, the team president, and General Manager Steve Mills tell him he had been traded. They wished him the best, he recalled, and some 30 seconds later the trade was made public. He had been dealt to the Hawks for a first-round pick. Hardaway walked back into the restaurant, grabbed his belongings and went home.\n\nThe deal hurt. He spent the next few weeks processing his fate. The Knicks had taken him 24th over all in 2013 and he averaged double-digit scoring over his first two seasons. He was not a star, but he\u2019d shown promise.\n\nIn Atlanta, he would have to start anew. Hardaway had suffered a right wrist injury late in the 2014-15 season and had not fully recovered. His summer workouts were affected, and he arrived to his new team out of shape.", "title": "Humbled in the N.B.A.\u2019s Shadows, Tim Hardaway Jr. Returns to the Spotlight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "The seeming contradiction between the analysis based on partisan symmetry and one based on simulated nonpartisan congressional districts gets at the heart of what may be the next big debate in gerrymandering: whether nonpartisan maps should strive for partisan symmetry, or whether they should try to avoid political considerations altogether.\n\nThe question is important because both methods of analysis are routinely employed to identify Republican gerrymanders.\n\nAnd it is likely to continue to be a question, because it emerges when Democrats are at a geographic disadvantage, as they often tend to be. Just look at Pennsylvania. Democrats waste more votes than Republicans by carrying urban areas, like Pittsburgh or Philadelphia, by more lopsided margins than the Republicans carry their best areas. The result is that the rest of the state, and therefore the rest of its districts, tend to favor Republicans.\n\nIf one believes that partisan symmetry should be a goal in redistricting, the new map is eminently fair. It gives both parties a similar chance to translate their votes to seats, and makes no compromises to do so; it still admirably adheres to standard nonpartisan criteria like compactness or minimizing county splits.\n\nThe Upshot analysis also helps address a more arcane matter in the debate about the new court-ordered map: why many nonpartisan analysts thought it favored Democrats, even though it seemed to score well \u2014 it wasn\u2019t an outlier \u2014 by the measure of Mr. Chen\u2019s analysis. The reason is simple: Most nonpartisan analysts have judged the map by today\u2019s electoral landscape, while Mr. Chen\u2019s analysis used elections from 2008 and 2010.\n\nBack then, Pennsylvania\u2019s political geography did not pose such a severe challenge to Democrats. But since then, the Democrats\u2019 geographic disadvantage has worsened. State and national Democrats lost ground in traditionally Democratic areas in western and northeastern Pennsylvania where the party still excelled as late as 2008 and 2010; they gained additional ground in many urban and suburban areas where Democrats already had an advantage. As a result, Mr. Chen\u2019s simulations imply that Democrats were at a notable geographic disadvantage in 2016, but not 2008 or 2010.\n\nWhatever the limitations of these simulations, the fact remains that the court seemed to find this sort of analysis persuasive. The strong Democratic performance on the remedial map adopted last week may imply that the map was drawn with consideration for attaining partisan symmetry, and perhaps even specifically by the measure of average Democratic performance in 2016 statewide elections.", "title": "Hundreds of Simulated Maps Show How Well Democrats Fared in Pennsylvania", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Balint Ablonczy, who followed the election for the magazine, said that the opposition had grown used to a long string of Fidesz victories in the past decade, and that this victory was a cause for optimism for it.\n\nHodmezovasarhely in many ways stands for both the successes and failures of nearly eight years of governments led by Mr. Orban. The city, widely seen as loyal to prime minister, has benefited under the tutelage of Mr. Lazar, the chief of staff and a former mayor, who continued to sit in on town hall meetings. Its infrastructure was improved and planning started on a light-rail line to connect Hodmezovasarhely to the nearby city of Szeged, where many residents commute to work.\n\nBut the local Fidesz leadership faced accusations of cronyism, often in the distribution of European Union funding, that, as in the rest of the country, have grown louder.\n\nEarlier this year the European Anti-Fraud Office announced that it was investigating almost three dozen public lighting projects in Hungary run by a company once controlled by Mr. Orban\u2019s son-in-law. The first such project was completed in Hodmezovasarhely, and news reports, which have suggested that the project was a pilot for later ones, described some of the practices involved as comparable to those used by organized crime.\n\nSuch accusations, which the leadership denied, appeared to have helped the winning candidate, who mobilized new voters to go to the ballots.\n\n\u201cCorruption is like slow poison,\u201d said Robert Laszlo, a researcher who specializes in elections at Political Capital, an independent think tank in Budapest, the capital. \u201cPeople go along with it for a while, but there is a level beyond which people have had enough, when it\u2019s really obvious.\u201d\n\nWinning in a place like Hodmezovasarhely could be a catalyst for the opposition. Although the restructuring of Hungary\u2019s election system has helped Mr. Orban remain in power, Mr. Laszlo pointed out that Fidesz and the Christian Democratic People\u2019s Party, its coalition partner, received a smaller share of the vote than the opposition in the last general election in 2014.", "title": "Hungary\u2019s Opposition Sees Hope After Orban\u2019s Candidate Falls", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Hungary joined the European Union in 2004, but Mr. Orban\u2019s rise as an autocrat and a threat to liberal democracy as established in the bloc has been accompanied by increasingly strident views toward migrants ever since hundreds of thousands passed through the country on their way to Northern Europe in 2015.\n\nThe Hungarian government has repeatedly accused Mr. Soros \u2014 a Hungarian-American who has spent millions backing organizations that promote liberal democracy and open borders in Europe \u2014 of plotting to destabilize the continent by allowing millions of migrants to settle in Europe. (Mr. Soros issued a rebuttal to the government\u2019s claims.)\n\nMr. Soros began his work in Hungary, the country where he was born, in the 1980s before the fall of the Iron Curtain. Mr. Orban was among the recipients of scholarships from foundations sponsored by the financier during the transition to democracy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn 1991, he founded Central European University and gave it a generous endowment, which stood at 500 million euros, or about $610 million, last year, creating one of the most modern and sought-after centers for the social sciences in the country and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe threat to close it was part of relentless government campaign to associate Mr. Soros with the migration crisis and to persuade Hungarians that he was educating and financing opposition to Mr. Orban\u2019s government.\n\nAs Hungary prepares for elections in April that are widely expected to hand Mr. Orban four more years as prime minister, the campaign has grown more intense. Visitors to Hungary this winter saw a country in which Mr. Soros was depicted as a public enemy.\n\nLarge billboards were a frequent presence throughout the country, and advertisements on radio, television and the internet all had the same message: Mr. Soros is organizing mass migration to Hungary and the rest of Europe.\n\nLast month, the government proposed the so-called Stop Soros Bill, which would ban organizations judged to support migration and tax financing they receive from organizations abroad.\n\n\u201cThe government wants to arbitrarily label, malign and separate from society certain N.G.O.s it dislikes\u201d and, eventually, to force them to cease their operations, the Hungarian Helsinki Committee, which provides legal assistance to asylum seekers among others, said in a statement.", "title": "Hungary\u2019s Soros-Backed University Is Reaccredited", "authors": ["Palko Karasz"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was speed-walking through Grand Central to catch a Metro-North train. I saw someone ahead of me in the crowd eating a giant chocolate chip cookie. I wanted a snack, but I didn\u2019t have time to stop.\n\nJust then, I saw a man outside Zaro\u2019s holding a tray of giant chocolate chip cookies. He was standing still, which made me wonder whether he was handing out free samples. I slowed down to get a closer look, and was dismayed to see that the tray was full \u2014 there were no spaces left empty by people taking a cookie. It had been too much to hope for.\n\nThen the man beckoned me toward him. I approached.\n\n\u201cYou can take one cookie,\u201d he said, to my surprise and delight.\n\nI munched on the cookie happily all the way to Track 16. Once I was on the train, I discovered that the sweet exchange had not gone unnoticed: The passengers in front and in back of me congratulated me on scoring the fresh-baked treat.", "title": "Hungry Eyes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis book had to be finished,\u201d he said in a telephone interview. \u201cKnowing how horrible this guy was, there was this feeling of, you\u2019re not going to silence another victim. Michelle died, but her testimony is going to get out there.\u201d\n\nShortly after her death, Mr. Oswalt recruited Billy Jensen, an investigative journalist, and Paul Haynes, who worked closely with Ms. McNamara on the book as a researcher, to comb through her handwritten notes and the roughly 3,500 files on her computer and piece together the story she set out to tell.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll Be Gone in the Dark,\u201d due out Feb. 27, is both a vivid and meticulous investigation of a twisted predator who terrorized quiet, upper middle-class communities in California for nearly a decade, and a wrenching personal account from a writer who became consumed by her subject. It\u2019s drawn accolades from some of the country\u2019s top crime and horror writers, including Stephen King, Michael Connelly, Megan Abbott and Gillian Flynn, who wrote an introduction to the book.\n\nThe tragedy of Ms. McNamara\u2019s death became a meta-narrative running through the book. Its pages are punctuated with recurring editor\u2019s notes that serve as a reminder that the author, who is so palpably present on the page, is absent from the world. She wrote frankly about the psychological toll the project took on her, how immersing herself in the grisly details left her emotionally frayed. \u201cThere\u2019s a scream permanently lodged in my throat now,\u201d Ms. McNamara wrote.\n\nRather than attempting to mimic her voice and flesh out fragmentary chapters, or condense her sprawling research into a taut true crime narrative, Mr. Haynes and Mr. Jensen let the jagged edges of the unfinished project show. They preserved her completed chapters, which recount the killer\u2019s attacks in unsparing detail and examine his methodology, and explore her own fascination with unsolved crimes and her evolution as an amateur detective. Other chapters were pieced together from her notes, and are marked with disclaimers. Some sections read like raw, unfiltered research: one mesmerizing chapter consists entirely of a transcript from Ms. McNamara\u2019s interview with Paul Holes, a criminalist in the Contra Costa sheriff\u2019s office.\n\nPhoto\n\nToward the end of the book, just as Ms. McNamara\u2019s investigation seems to be gaining momentum and the killer\u2019s hazy profile begins to come into focus, it grinds to a halt. An editor\u2019s note explains how, after Ms. McNamara died, Mr. Haynes and Mr. Jensen were brought in to \u201ctie up loose ends and organize the materials Michelle left behind.\u201d In that final section, Mr. Haynes and Mr. Jensen lay out some of the avenues that Ms. McNamara had planned to explore. They describe what they found on her laptop \u2014 old maps and aerial photographs of Goleta, the site of multiple murders, images of shoe prints found at crime scenes, and a spreadsheet with names and addresses of men who competed on a 1976 high school cross-country team (she thought the perpetrator might be a runner, based on victims\u2019s descriptions of his muscular legs). They explore the potential for using D.N.A. and genealogy databases to identify the killer\u2019s family, which Ms. McNamara believed was the best route for finding a criminal who had evaded investigators for four decades.\n\nIt took Mr. Haynes and Mr. Jensen about a year to put the book together, and one can feel their frustration at wrestling with all of the evidence and theories that Ms. McNamara compiled, and still coming up empty.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Haynes, who worked closely with Ms. McNamara for several years, was stunned and devastated by her death, he said. He also had to wrestle with the sweeping territory Ms. McNamara intended to cover.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a very ambitious book to write, about a case like this with a scope as vast as it is,\u201d Mr. Haynes said. \u201cThe question was, what holes should we attempt to patch?\u201d\n\nMs. McNamara became fascinated with unsolved crimes when she was growing up in Oak Park, Ill., the youngest of six siblings in a large Irish Catholic family. When Ms. McNamara was 14, a young woman named Kathleen Lombardo was murdered near the McNamaras\u2019s home. More curious than afraid, Ms. McNamara went to the alley where the body was found, and picked up shards of the victim\u2019s broken Walkman. The killer was never caught.\n\nShe was living in Los Angeles and writing screenplays and TV pilots when she met Mr. Oswalt in 2003, at one of his comedy shows. They went on a few dates and bonded over their shared obsession with serial killers. They got married a couple of years later, and Mr. Oswalt urged her to channel her grim hobby into writing. In 2006, she launched her website, True Crime Diary, where she chronicled hundreds of unsolved crimes.\n\nIn 2011, she wrote on her blog about a string of unsolved rapes and murders from the 1970s and 1980s that were committed by an unidentified man who was known as the East Area Rapist and the Original Night Stalker. \u201cI\u2019m obsessed,\u201d she wrote. \u201cIt\u2019s not healthy.\u201d For a true crime addict, the case was tantalizingly complex. So much was known about his methods and even his psychology, yet the killer had thwarted investigators for decades. He was a meticulous planner who stalked his targets in advance, learning their daily routines before breaking into their homes. He brought his own precut ligatures to tie victims up, and always wore a mask. He stole objects that had sentimental value for the victims, like engraved jewelry and class rings. He grew increasingly confident, and went from assaulting women who were home alone to attacking couples in their bedrooms. She gave him a catchier name: the Golden State Killer.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. McNamara wrote about the case for Los Angeles magazine, and signed a book deal with Harper several months later.\n\nThe research consumed her, and began to weigh on her. She suffered from insomnia and anxiety. Once, she panicked because she woke up to a scraping sound: A neighbor was dragging his trash can to the curb in the middle of the night, Mr. Oswalt said. Another time, when Mr. Oswalt tiptoed into their bedroom, trying not to wake her, she mistook him for an intruder and jumped out of bed and swung a lamp at his head. She felt an obligation to solve the case, and was devastated each time she developed a promising theory or zeroed in on a suspect but failed to find sufficient evidence.\n\n\u201cShe had overloaded her mind with information with very dark implications,\u201d Mr. Oswalt said.\n\nMr. Oswalt wasn\u2019t aware of all the prescriptions she was taking or what the medications were for, he said. Both of them led busy work lives and were devoted parents to their then 7-year-old daughter, Alice, and Ms. McNamara seemed to be managing the stress. It wasn\u2019t until he saw the coroner\u2019s report months after her death that he realized that Ms. McNamara was coping in part by taking prescription drugs.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s so clear that the stress led her to make some bad choices in terms of the pharmaceuticals she was using,\u201d he said. \u201cShe just took this stuff on, and she didn\u2019t have the years of being a hardened detective to compartmentalize it.\u201d\n\nMr. Oswalt, who married the actress Meredith Salenger last year, said he still thinks there\u2019s a chance the killer will eventually be caught, due in part to the work Ms. McNamara did and the attention it brought to a decades old cold case.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. McNamara believed that too. In a letter to the killer that appears at the end of \u201cI\u2019ll Be Gone in the Dark,\u201d she addresses him directly, and says it\u2019s only a matter of time until officers arrive at his door. \u201cThis is how it ends for you,\u201d she writes.", "title": "Michelle McNamara Hunted, and Was Haunted by, the Golden State Killer", "authors": ["Alexandra Alter"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s easy to discount water\u2019s importance in the kitchen. After all, it has no flavor, and more often than not it\u2019s left off ingredient lists, making it seem like an afterthought. Yet water is an essential element of almost everything we cook and eat, and it affects the flavor and texture of all our food. This is in part because many ingredients \u2014 including all fruits and vegetables \u2014 contain some water, which they\u2019ll start to release when they\u2019re cut, salted and heated. And water affects how an ingredient will brown. The temperatures required for caramelization and browning almost always far exceed the boiling point of water. So the presence of water on the surface of a food, or on the bottom of a pan, is a signal that browning can\u2019t yet occur. And in a lidded pot, steam \u2014 water\u2019s gaseous alter ego \u2014 will condense, return to its former state and drip back inside.\n\nRemember this when you set out to caramelize the huge pile of onions for your panade, and use it to your advantage. Slide the heap of onions into the heated oil, and add a pinch of salt, which will begin to draw water out. Give the onions a stir, release some steam and set the lid on the pan. Let the onions wilt and soften. Now that you\u2019ve drawn the bulk of the water out of the onions, remove the lid, increase the heat and let that water cook away so that browning can commence.\n\nWater also affects flavor in a simpler way: Add it to dilute, and remove it \u2014 or let it evaporate \u2014 to intensify flavor. When introducing his panade recipe, Olney emphasized that the precise measurements don\u2019t matter much. \u201cThe important thing,\u201d he wrote, \u201cis that there should be lots of onion, lots of bread and lots of cheese in relation to the amount of water.\u201d Increase the proportion of liquid, and you\u2019ll turn this dish into a less filling \u2014 but no less delicious \u2014 first course: soup. Because I\u2019m always looking to boost flavor, I\u2019m quick to replace water with stock, as I urge you to do with this dish. But no matter what you\u2019re cooking, you can consider replacing water with another, more savory liquid, be it chopped canned tomatoes, coconut milk or wine, to weave in an extra strand of flavor.", "title": "I Buy Fancy Bread Just to Let It Grow Stale. Here\u2019s Why.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "This is no indictment of suburbia. I fully enjoy the trappings of my suburban life \u2014 the schools, the space, the fawns in our backyard. My husband and I bought our house in West Orange, N.J., after first renting 10 minutes away in Montclair. We entered the deal aware that we were forever signing away our previous life in Brooklyn. I accepted the bargain because I like the slower pace and the small-town vibe. But I have also made peace with the fact that the city is no longer at my doorstep, and that my quaint downtown strip is no New York.\n\nI, of course, am not alone. In 2017, home sales hit a 35-year high in Westchester County and a 14-year high in Nassau County, according to Jonathan J. Miller, the president of Miller Samuel Real Estate Appraisers and Consultants. \u201cCity costs have risen more than the cost of a home\u201d in the suburbs, Mr. Miller said. \u201cWe can see that in the massive migration in the last three or four years of city dwellers.\u201d\n\nOver the past 25 years, the number of people commuting across the Hudson River has grown by 28 percent, to 320,000 people a day, with bus trips up 83 percent and nearly tripling the number of rail trips in and out of Penn Station, according to a 2017 Regional Plan Association report.\n\nCompanies like PicketFencer and NeighborhoodScout offer services that play destination matchmaker for these newcomers. But until you get here, it\u2019s hard to realize how far you have actually gone. Train and bus schedules are deceptively optimistic. Talk to real estate brokers and they reinforce the rosy narrative, rattling off options \u2014 the jitney stops at the corner! There\u2019s a park-n-ride five minutes away! You can walk to the train!\n\nMaps don\u2019t do the situation justice either. Just ask Ilana Dubrovsky, 32. When she was considering moving out of Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, with her husband, Allen Razam, 40, and their two children, she pulled out a map and drew a circle around the city. She limited her search to towns less than an hour away. She settled on South Orange, N.J., where she and her husband bought a six-bedroom house in 2014. \u201cI wanted that access. I wanted to see our friends,\u201d said Ms. Dubrovsky, who works in sales.\n\nDo you want to know how many times she has been to Brooklyn in the past four years? Twice.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s such a pain in the butt,\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t want to put two kids on the train, so then I drive. Last time it took us an hour to get from Bay Ridge to Park Slope. An hour! Do you know how many places I go to in an hour in New Jersey?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTo her surprise, Ms. Dubrovsky, who works from home, found that she did not miss her old stamping grounds. Why battle crowds and traffic to go to Prospect Park when there\u2019s a nature reserve with a zoo and miniature golf up the road? \u201cI just don\u2019t have the patience for the city anymore,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer husband, however, a real estate broker and personal trainer, still works in Brooklyn, and leaves the house at 4 a.m. every morning to beat the traffic.\n\nLeave Brooklyn and you trade Sahadi\u2019s grocery for impromptu barbecues with a dozen neighbors. Have you seen the size of the parking lot at Costco? You can really load up on burgers. Join the town pool, and you spread out your towel on the grass \u2014 yes, there\u2019s grass at the pool \u2014 and wait for friends from the neighborhood to just show up.\n\nThe perks make it easier to forget the two miserable hours you spent commuting on the train this morning when a city friend asks what it\u2019s like to live out here. Instead, you focus on the charm. Did I tell you about those cute fawns in the yard? And, of course, there are the happy Park Slope transplants.\n\nThis might explain how Jennifer and Mark Loga ended up buying a four-bedroom house in Maplewood last December without realizing how long their new commutes would soon be. \u201cEverything that we heard was that it was really convenient,\u201d Mrs. Loga, 31, told me in January when she was eight months pregnant. It was about three weeks after they had moved from Jersey City. The couple had lived in Brooklyn before that.\n\n\u201cNobody was like, \u2018Yeah, it\u2019s a great area, but your commute is going to be horrible,\u2019\u201d she said. Mrs. Loga works in marketing near Madison Square Park and Mr. Loga, 32, a civil engineer, works in the Financial District. \u201cDid we think it was going to be an hour and a half each way? No.\u201d\n\nWondering how buyers can arrive here unprepared for what\u2019s ahead, I called Leslie Kunkin, a real estate broker who I met one night in 2010 while trapped on a bus for three hours in a snowstorm. Finally, at 3 a.m., we were dropped off on a deserted Montclair street corner to trudge home in knee high snow. Yet, somehow, the odyssey didn\u2019t completely sour me on the suburbs and Ms. Kunkin sold me my house three years later.\n\nIn December, Ms. Kunkin and a group of other brokers started an agency, West of Hudson Realty Group, because Montclair is, you know, west of the Hudson River. \u201cDespite our snowstorm, I stand behind our commute,\u201d she said, describing the commute, on the whole, as \u201camazing.\u201d\n\n\u201cSure you get stuck in traffic,\u201d she said. But compared with the subway, the ride to the suburbs \u201cis so much more civilized.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom Ms. Kunkin\u2019s perspective, a ride where you can usually get a plush seat with some elbow room offsets that rigid train schedule.\n\nI asked Mrs. Loga if she regretted her decision, or if the charm of a conductor who stamps your ticket takes the edge off. \u201cYou have all these great things, but it\u2019s the one little blemish,\u201d she said. \u201cIf you can deal with it, you\u2019re fine.\u201d\n\nAnd if you can\u2019t, well, then maybe you end up working from home.", "title": "I Can See New York From My House!", "authors": ["Ronda Kaysen", "Right At Home"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Though Ms. Haley\u2019s presentation missed the mark, and no one other than the national security elite will even read the strategy, it won\u2019t matter. We\u2019ve seen this before: a campaign built on the politicization of intelligence and shortsighted policy decisions to make the case for war. And the American people have apparently become so accustomed to executive branch warmongering \u2014 approved almost unanimously by the Congress \u2014 that such actions are not significantly contested.\n\nSo far, news organizations have largely failed to refute false narratives coming out of the Trump White House on Iran. In early November, news outlets latched onto claims by unnamed American officials that newly released documents from Osama bin Laden\u2019s compound represented \u201cevidence of Iran\u2019s support of Al Qaeda\u2019s war with the United States.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a vivid reminder of Vice President Cheney\u2019s desperate attempts in 2002-03 to conjure up evidence of Saddam Hussein\u2019s relationship with Al Qaeda from detainees at Guant\u00e1namo Bay. It harks back to the C.I.A. director George Tenet\u2019s assurances to Mr. Powell that the connection between Saddam Hussein and Osama bin Laden was ironclad in the lead-up to his United Nations presentation. Today, we know how terribly wrong Mr. Tenet was.\n\nToday, the analysts claiming close ties between Al Qaeda and Iran come from the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, which vehemently opposes the Iran nuclear deal and unabashedly calls for regime change in Iran.\n\nIt seems not to matter that 15 of the 19 hijackers on Sept. 11 were Saudis and none were Iranians. Or that, according to the United States intelligence community, of the groups listed as actively hostile to the United States, only one is loosely affiliated with Iran, and Hezbollah doesn\u2019t make the cut. More than ever the Foundation for Defense of Democracies seems like the Pentagon\u2019s Office of Special Plans that pushed falsehoods in support of waging war with Iraq.\n\nThe Trump administration\u2019s case for war with Iran ranges much wider than Ms. Haley\u2019s work. We should include the president\u2019s decertification ultimatum in January that Congress must \u201cfix\u201d the Iran nuclear deal, despite the reality of Iran\u2019s compliance; the White House\u2019s pressure on the intelligence community to cook up evidence of Iran\u2019s noncompliance; and the administration\u2019s choosing to view the recent protests in Iran as the beginning of regime change. Like the Bush administration before, these seemingly disconnected events serve to create a narrative in which war with Iran is the only viable policy.\n\nAs I look back at our lock-step march toward war with Iraq, I realize that it didn\u2019t seem to matter to us that we used shoddy or cherry-picked intelligence; that it was unrealistic to argue that the war would \u201cpay for itself,\u201d rather than cost trillions of dollars; that we might be hopelessly na\u00efve in thinking that the war would lead to democracy instead of pushing the region into a downward spiral.\n\nThe sole purpose of our actions was to sell the American people on the case for war with Iraq. Polls show that we did. Mr. Trump and his team are trying to do it again. If we\u2019re not careful, they\u2019ll succeed.", "title": "Opinion | I Helped Sell the False Choice of War Once. It\u2019s Happening Again.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "The video above is based on the following letter, which I wrote to my senator, Marco Rubio, in the wake of the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School. I urge you to hold your elected officials accountable by sending them a letter and tagging them on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and whatever other social media platforms you use.\n\nDear Senator Rubio,\n\nI am writing to you as a former employee of your Tallahassee, Florida office. My sophomore year at Florida State University, I accepted a non-partisan internship at your Tallahassee, Fla. location. As an eager, young Political Science student, I was excited to get my foot in the door of a Senator\u2019s office; however, I was dismayed when your staff told me that you probably wouldn\u2019t be present for the duration of my internship.\n\nAs it turns out, they were right \u2013 I worked for your team for five whole months, twenty hours a week, and never once saw you in the office.\n\nAs an intern, I was tasked with fielding constituents\u2019 calls and writing their comments into a call log, which was sent to you at the end of each week. Supposedly, you used this log to address the needs of constituents, but I am skeptical that you ever actually read through it.\n\nNow, three years later, I am one of those concerned constituents pleading for change from you, our elected Florida official. I am afraid, though, that my pleas for help will fall on the ears of another intern and go no further \u2013 but you can prove me wrong by taking action against gun violence.\n\nWhen I was 19-years-old, FSU \u2013 my home away from home \u2013 experienced a campus shooting. On November 20, 2015, Myron May approached the Strozier Library on FSU\u2019s campus and opened fire on students using a .380-caliber handgun. Three of my fellow colleagues were injured. May was mentally disturbed and consumed by paranoia to a point where he sought to murder people on my campus.\n\nThankfully, during the shooting I was not at the scene of the crime, but rather, across the street sitting in my dorm. While I studied for my upcoming finals, students were being shot a few yards away from me.\n\nWhen I was 20-years-old, yet another community I hold close to my heart suffered a mass shooting. On June 12, 2016, Omar Mateen killed 49 people and wounded 58 others using an AR-15 style-rifle at Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla. Mateen specifically targeted LGBTQ+ Latinx/people-of-color that evening.\n\nI was about one mile up the same street from the massacre that night. Again, a blood bath occurred yards away from me and my friends.\n\nLess than 7 months later, tragedy struck while I was visiting home for winter break. January 6, 2017, Esteban Santiago-Ruiz used a Walther PPS 9mm semi-automatic pistol to gun down five individuals and injure six others at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The Broward County airport my family used to travel our entire lives became a warzone.\n\nToday, I am a 21-year-old college graduate and am writing this with great despair \u2013 and even more anger. On February 14, 2018, Nikolas Cruz used an AR-15 style-rifle to murder 17 Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School students and staff, and injured at least 14 more.\n\nI sat in my parents\u2019 home, just around the corner from my alma mater, as children were being slaughtered. Once again, I sat in a silo of safety as a bloody massacre literally played out across the street.\n\nI\u2019ve lived in the serene town of Parkland since I was three-years-old, and attended MSD for four formative years of my life. The hallways where I once shared laughter, curiosity, and hope are now crime scenes. Members of my community have lost their lives. Students and staff of MSD are traumatized. My tight-knit community of loving people is broken.\n\nI am in shock that one of the deadliest mass shootings in American history happened in Parkland, Fla., my hometown \u2013 the safest place in Florida.\n\nIn my short lifetime, these countless acts of terror have plagued communities throughout the United States with unimaginable grief, and it is time for this pattern to stop. I will no longer feel helpless nor sit idly by while these atrocities occur.\n\nI will not accept mass shootings as the norm.\n\nIt is YOUR responsibility as our elected official to pass laws that protect your constituents. This isn\u2019t about party politics - this is about human lives. I am begging you to implement a systematic plan that will end the mass shooting epidemic in Florida and beyond, starting with:\n\n\u00b7 Stricter gun licensing\n\n\u00b7 Recognizing gun violence as a public health issue\n\n\u00b7 Funding research on gun violence and gun violence prevention\n\n\u00b7 Extensive background checks for gun purchases\n\n\u00b7 Close loopholes in gun purchasing (i.e. gun shows)\n\n\u00b7 Implementing a buffer period between purchasing a rifle and taking it home\n\nIt is shameful that I have to write this and beg you to do SOMETHING.\n\nI hope you have read my letter free from the influence of wealthy lobbyists who may impede your senatorial judgment. I hope you read this letter at all.\n\nRespectfully, your former intern and concerned Parkland citizen,\n\nShana Miranda Rosenthal", "title": "Opinion | I Interned for Senator Rubio. Now I\u2019m Begging Him to Act on Guns.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "To be clear, it\u2019s not brave to quit Twitter, or righteous (I\u2019m still on Facebook, which is just a differently shaped moral stockyard), or noteworthy. Quitting Twitter is just a thing that you can do. I mention it only because there was a time when I didn\u2019t think it was a thing that I could do, and then I did it, and now my life is better.\n\nI\u2019m frequently approached by colleagues, usually women, who ask me about quitting Twitter with hushed titillation, as if I\u2019ve escaped a cult or broken a particularly seductive taboo. Well, here\u2019s what my new life is like: I don\u2019t wake up with a pit in my stomach every day, dreading what horrors accrued in my phone overnight. I don\u2019t get dragged into protracted, bad-faith arguments with teenage boys about whether poor people deserve medical care, or whether putting nice guys in the friend zone is a hate crime. I don\u2019t spend hours every week blocking and reporting trolls and screen-grabbing abuse in case it someday escalates into a credible threat. I no longer feel like my brain is trapped in a centrifuge filled with swastikas and Alex Jones\u2019s spittle. Time is finite, and now I have more of it.\n\nAt the same time, I know this conversation is more complicated than that. I\u2019ve lost a large platform to self-promote and make professional connections, which isn\u2019t something many writers can afford to give up (less established writers and marginalized writers most of all \u2014 in a horrid irony, the same writers disproportionately abused on Twitter). I get my news on a slight delay. I seethe at the perception that I ceded any ground to trolls trying to push me out. I will probably never persuade RuPaul to be my friend. Also, I loved Twitter. Twitter is funny and smart and validating and cathartic. It feels, when you are embroiled in it, like the place where everything is happening. (Scoff if you like, but the president of the United States makes major policy announcements there. This is the world now.)\n\nI shouldn\u2019t have had to walk away from all that because for Twitter to take a firm stance against neo-Nazism might have cost it some incalculable sliver of profit. No one should. Sure, as in everything, global culture change would have been better. But I didn\u2019t have global culture change, and I\u2019m better equipped to fight for global culture change now that I\u2019m not locked in eternal whack-a-mole with a sea of angry boy-men, an unknown percentage of which are probably robots.\n\nWhen you deactivate a verified Twitter account (nail-polish emoji), you have one year to log back in or your account \u2014 everything you ever tweeted, every reply in every thread \u2014 is permanently deleted. I always planned to log in and then immediately deactivate again, to re-up for another year. I figured I\u2019d eventually reactivate, even if just for posterity. I was part of some important cultural conversations; I said some smart things before other people said them; I made some good jokes. One time the actor Michael McKean called me \u201cdoodlebug\u201d in an affectionate manner because he liked one of my movie reviews. I wouldn\u2019t mind preserving that.\n\nLast week I realized: I was late. I\u2019d forgotten to log back in. A year had passed. It\u2019s all gone. It\u2019s like I was halfway through a difficult column and asked a thief to watch my laptop while I peed. It\u2019s like a great wind came and blew my problem novel into the river. It\u2019s like I ate a very good sandwich without taking a picture of it. Sometimes it is O.K. to just remember things.", "title": "Opinion | I Quit Twitter and It Feels Great", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Men like Sykes reflect the other dimension, the powerful backlash fueled by a combination of male resentment, anxiety at social change and a newfound freedom in the Age of Trump to say things that were previously beyond the pale.\n\nBacklashes go way back, of course. After Mary Wollstonecraft published her \u201cVindication of the Rights of Woman\u201d in 1792, laying the groundwork for discussions of gender equity, Horace Walpole mocked her as a \u201chyena in petticoats,\u201d and she was savaged for her \u201cwhoredoms.\u201d\n\nFlash forward, and Breitbart reflected the same ethos when it published an article declaring \u201cBirth Control Makes Women Unattractive and Crazy.\u201d But this isn\u2019t just a battle of the sexes, and one reason for hope is that youth and education are sometimes better predictors of attitudes toward women\u2019s rights than gender is. Last year for the first time, Gallup found that a majority of Americans don\u2019t care whether their boss is a man or a woman; Americans under 35 actually prefer a female boss over a male boss by 14 percentage points.\n\nThe most important trend in the world, I believe, is the empowerment of women. This is transforming society and the global economy (although researchers believe that the world would still be $28 trillion richer if gender gaps were bridged).\n\nWhy is a man writing this column? Frankly, because women\u2019s rights aren\u2019t \u201cjust a woman\u2019s issue,\u201d any more than civil rights were \u201cjust a black issue.\u201d We all have an interest in a more fair society \u2014 and if only women speak up for gender equity, they may be dismissed as shrill \u201chyenas.\u201d\n\nWhat matters above all are policies. That means pushing for easier family leave, better child care, more women on boards, and cracking down on sex trafficking and domestic violence. It means helping teenage girls avoid pregnancy, providing locations at work for moms to express milk, and confronting the general tendency to defer to male self-confidence rather than female expertise. It means a determined effort to hold accountable sexual predators even when they\u2019re not Hollywood figures but simply factory supervisors or shift managers at a McDonald\u2019s.\n\nOf course there will be disagreements about policies or about where to draw lines \u2014 about what to make of Aziz Ansari and how to distinguish between the Harvey Weinsteins and the Al Frankens. But those controversies are secondary.\n\nThe fundamental fault line today is between those working toward broader opportunity and those yearning for a mythic past before feminists developed \u201cnasty, snake-filled heads.\u201d To be on the right side of history, we should all, men and women alike, stand on the side of the she-devils.", "title": "Opinion | I Stand With the \u2018She-Devils\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Seven seventh graders arrived at the theater, excited. There were braces and glasses, sneakers and hoodies, teasing and giggles \u2014 all the trappings of tweens. They clapped, whispered, squirmed and guffawed. They quite literally sat on the edge of their seats.\n\nI had invited a handful of 12-year-olds from P.S. 282 in Brooklyn to an early screening of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. (Disney donated the tickets and BAM provided a place to talk afterward.)\n\nIn 23 years as an educator specializing in the relationships of law, society and entertainment in the construction of racial norms and beliefs, I had been keenly following the hype surrounding \u201cBlack Panther\u201d and the argument that the story of an African superhero would benefit black children\u2019s self-esteem. There was even the #BlackPantherChallenge and there were crowdfunding campaigns to send youngsters around the country to see the movie.\n\nBut in all the talk, a crucial element was missing: the voices of black children. What did they actually think of the film, and how did it make them feel?", "title": "I Took 7th Graders to See \u2018Black Panther.\u2019 Here\u2019s What They Said.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "My husband and I fought (again) today about something that happened eight years ago, when we were newly married. He was devastated that I tried to have a cordial relationship with his ex-wife (who wronged him). He felt betrayed that I didn\u2019t mirror his feelings toward her, and abandoned by my attempts to create a workable relationship for their children. Frankly, I can no more apologize and have a hand-holding cry with him than fly to the moon. I am emotionally detached, and he is wildly demonstrative. How to bridge this gap?\n\nS. C.\n\nCreating categories can be comforting, even when they are utter nonsense: the four humors of the ancient Greeks, for instance, or the blood-type diet. Your husband is not upset with you because of your incompatible temperaments. No, he\u2019s distraught because you are not (and I suspect, never were) sorry for your behavior. Any apology you made would be unsatisfying. You feel no actual remorse.\n\nInstead, you made a pragmatic call about the best way to deal with his ex-wife. (You rationalize it still, and I may agree with you.) But deciding how to interact with his ex, early in your marriage, was mostly your husband\u2019s call. You robbed him of that choice, probably accidentally, but you seem not to have acknowledged your mistake.\n\nGive him his due now. Say, \u201cI\u2019m sorry I overstepped with Susan, and even sorrier for dragging my heels in apologizing sincerely. I promise that I have your back.\u201d If that\u2019s too \u201cdemonstrative\u201d for you, get yourself to a therapist. But if you make an honest go of it, you may be amazed at how nicely your different temperaments align.", "title": "I Tried to Befriend My Husband\u2019s Ex. So What?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Before the United States Marine Corps allowed me to carry a live M-16 assault rifle, I went through hundreds of hours of firearms training. Classroom sessions devoted to nomenclature, maintenance and basic operation accounted for more than two weeks of study before I even set eyes on ammunition. For weeks, I carried an M-16 without a magazine \u2014 a dummy weapon, basically. I secured it with a padlock overnight while I slept in the barracks, and unlocked it each morning before chow.\n\nOnly at the shooting range was I allowed to check out magazines and ammo from the armory. The first day at the range I spent 12 hours disassembling, cleaning and reassembling the weapon. I had to do this blindfolded. I had to do this while a drill instructor hurried me, yelling that enemies were at the gate. I had to do this while fellow Marines wept nearby from doing hundreds of burpees as punishment for not being able to reassemble their weapons fast enough.\n\nThe military issue M-16 is the model for the AR-15 assault rifle that the accused shooter used to kill 17 people this month at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla. The shooter bought the weapon lawfully. He received zero hours of mandated training. There is no reason that any civilian, of any age, should possess this rifle.\n\nAt the White House on Wednesday, President Trump suggested that if a football coach at the high school, Aaron Feis, had been armed, he would have saved even more lives than he did, perhaps even his own, because rather than simply shielding students from gunfire, he could have drawn his weapon, fired and killed the assailant \u2014 putting a tidy end to the rampage.", "title": "Opinion | I Was a Marine. I Don\u2019t Want a Gun in My Classroom.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "Whenever I think of those alternate realities, those theories of time where new dimensions split open every time you choose between hot or cold coffee, I feel like hurtling myself into the sun. It\u2019s just too big, there\u2019s too much, and I begin to feel shackled by the \u201cshoulds.\u201d Which decisions might, or might not, make me the person I\u2019m supposed to be? And, sometimes when you order cold brew they give you yesterday\u2019s coffee on ice, and it\u2019s like: Great, why can\u2019t I be in the dimension where I have drinkable coffee?\n\nThere\u2019s something so freeing about abandoning it all, or maybe just the urge to. The way in elementary school my paintings just ended up being a puddle of gray, and the art teacher would sit down with me and ask, \u201cWhat were you going for? What happened?\u201d And I would stare down at my gray puddle, unable to explain what happened.", "title": "I Will Die in This Beautiful Place", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The speed with which the I.O.C. dispensed with Pengilly stands in contrast with the way the organization has dealt with other members whose behavior has drawn scrutiny.\n\nAlex Gilady, one of the I.O.C.\u2019s longest serving members, faces accusations of sexual harassment and assault in Israel. Last year, he announced his temporary resignation from the media company he runs to concentrate on clearing his name. He decided to remain on the I.O.C., however, where he is monitoring the buildup to the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo.\n\nKuwait\u2019s Sheikh Ahmad al-Fahad al-Sabah, a major power broker in Asian sports, remains the head of the body that delivers about $130 million a year in annual grants. He quit all his roles in soccer last year after an official from Guam pleaded guilty to accepting millions of dollars in bribes linked to Sheikh Ahmad. He has not been punished by the I.O.C.\n\nAdams explained that Ahmad, Gilady and Patrick Hickey \u2014 a member from Ireland arrested at the Rio de Janeiro Games in 2016 for ticket scalping \u2014 all continue to deny the claims against them. Hickey has been serving a self-imposed suspension for nearly two years. The I.O.C. has not ruled on any of those cases.\n\nPengilly, 40, is also the vice president of international federation for bobsled and skeleton. His eight-year term with the I.O.C. is scheduled to end on Feb. 25.\n\nHis departure from these Games means both members who abstained from a confidence vote over the I.O.C.\u2019s handling of the Russia affair will be absent from the closing ceremony, when Russia\u2019s banned Olympic committee could be welcomed back. The other member, Canada\u2019s Richard Pound, said he plans to skip the parade because he fears the I.O.C. will decide to restore Russia\u2019s team, its uniform and its flag.\n\nThe Korean authorities demanded apologies from both Pengilly and the I.O.C. after his altercation. The case also highlighted how cultural sensitives have occasionally been strained here.", "title": "I.O.C Orders One of Its Members to Leave Games After Altercation With Guard", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "The 44 or so Olympians being honored \u2014 first with medals, then with a Champagne toast and finally with a new BMW each \u2014 had the option of saying a few words from the podium.\n\nThe few who spoke welcomed the end of the Olympic penalties, but they too expressed a certain defiance that the Russian Olympic team, and by extension the country, had emerged from the Winter Olympics relatively well despite the hurdles involved.\n\nPavel Datsyuk, a former N.H.L. player for the Detroit Red Wings and the captain of the Russian team that won gold in men\u2019s ice hockey, called it a \u201clandmark Olympics\u201d for his country.\n\n\u201cWe did a decent job defending the honor of our country,\u201d he said in thanking the president, attributing the outcome to both the Russian character and support from across this vast land. \u201cThanks for your help, thanks for letting us vindicate to the whole world that our Russian character is not broken and won\u2019t ever be broken.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nRussia\u2019s flag and anthem were missing from the Pyeongchang Games, though more than 160 of the nation\u2019s athletes were able to participate as neutrals called \u201cOlympic Athletes From Russia.\u201d Two of them accounted for half of the failed drug tests at the Pyeongchang Games. Russia was not allowed to march under its flag in the closing ceremony.\n\nRussia\u2019s reinstatement followed a decision on Sunday by the I.O.C.\u2019s executive board, led by Thomas Bach, its president, to bring Russia back into the fold if the remaining drug tests of its athletes from the Pyeongchang Games were confirmed as negative.\n\nScores of Russian athletes, coaches and officials were barred after an investigation into the yearslong conspiracy that peaked at the 2014 Olympics in Sochi, Russia, when the state security apparatus colluded with sports officials to swap drug-tainted urine samples with clean ones in a clandestine, dead-of-night operation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe scandal and its aftermath have led to much upheaval in the global sporting movement, with many athletes and some of the I.O.C.\u2019s own members critical of the way it had been dealt with. Richard Pound, the organization\u2019s longest serving member, boycotted the closing of the Pyeongchang Games in protest. The doping scheme has now tarnished no fewer than three Olympic Games.\n\nAt Sunday\u2019s I.O.C. session, where the plan to rehabilitate Russia was first announced, Nicole Hoevertsz, an official from Aruba tasked with monitoring Russian compliance, said the time had come to move on.\n\n\u201cWe should draw a line, we have to draw a line and look to the future,\u201d she said. After the two failed drug tests by Russian athletes \u2014 by the curler Alexander Krushelnytsky and the bobsledder Nadezhda Sergeeva \u2014 the I.O.C. did not lift the suspension for the closing ceremony, which it had called a possibility.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt the Kremlin, various Russian medalists said that being able to participate in the Olympics was more important than being able to display their national symbols, and several thanked Mr. Putin for allowing them to compete despite the restrictions.\n\nIlya Kovalchuk, a star in both the American and Russian hockey leagues, said in an interview that the most important factor was fulfilling his dream of winning an Olympic gold medal; the other circumstances proved secondary.\n\n\u201cIt was a little different, but we tried not to think about it too much,\u201d he said.\n\nPerhaps the most emotional moment, he said, was when the Russian hockey players began singing their own national anthem instead of the Olympic hymn being played as they were awarded their gold medals.\n\n\u201cEveryone knows where we are from,\u201d he said. \u201cNinety percent of the fans were cheering for us, and there were a lot of Russian flags in the stands. Our friends and families were there, singing, our kids, it was great.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe athletes seemed to consider their \u201cOlympic Athlete From Russia\u201d uniforms something of a historical treasure to be preserved, not a mark of Cain to be discarded.\n\n\u201cAthletes from other countries were coming up to us and saying, \u2018Olympic Athlete From Russia,\u2019 it sounds very honorable, really good; they wanted a name like that,\u201d said Ekaterina Bobrova, a silver medalist in ice dancing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe winners generally attributed the far lower Russian medal count \u2014 with 17 over all, compared with 29 at Sochi, after some were later rescinded for doping \u2014 to the fact that much of the squad was not there.\n\nBut Ms. Bobrova said you could also look at it from the point of view that the Russians did really well winning 17 medals with so many athletes barred.\n\nThat was also a common sentiment at the podium during the ceremony with Mr. Putin, which was held in the round St. Catherine\u2019s Hall, decorated in shades of blue and gold.\n\nAfter a winner\u2019s name was announced, he or she was serenaded to the front of the room by an orchestra of about 30 musicians. All the hockey players walked forward to a blast of brass instruments playing an old Soviet hockey tune, \u201cNo Coward Plays Hockey.\u201d\n\n\u201cCross-country skiing was hit especially hard,\u201d said Yulia Belorukova, who clanked forward wearing her two bronze medals in the sport. \u201cWe had lots of young people on board, but we proved that Russia is clean and that we\u2019re capable of competing for medals in any situation.\u201d\n\nRussia has never accepted the description of a state-controlled doping operation in the country set out in great detail by its former doping laboratory head, Grigory Rodchenkov, and confirmed by three separate investigations. The World Anti-Doping Agency said it would continue to regard Russia\u2019s domestic drug testing organization as noncompliant until it does.\n\nMany of Russia\u2019s top athletes were barred from the 2018 Games because of links to the doping scandal. That led to a weak performance, and a vast downgrade from the doping-fueled success in Sochi, where Russia topped the medals table. Alina Zagitova, a 15-year-old figure skater, beat her compatriot Evgenia Medvedeva in a battle for gold, before the Russians secured the hockey title in an overtime victory over Germany on the final day.\n\nAs well as the Olympic ban, Russia was forced to pay a $15 million fine. The effects of the scandal continue to roil the sports world. Several biathletes, including members of the United States team, have announced that they will not participate in next month\u2019s season-ending competition in Russia, while soccer\u2019s governing body, FIFA, is facing scrutiny just four months before the World Cup in Russia over claims of doping by players from there.", "title": "I.O.C. Reinstates a Russia That Is Defiant and Eager to Move On", "authors": ["Neil Macfarquhar", "Tariq Panja"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Currently, 16 men\u2019s teams play in Davis Cup\u2019s top division, known as the World Group, in a home-and-away format over four rounds interspersed throughout the season, and all live matches are best of five sets.\n\nSome former Davis Cup champions, like Yevgeny Kafelnikov of Russia, consider the proposal a travesty.\n\n\u201cTerrible,\u201d Kafelnikov said in an interview Monday. \u201cThe value and spirit of the whole team competition is gone.\u201d\n\nBut like many influential figures in the game, I.T.F. President David Haggerty is convinced that big moves are necessary to keep the event relevant. Haggerty said the proposal had received unanimous support from the I.T.F.\u2019s board of directors.\n\nThough mild-mannered in person, Haggerty is unafraid to make bold moves (if this one fails, his bid for re-election in 2019 certainly will suffer, too). A former tennis industry executive and a former president of the United States Tennis Association, Haggerty was among those who pushed successfully for a roof over Arthur Ashe Stadium at the U.S. Open and for the U.S.T.A.\u2019s vast new complex at Lake Nona in Orlando, Fla.\n\n\u201cCertainly this is a big decision for the I.T.F.,\u201d Haggerty said by telephone from London on Monday. \u201cWe know the environment has changed in tennis over the last few years. Players are playing later in their careers. It\u2019s a very physical sport, so I think many factors were taken into account.\n\n\u201cAt the same time, if you go back 50 years ago, in Bournemouth they had the first Open tennis event. There had to have been a number of tennis leaders sitting around saying, \u2018Jeez, tennis is O.K., do we really need to make this change? What is it going to do to us? Is it good or bad?\u2019 You never know, so that strength of conviction, they had that at the time. They took a risk, but look how tennis has changed. Perhaps in the future, we will look back on this and say the I.T.F. board took such a risk.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHaggerty also wants a more solid financial base for the I.T.F., which has become the weakest pillar among the sport\u2019s bloated network of governing bodies.\n\nThe money could indeed be transformative: Haggerty said the partnership with Kosmos, the investment firm headed by Piqu\u00e9 and backed by the 52-year-old Japanese billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani, would provide more than $20 million in prize money for the players in the final phase each year.\n\nIf the $3 billion figure is correct, it would also provide the I.T.F., whose main source of revenue is Davis Cup, with an unheard-of influx of cash to fund its own activities, which include developing the game worldwide and running amateur and lower-level professional circuits. Haggerty also said that national federations would benefit.\n\nIf the overhaul is approved, only the seasons ahead will determine who was correct in their assessment: the Kafelnikovs or the Haggertys. But one can understand the lure and the timing. Despite pockets of passion, and a compelling history, Davis Cup is losing traction globally.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere were certainly less extreme potential solutions: A partnership with the ATP Tour; shifting the Davis Cup dates away from such proximity to Grand Slam tournaments; or switching to a biennial format that might have lured the biggest stars.\n\nBut after being thwarted last year in an attempt to tweak the format with smaller changes, like using a neutral-site final and best-of-three-set singles matches, Haggerty doubled down and pushed instead for more radical change.\n\nAt least initially, the event would most likely be held in Asia, Haggerty said, and because of the number of courts required, it would most likely be staged outdoors.\n\n\u201cThe next step in my view to make this event all it could be would be to include the Fed Cup in this tennis extravaganza,\u201d Courier said, referring to the I.T.F\u2019s women\u2019s team competition. \u201cThat should be the ultimate goal.\u201d\n\nFor now, the I.T.F. is focused on expanding Fed Cup\u2019s top division from eight to 16 teams, although Haggerty expressed support for a similar, single-site Fed Cup competition in the future.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the Davis Cup proposal, the plan is for the 18 national teams to be divided into six groups of three for round-robin play over three days. Each team would have four players, and each encounter would include two singles matches and one doubles match. Eight teams would advance to the quarterfinals (the six group winners plus the two best second-place teams) and would be guaranteed a spot in the following year\u2019s final phase.\n\nDuring the week, the strongest eight of the 10 eliminated teams would then play for a place in the following year\u2019s competition against the eight teams who have come through home-and-away qualifying during the Davis Cup\u2019s traditional dates earlier in the season. The semifinals would be played on Saturday, and the final on Sunday.\n\n\u201cThe nice thing is that by the end of the week, you\u2019ll know the 16 teams playing in next year\u2019s event,\u201d Haggerty said.\n\nHe said the 17th and 18th teams would be selected by the I.T.F. and Kosmos \u201cbased on criteria to be determined.\u201d\n\nSuch an overhaul would have been unthinkable in Davis Cup\u2019s heyday, when its prestige was on par with the four Grand Slam tournaments in the 1930s, \u201940s and \u201950s. But those moments are long gone, even if Davis Cup continues to generate big crowds and enthusiasm in several countries, including France, which won the title for the 10th time last year.\n\nBut many leading players and tennis officials have been clamoring for a change in format for decades. In this golden age in the men\u2019s game, the biggest stars \u2014 including Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic \u2014 have all been part of winning Davis Cup teams but have rarely participated at the same time as one another and have faced each other too rarely in the event.\n\nAlso, rival national-team events with shorter formats have surfaced, including the Laver Cup, which was started successfully last year by Roger Federer\u2019s management company, pitting a European Team against an International Team.\n\nBut the biggest threat was the ATP\u2019s recent interest in relaunching the single-week World Team Cup, which could have further reduced top players\u2019 interest in committing to Davis Cup. Piqu\u00e9\u2019s group, with support from Djokovic, first negotiated with the ATP and its executive chairman Chris Kermode about creating such an event before turning to the I.T.F. in late November.\n\nThe result was Monday\u2019s announcement. The Davis Cup \u2014 and tennis \u2014 may never be the same.", "title": "I.T.F. Proposes a Huge Makeover for a Stale Davis Cup", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Does ICE have to let deportees get their affairs in order?\n\nWhile they sometimes do, immigration officers are not required to give arrestees the chance to gather their belongings or even say farewell to their loved ones. Mr. Jamal\u2019s family said that the officers who arrested him, for example, denied them the right to hug him goodbye. And, often, those being arrested may be far from home and family.\n\nDepending on the stage of the deportation process and criminal history, some individuals are allowed to go free on the condition that they commit to voluntarily leave the country within a specified period.\n\nDo contributions to society make any difference?\n\nICE agents are given discretion to decide whether someone should be deported.\n\nThe agency may let someone stay, under supervision, in extenuating circumstances \u2014 if the person is receiving medical treatment or caring for an elderly parent, for example. That appears to have been the case for Mr. Berrones, who reportedly received a one-year stay on his removal that will allow him to continue caring for his ill son.\n\nCommunity pressure, and media attention, has swayed the agency in the past, too.\n\nBut, under President Trump, ICE is using that discretion in favor of detainees less often. The administration\u2019s position is that anyone who is in the United States illegally is a target for deportation. In the last few years of the Obama administration, on the other hand, agents were told to prioritize some groups, like serious criminals and recent arrivals.\n\nSo while family, personal circumstances or contributions to society may be considered, they are less likely to help an individual\u2019s cause now than they once were.\n\nWhat role does a criminal record, or the lack of one, play?\n\nThe Trump administration considers being in the United States without proper documentation to be a crime, a stricter approach than in the past, when immigration offenses were often thought of more like civil infractions.\n\nThat means that the agency takes seriously cases in which the only significant mark on someone\u2019s record is a failure to comply with a deportation order, as it says was true of Mr. Jamal.", "title": "ICE Deportation Cases: Your Questions Answered", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "The top lawyer for the Immigration and Customs Enforcement field office in Seattle has been charged with trying to steal the identities of seven people who were in immigration proceedings.\n\nThe ICE chief counsel, Raphael A. Sanchez, was charged with one count of wire fraud and one count of aggravated identity theft, according to court documents filed on Monday in United States District Court for the Western District of Washington. He allegedly used the personal information \u201cto obtain money and property by means of materially false and fraudulent pretenses\u201d when their cases were under review by ICE, the charging document said.\n\nHis fraud attempts allegedly involved American Express, JP Morgan Chase, Bank of America, Capital One, Citibank and Discover Financial Services. They began in October 2013 and continued through Oct. 25, 2017.\n\nThe documents said the seven people were at various stages of immigration proceedings when Mr. Sanchez had access to their identification information.", "title": "ICE Lawyer Charged With Stealing Immigrants\u2019 Identities", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA man carrying a knife and a hunting rifle opened fire on worshipers on Sunday at an Orthodox church in Kizlyar, in the Dagestan region of Russia, killing at least five people and wounding several others, according to a Russian state news agency.\n\nThe gunman shouted, \u201cAllahu akbar\u201d and began firing, a priest told the local news media. Churchgoers said they had prevented more casualties by closing the door to the church and stopping the attacker from getting inside.\n\nThe man was later shot and killed by security forces on duty at the time, reports said. The assailant was identified only as a 22-year-old man from the region, the Russian news agency Tass said.\n\nThe Islamic State claimed credit for the attack on the church, issuing a bulletin on its Amaq news agency, followed by a lengthier official statement in which the group described the assailant as a \u201csoldier of the caliphate\u201d and provided a nom de guerre for the attacker, Khalil al-Dagestani.\n\nNot long afterward, pro-Islamic State channels on the Telegram app released a video showing a man said to be the assailant sitting before the Islamic State flag, his face covered by a ski mask. A gun and a long knife leaned against the wall behind him, presumably the weapons that would later be used in the attack.\n\nIn the video, the man pledges allegiance to Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Islamic State leader, referring to him as \u201cthe Emir of the believers,\u201d the honorific that Islamic State members reserve for the man they view as their caliph.\n\nWhile the authenticity of the video could not be independently confirmed, Islamic State members and supporters were promoting it online.\n\nThe attack took place in Kizlyar, a town of about 50,000 people on the Terek River delta on the border with Chechnya, Tass said.\n\n300 miles Moscow RUSSIA UKRAINE KAZAKH. DAGESTAN CHECHNYA Kizlyar Black Sea Caspian Sea GEORGIA TURKEY\n\nSunday is the last day before Orthodox Christian Lent. A bearded man ran towards the church shouting, \u2018Allahu akbar.\u2019 \u201d\n\nFour women died at the scene, and a fifth died of her injuries at a hospital, a Health Ministry spokeswoman, Zalina Mourtazalieva, told Tass.
