His head was bloodied, and empty cartridges were scattered nearby. Other images showed what appeared to be a weapon.\n\nDagestan is a predominantly Muslim region between Chechnya and the Caspian Sea and is known for, among other things, widespread nepotism. Its administration has recently undergone a major cleanup that, according to some analysts, is meant to show the central government\u2019s commitment to fighting corruption before presidential elections in March.\n\nBut two separatist wars in Chechnya have spread to Dagestan. In 2015, the Islamic State declared that it had established a \u201cfranchise\u201d in the North Caucasus. It has claimed a number of attacks on the police in Dagestan.\n\nA recent report by the Soufan Group, which offers strategic security intelligence services to governments and multinationals, determined that countries belonging to the former Soviet Union have sent the highest number of foreign fighters to Syria, accounting for about 8,700 of the estimated 40,000 foreigners who have traveled to join the jihad.", "title": "ISIS Claims Deadly Attack on Church in Russian Region of Dagestan", "authors": ["Andrew E. Kramer", "Rukmini Callimachi"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "The prize has only been awarded five previous times: to Nelson Mandela of South Africa (an honorary laureate) and Joaquim A. Chissano of Mozambique in 2007; to Festus G. Mogae of Botswana in 2008; to Pedro de Verona Rodrigues Pires of Cape Verde in 2011; and to Hifikepunye Pohamba of Namibia in 2014. It was supposed to be an annual prize, but in some years, the selection committee apparently has not found suitable candidates for the award.\n\nCritics say the award sets a low bar for African democracy, rewarding leaders merely for leaving office. But Mr. Ibrahim has insisted that the award recognizes \u201cexcellence in leadership.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe continent is home to several so-called leaders for life, including Joseph Kabila of the Democratic Republic of Congo, who has delayed elections for more than a year and overseen a crackdown on dissent; Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, who favors the scrapping of age limits for holding office; and Paul Biya of Cameroon, who has been in power for 35 years and turns 85 on Tuesday.\n\nBut hopes for democracy have revived elsewhere. Last year, Yahya Jammeh of Gambia stepped down under threat of regional military intervention after he lost an election, and Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, who had been in power since 1980, was removed as president after an internal party coup.\n\nFrom late 1989 to 2003, Liberia suffered from two civil wars that claimed an estimated 250,000 lives, displaced millions and shattered infrastructure.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Johnson Sirleaf restructured the military, which, like rebel groups, had committed atrocities during the civil war, and had even once imprisoned her. She also reformed the police and established a Truth and Reconciliation Commission. Ms. Johnson Sirleaf shared the Nobel Peace Prize in 2011, shortly before she won a second term.\n\nHowever, her government was criticized for its initially slow response to the Ebola epidemic and its heavy-handed tactics, including a military quarantine of West Point, the largest slum in the capital, Monrovia.\n\nWhile Ms. Johnson Sirleaf is internationally celebrated, her legacy at home remains disputed. In 2012, a fellow Nobel laureate, Leymah Gbowee, quit in frustration as the head of the Liberia\u2019s reconciliation initiative and criticized Ms. Johnson Sirleaf for hiring her sons for high-level government posts and failing to tackle graft and corruption. Last month, her party expelled her and accused her of supporting Mr. Weah over his rival, Joseph Nyumah Boakai, her former vice president.\n\nMs. Johnson Sirleaf is credited with negotiating with the International Monetary Fund and World Bank to erase $4.6 billion worth of debt, and her government attracted commitments of $18 billion worth of investment during her first term.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the challenges facing Liberia remain formidable. It remains one of the poorest countries in the world, and with commodities like rubber and iron ore fetching low prices on the international market, it is expected to encounter tougher economic times.", "title": "Ibrahim Prize for African Leadership Goes to Liberia\u2019s Ellen Johnson Sirleaf", "authors": ["Clair Macdougall"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "#Speakingindance\n\nIce Birds\n\nThis may look like a performance, but it\u2019s actually Ice Theater of New York\u2019s company class. Here skaters are birding, or moving like a flock in perfect coordination.", "title": "Ice Birds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Behind them, the ice skating rink at Bryant Park had become, essentially, a very large kiddie pool, covered by vast patches of water about an inch deep. Skaters described it as a \u201cpool,\u201d a \u201cwater park,\u201d or \u201cjust terrible.\u201d But they laced up their skates and went out on the \u201cice\u201d nonetheless, where little wakes of water formed behind their blades.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like skating in a puddle,\u201d said a girl who gave her name only as Marjona, 14.\n\nAccording to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration\u2019s environmental information center, the previous record for Feb. 21 was set in 1930, when the temperature in Central Park reached 68 degrees. By 5 p.m. on Wednesday, the National Weather Service said it was 78 degrees in Manhattan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMing Fei, 18, grew up ice skating in Shenzhen, China, and now, as a student at Parsons School of Design, she likes to come to Bryant Park to skate with a friend. On Wednesday, they cut their outing short because there was so much water on the ice.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI saw it like this once in China \u2014 it was because the cooler system was broken,\u201d Ms. Fei said as she loaded her figure skates into a bag. \u201cThey didn\u2019t allow people to go on the ice.\u201d", "title": "Ice Rink or Pool? Harris"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "While Idaho teachers can still choose to include climate change in their lesson plans \u2014 and many do in places like Boise, the state\u2019s capital and biggest city \u2014 science educators said they were concerned for teachers in districts where climate change was considered more controversial. Without state standards, those teachers might choose not to teach climate change at all, said Christopher Taylor, the science supervisor for the Boise School District.\n\nMr. Taylor said he was not worried about his own district. \u201cIt\u2019s these small rural districts,\u201d he said. \u201cThey will do what the state says.\u201d\n\nEven in Boise, \u201cWhen you teach environmental science, you\u2019re constantly being discredited,\u201d said Erin Stutzman, a science teacher at Timberline High School in the capital, which, along with other schools nationally, has been mailed anti-science materials from the Heartland Institute, a group that denies the reality of human-induced climate change.\n\n\u201cIf the community opposes it or thinks it\u2019s some kind of propaganda, it puts those children coming out of those districts at a major disadvantage,\u201d Ms. Stutzman said. \u201cIt\u2019s an equity issue.\u201d\n\nOnly 24 percent of Republicans in solid-red Idaho agree with the scientific consensus that climate change is caused mostly by human activities, according to the Yale Program on Climate Change Communication, the lowest percentage of any state.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a political issue, and it shouldn\u2019t be a political issue,\u201d Mr. Taylor said.\n\nThe public response to the new proposal appears to be largely positive. House lawmakers heard testimony last week from 28 people, all of whom spoke in favor of the revised standards. And roughly 1,000 comments were received during the public comment period, only five of which were negative, Mr. Cook said.\n\nEmily Her, 17, a student of Ms. Stutzman\u2019s, testified at the hearing and is leading a petition that supports the teaching of climate change in Idaho. Now, It\u2019s a Battle.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Ouedraogo made a series of short films before \u201cThe Choice,\u201d and he followed that feature with \u201cYaaba\u201d (\u201cGrandmother\u201d), which won a critic\u2019s prize at Cannes in 1989.\n\nHis later films included \u201cSamba Traor\u00e9\u201d (1993), about the aftermath of a botched robbery (the title is a character\u2019s name), and \u201cKini & Adams\u201d (1997), a story about two friends in Zimbabwe. \u201cSamba Traor\u00e9\u201d won a prize at the Berlin Film Festival, and \u201cKini & Adams\u201d was shown at Cannes.\n\nIn 2002, he contributed a segment to \u201cSeptember 11,\u201d a composite film in which 11 directors provided different perspectives from around the world on the 9/11 attacks. His was a somewhat humorous take, a story about five impoverished boys who become convinced that Osama bin Laden is in their town and hope to earn a $25 million reward by capturing him.\n\nMr. Ouedraogo largely used villagers and other nonprofessional actors in his films. Sometimes, to explain what he was doing, he would have to show them a movie first because they had never seen one. Scripts were often useless because his amateur actors couldn\u2019t read.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t teach them how to act,\u201d he said in a 1989 interview with The Times. \u201cThe lines are easy and often ad-libbed. I simply explain to them what emotions I want them to feel under certain situations. And they already know a very wide range of these emotions.\u201d\n\nThroughout his career, Mr. Ouedraogo advocated for better financing for African films \u2014 he would often travel to Paris to secure backing for his \u2014 and for setting a high bar.\n\n\u201cI want African cinema to escape from the ghetto, to get more resources,\u201d he told The Guardian in 1991, \u201cbut I don\u2019t see myself as an \u2018African\u2019 director. I think films should be relevant to everybody.\u201d", "title": "Idrissa Ouedraogo, Lauded African Filmmaker, Dies at 64", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "She thinks the Trump administration\u2019s immigration policies and rhetoric have discouraged potential workers. Menorah, part of MJHS Health System, draws heavily on immigrants for its 3,500 employees.\n\nAmong them are 25 Haitian-American nursing assistants and practical nurses whose temporary protected status was terminated in November. They will have to leave by July 2019, unless the Secretary of Homeland Security changes her mind. Other Menorah staffers brought to this country as children, now DACA recipients, also remain in limbo.\n\n\u201cEmployees have told me they know it\u2019s going to be OK,\u201d Ms. DiGangi said. \u201cI\u2019m not sure if they\u2019re convincing me or themselves.\u201d\n\nOne in four of the direct-care workers in the nation\u2019s nursing homes, assisted living facilities and home care agencies are foreign-born, according to an analysis of census data by P.H.I., the New York research organization.\n\nIn the so-called gray market, where consumers hire home care workers directly and often pay them under the table, the proportion is likely far higher.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re seeing a growing work force shortage in direct care,\u201d said Robert Espinoza, vice president of policy for P.H.I. \u201cIt\u2019s affecting the entire industry, and it\u2019s affecting older and disabled people and their families.\u201d\n\nThe shortage stems partly from a growing economy, said Robyn Stone, a veteran researcher at Leading Age, whose nonprofit members include long-term care providers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen employers are hiring, she explained, \u201cthese folks are likely to look down the street at a hospital that pays more, or another industry like fast food, and leave.\u201d\n\nMostly, however, what drives the labor shortage is long-term demographic change. Older people are living longer, most developing chronic diseases and disabilities; the sheer numbers of baby boomers further increases the demand for assistance.\n\nBut the population of working-age women, who typically provide care both paid and unpaid, has shrunk \u2014 and they have more career options than they once did.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo providing care for older people, in their homes or in facilities, has become the classic example of a job native-born Americans would rather not take.\n\nIt\u2019s physically demanding work that pays poorly \u2014 the median wage for home care workers was $10.49 an hour in 2016, P.H.I. reports \u2014 and usually doesn\u2019t include benefits. The aides, mostly women, who serve in this crucial but low-income role frequently qualify for federal programs like food stamps or Medicaid.\n\nTheir advocates have long argued for ways to improve these jobs, with more training and higher pay. For now, though, what P.H.I. calls the \u201ccaregiving gap\u201d has been filled by immigrants.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe number of immigrants in direct care ballooned from 520,000 in 2005 to approximately one million in 2015, including those who work independently through state home care programs, P.H.I. estimates. In New York, California, New Jersey and Florida, more than 40 percent of direct-care workers are immigrants.\n\nIf large numbers of immigrants become unable to work or fearful of attracting unwanted attention, \u201cthis is going to create tremendous strain,\u201d Dr. Stone said. Already, \u201cwe\u2019ve heard of nursing homes that have shut down, or stopped admissions, because they could not hire enough people.\u201d\n\nExcluding the gray market, the majority of aides and nursing assistants are American citizens. But P.H.I. has calculated that nearly 35,000 come from Haiti, El Salvador, Nicaragua and Honduras, whose immigrants have had temporary protected status in the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe administration has so far terminated T.P.S. status for Haitians, Salvadorans and Nicaraguans; other nationalities may follow. Immigrants from Sudan, whose T.P.S. status was also terminated, will have to leave the United States as early as this fall.\n\nAnother nearly 11,000 direct care workers come from largely Muslim countries affected by the Trump travel ban and might leave if family members can never join them. An unknown number of workers are DACA recipients who might eventually be forced to leave.\n\nEven when workers are legal residents, though, they may consider moving when relatives are deported. Whole neighborhoods and communities feel targeted.\n\n\u201cJust the scrutiny is casting a pall,\u201d Dr. Stone said. \u201cIf they\u2019re afraid, if they won\u2019t apply for jobs, we could see more shortages.\u201d\n\nAs that happens, the effects ripple through nursing facilities and home care agencies. \u201cWhen we struggle to fill positions, the people already working here are working harder,\u201d Ms. DiGangi pointed out. They may take more shifts, or become responsible for more patients.\n\nEventually, especially in rural areas where home care workers have to travel long distances to clients, older adults (and younger ones with disabilities) may not be able to hire people who can help them remain in their homes. In cities and suburbs, older immigrants who want assistance from those who speak their native language could be similarly at a loss.\n\nIn the San Fernando Valley in Southern California, a home care worker named Norma, who fled El Salvador with her family almost 20 years ago, assists her 91-year-old disabled neighbor under a state program. She works every day from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m., helping her client bathe, dress, eat, and circle the block in a wheelchair.\n\nBoth Spanish speakers, the women have drawn close. \u201cIn the morning, when I arrive at the house, she brightens and says, \u2018Norma, you\u2019re here!\u2019\u201d Norma told me through an interpreter. But the administration has terminated Salvadorans\u2019 temporary protected status as of September 2019. \u201cI feel scared,\u201d Norma said. \u201cThere\u2019s so much unknown.\u201d\n\nWhile she worries for herself and her husband \u2014 and her two daughters, who are DACA recipients \u2014 she also fears for her client.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf one day I don\u2019t show up to work, nobody will be there to get her out of bed and change her,\u201d she said. \u201cThis could be my own mom, who would be alone one day if nobody came to help.\u201d", "title": "If Immigrants Are Pushed Out, Who Will Care for the Elderly?", "authors": ["Paula Span", "The New Old Age"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "The result is that the highest echelons of academia, think tanks and research institutions are dominated by men. So if we go by seemingly objective criteria like seniority or citation counts, the \u201cbest\u201d experts will overwhelmingly be men. We can\u2019t fix those imbalances on our own, but we can try to correct for them in our own writing by ignoring seniority and deciding for ourselves whose work is worth quoting. We start by looking offline to find equally qualified \u2014 or, often, better qualified \u2014 women, by scanning academic journals and asking around for names.\n\nThat, unsurprisingly, can rankle people. It can rankle the men who believe we skipped over them unfairly and the institutions that wish to promote their most senior figures. Tellingly, some think tanks that publicize all-female panels also bar junior fellows from speaking to the news media, silencing the women in that role. And it can rankle readers, some of whom inevitably ask a variation of, \u201cIsn\u2019t that just more discrimination?\u201d\n\nThis is the challenge of systemic gender bias. No one person can fix it, even with the benefit of a platform as powerful as The New York Times. But conscious efforts to correct for its effects can, at a glance, look unfair because the biases that privilege men, while far more systemic, are often less visible. Last November, over 200 women in national security signed an open letter warning that sexual assault, harassment and \u201cenvironments that silence, demean, belittle or neglect women\u201d were driving their female colleagues from the field. And a 2015 analysis by Micah Zenko and Amelia M. Wolf found that women were sharply underrepresented in think tank leadership and senior government positions relating to foreign policy and national security.\n\nWe haven\u2019t undertaken the kind of rigorous accounting of our sources that Ed Yong and Adrienne LaFrance of The Atlantic have, though we suspect we\u2019d be similarly disappointed by the results. But even if we\u2019ve hardly closed the gender gap in our work, the act of trying isn\u2019t just our responsibility: It has its own benefits. We, and readers, are exposed to ideas and research otherwise obscured by systemic bias. Articles exclusively quoting women register with colleagues, who tell us they will try it themselves. The most rewarding feedback comes from young professional women, who see encouragement amid the many obstacles they face.\n\nThese are only symbolic gestures. But perhaps they are a reminder that the gender gap, though so pervasive it can sometimes feel normal, is anything but.\n\nRebecca Hamilton, an American University assistant law professor, tweeted in response to our recent article, \u201cSuch a surreal experience to read a national security article so populated with the voices of female experts.\u201d\n\nIt can indeed feel surreal to see women granted the same intellectual weight as men. But it doesn\u2019t need to.", "title": "If Only Quoting Women Were Enough", "authors": ["Amanda Taub", "Max Fisher"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "In fact, President Trump\u2019s threats to tear up the trade agreement, and his administration\u2019s aggressive use of trade laws, may actually help prod export-dependent industries in Canada to finally look beyond the United States market to do business.\n\n\u201cCanadian industries have tended to have a pretty comfortable ride with the largest economy in the world sitting on their doorstep,\u201d said Laura Dawson, the director of the Canada Institute at the Wilson Center, a research organization in Washington. \u201cSo Canada has not been very aggressive about going after new markets. The current situation is certainly accelerating decisions about this.\u201d\n\nCanada\u2019s original decision to join the free trade pact with the United States divided the country.\n\nTrade policies dating back almost to Canada\u2019s founding meant that aside from automobile and car part plants \u2014 which had been under a limited free trade agreement since 1965 \u2014 many Canadian factories were relatively small and inefficient. They largely owed their existence to the high tariffs that kept out imports from the United States and elsewhere.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the same time, tariffs in the United States made Canadian exports a tough sell for many industries.\n\nAs those tariffs disappeared under Nafta, so did many Canadian businesses, and the jobs that went with them. Memories of those closings still rankle many Canadians, even though many economists say that automation and other factors would have doomed many of the jobs regardless of new trade rules.\n\nWhile much is unclear about exactly what would happen if Nafta comes to an end, there is universal agreement that the factories that closed \u2014 like a Hershey chocolate plant that moved from Smiths Falls, Ontario, to Mexico after that country joined Nafta in 1994 \u2014 are not coming back.\n\nAlso not returning are the high tariffs that created and sustained many factories, both in the United States and Canada.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe agreement that created the World Trade Organization in 1995 means that, in the worst-case scenarios, Canadian companies would be facing duties of about 5 percent on shipments to American customers, and closer to 3 percent on many auto parts.\n\nWhile those duties are not exactly negligible, Canadian companies have successfully dealt for years with much larger percentage swings in the exchange rate between the American and Canadian dollars.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThere would be difficulties adjusting to the disappearance of Nafta, but it would not be a catastrophe,\u201d said Lawrence L. Herman, a trade lawyer in Toronto and a former Canadian diplomat. \u201cCanada would continue to do business with the United States \u2014 maybe just not as efficiently.\u201d\n\nGus Van Harten, a professor of international investment law at the Osgoode Hall Law School at York University in Toronto, has long criticized Nafta for allowing American and Mexican companies to sue if they feel they have been treated unfairly by Canadian laws and regulations. These complaints (which can also be filed by Canadian companies over practices in the other two Nafta countries) are heard by arbitrators, not courts, and the decisions cannot be reversed.\n\nThe system was originally introduced, Professor Van Harten said, to protect Canadian and American investments in Mexico. But based on his research, Canada has been sued twice as much as Mexico and has lost several prominent cases, including one in which the Canadian government had rejected, for \u201csignificant adverse environmental effects,\u201d a quarry in Nova Scotia proposed by an American company. Because these complaints allow retroactive damages, including compensation for lost profits, the amounts involved could be billions of dollars, creating what Professor Van Harten called \u201cpotentially catastrophic risk.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWith or without Nafta, geography means that the United States will continue to be Canada\u2019s largest customer.\n\nBut the recently concluded Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement \u2014 which was initially to include the United States, until Mr. Trump pulled out \u2014 and a Canada-European Union trade deal reached in late 2016 could significantly expand business opportunities for Canadian companies across oceans.\n\nSuch entry into new global markets will not be possible for every industry. Philip Cross, the former chief economic analyst at Statistics Canada, a government agency, said that, for example, it is unlikely that Canadian auto parts will make their way to Japan or Europe. \u201cSo we\u2019d better stay on good terms with the U.S.,\u201d said Mr. Cross, now a senior fellow at the Macdonald-Laurier Institute, a research group in Ottawa.\n\nBut some major Canadian industries have weaned themselves off a near-total reliance on Nafta markets for their exports.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBritish Columbia once sent nearly all of its softwood lumber exports to the United States. Now, the United States accounts for about 49 percent of that industry\u2019s 5 billion Canadian dollar export business, with 26 percent of sales going to China and 16 percent to Japan.\n\nEven if Nafta disappears, Susan Yurkovich, the president of the B.C. Lumber Trade Council, an industry group, said she doesn\u2019t anticipate that access to the United States would be significantly affected, even if what would succeed it is not clear.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m very curious to see how you put the genie back in the bottle,\u201d she said.\n\nSeveral Canadian agricultural groups have followed the lumber industry to Asia with success.\n\nRichard Davies, the senior vice president of sales and marketing at Olymel, a pork and poultry producer based in Montreal, said that some of the growth in overseas sales was driven by making more efficient use of animals. Parts like pig\u2019s feet, which have a relatively small market in North America, can fetch premium prices in Asia.\n\nBut, Mr. Davies added, the search for new markets also came out of concerns about relying too heavily on a single customer. During the early 1990s, the United States took more than three-quarters of Canada\u2019s pork exports. Today, Mr. Davies said, it accounts for less than 30 percent at Olymel.\n\nGiven all the uncertainty surrounding Nafta, Mr. Davies said it is not practical to try to plan for its demise. But he added: \u201cI would have had a lot more anxiety in 1992 than I have today about potential trade disruptions.\u201d", "title": "If Trump Rips Up Nafta, Canada May Shrug, Not Shudder", "authors": ["Ian Austen"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "But the patent disclosure goes to the heart about a global debate about privacy and security. Amazon already has a reputation for a workplace culture that thrives on a hard-hitting management style, and has experimented with how far it can push white-collar workers in order to reach its delivery targets.\n\nPrivacy advocates, however, note that a lot can go wrong even with everyday tracking technology. On Monday, the tech industry was jolted by the discovery that Strava, a fitness app that allows users to track their activities and compare their performance with other people running or cycling in the same places, had unwittingly highlighted the locations of United States military bases and the movements of their personnel in Iraq and Syria.\n\nThe patent applications, filed in 2016, were published in September, and Amazon won them this week, according to GeekWire, which reported the patents\u2019 publication on Tuesday.\n\nIn theory, Amazon\u2019s proposed technology would emit ultrasonic sound pulses and radio transmissions to track where an employee\u2019s hands were in relation to inventory bins, and provide \u201chaptic feedback\u201d to steer the worker toward the correct bin.\n\nThe aim, Amazon says in the patent, is to streamline \u201ctime consuming\u201d tasks, like responding to orders and packaging them for speedy delivery. With guidance from a wristband, workers could fill orders faster.\n\nCritics say such wristbands raise concerns about privacy and would add a new layer of surveillance to the workplace, and that the use of the devices could result in employees being treated more like robots than human beings.\n\nCurrent and former Amazon employees said the company already used similar tracking technology in its warehouses and said they would not be surprised if it put the patents into practice.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMax Crawford, a former Amazon warehouse worker in Britain, said in a phone interview, \u201cAfter a year working on the floor, I felt like I had become a version of the robots I was working with.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe described having to process hundreds of items in an hour \u2014 a pace so extreme that one day, he said, he fell over from dizziness.\n\n\u201cThere was no time to go to the loo,\u201d he said, using the British slang for toilet. \u201cYou had to process the items in seconds and then move on. If you didn\u2019t meet targets, you were fired.\u201d\n\nHe worked back and forth at two Amazon warehouses for more than two years and then quit in 2015 because of health concerns, he said: \u201cI got burned out.\u201d\n\nMr. Crawford agreed that the wristbands might save some time and labor, but he said the tracking was \u201cstalkerish\u201d and feared that workers might be unfairly scrutinized if their hands were found to be \u201cin the wrong place at the wrong time.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey want to turn people into machines,\u201d he said. \u201cThe robotic technology isn\u2019t up to scratch yet, so until it is, they will use human robots.\u201d\n\nMany companies file patents for products that never see the light of day. And Amazon would not be the first employer to push boundaries in the search for a more efficient, speedy work force. Companies are increasingly introducing artificial intelligence into the workplace to help with productivity, and technology is often used to monitor employee whereabouts.\n\nOne company in London is developing artificial intelligence systems to flag unusual workplace behavior, while another used a messaging application to track its employees.\n\nIn Wisconsin, a technology company called Three Square Market offered employees an opportunity to have microchips implanted under their skin in order, it said, to be able to use its services seamlessly.\n\nInitially, more than 50 out of 80 staff members at its headquarters in River Falls, Wis., volunteered.", "title": "If Workers Slack Off, the Wristband Will Know. (And Amazon Has a Patent for It.)", "authors": ["Ceylan Yeginsu"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Ruth Ann Harnisch, a philanthropist with no biological children, takes it further: \u201cEven though I\u2019ve never been pregnant or adopted, it\u2019s not in my soul that I have no children,\u201d she told me. \u201cEverybody\u2019s child is everybody\u2019s child. And I feel responsible for all kids as a resident of this planet.\u201d\n\nMy friend Audrey, who died a few years ago, was a high school English teacher and poet who never married or had children, yet she found her way into the lives of scores of young people. She was not my teacher, but I inherited a relationship with her when I married one of her former students. After our divorce, Audrey was one of the few people we continued to share.\n\nWhen she joined my book club, she was 25 years older than the rest of us, and provided another generation\u2019s perspective during literary discussions. She had a surprising ease with us, maybe because she was used to being around much younger people. I have reminders of Audrey everywhere \u2014 a silk scarf from Thailand, a bulging envelope of handwritten notes and museum postcards.\n\nChanneling Audrey, I\u2019m collecting younger friends with a vengeance. Last year, as many of our peers were packing their children off to college, my husband and I traveled to Colombia and Jamaica for weddings of two much younger couples. In each case, we played the Audrey role, the friend who looks old enough to be the parent. After the Colombian wedding, we hosted a party for the newlyweds in our apartment. It was our gift to them and an excuse to spend more time with an energizing group of people.\n\nAs I was sorting all this out, I reread Meghan Daum\u2019s 2014 essay in The New Yorker, \u201cDifference Maker: The childless, the parentless, and the Central Sadness.\u201d It\u2019s an unvarnished account of her experience as a court-appointed advocate in the foster care system. She captured the yearning so many of us feel to influence or be of service to children even when they are not our own.\n\nBut the essay also captured the imperfection of it: \u201cI was more like a random port in the unrelenting storm that was his life,\u201d Ms. Daum wrote of her relationship with the boy she calls Matthew. The article helped me realize why I\u2019ve made the choice I\u2019ve made, to go where I think I can make a difference.\n\nThese days I spend a lot of my time with a nonprofit, Girls Write Now, which hits the trifecta of my passions: college access, empowering girls, and writing. I\u2019m a relentless fund-raiser and evangelist for the group, and I do it for myself as much as for the girls.", "title": "If You Don\u2019t Have Children, What Do You Leave Behind?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nI am heartbroken! Please help me understand why friends have kept silent, not donated or even acknowledged my GoFundMe plea. I am recovering from breast cancer and cannot afford the medicine I need. Only one man, from the 50 requests I sent, has donated. At first, I made excuses: \u201cIt\u2019s the holidays.\u201d Then I hoped folks were sending checks directly. Now, I\u2019ve started to think: If so-and-so gave up her latte once a week, she could donate. It\u2019s been over a month. How could close friends do this to me?\n\nANONYMOUS\n\nBefore answering the social question, let\u2019s grapple with a moral one: When someone declares, \u201cI am heartbroken,\u201d does that become the immediate priority, requiring us to sugarcoat what follows in deference? Or is it better, as Nick Lowe put it musically, to be \u201cCruel to Be Kind\u201d \u2014 speak the truth and damn the heartache, possibly causing more hurt to someone who doesn\u2019t really want advice? There are a million paths here. Try to choose kindly.\n\nI\u2019m sorry that you are hurt, Anonymous. I can imagine the anguish of feeling abandoned by your friends. But when making intimate and possibly life-altering requests of others, do it in person \u2014 or at least by phone or direct email. You have essentially put up a digital flyer in the town square, sending your pals a form letter over the internet. (I can see myself ignoring it.)\n\nI can also see how you talked yourself into this approach. It\u2019s awkward to ask friends for cash. Your route was less direct. And there are all those heartwarming stories of tiny children with medical needs awash in GoFundMe loot. But I suggest you start over. Get on the phone. Do not mention your hurt feelings at the internet appeal or, for the love of caffeine, suggest they economize to subsidize you. (It\u2019s their money!) Just ask from the heart. I predict happier results. Good luck!\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLocker Room Lessons?\n\nA sign in my gym\u2019s locker room reads: \u201cPlease use a lock. Not responsible for lost or stolen items.\u201d Frustrated at searching for free lockers (because people stow their things, but don\u2019t use a lock \u2014 thus making lockers look free when they aren\u2019t), I move the contents of unlocked lockers to the ledge above. I am trying to square the owners\u2019 apparent indifference to what happens to their things (by failing to use a lock) with the idea that a locker is occupied. I am frustrated by the time-consuming search for unused lockers. And these people fail to follow instructions: \u201cPlease use a lock.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. And by all that is holy (in a locker room), I beg you to stop your attempts at logical \u201csquaring.\u201d They make you sound like a monster. The sign\u2019s request for use of locks is merely a precursor to the gym\u2019s denial of liability for theft. It does not empower you to move an unlocked locker\u2019s contents into the open. And the notion that your inconvenience at opening a few lockers before finding one that\u2019s free somehow trumps \u2026 Well, we\u2019re back to you sounding like a monster again.", "title": "If You Love Me, Why Won\u2019t You GoFundMe?", "authors": ["Philip Galanes", "Social Q S"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. The editor, Tim Herrera, emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.\n\nThat one little piece of advice is really all you ever need to know, if you ask me.\n\nThe idea is an obvious one, but it\u2019s incredibly powerful, and it\u2019s something we\u2019ve talked about in this newsletter before: Figure out what\u2019s core to your identity, the things you\u2019re truly passionate about, and dive into them head-first.\n\nIf an opportunity inspires genuine excitement in you \u2014 whether it\u2019s at work, in your personal life or anywhere else \u2014 then dive in 100 percent and don\u2019t look back. But if that spark isn\u2019t there, even if you\u2019re pretty excited about it, it\u2019s a no. The binary here is a little dramatic, sure, but the lesson is crucial: If you don\u2019t love it, don\u2019t do it.\n\nThis particular variation of this philosophy \u2014 \u201cIf it\u2019s not a \u2018hell yeah,\u2019 it\u2019s a \u2018no\u2019\u201d \u2014 comes from Derek Sivers, who said years ago: \u201cWe\u2019re all busy, we\u2019ve all taken on too much. Saying yes to less is the way out.\u201d", "title": "If You\u2019re Not All-In About a New Opportunity, Just Say No", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Our elected officials need to stop trying to pass a large immigration bill that combines protection for Dreamers with other divisive issues, like money for border enforcement and the wall and new rules to limit immigrants\u2019 ability to sponsor family members. Using the plight of Dreamers to introduce measures that otherwise would not pass on their own merits is especially cruel, as it leaves these young people hostage to the wider debate on our broken immigration system.\n\nInstead we need a \u201cclean\u201d Dream Act to help these youths now. After all, the reason Congress is even debating immigration at this point stems from the Dreamers\u2019 own courage in advocating a solution consistent with our best democratic traditions.\n\nIf the Dreamers are deported, it will do great harm to this country. According to the Center for Migration Studies of New York, the two million or so young people who could be covered by a Dream Act have integrated successfully into our society. Sixty-five percent work, with over 70,000 self-employed. Eighty-eight percent speak English exclusively, very well or well. Nearly 30 percent have attended college or earned a college degree. They have lived in the United States an average of 14 years and are parents to 392,000 American citizen children. Removing them would hurt our country economically and socially. It is not an option.\n\nThe American public already agrees with this. Eight-seven percent support passage of a Dream Act to let young immigrants stay here. The parties in Congress now need to work together to pass a bill consistent with the views of the American people. And the Trump administration must lead and seek consensus in Congress, not try to sabotage proposals to reach a solution. President Trump has articulated his support for \u201ca bill of love\u201d \u2014 exactly what we need in this situation \u2014 not a bill of discord. A just and humane bill would show that Congress can indeed promote the common good and that the legislative process need not be dysfunctional.\n\nAt this moment, however, there seems to be no sanity or progress in the pursuit of a solution for the Dreamers. That is why the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops is urging all Catholics and others of good will to phone their senators and House members today and implore them to pass the Dream Act. Catholic teaching calls for all people to make a commitment to uphold the dignity of every person and to work for the common good of our nation. It is both our moral duty and in our nation\u2019s best interest to guide our lawmakers in this matter.\n\nHelping Dreamers to become American citizens is a clear moral test. Condemning them to be sent to countries they do not know would be a stain on our national character and an abandonment of our values.", "title": "Opinion | If You\u2019re a Patriot and a Christian, You Should Support the Dream Act", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Laws prohibiting employers from asking job candidates about their past compensation before making a salary offer are gaining momentum, aimed at reducing pay disparities and other obstacles confronting women and minorities.\n\nThe premise is simple: Judging an applicant\u2019s worth from his or her previous salary can perpetuate pay gaps that arise from discrimination \u2014 or make it hard to get in the door at all.\n\nLaws banning the practice have taken effect in New York City, Delaware and California in recent months. But the way some researchers see it, such laws are likely to be ineffective or even backfire. For example, employers who can\u2019t ask about prior salary might assume that a female candidate would accept less money than a man, because women make less on average.\n\n\u201cIt seems like the general social impulse is, \u2018We don\u2019t like employers using particular information, so we\u2019ll tell them they can\u2019t use it any more and assume that\u2019s the end of the conversation,\u2019\u201d said Jennifer Doleac, an economist at the University of Virginia. \u201cBut if they cared enough about it to ask it to begin with, they probably care about it enough to try to guess.\u201d", "title": "If a Law Bars Asking Your Past Salary, Does It Help or Hurt?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The stock market has lost ground since the start of the year, thanks to the sharp sell-off Monday. But the yield on 10-year Treasury bonds is up in that span, from 2.4 percent to 2.8 percent at Tuesday\u2019s close. That suggests bond investors think that continued steady recovery will allow the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates gradually.\n\nBond investors are pricing in higher inflation than the United States has experienced in recent years, but roughly in line with the 2 percent the Federal Reserve aims for. Prices for inflation-protected bonds imply 2.09 percent annual inflation over the coming decade, up from 1.98 percent at the start of the year.\n\nOther market indicators that might signal global economic troubles, like the price of oil, instead point to a steady-as-she-goes global economy.\n\nNone of this makes a case for economic complacency. There are plenty of things that could go wrong in the world, from conflict on the Korean Peninsula or in the Middle East to destructive trade wars. But if the stock market was actually giving us any insight into the likelihood of those outcomes, we would expect to see moves in bond and commodity markets that just aren\u2019t happening.\n\nThink of it this way. The economy is like a horse race \u2014 and what we really care about is which horse wins, places or shows. The bond market is the equivalent of the people betting directly on the race. And while of course gamblers get it wrong sometimes, the market is efficient enough that there\u2019s a fairly direct relationship between the odds a horse pays and its probability of victory.\n\nThe stock market, by contrast, is like a weird side game in which people bet one another on which gambler is going to have the best day. It\u2019s erratic, volatile and a couple of degrees removed from the underlying horse race on which it is all based.\n\nAnd that\u2019s why the best way to make sense of the drop in the stock market is to think of it as a sideshow to the broader trajectory of the United States and global economy, which for now look perfectly fine.", "title": "Ignore the Stock Market.
