If it had linked to my research, readers would see that the data show that legal and illegal immigrants as a whole have a much larger share of the Arizona prison population than they do of the state population. If illegal immigrants constituted only a small part of that, then legal immigrants\u2019 share of incarcerations would be twice their share of the overall population.\n\nThese are reliable classifications based on pre-sentencing reports.\n\nJOHN R. LOTT JR., ALEXANDRIA, VA.\n\nThe writer is president of the Crime Prevention Research Center.", "title": "Opinion | Immigrants in Prison in Arizona", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "In a statement, the agency\u2019s acting director, Thomas D. Homan, called Ms. Schaaf\u2019s announcement a \u201creckless decision\u201d made for political purposes.\n\nSpeaking on Wednesday morning on Fox News, Mr. Homan said Ms. Schaaf\u2019s warning was \u201cno better than a gang lookout yelling \u2018Police!\u2019 when a police cruiser comes in the neighborhood, except she did it to an entire community.\u201d\n\nThe fight between ICE officials and Ms. Schaaf added a fresh layer of acrimony to a battle between the Trump administration, which has stepped up efforts to detain and deport unauthorized immigrants, and California officials determined to resist the president\u2019s agenda.\n\nPhoto\n\nState laws passed in the last year limit the ability of local police to cooperate with federal immigration officials, and require employers to warn their workers whenever ICE makes a request for employee paperwork, which could give any undocumented employee the chance to leave before federal agents detect their presence.\n\nPresident Trump, meanwhile, has singled out California for attacks and derision, saying its policies were letting dangerous immigrants live freely in the United States. Mr. Homan, the ICE chief, had promised to increase enforcement in California, saying in January that the state had \u201cbetter hold on tight.\u201d\n\nJames Schwab, a spokesman for ICE in San Francisco, said agents were targeting around 1,000 people in the area, which appeared to be one of the largest operations since Mr. Trump took office. Mr. Homan blamed the mayor\u2019s warning for agents not being able to detain 800 people they had targeted in recent days.\n\nOne official briefed on the plans for the operation at the Department of Homeland Security, which includes ICE, said that ICE agents typically find only about 30 percent of their targets during any large sweep. The official, who was not authorized to discuss the operation, declined to be identified.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe 30 percent rate would suggest that while some immigrants may have benefited from the tip-off, it is unlikely that 800 of them did, as Mr. Homan suggested.\n\nImmigration advocates have occasionally sought to warn of rumors of impending ICE arrests, but Ms. Schaaf\u2019s decision was striking because it came from the mayor of one of California\u2019s largest cities.\n\nMs. Schaaf, the mayor since January 2015, has been a strong promoter of Oakland\u2019s diversity, including its large population of immigrants, who make up around a third of the city\u2019s 420,000 residents.\n\nIn an interview on Wednesday, the mayor said she did not regret her decision to issue advance warning.\n\n\u201cI still contend that what I did was both legal and moral,\u201d she said, batting away a suggestion made during Mr. Homan\u2019s appearance on Fox News that she could have obstructed justice. \u201cI did not provide any specific detail that could have endangered law enforcement.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA Bay Area liberal standard-bearer in a decidedly liberal city, Ms. Schaaf has been an unshrinking critic of Mr. Trump, whom she has called the \u201cbully in chief.\u201d\n\nShe said she interpreted the raids as both racist and politically motivated, targeting liberal California.\n\n\u201cThe Trump administration and ICE officials have been very transparent that they are retaliating against California for its political position,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe president, she said, \u201cis trying to equate immigrants with dangerous criminals.\u201d\n\nAlthough Ms. Schaaf said she had information that ICE had been targeting people in Oakland, she had not heard of any arrests taking place in the city.\n\nImmigrant advocates reported arrests by ICE in Merced, Contra Costa, Sacramento, Monterey and Napa Counties \u2014 an area much broader than just the San Francisco Bay Area. On Wednesday, several dozen protesters gathered outside the ICE office in San Francisco, chanting support for undocumented immigrants and writing \u201cKEEP FAMILIES TOGETHER\u201d across an intersection.\n\nWhile the Obama administration focused arrest efforts on undocumented immigrants who had committed crimes in the United States, Mr. Trump has made clear that anyone in the country without permission can be arrested. Last year, immigration arrests nationwide rose by more than a third from the previous year, in large part because officers have more freedom to detain unauthorized immigrants with no criminal record.\n\nStill, the administration has made a point of highlighting the criminal pasts of undocumented immigrants. Around half of those arrested in Northern California in recent days had previous criminal convictions in addition to immigration violations, said Mr. Schwab, the ICE spokesman.\n\nAn ICE statement said some had lengthy criminal records, including one, Armando Nu\u00f1ez-Salgado, whom the agency called a \u201cdocumented Sure\u00f1o gang member\u201d who had been deported four times and who over the past 18 years had accumulated convictions \u2014 it listed burglary and hit-and-run causing injury \u2014 resulting in more than 15 years in prison.\n\nMr. Schwab would not say on Wednesday whether the arrest operation was continuing, but he said the agency would issue a statement once it was completed.", "title": "Immigration Agency Rails Against Oakland Mayor\u2019s Warning of Raids", "authors": ["Thomas Fuller"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Seeing \u201cSound House\u201d and \u201cThis Is the Color Described by the Time\u201d is a bracing reminder of what most other shows do not do. The two plays, presented in repertory at the Flea Theater explore a sense that too often falls by the wayside onstage \u2014 sound.\n\nGoing to the theater, you would be forgiven for thinking only sight matters. Sound design is a stepchild that\u2019s neglected at best, abused at worst. The mud coming out of speakers at too many Broadway shows, supposedly the apex of stagecraft, is appalling.\n\nVision \u2014 ahem \u2014 is lacking when it comes to theatrical sound. Everybody knows you need to have it, but too many productions do not care all that much. Can the audience hear what the actors say? Good enough! What about playing songs during scene changes? My, what an inspired device! Are singers properly miked? Bring on the Tony! (Or not: It took until 2008 to have awards for sound design. The category was eliminated in 2014; it will be back for the 2018 edition, but voting will be restricted to a subset of expert voters \u2014 as if everyone else doesn\u2019t have functioning ears.)", "title": "In 2 New Plays, Sound Design Is Front and Center (for a Change)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Though far from the most promising option, it is the least humiliating. But sooner or later, the United States and Afghanistan will find themselves facing one of Afghanistan\u2019s endgames \u2014 whether by choice or not.\n\nVideo\n\n1. Nation-Building, Minus the Nation\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll tell you what my best-case scenario would be,\u201d said Frances Z. Brown, an Afghanistan expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\nThat, she said, would see the American-led coalition abandon its efforts to impose a centralized state and instead allow Afghans to build their own state from the bottom-up.\n\nIt would mean accepting a central government that acts more like a horse trader among local strongmen and warlords. American and allied troops would guarantee enough security to sustain the state. Afghans would figure out the rest for themselves.\n\nOver time, ideally, Afghans might develop a functioning economy, then something like real democracy and, finally, peace and stability.\n\n\u201cBut what we know from other cases is that this takes generations,\u201d Ms. Brown said. \u201cSo the 18-month time frames we\u2019ve always had for Afghanistan are not realistic.\u201d\n\nThe perpetual occupation necessary for this to work might also doom it. Continued foreign aid incentivizes Afghan elites, who are already on the verge of splintering, to compete rather than come together.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis approach would involve tolerating the Taliban\u2019s presence in rural areas. And rolling crises would be built into this model, so Afghans would have to hope that they would somehow never derail the decades of progress needed before lasting change could take hold.\n\nPhoto\n\n2. Starting Over\n\nIf Afghanistan were forced back to square one, it might, some scholars think, be able to rebuild itself from scratch.\n\nAfter all, humanity lived for millenniums in something resembling low-grade anarchy. Modern nation-states grew out of that chaos only recently.\n\nThis would start with the effective collapse of the state and American withdrawal. Because the Taliban are too weak and unpopular to retake the country, as most analysts believe, Afghanistan would splinter.\n\nOut of the ashes, local warlords and strongmen would rise up. Without the United States forcing them to take sides in an all-or-nothing war, they might eventually accommodate one another, and the Taliban. Their fiefs, once stable, could coalesce over years or decades into a fully realized state.\n\nResearch by Dipali Mukhopadhyay, a Columbia University political scientist, suggests that the warlords would gravitate toward the kind of state building that occurred in medieval Europe over centuries.\n\nJennifer Murtazashvili, a University of Pittsburgh political scientist who studies state building and failure, said the process might unfold more quickly and stably in Afghanistan. She has studied rural Afghan communities that outside the reach of the state, have begun reproducing the basic building blocks of one.\n\nBut hers is only a theory, untested in modern history.\n\n3. The Somalia Model\n\nIn a sign of how far hopes have fallen, the war-torn East African country of Somalia is increasingly being raised as worthy of emulation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Afghan government would retreat to major cities. Formally, it would switch to a federal system, as Somalia did in 2012. But power would effectively flow to whichever warlords and strongmen \u2014 potentially including the Taliban \u2014 rose up in the countryside.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis would, in theory, combine the first two models. The government could reconstitute itself as it mediated between local enclaves that would one day reintegrate with the state.\n\n\u201cThis is the outcome we have de facto ended up with, but not in a peaceful sense,\u201d Ms. Murtazashvili said. The government is receding and the warlords are rising, but the two are in conflict.\n\nThe Somalia model would manage that process of disintegration, like crash-landing a plane rather than waiting for it to fall from the sky. It would leave communities to find their own peace with the Taliban, which some in remote parts of the country are already doing.\n\nIn Somalia itself, this model has found mixed success. Security has improved nationwide, but a devolving state has been left unable to root out extremists, who still carry out devastating attacks.\n\n4. A Peace That Satisfies No One\n\nThe paradox of peace deals is that while all sides benefit, each fears that it will not do as well as it could \u2014 or that its enemies might do too well. This gives each an incentive to block all but the perfect deal, a dynamic so pronounced in Afghanistan that in 16 years, talks have never advanced far enough to make clear what each side considers acceptable.\n\n\u201cI doubt the Taliban has even given any thought at a higher level to what a government looks like that it could have a stake in,\u201d said Courtney Cooper, a Council on Foreign Relations analyst.\n\nThe fear of losing out is not misplaced. Afghan elites already squabble over control of ministries and lucrative patronage networks, and their infighting grows as those resources shrink. In any peace deal, they would need to surrender many or most of those resources to the Taliban.\n\nThe Taliban, too, would probably need to surrender or curtail their hopes for dominating Afghanistan. That could anger the extremists rising in the group\u2019s ranks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd any American president would risk a political backlash for appearing to usher the Taliban back into power. Veterans and military leaders might reasonably ask what they had fought for.\n\nThe clearest winner of any deal might be the Afghans themselves, but they are largely at the mercy of political actors for whom peace is risky.\n\nPhoto\n\n5. A Post-American Civil War\n\nThere is a more pessimistic version of the collapse-then-rebuild model, in which warlords compete until one prevails over all.\n\nAfghanistan itself offers a particularly vivid example of this scenario: After the 1992 collapse of the Soviet-backed government there, the country was gripped by a terrible civil war. If the Americans abandoned the government now in place, that history could repeat.\n\n\u201cThere is a strong possibility that this county could splinter, and not in consensual ways,\u201d Ms. Murtazashvili said.\n\nThat war culminated, in 1996, with one faction prevailing: the Taliban. It then sheltered Al Qaeda, prompting the American-led invasion and the war still raging all these years later.\n\nThat history, too, could repeat. Research by Barbara F. Walter, a political scientist at the University of California, San Diego, has found that extremists tend to prevail in civil war, and to do better as the war drags on. I f the Americans exit Afghanistan, it might not be for long.\n\n6. Perpetual Stalemate\n\nThe likeliest outcome may be allowing the status quo to continue, even as all sides suffer under rising violence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNeither the government nor the Taliban are strong enough to retake control. Outside actors like the United States and Pakistan may be unable to impose their vision of victory, but they can forestall losing indefinitely.\n\nForeign aid can sustain the government, even as its control of the country shrinks. There is little to stop the Taliban from carrying out ever more brazen attacks in the capital. The death toll, already high, would probably rise.\n\nEventually, the stalemate would almost certainly break, hurtling Afghanistan into one of its possible endgames. But it is difficult to say when.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard to think of an analogous case,\u201d said Ms. Brown, the Carnegie Afghanistan expert.\n\nFew modern wars have raged this long, this destructively and with this much outside intervention. If there is an obvious way out, history does not provide it.", "title": "In Afghanistan\u2019s Unwinnable War, What\u2019s the Best Loss to Hope For?", "authors": ["Max Fisher", "The Interpreter"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Prosecutors have charged Mr. Percoco, once one of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s closest friends and aides, with conspiracy, extortion and solicitation of bribes. Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat seeking a third term in November, has not been accused of any wrongdoing. Mr. Howe, a disgraced Washington lobbyist now working as groundskeeper in Idaho, has pleaded guilty and is cooperating with the government.\n\nMr. Howe\u2019s testimony also shed light on Mr. Percoco\u2019s alleged improper use of his influence after he left the administration for nearly eight months in 2014 to run Mr. Cuomo\u2019s re-election campaign.\n\nDespite not serving in an official government capacity, Mr. Percoco continued to come and go from the governor\u2019s Manhattan offices, using a government swipe card, prosecutors have shown.\n\nMr. Howe testified on Tuesday that Mr. Percoco also continued to call members of the governor\u2019s staff and \u201cinstruct them on various topics.\u201d\n\nMr. Howe also described how he helped establish a relationship between a client and the governor\u2019s office. He instructed the client, COR Development, a Syracuse-area construction firm, to donate to Mr. Cuomo as a way of getting \u201cin the New York State arena\u201d of big-money contracts. Two COR executives, Steven Aiello and Joseph Gerardi, were also charged and are being tried with Mr. Percoco, accused of funneling him $35,000 for several favors, including securing a raise for Mr. Aiello\u2019s son, who was working for the state.\n\nMr. Howe said he introduced Mr. Aiello and Mr. Gerardi to Mr. Cuomo at a fund-raiser. He then gave another COR executive a surefire icebreaker with the governor: He told him to chat with Mr. Cuomo about Corvettes. The plan worked, Mr. Howe said. \u201cHe parked himself in the center of the ballroom and they talked about Corvettes for about 35 minutes,\u201d Mr. Howe testified.\n\nMr. Howe said that he also advised COR to funnel donations to Mr. Cuomo through limited liability companies that \u201cdon\u2019t include the name \u2018COR\u2019 in them,\u201d one email showed.", "title": "In Albany, Percoco Secretly Strained to Keep the \u2018Ziti\u2019 Flowing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Sony Pictures has issued an apology, but parents say the movie illustrates one of the persistent preventable threats to their children\u2019s health: bullies who pick on children because of their food allergies, going beyond verbal taunting to attack them with allergens.\n\nChildren with food allergies have had milk poured over them, peanuts waved in their faces, cake thrown at them, and peanut butter smeared on them.\n\nThe most dangerous incidents occur when bullies surreptitiously contaminate the child\u2019s own food with a food allergen, triggering a life-threatening reaction that cannot always be resolved by the use of an EpiPen, advocates say.\n\n\u201cKids may think something like that is funny, but when a child has an allergy, this is like an assault with a deadly weapon,\u201d said Ms. Starbuck, the mother from Kansas.\n\nEven when children aren\u2019t physically harmed, the incidents can take a psychological toll, causing distress and anxiety and affecting their quality of life. Children may refuse to go to school, or become socially isolated, depressed or even suicidal, experts say.\n\nThe bullying problem is widespread. Some 5.9 million children in the United States, or about one in 13, suffer from food allergies, and studies have found that close to one in three children with food allergies have been bullied specifically because of their allergy.\n\nMost of the bullying is done by other children who are peers or classmates, but adults may also make insensitive remarks. All too often, children make the mistake of not telling their parents they are being bullied, even though studies have found that adult involvement is effective and can usually put a stop to the behavior. As children get older, however, they are more reluctant to have their parents get involved.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAmong children who were bullied, one study found, more than half said they had been touched by an allergen, had an allergen thrown or waved at them or had their food intentionally contaminated with an allergen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMost of the bullying was verbal, as in \u2018Ha ha, you can\u2019t eat this,\u2019 but occasionally they would wave the food at the person and threaten them with it, and if they dropped the allergen into the child\u2019s own food, that could cause a serious reaction,\u201d said the author of that study, Dr. Scott H. Sicherer, director of the Jaffe Food Allergy Institute and chief of pediatric allergy and immunology at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai in New York City.\n\nLast fall, the company Kal\u00e9o Pharma and several advocacy organizations \u2014 including the Allergy & Asthma Network, Food Allergy & Anaphylaxis Connection Team, Food Allergy Research & Education and Kids with Food Allergies \u2014 started a campaign against bullying in an effort to stamp it out.\n\nThe campaign\u2019s goal is to convey to would-be bullies that attacking someone with allergens is not merely cruel; it could be deadly.\n\nAttacks may also carry legal repercussions for the assailants. A growing number of victims are alerting law enforcement officials and pressing charges.\n\nJust last month, a 14-year-old girl from Butler, Pa., was charged with felony aggravated assault after an incident in December in which she rubbed pineapple on her hand and then high-fived a girl known to have a severe pineapple allergy. Two other teenagers were charged with criminal conspiracy.\n\nIn August, a Central Michigan University student pleaded guilty to assault and battery after being charged with hazing for smearing peanut butter on the face of an unconscious student with a severe peanut allergy. The victim was treated at a campus clinic and recovered, but his parents said he could have died if the peanut butter had gotten inside his mouth.\n\nCivil lawsuits have been filed against restaurants accused of deliberately inserting allergens into food ordered by customers who made their allergies known when they placed their orders.\n\nIn one such case, a Natick, Mass., man has filed suit against Panera LLC and its franchisee organizations on behalf of his daughter, who experienced an allergic reaction after eating a grilled cheese the family had ordered from a local restaurant.\n\nThe family had specifically noted in its online order that the customer was allergic to peanuts, but the grilled cheese came with peanut butter hidden inside.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThese kinds of incidents have long-term impacts on kids,\u201d said Mary Vargas, one of the lawyers representing the family. \u201cThis little girl thought she was going to die.\u201d", "title": "In Allergy Bullying, Food Can Hurt", "authors": ["Roni Caryn Rabin"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Over the course of two years, Bob Gosford, an ornithologist, and Mark Bonta, an assistant professor of earth sciences at Penn State Altoona, and their colleagues team collected older ethnographic reports and conducted detailed interviews with six eyewitnesses, including Aboriginal firefighters and academics.\n\nThey told stories of raptors stealing burning twigs from cook fires and transporting the brands up to a kilometer (about a half mile) away. One firefighter reported seeing a flock spread a wildfire all the way up a small valley.\n\nA cattle station caretaker described a small group of raptors moving a fire front across a river, resulting in a blaze that wiped out much of the station infrastructure.\n\nPhoto\n\nStories like these are part of the reason black kites and other raptors are illegally shot on sight by irate station managers, Dr. Bonta said in an interview.\n\nTaken together, the accounts suggested that the birds act primarily when wildfires are going out because they have reached a natural barrier or through human intervention.\n\nIt\u2019s unclear how common the behavior is \u2014 or whether it exists at all. As yet, no conclusive photographic or video documentation exists.\n\nEven without direct evidence, though, formerly skeptical ornithologists have found the combination of ethnographic research and firsthand accounts compelling.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRaptors are already well known for \u201csmart\u201d hunting approaches, including following human vehicles that might flush prey to dropping stones on tough eggs, said Steve Debus, an adjunct lecturer at the University of New England in Armidale, Australia.\n\nBlack kites, one of the species implicated in fire-spreading, have a reputation for being particularly clever. \u201cThey seem intelligent and quick to learn ways of obtaining food,\u201d Dr. Debus said. \u201cThey\u2019ve been known to take food from schoolyards, even from children\u2019s hands, and use bread scraps at picnic areas to bait fish within capture range.\u201d\n\nDr. Bonta believes that fire-spreading is not observed more often because only a few birds in any large flock understand how to do it.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s notable that we did not receive credible reports from casual tourists or others who might have simply gotten lucky,\u201d he said. \u201cIt appears that one needs to have spent a lot of time in the bush, and a fair amount of it close to wildfires.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAboriginal peoples, on the other hand, know the bush intimately and are no strangers to wildfire. The idea that some birds spread fires is common among indigenous groups in the Northern Territory, Dr. Bonta said.\n\nMr. Redford pointed out that the birds are ceremonially important. According to Aboriginal lore, human knowledge of fire dates to the Dreaming, the time before time, when the firehawk brought embers to people in a burning stick.\n\nIn complex Dreaming ceremonies, like the hollow log ritual Lorrkon, those with special knowledge re-enact the story.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe still repeat, same way, what the old people did,\u201d Mr. Redford said. \u201cHe used to play with that firestick, too, that bird. That\u2019s feeding time for him.\u201d\n\nFire-spreading birds came to mainstream attention in 1964 with the publication of \u201cI, The Aboriginal,\u201d the purported autobiography (it was ghostwritten) of indigenous activist Waipuldanya, which described firehawks spreading wildfires to hunt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile the account raised scholarly interest, no follow-up research appeared. Many scientists dismissed accounts of fire-spreading as accidental, a misperception about birds mistakenly snatching smoldering material.\n\nFirehawks have also tended to be regarded as folklore by government officials, Dr. Bonta said, becoming scapegoats for fires that have been improperly managed.\n\nWhen Mr. Gosford reread his copy of the book in 2011, however, the section on fire-spreading caught his eye. As an amateur ornithologist and lawyer working on indigenous cases in the Northern Territory, Mr. Gosford said, he\u2019d developed a deep respect for Aboriginal knowledge of the landscape.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe wrote a pair of blog posts on the subject that received media attention in 2016. He and Dr. Bonta, a frequent correspondent, decided it was time to collaborate on a peer-reviewed paper.\n\nDr. Bonta and Mr. Gosford hope to launch a three-week research expedition in May, where they\u2019ll work with fire rangers in hopes of documenting the behavior firsthand. They\u2019ll be accompanied by volunteer birders with cameras and with drones.\n\nThe team also plans on collaborating with Aboriginal authors on future publications, part of an effort to incorporate indigenous ecological knowledge into ornithology.\n\nFire has long been a central land management tool for Aboriginal people; carefully controlled burns shaped forests and savannas for hunting and agriculture.\n\nWhile the indigenous practice of controlled burns was largely suppressed during Australia\u2019s colonial period, legal decisions that delivered land back to Aboriginal ownership have fueled a return to traditional strategies that more closely mimic natural processes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor these strategies to be successful, Dr. Bonta said, officials need to take local expertise seriously about animal habits, including firehawks.\n\n\u201cAboriginal people \u2014 like the peoples of New Guinea and Amazonia and many other places \u2014 often have far better knowledge of local flora and fauna than outsiders, built up over the course of millennia,\u201d Dr. Bonta said.\n\n\u201cWhat possible reason could there be to not put enormous effort into helping them preserve what they know and collaborate to improve our overall understanding of nature?\u201d\n\nPerhaps the Australia\u2019s firehawks are enacting a process similar to the one humanity used to control fires. Or perhaps, as the Aboriginal people say, the birds\u2019 activities lit the spark for people in the first place.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m glad that others are now talking about co-evolution and learning from birds,\u201d Dr. Bonta said. \u201cFire may not be so uniquely human after all.\u201d", "title": "In Australia, Arsonists May Have Wings", "authors": ["Asher Elbein"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "SYDNEY, Australia \u2014 During her second week waitressing at a barbecue restaurant in Sydney, a customer asked Yating Yang if she was Chinese. \u201cNo, I\u2019m Taiwanese,\u201d she said.\n\nHer boss, who was from mainland China, never gave her another shift.\n\nMan-Tzu Tuan said her loyalty test came even sooner: on her first day at a hot pot restaurant in a comfortable Sydney suburb. \u201cIs Taiwan part of China?\u201d her manager asked in Mandarin over a walkie talkie. \u201cNo, definitely not,\u201d she said.\n\nA half-hour later, she was fired.\n\nChina\u2019s assertiveness has already set off alarms in Australia, with officials warning that Beijing has been meddling in Australian politics more than the public realizes. But the experiences of Ms. Yang and Ms. Tuan \u2014 along with many others \u2014 reveal how Chinese nationalism is also affecting private enterprise and, in some cases, leading to accusations of discrimination.\n\nAustralia\u2019s fair work laws make clear that an employer cannot discriminate against an employee or prospective employee because of the person\u2019s \u201cpolitical opinion, national extraction or social origin.\u201d But experts and Taiwanese workers say that is exactly what many Chinese business owners are doing, with few repercussions.", "title": "In Australia, Staying Loyal to Taiwan Can Mean Losing a Job", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey were simply put, both cops and robbers,\u201d said Leo Wise, the lead federal prosecutor, in his opening argument.\n\nThe trial comes amid intense scrutiny on police departments nationally, and mounting pressure on officers to work to heal rifts with minority communities after findings by the Justice Department that some departments, including those in San Francisco, Chicago and Baltimore, have a pattern of unconstitutional and biased policing.\n\nIn Baltimore, the members of the anti-crime unit were so reckless that they carried out elaborate criminal schemes even as Justice Department investigators were scouring departmental records and interviewing the officers\u2019 colleagues as part of their civil rights investigation. The gun unit\u2019s criminal schemes appear to have started at least five years ago.\n\nBut the officers believed that their victims would not speak up. \u201cMore than likely, a drug dealer is not going to complain about their money being taken,\u201d said Momodu Gondo, a former member of the gun unit who testified Monday. He wore an orange jail jumpsuit, having pleaded guilty to an array of crimes.\n\nMr. Gondo estimated that he had stolen as much as $100,000 from people during his career and said he had once given a gun he took during a home invasion to a friend who was a drug dealer.\n\nThe police accounts continue a drumbeat of negative news that has battered Baltimore\u2019s police, which was highlighted by Freddie Gray, who died in 2015 from injuries sustained while in police custody. His death was followed by days of rioting and unsuccessful attempts to prosecute the officers involved in his arrest.\n\nLast year, Baltimore had the highest per capita murder rate in its history. Last October it opened a rooftop garden terrace and bar, and in December 2017 added 31 additional rooms. Named for the late star\u2019s car-chasing 1968 detective thriller of that title, the hotel calls itself no-frills, but the design is fun and stylish. Visitors liked the theme so much that soon after its opening, two older women tried to swipe a six-foot canvas of McQueen smoking a cigarette behind aviator shades. The near-heist generated publicity for the new hotel as the Not-So-Great Escape, but the desk clerks who checked me in swore it had been a true crime, not a stunt.\n\nImage The Bullitt Hotel in Belfast. Credit Bullitt Hotel\n\nLocation\n\nAs Belfast has settled into two decades of post-conflict peace, the Cathedral Quarter where the Bullitt is situated has emerged as one of the city\u2019s most vibrant neighborhoods, with restaurants, hotels, shops, and edgy street art. The hotel is also a doable stroll from the riverfront and blockbuster Titanic Museum, as well as some of Belfast\u2019s most character-saturated pubs.\n\nThe Room\n\nBullitt rooms are named in three sizes: \u201cDinky,\u201d Comfy\u201d and \u201cRoomy.\u201d Slate-gray paint and a full-wall mural of \u201cBullitt\u201d stars Steve McQueen and Jacqueline Bisset dominated our mid-sized and indeed comfortable room. Playful touches include the warning \u201cFaceplant!\u201d printed on the double-paned windows (which didn\u2019t keep the childhood friend with me from bonking her head trying to see the space-themed \u201cIntrepid Traveler\u201d art installation outside). Replacing a closet was a bright red wire rack with a few hooks and hangers, along with a simple luggage rack, desk, TV and a tiny metal shelf for the remote. No iron was provided, but a basic model was delivered within two minutes of asking.\n\nThe Bathroom\n\nWhite square tile on the walls and gray square tile on the floor, the bathroom was all business. Toiletries bcreated for the hotel were provided in a tart Irish nettle scent. An oversize rainfall showerhead was mounted high; and while the water temperature could have gone hotter, the warming towel rack was nice on a cool Belfast day.", "title": "In Belfast, a Hotel Inspired by a Steve McQueen Movie", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "The vote came after Mr. de Le\u00f3n, who has been running an insurgent campaign, delivered a blistering speech that reflects deep divisions among Democrats here \u2014 and across the nation \u2014 about how to respond to President Trump. The British-based Harbour Hotels has turned two ornate bank buildings, including one inspired by a 16th century Venetian library, into stylish accommodations (it opened in late 2016). Public spaces now burst with vibrant colors and exuberant modern design set against a backdrop of curving stone walls and intricately carved friezes that are more than a century old.\n\nLocation\n\nThe property is in the heart of the cobblestoned Old City just opposite St. Nicholas Market and its bustling glass-covered arcade, along with lots of restaurants, bars and night life. Most of Bristol\u2019s main attractions are within a 20-minute stroll, including the massive ocean liner-turned experiential museum S.S. Great Britain, the local history museum M Shed, the Wills Memorial Building, and two works of street art from the city\u2019s most notorious son, Banksy.", "title": "In Bristol, a Hotel That Is Stately and Stylish", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "That evening, I walked along quiet cobbled streets past candy-colored houses where old men and women sat out on the sidewalks to play cards and gossip. For dinner, I ate tamales and drank coconut horchata, slushy and sweet as a milkshake, at the open-air Portales de San Mart\u00edn just outside the old city walls (there are several small restaurants, or antojer\u00edas, located in the Portales, all serving more or less the same food). I tried to imagine the city\u2019s bloody, lawless past, but the image wouldn\u2019t materialize. If Campeche today is one of the safest places in Mexico, it\u2019s in part because, Mr. MacGregor told me, \u201cwe had 200 years of piracy, fear and violence. We\u2019re not interested in all that now.\u201d Pirates and traders, an empirical fact of a knowable past, seemed more remote and fantastic than a Maya world conjured from stone and dust.\n\nI had come back to Campeche, despite warnings about the May heat, to see an archaeological site that Mr. Pech had told me about, not far from Calakmul. His grandfather, he told me, had uncovered it back in 1950 during his youth as a rubber tapper (nearly all the ruins around Calakmul were found this way, though there are no records to confirm these stories). The first archaeologist officially entered the site in 1993, guided by Mr. Pech\u2019s grandfather, and although I.N.A.H. spent a year restoring it in 2001, they soon abandoned it to the forest. They called the place Nadzcaan \u2014 Maya for Closer to the Sky.\n\nNadzcaan isn\u2019t technically open to the public, but the only real restriction on getting there is stamina. Set about nine miles back from the road, it\u2019s accessible either on foot, a three-hour hike through the forest, or by motorbike (40 minutes plus a half-hour trudge on a gradual incline). Walking in, we passed iridescent wild turkeys and the fresh tracks of feral pigs. A troop of spider monkeys high up in the trees shook branches to scare us off. Eventually, Nadzcaan emerged coyly from the forest, the 130-foot pyramid at its center dissolving into the trees like the memory of a dream.", "title": "In Campeche, Pyramids Are Everywhere. Crowds Are Not.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Tillerson heads to the Middle East next week, where the growing American tilt toward Qatar is likely to be on stark display. At a meeting in Kuwait to solicit investments and donations for Iraq\u2019s reconstruction, the Qataris are expected to make a significant pledge of funds, according to a senior State Department official. But the Saudis, saddled with a costly war in Yemen, and Emiratis, long suspicious of Iraq\u2019s Shiite-led government, are not expected to make similar pledges, said diplomats in the region who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the funding assistance had not yet been announced.\n\nQatar\u2019s foreign minister and defense minister led the delegation to Washington last week for the country\u2019s first strategic dialogue with the United States \u2014 a diplomatic platform that the Trump administration has generally reserved for global heavyweights like China and India. Mr. Tillerson has been among Qatar\u2019s chief supporters in the administration; he played a key role when he was at Exxon Mobile helping Qatar develop its vast gas field.\n\nThere are signs that Mr. Tillerson\u2019s view now holds sway in the White House.\n\nSince the summer, the Trump administration has become increasingly unnerved by Saudi moves to remove Lebanon\u2019s prime minister, jail hundreds of princes and businessmen and prosecute a war in Yemen that has created a humanitarian disaster. Additionally, Stephen K. Bannon, Mr. Trump\u2019s one-time chief strategist who has close ties to the Emirates and has sharply criticized Qatar, is no longer at the White House.\n\nQatar, meanwhile, signed agreements with the United States for sharing information on terrorists and terrorist financing, fighting human trafficking and disclosing detailed financial information about its national airline. Last month, Mr. Trump called Emir Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani of Qatar and praised the nation for being \u201cone of the few countries\u201d to sign a counterterrorism agreement.\n\nIn his meetings last week, Defense Minister Khalid bin Mohammed al-Attiyah said Qatar would upgrade living quarters for United States military personnel stationed at al-Udeid Air Base, which hosts nearly 10,000 American troops. The base, southwest of Doha, is the overseas headquarters for United States Central Command.\n\nAt the same time, Qatar has hired some of Washington\u2019s most influential deal makers and now pays 21 lobbyists in Washington.\n\nThey include Nicolas D. Muzin, a former top aide to Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, who signed on in August for $50,000 per month and received $300,000 per month by December, according to records filed with the Justice Department. He has been booking prominent Jewish and conservative Americans on all-expense-paid trips to Doha to meet with the emir, who has denied claims that Qatar funds Hamas, a militant Islamist group that the United States lists as a terrorist organization.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCongress is considering legislation to impose sanctions on countries that support Hamas. It specifically says Qatar \u201chas for many years openly financed Hamas.\u201d\n\nAlan Dershowitz, a prominent lawyer, called Qatar the \u201cIsrael of the Gulf States\u201d after his meeting with the emir. Morton Klein, the president of the Zionist Organization of America, told Haaretz, an Israeli newspaper, that he decided to make the trip only after determining that, among American Jewish leaders, \u201ceveryone is already going.\u201d The parade to Doha grew so large that Itai Bar Dov, a spokesman for the Israeli Embassy in Washington, issued a scolding. \u201cWe do not approve of these visits by the Jewish organizations to Qatar,\u201d Mr. Dov said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Saudis and Emiratis have mobilized their own extensive lobbying network in Washington to push back against the Qataris, and a delegation of prominent American Jewish leaders is scheduled to fly soon to Abu Dhabi.\n\nOfficials on Capitol Hill say they have been inundated by competing lobbying teams. And the Saudis and Emiratis remain formidable players in Washington\u2019s influence game, with the Emirati ambassador to Washington, Yousef al-Otaiba, being one of the city\u2019s most popular hosts. Mr. Otaiba declined to comment.\n\n\u201cFoggy Bottom might be rolling out the red carpet, but I don\u2019t see any evidence the charm offensive is changing minds on Capitol Hill,\u201d said Richard Goldberg, a senior adviser at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, which has aligned with the Saudi and Emirati view of the dispute.\n\nQatar has long shared a testy relationship with fellow Sunni Muslim nations Saudi Arabia and the U.A.E., largely because of Doha\u2019s support of the Muslim Brotherhood. The regional neighbors also distrust the TV network Al Jazeera, based in Doha, which has been critical of Riyadh and Abu Dhabi. And Qatar\u2019s relatively good relations with Shiite-majority Iran, with which it shares a vast gas field, has strained rapport with Saudi Arabia.\n\nWhile the Trump administration has quietly suggested a summit meeting of the Gulf Cooperation Council in Washington \u2014 which the State Department hopes will lead to ending the embargo against Qatar \u2014 the Saudis and Emiratis have expressed little interest.\n\n\u201cThe Emirati and Saudi view is, \u2018We will wait the Qataris out. We can live this way for a very long time,\u2019\u201d Jon B. Alterman, the director of the Middle East program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said in a phone interview from Abu Dhabi.\n\nRepresentative Josh Gottheimer, Democrat of New Jersey, is among the lawmakers asking Attorney General Jeff Sessions to require Al Jazeera to register as a foreign agent \u2014 a designation that could limit its access to American officials and facilities. The congressional request, which has yet to be issued, follows a recent revelation that an undercover Al Jazeera reporter secretly filmed pro-Israeli organizations in Washington.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Qataris have been bad actors,\u201d he said.\n\nThat view was not widely shared in the Trump administration while the Doha delegation was in Washington.\n\nMr. Tillerson was the featured speaker at an elaborate reception that the U.S. Chamber of Commerce hosted for the Qatari officials; it was a rare evening social appearance for the secretary of state. Then, Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani, Qatar\u2019s foreign minister, was given a respectful audience at the American Enterprise Institute, one of Washington\u2019s most prestigious conservative think tanks.\n\nSeveral days later, top Qatari officials lunched at the Boeing assembly plant with Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, and the state\u2019s governor, Henry McMaster. Qatar has invested billions of dollars in the United States, buying Miramax Studios in 2016 and a stake in the Empire State Building.\n\nBut risks remain for Qatar, especially as it works with the Trump administration, which views Iran as the region\u2019s villain.\n\n\u201cThe administration\u2019s policy in the Middle East is moving from primarily an anti-ISIS approach to an anti-Iran one,\u201d said Brian Katulis, a senior fellow at the left-leaning Center for American Progress. \u201cAnd I\u2019m not sure how well Qatar fits into that.\u201d", "title": "In Charm Offensive, Qatar Pushes for a Comeback in Washington", "authors": ["Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "How to get there? I recommend Chengdu\u2019s clean, efficient subway system, and suggest you get used to taking it. The metro, which went into service in 2010, has been built with blinding, almost frightening, speed. There are now six subway lines in operation, meaning that a new one is added every 16 months or so in a city of more than 14 million people. Single-ride tickets vary based on distance, but expect to pay between 2 and 5 yuan when you ride. You\u2019ll also notice no one bolting down the stairs to make a train in Chengdu; there\u2019s almost always another one about three minutes behind.\n\nMy lodging at the Chengdu Panda Apartment (Chengdu is proud of its pandas and you will see them in advertising and the names of businesses everywhere) was tricky to locate \u2014 it\u2019s hidden in a residential apartment block \u2014 but the room was comfortable and the price reasonable (276 yuan per night). The d\u00e9cor was, as you might guess, extremely panda-heavy: blankets, towels, bedspreads \u2014 everything. Fortunately, I thought it was pretty cute.\n\nIf you\u2019re looking for something a little more traditional, I also stayed at the Sheraton Chengdu Lido Hotel, just one stop north of Tianfu Square, on the metro\u2019s primary north-south line, for just 488 yuan per night. Getting into the city from the airport, incidentally, is fairly hassle-free. While there are shuttles into downtown, I would download and set up Didi Chuxing before your trip (check out other general China travel tips in my last article). My ride into the city cost just 45 yuan. One nice perk of the app is that if you message your driver in English (to tell him or her where you are, for example), it is automatically translated into Chinese.\n\nTaxis are also easy to hail in Chengdu, as are guys on motorbikes who will, for a fee, let you hop on the back and shuttle you to your destination. But I found that walking is the best way to get around Chengdu \u2014 the city isn\u2019t as hectic as Beijing or Shanghai, and it\u2019s a pleasant place to take a stroll.", "title": "In Chengdu, Finding Peace in Parks and Heat in Cuisine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "What has happened here in the northern Chinese province of Shanxi, the country\u2019s largest coal-producing region, and in other regions shows how far the government has gone in imposing its environmentalism from above. Eager to impress Beijing, officials in this province of 37 million people have moved so aggressively that in some cases they have created unintended consequences.\n\nMany coal stoves were removed before new furnaces were installed, leaving tens of thousands of people shivering without heat when winter\u2019s first cold snap arrived earlier than normal. Then, with so many districts switching to natural gas at once, demand for the new source of fuel overwhelmed supplies, sending prices soaring and creating shortages.\n\nThe benefits of the government\u2019s campaign are nonetheless being felt in the comparatively blue skies that have blessed Beijing and other cities that were a focus of the authorities\u2019 efforts, including in Shanxi\u2019s provincial capital, Taiyuan.\n\n\n\nLonger term, the impact could be felt globally, too, backing up President Xi Jinping\u2019s pledge to put China in the \u201cdriving seat in international cooperation to respond to climate change\u201d by reducing emissions at a time when the United States under President Trump has treated the issue dismissively.", "title": "In China\u2019s Coal Country, a Ban Brings Blue Skies and Cold Homes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "In filming just the first joke \u2014 \u201cYou would think that cops would occasionally shoot a white kid, just to make it look good\u201d \u2014 Mr. Burnham shifts angles four times, but he also knows when to stop moving the camera. As Mr. Rock confesses he cheated on his wife, he goes in for the close-up and lingers.\n\nThis risks heavy-handedness but displays a perceptive eye for the importance of a pivot point where the star could lose his audience. Kevin Hart, who recently confessed to cheating on his wife before announcing a tour called \u201cIrresponsible,\u201d might face a similar onstage moment soon.\n\nWhen I saw Mr. Rock play Madison Square Garden in December, he took a few glancing shots at Matt Lauer, the \u201cToday\u201d host who was fired over allegations of inappropriate sexual behavior, but the comic mostly avoided #MeToo as he does in the new special. Though Mr. Rock evoked the movement at one point by shifting from his mistakes with his wife to a broader question: \u201cWhat is wrong with men?\u201d\n\nOver the course of his career, mixing the voice of a preacher with that of a litigator, Mr. Rock has built up an authority skewering the foibles of the world while keeping his own offstage. This special represents a shift in that dynamic. In describing his flaws, Mr. Rock says he was hooked on pornography. There is a lot of comedy about pornography, but to hear a superstar break down how watching it made him \u201csexually autistic\u201d is bracing, and may even provide grist to certain warnings against online porn.\n\nIn that North Carolina show, Mr. Rock went into more detail about his affairs. That was cut from the special, leaving nothing to invite jealousy. His tone is contrite, but it also suggests he has recovered, both from porn addiction and cheating, which he says he\u2019s done with. In an hour dense with jokes, he gets serious. \u201cWhen guys cheat, we want something new,\u201d he says, still in close-up. \u201cBut you know what happens? Your woman finds out and now she\u2019s new. She\u2019s never the same again. You got new but you got a bad new.\u201d\n\nOffstage, Chris Rock is soft-spoken, thoughtful, even shy \u2014 an alter ego to the strutting superhero he becomes in his stand-up specials whose titles (\u201cBigger & Blacker,\u201d \u201cNever Scared\u201d) telegraph swagger. In the age of Trump, he has shifted to something quieter, more humble, and yet, with the same old confidence, with lessons learned at the end.\n\nMr. Rock does not wallow in melancholy and regret over lost love. He turns them into a great comedy special, just in time for Valentine\u2019s Day.", "title": "In Chris Rock\u2019s Netflix Special \u2018Tamborine,\u2019 a Humbler Master at Work", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Four years ago, spurred on by a newly elected mayor who ran on a progressive agenda, an insurgent group of like-minded reformers took control of the City Council, standing up to the Democratic Party establishment and its powerful county bosses.\n\nBut now, after the re-election of Mayor Bill de Blasio, the Democratic establishment in New York City is again flexing its muscles \u2014 forcing the progressives to retreat.\n\nThe shift of alignment among Democrats in this one-party town could spell trouble for Mr. de Blasio, who may have to govern with less Council support than he is accustomed to. It also runs counter to the broader national narrative of the Democratic Party, whose energized left wing has put the establishment on its heels.\n\nIt is far from clear how this shift will play out over the next four years; the new Council speaker, Corey Johnson, is a liberal and a member of the Progressive Caucus. Its roomy penthouse, nestled under the eaves, offers views of the green-spired city hall and the tower of Christiansborg Palace. Skylights flood the suite with natural light, highlighting warm champagne- and tan-colored leather couches and beds with individually mounted oak headboards and soft leather neck-pillows.\n\nImage Credit Courtesy of the Radisson Blu Hotel\n\nWhen it opened in 1960, the Radisson Blu Hotel became a \u201clandmark of the jet age,\u201d Denmark\u2019s first skyscraper \u2014 and the world\u2019s first design hotel. (It was conceived entirely by Arne Jacobsen for SAS Airlines, which ran a terminal on the ground floor.)\n\nSince then, the hotel\u2019s spaces have been upgraded several times, but rooms in every category still include Jacobsen\u2019s chair designs. Four suites have been refreshed in partnership with design house Fritz Hansen, in keeping with Jacobsen\u2019s signature aesthetic \u2014 Room 1206 features Poul Kjaerholm furnishings, including a one-of-a-kind graphic artwork; Room 1106 incorporates several one-off pieces, such as a marble AJ sofa table, a leather Egg chair and a velvet Swan chair.\n\nBut in room 606 \u2014 now open only for guided tours \u2014 Jacobsen\u2019s original interiors have been maintained exactly as installed. The two men are not related.\n\nMr. Alvarado had won almost 25 percent of the vote to nearly 22 percent for Mr. Alvarado Quesada, with about 90 percent of the polling places counted, the nation\u2019s electoral board said.\n\nWhat had been a conventional campaign in Latin America\u2019s most enduring democracy \u2014 with debates over corruption, crime and the economy \u2014 was suddenly upended four weeks ago when an international court decision required Costa Rica to legalize same-sex marriage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFabricio Alvarado, 43, who was first elected to the Legislative Assembly in 2014, made his opposition to the ruling the centerpiece of his campaign and suddenly emerged from the crowded field of 13 candidates to take the lead in opinion polls.", "title": "In Costa Rica Election, Gay-Marriage Foe Takes First Round", "authors": ["Elisabeth Malkin"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Eugenie Bouchard on Wednesday gave her first public account of the night she fell and hit her head at the 2015 United States Open as her trial against the United States Tennis Association continued in federal court in Brooklyn.\n\nOn that night, Bouchard, a player from Canada, said she told a trainer, Kristy Stahr, that she would return to take an ice bath after completing other postmatch activities, which included cooling down with stretching and fulfilling news media obligations.\n\nWhen she came back, the trainers had left. Several more women used The Lefsetz Letter, an emailed newsletter by Bob Lefsetz, a former lawyer who is the industry\u2019s full-time gadfly, as a forum to accuse Mr. Walk, anonymously, of various forms of harassment, including sending explicit pictures and inappropriate text messages.\n\nIn a signed comment, Harvey Leeds, a former executive at Epic Records who had worked with Michael Jackson and others, challenged Mr. Walk\u2019s assertion, in a statement this week, that \u201cthere has never been a single HR claim against me at any time during my 25+ year career, spanning three major companies.\u201d", "title": "In Days After Grammys, a #MeToo Spark Comes to Music", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Waronker has now sued the district and the board in federal court, seeking to be reinstated.\n\nIn an interview, Dr. Waronker said he believed the school board majority had removed him because he was uncovering evidence of corruption, which he said he could not describe because he had passed it on to law enforcement. (The Nassau County district attorney\u2019s office declined to comment.)\n\nHe said that, just as he was driving into the high school on Dec. 7 for a school board meeting, someone had fired several gunshots into a building on the corner, and that around the same time, nearby, someone had fired into a car parked outside his lawyer\u2019s office.\n\n\u201cThey follow you over there; they track your movements \u2014 not to sound paranoid,\u201d he said.\n\nBut he said that he would not back down. \u201cI\u2019m willing to risk my life for the kids,\u201d he said, adding, \u201cMost people there in the district are terrified.\u201d\n\nThe state has only ever once taken over a district completely, when in 2002 it took control of the Roosevelt School District, a nearby district with similar demographics to Hempstead. Like Hempstead, Roosevelt\u2019s schools were low-performing and dangerous, and the leadership was chaotic. In addition, partly because the district lacked almost any commercial tax base, Roosevelt had very little money.\n\nThe state\u2019s takeover lasted 11 years and is not generally regarded as a success: The state spent millions of dollars; some of the leaders it appointed were problematic; and the district\u2019s results improved only marginally.\n\nHempstead and Roosevelt are among the poorest and most segregated districts in Nassau County. According to state records, Roosevelt did not have a single white student in the 2016-17 school year. Roughly 2 percent of Hempstead\u2019s students were white. Nassau County\u2019s population overall is 61 percent white, according to census records. In the district just north of Hempstead, Garden City, 88 percent of the students are white.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Singer, the Hofstra professor, said he felt the state\u2019s decision to take over the Roosevelt district was a way for it to avoid dealing with the larger segregation issue.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn interviews, parents and students in the Hempstead district expressed distress about the schools, in particular the violence at the district\u2019s middle and high schools. According to the report prepared for the state by the retired superintendent, Jack Bierwirth, there were more than 50 fights at the high school between September and early December.\n\n\u201cIt disrupts me from learning in class,\u201d said Tamia Grant, 17, a senior at the high school. She said she hears the students fighting right outside her classrooms. \u201cThe doors are so thin, they\u2019re like plexiglass, and they knock into the door,\u201d she said. \"My teacher has to stop what she\u2019s doing to lock the door, because we\u2019re scared that they\u2019ll come into our classroom.\u201d\n\nSeveral Hispanic parents said that they felt that Hispanic students and families were particularly marginalized. They said that there were no Spanish interpreters at school meetings or at parent-teacher conferences.\n\n\u201cI always go to my kids\u2019 meetings, but they say there\u2019s no one there that speaks Spanish, so I don\u2019t understand what they say to me,\u201d said Emily Flores, 40, an immigrant from Mexico who has two children at Hempstead High School. Ms. Flores spoke in Spanish through an interpreter.\n\nIn 2015, an investigation by the state attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, found that the district had denied or delayed the enrollment of dozens of Hispanic students, many of them unaccompanied minors from Central and South America. In some cases, the district told students or their guardians that there was no room for them in the schools and put them on a \u201cwait list,\u201d which eventually had 60 students on it.\n\nDr. Waronker, who grew up in South America and speaks fluent Spanish, had made a particular effort to connect with Hispanic families, said the Rev. Luis Miguel Romero, the pastor of Our Lady of Loretto, a local Roman Catholic church. Among other things, Father Romero said that Dr. Waronker had personally offered a course to parents at the church about how they could help in their children\u2019s education.\n\nFather Romero said that he was distressed by the school board\u2019s decision to put Dr. Waronker on leave.\n\n\u201cIt is jeopardizing the only hope that we have seen in Hempstead,\u201d he said.\n\nMs. Elia, who visited the district in mid-January, said that it was too soon to say what options would be on the table if the board\u2019s response did not prove to her that it could address the issues raised in the state report. The commissioner has the authority in some circumstances to remove individual school board members, but she would need to be empowered by the Legislature to fire and replace the whole board.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cObviously, removing someone from elected position is not something that any agency or anyone would want to do lightly,\u201d she said. But, she said, \u201cI\u2019ve made it very clear to them that we are not going to allow this district to not focus their attention on the needs of the children there.\u201d", "title": "In District Known for Failure, Will the State Finally Step In?", "authors": ["Kate Taylor"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Evangelical leaders also see a civic obligation to speak godly counsel to him, on policy and personal matters. He is, after all, the president. And it\u2019s paying off. I\u2019ve watched Mr. Trump through the lens of the faith community for years, and he has delivered the policy goods and is progressing on the spiritual ones.\n\nMy reporting suggests Donald Trump is on a spiritual voyage that has accelerated in recent years, thanks to evangelicals who have employed the biblical mandate of sharing and showing God\u2019s love to him rather than shunning him. President Trump told me that he \u201cwas exposed to a lot of people, from a religious standpoint, that I would\u2019ve never met before. And so it has had an impact on me.\u201d\n\nThis president\u2019s effect on our cultural norms has been shocking. His critics would call it appalling; evangelicals say it\u2019s immensely satisfying: They\u2019ve seen a culture deteriorate quickly in the past decade, and they\u2019re looking for a bold culture warrior to fight for them. Showing that God does indeed have a sense of humor, He gave them Mr. Trump. Yet in God\u2019s perfection, it\u2019s a match made in heaven. Mr. Trump and evangelicals share a disdain for political correctness, a world seen through absolutes and a desire to see an America that embraces Judeo-Christian values again rather than rejecting them.\n\nFinally, why in the world wouldn\u2019t evangelicals get behind and support a man who not only is in line with most of their agenda but also has delivered time and time again? The victories are numerous: the courts, pro-life policies, the coming Embassy in Jerusalem and religious liberty issues, just to name a few. He easily wins the unofficial label of \u201cmost evangelical-friendly United States president ever.\u201d\n\nDoes Mr. Trump have moral failings? Yes. Critics will suggest a hypocrisy coming from evangelical leaders who are quick to denounce the ethical failings of others who don\u2019t have an \u201cR\u201d next to their name. But the goal of evangelicals has always been winning the larger battle over control of the culture, not to get mired in the moral failings of each and every candidate. For evangelicals, voting in the macro is the moral thing to do, even if the candidate is morally flawed. Evangelicals have tried the \u201cmoral\u201d candidate before.\n\nJimmy Carter was once the evangelical candidate. How did that work out in the macro? George W. Bush was the evangelical candidate in 2000: He pushed traditional conservative policies, but he doesn\u2019t come close to Mr. Trump\u2019s courageous blunt strokes in defense of evangelicals.\n\nEvangelicals have found their man. It may seem mystifying to outsiders, but for someone like me, with a front-row seat to an inside view, it makes perfect sense. Maybe they\u2019re taking their cue from Billy Graham, embracing presidents with moral failings rather than rejecting them.", "title": "Opinion | In Donald Trump, Evangelicals Have Found Their President", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "When Idaho lawmakers scrubbed all mentions of human-caused climate change from the state\u2019s education standards last year, they faced a swift backlash from teachers, parents and students who said that censoring science would leave students disadvantaged, jobs unfilled and the state unprepared for the future.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Idaho House Education Committee approved a revised set of standards that included some discussion of climate change . But the committee cut a section on the environmental impact of nonrenewable sources of energy and removed supporting content for standards that contained multiple references to human-driven warming.\n\nThe House committee\u2019s decision is not final. The state\u2019s Senate Education Committee will have a chance to weigh in, and the standards will need final approval from both chambers.\n\nThe sections on climate change that were cut had been watered down to satisfy lawmakers, and science education advocates had hoped the House committee would accept the revised standards in full. They said they were disappointed but not surprised by the committee\u2019s decision.", "title": "In Fight Over Science Education in Idaho, Lawmakers Move to Minimize Climate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "In any case, Mr. Baxley said lawmakers later decided to take the proposal off this week\u2019s agenda. \u201cI don\u2019t think we\u2019re ready for that discussion yet,\u201d he said.\n\nMore to the point for gun-control advocates is whether fury over the Parkland massacre might make a difference among Republican legislators who did not tighten gun laws after the killing of 49 people at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando two years ago.\n\n\u201cThey didn\u2019t do anything after Pulse, but these are 15-, 16- and 17-year-olds getting slaughtered,\u201d said State Senator Linda Stewart, a Democrat who represents part of Orange County. Ms. Stewart said her legislation banning assault weapons after the Orlando massacre had not even been assigned to a committee.\n\n\u201cThis is going to be harder to ignore,\u201d she said.\n\nAt the federal courthouse in Fort Lauderdale on Saturday, hundreds of people gathered for a rally promoting gun reform in what one official called the \u201cgunshine state.\u201d The day\u2019s speakers shouted into a microphone until their voices were hoarse and children barely out of diapers gripped giant signs. \u201cEnough is enough,\u201d read one.\n\nChanging Florida\u2019s gun laws could come down to two things: Whether Ms. Hammer can keep legislators from breaking ranks. And, the ambitions of Mr. Scott, who is increasingly expected to challenge Bill Nelson, the state\u2019s incumbent Democratic senator this year.\n\nMs. Hammer, who stands barely 5 feet tall, has been the state\u2019s chief gun lobbyist for decades and was the first woman to serve as national N.R.A. president. The state\u2019s Stand Your Ground and concealed-carry laws were largely her initiatives.", "title": "In Florida, Extraordinary Obstacles for Changes to Gun Laws", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "But other features that make the AR-15 so deadly on the battlefield remain. It is light, easy to hold and easy to fire, with a limited recoil. Bullets fly out of the muzzle more than twice as fast as most handgun rounds.\n\nEqually important for a gunman looking to do a lot of damage in a hurry: AR-15-style weapons are fed with box magazines that can be swapped out quickly. The standard magazine holds 30 rounds. Equipped in this way, a gunman can fire more than a hundred rounds in minutes.\n\nThe man accused of the killings in Parkland had \u201ccountless magazines\u201d for his AR-15, the local sheriff said.\n\nAnd there is still one more reason the weapons are so popular in states like Florida: They are very easy to buy \u2014 and for a 19-year-old like Nikolas Cruz, the shooting suspect, far easier to obtain than a handgun.\n\nFlorida has a three-day waiting period for handgun purchases. But anyone without a felony record, domestic abuse conviction, or a handful of other exceptions \u2014 such as a commitment to a mental institution \u2014 can walk into a gun store, wait a few minutes to clear a background check, and walk out with an AR-15 -style rifle, magazines and ammunition.\n\nUnder federal law, you also must be 21 to buy a handgun from a firearms dealer. But 18-year-olds can buy semiautomatic rifles.\n\nThe AR-15 rifle used in the attack was purchased legally, at Sunrise Tactical Supply in Florida, according to a federal law enforcement official. \u201cNo laws were violated in the procurement of this weapon,\u201d said Peter J. Forcelli, the special agent in charge for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives in Miami.\n\nVideo\n\nCongress explicitly banned AR-15s and other semiautomatic rifles that fit its definition of assault weapons from 1994 to 2004.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince that law expired 14 years ago, in most states it has been just as easy to buy an AR-15-style gun as it is in Florida. (Buyers can also purchase the weapon in person or online from private sellers who are not required to perform a background check \u2014 an exemption known as the \u201cgun show loophole.\u201d)\n\nOnly New York, California, Washington, D.C., and five other states have their own assault-weapon bans, according to the Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence. Washington, D.C., and eight states also limit the large capacity magazines that have made many mass shootings so deadly. Even so, there have been efforts to circumvent the bans, legally and illegally, by making minor changes to the weapons.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
