Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThese guns are much more deadly than traditional bolt-action rifles or traditional shotguns, but they are regulated the same way\u201d in most of the country, said Adam Skaggs, chief counsel of the Giffords center.\n\nAmong the six deadliest mass shootings in the last six years, the only one not carried out with an AR-15 style rifle was the Orlando nightclub attack two years ago that left 49 dead.\n\nThe gunman, Omar Mateen, had a Sig Sauer MCX semiautomatic rifle, which shares features with the AR-15, though it functions via a different semiautomatic design \u2014 and is just as deadly.\n\nAll of these military-style semiautomatic weapons have something else in common. They have been heavily marketed as home-defense and marksmanship weapons, and their sales have been a major driver of profits for gun manufacturers over the past two decades.\n\n\u201cAmericans own about five million AR-15s and it should go without saying that virtually all AR-15s are never misused,\u201d a post on an N.R.A. website said a few years ago, describing home protection and shooting competitions as among the ways the guns \u201care used by good people for perfectly good reasons.\u201d\n\nThe industry also now calls these weapons \u201cmodern sporting rifles.\u201d Gun organizations detest the label \u201cassault rifle,\u201d even though the federal legislation that enacted the decade-long ban specifically described the AR-15 and similar models as assault weapons. (The \u201cAR\u201d in the name, however, does not stand for assault rifle \u2014 it actually stands for ArmaLite rifle, reflecting the name of its original manufacturer.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nParadoxically, the industry has boomed when under threat of new regulations, as buyers made new purchases because they feared additional ownership limits were about to be imposed.\n\nFor similar reasons, the election of Donald J. Trump helped clobber the share prices of some gun makers, as fears of new restrictions eased.\n\nThe publicly traded gun makers Sturm, Ruger & Company and American Outdoor Brands both lost about a quarter of their market value in the days after Mr. Trump\u2019s victory.\n\nEarlier this week the Remington Outdoor Company, one of the country\u2019s biggest and oldest gun manufacturers, said it would seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection amid plunging sales and mounting losses.", "title": "In Florida, an AR-15 Is Easier to Buy Than a Handgun", "authors": ["Richard A. Oppel Jr."]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Thus we prepared. We purchased a gizmo known as an anti-bark collar. The way it worked: Whenever he barked, he would be sprayed in the face with citronella. It helped somewhat, but we felt bad when he scratched his neck in our elevator and got sprayed.\n\nSo we enrolled him in a six-session Canine Good Citizen class at the Southampton Animal Shelter in Hampton Bays, N.Y. Unexpectedly, the one dog he was tranquil around was a pit bull named Bundles. Great, but how many pit bulls were we likely to encounter on the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es? As summer wore on, Pip got better. He did not get perfect.\n\nThere was one other ticklish issue. Pronounced in French, \u201cPip\u201d translates poorly, to a word vastly inappropriate for proper public discourse. It would be awkward to yell out breezily while on a congested street, \u201cPip. Pip. Pip.\u201d It is not unknown for the French to call dogs names like Marceau or Quesnel or Xarles. For his time on French soil, Susan suggested Pip should just become Pierre.\n\nOur trip was to Paris for a week, then a few days in Bordeaux, winding up back in Paris. We chose September, when vacationing Parisians would have replenished the city and be ready to greet people who fit in smoothly. Like us and Pip.\n\nPip strutted onto our Air France plane as if he did this every day, while we toted the canine carrier he was supposed to occupy. To ride in the cabin on Air France, a dog plus carrier must not exceed 17 pounds. Pip made it by ounces, but, then, no one weighed him. He was also required to have a microchip and rabies vaccination, plus the U.S.D.A. needed to sign off on a health certificate. The vet gave us anti-anxiety pills, but Pip nodded off at the first hum of the engines. When he awoke, we were in Paris.", "title": "In France, Our Dog Has His Day", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "The ruling highlights a strange bipolar quality of Germany when it comes to the environment: Famous for its meticulous recycling, its decision to abandon nuclear power and its subsidies for wind and solar energy, Germany has long had a reputation for being a green powerhouse, and it now draws roughly a third of its electricity production from renewable sources. Chancellor Angela Merkel has been nicknamed the \u201cclimate chancellor.\u201d\n\nBut Ms. Merkel also has lobbied in Brussels for softer emissions targets and has so far refused to set a date for exiting coal production. Germany\u2019s carbon emissions have not declined in about a decade. Having reiterated a target to cut carbon emissions by 40 percent by 2020 as recently as last summer, Ms. Merkel recently admitted that it will in fact be missed by a wide margin.\n\nOn the question of diesel bans, she has long taken the side of the industry. \u201cWe will use all our power to prevent such bans,\u201d she told Parliament ahead of elections last September.\n\n\u201cShe is the No. 1 lobbyist for the car industry,\u201d said J\u00fcrgen Resch of Deutsche Umwelthilfe, the nonprofit environmental organization that won the court ruling on Tuesday. \u201cIn other countries the commerce minister might lobby for the car industry; in Germany it is the chancellor.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe ruling came as the German car industry is still struggling to emerge from an ongoing global emissions scandal that forced Volkswagen to pay more than $26 billion in fines and plead guilty to federal fraud and conspiracy charges in the United States. The company admitted to manipulating pollution controls on vehicles so that they could pass laboratory emissions tests, even as the cars continued to far exceed pollution standards on the road.\n\nIn few cities is the country\u2019s environmental schizophrenia more stark than Stuttgart, capital of the wealthy state of Baden-W\u00fcrttemberg.\n\nThe Daimler star was visible on Tuesday, but so were brightly lit electronic signs across the city that declared a \u201cparticulate-matter alarm\u201d and urged residents to leave their cars at home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn days like this, a yellowish cloud hangs over Stuttgart. Regional courts here and in D\u00fcsseldorf, two of 19 cities where the environmental organization is suing, had ruled that diesel bans were a viable way to bring down harmful and illegal levels of air pollution. Diesel engines emit small particles and nitrogen dioxide that have been linked to cancer and more than 12,000 of premature deaths in Germany, experts say. Local authorities appealed the rulings, but on Tuesday the Federal Administrative Court rejected those appeals.\n\nIndustry leaders were stunned. Daimler declined to comment, but other carmakers expressed bewilderment. Volkswagen \u201cis unable to comprehend\u201d the ruling, a company statement said. \u201cIt threatens to produce a regulatory hodgepodge in Germany, which is unsettling for millions of motorists.\u201d\n\nThe Mechanical Engineering Industry Association, whose members include car-parts makers and other companies in the automotive supply chain, said in a statement that \u201cdriving bans for diesel vehicles are the wrong way to solve a problem that arises in very particular locations under very particular conditions.\u201d\n\nGottlieb Daimler famously invented one of the first cars here in his garden in 1886. It is now home to Daimler and Porsche and Bosch, the world\u2019s biggest car-part maker. Roughly one in five jobs in the region depends on the industry. School classes flock to the Daimler museum. Concert lovers attend performances at the Porsche arena. Once a year, Formula 1 drivers meet locals at the \u201cStars in Cars\u201d festival. The vast majority of taxis in the city are Mercedeses \u2014 fueled by diesel.\n\nBut Stuttgart, nestled in a basin framed by vineyards and forested hills, also has a long tradition of hiking clubs and solar panels on its rooftops. The city has a Green mayor, who drives an electric car, and has been governed by a coalition led by the Greens since 2011. It also has a vibrant local environmental movement, which has been protesting a multiyear, multibillion euro project in the heart of the city to move the main train station underground.\n\nOutraged at the sprawling and polluting building site, known as \u201cStuttgart 21,\u201d residents have been demonstrating every Monday for seven years.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis week, on the eve of the diesel ruling, as air pollution measurements reached twice the level permitted under European standards, the 406th protest took place. Braving subzero temperatures, Mr. Resch, the man who filed the driving ban lawsuit, addressed a small but noisy crowd.\n\n\u201cIn Baden-W\u00fcrttemberg it\u2019s not the people who decide,\u201d he shouted to loud cheers, \u201cit\u2019s the car industry!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe state\u2019s transport minister, Winfried Hermann of the Greens, says he sympathizes. Whenever politicians demand action on automobile emissions, he said, a familiar pattern is repeated. \u201cWe say, clean up your technology, they say it is impossible,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Hermann has been increasing suburban train services and bus lines to fight pollution and also wants to create a 7,000-kilometer network of bike paths. But he knows it is an uphill battle.\n\n\u201cThe people who make cars want to drive them, too,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s professional pride. To a certain extent, it is identity.\u201d\n\nA short journey from the city center, in one of the many Daimler factories dotted around Stuttgart, Andreas Klatt, a machinist who has worked for Daimler for almost four decades, proudly showed off his company ID badge.\n\n\u201cThis gives you special standing, it gives you respect,\u201d he said, describing how working for the company has helped him secure bank loans.\n\nThis January, the company sold the most cars in its history, Mr. Klatt proudly recounted. Last year, he got a 5,700-euro bonus. This year it might be even more. Mr. Klatt works 35 hours a week, has seven weeks of annual vacation and makes close to 80,000 euros a year.\n\n\u201cWorking for Daimler is like winning the lottery,\u201d he said.\n\nWolfgang Nieke, a member of the powerful IG Metall labor union at Daimler, once worked on the factory floor but is now one of 10 employee representatives on the company\u2019s supervisory board. Workers and bosses fight over pay. But they both oppose a diesel ban.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like changing the offside rule in the middle of the soccer match,\u201d Mr. Nieke said. \u201cYou can\u2019t do that.\u201d\n\nSome 150,000 people work for Daimler and more than 60,000 of them drive a Mercedes, he said. Daimler employees get a 21.5 percent discount when they buy an in-house brand.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat about all those who bought a diesel three years ago?\u201d Mr. Nieke asked. \u201cAnd now you want to tell them that they can\u2019t drive their car?\u201d\n\nMr. Niess, the retired teacher and environmental activist, has won three court cases against the city for not upholding air quality standards. Once, he owned a diesel-powered car, having bought it after being told it had lower carbon emissions than a regular gas-powered car. \u201cI bought it because they told me it was good for climate change,\u201d he recalled.\n\n\u201cWe have all been fooled by the car industry,\u201d he said.\n\nThese days, Mr. Niess only bikes in the city. He lives around the corner from Neckartor, long one of the most polluted areas in the country. Stuttgart exceeded safe pollution levels 45 days last year, down from 63 days the year before. But the European Union ceiling is 35 days.\n\nMore than a century ago, Mr. Daimler predicted that there would never be more than a million cars in the world. These days, that number passes Neckartor roughly every two weeks.\n\nThe mayor of Stuttgart, Fritz Kuhn, says the only way to reconcile the dependence on the car industry for jobs and export revenues is to build clean cars.\n\n\u201cEconomic history is littered with examples where protecting today\u2019s jobs destroys tomorrow\u2019s,\u201d he said. Stuttgart knows this first hand: A once-thriving and highly skilled watchmaking industry failed to keep up with modernization and largely died out. The only thing left are the handcrafted cuckoo clocks.\n\n\u201cIf Germany wants to continue to dominate the car industry, it needs to become a champion of electric cars and sustainable mobility and autonomous cars,\u201d Mr. Kuhn said.\n\nHe drives an electric Smart. Made by Daimler.", "title": "In Germany\u2019s Car Capital, the Unthinkable: The Right to Ban Cars", "authors": ["Katrin Bennhold"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Though Guam is a tiny island without soccer pedigree, FIFA\u2019s political structure allows it to have as much weight in important decisions, including the choice of the president and the host of the World Cup, as powerhouse nations like Germany, Brazil and Argentina.\n\nLai, a prominent businessman and political donor in Guam, in April 2017 pleaded guilty to wire fraud charges in New York, telling the U.S. District Court in Brooklyn he accepted almost $1 million from wealthy sports power brokers in the Persian Gulf who were seeking to buy his support and use him to recruit other Asian soccer officials prepared to take bribes. The American authorities overseeing the case allowed Lai to return to Guam while he awaits sentencing.\n\nAfter his guilty plea, Lai received a lifetime ban from soccer in November 2017. But that has not stopped him from meddling in local soccer, according to an affidavit provided to FIFA by Randall Cunliffe, one of the 13 voters in the election to fill Lai\u2019s former post in 2017.\n\nCunliffe told FIFA, where he is a member of the soccer body\u2019s disciplinary panel, that Lai contacted him by telephone and urged him to pick the man who went on to win the race to be his successor, Valentino San Gil. San Gil, who had been the Guam federation\u2019s general secretary under Lai, beat his opponent, Robert Torres, a longtime former member of FIFA\u2019s ethics committee, by one vote.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTorres, who served as Guam\u2019s chief justice until January 2017, said in a telephone interview that he was aware of the accusations about Lai\u2019s involvement in the election, which used handwritten paper ballots. He called for an investigation to determine whether the vote had been corrupted.\n\nSan Gil did not reply to messages seeking comment. Lai\u2019s testimony in federal court forced Sheikh Ahmad al-Fahad al-Sabah of Kuwait, a powerful power broker in soccer and the Olympic movement, to quit his soccer roles after allegations surfaced in Lai\u2019s guilty plea that he had bribed Asian officials, though he denies any wrongdoing.\n\nSheikh Ahmad spent months out of public view before resurfacing at a gathering of Olympic officials late last year. He has been attending the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea.\n\nA FIFA spokesman said its disciplinary committee had received an anonymous complaint about Lai but no direct evidence. However, Cunliffe\u2019s affidavit shows he has been in contact with FIFA, including with Gautier Aubert, the organization\u2019s head of ethics. Cunliffe, a lawyer who serves on FIFA\u2019s appeals committee, did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGuam, like all FIFA members, is entitled to a share of the largess FIFA dispenses. FIFA\u2019s president, Gianni Infantino, has increased those sums four times, to $1.4 billion across each quadrennial World Cup cycle.\n\nIn his affidavit, Cunliffe said Lai had told him in the past he had paid stipends of $10,000 to board members of Guam\u2019s federation \u201cin order to ameliorate them and continue to support his candidacy.\u201d\n\nCunliffe also told FIFA of at least three examples when soccer federation contracts were given to family members of board members, including some projects that would be directly financed through FIFA and Guam government funds. In one example, a firm run by the brother of San Gil, the new federation president, has received thousands of dollars in contracts dating back several years, according to documents reviewed by The Times.", "title": "In Guam, Soccer Powerbroker Is Accused of Wielding Influence Despite Ban", "authors": ["Tariq Panja"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. DeVos called the expansion of 529 plans in the December tax law to cover K-12 expenses a \u201cbig win\u201d for private and parochial school choice but agreed with analysts who said that the legislation was limited in its impact, especially for low-income students from families with limited means to save.\n\nShe signaled that she had settled for using her platform to champion the cause.\n\n\u201cThere hasn\u2019t been a secretary that has talked about empowering parents and giving them choices before,\u201d Ms. DeVos said. \u201cAnd I think that\u2019s a huge benefit, and frankly a privilege to do \u2014 to try to be a voice for many parents who don\u2019t have voices.\u201d\n\n2. She is proud and pained by regulatory rollbacks.\n\nMs. DeVos said she believed that reducing the department\u2019s footprint had been \u201csome of the most important work we\u2019ve done in this first year.\u201d But she said that the most significant rollback thus far \u2014 Title IX guidance issued under President Barack Obama for investigating sexual assaults on campus \u2014 had been \u201cprobably one of the most heartbreaking parts of this job.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs a mom and a grandma, I think about my children, and we need to get this right. We need to get it right for all students, and it clearly hasn\u2019t worked in far too many cases,\u201d she said.\n\nVictims and advocates have said that Ms. DeVos\u2019s rescission of the campus sexual assault guidance, which she replaced with interim guidance that changed the standard of proof for investigations, has had a chilling effect on victims who are reluctant to report assaults.\n\n\u201cThat would certainly be the last thing I would desire or want,\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t think that the interim guidance that we provided ultimately does that in any way.\u201d\n\nMs. DeVos said the department was still examining the Obama-era guidance that addressed the disproportionate impact of discipline policies and special education placements on minority students. Civil rights organizations have pointed to Ms. DeVos\u2019s re-examination of these policies as evidence of her lack of empathy for vulnerable populations.", "title": "In Her Words: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos Assesses a Year on the Job", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Each of the 44 pieces is tagged with the name of the publication, including this one, that first commissioned and paid for it. The range of topics \u2014 literary and sporting, personal and political \u2014 provides a map of what various editors over the years thought Amis might be interested in. Or (not quite the same thing) what they thought their readers might be interested in Amis on. I\u2019m not snarking, I\u2019m admiring. We can quibble about whether the ability to turn out a predetermined quantity of lucid, witty, sometimes moving, rarely boring prose on assignment and on deadline should be classified as a talent or a skill \u2014 I\u2019m here to tell you it isn\u2019t easy \u2014 or about whether thinky journalism is an art or a craft. What seems to me beyond argument is that Amis is good at it.\n\nHe is especially good at literary criticism. The best parts of \u201cThe Rub of Time\u201d are devoted to his two favorite novelists, Vladimir Nabokov and Saul Bellow (whom he calls his \u201cTwin Peaks\u201d). Amis\u2019s affection for them is hardly news, and there is some repetition among the essays, but they serve as vaccines against cynicism, as reminders that affection is a powerful engine of critical inquiry. Bellow he adores without qualification: \u201cI hereby trumpet the prediction that Bellow will emerge as the supreme American novelist.\u201d Nabokov, arguably a more pervasive influence, is a more complicated case. Amis has never been able to finish \u201cAda,\u201d and he notes with measured distaste that Nabokov\u2019s imagination, in his later years, \u201cinsufficiently honored the innocence \u2026 of 12-year-old girls,\u201d adding, \u201cThis leaves a faint but visible scar on the leviathan of his corpus.\u201d\n\nImage Credit Alessandra Montalto/The New York Times\n\nOur favorite writers can lead us into ideological brier patches and ethical thickets. They can confuse and disappoint us, which is why we must keep rereading them. That is how I am with Amis. I will confess an absolute and steadfast devotion to his novels \u2014 including the bad ones, of which there are not a few \u2014 even as I chuckle to see him (and by implication myself) described, in a jokey online catalog of rotten literary men, as \u201cthe favorite author of every dude who hates women but loves telling people about the year he lived in London.\u201d When asked by one of his Independent questioners whether he\u2019s a misogynist, Amis responds that his wife doesn\u2019t seem to think so, that he has written some fine female characters and that he is a \u201cgynocrat\u201d who believes women should run the world. Maybe so, but he doesn\u2019t seem to believe they write novels worth discussing. He does, in passing, mention reading Zadie Smith \u201cwith a constant smile of admiration,\u201d but the essay about Iris Murdoch is really about her husband, John Bayley, and the one about Jane Austen is really about Hollywood.\n\nAmis\u2019s literary interests are limited not only by gender, but also by generation, and the two limitations are entwined. Like Prince Charles, who was also born just after World War II, and with whom he has half-ironically identified, he is a permanent son. This means he cranes his neck to see what the grown-ups are doing long after becoming a grown-up himself. The criticism collected here is mostly about his male elders: Philip Roth, John Updike, Don DeLillo, Anthony Burgess, J. G. Ballard, Philip Larkin and of course Kingsley Amis. Whatever Oedipal aggression Martin may have harbored toward these dads has softened into mildly barbed fondness, and the result is assessments that are clearsighted and generous. This is especially valuable in the case of Larkin, whose greatness is wound up tightly with his flaws. Amis\u2019s explanation of why Larkin is not \u201ca poet\u2019s poet\u201d but \u201ca novelist\u2019s poet\u201d is so illuminating, so useful to a reader, that it almost justifies the book all by itself.\n\nBut there is some filler to get through. Sending Amis \u2014 the author of books called \u201cMoney\u201d and \u201cSuccess\u201d \u2014 to Las Vegas to play poker may have seemed inspired, but his insights prove to be as middling as the cards that sent him home a loser. The essay isn\u2019t a bad read, but Colson Whitehead on poker is a much better one. Likewise, if you want to read about the porn industry, you\u2019re better off with David Foster Wallace (or, more recently, Molly Lambert). Those writers allow themselves to be genuinely troubled or flummoxed by what they see, whereas Amis is hampered by his unflappability and his reluctance to be seen taking the wrong things too seriously.", "title": "In His New Collection, \u2018The Rub of Time,\u2019 Martin Amis Takes On Everyone From Travolta to Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "In 2010, Virtue and Moir became the first North Americans to win Olympic gold in ice dancing, a sport once dominated, with some notable exceptions, by Soviet and Russian skaters.\n\nLast week, Virtue and Moir won a second gold medal, in the team skating event. A third gold places them among legends in the sport, alongside Gillis Grafstrom of Sweden, who won the men\u2019s singles competition in 1920, 1924 and 1928; Sonja Henie of Norway, who won the women\u2019s singles in 1928, 1932 and 1936; and Irina Rodnina, the Soviet pairs skater who swept three consecutive golds with two partners in 1976, 1980 and 1984.\n\nVirtue and Moir now have five career Olympic medals, the most among figure skaters, though earlier generations did not have a chance to compete in the Olympic team competition, which began at the 2014 Games.\n\nIce dancing often does not receive the same respect from outsiders as singles and pairs skating. No throws or jumps or lifts above the head are allowed. That can make it difficult to discern between competitors based on the precision and edge control of their dance steps, unless someone makes an obvious mistake as they earn points with step sequences and permitted lifts.\n\nThe Canadian and French couples are highly regarded across the sport, given their accomplishments and fearlessly aspirational performances. Virtue and Moir carried the flag for Canada in the opening ceremony at these Games. \u201cOne thing I\u2019ve always admired, they never seem to play it safe,\u201d Hubbell, the American, said of the Canadians.\n\nFor many fans of ice dancing, Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean of Britain remain the best ever, signature innovators whose gold medal \u201cBolero\u201d routine at the 1984 Winter Olympics remains one of the most memorable moments in figure skating.", "title": "In Ice Dancing, the Electric Tops the Ethereal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "The spokesman said that the family had been told that he killed himself in prison after having confessed to spying. The family denies the allegation of spying and doubts he committed suicide, but the prison authorities have so far refused to return Mr. Seyed Emami\u2019s body to the family for a proper autopsy. He was to be buried on Tuesday, and it remained unclear if the family\u2019s wish for an independent autopsy would be granted.\n\nAlso unclear is where the country\u2019s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, comes down in the feud between the hard-liners and Mr. Rouhani. Mr. Khamenei has long sought to balance opposing factions to preserve his power, and analysts said he would be unlikely to take a strong stand on one side or the other until he felt he had no choice. On major decisions, like the nuclear agreement and seeking better relations with the international community, he has supported Mr. Rouhani, if grudgingly.\n\nOn Sunday, Mr. Rouhani struck back at his opponents, warning the Revolutionary Guards, the judiciary and the clerical councils that his government is considering organizing a referendum to break the deadlock between those who want change and those who want to hold it back.\n\n\u201cAnywhere we may have differences,\u201d he said in a speech at the 39th anniversary of the Islamic Revolution, \u201cwe should refer to the vote of the people and a referendum.\u201d\n\nWhile there is little chance of that plan succeeding, analysts say, suggesting a referendum could perhaps help Mr. Rouhani regain popularity among the middle classes who have become cynical over his inability to deliver on years of promises of a more open and transparent economy and greater personal freedoms.\n\n\u201cMr. Rouhani insists on diverting attention away from his failing economic policies,\u201d said Hamidreza Taraghi, a hard-line political analyst. \u201cThe government is not allowed to initiate referendums on everything, only in the case of a stalemate between separate powers. These are just disputes.\u201d\n\nSince the New Year\u2019s protests, the pressure on the two sides has only increased, with the economy dragging and the national currency, the rial, falling sharply in value against the dollar and the euro. The government is having trouble attracting desperately needed foreign investment, because of unilateral United States sanctions and uncertainty over the fate of the nuclear agreement.", "title": "In Iran, Environmentalists Are Now Seen as Spies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "In an interview at the Foreign Ministry last month, Mr. Kono smiled impishly when asked how soon he might make a bid to lead the Liberal Democratic Party. \u201cYou never know,\u201d he said. \u201cWho predicted President Trump two years ago?\u201d\n\nUntil being appointed to the cabinet last August, Mr. Kono, who speaks English fluently and left Tokyo\u2019s prestigious Keio University to study at Georgetown University in Washington, was not usually on the list of potential heirs to Mr. Abe, given his sometimes more liberal views.\n\nHe is also the son of Yohei Kono, a previous foreign minister who, as chief cabinet secretary in 1993, issued a breakthrough apology to women from Korea and elsewhere who were forced to work as sex slaves in Japanese military brothels during World War II. Nationalists in the governing party have long resented the so-called Kono Statement, with some holding it against the son.\n\nAnd unlike the typically somber political elite, Mr. Kono frequently shows a playful side.\n\nOn Twitter, in Japanese and English, he reveals glimpses of his sense of humor.\n\nExhibiting a sweet tooth, he regularly posts pictures of macarons served in foreign destinations. Of a photo of a box of M&M\u2019s bearing Mr. Trump\u2019s signature, Mr. Kono quipped, \u201cTastes the same.\u201d Last month, he posted photos with Chinese officials and of a lunch menu in Beijing.\n\nPhoto\n\nWith an eye on persuading his own party to consider him for the top office, Mr. Kono has toned down some of his views and aligned himself with the administration.\n\nAs soon as he was appointed to the cabinet, Mr. Kono distanced himself from his father (to whom he famously donated a piece of his liver 16 years ago), reminding Foreign Ministry staff that \u201cYohei Kono and Taro Kono are completely different.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKunihiko Miyake, a former senior Japanese diplomat, said, \u201cTaro Kono version 1.0 is now becoming version 2.0.\u201d\n\nIn the interview last month, Mr. Kono declined to comment on his previous proposals to rid Japan of nuclear power. Instead, he offered an administration talking point: \u201cThe official Abe government nuclear policy is to reduce dependency on nuclear as much as possible,\u201d he said.\n\nTakao Toshikawa, editor of a political newsletter, Insideline, said of Mr. Kono: \u201cSince he assumed an important ministerial position, I think he realized that the reality would not be changed only with an ideal.\u201d\n\nStill, the rebel peeks out. In a January speech in Abu Dhabi, Mr. Kono criticized Japan\u2019s \u201clamentable\u201d energy policy and exhorted his country to expand renewable energy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cJapan was way ahead in solar heat and photovoltaic before,\u201d Mr. Kono said in the interview last month. \u201cI think Japan was No. 1 and then we kind of fell behind.\u201d He added, \u201cIf you don\u2019t call it lamentable, I don\u2019t know how to call it.\u201d\n\nMr. Kono stays on the party\u2019s message on key issues, including keeping up pressure on North Korea and adhering to a 2015 agreement with South Korea to resolve the dispute over the so-called comfort women who worked in military brothels.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s been mostly very much toeing the Abe line,\u201d said Kristi Govella, assistant professor of Asian Studies at the University of Hawaii at Manoa. \u201cBut there are some cases where he has been willing to say this is not the best policy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWith a tweet, he can pierce the bubble of political pomposity. After giving an opening speech in Parliament last month, he called his performance \u201csuper high-strung.\u201d\n\nHe takes some lumps on social media. After suggesting that the foreign minister should have a dedicated plane (he currently travels on commercial flights), he blocked several Twitter followers who criticized him for wanting to waste tax money.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile at Georgetown, he volunteered in a campaign for Alan Cranston, a Democratic senator from California, and interned for Richard Shelby, then a Democratic congressman from Alabama and now a Republican senator.\n\nSenator Shelby described Mr. Kono as \u201cprobably stubborn, but he\u2019s not stupid.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf he believes in something and he thinks he\u2019s right,\u201d Mr. Shelby said in a telephone interview, \u201che\u2019ll stand his ground.\u201d\n\nMr. Kono\u2019s fluency in English makes him well suited to the role of foreign minister. At a meeting of world leaders in Manila last August, Mr. Kono effectively doubled the amount of time he was able to spend speaking with Rex Tillerson, the American secretary of state, because he did not need an interpreter.\n\nHe is the first Japanese foreign minister to visit Pakistan since 2009. He has taken an active interest in the Middle East and South Asia as the United States makes controversial decisions like moving the United States Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem and freezing security aid to Pakistan. In Jerusalem in December, Mr. Kono told Israeli and Palestinian leaders that the city\u2019s status should be resolved through negotiations.\n\nAt home, he has called on Japan to open its borders to more immigration.\n\n\u201cWe need to talk about immigration policy sooner because it\u2019s a very psychological issue,\u201d Mr. Kono said, acknowledging public wariness of foreigners. \u201cI don\u2019t think we can wait that long because we are losing our aging population fast,\u201d he added.\n\nAnalysts point out that some of his views may not be so progressive. In the interview last month, he suggested that immigrants could be admitted if they demonstrate proficiency in Japanese, but in the past, Japan has used language requirements to bar immigrants.\n\nTo explain the tiny number of refugees in Japan, Mr. Kono repeated the government\u2019s line that most asylum seekers are \u201cfalsely applying\u201d and just want to work in Japan.\n\nAs for his political ambitions, commentators say one challenge will be persuading the right-leaning Liberal Democrats to choose him.\n\n\u201cHe must be dreaming of a version 3.0 in the future,\u201d said Mr. Miyake, the former diplomat. \u201cBut to get to version 3.0 is much more difficult than getting from 1.0 to 2.0.\u201d", "title": "In Japan, a Liberal Maverick Is Seeking to Lead a Conservative Party", "authors": ["Motoko Rich"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 He was perhaps the least famous billionaire in a city brimming with wealthy celebrities.\n\nBut Patrick Soon-Shiong, 65, a doctor who turned a cancer drug into a multibillion-dollar biotech empire, emerged on Wednesday as a major figure in Los Angeles life with his surprise $500 million purchase of The Los Angeles Times and its sister newspaper, The San Diego Union-Tribune.\n\nDr. Soon-Shiong has a long \u2014 and sometimes checkered \u2014 history in the medical field going back to the 1990s, but has kept a relatively low profile in the political, cultural and philanthropic doings of the city. He now faces the challenge of stabilizing a newspaper engulfed by turmoil and diminished in resources.\n\nHis is an immigrant\u2019s tale that captures the story of Los Angeles today: a Chinese doctor who was raised in South Africa before coming to Los Angeles to make his fortune. He is worth an estimated $8 billion, and has been called the richest man in Los Angeles. He is a part owner of the Los Angeles Lakers, having bought Magic Johnson\u2019s 4.5 percent stake in the team in 2010 before setting his sights on what friends said he viewed as the ultimate prize of social cachet: the 136-year-old, award-winning newspaper that has long displayed the city\u2019s ambitions to the world.", "title": "In Los Angeles, a Billionaire Doctor Takes On an Ailing Newspaper", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Real Madrid, like P.S.G., obsesses over the Champions League, though its reasons are very different. To Real, this competition is a central part of its identity: It has won the trophy 12 times, including three of the last four years; the European Cup defines what Real is.\n\nIn Parisian eyes, by contrast, the competition is a symbol of what P.S.G. wishes \u2014 no, craves \u2014 to be. There is no glory in winning the French domestic championship, not for a club with a budget vastly larger than any of its rivals\u2019. There is no pride in claiming either of the country\u2019s domestic cups, not to a Qatari ownership group that got involved in soccer to accrue that unique soft power, that sense of relevance that the world\u2019s most popular sport offers.\n\nOnly the Champions League justifies the investment, only the Champions League validates the project, only the Champions League brings Qatar the kudos it desires: proof that what was once a backwater can become a global player.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt was for the Champions League that P.S.G. sanctioned a $276 million move last summer for Neymar, the Brazilian superstar. It did not sign him from Barcelona, in the words of the midfielder Adrien Rabiot, to help P.S.G. \u201cscore eight against Dijon.\u201d\n\nThe club does not indulge Neymar \u2014 throwing him a lavish, two-day birthday party earlier this month and giving him a variety of \u201cprivileges,\u201d in Rabiot\u2019s words again, that others do not enjoy \u2014 to perform party tricks in Ligue 1. It does so because it sees him as the sort of player who can deliver in these moments, on the biggest stages, against the most illustrious opponents.\n\nHis ability to do so is not in question: P.S.G. knows that all too well \u2014 it was Neymar, after all, who orchestrated that humiliation in Barcelona last year. In Madrid, though, in Parisian colors, he could not repeat the trick.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor his part, Neymar\u2019s decision to leave Catalonia centered on his desire to establish himself as the best player in the world, the standard-bearer for the generation behind Lionel Messi and Ronaldo. He could not be heralded as the finest player on the planet, ran the logic, if he was not the finest player on his team. If, from the outside, it looked almost like a step down, there was a sense that the ambitions of player and team meshed rather neatly. Both, after all, had their eyes on usurping the established order.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor Neymar, then, as much as P.S.G., this was a night to shine, and not just because Real has convinced itself that the Brazilian yearns to make Madrid his permanent home. This was his chance to demonstrate that his move to Paris had been more than folly, that change was coming.\n\nHe did not do it. Neymar did not decide this game: Ronaldo, the man he would depose, did. It should not be a source of great controversy to suggest that Ronaldo, at 33, is now beyond his wondrous peak, no longer the force of nature he once was. He has had to metamorphose into something different to remain pre-eminent. Where once Ronaldo\u2019s embroidery \u2014 his dazzling array of tricks, his jet heels \u2014 set him apart, now it is his economy, his ruthlessness.\n\nTwice, when the pressure was greatest, Ronaldo delivered. Not prettily, necessarily \u2014 he converted a penalty kick to draw Real level, after Rabiot had given P.S.G. the lead, and then scuttled the ball home fortuitously to put his team ahead \u2014 but decisively.\n\nIt was a model of efficiency, an object lesson of what big players do in big moments.\n\nNeymar was the opposite: endless slaloming dribbles, drifting effortlessly past defenders with sure touches and elegant movement \u2014 all culminating in cul-de-sacs. It was an inherently cinematic performance. He played as you imagine a superstar should, as opposed to how a superstar does.\n\nHe will have a chance, in Paris next month, to make amends. Unai Emery, his coach, saw enough here to believe his team can score the two goals it needs to progress to the quarterfinals (though it may well require more). The score line, he said, \u201cdoes not reflect what we saw on the pitch.\u201d\n\nP.S.G. has heard that line before. It has felt this sensation before. It is the mantra of a team that gets so far and then can go no further: We are so close, we will get there in the end. The ceiling, though, never seems to shift. It always there, just beyond reach, unyielding, unforgiving.", "title": "In Loss to Real Madrid, P.S.G. Fails on the Big Stage It Covets", "authors": ["Rory Smith", "On Soccer"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "On a grim, traffic-clogged corporate block in Milan, Moschino marks the entrance to its joyful world as only the Italian brand would: with an eight-foot teddy bear.\n\nHere, on the day before the brand\u2019s fall/winter 2018 show, a white-walled upstairs studio was brimming with an unruly rainbow of clothing: racks of boucl\u00e9 skirt suits in sky blue and tangerine, satin glamour gowns in jewel-like pinks and purples, prim biker jackets with matching skirts in fuchsia and Big-Bird yellow. And many accessories (baby backpacks, biker jacket-shaped bags, fluffy berets) to match.\n\nDressed in cropped leather motorcycle pants, a cycling cap that reads \u201cNormal\u201d and a T-shirt on which he had safety-pinned a hand-markered message to \u201cDemand Gun Conrol Now,\u201d Jeremy Scott sat perched on a tall director\u2019s chair emblazoned with his name. He surveyed models in a succession of candy-colored Jackie O. coordinates with matching pillbox hats, pumps, and patent leather gloves.\n\nA designer who has built his career around surrealistic gibes exploiting pop iconography, Scott\u2019s offering this season is a cockeyed caricature of the styles favored by the former first lady and Marilyn Monroe. \u201cTrump is drowning us with conspiracy theories and fake news, so I\u2019m taking it back to the original conspiracy theory,\u201d he said. Thus his inspiration of the moment: the deaths of Marilyn and JFK, and an out-there set-up which claims that the president shared the government secret of alien existence with the starlet. \u201cAnd maybe Jackie was an alien,\u201d Scott laughs, out-imagining even the loopiest conspiracy theories. He shrugs. \u201cWe need crazy fantasies.\u201d For the next day\u2019s show, Scott will have a handful of models painted in acid bright shades from head-to-toe \u2014 an army of extraterrestrial Jackies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nScott is a Los Angeles man who commutes to Milan for Moschino. \u201cI love my home. I love the sun. I love that people have the same political views as I do, and that there\u2019s the sugary and saccharine sweet fantasy of Hollywood,\u201d he said, as the model Birgit Kos crossed the room in an orchid-toned satin gown, its dense tail of heavy black sequins crunching with each step. \u201cL.A. is the land of dreams and fantasies, and that\u2019s so much of what\u2019s informed my vision throughout my career.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe next day, in a vast former train depot where the show would be held in a few hours time, the hairstylist Paul Hanlon and the makeup artist Kabuki were already at work with their teams. Models still in their street clothes were being fitted with fishnet caps, their hair slicked down underneath to prepare for the bobbed wigs that would transform them into \u201960s vixens for the runway. A few sat in the corner, already being brushed with the thick pigment that would turn their skin alien color. Eschewing the preparations to go for a jog, the designer arrived backstage an hour before showtime, as the models walked a final run-through with their makeup and hair mostly finished.\n\nRaised on a farm in Kansas, Scott rose to fame in a flash when, 20 years ago in Paris, he launched his own eponymous brand, a sendup of commercial culture incorporating mass symbols from McDonald\u2019s and Coca-Cola to \u201cSponge Bob\u201d and \u201cThe Simpsons.\u201d There was always a marked congruence between Scott\u2019s flippant aesthetic and the famous irreverence of Franco Moschino, who founded his namesake brand in Milan in 1983, yet even though during his student years he interned at Aeffe (which owns Moschino, among other brands), \u201cI never thought, one day I\u2019m going to take over,\u201d said the designer, who is now approaching his fifth anniversary as creative director. \u201cI was just taking out the trash and doing my intern duties for Michelle Stein then. Years later, Michelle called to give me the news, and it dawned on me that I\u2019m the only person who can do this, I\u2019m the only one with the integrity of Franco\u2019s voice, because we do have this commonality. I merged into it like putting on a glove.\u201d", "title": "In Milan, a Trip to Jeremy Scott\u2019s Candy-Colored World", "authors": ["Laura Rysman"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "The ad hoc tour Mr. McNeal took me on had been refreshingly frank. He drove straight to a historical placard describing the bustling slave markets that had been held at Court Square, the city\u2019s central roundabout. I asked Mr. McNeal why it didn\u2019t have more central placement in the square and he just laughed: \u201cWhat else are they going to do? It\u2019s not like they can build an auction platform here. That would really piss some people off!\u201d\n\nWhen I mentioned to him that multiple people had suggested I eat at Central, an upscale Southern food restaurant in downtown\u2019s tiny revitalized commercial district, he joked, \u201cCentral is so expensive, you\u2019d be better off buying a restaurant and opening and stocking the kitchen yourself.\u201d We went to Applebee\u2019s instead, and gorged on spinach and artichoke dip.\n\nI did end up at Central on another night, and it was indeed quite good \u2014 part of a growing culinary scene that will include gourmet offerings at the renovated Kress on Dexter building downtown, which opens in April. The former block-wide department store, built in 1929, will host rotating pop-up markets devoted to local artists \u2014 and has been engaged in incredibly responsible historical preservation, which has included donating bricks made by enslaved people to EJI \u2014 as well as keep its old \u201cWhites Only\u201d and \u201cColored Only\u201d signs on display for posterity. I\u2019m also a fan of the coffee shops Prevail Union and Cafe Louisa, as well as bar standouts like Leroy Lounge, a dive with a terrific selection of wines and craft beers, and Aviator Bar, covered in airplane-themed kitsch \u2014 inspired by the Wright Brothers, who started the country\u2019s first civilian flight school outside Montgomery.\n\nI met a group of black culinary students there one night who not only knew the city\u2019s history but said it fueled their ambitions. \u201cWe\u2019re in a bar on the road that was used to bring people to be auctioned off,\u201d said Steven McIntyre, who interns as a line cook at the highly regarded restaurant Vintage Year, \u201cand the fact that we are here today, just hanging out, enjoying life, it\u2019s incredible. Not super long ago, we would not be chilling here. This would not be chill.\u201d\n\nMy best culinary experiences, though, came by way of cabdrivers I\u2019d met. Nick Alloway, that lone Sunday driver, sent me to Mrs. B\u2019s Home Cooking, a yellow-painted soul food restaurant a few minutes west of downtown that serves up a different featured meat every day. Blocks north of the Capitol building is Davis Cafe, an even older family-run soul food joint that\u2019s the haunt of Hillard Wright, a King\u2019s Airport shuttle driver with a salt-and-pepper mustache, a gruff baritone voice and a leather rancher\u2019s hat that never left his head. He spent a whole afternoon showing me his version of the city he\u2019s lived in all of his 66 years. State senators were crowded into every vinyl booth. My plate overflowing with collard greens, creamed corn, peas and okra, turkey dressing, yams and cornbread cost around $6.\n\nFollowing the spirit of the locals I had met, I tried to absorb as much history as I could in four days: The Dexter Parsonage Museum, where Dr. King lived in the 1950s; the F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald Museum in the home where their marriage dissolved; Hank Williams\u2019s grave in the Oakwood Annex Cemetery. What stuck with me more than any of those, though, were the three hours I spent with Mr. Wright, engaging in his favorite pastime of driving around and looking at old houses. He\u2019d introduce each neighborhood with factoids about its legal, and later, de facto, segregation status. Entering the \u201cold money\u201d neighborhood of Old Cloverdale, for example, he pointed out, \u201cif you\u2019ll notice, you don\u2019t see any black folks living in there.\u201d I did notice.\n\nMr. Wright, though, is not bitter. He has built for himself a quiet life of hunting and fishing, driving around for money and minding his own business. \u201cEven through the segregation and hatred,\u201d he said, \u201cMontgomery, I wouldn\u2019t trade it. I\u2019ve been here my whole life and I\u2019ve enjoyed every day.\u201d", "title": "Place 3 of 52: In Montgomery, a City Embedded With Pain, Finding Progress", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe are very clear that, when we set pricing strategy or look to adjust pricing, it is not based on political positions or points of view,\u201d Patrick Fitzgerald, the company\u2019s senior vice president, integrated marketing and communications, said in an interview on Tuesday. \u201cBut we do have a very clear corporate position in terms of gun safety and school safety.\u201d\n\nIn Georgia, the debate has been surprisingly fiery, even in a state long defined by tensions between the liberal metropolis and conservative countryside, and between the values of global corporate culture and those of Southern Republicans.\n\n\u201cCorporations cannot attack conservatives and expect us not to fight back,\u201d Mr. Cagle, a leading G.O.P. candidate for governor, wrote in a tweet Monday, in which he announced that he would \u201ckill any tax legislation\u201d that benefited Delta unless it changed its position.\n\nState Senator Josh McKoon said in an interview Tuesday that he was put off by Delta\u2019s assertion that it was trying to remain neutral on the guns issue, when it had taken positions on other social topics in the past.\n\n\u201cIt just came off as very disingenuous,\u201d Mr. McKoon said of Delta\u2019s statement.\n\nReferring to Mr. Cagle\u2019s pushback, Mr. McKoon said, \u201cI think he captured the sentiment and the feeling of a lot of Georgians,\u201d who, he said, were frustrated \u201cwith Delta weighing in on an issue that has nothing to do with the topic of transportation, for sure.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Massell, the former mayor who is president of the Buckhead Coalition, an influential Atlanta business and civic group, called the entire debate \u201cembarrassing.\u201d He said that he feared the threat against Delta would scare away Amazon, the online retail giant that has listed Atlanta among the finalists for its second headquarters.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t believe in blackmail, and I\u2019m sorry to use such a dirty word, but that\u2019s almost what it tastes like,\u201d said Mr. Massell, a Democrat who served as mayor from 1970 to 1974. \u201cThat\u2019s terrible. That\u2019s not Georgia\u2019s image. That\u2019s backwoods stuff that doesn\u2019t belong at all.\u201d", "title": "In N.R.A. Fight, Delta Finds There Is No Neutral Ground", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "JERUSALEM \u2014 In a trio of new polls, Israelis have declared what they think of the bribery case against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, and the answer is roughly the same as what they think of Mr. Netanyahu himself: About half think he should step aside. His right-wing supporters overwhelmingly think he should stay.\n\nMr. Netanyahu\u2019s Israel is as polarized as it has been in generations, and under his lengthy tenure, the national conversation has become steadily more toxic. Now, as the prime minister awaits a possible criminal indictment, his efforts to cling to power could pose even greater strains on a society that already seems at risk of tearing itself apart.\n\n\u201cImagine if, in the next few weeks, there is a justified case for Israel to go to war,\u201d said Shlomo Avineri, a professor emeritus of political science at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. \u201cHalf of this country would think Netanyahu\u2019s position was impacted by his legal situation. That is unacceptable. Political decisions are sometimes existential in Israel. If we had to go to war, the decision would be contaminated for a lot of people.\u201d\n\nMr. Netanyahu has dismissed the police recommendations to charge him as \u201cslanted\u201d and \u201cfull of holes, like Swiss cheese.\u201d The attorney general, Avichai Mandelblit, praised the police on Thursday, in his first public remarks on the recommendations. The state prosecutors and the police, he said, had worked with the goal of \u201cpreserving the rule of law in Israel, turning over every stone in order to bring the truth to light.\u201d", "title": "In Netanyahu\u2019s Israel, the Divisiveness Is Now All About Him", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "THE NIGHT DIARY\n\nBy Veera Hiranandani\n\n272 pp. Dial. $16.99.\n\n(Ages 8 to 12)\n\nImage\n\nHow does it feel to almost die of thirst? Most readers will never know, though this riveting book will make many feel as if they\u2019ve had a taste of it. Twelve-year-old Nisha and her family, refugees headed for the border of India, are on a desperate journey through the desert. Nisha\u2019s legs start \u201cquivering like jelly in the heat,\u201d her \u201cteeth feel like apricot skin\u201d and, when she tries to stand, \u201cmy arms and legs felt filled with sand.\u201d\n\nSet in 1947, the novel tells the story of Nisha\u2019s family\u2019s struggle during the bloody events of Partition, when India was divided into two countries after the nation\u2019s independence from Britain. Nisha and her brother, Amil, are from a mixed family; their deceased mother was Muslim and their father, a respected physician, is Hindu. As violence looms, the family must flee their comfortable home in what\u2019s now Pakistan and cross the border to the new India. Nisha is especially bereft at her separation from the family\u2019s kind Muslim cook, Kazu, who kindles her love of cooking (a freshly folded samosa feels to her like a \u201csmall animal, soft and warm in my hand\u201d) and encourages her to keep a diary.\n\nHiranandani (\u201cThe Whole Story of Half a Girl\u201d) does a remarkable job conveying the terrors and absurdities of the conflict in ways young readers can understand. Neighbors turn against neighbors and fear is so thick that even children are seen as a threat. (\u201cWhat side are we even on?\u201d Amil asks at one point.) She\u2019s also created a family with satisfying complexity: While the father is a good man, he shows scorn for Amil\u2019s poor academic performance. But it\u2019s the family\u2019s dramatic journey that will keep readers to the end. The finale \u2014 unabashedly weepy, deeply cathartic \u2014 is as satisfying as a long, cool drink of water.\n\nCHECKED\n\nBy Cynthia Kadohata\n\n400 pp. Atheneum. $16.99.\n\n(Ages 10 to 14)\n\nImage\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve known for a long time that you gotta be intense about stuff, since anything can happen in the future.\u201d So says Conor McRae, the 11-year-old hockey player at the heart of Kadohata\u2019s quiet, masterly seventh novel. Conor is nothing if not intense about his sport \u2014 his goal of making it to the N.H.L. pushes him to 4 a.m. wake-up times and grueling practices where coaches pinch his neck and scream, \u201cWhy aren\u2019t you moving your feet?!!\u201d But hockey is an expensive pursuit and Conor\u2019s dad, a police officer, barely makes enough to cover equipment. Then Conor\u2019s dog and \u201csoul mate,\u201d Sinbad, develops cancer and Conor must face the messy aspects of life outside hockey \u2014 his dad\u2019s depression, his estranged maternal grandparents (Conor\u2019s mom died when he was 2), the possibility of life without Sinbad.", "title": "In New Novels for Kids, Dangerous Journeys and Hockey Madness", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "NEW ORLEANS \u2014 R\u00e9gine Chassagne was standing barefoot in her rambling New Orleans home on a recent weekday, showing members of the Preservation Hall Jazz Band how to play the horn parts for her latest musical project.\n\nIt was a galloping Carnival anthem played in the Haitian style and sung largely in Haitian Creole, a language the jazz players did not understand. Ms. Chassagne, a Canadian-born daughter of Haitian exiles, described their parts with swooping hand gestures. At one point, she told them to play \u201clike fireworks \u2014 poof!\u201d\n\nThe jazzmen, masters of translating emotion into sound, nodded along, unfazed.\n\nMs. Chassagne, 41, is a founder of the rock group Arcade Fire, a French speaker of mixed racial heritage who grew up in Montreal playing the piano to old Louis Armstrong recordings. More recently, she has become a prominent advocate for the Haitian people and for a Haitian culture that has had an outsize, if not always recognizable, influence on New Orleans, where she and her husband, Win Butler, have lived for about three years.\n\nFor this year\u2019s Carnival season, the period of revelry before Lent, Ms. Chassagne and Mr. Butler, the Arcade Fire frontman, will highlight their adopted city\u2019s Haitian connections with the kind of primer its residents readily understand: a raucous procession by the couple\u2019s Haitian-themed Mardi Gras troupe, the Krewe du Kanaval. Founded in collaboration with the New Orleans jazz hub Preservation Hall and rounded out by local and Haitian musicians, the krewe plans to parade through the streets of the French Quarter and Treme on Tuesday, a week before Mardi Gras, and put on a free street party.", "title": "In New Orleans, Whispers of Haiti Become a Brassy Mardi Gras Shout", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Another site, on Second Avenue and East 21st Street, is across the street from Peter\u2019s Field, a blocklong stretch of basketball and tennis courts. And at 67 Livingston Street in Brooklyn Heights, where Silverback is converting a former college dorm into condos, one side of the building looks down on the schoolyard of the Packer Collegiate Institute, where on a recent afternoon children were jostling for control of a big red ball.\n\nWhile such parks may lack the splendor of Central or Prospect Parks, unsung green spaces can claim near-equivalent benefits: In addition to extra light and sky, many offer playgrounds, dog runs, farmers\u2019 markets, a bench to read a book, or a lawn for a picnic.\n\nMany cities prize their waterfronts above all else, but Jonathan J. Miller, the president of the real estate appraisal and consulting firm Miller Samuel, said that New York is a bit different. \u201cOne of the things about Manhattan is that we\u2019re inward looking,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re more into our park views than our water views.\u201d\n\nWhich could have something to do with Robert Moses, the major builder last century of New York City infrastructure \u2014 and the fact that nearly all of Manhattan\u2019s waterfront views have highways in them. But whatever the reason, living on even a small park does make a difference to buyers. And, ultimately, the apartment\u2019s value.\n\nWhen it comes to pricing, however, expectations should be modest: According to Mr. Miller, apartments on Central Park are only about 10 to 15 percent more than those on a side street if they\u2019re below the tree-line, and 15 to 25 percent more if they\u2019re above. And any analysis of prices for park-facing units comes with a caveat: Developers are more likely to put the largest apartments where the best views are, and there\u2019s also a premium for more contiguous space.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd, he added, \u201cwhile there\u2019s an aesthetic of openness that people gravitate to,\u201d there is a difference between living on a tiny Moses-era playground and a Frederick Law Olmsted masterpiece like Morningside Park \u201cthat has been a stalwart of the neighborhood for many years.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nToni Martin, an associate broker with the Corcoran Group, said that anytime she has a listing on a park \u2014 be it Von King Park in Bedford-Stuyvesant, or Washington Park in Park Slope \u2014 it gets snapped up fast. Fort Greene Park is such a huge draw that she\u2019s seen bidding wars for condos in townhouses half a block away. One of her clients lost a bidding war for a 950-square-foot two-bedroom in one such building. \u201cIt was a nice apartment, but nothing overwhelming. And it was a fourth-floor walk-up!\u201d Ms. Martin said, adding that the place sold for $125,000 over the asking price.\n\n\u201cIn a city as dense as New York, to live next to something green is a beautiful thing,\u201d she said.\n\nOf course, not all buyers come to tour a new condo with a strong desire to live on a small square or playground whose name they might not even know.\n\nFred Duck, who works in marketing at Bloomberg, recently bought a one-bedroom at 1790 Third Avenue, a condo project across from Cherry Tree Park in East Harlem.\n\n\u201cTo be honest, I\u2019d never been to that park,\u201d said Mr. Duck, who previously owned a condo on Second Avenue and East 92nd Street. \u201cBut I had just come back from working in Hong Kong for several years, where I lived very high up, on the 37th floor. I got used to that light and I wanted to find something that wasn\u2019t just looking into an adjacent building.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe advantage is real enough that developers are keen to play up any nearby green space. In Jersey City, Fields Development staked out a site by St. Peter\u2019s Prep\u2019s football field for its new luxury rental, Lenox, which will also have a courtyard open to the public.\n\nAnd in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Brookland Capital is building condos at 850 Metropolitan Avenue, across the street from a small community garden in Orient Grove, a tiny .149-acre triangle park.\n\n\u201cI won\u2019t tell you the site was appealing just because of the community garden,\u201d said Boaz Gilad, the chief executive and a founder of Brookland. \u201cBut if I can give you a park, I will.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBrookland\u2019s condos are priced to attract younger first-time buyers \u2014 a price point that \u201ccan\u2019t usually afford to be on a park.\u201d But Mr. Gilad said that buyers and renters like \u201ceven a small piece of greenery they feel like they can have access to.\u201d\n\nWhile not all New Yorkers warm to the sound of children\u2019s happy shouting, even the developers of new buildings with significant private outdoor amenities consider a small public park to be a significant boon. At Extell Development\u2019s Brooklyn Point, a 68-story condo tower rising in Downtown Brooklyn, residents will have access to the highest rooftop pool in the Western Hemisphere, outdoor showers and a stargazing observatory. But Ari Alowan Goldstein, a senior vice president for development at the company, considers Willoughby Square, the one-acre park the city is building across the street as part of the Downtown Brooklyn Redevelopment Plan, to be on par with those perks.\n\n\u201cIn my mind, parks are one of the best parts of New York and the perfect complement to the built environment,\u201d he said. \u201cI spend my weekends taking my 20-month-old daughter to different Brooklyn parks.\u201d", "title": "In New York, a View of Even a Small Park Adds Value", "authors": ["Kim Velsey"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Ezekwesili\u2019s group and others have criticized the government for not immediately addressing the Dapchi kidnapping and muddling an already chaotic situation after the attack, which scattered hundreds of students and teachers as they ran for their lives. Federal officials are now saying 110 students are missing. Parents a day earlier released names of 105 missing girls.\n\nPresident Muhammadu Buhari, who campaigned in 2015 on pledges to find the Chibok students, said on Friday that as soon as he heard about the Dapchi attack, he had deployed security forces with instructions to \u201cnot spare any effort to ensure all the girls are returned safely.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe entire country stands as one with the girls\u2019 families,\u201d Mr. Buhari said in a statement. \u201cThis is a national disaster. We are sorry that this could have happened and share your pain.\u201d\n\nGovernment officials have pointed out that after girls were stolen in Chibok, the administration of Nigeria\u2019s president at the time, Goodluck Jonathan, waited more than two weeks to acknowledge the kidnapping, a delay they said allowed militants to flee with the girls. This time, they said, the military has already been deployed and is combing Yobe State, where Dapchi is.\n\nConfusion has surrounded the events in Dapchi, said Lai Mohammed, the minister of information, because dozens of girls ran into hiding and have been slowly trickling back to the school.\n\n\u201cThis is why the whole situation has been hazy,\u201d he said.\n\nOfficials have been careful to avoid acknowledging anyone was kidnapped in Dapchi. Instead, they say only that the girls are missing.\n\nWitnesses, however, described seeing the girls in militants\u2019 vehicles as part of what appeared to be a deliberate plan to steal them. And they said militants arrived at the town looking specifically for the building, which is a boarding place with about 900 students.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne resident who lives a mile outside Dapchi, who asked that his name not be used because he feared for his safety, said his neighbor was outside his home late in the day on Monday when militants pulled up, grabbed him and asked him to point them to the school. He told the fighters he didn\u2019t know where it was and begged to be released. They threw him aside and headed toward the town.\n\nOther residents were also abducted by the militants and ordered to direct them to the school before being released, townspeople said.\n\nFighters arrived at the school about 5:30 p.m., guns blazing.\n\nHafsat Lawan, 15, said she and classmates heard gunshots in the distance.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe joked about it\u201d at first, she said, unable to imagine what was about to happen. \u201cBut the sound kept coming and getting serious. We then started running.\u201d\n\nSome girls began climbing over a fence that lined the perimeter. Militants dragged away those who didn\u2019t make it, witnesses said.\n\nThe fighters were dressed in army fatigues, but with flip-flops and turbans, another student said. They started telling the terrified girls they were soldiers there to help them, and shepherded them toward their vehicles. In the blur of the moment, some girls believed them, so much so that they desperately scrambled to get into the trucks.\n\nAisha Ibrahim, another student, said militants beckoned her and her friends to come to them for help.\n\n\u201cBut as we came close, I noticed they were not wearing military shoes,\u201d and were speaking a local dialect, Ms. Ibrahim said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Ibrahim knew it was unlikely that Nigerian soldiers, who generally are recruited from across the country, would know that language. Her friends didn\u2019t realize they were being deceived, she said.\n\n\u201cThey kept threatening me to come back to them or they will they will kill me, but I was courageous enough to run away to join some of my colleagues who were far ahead of me,\u201d she said.\n\nHauwa Modu, another student, said she and her friends were also suspicious of the men in camouflage. Terrified and sobbing, they ran in every direction to escape.\n\n300 miles niger CHAD Dapchi BENIN Chibok nigeria Abuja Lagos cameroon Gulf of Guinea\n\n\u201cThe terrorists pursued us,\u201d Ms. Modu said. \u201cThey apprehend some, while others ran away escaping into the bushes for safety.\u201d\n\nThe militants threated to shoot anyone who ran, \u201cbut they never shot anybody,\u201d she said. Residents said fighters took no food or anything of value.\n\nSome students hid safely inside their dormitories. Other students and teachers ran into the scrubby desert countryside. Some stayed in the bush overnight until they were certain it was safe to return.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
