A key to Iran\u2019s strategy, analysts and officials say, is to rely not on conventional military hardware or control of territory, which Israel can easily bomb, but on building ties with local forces who share its goals and benefit from its financing and expertise.\n\nThat approach has enabled Iran to amplify its power in the Arab world while decreasing the threat to its own forces and homeland. It has also created a problem for countries including the United States, Israel and Saudi Arabia, who fear Iran\u2019s growing influence but have struggled to come up with ways to stop it.\n\nSome people in Israel have started referring to a potential \u201cFirst Northern War,\u201d meaning that Israel will have to fight across both the Lebanese and Syrian frontiers. And many Israelis say the danger is not just from the new Iranian-backed militias, but also from the Iranian efforts to give advanced, high-precision weapons capable of hitting sensitive infrastructure to Hezbollah, Iran\u2019s most powerful and experienced external force.\n\nPhoto\n\nIsraeli officials have said that Iran and its allies are seeking to establish a land corridor from Iran to the Mediterranean, via Iraq, Syria and Lebanon, to ease the transportation of such weapons and to build underground factories to manufacture them in Lebanon and Syria. Israel has been bombing convoys in Syria that are believed to be carrying advanced arms to Hezbollah, but the group\u2019s covert nature makes it hard to determine which arms have slipped through and whether its arms factories are functioning.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSuch arms, coupled with heavy barrages from the more than 100,000 rockets and missiles without high-precision targeting capability that Israel says Hezbollah already has, could overwhelm Israel\u2019s defenses.\n\n\u201cIsrael will face not only quantity, but the threat to vulnerable strategic sites,\u201d said Yaakov Amidror, a former Israeli national security adviser and now a fellow at the Jerusalem Institute for Strategic Studies. Referring to the combination of more precise weapons and a new front, he added: \u201cEach one is problematic; together, they are devastating.\u201d\n\nIran\u2019s moves in the region have alarmed the United States. \u201cWhat\u2019s particularly concerning is that this network of proxies is becoming more and more capable as Iran seeds more and more\u201d of its \u201cdestructive weapons into these networks,\u201d Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster, President Trump\u2019s national security adviser, said at a security conference in Munich on Saturday. \u201cSo the time is now, we think, to act against Iran,\u201d General McMaster added.\n\nIn expanding its influence in Syria in recent years, Iran has followed a standard template. In Lebanon in the 1980s, it helped create Hezbollah, which has since evolved into the country\u2019s predominant military force and a regional power in its own right, joining the wars in Syria, Iraq and Yemen. In Iraq, Iran has sponsored a range of militias while developing deep ties to the Iraqi economy and political system.\n\nThe war in Syria gave Iran a new opportunity to advance that project by linking its allies across the Levant together.\n\nFighters from Hezbollah routed Syrian rebels near the Lebanese border and Iran sent advisers to help Mr. Assad\u2019s beleaguered forces during the early years of the war.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut by 2013, Mr. Assad\u2019s forces were on the verge of collapse, and Iran intervened more forcefully, undertaking an extensive regional operation to train, arm and transport thousands of Shiite militiamen from abroad to Syria to fight the rebels and the jihadists of the Islamic State.\n\nEstimates of the number of Iranian military personnel in Syria today range from the high hundreds to the low thousands. While some directly participate in combat, most are trainers, commanders or experts who advise the Syrian military and oversee militias. It is these militias, which could have as many as 20,000 fighters, that give Iran its true muscle.\n\nThose fighters include about 6,000 from Hezbollah. Most of the rest of the militia members \u2014 who come from Afghanistan, Iraq, Lebanon, Pakistan and elsewhere \u2014 have been enticed to fight in Syria with money and appeals to their Shiite faith. Indeed, most see the war in Syria in religious terms, as a jihad against enemies of their religion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAli Alfoneh, a researcher at the Atlantic Council who tracks reports of foreign militia fighters killed in Syria, said the number of deaths reported had decreased substantially as those fighting for Mr. Assad have gotten the upper hand in the war. But instead of leaving the country, he said, the militias appeared to be shifting their sights toward Israel.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIran has realized that it is actually possible to maintain a front against Israel where there is no war but also no peace,\u201d Mr. Alfoneh said.\n\nIn his research, Mr. Alfoneh said he had identified three main Iranian bases that oversee operations in large parts of Syria \u2014 one near Aleppo in the north and two south of the capital, Damascus \u2014 as well as seven smaller tactical bases near active front lines where Iran and its proxies have a presence.\n\nThe idea of a permanent Iranian presence in Syria worries Israel, which fears that it could face a threat there similar to that posed by Hezbollah in Lebanon. Analysts close to Iran and its proxies say that is exactly the idea.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like a replication of the Hezbollah model,\u201d said Ali Rizk, a Lebanese analyst who writes for Al Monitor, a news website focused on the Middle East. Iran is already training fighters in southern Syria, he said, so that if Hezbollah draws down its presence there, as its leaders have vowed to, it will leave behind a Syrian prototype.\n\nIn recent months, at least two Iraqi militia leaders have visited the Lebanon-Israel border with Hezbollah, and militia members say the visits have included developing plans for how they might collaborate in a future conflict.\n\nLife has returned to normal in the Israel-controlled Golan Heights since the day of battle on Feb. 10, and the ski resort on Mount Hermon has been operating as usual. There was no immediate sense among Israelis of being on a war footing.\n\nBut Israelis and many Lebanese have long worried that another war across their border is inevitable. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ratcheted up the rhetoric on Sunday at the security conference in Munich, warning Iran\u2019s leaders not to test Israel\u2019s resolve and pledging that if pushed, Israel would act \u201cnot only against Iranian proxies that are attacking us, but against Iran itself.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBoth sides say they do not want war, and the fear of extensive destruction and civilian deaths has deterred new hostilities since the last war between Israel and Hezbollah in 2006. But the more entrenched Iran\u2019s allies become, the greater the pressure Israeli leaders could face to launch a strike \u2014 and the greater the chances that a miscalculation or mistake by either side could provoke new hostilities.\n\nSome analysts have expressed hopes that Russia, which also intervened in Syria on Mr. Assad\u2019s behalf, could serve as a check on Iran\u2019s ambitions. Russia has cooperated with Iran during the war but also seeks to maintain good relations with Israel.\n\nNotably, Russia has not publicly complained when Israel has bombed convoys believed to be bound for Hezbollah. Others question to what degree the Syrian population will buy into Iran\u2019s ideological project, noting that only a tiny portion of Syrians share Iran\u2019s Shiite faith.\n\nMuch remains unclear about Iran\u2019s intentions. Days after Israel destroyed the drone, Israeli military officials said they were still not sure whether it had been armed, had been sent on a surveillance mission or was merely a test of Israel\u2019s defenses.\n\n\u201cIt is very important for us to understand its mission,\u201d Brig. Gen. Tomer Bar, the chief of staff of the Israeli Air Force, told reporters. \u201cWe have to understand it and we will investigate it till the end.\u201d", "title": "Iran, Deeply Embedded in Syria, Expands \u2018Axis of Resistance\u2019", "authors": ["Ben Hubbard", "Isabel Kershner", "Anne Barnard"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 In the U.S., indictments secured by the special counsel against more than a dozen Russians and three companies over interference in the 2016 elections have put President Trump on the defensive.\n\nMr. Trump said that President Barack Obama had not done enough to stop the interference, and despite his frequent assertions that Russia had not meddled, denied ever having said so.\n\nAs our chief White House correspondent points out, the national struggle against Moscow is leaderless.\n\nAnd what digital instruments did the Russians use to stir discord? Facebook and Instagram.", "title": "Iran, Russia, Olympics: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Numerous Iraqi cities were reduced to rubble in the fighting, particularly Mosul, the country\u2019s second largest. Yet while Iraq estimated that it would need $88 billion to pay for reconstruction, it was expected to receive only $4 billion in pledges by the time the conference ends. The majority of that is to come from Arab donors in the Persian Gulf, with the Saudis, Emiratis, Kuwaitis and Qataris all pledging around $1 billion each.\n\nThere was also a flurry of loan guarantees, including one by the United States. But all in all, the pledges amounted to less than 5 percent of what Iraq said it wanted and needed.\n\nThe State Department emphasized that the United States since 2014 had already given Iraq $1.7 billion in humanitarian aid and $6 billion in economic and security assistance, money mostly committed during the Obama administration. In an evening speech to the conference, Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson called on others to do their part.\n\n\u201cEveryone in this room has an opportunity to help set Iraq on a new course and contribute to its long-term development,\u201d he said, although he admitted that \u201cdoing business in Iraq can be complicated.\u201d\n\nThe conference was held against the backdrop of President Trump\u2019s emphasis on more military spending. The administration\u2019s budget for fiscal year 2019, unveiled Monday, proposed eliminating much of the nation\u2019s foreign aid and reducing the State Department\u2019s overall spending by a third while increasing the Pentagon\u2019s budget by $195 billion in the next two years.\n\nAmong the programs the administration has proposed eliminating are a $4.6 billion economic support fund, a $3 billion budget for international development assistance and a $211 million fund to promote democratic institutions.\n\nIn Iraq, those priorities seem to mean that the United States, after leaning heavily on the Iraqi military, which suffered heavy casualties in the fight against the Islamic State, appears to be leaving the task of rebuilding Iraq\u2019s shattered cities to other nations and the private sector.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFew other nations have stepped up. Most of the four dozen foreign ministers in Kuwait City for the donor conference brought only good wishes, not money.\n\nSaudi Arabia, in a statement from its embassy in Washington, said that it \u201ccontinues to support a secure, stable and united nonsectarian Iraq.\u201d And American officials emphasized that the pledge campaign was just beginning.\n\nMr. Tillerson and other diplomats hoped to compensate for the shortfall by calling for private sector investments, much as President Trump has done for his own infrastructure plan in the United States. Representatives from nearly 2,000 companies, many brought by the United States, Iran, Germany and other governments, gave the conference an atmosphere of an investment road show.\n\nBut Sami Al-Araji, the head of Iraq\u2019s National Investment Commission, said no investments had been generated so far from the companies. \u201cI am not expecting any contracts to be signed,\u201d he said on Monday evening.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSome analysts noted that most if not all of the Iraqi cities ravaged during the fight against the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, ISIL and Daesh, are in predominantly Sunni areas. Those were the places where a Sunni insurgency took root after the American-led invasion of Iraq in 2003, and later gave rise to an affiliate of Al Qaeda and the leadership ranks of the Islamic State. If they are not rebuilt, diplomats fear the region\u2019s populace will once again turn to extremism, a risk Mr. Tillerson highlighted in a morning speech to a separate gathering of the 74-nation coalition to defeat the Islamic State.\n\n\u201cThe end of major combat operations does not mean that we have achieved the enduring defeat of ISIS,\u201d he said. \u201cISIS remains a serious threat to the stability of the region, our homelands and other parts of the globe. Without continued attention on the part of coalition members, we risk the return of extremist groups like ISIS in liberated areas in Iraq and Syria and their spread to new locations.\u201d\n\nApproximately 2.5 million Iraqi citizens remain displaced after their homes were flattened, utilities destroyed and schools bombed. Almost half of Mosul remains uninhabited.\n\nThe Trump administration has vastly reduced American aid for refugees and resettlement, arguing that helping displaced people return to war-torn regions is preferable to resettling them in the United States or elsewhere. But no one can return without intense rebuilding efforts.\n\nMr. Trump complained Monday that the United States had spent $7 trillion in the Middle East over the past 17 years with little to show for it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSeven trillion dollars. What a mistake. But it is what it is,\u201d he said in introducing his domestic infrastructure plan.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s calculation included the direct costs of wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, as well as estimates for the costs of care for veterans. Whatever the total, the Pentagon has spent the vast majority of the money, not the State Department.\n\nOn Sunday, a group of 151 retired senior military commanders, including former chiefs of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, Special Operations and Air Force, sent a letter to congressional leaders saying that cuts to aid programs would threaten the military gains made against the Islamic State.\n\n\u201cAnd while we have seen military progress against ISIS, the question that looms is whether we are prepared to protect those battlefield gains and prevent bad actors from stepping into the void,\u201d the letter states.\n\nDonors have expressed wariness at what some see as throwing good money into a black hole in Iraq, which Transparency International, an anti-corruption research group, ranks as among the 10 most corrupt nations in the world. Of the $61 billion in American funds spent on development aid in Iraq between 2003 and 2012, around $6 billion vanished and a further $1 billion was wasted, American auditors concluded.\n\nMr. Abadi has made fighting corruption a priority, and his ministers have promoted a 300-page manifesto for investment that acknowledges past failures and pledges better oversight and fiscal management for reconstruction funds.\n\nThe shortfall in pledges on Tuesday could hurt the political standing of Mr. Abadi, who faces a tough re-election battle May 12 against pro-Iranian political blocs. Western diplomats have warned that Mr. Abadi\u2019s defeat could plunge the country into a sectarian struggle that could rip it apart.\n\nIraqi officials from politically important Sunni regions, as well as leaders from minority groups that Mr. Abadi had hoped to win over in the upcoming elections, criticized the list of reconstruction projects that his ministers highlighted at the conference for ignoring their communities and needs. Their outrage was fierce, despite Mr. Abadi\u2019s failure to secure support of any kind for any project.\n\n\u201cWe are sorely underrepresented,\u201d said Marwan al-Jibara, a spokesman for the council of tribal sheikhs in Salahuddin Province, one of the predominantly Sunni areas that produced the leader of the Islamic State, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe failure of the donor conference could also cool the extraordinarily warm ties between the Trump administration and Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, which reached a high point in a euphoric trip by President Trump to Riyadh in May. The United States had expected the countries\u2019 pledges to be many times more what they announced.", "title": "Iraq Wants $88 Billion for Rebuilding. Allies Offer a Fraction of That.", "authors": ["Margaret Coker", "Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "State-run schools have long offered religious instruction in keeping with community norms \u2014 which almost always means Catholic, in a country where about four-fifths of the population identifies as belonging to that denomination.\n\n\u201cIt may have been reasonable when these schools were originally established for a school to assume that its pupil population was predominately Catholic and to arrange religious instruction accordingly,\u201d the Department of Education said in a statement announcing the new policy. \u201cIn a changing context, the constitutional right not to attend religious instruction must be given effect through changed practices.\u201d\n\nThe change offers the latest example of Ireland\u2019s liberalization and the waning influence of the Catholic Church over public policy and social mores, but the country\u2019s education system also illustrates how deeply entwined the church remains in Irish life. In some parts of the country, Catholic schools are the only schools available, particularly at the primary-school level, and in other places they are considered superior to the alternatives.\n\nCatholic schools are allowed to give Catholic students preference in admissions, a phenomenon known as \u201cthe baptism barrier.\u201d As a result, some non-Catholic parents have their children baptized in the church to get them into schools.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe centrist governing coalition is shepherding a bill through Parliament that would stop schools giving that sort of admissions preference, and would require religious schools to state publicly how they treat students who do not follow the school\u2019s faith. The government also wants the church to relinquish control of some schools.\n\nThe archbishop of Dublin, Diarmuid Martin, warning that schools are gradually losing their Catholic character, has pushed for years for the church to divest itself of hundreds of schools. But he has had little success, meeting strong resistance from the religious orders that control them.\n\nIt is a measure of how much Ireland has changed that the loudest objections to the new policy on religion classes in state-run schools have come from the schools themselves. Teachers and administrators have objected not to having less religious instruction, but to the statement by the education minister, Richard Bruton, that the government will not provide funding for alternative classes.\n\n\u201cIreland has changed tremendously, and in urban areas there will be significant numbers of people choosing other subjects rather than religion,\u201d said Michael Moriarty, the general secretary of Education and Training Boards Ireland, the organization created by the government that oversees most state-run schools. \u201cWe don\u2019t have the staffing resources to put on extra classes with extra teachers.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe teachers\u2019 union went a step further, not only calling for more money and more teachers to carry out the policy, but also asking why \u201csuch a measure would only be implemented for a proportion of the country\u2019s second-level schools\u201d and not the religious ones.\n\nFor generations, Ireland was deeply conservative and its governments ceded much of the public service sector \u2014 schools, hospitals and orphanages, among other institutions \u2014 to the church. In recent years, the church\u2019s role and reputation have been eroded by revelations about how its people and institutions abused that power \u2014 including widespread sexual abuse and the mistreatment of unwed mothers and their children in homes that resembled prisons.\n\nAt the same time, the country has become much more liberal on social issues, often in ways opposed by the church. In the 1990s, Ireland decriminalized same-sex relations and legalized divorce.\n\nIt legalized same-sex marriage by referendum in 2015, with 62 percent of voters approving the change. And in May, the country will vote on a referendum to repeal the constitutional ban on abortion.", "title": "Ireland Tells State-Run Schools: Stop Steering Pupils to Religion Class", "authors": ["Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA new Irish whiskey with New York roots is ready for your home bar. Jack McGarry and Sean Muldoon, who founded and run an award-winning Irish pub, the Dead Rabbit Grocery & Grog, worked with the Dublin Liberties Distillery in Ireland to fine-tune a new 88-proof whiskey. The result is a honey-colored blend of single malt and grain whiskies aged for five years, first in Kentucky bourbon casks, then in small new American oak barrels. It delivers plenty of sweet vanilla and tropical fruit aromas along with rich smoothness on the palate: The Dead Rabbit Irish Whiskey, $34.99 for 750 milliliters, warehousewineandspirits.com, deadrabbitirishwhiskey.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Irish Whiskey, From New York", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "However, Mr. Cissna did note that he had eliminated the word \u201ccustomers\u201d in describing the foreign nationals whom the agency serves, \u201ca reminder that we are always working for the American people.\u201d\n\nLe\u00f3n Rodr\u00edguez, director of the agency from 2014 to 2017, said the revision of the mission statement marked \u201ca particularly sad turn of history.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe should not forget that under the discarded mission statement, the integrity and national security functions of U.S.C.I.S. grew \u2014 dramatically so \u2014 showing that we could be both a welcoming nation and a safe one,\u201d Mr. Rodr\u00edguez said. \u201cWe should stop to reflect about the many opportunities that America will lose because of the attitudes reflected in this statement, and ask ourselves whether this is really the country we want to be.\u201d\n\nIra Mehlman, a spokesman for the Federation for American Immigration Reform, which favors restricting immigration, applauded the change.\n\n\u201cA nation of immigrants isn\u2019t a mission statement,\u201d he said, \u201cit\u2019s a slogan.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe biggest problem with our immigration system is that it lacks a clear national interest objective,\u201d he added.\n\nAs director of U.S.C.I.S., Mr. Cissna has promoted an agenda that reflects the Trump administration\u2019s skeptical and often hard-line stance on immigration. The agency has increased scrutiny of visa applications for foreign workers whom American companies seek to hire; it has changed the asylum application process to discourage people from seeking safe haven in the United States; and it has added steps to the process for foreigners already in the country to obtain legal permanent residency, or a green card.\n\nU.S.C.I.S., a unit of the Department of Homeland Security, reviews petitions of foreign nationals who seek to visit, work, reside and find refuge in the United States. It also processes citizenship applications, which have surged since President Trump won the election in 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn his letter to his staff, Mr. Cissna wrote, \u201cWe are also responsible for ensuring that those who naturalize are dedicated to this country, share our values, assimilate into our communities, and understand their responsibility to help preserve our freedom and liberty.\u201d\n\nPublished posthumously, Kennedy\u2019s \u201cA Nation of Immigrants\u201d highlighted the contribution of immigrants when the country was engulfed in a debate over the direction of its immigration policy.\n\nThe phrase appears at least as far back as 1874, in an editorial published in The Daily State Journal of Alexandria, which praised a bill passed by the Virginia Senate appropriating $15,000 to encourage European immigration. \u201cWe are a nation of immigrants and immigrants\u2019 children,\u201d it said.\n\nImmigrant advocates today invoke the phrase to remind the country that most Americans have an ancestor who was once a newcomer to the United States.", "title": "Is America a \u2018Nation of Immigrants\u2019? Immigration Agency Says No", "authors": ["Miriam Jordan"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Barnaby Joyce was probably the last politician average Australians would expect to be embroiled in a sex scandal. A comparison to Mike Pence isn\u2019t so far-fetched: They\u2019re both second in charge of a conservative government led by a flashy businessman, and standard-bearers for family values, tilled in the nation\u2019s agrarian heartland. For most of the Australian public, Mr. Joyce was a bumbling farm boy who meant well.\n\nLast week, though, a story broke that turned public sentiment against him. Following investigations by two small websites last year, the Sydney-based Daily Telegraph reported that the deputy prime minister was having a child with a former staff member, Vikki Campion. A photo on the front page of the tabloid showed Ms. Campion, pregnant and unwitting, crossing the street. (\u201cBundle of Joyce\u201d said the headline.) That this story, like so many others, involves personal hypocrisy is hardly surprising. Mr. Joyce has been a strident opponent of gay marriage, basing his opposition in part on what he has called his four daughters\u2019 right to a \u201csecure relationship with a loving husband\u201d and the right of every child \u201cto know her or his mother and father.\u201d What is more noteworthy is the degree to which the Joyce affair has sparked a long-overdue debate about the deference Australian media still accords politicians when it comes to their private lives.\n\nMr. Joyce\u2019s relationship with Ms. Campion, we\u2019ve learned in the past few days, was an open secret among the Canberra press corps. Back in October, Sharri Markson, the reporter who eventually got the print scoop, wrote a piece alluding to a \u201cdeeply personal crisis\u201d in Mr. Joyce\u2019s life. Now that the story\u2019s out there, it\u2019s very easy to read between the lines about \u201cvicious rumors\u201d and \u201cpersonal pressures\u201d in dozens of media clips from last year. The deputy prime minister\u2019s private situation was well known enough that he got into a pub brawl with a constituent about it last year and apparently knocked the man\u2019s hat off.\n\nDid the media choose not report on Mr. Joyce because they didn\u2019t have all the facts? Perhaps in part. As the national broadsheet The Australian has reported, repeated inquiries about Ms. Campion\u2019s multiple job titles, let alone her taxpayer-funded salary, were met with stonewalling. Mr. Joyce would refuse to talk about the relationship when they asked. (This week, he released a statement denying that the relationship, and Ms. Campion\u2019s employment in the government, breached ministerial rules.) Another major consideration is that Australian journalists face extremely strict libel laws, the kind Donald Trump would appreciate.", "title": "Opinion | Is Australia\u2019s Media Too Prudish for a Sex Scandal?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "As Dell Technologies publicly confirmed that it was exploring a number of potential transactions \u2014 ranging from an initial public offering to a combination with VMware, of which it owns 80 percent \u2014 much of the media coverage has focused on why it\u2019s doing so.\n\nOne theory has been the company\u2019s debt, of which there is a lot (particularly after its $67 billion takeover of data storage company EMC in 2016). A combination with VMware could help provide a way for Dell to manage its balance sheet, through both additional earnings power and the ability to raise money through stock sales.\n\nBut a closer look at Dell\u2019s financials suggests that the company doesn\u2019t have to strike a deal solely to manage its debt.\n\nDiving In\n\nDell has a total of roughly $52.5 billion in gross debt. But company executives have explained to debt investors that such a number doesn\u2019t factor in a number of mitigating circumstances:\n\n\u25a0 About $4 billion of that is investment-grade long-term debt that sits at VMware.\n\n\u25a0 About $6 billion is held by Dell Financial Services, which is backed by computer equipment and, Dell has argued, shouldn\u2019t be lumped in with general corporate bonds or loans.", "title": "Is Dell\u2019s Debt Load Pushing It Into a Deal?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Such conduct could expose Mr. Nunes and his staff to liability for conspiracy to obstruct justice. According to press accounts, the Nunes memo may be designed at least in part to provide the president an excuse for firing Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, the individual with supervisory authority over Mr. Mueller, the special counsel in charge of the investigation. The purported scheme: clear a path to install a Trump-friendly replacement who would either fire Mr. Mueller or otherwise defang the investigation. Indeed, after the memo was released the president did nothing to quell these suspicions, ominously responding \u201cyou figure that one out\u201d when asked if the memo made him more likely to fire Mr. Rosenstein. The double standard applied by the president in refusing the immediate release of a rebuttal memo offered by the minority is hardly reassuring as to his good intentions.\n\nEndeavoring to stop an investigation, if done with corrupt intent, may constitute obstruction of justice. Plotting to assist such action may be conspiracy to obstruct justice.\n\nNormally, what is called \u201cspeech or debate\u201d immunity would provide a strong bulwark against any such liability for Mr. Nunes or his staff. The Constitution provides that senators and representatives \u201cshall not be questioned in any other Place\u201d for \u201cany Speech or Debate in either House,\u201d immunizing members of Congress from criminal prosecution and civil lawsuits that concern the legislative process. The Supreme Court has explained that this immunity extends to legislative acts that are an \u201cintegral part of the deliberative and communicative processes by which Members participate in committee and House proceedings.\u201d The court also has made clear that the clause covers not just members of Congress but also their staff, and that oversight activity may come under its ambit.\n\nIn this case, however, Mr. Nunes and company may have ranged so far afield that those protections no longer apply. Under the clause, mere peripheral connection to legislative acts cannot serve as a fig leaf to shield criminal conduct. Mr. Nunes would do well to remember what befell Senator Daniel Brewster of Maryland: In 1972 the Supreme Court declined to afford him speech or debate immunity in a bribery prosecution, pointing out that the alleged crime turned on acceptance of payment, not the ultimate voting act promised in return.\n\nAn additional worry for Team Nunes: The clause does not protect activities that courts consider \u201cpolitical,\u201d such as communicating with the executive branch on behalf of constituents, issuing a newsletter or news release or speaking outside of Congress. The most famous example involves Alaska Senator Mike Gravel and his staff, who were involved in the release and publication of the Pentagon Papers. The courts found that the speech or debate protections applied to Senator Gravel\u2019s actions in entering the documents into the record of a subcommittee hearing, but did not apply to actions of the senator and his staff in arranging private publication following the hearing. The reason: The latter conduct was \u201cin no way essential to the deliberations of the Senate.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Is Devin Nunes Obstructing Justice?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "A 2012 study by Janet E. Rosenbaum, an epidemiologist at SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, examined the perception of many gun-rights advocates that Israel and Switzerland were \u201cgun utopias\u201d that had fairly permissive firearms laws and widespread gun ownership, and encouraged armed civilians to intercept shooters.\n\nShe found that gun ownership was in fact far lower in Israel than in the United States. In the United States there are roughly 310 million firearms in the hands of civilians, nearly one for every adult and child. In Israel \u2014 which has a population of about 8.5 million, not counting about 5 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza \u2014 about 135,000 citizens are currently licensed to own guns. Of those, 37,500 work as guards, according to the Ministry of Public Security, which issues the permits.\n\nThe United States considers handgun ownership a constitutionally protected right, while Israel considers gun permits a privilege, granted by the Ministry of Public Security strictly on the basis of need.\n\nIt is true that Israelis tend to exhibit more comfort with firearms than, say, civilians in countries like Germany and Japan, where handguns are almost impossible to obtain.\n\nMost Jewish Israelis are conscripted for mandatory military service at 18 for a period of at least two years, and receive at least some formal firearms training. Soldiers are issued guns only for their period of service.\n\n\u201cAs we are a people\u2019s army, a lot of the population has at least undergone basic training and knows how to handle and conduct themselves with a weapon,\u201d said Simon Perry, a criminologist at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. \u201cWe don\u2019t have a gun fetish here,\u201d he added.\n\nIsraelis who have completed military service or national service may apply for a gun license at 21; others must wait until 27. Those who are eligible include civilians who live or work in areas considered dangerous; people working in security and emergency services or as civilian security guards; and some farmers, tour guides, veterinarians and registered hunters.", "title": "Is Israel a Model When It Comes to Guns, as Mike Huckabee Says?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Frahm had already held a number of recording sessions in the space, including for the soundtrack of \u201cVictoria,\u201d a 2015 thriller directed by Sebastian Schipper as a single continuous take, when the building\u2019s new owners invited him to house his studio there. In the two years since, he has filled it with a huge collection of synthesizers, pianos and custom-built instruments.\n\nWhen Ms. Hobbs visited the studio in Feb. 2017, she said Mr. Frahm was in the middle of making \u201cAll Melody\u201d and he had taken to sleeping there. \u201cHe\u2019d made a tiny makeshift bed which was little more than a blanket folded over and a pillow on the ground,\u201d she said. \u201cThe place of rest he created for himself was so humble and simple by comparison to the beautiful environment he made for his instruments.\u201d\n\nReverence for instruments started in Mr. Frahm\u2019s youth, when he learned the piano from Nahum Brodski, who Mr. Frahm said had been taught by a student of Tchaikovsky. \u201cIt was nasty learning piano, boring,\u201d he said, but he was disciplined in his practice.\n\n\u201cI understood that you have to suffer for something which is beautiful,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is my biggest criticism in our age, that we try to erase suffering and hardship from our lives in order to just be left only with beauty.\u201d\n\nMr. Frahm was about to play the final show in a four-day run of performances at the Funkhaus, the first leg of his world tour, and he turned to ruminating on how the concerts had gone so far. \u201cThese people have wet eyes and they look at me all smiling, and I feel like it\u2019s my birthday every day,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cBut it makes me very skeptical,\u201d he said. \u201cIt can\u2019t be my birthday every day.\u201d\n\nMr. Frahm said that he didn\u2019t think he could make music forever. He\u2019s too troubled by the ills he sees in the world and making music doesn\u2019t do enough to solve them.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m already thinking of when the right time will be to change jobs,\u201d he said. \u201cI still feel like I have a little bit of potential, but when I feel like I\u2019m fully blossomed as a flower, I will cut myself down and something else will grow.\u201d", "title": "Is It Classical, or Pop? Nils Frahm Is Worried, but Not About That", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHave you ever held a paying job, an internship or a volunteer position?\n\nHow did you learn about the position? How did you get the job?\n\nWhat is your experience as a job seeker, and what stories have you heard from family members or friends about how they\u2019ve found out about job openings and been hired?\n\nIn \u201cCan I Use My Dad\u2019s Connections to Get an Internship?,\u201d the Ethicist columnist Kwame Anthony Appiah responded to a reader\u2019s inquiry:\n\nI\u2019m a college student, and like many college students, I am looking to do an internship. My dad\u2019s previous job was at a company that offers internships in my area of interest. He suggested that I consider interning there and use his connection to my advantage. I think that internships should be earned based on merit, and that nepotism is unethical. I am not sure, however, if avoiding nepotism as an applicant would do anything to put a stop to the practice. I worry that only employers have the power to stop nepotism, and that by avoiding it, I would just hand the internship to other children of employees or former employees who are less concerned about the ethics of nepotism. Also, if I intern (and possibly get a full-time job) with a company that practices nepotism, I might one day be able to change the hiring policy from the inside. What do you recommend? Name Withheld The world of work is full of unfairness. Nepotism \u2014 from the Latin for nephew \u2014 occurs when we give a resource to a relative while overlooking people who are more deserving. One of my favorite historical titles is cardinal nipote, Italian for cardinal nephew, which would be awarded when a pope appointed a kinsman to the College of Cardinals. That old papal practice is what gave us the word. (The last time a papal relative was appointed cardinal was in 1879, when Leo XIII appointed Giuseppe Pecci, his brother.) But nepotism isn\u2019t the most important source of unjustified inequality. Those who already have the advantage of better educations, better connections and better financial resources often parlay these advantages into securing more valuable opportunities and more remunerative careers. Internships are one device for doing this. They\u2019re often unpaid or low-paid, so that only those with substantial family resources can afford to do them. And access to them is often by way of connections. So, internships require both social capital and financial capital. (Charles Murray has famously pronounced them \u201caffirmative action for the advantaged.\u201d) Given all this, you might think that internships should be given to applicants with the best qualifications, but these qualifications are easier for the rich and well connected to acquire, which is why such people often have more cultural capital, too. So, there\u2019s a real problem here. The question is what your role should be in finding a solution. If the system is as you describe it, you\u2019re unlikely to get this internship unless you agree to the pulling of the paternal strings. Should you forswear a system you rightly think unfair at the cost of not getting an internship? There are at least two worries about that.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Do you agree with Mr. Appiah\u2019s advice to the student? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 Have you ever used family connections to get a job? If so, how did you feel about it, and why? If not, why not?\n\n\u2014 What advice would you have given the college student who wrote to Mr. Appiah, above, and why?", "title": "Is It O.K. to Use Family Connections to Get a Job?", "authors": ["Caroline Crosson Gilpin", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Is there a duty, even for those who fear how President Trump governs, to serve in the administration? The debate, which began after Mr. Trump\u2019s election, has often been revisited during his presidency, most recently when Rachel Brand resigned this month as associate attorney general. She said that she did it solely to take a \u201cdream job\u201d as Walmart\u2019s top lawyer, but it\u2019s easy to imagine that she also left because of the stress of serving in the Trump administration\u2019s Justice Department.\n\nIf so, she is not the only one finding government service difficult at this time. Even under the best circumstances, the hours for senior officials are often long and the pay is low compared with what colleagues in the private sector earn.\n\nUnder Mr. Trump, the challenges are particularly daunting. The president and his senior advisers have little use for government professionals. Agencies from the State Department to the Bureau of Prisons are understaffed. The president has crossed once-bright ethical lines, refusing to release his tax returns or to completely dissociate himself from his business while hiring family members for critical positions.\n\nMost disturbingly, the president and his surrogates often attack government institutions, including many that are among America\u2019s most respected. Mr. Trump declared the F.B.I. and the Justice Department \u201cdisgraceful\u201d and even singled out some public servants by name. Most recently, it was his national security adviser, Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, after he accused Russia of \u201cdisinformation, subversion and espionage.\u201d The president promptly called him out in a tweet because the general \u201cforgot to say\u201d that it was \u201cCrooked H, the D.N.C. and the Dems\u201d who colluded with Russia.", "title": "Opinion | Is It Possible to Serve Honorably in the Trump Administration?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam \u2014 In 1978, when he was 2 years old, Tuan Andrew Nguyen was on a plane to the United States. He and his parents were \u201cboat people,\u201d postwar refugees from Communist Vietnam. They were lucky: After a week at sea in a small, open craft, they made landfall on Bidong Island, a speck of land that would soon become the world\u2019s largest refugee camp. Then an American church group offered to resettle them in Oklahoma. When Tuan started crying somewhere over the Pacific, a flight attendant gave him a Dennis the Menace comic book. It\u2019s his earliest memory.\n\nToday, at 41, Mr. Nguyen is living in the city his parents fled, one of eight million souls careening around its overheated streets on motor scooters. He is a Viet Kieu, an overseas Vietnamese, who came back with alien influences like hip-hop, graffiti art and comics. He is also a member of the Propeller Group, an artists\u2019 collective that offers a sly commentary on contemporary Vietnam through works like \u201cTelevision Commercial for Communism,\u201d a 60-second spot that purports to repackage the ideology of Marx and Lenin as a sleek, egalitarian, consumer-friendly lifestyle. It comes with a manifesto, of course, but also with a 24-page booklet of \u201cbrand guidelines.\u201d The logo for the new Communism \u201chas been carefully crafted to be fair to every letterform,\u201d the guidelines specify in deadpan fashion. \u201cEqual spacing is important.\u201d", "title": "Is It an Art Collective or a Vietnamese Ad Agency? Yes and Yes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The debate in many ways echoes the tussling in the 1990s over the word \u201corganic,\u201d when foodmakers played fast and loose with the term and frustrated consumers tried to make sense of it all.\n\nThe United States Department of Agriculture, tasked with creating an \u201corganic\u201d program, was pestered by consumers, farmers, manufacturers and states as it developed a definition, guidelines and a certification process.\n\nToday, while regulators are weighing whether to define the term \u201cnatural,\u201d the lack of clarity for over the past decade has resulted in a freewheeling, and litigious, environment.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn one side are companies eager to cash in on consumers\u2019 willingness to pay higher prices for natural products by slapping \u201call natural\u201d labels on them. At times, the claims have stretched the limits of credulity \u2014 like \u201cAll Natural\u201d 7Up, Pop-Tarts \u201cBaked With Real Fruit\u201d and Crystal Light \u201cNatural\u201d lemonade. (Some labels like these were eventually changed.)\n\nOn the other side is a cadre of plaintiffs\u2019 lawyers \u2014 nicknamed \u201cthe Food Bar\u201d \u2014 who have filed more than 300 lawsuits seeking class-action status in the past three years. Those claims involve allegations of misrepresentations, just on food labels, of the term \u201cnatural\u201d and other descriptions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd, increasingly, the lawsuits are moving beyond food and focusing on consumer goods like baby wipes and cleaning products.\n\nAmong the brands that have faced legal challenges are several that have long promoted their use of natural ingredients: Tom\u2019s of Maine antiperspirants and toothpastes, the Honest Company\u2019s laundry detergent and dish soap, Annie\u2019s Homegrown salad dressings, Breyers and Ben & Jerry\u2019s ice cream, Aveeno face moisturizers and Seventh Generation dish soap.\n\n\u201cThe lawsuits you see are only a fraction of the claims that are made,\u201d said David T. Biderman, a partner at Perkins Coie who defends food companies in class-action lawsuits. Behind the scenes, Mr. Biderman said, plaintiffs\u2019 lawyers are sending letters to companies and threatening to file lawsuits over labels they argue are misleading or violate consumer protection laws. Those letters, Mr. Biderman said, are often rejected, go away or are resolved with a small payment.\n\nWhether the lawsuits are necessary, or a nuisance, depends on whom you ask.\n\nProponents say that in lieu of clear regulation, consumers have been protected by these lawsuits, pointing to a number of cases in which manufacturers have altered their labels. General Mills, which faced at least two federal lawsuits claiming that its Nature Valley granola bars contained artificial ingredients, replaced labels that once read \u201c100% Natural\u201d to say they are \u201cMade With 100% Natural Whole Grain Oats.\u201d\n\nCorporations, lawyers say, have been reluctant to allow a case to go to trial and risk having a legal definition of \u201cnatural\u201d emerge \u2014 which might set standards companies would have to meet. As a result, the bulk of the lawsuits filed over the past decade have been settled, dismissed or, more recently, stayed by judges who hope regulators will step in with a definition.\n\nKim Richman, a plaintiffs\u2019 lawyer, said his clients, including consumers and nonprofit groups, \u201cengage in socially conscious litigation to level the playing field against corporate America as government oversight increasingly falls short.\u201d\n\nBut critics say a big chunk of the settlement money lands in the pockets of the plaintiffs\u2019 lawyers, and does not financially benefit consumers.\n\nCritics also argue that some lawyers are robo-filing lawsuits \u2014 cut-and-pasting nearly identical allegations into complaints against multiple companies \u2014 and in the process are bringing head-scratching cases that risk undermining the credible ones.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA federal judge tossed a case a few years back, for instance, after concluding that reasonable consumers would understand that the \u201ccrunchberries\u201d in Cap\u2019n Crunch cereal were not real fruit. But another judge in California last year refused to dismiss a case against Krispy Kreme, which claimed that consumers were denied the health benefits found in raspberries because the company\u2019s \u201craspberry-filled\u201d doughnuts did not include real fruit. The plaintiff later dropped the lawsuit.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA number of more recent cases involve allegations that products labeled natural were misleading because they contained small amounts of materials linked to genetically modified organisms. In December, a New York federal court judge dismissed a lawsuit claiming that Dannon yogurt was falsely labeled natural because the cows might have been given genetically modified feed.\n\nThe new focus in litigation away from the ingredients in the food to the actual food chain \u2014 how the crop was grown or what the animals were fed \u2014 may undermine the original goal of the lawsuits, which was addressing nutritional concerns, some experts say.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re really getting into splitting hairs about what is natural and what\u2019s not,\u201d said Maia Kats, the director of litigation for the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a public advocacy group has been involved in a handful of lawsuits over so-called natural products.\n\nStuck in the middle of this natural-or-not morass are consumers. Unable to trust the labels lining store shelves, shoppers are left with little choice but to examine the small type on the back of the box and try to decipher terms like methylisothiazolinone, a synthetic preservative found in some personal- and skin-care products.\n\nA survey of consumers in 2015 by Consumer Reports magazine showed that at least 60 percent of respondents believed \u201cnatural\u201d on packaged and processed foods meant they contained no artificial colors or ingredients and no genetically modified materials.\n\n\u201cAbout two-thirds of consumers surveyed think that natural on a food package means no pesticides were used,\u201d said Charlotte Vallaeys, a senior policy analyst with Consumers Union, the advocacy division of Consumer Reports. \u201cThey\u2019re confusing it with organic,\u201d which prohibits nearly all pesticides from use on food products.\n\nBut when it comes to commonly used terms like \u201cnatural\u201d or even \u201chealthy,\u201d the various agencies that oversee food and beverages and advertising have been slow to come up with definitions.\n\nIn late 2015, the United States Food and Drug Administration sought feedback from consumers and the industry on whether it should define and regulate the word \u201cnatural\u201d on food labeling.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore than 7,600 comments flooded in. Some consumers wanted the word banned from all food labeling. Others asked that the term be defined simply.\n\n\u201cWe recognize that consumers are trusting in products labeled \u2018natural\u2019 without clarity around the term,\u201d Dr. Scott Gottlieb, the commissioner of the F.D.A., said in an emailed statement. \u201cConsumers have called upon the F.D.A. to help define the term \u2018natural\u2019 and we take the responsibility to provide this clarity seriously. We will have more to say on the issue soon.\u201d\n\nMost agencies argue they lack the resources to police products that, while not necessarily truthful in their labeling, do not appear to be causing harm to consumers, either. The class-action lawsuits, for the most part, seek reimbursement in the price difference between the \u201cnatural\u201d product and its less natural competition.\n\nApart from food, the regulation of claims in the advertising of shampoos and laundry detergent gets even murkier.\n\nIn 2012, when the Federal Trade Commission updated its Green Guides, a road map to help marketers avoid making environmental claims that could mislead consumers, it did not define the word \u201cnatural.\u201d Laura Koss, a lawyer in the division of enforcement, said the commission received insufficient consumer feedback about the term when it sought comment.\n\nStill, lawyers say that until regulators come up with a definition, the not-so-natural dance among consumers, manufacturers and lawyers will continue.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019ve got a lot of companies, in the absence of clear standards, willing to take the class-action risk because there is so much consumer demand for products that are marketed as natural,\u201d said Randal M. Shaheen, a lawyer with Venable who defends corporate advertising and marketing claims. \u201cBut if you\u2019re a consumer who is really passionate about, for example, not giving your kids high-fructose corn syrup, you should read the label to see how it is sweetened.\u201d", "title": "Is It \u2018Natural\u2019? Consumers, and Lawyers, Want to Know", "authors": ["Julie Creswell"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Anxiety about loneliness is a common feature of modern societies. Today, two major causes of loneliness seem possible. One is that societies throughout the world have embraced a culture of individualism. More people are living alone, and aging alone, than ever. Neoliberal social policies have turned workers into precarious free agents, and when jobs disappear, things fall apart fast. Labor unions, civic associations, neighborhood organizations, religious groups and other traditional sources of social solidarity are in steady decline. Increasingly, we all feel that we\u2019re on our own.\n\nThe other possible cause is the rise of communications technology, including smartphones, social media and the internet. A decade ago, companies like Facebook, Apple and Google pledged that their products would help create meaningful relationships and communities. Instead, we\u2019ve used the media system to deepen existing divisions, at both the individual and group levels. We may have thousands of \u201cfriends\u201d and \u201cfollowers\u201d on Facebook and Instagram, but when it comes to human relationships, it turns out there\u2019s no substitute for building them the old-fashioned way, in person.\n\nIn light of these two trends, it\u2019s easy to believe we\u2019re experiencing an \u201cepidemic\u201d of loneliness and isolation. Surprisingly, though, the best data do not actually show drastic spikes in either loneliness or social isolation.\n\nThe main evidence for rising isolation comes from a widely reported sociology journal article claiming that in 2004, one in four Americans had no one in their life they felt they could confide in, compared with one in 10 during the 1980s. But that study turned out to be based on faulty data, and other research shows that the portion of Americans without a confidant is about the same as it has long been. Although one of the authors has distanced himself from the paper (saying, \u201cI no longer think it\u2019s reliable\u201d), scholars, journalists and policymakers continue to cite it.\n\nThe other data on loneliness are complicated and often contradictory, in part because there are so many different ways of measuring the phenomenon. But it\u2019s clear that the loneliness statistics cited by those who say we have an epidemic are outliers. For example, one set of statistics comes from a study that counted as lonely people who said they felt \u201cleft out\u201d or \u201cisolated,\u201d or \u201clacked companionship\u201d \u2014 even just \u201csome of the time.\u201d That\u2019s an exceedingly low bar, and surely not one we\u2019d want doctors or policymakers to use in their work.", "title": "Opinion | Is Loneliness a Health Epidemic?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "After its charm offensive at the Olympics, North Korea\u2019s delegation has returned home from South Korea, leaving some questions behind. Chief among them: Can the new opening between the two Koreas, begun amid the feel-good spirit of the Winter Games, be nudged and nurtured into serious dialogue over North Korea\u2019s nuclear program?\n\nWhile still a long shot, there\u2019s a somewhat better chance of engagement now owing to two developments since President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, Vice President Mike Pence, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan and the North Korean delegation, including Kim Yo-jong, the only sister of the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, attended the Olympic opening ceremony.\n\nFirst was Mr. Kim\u2019s surprise decision to dispatch his sister, his most trusted envoy, to carry his personal invitation for Mr. Moon to join him in a summit meeting in the North. Mr. Moon and Ms. Kim met four times during the Olympics, the highest-level contact between the two Koreas in years. Mr. Moon\u2019s visit would be an even rarer event, since the reclusive Mr. Kim has never met another foreign leader.\n\nWhile many officials fear that North Korea\u2019s primary goal is to drive a wedge between South Korea, which has been eager to engage the North, and the United States, which has resisted engagement, close coordination between Washington and Seoul would keep the alliance strong.", "title": "Opinion | Is North Korea Causing Trouble or Giving Peace a Chance?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNote: This question and related article were suggested by a student-reader named Hayley DeArmond. Do you have an idea for a Student Opinion question we might ask? Post a comment here, or write to LNFeedback@nytimes.com.\n\n_________\n\nIs there a dream college you want to attend? If you were accepted to this school, do you know how you would finance it?\n\nWhat do you know about taking out student loans to pay for college?\n\nIn \u201cThe Student Loan Serenity Prayer,\u201d Michael Arceneaux writes:\n\nIt was a very handsome college recruiter who, almost a decade earlier, had come to my public high school in Houston and convinced me that if I wanted to attend a prestigious college \u2014 private, out of state, even \u2014 it was possible, no matter what my surroundings or financial circumstances suggested. My mother made clear that I would go to college, but neither she nor I had entertained the idea that I might go to schools like that. Inspired by Recruiter Bae, I applied for as many scholarships as I could find and won 17 in a semester. But I needed additional money to cover the cost of Howard University in Washington. So I turned to Citibank. I took out about $10,000 for the first year, but it soon became clear that I\u2019d need much more to keep studying at Howard and living in Washington until graduation. After I received my diploma, I immediately owed almost $800 a month in private loans, with 12 years to pay it off. That\u2019s not counting the few hundred dollars I pay each month in federal loans. Fortunately, the government gives me more than twice the time to cough it up. This may be the part of my story where you question my judgment. Why did I choose a fancy school if I didn\u2019t have the money? How could I not have understood the financial commitment I was making? And if I\u2019m so far in debt now, why am I writing this and not pursuing a more lucrative career as a doctor or lawyer \u2014 or, as one relative put it bluntly, \u201cWhen are you going to work in a building?\u201d I\u2019m not dismissing my responsibility for this. But along with many other 17- and 18-year-olds, when I went to college, I didn\u2019t know anything about student loans, interest rates or rude private debt companies that hound the living hell out of you. All I knew was what I was told: College was the ticket to social mobility, and good students deserved to go to schools that matched our talent and ambition. Folks like me, who come from working-class backgrounds, are told to chase down a bachelor\u2019s degree by any means necessary. But no one mentions just how expensive and soul-crushing the debt will be.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What more have you learned about student loans from this article? How do you feel about the system based on this author\u2019s experience or that of people you know? What more would you like to know about taking out student loans?\n\n\u2014 In your opinion, is going to the college of your dreams \u2014 one that matches your talents and ambitions \u2014 worth the debt you might accrue? Or would you choose a school based on its affordability for you and your family? Why?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 If you do plan to take out loans to finance your education, how much will this debt influence your career choice? In other words, will you choose your job based on how much money you can make, or based on your interest in a particular field?\n\n\u2014 Over all, do you think that student debt is a problem in the United States? If so, what can schools, students or the government do to address this issue? If not, why not?", "title": "Is Student Debt Worth It?", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "If the past is prologue, Congress will do nothing.\n\nBut governors who gathered in Washington for their annual winter meeting warned of the perils of inaction. Animated by a wave of polling since the Florida massacre, Democratic governors warned that candidates would pay a political price for opposing new gun regulations, and some of their Republican counterparts conceded that the pleas of voters could no longer be ignored as they increasingly abandon the party.\n\n\u201cI think for Republicans our challenge in the next race is going to be about appealing to the suburban vote that hasn\u2019t been so good for Republicans the last few races,\u201d said Gov. Bill Haslam of Tennessee, citing in particular suburban women. It is clear, he added, that \u201cpeople want to see action.\u201d\n\nThe combination of political pressure from the governors and moves by President Trump to embrace certain limited measures opposed by the National Rifle Association could set up a congressional showdown with the powerful firearms lobby not seen since the gun debate that followed the deadly school shooting in 2012 in Newtown, Conn.\n\nThe sudden focus on guns is likely to complicate an already busy agenda. Congress left Washington without coming up with a replacement for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which protects hundreds of thousands of young immigrants from deportation and expires next week. A contentious debate over gun legislation could push immigration to the back burner.\n\nWhile the Newtown massacre and the many that have followed have produced familiar scenes in which Democrats push for tough new gun restrictions and Republicans dig in and resist, the latest mass shooting appears to have shifted the landscape, even if just slightly, as the Parkland students have become overnight gun control advocates and media fixtures.", "title": "Is This the Moment for Gun Control? A Gridlocked Congress Is Under Pressure", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "A Federal District Court ruled, in Nader v. Bork, that Mr. Nixon \u201cillegally discharged\u201d the prosecutor because he \u201cdid not serve at the president\u2019s pleasure.\u201d\n\nThat case holds both peril and promise for Mr. Trump.\n\nThe risk comes in the precedent. It shows how even if a president gets the Department of Justice to do his dirty work, judges have the final say. They can keep prosecutors on the job. (With different facts and law, the Nixon case does not predict how courts would rule today on any potential removal of Mr. Mueller. But courts do have the power to reverse an illegal firing.)\n\nThe promise for Mr. Trump comes in how he is pressuring the Justice Department. He may be reshaping law-enforcement leadership, and the key people around the Russia probe, without actually crossing into the potentially illegal firing of a special counsel.\n\nIn other words, Mr. Trump may be slowly bending the system and personnel toward him, without explicitly ordering people to choose between their job and Mr. Mueller\u2019s job.\n\nThat can build internal resistance to whatever Mr. Mueller ultimately finds, stacking skeptics around him. Indeed, few legal experts say firing federal appointees is itself illegal. (In an obstruction case, prosecutors look at how firings form one element of a wider plot.)\n\nHas Mr. Trump decided to pursue his Russia agenda through this method, having learned the red line \u2014 trying to get Mr. Mueller fired, which his own White House counsel reportedly threatened to resign over \u2014 is not worth the personal risk?\n\nTo observe that this tarrying plot may be lawful is not, of course, to endorse it.\n\nFinding technically legal ways to grind down, pressure and reshape law enforcement is an affront to our constitutional democracy. It weeds out the type of independent public servants who are supposed to be in these posts. It invites partisanship and abuse. It undermines public confidence in the one institution that we trust to patrol, prosecute and even kill our fellow citizens.", "title": "Opinion | Is Trump Working on a Different Kind of \u2018Massacre\u2019?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "The culture right now is in a state of acute ambivalence about Woody Allen, which is to say that, as in so many other matters, the public conversation is defined by conflict, polarization and the exclusion of the middle ground. Love and hate occupy opposing camps, and reconciliation of their claims seems impossible, at least when those claims involve the allegations that Mr. Allen molested his daughter Dylan Farrow when she was a young child. He adamantly denies the accusations, and his most passionate defenders insist that to doubt it is to be a latter-day McCarthyite, a witch hunter.\n\nBut relitigating the abuse charges is a way of avoiding the real work, which is the endless, not always pleasant task of interpreting Mr. Allen\u2019s work. The movies and what they have meant to so many of us will not just vanish. The ambivalence needs to be acknowledged and analyzed, which is why I\u2019ve spent much of the past few weeks rewatching movies that I used to count among my favorites.\n\nThat is an analysis that Mr. Allen\u2019s most vociferous detractors and his most ardent partisans share a wish to terminate. Dylan Farrow\u2019s allegations and the other episode they bring up \u2014 the demise of Mr. Allen\u2019s 12-year relationship with the actress Mia Farrow and his affair with her daughter Soon-Yi Previn, who is now his wife \u2014 are to many people, especially young people, a deal breaker, evidence of a creepiness they find impossible to see past. For others, including myself for most of my career as a film critic and for those who stuck with Mr. Allen for the last 25 years, seeing past it was nearly a reflex. It seemed to be the more mature, the more reasonable, the less hysterical stance to adopt.\n\nI\u2019ve already written about why I no longer find that an ethically or intellectually tenable stance. Not everyone was persuaded, of course, and some readers helpfully sent along lists of Great Artists Who Have Done Terrible Things. What about them? Should we judge their work by their actions? Should we banish it because these men treated women badly, or represented them in ways we now consider misogynist?\n\nThe fact that bad men make great art tends to be asserted as if it were the solution to, rather than the statement of, a problem. It also supposes greatness to be a fixed quantity, rather than the subject and result of perpetual argument.", "title": "Is Woody Allen a Great Filmmaker? Discuss", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "What conclusions may be drawn? For one thing, Instagram puts a premium on superficial dog traits like cuteness over ones like intelligence or obedience.\n\n\u201cInstagram and social media is impacting everything, and influencing all kinds of lifestyle and consumer decisions, so it makes sense that it would influence what kind of dog people choose,\u201d said Cameron Woo, the publisher of The Bark, a dog-culture magazine based in Berkeley, Calif. In that way, Instagram is like television was in an earlier era, Mr. Woo said. \u201cLassie\u201d inspired a mid-century collie boom; \u201cFrasier\u201d propelled a Jack Russell terrier moment in the 1990s.\n\nThat was certainly the case with Aleksandar Gligoric, a dog breeder from Serbia who named his online dog store Frenchie World, in part because of Instagram. \u201cPeople are considering Instagram worthiness in all aspects of their life,\u201d he said. \u201cI felt that the Frenchie would be the next big thing on Instagram.\u201d\n\nAlmost Human\n\nSo, what dog traits are favored by Instagram users? Well, for starters, they like dogs that look like them.\n\nBreeds like pugs and Boston terriers \u201creally resemble humans, or babies,\u201d Mr. Woo said. These so-called brachycephalic breeds, with their shortened heads, flat faces and barely there noses, \u201care very photogenic with their large, forward-looking eyes,\u201d Mr. Woo said. \u201cThey appear to be grinning or smiling,\u201d never mind that the \u201csmiles\u201d are often caused by breathing difficulties native to their breeds.\n\nPug owners don\u2019t disagree.\n\n\u201cWith their smushed-in faces, all the rolls, and their funny tails, pugs are the least doglike dogs,\u201d said Leslie Mosier of Nashville, whose pug, Doug (@itsdougthepug), is one of the most popular pets on Instagram, with 3.2 million reputed followers. \u201cThey are more like humans-slash-pigs-slash-dogs.\u201d\n\nThe breed\u2019s almost-human face makes it easy for owners to anthropomorphize their pets with costumes. Ms. Mosier routinely plays off Doug\u2019s perma-frown by dressing him \u2014 wrapped in towels, say, with cucumber slices over his eyes, looking like a moneyed divorc\u00e9e taking refuge at Canyon Ranch.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs actors or models, pugs are the canine equivalent of hams. \u201cThey were bred in China to sit at the emperor\u2019s feet and entertain,\u201d Ms. Mosier said.\n\nA dog\u2019s popularity can increase exponentially when it has a signature style flourish, the canine equivalent of Anna Wintour\u2019s sunglasses or Pharrell Williams\u2019s hats. Case in point: the Gene Simmons-length tongue of @marniethedog, a Shih Tzu rescue that at this point may be more famous than the real Gene Simmons, thanks to an explosively popular Instagram feed.\n\nAnd if the canine flourish isn\u2019t genetic, there\u2019s no stopping the owner from creating one with careful grooming. Take Agador (@poochofnyc), a maltipoo with teddy bear looks who has appeared in ad campaigns for Google and a teaser for Katy Perry\u2019s \u201cBon App\u00e9tit\u201d video.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAgador\u2019s explosive orb of copper-colored frizz is routinely gussied up into a spherical confection atop his head. It is a look that conjures Bob Ross, the TV painter who died in 1995. And who isn\u2019t going to follow \u201cthe Bob Ross of dogs,\u201d as Agador is billed on Instagram.\n\n\u201cIt makes him instantly recognizable,\u201d said Allan Monteron, one of his owners. \u201cPeople stop us on the street and say, \u2018I follow that dog on Instagram!\u2019\u201d\n\nExaggerated features are a plus, too. Take corgis, those squat-legged canine courtiers to the queen. They are certainly hot on Instagram, with accounts that have \u201ccorgi\u201d in the user name rising 200 percent over the past year, according to Instagram, and that cannot all be attributable to the breed\u2019s occasional cameo on \u201cThe Crown.\u201d\n\nEvery feature of the corgi works as a visual punch line: those oversize Yoda ears, the squat \u201cHoney I Shrunk the Collie\u201d body, the 50-percent-off appendages, which make the corgi\u2019s movements particularly comical on social media.\n\nThe same may be said of bulldogs, the one breed that appears in the top five of both Instagram and the American Kennel Club. Outside of social media, bulldogs\u2019 popularity will be assured so long as there are Anglophiles, Marine Corps veterans and college football fans in the state of Georgia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd on Instagram, where user names that include \u201cbulldog\u201d have seen a 60 percent surge in the past year, bulldogs check multiple boxes: They look like people (specifically, grumpy old men), have inherently comic features (the volleyball-size head, the tiny bow legs) and are easy to anthropomorphize.\n\nThe breed has also reaped a windfall of \u201cit dog\u201d publicity from celebrities, including Brad Pitt, Jessica Biel and David Beckham, for whom these homely little bruisers seem to make the perfect foil. The message seems to be: \u201cDo not hate me because I am beautiful, since my dog is not.\u201d\n\nMutts and Tripods\n\nBecause of their associations with the queen and the British Empire, however, both corgis and bulldogs seem out of step with the current vogue for rescue dogs and less rarefied breeds.\n\nThese days, pointedly aristocratic breeds tend not to pop on social media as much as dogs with quirky features or compelling back stories, said Elias Weiss Friedman, a New Yorker photographer who spends his days snapping pictures for The Dogist, a dog-centric street photography site that has a rabid Instagram following.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve found that people prefer the more real, natural dogs,\u201d Mr. Friedman said. \u201cPoodles seem to give off a pretentious vibe, especially if they have the classic poodle haircut. The older generations love them, but I think the younger generation sees that style as fake, undogly.\u201d\n\nIndeed, his two most popular posts have been a mixed breed puppy with funny ears named Larry and a 12-year-old Labrador with vitiligo named Rowdy. \u201cPeople crave relatability, and see dogs as individuals with similar life challenges to themselves,\u201d he said.\n\nThe right kinds of mixed breed \u2014 they were once called mutts \u2014 play well on social media, particularly if their features are camera worthy. A husky-malamute-wolf mix called @loki_the_wolfdog has become one of the 10 most popular pets on Instagram, thanks in part to his rugged \u201cCall of the Wild\u201d aura and head-turning looks (including mismatched eye colors and a silky coat that changes color with the seasons), that his owner, Kelly Lund, uses to poetic effect in his shots of Loki in the snow-dusted Colorado wilderness.\n\nMany dog owners interviewed also said they see mutts, rescues and disabled dogs as a more ethical choice.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think the most difficult question posed to us is always \u2018Where did you get that dog? I want to get one exactly like it,\u201d said Francis Bott, who owns Agador with his partner, Mr. Monteron. \u201cIt is simple enough to provide the breeder\u2019s name, but we are big proponents of adopting rescues whenever possible.\u201d\n\n(They opted buy a hypoallergenic poodle mix from a breeder, Mr. Bott said, because their previous dog, a rescue Shih Tzu/Bichon mix, aggravated their allergies.)\n\nRescue organizations like the North Shore Animal League and the Brooklyn Animal Resource Coalition blanket social media with heart-rending photos of doe-eyed animals looking for a home.\n\nSuch social media efforts to raise awareness have led to a demand for differently abled dogs and so-called tripods, or those missing a limb, said Jennifer Nosek, the editor of Modern Dog magazine. One such unlikely Instagram star was Smiley, a golden retriever born without eyes, and with a form of dwarfism, in a puppy mill, who went on to become a widely publicized service dog in nursing homes and hospitals.
