(Smiley\u2019s death last year, after a battle with cancer, was covered by the news media.)\n\n\u201cPerhaps it\u2019s an antidote to all the bad news we\u2019re so often bombarded with,\u201d Ms. Nosek said. \u201cThese accounts remind us that there are people, and dogs, out there doing good.\u201d\n\nEither that, or such dogs just provide a break from the pressure that the rest of us feel trying to look too perfect for Instagram.\n\nTake @chloekardoggian, a gray-whiskered 13-year-old rescue Chihuahua in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, with huge eyes and 153,000 followers. \u201cHer ears go up, her nose goes right, her tongue goes left, and her eyes each go in different directions,\u201d said Dorie Herman, her owner. \u201cEveryone has felt like Chloe looks at some point in their lives.\u201d", "title": "Is Your Dog Ready for Instagram?", "authors": ["Alex Williams"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Rudian, who becomes an object of desire for the two young women, is selfish, bad-tempered, occasionally violent, but gifted. The authorities have held up his new play because it includes the ghost of a World War II partisan who questions his murderers. The diktats of social realism do not allow for the supernatural on stage.\n\nPhoto\n\nSure enough, Rudian is called in for questioning, in a country where interrogations leave \u201cblood on the floor.\u201d But the officials target neither his play nor his burgeoning affair with the art student \u2014 but rather her enigmatic friend, \u201cLinda B.,\u201d who committed suicide with his signed book in her possession.\n\nLinda\u2019s passion for the man she has never met will literally defy death. In the meantime, her obsession pulls the plot together, along with her ecstatic, idealized longing for the Albanian capital Tirana, far from the provincial backwater where she and her bourgeois family are sentenced to internal exile for their ties to the banished monarchy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKadare is still mapping out the boundaries of Albanian, a relatively recent literary language, where everything is new and newly sayable. He is the first of its writers to achieve an international standing. But how to describe something beyond words? \u201cBetter if you don\u2019t know\u201d is a repeated phrase in the book, along with variations of \u201cit\u2019s complicated.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe two girls, \u201cdaughters of socialism, as the phrase went,\u201d resolve their eternal love triangle with a stunning metaphysical selflessness. And they reply to injustice and repression not by resistance or retaliation, but with an utterly new, unconditioned response that leaves the reader lightheaded, transcending even that which we value as \u201cfreedom.\u201d In Kadare\u2019s words, they move \u201cbeyond the laws of this world.\u201d\n\nKadare has commented on his native tongue\u2019s unique affinities with classical Greek, and in the past he used allegory and myth to veil meaning and evade censorship. Western readers may find the allusions frustratingly indirect, but Kadare has accustomed himself to telling his tales slantwise, even in a post-totalitarian era where anything goes.\n\nHe returns again and again to the legends around Orpheus, for example, his addition of two strings to the traditional lyre \u2014 in Kadare\u2019s telling, a radical breakthrough that causes a bureaucratic hubbub in Olympus. The author doesn\u2019t tether his own story to the classical one too tightly, but the parallels are obvious \u2014 for Rudian with his forbidden ghost; and for Kadare, who once spirited his messages past Communist censors.\n\nThe two extra strings may signify more than the headaches of writers, however. Perhaps they create an altogether new sound, beyond the range of human hearing. It is, after all, the vibration that lulled Cerberus, the hound of Hades, and rescued Orpheus\u2019 beloved Eurydice from the underworld.\n\nBy the end of this story Kadare allows his characters to violate nature and death, echoing the footsteps of Orpheus. Rudian\u2019s Eurydice tells him of her otherworldly journey to come to him \u2014 the cold, the dogs and the barbed wire that stretches everywhere. It is a denouement that illuminates the final pages like a flame glowing through alabaster.", "title": "Ismail Kadare Grapples With the Supernatural", "authors": ["Cynthia Haven", "Ismail Kadare"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "In a letter to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, 36 Holocaust survivors, many of them refugees from the ghettos and concentration camps of Europe, beseeched him \u201cto learn the lesson\u201d and not to expel Africans seeking asylum in Israel.\n\n\u201cAs a country founded by refugees,\u201d said another letter signed by 850 Jewish clergy and delivered to Israeli embassies and consulates in the United States and Canada, \u201cand whose early leaders helped craft the 1951 International Convention on the Status of Refugees, Israel must not deport those seeking asylum within its borders.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nLike much of the Western world, Israel is grappling with how to balance its right to protect its borders and prevent illegal immigration with showing compassion and humanity. But the government\u2019s decision has struck a particular chord here and among Jews abroad since the modern state of Israel has served as a safe haven for Jews fleeing persecution and was largely built by immigrants.\n\nThe issue is also testing what it means to be a Jewish state: to preserve its Jewish majority, or to be governed by Jewish values, including the ideal of \u201ctikkun olam,\u201d or repairing the world.\n\n\u201cEvery country must guard its borders,\u201d Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in announcing the policy last month. \u201cIt is important that people understand that we are doing something here that is completely legal and completely essential.\u201d\n\nHe cited the \u201cplight\u201d of residents of south Tel Aviv, where many of the migrants are concentrated. In the past, he has also said that the influx of Africans threatened Israel\u2019s Jewish majority.\n\nMany of the solidarity events are taking place under the umbrella of a grass-roots movement, \u201cStop the Deportation,\u201d which was started by students. In addition to the meeting in the basement studio of a Jerusalem yoga teacher, there was a gathering this week in a bar in Kiryat Shemona, a town on Israel\u2019s northern border, and another in the southern city of Beersheba in the Negev desert.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother initiative, \u201cMiklat Israel,\u201d Hebrew for Israel Sanctuary, and known informally as the Anne Frank Home Sanctuary movement, signed up about 500 Israeli families from scores of towns and communities willing to adopt asylum seekers and, if necessary, hide them in their homes.\n\nFirst conceived by Susan Silverman, a rabbi and the sister of the American comedian Sarah Silverman, the idea was partly inspired by the story of another Eritrean who was so moved by Anne Frank\u2019s diary that he translated it into Tigrinya while in a camp in Ethiopia, then carried it with him on his journey to Israel, convinced that its people would receive him.\n\n\u201cWe are exploding the myth that ordinary Israelis don\u2019t want them,\u201d said Rabbi Nava Hefetz, one of the group\u2019s leaders, adding that the small team of volunteers couldn\u2019t keep up with the flood of phone calls and emails.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe are talking about the history of the Jewish people,\u201d she said, \u201cfrom the exodus from Egypt to the terrible tragedy of the Holocaust. Refugeedom is in our DNA. Seeking asylum is in our blood.\u201d\n\nEven secular Israelis have taken to citing biblical verses like Leviticus 19:34: \u201cThe stranger who resides among you shall be to you as one of your citizens; you shall love him as yourself, for you were strangers in the land of Egypt.\u201d\n\nAnd liberals hark back to the decision of Menachem Begin, the prime minister who brought Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s right-wing Likud Party to power in 1977, to welcome several hundred Vietnamese boat people.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Israelis are divided, with many others eager to see the departure of the Africans. Officials here routinely refer to them as \u201cinfiltrators\u201d because they sneaked across the border from the Egyptian Sinai, and insist that the majority \u2014 young men of working age \u2014 are economic migrants, not refugees.\n\n\u201cIsrael is too small and has its own problems,\u201d Israel\u2019s justice minister, Ayelet Shaked, said in a Facebook post. \u201cIt cannot serve as the employment agency for the African continent.\u201d\n\nMany, including the Ashkenazi chief rabbi of Israel, David Lau, and his father, Yisrael Meir Lau, a former chief rabbi and child Holocaust survivor, reject the comparisons with the Holocaust. The migrants, they note, are not being sent to extermination camps and their Israeli sympathizers will not be risking their lives by harboring them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout 60,000 African migrants have surreptitiously crossed into Israel over the once-porous border with Egypt since 2005, most of them Sudanese or Eritreans who cannot be sent back home because of international conventions that prevent the repatriation of asylum seekers to home countries where they could face persecution. The influx stopped in 2012, when Israel constructed a steel barrier along the 150-mile border with Egypt.\n\nOf the thousands of Eritreans and Sudanese who have filed asylum requests in Israel in recent years, only about 10 have received refugee status. Some Sudanese refugees from war-torn Darfur have been given a special humanitarian status but most of the other asylum requests have not been processed.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt least 20,000 African migrants have since left Israel. Mr. Netanyahu said he had made it his mission to deport the rest. He and his ministers have alluded to secret understandings with third countries in Africa, without naming them.\n\nThe migrants say the main destination is Rwanda, but the Rwandan government has denied signing any secret deal. It says its policy toward Africans in need of a home is one of \u201copen doors,\u201d but only to those who come voluntarily.\n\nMigrant and human rights organizations say many Africans who left Israel for Rwanda and Uganda did not find work or receive legal status. Many are said to have continued on their journeys, often putting themselves in grave danger.\n\nInterior Minister Aryeh Deri told a parliamentary committee this week that Israel had deported more than 5,000 non-African illegal immigrants since last year, proof that the government policy was not racist; more than 20,000 Ukrainians and Georgians have sought asylum in Israel in recent years.\n\nUnder increasing public pressure, he clarified that the new policy would apply only to single African men who had not formally submitted an asylum request by Jan. 1. It would not apply to families or the roughly 5,000 children of asylum-seekers who had been born in Israel. The migrants have until April 1 to accept the cash and flight or face detention.\n\nYonatan Jakubowicz, director of the Israeli Immigration Policy Center, an organization supportive of the government\u2019s arguments, said he thought that Israel had taken a \u201cvery balanced\u201d position in \u201clooking for that middle ground,\u201d and that other countries could learn from it.\n\nIn the Jerusalem basement, Mr. Tehehaymanut said he had initially hoped to go to Libya, and from there to Europe. But the Bedouin smugglers dropped his group off in the desert in the middle of the night and told them to walk straight ahead toward the lights of Israel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIsraeli soldiers received them with smiles, food and drink. \u201cWe did not come to eat,\u201d Mr. Tehehaymanut said. \u201cJust to live.\u201d", "title": "Israel Moves to Expel Africans. Critics Say That\u2019s Not Jewish.", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner"]} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is indeed a dangerous escalation that raises the specter of direct conflict between Israel and Iran in Syria \u2014 a far more serious situation than the drawing of red lines and tit-for-tat exchanges that have occurred before,\u201d said Robert Satloff, executive director of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy.\n\nVideo\n\nForces from Russia, Turkey and the United States are also on the ground in Syria in a war with multiple fronts and multiple factions, including the remnants of the Islamic State and other Islamist militant groups.\n\nIn the past week, aircraft from three foreign countries have been brought down in the conflict: the Israeli plane; a Turkish helicopter shot down, also on Saturday, as it attacked Kurdish militias; and a Russian plane over Idlib that was bombing rebel-held territory.\n\nIsrael has long warned about the risk of conflict as Iranian forces and their allies, including Hezbollah, the Lebanese militant group, have dug in on Syrian territory and approached the boundary with the Israeli-held portion of the Golan Heights. Israel, which considers Iran its most potent enemy in the region, has been lobbying world powers to push these forces from the border areas.\n\nIsrael has carried out scores of strikes in Syria in recent years, largely targeting what it says are advanced weapons stores or convoys taking weapons to Hezbollah in neighboring Lebanon. Israel has also reportedly hit Syrian government facilities involved in weapons development and an Iranian base under construction in Syria.\n\nBut this was the first Israeli strike on a site where Iranian forces were present, analysts said, and Israeli military officials said this was the first time an Iranian drone had penetrated Israeli airspace during the Syrian war. There was no immediate indication that the drone was armed.\n\nIsraeli military officials accused the Syrians and Iranians of \u201cplaying with fire,\u201d but indicated that Israel wanted to contain the situation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe are ready to exact a very heavy price from whoever acts against us,\u201d said Brig. Gen. Ronen Manelis, the chief spokesman of the Israeli military, \u201cbut we are not seeking an escalation.\u201d\n\nThe jet crash represented a severe blow to Israel\u2019s prestige and could mark a major change after years in which it acted against targets in Syria with relative impunity.\n\nIn the past, Syria has claimed, falsely, that it had shot down Israeli aircraft. The last time an Israeli jet was downed under enemy fire appears to have been in the early 1980s.\n\nHezbollah said on Saturday that the downing of the Israeli F-16 jet by the Syrian Army marked the \u201cstart of a new strategic phase,\u201d which would limit Israeli exploitation of Syrian airspace. \u201cToday\u2019s developments mean the old equations have categorically ended,\u201d the Lebanese Shiite group said in a statement.\n\nIn Syria, the day\u2019s events were viewed as potential game-changers. Government supporters celebrated in the streets of Damascus, handing out sweets and hailing Mr. Assad and the army.\n\nThis is the first time the Syrian government appears to have made good on promises to shoot down Israeli aircraft, after years of threats against both Israel and the other international militaries that have flown sorties over Syria without permission.\n\n\u201cI am so happy,\u201d said Haidar, 30, a government supporter, as he handed out sweets downtown. \u201cIt makes me proud to see a Syrian response, shooting down the Israeli F-16. For years we have been waiting for a Syrian reaction against the Israeli violations and airstrikes.\u201d\n\nBut just as Syrian self-confidence appears to have grown, Israel also sent a strong message with its broad wave of strikes on Saturday, Israeli analysts said. They noted that this was the first time in recent years Israel had struck Syrian territory in broad daylight and said that Israel had inflicted serious damage on Syria\u2019s air-defense system. Despite more Syrian antiaircraft fire, all Israeli jets returned to base safely from the second mission, after the first jet was lost, according to the Israeli military. Syria is believed to have fired at least a dozen antiaircraft missiles, with the wreckage of one landing in Lebanon.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was not immediately clear if the Israeli F-16 was directly hit by the Syrian antiaircraft fire. Early assessments suggested that it was, said Lt. Col. Jonathan Conricus, another spokesman for the Israeli military, though he added that nothing had been officially confirmed.\n\nThe Israeli military said two pilots had bailed from the downed aircraft \u201cas per procedure.\u201d One pilot was severely injured.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spent much of Saturday in consultations with his defense minister, the Israeli chief of staff and other military officials.\n\nRussia, along with Iran, has been helping prop up the government of President Bashar al-Assad in Syria, and the Russian Foreign Ministry issued a statement calling on \u201call sides involved to show restraint and avoid all acts that could lead to complicating the situation further.\u201d\n\nThe ministry added: \u201cIt is absolutely unacceptable to create threats to the lives and security of Russian soldiers that are in the Syrian Arab Republic on the invitation of the legal government to assist in the fight against terrorism.\u201d\n\nAfter a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow two weeks ago, Mr. Netanyahu said in a statement that Israel viewed with \u201cutmost gravity\u201d Iran\u2019s efforts to establish a military presence in Syria, and said he had made clear to Mr. Putin that Israel would \u201cact according to need.\u201d\n\nMr. Netanyahu said he spoke with Mr. Putin on Saturday and agreed that security coordination between the two countries would continue. The Israeli prime minister also said he spoke with Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson about Saturday\u2019s confrontation.\n\n\u201cThe United States is deeply concerned about today\u2019s escalation of violence over Israel\u2019s border,\u201d Heather Nauert, a State Department spokeswoman, said in a statement. \u201cIran\u2019s calculated escalation of threat, and its ambition to project its power and dominance, places all the people of the region \u2014 from Yemen to Lebanon \u2014 at risk.\u201d\n\nA Pentagon spokesman, Maj. Adrian J. Rankine-Galloway, said the United States military supported Israel\u2019s right of self-defense. \u201cWe share the concerns of many throughout the region that Iran\u2019s destabilizing activities threaten international peace and security, and we seek greater international resolve in countering Iran\u2019s malign activities,\u201d Major Rankine-Galloway said in a statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith so many foreign forces engaged in Syria, the risks of the conflict extending beyond its borders are real, but analysts said all sides have an interest in making sure Saturday\u2019s events do not spiral into something larger.\n\n\u201cI think it will be contained for the moment,\u201d said Steven Simon, a Middle East specialist at Amherst College who was a senior official on President Barack Obama\u2019s National Security Council. \u201cBut the situation is highly volatile,\u201d Mr. Simon said, adding, \u201cthis has been simmering for quite a while and things are coming to a boil.\u201d\n\nMr. Simon said an important question is whether the White House is counseling restraint.\n\n\u201cThe U.S. and Israel could be thinking of their respective operations in Syria as a hammer and anvil, with Iran and its proxy forces in the middle,\u201d he said. \u201cIf true, fighting will escalate.\u201d\n\nAmos Yadlin, a former chief of Israeli military intelligence and now the executive director of the Institute for National Security Studies at Tel Aviv University, said Syria, Iran and Russia would appear to have little interest now in getting into a full-blown conflict with Israel.\n\n\u201cIsrael has the capability to destroy the Russian and Iranian project to save the Assad regime,\u201d Mr. Yadlin said. \u201cThis is not the weak Syrian opposition. This is strong Israel.\u201d\n\nWhile Israel\u2019s military strength is a significant factor in any response, the improving situation for the Assad government is also a consideration.\n\n\u201cThere is no incentive for the Iranians, Syrians or Russians to draw the Israelis into a military situation that has been moving in their favor for some time,\u201d said Stephen B. Slick, a former C.I.A. station chief in Israel who now directs the Intelligence Studies Project at the University of Texas at Austin.\n\nThe Iranian Foreign Ministry denied the drone had strayed into Israeli airspace and rejected as \u201claughable\u201d reports that Israel had intercepted a drone launched from Syria.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSyrian Army officials said the drone had been carrying out a routine mission against the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL, over Syrian airspace, according to the news site Al-Manar.\n\nColonel Conricus insisted that the drone was \u201con a specific Iranian mission,\u201d and was shot down deep in Israeli territory.\n\nStill, some Israeli analysts did not discount the possibility that the Iranian drone had crossed into Israel because of a malfunction.\n\n\u201cI fail to see the logic behind the Iranians sending a drone to Israel,\u201d said Ehud Yaari, an Israeli television analyst of Arab affairs and an Israel-based fellow of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. \u201cThey have other priorities right now in Syria.\u201d\n\nBut once it had crossed into Israeli airspace, the Israelis had no choice but to respond, Mr. Yaari said.\n\nHe added, \u201cThe almost constant friction between the Iranian presence in Syria and the Israeli Army is taking its toll.\u201d", "title": "Israel Strikes Iran in Syria and Loses a Jet", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner", "Anne Barnard", "Eric Schmitt"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is fighting new allegations of corruption from the Israeli police that have led to calls for his resignation.\n\nThis is not the first time Mr. Netanyahu has struggled with corruption investigations \u2014 he is sometimes referred to as Mr. Teflon for the trouble the police have had getting accusations to stick \u2014 nor is he the first of the country\u2019s prime ministers to do so.\n\nHere\u2019s a brief timeline of his predecessors\u2019 run-ins with the law, as well as his own past clashes with Israel\u2019s criminal justice system.\n\nPhoto\n\nYitzhak Rabin\n\n1977 During a trip to Washington that Mr. Rabin took with his wife, Leah, an Israeli journalist discovered that the Rabins held a savings account that had been opened when Mr. Rabin was Israel\u2019s ambassador there. Israeli citizens were barred at the time from holding foreign accounts, and the attorney general ruled that Mrs. Rabin should stand trial and that Mr. Rabin should be fined. Mr. Rabin abandoned his campaign for a second term and was not charged; his wife was convicted and fined nearly $27,000.\n\nPhoto\n\nEhud Barak\n\n2000 Israel\u2019s comptroller fined Mr. Barak\u2019s One Israel party, and the attorney general began a criminal investigation, over fund-raising for Mr. Barak\u2019s 1999 campaign, saying his associates had evaded strict campaign-finance rules by channeling illegal donations into a host of nonprofit groups. Mr. Barak said he was unaware of any impropriety and had ordered his campaign aides to obey the law. In 2002, the police recommended against indictment, for lack of evidence; the case against him was closed in 2003.\n\nPhoto\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAriel Sharon\n\n2001 Mr. Sharon was accused of accepting bribes from a developer, David Appel, to gain the prime minister\u2019s help in real estate deals including a resort and casino on the Greek island of Patroklos, beginning in the late 1990s, when Mr. Sharon was foreign minister. The police, who had been tapping Mr. Appel\u2019s phones, said he had paid large consulting fees to Gilad Sharon, Mr. Sharon\u2019s son. The state prosecutor recommended in 2004 that Mr. Sharon be indicted on bribery charges, but the attorney general dropped the case, saying the evidence did not come \u201cremotely close\u201d to enough for a conviction.\n\nPhoto\n\nEhud Olmert\n\n2008 After months of public and political pressure following corruption allegations, Mr. Olmert announced he would not seek re-election, and would step down after a new chairman was elected within his party. In September, he officially resigned as prime minister, a week after the police recommended that he be indicted on charges of bribery, breach of public trust, money laundering and fraudulent receipt of goods. He remained at the head of an interim government until March 2009.", "title": "Israeli Prime Ministers\u2019 Struggles With Corruption: A Timeline", "authors": ["Irit Pazner Garshowitz", "Jonah Engel Bromwich"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "JERUSALEM \u2014 Israel\u2019s cross-border clash with Iranian and Syrian forces on Saturday was a sharp escalation of long-brewing hostilities along its northern frontier \u2014 and a bracing alert to those who have focused on other areas of the Syrian civil war, on other aspects of Iran\u2019s strategic assertiveness, or who believed that Israel\u2019s air superiority left it invincible in its own skies.\n\nIn the space of several hours, Israel downed what it said was an Iranian drone that had penetrated its airspace, then struck back at what it called the command-and-control center in Syria from which Iran launched the drone. An Israeli F-16, returning from the attack, crashed in northern Israel after coming under heavy Syrian antiaircraft fire \u2014 the first Israeli jet downed under enemy fire in decades.\n\nIsrael responded with strikes against eight Syrian and four Iranian targets in Syrian territory.\n\nPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu described the day\u2019s events as proof of Israel\u2019s resolve. \u201cYesterday we dealt severe blows to the Iranian and Syrian forces,\u201d he said Sunday. \u201cWe made it unequivocally clear to everyone that our rules of action have not changed one bit. We will continue to strike at every attempt to strike at us.\u201d\n\nBut strategists and military analysts in Israel did not see things quite so simply. As both sides sift through the debris, here are some important points:\n\nThis isn\u2019t over. It\u2019s just beginning.\n\nAs the Syrian civil war winds down, a new conflict is emerging among Iran, which appears to want a lasting Syrian base to threaten Israel; Israel, which is determined to prevent this; and the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, which showed renewed confidence in firing on Israel\u2019s warplanes.", "title": "Israel\u2019s Clash With Iran and Syria: 5 Takeaways", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nMy wife and I felt so lucky to find a parking spot on the street two blocks from Lincoln Center when we attended a production of \u201cTurandot\u201d at the Metropolitan Opera. All we had to do was stay in the car until 6 o\u2019clock when the spot would become legal.\n\nAs we chatted about our good fortune in not having to pay for a parking garage, out of the corner of my eye I saw a car coming down the street that seemed to be way too close to ours as it tried to squeeze past the backed-up traffic.\n\nAnd then, boom: Our driver\u2019s side rearview mirror was gone.\n\nI ran after the car, which stopped a few car lengths ahead of ours. The driver, a woman who appeared perplexed, listened as I told her she needed to give us her information.\n\nShe backed up into a driveway behind us to get out of traffic. We all calmed down, the matter was resolved and the woman promised to compensate us for the damage.\n\nWe had gotten back into our car to continue waiting for 6 o\u2019clock to arrive when the woman who had knocked off our mirror pulled up next to us and rolled down her window.\n\nThinking she had forgotten something, I rolled mine down as well.\n\n\u201cAre you staying in that space?\u201d she asked.", "title": "It Happened by Lincoln Center", "authors": ["Kenneth Sinclair", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt was about time,\u201d said Ms. Ballance, who along with Mr. McCaughan also runs the respected independent record label Merge. \u201cIt\u2019s all very Mac-driven. He\u2019s always got ideas, and after a while, he resurfaces with stuff written.\u201d It helps when he\u2019s angry, she added.\n\nThe album\u2019s primary emotion at times is a blinding, sputtering fury. On the squalling \u201cI Got Cut,\u201d Mr. McCaughan spews bile from the start: \u201cAll these old men won\u2019t die too soon.\u201d But there\u2019s a recognition that anger alone isn\u2019t productive. The anthemic chorus of \u201cAll for You\u201d (where Mr. McCaughan sings, \u201cFight me!\u201d) is a joke.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never been in a fight,\u201d he said. \u201cBut in the aftermath of the election, I\u2019d leave the house thinking, if I see someone in a Make America Great Again hat, I will not be able to restrain myself. Which is an unusual way for me to go through the world. It\u2019s not tenable.\u201d\n\nMr. McCaughan\u2019s misgivings about protest music also bubble to the surface. \u201cReagan Youth\u201d is both an ode to the \u201980s anarchist-punk band of the same name and a frustrated acknowledgment that the \u201cother Reagan Youth,\u201d those inspired by the former president who are now in positions of power in the Conservative movement, have had a more durable legacy. \u201cThat song is questioning what good did all that punk rock do?\u201d Mr. McCaughan said. That query inevitably leads to others. \u201cAs an artist, what good am I doing? What am I going to do? Write a song? What\u2019s that going to do?\u2019\u201d\n\nAccording to Billy Bragg, an English singer-songwriter and a purveyor of protest music since the 1970s, what makes writing political music these days different than in previous eras is that what was once considered outrageous behavior is now shrugged at. \u201cWhen the people who elected Trump aren\u2019t even offended when you call him a liar, it makes him a very slippery customer,\u201d he said by phone.\n\nThe music industry and the overall media landscape have been remade, too. The fading influence of radio, MTV and music magazines coupled with the rise of streaming services and social media has virtually erased the idea of a musical monoculture. \u201cThe centrality of music to youth culture, that\u2019s changed,\u201d Mr. Bragg said. \u201cIn the 20th century, music, for young people, was our only social medium. It was the way we talked to each other, to our parents\u2019 generation, the way we identified ourselves. Music doesn\u2019t have that vanguard role anymore.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDespite disdain for Trump from across the popular music universe (save, perhaps, country), musicians have mostly played minor roles in leading, organizing or even soundtracking the so-called resistance to his administration. Even superstars are unable to capture the attention of the masses, let alone rally them to action, in the same way it might have been possible 10 or 20 years ago. When Eminem, Kendrick Lamar or Beyonc\u00e9, who have far bigger audiences than Superchunk, inject their politics into their music, the best they can usually hope for is to generate social media hashtags or appreciative nods. But Mr. Bragg doesn\u2019t believe it\u2019s mass popularity that necessarily spurs real change.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cLess than 5,000 people bought Woody Guthrie\u2019s \u2018Dust Bowl Ballads.\u2019 It\u2019s how culture picks up on those ideas and runs with them,\u201d he said. \u201cWoody\u2019s guitar didn\u2019t actually kill fascists. It was an idea he painted on his guitar and that idea inspired people. That\u2019s what music does.\u201d\n\nTed Leo, a veteran indie-rocker who was a fierce critic of the Bush administration, and whose 2017 album, \u201cThe Hanged Man,\u201d opens with lines about waking up after Trump\u2019s election, \u201cinto a world of foes,\u201d said that while \u201cit\u2019d be great if something I wrote opened someone\u2019s eyes to something, it\u2019s more for people seeking solace, inspiration or a fiery call to action.\u201d He has no illusions that his music will \u201cland on somebody\u2019s desk who disagrees with me and blow their mind.\u201d In fact, he\u2019s pretty sure most of his fans already share his views. \u201cThe idea of preaching to the choir gets a bad rap,\u201d he said. \u201cOne could just look at it as community-building.\u201d\n\nPolitically charged songwriting isn\u2019t always, or even usually, driven by the aim of affecting politics. Often, it works the same cathartic release valve as writing any other kind of song. \u201cThrough music, you can express your anger without it being a violent act,\u201d said Rick Valentin of the Illinois-based indie-rock band the Poster Children, whose ferocious new single, \u201cGrand Bargain!,\u201d is indicative of the strident, political tone of a full album that will follow in May. \u201cIt\u2019s an aggressive act but it\u2019s not like going onto a street corner, asking people who they voted for, then screaming at them, \u2018Why did you do that?\u2019\u201d\n\nThe musical results of all this catharsis can certainly feel like screaming into a void, but the goal for many of these artists is accomplished by these songs\u2019 mere existence: to keep pessimism, cynicism and nihilism at bay.\n\n\u201cMusic isn\u2019t necessarily going to change what\u2019s happening in the world, but it does make a difference in people\u2019s lives,\u201d Mr. McCaughan said. \u201cIt gives me a sense of purpose and somewhere to put stuff that\u2019s happening in my head.\u201d", "title": "It Took Trump to Make Superchunk Go Political", "authors": ["David Peisner"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt would increase uncertainty,\u201d said Mujtaba Rahman, the London-based managing director for Europe at the risk consultancy Eurasia Group. \u201cThe markets could be spooked.\u201d\n\nThe more likely outcome is a coalition led by a rehabilitated Silvio Berlusconi and his Forza Italia party, following his years of disgrace for tax evasion and reports of sex-filled bacchanals. If Mr. Berlusconi emerges from the wilderness to become an Italian kingmaker, that too could roil Europe, given that he has previously scoffed at European rules limiting deficit spending.\n\nOne might expect Italy to be in a more optimistic mood. The economy is expanding, albeit slowly, following a decade of crisis. Companies are tentatively hiring. A slow-motion banking disaster has largely been contained, as growth has limited bad loans while the most rickety institutions have been bailed out and restructured.\n\nStill, more than 32 percent of Italians under 25 remain unemployed, while the overall jobless rate is 11 percent. Even after three years of modest growth, the Italian economy remains slightly smaller than it was in early 2004, after accounting for rising prices.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe general perception is actually very gloomy,\u201d said Nicola Borri, a finance professor at Luiss, a university in Rome. \u201cThe recession was particularly bad. A lot of people lost their jobs. A lot of people lost their savings.\u201d\n\nYoung Italians see the political class as having failed to refashion an ossified economy in which the elite maintain beach houses, fancy cars and extravagant wardrobes, while everyone else grapples with stagnation. They denounce the still-cozy world of banking in which insiders steer money to politically connected firms while would-be entrepreneurs struggle to secure capital.\n\nThey also resent paying taxes to finance comfortable pensions, certain that such funds will be exhausted when they reach their senior years given Italy\u2019s monumental public debt.", "title": "Italy Is Having an Election. Most Italians Are Too Depressed to Care.", "authors": ["Peter S. Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere is racism in Italy \u2014 against Italians,\u201d Ms. Meloni proclaimed.\n\nThe museum director, Christian Greco, left his office inside the building to confront the chanting protesters.\n\n\u201cThe museum belongs to everybody,\u201d Mr. Greco explained calmly to Ms. Meloni, in an exchange that was captured on video, and then widely circulated on social media and on Italian television stations over the weekend.\n\nMr. Greco made the point that the museum belonged to everyone and had various promotions to lure many types of visitors \u2014 including discounts for couples on Valentine\u2019s Day.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhy don\u2019t you come to protest when students get in free on Thursdays?\u201d he asked jokingly.\n\nBut none of that has stopped the anti-immigrant Brothers of Italy from using the museum\u2019s offer to grab the spotlight.\n\nOn Sunday, the party\u2019s head of communications, Federico Mollicone, said in an interview to the Italian news agency ANSA that the museum\u2019s offer was a \u201csymptom of the illness of the West.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Mollicone added that, once in government, the party would \u201cimplement a spoils system\u201d for all Culture Ministry appointees, based on \u201ctransparency and meritocracy, not ideological membership.\u201d\n\nThe perceived threat to Mr. Greco stirred academic and institutional circles. Italy\u2019s culture minister defended the director in a Tweet, and the country\u2019s top-ranking archaeology and culture experts wrote a statement expressing solidarity with Mr. Greco and his campaign \u2014 the second one aimed at Arabic speakers in 13 months.\n\nSome also pointed out that the museum was in any case run by a foundation, not the state, and that the director\u2019s position was not a government job.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Monday, Mr. Mollicone backpedaled, and denied ever threatening to fire the museum\u2019s director.\n\nBrothers of Italy derives the name from the first line of Italy\u2019s national anthem, and is a direct successor of the country\u2019s long-disbanded Fascist Party, which has continued to inspire political movements in Italy even though it is illegal. Others include the neo-fascist party CasaPound.\n\nKnown for its stances against the euro currency, Brothers of Italy is now the third leg of Mr. Berlusconi\u2019s center-right alliance, alongside with the anti-immigrant League of Matteo Salvini. It was formerly allied with Marine Le Pen, of the far-right National Front in France.\n\nCurrently, polls estimate Brothers of Italy\u2019s support at around 5 percent, more than twice the consensus that they gained in the 2013 elections.\n\nWhile authorities and commentators were engaged in a public soul-searching last week following the xenophobic shooting in central Italy, Ms. Meloni noted that there is a \u201cconnection between uncontrolled immigration and a spike in crimes.\u201d\n\nThe party also recently called for \u201csuspended democracy\u201d in Pontedera, a town in western Tuscany. The authorities there barred the Brothers of Italy from setting a campaign stand after its local chapter refused to sign a form stating that it would respect Italy\u2019s laws against racial hate and apology for fascism.", "title": "Italy\u2019s Far Right Targets a Museum Discount for Arabic Speakers", "authors": ["Gaia Pianigiani"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "He is not only a favorite of Marine Le Pen of France, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and nationalist politicians across Europe. Some fear that Mr. Salvini, while now aligned with former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi in a center-right coalition, could eventually join forces with the populist Five Star Movement, which echoes his strong anti-immigrant and anti-European Union message. Together they would be an anti-establishment nightmare.\n\n\u201cThe project of Salvini is a national project. His political ideas, his notion of protecting the territory, is seen the same in the north and the south,\u201d said Francesco Zicchieri, a leader of We\u2019re With Salvini, a movement that has acted as the southern and central Italian branch of the Northern League.\n\nUntil a few years ago, the Northern League was a separatist party built on antagonism toward Rome (the great thief) and the south (filled with \u201cterroni,\u201d a derogatory term for southerners). The dream was sovereignty for Padania, a mystical northern Italian land imbued with the sanctity of the River Po.\n\nMr. Salvini, 44, took over the party in 2013 from its founder, Umberto Bossi, who had been weakened by a stroke and corruption scandals. Mr. Salvini has since been an indefatigable candidate for prime minister and an omnipresent media figure, while severing the party from its secessionist roots.\n\nHe has used the country\u2019s growing economic discontent, and especially its wariness about immigrants, as a vehicle to reach voters in former enemy territory.\n\nPhoto\n\nEven as Italy\u2019s center-left government \u2014 like other formerly more welcoming European countries \u2014 has cracked down on illegal immigration, Mr. Salvini\u2019s message continues to resonate in a country on the front lines of a great migration that has reshaped European politics.\n\nMore than 600,000 migrants, many from Africa, have landed on Italian shores in the last four years, prompting a backlash that has fueled the the center right.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast summer, a candidate of Mr. Salvini\u2019s party shocked Italy by winning in Cascina, a liberal stronghold in Tuscany once liberated by American soldiers in World War II. In the Roman seaside suburb Ostia, supporters of the post-fascist CasaPound party said they would vote for Mr. Salvini in national elections.\n\n\u201cSalvini is a good man,\u201d said Sonia Valentini, 53. \u201cI like him because he puts Italians first. And I guess he\u2019s a fascist, too. What can you do?\u201d\n\nAnti-immigrant sentiment stoked by Mr. Salvini forced the government to drop a proposed law to grant citizenship to the children of immigrants born and raised in Italy.\n\nIn September, Mr. Salvini \u2014 who has expressed doubt about vaccinations \u2014 blamed the death of a child from malaria on migrants who \u201cbring back to Europe\u201d once-eradicated illnesses.\n\nIn recent weeks, a candidate for the League in the northern region of Lombardy said on the party\u2019s Radio Padania station that Italy must put an end to migrant arrivals because they endangered the \u201cwhite race.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat sentiment is spreading.\n\nAfter the Macerata shooting spree, Mr. Salvini\u2019s political ally, Mr. Berlusconi, promised to send home Italy\u2019s 600,000 undocumented migrants, calling them a \u201csocial bomb ready to explode.\u201d In an Italian television interview he added, \u201cAll these migrants live off trickery and crime.\u201d\n\nMr. Berlusconi was supposed to be the moderating influence on Mr. Salvini.\n\nAt a legal assistance center for migrants in Milan, Pierangelo Lopopolo said the fear-mongering had made the tough lives of the people he volunteered to help even harder.\n\n\u201cSalvini is taking advantage of the discontent in the south and the immigrant is the ideal enemy,\u201d he said. \u201c\u2018Don\u2019t have a job? Immigrants. Pay too much taxes? Services go to immigrants. Crime? Immigrants.\u2019 He repeats it over and over.\u201d\n\nEven some of Mr. Salvini\u2019s old partners in the Northern League think he has gone too far.\n\n\u201cWith Salvini, immigration is all about fear. If you take away immigration what does he talk about? Has he ever offered a solution besides throw them all out?\u201d said Roberto Bernardelli, a gregarious hotel owner and old guard Northern League member in Milan who has recently started a splinter party, The Great North.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Bernardelli, who is currently facing charges of funding the arming of a military tank for separatists, added: \u201cBossi gave us the dream of independence in the north. When Salvini changes the Northern League to a nationalist league, he is destroying the dream.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Salvini, a deeply ambitious politician, has his own dream, and critics say it is primarily for himself, regardless of who gets hurt. He currently has about 12 percent of the vote, but has become a challenger to Mr. Berlusconi as well as a potentially mutinous partner in their leading center-right alliance.\n\nHe has shown a capacity for change before. Mr. Salvini, a critic of the European Union despite being a paid deputy in the European Parliament, used to reserve his hostility for Italy\u2019s southerners. In 2009, at the League\u2019s annual festival in Pontida, he sang, \u201cWhat a stink, even dogs are running away, here come the Neapolitans.\u201d\n\nTraveling to Rome, he once called his train the \u201cNero Express,\u201d in reference to the emperor blamed for burning down the city.\n\nBut this summer he campaigned across Sicily on a slow regional train and spent a recent afternoon headlining a rally in Rome that served to demonstrate his national reach.\n\nSome supporters waved the green leaf on the Padanian flag. Clara Agnoletti showed off a Northern League sign that she had made herself by hand with 4,000 green crystals.\n\nShe was for the national expansion but expressed exasperation that Mr. Salvini had eliminated the word Northern from the party\u2019s name. \u201cI\u2019ll put some paper over the Northern,\u201d she said with a shrug.\n\nBehind her, a group of white nationalists who called themselves \u201cYoung Identitarians,\u201d held a sign against offering citizenship to Italian-born children of immigrants. Southerners from the region of Puglia held up a pro-Salvini banner.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cGetting rid of the north on the sign allowed a lot of us to get closer to the League,\u201d said Silvano Contini, the southern group\u2019s coordinator. \u201cBecause of the immigrants we have come together.\u201d\n\nMr. Salvini, wearing a powder blue sweater in keeping with his paunchy everyman aesthetic, gave his usual remarks against the euro and radical Islam and in defense of pensioners and the unemployed.\n\nBut his biggest applause lines were about immigrants. \u201cI\u2019m sick of seeing the immigrants in the hotels and the Italians who sleep in cars,\u201d Mr. Salvini said to cheers. \u201cThis is the racist country.\u201d", "title": "Italy\u2019s Populists Turn Up the Heat as Anti-Migrant Anger Boils", "authors": ["Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "SANTA MARIA DI CASTELLABATE, Italy \u2014 On a recent afternoon, Alessia D\u2019Alessandro ran into a couple of friends on the boardwalk of the town along the southern Italian coast where she spent her teenage summers swimming in the sea and living with her mother in the local prince\u2019spalace.\n\n\u201cThey were like, \u2018Oh, my god, you came back!\u201d said the 27-year-old, who had left Italy after high school to pursue academic and employment opportunities in her mother\u2019s native Germany. \u201cWhat are you doing here?\u2019\u201d\n\nMany Italians are asking the same thing.\n\nBefore critical elections on March 4, Italy\u2019s leading party, the anti-establishment Five Star Movement, has sought to counter its image as a eurosceptic movement populated with unqualified, web-based activists by recruiting candidates from the country\u2019s professional class. This month, they reimported Ms. D\u2019Alessandro, a self-described \u201cchild of Europe,\u201d from her job at a Berlin think-tank, and prominently rolled her out as a response to patronage politics as usual in the pivotal south.\n\nBut revelations that the party\u2019s leadership inflated Ms. D\u2019Alessandro\u2019s r\u00e9sum\u00e9 \u2014 apparently without her knowledge \u2014 drew criticism that the party was fundamentally dishonest, unprepared to govern and, most damningly, just like other parties.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn recent weeks, the Five Star Movement has experienced growing pains as it has sprouted from a protest movement into Italy\u2019s leading political force. The party has faced evidence of plagiarism in its party platform, Free Masons among its members, accusations of domestic abuse and violence against immigrants by its candidates. A reimbursement scandal has dangerously undercut its purist appeal.", "title": "Italy\u2019s \u2018Five Star\u2019 Grows Up Into a Real Party, Scandals and All", "authors": ["Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 \u201cHope \u2014 the worst epidemic ever to strike men,\u201d is one character\u2019s downbeat assessment near the end of \u201cPoussi\u00e8re\u201d (\u201cDust\u201d), a new play the Swedish playwright Lars Noren has written for the Com\u00e9die-Fran\u00e7aise in Paris. It\u2019s a view of the world that applies to Scandinavian theater in general, and Mr. Noren in particular.\n\nConsidered the most important playwright since August Strindberg in his native Sweden, Mr. Noren, who has written over 80 plays, consistently mines the darker corners of the human psyche, from mental illness to violent crime. With \u201cPoussi\u00e8re,\u201d Mr. Nor\u00e9n, who is now 73, turns his unflinching gaze to old age and its indignities, small and large.\n\nIt is a chilling, diffuse play. Its 11 characters are vacationing in what seems to be a holiday resort in an impoverished country \u2014 in Gilles Taschet\u2019s set design, it is a gray space between gray walls, with debris strewn on the floor. As these retirees, designated by initials only, sit by an imaginary sea, the text juxtaposes their streams of consciousness to create a stuttering chorus: Thoughts spring up then falter, memories ebb and flow.\n\nMr. Noren not only wrote, but also directs, \u201cPoussi\u00e8re\u201d for the Com\u00e9die-Fran\u00e7aise, France\u2019s sole permanent repertory company. With a large back catalog of plays to maintain, stretching back to the days of Moli\u00e8re, its versatile actors seldom get to perform works written for them. \u201cPoussi\u00e8re\u201d is a welcome change of pace, and a tribute to the collective craft and intelligence of the troupe\u2019s older performers, many of whom have shared the stage for decades.", "title": "It\u2019s Cold and Gray in Scandinavian Plays", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Shiffrin is well aware that the Olympics \u2014 not her World Cup achievements \u2014 will be the yardstick against which she will continually be measured, at least by the majority of Americans who tune into ski racing only once every four years. That is fair, she says; she grew up watching the Olympics at home, too.\n\n\u201cAfter many of my victories, I hear people asking me these questions: \u2018What else is there to win?\u2019\u201d Shiffrin said as she sat in the quiet of a Vermont lodge between races late last year. \u201cAnd I want to shout: \u2018What do you mean, what else? There\u2019s so much else!\u2019\n\n\u201cI feel like I\u2019m only a quarter of the way through what I can do. And it\u2019s an Olympic year, too.\u201d\n\nPublic Poise, Inner Doubt\n\nAlthough Shiffrin has emerged more triumphant than ever, she remains very much a work in progress, both on the snow and, perhaps as notably, when she is not on skis.\n\nShe is evolving in myriad ways \u2014 more inquisitive, cognizant of her vulnerabilities and subtly waggish. In public settings, Shiffrin is always poised, gracious, insightful and winsome, which is why she has become one of the most sought-after athletes in the buildup to the Games. But privately, she said that she fights gripping self-doubt and abject fear.\n\n\u201cSometimes I feel surrounded by this dark cloud and it feels like I can\u2019t breathe,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s nervousness and I don\u2019t know what else. Although I am starting to find a way to control it.\u201d\n\nA year ago, she might vomit in pre-race hours. She has since seen a sports psychologist and learned some anxiety-averting techniques.\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t puked this year,\u201d Shiffrin said, laughing, which she does often. \u201cI picture the cloud and push it away. I\u2019m finding ways to believe in myself even when I don\u2019t feel totally confident.\u201d", "title": "It\u2019s Crazy Mikaela Shiffrin Will Aim for 3 Skiing Golds. It\u2019s Crazier She May Get Them.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOn one hand it\u2019s like any other hockey tournament,\u201d Canadian forward Brianne Jenner said, \u201cand on the other, it is our Stanley Cup.\u201d That is, if the Boston Bruins and the Montreal Canadiens played each other in the Stanley Cup finals every year.\n\nTo say the 2014 loss to the Canadians has elicited strong emotions from the American women is putting it mildly.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like having a bad relationship and it going sour. That\u2019s what it is, right?,\u201d said Hilary Knight, a forward for the United States. \u201cIt\u2019s always going to be there. It\u2019s a daily part of your fabric. At the same time, it motivated me tremendously.\u201d\n\nThe United States won the first women\u2019s hockey gold medal in 1998, and Canada has won every one since then. The countries have faced each other in all but one gold medal game \u2014 2006 was the lone exception, when the United States fell to Sweden in the semifinals. They have played each other in all 20 world championship finals. The United States has won the last four.\n\nHere at the Olympics, excluding their group-stage game against each other, the United States and Canada have outscored opponents by 27-2, combined.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cA battle for the ages, as usual,\u201d Jenner said. \u201cIt\u2019s one of the best rivalries in hockey. Not much more you can say.\u201d\n\nThe teams faced each other five times in a fall tournament and a tour to prepare for the Olympics, with Canada winning three. Canada won in group play here, 2-1, though the American women took some solace in outshooting the Canadians, 45-23.\n\nAsked what the United States needed to do to turn the score around in the gold medal game, Kessel stated the obvious. \u201cBury our chances,\u201d she said. \u201cIf we come and play like that again, I feel really good about our chances.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United States team comes into the game trying to take advantage of a new style that emphasizes puck possession and crisscrossing the ice until a seam opens, allowing a player to slice through the defense and attack the goal. They are strong, fast and skilled.\n\n\u201cEveryone\u2019s plans are falling into place,\u201d said Laura Schuler, the Canadian coach, who played against the United States in 1998 for the gold medal. \u201cYou have two great opponents at the end. It\u2019s awesome.\u201d\n\nFor the Americans, it will be awesome only if this game goes the way that 1998 game did.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s always been our dream, to follow up the 1998 Olympic team; they\u2019ve been our leaders and our great role models,\u201d goaltender Maddie Rooney said. \u201cIt would mean everything for us.\u201d", "title": "It\u2019s Groundhog Day for Women\u2019s Hockey: U.S. vs. Canada Again", "authors": ["Karen Crouse", "Matthew Futterman"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "BEIRUT, Lebanon \u2014 Half a dozen newborns, blinking and arching their backs, were carried from a burning hospital hit by airstrikes. A bombed apartment house collapsed, burying families. Medics doused patients with water after a suspected chlorine attack, one of five in Syria since the start of the year.\n\nThat was just a fraction of the violence this week in northern Syria, according to residents and rescue workers, as the Syrian government and its Russian ally stepped up their air war on two of the country\u2019s last major rebel-held areas.\n\n\u201cAll types of weapons have been used on us for seven years, and the whole world is watching,\u201d said Moaz al-Shami, an antigovernment activist in the north Syrian town of Saraqeb, where a medical clinic was hit as its staff was treating people wounded in a market bombing while buying potatoes. \u201cIn Saraqeb, we die twice.\u201d", "title": "It\u2019s Hard to Believe, but Syria\u2019s War Is Getting Even Worse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. Does it take longer to cook food at higher altitudes, and does it cool more quickly there?\n\nA. Some foods take longer to cook by some methods at altitudes higher than 3,000 feet above sea level. But other foods actually take less time, according to the Department of Agriculture.\n\nThe key factor is declining air pressure at higher altitudes. Falling air pressure lowers the boiling point of water by just under 1 degree Fahrenheit for each 500 feet of increased elevation.\n\nThe lower boiling point means water will cook off more quickly, and at a lower temperature. Any food prepared with moist-heat methods, like boiling or simmering, will take longer to become fully cooked.\n\nAnd because these foods generally aren\u2019t as hot as they would be at sea level, they will cool off more quickly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith some other methods, like oven roasting, normal sea-level cooking times still apply, because the heat inside the oven is not affected by the lower air pressure.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSome foods in a microwave oven may cook more quickly at higher altitudes, because the water in the food will boil off faster. This does not hold true for meat, poultry, pasta and rice, however.\n\nCakes, breads and other foods that contain leavening agents rise more quickly at higher altitudes, because gases produced by the agents expand faster than at sea level. The loaves may collapse if the gases dissipate before the proper temperature is reached.", "title": "It\u2019s Harder to Make Meals in the Mountains", "authors": ["C. Claiborne Ray", "Q A"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "In the 1980 disaster spoof \u201cAirplane!,\u201d there\u2019s a great running gag by Lloyd Bridges, who plays a control-tower supervisor. As trouble rears its head, he mutters, \u201cLooks like I picked the wrong week to quit smoking\u201d (and lights up a cigarette). Later, when the situation has grown even more dire (and absurd), he laments, \u201cLooks like I picked the wrong week to quit amphetamines\u201d (and swallows a handful of pills with a glass of milk). Finally, at the climax, he declares, \u201cLooks like I picked the wrong week to quit sniffin\u2019 glue!\u201d and \u2014 well, you get the idea.\n\nI\u2019ve had that sequence in mind the past few days because let\u2019s face it, if you were looking for encouraging news for L.G.B.T.Q. people, it looks like you picked the wrong week. On Feb. 17, for instance, the Kansas Republican Party adopted a resolution that opposes \u2014 and this is the actual language \u2014 \u201call efforts to validate transgender identity.\u201d\n\nMind you, this is not a law about telling men and women where they can go to the bathroom. It\u2019s not an executive action, like the president\u2019s attempt to determine who may and may not serve in the military. It\u2019s not even something as simple (and nefarious) as allowing businesses to selectively refuse service to gay individuals \u201con religious grounds.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s about making the dignity of certain human beings illegal. It means, should this resolution become law, that it will be a crime for the tiny transgender population \u2014 already one of the most maligned and marginalized in the nation \u2014 to exist \u201cwith validity\u201d in the Sunflower State.", "title": "Opinion | It\u2019s Not a Disaster Movie. It\u2019s Reality.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The first pillar of Mr. Trump\u2019s proposal \u2014 regularizing the status of the Dreamers and a million other young people who also could qualify for DACA status with a long and winding road to citizenship \u2014 works to Mexico\u2019s advantage. Somewhere near 1.5 million of these young people are Mexican; that is roughly one-quarter of all undocumented Mexican citizens in the United States. Granting them the equivalent of amnesty, with the beacon of eventual citizenship, satisfies one of Mexico\u2019s most crucial immigration demands.\n\nThe second pillar \u2014 $25 billion for a border wall \u2014 is obviously offensive to Mexico, but the country\u2019s lame-duck president, Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto, has been much more adamant in his opposition to paying for the wall than to its actual construction. Mr. Pe\u00f1a Nieto either doesn\u2019t believe it will ever see the light of day or lacks the backbone to oppose it. But Mr. Trump\u2019s wall is something Mexico can simultaneously reject and live with, particularly if it will take years to build and if it merely complements segments of fences erected by Presidents Bill Clinton, George W. Bush and Obama.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s third pillar is the most insulting for many Americans, since it eliminates the family reunification principle for accepting legal immigrants from abroad. Intended to deter \u201cchain migration,\u201d it would replace the family criterion with a merit-based system. In the future, only spouses and underage offspring (as opposed to parents and siblings today) of American citizens would be allowed permanent residence, and eventually citizenship. The net effect would be to \u201cwhiten\u201d immigration and limit the share of Mexicans.\n\nSince the largest group of foreigners applying for family reunification is by far Mexican (three times as many as Chinese citizens, for example), this would reduce the number of applicants from Mexico who get green cards. Nearly 200,000 Mexicans got green cards in fiscal year 2016; halving that number through a lengthy and tedious procedure that frustrates many Mexicans would not be as bad as shutting down the whole program.\n\nThe last pillar would suppress the lottery system that grants a small number of immigrant visas to applicants from underrepresented nations, mainly African. Again, this would surely \u201cwhiten\u201d immigration and is thus a despicable proposal, but it does not affect Mexico. There is no lottery system for Mexicans.", "title": "Opinion | It\u2019s Time for an Immigration Enchilada", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "One day, we may all owe a debt of gratitude to Dexter the peacock.\n\nAt Newark Airport last weekend, a woman tried to board a United Airlines flight with Dexter. She described him as her emotional-support animal. But given that peacocks are large birds and there is not much evidence of their therapeutic benefits, United said no, Dexter could not board.\n\nA predictable social-media storm ensued, both pro- and anti-peacock. By late last week, United Airlines decided it had enough of making ad hoc decisions about traveling animals and announced a tighter new policy. Dexter, unwittingly, may have struck a blow for sanity.\n\nIf you spend any time on planes, you\u2019ve probably noticed the surge of animals. There have been pigs, monkeys, turkeys, snakes and oh-so-many dogs, often sprawled across crowded cabins. Delta alone flies about 250,000 animals a year \u2014 not even counting those tucked inside carry-on bags or checked in cargo holds \u2014 more than double how many it flew in 2015.\n\nThe number of problems is rising, too. A large part-Labrador mauled a man on a flight to San Diego last summer. A recent Delta news release included some words that don\u2019t normally appear in a corporate news release: \u201curination/defecation\u201d and \u201cbarking, growling, lunging and biting.\u201d According to a labor union for flight attendants, more passengers are suffering allergy attacks, and more are arguing, or worse, over animals.", "title": "Opinion | It\u2019s Time to End the Scam of Flying Pets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nAccording to \u201cWhy People Love to Jump Off Cliffs\u201d (Sunday Review, Feb. 25), \u201cHigh-risk sports are also seen as a reaction against living life mediated through a mobile device rather than having real experiences.\u201d This denigration of online activities could hardly be more in tune with conventional wisdom.\n\nBut cyberspace keeps me in touch with friends who live far away, enables me to make new friends based on mutual interests rather than mere propinquity, and gives me access to thousands of books, articles and works of music. How are such experiences unreal?\n\nFELICIA NIMUE ACKERMAN\n\nPROVIDENCE, R.I.", "title": "Opinion | It\u2019s on the Web, but It\u2019s Still \u2018Real\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cCarmen\u201d has been performed hundreds of times here at the Royal Opera, but your version is different. How?\n\nFirst, you\u2019ve got to understand that there\u2019s no definitive version of \u201cCarmen.\u201d The printed score was done after Bizet\u2019s death, and we know that there\u2019s a handwritten score, which was then changed in rehearsal. Those rehearsals were a catastrophe: The chorus went on strike, the orchestra couldn\u2019t play the music, Bizet had to change the ending. The management kept saying, \u201cYou can\u2019t do this, you can\u2019t do that.\u201d When he died, there was no definitive version.\n\nOne of the differences in our version is that we stick with the idea that the piece was written with spoken dialogue between the musical elements, because it was an \u201cop\u00e9ra comique.\u201d But we don\u2019t do spoken dialogue between the characters; we have a narrator.\n\nYou seem very interested in op\u00e9ra comique and operetta, traditions of music theater that many big opera houses shy away from. How does \u201cCarmen\u201d fit into those?\n\nThe piece is not a Spanish opera. It\u2019s a French opera, from the first note. Actually it\u2019s not even a French opera, it\u2019s an operetta that turns into an opera in the fourth act.\n\nThis is the mistake that people make. They assume that it\u2019s a doom-laden story of a Gypsy with black curly hair and gold earrings, and a story of love and sex and whatever. Well, it turns into that, but for the first two thirds of the evening, it\u2019s sunlight, it\u2019s joy, it\u2019s naughtiness, it\u2019s irony. I keep saying to the cast, \u201cYou\u2019re in an operetta. You are not in \u2018le grand op\u00e9ra.\u2019 \u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut the opera comes to us so steeped in all these Spanish clich\u00e9s.\n\nWe play with the Spanish clich\u00e9s. For example, I said to my designer, \u201cWe are not setting the production in any place. We don\u2019t need to worry about what country are we in; we can do whatever we bloody well like.\u201d And that opens you up to all sorts of things. But I said, \u201cLet\u2019s just put Escamillo in a fabulous toreador\u2019s costume.\u201d When he comes on, everyone\u2019s waiting for that number \u2014 and we turn it into a huge number. I said, \u201cJust make sure the toreador costume looks fabulous, and it solves the problem.\u201d\n\nA lot of the Spanish flavor comes from dance rhythms in the music: The overture opens with a pasodoble, there\u2019s the famous \u201cHabanera,\u201d and so forth. What role does dance play in your \u201cCarmen\u201d?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs you say, it\u2019s in the music. She dances, and we\u2019ve put other dance elements in, in places where there\u2019s not normally dancing.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe uses dance but not in the form of go-go dancing: It\u2019s not pole dancing, and it\u2019s not the local men\u2019s night, with a stripper there. She uses dance in the absolute primal sense of a kind of Dionysian expression of joy and power, which is an entirely different thing.\n\nEarlier this year, in a production of \u201cCarmen\u201d in Florence, there was a lot of controversy when the ending was changed so that she kills Don Jos\u00e9, and not the other way around. What do you think about that?\n\nI\u2019m a little bit cynical because I think it was very connected to the whole #MeToo movement. I mean there have been thousands of productions in the last hundred years where people change the ending. There have been thousands where it says in the libretto that she dies, and a production makes him die. This is nothing new.\n\nIf people think that that\u2019s contributing to a debate about #MeToo, then I roll my eyes in enormous cynicism, because the #MeToo moment is very important: It has to do with what is happening in the offices and streets and corridors of real life. But we are in the fantasy space of theater.\n\nWhen you make decisions about what to do onstage, do you think about the statements these make, politically?\n\nI\u2019ve got to think about it, because I\u2019m a man who lives in the 21st century. We\u2019ve got to be honest here: The history of opera is a history of misogyny. With glaring exceptions \u2014 Monteverdi, Mozart, Janacek \u2014 most of the rest, particularly the 19th century, is deeply problematic.\n\nYou have a duty as a director, male or female, to investigate that and try and twist it or try and play with it or try and subvert it. That\u2019s what makes opera so fantastic. You operate in opera on many different levels. You are having a conversation with the past, on a stage, to a contemporary audience. This is what makes it exciting.", "title": "It\u2019s \u2018Carmen.\u2019 But Not Like You\u2019ve Ever Seen It.", "authors": ["Matthew Anderson"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nShould the women who have accused the president of sexual misconduct be believed? That\u2019s a question that his elder daughter and White House senior adviser, Ivanka Trump, believes she should not be asked.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s a pretty inappropriate question to ask a daughter if she believes the accusers of her father when he\u2019s affirmatively stated that there\u2019s no truth to it,\u201d Ms. Trump told the NBC News correspondent Peter Alexander in an interview that aired on NBC\u2019s \u201cToday\u201d on Monday.\n\nMs. Trump had been in South Korea since Friday, leading the United States delegation at the Winter Olympics. In a wide-ranging interview there on Sunday, Mr. Alexander asked her, \u201cDo you believe your father\u2019s accusers?\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think that\u2019s a question you would ask many other daughters,\u201d she said. \u201cI believe my father. I know my father. So, I think I have that right as a daughter to believe my father.\u201d\n\nMs. Trump\u2019s suggestion that she be spared the question faced pushback online from journalists and others, who noted that she not only led the American delegation for the closing ceremony of the Olympics, but has also positioned herself as a voice for women\u2019s issues inside the White House.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome conservatives, in the meantime, suggested that her dismissal of the question was akin to one offered by Chelsea Clinton during the 2016 presidential campaign, when asked whether her father\u2019s sex scandal had affected her mother\u2019s credibility.", "title": "Ivanka Trump Calls Question About Father\u2019s Sexual Misconduct \u2018Inappropriate\u2019", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "At the opening ceremony of the Games, the surprise visit by Kim Yo-jong, sister of the North Korean leader created something of a sensation in the South, overshadowing Vice President Mike Pence\u2019s trip at the same time. Ms. Kim met with Mr. Moon and delivered a surprise offer: her brother\u2019s invitation to visit the North for a summit meeting.\n\nDespite South Korean hopes that Ms. Kim and Mr. Pence would use the Games as an opportunity for their own diplomacy, the two ignored each other in Mr. Moon\u2019s V.I.P. box at the ceremony, where they sat just feet apart. South Korean officials arranged a later meeting between the two, American officials said, but the North Koreans pulled out at the last minute.\n\nPhoto\n\nWith Ms. Kim having seized the media spotlight as the first immediate member of the North\u2019s ruling family to set foot in South Korea, Ms. Trump\u2019s visit is expected to restore some luster to the American side of the unspoken propaganda contest.\n\nMr. Moon drew laughter at the dinner by saying that whenever he was on the phone with Mr. Trump, the president always asked whether ticket sales for the Olympics were high. Mr. Moon then stressed the importance of easing tensions on the peninsula, thanking \u201cPresident Trump\u2019s strong support for inter-Korean dialogue.\u201d\n\n\u201cNorth Korea\u2019s participation in the Winter Olympic Games has served as an opportunity for us to engage in active discussions between the two Koreas, and this has led to lowering of tensions on the peninsula,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
