Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Trump said she was in South Korea to \u201creaffirm our bonds of friendship and partnership\u201d but also \u201cto reaffirm our commitment to our maximum-pressure campaign to ensure that the Korean Peninsula is denuclearized,\u201d according to a media pool report.\n\nThe local news media has already been touting similarities between the women, calling Ms. Kim \u201cNorth Korea\u2019s Ivanka\u201d because of the influence the two are purported to have over the heads of state in their respective families.\n\nSouth Korean officials are intent on not seeing a repeat of the tense standoff between Ms. Kim and Mr. Pence at the opening ceremony, and have said they do not intend to arrange a meeting between Ms. Trump and the North Korean delegation.\n\nOne obstacle is that the North\u2019s delegation is headed by Kim Yong-chol, a former spy chief who is widely blamed in the South for the 2010 sinking of a South Korean warship and some of the North\u2019s alleged hacking attacks in recent years. Mr. Kim has been on a United States sanctions list since 2010.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnited States officials said that Ms. Trump would not meet with any North Korean defectors during her visit, as Mr. Pence did in an attempt to draw attention to the North Korean government\u2019s many human rights abuses.", "title": "Ivanka Trump, in South Korea, Calls for Pressure on the North", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "My panel was about the #MeToo movement, which was a natural for me since my new book coming out in June, \u201cSex Matters,\u201d grapples with the movement and other aspects of our fraught sexual ecosystem.\n\nAfter every woman on the panel had a chance to speak and with 10 minutes remaining on the clock, the moderator threw a slow pitch right over the plate. She asked us about feminist hypocrisy. Ask me that at a cocktail party and I will talk your ear off about how the very people who had lectured us about the utter venality of workplace sexual harassment throughout the 1980s became suddenly quiescent when the malefactor was Bill Clinton.\n\nBut this time, and particularly in front of this crowd, it felt far more urgent to point out the hypocrisy of our side. How can conservative women hope to have any credibility on the subject of sexual harassment or relations between the sexes when they excuse the behavior of President Trump? And how can we participate in any conversation about sexual ethics when the Republican president and the Republican Party backed a man credibly accused of child molestation for the United States Senate?\n\nI watched my fellow panelists\u2019 eyes widen. And then the booing began.\n\nI\u2019d been dreading it for days, but when it came, I almost welcomed it. There is nothing more freeing than telling the truth. And it must be done, again and again, by those of us who refuse to be absorbed into this brainless, sinister, clownish thing called Trumpism, by those of us who refuse to overlook the fools, frauds and fascists attempting to glide along in his slipstream into respectability.\n\nI spoke to a hostile audience for the sake of every person who has watched this spectacle of mendacity in disbelief and misery for the past two years. Just hearing the words you know are true can serve as ballast, steadying your mind when so much seems unreal.\n\nFor traditional conservatives, the past two years have felt like a Twilight Zone episode. Politicians, activists and intellectuals have succumbed with numbing regularity, betraying every principle they once claimed to uphold. But there remains a vigorous remnant of dissenters. I hear from them. There were even some at CPAC.\n\nA substantial number of people applauded. And as I was hustled out of the building by security, various supporters gave me the thumbs up sign.", "title": "Opinion | I\u2019m Glad I Got Booed at CPAC", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "I also know that I am made less safe by the threat of tactical rifles. I am confident I can eliminate an active shooter who is attacking with a pistol because the attacker would have to be close to me. But the defense my concealed 9-millimeter affords me is largely gone if the attacker is firing from beyond 40 yards, as he could easily do with the AR-15.\n\nNo firearm is evil. Guns are tools that fulfill the intent of their users, good or bad. But we\u2019ve seen that the rifle of choice for many mass shooters is the AR-15.\n\nThe Second Amendment is unimpeachable. It guarantees the right of citizens to defend themselves. I accept, however, that it does not guarantee that every civilian can bear any and all arms.\n\nFor example, the purchase of fully automatic firearms is largely banned already, and I cannot purchase an AT-4 rocket, grenades, a Bradley fighting vehicle or an Abrams tank. I know that no single action can prevent a truly determined person from committing mass murder, and I am aware of other ways to commit mass murder, such as bombings and mass vehicular slaughter. Not being able to control everything, however, should not prevent us from doing something.\n\nTherefore, I support the following:\n\nDefining what constitutes an assault or tactical firearm and not allowing them for future purchase \u2014 just as we already prohibit the purchase of fully automatic firearms. The exact definition of assault weapon will need to be determined. But we should all be able to agree that the civilian version of the very deadly weapon that the Army issued to me should certainly qualify. I would not support any version of a ban that results in confiscating existing legally owned firearms.\n\nEnsuring that every firearm purchaser has a background check. We also need to improve the background check system.\n\nBanning the sale of accessories and add-ons that circumvent the ban on automatic firearms, and increasing the ages at which individuals can purchase various categories of firearms.", "title": "Opinion | I\u2019m Republican. I Appreciate Assault Weapons. And I Support a Ban.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "When I was assaulted at 18, I knew clearly what I wanted: I wanted him to never violate anyone else again, ever. Four of us whom he\u2019d assaulted told the university, through proper channels; he was eventually found responsible, but the punishment was negligible. Nor did it achieve my goal: He assaulted another person the weekend of his graduation. The whole process made me feel betrayed, angry and unvalued. It was worse than the assault itself.\n\nLater, when I got involved in campus sexual assault activism and did Q. and A. sessions around the country, people often asked me why I hadn\u2019t then gone further, seeking to have him expelled or reporting him to the police. I always felt uncomfortable when asked these questions \u2014 it was as though I had to prove that my story was really \u201cthat bad,\u201d as if I admitted I didn\u2019t want him to go to jail, it would minimize his wrongdoing. The reason I gave for not reporting him to the police was that I didn\u2019t want to go through a lengthy court process. While this was true, it was more than that: First, I wanted to get on with my life. But second, putting him in prison seemed almost laughably ill suited to what I needed. What I wanted was for him to change his behavior. He needed an intervention, not prison. He got neither.\n\nI had to fit my priorities into a box that was never designed to hold them, as do so many other survivors. Sexual injustices exist in many forms, from casual sexism and harassment to sexual assault and rape. But people harmed by them have, by and large, only two options: They can try to have the perpetrator formally punished, or they can do nothing. The process of reporting formally is important to many survivors and must be protected; we know, however, that a vast majority of people will not choose this path. And all survivors \u2014 regardless of whether a report is filed or a harm-doer is exposed \u2014 deserve justice, healing and trust.\n\nRecognition of the scale of sexual assault and harassment in the United States has, understandably, inspired a wave of outrage. Women who have watched known predators act without consequences for years are angry, as they should be.\n\nBut it is this same factor \u2014 the scale of the problem \u2014 that ensures that cries for retribution on a mass scale are untenable. We\u2019re simultaneously dehumanizing the people who committed sexual assault for years by calling them monsters and learning that the people who commit these crimes are our friends, co-workers, family members and partners. Such dynamics become too much to grapple with; as a result, the conversation devolves into an argument about whether #MeToo has gone \u201ctoo far\u201d versus \u201cnot far enough\u201d; my fear is that this is where it will stall until we lose patience and move on, when what we really need is a new approach.", "title": "Opinion | I\u2019m a Campus Sexual Assault Activist. It\u2019s Time to Reimagine How We Punish Sex Crimes.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Jack Hamilton pitched for all or part of eight seasons in the major leagues, but he was remembered mostly for a single moment. He threw the fastball that struck the head of the slugging Boston Red Sox outfielder Tony Conigliaro in August 1967, a gruesome episode that shortened the career of a potential Hall of Famer.\n\nIn the decades that followed, Hamilton was sought out from time to time for interviews about that night in Boston, in a season when the long-shot Red Sox went on to their Impossible Dream pennant victory.\n\nHe died on Thursday in Branson, Mo., at 79. His wife, Janyce, said he had had heart problems and other ailments.\n\nA journeyman pitcher, Hamilton had been traded from the Mets to the California Angels in June 1967 and had a record of 8-2 when he started against the Red Sox at Fenway Park on the night of Aug. 18.", "title": "Jack Hamilton, Who Hurled a Fateful Pitch, Dies at 79", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Patrick Chappatte is an editorial cartoonist for The New York Times. View more of his work, visit his website or follow him on Twitter.\n\nFollow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter, and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.", "title": "Opinion | Jacob Zuma Resigns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "JOHANNESBURG \u2014 President Jacob Zuma of South Africa, a master tactician who survived a string of corruption scandals and harsh court judgments during his nearly nine-year presidency, agreed on Wednesday night to step down, repudiated by the governing African National Congress Party, threatened by a no-confidence vote in Parliament, cornered by opposition parties and abandoned by millions of voters.\n\nIn an address to the nation Wednesday night, Mr. Zuma said he was resigning even though he disagreed with the party\u2019s decision ordering him to do so.\n\n\u201cI have therefore come to the decision to resign as president of the Republic with immediate effect, even though I disagree with the decision of the leadership of my organization,\u201d he said at the end of a lengthy address on television. \u201cI have always been a disciplined member of the A.N.C.\u201d\n\nIt was a humiliating end for Mr. Zuma, a charismatic anti-apartheid hero who was imprisoned on Robben Island with Nelson Mandela and was once the A.N.C.\u2019s intelligence chief. Cyril Ramaphosa, the deputy president whose election as A.N.C. leader in December set off a power struggle with Mr. Zuma, immediately became acting president.", "title": "Jacob Zuma Resigns as South Africa\u2019s President", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Other riveting stories: A gay athlete spoke publicly about what has been an open secret among male skaters: crippling body image issues. (Shares in Lotte\u2019s retail division fell 4 percent.)\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 You know what day it is.\n\nTo mark Valentine\u2019s Day, our reporter mined a collection of about 12,000 paper valentines that span three centuries. He was inspired by the Mosuo, a small matriarchal tribe in far-western China. \u201cWhat I really loved was the absolute celebration of the femininity and empowerment,\u201d he said.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nValentine\u2019s Day is widely thought to mark a wine-fueled festival for courting couples in ancient Rome.\n\nBut in North Korea, it marks a different kind of affection. On this day in 2012, Kim Jong-il, who ruled the country from 1994 until his death in 2011, was posthumously named a \u201cgeneralissimo.\u201d\n\nThe announcement came two days before what would have been Mr. Kim\u2019s 70th birthday, which is still celebrated in the country as \u201cThe Day of the Shining Star.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe only other North Korean \u201cgeneralissimo\u201d is Mr. Kim\u2019s father, Kim Il-sung, who began ruling in 1945 and received the title in 1992, two years before his death. The term is a clear cut above the \u201cmarshal\u201d title held by North Korea\u2019s third and current leader, Kim Jong-un.\n\nThe younger Mr. Kim may stay in power for decades, though, and he already has several titles: \u201cDear respected comrade,\u201d for one, as well as \u201csupreme commander\u201d of the Korean People\u2019s Army.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Sign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning, or to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights.\n\nAnd our Australia bureau chief offers a weekly letter adding analysis and conversations with readers.\n\nBrowse our full range of Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Jacob Zuma, North Korea, Julian Assange: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": ["Mike Ives", "Charles Mcdermid"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "But despite his role in the struggle against apartheid, Mr. Zuma did not surprise those who predicted from the start that his presidency would be troubled. Even before he became the nation\u2019s leader, he had been dogged by scandal and corruption charges. He spent much of his presidency fighting similar battles in the courts, Parliament and the public.\n\nMost South Africans will remember Mr. Zuma for his personal ethical problems, especially those related to his homestead, Nkandla. His stubborn reluctance to pay what amounted to a relatively modest sum of about $650,000 for personal upgrades to his home led to outsize consequences: court judgments, invigorated opposition parties and the erosion of public trust.\n\nPhoto\n\nAmong voters, Mr. Zuma helped precipitate the decline of the A.N.C., a party that, thanks to its heroic liberation past, had seemed invincible at the polls just a few years earlier.\n\nAs he steps down, Mr. Zuma may be regarded as the weakest leader in South Africa\u2019s post-apartheid history. His tenure lacked lasting policy successes. His words, actions and appointments repelled investors and often sent the local currency, the rand, spiraling lower.\n\nAt the same time, he reflected the problems of a party that has struggled to transform itself from a liberation movement to a modern political party, and that has led, mostly unchallenged, for a quarter of a century.\n\nThe A.N.C. unfailingly stood behind Mr. Zuma until the end of his second term as party leader in December and the election as party leader of Mr. Ramaphosa, an anti-apartheid leader who went on to become one of the nation\u2019s most successful businessmen.\n\nDo You Live in South Africa? We Want to Hear From You Are you South African? Please share your story. Your response may be used in a future article. As Cyril Ramaphosa takes office, what are your hopes or expectations? * You have 250 words left. What are the most pressing issues in your community? Share your personal experience. * You have 250 words left. Continue What is your full name? (If we publish your response, your name will be included.) * What is your age? * What is your profession? * Where in South Africa do you live? * What is your email address? (This is not for publication.) * Please share a recent image of yourself. The media you share may be used in a New York Times feature. By submitting to us, you are promising that the content is original, does not plagiarize from anyone or infringe a copyright or trademark, does not violate anyone\u2019s rights and is not libelous or otherwise unlawful or misleading. You are agreeing that we can use your submission in all manner and media of The New York Times and that we shall have the right to authorize third parties to do so. And you agree to our Terms of Service. Thank you for your submission.\n\nEven after that, a sizable faction fought fiercely for Mr. Zuma to complete his full term.\n\n\u201cSouth Africa\u2019s downward trajectory cannot be blamed on Zuma alone,\u201d Ralph Mathekga, the author of \u201cWhen Zuma Goes,\u201d wrote. \u201cHe is, after all, just one man and part of a much bigger system.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn economic populist, Mr. Zuma spoke often of a \u201cradical economic transformation\u201d to make South Africa work better for the vast impoverished black underclass that had been left behind during the rapid years of growth under his archrival, Mr. Mbeki. But under Mr. Zuma, the country\u2019s economy stagnated.\n\nGovernment debt was downgraded to junk status because of poor governing. Unemployment topped 25 percent, and the nation remained one of the world\u2019s most unequal societies.\n\nSome successes, like a push into renewable energy, were eventually undermined by Mr. Zuma\u2019s administration; the effects of others, like the passing of a minimum wage, are still unclear.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe police massacre of 34 miners involved in a wildcat strike in Marikana in 2012, the worst act of official violence since the end of apartheid, intensified the widespread belief that the A.N.C. had betrayed the people it claimed to be representing.\n\nWhile Mr. Zuma remained popular in many areas that were economically dependent on the party and public works, he was deeply unpopular in Gauteng, the province that includes Johannesburg and Pretoria, where the black middle class is concentrated.\n\nStill, though mocked by the country\u2019s black elite, Mr. Zuma was the most gifted politician in townships and rural areas, where he tapped into the resentment of those left behind. He excited crowds by dancing, delivering speeches in English and Zulu, and often performing a song by the A.N.C.\u2019s former military wing, \u201cBring Me My Machine Gun.\u201d\n\nProblems in his private life spilled out often into public view. In 2006, Mr. Zuma was found not guilty of raping a 31-year-old family friend. He testified in court that she had seduced him by wearing a short skirt. He also said he had taken a shower afterward to minimize the risk of contracting H.I.V.\n\nPhoto\n\nA polygamist under Zulu tradition, Mr. Zuma has more than 20 children, some of whom have been involved in questionable business deals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThroughout his time in office, corruption flourished, especially at the state enterprises where access was given to family, friends and business associates, including the Guptas, a wealthy family with widespread business interests.\n\nHe appointed loyalists \u2014 sometimes with little experience \u2014 to his cabinet and to top positions at state companies like Eskom, the power utility, and South African Airways, the national carrier.\n\nIn a 2016 report on corruption, Thulisile Madonsela, the former public protector, described widespread influence-peddling in the Zuma administration and called for a public inquiry. After failing to quash the investigation in the courts, Mr. Zuma recently announced the appointment of a commission of inquiry.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Zuma spent his adult life in Africa\u2019s oldest and most famous liberation party, serving as the party\u2019s intelligence chief during the anti-apartheid struggle. He succeeded in becoming president despite a string of problems that would have ended the careers of less skilled politicians.\n\nHe faced charges of corruption in an arms deal in the 1990s when he was a senior party leader. He has avoided prosecution in the case, but state prosecutors are expected to decide this month whether to indict him on corruption charges.\n\nMr. Zuma often said critics exaggerated the level of graft in his administration. In his last speech as party leader in December, he said the party needed to be protected from \u201ccorporate greed\u201d and attacked the country\u2019s white-dominated business community.\n\n\u201cTheft and corruption in the private sector is as bad as that in government,\u201d he said.\n\nBut the case that perhaps angered most South Africans was related to the improvements to Mr. Zuma\u2019s homestead in Nkandla, in KwaZulu Natal Province.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Zuma said that the upgrades, including a swimming pool and chicken coop, were necessary to ensure his safety and that the costs should therefore be borne by taxpayers. In Parliament, he mocked opposition lawmakers\u2019 pronunciation of Nkandla and cackled openly, secure in his party\u2019s overwhelming majority.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Public Protector\u2019s office rejected the president\u2019s claims and ordered him to reimburse the state. Mr. Zuma refused, leading the nation\u2019s highest court to rule that he had acted unconstitutionally by disregarding the Public Protector.\n\nMr. Zuma eventually paid the government the $650,000 \u2014 about 7.8 million rand \u2014 but his intransigence led to further legal problems.\n\nThe nation\u2019s highest court ruled in December that the A.N.C.-dominated Parliament had not properly investigated Mr. Zuma\u2019s conduct in the Nkandla case when it defeated an opposition-led effort to impeach him in 2016.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe court ordered lawmakers to create rules to regulate a president\u2019s impeachment, raising the possibility that a sitting Mr. Zuma would have faced proceedings this year.\n\nThe Nkandla affair turned many loyal voters against the A.N.C. in local elections in 2016. For the first time, many urban middle-class black voters stayed home or jumped to the opposition at the ballot box, as the party lost control over the nation\u2019s biggest cities.\n\nEven with their rural strongholds, A.N.C. leaders worried that the party might garner less than half the vote in national elections in 2019, forcing it to take on a coalition partner to govern, or lose power outright.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t want to be relegated to a rural party,\u201d Gwede Mantashe, the A.N.C.\u2019s national chairman, said during the election for party leader in December. \u201cWe want to regain the metros and be a strong A.N.C.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Mantashe is an ally of Mr. Ramaphosa, who is backed by business and whose core supporters include educated, middle-class black South Africans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Zuma probably realized the end was near when Mr. Ramaphosa defeated Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma, Mr. Zuma\u2019s preferred candidate and his former wife, in the election in December. As the results were announced in a large convention hall in Johannesburg, Mr. Zuma, famous for his joviality and charisma before crowds, sat stone-faced and bit his lips.\n\nIt took less than two months for Mr. Ramaphosa and his allies to win over fence-sitters and recalcitrant members of the Zuma camp. For all of Mr. Zuma\u2019s skills as a strategist, he was a lame-duck leader battling the future as embodied in Mr. Ramaphosa and the new leader\u2019s power over appointments and patronage.\n\nMr. Zuma was well acquainted with the dangers of what South Africans call the two centers of power: the year and a half during which the nation and the all-powerful A.N.C. are headed by different people. After being elected A.N.C. leader in 2007, Mr. Zuma himself orchestrated the early exit of his rival Mr. Mbeki as South Africa\u2019s president.\n\nIn pressing Mr. Zuma to step down, Mr. Ramaphosa\u2019s allies argued that the new leader should take over the government as soon as possible to rebuild the A.N.C.\u2019s reputation and brand before the 2019 elections. The longer Mr. Zuma remained in power, they said, the greater the risk of performing poorly next year.\n\nThe party that had always shielded Mr. Zuma agreed.", "title": "Jacob Zuma\u2019s Legacy Is a Weakened South Africa", "authors": ["Norimitsu Onishi"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "But what about the men? While female dancers are usually front and center in Balanchine works \u2014 the men, as partners, are responsible for making them shine \u2014 the men don\u2019t always take second place. The repertory has plenty of shining opportunities for them too, like the title roles of \u201cProdigal Son\u201d and \u201cApollo\u201d and parts like the Phlegmatic variation in \u201cThe Four Temperaments.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Danchig-Waring said that as a male principal at City Ballet \u201cthere\u2019s so much space for self-expression.\u201d And that he sees, in part, as a testament to Mr. d\u2019Amboise.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s interesting because he\u2019s like this \u2018bro,\u2019 Mr. Danchig-Waring said with an affectionate laugh. For the Balanchine men, he continued: \u201cThere\u2019s this machismo that is sometimes required onstage \u2014 that bravura, that swagger, that confidence, and we all have to learn to cultivate that and yet it\u2019s such a huge canon of work. Within that, there are poets and dreamers and animals. Jacques is a reminder that all of that can be contained in one body.\u201d\n\nThis isn\u2019t the first time Mr. Danchig-Waring has participated in the Art Nest series, an intimate performance showcase that Mr. d\u2019Amboise started in 2011. For this one, he\u2019ll perform a section of \u201cApollo,\u201d which Mr. d\u2019Amboise \u2014 a revered interpreter of the role \u2014 has coached him on.\n\n\u201cHe just brings the dances to life,\u201d Mr. Danchig-Waring said. \u201cThey go from being steps that you\u2019ve learned to authentic expressions of your personhood.\u201d\n\nAnd while spending time with someone with such direct lineage to Balanchine is a gift, it\u2019s also just fun, Mr. Danchig-Waring said, to have an 83-year-old friend who is \u201ctirelessly enthusiastic.\u201d\n\nCertainly, that part is true. As he talked about the coming program, Mr. d\u2019Amboise narrated bits of his career, which has included decades at City Ballet, where Balanchine created dozens of works for him. Hollywood beckoned \u2014 he appeared in films like \u201cCarousel\u201d and \u201cSeven Brides for Seven Brothers\u201d \u2014 but he always remained loyal to City Ballet and to Balanchine. While still a principal, in 1976, he created the National Dance Institute to engage children with dance, no matter their background or ability.\n\nPhoto\n\nEven when he was a student himself, Mr. d\u2019Amboise was quick to recognize talent. He recalled when he first met Mr. Villella at the School of American Ballet in the 1940s. \u201cThere were only two or three boys at S.A.B. \u2014 Eddie and me and another boy,\u201d he said. \u201cEddie was terrific. He went over the stage like a dynamo. The closest to Eddie was Baryshnikov. And, today, Daniel Ulbricht. They\u2019re like crossbows \u2014 bang! Wonderful.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShorthand help: Baryshnikov as in Mikhail, the transcendent Russian dancer. And Mr. Ulbricht is a City Ballet dancer who has inherited some of Mr. Villella\u2019s roles.\n\nMr. d\u2019Amboise\u2019s memories of Mr. Mitchell, City Ballet\u2019s first African-American principal, are just as exuberant. \u201cArthur was, first of all, gorgeous. And inspiring.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn 1957, Balanchine choreographed \u201cAgon,\u201d set to Stravinsky and featuring a central pas de deux for Mr. Mitchell and a white ballerina, Diana Adams. Mr. d\u2019Amboise recalled that during a tour to the South \u201ca stagehand wouldn\u2019t open the curtain because there was a black guy onstage.\u201d Instead, the lighting designer stepped in and did it.\n\nBut when another stagehand refused to aim the spotlight on Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Balanchine had a simple solution: \u201cHe said, \u2018You know, just make light brighter and don\u2019t worry.\u2019 \u201d\n\nIf he had to describe Balanchine in just a few words, Mr. d\u2019Amboise said, he would single out \u201cexquisite manners\u201d: \u201cBalanchine got what he wanted by good manners and diplomacy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn recent weeks, City Ballet has been dogged by more drama than good manners: Peter Martins, its longtime ballet master in chief, resigned on Jan. 1 after allegations of harassment and abuse. \u201cIt\u2019s a scandal,\u201d Mr. d\u2019Amboise said, \u201cbut you know there\u2019s a repertoire of Balanchine and Robbins that\u2019s the best in the world.\u201d\n\nAs for who should take over? \u201cI don\u2019t care,\u201d he said with a shrug.\n\nDespite his program\u2019s theme of \u201cBalanchine\u2019s Guys,\u201d Mr. d\u2019Amboise was more eager to talk about the ballerinas he partnered at City Ballet, including Allegra Kent, Suzanne Farrell and, his favorite, the firecracker virtuoso Melissa Hayden.\n\nShe once told him, Mr. d\u2019Amboise recalled: \u201cHoney, we\u2019re going to go dance now: This is our first performance and, buster, it\u2019s our last too.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou never know, in other words, if you\u2019re going to dance tomorrow. When he heard she was gravely ill with pancreatic cancer in 2006, he flew to North Carolina to say goodbye. \u201cShe said, \u2018So you came for my last dance?\u2019\u201d He laughed. \u201cIsn\u2019t that great?\u201d\n\nWhen you live to be too old, Mr. d\u2019Amboise said, \u201cyou lose a lot of friends.\u201d\n\nBut he\u2019s still as indefatigable as Mary Poppins and he could probably cheer up any task, like the one he related about fulfilling his wife\u2019s wishes to have her ashes spread at the subway station at 72nd Street and Broadway. He did it on a Sunday morning.\n\n\u201cI asked some kids to come in and dance and make a lot of noise,\u201d he said conspiratorially. \u201cThen I thought, does she want uptown or downtown? So we went down and I said, \u2018Go make a lot of noise on the downtown station.\u2019\u201d He sprinkled some of the ashes on the uptown tracks and then repeated the procedure on the opposite side.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s illegal,\u201d he said. \u201cI think lots of people try to do it.\u201d As for Mr. d\u2019Amboise? \u201cSpread me in Times Square or the Belasco Theater.\u201d", "title": "Jacques d\u2019Amboise: Apollo at 83", "authors": ["Gia Kourlas"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Moukarbel\u2019s work was pulling him westward (he directed documentaries about Banksy and Lady Gaga), so they gave up their New York life and bought a Streamline Moderne-style house in Los Feliz for $1.92 million. \u201cI had nothing going on. Just partying a lot,\u201d Mr. Shears said. (He celebrated his 35th birthday with a disco foam party in the backyard.) \u201cThat first year in L.A., I was just lost. Wanting to work, because I\u2019m happiest when I\u2019m working, but without the band I didn\u2019t know what to do.\u201d\n\nThe end of his 11-year relationship with Mr. Moukarbel was \u201cbrutal.\u201d Even now, he said, \u201cI think I\u2019m over stuff, and I\u2019ll wake up from nightmares.\u201d (Mr. Moukarbel, for his part, said, \u201cJason and I basically grew into adulthood together and I still think of him as family. He\u2019s always inspired me and I\u2019m incredibly proud of his recent work.\u201d)\n\nAs Mr. Shears\u2019s personal life was falling apart, the director Mois\u00e9s Kaufman cast him in the play \u201cBent\u201d at the Mark Taper Forum. \u201cThat was a real catalyst for me and made me examine my life and really ask myself how I was going to make myself happy again,\u201d Mr. Shears said. \u201cI learned that it\u2019s really important to be creative for the right reasons. And if you\u2019re not, it\u2019ll come back and bite you.\u201d\n\nStill, it wasn\u2019t until he got back to writing music, and writing his life story, that Mr. Shears returned to his swinging self. In addition to the new album, he is working on a musical with Elton John, following up his 2011 stage adaptation of \u201cTales of the City.\u201d In June, he ended his solo tour with a concert in New Orleans, the same weekend he was celebrity grand marshal of the city\u2019s gay pride parade.\n\n\u201cAll my friends were down, my mom, everybody,\u201d he said. \u201cEveryone got to be in the parade. It was one of the best times I\u2019ve had in my whole life. This sounds so stupid, but it felt like a wedding, even though I wasn\u2019t marrying anybody. It was just this amazing celebration I got to have with everyone. It felt like I had found myself again.\u201d", "title": "Jake Shears, of Scissor Sisters, Stages His Own Comeback", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Some restaurants that topped critics\u2019 lists in 2017 are noticeably absent, omitted by the foundation for either proven or perceived violations of the new code.\n\n\u201cWhen creating the semifinalist list, the committee certainly took to heart this moment of reckoning in the restaurant industry,\u201d said Bill Addison, the chairman of the restaurant committee and the national food critic for the website Eater.\n\nAqui, in Houston, was not put on the best new restaurant list because the chef, Paul Qui, is awaiting trial after a fight that left his girlfriend bloody. But Jillian Bartolome, the restaurant\u2019s pastry chef, won a nomination.\n\nThe Hearth & Hound, the much-anticipated Los Angeles restaurant from the chef April Bloomfield and her partner Ken Friedman, didn\u2019t make the cut for best new restaurant, either. Several staff members told The New York Times last year that they were sexually harassed and groped by Mr. Friedman and high-profile guests at some of their other restaurants, and that Ms. Bloomfield didn\u2019t do enough to stop those abuses.\n\nA committee of 18 food writers, editors and producers is charged with sifting through 23,000 nominations \u2014 from regional judges, restaurants and the public \u2014 to create the semifinal list. In a sometimes contentious meeting in Honolulu last month, they grappled with how best to apply the foundation\u2019s new standards for personal and corporate behavior. Because members signed nondisclosure agreements, they would not publicly discuss why certain restaurants did or did not make the list.\n\n\u201cObviously, the names in these categories are presented without context, but we hope that they reflect the foundation\u2019s desire to present awards that will more accurately represent the nation\u2019s true wealth of culinary talent,\u201d Mr. Addison said.\n\nIt has been a challenging year for the Beard Foundation, which welcomes Clare Reichenbach, its first new chief executive in 11 years, on Tuesday. Some of its marquee award winners, like the chefs Mario Batali, John Besh and Mr. Friedman, have been accused of sexual harassment or worse, and the organization has been criticized for not taking enough action against race and gender imbalances in the restaurant industry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere have been calls to strip medals from previous winners, which the foundation has declined to do. Instead, past winners who have faced public charges of sexual harassment or abuse have been barred from voting from now on. (Previous winners make up the bulk of the 600 or so voters who will use the semifinalist list as a ballot to pick the finalists in each category. The same voters then choose the winners.)\n\nClark Wolf, a food business consultant who has been honored by the foundation and who was a friend of James Beard\u2019s, said the group needed to be more forceful. \u201cThe fact that they didn\u2019t make a clear and definitive statement and didn\u2019t take away those medals is a problem,\u201d he said. \u201cWe want to know where every leaf and bone comes from, but we don\u2019t care that chef is a douche?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOthers said the guidelines for both the larger group that nominates contenders and the committee that selects the semifinalists were too open to interpretation.\n\nDuring a radio talk show on WGBH in Boston last week, the food journalist Corby Kummer, a former longtime member of the restaurant committee, said instructions to bar people if there are doubts about behavior or the culture of a restaurant are \u201creally shaded and difficult.\u201d\n\nThe policy, he said in a follow-up phone interview, could be used in an unfairly draconian way. \u201cIt\u2019s a time of adjustment, and people are understandably cautious,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cIn another year and another awards cycle, after this initial period of pulling back, there is going to be a new normal for what has been proven, how it has been reported and what goes on everyone\u2019s best of lists.\u201d\n\nAnne Quatrano, the Atlanta chef who oversees the foundation\u2019s awards, agreed that judging the character of a chef or the culture of a restaurant could be challenging. \u201cThat\u2019s why we are in some ways in an awkward position,\u201d she said. \u201cBut really, it\u2019s just making sure we feel comfortable that people on that list have integrity, and that those restaurants have good leaders and that everyone can thrive in their kitchens.\u201d\n\nOther food journalists are drawing their own lines. Jonathan Gold, the Los Angeles Times restaurant critic, gave a positive review to the Hearth & Hound although he engaged in some hand-wringing to do it.\n\n\u201cI think it may be more important that Bloomfield\u2019s talent is heard. But I\u2019m a white dude \u2014 this line is not mine to draw,\u201d Mr. Gold wrote. \u201cAnd whichever side of the question you lean toward, it is hard not to feel queasy at the result.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmanda Kludt, the editor in chief of Eater, is taking a harder line. She wrote in a column this week that the Hearth & Hound and other restaurants whose leaders had been caught abusing people would be stripped from the site\u2019s lists, guides and other forms of non-news coverage.\n\n\u201cWhy, with so much talent out there, with so many compelling restaurants to cover, would you review the one veiled in controversy?\u201d she wrote.\n\nEater\u2019s map of the \u201cmost iconic pizzerias\u201d in the East Bay Area, for example, will not include Oakland\u2019s well-regarded Pizzaola because its owner, Charlie Hallowell, sexually harassed his staff.\n\nThe policy is limited to cases in which the behavior has been investigated and publicly exposed. \u201cI don\u2019t think its fair to punish restaurants based on rumors,\u201d she said.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "James Beard Awards Apply a New Yardstick: Good Behavior", "authors": ["Kim Severson"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "One surprising place we can find counter-narratives of what women want and desire is in at least two of the movies that Clint Eastwood has directed. In one of his earlier films as a director, \u201cSudden Impact,\u201d Harry Callahan, yes, the infamous Dirty Harry, ends up on the trail of what seems to be a serial murderer, Jennifer Spencer, who is systematically murdering all of the men, and indeed one woman, who raped her and her sister in the small town of San Paolo, Calif.\n\nSpencer is a painter who has returned to San Paolo with these murders as a goal. Her excuse for being there is to paint hobby horses, a famous symbol of the penis, on the merry-go-round in the amusement park in which she was raped. Her sister is institutionalized and has not spoken since having been raped multiple times. Harry Callahan becomes romantically involved with her and sees the anguish in her paintings. Her killings are premeditated. She shoots her victims in the scrotum, watches them suffer, and then she shoots them in the head. It\u2019s a Dirty Harry movie so, yes, Harry comes out of the midst to save the day when she is embattled with the last murder.\n\nHarry takes out the last rapist and is about to read Jennifer Spencer her rights, but she interrupts with the following speech: \u201cRead me my rights? What exactly are my rights? Where was all this concern for my rights when I was being beaten and mauled? And what about my sister\u2019s rights when she was being brutalized? There is a thing called justice. And was it justice that they should all just walk away? You\u2019d never understand, Callahan.\u201d\n\nHarry makes a decision knowing that the last rapist\u2019s fingerprints are on the gun that killed him. He hands the gun to another officer and simply says, \u201cIt\u2019s over,\u201d and walks away with Jennifer Spencer. Is Eastwood showing us that if there is no justice for women, then they cannot be judged by Man\u2019s law? Watch the movie. I started with \u201cSudden Impact\u201d because we are dealing now with men who are violent sexual harassers, indeed some who are accused of rape.\n\nIn \u201cThe Bridges of Madison County,\u201d Eastwood redoes a popular novel by focusing on how the two children of Francesca Johnson, played by Meryl Streep, take up the search for the woman in the mother by reading the diaries she had left behind for them. The diaries tell of her four-day affair when her children and husband were gone to the state fair. The dairies tell a sexually explicit story. The film is shot from the perspective of Francesca Johnson and we watch her joyously embracing her own eroticism, and indeed lust, for Robert Kincaid.\n\nWe know how heterosexual sex is often shot in Hollywood movies. The man picks the woman up, throws her against the wall, penetrates her, and we see ecstasy on her face in about 10 seconds \u2014 same formula used in pornography. In \u201cBridges,\u201d the couple dance in the kitchen in what some women see as one of the most sensual and erotic scenes ever shot in Hollywood. Then there is the fade-out into the bedroom, which is deliberately kept blurry.\n\nFrancesca is a woman in her late 40s, not a teenybopper with redone boobs. So, do we need to lose Eros if we are to treat women as full persons with equality? Clearly not. The two are reunited in death as both have their ashes thrown off the bridge where their romance begins. The narrative in the movies that Eastwood directs follows men, and, yes, we are talking about straight white men here, as they move from conventional sexism to being shaken by a woman who testifies to that sexism, to having the courage \u2014 and yes it does take courage \u2014 to see women as full persons and to treating them with the respect that they deserve.", "title": "Opinion | James Bond Is a Wimp", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFIRE SERMON\n\nBy Jamie Quatro\n\n208 pp. Grove Press. $24\n\nTHERE ARE BOOKS with front doors, through which the reader walks right in, and there are books with side doors. Side door books take more interpretive work, but yield special pleasures. Jamie Quatro\u2019s fantastic new novel, \u201cFire Sermon,\u201d is a side door book. The novel delivers its story through a variety of methods: first-person confessions, \u201cfictional\u201d third-person descriptions, letters sent and unsent, emails, questionnaires, Socratic dialogues with the self. Roiling, raw and sensual on the surface, this mazy novel rewards a second reading.\n\nThe plot is simple: A married woman is trying to forget her lover. The woman, Maggie Ellmann, a contented mother of two grown children, meets James, a married poet, at a conference. They spend two years falling into a long-distance emotional affair. The affair culminates in a single, searing night together in Chicago, after which they part for good. In the unsent letters she writes to James during this embargo, Maggie struggles to find a theological framework for her longing and her pain. In one such letter, she admires the Buddhist notion of death as the ultimate lack of attachment, noting, \u201cWhat relief there would be in no longer longing to feel, again, your whiskers on my inner thighs.\u201d Her antagonist is time \u2014 so slow when she is trying to forget, so quick when she reflects on the simpler years with her husband and children, before the erotic disruption.\n\nThe novel dips back through time to track life before the affair. The mores of the Ellmanns\u2019 lives are exceedingly conventional, as are many of the novel\u2019s touchstones \u2014 weddings, baptisms, the death of pets. But the way this slim book condenses these happenings in the context of the affair gives them poetry. Lyrical lists of domestic detritus contain the sweetness of child rearing, as well as a mysterious sense of loss: \u201cParent meetings, medical forms, class photos, permission slips. Organelles. Passive versus active transport.\u201d Quatro cuts gorgeous topiaries into the domestic landscape. Maggie\u2019s little daughter mispronounces \u201cnail polish\u201d as \u201cpale nolish\u201d; her son fashions a makeshift loincloth from his father\u2019s old T-shirt, with a wrapping-paper tube for a spear. But over the years, \u201cinvasive plants encroach, privet and wisteria, thistle and honeysuckle. The backyard steadily shrinks.\u201d Even before she meets James, Maggie is aware of a lack of feeling, an inattentiveness to self \u2014 \u201cthis nothing.\u201d This nothing can partly be traced back to two difficult childbirths, and the habitual surrendering of her own body to others, most especially during sex, into which her usually benign husband manipulates and bullies her. Middle age looms. The children grow into complicated teenagers, then leave for college. In other words, Maggie has been in a personal stasis for a long time. Enter James. She first becomes aware of him through reading his poetry, which she admires. \u201cI think I\u2019m going to write to him,\u201d she announces to her husband, Thomas.\n\nPhoto\n\nPoor Thomas. He surely has his side of the story, but we don\u2019t get it here. Instead we are told: \u201cThomas is, in fact, a good husband.\u201d Syntactically, the sentence says so much. The fact of the husband\u2019s goodness becomes a sidebar. Maggie is aware of, but helpless against, the greed for more love, when she already has more than most. The marriage has its problems, but the biggest one is its earthly limitations, the waning of interest and desire \u2014 its mortality. Only if a person were \u201cmarried to God\u201d would she or he have a partner who would never suffer from overfamiliarity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGod is crucial to \u201cFire Sermon.\u201d Quatro\u2019s protagonist is genuinely at a loss over the contradictions of her specifically Christian body, one that is both devout and also full of appetite. (The themes here re-tread precisely those of her hugely original collection of stories, \u201cI Want to Show You More,\u201d from 2013.) Maggie genuinely cannot understand how to religiously interpret her adultery. She is full of guilt, but also suspects that she uses \u201cguilt as fuel, guilt as food, guilt as energy.\u201d In the next breath she wonders why she can\u2019t just give in to her desires if God has already granted \u201ceternal forgiveness from before all time.\u201d She doesn\u2019t know whether to believe the pastor at her parents\u2019 church, who says: \u201cGod wants your holiness, not your happiness. \u2026 All of history \u2026 is one long terrible story of men and women trying to make themselves happy.\u201d", "title": "Jamie Quatro\u2019s First Novel Centers on Religious and Sexual Passion", "authors": ["Amity Gaige", "Jamie Quatro"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA luminous wit, the kind that seems edged in fire, glows from certain stage performances, and on the rare occasions you encounter it, you can\u2019t help but feel more alive. This trait isn\u2019t just about the usual qualities associated with memorable acting \u2014 emotional verisimilitude, being in the moment, a star\u2019s towering presence.\n\nNo, this particular radiance has more to do with a sharp and playful intelligence that, without being grand or self-conscious, transmits the joy of being able to shape a character out of air, in real time and a shared space, for an audience\u2019s delectation. Among Americans these days, Kevin Kline and Frank Langella have it; so does Audra McDonald and, on the few occasions I\u2019ve seen her perform live, Meryl Streep.\n\nJan Maxwell, who died on Sunday at 61, also belongs in that select group. Except among connoisseurs of theater, her name has never been as well-known as that of a Streep or Langella. This despite her having received five Tony Award nominations \u2014 and her being one of only five women nominated in all of the possible Tony acting categories. (Ms. McDonald is another).\n\n[ Read the obituary of Jan Maxwell. ]\n\nI sometimes wondered why Ms. Maxwell never achieved wider recognition. (She never did win a Tony.) Perhaps it was a matter of choice, of not wanting or needing the ego shot of marquee-goddess stature, though her high cheekbones and lynx\u2019s eyes endowed her with the appropriate appearance. It may also be that she seemed to hail from another era, when theater stardom was perceived as the headiest kind of celebrity and sufficient unto itself.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe incarnated the golden age of that period, the 1920s, with butterfly grace eight years ago, when she appeared at the Manhattan Theater Club production of \u201cThe Royal Family,\u201d George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber\u2019s vintage satire about a clan of self-dramatizing show people, inspired by those Broadway stalwarts the Barrymores. Ms. Maxwell played Julie Cavendish, a leading lady who couldn\u2019t cross a room without seeking the spotlight and striking a pose.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s a role that could easily slide into winking caricature. What\u2019s more, Ms. Maxwell was appearing with Rosemary Harris, as the family matriarch, and Ms. Harris had indelibly appeared as Julie in a much-loved production in the mid-1970s. Yet when these two actresses from different generations shared the stage, they seemed unmistakably cut from the same luxurious cloth.", "title": "Jan Maxwell Was a Star Made for the Stage", "authors": ["Ben Brantley"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Jan Maxwell, the fiercely passionate, adoringly reviewed New York stage actress who earned five Tony Award nominations in seven years, including two in one season, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 61.\n\nThe death was confirmed by her husband, the actor and playwright Robert Emmet Lunney, who said the cause was leptomeningeal disease, a consequence of her struggle with breast cancer. She received the original cancer diagnosis in 2006, he said, and learned that it had returned, in metastatic form, in 2013.\n\nMs. Maxwell announced her retirement from the stage in 2015, telling Time Out magazine that it was because \u201cthe kinds of roles I was being offered were just \u2014 I\u2019d been there and done that.\u201d Her last performance was as Galactia, a 16th-century Venetian painter who fights back when her art angers the government, in \u201cScenes From an Execution,\u201d at Atlantic Stage 2 in Chelsea.", "title": "Jan Maxwell, Celebrated Stage Actress, Is Dead at 61", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "1\n\n$9,500,000 3 Countryside Lane Cherry Hills Village, Colo. The most viewed listing in January was a modern house about 20 minutes south of Denver, with four bedrooms and 10,070 square feet of living space. Sliding glass walls extend the home\u2019s indoor space out into the two-and-a-half-acre property. Broker LIV Sotheby\u2019s International Realty\n\n2\n\n$1,449,999 1 Coach Road Bear Creek, Pa. The Bischwind, a Pocono Mountains bed-and-breakfast with 10 bedrooms, a 60-person event space, a terrace and a pool was the second most viewed. According to the listing, President William Taft was once a guest at the 19th-century house. Broker Kurfiss Sotheby\u2019s International Realty\n\n3\n\n$799,500 6008 N Landis Avenue Sea Isle City, N.J. Next, a four-bedroom townhouse on the Jersey Shore. With three levels, two decks and good parking, it has rental potential and plenty of space for entertaining. The house is about an hour and a half from Philadelphia and two and a half hours from New York. Broker Landis Company\n\n4\n\n$999,000 170 East 78th Street, No. 3C Upper East Side Fourth most viewed was a refined-looking one-bedroom in a prewar co-op. But the home\u2019s 16-by-29-foot living room, large windows, 13-foot ceilings and washer/dryer come with a steep monthly maintenance of $2,980. Pieds-\u00e0-terre and pets are allowed. Broker Brown Harris Stevens\n\n5", "title": "January\u2019s Most Popular Listings", "authors": ["Michael Kolomatsky"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Japan hosts about 40,000 American troops. During the Korean War in 1950-53, it served as a major operating platform for United States forces fighting in support of South Korea: American soldiers who had been maintained in Japan after World War II were quickly sent to the Korean Peninsula, and American battleships, aircraft carriers, fighter jets and bombers operated from bases in Japan. Should conflict break out in South Korea today, the United States could, and presumably would, come to its ally\u2019s help by using once again its main footholds in Japan, including its air force base in Yokota, naval base in Sasebo and Marine air station in Futenma.\n\nWhat\u2019s more, the Japanese government stands ready to support American military operations that would be deployed in the event of a conflict. In 1997, the United States and Japan agreed that Japan\u2019s Self-Defense Force would provide noncombat assistance to United States troops \u201cin situations in areas surrounding Japan\u201d \u2014 a code phrase, in part, for the Korean Peninsula.\n\nOver the years, United States-Japan cooperation for the defense of South Korea became so close that some specialists said it created a \u201cvirtual alliance\u201d among the three countries, and have credited it with deterring war in East Asia despite North Korea\u2019s steady pursuit of nuclear weapons and regular flare-ups and crises, such as in early 2003 and 2009.\n\nJapan\u2019s commitment to South Korea has only been strengthened since, bolstered by Mr. Abe\u2019s return to power as prime minister in 2012. For all his nationalistic bluster, Mr. Abe\u2019s hawkishness has served South Korea\u2019s defense interests well.\n\nIn 2014, the Japanese government reinterpreted the Constitution to allow Japan to use force \u2014 under limited conditions \u2014 to defend itself or its allies, including the United States and South Korea. The legislature passed security legislation in 2015 authorizing Japanese forces to provide combat support to United States troops that might fight in the waters or air space around the Korean Peninsula. If necessary, they may, for example, shoot down a North Korean ballistic missile aimed at Guam or Hawaii, conduct anti-submarine operations to protect American naval forces or clear mines in waters near North Korea ahead of United States amphibious operations.\n\nIn other words, Japan\u2019s participation in the defense of South Korea is consequential.\n\nAnd yet it has largely been downplayed, if not deliberately ignored \u2014 mostly, again, for pragmatic reasons.\n\nThe idea of defending South Korea isn\u2019t very popular in Japan, especially among people who identify as liberal pacifists. Some Japanese are wary of seeing their country dragged into someone else\u2019s war or cannot fathom having to sacrifice for South Koreans who keep criticizing Japan for its historical record.\n\nSome South Koreans, for their part, are uncomfortable about receiving security support from a government that once colonized them. Many South Korean journalists and academics I have spoken to over the years gladly acknowledge the importance of America\u2019s security commitment, but regard any such contribution by Japan as suspect \u2014 or even, as one legislator has said, as an attempt to \u201cseize hegemony in East Asia.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Japan and South Korea, the Friendly Foes of East Asia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The meaning of Smile Japan has evolved since it was first coined in February 2013, by a Canadian in the Tatra Mountains of Slovakia.\n\nCarla MacLeod, a two-time Olympic gold medalist, was a member of Japan\u2019s coaching staff during the 2014 Olympic qualifying tournament in Poprad. The Japanese team had just finished breakfast before its opening game against Norway when MacLeod felt a nervous energy permeating the room. MacLeod watched as a thick, fluffy snow fell and ordered the team to put on their outerwear. Outside, MacLeod engaged the entire team in a snowball fight, melting away their nerves.\n\n\u201cI could see the Norwegian players standing at their windows looking at us like, \u2018What is going on there?\u2019\u201d MacLeod said. \u201cI pulled them in and said: \u2018This is how we have to play. Because when you play with a smile, you play your best hockey.\u2019 Then before every game, when I fist-pumped them, I said, \u2018smile\u2019 and they would smile back at me.\u201d\n\nFrom that moment, the concept of Smile Japan became a rallying cry for Japanese women\u2019s hockey. The team\u2019s logo is now a red circular face \u2014 similar to the sun found on Japan\u2019s national flag \u2014 with a hockey stick forming a smile.\n\nAlmost every Japanese national team has a nickname. Japan\u2019s baseball team is Samurai Japan. The women\u2019s soccer team is Nadeshiko Japan, named after a flower that symbolizes beauty.\n\nBut some players on the women\u2019s hockey team worried Smile Japan presented the wrong message to audiences who did not understand its meaning and only associated the name with the images from the Olympics.\n\nAfter Japan scored its first goal of the 2014 tournament, the team\u2019s celebration of forming a circle and bowing instantly became an animated GIF. Canadian newspapers ran articles with headlines like \u201cJapan\u2019s team is just adorbs\u201d with polls asking \u201cHow cute is Japan\u2019s Olympic women\u2019s hockey team?\u201d The players were called \u201ca lovable underdog\u201d and \u201ckawaii\u201d \u2014 the Japanese term for cute \u2014 as if they were Hello Kitty characters, not world-class athletes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not just we\u2019re happy to be here; we worked our butts off to be here and we\u2019re going to share this time with the people we got here with,\u201d said MacLeod, who was not retained after the 2014 Olympics. \u201cThe Smile Japan moniker, the name is incredibly powerful to me and what it stands for. It wasn\u2019t because they were these small petite women who were happy go lucky.\u201d\n\nMacLeod noted that even Canada, which has won the last four Olympic tournaments, takes photos on the ice during practices.\n\nPhoto\n\nAina Takeuchi, a defender on the 2014 Olympic team who played in the Canadian Women\u2019s Hockey League after the Sochi Olympics, said she was motivated to change the perception of Japanese players.\n\n\u201cI went to Calgary for three years so I have to show them even as a Japanese player, I can do it,\u201d she said. \u201cAfter Sochi, each of us learned so many things, so now we have to show in Pyeongchang we are not the team that is always smiling.\u201d\n\nAs Japan attempts to shed labels, win its first Olympic game and qualify for the medal round, the team simultaneously feels pressure to grow women\u2019s hockey at home. South Korea and China are investing heavily in the sport, strengthening the competition in Asia. After the Sochi Games, interest in Smile Japan sharply declined. When Japanese sports papers did cover the team, the coverage often consisted of only photos of players, notably goaltender Nana Fujimoto.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
