Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn the ice, Fujimoto won the Best Goaltender award at the International Ice Hockey Federation world championships in 2015, and later that year she played in the inaugural season of the National Women\u2019s Hockey League, where she was named an All-Star.\n\n\u201cHockey in Japan is a really minor sport,\u201d Fujimoto said. \u201cWhat we have to do, first of all, we have to get a good result. Then the media is going to treat us to get more coverage. The Olympic Games is the best place for us to appeal, when we get the medal.\u201d\n\nOne advantage for Japan this time will be experience. In 2014, only one player had competed in the Olympics. Almost two-thirds of this year\u2019s team will be carry-overs from Sochi.\n\nOne first-timer is Shoko Ono, 36, who played in three Olympic qualifying tournaments with the national team, falling short each time. She retired after 2010, resigned that Japan could not compete on the level of Olympic teams. Watching her former teammates qualify for the 2014 Games, though, reignited Ono\u2019s passion for hockey. She rejoined the national team in 2015, where she was soon competing alongside 16-year-olds.\n\n\u201cI saw my teammates\u2019 smiles,\u201d Ono said, \u201cand I thought I want to go back and smile again.\u201d", "title": "Japan\u2019s Women\u2019s Hockey Team Wants to Be Known for Wins, Not Smiles", "authors": ["Seth Berkman"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "1. Jared Kushner, the president\u2019s adviser and son-in-law, has been downgraded.\n\nHe\u2019s been stripped of his top-secret security clearance. (Now he\u2019s only privy to more ordinary secrets.) The move was part of an overhaul by the White House chief of staff, John Kelly.\n\nThe question now is whether Mr. Kushner, above center, will be able to keep his portfolio, which includes negotiations with Israel and the Palestinians.", "title": "Jared Kushner, N.R.A., Syria: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Jared Kushner, the president\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser, has been stripped of his top-secret security clearance after months of delays in completing his background check, and will now be limited in his ability to view highly classified information, a White House official and another person familiar with Mr. Kushner\u2019s situation said on Tuesday.\n\nMr. Kushner\u2019s clearance was reduced to the level of secret and his official portfolio inside the West Wing, especially with regard to his globe-trotting foreign affairs work on behalf of President Trump, is expected to be sharply reduced, as well, the people said.\n\nSince the beginning of the Trump administration, both Mr. Kushner, 37, and his wife, Ivanka Trump, the president\u2019s elder daughter, 36, have enjoyed a special status within the White House as both family members and assistants to the president. But the complicated finances surrounding Mr. Kushner\u2019s family\u2019s vast real estate empire and his qualifications for the foreign policy responsibilities given to him by his father-in-law invited scrutiny from the start.\n\nOften seen by Mr. Trump\u2019s side during key moments of international diplomacy and presidential announcements during much of 2017, Mr. Kushner accompanied Mr. Trump on trips to Asia, including China and Japan; to the Mideast, including Israel and Saudi Arabia; and to Europe, meeting with officials in each place. He also made his own trips abroad.", "title": "Jared Kushner\u2019s Security Clearance Downgraded", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Johns\u2019s early flags and targets, as everyone now knows, rewrote postwar American art by repudiating most everything about Ab Ex \u2014 the splashy emotionalism, the metaphysical longings, the well-rehearsed enactments of agony and ecstasy played out against the quaint bohemian backdrop of Tenth Street and the Cedar Tavern.\n\nMr. Johns\u2019s early flags were radical because they did just the opposite. Instead of turning private feelings into bland public statements, he claimed public symbols for the realm of inwardness and private experience. Viewers were puzzled by his apparent lack of interest in communicating a higher truth in the usual sense. His goal, it seemed, was less to convey a message than to circle cryptically around it.\n\nThe sculptor Richard Serra put it as well as anyone when he recently told me: \u201cWhat Johns did was he presented a new model. There was an abrupt shift. It was sort of like the Beatles kicking out Elvis.\u201d\n\nThe Broad show, a version of which was first seen at the Royal Academy of Arts in London in the fall, freely mixes work from different decades, sometimes on the same wall. It implicitly argues that Mr. Johns\u2019s later paintings and occasional sculptures can hold their own beside the dazzle of his early works. The paintings in his \u201cCatenary\u201d series, which date from the late 1990s, look especially strong. Most are large, horizontal, gray-hued works that vaguely resemble a blackboard, with an actual string suspended in a U-shape from their top corners. The paintings feel both intimate and vast. Their trademark curved string evokes the anatomical (a breast); the architectural (the span of a bridge); and the cosmic. They have a calm, summing-up feeling, and the slight movements of the string somehow add to their sense of enveloping stillness.\n\nMr. Johns is a formidable presence, six feet tall, with a large, craggy face and watchful eyes. He describes his health as moderate to fair, and you can tell that his knees torment him when he stands up from a chair. On most days, he can be found in his studio, tailed by his dog Dougal, a wiry mutt who might have some Greyhound in him, and who arrived from the Caribbean islands two years ago, as a gift from a friend.\n\nIndeed, Mr. Johns has no shortage of devoted friends who have known him for decades. Nonetheless, his friends \u2014 much like his viewers \u2014 can be kept on edge by his remove. Nearly everyone agrees that certain topics reliably engage him, such as gardening and cooking, but that attempts to discuss the meaning of his work with him will bring on instantaneous silence.", "title": "Jasper Johns Still Doesn\u2019t Want to Explain His Art", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTributes to jazz legends, excursions into bluegrass and contemporary dance, and appearances by pre-eminent improvisers such as McCoy Tyner and Charles Lloyd will all be a part of Jazz at Lincoln Center\u2019s 31st season.\n\nThe concert series will start Sept. 13 at the Rose Theater with a performance of \u201cSpaces,\u201d a broadly accessible work composed by the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis, the organization\u2019s artistic director, as a homage to the animal kingdom. The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra will perform the suite in conversation with the contemporary dancers Lil Buck and Jared Grimes. Subsequent concerts by the orchestra will focus on the songbooks of Thelonious Monk (Oct. 25-27) and Miles Davis (Nov. 8-10).\n\nOther major shows will also pay tribute to departed jazz luminaries, in keeping with Jazz at Lincoln Center tradition. On Dec. 14-15, the vocalist Sachal Vasandani will present a program celebrating the 100th birthday of Nat King Cole. A conclave of eminent pianists \u2014 including Gerald Clayton, Gonzalo Rubalcaba and Kenny Barron, a National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Master \u2014 will perform a concert on Feb. 22-23, 2019, dedicated to the repertoire of Oscar Peterson. And on March 29-30, the bassist Marcus Miller will offer a tribute to Davis, his former employer, entitled \u201cElectric Miles.\u201d\n\nThe season will include some concerts exploring parallel music traditions, including \u201cJazz, Bluegrass and Folk,\u201d on Oct. 5-6, featuring the violinist Mark O\u2019Connor and his ensemble; \u201cMusic from Appalachia,\u201d on Dec. 7-8, headlined by the singer-songwriters Steve Miller and Marty Stuart; and \u201cCountry Music,\u201d on April 25-27, in which the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra will share the stage with the documentarian Ken Burns.\n\nAnd audiences will have ample opportunity to hear from throwback jazz vocalists. Diane Schuur will sing music from the Count Basie Orchestra\u2019s repertoire on Nov. 2-3. And Michael Feinstein will present three different programs, one dedicated to the music of Peter Allen (April 10-11), another titled \u201cGreat American Crooners\u201d (May 15-16), and the last focused on the songwriting team Lerner and Loewe (June 5-6).\n\nA full schedule can be found at jazz.org.", "title": "Jazz at Lincoln Center Lines Up a New Season", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Unlike the film, the commandments are presented out of order, often prompting the viewer to consult the playbill to figure out where we are in the cycle. Like the film, however, \u201cDie Zehn Gebote\u201d often leaves the viewer to meditate on the relationship between the kitchen-sink realism of the individual tales and the biblical injunctions to which they are joined, however obliquely.\n\n\u201cDie Zehn Gebote\u201d is a true ensemble piece and the actors are excitingly matched. Lukas Holzhausen is both tender and weary as a single parent whose teenage daughter suspects he is not her biological father. Anja Herden gets to survey a wide dramatic range, from a matriarch who must plead for her grandchild\u2019s return to the cynical, promiscuous neighbor in the most famous episode of \u201cThe Decalogue.\u201d As both a lawyer against capital punishment and a committed doctor who is forced to play God, Gabor Biedermann demonstrates how a practiced, professional demeanor cracks up in the face of moral uncertainty and outrage.\n\nPhoto\n\nOne of Kieslowski\u2019s most admired traits as a filmmaker was his ability to translate his philosophical and dramatic ideas into stark images. In putting \u201cThe Decalogue\u201d on stage, one has to find equivalents for visual storytelling. Mr. Kimmig, a prolific German director, resists the urge to use video, concentrating the entire drama in the raw performances of the actors. Instead, he finds cinematic texture by fiddling with narrative structure.\n\nKieslowski\u2019s film is centered on a large social housing project. Over the long course of the series, there are many chance encounters: We gain new perspectives on stories we have already seen. In Mr. Kimmig\u2019s version, the characters from various episodes intrude on each other. Sometimes they take a seat downstage and spectate. At others, they interrupt to introduce a new tale. Each segment builds to a moment of ethical crisis, and so these narrative breaks, which become increasingly frenzied after the intermission, succeed in sustaining tension over the course of the whole performance. After the emotionally frantic, \u201cShort Cuts\u201d-like crisscrossing of the final half-hour, the energetic curtain call, with its numerous costume changes (to remind the audience who played whom) felt cathartic in itself.\n\nThe ethical conundrums of a building full of Poles would probably seem like small fry to those of the House of Atreus, whose famous family curse is being revisited next door in the Burgtheater\u2019s powerful all-female production of \u201cDie Orestie\u201d (\u201cThe Oresteia\u201d). Using a much-whittled-down version of Peter Stein\u2019s German prose translation (that version ran to nine and a half hours during its original performances at the Berlin Schaub\u00fchne in 1980), Ant\u00fa Romero Nunes has brought his stripped-down, savage aesthetic to Aeschylus\u2019 tragic trilogy. Over 140 intermission-less minutes, seven of the Burgtheater\u2019s powerful actresses transform the broad stage of Vienna\u2019s most elegant dramatic theater into a claustrophobic pressure cooker.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe staging by Mr. Nunes, a young and in-demand German director (next month, he will direct the Bavarian State Opera\u2019s premiere of Verdi\u2019s \u201cLes V\u00eapres Siciliennes\u201d), suggests that the story is being told from the point of view of the Furies, the goddesses who mete out divine justice in the pre-legal world of Greek myth. The trilogy\u2019s final chapter, \u201cThe Eumenides,\u201d can, in fact, be read as a parable for the establishment of the Athenian judicial system.\n\nBy assigning all the roles to a handful of actors, Mr. Nunes also highlights how the cycle of familial violence affects everyone \u2014 protagonists, chorus, gods and Furies. For the spectator as well, it is impossible to remain neutral or indifferent to the vicissitudes of this 2,500-year-old tragedy.\n\nWith soiled white garments, black boots and ratty blonde locks, their faces caked in white paint, the actresses look like a chorus of the undead. Save for the ambient music, the occasional fog and the black blood that comes streaming downstage at one point, these women are themselves the production, from Andrea Wenzl\u2019s pained, defenseless Cassandra to Aenne Schwarz\u2019s violent and conflicted Orestes. (Ms. Schwarz is also sensational in the Burgtheater\u2019s \u201cAntigone,\u201d which makes an excellent companion piece for this \u201cOresteia.\u201d)\n\nMaria Happel and Barbara Petritsch are boldly cast as Agamemnon, who sacrifices his daughter to secure favorable winds for the Greek fleet sailing to Troy, and Aegisthus, who plots the king\u2019s downfall. Two longtime members of the Burgtheater\u2019s ensemble, they more than hold their own against the production\u2019s younger actresses, matching them in dramatic and even physical intensity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPerhaps best of all is Caroline Peters\u2019s nuanced Clytemnestra. Her performance is shot through with pride, grief and cunning, never more so than in her unsettlingly tender scene with Orestes, the long-exiled son who has returned to murder her. That love, suffering, fear and the desire for revenge can coexist inside one breast is something that perceptive artists of subtle moral imagination have always been able to comprehend.", "title": "Jealousy, Infidelity, Murder, Lies: It\u2019s All on Vienna\u2019s Stages", "authors": ["A.J. Goldmann"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Jeffrey Bell, a conservative theorist who transformed his relentless campaign for tax cuts into a stunning primary upset that toppled a liberal fellow Republican, United States Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey, died on Feb. 10 in Annandale, Va. He was 74.\n\nThe cause was cardiac arrest, his wife, Rosalie O\u2019Connell, said.\n\nMr. Bell lost two other Senate bids, but his electoral record belied an enduring national political influence on economic and social issues.\n\n\u201cHe turbocharged the policy agenda that culminated with Reagan\u2019s landslide election and a mandate for massive tax cuts,\u201d Rich Danker wrote last week in the conservative magazine The Weekly Standard.\n\nMr. Bell was only 34 in 1978 when he challenged Mr. Case, a last pillar of liberal Republicanism. Mr. Case had been undefeated since he was first elected to Congress in 1944, a year after Mr. Bell was born. Mr. Bell lost the 1978 general election to Bill Bradley, a Democrat.", "title": "Jeffrey Bell, G.O.P. Giant-Killer and Supply-Sider, Dies at 74", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Here are some highlights from the night.\n\nThe Russians did train \u201choney pots\u201d to seduce \u201cassets.\u201d\n\nThe Russian intelligence agencies did have a school where they taught women to use sex as a seduction tool, Ms. Mendez said. In the 1980s, she said, an American Marine who guarded the American embassy in Moscow fell prey to a Russian sex operation. A female Russian spy seduced the Marine, who ended up allowing other Russians onto the embassy\u2019s property in Russia. The Marine was later convicted of allowing a security breach.\n\n\u201cIt was a seduction scenario not unlike what you would have done in your movie,\u201d Ms. Mendez said, referring to Ms. Lawrence.\n\nMs. Mendez said that spies from China, Taiwan and Czechoslovakia had used sex to seduce sources. But the C.I.A., she said, did not teach those tactics.\n\n\u201cThat doesn\u2019t mean there haven\u2019t been some entrepreneurs here and there,\u201d Ms. Mendez said coyly, adding that in her time at the agency, she knew of a woman who had lost her job after falling in love with a foreign asset.\n\nA couple of men at the agency had also found themselves in similar situations, but had kept their jobs, she said.\n\nMr. Lawrence said he had been told that, or read that, the C.I.A. tried to create its own sparrows program in the 1960s to use against the Russians.\n\n\u201cIt didn\u2019t work because of the difference in terms of values and morality around sex\u201d he said. \u201cThey just didn\u2019t care as much, and it didn\u2019t work and it was scrapped.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Mendez responded, \u201cThose reasons would be reasons it wouldn\u2019t work but I never heard it was attempted.\u201d\n\nAfter doubts about a Russia film, \u201cthe world came to\u201d them.\n\nAs the directors and producers started working on the movie\u2019s script three years ago, they grew concerned that the idea of tension between the United States and Russia did not feel relevant.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe thought, \u2018God, this Cold War thing doesn\u2019t feel all that relevant,\u2019\u201d Mr. Lawrence said. \u201cUh, maybe we should brainstorm a little about making it more relevant.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cWe sort of set that aside and went with the character story.\u201d\n\nMr. Shane jumped in, \u201cAnd the world came to you.\u201d\n\nMr. Lawrence insisted, \u201cIt is really about the people, right, but it\u2019s not a political movie.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut as we were shooting and actually prepping,\u201d he added, \u201cthis all started to come up, and the movie became more and more relevant as we\u2019ve progressed.\u201d\n\nShe got the arms, fingers and head of a ballerina.\n\nWhen Ms. Lawrence prepared for the \u201cHunger Games\u201d movies, she spent her time practicing the use of her weapon, a bow and arrow. For \u201cRed Sparrow,\u201d she studied ballet and developed a slight Russian accent.\n\n\u201cEven just to play an ex-ballerina, everything had to change,\u201d she said, adding that she spent three hours a day for four months working with the Hollywood ballet instructor Kurt Froman.\n\nMs. Lawrence said it was difficult because she had never wanted to dance ballet.\n\n\u201cWe tried to condense a lifetime of training into four months, and we got arms, fingers, and a little bit of head,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was most important to move and hold my body differently, and get behind a dancer\u2019s mental and physical discipline.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe movie was always going to be in English, but to enhance the believability of her character onscreen, Ms. Lawrence needed to develop a slight Russian accent. She was assigned to an instructor who studied the voices of women who had come to the United States many years ago from Russia but still had slight accents.\n\nThat preparation was \u201cvery boring,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Shane quipped, \u201cIt\u2019s easier to do that than to learn Russian.\u201d\n\nJLaw and the Burger Boy.\n\nAmid all the spy talk, we learned an incredibly juicy detail about Ms. Lawrence\u2019s dating life: She once dated a hamburger \u2014 in a commercial.\n\n\u201cUntil I did my research, I had not seen your Burger King commercial,\u201d Mr. Shane asked.\n\n\u201cOh, my God \u2014 oh, my God!\u201d Ms. Lawrence responded.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s out there on YouTube,\u201d Mr. Shane said.\n\nIn the commercial, Ms. Lawrence plays a teenage girl who is in the bedroom of a teenage boy \u2014 who happens to be a Whopper Jr.\n\nThe boy\u2019s father, who is dressed as a Whopper, walks into the room as Ms. Lawrence and the Whopper Jr. start cuddling.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s going on?\u201d the father said. \u201cFirst, you sell yourself for a buck, and now this.\u201d\n\n\u201cStop treating me like I\u2019m on the kids\u2019 menu,\u201d the son responded.\n\n\u201cYou get your buns downstairs right now.\u201d\n\nMs. Lawrence said she was 15 when the commercial was shot.\n\n\u201cYou had real stage presence as a hamburger,\u201d Mr. Shane said.\n\n\u201cI wasn\u2019t the hamburger,\u201d Ms. Lawrence said about the commercial. \u201cMy boyfriend was a hamburger.\u201d", "title": "Jennifer Lawrence as a Russian \u2018Sparrow\u2019: Four Takeaways", "authors": ["Michael S. Schmidt"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Jensen Kober Henry and Nathaniel Adam William Crider were married Feb. 14 at the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey in Newark by Kevin McNulty, a judge there for whom the groom had been a law clerk. On Feb. 17, Judge McNulty led the couple in an exchange of vows at 501 Union, an event space in Brooklyn.\n\nDr. Henry, 28, is an orthopedic surgery resident at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan. She graduated summa cum laude from Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, and received a medical degree from N.Y.U.\n\nShe is the daughter of Karilyn E. Kober of Omaha and the late J. William Henry. He graduated cum laude from Ithaca College and received a law degree from Columbia.", "title": "Jensen Henry, Nathaniel Crider", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Mrs. May has seemed eager to steer a middle path, but she is under pressure from hard-liners in her party who advocate severing ties with the single market and customs union, and steering the country toward a low-regulation, low-tax economy.\n\nMr. Corbyn mocked Tory infighting over the terms of the deal on Monday, joking that \u201canything agreed at breakfast is being briefed against at lunch and abandoned at teatime,\u201d and tried to present himself as a voice of sanity.\n\n\u201cThe European Union is not the root of all our problems, and leaving it will not solve all our problems,\u201d he said. \u201cThere will be some who will tell you that Brexit is a disaster for our country, and some who will tell you that Brexit will create a land of milk and honey. The truth is more down to earth, and it\u2019s in our hands.\u201d\n\nConservatives had attacked Mr. Corbyn in advance of the speech, describing his promise of renegotiated trade deals as unrealistic. Iain Duncan Smith, a former leader of the Conservatives, also warned potential defectors in the party against being swayed by Mr. Corbyn.\n\n\u201cBe very careful on this one, because you\u2019re being invited into a Labour Party tactical game, which will actually end up in real damage to the United Kingdom,\u201d he told the BBC.\n\nKeir Starmer, Mr. Corbyn\u2019s chief adviser on Brexit, predicted that Mrs. May would face a rebellion.\n\n\u201cCrunchtime is now coming for the prime minister, because the majority in Parliament does not back her approach to a customs union\u201d and \u201cwill be heard sooner or later,\u201d he said.\n\nReactions to the speech divided neatly along positions on Brexit.\n\nGeorge Osborne, a Conservative opponent of leaving the European Union who served as chancellor of the Exchequer from 2010 to 2016, wrote in The Evening Standard that Mrs. May had made a fatal mistake by appeasing hard-core Brexiteers, and that Mr. Corbyn had \u201copened up the looming prospect of suffering a huge defeat in the Commons.\u201d", "title": "Jeremy Corbyn, Backing a \u2018Soft\u2019 Brexit, Takes Aim at Conservatives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "The current downturn is much smaller. The Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index is down 6 percent since Thursday. Mr. Powell said on Monday that the economy is in good health. With unemployment low, the Fed is focused on raising its benchmark interest rates to stay ahead of inflation.\n\n\u201cPowell could have done without a slump in the U.S. stock market, but unless the slump becomes a rout, he is unlikely to intervene,\u201d wrote John Higgins, an economist at Capital Economics.\n\nThe Fed\u2019s enforcement action against Wells Fargo on Friday is another new addition to Mr. Powell\u2019s plate. The Fed halted the bank\u2019s growth until it improves its internal checks and balances, a move that comes as the Fed\u2019s seven-member board is down to just three governors, the smallest number in the institution\u2019s history.\n\nIn addition to Mr. Powell, the members of the board are Randal K. Quarles, the vice chairman for supervision, and Lael Brainard.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Quarles, who oversees financial regulation issues at the Fed, has recused himself from Wells Fargo-related business because he held significant investments in the firm before he joined the Fed last year. That leaves Ms. Brainard, the other member of the committee that oversees supervision, as the Fed\u2019s point person on the Wells case, although Mr. Powell would also participate in significant decisions.\n\nOther Fed governors could be arriving. President Trump has nominated Marvin Goodfriend, a conservative economist, to join the board. He is awaiting Senate confirmation.\n\nMr. Trump has not announced nominees for the other three seats on the board.\n\nThe regulators who directly supervise Wells Fargo are employees of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, one of the 12 regional banks that make up the Fed system. Before the 2008 financial crisis, the regional reserve banks exercised significant control over the institutions headquartered in their regions. But in 2010, the Fed centralized the regulation of large banks to improve the consistency of regulation and to take a broad view of issues affecting multiple banks.\n\nThe judgment about Wells Fargo\u2019s progress will be made by a staff committee, the Large Institution Supervision Coordinating Committee, that is led by Michael S. Gibson, the Fed\u2019s director of supervision and regulation, in close consultation with the board of governors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWells Fargo has been through this process once before. The company was censured in December 2016 for failing to file an adequate plan for dealing with a financial crisis.\n\nMr. Powell was sworn into office by Mr. Quarles, a longtime friend. When Mr. Powell worked as a senior Treasury Department official under President George Bush in the early 1990s, he hired Mr. Quarles as an assistant. Later the two men worked together at the Carlyle Group, a private equity investment firm.\n\nMr. Quarles was selected by Mr. Trump as the Fed\u2019s point man for an overhaul of post-crisis financial regulations, which the president views as excessive. Mr. Powell on Monday reiterated his view that the financial system \u201cis now far stronger and more resilient\u201d as a result of increased regulation and \u201cwe intend to keep it that way.\u201d He added that there is room for improvement to make regulation \u201cefficient as well as effective.\u201d", "title": "Jerome Powell Is Sworn In as Federal Reserve Chairman", "authors": ["Binyamin Appelbaum"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Everybody has that one friend who knows exactly what clothes look perfect on her, who she should (and shouldn\u2019t) date and which A-list celebrities she\u2019d become besties with if they ever got the chance to hang out.\n\nThe comedians Jessica Williams and Phoebe Robinson are not only that friend to each other, they\u2019re also longtime collaborators who have turned their repartee into a hit podcast, \u201c2 Dope Queens.\u201d\n\nThe show, which is recorded live at the Bell House in Brooklyn, has gained a following for Ms. Williams and Ms. Robinson\u2019s riffs on popular culture and their daily adventures, and for emphasizing female and L.G.B.T. comedians as well as performers of color.\n\nNow Ms. Williams (an alumna of \u201cThe Daily Show\u201d) and Ms. Robinson (who has written for \u201cPortlandia\u201d and acted on \u201cSearch Party\u201d) are taking \u201c2 Dope Queens\u201d to the next level: a four-episode HBO series, which makes its debut on Friday and features their banter on the stage of the Kings Theater in Brooklyn, with help from their stand-up comedy pals and celebrity guests like Jon Stewart and Sarah Jessica Parker.", "title": "Jessica Williams and Phoebe Robinson Save It for the Stage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Jill Nicole Filipovic and Ty Lohrer McCormick were married Jan. 29 at the Talisman restaurant in Nairobi, Kenya. Another top-tier candidate, Mike Nagy, has already been hired by the Chicago Bears. Baylor Coach Matt Rhule, who also interviewed for the job, is back on campus getting ready for spring football. And it\u2019s unclear where the Colts may turn next.\n\n\u201cWe have a list of candidates, I\u2019ve had them from the get-go,\u201d Ballard said. \u201cThere are other guys we wanted to interview, but because of the playoffs, we weren\u2019t able to.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ll move forward with them and we will get the right leader for the Indianapolis Colts \u2014 one that believes what we believe and wants to go where we want to go. I\u2019m very confident in this.\u201d\n\nBallard didn\u2019t name names, of course, nor did he provide a timetable.\n\nThe timing could present Indy with an opportunity to pick off a coach who might emerge as a top candidate on next year\u2019s coaching carousel.\n\nSeveral possibilities exist, including Philadelphia Eagles offensive coordinator Frank Reich, who was part of a Super Bowl victory over the Patriots with a backup quarterback.\n\nThe good news for the Colts is that they have the only coaching vacancy and it still looks pretty attractive \u2014 if Andrew Luck is healthy.\n\nIndianapolis still has the Pro Bowl receiver T.Y. I have not gotten that from the two doctors that he\u2019s seen here after the season. His strength is good. He has not picked up a football, but he is throwing balls, working on arm speed.\u201d\n\nBallard added, \u201cHe\u2019s going to do everything right to get himself ready to play and I\u2019m very confident, he\u2019s very confident, that he\u2019s going to come back and prove a lot of people wrong.\u201d\n\nMcDaniels\u2019s decision didn\u2019t just leave the Colts in the lurch.\n\nThree assistant coaches \u2014 Matt Eberflus, Mike Phair and Dave DeGuglielmo \u2014 had already been hired.\n\nBallard said he liked all three and would honor their contracts by keeping them on the next coach\u2019s staff, but others strongly criticized McDaniels from walking away from them.\n\n\u201cThere is NO excuse big enough to justify this,\u201d the former Colts coach Tony Dungy wrote on Twitter. \u201cIt\u2019s one thing to go back on your word to an organization. But having assistant coaches leave jobs to go with you then leave them out to dry is indefensible.\u201d\n\nBut as Wednesday\u2019s news conference continued, Ballard said that people say no to job offers every day, that he wished McDaniels well at the end of Tuesday night\u2019s brief call and that his primary concern now is finding someone who wants the job.\n\n\u201cTo me, it\u2019s about being right,\u201d Ballard said. \u201cYou\u2019ve got to be right. It doesn\u2019t matter if you\u2019re the first out of the box and everybody praises you, or you are the last one to make the hire. We want to be right.\u201d", "title": "Jilted by McDaniels, Colts G.M. Stokes Rivalry With Patriots", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Years later, Mr. Long would reminisce about the first time he saw El Capitan, in 1970, and about that historic climb five years later.\n\n\u201cIf someone had told me, as I stood in the meadow after that first trip up to El Capitan, that I would someday climb it in one day, I would have laughed in his face,\u201d Mr. Long wrote. \u201cBut that was before I had met Jim Bridwell.\u201d\n\nJames Bridwell was born on July 29, 1944, in San Antonio. His father, Donald, was a pilot in World War II and later for Pan Am, and his mother, the former Miriam Boxwell, was a homemaker who occasionally painted. The family moved around when Jim was young, spending time in Japan, New York and Connecticut.\n\nMr. Bridwell\u2019s wife of 45 years, Peggy, said his interest in mountaineering started with birds.\n\n\u201cHe got into climbing because he was fascinated by birds of prey,\u201d she said, \u201cand he used to climb to watch their habitat and flight patterns.\u201d\n\nHe began mountaineering around 1965, during what is sometimes called the golden age of climbing at Yosemite, when climbers like Mr. Robbins (who died last year) and Warren Harding were blazing vertical trails up rock faces once thought impossible to master. Exposure to those fabled mountaineers made Mr. Bridwell a leader for the next generation.", "title": "Jim Bridwell, Mountaineering Maverick, Is Dead at 73", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Years later, Mr. Long would reminisce about the first time he saw El Capitan, in 1970, and about that historic climb five years later.\n\n\u201cIf someone had told me, as I stood in the meadow after that first trip up to El Capitan, that I would someday climb it in one day, I would have laughed in his face,\u201d Mr. Long wrote. \u201cBut that was before I had met Jim Bridwell.\u201d\n\nJames Bridwell was born on July 29, 1944, in San Antonio. His father, Donald, was a pilot in World War II and later for Pan Am, and his mother, the former Miriam Boxwell, was a homemaker who occasionally painted. The family moved around when Jim was young, spending time in Japan, New York and Connecticut.\n\nMr. Bridwell\u2019s wife of 45 years, Peggy, said his interest in mountaineering started with birds.\n\n\u201cHe got into climbing because he was fascinated by birds of prey,\u201d she said, \u201cand he used to climb to watch their habitat and flight patterns.\u201d\n\nHe began mountaineering around 1965, during what is sometimes called the golden age of climbing at Yosemite, when climbers like Mr. Robbins (who died last year) and Warren Harding were blazing vertical trails up rock faces once thought impossible to master. Exposure to those fabled mountaineers made Mr. Bridwell a leader for the next generation.", "title": "Jim Bridwell, Mountaineering Maverick, Is Dead at 73", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "He\u2019s going to speak with the ushers, too. \u201cThey\u2019re like 60 years old, up to 80. They come out and tell you, \u201c\u2018You\u2019ve got to sit down!\u2019 and \u2018You can\u2019t do this.\u2019 \u2018You can\u2019t do that.\u2019 It\u2019s like having a schoolteacher.\u201d Mr. Buffett wants his ushers to understand that this show is more like \u201cRocky Horror\u201d than a conventional musical. \u201cThere\u2019s an opportunity here to give people a really great, full experience,\u201d he told them. \u201cThey\u2019ve paid money to be here. They deserve it.\u201d\n\nRecently, he went to the Springsteen show on Broadway, where ushers double as military snipers, ready to do whatever is necessary to shut down phone usage or singing along. Onstage, Mr. Springsteen, whose working class anthems made him rich, revealed that he\u2019d never been inside a factory. It\u2019s an easy thing to admit to people who paid up to $850 for a seat. They\u2019d assumed the factory thing was a metaphor anyway.\n\nMr. Buffett may no longer be Jimmy Buffett, but at one time he was. Most of the songs he\u2019s famous for aren\u2019t about love. They\u2019re seemingly simple songs about how we spend our lives. But listen closer. \u201cA Pirate Looks at Forty\u201d is about a middle-age crisis wherein a man\u2019s skills become obsolete before he\u2019s ready to retire. \u201cI have been drunk now for over two weeks\u201d seems like a party lyric but it\u2019s not \u2014 it\u2019s a crushing one. \u201cCheeseburger in Paradise,\u201d which he wrote after a precarious sailing trip, is about a cheeseburger, plain and simple, with a euphoric bridge that is just a list of condiments he loves. Where are our simple pleasures now, it asks without asking? Why has everything become so complicated? Why is life filled with so many things we don\u2019t want and so few things we do?\n\nBut \u201cIt\u2019s 5 o\u2019Clock Somewhere\u201d \u2014 a song he didn\u2019t write but recorded with Alan Jackson and took out on tour \u2014 man, that one\u2019s the real heartbreaker. Take away the jaunty island beat and you\u2019ll find a song about a man who is so miserable that he can\u2019t bring himself to return to work from his lunch break. \u201cI\u2019m getting paid by the hour, and older by the minute,\u201d it goes. \u201cMy boss just pushed me over the limit.\u201d The guy hasn\u2019t taken a vacation day in a year. He knows that there will be consequences tomorrow, but he doesn\u2019t care. He can\u2019t face it for another afternoon. Just keep pouring those Hurricanes.\n\nHas any pop star identified this particular strain of existential crisis better than Mr. Buffett? Who has been such a dedicated balladeer of the T.G.I.F. class? Who has been such a folk hero of workaday boredom and 9 to 5 drudgery? The knowledge that if we allow ourselves to think hard enough about our lives we will realize that they are spent in service of making someone else rich while we merely scrape by? Mr. Buffett may be rich, but he wasn\u2019t always. He has grappled with dark thoughts about time and existence. He saw from the stage that we had, too. So he gave language to it: There has to be something more to this. There has to be a way to exist that isn\u2019t quite so compromised. The ocean is often so far away. But a T-shirt that says \u201cNo Shoes No Shirt No Problem?\u201d That you can take with you.\n\nYou know, he could be rewatching \u201cGame of Thrones,\u201d like he wants to, enjoying it even more now that he can tell the characters apart. He could be watching \u201cNarcos,\u201d which he loves, and vaping all day. He could be flying from house to house and kayaking and surfing. He could never work another day in his life and still dive like Scrooge McDuck into a swimming pool full of money. He could splash his name across the marquee of the Marquis and never care for a second if the musical you got was something that felt real \u2014 that really delivered escape. This is America, and poor-quality licensed products are our birthright.\n\nBut Mr. Buffett won\u2019t give you that. He still remembers who got him here. He still shares the existential worry of how to spend a day. He protects your experience of the lifestyle he sells in a way that someone living that lifestyle should be incapable of. Look beyond the MAMA NEEDS SOME WINE sign in the Margaritaville gift shop. Look beyond the beer cozy that says \u201cFins to the left, fins to the right.\u201d This is no longer a business. This is a cause. Can you hear its anthem? You can hear the Parrotheads singing it from beneath their feathers; you can hear it in their hums.\n\nMr. Buffett arrived at the rehearsal space. He spotted Mr. Nolan and complimented him on his tan.", "title": "Jimmy Buffett Does Not Live the Jimmy Buffett Lifestyle", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night\u2019s highlights that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you\u2019re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.\n\nStanding Up for Students\n\nJimmy Kimmel on Wednesday attacked conspiracy theorists who have suggested that students at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla. \u2014 where a gunman killed 17 people last week \u2014 might be actors.\n\n\u201cI want you to consider this, especially if you are a Trump supporter or a member of the N.R.A. Do you really think these kids, these teenagers who spoke out after a shooting at their school, are actors who are part of some kind of deep-state, left-wing conspiracy? If the answer is \u2018Yes, I do believe that,\u2019 I have some bad news for you: You\u2019re crazy. You\u2019re a crazy person. Your brain is not functioning, and I\u2019m worried about you.\u201d \u2014 JIMMY KIMMEL\n\nKimmel called on his viewers to stand up for established facts.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t just sit there and let these scumbags spread these lies about these kids.\u201d \u2014 JIMMY KIMMEL\n\nColbert Chimes In\n\nStephen Colbert also expressed dismay at the so-called \u201ccrisis actors\u201d theory.\n\n\u201cThat is wrong on a lot of levels. Not just because it diminishes the tragedy of what these kids experienced, but it also gives theater majors false hope that someday they\u2019ll get jobs. I speak from experience here.\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nAnd Colbert attacked Florida lawmakers for refusing to debate a gun control bill, even after students from Stoneman Douglas showed up at the legislative session.\n\n\u201cWith Parkland students watching from the gallery, State House members voted down a motion to debate an existing bill that would ban assault weapons and large-capacity ammunition magazines. So what legislation did they focus on instead? A bill that declares porn dangerous. What do you have against teenagers? First you won\u2019t do anything about guns, now you\u2019re taking away their porn. [Pretends to knock on door] \u2018What are you doing in there? You better be loading a gun, young man!\u2019 \u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nThe Punchiest Punchlines (Russia Edition)\n\n\u201cCurling should be the cleanest event \u2014 the entire sport is sweeping. In fact, the only thing cleaner than the ice is the seats, because no one\u2019s watching.\u201d \u2014 TREVOR NOAH, responding to news that a Russian curler at the Olympics had been accused of doping\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s not how investigations work. That\u2019s like saying, \u2018I\u2019m the new police chief. When I was running for police chief, I stabbed a guy \u2014 a bunch. Why didn\u2019t the old police chief stop me? There\u2019s your crime, O.K.? Stabbity-stabbity, stab-stab-stab.\u2019 \u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT, on a tweet by President Trump appearing to blame former President Barack Obama for Russian meddling in the 2016 election\n\nThe Bits Worth Watching\n\nTrump misspelled the name of his attorney general in a tweet, and James Corden didn\u2019t let him off easy.\n\nDonald Trump Jr., currently in India, said he was impressed that poor people in that country tended to have a \u201csmile on a face.\u201d Colbert created a Bollywood film \u201cstarring\u201d him to memorialize the comments.\n\nWhat We\u2019re Excited About on Thursday Night\n\nOprah Winfrey, the subject of recent presidential rumors, will sit down with Kimmel on Thursday.\n\nAlso, Check This Out\n\nPhoto\n\nA.O. Scott, one of our chief film critics, continues to reinvestigate Woody Allen\u2019s catalog in light of the #MeToo movement.", "title": "Jimmy Kimmel Attacks Conspiracy Theorists for Trying to Discredit Students", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.\n\n\u2018An Insult to Dogs and Laps\u2019\n\nJimmy Kimmel expressed ire over House Republicans\u2019 intention to release a secret memo related to the Russia investigation. He pointed out that Representative Devin Nunes, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, has reportedly developed a close relationship with the White House.\n\n\u201cDevin Nunes somehow still is in charge of this Russia investigation in the House, in spite of the fact that he recused himself from the investigation after he got caught sneaking to the White House to share information with the people he was supposed to be investigating. To call Devin Nunes Donald Trump\u2019s lap dog would be an insult to dogs and laps. He\u2019s not a lap dog. He\u2019s more of a retriever. \u2018Here boy, go write me a memo to smear the F.B.I.! Good, good boy!\u2019\u201d \u2014 JIMMY KIMMEL\n\nStephen Colbert, a dogged chronicler of the Russia investigation, said that it\u2019s all getting a little too complicated \u2014 and nowadays, there are juicier stories.\n\n\u201cNunes\u2019s memo supposedly paints a picture of how the F.B.I. and the Justice Department abused their authority to obtain a warrant to spy on a former Trump campaign adviser. Ugh, that sounds a little dry. Can\u2019t another porn star come forward about spanking the president? I mean, it\u2019s been over a week, daddy needs his juice.\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nTrump\u2019s Battle for Applause Continues\n\nPresident Trump tweeted on Thursday that his State of the Union address had been watched by more Americans than any such speech in American history. As Colbert pointed out, that\u2019s not true.\n\n\u201cLook, it doesn\u2019t matter how many people watched. But what does matter is that the president needs to lie about it \u2014 and then somehow get away with it. This is the new world we live in. So let me just say, right now, in advance, congratulations to President Trump on winning the Super Bowl.\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nThe president said on Thursday that congressional Democrats had not applauded at his State of the Union address when he mentioned the country\u2019s low unemployment rate among African-Americans. Colbert doesn\u2019t think the president can take credit for those statistics in the first place.\n\n\u201cYeah, you\u2019d think people would applaud \u2014 since that\u2019s all because of Obama.\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nThe Bits Worth Watching\n\nSeth Meyers and Kelly Clarkson went day drinking \u2014 hard.\n\nTo celebrate the Super Bowl, Kimmel invited football players to read tweets insulting them.\n\nEnjoy the Weekend\n\nWe\u2019ll be back here on Tuesday for another week of shows.\n\nAlso, Check This Out\n\nPhoto\n\nFebruary is Black History Month. He graduated from the University of Colorado Boulder.", "title": "Joanna Solazzo, David Fertig", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Mooyah is also trying to recruit untapped sources of talent. The company recently started a program to help franchisees expand their marketing efforts by hiring at-home parents and others who had not been in the labor force. The jobs are meant to appeal to people who might not be looking for traditional work: They do not require being at an office every day or having a traditional schedule. Mr. Mabry said that kind of flexibility made sense when filling full-time slots with experienced workers was harder than ever.\n\n\u201cWhy do I have to be pigeonholed into a particular r\u00e9sum\u00e9 or a particular experience?\u201d Mr. Mabry said of his recruitment approach. \u201cI\u2019m sure there is someone out there who can bring something different to the team. It\u2019s just having an open mind.\u201d\n\nMore companies are likely to adopt that kind of flexible approach as the labor market tightens. And there are other signs that companies are rethinking their approach to hiring. They are becoming more willing to consider candidates with criminal records, for example, or to waive educational requirements. The car retailer AutoNation said this week that it was no longer refusing to hire workers who tested positive for marijuana use \u2014 a sign of changing legal and societal norms, but also an indication that companies are rethinking hiring practices in a tight labor market.\n\n\u201cPeople who are marginally employable suddenly become highly employable in a period like this,\u201d said Joseph Brusuelas, chief economist of RSM, a financial consulting firm.\n\nThere were some notes of caution in Friday\u2019s report. The total number of hours worked \u2014 a measure that combines the number of jobs and the average hours worked on those jobs \u2014 fell slightly, a sign that demand for labor might not be as strong as the headline job-growth figures suggest. And the unemployment rate for African-Americans, a figure highlighted by Mr. Trump after it fell to its lowest recorded level in December, jumped nearly a full percentage point, to 7.7 percent. The unemployment rate for white Americans fell to 3.5 percent.\n\nBut despite such month-to-month fluctuations, economists say the tightening labor market is paying dividends to groups that were left behind by earlier stages of the recovery. Wages have risen most quickly in lower-paying industries in recent months, and employment gains have gone disproportionately to less-educated workers.\n\nCompanies including Walmart, Starbucks and Lowe\u2019s have also announced new benefits for hourly workers, such as paid time off to care for sick relatives and paid parental leave. And the number of Americans working part time because they can\u2019t find full-time work has fallen 15 percent in the past year.", "title": "Job and Wage Gains Deliver a Promising Start for the Year", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "That may simply be Girardi\u2019s nature. In his 10 years as the Yankees\u2019 manager, Girardi fastidiously protected his players from public criticism; one notable exception came last August when Girardi became exasperated with Sanchez\u2019s defensive shortcomings. He also tried to be as bland as possible in his daily meetings with the news media.\n\nBut Girardi, 53, also has aspirations of managing again and should be a prime candidate somewhere next season. Thus, there seems little point in publicly laying bare the shortcomings of a player you might soon be managing.\n\n\u201cWhen you hire somebody like Joe with the amount of success that he\u2019s had in the past, you know there\u2019s a very real possibility that at some point he may get back on the field, and we\u2019re fine with that,\u201d said Rob McGlarry, the MLB Network president.\n\nMcGlarry said that what made Girardi attractive for his network was not only his success with the Yankees, whom he led to the 2009 World Series title, but also that he has recently been in the dugout.\n\nStill, on the conference call a few hours before he was to make his on-air debut, Girardi delivered few insights.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
