Wilson made similar appearances with the Rangers in 2014 and 2015, but has given no indication that he plans to pursue a baseball career.", "title": "Joe Girardi Joins MLB Network as an Analyst", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "BERLIN \u2014 Johann Johannsson, an Icelandic composer who blended elements of electronic and classical music to create acclaimed soundtracks for films including \u201cThe Theory of Everything\u201d and \u201cArrival,\u201d died on Friday in Berlin. He was 48.\n\nHis death was confirmed by Rosalie Vos, who runs the European office of his management company, Redbird Music. The cause was being investigated.\n\nBest known for his movie soundtracks, Mr. Johannsson won a Golden Globe in 2015, as well as Grammy and Academy Award nominations, for his score for \u201cThe Theory of Everything\u201d (2014), James Marsh\u2019s film about the romance between the physicist Stephen Hawking (Eddie Redmayne, who won an Oscar for his performance) and his wife, Jane (Felicity Jones).\n\nIn an interview with The New York Times at the time of the film\u2019s release, Mr. Johannsson said he had wanted the soundtrack to \u201creflect the cosmology, the poetry of physics, and the way that the beauty of the logic and the mathematics of the universe are revealed.\u201d", "title": "Johann Johannsson, Award-Winning Movie Composer, Dies at 48", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "In Joseph Conrad\u2019s great short story, \u201cThe Secret Sharer,\u201d the captain of a ship comes to harbor a secret. A murderer named Leggatt slips on board in the night, and the captain, without exactly knowing why, chooses to hide him in his cabin. Desperate to save the man, and safeguard his deception, the captain almost drives the ship aground as he steers it close enough to shore for the killer to plunge into the water and escape.\n\nThe captain, new to the ship, asks himself a question at the outset: \u201cI wondered how far I should turn out faithful to that ideal conception of one\u2019s own personality every man sets up for himself secretly.\u201d Yet, faced by events that seem to awaken some personal demon, he is unmoored. \u201cIt was, in the night, as though I had been faced by my own reflection in the depths of a somber and immense mirror.\u201d\n\nWhat does the captain see reflected that leads him to an almost fatal compromise? It could be a personal memory of some act of violence; it could be Leggatt\u2019s desperate humanity; it could even be that he draws this doppelg\u00e4nger out of his subconscious, an apparition, as he anxiously embarks on a ship to which he is a stranger, with a crew he does not know.\n\nI have been thinking of \u201cThe Secret Sharer\u201d as I contemplate the American carnage of the Trump administration after 13 months. Everybody who serves President Trump is faced with his or her \u201cown reflection in the depths of a somber and immense mirror.\u201d Everyone is compromised, whether fatally or not. How could it be otherwise serving a man who does not know the difference between reality and make-believe?", "title": "Opinion | John F. Kelly, Secret Sharer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "As his entertainment career ebbed, Mr. Gavin became increasingly involved in inter-American political affairs. In the 1960s and early \u203270s, he was a special adviser to the secretary general of the Organization of American States, which fosters democracy and regional security. He also undertook assignments promoting American and Latin American film production for the Alliance for Progress, established by President John F. Kennedy.\n\nMr. Gavin was president of the Screen Actors Guild from 1971 to 1973.\n\nHe was named ambassador to Mexico when Ronald Reagan, a like-minded conservative Republican who had also been president of the actors guild, entered the White House in 1981. Mr. Gavin had been active in Reagan\u2019s 1980 presidential campaign.\n\nAmid complaints from veteran diplomats that American embassies were still being turned over to financial backers and unqualified amateurs, the selection of an actor and friend of the president for one of the nation\u2019s most sensitive diplomatic posts was met with dismay in Mexico. Officials there sardonically jested about sending the comedian Cantinflas to Washington in retaliation.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Gavin was chiefly known in Mexico at the time as the tuxedoed spokesman for Bacardi rum in television commercials. He had some qualifications for the assignment, however. His mother was Mexican, he spoke fluent Spanish, he had extensive travel and business experience in Latin America and he had a degree in Latin American economic history from Stanford University.\n\nBut his tenure as ambassador in Mexico City, in charge of an embassy with more than 1,100 American and Mexican employees, became extremely contentious, despite a close relationship between President Reagan and President Jos\u00e9 L\u00f3pez Portillo and his successor, Miguel de la Madrid.\n\nMr. Gavin pressed Mexico to limit the flow of illicit drugs and illegal immigrants into the United States, and voiced Washington\u2019s belief that the revolutionary Sandinista government in Nicaragua posed dangers to the security of Mexico and Central America. Mexico was cool to many of Washington\u2019s concerns, even when Mr. Gavin relayed intelligence that implicated Mexican officials in corrupt activities.\n\nThe ambassador feuded regularly with the Mexican press. Journalists who tracked his movements called him an absentee envoy who had been out of Mexico for 142 of his first 438 days on the job, traveling frequently to Los Angeles. Mr. Gavin insisted that his trips were work-related.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Gavin was denounced by Mexican business and labor leaders, politicians and academics after he appeared in a 1982 ABC television special, \u201cMexico: Times of Crisis,\u201d in which he spoke of fears that Central America\u2019s economic and political troubles could \u201cspill over\u201d into Mexico. President L\u00f3pez Portillo did not comment, but there were wide demands for Mr. Gavin to resign or be declared persona non grata.\n\nIn 1984, after Mr. Gavin had a casual lunch with leaders of the opposition National Action Party, the head of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, which had long controlled political life in Mexico, accused him of interfering in Mexican politics and of insensitivity to Mexican traditions.\n\nAnd Mr. Gavin sometimes put his foot in his mouth. In 1985, after earthquakes toppled buildings and killed thousands in Mexico, he told reporters \u201cwe have been extremely fortunate\u201d that more Americans had not been killed or injured, a circumstance he explained by saying, \u201cThe types of hotels that fell down were not the types normally frequented by citizens of the United States.\u201d\n\nMr. Gavin quietly resigned in 1986 and went on to a successful business career. In retrospect, American business executives gave him high marks for fostering trade, and he was credited with helping Mexican businesses obtain foreign loans as the economy worsened.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe was born Juan Vincent Apablasa in Los Angeles on April 8, 1931, to Juan Apablasa and Delia Diana Pablos. His father was of Chilean descent, and his mother was from an influential family in Sonora, Mexico. His parents divorced when he was a young child; his mother later married Herald Golenor, who adopted him and changed his name to John Anthony Golenor. He attended St. John\u2019s Military Academy in Los Angeles and Villanova Preparatory School in Ojai, and graduated from Stanford in 1952.\n\nIn the Navy over the next three years, he served as an intelligence officer aboard the aircraft carrier Princeton in the Korean War theater and was an aide to Adm. Milton E. Miles in the Panama Canal Zone.\n\nAfter his ambassadorship, Mr. Gavin joined the Atlantic Richfield Company as a public relations executive. In 1987 he became president of Univisa Satellite Communications, which at the time was the parent of the Spanish-language television network Univision. He later became a director of various capital investment and financial consulting companies.\n\nHe married the actress Cicely Evans in 1957. They had two children, Cristina and Maria, and were divorced in 1965. He had been married to Ms. Towers since 1974. She had two children from a previous marriage, Michael and Maureen McGrath.\n\nBesides Ms. Towers, his survivors include his children and stepchildren and several grandchildren.", "title": "John Gavin, Actor and Ambassador to Mexico Under Reagan, Dies at 86", "authors": ["Robert D. Mcfadden"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "3. The opening ceremony of the 23rd Winter Olympics took place early Friday \u2014 but in the U.S., it won\u2019t be broadcast until 8 p.m. Eastern, on NBC. And for the next two and a half weeks, the company\u2019s platforms will air more than 2,400 hours of competition. Here\u2019s how to watch on a variety of platforms and devices.\n\nWe spoke with Song Seung-whan, the South Korean actor and theatrical creator who directed the ceremony. He sought to project a vision of unity and peace on the long-divided peninsula.\n\nThe political drama was hard to beat, as Kim Yo-jong, the sister of North Korea\u2019s leader, sat behind Vice President Mike Pence to watch. (She is fourth from left in the photo above.)", "title": "John Kelly, Winter Games, Flu: Your Friday Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Charles John Mahoney was born on June 20, 1940, in Blackpool, Lancashire, England, one of eight children of Reg Mahoney, a Manchester baker, and the former Margaret Watson. The family had been evacuated from Manchester to Blackpool when Manchester was a bombing target in World War II.\n\nAfter the war, John traveled to the United States to visit an older sister, who had married an American and lived in Illinois. He decided he wanted to make his life there when he grew up. In his late teens, he returned and earned his United States citizenship by serving in the Army.\n\nAfter his military service (during which, he said, he deliberately shed his British accent), he went to college, earning a bachelor\u2019s degree from Quincy College in Illinois (now Quincy University) and a master\u2019s in English from Western Illinois University in Macomb. He taught for a while, then settled into a life of office work. At 37, he was an editor at a medical journal and desperately dissatisfied.\n\n\u201cI had to do something or I was just going to be a miserable, complaining, crabby old man,\u201d Mr. Mahoney told NWI Times, an Indiana publication, in 2011. He had enjoyed doing children\u2019s theater long ago, so he decided to give acting a try. And, as he said in the same interview, \u201cThings fell into place.\u201d\n\nHe took acting classes at the St. Nicholas Theater in Chicago, where his teacher happened to be the playwright David Mamet. That same year he appeared in Mr. Mamet\u2019s \u201cThe Water Engine.\u201d One of his fellow cast members happened to be John Malkovich, then an unknown actor, who invited him to join the fledgling Steppenwolf Theater Company, founded in 1974.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Mahoney appeared in dozens of Steppenwolf productions, including \u201cOf Mice and Men,\u201d \u201cBorn Yesterday,\u201d \u201cThe Man Who Came to Dinner\u201d and \u201cThe Dresser.\u201d One production, \u201cOrphans,\u201d transferred to New York in 1985, and Mr. Mahoney found himself with a Theater World Award for his performance as a mobster kidnapped by small-time criminals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA year later he was starring at Lincoln Center, alongside Stockard Channing, Christopher Walken, Ben Stiller and Swoosie Kurtz, in \u201cThe House of Blue Leaves.\u201d\n\nHe returned to Broadway only once, in 2007. He played the frail character, known only as Old Man, who magically trades bodies with a healthy young woman in a revival of Craig Lucas\u2019s \u201cPrelude to a Kiss.\u201d\n\nMr. Mahoney never married. He told one interviewer that his love of theater was his family substitute \u2014 and another that he would never consider a romantic relationship after dealing with serious medical problems.\n\nHe is survived by a sister, Rita Sullivan.\n\nMr. Mahoney appeared in some 30 films, beginning in 1981 with \u201cHudson Taylor,\u201d a religious drama about a British missionary. The big-name directors soon came calling.\n\nFor Joel and Ethan Coen, he played an alcoholic Southern novelist in \u201cBarton Fink\u201d (1989) and a gruff newspaper editor in \u201cThe Hudsucker Proxy\u201d (1994).\n\nPhoto\n\nHe had a particularly good year in 1987 when Barry Levinson cast him as an aluminum-siding salesman in the highly praised \u201cTin Men,\u201d and he won a small but meaty part in Norman Jewison\u2019s \u201cMoonstruck\u201d as a silver-haired college professor who joins Olympia Dukakis for dinner at an Italian restaurant \u2014 and walks her home \u2014 after his student-age date had thrown a drink in his face.\n\nOther roles included Ione Skye\u2019s seemingly upstanding father in \u201cSay Anything\u201d (1989) and a Washington lobbyist in \u201cThe American President.\u201d\n\nAfter \u201cFrasier,\u201d he continued to work in television, making memorable appearances on the HBO drama series \u201cIn Treatment\u201d (2009) as an insomniac executive with deeper problems, and on the comedy \u201cHot in Cleveland\u201d (which also starred his \u201cFrasier\u201d co-star Jane Leeves) in a recurring role (2011-14) as Betty White\u2019s love interest.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis last screen appearance was in a 2015 episode of the British drama series \u201cFoyle\u2019s War,\u201d set in his childhood environment, 1940s England. He played a dying rich man \u2014 American, of course.\n\nMr. Mahoney was never fond of being interviewed. \u201cI would rather walk across broken glass,\u201d he told a reporter for The Chicago Tribune in 1996.\n\nHe was not crazy about Hollywood, either, and spent as much time as possible in Chicago, his adopted hometown, which he praised for its combination of culture and Midwestern friendliness.\n\n\u201cI can walk to all sorts of good places,\u201d he said, describing the restaurant scene in his longtime Oak Park neighborhood, \u201cwhere the waiters and waitresses don\u2019t want me to read their screenplays.\u201d", "title": "John Mahoney, Actor Best Known for \u2018Frasier,\u2019 Dies at 77", "authors": ["Anita Gates"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "John Perry Barlow, a former cowpoke, Republican politician and lyricist for the Grateful Dead whose affinity for wide open spaces and free expression transformed him into a leading defender of an unfettered internet, died on Wednesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 70.\n\nHis death was confirmed by the Electronic Frontier Foundation, which he helped found in San Francisco in 1990. No cause was given, but the organization said he had been ailing after a heart attack in 2015.\n\nAt his death, Mr. Barlow was a vice chairman of the foundation, which has been in the vanguard of legal challenges to government constraints on cyberspace \u2014 a term he helped popularize in 1990 to describe boundless digital telecommunications networks.\n\n\u201cThere are a lot of similarities between cyberspace and open space,\u201d Mr. Barlow, who was raised on his family\u2019s 22,000-acre cattle ranch in Wyoming, told People magazine in 1995. \u201cThere is a lot of room to define yourself. You can literally make yourself up.\u201d", "title": "John Perry Barlow, 70, Dies; Championed an Unfettered Internet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Swedish skip Nik Edin has won world championships and knows big game pressure. American skip John Shuster has been around the sport for a long time, including winning bronze with Pete Fenson\u2019s team at the 2006 Olympics.\n\nExpect these first couple ends (maybe more) to be wide open as both teams get a feel for the ice and calm their nerves. It should also be pointed out that Edin likes to play an open style of curling and pounce on opposition mistakes \u2014 the Americans haven\u2019t made many in their five-game winning streak.\n\n2nd End: Sweden Makes Shuster Pay for Miss\n\nWe\u2019re seeing some high-level curling from both sides. The Swedes packed the second end with exquisite shotmaking, and when John Shuster misfired on a double takeout with his last stone of the end, Nik Edin took advantage, scoring two for Sweden. Edin is widely regarded as the best skip in the world for a reason. Opponents pay for making mistakes against him.\n\nAlso, Ivanka Trump is here with a swarm of secret service personnel.\n\nDevin Heroux: Edin learned how to curl by watching past Canadian curling championship games on VHS tapes while growing up in Sweden. In fact, his favorite curler to watch was Kevin Martin. He studied his strategy and learned the game by watching tapes over and over.\n\nEdin moved his team to Canada two years ago for a year to practice in the curling-crazed nation and compete against the top teams there. His team is fully funded by the Swedish government to curl. This is their full-time job, to curl and win a gold medal at the Olympics.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n3rd End: Americans Tie Match, 2-2\n\nTyler George, the American vice skip who wears really ratty sneakers, made two outstanding shots to set up Shuster, who came through in a huge way: a double takeout on his last throw to score two for the Americans and tie the match. More chants of \u201cU-S-A!\u201d are filling this place.\n\nThroughout their run here, the members of the American team have given huge credit to Dr. Carly Anderson, who came on as U.S.A. Curling\u2019s sports psychologist after their dismal showing at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve had team meetings where we\u2019re kind of slumping, and she\u2019s just tough on us,\u201d Matt Hamilton said in an interview before the start of the Olympics. \u201cShe\u2019ll tell us, \u2018You guys have to pull your heads out of your butts!\u2019 She\u2019ll tell it how it is.\u201d\n\nAnderson has worked with the players in individual and group sessions. A huge emphasis, she said, has been developing strategies to help them execute in pressure situations. So far, so good.\n\nDevin Heroux: In this third end, it was all about placement of stones and getting the proper angles. Edin changed the end around by making a double and rolling perfectly. This is how precise the game has become. But a slight error by Edin on his last rock allowed Shuster a tough double takeout and he threw his rock perfectly to score two.\n\nSweden likes low-scoring battles. They wait for their opponents to crack. The USA has hung tough with teams throughout this Olympic competition. We\u2019ll see how Shuster and his team handle the added pressure of this game, though. Sweden is the top-ranked team in the world right now. USA has the ability to play a simple style of curling but can also complicate the game and draw opponents into making mistakes. Many curlers in the game say Shuster has the ability to single-handedly win a curling game because of his shotmaking brilliance. He\u2019ll need to do that today to propel the Americans to their first gold at the Olympics.\n\n4th End: Americans Steal a Point\n\n\u201cYep! Yep! Whoa! Whoa!\u201d This is the soundtrack being provided at the moment by the Americans, who are putting all sorts of pressure on the Swedes. After a measurement, the United States stole a point (Sweden had the hammer) to take their first lead of the match. This is heady stuff for John Shuster and his teammates. It sounds as if all of Duluth is here at Gangneung Curling Centre, and these people are screaming.", "title": "John Shuster and the U.S. Curling Team Win First Gold Medal", "authors": ["Scott Cacciola"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "But the move does mark a perilous entry into academe, something that Mr. Zorn had long resisted \u2014 and something that, more often than not, musicians of his cohort haven\u2019t had the opportunity to resist.\n\nWhen Mr. Zorn opened the Stone in 2005, he was seeking a respectful home for the ardent, unconditional music that his community of free improvisers had been making since the 1970s. (The music\u2019s roots actually coil back to the 1950s, when free jazz was born and John Cage helped lay some of the groundwork for minimalism).\n\nMost of the venues that welcomed these so-called creative musicians were dive bars and semiofficial studios or living spaces. Most could hardly stay afloat. The ones that could, like the Knitting Factory and Tonic, eventually scaled up, meaning they expected larger crowds that would patronize the bar.\n\nSo Mr. Zorn consulted Ela Troyano, a filmmaker who owns the building at Avenue C and East Second Street, and he opened a one-room venue on its ground floor. He paid rent with the revenue from monthly benefit concerts, philanthropic donations and album sales on his Tzadik label.\n\n\u201cTo have a space that\u2019s completely run and curated by musicians was unusual,\u201d said the guitarist Mary Halvorson, who moved to New York a few years before the Stone opened, and has played there regularly ever since. \u201cIt really gave musicians an opportunity to workshop new material, and also to try out things that they might not try normally,\u201d she added. \u201cYou really felt like the audience was there with you.\u201d\n\nLast Thursday, almost a dozen performers, varying widely in age and stature, took turns improvising in groups of two or three or four. Laurie Anderson and Laura Ortman played bright, arcing lines on their violins as the electronic musician Jad Atoui made slow, mushrooming palls underneath. Later, the guitarist Nels Cline and the pianist Sylvie Courvoisier joined Mr. Zorn for a short sortie. It began with a scraping, aggro spill, but then Ms. Courvoisier started hammering a high note with both hands, at top velocity but medium volume; she was seizing the room\u2019s ears, and thinning out the trio\u2019s sound. Mr. Zorn and Mr. Cline relaxed into a vigilant consensus behind her.\n\nAll along, no one in the room spoke a word.", "title": "John Zorn\u2019s Club the Stone Begins a New Life on the Other Side of Town", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJon Huntsman Sr., the son of a music teacher in the heart of the Idaho potato country who rose to become a billionaire industrialist and philanthropist in Utah and the father of that state\u2019s governor, died on Friday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 80.\n\nGary Chapman, a spokesman for the Huntsman Corporation, the specialty chemical company where Mr. Huntsman was executive chairman, confirmed the death but declined to give the cause. He had been ill for an extended period of time.\n\nIn early 1970s, Mr. Huntsman built a packaging company that created many of the first plastic plates, bowls and fast-food containers, including the plastic \u201cclamshell\u201d that held McDonald\u2019s Big Mac. After selling the company, he went on to found the Huntsman Corporation, an $8 billion multinational operation that produces chemicals used in everything from clothing to automobiles.\n\nHe also served in the Nixon administration and in 1988 ran unsuccessfully for governor in Utah.\n\nBut he became known as much for his philanthropy as for his business and political ambitions. In 1992, after both of his parents died of cancer and he, too, battled the disease, he created the Huntsman Cancer Institute at the University of Utah with a $10 million grant, and in the years since, he and his family donated more than $1.4 billion to cancer research.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe was a great entrepreneur and a real humanitarian,\u201d said Patrick Byrne, the chief executive and founder of Overstock.com, the online retailer based in Salt Lake City, and a three-time cancer survivor. \u201cHe made a ton of money, and he gave it away while he was alive.\u201d", "title": "Jon Huntsman Sr., Billionaire Businessman and Philanthropist, Dies at 80", "authors": ["Cade Metz"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAs you know, we made our position on Jerusalem clear and we view these final-status issues as needing to be negotiated among the parties on the basis of a final solution,\u201d Mr. Safadi said while sitting beside Mr. Tillerson. \u201cThe challenge is how to move forward and make sure it does not get worse.\u201d\n\nThe softer response may have partly resulted from the passage of several weeks\u2019 time, or the signing of the aid agreement. Or maybe it was because Mr. Pence had stood smiling behind President Trump when he made the announcement about Jerusalem, while Mr. Tillerson was nowhere to be seen. Or maybe it was because Mr. Tillerson was known to have successfully lobbied President Trump to only halve funding for the United Nations agency that provides aid to millions of Palestinian refugees instead of eliminating it altogether, as Ms. Haley and others in the White House were known to have advocated.\n\nThe relief agency underwrites schools and health clinics that serve hundreds of thousands of Palestinian refugees in Jordan.\n\nMr. Tillerson also made clear during his Jordan visit that he was not directly involved in the Trump administration\u2019s long-awaited Middle East peace plan between Israelis and Palestinians. While describing it as \u201cfairly well advanced,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said it was up to Mr. Trump to decide when to release the plan.\n\nJared Kushner, the president\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser, and Jason D. Greenblatt, Mr. Trump\u2019s special Middle East envoy, have been developing the plan, which has largely excluded Mr. Tillerson and the State Department. Palestinian leaders have in recent months refused to participate in talks about the plan to protest Mr. Trump\u2019s Jerusalem decision.\n\nNonetheless, Mr. Trump is expected to unveil the peace plan fairly soon.\n\n\u201cI have seen the elements of the plan that\u2019s been under development for a number of months,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said at a news conference in Jordan\u2019s Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Expatriates. \u201cI have consulted with them on the plan and identified areas that we feel need further work.\u201d\n\nBut he said the plan and the timing for its release were in Mr. Trump\u2019s hands.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019ll be up to the president to decide when he feels it\u2019s time and he\u2019s ready to put that plan forward,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said.", "title": "Jordan, a Pivotal Arab Ally, Gets More U.S. Aid Despite Rancor Over Jerusalem", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Joseph Polchinski, one of the most creative physicists of his generation, whose work helped lay the mathematical foundation for the controversial proposition that our universe is only one in an almost endless assemblage that cosmologists call the \u201cmultiverse,\u201d died on Friday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 63.\n\nHis death was announced by the University of California, Santa Barbara, where he was a longtime professor and a permanent member of the Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics. He had been treated for brain cancer since late 2015.\n\nDr. Polchinski was a giant force in the development of string theory, the ambitious attempt to achieve a \u201ctheory of everything,\u201d which envisions the fundamental particles of nature as tiny wriggling strings. The theory has brought forth ideas and calculations that have opened new fields of study and new visions of a universe that is weirder and richer than astronomers had dreamed.\n\nIn recent years, Dr. Polchinski\u2019s investigation of black holes, the Einsteinian monsters that gobble light and everything else, uncovered a mystery that calls into question what scientists thought they understood about how these objects work. The Firewall Paradox, as he and his collaborators called it, led to a firestorm of speculation about the nature of gravity and space-time.", "title": "Joseph Polchinski, 63, Leading Theorist on Multiple Universes, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The Colts went on to add several other Twitter posts about the coach\u2019s imminent signing, including one announcing a time for an introductory news conference on Wednesday.\n\nBut hours later, Adam Schefter of ESPN first reported that McDaniels, 41, had backed out of the agreement, and the Colts issued a statement at 8:35 p.m. confirming the decision.\n\n\u201cAfter agreeing to contract terms to become the Indianapolis Colts\u2019 new head coach, New England Patriots assistant coach Josh McDaniels this evening informed us that he would not be joining our team,\u201d the statement said. \u201cAlthough we are surprised and disappointed, we will resume our head coaching search immediately and find the right fit to lead our team and organization on and off the field.\u201d\n\nThe situation is similar to the decision by Bill Belichick, the Patriots\u2019 current head coach, in 2000 when he was promoted to be head coach of the Jets after Bill Parcells stepped down. But at his introductory news conference, Belichick said that he had decided not to take the job. Belichick\u2019s reversal had the added element of it happening in front of reporters, and it quickly became famous for his hastily written resignation letter, which was reported to have said simply, \u201cI resign as the HC of the NYJ.\u201d\n\nBelichick was subsequently named the coach of the Patriots and has been with the team since, leading them to eight Super Bowl appearances and five championships.", "title": "Josh McDaniels Will Stay With Patriots After Spurning Colts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "You spent months in Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria hit in October, distributing millions of cooked meals. Your charity, World Central Kitchen, generally stays in disaster zones for only a short period of time. What was it about Puerto Rico that moved you to stay for so long? Many people on the island rely on electric kitchens \u2014 even if you gave them dry beans and rice, they wouldn\u2019t be able to cook it. On top of that, many of them barely had water for drinking \u2014 imagine for cooking. We thought we were going to provide relief for a few days until everything came back to normal. But then I realized that the problem was much bigger than that and that the need was only going to become bigger, not smaller.\n\nYou lost 25 pounds during your time there, which is pretty surprising considering you were turning out tens of thousands of meals a day. You couldn\u2019t take a couple of those meals for yourself? There was no time.\n\nWas it important to you, as a chef, that you served not just any food but food that tasted good? Of course you wouldn\u2019t serve something bad. But you need to be in those situations to understand the meaning of a decent hot plate of food.\n\nI\u2019ve read multiple references to your making sure that the sandwiches you served contained a ton of mayo. What was that about? Mayo, remember, is fat. It\u2019s calories, No. 1; No. 2, it\u2019s moisture. People didn\u2019t have a lot of water to drink in Puerto Rico. So I had to give them a sandwich that was full of calories and moist. If it was not moist, it was harder to eat that sandwich.", "title": "Jos\u00e9 Andr\u00e9s Fights Starvation With Mayo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s absurd,\u201d said Syed Shujaat Bukhari, one of Kashmir\u2019s most senior journalists. \u201cKamran\u2019s a genuine journalist, and it\u2019s not a government agency\u2019s business to tell a journalist what to report or not report.\u201d\n\nFor decades, Kashmir has been the subject of a brutal territorial dispute between India, which controls much of the territory, and Pakistan. It lies right on the border, and tens of thousands of people have died here among the ruggedly beautiful mountain slopes and endless apple orchards.\n\nThe conflict ebbs and flows, but in the past few years, Mr. Bukhari said, the predominant feelings among many young Kashmiris have hardened from \u201canti-India to hate India.\u201d\n\nMr. Yousuf, who hails from a small, apple-growing town, dropped out of college to document Kashmir\u2019s conflict. He is tall and thin, with thick black hair and a black goatee on a cherubic face. \u201cHungry\u201d is the first word his friends use to describe him.\n\nHe could often be seen racing around on his grandfather\u2019s motorbike, backpack stuffed with camera gear, business cards, notepads and wires, getting to the action often before anyone else. He is known for his pictures of fiery riots, militant funerals and smashed-up cars.", "title": "Journalist or Terrorist? Kashmir Photographer Is Jailed, Pending Answer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "AT&T has argued that the Justice Department has unfairly singled out its proposed merger with Time Warner partly to stay in favor with the White House. President Trump has been a vocal critic of Time Warner\u2019s news network, CNN, and said before the election that the deal should be stopped.\n\nThe bigger picture\n\nCecilia Kang of the NYT:\n\nThe decision puts a crimp in AT&T\u2019s defense for its $85 billion proposed merger with Time Warner. And it is a big win for the Justice Department, which would like to avoid attention on the role of politics in its decision to stop the deal. The merger would transform the media landscape by combining a television and movie giant with one of the nation\u2019s biggest media distributors.\n\nThe trial is set to begin on March 19.\n\n\n\nExpect the revolution imminently.\n\nFor the first time, and after much protest, public companies must report their employees\u2019 median pay and compare it with that of the chief executive. The Dodd-Frank Act, passed nearly eight years ago, required the disclosure, and firms are now disclosing it in proxy reports for 2017.\n\nCompanies, lobbyists and some compensation experts spent years criticizing the rule, arguing that it revealed little about pay trends and was of little use to shareholders. The Institute for Policy Studies, a liberal-leaning think tank, on Tuesday noted that Honeywell was the first United States corporation to release the ratio. The company\u2019s C.E.O., Darius Adamczyk, had a total pay package of $16.8 million in 2017, which was 333 times the pay of the median employee.\n\nThe rule allows certain companies to exclude some foreign employees from the calculation of the ratio. Honeywell excluded workers from several countries where pay is most likely lower than in the United States. \u201cThe 333:1 ratio that Honeywell is reporting most likely would be even wider if Honeywell took all its workers into account,\u201d the Institute said.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nBillionaire investor Steven A. Cohen lost a bid to seal a sex discrimination lawsuit against his investment firm.\n\nA federal judge in Manhattan, in a brief order, rejected a motion filed by lawyers for Mr. Cohen and his firm, Point72 Asset Management, to temporarily seal a complaint filed last week by Lauren Bonner, an employee of the firm. Mr. Cohen\u2019s lawyer had asked the judge to seal the lawsuit, which alleges the firm underpays female employees and fosters a hostile workplace for women, pending the resolution of another motion to push the matter into arbitration.\n\nJudge Analisa Torres of Federal District Court in Manhattan said the request to seal the entire complaint was \u201cnot narrowly tailored\u201d and was inconsistent with the \u201cpresumption of public access\u201d to court records.\n\nLawyers for Mr. Cohen had sought to seal the order because it contained details of other employees\u2019 compensation packages. The lawsuit also detailed a testosterone-fueled \u201cboys\u2019 club\u201d atmosphere in which men commented frequently on women\u2019s bodies and belittled their abilities.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Matthew Goldstein\n\nPhoto\n\nHow financial firms could set new rules for gun sales\n\nAndrew writes:\n\nMy latest column, on how banks and credit card companies could restrict support of gun sales in the wake of last week\u2019s school shooting, has stirred up chatter in the business world. I\u2019ve heard from people throughout corporate America overnight since it was published. Many said privately that they want to look at what they can do.\n\nMore from the column:\n\nThere is precedent for credit card issuers to ban the purchase of completely legal products. Just this month, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Bank of America banned the use of their cards to buy Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies. To be clear: Those three banks won\u2019t let you use your credit card to buy Bitcoin, but they will happily let you use it to buy an AR-15-style semiautomatic rifle \u2014 the same kind of gun used in mass shootings in Parkland; Newtown, Conn.; San Bernardino, Calif.; Las Vegas; and Sutherland Springs, Tex.\n\nElsewhere in gun regulation: President Trump expressed some openness to tightening background checks.\n\nNow that the debt ceiling is no longer an immediate issue...\n\nThe United States Treasury Department is flooding the market with debt. On Tuesday, the government sold $179 billion worth of debt.\n\nBloomberg reports:\n\n\u201cConcerns about the U.S. borrowing cap had forced the Treasury to trim the total amount of bills it had outstanding, but that\u2019s no longer a problem and the government is now busy ramping up issuance. Financing estimates from January show that the Treasury expects to issue $441 billion in net marketable debt in the current quarter and the bulk of that is likely to be in the short-term market.\u201d\n\nHow will corporate America spend its tax windfall?\n\nThat\u2019s been a regular question since the tax overhaul was signed into law last year. Analysts at Goldman Sachs in a note over the weekend shed some light on the answer.\n\n\u2022 \u201cCompanies have pointed to a modest increase in investment as one destination for the incremental cash flow from tax reform. Consensus estimates for 2018 capex have increased by $17 billion (3 percent) since the passage of tax reform.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Last month 39 S.&P. 500 companies increased their dividend, while for the first since 2012 no companies cut their payments.\n\n\u2022 Buying back shares remains a priority of companies, Goldman writes. Over the past 2 \u00bd months, S.&P. 500 firms have announced $171 billion of buybacks, $67 billion of which has come this year, a 22% increase from the same period in 2017.\n\nIn the same note, Goldman also took a closer look at this earnings season.\n\nBy many measures, corporate earnings are the strongest they have been in the past decade. Goldman points out:\n\n\u2022 Companies in the S.&P. 500 are set to report that profit grew 15 percent last quarter. That\u2019s the fastest pace since 2011.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The percentage of companies beating estimates is at its highest level since 2010. The percentage beating sales forecast is at its highest since 2004.\n\nBut the stock reaction to S.&P. 500 companies either beating or missing expectations \u201chas been muted relative to history.\u201d\n\nThe reason? Investors are more focused on tax reform and earnings forecasts for 2018, Goldman writes. Analysts have raised their 2018 earnings estimates for companies in the S.&P. 500 by 7 percent so far this year.\n\nSome context\n\nHigher profit margins because of the lower corporate tax rate are driving much of the increase in this year\u2019s earnings forecast. A point that becomes clearer by looking at 2018 sales estimates. Analysts have increased their revenue forecasts by only one percentage point and much of that increase comes from higher oil prices boosting forecasts for energy companies.\n\nLong Blockchain is back in the news\n\nRemember when the company said that it was changing its name from Long Island Iced Tea and shift its corporate focus to virtual currencies?\n\nWell, new developments have come up:\n\n\u2022 Long Blockchain has named a new C.E.O., Shamyl Malik.\n\n\u2022 It plans to spin off its beverage division into the publicly traded Long Island Brand Beverages by June 30, and the company\u2019s last C.E.O., Philip Thomas, will be on the new business\u2019 board.\n\n\u2022 And last week, Nasdaq informed Long Blockchain that it planned to delist the company because its stock price had traded too low. Long Blockchain\u2019s market cap as of this morning was $31.9 million, below Nasdaq\u2019s threshold, after shares in the company tumbled amid the great crypto crash of early 2018. The company is appealing.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nWalmart\u2019s earnings miss, by the numbers\n\nHere\u2019s why the company\u2019s shares are down 10percent \u2014 their biggest fall since 2015 \u2014 after its fourth-quarter earnings report:\n\n\u2022 The company earned $1.33 a share, while analysts had expected $1.37.\n\n\u2022 Operating income fell 28 percent, to $4.5 billion, thanks to charges tied to the closing of Sam\u2019s Club stores.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 E-commerce sales rose 23 percent during the quarter, a slower pace than in previous quarters.\n\n\u2022 Full-year sales growth expectations went down by close to half, to 1.5 percent to 2 percent, in part because of Sam\u2019s Club and a curb on the sales of tobacco products.\n\nWhat the company\u2019s chief, Doug McMillon, said:\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re making real progress putting our unique assets to work to serve customers in all the ways they want to shop.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nHow Facebook ended up quoted by Trump and apologizing to Mueller\n\nDays after Rob Goldman, its vice president of advertising, tried to clear up misconceptions about the company\u2019s role in the 2016 presidential election, Facebook still finds itself in hot water. President Trump took the tweets as proof that Russia didn\u2019t try to help him win, while critics said they contradicted Robert Mueller\u2019s indictment.\n\nMr. Goldman apologized in an internal Facebook post. But his tweets \u2014 which contained inaccuracies \u2014 suggested that Facebook executives still don\u2019t understand how central the company was to Russia\u2019s misinformation campaign, according to Nicholas Thomson of Wired.\n\nMore from Kevin Roose of the NYT:\n\nIn real-world terms, a part of Facebook still sees itself as the bank that got robbed, rather than the architect who designed a bank with no safes, and no alarms or locks on the doors, and then acted surprised when burglars struck.\n\nJosh Hendler, the former head of tech for the Democratic National Committee, told the WSJ, \u201cIt was an almost perfect example of Silicon Valley overconfidence and lack of sophistication when it comes to politics.\u201d\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 One sign of how highly Google and Facebook value A.I.: The researchers sit near their C.E.O.s. Broadcom has said a higher NXP bid would be a deal-breaker (as of this morning, however, Michael hears that it isn\u2019t clear whether it will walk away).\n\nThe new offer may have come at an opportune time: I.S.S., the influential proxy adviser, recommended that Qualcomm shareholders vote for four of Broadcom\u2019s six board nominees. (But that too falls short of Broadcom\u2019s goals. The fifth-biggest U.S. box office opening ever, not adjusted for inflation. An estimated $387 million in sales worldwide. How would its immigration policies work if the country\u2019s ruler says, \u201cIn times of crisis, the wise build bridges?\u201d Does Wakanda have its own blockchain technology?\n\nPhoto\n\nVirtual money, real violence\n\nInvestors have been held hostage until they paid Bitcoin or Ether ransoms worth millions of dollars, as criminals increasingly target at the crypto-rich. The worst part: There\u2019s no way to halt or reverse a Bitcoin transfer.\n\nSolutions discussed at a recent conference included hiring security, setting up \u201cduress wallets\u201d to fool hostage takers, and keeping Bitcoin fortunes secret.\n\nElsewhere in virtual currencies: China\u2019s crackdown on crypto hasn\u2019t dented investor enthusiasm there. Prime Shipping Foundation, which struck the first freight deal settled in Bitcoin, plans an initial coin offering And retail investors would suffer most if the digital money markets collapsed, according to S. & P. Global Ratings.\n\nWhere Bitcoin is today: About $11,490, according to CoinMarketCap.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 Mark Carney of the Bank of England says Bitcoin has failed as a currency. Preska, of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, ruled that the estate of the businessman, Paul Leffmann, had failed to show that he had been forced to sell the painting under duress after he fled the Nazis.\n\nIn the original lawsuit filed in September 2016, lawyers representing the great-grandniece, Laurel Zuckerman, administrator of the estate, said that Mr. Leffmann had been forced to sell his home and businesses in Cologne, Germany, before he fled with his wife, Alice, to Italy in 1937, as conditions in Europe deteriorated.\n\nThe painting was sold in 1938, before the Leffmanns moved on to Switzerland and finally to Brazil.\n\nThe lawsuit argued that the sale was made under duress to the Paris art dealers Hugo Perls, a collector of Picasso\u2019s work, and Paul Rosenberg, Picasso\u2019s dealer, for $13,200.\n\nA year later, the painting was lent to the Museum of Modern Art with an insured value of $18,000, and in 1941, Thelma Chrysler Foy acquired the painting through New York\u2019s Knoedler Gallery for $22,500 \u2014 both values were evidence, the estate argued, that the 1938 sale had been at a discount. My stepmom refuses to let me eat in her car. I understand: Her seats are white, and I am a messy eater. But she recently installed a dog-proof seat cover for the entire back seat. When the dog uses it, he leaves it covered in hair and dirt. No one but me and the dog ever sits there. But she still refuses to let me eat in the car, even on the cover specifically designed to protect the seat! Can you please order her to let me eat in her car?\n\nThe court appreciates the self-knowledge you display in recognizing that teenagers are disgusting eaters and, in terms of mouth smacks and food drools, little more than animals. But I still say: \u201cmore.\u201d It\u2019s impossible to imagine that you slobber as much as a dog does, and furthermore, your paws aren\u2019t covered in feces. Not only is your stepmom\u2019s car seat safe from your mess, but also I detest clich\u00e9, and thus I order her: Don\u2019t make your stepdaughter sit with the dog and also starve her! My girlfriend, Sarah, began calling it \u201csquirrel friend.\u201d More squirrels joined him. They\u2019re noisy; I want to clear the nest. Sarah wants me to let \u201csquirrel friend\u201d stay. I think she really just wants me to get a cat.\n\nAs this is your apartment, it\u2019s your right to clear the nest. Once, like Sarah, I was under the delusion that squirrels were \u201cfriends.\u201d I let one scamper up my leg to a proffered nut; then I saw up close its crooked yellow teeth and dead eyes. And for this reason I order you to let the nest be. Shoving your hand into a squirrel nest will only result in you succumbing to unimaginably gross biting. Get the cat instead! Either its presence will drive them away, or you get to enjoy watching a cat be humiliated. I say \u201cLauren\u201d like \u201cLawrence.\u201d She says \u201cLaura\u201d like \u201cLara.\u201d A complication: She is named after her mother, and they both pronounce it this way! I am not named after anyone. I\u2019m not asking you to order Laura to change her pronunciation. But I would like to know, officially, who is correct and who is living a lie.\n\nWell, Laura is getting an order anyway: Stop saying your name wrong. They are different names! Laura/Laurel/Lauren all derive from the Latin \u201claurus,\u201d meaning the laurel tree, whose leaves were awarded in victory \u2014 for, say, getting a fake newspaper judge to side with you (congrats). A day of clashes between the group and counterprotesters grew increasingly violent, resulting in the death of a woman when a man drove a car into a crowd of counterprotesters.\n\nAfter her death, the City Council voted to cover the two Confederate statues out of respect. Investigators found diary writings referring to an \u201cOperation Flash\u201d and a purple index card that read, \u201cUnder the full moon the small ones will know terror.\u201d\n\nThe criminal complaint filed in conjunction with the brothers\u2019 arrest last Thursday accused Mr. Toro of paying two students from Harlem Prep High School, where he was teaching at the time, $50 an hour to come to his apartment in the Bronx and take apart fireworks in order to collect their explosive powder.\n\nJudge Cott said Mr. Toro \u201cis not someone I am comfortable releasing to the community at this time.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe complaint, which Ms. Hanft revisited and fleshed out at Wednesday\u2019s bail hearing, said the brothers were arrested with more than 32 pounds of explosive ingredients, from an iron oxide to confectioner\u2019s sugar, which can be used as explosive fuel. The materials were stored in a closet of the apartment they shared with their mother, Carmen Melendez.\n\n\u201cThis is a defendant who had a cache of weapons in his apartment,\u201d Ms. Hanft said, describing a \u201cgrocery list\u201d of explosive ingredients, including incendiary powder kept in glass jars in quantities that could, if detonated, cause \u201can explosion sufficient to blow off a limb or body part.\u201d\n\nMs. Hanft said investigators also seized several boxes of fireworks, bullets, a magnesium strip that can serve as a fuse when lit, metal ball bearings and a container of \u201cimprovised napalm,\u201d consisting of gasoline and Styrofoam, found sitting on the apartment fire escape.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Their family members, including Ms. Melendez, all declined to comment after the hearing.", "title": "Judge Rejects Bail for Bomb-Making Suspect", "authors": ["Sean Piccoli"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "A federal judge in New York tossed out a sweeping lawsuit Monday that sought to make marijuana legal under federal law, ruling that the plaintiffs had failed to take the necessary first step of asking the Drug Enforcement Administration to remove cannabis from its list of dangerous substances.\n\nThe ruling by the judge, Alvin K. Hellerstein of Federal District Court in Manhattan, was a stinging defeat for the plaintiffs \u2014 among them a former professional football player who owns a company that sells pot-based pain relievers, a 12-year-old girl who treats her chronic epilepsy with medical marijuana and a nonprofit group that works on behalf of minorities in the marijuana industry.\n\nThough several courts have ruled in the past against similar litigation, the suit dismissed on Monday was passing through the courts as the Trump administration reversed an Obama-era policy and, in January, encouraged federal prosecutors to go after marijuana sellers, even in states that have legalized the drug, imperiling the viability of the country\u2019s multibillion-dollar pot industry.\n\nThe suit, filed in July, employed some novel legal arguments, including a claim that the country\u2019s marijuana laws have traditionally discriminated against minorities and have long precluded people who use pot for their illnesses from boarding airplanes, which are regulated by the federal government.", "title": "Judge Rejects Lawsuit Seeking to Legalize Marijuana Nationwide", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Because the state\u2019s bail law does not require judges to determine whether defendants can in fact pay the bail imposed on them, unaffordable amounts are often set. Justice Rosa said that \u201cpeople are being treated differently and unfairly based upon their indigent status\u201d \u2014 which, she added, violated the Constitution\u2019s guarantees of equal protection and due process.\n\nCourts in California, Massachusetts and Texas have all made similar rulings, and over the years, the United States Supreme Court has held that poor defendants cannot be penalized for lacking the ability to pay for things like fines, trial transcripts and restitution judgments. But Justice Rosa\u2019s decision was the first in New York State to explicitly point out the constitutional inequities that indigent defendants face when they cannot pay their bail.\n\nWhile her ruling did not strike down the state\u2019s bail law, it did set a precedent that other courts might follow, especially as comparable cases come up and are eventually considered by appellate judges.\n\n\u201cThe power of this ruling is the message it sends out,\u201d said Donna Lieberman, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, which filed a motion on behalf of Mr. Kunkeli that led to Justice Rosa\u2019s decision. \u201cThere is a move afoot not just in the courts, but in the political arena to overhaul the way bail is utilized in our criminal justice system.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn January, for example, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat, proposed curtailing the use of cash bail in many low-level cases as the centerpiece of a package of criminal justice legislative fixes.\n\nAt the same time, district attorneys in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Westchester County have all announced that they will no longer ask for cash bail in many misdemeanor cases. In April, Jonathan Lippman, the state\u2019s former chief judge, called for bail reform, noting in a broad report on the state\u2019s criminal justice system that judges and prosecutors rarely consider a defendant\u2019s financial situation when requesting or imposing bail.\n\nThe purpose of bail is to ensure that defendants return to court to answer charges against them and, in part, to ensure public safety. But relying heavily on cash bail often leads to what Ms. Lieberman called a \u201ctwo-tiered system of justice\u201d in which wealthy people can pay their way out of custody while the poor remain locked up before they can even contest the accusations against them.\n\nThe collateral effects can be devastating and include losing jobs, housing, even the custody of children. Cash bail also places enormous pressures on the poor, Ms. Lieberman said, to plead guilty in their cases simply as a means to get themselves out from behind bars.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat, in fact, is precisely what Mr. Kunkeli did. Shortly after the N.Y.C.L.U. filed its motion in his case, the Dutchess County district attorney\u2019s office offered him a plea deal, said his lawyer, Philip Desgranges. Mr. Kunkeli took the deal, which called for him to be sentenced to five months in prison, minus time served. Since he had already served most of that time waiting for his trial, he spent only another week in custody before he was released.\n\nJustice Rosa issued her decision in Mr. Kunkeli\u2019s case after he had been freed and his case was already over, suggesting she was trying to make a declaratory statement about cash bail not only to her colleagues on the bench, but also to lawmakers in Albany.\n\n\u201cWhile it is clear that the Legislature must act,\u201d she wrote, \u201cit is undisputed that the earliest such action could occur would be 2019. In the interim, thousands of individuals will be in a similar situation as the petitioner was.\u201d", "title": "Judge Says New York\u2019s Bail Law Treats Poor Unfairly", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOfficers can fire to protect their own lives when confronted by a lethal weapon,\u201d Mr. Quinn said.\n\nWhile Mr. Quinn focused on the final moment of the encounter \u2014 once Ms. Danner had assumed what he called a \u201cclassic right-handed baseball batter\u2019s stance\u201d \u2014 prosecutors sought to blame Sergeant Barry for making the situation so dangerous in the first place.\n\nAn assistant district attorney, Wanda Perez-Maldonado, argued that Sergeant Barry had escalated the encounter to its fatal conclusion by unnecessarily rushing into her bedroom \u2014 her \u201csafe place,\u201d as Ms. Perez-Maldonado called it.\n\n\u201cHe placed himself and Deborah Danner in this situation, which resulted in her death,\u201d Ms. Perez-Maldonado argued, as she asked Judge Robert A. Neary, who is deciding the case in lieu of a jury, to find Sergeant Barry guilty.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe ask for justice for Deborah Danner,\u201d she said. \u201cWe ask for justice for the community. We ask for justice for Hugh Barry.\u201d\n\nMs. Perez-Maldonado cataloged what the prosecution regards as lapses on Sergeant Barry\u2019s part. He had not arrived with a protective shield. Nor had he bothered to learn the details of two encounters that Ms. Danner had with the police in recent years, despite riding the elevator up to Ms. Danner\u2019s floor with her sister. And once he arrived at Ms. Danner\u2019s apartment, the prosecutor said, he appeared to seek little information from the other officers who were already there.\n\nMs. Danner had been clear in her wish that she did not want the police to come into her bedroom, Ms. Perez-Maldonado said. \u201cI didn\u2019t ask for the police\u201d and \u201cNothing\u2019s going on here \u2014 I\u2019m fine\u201d are among the things Ms. Danner called out during the tense minutes before her death, according to the prosecutor. She noted that, from her bedroom, Ms. Danner had warned officers that she would fight them.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
