Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSergeant Barry might have tried to keep engaging Ms. Danner in conversation from a distance, or called specialized officers to the scene who had more training in how to remove the mentally ill from their homes and into ambulances, Ms. Perez-Maldonado argued.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSergeant Barry failed to follow his training,\u201d Ms. Perez-Maldonado said. \u201cHe did not respect her boundaries,\u201d she added.\n\nTestifying in his own defense on Tuesday, Sergeant Barry, 32, said that at one point Ms. Danner had put the scissors down and come out of her bedroom. Concerned that she would run back in and pick up the scissors and seeing an opportunity to end the standoff, Sergeant Barry said, he rushed toward her to grab her so that the medics waiting nearby could take her to a hospital.\n\n\u201cShe was much faster than I thought,\u201d Sergeant Barry testified, saying that she pulled a baseball bat from under a pillow and took a step toward him. He recalled pleading with her to drop the bat.\n\n\u201cI just see the bat swinging, and that\u2019s when I fired,\u201d he testified.\n\nBut in her closing arguments, Ms. Perez-Maldonado pointed to several discrepancies between Sergeant Barry\u2019s testimony and that of other witnesses, including Sergeant Barry\u2019s claim that Ms. Danner had already begun to swing the bat when he fired.\n\nShe also noted that in testimony before the grand jury, Sergeant Barry claimed that the distance between his gun and Ms. Danner was a foot or less, while another police witness described the distance as four or five feet.\n\nThe effect of Sergeant Barry\u2019s testimony, she said, was to present Ms. Danner as posing a more imminent danger than she, in fact, did.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t believe Sergeant Barry\u2019s actions were reasonable,\u201d she said.\n\nJudge Neary indicated that he would announce a verdict from the bench on Thursday morning.", "title": "Judge in Trial of Sergeant Who Killed 66-Year-Old Woman Is Urged to Focus on Bat She Was Swinging", "authors": ["Joseph Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is Trumpism at the lower level,\u201d said Bernard Grofman, an elections expert at the University of California, Irvine who redrew Virginia\u2019s congressional map in 2015 following a federal court finding that districts had been racially gerrymandered. \u201cThis is the view that if independent branches of government say things that don\u2019t match what you say or do, you fire them; you impeach them; you malign them; you destroy them as best you can.\u201d\n\nThe latest example is in Pennsylvania, where the State Supreme Court split along party lines last month when it struck down the congressional district map as a Republican-drawn gerrymander. The court gave the Republican-dominated legislature three weeks to draw a new House map, adding that it would take over the map-drawing if the lawmakers could not reach agreement on new boundaries with the state\u2019s Democratic governor.\n\nEven after the United States Supreme Court rejected the legislature\u2019s plea to intervene on Feb. 5, Republicans have refused to completely accept the state court\u2019s decision. The president of the State Senate, Joe Scarnati, first raised eyebrows by stating that he would not comply with the court\u2019s order to turn over any data used in drawing the House maps. Later, he said he might file ethics complaints against two Democratic justices who expressed opinions on gerrymandering before the January decision, seeking to disqualify them from the ruling.\n\nOn Friday, hours before the court-appointed deadline, Republican legislators sent a proposed new House map to Gov. Tom Wolf, a Democrat.\n\nBut analysts say the proposed map, which was prepared without input from the legislature\u2019s Democrats, effectively preserves the existing Republican dominance in the House, albeit with boundaries that do not \u201cwander seemingly arbitrarily across Pennsylvania,\u201d as the court said of the map it struck down.\n\nOn Tuesday, Mr. Wolf rejected the map, and the job of redistricting will fall to Nathaniel Persily, a professor of law at Stanford University who is the court-appointed special master. But in an interview last week, Mr. Scarnati called a court takeover of the mapping process \u201cgrossly unconstitutional,\u201d and pledged to challenge it in federal court.\n\nIn the State House, Cris Dush, a Republican, is circulating a proposal to impeach the Democratic justices who were the 5-2 majority in the decision. In an interview, Mr. Dush said he did not dispute their authority to strike down the Republican map, but complained that their order to draw new boundaries tramples on legislative powers.", "title": "Judges Say Throw Out the Map. Lawmakers Say Throw Out the Judges.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Chicago was shocked. To be rejected by the art world was a refutation of her identity. She\u2019d studied art since she was 5 years old, and had been one of the few women to gain recognition in the 1960s L.A. art scene. For her, \u201cThe Dinner Party\u201d was the culmination of a process of radical self-transformation. She retreated to her modest studio in a small town outside San Francisco, $30,000 in debt from loans she\u2019d taken out to pay for the work\u2019s completion, and spent the rest of the summer alone. \u201cThe Dinner Party\u201d was taken apart, boxed up and put into storage.\n\nFor years, the gulf between popular adulation and critical dismissal of \u201cThe Dinner Party\u201d persisted. Over the next two decades, it was largely ignored by American art institutions. (An exception was the Brooklyn Museum, which showed it in 1980, prompting a nasty review in The New York Times by Hilton Kramer, who plainly disdained the work\u2019s vaginal imagery.) But thanks to the strenuous efforts of Diane Gelon, who had been the project coordinator on \u201cThe Dinner Party,\u201d it was shown all over the country in alternative venues \u2014 the top floor of an office building in Chicago, the Cyclorama in Boston \u2014 and supported by donors, from the Rockefellers to women who sent Chicago five dollars because they thought the work was revolutionary. Slowly, \u201cThe Dinner Party\u201d was reinscribed into art history. In 2002, when it was acquired and again shown at the Brooklyn Museum, Roberta Smith, an art critic for The Times, pithily summarized its jagged reception. \u201cCall it what you will: kitsch, pornography, artifact, feminist propaganda or a major work of 20th-century art,\u201d she wrote. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t make much difference. \u2018The Dinner Party\u2019 \u2026 is important.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen I first saw \u201cThe Dinner Party\u201d several years ago, I regarded it with a mixture of reverence and suspicion. I had somehow absorbed two contradictory ideas about it \u2014 that it was major and that it was kitsch. Its symbolism had come to supersede its status as a made thing, the product of a particular brain. Standing next to it alongside its creator, the plates glinted with a new meaning. It was a repository of women\u2019s history, but it was also an archive of Chicago\u2019s evolution as an artist.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI started to imagine how different the fate of \u201cThe Dinner Party\u201d would have been if it had been shown for the first time in 2018. The opening with Solange and Patti Smith and Oprah and maybe even Hillary Clinton in attendance; the scores of Instagram posts \u2014 loving shots of the plates accompanied by hashtags: #JudyChicago, #Vaginachina, #Herstory \u2014 the winking references to it during fashion week. The work\u2019s populism, I suspect, would have been instantly embraced by artists and thinkers; no critic would have dared to dismiss it out of hand, though the small number of women of color included in the work might have prompted a heated discussion on social media of an alternative canon of names who could have been listed on the floor. It would have penetrated the culture so deeply that it would have been impossible to reject.\n\nThe audacity of \u201cThe Dinner Party,\u201d its rhetorical energy, its humor (the vulva plates are, among other things, a play on what it might be like if women took as much pride in their anatomy as men did) would be obvious to us now. Chicago anticipated this generation\u2019s style of feminism \u2014 pugilistic, sincere, frank and unapologetically grandiose. Her investigation of \u201cdomestic\u201d forms was also prescient: Artists as different as Swoon, Cindy Sherman and Emma Sulkowicz are indebted to her. Her vision reached beyond the art world as well: She saw how identity could be the locus of larger structural change, how the fury women felt at being left out could be channeled to dismantle the fortified institutions men have built to retain their control. She anticipated the very question at the core of the #MeToo movement: What would the world look like if women held power?\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Chicago seems doomed to a lonely clairvoyance. Of course, she doesn\u2019t mind that her nearly-60-year career is finally being considered as a whole \u2014 she has upcoming or current shows at the Brooklyn Museum, Salon 94 in New York, the Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami and the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington, D. C. For a long time, she has chosen to work outside familiar methods and institutions \u2014 a path that promised little recognition or attention. She has always taken the long view. Now she has posterity in mind: What will happen to her work once she\u2019s gone?\n\nJUDY CHICAGO WAS born Judy Cohen to a progressive Jewish family in Chicago in 1939. Her mother was a former dancer and medical secretary, and her father was a labor organizer who adored his daughter and encouraged her precocity. The house was often full of friends debating books and Marxism, and Chicago was invited to participate. As she writes in \u201cThrough the Flower: My Struggle as a Woman Artist,\u201d the first volume of her wonderfully earnest 1975 autobiography, her father instilled in her a lasting sense that she was a match for any interlocutor. Throughout her childhood, she spent Saturdays at the Art Institute of Chicago, taking figure drawing and painting classes, and then wandering through the museum alone, studying Seurat, Monet, Toulouse-Lautrec. When Chicago was 13, her father died suddenly \u2014 the great loss of her life.\n\nIn 1957, she enrolled as an undergraduate at U.C.L.A., eventually earning a master\u2019s in painting and sculpture. Through her roommate, she met her first husband Jerry Gerowitz, a rebellious free spirit who was killed in a car accident. At 23, she was a widow, and one of the few women to participate in the burgeoning scene around the Ferus Gallery, a locus of West Coast cool whose artists included Edward Kienholz, Robert Irwin, Ed Moses and Ken Price. This storefront on La Cienega Boulevard represented an irreverent hyper-masculinity. (A 1959 photograph showed four Ferus artists draped over a motorcycle.) Chicago would join \u201cthe boys\u201d at the bar where they jousted with one another, teased her and talked about cars and their \u201cjoints.\u201d She often went home and cried, but told herself to suck it up. This was the world she wanted to be part of.\n\nVideo\n\nTo fit in, Chicago cultivated her own brand of machismo, shearing her hair, wearing big boots and smoking cigars. She moved away from the biomorphic, feminine imagery that her graduate school professors had ridiculed, and pushed herself to do work that was increasingly abstract and technically difficult. She went to autobody school to learn to spray-paint, making a series of four pastel-colored paintings on car hoods; she created an enormous fiberglass sculpture modeled on freeway pillars and environmental sculptures she called \u201cAtmospheres,\u201d setting off flares of colored smoke in the desert, in the mountains and on the beach.\n\nOne day, Walter Hopps, an owner of Ferus, visited the Pasadena studio Chicago shared with her second husband, Lloyd Hamrol. Her 1965 sculpture \u201cRainbow Pickett,\u201d a series of brightly colored wooden beams, each progressively larger in size, leaned against the wall. Rather than look at the work, Hopps literally turned his back on it and started talking with Hamrol and another male artist. (In 1966, it was included in \u201cPrimary Structures,\u201d a major Minimalist show at the Jewish Museum.) Years later, she ran into Hopps and he explained that he\u2019d been paralyzed by the fact that her work was better than that of the men in her circle, and he didn\u2019t know how to respond. She was demoralized and increasingly angry. She hated being ignored by critics. She hated constantly being told her ambition made her a bitch and a dyke and that women couldn\u2019t be artists.\n\nPhoto\n\nThese experiences of misogyny radicalized her, a stance that was reinforced by literature from the women\u2019s movement that was reaching the West Coast \u2014 Valerie Solanas\u2019s \u201cSCUM Manifesto\u201d (1967), Kate Millet\u2019s \u201cSexual Politics\u201d (1970) and Shulamith Firestone\u2019s \u201cThe Dialectic of Sex: The Case for Feminist Revolution\u201d (1970). \u201cIf these women could say how they felt,\u201d she writes in \u201cThrough the Flower,\u201d \u201cso could I.\u201d Rather than distort her ideas to suit the male-dominated art world, she wanted to invent a new art world, and a new way of being in it. In 1970, she decided to divest herself of her married name. Together with Jack Glenn, the owner of a local gallery, she created an announcement of a solo show that was a spoof on the brawny posters of the Ferus boys. She posed in a boxing ring \u2014 one where Muhammad Ali had once trained \u2014 wearing work boots, satin shorts and a sweatshirt emblazoned with her chosen name: Judy Chicago. In the ad, Glenn crouches in the background, a skulking manager, and her friend\u2019s girlfriend, who was pulled into the shoot at the last minute, poses alongside her. Chicago\u2019s expression is confrontational and cocksure.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer paintings from this period, however, tell a different story. They suggest she was struggling, frightened, trying to invent an image-language that reflected her vulnerability and the bruises she\u2019d sustained trying to wedge her work into the rigid strictures of the art world. She asked herself the question, \u201cHow do you fit a soft shape into a hard framework?\u201d and made a series of paintings that tried to answer it. Her painting \u201cFlesh Gate I\u201d from 1972 has a repetitive grid structure painted in gentle oranges and pinks; inside each cell is a dark opening that seems to pulse or beckon. In another series from the same period called \u201cFresno Fans,\u201d pinks and yellows fade and flicker. The paintings are tense and luminous, forceful and delicate. You can feel Chicago breaking out of the cage of abstraction, teaching herself to become the artist who could make work that was declarative and explicit.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nChicago began immersing herself in art made by women, reading literature (Jane Austen, George Eliot, Virginia Woolf and others) and studying generations of female artists (from Judith Leyster to Mary Cassatt to Barbara Hepworth), trying to locate in their work an iconography that reflected the female body and its particular sensations. She painted round forms, shapes that opened and closed and seemed to pulsate or wriggle. She became a teacher of studio classes on feminist art, the first of their kind, at Fresno State College and then at CalArts in Valencia. She pushed her students to create work based on consciousness-raising sessions in which they investigated their experiences as women, including being harassed by men.\n\nIn the summer of 1971, along with Dextra Frankel, a curator and professor of art at California State University, Fullerton and Miriam Schapiro, a painter whose work was a model for Chicago\u2019s, she toured the West Coast to find pieces for a women\u2019s art show. Many of the artists they encountered were self-taught, working in cramped spaces in their bedrooms, on porches, or in the back rooms of studios belonging to male friends or partners. Chicago was struck by the way their art-making was tucked between laundry and cooking, their work displayed among toys and family curios. Some of it was excellent \u2014 like the paintings of a woman who worked on scraps of her husband\u2019s canvas \u2014 but Chicago had to overcome her own snobbery to really begin to see it. Her idea of what it meant to be an artist was changing: It was no longer being alone, making large paintings in a studio; it could be something more improvisatory and intimate.\n\nDuring this time, her New York contemporaries, feminist artists like the sculptor Lynda Benglis (famous for her nude 1974 Artforum ad \u2014 inspired by Chicago \u2014 in which she posed with a dildo) or Judith Bernstein (who outraged critics and gallery-goers alike with her large-scale phallic drawings) were establishing themselves as deliberate provocateurs: Their goal was to make men uncomfortable. Chicago was more interested in how feminism could be cultivated within a community. Frustrated by the lack of cohesion among feminist artists, she began to seek a way to create it herself. That, as well as the idea of taking work made at a small scale and enlarging it, of mingling the domestic and the personal, became the basis of an installation, \u201cWomanhouse\u201d (1972), that Chicago and Schapiro undertook with local artists and students at CalArts. (This predated the first all-female cooperative gallery \u2014 New York\u2019s A.I.R., which counted Bernstein among its members \u2014 by about eight months.)\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWomen had embedded in houses for centuries and had quilted, sewed, baked, cooked, decorated and nested their creative energies away,\u201d Chicago wrote in \u201cThrough the Flower.\u201d \u201cWhat would happen, we wondered, if women took those same homemaking activities and carried them to fantasy proportions?\u201d Along with 21 of their students, Schapiro and Chicago renovated a dilapidated 17-room mansion in Hollywood, turning each room into a sculptural environment \u2014 Chicago\u2019s contribution was the \u201cMenstruation Bathroom,\u201d a pristine white-tiled space with a garbage can overflowing with bloody tampons. The living room became the site of performance pieces in which the women enacted births, or engaged in mundane domestic tasks like ironing. Ten thousand people came to see it during its one-month run.\n\nChicago was becoming convinced that in order for her work to be seen and understood, she would have to create an alternative canon, placing herself in a lineage of powerful women. In 1972, she began a series of biographical portraits called the \u201cGreat Ladies,\u201d dedicated to historical queens: Marie Antoinette, Catherine the Great, Queen Victoria. They were still abstract: spirals of undulating lines radiating from a taut center, painted in subtly graded pinks, yellows and blues that seemed almost to breathe. She told an interviewer that she \u201ctried to make my form-language and color reveal something really specific about a particular woman in history, like the quality of opening and blockage and stopping, the whole quality of a personality.\u201d Eventually, to make her meaning even clearer, she began to write on her paintings, documenting her fears, her methods, her daily experiences, in a cursive that is touchingly neat and girlish. (\u201cI put my finger in my pants and up my vagina, pulling out a bit of leftover menstrual blood,\u201d she wrote on a 1973 painting called \u201cThe Liberation of the Great Ladies.\u201d) The writing unleashed in her a sense of freedom. She began to study the craft of china painting (the decoration and glazing of porcelain) and to wrestle it into the realm of high art with \u201cThe Dinner Party.\u201d Chicago had to unlearn everything she knew in order to teach herself how to make something so bizarre and original.", "title": "Judy Chicago, the Godmother", "authors": ["Sasha Weiss"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 A British judge upheld an arrest warrant for Julian Assange for the second time in a week on Tuesday, a significant setback for him after five and a half years of evading the authorities by living in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London.\n\nBefore a packed London courtroom, Senior District Judge Emma Arbuthnot rejected the arguments made by Mr. Assange\u2019s lawyer, stating that he was not a prisoner, that his living conditions were nothing like those of a prison, and that he could have as many visitors as he liked. In fact, she said, he could \u2014 and should \u2014 walk free at any time to meet his legal fate.\n\n\u201cHe is a man who wants to impose his terms on the course of justice,\u201d Judge Arbuthnot said. \u201cHe wants justice only when it\u2019s in his favor.\u201d\n\nIf the judge had nullified the warrant, Mr. Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, might have left the embassy, but that was far from certain. The United States and British governments have never publicly ruled out the existence of a secret request to extradite him to the United States, where he could face prosecution for publishing classified documents.", "title": "Julian Assange\u2019s Arrest Warrant Is Again Upheld by U.K. Judge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "But at this point, so many next years have piled up that an entire generation of Browns fans has come to know the team only as perennial losers \u2014 and, by now, many of the Dawg Pound superfans who defined the city\u2019s sporting culture in the \u201980s and \u201990s have vanished from the stands. Those who are left \u2014 fans like Dawg Face and D. Dawg \u2014 have become an ever-shrinking subculture in Northeast Ohio, custodians of the fading memory of the Browns as a gritty and formidable football team, one that, between \u201986 and \u201989, played in three out of four A.F.C. championship games, and, in the 1950s and \u201960s, won four N.F.L. championships.\n\nAs the fan base has changed, so, too, has the nature of the Dawg Pound itself. Heightened security measures have made the section less rowdy and more family friendly, and have prevented fans from carrying in some of their more distinctive flair. Mr. Erwin, for example, was barred from carrying in both his large orange bone (a potential weapon) and his cowbell (a \u201cnoise maker\u201d). Far from the intimidating fan section it once was, the Dawg Pound became, in the words of one commentator, \u201ca surly collection of unsatisfied fans.\u201d\n\n\u201cBack in the day, it was rare to see more than one, maybe two fans from the opposing team in the Dawg Pound,\u201d Mr. Kochever said. \u201cNow they come in like it\u2019s nothing.\u201d", "title": "Jump on the Bandwagon of a Winning Super Bowl N.F.L. During the standoff, the son, Kodi Gaines, was struck twice by the officer\u2019s gunfire \u2014 once in the face and once in the elbow.\n\nAfter an approximately three-week trial and less than three hours of deliberation, the all-female jury found that the first shot the officer had fired was not reasonable; they then doled out damages on the grounds that Baltimore County had violated the Gaineses\u2019 civil rights and had committed battery on the mother and son.\n\nThe jury awarded Kodi Gaines, now 6, more than $32.8 million; Karsyn Courtney, Kodi\u2019s younger sister, who was not in the apartment at the time of the shooting, was awarded more than $4.5 million; and Korryn\u2019s mother and father were awarded $300,000 each, as was the estate of Korryn Gaines.", "title": "Jury Awards $38 Million to Family of Maryland Woman Shot by Police", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "The damages phase of the trial will begin Friday at the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York to determine how much the injury cost Bouchard. Liable in Lawsuit Brought by Eugenie Bouchard", "authors": ["Ben Rothenberg"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\"It wasn\u2019t about fighting crime that day,\u201d Mr. Harvis said. \u201cIt was about getting paid.\u201d\n\nPhilip DePaul, a lawyer for the city, had a very different version of events. He told the jury that after the exchange took place outside the mini-market, the officers arrested the buyer, Matthew Ninos, and found that he was carrying a small amount of crack \u2014 a crime to which he eventually pleaded guilty. Twenty minutes later, when the officers arrested Mr. Cordero, they found that he was carrying $584 in cash.\n\n\u201cCrack from the buyer \u2014 money from the seller,\u201d Mr. DePaul said. \u201cThat\u2019s a drug deal.\u201d\n\nThe officers on trial all belong to one of the city\u2019s elite antidrug teams \u2014 known as a special narcotics enforcement units \u2014 and the courtroom testimony gave a glimpse into their operations.\n\nOne of the officers, Hugo Hugasian, testified that witnesses were never interviewed in Mr. Cordero\u2019s case because no corroboration was needed: The officer had seen the deal himself. He also said that no one looked for drugs in the mini-market because the deal took place on the street and the unit was constitutionally banned from searching the bodega.\n\nOn Wednesday, testimony shifted to the issue of overtime. Mr. Harvis noted that Mr. Cordero had been arrested around 1:30 p.m. and was at the precinct station house until almost 6:30 p.m. Then he was taken to Brooklyn Central Booking. Officer Hugasian said he signed Mr. Cordero\u2019s criminal complaint at shortly after 8 p.m., which would generally mean that he was done with that day\u2019s part of the case.\n\nSo why, Mr. Harvis asked, had the officer filed paperwork indicating that he stayed on duty until 12:25 a.m. the following day?\n\nOfficer Hugasian said that he \u201cstayed after\u201d to voucher evidence and read intelligence reports to prepare for the next day\u2019s operations. Under questioning, however, he admitted he had never noted the extra work in his memo book.\n\nOn Thursday, Mr. Cordero took the stand, telling the jury that for the five hours or so that he was locked inside the holding cell, no one ever told him why he had been arrested. He also said that Officer Peter Rubin, a defendant in the case, strip-searched him \u2014 a claim that Officer Rubin has denied.\n\n\u201cI was terribly depressed because I am a very honest person,\u201d Mr. Cordero said. \u201cEverybody knows me and knows who I am.\u201d", "title": "Jury Finds on Behalf of Officers in Police Overtime Trial", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "But we\u2019re not all aspiring grandmasters, so here\u2019s a more real-world example: Just as the best chess players in the world get there through serious study, research has shown that \u201cstructured reflection\u201d of one\u2019s performance has a positive impact on leadership development, according to a study published in the Journal of Applied Psychology.\n\nMeaning: Spend more conscious hours and effort in genuine introspection and self-examination, and fewer hours ... ahem, goofing around on Twitter.\n\nOne last thought I\u2019ll leave you with: One of the best pieces of career counseling I\u2019ve read is this advice column addressing what boils down to career-induced #fomo: Why is everyone else so much more successful than I am? What\u2019s wrong with me?\n\nThe despairing advice-seeker wonders why, despite multiple attempts, she hasn\u2019t gotten a job at a particular company, then lists a few successful people she wants to be like.\n\nThe part of the response that has stuck with me for years comes when the advice-giver refers to one of those people because he knows her personally: \u201cYou can be jealous of Mallory Ortberg,\u201d the author, entrepreneur and current Dear Prudence columnist at Slate, \u201cand that\u2019s totally fair, but like, she\u2019s sweating her ass off on her work until her bountiful hair goes limp at least four nights a week.\u201d\n\nEven our idols who make success look effortless worked for every bit of it.\n\nTweet me or email me your thoughts and ideas, and have a great week!\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2014 Tim\n\nBest of Smarter Living\n\nHow to Preserve Your Family Memories, Letters and Trinkets Good archival practices might not be exciting, but they could be the key to keeping your family history intact for future generations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA Doctor\u2019s Guide to a Good Appointment Going to the doctor is part of staying healthy (the other major parts are what you eat and how much you exercise). So you may as well get the most out of it. Here\u2019s some advice from a doctor about what you should do.\n\nHow to Stop Rushing Into Love Exercising restraint and applying a sensible structure to the relationships aids in the full embrace of a romantic partner.\n\nHow Taxpayers Who Want Help Can Find a Reputable Preparer \u201cIf you\u2019re just putting in numbers and hoping for the best,\u201d an accountant says, \u201cthen maybe you need a preparer.\u201d\n\nDo Hangovers Get Worse as We Age? It\u2019s still unclear what causes hangovers. But they are a sign that you are drinking too much, at any age.\n\nThe Right Way to Order Room Service at a Hotel Room service has a reputation for being overpriced and under-seasoned. Here are a few techniques to make sure your room service meals are worth your money and appetite.\n\nSticking to Your Money Resolution\n\nIt\u2019s Week 2 of resolutions month, and I\u2019ve invited Kristin Wong, author of the personal finance book \u201cGet Money\u201d and friend of SL, to give us some tips on sticking to our money resolutions.\n\nGive Money Some Meaning\n\nPersonal finance is more about behavior than it is math, and it\u2019s much easier to stick to a money habit when that habit is attached to a larger, more meaningful goal. If you haven\u2019t already, clarify the real purpose of your money resolution. Ask yourself why, exactly, you want to save more of your paycheck or cut back on restaurants.\n\nBreak It Down\n\nLet\u2019s say you\u2019ve resolved to stop spending money on restaurants, clothing, gadgets and books this year. That is simply too many things to resist!\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s much easier to focus on one area at a time. For example, this month focus on decreasing your restaurant spending. Once that\u2019s under control, spend the next month focused on cutting back on gadgets, then clothing and so on. One thing at a time; one month at a time.\n\nDon\u2019t Beat Yourself Up\n\nI don\u2019t know about you, but when I destroy my budget or fail at a savings goal, this is what usually happens:\n\n1. Get angry at myself for not being smarter with money\n\n2. Shrug and buy everything in my Amazon cart\n\nDwelling on your slip-ups makes you more likely to repeat them. So the smarter move is to forgive yourself, recalibrate your budget and your goal, and move on.", "title": "Just Working Harder Won\u2019t Get You Ahead. Working Smarter Will.", "authors": ["Tim Herrera"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Neither of us was practiced at role-playing; we\u2019re not into elaborate schoolgirl/professor, applicant/employer, or slave-princess/Hutt scenarios. We weren\u2019t going to pretend to be other people; we were going to be ourselves in a parallel reality in which we hadn\u2019t met.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWe both worried that we might just feel stupid and want to quit. There was some last-minute waffling. She was having a bad day and I told her we could postpone if she wasn\u2019t in the mood, but she decided to rally. We established some code words: one as a warning and another to call the whole thing off.\n\nWalking to the bar that night to meet my own girlfriend, I was nervous. I had freaked out over what to wear. Choosing a bar stool felt as fraught with possibilities and drawbacks as an opening chess move. In the end I settled on a stool two away from a guy at the end of the bar, leaving my girlfriend the choice to sit beside either him or me. I took out the book I had brought, Nabokov\u2019s \u201cPale Fire\u201d (whose narrator is also pretending to be someone else), and waited.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen she arrived, she wounded me by taking the stool next to the other guy. \u201cI couldn\u2019t take the one next to you,\u201d she later said. \u201cThat would have been too easy.\u201d She said she had even considered sitting on the other side of the bar from me, making eyes at me from there.\n\nI have no idea how to pick someone up on the other side of a bar and would certainly have failed and disgraced myself.\n\nIt\u2019s relevant to mention here that my girlfriend is, um, voluptuous. She tired long ago of men staring at her cleavage and now dresses in severe black clothing with high necklines and austere copper accessories that look like machine parts or totemic objects. So when she slid onto her stool in a tight sleeveless shirt that clung to her breasts and bared her midriff it had roughly the same warm, disorienting effect on me of half a Dilaudid, chewed. Her skirt, with an angled hemline that showed off her thighs, only added to the feeling.\n\nShe took a book out of her purse and opened it \u2014 also \u201cPale Fire\u201d (we were reading it together as a winter project). The other guy was also reading a book.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the end-of-the-bar book club,\u201d I said as an opening gambit.\n\n\u201cHey,\u201d Other Guy said. \u201cDid you know you two are reading the same book?\u201d\n\nWe both feigned surprise, and the three of us got into a conversation. Other Guy\u2019s book was a collection of essays that sounded pretty good. Alarmingly, he turned out to be smart and well read, because of course New York is full of smart, well-read people vying, with their formidable educations and charm, for mates.\n\nHe was a lawyer, and not even a boring lawyer but one who did something interesting and cool. It seemed to me that my girlfriend was talking with him more than me. It began to seem as if Other Guy might be doing better with her than I was, and that it was by no means a foregone conclusion that I would win her.\n\nI had begun to both like and feel sorry for this guy (since he had no idea he was a supporting player in our private game and, I hoped, had no actual chance with her), but also to hate him and want to best him in combat.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMy girlfriend and I had once seen two male Canada geese fighting over a female goose, squawking furiously and beating the water with their wings and grappling at each other\u2019s snaking throats with their bills. Because (no offense) all geese look pretty much alike, it was hard to say which goose won, the attacker or the defender, but I knew that I wanted to be the goose that ended up with the girl, not the one who flew off honking in ignominious defeat.\n\nThank God the guy\u2019s wife eventually showed up, with a colleague of hers. They were both writers for a TV show they assured us we had never seen, who got together every Tuesday night to watch the new episode. They were all interesting people; we liked them. But we also couldn\u2019t break character.\n\nWe had felt self-conscious and uncertain about this plan to start out with, but now that our private game had become an uncontrolled experiment, involving other people, we were committed. It had gotten real.\n\nHaving to maintain our pose of being strangers in front of a third party also forced us to reintroduce ourselves \u2014 to ask each other, \u201cSo, what do you do?\u201d and \u201cWhat neighborhood do you live in?\u201d And we had to try to answer without being boring, and to listen to each other\u2019s answers anew.\n\nMy girlfriend said later that she was sure she would have dropped the act 15 minutes in if not for the presence of these strangers. It also kept our role play tethered to reality; she was forced to be more realistically flirtatious, treating me like a stranger at a bar, with some wariness and respectability, instead of just inviting me back to her place after one drink or having sex with me in the bathroom.\n\nJust before our three new friends left, the lawyer gave us each his card and said, \u201cI\u2019m here every Tuesday, if you want to keep our book club going.\u201d\n\nI thought he gave me a collegial-guy look of \u201cGood luck\u201d or \u201cCongratulations.\u201d\n\nAfter they left, I asked my girlfriend if she would let me pay for our drinks. I was as anxious asking (and as thrilled when she accepted) as I would have been had I been meeting her for the first time.\n\nLet us draw the curtain of discretion over the evening\u2019s conclusion except to say that it is a singular experience to have awkward, drunken hookup sex with your own girlfriend.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis wasn\u2019t about spicing up a relationship gone stale. I\u2019m not necessarily recommending this particular game to others.\n\nWhat I would recommend is what it did for us: It reminded us that, despite the illusion of familiarity our months together may have fostered, my girlfriend and I are still strange to each other.\n\nTelling each other stories about our romantic and sexual pasts has something of the same effect, reminding me that she is a whole person of whom I know only a recent and narrow sample, with a long history of relationships, flings and fantasies, a whole spectrum of desire, much of which may be invisible to me.\n\nThis is frightening but also exciting. It\u2019s easy to get complacent and imagine that the narrow band your partner allows you to see (or the only one you\u2019re comfortable looking at) is all there is.\n\nIn the end, our game was not just an aphrodisiac, but also a tonic \u2014 a reminder that she could, if she wanted, go home with someone else any night she wants. Although I trust her and believe that she loves me, I still have to win her once in a while.\n\nMaybe it will become a tradition for us, a ritual reminder of a perennial truth. Assuming we get to do it again. But no one is guaranteed another Valentine\u2019s Day.", "title": "Just for Tonight, Pretend You Don\u2019t Know Me, O.K.?", "authors": ["Tim Kreider", "Modern Love"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe will use criminal penalties,\u201d Mr. Sessions said. \u201cWe will use civil penalties. We will use whatever tools we have to hold people accountable for breaking our laws.\u201d\n\nThe lawsuit pending in Federal District Court in Cleveland consolidates more than 400 complaints by cities, counties and Native American tribes nationwide. They accused manufacturers, distributors and dispensers of prescription opioids of using misleading marketing to promote the painkillers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe lawsuit also accuses the defendants of playing down the addictiveness of the drugs and failing to report suspicious orders by consumers that would indicate the drugs were being abused.\n\nSome of the high-profile defendants include pharmaceutical giants Johnson & Johnson, Purdue Pharma and Teva Pharmaceuticals, large distributors McKesson and Cardinal Health and pharmacy chains like CVS, Rite Aid and Walgreens.\n\nMr. Sessions called the opioid addiction crisis \u201cbeyond imagining\u201d during separate remarks on Tuesday morning at the National Association of Attorneys General. He said the government would take a hard look at doctors who overprescribe prescription painkillers, which can lead to addiction and abuse of illegal drugs like heroin.\n\nMr. Sessions has described the opioid epidemic as a national health crisis and estimates that 64,000 Americans died of drug overdoses in 2016, a record increase. The vast majority of those deaths, he said, happened after users took opioids like prescription painkillers, heroin and fentanyl.\n\nHe also called the opioid crisis a significant drain on federal resources, costing the government $115 billion in 2017 and $1 trillion since 2001. He predicted that it could cost the United States an additional $500 billion over the next three years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe attorney general is legally able to argue on behalf of the government\u2019s interest in any court in the country via a statement of interest, which does not make the government a plaintiff. Mr. Sessions\u2019s announcement on Tuesday followed a significant dispute in the case in Ohio.\n\nOn Monday, lawyers for the Drug Enforcement Administration attended a hearing in the Ohio courtroom about how much data they would share about the national distribution of painkillers.\n\nInsisting that it did not want to compromise ongoing criminal investigations, the agency offered to provide two years\u2019 worth of information in the case. Judge Dan Aaron Polster has given the agency until next Monday to decide whether it will comply with his request to provide the sides with nine years of data. Determining the number of pills, the location and the distributors can be a major factor in assigning liability.\n\nRichard Fields, a lawyer who represents state attorneys general and sovereign Native American nations in opioid litigation, predicted that the statement of interest \u201cwill help unlock this data so that we can hold manufacturers, distributors and pharmacies accountable for flooding communities with pills.\u201d", "title": "Justice Dept. Backs High-Stakes Lawsuit Against Opioid Makers", "authors": ["Katie Benner", "Jan Hoffman"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The Justice Department has effectively shuttered an Obama-era office dedicated to making legal aid accessible to all citizens, according to two people familiar with the situation.\n\nThe division, the Office for Access to Justice, began as an initiative in 2010 under former Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to increase and improve legal resources for indigent litigants in civil, criminal and tribal courts. Though the head of the office reports directly to the associate attorney general, it never gained much visibility within the Justice Department because it did not oversee a large staff of prosecutors.\n\nWhile Attorney General Jeff Sessions cannot close the office without notifying the Congress, he can sideline it by moving its resources elsewhere. Its offices now sit dark on the third floor of the Justice Department building. The staff of a dozen or so has dwindled and left the department over the past few months, the people said. Maha Jweied, the acting director of the department, left this month to start a consulting business, according to her LinkedIn profile.\n\nThe Justice Department did not respond to repeated requests for comment, and Ms. Jweied did not respond to an emailed request for comment. Career prosecutors emphasized that new administrations reshuffle the Justice Department\u2019s priorities, de-emphasizing or shuttering projects that previous administrations had supported to devote resources to their own agendas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe office\u2019s stated mission was to \u201cdeliver outcomes that are fair and accessible to all, irrespective of wealth and status.\u201d It worked with other federal, state and local entities in the justice system to \u201cincrease access to counsel and legal assistance\u201d for people who could not afford lawyers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Office to Make Legal Aid More Accessible Is Quietly Closed", "authors": ["Katie Benner"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Thousands of prospective gun buyers are denied firearm purchases every year through the F.B.I.\u2019s National Instant Criminal Background Check System. Prospective buyers must fill out a six-page application, including whether they have ever been convicted of or indicted in a crime, which would disqualify them from purchasing a firearm.\n\nThe buyer can be approved, denied or issued a delay for the purchase. Under the third option, the firearms dealer must wait three days while the F.B.I. determines whether the prospective buyer\u2019s application is truthful and whether that person is eligible to buy a gun. If firearms dealers do not hear back from the bureau during the waiting period, they are legally allowed to sell the gun.\n\nWhile lying on the background forms is a felony, it is a crime that has rarely, if ever, been prosecuted.\n\nThousands of prospective gun buyers are denied firearms purchasers annually, but between 2008 and 2015, fewer than 32 cases a year were even considered for prosecution, according to the Justice Department\u2019s inspector general.\n\nThe new directive is expected to be welcomed by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, which is responsible for policing background check violations. The court told state lawmakers to redraw the state\u2019s 18 House districts, which currently favor Republicans, and it left open the possibility that it would impose its own map.\n\nUnder the current map, Republicans control 13 of those 18 seats. Election law experts say that a nonpartisan map could move as many as three of those seats to Democrats and increase that party\u2019s chances of regaining control of the House in the midterm elections this fall.\n\nThe State Supreme Court\u2019s 5-2 decision divided along partisan lines, with the Democratic justices in the majority and the Republicans in dissent. The majority has promised to issue an opinion providing its detailed reasoning but has yet to do so.\n\nRepublican lawmakers filed an emergency application last month asking the United States Supreme Court to step in, saying the case was partly governed by federal law. They pointed to Article I, Section 4 of the United States Constitution, which says that the times, places and manners of congressional elections \u201cshall be prescribed in each state by the legislature thereof.\u201d\n\nThe lawmakers said the State Supreme Court had thus usurped the legislature\u2019s role in violation of federal law. He grabbed, she was vulnerable \u2014 yet she faced the consequences. In a video promo for this year\u2019s Super Bowl show, an interviewer, Mike Tirico, puts upfront a question about the \u201cwardrobe thing\u201d; with a laugh, Mr. Timberlake assures him, \u201cThat won\u2019t happen this time.\u201d Later, Mr. Timberlake declares that the theme of the 2018 halftime show will be \u201cunity.\u201d Ms. Jackson has maintained her silence.\n\nThat 2004 halftime show \u2014 which was also assessed a $550,000 fine from the Federal Communications Commission (eventually overturned) and additional indecency fines of $3.5 million \u2014 turned the Super Bowl against youth-oriented pop. For the rest of the decade, the N.F.L. booked elder-generation male rockers who wouldn\u2019t be baring anything: Paul McCartney, the Rolling Stones, the Who. High-definition close-ups weren\u2019t kind to their weary faces.\n\nBy the time current pop returned to halftime show in 2011 with the Black Eyed Peas and Usher, the whole presentation had grown more airtight. Both the N.F.L. and video-savvy pop performers had learned to treat the halftime show as a 12-minute music video, not a stadium concert with all its anarchic variables. In this decade, digital effects have merged with live performances that are always conscious of the camera above all.\n\nThe shocks have dwindled, and not only because far more extreme behavior and imagery are a cable channel or an internet click away \u2014 not to mention the fact that the halftime show is the intermission in a game that depends on concussive force. Yes, M.I.A. raised a middle finger to the world as a guest in Madonna\u2019s 2012 show; the N.F.L., not the F.C.C., sued her and eventually reached a confidential settlement. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Timberlake got his start in a boy band, \u2019N Sync, and he has a natural gift for grand-scale presentation. (This was actually his third halftime performance, including 2004 and also \u2019N Sync\u2019s appearance in 2001.) The dance routines, including an exuberant tuxedo-clad brass section and a phalanx of bodies holding aloft mirrors that refracted light throughout the stadium (during \u201cMirrors\u201d), were effective without being ostentatious. Shows of this size are light work for Mr. Timberlake, even if he was working at about three-fourths the intensity of his backing troupe.\n\nThat Mr. Timberlake, who has had a smattering of hits in recent years \u2014 including the \u201cTrolls\u201d soundtrack anthem \u201cCan\u2019t Stop the Feeling!,\u201d which he performed near the end of his set \u2014 was offered this halftime-show slot is a reminder of the wide-scale cultural cachet he once corralled. Though he released a new solo album \u2014 \u201cMan of the Woods,\u201d his fifth \u2014 on Friday, Mr. Timberlake is, in effect, a heritage act. (The heritage of the early-to-mid-2000s, but still.)\n\nHis booking also displays the differing ways forgiveness is deployed in public life. That Mr. Timberlake was deemed fit for this rehabilitation has less to do with contrition on his part than the presumption that whiteness is resilient armor, and also the convenience of having a nonwhite scapegoat. In a year in which the N.F.L.\u2019s bumbling relationship to race has been at its most visible, this whitewashing has a particularly acrid smell. On Sunday, in anticipation of Mr. Timberlake\u2019s performance, Twitter and Instagram were flooded with photos and videos of Ms. Jackson, often posted with the hashtag #JanetJacksonAppreciationDay.\n\nIn the days before the Super Bowl, there was also a minor conflagration at a report that Mr. Timberlake would be joined onstage by Prince, in hologram form, causing offense to Prince fans (who knew he rejected such spectacles); to those who recall Prince\u2019s 2007 halftime performance \u2014 one of the greats, full of range, attitude and carnal verve; and to those loath to see another black body handed over to a performer who had so famously mishandled one in the past.\n\nAs it happened, there was no hologram, just a projection of Prince onto a gargantuan scrim as the lights turned purple, and a quick, inoffensive duet of \u201cI Would Die 4 U\u201d that served more as an exaltation than a musical performance. Mays"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 K. T. McFarland, who was a deputy national security adviser in the Trump administration and then was picked to serve as ambassador to Singapore, withdrew her ambassadorial nomination on Friday after it had stalled in the Senate.\n\nMs. McFarland\u2019s nomination had become embroiled in the controversy over the Trump campaign\u2019s contacts with Russian officials, with some senators left wondering if she had answered questions deceptively when asked if she knew of discussions between Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, and a Russian ambassador.\n\n\u201cUnfortunately, some Democrats chose to play politics rather than move forward with a qualified nominee for a critically important post,\u201d President Trump said in a statement released Friday by the White House. \u201cI wish K. T. the best as she uses her considerable wisdom and skill as a commentator to explain to the American people how to make American foreign policy great again.\u201d\n\nSenate Republicans could have approved her nomination unilaterally, but the fact that it was never brought to a vote suggested that she had made even some of them uneasy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. McFarland was a member of the Trump transition team and then became Mr. Flynn\u2019s deputy on the National Security Council, where she ruffled feathers with her intense partisanship.", "title": "K. The chain, owned by Yum Brands, said its new delivery partner was experiencing \u201ca couple of teething problems.\u201d Getting fresh chicken to 900 outlets across the country, KFC added, \u201cis pretty complex!\u201d\n\nGMB, a trade union, said it had warned the company against making the switch, and that the closing of a Bidvest depot after it lost the contract had resulted in the loss of 255 jobs.\n\n\u201cWe tried to warn KFC this decision would have consequences,\u201d Mick Rix, GMB\u2019s national officer, said in a statement, though he couldn\u2019t help using puns. \u201cWell now the chickens are coming home to roost. It\u2019s the most successful thing Mr. West has ever done in fashion.\n\n#YeezySeason6 A post shared by Paris Hilton (@parishilton) on Jan 30, 2018 at 9:57pm PST\n\nNot so much because of the clothes, which look like pretty standard athleisure gear (crop tops and sweats and bike shorts and bomber jackets), but because it has the one element that has always been lacking in Mr. West\u2019s myriad attempts to transform himself into a credible style guru: humor.\n\n#YEEZYSEASON6 A post shared by HEIR JORDYN (@jordynwoods) on Jan 30, 2018 at 4:36pm PST\n\nEver since he introduced his first eponymous line in Paris in October 2011 (remember that?), his shows have been marked, largely, by bombast, pretentiousness and overwhelming self-seriousness. There was, for example, the time in Paris when he sent what Vogue called \u201cgothic go-karts\u201d speeding out for his finale. Then, after he repositioned himself as Yeezy in New York, there was the Madison Square Garden extravaganza at which he announced that he was ready to be the creative director of Herm\u00e8s.\n\n#YEEZYSEASON6 A post shared by A R \u26a1\ufe0f (@abigailratchford) on Jan 30, 2018 at 3:46pm PST\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNot to mention the Roosevelt Island fiasco when he dragged everyone out to Four Freedoms Park, kept them waiting in the stifling heat for hours, and then treated them to the sight of models fainting in the sun and unable to walk the runway in their stiletto boots. Or his tendency to schedule his shows at the same time as some other designer\u2019s show, forcing attendees to choose between them.\n\n#YEEZYSEASON6 A post shared by Kristen Noel Crawley (@kristennoelcrawley) on Jan 30, 2018 at 3:13pm PST\n\nIn each case the actual clothes on the catwalk could not live up to the expectations created by the venue and presentation. They just weren\u2019t original or alluring enough on their own.\n\n#YEEZYSEASON6 A post shared by SIERRA SKYE (@sierraaaskyee) on Jan 30, 2018 at 4:24pm PST\n\nBy February 2017, he was slightly cowed but still held his presentation before an enormous screen on which images of his collection towered over the actual people on the catwalk. It was a metaphor for his approach to the industry.\n\n#YEEZYSEASON6 A post shared by SAMI MIR\u00d3 (@samimiro) on Jan 30, 2018 at 3:14pm PST\n\nBut perhaps not anymore.\n\nAdmittedly, it\u2019s possible the Kim-clones series is actually a statement that, as far as Mr. West is concerned, he and his wife are the dominating forces in the pop culture landscape \u2014 proof positive that it\u2019s a Kimye world, and we just live in it. Maybe he\u2019s not really poking fun at the whole celebrity-fashion circus, and his own role in it: He\u2019s exposing it! You want to buy a piece of him and his lifestyle by buying his products? Well, let\u2019s just call it like it is.\n\n#YEEZYSEASON6 A post shared by I AM THE INFLUENCE (@amina.blue) on Jan 30, 2018 at 2:57pm PST\n\nChances are, given the ego involved, that\u2019s part of it. But it\u2019s still almost impossible not to look at the images and laugh. They are knowing, in the best way \u2014 in the way that travels most effectively via social media and the digital highway. And for that Mr. West deserves credit.\n\nThere\u2019s a lot of talk in fashion about direct-to-consumer marketing and how designers can use the internet and the end of shows and how the system doesn\u2019t work; a lot of talk of how everyone is experimenting with different ways to communicate \u2014 fashion films! exhibitions! parties! There\u2019s a lot of chopping and changing, and rarely has any of it seemed like a truly successful alternative to the traditional show.\n\nAs far as Mr. West and what he makes is concerned, however, I think he may have found it. The medium fits his message (to redesign a phrase from Marshall McLuhan) in a way the classic catwalk format never did. Would-be disrupters might pay attention.\n\nNow what I want to know is: Are they going to sell the wigs, too?", "title": "Kanye West Finally Gets His Fashion Right", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman", "On The Runway"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Former American Media employees told The New Yorker that the company\u2019s chairman and chief executive, David Pecker, who is close with Mr. Trump, routinely bought stories with no intention of running them, sometimes using the pieces as leverage.\n\nThe company denied the practice in a statement, referring to the author of the New Yorker piece by name.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.
