[]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI wanted to be helpful because I wanted him to continue to help my clients as he had been in the past,\u201d Mr. Howe said.\n\nIn 2012, Mr. Howe said that he had received a call from Mr. Percoco, who indicated that he was facing financial strains, and his wife, Lisa, a former schoolteacher, was unemployed.\n\n\u201cHe asked if there were any clients of mine that could possibly hire her to be a consultant or to teach in some capacity, if I had a client that might be willing to hire her,\u201d Mr. Howe said.\n\nAnd Mr. Howe\u2019s client, Competitive Power Ventures, seemed well aware of Mr. Percoco\u2019s potential influence. \u201cMy understanding was he wanted Joe to be an advocate and his eyes and ears in the governor\u2019s office,\u201d Mr. Howe said of Peter Galbraith Kelly Jr., then an executive with Competitive Power Ventures who is one of the four defendants on trial.\n\nMr. Percoco\u2019s wife was later hired as an educational consultant by Mr. Kelly\u2019s company, drawing about $285,000 in salary over roughly three years for what prosecutors called a \u201clow-show job.\u201d\n\nIn another instance, a Syracuse-area developer, COR Development, was also seeking help from Mr. Percoco, who served as Mr. Cuomo\u2019s executive deputy secretary. \u201cThey wanted that labor peace agreement to go away,\u201d Mr. Howe recalled, \u201cand realized that Joe was in a position\u201d to make that happen.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Percoco\u2019s intervention helped that labor issue disappear as well, according to prosecutors.\n\nIn all, prosecutors say, Mr. Percoco received at least $315,000 in bribes, paid to Mr. Percoco\u2019s wife through a third party and through a company operated by Mr. Howe.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe testimony from Mr. Howe, whose questioning by prosecutors is to continue on Tuesday, offered a vivid and sometimes shadowy look at the inner workings of the State Capitol, where Mr. Percoco, as the close friend and political enforcer of Mr. Cuomo, was for years an imposing presence.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Percoco\u2019s influence was well-known, Mr. Howe testified. \u201cHe had the ability to pick up the phone and get things done,\u201d Mr. Howe said, likening it to the old commercial for E. F. Hutton (\u201cWhen E. F. Hutton talks, people listen\u201d).\n\nMr. Cuomo, a Democrat facing re-election in the fall, has not been accused of any wrongdoing. But the governor\u2019s proximity to Mr. Percoco \u2014 whom Mr. Cuomo once referred to as family, but who is now facing felony charges that include conspiracy, extortion and solicitation of bribes \u2014 has already cast questions on his choice of friends and personnel.\n\nNot all of Mr. Howe\u2019s testimony directly related to illegal actions, but it still underscored how money led to access, and a direct pipeline to request favors. He testified that he had persuaded Competitive Power Ventures to contribute to Mr. Cuomo\u2019s election campaign in 2010, during his first successful run for governor.\n\nMr. Howe said he set up a breakfast with Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Kelly and other officials with Competitive Power Ventures in New York City. Some $25,000 was raised at that event. Later, other executives from the company also contributed to the campaign. Prosecutors have said that the contributions were not illegal, a point reiterated to the jury by Judge Valerie E. Caproni, who is overseeing the trial.\n\nThe candidate also used a plane paid for by Competitive Power Ventures for a day near the close of the campaign, Mr. Howe said. \u201cThe governor did fly on it,\u201d he said.\n\nShortly after Mr. Cuomo was elected, Mr. Howe, Mr. Percoco and Mr. Kelly had lunch at Smith & Wollensky, the famed steakhouse, Mr. Howe testified. He said they discussed a power plant that Mr. Kelly\u2019s company was seeking to build in the Hudson Valley and an agreement the firm wanted that the state would buy the power it produced.\n\nMr. Howe painted a jokey, and sometimes insulting, culture of cooperation between himself and Mr. Percoco, who called each other \u201cHerb\u201d and secretly called Mr. Kelly \u201cfat man.\u201d (After a 2010 fishing trip, in which Mr. Percoco caught a tuna, Mr. Kelly earned another moniker: Skipper.)\n\nMr. Howe also testified to the damage the scandal had done to him personally, noting that he had \u201cmade a huge mistake that has wrecked my career and my family\u2019s life.\u201d The charges which he pleaded guilty to as part of his cooperation deal \u2014 including extortion, fraud and conspiracies to commit honest services fraud and bribery \u2014 were a result of his living beyond his means, he said, despite earning more than $750,000 a year.\n\nOnce a denizen of the halls of power in Washington and Albany, Mr. Howe said he was forced to move from the East Coast. His government affairs career was over, he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Howe said he now lives in Idaho, where he works as a groundskeeper at a golf course.", "title": "Key Prosecution Witness Describes Bribes to Top Cuomo Aide", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley", "Benjamin Weiser"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg reflected on the consequences of ruling against the union in the case before the court. \u201cIt drains it of resources that make it an equal partner\u201d with the government in negotiations, she told William L. Messenger, a lawyer for Mark Janus, an Illinois child support specialist who objected to positions taken by his union in negotiations. \u201cAnd then you\u2019ll have a union with diminished resources, not able to investigate what it should demand at the bargaining table, not equal to the employer that it faces.\u201d\n\nNear the end of the argument, Justice Sonia Sotomayor said the case represented an existential threat to the labor movement. \u201cYou\u2019re basically arguing, \u2018Do away with unions,\u2019 \u201d she told Mr. Messenger.\n\nThe case was a challenge to an Illinois law that requires government workers who choose not to join unions to \u201cpay their proportionate share of the costs of the collective bargaining process, contract administration and pursuing matters affecting wages, hours and other conditions of employment.\u201d More than 20 states have similar laws.\n\nThe Supreme Court ruled that such laws are constitutional in Abood v. Detroit Board of Education, a foundational 1977 decision that made a distinction between two kinds of compelled payments. Forcing nonmembers to pay for a union\u2019s political activities violated the First Amendment, the court said. But it was constitutional, the court added, to require nonmembers to help pay for the union\u2019s collective bargaining efforts to prevent freeloading and ensure \u201clabor peace.\u201d\n\nConservative groups have long urged the court to overrule the Abood decision, and they have repeatedly gotten close to their goal. In 2014, the court stopped just short of overruling the decision.\n\nWhen the court revisited the issue in 2016, the Obama administration argued in favor of the unions. The Trump administration switched sides in the new case, prompting a comment from Justice Sotomayor to Solicitor General Noel J. Francisco.\n\n\u201cThis is such a radical new position on your part,\u201d she said.\n\nJustice Kagan noted that the administration\u2019s position could open the federal government to First Amendment challenges in various kinds of workplace disputes. \u201cIt strikes me as a very unusual position for the government to be taking,\u201d Justice Kagan said, perhaps reflecting on her own experience in representing the government as solicitor general in the Obama administration.", "title": "Key Voice Is Silent in Supreme Court Case on Unions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Still, Mr. Howe\u2019s testimony on Thursday \u2014 and in particular, his account of that 2014 meeting with Mr. Cuomo and the circumstances that preceded it \u2014 was one of the first times that the governor has emerged as a major character in one of Mr. Howe\u2019s many anecdotes of how he tried to pull Albany\u2019s unseen levers. And it thrust back into the limelight a host of issues that have dogged Mr. Cuomo in recent years, from his unwavering attempts to revive the stuttering upstate economy, to his longstanding political feuds, to rumors of his temper.\n\nThe occasion for the governor\u2019s anger in 2014, according to Mr. Howe, was the dissipation of a major construction project in Syracuse that he said Mr. Cuomo had supported.\n\n\u201cHe blamed you for what had happened in Syracuse, correct?\u201d the lawyer, Stephen Coffey, asked.\n\n\u201cYes.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou didn\u2019t think that was fair?\u201d\n\n\u201cI know the governor well enough to know what\u2019s fair and unfair doesn\u2019t really matter in a situation like this,\u201d Mr. Howe replied.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Howe had previously spoken glowingly of both Mr. Cuomo and his father, Mario M. Cuomo, having worked as an aide to both men. But on Thursday, he seemed to indicate that his admiration of the current governor was tempered by a fearful respect. At one point, he acknowledged Mr. Cuomo\u2019s reputation as a \u201cbully.\u201d\n\nThe Syracuse project was a proposed new basketball stadium that would replace the famed Carrier Dome, home of Syracuse University\u2019s basketball team.\n\nFrom its inception, the project was steeped in controversy. Mr. Aiello\u2019s company, COR Development, hatched the plans for the new multipurpose stadium and approached Onondaga County Executive Joanie Mahoney with the idea in the summer of 2013, according to a timeline compiled by The Syracuse Post-Standard. A few months later, Mr. Cuomo, who has made rejuvenating the upstate economy a centerpiece of his administration, approached Ms. Mahoney with his desire to fund a major project in central New York.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Syracuse\u2019s mayor, Stephanie Miner, was not informed of the governor\u2019s plans to move ahead with the stadium project until December, and she was not pleased, The Post-Standard reported. She declined to endorse it. By January 2014, the deal had fallen apart.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt blew up, and the governor was pretty upset,\u201d Mr. Howe said on Thursday.\n\nIn an interview on Thursday, Ms. Miner confirmed Mr. Howe\u2019s account of the governor\u2019s displeasure after the stadium deal collapsed. \u201cTodd came to me and apologized and said to me that the governor was angry with him,\u201d Ms. Miner said. \u201cAnd I knew that the governor and his people were extraordinarily angry with me.\u201d\n\nMr. Howe, now a groundskeeper in Idaho, testified that the 2014 meeting he set up, which included himself, Mr. Aiello and Mr. Cuomo, was an attempt to clean up the fallout of the stadium project. Apparently, it did not go well.\n\nAfterward, Mr. Howe said, Mr. Percoco tasked him with helping the governor smooth over his relationship with Ms. Miner. Those efforts have not appeared successful, either: Ms. Miner announced last month that she was \u201cseriously considering\u201d running against Mr. Cuomo for governor this fall.\n\nAs for the trial, things also do not appear to have worked out as Mr. Howe might have liked. Last Thursday, his bail was revoked because he admitted he had tried to defraud his credit card company after he signed his cooperation agreement; he has since spent each night at the Metropolitan Correctional Center a block from the courthouse.\n\nWhen the last question was finally asked and Mr. Howe\u2019s testimony ended, the judge, Valerie E. Caproni, addressed the prosecution\u2019s star witness.\n\n\u201cMr. Howe, go back to Idaho!\u201d she said. Then she reconsidered his circumstance. \u201cNo! Go back to the M.C.C.!\u201d", "title": "Key Witness in Corruption Trial Tells a Tale of Cuomo", "authors": ["Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Percoco has been charged with taking at least $315,000 in bribes from the executives, paid to Mr. Percoco\u2019s wife through a third party and through a company operated by Mr. Howe, in return for taking official actions on the firms\u2019 behalf.\n\nMr. Howe, a former prominent lobbyist in Albany and Washington, testified on Monday and Tuesday about his role in the scheme. Under questioning from prosecutors, Mr. Howe portrayed Mr. Percoco as a man consumed by the pursuit of bribe money \u2014 which the two men referred to as \u201cziti,\u201d a reference from \u201cThe Sopranos\u201d \u2014 from the two firms, Competitive Power Ventures and COR Development.\n\nMr. Howe was a friend to Mr. Percoco and Governor Cuomo, and had the trust of both men. Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat seeking a third term, has not been accused of any wrongdoing.\n\nThrough his testimony, it became clear that Mr. Howe had significant problems that had damaged his credibility. The government has already told the jury of Mr. Howe\u2019s tawdry past, which included a 2010 felony conviction for theft related to a fake $45,000 bank deposit, and indicated it would offer other supportive evidence to his testimony.\n\nMr. Howe also testified that under terms of his agreement, if he lied on the witness stand, the government could cancel his cooperation deal. He could face decades in prison.\n\nBut under questioning by Mr. Gitner, Mr. Howe seemed to make damaging admissions.\n\nHe acknowledged, for example, that in applying for a disability insurance policy in 2014, he checked a box stating that he had never been convicted of a felony, even though that was not true.\n\n\u201cAnd the government is hearing about that for the first time right now?\u201d Mr. Gitner asked.\n\n\u201cYes,\u201d Mr. Howe said.", "title": "Key Witness in Percoco Case Admits to Violating His Plea Deal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "TORONTO \u2014 A day after attending Toronto\u2019s gay pride festivities last June, Andrew Kinsman, 49, a building superintendent with deep roots in the community, dropped out of sight, missing his volunteer food-bank shift and leaving his cat unfed.\n\nFriends knew right away there had to be something wrong, and now, after months of anguished searching, the horrific answer to what happened to him has not only shaken the gay community, but has also widened its longstanding rift with the Toronto police.\n\nLast week, the police said they had recovered the dismembered remains of six people, including Mr. Kinsman, from planters on a property where Bruce McArthur, a 66-year-old landscaper, worked, and investigators were searching 30 other places across the city. Mr. McArthur has been charged with the murders of Mr. Kinsman and four other men, and police said additional charges were expected.\n\nBut as the investigation has grown, so, too, has anger among gay activists in Toronto, Canada\u2019s largest city, who accuse the authorities of neglect in missing-person cases involving gay men that have stretched out over nearly a decade.", "title": "Killings in Toronto\u2019s Gay Community Expose \u2018an Open Wound\u2019 With Police", "authors": ["Dan Levin"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "The Trump administration is wary of engagement with the North, which has been subjected to increasingly tough international sanctions, unless it shows clear signs of giving up its nuclear weapons program.\n\nMr. Pence \u2014 who sat just feet away from Ms. Kim at the Olympic opening ceremony, with neither apparently speaking to the other \u2014 has also been critical of the North\u2019s participation in the Games, seeing it as an attempt to create a division between United States and the South.\n\nSouth Korea\u2019s president, Mr. Moon, welcomed the possibility of a meeting with the North Korean leader, saying the two Koreas should \u201cwork together to create the environment to make it happen,\u201d a spokesman said.\n\nBut Mr. Moon has also said that he would be willing to meet Mr. Kim only if he received assurances from the North that it would help resolve the crisis over the North\u2019s nuclear weapons program.\n\n\u201cThe South and North shared an understanding that they should continue the positive mood for peace and reconciliation created by the Pyeongchang Olympics and should promote inter-Korean dialogue, exchanges and cooperation,\u201d Mr. Moon\u2019s office said in a statement.\n\nIf Mr. Moon accepts Mr. Kim\u2019s offer to come to the North, it will be the third summit meeting between the two Koreas. But it would be Mr. Kim\u2019s first meeting with a foreign head of state.\n\nKim Jong-il, Mr. Kim\u2019s father, had met with two South Korean presidents in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, before his death in 2011: with President Kim Dae-jung in 2000, and with President Roh Moo-hyun in 2007.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBoth of those South Korean presidents struggled under growing domestic criticism after their trips to Pyongyang had resulted in large shipments of aid and investment but failed to end the North\u2019s nuclear weapons program.\n\nMr. Moon also urged North Korea to talk to the United States, his office said. In the past, he has said that there was a limit to how much the Koreas\u2019 ties could improve without a resolution of the nuclear weapons issue. In a news conference last month, he said he was not interested in \u201ctalks for talks\u2019 sake.\u201d\n\nNorth Korea\u2019s leader, Mr. Kim, once dismissed as an inexperienced figurehead, has quickly built a reputation as a ruthless dictator at home and a wily strategist in handling North Korea\u2019s external enemies. Since he took power six years ago, he has not only executed scores of senior party officials and military generals but also rattled the region by accelerating nuclear and missile tests.\n\nHe has gotten closer to completing nuclear missiles capable of hitting the United States than his father and grandfather, who had ruled before him, had ever hoped for, and did do with a heavy cost: increasingly biting sanctions.\n\nVideo\n\nNow, Mr. Kim, 34, has switched tactics to a charm offensive aimed at persuading South Korea to break ranks with Washington, analysts said.\n\nMr. Moon\u2019s government is clearly more optimistic than the Trump administration about the potential for the Koreas\u2019 cooperation at the Olympics to create the groundwork for more substantial discussions. At a reception on Friday, Mr. Moon pointed to the joint Korean women\u2019s ice hockey team \u2014 an Olympic first \u2014 as a starting point.\n\n\u201cThe female ice hockey players from the two Koreas are now holding a small snowball in their hands,\u201d he said. \u201cNow, if we put our hearts and minds together, it will continue to grow larger and larger and turn into a snowman of peace.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Moon joined Ms. Kim and other North Korean supporters on Saturday in cheering for the team against Switzerland. The supporters waved blue and white flags that showed an undivided Korean Peninsula.\n\nNorth and South Korea marched under one flag at the Olympics\u2019 opening ceremony. Some South Koreans hope it is a symbol of a peaceful unification. Others fear it is an omen of larger political ambitions of the North.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Pence, by contrast, avoided speaking with North Korean officials on Friday, and he and his wife did not stand, as most spectators did, when the athletes from both Koreas marched together under a flag representing a unified Korea. Earlier Friday, Mr. Pence met with defectors from the North and invited them to tell their stories of repression under Pyongyang.\n\nMr. Moon would like to bring both North Korea and the United States to the negotiating table. China has suggested that talks could start if the United States suspended its regular joint military exercises with South Korea, and if North Korea reciprocated by shelving nuclear and missile tests.\n\nBut both sides have held their ground. North Korea has said that its nuclear weapons are not for bargaining away. In a speech that Mr. Kim gave on New Year\u2019s Day, in which he first raised the possibility of the North participating in the Olympics, he vowed to \u201cmass-produce\u201d nuclear weapons and missiles.\n\nMr. Pence reiterated on Friday that the North must \u201cput denuclearization on the table and take concrete steps with the world community to dismantle, permanently and irreversibly, their nuclear and ballistic missile programs.\u201d\n\n\u201cThen, and only then, will the world community consider negotiating and making changes in the sanctions regime that\u2019s placed on them today,\u201d Mr. Pence said after a meeting with Mr. Moon.\n\n\u201cKim Jong-un has no intention of giving up his nuclear weapons,\u201d said Cheon Seong-whun, a former presidential secretary for security strategy and now a visiting research fellow at the Asan Institute for Policy Studies in Seoul. \u201cWith his summit proposal, he seeks to incite friction between Seoul and Washington by widening their policy gap.\u201d\n\nMr. Moon cannot rush for a summit meeting given Washington\u2019s deep misgivings and because \u201cSouth Koreans are not as enthused about another summit meeting with North Korea as they used to,\u201d Mr. Cheon added.\n\nA senior analyst at the Sejong Institute in South Korea, Cheong Seong-chang, agreed that Mr. Kim\u2019s latest overtures were aimed at easing its isolation and the impact of sanctions. But South Korea also needed to ease tensions, especially given Mr. Trump\u2019s threat to take a military option, he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt will not be wise for President Moon to reject dialogue with the North and do nothing but stick to sanctions for the sake of the alliance with the United States,\u201d Mr. Cheong said. \u201cSouth Korea will suffer the most if miscalculation or hostility drives the North and the United States into an armed clash.\u201d\n\nThe main political opposition, the conservative Liberty Korea Party, warned that Mr. Moon was duped by the North\u2019s \u201cfalse peace offensives.\u201d But Mr. Moon\u2019s governing Democratic Party heartily welcomed the prospect of an inter-Korean summit meeting.\n\nA party spokeswoman, Kim Hyo-eun, went so far as to call for the reopening of a joint factory park in the North Korean town of Kaesong. Mr. Moon\u2019s conservative and impeached predecessor, President Park Geun-hye, shut down the park two years ago. Washington says that the reopening of the park would violate sanctions \u2014 a concern Mr. Moon shared.\n\nThe United States has also opposed suspending its joint military exercises with the South, though it agreed to delay drills scheduled for February until the Olympics are over. Shinzo Abe, the prime minister of Japan, asked Mr. Moon on Friday to hold the exercises soon after the Games end, but Mr. Moon told Mr. Abe not to meddle in South Korea\u2019s \u201csovereignty and internal affairs,\u201d South Korean officials said.\n\nOn Saturday, members of the small progressive Minjung Party held a rally near an Olympic site, condemning Mr. Pence and Mr. Abe for committing \u201cdiplomatic discourtesy\u201d and \u201cruining South Korea\u2019s party.\u201d", "title": "Kim Jong-un Invites South Korean Leader to North for Summit Meeting", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Kim has an older brother, Kim Jong-chol, who has never been seen in the North Korean media and whose role, if any, remains a mystery. He was last spotted at an Eric Clapton concert in London in 2015, but little else is known of him. Ms. Kim and her brothers studied in Switzerland as teenagers.\n\nKim Jong-un\u2019s older half brother, Kim Jong-nam, was killed in an airport in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in February last year by two women who smeared his face with a rare nerve agent. The assassins, who are on trial, were hired by North Korean agents who analysts said were sent by Kim Jong-un to eliminate a potential threat to his dynastic grip on power.\n\nOutside officials and analysts consider Ms. Kim the pre-eminent female face of the Kim family, which has ruled North Korea since its founding seven decades ago. Her father, Kim Jong-il, also allowed his own sister, Kim Kyong-hui, to hold prominent jobs in the government until his death in 2011. But she disappeared from view after her husband, Jang Song-thaek, was executed in 2013 by Kim Jong-un on charges of plotting a coup.\n\n\u201cAlthough Kim Yong-nam is the official head of the delegation, it will be Kim Yo-jong who will decide its activities,\u201d said Cheong Seong-chang, a senior analyst at the Sejong Institute in Seoul, South Korea. \u201cBy including his sister in the delegation, Kim Jong-un may want to show his interest in improving ties with South Korea.\u201d\n\nWord of Ms. Kim\u2019s visit came as Vice President Pence warned North Korea that it would face a new round of tougher sanctions.\n\n\u201cThe United States of America will soon unveil the toughest and most aggressive round of economic sanctions on North Korea ever \u2014 and we will continue to isolate North Korea until it abandons its nuclear and ballistic missile programs once and for all,\u201d he said Wednesday while visiting Japan.\n\nBut a day earlier, Mr. Pence had stirred speculation about a possible meeting with North Korean officials, saying, \u201cI have not requested a meeting, but we\u2019ll see what happens.\u201d On Thursday, however, North Korea ruled out such a meeting.", "title": "Kim Jong-un\u2019s Influential Sister to Visit South Korea for Olympic Ceremony", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Kim attracted attention wherever she turned up \u2014 at the opening ceremony, in the stands at the Olympic debut of the unified Korean women\u2019s ice hockey team, and at a performance in Seoul by a North Korean art troupe.\n\nBut Mr. Pence drew the greatest reaction for where he did not appear: most pointedly, at a dinner Mr. Moon hosted before the opening ceremony. That meant that he avoided spending much time with the North Korean delegation, including Kim Yong-nam, the country\u2019s ceremonial head of state.\n\nAnd while the unified Korean Olympic team received a standing ovation as they marched into the stadium Friday night, Mr. Pence remained seated, which critics said was disrespectful of the athletes and his host, Mr. Moon.\n\nMr. Pence is playing \u201cright into North Korea\u2019s hands by making it look like the U.S. is straying from its ally and actively undermining efforts for inter-Korean relations,\u201d said Mintaro Oba, a former diplomat at the State Department specializing in the Koreas, who now works as a speechwriter in Washington.\n\nMs. Kim, on the other hand, \u201cis a very effective tip of the spear for the North Korean charm offensive,\u201d Mr. Oba said.\n\nAnalysts of Korean affairs said that Mr. Pence had missed an opportunity.\n\n\u201cI think it would have been really helpful to the conversation of denuclearization for the Pences to have appreciated the effort put into bringing team unified Korea into the stadium,\u201d said Alexis Dudden, a professor of history at the University of Connecticut. \u201cAnd it wouldn\u2019t have lessened the American position.\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cThe fact that he and Mrs. Pence didn\u2019t stand when the unified team came in was a new low in a bullying type of American diplomacy.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a pool report filed from Mr. Pence\u2019s flight to Alaska from Pyeongchang on Saturday night, a senior administration official said that the vice president had not been trying to avoid the North Koreans so much as he was trying to ignore them.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor Mr. Pence\u2019s supporters, \u201cI think the hard-line wing of the United States thinks he did a fine job,\u201d said David C. Kang, director of the Korean Studies Institute at the University of Southern California.\n\nAnd while Mr. Moon could not miss the chance to \u201clower the temperature in the room\u201d by engaging with Ms. Kim during her visit for the Olympics, her public relations blitz could subject the South Korean president to criticism that \u201che fell for a charm offensive,\u201d Mr. Kang said.\n\nAt a protest on Sunday in central Seoul, where a few hundred anti-North Korea demonstrators waving South Korean and American flags gathered and shouted slogans denouncing Kim Jong-un, Yang Sun-woo, 55, said, \u201cI\u2019m afraid a lot of Koreans have been fooled by Kim Yo-jong\u2019s visit.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very unfortunate that the Pyeongchang Olympics are becoming the Pyongyang Olympics when South and North Korea are still at odds with each other over ideologies,\u201d added Mr. Yang, who carried a foam head depicting a bloodied face of the North Korean leader.\n\nMs. Kim, who is believed to be 30, was a natural choice for the trip to South Korea. Her clout, because of her shared bloodline, is unmistakable.\n\nAt home, she is mindful of the need to keep the spotlight on her brother. When senior officials cluster around him, reverentially taking notes, she lingers in the background. When her brother speaks in public, she hides behind a pillar, occasionally peeking out.\n\nAs the first immediate member of the North\u2019s ruling family to visit South Korea, Ms. Kim was swarmed by the local news media. Even before she touched down in her brother\u2019s private jet at Incheon airport, west of Seoul, the approach of the plane drew news exhaustive coverage.\n\nCommentators analyzed her no-nonsense hairstyle and dress, her low-key makeup and the sprinkle of freckles on her cheeks. After she attended a luncheon at the presidential palace on Saturday, the palace released photographs of the message she wrote in the guest book expressing hope that \u201cPyongyang and Seoul get closer in our people\u2019s hearts.\u201d Social media promptly lit up with analysis of her peculiar handwriting.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer quietly friendly approach while in South Korea \u2014 photographers repeatedly captured her smiling \u2014 seemed to endear her to some observers.\n\nWaiting to enter the concert in Seoul on Sunday night, where Ms. Kim sat next to Mr. Moon, Lee Hwa-ik, 61, president of the Galleries Association of Korea, said that Ms. Kim \u201cseems like someone we can become closer to on a personal level and on a human-to-human level.\u201d\n\nOthers said they were horrified by the notion that Ms. Kim could lull South Koreans, or anyone else, into forgetting the North\u2019s repression and human rights abuses.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the face of the Kim family, which wouldn\u2019t even flinch when tens of thousands of people died for it,\u201d one Twitter user wrote. \u201cI see the arrogance and ruthlessness that one cannot find in people who grew up in a free society.\u201d\n\nA group of university students who had come to cheer on the Korean women\u2019s hockey team Saturday night (the Koreans lost to Switzerland, 8-0), said that they were excited about the historic moment and having the chance to see women from the two countries play together.\n\nBut they drew a sharp line between the athletes and citizens of North Korea, on one hand, and the dignitaries sitting in the stands representing Kim Jong-un\u2019s regime on the other.\n\n\u201cI think Kim Jong-un is really a bad person and a villain,\u201d said Park Keon-ho, 24, a computer science student at Korea University of Technology and Education. \u201cBut I love North Koreans. I think North Koreans and South Koreans were all together as one family, and we come from the same root.\u201d", "title": "Kim Jong-un\u2019s Sister Turns On the Charm, Taking Pence\u2019s Spotlight", "authors": ["Motoko Rich", "Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "About half of the king penguin population nests on the Crozet and Prince Edward Islands, in the Indian Ocean south of Madagascar, and are projected to lose their habitat by 2100, according to the model. The 21 percent that nest on the Kerguelen Islands in the Indian Ocean and the Falkland and Tierra del Fuego islands close to South America would find their nesting grounds altered and would have to travel farther to find food and so might relocate. But, the researchers said, some of that would be offset by the colonization of Bouvet Island and a few other islands.\n\nSeveral others are likely to become more habitable, according to the research. But unlike their bigger cousins the emperor penguins, king penguins can\u2019t nest on ice so their choices are limited and may be hundreds or even thousands of miles from their current nesting areas.\n\nIt\u2019s a tall order, said Dr. Trucchi, who collaborated on the study with C\u00e9line Le Bohec of the National Center of Scientific Research in France and the Scientific Center of Monaco, as well as Robin Cristofari of the University of Turku, Finland, among others.\n\nMore Reporting on Penguins\n\nGenetically, all the king penguins belong to one population, though they are dispersed by thousands of miles, suggesting they already migrate somewhat among the islands, he said.\n\nAlthough a 70 percent loss sounds like a lot, it\u2019s probably a conservative estimate, said Jane Younger, an evolutionary ecologist at Loyola University Chicago, who was not involved in the research.\n\nThe fish and krill that penguins feed on are subject to overfishing and acidification with climate change, which will probably mean less food will be available in the years and decades to come, she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nProtecting the fish in the polar front will be crucial for the king penguins, \u201cto ensure they have the best chance of surviving climate change,\u201d said Gemma Clucas, a postdoctoral research assistant at the University of New Hampshire, who was not involved in the new study.\n\nThe new model is particularly useful for making conservation decisions, Dr. Younger said. \u201cIf there are some islands that are likely to be relatively safe, like those in the south, then we know about that now, and we can potentially protect those from other threats like fishing and tourism \u2014 to give animals the best chance of survival,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCeridwen Fraser, a marine molecular ecologist at the Australian National University, in Canberra, said that many species are trying to move toward the poles to find cooler homes. \u201cIn the northern hemisphere, there\u2019s land and coast at most latitudes, so it\u2019s not too hard for lots of plants and animals to shift north and find places they can live,\u201d said Dr. Fraser, who was not involved in the new research.\n\nBut in the south, she said, \u201cyou\u2019ve got Antarctica and then you\u2019ve got this whopping great ocean around it, with just a handful of scattered islands.\u201d\n\nShe hopes that attention to the plight of the king penguin will encourage people to do more to combat global warming.\n\n\u201cThese are kind of poster children for what\u2019s going to happen with climate change,\u201d Dr. Fraser said. \u201cPeople wouldn\u2019t care as much if it were a slug or a slime mold, but the same sorts of impacts will happen to many different species. In a way it\u2019s good for us to see these impacts happening to animals we love, because it might spur a little bit of action.\u201d", "title": "King Penguins Are Endangered by Warmer Seas", "authors": ["Karen Weintraub"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "The ferry was reported missing when it did not arrive two days after setting sail from Nonouti Island, but New Zealand, which assists with maritime rescues in the area, was not asked for help for more than a week.\n\nOn its second day of an aerial search using radar and ocean-current modeling, the New Zealand military found an aluminum dinghy with seven people on board, including a 14-year-old girl, who had survived in the motorless vessel for more than a week with no shade or supplies.\n\nAt the time, the New Zealand military said it was \u201coptimistic\u201d about finding more survivors. The passengers rescued from the dinghy said others had escaped the sinking in a life raft after the ferry split in two.\n\nThe ferry hit an atoll after setting sail, and repairs were carried out to the propeller shaft.\n\nThe New Zealand military said a week of wind and ocean currents meant the search area was growing by the day, and by Monday it had reached 200,000 square miles.\n\nAir Commodore Darryn Webb, a spokesman for the New Zealand effort, said that it was not unusual for the country\u2019s military to be asked for help when boats went missing, and that people often traveled between Kiribati\u2019s atolls in \u201crudimentary vessels.\u201d", "title": "Kiribati Ends Aerial Search for Missing Ferry Passengers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was at the West 72nd Street subway station at the tail end of the morning rush hour. Sherman", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Knicks made a three-way trade in the final minutes before the N.B.A. trade deadline on Thursday that brings Emmanuel Mudiay of the Denver Nuggets to New York. The 21-year-old guard was the most prominent piece of the trade that also sent small forward Doug McDermott to the Dallas Mavericks.\n\nAs part of the deal, the Mavericks agreed to send Devin Harris to Denver, and the Nuggets and Knicks exchanged second-round picks in the 2018 draft.\n\nPlaying without Mudiay on Thursday, the Knicks lost to the Toronto Raptors by a score of 113-88.\n\nMudiay is coming off a tough two seasons for the Nuggets. The Knicks selected Hernangomez, a Spaniard, with the 35th pick in the 2015 draft.", "title": "Knicks Trade Willy Hernangomez to Charlotte Hornets for Picks", "authors": ["Marc Stein"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "There is also some controversy surrounding the nomination: #MeToo activists say that a 2003 sexual-assault case against Mr. Bryant is reason not to reward the movie. (The case was dismissed.) An online petition is seeking to rescind the nod, and the argument has been taken up on social media.\n\nMr. Bryant deliberately chose an artist who didn\u2019t know basketball: \u201cSomeone who\u2019s been watching basketball their whole lives \u2014 and playing it \u2014 tends to miss the small moves, the details. When you come at it with fresh eyes, you look at every single thing because it\u2019s all new.\u201d\n\nMr. Keane said, \u201cI\u2019ve always believed animation can help an audience understand an action in deeper ways than live action.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou can edit the movement, leaving out extraneous details and emphasizing the important points,\u201d he added. \u201cThere\u2019s something deeper and more emotional that art can communicate, even though you can take a photo of the same thing.\u201d\n\nMr. Bryant\u2019s poem begins with recollections of himself as a boy, practicing dribbling with a basketball made of his father\u2019s tube socks. He attains his dream of playing professionally, then realizes his career must eventually end: His aging body can no longer endure the demands of the sport. Mr. Keane\u2019s drawings juxtapose the boy and the adult.\n\nMr. Bryant, who spent two decades with the Los Angeles Lakers in a run that included five N.B.A. titles, said he wanted a younger generation of athletes to see the film and learn \u201cabout the emotional journey of having a dream, believing it\u2019ll come true; it comes true, then the realization that you have to wake up from that dream and move on to another.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Keane added, \u201cThe film doesn\u2019t have to be \u2018Dear Basketball,\u2019 it\u2019s \u2018Dear Animation,\u2019 it\u2019s \u2018Dear Medicine,\u2019 it\u2019s \u2018Dear Whatever-You-Dreamed-of-When-You-Were-a-Child.\u2019\u201d\n\nAt Disney, Mr. Keane was known for loose, powerful drawings. Some of their strength was inevitably lost when they were traced, inked and painted for the films. Although this practice is standard throughout the animation industry, Mr. Bryant wanted the spontaneity and roughness of Mr. Keane\u2019s original drawings \u2014 which appear on screen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMy career \u2014 like other things in life \u2014 was never perfect. There\u2019s beauty in those imperfections, and the last thing I wanted to do was create a film where all the lines were perfect and the coloring was perfect,\u201d he explained. \u201cThat would have taken away from the humanity of the piece, which is about creating and enjoying that journey of imperfection. It was really important for the animation to be 2D and feel almost sketchy.\u201d\n\nThree years earlier, Mr. Bryant had reached out to John Williams, but not about film. He thought understanding the composer\u2019s writing and conducting process might help him on the court: \u201cHow did he lead a large orchestra to create such beautiful music? I was trying to relate the art of conducting to leading a basketball team to a championship.\u201d\n\nThe composer was surprised when the athlete contacted him. \u201cI couldn\u2019t imagine why Kobe wanted to meet me,\u201d Mr. Williams recalled. \u201cI told him I had never been to a basketball game \u2014 high school, college or professional.\u201d\n\nNevertheless, they quickly became friends, and when he was asked to compose the score, Mr. Williams agreed immediately: \u201cI thought \u2018Dear Basketball\u2019 was a very reassuring and contributive little piece.\u201d\n\nAlthough they\u2019re excited about the Oscar nomination and enjoyed working together, Mr. Keane and Mr. Bryant will not be collaborating in the immediate future. Mr. Keane is slated to direct the feature \u201cOver the Moon\u201d for Pearl Studio in China. \u201cThis has been an amazing moment in my artistic life, pushing me into a field where I felt I had no business,\u201d he said. \u201cThen I realized, animation can go anywhere, can\u2019t it?\n\nMr. Bryant is developing other ideas for films. \u201cAging can be very difficult for athletes,\u201d he said. \u201cWe train our whole lives, we dedicate ourselves to a craft we have to leave early because our bodies will not allow us to go on.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhat you\u2019ve done for so long becomes who you are, and it\u2019s very, very difficult to walk away from it and do something else,\u201d he continued. \u201cSo to be two years into retirement and have an Oscar nomination means so much.\u201d", "title": "With \u2018Dear Basketball,\u2019 Kobe Bryant Could Add an Oscar to His Victories", "authors": ["Charles Solomon"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Ten years ago on Feb. 17, the mountainous, landlocked region of less than two million people declared independence from Serbia. Yet far from ending Kosovo\u2019s troubles, independence seems to have brought a new set of problems.\n\nI have visited Kosovo frequently since arriving for the first time in late 1998 for a two-week trip. I returned in February 1999 and based myself in Pristina, the capital, until 2005. Babies are given the names of the war dead; friends change their names to those of famous fighters who have been killed, or just of fallen friends.\n\nSome Kurds even seem to invite death in war, which their American advisers say makes them formidable in battle \u2014 though likely to take considerable casualties. The Americans have expressed consternation that the Kurds will seldom wear body armor or helmets, even when they have the equipment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe have a lot of that stuff here, somewhere in storage,\u201d said Haqi Kobani, the deputy commander in charge of administration for the Syrian Democratic Forces, at the militia\u2019s headquarters in northern Syria. \u201cNo one ever wants to wear them.\u201d\n\nOf female fighters, suicide attackers are the most highly praised, and pictures of them are displayed especially prominently, as with the recent case of Avesta Khabur, who blew herself up to destroy a Turkish tank in Afrin. Within two days, her face was everywhere in northern Syria.\n\nIn the cemetery for war dead in Qamishli, a city in northern Syria, Farhan Ebid, his son and a friend were planting an olive tree this month in front of the grave of another son, Orhan Qamislo, who died fighting with the Syrian Democratic Forces in Manbij at age 21.\n\nMr. Ebid\u2019s son Abdulrazaq, 19, then joined the Y.P.G. to replace his brother, taking his brother\u2019s backpack, his rifle \u2014 and his name. In the talks, the officials say, Mr. Kushner has insisted that he maintain his current level of access, including the ability to review the daily intelligence briefing when he sees fit.\n\nBut Mr. Kelly, who has been privately dismissive of Mr. Kushner since taking the post of chief of staff but has rarely taken him on directly, has made no guarantees, saying only that the president\u2019s son-in-law will still have all the access he needs to do his job under the new system.\n\n\u201cAs I told Jared days ago, I have full confidence in his ability to continue performing his duties in his foreign policy portfolio including overseeing our Israeli-Palestinian peace effort and serving as an integral part of our relationship with Mexico,\u201d Mr. Kelly said in a statement the White House released on Tuesday in which he refused to address Mr. Kushner\u2019s security clearance or elaborate on his memo.\n\n\u201cEveryone in the White House is grateful for these valuable contributions to furthering the president\u2019s agenda,\u201d Mr. Kelly said of Mr. Kushner. \u201cThere is no truth to any suggestion otherwise.\u201d\n\nIt is unclear whether Mr. Kushner would need to review highly classified information. His current portfolio \u2014 which includes acting as an intermediary with Mexico, trying to forge Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations, participating in an economic dialogue with China and working on revising the North American Free Trade Agreement \u2014 seems unlikely to involve major intelligence or national security secrets. But Mr. Kushner, by dint of his relationship with Mr. Trump, has wide-ranging access to the president and the information that he sees, and senior advisers to the president typically require such access to perform their duties.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe fact that the White House chief of staff would take the step of publicly denying that a policy change would harm the president\u2019s son-in-law pointed up the tension in the West Wing after the Porter episode, particularly between Mr. Kelly on one side, and Mr. Kushner and his wife, Ivanka Trump, who had been close allies of Mr. Porter, on the other.\n\nMr. Kushner and Ms. Trump have been critical of Mr. Kelly in conversations with the president, who spent the weekend at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Fla., surveying people about whether he should fire his chief of staff. However, since Mr. Porter\u2019s departure, one official said, Mr. Kushner and Ms. Trump have told people around the White House that they have been vocal in their attempts to defend Mr. Kelly but are being treated unfairly in return.\n\nOne person familiar with Mr. Kushner\u2019s thinking, who insisted on anonymity to describe it, denied that he felt personally targeted by Mr. Kelly or was agitating to have him removed. Another White House official denied that Mr. Kushner had ever raised the issue of the intelligence summary in his discussions with Mr. Kelly over his clearance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the memo, deliberately or otherwise, has shone an unflattering light on Mr. Kushner, raising questions about whether he can be effective in his post and how much authority he has. That debate threatens to complicate what Mr. Kelly has acknowledged is a long-overdue effort inside the White House to get a handle on the clearance process, a national security imperative over which top officials appear to have placed little priority after Mr. Trump took office.\n\n\u201cWe should \u2014 and in the future, must \u2014 do better,\u201d Mr. Kelly said in his memo last week.\n\nThe questions surrounding Mr. Kushner\u2019s clearance are particularly acute because of the possibility that his extensive contacts with foreign actors \u2014 including travel, meetings with leaders overseas and multiple business ventures \u2014 might be relevant to the investigation by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election.\n\nMr. Kushner initially failed to disclose scores of those contacts on the standard form required for all prospective government officials, and has since amended his submission, substantially delaying his background check.\n\nThat meant that his background information was not submitted in its entirety until June, after the June 1 cutoff that Mr. Kelly set in his memo.\n\nUnder the new policy, anyone holding interim clearance to see top secret or sensitive compartmented information whose background investigation had been pending since then is to be stripped of that access by Friday. Even if Mr. Kushner was not in that initial group, the document suggested that his status would soon be reviewed, and that his access going forward would be subject entirely to Mr. Kelly\u2019s discretion.\n\n\u201cSimilar reviews will occur monthly for long-outstanding adjudications,\u201d Mr. Kelly wrote. The new rules, he said, would \u201climit access to certain highly classified information for those individuals working with interim clearance status absent explicit chief of staff\u2019s office approval, which would be granted only in the most compelling circumstances.\u201d\n\n", "title": "Kushner Resists Losing Access as Kelly Tackles Security Clearance Issues", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "In 2003, J.T. sued the prosecutors who had hidden the evidence in his case for failing to train their lawyers on the importance of turning over favorable evidence. The jury, considering the blatant destruction of evidence in J.T.\u2019s case, awarded him $1 million for every year he was on death row \u2014 $14 million in total.\n\nWhen the prosecutors appealed, they argued, with a straight face, that what had happened to J.T. was so outrageous and illegal that the New Orleans district attorney could not be held responsible. The case went all the way to the Supreme Court.\n\nEnter Kyle Duncan, the man we are to believe has the fairness and temperament to be a federal judge.\n\nMr. Duncan is best known for his work in Washington, D.C., as the former general counsel for the Becket Fund for Religious Liberty, a conservative organization that \u201cdefends religious liberty for all.\u201d He played a leading role in opposing the provision of the Affordable Care Act requiring employers to provide insurance coverage for contraceptives. Mr. Duncan also defended North Carolina\u2019s photo ID law that the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit wrote had targeted black voters \u201cwith almost surgical precision.\u201d He also defended Louisiana\u2019s ban on gay marriage in several different courts before the Supreme Court prohibited state bans on gay marriage.\n\nWhile representing the prosecutors when the case went to the Supreme Court, Mr. Duncan was serving as what he later called \u201csolicitor general\u201d of Louisiana, a position that does not exist. He devised the argument that, although the district attorney had withheld evidence in many cases involving innocent men, there was no need to train lawyers in his office because they would have learned about their obligation in law school.\n\nThe Supreme Court sided with the prosecutors, 5 to 4. Mr. Duncan received the Louisiana District Attorneys Association award for outstanding service for his work on the case.", "title": "Opinion | Kyle Duncan Is Unfit to Be a Judge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "L .L. Bean is no longer interested in replacing the ratty sweatshirts or worn-down boots you bought from the company decades ago.\n\nThe purveyor of outdoor products, famous for its 100 percent satisfaction guarantee, said that a growing number of customers had abused the policy by treating it as a \u201clifetime product-replacement program.\u201d The retailer will immediately begin enforcing stricter rules for shoppers seeking to exchange items or obtain or get refunds.\n\nUnder the new policy, consumers will have a year to make returns, and will be required to provide proof of purchase, L. L. Bean said in a Facebook post on Friday. The company, which is based in Freeport, Me., said it would work with customers to provide a \u201cfair solution\u201d if products showed defects after the return window had closed.\n\nShawn O. Gorman, L. L. Bean\u2019s executive chairman and a great-grandson of Leon Leonwood Bean, the company\u2019s founder, wrote in the post that the changes would affect a small percentage of returns and would have \u201cno impact for the vast majority\u201d of customers.", "title": "L.L. Bean, Citing Abuse, Tightens Its Generous Policy on Returns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Before 2015, a company could be considered a joint employer under federal labor law only if it exercised direct and immediate control over workers at the franchise.\n\nBut in a case known as Browning-Ferris, the board ruled that the parent company could be deemed a joint employer even if the control it exerted was indirect \u2014 for example, if it forced the franchisee to use software that committed it to certain scheduling practices. The board ruled that the parent company could also be considered a joint employer if the company had the right to exercise control over a franchisee that it did not exercise in practice.\n\nThe more liberal definition of who qualified as a joint employer removed a potentially significant obstacle to workers at fast-food restaurants and hotels who sought to unionize. A parent company that terminates a franchise agreement to avoid doing business with a franchisee whose workers are trying to unionize may face legal liability for doing so if it is considered a joint employer.\n\nIn December, the board, with its new Republican majority, took up a case known as Hy-Brand and voted to revert to the pre-2015 standard requiring direct and immediate control.\n\nBut that case did not raise any questions that hinged on what standard to apply \u2014 the Obama-era guidelines or the previous ones. Partly as a result, the inspector general argued in his report, it was simply a pretext for relitigating Browning-Ferris.\n\n\u201cThe practical effect of the Hy-Brand deliberative process was a \u2018do-over\u2019 for the Browning-Ferris parties,\u201d the inspector general stated.\n\nThis created the potential conflict for Mr. Emanuel, whose former law firm had represented a party in the Browning-Ferris case. If the more recent case was simply a do-over for the previous case, the inspector general argued, then Mr. Emanuel should have recused himself.", "title": "Labor Board\u2019s Do-Over Leaves an Obama-Era Rule Intact", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "But labor advocacy groups and former Obama administration officials argue that the regulation would legalize a vast income transfer from workers to employers, who would be permitted to pocket the tips.\n\n\u201cThere is a lot of wage theft, tip stealing in restaurants and other sectors where workers depend on tips,\u201d Christine Owens of the National Employment Law Project said. \u201cThis would be one more reason for employers to take workers\u2019 tips and do whatever they want to do with them.\u201d\n\nA study by the Economic Policy Institute, a left-leaning think tank, estimated that the change would cost current tipped workers $5.8 billion a year in pay. It cast doubt on the idea that employers would use the money to compensate other workers better.\n\nHeidi Shierholz, a former chief economist at the Labor Department who oversaw the study, said that under standard economic theory, employers were unlikely to pay workers more than needed to attract and retain them, which they are by definition already doing in most cases.\n\nShe predicted that if the regulation took effect and employers decided to share tips with these workers, \u201ctheir base pay would be reduced and there would be no more take-home pay.\u201d\n\nThe Labor Department estimated that the rule would affect about one million waiters and waitresses and over 200,000 bartenders. Workers in other industries, like hairstylists and manicurists, would also be affected.\n\nMany tipped workers would not be affected, however, because the law would continue to prevent employers from taking the tips of those who earned less than the minimum wage. The law allows workers to be paid below the minimum wage as long as their tips make up the difference.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe proposed rule has generated a surprising amount of attention, attracting more than 180,000 comments from the public by Friday. That is roughly two-thirds the number of comments that the Obama administration\u2019s proposal to increase overtime eligibility \u2014 which affected millions more workers and nearly every industry \u2014 generated after it was formally unveiled in 2015.\n\nAt least one major business group and some restaurant owners wrote that the rule would allow employers to put in place new pay practices that benefited both them and workers.\n\n\u201cIt used to be that our servers typically made 1.5 to two times more than our kitchen staff, which is a big gap, but now they make two to four times more,\u201d wrote Kim Snuggerud, who owns the Hilo Bay Cafe in Hawaii. \u201cThis gap can be better managed with this change in the regulations. The wage disparity creates many problems, from morale issues to higher turnover.\u201d\n\nIn an interview, Ms. Snuggerud emphasized that she was not a supporter of President Trump and tended to favor minimum-wage increases and \u201cbig government.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut many self-identified former restaurant owners, along with many workers and customers, wrote in to oppose the rule, saying it was unfair and might even amount to theft.\n\nAdding to the controversy is the Labor Department\u2019s failure to include a numerical analysis of the costs and benefits of the rule when it formally released the proposal. A longstanding executive order typically requires such an analysis for regulations that would have an economic impact of at least $100 million.\n\n\u201cWhen you put out a proposed rule, you have to put out the analysis you have that shows the impact of it,\u201d said Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the top Democrat on the committee that has oversight over the department. \u201cI think, frankly, if they do that, people would be outraged.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen it released the proposal, the department said that the omission was the result of \u201ca lack of adequate data and the speculative nature of determining how employers, employees and customers would all react.\u201d\n\nBut several former Labor Department officials said that while uncertainties and data limitations complicated any effort to measure costs and benefits, economists had well-established practices for addressing them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere are assumptions one has to make, but you build that into the analysis,\u201d said David Weil, the former head of the division that enforces minimum-wage and overtime rules, which also produced this proposal. \u201cOn its face, it\u2019s just a ridiculous assertion.\u201d\n\nMs. Shierholz said it had taken her team of four primary researchers less than two weeks to generate their estimate.\n\nA Labor Department spokesman said that the department had sought public input about how to estimate costs and benefits when it released its proposal and that it \u201cintends to publish an informed cost-benefit analysis as part of any final rule.\u201d\n\nThe spokesman pointed out that the 2011 rule also did not include a detailed cost-benefit analysis, though former Labor Department officials say that was because the rule codified existing policy and did not change policy.\n\nOn Thursday, Bloomberg Law reported that the department had, in fact, produced an economic analysis, but that Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta and his aides had chosen not to release it after it showed that the cost to tipped workers could be substantial.\n\nThe department declined to comment. But two former Labor Department officials said they had been briefed on the analysis by people currently at the department and echoed this account.\n\nMichael Hancock, another former top official in the division that produced the proposal, said he found it unimaginable that the department would not have produced an economic analysis because officials at the Office of Management and Budget, who must typically sign off on new regulations, would refuse to do so without one.\n\n\u201cAt least during my time, O.M.B. jealously guarded the executive order,\u201d said Mr. Hancock, who worked at the department for two decades beginning in 1995. \u201cThey always insisted if it\u2019s even close to the threshold that you\u2019ve got to do an economic analysis, no matter how challenging.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe restaurant industry contends that the Obama-era regulation is illegal because it goes beyond what the underlying law supports. It asked the Supreme Court to review the Obama rule after appellate courts in different parts of the country split on the issue.\n\n\u201cI would say the process was not followed in 2011,\u201d Mr. Amador said. \u201cIf there\u2019s any flaw here, it\u2019s that an illegal regulation passed in 2011.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Hancock said the proposed change would be highly vulnerable to a legal challenge if completed because omitting an economic analysis denied the public a chance to comment.\n\n\u201cThe rule-making process is designed to give the public an opportunity to have their voices heard,\u201d he said. \u201cIf you don\u2019t include the economic analysis that underlies all of this, the public never had an opportunity to do that. I think it\u2019s going to create legal problems.\u201d", "title": "Labor Dept. Plan Could Let the Boss Pocket the Tip", "authors": ["Noam Scheiber"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe French dairy giant Lactalis is at the center of one of Europe\u2019s biggest food-safety scandals amid revelations that its infant formulas were tainted with salmonella. The company initially found traces of the bacteria at its main factory in August and has recalled more than 7,000 tons of potentially contaminated products from more than 80 countries, mostly in Europe, Africa and Asia. Here\u2019s some information that could be useful for those who think their children may have been exposed to the contaminated products.\n\nHow can I tell if my baby has salmonella poisoning?\n\nSalmonella is a bacteria that can cause infections like gastroenteritis. Symptoms usually appear eight to 48 hours after a child has been exposed to the bacteria. Telltale signs include sudden high fever, cramps, vomiting, diarrhea, blood in the stool and possible rectal bleeding. The symptoms can last from a couple of days to a week and may be relatively mild. But several parents in France have reported that their infants had worse reactions and weakened immune systems, requiring further hospitalization.\n\nWhat should I do if I think there\u2019s a problem?\n\nIf your child has salmonella poisoning, gastroenteritis or any other type of serious stomach illness, seek medical advice if her temperature rises suddenly, if she appears drowsy or confused, if she has cramps or is vomiting and can\u2019t keep fluids down. Check her stool for signs of blood. Be sure to double-check which products she has consumed.\n\nWhat Lactalis products were affected?\n\nOver 7,000 tons of Lactalis baby food products suspected of salmonella contamination have been recalled since December, although a full recall from supermarkets, pharmacies and even hospitals took at least a month to play out. It is unclear how many potentially affected products are still on the shelves in countries besides France. The most popular infant formula brands affected were Milumel, Pepti Junior and Picot. Also recalled was Maltodextridine, a milk powder used for industrial production and sold to consumers in Africa and other countries. The full list of recalled products is here.\n\nWhere can I turn for support?\n\nAn organization of French families, the Association of Victims of Salmonella Contaminated Milk, is providing support and information to parents who think or know their children have been sickened by Lactalis products. The company has said that baby foods produced at its French factory may have been exposed to salmonella since 2005. The French Health Ministry has up-to-date information, including recommendations from pediatricians.", "title": "Lactalis\u2019s Salmonella-Contaminated Baby Formula: What Parents Should Know", "authors": ["Liz Alderman"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Le g\u00e9ant fran\u00e7ais de l\u2019industrie laiti\u00e8re Lactalis est au coeur d\u2019un des plus grands scandales alimentaires d\u2019Europe apr\u00e8s la r\u00e9v\u00e9lation d\u2019une contamination aux salmonelles de certains de ses produits infantiles. L\u2019entreprise a rappel\u00e9 plus de 7000 tonnes de laits potentiellement contamin\u00e9s dans plus de 80 pays, pour la plupart europ\u00e9ens, africains et asiatiques. Voici quelques informations utiles \u00e0 ceux dont les enfants pourraient avoir \u00e9t\u00e9 expos\u00e9s \u00e0 l\u2019un des produits contamin\u00e9s.\n\nComment savoir si mon b\u00e9b\u00e9 souffre de salmonellose?\n\nLa salmonellose est une infection bact\u00e9rienne qui peut provoquer une affection intestinale telle que la gastro-ent\u00e9rite. La contamination devient en g\u00e9n\u00e9ral visible entre 8 et 48 heures apr\u00e8s l\u2019exposition de l\u2018enfant \u00e0 la bact\u00e9rie. Les premiers signes sont une fi\u00e8vre soudaine, des crampes d\u2019estomac, une diarrh\u00e9e, des vomissements, du sang dans les selles et, dans certains cas, des saignements au niveau du rectum. Les sympt\u00f4mes peuvent durer entre deux jours et une semaine et \u00eatre assez l\u00e9gers. En France, plusieurs parents ont cependant fait part d\u2019une soudaine d\u00e9gradation de l\u2019\u00e9tat de sant\u00e9 de leur enfant et d\u2019un affaiblissement de leur syst\u00e8me immunitaire n\u00e9cessitant la prolongation de leur hospitalisation.\n\nQue faire en cas de probl\u00e8me potentiel?\n\nSi votre enfant souffre de salmonellose, de gastro-ent\u00e9rite ou de tout autre probl\u00e8me pr\u00e9occupant \u00e0 l\u2019estomac, il est imp\u00e9ratif de consulter un m\u00e9decin si sa temp\u00e9rature augmente soudainement, s\u2019il semble engourdi, s\u2019il a des crampes ou vomit sans retenue. Il convient de v\u00e9rifier la pr\u00e9sence de sang dans ses selles. Prenez soin de v\u00e9rifier les produits qu\u2019il a consomm\u00e9s.\n\nQuels sont les produits Lactalis concern\u00e9s ?\n\nPlus de 7 000 tonnes de laits infantiles susceptibles d\u2019avoir \u00e9t\u00e9 contamin\u00e9s par la salmonelle ont \u00e9t\u00e9 retir\u00e9s du march\u00e9 depuis d\u00e9but d\u00e9cembre en France. Il a cependant fallu attendre plus d\u2019un mois pour que la totalit\u00e9 des produits concern\u00e9s soient retir\u00e9s des pharmacies, des supermarch\u00e9s et des h\u00f4pitaux. Il est difficile de d\u00e9terminer combien de ces laits demeurent en vente hors de France. Les marques concern\u00e9es les plus r\u00e9pandues sont les laits Picot, Pepti Junior et Milumel. Le lait en poudre Maltodextridine, utilis\u00e9 dans la production alimentaire industrielle et vendu en Afrique et dans d\u2019autres pays, a \u00e9galement fait l\u2019objet d\u2019un rappel. La liste compl\u00e8te des produits rappel\u00e9s est consultable ici.", "title": "Lait infantile Lactalis contamin\u00e9 par la salmonelle: ce que les parents doivent savoir", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Nassar, in a final statement, said that he was sorry, and that the words of the young women and parents \u201cimpacted me to my innermost core.\u201d But he added that he knew \u201cit pales in comparison to the pain, trauma and emotions that you all feel.\u201d\n\nThe sentencing in Eaton County marked the end of weeks of emotional statements by young women and girls who said they were abused by Dr. Nassar under the guise of medical treatment. Judge Cunningham said on the first day of the hearing that the number of victims who had come forward had risen to 265, some of whom have chosen to remain anonymous.\n\nLast month, more than 150 of them publicly confronted him during a seven-day hearing in Ingham County Circuit Court in Lansing, where he had pleaded guilty in November to seven counts of sexual assault. Last month, its entire board of directors stepped down after the United States Olympic Committee threatened it with decertification.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe case has also prompted a shake-up within M.S.U., Dr. Nassar\u2019s former employer.
