Adriana Urbina, who worked at Rouge Tomate and Atera, will take over the kitchen next month.", "title": "Legacy Records Lends Several Dining Options to Hudson Yards", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "We\u2019re guarding against death.\n\nBut I don\u2019t say that out loud. Not before his surgery, not during, and not after. Because if I do, and he dies \u2026 then none of the pieces will fit together. We won\u2019t be a set anymore. It will just be me, standing in Target, holding those Legos, and holding onto that perfect moment where there was space and a smile and an aisle full of toys; where there was air and there was life and there was a perfect little boy. Where we were riding the Ninjago ride for the fourth time with our 3D glasses, and money and credit cards and hospital bills didn\u2019t matter because he was there, and he was happy.\n\nI stare down at the package in his hands. It\u2019s a Batman set \u2014 the Joker Balloon Escape. It\u2019s ridiculous, really. Batman is shooting his grappling gun at the Joker, who is flying away in a cloud of rainbow-colored balloons. All for $14.99.\n\nI swallow the stone, clear my throat, and nod my head.\n\n\u201cYes,\u201d I say. His eyes light up. His face breaks into a smile. \u201cPut it in the cart.\u201d\n\nAs I write this, my eyes well up and the stone rises. I wipe my face, and I swallow it down again, but never away, never gone \u2014 even after the surgery, even after the weeks of recovery. Because I\u2019ve waited those seven hours. I\u2019ve walked into that intensive care unit. I\u2019ve seen him with that breathing tube, I\u2019ve seen him in that wheelchair, and I\u2019ve seen him dizzy \u2014 struggling to stand. I\u2019ve heard the cardiologist say blood clot, and I\u2019ve watched the fluid in his chest. I\u2019ve stood on the edge of life as the heart bypass machine worked the blood through his body, and I swallowed that stone 30 times as I waited for him to open his eyes. Just open his eyes. Just open his eyes.\n\nAnd sometimes I think that\u2019s what love is. It\u2019s the heart-shaped stone stuck in your throat. It\u2019s the Legos. It\u2019s the way he looks up at you. It\u2019s the flash of smile, his glittering eyes, and the feeling that if anything ever went wrong, you\u2019d find those Legos, you\u2019d hold up that toy and you\u2019d tell anyone \u2014 anyone who\u2019d listen \u2014 that he was the best of you.\n\nThat he was the heart and the stone and the smile and the balloons. He was the air and the tears and the laughter and the toys. He was yours. Forever.", "title": "Legos for a Child With a Hole in His Heart", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey don\u2019t contemplate this request lightly, doctors,\u201d she wrote. \u201cMedical-malpractice suits are real, and women are attached to their uteruses (for me, an almost blind, delusional loyalty, like I\u2019d have to a bad boyfriend).\u201d\n\nBecause of the nature of the procedure, Ms. Dunham said her doctor required \u201cevidence he\u2019s operating on someone resolved enough to give consent and never take it back.\u201d That meant she had to sit through consultations with two different therapists, one of whom was recommended by her doctor, while she managed extreme chronic pain, she said.\n\nThe National Women\u2019s Health Network says hysterectomies are the second most performed procedure in the United States for women of reproductive age, though doctors are reluctant to perform them on women as young as Ms. Dunham.\n\nAccording to the organization, it is \u201cincredibly unlikely that a doctor will perform a hysterectomy on women ages 18-35 unless it is absolutely necessary for their well-being and no other options will suffice.\u201d\n\nThe procedure can be performed on younger women in response to maladies like uterine fibroids, cancer or endometriosis, a condition in which the tissue that normally lines the inside of the uterus grows on the outside of it, sometimes on organs like the bladder or the bowel, according to the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development.", "title": "Lena Dunham Says She Had Hysterectomy After Endometriosis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Chancler was born in Shreveport, La., on July 1, 1952, and moved with his family to Los Angeles. At 13 he started teaching himself to play drums, with advice from older musicians.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe started playing Latin jazz with the percussionist Willie Bobo while still in high school, and soon after graduation he joined Gerald Wilson\u2019s big band. He performed with the trumpeter Hugh Masekela on weekends (he died on Jan. 23) while studying music education at California State University, Dominguez Hills.\n\nMr. Chancler turned down an offer to join the keyboardist Herbie Hancock\u2019s band, choosing to stay in college, but he was a guest percussionist on Mr. Hancock\u2019s 1971 album, \u201cMwandishi.\u201d His reputation spread as he performed with visiting musicians at Shelly\u2019s Manne-Hole, a top Los Angeles jazz club.\n\nThroughout his recording career, he billed himself as Leon (Ndugu) Chancler, or sometimes Ndugu Chancler. The name Ndugu, given to him by the percussionist James Mtume in the early 1970s, is Swahili for \u201cearth brother,\u201d a family member or comrade.\n\nMr. Chancler was 19 when Mr. Davis asked him to join his group in 1971, and he left college behind. A CD-length performance by that group was released on the 2015 collection \u201cMiles Davis at Newport 1955-1975: The Bootleg Series Vol. 4.\u201d\n\nMr. Chancler worked widely and steadily, in the studio and on the road, in the 1970s. After a guest appearance on Santana\u2019s 1974 album \u201cBorboletta,\u201d he joined Santana on tour and on its 1976 album, \u201cAmigos,\u201d for which he was also one of the songwriters and producers\n\nThe jazz-rock band Weather Report, led by Mr. Shorter and Joe Zawinul, heard Mr. Chancler while working in a nearby studio and invited him to sit in. The sessions stretched to a week and yielded the 1975 album \u201cTale Spinnin\u2019.\u201d Mr. Chancler later played drums for a 1988 Montreux Jazz Festival collaboration between Carlos Santana and Mr. Shorter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs the 1970s ended, Mr. Chancler founded his own funk-pop group, the Chocolate Jam Co., which made two albums before disbanding, and became a first-call studio player in Los Angeles. The producer Quincy Jones hired Mr. Chancler for three songs on \u201cThriller,\u201d Michael Jackson\u2019s record-shattering 1982 album: \u201cP.Y.T. (Pretty Young Thing),\u201d \u201cBaby Be Mine\u201d and \u201cBillie Jean.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201c \u2018Billie Jean,\u2019 for me, was a lesson in musical discipline,\u201d Mr. Chancler told Modern Drummer magazine in 1983. \u201cA very simple rhythm that anybody can play who can play drums, but the whole discipline of it was just playing that, and being consistent at it.\u201d\n\nIn an Instagram post, Questlove, the Roots\u2019 drummer and bandleader, wrote that Mr. Chancler\u2019s drumming on \u201cBillie Jean\u201d was \u201ctimeless like a tuxedo\u201d and \u201cliterally gives MJ his DNA.\u201d\n\nMr. Chancler also appeared on Mr. Jackson\u2019s next album, \u201cBad,\u201d and on another early 1980s blockbuster album, Tina Turner\u2019s \u201cPrivate Dancer\u201d (1984). He embraced electronic drums and drum machines, learning to work with and alongside them, but also maintained his jazz virtuosity.\n\nIn recent decades, Mr. Chancler had mixed performing and teaching. He was a professor of jazz studies at the Thornton School of Music at the University of Southern California, where he created the drum curriculum. Since 1997 he had taught at the Stanford Jazz Workshop, a summer program held at Stanford University. He also performed at drum clinics presented by musical instrument companies.\n\n\u201cHe sponsored and funded kids for percussion and education trips, offering his own home,\u201d his son, Rashon Chancler, said in a statement. In addition to his son, he is survived by his companion, Brenda Curry, and six siblings: Londell Chaff, Louis Remer, Leroy Gibson, Henry Chancler Jr., Opal Chancler and Irma Gibson.\n\nMr. Chancler learned he had prostate cancer in 2003, but he continued to teach, perform and record until recently. He published a book of musical and career advice, \u201cPocket Change,\u201d in 2013.\n\n\u201cThe player has to do much more listening than the listener coming to enjoy the music,\u201d he told Drummer\u2019s Resource. \u201cAnd if that player is doing that listening, he will become a great player.\u201d", "title": "Leon (Ndugu) Chancler, Versatile Drummer, Is Dead at 65", "authors": ["Jon Pareles"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Lerone Bennett Jr., a historian and journalist who wrote extensively on race relations and black history and was a top editor at Ebony magazine for decades, died on Wednesday in Chicago. He was 89.\n\nThe cause was advanced vascular dementia, Ebony said on its website.\n\nMr. Bennett was both lyrical and outspoken in his writing, arguing that the history of black people in the United States had been ignored or told only through a white filter.\n\nHis best-known book was \u201cBefore the Mayflower,\u201d drawn from a series of articles for Ebony and first published in 1962. (Revised editions were still being published decades later.) In it he noted that the first blacks arrived in the colonies in 1619, the year before the Mayflower did, on a ship that reached Jamestown, Va. He wrote of that same arrival in a 1992 article in Ebony.", "title": "Lerone Bennett Jr., Historian of Black America, Dies at 89", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLaura Kumin was watching the Winter Olympics on Sunday night when the Italian figurer skater Matteo Rizzo appeared on the ice in a black jumpsuit with gold braiding across his chest. \u201cI was thinking, \u2018Oh my God. What about that outfit?\u2019\u201d she said. As she often does while watching television, she checked Twitter and saw that Leslie Jones, the \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d star who is live tweeting the Olympics for NBC, had the same reaction.\n\nMs. Jones has emerged as the Olympics\u2019 anti-announcer, funny and often salty, especially when it comes to the fashion, which, at its best, can be daring, and, its worst, well, she has her views.\n\n\u201cHe looks like the Nutcracker,\u201d Ms. Jones said of Mr. Rizzo in her spoken commentary, which often accompanies the phone video clips of the NBC broadcast. \u201cI don\u2019t like it.\u201d\n\nNothing escapes her sharp eye: not black gloves, not a skating pair in checkers (\u201cI don\u2019t even really know how to express the hate that I have\u201d), not even her and Johnny Weir\u2019s matching hairstyles. And she does it all while watching from home on her television and, sometimes, her laptop too. \u201cShe\u2019s not a fashion expert, and she is not holding herself out to be,\u201d said Melissa Rivers, the former host of E\u2019s \u201cFashion Police.\u201d \u201cShe takes all the haughtiness out of it.\u201d\n\nIt was Ms. Rivers\u2019s mother, Joan, who effectively created a genre of comedians commenting on fashion, with her scathing reviews of Hollywood glitterati. But unlike when the elder Ms. Rivers was alive, when the commentary would follow the event, the fashion curious now expect their commentary (and comedy) simultaneously. When Ms. Jones wondered aloud why some skating outfits seemed better than others last weekend, her followers chimed in right away, explaining the difference between ice dancing and figure skating.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis, of course, is not Ms. Jones\u2019s first time sharing Olympic gold with sports fans. In August 2016, Mike Shoemaker, a former producer for \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d who works with Seth Meyers, saw her tweets and told Jim Bell, now the president of NBC Olympics Production and Programming. (In one tweet, Ms. Jones was dressed as superfan in a red, white and blue costume.) She was hired to go to Rio de Janeiro to work on NBC\u2019s coverage of the Summer Olympics.\n\nFor some, Ms. Jones\u2019s account is how they watch the Olympics. John Moss, a business technology specialist in Atlanta, said he began following Ms. Jones on Twitter six months ago. When he does not have time to watch the Olympics, he checks in with her. \u201cI experience the Olympics through her,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Sunday, she tweeted about the fit of an skater\u2019s suspenders. Mr. Moss had issues with her fashion take. (\u201cSuspenders rock,\u201d he commented.) \u201cI thought, What is wrong with suspenders?\u201d he said. \u201cI wear suspenders.\u201d He agreed, though, about her assessment of a snowboarder whose pants were bunched around his knees. \u201cThat didn\u2019t seem right,\u201d he said.\n\nMs. Jones is headed to Pyeongchang, South Korea, in a few days for NBC. There she will be a contributor, according to the network, and attend Olympic events, meet and interview athletes, and continue to tweet. Her followers wouldn\u2019t want it any other way.", "title": "Leslie Jones\u2019s Twitter Makes Her the De Facto Olympics Fashion Critic (Again)", "authors": ["Laura M. Holson"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "My grandparents, great-aunts and great-uncles, the generation who lived through World War II, never visited a concentration camp. Neither have I. To remember the Holocaust, it\u2019s enough to ride the No. 35 tram through Warsaw. On its voyage from north to south, it passes sites of public commemoration, like the Monument to the Ghetto Heroes; the Umschlagplatz, where Jews from the ghetto were herded into railcars for transport to the death camps; and the Pawiak prison, the main holding place for political prisoners during the Nazi occupation. It also passes by places that have a more personal meaning: the location of what was once my great-grandparents\u2019 house and my grandfather\u2019s grave in Powazki Cemetery.\n\nSome places are public and private at the same time. I don\u2019t know how many relatives left Warsaw for the last time from the Umschlagplatz. Pawiak prison is where my grandfather\u2019s cousin, a Jew trying to survive with Aryan papers, died when the Warsaw Uprising began, on Aug. 1, 1944. One place that always makes me shudder when I pass doesn\u2019t even exist anymore: Ulica Gesia, or Goose Street. During the Nazi occupation, this was the location of the main prison for the ghetto. It\u2019s also where my mother\u2019s aunt Rose was shot to death with 14 other women on Dec. 15, 1941. According to what Rose\u2019s sisters heard after the war, she was caught on the Aryan side of the wall. A 12-year-old boy pointed her out to the Gestapo while she was riding a tram. It\u2019s likely that she\u2019s buried under the Arkadia Shopping Mall, a few stops up the line.\n\nWhat to make of this betrayal by a child? Should it be set against acts of kindness or heroism, like that of the Ukrainian who saved my father\u2019s father by helping him cross the Bug River in the fall of 1939, and the similar deeds of thousands of other Poles, Ukrainians and Belarussians who saved Jews? Or should it be paired with the even greater number of horrific acts committed by Polish citizens?\n\nThe history of the Holocaust in Poland is painful and complex. A new law passed by Poland\u2019s ruling Law and Justice Party aims to make it simple. Signed by President Andrzej Duda on Feb. 6, the legislation imposes punishment of up to three years in prison for those who \u201cpublicly and against the facts attribute to the Polish nation or the Polish state responsibility or co-responsibility for Nazi crimes committed by the German Third Reich.\u201d In other words, in Poland it may now be illegal to blame Poles for the Holocaust.", "title": "Opinion | Lessons on the Holocaust, From Warsaw\u2019s No. 35 Tram", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "And four separate studies have shown a positive association between using a safe injection site and starting addiction treatment.\n\nNeighbors and city officials sometimes challenge sites like these because they fear they will promote drug use and increase crime. Research instead suggests that they lead to increases in public order, with fewer discarded needles on the street and less drug use on the sidewalk, and have no impact on drug-related crimes.\n\nSuch sites certainly don\u2019t solve the problem of drug overdoses \u2014 Vancouver has had a recent spike in fentanyl-related overdose deaths, for instance. But they\u2019re effective as part of a larger harm-reduction movement, which assumes that no matter how many well-intentioned programs exist to prevent people from starting or continuing to use drugs, there will always be people who shoot up. It\u2019s better for everyone, the thinking goes, if they do that as safely as possible, with clean needles that are discarded properly. If the goal is to get drug users into treatment, the first step is to make sure they don\u2019t die.\n\nSo far, President Trump has advocated the opposite approach, focusing on law enforcement instead of harm reduction and promising to be \u201creally, really tough\u201d on people who deal drugs \u2014 an old idea that hasn\u2019t worked to save lives. The administration\u2019s 2019 budget plan proposed $13 billion over two years to address the opioid crisis, but it didn\u2019t include much detail about what, exactly, that money would fund. In December, the attorney general\u2019s office made its position on safe injection sites clear in response to a proposed facility in Vermont: \u201cIt is a crime, not only to use illicit narcotics, but to manage and maintain sites on which such drugs are used and distributed.\u201d\n\n\u201cIn short, opiate addicts need treatment, not a place to continue using,\u201d the office wrote.\n\nAdvocates agree on the need for evidence-based treatment and services to help homeless drug users find housing or mental health care, but that\u2019s not a reason to prosecute people trying to save lives at safe injection sites.\n\nThere is at least one unauthorized, invitation-only site in the United States that a small nonprofit has been secretly running, in an unadvertised location, for more than three years. Staff members have been able to reverse all eight overdoses that have occurred on-site.\n\nCritics of such sites raise legitimate concerns about normalizing drug use that could be fatal. But so far, the wealth of available evidence shows two things: Most of America\u2019s past policies have failed catastrophically, and the regions that have tried these sites have saved people.\n\nStates and other cities should follow the lead of Seattle and Philadelphia to open safe injection sites. One of the most meaningful things the Trump administration could do to help drug users and their families is to stay out of the way.", "title": "Opinion | Let Cities Open Safe Injection Sites", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "In a now-deleted tweet, which has nonetheless already become notorious, Paul Ryan tried to hype the benefits of his massive corporate tax cut by celebrating the example of a worker who\u2019s getting $1.50 more per week. That\u2019s roughly the price of a small French fries at McDonald\u2019s.\n\nShould we keep giving Ryan grief over that tweet? Yes, we should \u2013 and not just because it shows how out of touch he is. By highlighting the tiny tax cut some workers will get as if that were the point and main result of a bill that blows up the deficit by more than $1 trillion, he helps illustrate the bait-and-switch at the core of the whole G.O.P. agenda.\n\nFor tax cuts aren\u2019t free. Sooner or later, the federal government has to pay its way. Even if you don\u2019t think the budget deficit is currently a big problem, except under very special circumstances anything that reduces revenue will eventually have to be offset by later tax increases or spending cuts.\n\nAnd those special circumstances \u2013 basically a depressed economy that needs a fiscal boost \u2013 don\u2019t apply now, with the U.S. close to full employment.", "title": "Opinion | Let Them Eat French Fries", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "In August 2017, President Trump issued an executive order banning transgender Americans from serving in the military and tasked Defense Secretary Jim Mattis with giving him recommendations on how to carry out that ban. A Pentagon spokesman said that the recommendations were made on Friday.\n\nKristin Beck, a former Navy SEAL, served from 1990 to 2011. Ms. Beck, formerly known as Christopher, deployed 13 times, including to Afghanistan and Iraq. Along the way, she was awarded numerous ribbons and medals for her service, including a Bronze Star and a Purple Heart.\n\nIn 2013 Ms. Beck came out as a woman and began hormone therapy in preparation for sex reassignment surgery. If permitted, she would like to rejoin the military this year.\n\nIn this video op-ed, Ms. Beck makes a last-minute plea to allow all transgender Americans to serve their country.", "title": "Opinion | Let Transgender Americans Continue to Serve in the Military", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "NASHVILLE \u2014 The snow was three inches deep, a blizzard by Nashville standards, when I got a text from a parent supervising the neighborhood sledding: \u201cIt\u2019s a robin migration out in your front yard. Do you put food out there for them?\u201d\n\nI went to the window to look. There are nine bird feeders around my house, but I\u2019ve never seen a robin at a single one of them. In winter, robins do gather in great flocks here in Middle Tennessee, and our yard is always popular with them because we have a birdbath with a heating element that keeps it from freezing. Even in winter, birds need to bathe \u2014 a seemingly counterintuitive behavior that keeps their feathers in shape for maximum insulation.\n\nSo it didn\u2019t surprise me to find more than a hundred robins in our yard on that snowy day. What surprised me was what they were doing. A robin\u2019s usual practice here is to pick earthworms out of the exposed soil churned up by moles in what passes for a lawn at this house, but there are no worms near the surface on freezing days. Instead, these robins were eating dried berries from the brown monkey grass bordering our front walkway. Normally one of our sons mows down the monkey grass in late fall, after the first frost, but our youngest child left for college in August, and this year neither my husband nor I ever got around to cutting it back ourselves.\n\nI have never been a very orderly gardener. In spring I prefer planting to weeding. I like to watch birds pulling seeds from dried flowers, so I let the flowers fall to ruin in summer instead of deadheading them to force the plant to produce new blooms. In fall it has always seemed almost criminal to tidy up the golden windfall of sugar-maple leaves covering the ground like pirate\u2019s treasure in a storybook, so we let them lie until they\u2019re finally brown and brittle. By then there\u2019s no good reason not to bring out the mower and reduce the leaves to shreds so they can feed the trees they fell from.", "title": "Opinion | Let Your Winter Garden Go Wild", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump on Thursday repeated his call for \u201chighly trained\u201d schoolteachers to pack heat in their classrooms. If they were armed, the president said, they could fire back immediately at school shooters like the young man with an AR-15 semiautomatic rifle who took 17 lives in Parkland, Fla. Beyond that, he tweeted, the knowledge that teachers have guns of their own would deter \u201cthe sicko\u201d from heading to a school in the first place. With his usual fondness for capital letters, he added, \u201cATTACKS WOULD END!\u201d\n\nThus did Mr. Trump parrot a tired shibboleth repeated once again on Thursday by Wayne LaPierre, the executive vice president of the National Rifle Association. \u201cTo stop a bad guy with a gun, it takes a good guy with a gun,\u201d Mr. LaPierre told a gathering of conservative activists. Actually, it\u2019s hard to tell who was parroting whom. The president said much the same in a morning tweetstorm that said \u201ca \u2018gun free\u2019 school is a magnet for bad people.\u201d\n\nLet\u2019s ask someone who\u2019s in the trenches every day what he thinks of arming teachers. \u201cIt\u2019s hard to begin to count the number of ways this is a bad idea,\u201d said Chris Magnus, police chief of Tucson.\n\nFor starters, the number of gunslinging educators would be huge. In the United States, there are about 3.5 million elementary and secondary school teachers in public and private institutions. Arming 20 percent of them, as Mr. Trump suggested, would mean 700,000 or so teachers with Glocks and the like on their hips \u2014 an armed force half as large as America\u2019s real armed forces on active duty. One can envision parents with the means to do so swiftly yanking their children out of that sort of environment.", "title": "Opinion | Let the Teachers Teach", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "31A: \u201cOrder to go\u201d is a cute new way of cluing MUSH; not often something you\u2019d call ahead to pick up on the way to the office, although I suppose it\u2019s possible. More likely the command used to urge on one\u2019s sled dogs, a version of the French \u201cmarche,\u201d or \u201cgo.\u201d Speaking of ordering, if you happen to be getting ready to make a brunch selection I happened to read once that the canine Iditarod competitors (who weigh 40-60 pounds) consume 12,000 calories per day while racing, as many as Michael Phelps, the Olympic swimmer, when he\u2019s training. Just in case you were worried about eating some pancakes today. Eat them!\n\n58A: There are so many problems for office workers, and nobody wants to hear about them. Just because we\u2019re not getting pinned under tractors or gored by bulls or anything interesting doesn\u2019t mean that our pale, slumped bodies don\u2019t conceal hearts and minds that deserve attention. Actually, we\u2019re not paying attention to these things either because we\u2019re just staring at the screen all day getting EYESTRAIN.\n\nI found a website that offers exhaustive advice on how to deal with the double-edged sword of office technology (it allows us to do more work than we ever thought possible, while silently killing us). All this stuff I read online about the perils of too much time spent online is so depressing.\n\n70A: Is this one for the kids? I\u2019m old enough to have bought new records at the record store and made mixtapes but for this clue, \u201cJewel-case holder,\u201d I still thought of gems over music and didn\u2019t consider that funny stand with all the little slots, the CD TOWER. In my old neighborhood on the Upper West Side it seemed like there were always a few of these out on the street for garbage pickup (along with tube TVs \u2014 tube TVs sat out forever). I always wanted to be creative and find a use for them. All of my jewel-cases have long been recycled!\n\n104A: This was one of the theme answers and I figured it out from the crosses and process of elimination; using only the letters from 71D, DETESTABLE, I came to DADBLASTED, a word that I know I\u2019ve heard but don\u2019t think I\u2019ve ever seen \u2014 like \u201cdadgum\u201d or \u201cdagnabbit\u201d or \u201cdoggone\u201d, it\u2019s one of those regional American euphemisms. Did everyone know that dad, dag and dog are all euphemistic substitutes for \u201cgod?\u201d\n\n16D: This might be familiar to some, but I didn\u2019t know this medical term for one\u2019s armpit, AXILLA. It\u2019s an anatomical references that rings a bell to me because it resembles a botanical term, axillary bud, which refers to buds that come out of the little \u201cshoulders\u201d formed by lateral stems sprouting from the trunk (or main stem) of a plant.\n\n28D: I never would have recognized this entry from the clue, which strikes me as a little meanspirited, but maybe that\u2019s because I keep hearing NAILED IT (!) on TV this week as praise for people that, frankly, seem to be able to fly. I guess if the arrogant guy in your romcom slips on a banana peel this is an O.K. term to use sarcastically.", "title": "Letter Recycling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "ROME \u2014 Things keep getting worse for Pope Francis.\n\nLate last month, the pope reiterated his defense of a Chilean bishop, contending that he had never received any complaints that the prelate knew of abuse by the country\u2019s most notorious pedophile priest.\n\nBut on Monday, The Associated Press reported that the pope personally received an eight-page letter in 2015 from one of the victims. The letter explicitly detailed abuses the victim said were witnessed by other clerics, including Juan Barros Madrid, who was appointed bishop of Osorno, Chile, that year.\n\nThe report that one of the pope\u2019s top advisers had personally handed him the letter has revived accusations by advocates for abuse victims that the 81-year-old pontiff cannot, or will not, understand an issue that has long roiled the Roman Catholic Church.\n\n\u201cThere is what you might call a willful blindness,\u201d said Peter Saunders, a former member of the pope\u2019s Commission for the Protection of Minors, whose mandate expired in December. \u201cIt\u2019s almost angry unwillingness to accept what\u2019s in front of him, because to acknowledge it is to acknowledge that the church still has to clean up its act. He\u2019s been behaving like a spouse who is told that their spouse is abusing their kids, and can\u2019t believe it.\u201d", "title": "Letter Suggests Pope Knew About Abuse Complaints, Despite Denials", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "A little over a decade ago, I moved to Montreal expecting, perhaps foolishly, that I would become fluent in French. It was a goal that proved elusive \u2014 I just couldn\u2019t master the Quebecois accent, which was almost inscrutably nasal compared with the Parisian French I learned in high school. I stuttered through one quotidian exchange after another, painfully aware I was marking myself as a clumsy outsider. It was exhausting. Somewhat chastened, I gave up on French and turned my attention to a new language: Celsius.\n\nI gravitated toward Celsius for the same reason I had wanted to learn French: to experience the world through a foreign filter. Besides, I didn\u2019t really have a choice. Montreal is a bilingual city, but it uses just one temperature scale: Celsius. Of course, the same is true in every country aside from the United States and a few other global superpowers like the Cayman Islands and Belize. Using Fahrenheit in Canada was a sure way to brand myself not only as a recalcitrant American but also as a maniac. If you casually tell a friend who thinks in Celsius that it is 65 outside \u2014 nearly 150 degrees in Fahrenheit \u2014 and therefore a good day to go to the park, she will look at you as if you have misplaced your frontal lobe.\n\nMy hope was to internalize Celsius, not just to learn it but to feel it in my American flesh. The first thing I did to acquaint myself with it \u2014 forgoing that impossible conversion formula \u2014 was to memorize relative temperatures scattered throughout the scale so I could extrapolate from them. I was already aware, as most people are, that what I knew as 32 was 0, but I also came up with a few useful way stations: 10 in Celsius was 50 Fahrenheit; 21 was 70; 30 was 86. With this loose constellation of data points, I could safely guess that 15 degrees C, say, was about 60 degrees F, without constantly cross-referencing between the scales.\n\nScientists prefer Celsius because it integrates seamlessly with the metric system, but as a unit of measurement, it\u2019s far less precise than Fahrenheit. This laxity has its merits. For everyday use, it\u2019s an appealingly economical scale because it hovers mostly around 0, each unit packing a substantial punch. Still, it took me a while to regard Celsius as anything but absurd. \u201cSeven degrees outside,\u201d I\u2019d think to myself as I adjusted to the forecast. \u201cBalmy!\u201d Ian McEwan once pointed out that British tabloids like to capitalize on this dissonance, often reporting colder temperatures in Celsius and hotter ones in Fahrenheit, which makes for more sensational headlines.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: Celsius", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "When the university where Janna and I worked \u2014 I taught writing, she was a bioengineering postdoc \u2014 announced it was offering a dissection class, she enrolled. I had been writing a book about a murder and was poring over autopsy files that I was struggling to understand. No nonscientist had ever taken the course, but I asked the university if I could enroll, too. Nervous before my first class, I took solace in thinking about the people who had offered up their bodies to us. What had once been taboo became a powerful gift.\n\nFor four weeks, in that cold, white cadaver room, we cut the woman on the table to parts. With a scalpel, I sliced open her back, then dropped chunks of her into a white Home Depot bucket we kept under the table, so her remains could be cremated and returned to her family. She had been embalmed less than the other cadavers, an attempt to see if the dead could be left more lifelike, and dissecting her was a struggle. At times I had to rip fascia from muscles with my fingers. Once a piece of her skin hit my goggles. My scrubs dampened with grease stains where my body heat liquefied her fat. At night, stripping off my scrubs, I\u2019d find bits of her embedded in the laces of my Converse sneakers. Was it she? It looked like jelly.\n\nSoon, when Janna and I slid into bed together at night, I could no longer press my face to the back of her neck or wrap my arms around her. When my lips touched the skin of her back, I\u2019d flinch from the memory of carving though the woman in the same place. When I cupped my hand around her and brought it to her breast, I\u2019d remember scraping away the fascia that bound the woman\u2019s chest wall, peeling it back and watching the breasts lift away as well. I had braced my palm between her ear and nose and sawed through her face. The day I lifted her brain, pale pink and quivering, from the back of her skull, I walked the streets alone for an hour after, dazed. Her brain was as soft as Jell-O. My thumb could have gone right through it.\n\nJanna and I broke up almost a year after that summer. Now, when I lie in bed with another woman, and must calm my racing mind as it worries \u2014 whether this will become love and, if so, whether it will stick; or whether it, too, will be something I lose, and have to be O.K. with losing \u2014 I think of the woman whose remains I stripped to bone and flesh and fat. My mind conjures the smell of her the way it once conjured the idea of oblivion. I don\u2019t know who she was, or why she donated her body, or how she would have felt to know it was a writer who had seen inside her. But I am profoundly grateful for what she made real. The humidifier whirs; the sky outside the window is pitch black except for the street lamp. The pillow smells of the lavender I\u2019ve sprinkled on it and the sweet sweat at the back of a warm neck. I reach for her hand and hold it over her heart. Give me this moment, then, I think. And for now, we the living, we sleep.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: Dissecting a Human Body", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "The reasons piled up: Secretly lodged somewhere in my psyche was the sense, however irrational and antiquated, that the ability to have babies felt relevant to my physical identity as a woman, though I have never actually wanted to have a child. My bare-bones freelancer health insurance meant that having the operation would have emptied out my bank account, and then some. (I had recently gotten out of debt, and I wasn\u2019t ready to be broke again just to feel a nebulous \u201cbetter.\u201d) I travel a lot for work, and there never seemed to be a right moment to take the six weeks off required for recovery. I, like most people, have a fear of extreme physical pain. But draped over all of those rationalizations was my most powerful and seductive weakness: denial. I was fine! I didn\u2019t even know what anyone was talking about! I was fine!\n\nSo instead I struggled through my existence in partial pain. The symptoms had built up over time, and I had simply grown accustomed to feeling bad. A lot of people spend their lives in pain, often because our upbringing or gender or religion or self-esteem decrees that we deserve to suffer through it, that we aren\u2019t entitled to feel good \u2014 perhaps women more than most. Nearly our entire lives, from the first day we get our periods until menopause, we trade gestures of sympathy over menstrual cramps, a bond that is both heartening and depressing: We\u2019re destined to feel this way forever, so we might as well get used to it.\n\nBut then, through some confluence of events, a mental shift occurred in me. First, I signed a book deal, so I had a little money in the bank. Next, I moved to a new city, got new health insurance and a new doctor. During my first appointment, she felt around inside of me and instantly sensed trouble. \u201cDo you feel ... O.K.?\u201d she asked, before informing me that, among all the other problems of which I was already aware, I had a tipped uterus, which was likely the source of additional pain. Something about a complete stranger\u2019s pointing out even more gynecological issues forced me to admit that in fact I was not O.K. I did not feel good, and I needed to fix it, desperately.\n\nThat week, we scheduled the hysterectomy for just after the new year. Within a month, my uterus was gone. This thing that had tortured me for years had disappeared, in a snap. It took me six months to fully recover, but then, that was it: I hadn\u2019t understood I could just feel better.\n\nAnd then I couldn\u2019t stop feeling better. I felt so good that I nearly forgot what it was like to feel bad in the first place. For years, I\u2019d just accepted there would be times when my emotions and mood could be affected by the pain and hormones. There had often been a haziness that hung between my physical and emotional selves. Now a clearer and calmer version of me was in charge. The problem had been removed. I recognized I had the power to remove other things from my life that I\u2019d held onto for too long for all the wrong reasons, things that no longer worked and caused me pain or trouble. A leased apartment I hadn\u2019t lived in for a few years and had been renting out to a stranger? I closed up shop on it. The love letters I hadn\u2019t read in years but kept just because I liked the idea of being loved? I hadn\u2019t realized they were holding me back, so I tossed them unblinkingly. And these days I have coffee only with people I want to have coffee with and not people I feel as if I should, just because they asked nicely.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: Hysterectomies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "One fateful summer evening, I hurried home from work, eager to catch up on \u201cGame of Thrones.\u201d I don\u2019t have cable, so I often watch my shows a day or two after they air, usually via some streaming service or an app. At the time, I had become an obsessive avoider of spoilers, the kind of person who stayed off Instagram and Twitter during live episodes of popular shows, even going so far as to turn off notifications to avoid reading about a reveal or twist that would ruin a surprise.\n\nThat night, blissfully unaware of what was to come, I switched on my television, expecting to be greeted with the medieval tones and three-dimensional map of Westeros that signal the show\u2019s start. Instead, I was confronted by a massacre: This episode was \u201cThe Rains of Castamere,\u201d popularly known as the Red Wedding. Some friends and I shared an account, so the episode began where the previous person stopped watching, at the precise moment a pregnant character is stabbed in the stomach. I felt as if I had been stabbed in the stomach. I had invested nearly 30 hours into one of the biggest buildups of modern television only to have it \u2014 and my preciousness about spoilers \u2014 ruined.\n\nThe celebrated film critic Pauline Kael once wrote that movies function as escape pods, portals to parallel universes that can be radically different from emotional norms and societal conditioning of our own. What she meant was they parceled out freedom, allowing viewers to lose their selves in an effort to find greater connection to the self. \u201cA good movie can make you feel alive again, in contact, not just lost in another city,\u201d she wrote in 1969.\n\nSince then, movies \u2014 and now, increasingly, television shows \u2014 have become even more intense and immersive, ensuring that we lose ourselves more freely in them. Today\u2019s directors aim for attention totality in order to capture easily distracted audiences. A 2015 study conducted in part by James Cutting, a psychologist at Cornell University who chronicles the evolution of Hollywood cinematography, found that filmmakers have adapted their shooting styles to try to keep up with changes in our attention spans. Since the 1950s, the average shot time has dropped to less than four seconds from 12 seconds. Volume and cadence are manipulated to keep our eyes glued to the screen \u2014 think about the dubstep subwoofer beat drop that happens right before the tidal wave hits, or when a superhero performs an elaborate stunt involving an aerial body roll over a flaming vehicle. In other words, the highs are higher, and the lows are nonexistent.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: Spoilers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Antonio Vivaldi\u2019s \u201cSpring\u201d has more than twice as many film credits as any of its counterparts in his Baroque masterpiece, \u201cThe Four Seasons.\u201d \u201cSpring\u201d is weddings and day spas, your toddler\u2019s I.Q.-inflating sleep aid. \u201cSpring\u201d is the sassy classical of the baby boomers, music to accompany an anniversary toast at an expensive French restaurant. But, as my fellow millennials know far too well, an ill-timed frost nips yesteryear\u2019s aspirations in the bud. Now is the time for \u201cWinter,\u201d a composition that, like the season, holds us in a tighter grip.\n\nI first heard \u201cWinter\u201d in 1985, when I was 4. A snow-laced mountain fog had settled over the Potomac Highlands of West Virginia. I sat alone in the living room, watching a cartoon movie called \u201cSarah and the Squirrel.\u201d It was not the lighthearted fare suggested by its title. Sarah\u2019s village is invaded by Nazis, and her family members are captured and taken to a concentration camp. She escapes the slaughter by hiding in a nearby forest. It is under these circumstances of genocide, starvation and exposure to the elements that she befriends (or perhaps hallucinates) a squirrel. In the cartoon\u2019s final frames, Sarah wanders alone and barefoot through the snow. All of these events are set to Vivaldi\u2019s \u201cWinter.\u201d\n\nFrom there, it took the usual route of earworms: Having heard the music, I was desperate to hear it again. Better yet, I wanted to learn to play it myself. I asked my parents for a violin for my fifth birthday. When no violin arrived, I asked for a violin for Christmas. Then again for my sixth birthday. Seventh. There were no violin teachers in our part of West Virginia, my parents explained. Not even Santa could fix this problem. Eventually the VHS of \u201cSarah and the Squirrel\u201d disappeared from the video-rental store\u2019s shelves. Yet \u2014 and to this day I can\u2019t quite explain why \u2014 \u201cWinter\u201d remained in my head.\n\nBefore I fell asleep each night, I mentally played the few notes I could remember. These sounds felt to me like a crucial directional aid, an encrypted message on a map of my future, an aural Polaris. In retrospect, the darkness of \u201cWinter\u201d conveyed something I could not articulate as a child, namely, the peculiar sadness of Appalachia, the isolation and the poverty. Many of my elementary-school classmates faced challenges like Sarah\u2019s: cold, hunger and abuse. In \u201cWinter\u2019s\u201d ominous chords, I heard validation; the world was harsher than suggested by the cheerful, Disneyfied kid-culture of the 1980s. The wild arpeggios of the violin sounded like an unspoken truth: Some good little children die in the snow.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: Vivaldi\u2019s \u2018Winter\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Populism and Fascism\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn his review of Rob Riemen\u2019s \u201cTo Fight Against This Age: On Fascism and Humanism\u201d (Feb. 4), Damon Linker\u2019s implication that \u201cthe love of one\u2019s own\u201d has always reduced \u201ccitizenship\u201d to a relatively small group is surely mistaken. While the concept of \u201cone\u2019s own\u201d implies limitation, it just as certainly has expanded and shrunk over time, and it may well be that the European Union and the United Nations (let alone the United States), with all their setbacks and faults, illustrate by their very names the expansion of our view of the human family.\n\nBRUCE A. MCALLISTER\n\nWEST PALM BEACH, FLA.\n\n\u2666\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn his review of Rob Riemen\u2019s book, Damon Linker does not think that those threatening the established order (including Trump, who scowls and juts his jaw in an attempt to look like Churchill, but ends up looking like a dime-store Mussolini) are fascists because they lack \u201ca uniform, galvanizing ideology.\u201d That is his definition, but ethnic nationalist demagogues offering simplistic solutions based on blaming the other for all that ails society can also be defined as fascists. Anyway, evil is evil and quibbling about nomenclature is a waste of energy. Linker also evidently believes that \u201cthe love of one\u2019s own\u201d is incompatible with the \u201cglories of European high culture.\u201d What rot. We can love our own and work for a world that contains \u201ctruth, goodness, beauty, friendship, justice, compassion and wisdom\u201d at the same time. To \u201clove one\u2019s own\u201d does not mean hatred of everyone else.\n\nMICHAEL GORMAN\n\nCHICAGO\n\nPeter Matthiessen and the C.I.A.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nReading Jeff Wheelwright\u2019s essay, \u201cMatthiessen in Paris\u201d (Feb. 4), I was reminded that in the late 1970s the novelist Richard Elman was compiling an article about well-known writers who were in the C.I.A. during the 1950s; he contacted Peter Matthiessen, who was not happy with the news. And this project didn\u2019t make Elman popular. Back in the 1970s, being connected to the C.I.A. would not have been a reputation polisher; now it\u2019s largely a career enhancement. In the 1990s, Elman sent me the same photograph, featuring Matthiessen with Richard Wright, that you use as an illustration. Elman added his own handwritten caption: \u201cCan you guess from this photo who was being spooked and who was the spook?\u201d\n\nWILLIAM O\u2019ROURKE\n\nNOTRE DAME, IND.", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "To the Sports Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe American Dilemma: Why Do We Still Watch Football?\u201d Feb. 4:\n\nLike many others, I made plans to take part in an American tradition last Sunday and gather with friends to watch the Super Bowl.\n\nMany of my friends are guys I played high school football with in North Jersey in the 1970s, including one who has been paralyzed since the age of 16, when his neck was broken on the opening kickoff of the third game of our junior year.\n\nI saw it happen from the sideline, about 20 feet away. I watched him lie on the field face down for what seemed like an eternity, not moving, until he was taken away by an ambulance. I cried in my bedroom for hours after that game, and I was numb for the rest of the weekend. But when school let out Monday afternoon, I went to my gym locker, changed into my uniform, and joined the rest of the team on the field for practice.\n\nIt doesn\u2019t seem logical, as I write this, that I would still be a huge fan of football, or that my disabled friend, who has lived a life of immeasurable pain and hardship because of the football injury, would be one, too. But I am, and so is he, and so is everyone else who gathered around the TV last week to watch the game.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe go quiet, like everyone else, when a player is slow to get up, but we cheer the next hard hit.\n\nIt\u2019s football. I\u2019m not sure how I would react today if I had a young son who wanted to play contact sports. The game brought me great joy, both as a player and a fan, but also immense heartbreak. I know this: Something has to change.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. My favorite was Otis Spofford, the title character in Beverly Cleary\u2019s novel about a mischievous boy who outwitted all attempts to reform him. I bet that even (or maybe especially) in these politically charged times, plenty of kids would rather read about Otis (and his black counterparts) than about role models, and who can blame them?\n\nFELICIA NIMUE ACKERMAN\n\nPROVIDENCE, R.I.\n\nSubway Reading\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn his essay, \u201cSubway Reading\u201d (Feb. 4), Adam Sternbergh says he wants \u201cthrilling language\u201d from what he reads on the subway. This makes poetry the perfect choice. Here\u2019s how one Brooklyn poet put it: \u201cPoetry is that sort of writing you can read silently to yourself on the subway or the bus and not be embarrassed by moving your lips.\u201d\n\nJ. R. SOLONCHE\n\nBLOOMING GROVE, N.Y.\n\n\u2666\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAdam Sternbergh\u2019s ode to subway reading brought back a memory. Many years ago, on the IRT uptown to 59th Street from Sheridan Square, I was reading Proust\u2019s \u201cIn Search of Lost Time\u201d and was so engrossed in the Duchesse de Guermantes\u2019 dinner party that I was jolted by the sunlight as the train emerged from the tunnel by Yankee Stadium at 161st Street.\n\nSTEVEN BERKOWITZ\n\nNEW YORK\n\n\u2666\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nTo augment Adam Sternbergh\u2019s essay, I recommend the photographs of people reading on the subway in \u201cThe Last Book\u201d by Reinier Gerritsen.
