And to see others close by, discreetly (or not) appearing to read the book too.", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Philip Roth\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nCharles McGrath\u2019s introduction to his interview with Philip Roth (Jan. 21) includes the closing imprimatur to the 10th and final volume in the Library of America\u2019s edition of Roth\u2019s work, a quote that appears to reveal a striking allusion. In preparing for what turns out to be the abortive sacrifice of Isaac in Genesis, Abraham responds to the Almighty, \u201cHere I am.\u201d Roth may be concluding, in referring to one of the earliest narratives in the Hebrew Bible, with a bow to his beginnings.\n\nSTANLEY WEINTRAUB\n\nWEST GROVE, PA.\n\n\u2666\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI achieved senior citizen status last year. Philip Roth did so almost 20 years ago. If I\u2019m still around at 85, I hope I retain the same open-minded curiosity, as a reader, that enabled Roth, a man who hardly seems the type to have much stomach for rock \u2019n\u2019 roll, to not only read but to appreciate Bruce Springsteen\u2019s autobiography. Both men grew up in New Jersey; was this the spark that lit the fire of Roth\u2019s interest?\n\nFantasizing here, I\u2019d love to see these two onstage at the 92nd Street Y some evening, engaged in conversation about \u2014 well, anything. America, Donald Trump, books, music, pit barbecue, women, baseball, growing older, the creative process, celebrity, the pros and cons of having roots in the Garden State.\n\nI say this knowing that the odds of that ever happening are roughly equivalent to those of Thomas Pynchon participating in a live cooking segment on \u201cGood Morning America.\u201d Assisted by Bigfoot.\n\nDAVID ENGLISH\n\nACTON, MASS.\n\n\u2666\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nWhile introducing Philip Roth as a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Charles McGrath writes that Roth may recall such \u201call-but-forgotten\u201d members of the academy like Malcolm Cowley and Glenway Wescott. I grant you I\u2019ve never heard of Wescott, but Malcolm Cowley is so vivid to me that I did a double take. Surely McGrath cannot mean the author of my well-thumbed and bookmarked \u201cExile\u2019s Return: A Literary Saga of the Nineteen-Twenties,\u201d essential to a close-up view of the hot literary scene in and around Paris in the \u201920s, bohemianism and Dada, before the Depression sent many writers home. Among those profiled: Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Dos Passos, T.S. Eliot, Pound, James Joyce and Hart Crane. No fusty tome of academic lit-crit, it\u2019s lively and insightful. At times it even gives us sensational episodes. And you will learn a new word, \u201cfindrinny.\u201d Cowley gives us a footnote leading us to Melville, and I found it in Yeats.\n\nANTON MIKOFSKY\n\nNEW YORK", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Enrico Fermi\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIt is welcome news to have a new biography of Enrico Fermi, but it is misleading to say, as Richard Rhodes does in his review of \u201cThe Last Man Who Knew Everything\u201d by David N. Schwartz (Jan. 28), that this is \u201cthe first thorough biography to be published since Fermi\u2019s death 64 years ago in 1954.\u201d In fact, a fine biography, \u201cThe Pope of Physics: Enrico Fermi and the Birth of the Atomic Age,\u201d by Gino Segr\u00e8 and Bettina Hoerlin, appeared in 2016. It received excellent reviews in The New York Times and many other prominent places. People who are intrigued by Fermi will be happy to learn about this wonderful resource.\n\nFRANK WILCZEK\n\nCAMBRIDGE, MASS.\n\nThe writer won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2004.\n\n\u2666\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRichard Rhodes\u2019s review of the new biography of Enrico Fermi states that \u201ctwo Berlin radiochemists discovered nuclear fission.\u201d Not quite so. In 1938 Otto Hahn and his assistant Fritz Strassmann experimentally split uranium into barium and krypton but could not account for the result other than a \u201cbursting.\u201d They contacted Lise Meitner, a physicist at what later became the Max Planck Institute for Chemistry, who correctly stated that the cause was nuclear fission, the energy for which had been described by Einstein\u2019s equation E=mc2.\n\nHahn got the Nobel Prize for his discovery, but Meitner did not, although subsequently she was nominated multiple times.\n\nN. DAVID CHARKES\n\nCOLLEGEVILLE, PA.\n\nTrumpocracy\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAdrian Wooldridge, in reviewing David Frum\u2019s new book, \u201cTrumpocracy: The Corruption of the American Republic\u201d (Jan. 28), states that \u201ca group that thrived during the golden years of the 1950s and 1960s has seen its incomes stagnate and its job security disappear\u201d and never mentions union representation, which was the central factor of those years of better wages and job security. The fact that an editor of The Economist would fail to point this out is central to the Middle American disaffection and subsequent alienation from the political process that allowed a grifter like Trump to get himself elected with hollow jingoist sloganeering.", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s another way to think about those 21,000: Imagine the Sandy Hook firehouse, filled with the devastated families of 20 children. Now add two other Sandy Hook firehouses, each with 20 more families receiving the worst possible news. Now imagine that scene repeating itself every day, year after year after year.\n\nOur outlier status is relatively new, too. In the 1960s, the United States had a child-mortality rate slightly below that of other rich countries. So it\u2019s not as if the problem stems from an immutable American characteristic.\n\nOther countries are simply trying harder to keep their children alive. They have studied major causes of death and then attacked them, in an evidence-based way.\n\nWhat would such an approach look like in this country?\n\nOn guns, it would start with universal background checks and tighter semiautomatic restrictions. The United States is always likely to have gun deaths, given the sheer number of guns, but we could have many fewer.", "title": "Opinion | Letting American Kids Die", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "In this weekend\u2019s New York Times Magazine there is a long profile of a new kind of pedagogy unique to our particular stage of civilization. It\u2019s called \u201cporn literacy,\u201d and it involves explaining to young people whose sexual coming-of-age is being mediated by watching online gangbangs that actually hard-core pornography is not an appropriate guide to how the sexes should relate.\n\nFor anyone who grew up with the ideals of post-sexual revolution liberalism, there is a striking pathos to these educators\u2019 efforts. The sex education programs in my mostly liberal schools featured a touching faith from the adults in charge that they were engaged in a great work of enlightenment, that with the right curricula they could roll back the forces of repression and make sexuality a place of egalitarian pleasure and safety for us all.\n\nCompared to those idealists, the people teaching \u201cporn literacy\u201d have accepted a sweeping pedagogical defeat. They take for granted that the most important sex education may take place on Pornhub, that the purpose of their work is essentially remedial, and that there is no escape from the world that porn has made.\n\nWhich at the moment there is not. But we are supposed to be in the midst of a great sexual reassessment, a clearing-out of assumptions that serve misogyny and impose bad sex on semi-willing women. And such a reassessment will be incomplete if it never reconsiders our surrender to the idea that many teenagers, most young men especially, will get their sex education from online smut.", "title": "Opinion | Let\u2019s Ban Porn", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAlfie\u201d was a hit, but its gritty realism and its unflinching look at the consequences of casual sex did not typecast Mr. Gilbert: James Bond followed hard on Alfie\u2019s heels.\n\nMr. Gilbert\u2019s first foray into the world of 007 was \u201cYou Only Live Twice\u201d (1967), the fifth movie in the series. With a screenplay by Roald Dahl, it followed Bond (Sean Connery) into the dark universe of the villainous Blofeld (Donald Pleasance), who had plans to rule the world.\n\nMr. Gilbert returned to the franchise 10 years later, directing \u201cThe Spy Who Loved Me\u201d (1977) and \u201cMoonraker\u201d (1979), by which time Roger Moore had replaced Mr. Connery as Bond.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn his autobiography, \u201cAll My Flashbacks\u201d (2010), Mr. Gilbert wrote that he could immediately see that Mr. Moore had to be a different sort of Bond.\n\n\u201cWhile watching him, I\u2019d had the feeling that Cubby Broccoli and Harry Saltzman, the film\u2019s producers, wanted him to be Sean Connery,\u201d he wrote.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis was no use. Roger didn\u2019t have Sean\u2019s animal grace. However, he was at ease in light comedy. It therefore seemed to me much more sensible for Roger to play to the strength he had, rather than the one Sean had.\u201d\n\nBefore \u201cAlfie,\u201d Mr. Gilbert was best known for a series of fact-based World War II films. \u201cReach for the Sky\u201d (1957), which he wrote and directed, told the story of Douglas Bader, a Royal Air Force hero who, despite the loss of his legs, was able to become a fighter pilot and survive a Nazi prison camp.\n\nA year later came another tribute to wartime heroism, \u201cCarve Her Name With Pride.\u201d Written with his frequent collaborator Vernon Harris, the movie recounted the true-life adventures of Violette Szabo, a French-speaking widow living in London who was recruited by the British secret service and who was captured on her second undercover mission to France and executed by the Nazis.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe often took on a producing role as well, as he did with, among other films, \u201cEducating Rita,\u201d \u201cShirley Valentine\u201d and \u201cThe Adventurers,\u201d a 1970 political drama based on a Harold Robbins novel involving a jet-set son of an assassinated diplomat.\n\nMr. Gilbert was born in London on March 6, 1920, into a show business family, including a number of music hall performers. Before long he, too, was performing, leading to small roles in a few films as a teenager.\n\nHe got his start behind the camera with the Royal Air Force during World War II when he made several documentary shorts, an experience that he put to good use in his war films of the 1950s and \u201960s (although the first feature he directed was \u201cThe Little Ballerina,\u201d from 1948, the story of a young girl in London who dreams of becoming a famous dancer).\n\nHis wife, the former Hylda Tafler, died in 2005. They had two sons, John and Stephen. There was no immediate word on Mr. Gilbert\u2019s survivors.\n\nLate in his career, Mr. Gilbert mostly directed small-scale stories about women \u2014 making a slight detour with \u201cHaunted,\u201d a 1995 horror film with Kate Beckinsale, Aidan Quinn and John Gielgud. \u201cEducating Rita\u201d followed a young housewife (Julie Walters) through her chaste relationship with an alcoholic professor (Mr. Caine), who becomes her tutor and mentor and winds up with a few insights about himself as well.\n\nPhoto\n\nBoth Ms. Walters and Mr. Caine were nominated for Oscars in 1983. (The awards went to Shirley MacLaine, for \u201cTerms of Endearment,\u201d and Robert Duvall, for \u201cTender Mercies.\u201d)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother of Mr. Gilbert\u2019s later projects was \u201cShirley Valentine,\u201d which, like \u201cEducating Rita,\u201d was adapted from a play by Willy Russell. The film is a portrait of a Liverpool housewife (Pauline Collins) who breaks out of her numbing routine when she travels to Greece.\n\nIn Mr. Gilbert\u2019s last movie, \u201cBefore You Go\u201d (2002), based on Shelagh Stephenson\u2019s first play, \u201cThe Memory of Water,\u201d three sisters (Ms. Walters, Joanne Whalley and Victoria Hamilton) reunite to attend their mother\u2019s funeral.\n\nBut even with that film\u2019s release, he was not quite ready to call it a career, telling Variety that he could still get a movie done, and done on time and within budget.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s nothing that can replace experience,\u201d he said. \u201cI know to sit in a chair, not to rush around, and the film will get made. When you\u2019re young you get much more stressed. But now I don\u2019t encounter any problem that I haven\u2019t dealt with before.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cI sometime wonder whether to try another Hollywood movie. I suppose we all imagine we\u2019re immortal. I just hope that upstairs there\u2019s a film company that\u2019s looking for a young director.\u201d", "title": "Lewis Gilbert, Director of \u2018Alfie\u2019 and 007 Movies, Is Dead at 97", "authors": ["Robert Berkvist"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s a very weird and conflicted feeling,\u201d said Jared Bernstein of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, who worked in the Obama White House. \u201cOn some level I should be happy, and I am sort of happy right now, but with some nontrivial caveats.\u201d\n\nHe and others in this boat don\u2019t at all like the composition of this particular easing of fiscal policy. It is focused on tax cuts for businesses, rather than on investment in roads and bridges or worker training. The latter would be the kinds of steps more likely to have long-term payoffs and to benefit working-class Americans, they believe. (A big chunk of the additional spending will go toward the military.)\n\nLiberal skeptics of this new age of anti-austerity also don\u2019t like the timing. Mr. Bernstein, no one\u2019s idea of a deficit hawk, notes that never in its modern history has the United States run deficits as large as those now on the horizon while the unemployment rate was as low as it is now. That creates the risk that the government will have less capacity to respond to future recessions.\n\nBut those misgivings aside, this mix of budget-busting policies will provide the best test in years of some ideas that have percolated among economists, especially but not exclusively on the left. The former Federal Reserve chairman Ben Bernanke, originally a George W. Bush nominee, spent years imploring Congress to spend more money in the near term to try to boost growth, to little avail.\n\nThe case for a more expansionary fiscal policy varies depending on the individual, but arguments have included:\n\nIt might spur more jobs at higher wages.\n\nCoax people who had dropped out of the labor force to look for work.\n\nFuel higher productivity growth.\n\nMitigate a global shortage of safe government bonds.\n\nHelp break the United States out of a prolonged cycle of sluggish growth and financial booms and busts.\n\nFor example, Larry Summers, the Harvard economist and former adviser to Presidents Obama and Clinton, has been a leading advocate of the idea that \u201csecular stagnation\u201d has taken hold. The idea is that the economy is in a self-reinforcing pattern of low growth, low inflation and low interest rates, and that overreliance on the Federal Reserve\u2019s interest rate policies to try to spur growth has fueled financial bubbles.", "title": "Liberals Wanted Fiscal Stimulus. Conservatives Delivered It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "According to The New York Times: \u201cHis lawyers are concerned that the president, who has a history of making false statements and contradicting himself, could be charged with lying to investigators.\u201d\n\nTrump lies so much that people keep inventing new euphemisms to describe it. Former Vice President Joe Biden told CNN this week that if he were one of Trump\u2019s lawyers, he too would advise him not to talk to Mueller, because as Biden put it, \u201cThe president has some difficulty with precision.\u201d\n\nIn other words, he\u2019s a liar.\n\nThis lying may feel minor to some. It may feel inconsequential, an inconvenience around which we can maneuver. But I say that the lying is everything \u2014 the root thing, the foundational thing.\n\nIt may well be that Trump\u2019s lifelong assumption that he could simply lie with impunity, as a tactic to sell his brand or save his skin, will be the crux of the Mueller investigation and any finding of Trump\u2019s own wrongdoing.\n\nTrump has set a tone in his campaign and in his administration that lying is simply part of the communications strategy. They all do it. But you can\u2019t lie to the F.B.I., and you can\u2019t lie to impede an investigation, thereby obstructing justice.\n\nEven aside from the investigation and any talk of collusion or obstruction, Trump is a danger to the nation in a multitude of other ways.\n\nWe have a manipulative liar with autocratic tendencies as the American president. He has enormous power and an enormous ego. He prioritizes his personal feelings and fortunes over the country\u2019s health and stability.", "title": "Opinion | Lie, Exploit and Destroy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "The \u201cdossier,\u201d Mr. MacLeod explained, wasn\u2019t a leaked internal United Nations report. It was a two-page memo he had written for the British government long after he left the United Nations\u2019 employ, plus the text of an email he had sent to people he hoped would support a new nonprofit he and some lawyer colleagues were founding to work on this issue.\n\nMore important, the terrifying numbers the memo cited were just rough guesses intended to hint at the scale of the problem, not actual measurements.\n\nTake that estimate of 60,000 rapes, for instance. For one thing, it was actually an estimate of the number of victims of all forms of sexual abuse and exploitation, not just rape.\n\nTo arrive at that figure, Mr. MacLeod said, he started with a 2017 report in which the United Nations said it had recorded 311 victims of sexual exploitation by peacekeepers in the previous year. He then made a series of assumptions that led him from 311 reported cases to his headline-grabbing claim of 60,000. But those assumptions were little more than guesses, and Mr. MacLeod freely admits he has no hard data to back them up.\n\nThe first assumption was based on a remark by the United Nations secretary general, Ant\u00f3nio Guterres, that the problem of sexual abuse was probably worse on the civilian side of the organization than within the peacekeeping forces. Mr. MacLeod concluded that this meant there must be at least 312 victims of the non-peacekeeping staff \u2014 311 plus 1 \u2014 but to keep his \u201cestimate\u201d conservative, he put the number at 289, to arrive at an even 600 for the year. Needless to say, that kind of rounded guess based on an offhand statement is unlikely to be reliable.\n\nFrom there, Mr. MacLeod estimated that only 10 percent of the assaults were actually recorded, a figure he said was based on reporting rates in the United Kingdom, to arrive at a figure of 6,000 victims annually. But because the United Nations doesn\u2019t have good (or possibly any) data about the rate at which victims report assaults by its staff, there\u2019s no way to know if that was the right multiplier to use.\n\nThen, to arrive at an estimate for the decade, Mr. MacLeod assumed that 2016 was a representative year, so he multiplied 6,000 by 10.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPresto: 311 becomes 60,000.\n\nBy the Numbers\n\nIn Mr. MacLeod\u2019s telling, he always intended his memo to be an advocacy statement rather than what he called \u201cpeer-reviewed\u201d statistical analysis \u2014 essentially a way to say \u201chere is a problem that is very large and very bad\u201d (my phrase), with digits instead of words.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe problem is, that isn\u2019t how journalists use statistics, or how the public consumes them.\n\nGood journalists always try to check the provenance of the numbers we cite. But we aren\u2019t trained statisticians, so we can\u2019t necessarily perform independent checks of every figure experts provide to us. And sometimes numbers manage to enter the news ecosystem so quickly and pervasively that our fact checks can\u2019t keep up.\n\nAfter the Parkland school shooting, for instance, you may have seen the viral statistic that America had experienced 18 school shootings already this calendar year.\n\nIn fact, it turns out, that number was misleading. It came from Everytown for Gun Safety, a gun-control organization, whose definition of \u201cschool shootings\u201d is far broader than the common understanding of the term. It counts every time a person fires a gun in or near a school building as a \u201cschool shooting,\u201d including a suicide in Michigan that took place outside a shuttered, empty school.\n\nThat\u2019s not to say, of course, that such events are not upsetting and tragic in their own right. But they are not what people imagine when they hear the term \u201cschool shooting.\u201d So the statistic, without context, was misleading.\n\nThe Washington Post eventually published a careful debunking of Everytown\u2019s figures. But by that time, the number had already been tweeted by Senator Bernie Sanders and Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, and cited by news organizations including MSNBC, the BBC, NBC News, ABC News and CBS News.\n\nThat matters. Numbers, if trustworthy, are a way to make reporting more rigorous and objective, and to show that a story is based on cold hard facts rather than a handful of anecdotes. And when a number is big and splashy, like Mr. MacLeod\u2019s 60,000 victims or Everytown\u2019s 18 school shootings, it can make a point very powerfully.\n\nWhen people see a number in the paper or on a trusted news program, they tend to believe that it\u2019s valid, especially if an expert is cited as the source. They don\u2019t see an advocacy statement. They see rigor and objectivity, even if none actually exist. The result is that a number will often be taken much more seriously than an advocacy statement would be.\n\nThat\u2019s all the more true if the story gets picked up by other news outlets. Mr. MacLeod, who has appeared on television and given other print interviews, seems to be everywhere. And the more he gets quoted, the more authoritative he seems to be.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe first problem with that, of course, is that the public is now under the mistaken impression that a reliable whistle-blower investigation has concluded that the United Nations is harboring thousands of predators, when in fact it was just a back-of-the-envelope sketch of the size of the problem. It\u2019s entirely possible that the number of victims is much, much higher. It also might be much lower. We just don\u2019t know.\n\nBut even more worrying is the way that bad information, like bad money, drives out good.\n\n\u201cThose of us who work on this issue know that if we take one misstep, the men who abuse will use it against us to make sure nothing changes,\u201d Sarah Martin, a consultant who wrote a 2005 report on sexual assault and exploitation by members of United Nations peacekeeping missions, said by email.\n\nMs. Martin, who has advised the United Nations and other international aid organizations on gender-based violence, said she and her colleagues feared that Mr. MacLeod\u2019s figures would provide exactly that kind of excuse, distracting from the less splashy but more reliable information that is already available.\n\n\u201cI have heard so many horrific stories from women that I don\u2019t need false statistics waved around,\u201d Ms. Martin said. \u201cIt discredits the very brave women and children who struggle to come forward and then do \u2014 usually to disbelief and disinterest.\u201d", "title": "Lies, Damned Lies, and One Very Misleading Statistic", "authors": ["Amanda Taub", "The Interpreter"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhen I was shipped off to my father, I felt abandoned by mother,\u201d he said. \u201cIt never felt like my parents really had my back.\u201d\n\nHow did they meet?\n\nIn 1996 both worked as bakers in Minneapolis. After 10-hour shifts together they spent nights talking on the phone. She had married and was in middle of a friendly divorce because her first husband didn\u2019t want to have children.\n\n\u201cSteve seemed relationship oriented, and I wanted a serious boyfriend who had his career figured out,\u201d she said.\n\nA year later they decided to buy a house together, and within two months she was pregnant. She was thrilled. \u201cI wasn\u2019t quite ready,\u201d he said. \u201cI was a very distant father until my second child was born.\u201d\n\nWhat did they like about each other?\n\n\u201cBarbara is one of the kindest people you could know,\u201d he said. \u201cShe is open and friendly in a way that I am not, and I was drawn to that.\u201d\n\n\u201cSteve is goofy and funny,\u201d she said. \u201cWe had an instant rapport, we worked well together.\u201d\n\nWhy did they marry?\n\nIn 1999, when their daughter was 7 months old, they had a small ceremony. \u201cWe were making permanent what was already there,\u201d she said. \u201cIt didn\u2019t feel like a lot of change.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSteven was committed to the family but hesitant about marriage. \u201cMy whole life had been witnessing failed marriages, but I saw how important it was to Barbara and that it would be easier for the family if we were legally wed,\u201d he said.\n\nWhere did they live after marrying?\n\nThey had bought a small house in Minneapolis before they had children. In September 2001, they put that house up for sale, hoping to buy a larger one for their growing family and use some proceeds to start their own bakery. But they lost money on the sale and instead moved into a duplex owned by her mother, who also lived there.\n\nThey stayed in the home for 10 years. \u201cWe had little privacy and in retrospect, that was hard on the marriage,\u201d Barbara said. \u201cAt the time that wasn\u2019t clear.\u201d\n\nHow were the early years?\n\nIn 2004 they started their bakery. Her mother helped with the children, which enabled both to work long hours. Steven started work at 1 a.m. and worked 12- to 14-hour days.\n\n\u201cBarbara liked my ambition, but it didn\u2019t look like what she imagined,\u201d he said. \u201cThe demands of running a bakery are extreme. If we had opened a children\u2019s shoe store \u2014 another idea we had \u2014 there\u2019s a chance we might be married today.\u201d\n\n(She agrees.)\n\nWere they happy?\n\nThere were happy times, but for him, being away from the children made it difficult. He took only a few days off in 11 years and left town only once during that time. \u201cThe bakery was like the third child,\u201d she said noting that his grandfather, a farmer, was also a hard worker who \u201cdidn\u2019t know when to stop.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt was literally like one day off a year,\u201d Barbara said.\n\n\u201cWe hadn\u2019t stockpiled happy memories to fall back on when times were tough,\u201d she added.\n\n\u201cSuccess was great, but inside I still never felt I was good enough,\u201d Steven said. \u201cLiving with my unhappiness, I\u2019m surprised Barbara didn\u2019t divorce me earlier.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFirst signs of trouble?\n\nIn late 2011, they bought a house. Away from her mother\u2019s home, life was easier, but in 2012 he read her journal and discovered she wanted to split up. It was a violation of her privacy, he knew, but it was jarring. He didn\u2019t talk about it for months, instead retreating into silence and anger. She noticed the change and the silence, as did their employees.\n\n\u201cIt hadn\u2019t occurred to me that our marriage was in peril,\u201d he said. \u201cI should have used that moment as a wake up call. Instead we grew apart.\u201d\n\nWhen they finally talked in 2012, he suggested divorce. She said no. Both had come from broken homes, and neither, deep down, wanted to divorce.\n\nDid they try to work on things? Try therapy?\n\nThey tried twice, though neither thought it was helpful. At that time, Steven thought therapy meant something was wrong with him.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat then pushed them apart?\n\nFor a year they hardly talked. He moved into the basement and they explained to their girls, who were 14 and 12, that their father needed more sleep. A few months later, they admitted to a separation.\n\nBarbara began seeing a therapist. \u201cWith time, I was able to shed the notion of staying together for the sake of the children or the bakery,\u201d she said.\n\nThe final break?\n\nFor several years, they functioned as a family, with him living in the basement.\n\nAt the end of 2013, what she called \u201cthe quiet year,\u201d he drove her to the vet and comforted her when her beloved cat died. \u201cThat day was a turning point,\u201d she said. \u201cWe started climbing back towards a friendship.\u201d\n\n\u201cI was being a good friend,\u201d he said. \u201cIt felt important to solidify our friendship, and always in my mind were the girls.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow did they move on?\n\nThe divorce came through in 2014. In 2015, he moved into an apartment and by then was dating one of their employees at the bakery. Some employees took \u201csides\u201d in their breakup, though neither of them wanted that.\n\n\u201cI think they felt we were mom and dad,\u201d she said.\n\nDid they feel stigmatized?\n\nShe did not. He did.\n\n\u201cEven though my family is littered with divorce, I learned early about not giving up on a relationship,\u201d Steven said. \u201cBut in my family nothing is talked about, you don\u2019t talk anything except the weather, sports and crops.\u201d\n\nHow did they fare financially?\n\nThey are still tied financially. They used a mediator to make their financial agreements, which were amicable. When they went to court for the final divorce, they drove together.\n\nIn 2015 they decided to sell the bakery, though Barbara continued working with the new owners. He took a year off and then started a venture in wholesale baking and milling flour.\n\nNow living in her own condominium, she receives child support until their younger daughter graduates from high school this year. Both say she is not good with money. \u201cI never worried about what is mine and what was hers, it was always about the girls,\u201d he said.\n\nHow did their children react?\n\nThey were upset at first, but both came around, Barbara said, when they saw their parents happier apart. \u201cBut I think if they had their way, we\u2019d still be married,\u201d she said.\n\nShould they have divorced sooner?\n\n\u201cIn hindsight we were both unhappy and were not addressing it,\u201d Steven said.\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was complicated, we couldn\u2019t take it apart earlier. The bakery, the family, everything was tied together.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat did they do to start over?\n\nShe continued therapy and started taking art classes. \u201cI reclaimed a bit of who I was before I was baker,\u201d she said.\n\nHe, too, started therapy to address feelings of isolation and lack of self-worth. \u201cI\u2019d been checked out for most of my life, and pushed people away,\u201d he said. \u201cI can outwork and outperform people, but that ultimately didn\u2019t make me happy.\u201d\n\nAre their new lives better?\n\nBoth say yes. \u201cI lost myself in motherhood, marriage and the business,\u201d Barbara said. \u201cI\u2019m happy with having done all of that, but I am back to being me.\u201d\n\nShe started dating but found the same issues in a new relationship as in her marriage. Steven was supportive of that relationship and during that breakup.\n\nHe is working on work-life balance and regrets how the marriage affected their children. \u201cI need to forgive myself and be there for them now,\u201d he said. \u201cIf I had known my own issues during the marriage, I would have been happier and the marriage, healthier.\u201d\n\nWould they have done anything differently in the split?\n\nLiving together after they split gave them financial stability and showed their children how dedicated they were as parents, they said.\n\n\u201cI had self-confidence but not a lot of self-esteem,\u201d he said. \u201cI needed to admit that I had problems and deal with them.\u201d\n\nLooking back, what advice would they offer?\n\nBoth say they should have made time for each other. \u201cIf you want a family, you have to spend time with the family,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPropping up a failing marriage is draining,\u201d she said. \u201cAfter the split I remember other people remarking on how happy I seemed, almost as if I were in love. But I wasn\u2019t seeing anyone then, I was just so relieved.\u201d\n\nWhat is life like now?\n\nThey see each other once a month but text and talk often. \u201cSteve is almost like a brother, he is family,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s the mother of the two most important people in my life,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m so glad we are friends now.\u201d\n\nAdvice for others divorcing?\n\n\u201cDivorce doesn\u2019t have to be the end of the world even though it feels like it is,\u201d he said. \u201cUse it as a way to make changes in yourself. If you\u2019re not happy with yourself, no relationship is going to work.\u201d\n\nFor her, she now sees that there are ways around feeling trapped. \u201cIt took years to get untangled, but now we have our freedom,\u201d she said. \u201cTaking it slowly was the right way to go.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy unstable childhood had such a negative impact on me,\u201d he said. \u201cIn the divorce, do whatever is necessary to put the kids first.\u201d", "title": "Life in the Bakery Led to Love, Then Loss of Balance", "authors": ["Louise Rafkin"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "MATINICUS, Me. \u2014 The snow had begun falling overnight, and fell throughout the day, draping the towering pines and the lobster traps, stacked up on land for the winter, in blankets of white.\n\nStill, Sharon Daley, a nurse from the visiting vessel Sunbeam, which provides medical care to remote islands off the coast of Maine, made her appointed rounds. She forged a path in knee-high rubber boots to the home of Bill Hoadley, who is, at 80, this island\u2019s oldest resident.\n\nShe checked his blood pressure, which she pronounced \u201cso good, it\u2019s boring.\u201d She listened to his heart, which was ticking just fine, almost in rhythm with his many clocks. Mr. Hoadley is something of a clock aficionado, and he keeps his timepieces on daylight saving time, which in winter is an hour ahead of everyone else.\n\nWhy?\n\n\u201cBecause I can,\u201d the impish Mr. Hoadley declared from his nautically themed front parlor.\n\nBeing able to do exactly as he pleases \u2014 and have health care come to him \u2014 are big reasons Mr. Hoadley stays here, 22 miles out in the North Atlantic.", "title": "Life on an Island: Silence, Beauty and a Long Wait for the Ferry", "authors": ["Katharine Q. Seelye"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "People who would like to become physically stronger should start with weight training and add protein to their diets, according to a comprehensive scientific review of research.\n\nThe review finds that eating more protein, well past the amounts currently recommended, can significantly augment the effects of lifting weights, especially for people past the age of 40. But there is an upper limit to the benefits of protein, the review cautions.\n\nOn the other hand, any form of protein is likely to be effective, it concludes, not merely high-protein shakes and supplements. Beef, chicken, yogurt and even protein from peas or quinoa could help us to build larger and stronger muscles.\n\nIt makes intuitive sense that protein in our diets should aid in bulking up muscles in our bodies, since muscles consist mostly of protein. When we lift weights, we stress the muscles and cause minute damage to muscle tissue, which then makes new proteins to heal. But muscles also will readily turn to and slurp up any bonus proteins floating around in the bloodstream.", "title": "Lift Weights, Eat More Protein, Especially if You\u2019re Over 40", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Most prominent is the lighthouse. The 90-foot-tall octagonal tower, which dates from 1912, lost its last keeper in 2001, but continues to operate autonomously, helping ships navigate the Ambrose Channel between New Jersey and Queens. Little lighthouse-shaped birdhouses and mailboxes in some of the surrounding homes suggest its role as a neighborhood mascot.\n\nAnother attraction is the Jacques Marchais Museum of Tibetan Art. Ms. Marchais, a collector of Tibetan and Indian artifacts, built the fieldstone complex and terraced garden next to her home in the style of a Himalayan Buddhist monastery, with rocks handpicked on road trips around Staten Island. She died only months after it opened in 1948. Today the museum offers rotating exhibitions and tai chi and meditation classes that residents enjoy.\n\nJust beyond the neighborhood\u2019s southern border is Historic Richmond Town, a museum complex with about 30 antique buildings and frequent culinary and cultural events. The Amess\u00e9s said they like to round up friends and walk to its tavern concerts and chili cook-offs.\n\nLighthouse Hill is also the beneficiary of the only Frank Lloyd Wright house in New York City. It is one of the architect\u2019s late designs \u2014 a sleek experiment in prefabricated construction that looks a bit like a very long and attractive diner. This 1959 building is known as the Crimson Beech after a tree on the property that has since perished. The home is privately owned, which means that the many devotees of Mr. Wright who flock to it must gawk from the street.\n\nRoger Morace is an architect who recently moved to Lighthouse Hill, but in his case it was a homecoming. Born and raised in the community, he left for college in upstate New York, later returning to Staten Island to work in his family\u2019s architecture firm in neighboring Richmondtown. Mr. Morace and his wife, Allison, spent a year sifting through the sparse housing inventory before they found a way back onto Lighthouse Hill. Last year, they paid $650,000 for a 1952 raised ranch house with two bedrooms on Lighthouse Avenue.\n\nSTATEN ISLAND Lighthouse Hill ROCKLAND AVE. FOREST HILL RD. LaTourette Park Lighthouse Hill LONDON RD. Jacques Marchais Museum of Tibetan Art RICHMOND HILL RD. Staten Island Lighthouse The Crimson Beech RICHMOND RD. 1/4 mile\n\nHaving family nearby was important, but nature and open space were also draws, said Mr. Morace, 32. The Staten Island Greenbelt, a 2,800-acre ribbon of woodland on the northern edge, buffers Lighthouse Hill from urban sprawl. Mr. Morace can return to playing golf on the nearby La Tourette course, or sledding on the hilly terrain in winter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe air seems fresher,\u201d he said of the neighborhood, though he also noted that a surge in deer ticks and Lyme disease cases have come with the territory.\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Find\n\nAccording to the 1995 \u201cEncyclopedia of New York,\u201d Lighthouse Hill is bounded by Forest Hill Road to the north, Richmond Road to the south, Rockland Avenue to the east and the La Tourette Golf Course to the west. Though the streets were laid out in the first decade of the 20th century, when the area was known as Richmond Hill, Lighthouse Hill wasn\u2019t developed in earnest until enough cars came along to move residents comfortably up the slope, said Barnett Shepherd, a local architectural historian. As a result, it has the feeling of a midcentury suburb. Detached single-family homes sit on neatly tended lots when they\u2019re not clinging to the edge of a cliff, and there are few sidewalks along the winding streets.\n\nHere one finds brick-and-shingle ranch houses, Arts and Crafts cottages, baby Dutch colonials and flat-roofed modernist retorts to convention. Several of these last, Mr. Shepherd said, are the 1940s work of an architect named Matthew Leizer, who later moved to Los Angeles.\n\nHistoric homes include the Nathaniel J. and Ann C. Wyeth house, an 1856 Italianate brick cube with a cupola at 190 Meisner Avenue. The original circular driveway remains from the pre-automobile era, when coaches needed to turn around without backing up, Mr. Shepherd noted.\n\nAnd despite scant opportunities for development, new homes are rising, too. A quartet of houses in the Lighthouse Rise Estates project on Lowell Street were recently listed at $1,699,999 each. The homes will have four bedrooms with en-suite baths and 6,800-square-foot lots.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat the neighborhood lacks is any kind of commercial district. Residents drive less than 10 minutes to Clarke Avenue in Richmondtown, where the shops include a NetCost Market that specializes in foods from Russia and Eastern Europe. The Staten Island Mall is less than 15 minutes away.\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Pay\n\nMimi Neuhaus, an owner of Neuhaus Realty on Richmond Road and a neighborhood resident for more than 40 years, said the increase in prices reflects rising values everywhere in Staten Island. What is unique, she added, is Lighthouse Hill\u2019s small size \u2014 only 250 families \u2014 which drives up demand.\n\nAccording to data published on the real estate site Trulia, the median sales price of Lighthouse Hill homes as of August 2017 was $785,000, a year-on-year increase of 4 percent, based on 61 transactions and boundaries that extend somewhat northeast of Rockland Avenue.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs of Feb. 5, four homes were listed for sale, including the three-bedroom house at 340 Lighthouse Avenue that belonged to Jacques Marchais. The 1925 Dutch Colonial-style building, which has stained glass, a terraced garden and a separate one-bedroom cottage, is priced at $1.25 million.\n\nThe Vibe\n\nWith its big sky, big views and ivy-covered tree trunks, the neighborhood benefits from being somewhat remote and wrapped in greenery. Still, a car or a powerful interest in aerobic exercise is advisable.\n\nThe Schools\n\nThe small community lacks public schools, but they are not far away.\n\nP.S. 23, Richmondtown School, approximately a mile south, has about 560 students in prekindergarten through sixth grade. On 2016-17 state tests, 63 percent met standards in English versus 40 percent citywide; 67 percent met standards in math versus 42 percent citywide.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI.S. 2, George L. Egbert Intermediate School, about three miles east, has about 870 students in sixth through eighth grades. On state tests, 46 percent met standards in English versus 41 percent citywide; 35 percent met standards in math versus 33 percent citywide.\n\nSusan E. Wagner High School, less than two miles north, has about 3,300 students in ninth through 12th grades. The school has an 86 percent graduation rate. Average 2016-17 SAT scores were 505 in reading and writing and 537 in math, compared with 491 and 490 citywide.\n\nAmong the private and parochial schools in the area is the almost century-old St. Patrick\u2019s School, a coeducational Roman Catholic institution on Richmond Road with about 500 students in kindergarten through eighth grade. For one child, the price is $5,095 a year for parishioners, and $5,455 for nonparishioners.\n\nThe Commute\n\nDuring the morning rush hour, driving to Midtown Manhattan, via I-78 in New Jersey to the Holland Tunnel, takes an hour or two depending on traffic. The X15 express bus runs along Richmond Road and stops at the Rector Street subway station in Lower Manhattan (travel time during the morning rush hour: about an hour and 20 minutes).\n\nThe closest Staten Island Rail station is in New Dorp, about two miles east, with regular service to the St. George Ferry Terminal (a 14-minute trip) and a half-hour boat ride to Lower Manhattan.\n\nThe History\n\nWhere Rockland Avenue meets Meisner Avenue, there used to be the Richmond Seminary for Young Ladies, a finishing school housed in a Greek Revival building constructed around 1830. From 1852 to 1870, the building served as the Richmond Hill Hotel. Today, the site is occupied by Eger Harbor House, a senior-living facility.", "title": "Lighthouse Hill, Staten Island: Small and Semirural", "authors": ["Julie Lasky", "Living In"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 Chloe Kim, the 17-year-old who outsoared her helpless rivals to win the gold medal in the snowboard halfpipe Tuesday, was sitting near Shaun White on the eve of the Olympics, when a question about pressure was directed her way. Kim, lined up on an auditorium stage with the American team, was, after all, expected to overwhelm the competition here, and maybe at several more Games after this.\n\nShe shrugged the question away.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t really think about it as pressure,\u201d she said. Pressure is a byproduct of expectations, she added, and expectations mean that people believe in you.\n\nWhite, 31 years old and the most famous rider in history, fielded deeper questions about his life and career. Without much prompting, he kept returning to the concept of expectations and pressure. It was obviously on his mind, a constant companion for about 25 years now.\n\nThe years have taught him that the hardest trick is sustaining success when everyone expects it from you.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis audience was a room full of journalists, but it felt aimed, purposely or not, at an audience of one: Kim.", "title": "Like Shaun White Before Her, Chloe Kim Dazzles on Way to Winning Halfpipe Gold", "authors": ["John Branch"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "I liked BOX CAMERA, SPEEDBALL, PENTHOUSE SUITE, YOGURT SMOOTHIE, NEAT AS A PIN, FLAMBOYANT, LATIN LOVER, the TATE MODERN (which is a fabulous place to while away an afternoon), INAMORATA and even the word PIXELATED, although the clue is weird. He\u2019s not wrong, mind you \u2014 from what I\u2019ve been told \u2014 but is this kind of reference to pornography in appropriate taste for a New York Times crossword? Granted, we\u2019ve had our X-RATED and XXX entries, but this particular clue seems to zero in on an aspect of porn that goes beyond the ratings. And heaven knows there are other ways to clue PIXELATED than by focusing on someone\u2019s \u201cprivates.\u201d\n\nTricky Clues\n\nI\u2019m going to stick to the clues that involve wordplay today, because there was a lot in this puzzle that requires general (and not so general) knowledge, which you either know or you don\u2019t. Don\u2019t even get me started on how long I was stuck at the crossing of NEMEAN and AMBIT.\n\n5A: \u201cWhat Iran and Iraq do\u201d seems like the kind of clue that might be talking about international relations, but it\u2019s simpler than that. Their borders touch, so they ABUT.", "title": "Like a Mythical Lion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "The measures, known as \u201cred flag laws\u201d or extreme risk protection orders, have shown evidence of reducing suicides in Connecticut, where the first such law was passed in 1999, and in recent years have also been passed in California, Washington and Oregon. Eighteen states, including Florida, and the District of Columbia are considering such laws this year, according to a list compiled by Everytown for Gun Safety, a nonprofit advocacy group.\n\n\u201cTo claim, \u2018Oh, well, you should see the signs and tell law enforcement,\u2019 to me is disingenuous unless there is something law enforcement can do,\u201d said Avery Gardiner, the co-president of the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence.\n\nRed flag laws, she said, \u201cprovide a path to remove guns from somebody in a temporary crisis.\u201d And, she said, even if a family decides not to seek a gun restraining order, the fact that the option exists can prompt frank conversations with struggling relatives.\n\nVideo\n\nMr. Trump and Republican lawmakers have long tried to steer the national conversation after mass shootings to the mental health of people pulling the triggers, rather than the weapons they used. That effort is belied by the fact that mental illness is not the root of most cases of gun violence, though it does pose an increased risk for suicide.\n\nAs reactions poured in Thursday, Mr. Trump focused on the suspect\u2019s mental health, and Attorney General Jeff Sessions said he wanted the Justice Department to study how mental illness and gun violence intersect. He said it would help law enforcement better understand how law enforcement can use existing laws to intervene before school shootings happen.\n\n\u201cIt cannot be denied that something dangerous and unhealthy is happening in our country,\u201d Mr. Sessions told a group of sheriffs in Washington. In \u201cevery one of these cases, we\u2019ve had advance indications and perhaps we haven\u2019t been effective enough in intervening.\u201d\n\nSecretary Alex M. Azar II of the Department of Health and Human Services began a multiagency news conference on the flu epidemic by addressing the Florida shootings. The administration would be \u201claser-focused on getting Americans with mental illness the help they need,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe suspect in the Florida shooting, Nikolas Cruz, 19, had been expelled from the high school, and many former classmates avoided him, convinced he was dangerous. He was also apparently showing signs of depression, having recently lost his mother.\n\nIn an analysis of some 350 mass killers going back a century, about 22 percent were found to likely have had psychosis; the rate in the general population is closer to 1 percent. A much smaller percentage had severe depression; so far there is no evidence Mr. Cruz had psychosis.\n\nFederal law forbids people who have been involuntarily committed to a psychiatric hospital and people found to be a danger to themselves or others from having guns. But the federal government depends on states to report such cases so it can add them to a national background check system, and reporting varies widely.\n\nFlorida has entered 141,042 mental health records into the national background check system, according to the Brady Campaign. Wyoming, on the other hand, has entered four.\n\nThe number of mental health records in the system has grown rapidly, to 5.2 million in 2018 from 234,628 in 2005, the Brady Campaign said.\n\nBut after 20 children and six adults were killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School in 2012, the Obama administration tried to add some people to the background check system, by requiring the Social Security Administration to submit records of some beneficiaries with severe mental illness.\n\nLast year, Mr. Trump quietly revoked that rule, which was also opposed by the American Civil Liberties Union.\n\nSome states have tried to create their own databases of people deemed too mentally unstable to carry firearms. New York, one of the most restrictive states in the country, had put 34,500 names on its list by 2014, a figure that raised concerns among some mental health advocates that too many people had been categorized as dangerous.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut that approach has largely fallen out of favor, with more states turning to red flag laws that focus not on a mental health diagnosis but rather on dangerous behavior.\n\nThey bloomed in several states after the Isla Vista shooting in 2014, in which a disturbed man killed six University of California, Santa Barbara students after his family had tried unsuccessfully to alert the authorities about his troubling behavior.\n\nThe laws typically allow the police or family members to petition a court for a temporary gun restraining order that might last a few weeks. After a hearing in which the person can respond to evidence, a judge can issue a final order that typically lasts up to a year and can be renewed. The restraining orders usually allow the police to seize people\u2019s guns and restrict them from buying new ones.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week.
