Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Connecticut, where 762 gun seizure cases were carried out from 1999 to June 2013, a study by researchers at Duke University estimated that the law had averted approximately one suicide for every 10 to 11 gun seizure cases.\n\n\u201cWe see these laws as a way for law enforcement and families to intervene before these mass tragedies occur,\u201d said Elizabeth Avore, the legal and policy director at Everytown for Gun Safety. \u201cLaw enforcement or family are usually the first to see this threat.\u201d\n\nIn California, efforts to expand the list of those who could petition for restraining orders to include co-workers and employers drew opposition not only from pro-gun groups like the National Rifle Association but also from the A.C.L.U.\n\nFlorida is one of the less restrictive states when it comes to mental illness and guns. The police can confine people considered a danger to themselves or others for up to 72 hours as part of an involuntary psychiatric evaluation. And the police are allowed to take their guns when they are detained. But a 2009 advisory opinion by the state\u2019s attorney general said that without an arrest or criminal charge, the police could not hold onto their weapons.\n\nMental health experts said the proposals raised by the sheriff and Mr. Scott provoked concerns.\n\n\u201cTo say no one with mental illness should have a gun \u2014 how do you accomplish that?\u201d said Ronald Honberg, senior policy adviser for the National Alliance on Mental Illness. \u201cDoes that mean anybody that goes to a therapist for depression or anxiety should be reported and put in a database and prohibited from purchasing a firearm? That would impact a fair number of police officers.\u201d", "title": "Limiting Access to Guns for Mentally Ill Is Complicated", "authors": ["Benjamin Mueller"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "What could be better about some of these tools?\n\nProtonMail can be cumbersome. The service encrypts your emails before they reach the ProtonMail server. As a result, you can\u2019t search the texts of your emails for keywords if you use the free service. You can search only the subject lines.\n\nIt\u2019s a constant reminder that ceding to online surveillance is much more frictionless than trying to limit it.\n\nRecently Apple investors raised concerns about smartphone addiction and children. Is this a problem and are there adequate solutions?\n\nI\u2019ve heard from many parents, including a few physicians, concerned about the amount of time their kids are spending online at school and at home. It\u2019s so difficult to find the right balance between making sure our children are fluent with online tools and protecting them from getting sucked in by habit-forming video platforms and social networks. Many parents feel they are up against a powerful, interlocking ecosystem, designed to hook their kids on constant scrolling, watching, and clicking.\n\nGiven the vast ecosystem, however, singling out Apple as the culprit seems to me a little bit like blaming only soda can manufacturers for Americans\u2019 addiction to sugary beverages. Yes, it would be terrific if Apple introduced new control options for parents. But if shareholders want to fault companies for manipulating or addicting users, they should also be taking a hard look at Facebook, YouTube, Instagram, Snapchat, Netflix and many more.\n\nEven small user-interface changes could make a big difference. Imagine if the default setting for streaming video services wasn\u2019t autoplay.\n\nOn a larger level, we\u2019ve seen over the past year how some Big Tech companies initially refused to take responsibility for the spread of fake news and other side effects of their innovations. In that context, platforms that nudge children and adults to stay online are merely one symptom of a much bigger problem.", "title": "Limiting the Influence of Tech When You Report on It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Lin Bolen, who as the executive in charge of NBC\u2019s daytime programming in the early 1970s was the highest-ranking woman in television, died on Jan. 18 in Santa Monica, Calif. Most online sources put her age at 76.\n\nHer friend Lisa Demberg confirmed the death. The cause was not specified.\n\nMs. Bolen was just 31 in 1972 when she was named director of daytime programs at NBC, putting her in charge of the network\u2019s collection of soap operas and game shows. A year later she was given the title vice president for daytime programs \u2014 \u201cthe highest position a woman has so far achieved in network programming,\u201d The New York Times reported.\n\nIn that job, which she held until forming her own production company in 1976, she energized the network\u2019s game shows and expanded half-hour soaps to an hour. By 1975, NBC\u2019s daytime ratings surpassed both CBS and ABC for the first time in a dozen years.\n\nAccounts vary as to whether Ms. Bolen was the inspiration for Diana Christensen, the do-anything-for-ratings network executive played by Faye Dunaway in the 1976 film \u201cNetwork,\u201d written by Paddy Chayefsky. Ms. Bolen herself was somewhat equivocal.", "title": "Lin Bolen, a Trailblazing TV Executive, Dies at 76", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Lin-Manuel Miranda was on summer break from college when he learned something about how New York was put together. He was working for a bilingual newspaper started by his father, covering an event called \u201cSalsa, Blues and Shamrocks.\u201d The event, put on by an Irish bar and restaurant in the Dominican neighborhood of Washington Heights, was somewhat misnamed \u2014 it featured klezmer and merengue music as well.\n\nFor Mr. Miranda, then 20, it was a vision of New York\u2019s disparate cultures not battling one another but jamming side by side. The institutions that endured, he realized, were those that \u201cembraced every wave of immigration that\u2019s come.\u201d Within a few decades, this vision would inform the work that thrust him on the world.\n\nOn a December morning in Midtown Manhattan, Mr. Miranda, nursing a cold, reminisced about that summer, when he also discovered Morris-Jumel Mansion, the oldest house in New York, where Aaron Burr lived when he killed Alexander Hamilton in a duel. During the school year, Mr. Miranda had written and staged his first musical, \u201cIn the Heights,\u201d at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., and he had also moved into the Latino student house on campus, which gave him a new perspective on the layered worlds of New York and his own identity within them \u2014 part insider, part outsider looking in. Jumel Mansion, on Sugar Hill in Harlem, lay between Broadway and the two-story house in Inwood where Mr. Miranda grew up \u2014 with access to all those worlds but not bounded by any of them.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re in a different century for exactly one block, and then you go down the steps and there\u2019s a C-town, and you\u2019re back in 2017,\u201d Mr. Miranda said. \u201cThat\u2019s to me what makes New York great \u2014 it\u2019s all these things together at the same time. The feeling that you\u2019re on the train with the Wall Street guy and the mariachi bands. We\u2019re all in this thing together.\u201d", "title": "Lin-Manuel Miranda, the Next Lion of New York", "authors": ["John Leland"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "But since assuming the role, she has spent a large chunk of her time on the road, visiting the agency\u2019s local offices and sitting for business gatherings on a kind of meet-and-greet tour that resembles a campaign schedule.\n\nShe has strolled through a chocolaterie in Iowa (the company had grown with the help of three S.B.A.-backed loans), acquired a bobblehead doll from a grain company in Oregon (it now sits on a shelf in her office) and rerouted her team to a Dairy Queen in Pennsylvania after learning the identity of an attendee at a local chamber of commerce event.\n\n\u201cShe kind of looked at me and said, \u2018Are you the Dairy Queen person?\u2019\u201d said Judy Lynn-Craig, a franchisee for the ice cream chain. \u201cShe had read our bios.\u201d\n\nMs. McMahon\u2019s more consequential work has come in extreme weather, briefing the cabinet on recovery efforts for storm-affected businesses and overseeing the allocation of aid. The agency said it had approved more than 100,000 loans for nearly $6 billion in disaster-loan assistance for victims of Hurricanes Harvey, Irma and Maria, outpacing the loan totals and processing times from Hurricane Sandy and Hurricane Katrina. (The agency issues loans directly after natural disasters; in nonemergencies, it guarantees a portion of a loan in the event of default, reducing the risk for lenders.)\n\nIf Ms. McMahon has retained any discomfort with Mr. Trump\u2019s behavior since taking office, the two seem to have had little friction, in part because her agency\u2019s mission is less politically fraught than some others\u2019.\n\nReminded that Washington\u2019s power structure now included two prominent W.W.E. veterans, Ms. McMahon disputed any suggestion that the capital had come to resemble a professional wrestling scene. \u201cOh my goodness,\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t think that\u2019s it.\u201d\n\nBut the president has not forgotten their shared history.\n\n\u201cShe has been incredible,\u201d Mr. Trump told guests at a White House event last summer. \u201cKnown her for a long time.\u201d", "title": "Linda McMahon Gets a Ringside Seat for TrumpMania", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLindsay Anne Mendoza and Patrick Austin Christopher Temple-West were married Feb. 23 at St. Matthew\u2019s Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. Joseph Graff, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.\n\nThe bride, 37, was until December, working in Washington as the global vice president of sustainability at AstraZeneca, the pharmaceutical and biopharmaceutical company based in Cambridge, Mass. She graduated from McGill University and received a master's degree in social policy and development from the London School of Economics.\n\nShe is the daughter of Myles Mendoza and Dan Mendoza of North Bergen, N.J. The bride\u2019s father is retired as a director of sales at Bayer Pharmaceuticals in Whippany, N.J. Her mother, also retired, was the founder and principal designer of DesignMaster, a commercial interior design firm based in Toronto and North Bergen.\n\nThe groom, 33, is a journalist in Washington for Politico. He graduated from St. Joseph's University and received a master's degree in journalism from Northwestern University.\n\nHe is the son of Patrice Temple-West of Philadelphia and the late Patrick Temple-West. The groom\u2019s mother retired as a science teacher at Holy Child School at Rosemont in Rosemont, Pa. His father founded Nutritional Development Services, a company in Philadelphia that donates food to the needy.\n\nThe couple met during the Christmas season in 2013 while volunteering to wrap gifts for the needy in the basement at St. Matthew\u2019s Cathedral in Washington.", "title": "Lindsay Mendoza, Patrick Temple-West", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 The idea of redemption has always made the snowboard cross star Lindsey Jacobellis weary, because, in her mind, she did nothing that needed to be redeemed. Yet after her infamous fall at the 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin, where she spun gold into silver by falling near the finish line with a big lead, that is the way her Olympics career has been framed.\n\nIt was that way in Vancouver in 2010, and Sochi in 2014. Both times, Jacobellis, the most accomplished athlete in the sport\u2019s history, stumbled in the semifinals, leaving without a medal.\n\nTwelve years later, most of them spent dominating the World Cup circuit, she was back in the Olympics championship race, called the Big Final.\n\nAgain she left without a medal \u2014 by 0.03 seconds.\n\nJacobellis finished fourth, missing the medal stand by about half the length of a snowboard. She led the final race midway through the curling course of rises and jumps but was passed on the bottom half. She avoided a crash near the finish line and came across a fraction of a second behind Eva Samkova of the Czech Republic, who won gold four years ago and bronze this time.", "title": "Lindsey Jacobellis Again Misses Gold in Snowboard Cross", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Goggia came out of the gate slowly and was the 26th fastest \u2014 out of 31 racers who finished \u2014 in the first timed interval. But Goggia quickly settled into a confident, aggressive stance on her skis, which she repeatedly pressured for more and more speed. By the third interval, Goggia was fifth fastest in the field.\n\nAs it turned out, she was just finding her rhythm. By smoothly linking her turns and occasionally taking a more rounded approach to the gates, Goggia kept the flat bases of her skis on the snow surface for longer stretches. The payoff was the fastest time in each of the three final timed intervals.\n\nWhen Vonn followed two skiers later, she was faster at the start but less fluid in the middle section. Her skis seemed on edge and rattling more often than Goggia\u2019s, and after a bit of a miscue coming off the third jump in the course, Vonn trailed Goggia by nearly a half-second. She did not make up the time.\n\n\u201cI was maybe a little too precise with my line but it was a clean run,\u201d Vonn said later. \u201cMaybe I should have let the skis run a little more.\n\n\u201cBut I didn\u2019t ski stiff or nervous,\u201d she added.\n\nVonn had dedicated her performance to her late grandfather, Don Kildow, who had helped teach her to ski. Kildow died in November.\n\n\u201cI desperately wanted to win for him and I wish he could have been here to watch,\u201d she said. \u201cBut I still think he is watching and I think he\u2019d still be proud of me.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough not naturally introspective, Vonn seemed eager to use the occasion to reflect on her career.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m really proud of what I\u2019ve accomplished in four Olympic Games because some of them were pretty difficult,\u201d she said.", "title": "Lindsey Vonn Settles for Bronze in Downhill; Sofia Goggia Takes Gold", "authors": ["Bill Pennington"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "TAMPA, Fla. \u2014 The lines stretched out the door this weekend at a gun show in Tampa, Fla., as thousands of potential buyers and the merely curious waited for their turn to browse booths stocked with the latest firearms, ammunition, customizable holsters and patriotic paraphernalia.\n\nInside, parents pushed their babies in strollers past T-shirts emblazoned with phrases like \u201cI study triggernometry.\u201d A nonprofit group in one booth was raffling off a rifle to raise money to battle child and animal abuse. On large signs by the entrance, the National Rifle Association was offering refunds on the $11 admission if shoppers signed up for a membership. Outside, Girl Scouts were selling cookies.\n\nBut the deadly mass shooting a couple of hundred miles away at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School cast its shadow. Both buyers and sellers were talking about the attack, as well as about the divisive debate that it had recently reignited.", "title": "Lines Out the Door and Strong Sales at Tampa Gun Show", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music\n\nBook Review Lisa Halliday on \u2018Asymmetry\u2019 Halliday discusses her debut novel, and Naomi Novik and Gerald Jonas remember the life and work of Ursula K. Le Guin. Audio\n\nIn The New York Times Book Review, Alice Gregory reviews Lisa Halliday\u2019s debut novel, \u201cAsymmetry.\u201d Gregory writes:\n\nPhoto\n\nHalliday\u2019s novel is so strange and startlingly smart that its mere existence seems like commentary on the state of fiction. One finishes \u201cAsymmetry\u201d for the first or second (or like this reader, third) time and is left wondering what other writers are not doing with their freedom... Despite its title, \u201cAsymmetry\u201d comprises two seemingly unrelated sections of equal length, appended by a slim and quietly shocking coda. Halliday\u2019s prose is clean and lean, almost reportorial in the style of W. G. Sebald, and like the murmurings of a shy person at a cocktail party, often comic only in single clauses. It\u2019s a first novel that reads like the work of an author who has published many books over many years.\n\nOn this week\u2019s podcast, Halliday discusses \u201cAsymmetry\u201d; Naomi Novik and Gerald Jonas remember the life and work of Ursula K. Le Guin; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; and The Times\u2019s staff book critics, Dwight Garner, Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai, talk about books they\u2019ve recently reviewed. Pamela Paul is the host.\n\nWe would love to hear your thoughts about this episode, and about the Book Review\u2019s podcast in general. You can send them to books@nytimes.com.\n\nHow do I listen? Two ways\n\nFrom a desktop or laptop, you can listen by pressing play on the button above.\n\nOr if you\u2019re on a mobile device, the instructions below will help you find and subscribe to the series.\n\n1. Open your podcast app. It\u2019s a pre-loaded app called \u201cPodcasts\u201d with a purple icon.\n\n2. Search for the series. Tap on the \u201csearch\u201d magnifying glass icon at the bottom of the screen, type in \u201cInside The New York Times Book Review\u201d and select it from the list of results.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n3. Subscribe. Once on the series page, tap on the \u201csubscribe\u201d button to have new episodes sent to your phone free. You may want to adjust your notifications to be alerted when a new episode arrives.", "title": "Lisa Halliday on \u2018Asymmetry\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYes, some people are going to think of Philip Roth, but Ezra Blazer is a work of fiction,\u201d she said. \u201cThe entire book is an amalgam of details and impressions derived from experiences both romantic and platonic that I\u2019ve had over the years, plus a healthy dose of research and imagination. I can understand why some people would associate Philip Roth with Ezra Blazer, but really they are not neatly correlated.\u201d\n\nIn evoking the relationship, Ms. Halliday wasn\u2019t aiming to write a fictionalized romantic tell-all, she said, but saw it as a way to explore a young writer\u2019s creative struggles and to show how experience, along with imagination, shapes fiction.\n\n\u201cI wanted to write about an aspiring writer who was having trouble under what I think Harold Bloom called \u2018the anxiety of influence,\u2019 because I certainly felt that, working right at the heart of publishing,\u201d she said. \u201cTo go back to Philip, I wanted Alice\u2019s relationship to be with someone of that stature because it worked for the story.\u201d\n\n\u201cAsymmetry,\u201d which is being embraced as a virtuosic and daring literary debut, is hardly a conventional semi-autobiographical first novel about a young writer\u2019s coming-of-age. It unfolds in three disparate sections that don\u2019t intersect in obvious ways.\n\nThe first, \u201cFolly,\u201d centers on the asymmetrical romance between Alice and Ezra. He pays off her student loans, gives her shopping bags full of books and reads her his work in progress. She takes him to the hospital when he has chest pains, worries that their vigorous sexual encounters are exacerbating his bad back, and acquiesces when he introduces her to friends as his research assistant. They joke about their age difference \u2014 when she teases him for being a cradle robber, he calls her a grave robber. But while their relationship is playful and affectionate, his stature as a writer complicates Alice\u2019s own literary aspirations.\n\nIn a disorienting shift, the second section, \u201cMadness,\u201d is narrated by Amar Ala Jaafari, a young Iraqi-American economist who is detained by passport control at a London airport on his way to visit his brother in Iraqi Kurdistan. The final segment, \u201cEzra Blazer\u2019s Desert Island Discs,\u201d unfolds as a fictional interview segment on the BBC program, as a journalist asks Blazer about his writing and what music he would take to a desert island. His revealing answers about love, music and literature capture Mr. Roth\u2019s conversational voice perfectly, some people who know the author say.\n\nThere are subtle clues connecting the disjointed narrative strands, and recurring themes that take on new resonance as the novel progresses: the relationship between autobiography and fiction, the power of imagination, and how art can provoke empathy for people whose backgrounds and experiences diverge from our own.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Halliday didn\u2019t exactly emerge fully-formed out of nowhere \u2014 she published a short story in The Paris Review in 2005, and forged connections in the literary world through her work as an agent. But she\u2019s had a surprising trajectory, and is something of a late bloomer, having spent nearly two decades working on her fiction largely in private before submitting a book for publication.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe grew up in a working-class family in Medfield, a small town in Massachusetts, where her father worked as a mechanic and repairman and her mother made a living as a seamstress. They divorced when she was 5, and she and her sister moved in with her mother and her mother\u2019s boyfriend, who started an extermination business together and later married.\n\nThey lived near the library, and in the summer she would spend her days there, reading E.B. White and Laura Ingalls Wilder and then Dickens, Fitzgerald and Edith Wharton. She excelled in school and went on to study art history at Harvard, becoming the first person in her immediate family to go to college.\n\nAfter graduating in 1998, she got a job as an assistant literary agent at the Wylie Agency and was soon promoted. Ms. Halliday became friendly with some of the writers represented by the agency, including the novelist Louise Erdrich, the poet Louise Gluck and Mr. Roth.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cYou know she\u2019s unusual immediately,\u201d Ms. Erdrich said of Ms. Halliday. \u201cI\u2019ve never known anyone who has such precise syntax, it was like she was writing in the air.\u201d\n\nWorking with accomplished writers every day might intimidate some aspiring novelists, but Ms. Halliday found it exhilarating, and began to think about writing fiction.\n\n\u201cPrior to that, I thought there was some sort of magic involved, and that I just didn\u2019t have that magic,\u201d she said.\n\nShe started getting up at five in the morning to write. Mr. Roth\u2019s dedication to writing, the daily act and routine of it, made an impression on her, she said.\n\n\u201cHis example as a hard-working novelist was one of the most encouraging,\u201d she said. \u201cA lot of it is showing up even when you feel it\u2019s not working. He\u2019s very good at that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Halliday declined to say much about her relationship with Mr. Roth, beyond acknowledging that they were once romantically involved and remain friends, and she cautioned against reading Alice\u2019s story as autobiography.\n\n\u201cOf course there are details of Alice\u2019s life that overlap with my own, but so much is invented for the sake of the narrative,\u201d she said. \u201cPhilip, more than anyone, knows that\u2019s what writing is like.\u201d\n\nIn 2006, Ms. Halliday left the agency to focus on fiction. She did some freelance editing and ghostwriting to support herself, so progress was slow.\n\nShe moved to Milan in 2011 with her husband, who works at an Italian publishing house, and began working on \u201cAsymmetry.\u201d When her agent submitted it to publishers in the summer of 2016, it sparked a heated auction between eight publishing houses.\n\nPublishers\u2019 enthusiasm \u2014 fueled partly, no doubt, by Ms. Halliday\u2019s intriguing back story \u2014 caught her off guard. In the years she spent working on the novel, Ms. Halliday often relied on advice that Ms. Erdrich gave her. \u201cShe said, \u2018write as though you\u2019re writing in secret, as though no one will actually read it\u2019,\u201d she said.\n\nNow that her secret is out, Ms. Halliday no longer has the luxury of laboring in obscurity. She\u2019s already writing another novel, set partly in Italy, which explores how conspiracy theories take hold. It tackles a theme that has long preoccupied her: the blurred boundaries between fiction and reality.", "title": "Lisa Halliday\u2019s Debut Novel Is Drawing Comparisons to Philip Roth. Flat weave or shag? These are a few of our favorite rug options at various prices.\n\nMoroccan\n\nThe actress Julianne Moore, the designer Jenna Lyons and the artists Brice and Helen Marden are among the stylish New Yorkers who have helped make these shaggy, generally diamond-patterned carpets from North Africa one of the design world\u2019s biggest trends.\n\nSecret Berb\u00e8re has its central location in North Central Morocco, with outposts in Madrid and Paris. The company ships some of the world\u2019s best Berber carpets worldwide for less than $4,000.\n\nThat\u2019s a slightly better deal than you\u2019re likely to get from through Nazmiyal Antique Rugs in New York or Woven in Los Angeles. But those stores also have lush Beni Ourains in the $5,000 to $7,500 range. (Kat & Maouche, in Portland, Ore., is another shop worth checking out.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShoppers are sometimes frustrated by these carpets\u2019 sizes; because they are woven by nomadic tribespeople who sleep in long narrow tents, they seldom run wider than seven feet. That\u2019s why Ms. Lyons now has two side by side and Ms. Moore has two woven together for her West Village townhouse.", "title": "Listen, There\u2019s a Smorgasbord of Great Carpets Out There", "authors": ["Jacob Bernstein"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "One of Little Italy\u2019s longest-operating restaurants was damaged on Saturday by an early-morning fire that seriously injured two people and left 11 others with minor injuries, the New York City Fire Department said.\n\nAngelo\u2019s of Mulberry St., at 146 Mulberry St., has served Neapolitan cuisine since 1902, according to its website. Photographs show that politicians and celebrities who have eaten there include President Ronald Reagan and the basketball star Kobe Bryant.\n\nThe call about the fire came in at 7:41 a.m. through the city\u2019s 911 system, said Kenneth Reilly, a spokesman for the Fire Department. Firefighters arrived to find the first two floors of the six-story building engulfed in flames. Residential apartments sit above the ground-floor commercial unit.\n\nThe fire quickly generated a second alarm and 25 fire trucks and 106 firefighters arrived at the scene. The blaze was declared under control at 9:20 a.m., Mr. Reilly said.", "title": "Little Italy Fire Injures 13 and Damages a Century-Old Restaurant", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Scelsa said that in the early 1920s, a tenement apartment could be rented in the area for $10 a month \u2014 less than today\u2019s neighborhood Nova sandwich. Today, a three-bedroom apartment at 133 Mulberry Street, a condo project that appears to have been cobbled together from three tenement buildings, is for sale at $2.85 million.\n\nBut some remnants of those old bargains remained, long after the neighborhood was nearly devoured by Chinatown and then succumbed to gentrification. Dr. Scelsa said that about three years ago, his museum bought out a rent-controlled tenant in its building, on the corner of Mulberry and Grand Streets. The tenant had inherited the apartment from a parent who had been there since the turn of the last century \u2014 and he was paying less than $100 a month for 1,000 square feet of space.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt was a lot of money,\u201d Dr. Scelsa said of the price the museum paid to get the tenant to move out. \u201cBut he\u2019s very happy. He\u2019s got an apartment on the Upper East Side. And we\u2019ve got the space.\u201d\n\nBusinesses, too, have seen their rents explode. John Delutro owns Caff\u00e9 Palermo, right next door to Angelo\u2019s. Mr. Delutro, who goes by the sobriquet Baby John the Cannoli King, opened his cafe almost 45 years ago, and today it\u2019s hard to miss: A 12-foot-tall cannoli is affixed to the side of the building.\n\n\u201cI started this restaurant when I was 17 and my rent was $75 a month,\u201d Mr. Delutro said. \u201cYou don\u2019t want me to tell you what it is now. You\u2019ll fall down.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHis shop is busy every day and he has a great mail order business, the Cannoli King said, but he worries about the future.\n\n\u201cAs rents go up you know the prices go up, and after a while we\u2019ll be overpriced,\u201d he said. \u201cMy cheesecake is $6. So what am I going to charge, $9? That\u2019s a lot of money.\u201d\n\nSome might say that many nearby restaurants are already there. One establishment offers campagnola, described as a rustic dish of saut\u00e9ed steak, chicken and sausage, for $41.95, and a chicken breast crusted in pistachio for $25.95. Several restaurants station employees out front, armed with menus and an insistent smile, trying to cajole passers-by to stop in for a meal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAngelo\u2019s, many in the neighborhood said, was different. Bruno Brancaleone, who stood outside the restaurant on Monday chain-smoking Marlboro Lights and talking on his cellphone, said he had worked at Angelo\u2019s for about 30 years, an eternity in the food service industry. Mr. Brancaleone, who said he came to the United States from Naples, Italy, about 35 years ago, said many of his co-workers had been there for 20 or more years.\n\nAngelo\u2019s was also something of a destination, if often for those from out of town. Bill and Nidia Demma own an Italian restaurant near Utica, N.Y., and they come down to New York City several times a year with another couple. Every time they come to town, they go to Angelo\u2019s.\n\n\u201cWe just came here to eat,\u201d said their friend Anthony Giovinazzo, who stood in front of the barren restaurant on Monday. \u201cSo now,\u201d he said with a laugh, \u201cI guess we\u2019ll go to Chick-fil-A.\u201d", "title": "Little Italy Is Very Little, and Not Very Italian", "authors": ["Elizabeth A. Harris"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Concern about rising deficits may be weighing on financial markets, as well. The federal government, which competes with private investors for available funds, plans to borrow almost $1 trillion this year, a big jump from last year\u2019s total of $519 billion, the Treasury said last week. That is a direct result of the decision to cut taxes without reducing federal spending. Indeed, the administration is now pushing for more spending on defense.\n\nMr. Trump also decided last year that he would not nominate Janet L. Yellen for a second term as Fed chairwoman. Instead, he nominated Jerome H. Powell, who was sworn into office on Monday as the market opened for business.\n\nMr. Powell, who had been a Fed governor since 2012, has emphasized continuity. But investors have a long history of anxiety about new Fed chairmen. During Alan Greenspan\u2019s first months in office in 1987, the stock market lost more than 30 percent of its value. And Mr. Powell is a relatively unknown quantity on Wall Street.\n\nStill, some analysts cautioned against overinterpreting the meaning of market movements.\n\n\u201cIn many cases, it is near impossible to figure out what moves the stock market in any given day,\u201d said N. Gregory Mankiw, a Harvard University economist and former chairman of the president\u2019s Council of Economic Advisers under Mr. Bush. \u201cThe stock market is a leading indicator, albeit an imperfect one. So it is natural to see a rising market as good news. But it is highly speculative to tie a stock market movement to any particular set of policies.\u201d\n\nWhile the Dow closed at its lowest point in two months, the market remains well above where it was when Mr. Trump was elected. Even with the loss, the Dow is 23 percent higher than on Inauguration Day 2017 and 33 percent higher than on Election Day 2016.\n\nOver all, the 25 percent increase in 2017 was the largest annual rise since 2013, when the Dow shot up by 26.5 percent. Over the eight years of Mr. Obama\u2019s presidency, which began at the depths of a financial crisis and recession, the market rose nearly 150 percent.\n\nAfter calling attention to the daily running of the bulls for so much of the past year, Mr. Trump chose to focus on other metrics on Monday at a manufacturing plant in Ohio where the company used some of the proceeds from the tax cuts to give employees bonuses.", "title": "Live by the Dow, Die by the Dow? Trump Is Quiet on Market", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "And yet, despite the election cycle, despite the opioid crisis, despite the tax bill, despite yawning inequality, I still see good in this country.\n\nFor one thing, I\u2019ve heard it all before; when it comes to confronting anti-Americanism, I\u2019m a veteran. Anytime I work in Gaza or the West Bank, and must explain why the Trump administration is cutting funding to refugees. Every time I work with a Syrian refugee and must explain why we have a travel ban against Muslims. Over a decade ago, I climbed the stairs to my Baghdad hotel room thinking, how can I ever go home and live in a country that is so dedicated to occupation and regime change?\n\nBut there were other moments. I was walking down Rue de Rivoli in Paris on Sept. 11, 2001, when my phone rang. \u201cSomeone just flew a plane through the twin towers,\u201d a friend told me. The pain and despair I felt in the following days was matched by the private and public sympathy I felt from thousands of Parisians.\n\nWhen I served as the jury president for the prize for war reporting given in Bayeux, the first city to be liberated during the Battle of Normandy, the mayor showed me the expanse of American graves at the nearby military cemetery as a way of demonstrating what America meant to him, his family and his people.\n\nAs a liberal and human rights activist, I am cognizant of the dark times we live in. But I try to remember that generally, and where it counts, we usually do it right. The First Amendment. The New Deal. The Four Freedoms. The Marshall Plan. The opportunity and social mobility that is more possible than in any other country where I have lived.\n\nWithout getting into Norman Rockwell platitudes, I see a determined pragmatism, a freshness that comes from growing up in America that only someone who spent years away from it can notice. As the mother of a child in the French educational system, I was aware of how positive reinforcement and encouragement is frowned on in Europe. \u201cOh you Americans, always saying, \u2018Good boy!\u2019\u201d one of my son\u2019s teachers once told me. \u201cWe don\u2019t believe in doing that.\u201d\n\nIn France, only the very bright can enter programs to prepare them for the graduate schools that act as iron gateways to the elite. In America, we draw our political and economic leadership from everywhere. Yes, there are loans. But there are also chances.\n\nI am deeply aware of our health care problems. I am aware of continued segregation, the racism, the efforts to restrict voting rights. But I still believe that at its core America both recognizes its flaws and struggles to overcome them. \u201cAmerica is great because she is good,\u201d Alexis de Tocqueville is often quoted as saying. \u201cIf America ceases to be good, America will cease to be great.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Living Abroad Taught Me to Love America", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Eastern Ghouta showed great resilience and embraced innovative ways to survive. People continued growing food on their farms, and that partly helped keep hunger at bay. They found a way to breach the siege by digging a network of underground tunnels, some of which led to neighborhoods in Damascus and were used to smuggle in necessary commodities.\n\nNumerous conversations with friends and acquaintances still living there give me a fuller sense of how they survived. People recycled plastic garbage and extracted fuel from it. They used this fuel for the generators that had been smuggled in through the tunnels. The electricity this generated became essential to connect with satellite internet and the outside world. They ground fodder and used it as flour to bake bread; they toasted oats and used it to make a beverage to replace coffee. They embraced wild herbs, which were untouched in peace, as a staple vegetable. They turned the basements of hospitals and schools into storage facilities in the face of the barrel bombs.\n\nIn a cruel twist, the regime sought to extract profit by doing some business with the besieged populace. Muhyi Eddin Manfoush, a businessman connected to the Syrian Republican Guard headed by Mr. Assad\u2019s brother, Maher al-Assad, was allowed by the regime to sell flour, packaged food, butter, oil, tea and sugar, among other things, in the besieged area, according to several merchants in Eastern Ghouta.\n\nThe deal was that Mr. Manfoush would charge the besieged and impoverished buyers a tax beyond the usual price. For a kilogram of flour, sugar and rice he charged an extra 2,000 Syrian pounds, or about $4; for clothes, shoes and cleaning material he charged an extra 3,000 Syrian pounds, or about $6, according to multiple residents. But medicines, medical equipment, electronics and building equipment were strictly prohibited from entering the besieged area.\n\nThe people of Eastern Ghouta were left with few resources and a terribly depleted capacity to buy anything. The few sources of support were financial aid from a group of NGOs and some religious networks. By 2017, the fourth year of the siege, Mr. Assad\u2019s forces had taken control of many neighborhoods from the rebels. In March, the regime took Barzeh and Qaboun, two neighborhoods in Damascus that were crucial for the survival of the besieged areas. The tunnels that the opposition had dug to bring in supplies led from Eastern Ghouta to Barzeh and Qaboun. Mr. Assad\u2019s forces destroyed the tunnel network and blocked the supplies.\n\nWithin days of the fall of Barzeh and Qaboun, the price of diesel jumped to about $10 per liter from about 63 cents per liter. The season for harvesting crops and planting vegetables was days away. The farmers couldn\u2019t afford the fuel for their agricultural tools \u2014 generators, water pumps, tractors. They simply couldn\u2019t water their lands or even harvest the crops.\n\nThe failure to cultivate and harvest the local produce, the destruction of the tunnel system and the relentless siege pushed the cost of living punitively higher. In October, according to various residents and activists in Eastern Ghouta, a kilogram of sugar cost 2,400 Syrian pounds, or about $5; a kilo of rice was 2,900 Syrian pounds, or about $5; a kilo of lentils was 2,000 Syrian, or about $5; a liter of frying oil was 3,000 Syrian pounds, or about $6.", "title": "Opinion | Living Under Assad\u2019s Siege", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhen they say they\u2019ve sold the building, but stay as long as you like, get out \u2014 because you want to leave at your convenience, not theirs,\u201d she said. Within days, a friend who knew of Ms. Woodbridge\u2019s love of history called her up and asked, \u201cWould you be interested in becoming a caretaker at the Conference House?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Woodbridge went through several rounds of interviews before she and the association concluded the arrangement would be a good fit. During the last step of the process \u2014 touring the caretaker\u2019s apartment \u2014 \u201cI got three or four feet into the door and said, \u2018I\u2019ll take it,\u2019\u201d she recalled. \u201cThere were beautiful eight-foot ceilings with no popcorn on them, and I could paint the walls as I liked.\u201d\n\nWell, sort of. The colors have to be approved by the board as historically accurate, a requirement that Ms. Woodbridge did not find too onerous. She was, for example, able to select a butter yellow for her kitchen, where on a recent afternoon she was preparing soup with the last of the butternut squash from the 18th-century kitchen garden.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Woodbridge is, it would seem, uncommonly suited to her role as the Conference House caretaker. An artist and professional pattern designer and seamstress, she moved to New York in the early 1980s from Toronto, after meeting her husband in the Revolutionary War re-enactment community.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2004, she lost both her husband and her job at a pattern company, where she had worked as a designer. The next few years were difficult.\n\nName: Deborah Woodbridge Age: 62Rent: $0, in exchange for providing tours three days a week from April through November, assisting with events, gardening, and doing basic maintenance and cleaning of the Conference House interiors, among other tasks. Occupation: Ms. Woodbridge is an artist, working mostly in acrylic, gold leaf and gold pen, and does custom sewing projects. Periodically, she also works as a bed stylist for Hollander Home Fashions, a producer of pillows, comforters and linens.Can anyone become a caretaker for a historic house? No. Resident caretakers must have years of relevant skills and experience, be available at all times for house-related issues and display a passion for the property, as well as submitting to a thorough background check and interview process.The Historic House Trust: A nonprofit organization, it works in tandem with the Parks Department to maintain and preserve 23 historic house sites in the city. There are no open positions for caretakers at the present time. Security: Ms. Woodbridge has had two would-be intruders over the years, though they seemed more interested in breaking than entering, she said, and ran off as soon as the alarm sounded. The alarm system, however, took some getting used to. She set it off accidentally shortly after moving in, with steam from a shower, and was shocked when a barrage of police and fire trucks pulled up. That\u2019s when she discovered that the alarm was hard-wired to the fire department. Her historical re-enactment and sewing skills: come in handy every September when the house hosts the 1776 Peace Conference celebration.The kitchen garden: is a replica of an 18th-century kitchen garden, with peppers, potatoes, beans, peas, lettuce and herbs. Visitors sometimes complain that the tomatoes she grows are anachronistic, but they had been introduced here by the end of the 18th century, she said.Living off the last stop of the Staten Island Railroad: While some might have been hesitant to move so far from Manhattan, Ms. Woodbridge has lived in Staten Island since moving to New York in the early 1980s. First she lived in South Beach, by the Verrazano Bridge, before acclimating to the more suburban environs of Eltingville, followed by the somewhat rural ones of Tottenville.\n\n\u201cWhen my husband passed away; I lost a lot of solvency,\u201d she said. \u201cI was not floundering, but I was not in an ideal place. When I moved in here, I found the house and the greater connection to the seasons that I have here to be very stabilizing.\u201d\n\nHer contract, which is renewed on an annual basis, stipulates that she give tours between early April and early December on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, from 1 to 4 p.m. She also gives them by appointment and occasionally by happenstance, if she has the time and inclination. She dusts and vacuums, repairs broken furniture, maintains the kitchen garden and donates what she once calculated to be in the high hundreds of hours each year beyond her duties.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe has, for example, worked with the board to organize a number of concerts, art shows and literary events at the house. Her sewing skills have also come in handy: In the museum\u2019s upstairs bedrooms, she made new bedcovers, hangings and drapes, researching historically accurate fabrics before taking measurements, making the patterns and sewing them.\n\n\u201cBasically, this house comes first, then everything else,\u201d Ms. Woodbridge said. \u201cIt\u2019s not that they particularly say that, but you\u2019re here and given a big responsibility.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe two-bedroom apartment where Ms. Woodbridge lives was a 1740s addition on the back of the Conference House, originally used as a summer kitchen and servants\u2019 quarters. She has a big kitchen and living room on the first floor and two bedrooms upstairs, under the eaves.\n\nWhile her apartment is not part of the museum, she sometimes offers up her bathroom during events held at the house, since the property\u2019s only public bathroom is in the visitor center, a few hundred yards away.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis may have led to a recent decision to remodel her bathroom. \u201cRight now, there\u2019s a table by Kohler in the living room and a toilet in a box,\u201d she said. Even so, her apartment, a cheerful space with hardwood floors, remains cozy and welcoming, decorated with her paintings and homemade pillows.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDeer are the neighbors she sees the most of, though in winter other houses are visible beyond the park\u2019s bare trees.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. On one of her first nights there, she woke up to bright lights shining in her eyes and a rumbling that made the house tremble: It was an ocean tanker going by on Raritan Bay.\n\nAs for ghosts, every so often a medium comes through, asking if she can feel their presence in house. She replies that she doesn\u2019t need to meet anyone.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t deny their existence,\u201d she tells the mediums. \u201cBut I\u2019m here on my plane, taking care of the house.\u201d", "title": "Living in a 17th-Century Manor on Staten Island", "authors": ["Kim Velsey"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Imagine waking up and realizing that you are now living in a different country.\n\nBut you never moved.\n\nSuch is the case for people living in Tskhinvali, or South Ossetia, a region recognized by the United States and NATO as Georgian territory but a Russian stronghold for the last 30 years. I have grudging affection for its impractical streets and the unhinged ambition written into its architecture. I like the details: the font on the Underground station signs and the hundreds of sea gulls that perch, looking incongruously seaside and skeptical, on the Millennium Bridge each night. I like the self-conscious solemnity of the faces in the National Portrait Gallery and the variegated gray of the Thames. Most of all, and especially now, I cherish its defiantly global heart. But living in any city takes tensed muscles and a carefully calibrated deafness. There are moments when the desire for escape and a wider sky becomes overwhelming, and it\u2019s then that I go night climbing.\n\nI do so because to know a city properly, it helps to touch it and to know the textures and scents of the materials that built it. I have developed strong opinions about brickwork and brick dust and cement and concrete, about the skeleton of London. I have come to love the rich tawny color of the yellow London stock brick, its mellowness stemming from the clay of South East England.", "title": "Opinion | London\u2019s Concrete Ladders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "For the bulk of this production, Mr. Eyre and his company, which includes an impassioned Jeremy Irons in a rare West End appearance, hit every note one could wish for on a spectrum encompassing dissolution and devotion, affection and an abiding frustration that has curdled into something resembling rage. (Intriguingly, Rob Howell\u2019s semitransparent set suggests regions unknown, as if the emotions of this particular hothouse cannot be contained.)\n\nFrom the very start, the actors, talking over and across one another, convey a family so attuned to one another\u2019s rhythms that they can anticipate the next sentence. This approach echoes the one taken more than 30 years ago by the director Jonathan Miller in a production that starred a peculiarly cast Jack Lemmon, and it serves the practical purpose of eating away at what can \u2014 in sleepier, slower hands \u2014 result in a four-hour running time. (This production clocks in at three and a half hours, including intermission.)\n\nThere\u2019s a near-Chekhovian sense of self-inquiry to Mary\u2019s ceaseless monitoring of her state of mind, not to mention her gathering panic at her rheumatic fingers. An Oscar nominee for her tight-lipped turn as Daniel Day-Lewis\u2019s sister in \u201cPhantom Thread,\u201d Ms. Manville has reaffirmed my growing belief that \u201cLong Day\u2019s Journey\u201d is Mary\u2019s play \u2014 and one has a feeling that O\u2019Neill wouldn\u2019t want it any other way. (I suspect that he would also appreciate Mr. Irons as the rare James Tyrone who really fits the onetime dashing theatrical titan described so fully in the text.)\n\nThe sense that Mary rules the roost is in no way meant to diminish the company around her, although Rory Keenan and Matthew Beard, playing the variably infirm and combative Tyrone sons, don\u2019t quite deliver the scathing force of their 11th-hour face-off. That\u2019s the defining scene in which Mr. Keenan\u2019s Jamie finds it within himself to advise Mr. Beard\u2019s consumptive and willowy Edmund to beware a wastrel older brother in gathering thrall to drink. Both actors may find a deeper connection with time: They are new to this production, first seen in April 2016 to commemorate the 250th anniversary of the Bristol Old Vic (Mr. Irons trained at the theater school there).\n\nMr. Beard, a 2015 Tony nominee, has the advantage of looking as if he could be a child of Mr. Irons and Ms. Manville, and he is at his best in Edmund\u2019s revelatory encounters with each parent in turn. As Ms. Manville\u2019s Mary clucks over Edmund like some deeply haunted mother hen, one clocks the affinity between a son on deathwatch and a mother delivering herself into an oblivion that can be said to constitute a living death.", "title": "Loneliness and Loss Made Gloriously Alive in 2 Classic Dramas", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI have been retired for 15 years. Almost every day, I spend several hours taking walks.\n\nMy favorite destination is Central Park. I occasionally walk up to the circle of benches at the south end of Literary Walk. It\u2019s a nice place to take a break and I enjoy the people-watching there.\n\nOn a summer day a few years ago, I was watching some people taking a picture near the statue of Christopher Columbus. Everyone was dressed appropriately, except for an older man who was resting nearby. He was dressed in a long brown robe and floppy hat and he was carrying a wooden staff about six feet long. He looked like he had just stepped out of the 16th century. Most people ignored him; a few smiled in his direction. He disregarded them all.\n\nSuddenly, a small child began to cry. The man stood.\n\n\u201cI must calm the child,\u201d he said in a loud voice.\n\nI watched as he rushed to the child\u2019s side.
