Mr. D\u2019Vorkin was named the company\u2019s chief content officer.\n\nIf Dr. Soon-Shiong succeeds in acquiring The Times, he would become the latest billionaire to take ownership of a struggling newspaper in a big city, following Jeff Bezos (The Washington Post), John Henry (The Boston Globe) and Sheldon Adelson (The Las Vegas Review-Journal).\n\nDr. Soon-Shiong became a major shareholder in Tronc, formerly called Tribune Publishing, in May 2016 as the company and its chairman, Mr. Ferro tried to fend off a takeover attempt by Gannett, the publisher of USA Today. Dr. Soon-Shiong was also named the company\u2019s vice chairman.\n\nMany employees at The Times have of late adopted the mantra \u201canyone but Ferro,\u201d but it is also not clear what decisions Dr. Soon-Shiong, who largely made his fortune selling generic drugs and developing a new type of cancer drug, will make as the paper\u2019s owner.\n\nIn an interview with The New York Times at the time of his initial investment, Dr. Soon-Shiong, who grew up in apartheid South Africa, said he considered newspapers a \u201cpublic trust\u201d and wanted to preserve them. \u201cI recognize the press is a very valuable tool for the community, where it really adds to democracy,\u201d he said.\n\nBut Dr. Soon-Shiong\u2019s relationship with Mr. Ferro quickly deteriorated, leading to Dr. Soon-Shiong\u2019s removal from its board last year.", "title": "Los Angeles Times Said to Be Nearing Sale to Billionaire Doctor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nA few years ago, I came to New York from a small town in New Hampshire. Within days, I was drowning in anxiety and loneliness. Everything felt impossibly big, and I, impossibly small.\n\nAfter months of growing despair, I stumbled across the Strand. I have always found sanctuary in books, and discovering the store put me over the moon.\n\nWith nobody to share my excitement with, I ended up emailing my high school English teacher, a native of Harlem. In retrospect, I don\u2019t know what I was looking for in the exchange: comfort? affirmation? familiarity?\n\nWhatever it was, he seemed to know, even if I didn\u2019t. In his reply, he wrote: \u201cThe city is full of wonder, mystery, surprise, inspiration, a good amount of crazy and some loneliness. (The loneliness is where you find your soul.)\u201d", "title": "Lost and Found", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "She was an engaged member of her New Hampshire community: the sort of local who purchased a lotto ticket at a quaint, modest market that some say makes the \u201cbest subs in town.\u201d\n\nThat Powerball ticket, though, turned out to be worth $560 million \u2014 the seventh largest jackpot in this country\u2019s lottery history. And, according to a lawsuit filed late last month, now all the winner wants is her anonymity \u2014 the simple \u201cfreedom to walk into a grocery store or attend public events without being known or targeted,\u201d the lawsuit says.\n\nSo the winner of the Jan. 6 drawing, referred to in the lawsuit as Jane Doe, is going to court, arguing that New Hampshire lottery officials would be irreparably invading her privacy if they disclose her identity as a result of the state\u2019s \u201cRight to Know\u201d law.\n\n\u201cAs a lottery jackpot winner, Ms. Doe is now part of a small demographic which has historically been victimized by the unscrupulous with life threatening consequences,\u201d the lawsuit says.", "title": "Lottery Winner Knows Just What to Do With $560 Million: Fight to Stay Anonymous", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWould you want to win the lottery? Why or why not?\n\nIf you won, what would you do with the money? Why would you choose to spend it this way?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out how one woman handled her $560 million winnings.", "title": "Lottery Winnings", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Louis Zorich, a busy actor who appeared on Broadway with stars like Laurence Olivier and Dustin Hoffman, on television in the comedy \u201cMad About You\u201d and in numerous projects with his wife, the Oscar-winning actress Olympia Dukakis, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.\n\nHis son Peter confirmed his death.\n\nIn a career of some 60 years, Mr. Zorich played scores of roles, mostly of the character-actor variety. He was the father to Paul Reiser\u2019s character on NBC\u2019s \u201cMad About You\u201d from 1993 to 1999 and the grandfather on \u201cBrooklyn Bridge,\u201d a well-regarded CBS series that ran for two seasons earlier in the 1990s.\n\nBut he also occasionally tackled the big roles. The year before \u201cBrooklyn Bridge\u201d made its debut in 1991, he played King Lear in a production at the Whole Theater in Montclair, N.J., of which he and Ms. Dukakis were founding members. In 2004 he portrayed the title character in an Off Broadway version of Aeschylus\u2019 \u201cAgamemnon\u201d by the Aquila Theater Company, opposite Ms. Dukakis\u2019s Clytemnestra.\n\nMr. Zorich continued to work into his 90s, so there is some irony in the fact that his final film appearance was in \u201cNo Pay, Nudity\u201d (2016), a bittersweet comic drama by Lee Wilkof about the troubles older actors have finding work.", "title": "Louis Zorich, Familiar Actor on TV and Stage, Dies at 93", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "This year, under an interim head coach, the Cardinals are 18-9 over all and 8-6 in the A.C.C. They are considered a better-than-average contender to qualify for the N.C.A.A. tournament even as they face new accusations of improper recruiting.\n\nSeveral months ago, Louisville was one of six programs \u2014 and perhaps the most prominently figured \u2014 implicated in a broad bribery and corruption scheme outlined by federal investigators. In one complaint, investigators described a partnership involving Louisville basketball coaches and several other parties, including a former executive at Adidas, the apparel company that sponsors Louisville\u2019s teams, in which they planned to funnel $100,000 to the family of a recruit in exchange for his commitment to the Cardinals.\n\nThat scandal led to the ouster of Pitino and Louisville\u2019s athletic director, Tom Jurich, by the university\u2019s board. Pitino has sued Louisville for breach of contract, and Louisville has countersued. Those cases are pending.\n\nAn attorney representing Pitino did not immediately reply to a request for comment Tuesday.\n\nIt is unknown what the broader implications of the latest recruiting scandal will be on Louisville or any other program, or on college basketball itself. The N.C.A.A. has convened a commission to examine reforms to the sport in light of the scandal, which also implicated several other top programs.\n\nTuesday\u2019s ruling will sting at Louisville, which must surrender its 2013 national title less than six months after a conference rival, North Carolina, was able to avoid sanctions when the N.C.A.A. ruled that it had broken no rules in a major academic scandal involving dubious classes disproportionally taken by major-sport athletes. An adverse finding there could have stripped the Tar Heels of at least one national championship, and possibly more.\n\nThe title Louisville was ordered to surrender, won with an 82-76 victory over Michigan, will remain vacant, even though Postel, in his statement, urged Louisville fans to retain their claim to it.\n\n\u201cThe N.C.A.A.\u2019s ruling,\u201d he wrote, \u201ccannot change the accomplishments or the excitement generated by our Cardinals basketball team.\u201d", "title": "Louisville Must Forfeit Basketball Championship Over Sex Scandal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Sometimes the most clich\u00e9 thing about a romance novel is its cover and title. Take Julia London\u2019s latest: A ripped Lucifer in a kilt smolders darkly from the cover, and DEVIL IN TARTAN (Harlequin) renders the image in blunt syllables. But this is the fine yarn-spinner London here, and what follows is a rollicking seafaring adventure that feels fresh. Talk about meet cute: A perfectly paced farcical sequence puts the sea captain Aulay Mackenzie (he of the kilt) on a literal collision course with a hapless bunch of bootleggers led by Lottie Livingstone, who steps up to lead her clan after her father is gravely wounded. Lottie\u2019s ship is sinking, but rather than let the hero sail to her rescue, this heroine engineers her own. The audacity of her plan propels the plot, but despite the outwardly comical circumstances, the developing relationship is serious from the start. Lottie\u2019s sense of loyalty, justice and responsibility are equal to Aulay\u2019s \u2014 and he honors that equality in his acceptance of the fate that may await her for her crime. That makes the prospect of a happy ending as hard to see as a ghost ship through the Highland mists. Romantic bonus: Aulay\u2019s hobby on the high seas is painting melancholy seascapes with no people in them. His 18th-century version of Jerry Maguire\u2019s \u201cYou complete me\u201d to Lottie: \u201cYou filled my canvas.\u201d Don\u2019t be afraid to dampen the lacy hankie for this one.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf you can get past Jenny Holiday\u2019s fetishizing of her hunky hero\u2019s tattoos (I managed, barely), her ONE AND ONLY (Forever) is a satisfying iteration of the contemporary bridezilla subgenre, the first novel in a \u201cBridesmaids Behaving Badly\u201d series set in Toronto. Jane Denning writes young-adult novels, is a Comicon geek and, five years after a bad breakup, considers herself permanently single. On bridesmaid duty, Jane volunteers to keep a close eye on the groom\u2019s bad-boy brother, who has just been discharged from the Army, not honorably, and has shown up to cause trouble, or so the bridal party assumes. Wounded warriors are popular romance heroes, and Cameron MacKinnon makes a credible one. His feminist bona fides can seem piled on for a hypermasculine hero. As Jane obsesses about her weight, Cameron muses about the faults of \u201cthe patriarchy.\u201d But Holiday manages to keep things super-steamy even when Cameron, who has just told Jane that he doesn\u2019t do \u201cdrunk hookups,\u201d continues, \u201cBecause there\u2019s this little thing called consent?\u201d Romance fiction didn\u2019t go carnal until the 1970s, and consent was just a gleam in a good girl\u2019s eye. These days, even if the real world is slow to progress, consent is practically a fixture in the genre.\n\nIn Krentz\u2019s excellent new novel of romantic suspense, PROMISE NOT TO TELL (Berkley), Virginia Troy, a Seattle art gallery owner troubled by the suspicious suicide of a painter she represents, enlists the aid of Cabot Sutter, a private investigator, to look into their shared past as children who grew up in a cult. The psychopathic cult leader who tried to incinerate them at his compound succeeded in killing their parents, and now Virginia and Cabot are teaming up to see if he still lives, but also revisiting the scarring trauma that has stunted both their lives for decades. Yes, even two individuals as damaged as these can win, together. It is possible to be so absorbed by the quickening plot here that you overlook the unfolding of the relationship, which is subtler, gentler than it is in many romances. Most people put up walls of some sort, but Virginia and Cabot share a wall, so they need only each chip away half to reach the other. Consent, once again, is explicit. Virginia\u2019s panic attacks have resulted in several abortive attempts to have sex, but Cabot is the hero you want in this situation: \u201cWe can go this far and stop as often as you want,\u201d he says, a line all too often consigned to fiction.\n\nIf a romance novel must have a happy ending, a corollary is that half of any new batch of romances must feature a duke. Hardly a trope goes unturned in A DUKE IN SHINING ARMOR (Avon) by Loretta Chase. There\u2019s the confirmed rake, the bluestocking spinster, the runaway bride, the runaway dog. But Chase\u2019s dependable wit leads a reader willingly on a merry romp as Lady Olympia Hightower, not a little drunk, escapes her nuptials to one duke only to be pursued by his best friend, also a duke. When the wouldn\u2019t-be bride tumbles out the window, so does the Duke of Ripley\u2019s honor; he\u2019d meant only to retrieve the lady for his friend, not fall for her himself. The tale is on the anodyne side (read the classic \u201cLord of Scoundrels\u201d for the author at her most hilariously inventive); still, Chase\u2019s consistent gift is to gently puncture all the genre\u2019s conventions but one: the one that makes you care about her Regency hero and heroine and their happy ever after.\n\nBut enough of dukes; the prince takes the prize. Alyssa Cole\u2019s A PRINCESS IN THEORY (Avon) is the best new romance I\u2019ve read in a while. In Cole\u2019s contemporary story, Naledi Smith is an overworked epidemiologist studying for her doctorate in New York. She\u2019s an orphan with too much debt, too little sleep and no love in her life. To add to her discontents, some scammer has been emailing her to say that she has been betrothed from childhood to an African prince and that it is past time she fulfill her destiny. She declines to take the bait, but the prince comes calling anyway, just not as a royal. Prince Thabiso of Thesolo, a small African kingdom, masquerades as Jamal, Naledi\u2019s underemployed temporary neighbor who invites her to share the dinner he\u2019s ordered from a meal-kit service. Their relationship blossoms sweetly and sexily. Apart from his big deception, the prince is a near perfect hero to Naledi\u2019s science nerd. This novel checks a lot of boxes \u2014 STEM girls, gaslighting, science deniers, explicit consent in the bedroom, mineral exploitation in Africa \u2014 but it\u2019s more organic than obtrusive. Delightful details abound, especially when the scene shifts from New York to Africa (Segways to scoot around the royal palace, anyone?). There\u2019s even a nod to real-life royals. A redheaded playboy pal of Thabiso\u2019s is suspiciously reminiscent of Prince Harry \u2014 \u201cPrince Johan\u201d was once caught on tape playing strip poker. Until Harry, step-great-grandson of the romance writer Barbara Cartland, weds Meghan Markle in May, \u201cA Princess in Theory\u201d will do very well as the royal fairy tale of the young year.", "title": "Love Notes", "authors": ["Mary Jo Murphy"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Steinberg, 37, met Mr. Klein, 52, in March 2007, when she was a law student at Tulane University in New Orleans. Had she been less inclined to breach the boundaries of the New York neighborhood where she grew up with two sisters and her parents, Richard, a lawyer, and Nancy, a real estate agent, their paths may not have crossed.\n\n\u201cIt was spring break and I came home to visit,\u201d Ms. Steinberg said. \u201cMy sister and I went to a party, and then we went to Niagara,\u201d a downtown club. Downtown night life wasn\u2019t foreign to Ms. Steinberg even though she had an uptown pedigree: In high school, her best friend Melissa Broudo recalled, \u201cwe were nice Jewish girls but we thought we were punk rockers. We would go hang out in the East Village every weekend, and we worshiped Sid Vicious.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Klein, who was easing out of his music career after playing big festivals like the Warped Tour with Libertine, was D.J.ing at Niagara. Ms. Steinberg started talking to him. By the end of the night, he had her phone number and they were making plans to meet the next day. The differences in their backgrounds \u2014 he dropped out of high school when he was 14 to join a band, she studied classics and anthropology at Williams College before earning a master\u2019s degree in Latin American Studies at Tulane and enrolling in law school there \u2014 barely registered.\n\n\u201cI pretty much spent the rest of that spring break, which was my last year in law school, with him,\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t know if I thought it would lead to anything serious, but we connected.\u201d When she was back at law school, a long-distance relationship took shape. \u201cWe were on the phone a lot. I was thinking, There\u2019s definitely something there.\u201d She based her decision to move back to New York after earning her law degree on that seductive something.\n\nMr. Klein, lanky and heavily tattooed, was just as eager to resume his face-to-face relationship with Ms. Steinberg despite what he called the \u201cLady and the Tramp\u201d scenario. Though he had few stable relationships in his life \u2014 he and his mother, Wendy Klein, were only sporadically in touch with Ms. Harry when he was in his 30s despite her occasional pop-ins at his punk shows, and he was estranged from his father, a onetime New York cabdriver, after his parents divorced in the 1980s \u2014 he felt the potential for something lasting with Ms. Steinberg.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cNo one is going to believe these words came out of my mouth, but I feel like it was pretty electric right off the bat,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt first, navigating the social gulf between their families wasn\u2019t an issue. Ms. Steinberg\u2019s parents had moved to Scarsdale, N.Y., a few years earlier, and Mr. Klein\u2019s mother had moved to Lake Owassa, in northwestern New Jersey. Mr. Klein\u2019s schedule was an excuse to avoid Scarsdale. \u201cHe was always out at night D.J.ing or playing music, so there was no real opportunity for him to meet my parents,\u201d Ms. Steinberg said. But by the time they planned a trip to Belize a few months into their relationship, a Steinberg family tradition disrupted the cocoon they were building around themselves.\n\n\u201cWhen somebody in my family is going to leave the country, we always have dinner first,\u201d said Ms. Steinberg, now a lawyer practicing litigation defense at Kennedys CMK in New York. Mr. Klein covered his tattoos with a long-sleeved shirt and headed to what Ms. Broudo called the Steinberg\u2019s \u201cschmancy suburb\u201d in Westchester County.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWhen I got there, I was like, This has to be phony. It was this stereotypical perfect American house with a beautiful family. I was like, Why is no one screaming at each other and breaking things?\u201d Mr. Klein said. \u201cMy perception of family was chaos.\u201d\n\nThe Steinbergs, to Mr. Klein\u2019s surprise but not Ms. Steinberg\u2019s, expressed few reservations about the relationship. \u201cMy parents are pretty open,\u201d she said.\n\nHe said he felt uncomfortable for a long time. \u201cI probably spent the first three years I knew them wearing long-sleeve shirts,\u201d Mr. Klein said. \u201cBut at the end of the day they saw that their daughter was in love. And they accepted it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 2009, Ms. Steinberg and Mr. Klein moved into the one-bedroom apartment they still share in Greenpoint. In 2011, Ms. Broudo\u2019s husband, Aaron Broudo, a lawyer, approached Mr. Klein about starting a music club. Their first venture was an outdoor night bazaar in Brooklyn. That evolved into BK Bazaar, which has been featured on the opening credits to \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d and functions as kind of a community center, combining music, food, bars, art, karaoke and mini-golf.\n\nAs Mr. Klein\u2019s business acumen developed, his desire to marry Ms. Steinberg grew too. \u201cI knew around six years ago I wanted to marry her, but I\u2019d been completely consumed by work,\u201d he said. His mother\u2019s death after a long illness in 2014 also required some reckoning. Despite his messy childhood, they had been close.\n\nAfter a search, Ms. Harry resurfaced to help him grieve. \u201cI had lost her phone number like 12 cellphones ago,\u201d he said. But he knew she would want to know Ms. Klein had died. \u201cDebbie and my mom grew up together and were always the bad girls together at their high school\u201d in New Jersey. \u201cShe was my first babysitter.\u201d For Ms. Harry, he said, the news hit hard. \u201cShe was like, \u2018I wish I could have done something.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Love Rocks \u2014 And So Does a Walk Down the Aisle With Debbie Harry", "authors": ["Tammy La Gorce"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "25A/32D: I liked this fraternal twin clue. \u201cFurniture mover\u201d is the CASTER you place under a heavy piece of furniture so it doesn\u2019t scratch the floor, and \u201cFurniture mover, maybe\u201d is a VAN because VANs can be used for other things.\n\n28A: I love the fact that there are quotation marks around the word \u201cchoice\u201d in this clue, because HOBSON\u2019s choice was really no choice at all. What Thomas HOBSON offered was the \u201cchoice\u201d between what he offered and nothing at all. Here, from the Merriam-Webster dictionary, is the origin of this interesting phrase:\n\n\u201cIn the late 16th and early 17th centuries, Thomas Hobson worked as a licensed carrier of passengers, letters, and parcels between Cambridge and London, England. He kept horses for this purpose and rented them to university students when he wasn\u2019t using them. Of course, the students always wanted their favorite mounts, and consequently a few of Hobson\u2019s horses became overworked. To correct the situation, Hobson began a strict rotation system, giving each customer the choice of taking the horse nearest the stable door or none at all. This rule became known as Hobson\u2019s choice, and soon people were using that term to mean \u201cno choice at all\u201d in all kinds of situations.\u201d\n\n37A: TIL that the legend William Tell was not only Swiss, but that he also lived in a place called URI.\n\n58A: For all I know, there could be a Sherwin-Williams paint color called \u201cDINGE,\u201d but I honestly hope there isn\u2019t.\n\n35D: I had to think about this one after I got it, and when I did, I couldn\u2019t decide whether it was brilliant or grisly or both. Perhaps it\u2019s fowl. The \u201cGame\u2019s turning point?\u201d in today\u2019s puzzle is a ROTISSERIE, because we are supposed to be thinking of an animal on a spit.\n\n38D: \u201cOne getting smashed at a party?\u201d is not your weird uncle (at least not today), it\u2019s a PI\u00d1ATA.\n\n43D: Clever. \u201cSelf-denial?\u201d is not denying yourself something, it\u2019s merely the act of denying, as in NOT I.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nThis puzzle was originally submitted in December 2016 as a 17x17 diagramless crossword. Will surprised me, writing: \u201cOddly enough, I think this would work better for the regular paper than as a diagramless. As a diagramless the grid is too chunky \u2014 too difficult, I think. As a 69-word regular crossword, this could work as a daily. \u201cHowever, to run as a daily, the puzzle would have to meet themeless standards, and this grid has a lot of unappealing vocabulary \u2026 \u201cThis doesn\u2019t look like an easy grid to fill. But if somehow you can improve the vocabulary, I\u2019d be happy to take another look.\u201d After many go-rounds on a very slow, old laptop, I managed to come up with a more cleanly filled grid that Will was pleased with, except for the upper right corner. A big thank you to Frank Longo, who smoothed out the top of the grid, and to Will for his patience. I hope you enjoyed the puzzle. From my heart to yours.\n\nAnd back again, Ms. Guizzo.\n\nHappy Valentine\u2019s Day to all of you. I\u2019m so glad you\u2019re here.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Love at First Sight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Lovebug Starski, a versatile D.J. and rapper who was a key figure in the development and early evolution of hip-hop in the South Bronx throughout the 1970s, died on Thursday in Las Vegas. He was 57.\n\nHis manager, Jeremy Crittenden, confirmed the death but did not specify the cause.\n\nLovebug Starski was born Kevin Smith in the Bronx on May 16, 1960. In his teenage years, he was a member of the Black Spades gang, one of the borough\u2019s most notorious. \u201cEveryone used to carry machetes,\u201d he told Rolling Stone in 1993.\n\nBut he had musical aspirations and aptitude.\n\nDecades before hip-hop was the dominant influence on American popular culture, it was the work of Bronx teenagers gathering in parks, recreation centers and clubs and improvising a new approach to music by jury-rigging old records and technology.\n\nPhoto\n\nLovebug Starski was a mainstay of this scene in the 1970s. He started out carrying records and equipment for the disco and funk D.J. Pete (DJ) Jones \u2014 one of the first to mix two copies of the same record \u2014 at the Starland Ballroom in the Bronx before becoming a D.J. in his own right, spinning at numerous Bronx clubs.\n\nHe was a rapper as well, one of the first to rhyme and spin records at the same time. When rapping was little more than accompanying patter to enhance a D.J. set, he was a charismatic source of party-moving phraseology, and he would also handle the microphone for other D.J.s, including a young Grandmaster Flash.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 1978, just as hip-hop was making the transition from live parties to records, Lovebug Starski (sometimes known as just Starski, or Love Bug Starski, or Luv Bug Starski, or Luvbug Starski) was the house D.J. at the crucial South Bronx club Disco Fever.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe was also a regular at the New York venues the Audubon Ballroom, Harlem World and the Renaissance. He was famously mentioned as part of the roll call of influential early hip-hop D.J.s on the Notorious B.I.G.\u2019s seminal 1994 single \u201cJuicy.\u201d\n\nWhile D.J.-ing was the coin of the realm in the 1970s, after \u201cRapper\u2019s Delight\u201d was released its importance took a back seat to rapping, and Lovebug Starski released some music of his own in the early and mid-1980s as an M.C.\n\nHis recorded output amounts to just a few 12-inch singles \u2014 \u201cYou\u2019ve Gotta Believe\u201d / \u201cStarski Live at the Disco Fever\u201d is the most essential \u2014 and one album. He also contributed the title track to the soundtrack of \u201cRappin\u2019,\u201d the third film in the \u201cBreakin\u2019 \u201d franchise. (\u201cYou\u2019ve Gotta Believe\u201d was sampled by the rock group Smiths and by Marky Mark and the Funky Bunch.)\n\nPhoto\n\nDrugs were a significant part of the night-life scene in the late 1970s and early \u201980s, and as he was experiencing success and, later, as the genre was changing, moving away from the casual party rap of the early \u201880s, Lovebug Starski struggled with a cocaine habit.\n\n\u201cI was gettin\u2019 paid. Coked out of my mind,\u201d he told Rolling Stone. He was arrested twice for burglary and once for petty larceny in 1987 (he described the charges as drug-related) and was incarcerated for a few years, until 1991.\n\nAfter his release he returned to D.J.-ing, along with producing. In the 1990s he was the D.J. at Russell Simmons\u2019s wedding to Kimora Lee and at various events for the clothing company Phat Farm, and the M.C. at a birthday party for Wendy Williams, who was then a radio personality.\n\nHe moved to Las Vegas a year ago in hopes of securing regular work and had begun gaining traction there as a D.J.\n\nHe is survived by his mother, Martha Bowes; two sisters, Kim Shaw and Karen Rivers; two daughters, Tiffany Williams and Bryanna Smith; and two granddaughters.", "title": "Lovebug Starski, Hip-Hop Trailblazer, Is Dead at 57", "authors": ["Jon Caramanica"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "One idea addresses an issue that many consider fundamentally unjust: Consumers are increasingly being asked to pay a greater portion of their drug costs, but they don\u2019t get discounts that drug manufacturers offer to health insurers.\n\nThe proposal, first floated by federal officials last November, would give at least a portion of that discount to people in Medicare drug plans at the pharmacy counter. The move could lower out-of-pocket costs for people with high drug bills, but would increase the cost of these Medicare plans, offered by private insurers, for everyone. The idea seems to have the support of the Trump administration, including the new health secretary, Alex M. Azar II, a former Eli Lilly executive.\n\nThe proposal, which does not need congressional approval, represents the latest clash between powerful health care industries that are engaged in a war for the moral high ground over rising drug prices. The pharmaceutical industry, backed by influential members of the Trump administration, has been lobbying hard for the change, betting that it would act as an escape valve for patients\u2019 anger over drug costs while preserving drug makers\u2019 freedom to set any price they want.\n\nPhoto\n\nBy contrast, the insurance companies and pharmacy benefit managers, which oversee drug plans, are loathe to part with what amounts to billions of dollars in rebate windfalls, arguing that it will lead to higher prices.\n\nThe change could present a tidy solution for Mr. Trump, who has come under fire for doing little to follow through on his pledge to lower drug prices, even as he has installed several former drug industry executives in prominent government roles. But it would cost the government money \u2014 up to $82.1 billion over the next decade, according to its own estimates.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring his address to Congress last month, Mr. Trump reiterated that lowering drug prices was \u201cone of my greatest priorities,\u201d and promised: \u201cPrices will come down.\u201d\n\nIn a press briefing, Mr. Azar signaled his support of passing on rebates to customers. As a government lawyer during the George W. Bush administration, Mr. Azar oversaw the launch of the Medicare drug program.\n\nInsurers\u2019 rising use of manufacturer rebates has been a longstanding concern of federal officials, including those in the Obama administration who issued a report on the matter one day before Mr. Trump took office.\n\nAny decision by the federal government is likely to reverberate through the country\u2019s health care system, given that many people with employer-provided health insurance are exposed to the same inflated prices. Already, some private insurers are beginning to offer such rebates to customers.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a very basic question here about the role of insurance and health care,\u201d said Peter B. Bach, director of the Center for Health Policy and Outcomes at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, who supports the change. \u201cWe are still uncertain in the United States how much the sick should carry their own weight economically, versus the many should chip in financially to protect those who are sick. That\u2019s what this debate is about.\u201d\n\nPatients like Antoinette Lopez are the ones caught in the crossfire.\n\nMs. Lopez, 70, takes Enbrel for rheumatoid arthritis, and she\u2019s watched in frustration as her out-of-pocket costs have risen along with the drug\u2019s list price. In 2015, she paid $4,547 for 10 months of Enbrel. This year, she expects to pay $5,941 for the same period.\n\nBut the insurer that oversees her drug plan, Humana, is pocketing hundreds of dollars every time she fills her prescription from Amgen, which makes Enbrel. Ms. Lopez will never see that money \u2014 the rebates are instead applied across the board to keep premiums low for all of the people enrolled in Humana\u2019s Medicare plan.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s gouging,\u201d said Ms. Lopez, a retired nurse administrator from Athens, Georgia who blames insurers and drug makers. \u201cIt\u2019s despicable.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHumana did not respond to requests for comment, and Amgen said it was \u201cpleased\u201d with the federal proposal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf Medicare adopts the plan, federal officials estimate that consumers would save, on average, between $45 and $132 a month. But everyone would pay higher premiums, which Medicare estimates would increase anywhere from $14 to $44 a month.\n\nMark Merritt, chief executive of the Pharmaceutical Care Management Association, the trade group for pharmacy benefit managers, dislikes the proposal and believes the Medicare coverage is a \u201csound program.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t want to destabilize the program or inadvertently make things worse,\u201d he said.\n\nBut even as Medicare\u2019s drug coverage gets high marks, those who rely on expensive medications are exposed to spiraling drug prices.\n\nHigher prices have led insurers to push more of the cost onto consumers, by imposing high deductibles or requiring that people pay a percentage of a sale price at the pharmacy, not what the insurer pays for the drug after discounts. The administration is expected on Monday to propose placing a cap on out-of-pocket spending in Medicare drug plans, because without one some people pay tens of thousands of dollars a year.\n\nThere is a yawning gap between the list price of a drug, which is close to what the consumer typically pays, and the net price, which insurers pay, that is getting larger.\n\nThis has led to a huge increase in the amount of the rebates collected by insurers and pharmacy benefit managers.\n\nWhile insurers contend that most of the rebate money is used to lower premiums, the middlemen also pocket a percentage of those rebates, increasing their profits grow as the list price rises.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve built this incredibly complex, hard-to-understand machine,\u201d said Adam J. Fein, president of Pembroke Consulting, a research firm. \u201cEveryone in the system benefits from this pricing strategy, but it\u2019s not necessarily sensible or sending the right price signals to the consumer.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe pharmaceutical industry says the growing share of rebates is evidence they are working to keep drug costs low. \u201cWe are lowering the prices through greater and greater rebates and discounts, and they\u2019re not giving those to patients,\u201d said Robert Zirkelbach, a spokesman for the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, an industry group.\n\nMark Hamelburg, the senior vice president of federal programs for America\u2019s Health Insurance Plans, the trade group, said the new proposal is little more than a smoke screen by the pharmaceutical industry. \u201cIt\u2019s all part of that general effort to change the focus away from the true problem,\u201d he said.\n\nMany who oppose the idea point out that it won\u2019t help everyone because not every drug comes with a large rebate. Many new cancer treatments, as well as products that treat rare diseases, are not discounted at all.\n\nMany of those offering Part D plans say they do not want to raise premiums for everyone to lower the costs for a few. \u201cMandating rebates be applied at the point of sale would increase costs for the vast majority of seniors in Part D, taxpayers and the government, while benefiting drug manufacturers,\u201d said Carolyn Castel, a spokeswoman for CVS Health, one of the largest pharmacy managers, in an email.\n\nSome large employers have already begun experimenting with offering employees rebates at the pharmacy counter. Despite its opposition to the Medicare proposal, CVS is offering such rebates to commercial clients, like large employers, and has offered the rebates to its employees since 2013.\n\nMs. Lopez, meanwhile, said she would appreciate some help. Amgen raised the list price of Enbrel by 9.7 percent in January. \u201cI think anything that would make the total costs of high drug costs go down, even if the premiums went up a little bit, would offset it,\u201d she said.\n\nBut the solution seems like \u201csome sort of Band-Aid, or temporary, feel-good fix,\u201d she said.", "title": "Lower Drug Prices: New Proposals Carry Lots of Promises", "authors": ["Katie Thomas", "Reed Abelson"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "The ultimate success of the Saudi Aramco public offering and the entirety of the kingdom\u2019s economic reform remain in question, and progress so far has been mixed. Nevertheless, American, Chinese and even Russian financiers are entwined in a complex dance around the initial public offering, which is promised for later this year.\n\nPresident Trump has publicly called for the I.P.O. to be listed in New York. A Saudi listing now appears more likely, with additional trading in London or Hong Kong. Global financiers say they want a piece of the action wherever it occurs.\n\nThe interest in the I.P.O. has given the kingdom greater leverage at a time when the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, through which it has long wielded power, has lost much of its clout.\n\n\u201cThe Saudis are compensating for their lost power in OPEC and they are showing pure geopolitical pragmatism in their new energy and foreign policy,\u201d said Bill Richardson, a former energy secretary and ambassador to the United Nations. \u201cBut they are not just compensating for lost power. They are adding to their power in world politics.\u201d\n\nSaudi Arabia has had a central role in global energy since at least World War II. When the kingdom created a global glut of oil to gain market share in the mid-1980s, it sent prices into a tailspin that contributed to the bankruptcy of the Soviet Union at the same time that it was financing Afghan rebels fighting the Soviets.\n\nThe kingdom was such a crucial supplier of oil to the United States that Washington went to war in the early 1990s in part to protect it from a possible Iraqi invasion. And when China needed new energy supplies for its expanding economy in the early years of the new century, Saudi Arabia was there with an ambitious oil exploration program to meet the new demand.", "title": "Lower Oil Prices Force Saudis to Widen Their Circle of Friends", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump celebrated the milestone on Twitter and in his State of the Union address. The unemployment rate for black Americans had hit its lowest point on record, a sign that the recovery was at last reaching groups that had been left behind.\n\nBut the achievement was bittersweet: Black joblessness was still roughly twice the rate for whites.\n\nEven at the low of 6.8 percent recorded in December \u2014 it climbed back to 7.7 percent in January \u2014 the unemployment level for black Americans would qualify as a near crisis for whites. And the relative gains have not erased disparities in opportunity and pay.\n\nA tight labor market alone can\u2019t undo a legacy of unequal school funding, residential segregation or the disproportionate rate of incarceration for black Americans. Nor can it reverse the gradual shift of well-paying jobs from inner cities to mostly white suburbs. Studies have found that discrimination in hiring and pay persists even in good economic times, making parity an elusive goal.", "title": "Lowest Ever Black Jobless Rate Is Still Twice That of Whites", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cLet us support working families by supporting paid family leave,\u201d he said.\n\nLarge majorities of Americans favor paid parental leave, but only about one-fifth think state or federal government should pay for it, according to two recent Pew Research Center surveys. More than half said employers should provide it. Respondents were split on whether the government should require it.\n\nThe biggest employers have an easier time paying for leave and replacing employees when they are out. Small business owners say it\u2019s much more challenging for them. Although 94 percent of respondents in the Pew survey said paid leave would be good for families, 57 percent said it would be bad for small businesses.\n\nDespite the policies at the biggest employers, only 13 percent of private industry workers have access to paid family leave, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.\n\nPaid leave increases the chances that women keep working after having children, research has shown. It\u2019s time to tell my truth.\u201d\n\nMs. Williams first became known to a national audience with her self-titled album in 1988. She was 35. Since then, she has amassed three Grammys, including one in 1998, for best contemporary folk album \u2014 \u201cCar Wheels on a Gravel Road\u201d \u2014 considered to be among her best work. She has been nominated for 15 Grammys in total. In 2001, Time magazine named her America\u2019s Best Songwriter.\n\nThe book will detail Ms. Williams\u2019s upbringing \u2014 including her childhood, which was spread out across the South. She was born in Lake Charles, La., and spent some of her younger days busking in New Orleans. Complicit in the herd? In vile shame? Do the cries of our brothers not stir you?\u201d\n\nMr. Botstein asked, \u201cWhat are we going to do when in fact people start disappearing from our midst, legally?\u201d\n\nHe said he hoped that this would be the question in the minds of those hearing \u201cIntolleranza 1960.\u201d Mr. Botstein seemed far less worried about whether the mainstream classical audience was still as hostile as it once was to Nono\u2019s dissonances.\n\n\u201cModernism has left more of a residue than we remember,\u201d he said, \u201cwhether you hear it in Bernard Herrmann scores, or in the sound world that accompanies the visual media we have now. To the contrary, the company specializes in a sort of controlled flamboyance. Its most outr\u00e9 pieces are the ones designed with the most detail and care, lest you mistake lightness for slightness.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe new store \u2014 the Maison, as everyone inside referred to it \u2014 takes up a shocking half-block of Madison, a five-floor behemoth in a building that\u2019s the combination of three 19th-century townhouses.\n\nI came for the intrecciato, same as you\u2019d go to the Jets game for the existential misery or to Peter Luger for the steak for two. It is the company\u2019s quintessence, a crosshatched leather weave that runs through the shoes, the shirts, the wallets and almost everything else. Because the motif is so signature, the things around it don\u2019t have to speak as loudly.\n\nMy first nice wallet, many years ago, was a stone-colored intrecciato, and I\u2019d been interested in a simple card holder in color-blocked pink and purple ($250). Today, it is the last, having survived in part because Ms. Ratcliff had diversified early as others were squeezed out by the unforgiving economics of small farming, which she also faced.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been a struggle from Day 1 to make ends meet, to find enough money to keep the barn from falling down at the same time as you\u2019re buying feed for the animals,\u201d she said in an interview in 2009 with Jenny Attiyeh, a journalist who had grown up visiting Ms. Ratcliff in the summers.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t do it for a profit,\u201d she said.\n\nOver the years, Ms. Ratcliff made conservative investments, cut back her herd size, sold off parcels of her original 225 acres and kept working. Even as her health declined, she continued to ride atop her tractor, toting her oxygen tank.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t spend your life making a creation \u2014 be it a painting or a farm or a family \u2014 for it to disappear when you die,\u201d she told Ms. Attiyeh. Having no heirs, she left the farm, now 84 acres with about 50 animals, to her manager, Dwayne Nichols.\n\nLydia Lawrence Ratcliff was born on Oct. 12, 1933, in a Manhattan hospital to the former Marie Francoise Tonetti and John Drury Ratcliff and grew up in the exclusive enclave of Snedens Landing in Palisades, N.Y., on the west bank of the Hudson River. Her father, a journalist and author, contributed to several magazines, most prominently Reader\u2019s Digest and Time, where he covered science and medical news.\n\nLydia was the oldest of five children, one of whom died in infancy; another sibling, William, who was known as Tony, died in 2016. Besides her brother John, she is survived by a sister, Alexandra Richardson.\n\nMs. Ratcliff attended the Putney School in Vermont and Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania; when her family moved to Italy, she spent her junior year in Paris at the Sorbonne. Qualche settimana fa, un estremista di destra ha sparato a sei migranti africani nella citt\u00e0 di Macerata. Alcuni politici di destra lamentano \u201cl\u2019invasione\u201d e uno in particolare ha sostenuto che i migranti minacciano la \u201crazza bianca\u201d.\n\nA livello nazionale il tema dell\u2019immigrazione \u00e8 molto divisivo. Pochi giorni prima di Natale, il governo non \u00e8 riuscito a ottenere il sostegno necessario in Parlamento per approvare una legge disegnata per naturalizzare 800.000 bambini. Sono i figli e le figlie di immigrati nati in Italia o che sono arrivati molto piccoli e con genitori che hanno permessi di residenza e di lavoro a lungo termine. Questo significa che molti dei piccoli delle elementari di Castellina vivono in un limbo, anche quelli che abitano qui da anni.\n\nDa molto tempo vedo a Castellina migranti che lavorano nei campi e alcune donne che indossano il velo, ma non avevo capito quanto il mio paese fosse cambiato fino all\u2019anno scorso, durante una chiacchierata con Francesco. Ha nove anni e la mia mamma \u00e8 la sua tata da otto, un po\u2019 la sua nonna onoraria.\n\nUna sera a cena, Francesco mi ha detto che era triste perch\u00e9 il suo amico Igor se ne era andato. Igor si era rifugiato qui dall\u2019Ucraina, ma ora poteva tornare a casa perch\u00e9 non cadevano pi\u00f9 le bombe e suo padre aveva lasciato l\u2019esercito. Justin Verlander, the veteran pitcher for the Houston Astros, said catchers and pitchers meet more often now to combat sign stealing, which has become more sophisticated with advanced video technology.\n\n\u201cThe signs are getting so much more advanced to protect against that, so that\u2019s why you\u2019re seeing more mound visits,\u201d Verlander said. \u201cAnd when guys get on base, the game comes to a screeching halt. I don\u2019t think the adjustments they made here are going to change anything. A few minutes, maybe.\u201d\n\nCalls from the video room to the dugout will now be monitored, the league said, to prevent the instant communication of sign stealing. But there is nothing preventing a video technician from relaying such information in person, or in a pregame meeting.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. And it kind of throws us off too. It\u2019s a pain. Ruins the rhythm of the game, for us and the fans.\u201d\n\nYankees catcher Gary Sanchez was notorious last season for frequently visiting pitchers with runners on second base. Aaron Boone, the new Yankees\u2019 manager, said he hoped the team could use the new rules to gain an advantage, and the Mets\u2019 new manager, Mickey Callaway, agreed.\n\n\u201cTo gain an edge in any part of the game, you have to prepare,\u201d Callaway said. \u201cAnd if we can prepare our catchers and pitchers and their communication better than other teams, maybe we won\u2019t get confused like other teams.\u201d\n\nBrian McCann, the veteran Astros catcher, said six mound visits per game should be plenty, adding that the new rules would simply force pitchers and catchers to prepare a bit longer before games. Especially umpires, if there\u2019s any miscommunication with signs.\u201d\n\nIf a player leaves his position to discuss strategy with a pitcher after an offensive substitution, it will not count as a visit. The rules also allow extra mound visits if the umpire determines that the pitcher has misunderstood the catcher\u2019s signs.
