Indian influence in the Maldives has waned since 2012, when it did not stand firmly behind Mr. Nasheed, who had been an ally, as he was ousted from office.\n\nAnand Kumar, a fellow at the Institute for Defense Studies and Analyses in New Delhi, said although India was clearly alarmed about losing influence to the Chinese in the Indian Ocean, it had struggled to respond.\n\nBut he said India would be ill advised to consider a military option against a sitting president, because its attempt to send troops to counter an insurgency that was fighting another ally, the Sri Lankan government, had turned disastrous.\n\nPart of the dilemma is that \u201cthe Maldives is just another front for the Chinese,\u201d Mr. Kumar said, citing its militarization of islands in the South China Sea as one example. \u201cChina has deep-rooted economic, political and military interests in Maldives, and it\u2019s not going to be a win-win situation for India.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Maldives government has condemned Mr. Nasheed\u2019s calls for intervention by India\u2019s military.\n\n\u201cThere is no threat of Maldives being invaded by foreign military,\u201d the Defense Ministry said in a statement. \u201cThe government of Maldives would like to reiterate that it has maintained good relations with India since Maldives declared independence and firmly believes that India would not act on any such calls.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe latest escalation in the Maldives began this month after an order by the Supreme Court to release political prisoners and reinstate members of Parliament whom Mr. Yameen had removed for crossing over to the opposition. The court also threw out Mr. Nasheed\u2019s case; he is supposed to be serving a 13-year prison sentence but has been living outside the country.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter the Supreme Court overturned criminal convictions against nine of the president\u2019s opponents and ordered that those in jail be freed, Mr. Yameen sent troops to surround the court and arrest two of the judges and later even his half brother, former President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom.\n\nDespite calls from many Western countries for Mr. Yameen to lift the state of emergency and release the judges and opposition leaders, just how much leverage other nations beyond China and India have over the Maldives is an open question.\n\nAfter Mr. Yameen declared the state of emergency, several Western ambassadors arrived in Mal\u00e9, the capital, to meet with him and his officials and ask for an explanation of what was happening. But they said Mr. Yameen\u2019s government showed no interest in talking.\n\n\u201cThere was an announcement made by the government that the international community was welcome to come and visit the country and speak to the officials,\u201d Tung-Lai Margue, the European Union ambassador to Sri Lanka and the Maldives told a news conference in Mal\u00e9 afterward, flanked by his German and British colleagues. \u201cWell, we came. And we couldn\u2019t meet anybody.\u201d\n\nOne pressure point Mr. Yameen might feel is a steep drop in tourists from abroad, a major source of revenue. Tourist reservations fallen sharply since the state of emergency was declared, and many countries, including China, have cautioned their citizens against traveling to the Maldives.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn recent years, the Maldives has become a significant target for Beijing\u2019s ambitious economic expansion. Its international airport, the major road connecting it to the capital and other projects fall under \u201cOne Belt, One Road.\u201d\n\nPresident Xi Jinping\u2019s visit to the Maldives in 2014 underscored efforts by China to increase its presence in the Indian Ocean. And when Mr. Yameen went to Beijing last December, the two nations signed a trade agreement that opens up the huge Chinese consumer market to the Maldives\u2019 fishing industry.\n\nAfter declaring the state of emergency, Mr. Yameen sent envoys to China, Saudi Arabia and Pakistan, all of which he considers friendly to his rule, to update them on the situation and seek their support.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWestern diplomats said that Mr. Yameen\u2019s government had signaled a willingness to talk to opposition groups, but that its condition that the talks take place in Mal\u00e9 made it impossible, as no opposition leader trusted the government enough to fly home for such talks. The country\u2019s politics has been long treacherous, both before and after it became a republic, not least when its first president was lured into a mob lynching in the 1950s near an old mango tree that still stands in the army headquarters.\n\nMr. Nasheed, who has spent much of his adult life in prison, in exile or on the run, has been dismayed by international calls for the Maldives government and opposition to sort out the issue domestically.\n\n\u201cIf you tell us to \u2018Fend for yourselves and continue your hardship,\u2019 the next step would be a rebel army \u2014 and I don\u2019t want to see that,\u201d he said. \u201cI am afraid that by asking us to find a local solution, you are really asking us for a fist fight.\u201d", "title": "Maldives Crisis Could Stir Trouble Between China and India", "authors": ["Mujib Mashal"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA resident of an Upper Manhattan apartment building has been arrested on charges that he set the fire in November that left it badly damaged and displaced dozens of people, the authorities said on Thursday.\n\nThe man, Jelani Parker, was arrested around 5:30 p.m. and will face charges including felony assault, arson and reckless endangerment, Detective Hubert Reyes of the New York Police Department said.\n\nMr. Parker, 34, apparently fled to Los Angeles at some point after the Nov. 17 fire, which destroyed the top two floors of the six-story brownstone at 565 West 144th Street in Hamilton Heights.\n\nA Los Angeles police spokesman, Officer Tony Im, said late Thursday that officers from the department\u2019s central division had come in contact with Mr. Parker in January; he said they arrested Mr. Parker after verifying that he was wanted in New York on a warrant. The arrest was reported by WABC Thursday night.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nArrangements were then made for the authorities in New York to pick up Mr. Parker, Officer Im said. A spokeswoman for that office did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment.", "title": "Man Arrested in Upper Manhattan Building Fire That Displaced Dozens", "authors": ["Matt Stevens"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "A man crashed a stolen bakery truck into a Planned Parenthood clinic in East Orange, N.J., this week, injuring a pregnant woman and two others, the authorities said.\n\nThe suspect, Marckles Alcius, 31, who had a last known address in Lowell, Mass., was charged with attempting to cause widespread injury or damage, aggravated assault, theft and other counts.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe investigations are continuing,\u201d Thomas S. Fennelly, the chief assistant prosecutor for Essex County, said in a phone interview on Saturday. \u201cAdditional charges are possible, but we cannot comment on a motive.\u201d\n\nA staff member and two patients, one of whom was pregnant, were hurt in the crash on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cWe are pleased that only minor injuries occurred,\u201d Planned Parenthood said in a statement. The organization said there was \u201cextensive damage to the waiting room\u201d and the clinic would be closed for several weeks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe stolen truck belonged to a Newark bakery, the authorities said.\n\nMr. Alcius pleaded not guilty in a court appearance on Friday. He is being held at the Essex County Correctional Facility in Newark, and his next court appearance is scheduled for Feb. 21.", "title": "Man Crashes Truck Into Planned Parenthood Clinic, Police Say", "authors": ["Jacey Fortin"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "The acoustic one-upfrogship is energetically draining and risks attracting predators like bats. Yet the male frogs have no choice but to keep count of the competition, for the simple reason that female t\u00fangaras are doing the same: listening, counting and ultimately mating with the male of maximum chucks.\n\nBehind the frog\u2019s surprisingly sophisticated number sense, scientists have found, are specialized cells located in the amphibian midbrain that tally up sound signals and the intervals between them.\n\n\u201cThe neurons are counting the number of appropriate pulses, and they\u2019re highly selective,\u201d said Gary Rose, a biologist at the University of Utah. If the timing between pulses is off by just a fraction of a second, the neurons don\u2019t fire and the counting process breaks down.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s game over,\u201d Dr. Rose said. \u201cJust as in human communication, an inappropriate comment can end the whole conversation.\u201d\n\nThe story of the frog\u2019s neuro-abacus is just one example of nature\u2019s vast, ancient and versatile number sense, a talent explored in detail in a recent themed issue of Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B, edited by Brian Butterworth, a cognitive neuroscientist at University College London, C. Randy Gallistel of Rutgers University and Giorgio Vallortigara of the University of Trento.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nScientists have found that animals across the evolutionary spectrum have a keen sense of quantity, able to distinguish not just bigger from smaller or more from less, but two from four, four from ten, forty from sixty.\n\nOrb-weaving spiders, for example, keep a tally of how many silk-wrapped prey items are stashed in the \u201clarder\u201d segment of their web. When scientists experimentally remove the cache, the spiders will spend time searching for the stolen goods in proportion to how many separate items had been taken, rather than how big the total prey mass might have been.\n\nSmall fish benefit from living in schools, and the more numerous the group, the statistically better a fish\u2019s odds of escaping predation. As a result, many shoaling fish are excellent appraisers of relative head counts.\n\nGuppies, for example, have a so-called contrast ratio of .8, which means they can distinguish at a glance between four guppies and five, or eight guppies and ten, and if given the chance will swim toward the slightly fishier crowd.\n\nThree-spined sticklebacks are more discriminating still: with a contrast ratio of .86, they\u2019re able to tell six fellow fish from seven, or 18 from 21 \u2014 a comparative power that many birds, mammals and even humans might find hard to beat.\n\nPhoto\n\nDespite the prevalence of math phobia, people too are born with a strong innate number sense, and numerosity is deeply embedded in many aspects of our minds and culture.\n\nResearchers have determined that number words for small quantities \u2014 less than five \u2014 are strikingly similar across virtually every language studied, and the words are among the most stable, unchanging utterances in any lexicon.\n\nThey are more conserved through time and across cultures than words for other presumably bedrock concepts like mother, father and most body parts, with a few puzzling exceptions like the words for tongue and eye.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe sounds that you and I use to say \u2018two\u2019 or \u2018three\u2019 are the sounds that have been used for tens of thousands of years,\u201d said Mark Pagel, a biologist who studies the evolution of language at the University of Reading.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not out of the question that you could have been wandering around 15,000 years ago and encountered a few of the last remaining Neanderthals, pointed to yourself and said, \u2018one,\u2019 and pointed to them and said, \u2018three,\u2019 and those words, in an odd, coarse way, would have been understood.\u201d\n\nThat continuity, Dr. Pagel added, \u201cshould astonish us.\u201d\n\nThe earliest formal number systems, complete with those all-important place values, date back only about 3,500 years, to ancient Mesopotamia, but quantitative record keeping is much older. Francesco D\u2019Errico, an archaeologist at the University of Bordeaux, described his team\u2019s analysis of a 70,000-year-old hyena femur from the Les Pradelles site in France.\n\nThe leg bone fragment is incised with nine parallel, nearly identical notches, which look far too regular to be the incidental result of butchery with stone tools or an early attempt at artful decoration. \u201cThis fits with the idea that the incisions are a form of numerical notation,\u201d Dr. D\u2019Errico said. \u201cWe see the beginnings of externalizing our numeric sense, of taking it outside the body.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAttitudes about animal numerosity have changed dramatically since the mid-twentieth century when many researchers believed only humans had enough gray matter to think quantitatively. They cited as an object lesson the 1907 case of Clever Hans, the horse that supposedly could solve arithmetic problems and would tap out his answers by hoof; as it turned out, he was responding to unconscious cues from the people around him.\n\nSince then, researchers have approached the field with caution and rigor, seeking to identify the specific evolutionary pressures that might spur the need for numeric judgments in any given species.\n\nSocial carnivores like spotted hyenas, for example, live in fission-fusion societies, collectively defending their territories against rivals but in ever-shifting groups of widely roaming members. \u201cYou can never predict who you\u2019ll find in which group,\u201d said Sarah Benson-Amram, an assistant professor of zoology and physiology at the University of Wyoming. \u201cYou might be alone or in a group of ten.\u201d\n\nBecause hyena jaws can pulverize zebra bones, encounters between competitors can prove deadly; every spotted hyena must have a good sense from moment to moment of how many there are of us versus how many of them. Dr. Benson-Amram and her colleagues tested hyena numerosity skills in the field, playing back the recorded whoops of spotted hyenas living in South Africa and Namibia to hyenas in Kenya.\n\nThe Kenyan carnivores reacted to the whoops of strangers as predicted, approaching the hidden source of the sound when they had a home team advantage, retreating when they heard a few too many distinctive voices in a row. Or sometimes, when the local hyenas were outnumbered, they\u2019d call for backup.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI always loved it when the hyenas would whoop and others would come running in,\u201d Dr. Benson-Amram said. \u201cIt was very dramatic, very aggressive, and I appreciated this ability to recruit other group members to the cause.\u201d\n\nChimpanzees are social scorekeepers, episodic warriors and number ninjas, too. They can be taught to associate groups of objects with corresponding Arabic numerals up to the number 9 and sometimes beyond \u2014 three squares on a computer screen with the number 3, five squares with 5, and so on. They can put those numerals in order.\n\nMore Reporting on Mathematics\n\nThe numeric working memory of young chimpanzees is astonishing: Flash a random scattering of numerals on a screen for just 210 milliseconds \u2014 half an eye blink \u2014 and then cover the numbers with white squares, and a numerically schooled young chimpanzee will touch the squares sequentially to indicate the ascending order of the numbers hidden beneath.\n\nDon\u2019t bother trying to do this yourself, Tetsuro Matsuzawa, a primatologist at Kyoto University, said at the scientific meeting in London on which the themed journal was based. \u201cYou can\u2019t.\u201d\n\nBy the look of it, cerebral property in humans once dedicated to numeric memory has, in the six million years since we diverged from chimpanzees, been co-opted for grander purposes, like the ability to judge whether a sentence like this is true: \u201cThere is no non-vanishing continuous tangent vector field on even dimensional spheres.\u201d\n\nStanislas Dehaene, a psychologist at the University of Paris, and his colleagues presented evidence from brain scans of professional mathematicians that the neural circuitry for advanced mathematical thinking is an elaboration on the archaic number sense we share with other animals.\n\nIt is distinct from our everyday language pathways, even when that math-related challenge involves words rather than numbers \u2014 like the true statement above.\n\nYet our inborn numerosity hardly guarantees mathematical proficiency, and can sometimes work against us. Psychologists Rochel Gelman of Rutgers University and Jennifer Jacobs Danan of the University of California, Los Angeles, have studied how often reasonably well-educated people miscalculate percentages.\n\nWe hear that the price of something rose by 50 percent and then fell by 50 percent, and we reflexively, mistakenly conclude, \u201cOh good, we\u2019re back to where we started.\u201d Our natural number sense adds and subtracts whole numbers, whole chucks, guppies and hyenas. But it really abhors a fraction, and so has led us astray.", "title": "Many Animals Can Count, Some Better Than You", "authors": ["Natalie Angier"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump has doubled down on Guant\u00e1namo, signing an order last week to keep the prison open and vowing in his State of the Union address to send more prisoners to the island. But the tribunals at Guant\u00e1namo have repeatedly sputtered, dragging out for more than a decade cases that were originally envisioned to be so speedy that they were set in temporary buildings and tents.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs further evidence of the system\u2019s dysfunction, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis fired the top official overseeing the tribunals, Harvey Rishikof, as well as his chief of staff on Monday. A Pentagon spokesman said the change in leadership, which was first reported by The Miami Herald, would not affect continuing cases.\n\nThe Nashiri case began in 2011 and is still churning through pretrial hearings. So are the trials for those accused of being Sept. 11 collaborators. The judge for the Nashiri case has said he would like to begin picking a military jury by December, which puts the schedule of the case in doubt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn death penalty cases, the military tribunal rules require so-called learned counsel who have tried capital cases before. The team\u2019s former lead counsel had tried 38. Lieutenant Piette has tried none. But the judge in the case has decided to move forward with only the lieutenant \u2014 a move that has alarmed a number of legal scholars.\n\n\u201cHe doesn\u2019t come close to being qualified,\u201d said Ellen Yaroshefsky, a professor of legal ethics at Hofstra University. \u201cSo a death penalty case is basically going forward without a lawyer. If that is what we think passes as a court system, we\u2019re in big trouble.\u201d\n\nOne of the people questioning the lieutenant\u2019s decision to stay is the lieutenant himself. His presence in court allows the case to move forward without experienced counsel. \u201cThat is clearly a problem, because there is no way I qualify as learned counsel,\u201d he said. \u201cBut leaving the client without a lawyer to protect his rights could be even worse. I don\u2019t know if I\u2019ve done the right thing, but I don\u2019t think I really had a choice.\u201d\n\nThe dispute that prompted the resignations of the rest of Lieutenant Piette\u2019s team started this summer when the defense learned that conversations with their client \u2014 conversations that are typically strictly confidential \u2014 were likely being monitored by the government.\n\nThe defense team searched the detention block room at Guant\u00e1namo where they met with Mr. Nashiri and spotted something that to them confirmed government monitoring. The original lead defense attorney, Richard Kammen, said in an interview that what he found was classified, so he was barred from disclosing it, even to his client. He objected to the court, but the judge in the case ruled this fall that the client had only limited rights to confidentiality. Mr. Kammen quit the case in protest, saying it was ethically impossible to stay. Two assisting lawyers followed.\n\n\u201cWe were gobsmacked,\u201d said Mr. Kammen, who for years has jousted with the military tribunal, making his appraisal of it clear by wearing a kangaroo pin on his court jacket. \u201cUnder the law, we had to quit. We had no choice.\u201d\n\nBoth the judge and prosecutors were furious at the exodus, which threatened to derail an already slow-moving case. The lead civilian prosecutor, Mark Miller, denounced the defense for what he called \u201ca scorched-earth strategy to obstruct the proceeding by any means, however frivolous, however cynical.\u201d\n\nThe judge, Air Force Col. Vance Spath, ordered the defense back to court in October. When they refused, he ordered a Marine general in charge of the defense to force them back. The general also refused, and was confined in a trailer next to the razor wire-ringed court in November for contempt. At the most recent hearings in late January, Judge Spath was still trying to compel the lawyers to appear, so far without success.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a federal court, appointing a new experienced lawyer would be straightforward, but Guant\u00e1namo is no federal court. Few lawyers qualified to take death penalty cases have both the requisite top secret security clearance and the willingness to work with the special military tribunal rules created by Congress in 2009 for Guant\u00e1namo, said Navy Cmdr. Brian Mizer, who in the past has represented multiple detainees at the tribunals.\n\n\u201cThere is a perception that the tribunals are like tilting at windmills,\u201d he said. \u201cMany lawyers don\u2019t want to go near it.\u201d\n\nMr. Mizer and others said it could take at least a year for a new lawyer to be appointed and get caught up on the case.\n\nExperienced counsel in a case like Mr. Nashiri\u2019s is critical, Commander Mizer said, because the thicket of charges stemming from a series of attacks is complicated further by evidence gathered through years of torture at C.I.A. black sites.\n\nBut after Mr. Kammen left, Judge Spath ruled that learned counsel were required only \u201cto the extent practicable,\u201d and pushed forward with pretrial hearings with just the lieutenant at the helm.\n\nLieutenant Piette, who grew up in Texas and Wisconsin, said he was not easily swayed by long odds. He enlisted in the Navy right after high school in 1997, inspired by his grandfather, who had been a decorated commando during World War II. Despite limited swimming skills and no experience with weapons, he soon graduated from the notoriously punishing SEAL selection course in a year when nearly 90 percent of the class dropped out.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe was assigned to a cold-weather warfare team and deployed to Kosovo.\n\nAfter the U.S.S. Cole and the World Trade Center were attacked, he thought the team would be sent to hunt terrorists. Instead he was deployed again to Eastern Europe. He finished his enlistment without seeing combat. With a young family at home and a growing frustration at the lack of action, he left the Navy at the end of 2003.\n\nFor years after, he said, he was dogged by regret. SEAL teams began deploying to Iraq and Afghanistan. Three friends were killed in combat. Men he knew shot Osama bin Laden, he said. He worried he had fumbled his chance to make a difference.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat changed at Georgetown University\u2019s law school, where he started his degree program thinking he would become a prosecutor, but in his final year found the criminal defense clinic.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRaised Roman Catholic, he described representing destitute, often mentally ill clients as the moment he really understood the teachings of Jesus.\n\n\u201cIt was the first time since the SEALs I found something really meaningful,\u201d he said. \u201cI was standing between a person and the system. Everything I had learned about training and preparation and perseverance \u2014 it clicked.\u201d\n\nAfter graduating in 2012, he spent five years as a Navy lawyer, working criminal cases at Naval Station Norfolk in Virginia. Last April he was hired to work on the Nashiri case. He had barely started when his whole team quit.\n\nIn January, the judge repeatedly fumed at the missing defense team, calling it a strategic tactic intended to undermine the trial.\n\n\u201cNever have I seen such open and notorious rejection of orders from a court,\u201d the judge told the court.\n\nLieutenant Piette stood before him, respectful but unwavering. As a SEAL member, he said later, he was used to being yelled at.\n\nDuring hearings over several days in January, the prosecution called witnesses and moved to introduce photos and bags of blast fragments from the attack, which killed 17 sailors. Lieutenant Piette sat silently, spinning his pen in seeming frustration, but passed up dozens of chances to object and cross-examine.\n\nHe felt staying nearly silent was the only effective strategy for his client, he said. Over the course of two days, the judge asked 37 times for the defense to comment on the admission of evidence. Each time the lieutenant stood and responded, \u201cDefense takes no position other than to object to these proceedings continuing without learned counsel.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough he wanted to argue at length, challenging the very idea that evidence could be admitted without a jury present, he said he knew it would be unethical to even try, and could sink the case. He hoped his refusal to participate would preserve an issue for appeal. Whether it will upend the trial or be a mere footnote in the tribunals will likely not be known for years.\n\nThe prosecution declined requests for an interview, but in court, an Air Force major on the team denounced Lieutenant Piette\u2019s objections, calling them \u201cshameless, disingenuous and conceited.\u201d\n\nThe same day, though, Abbe Smith, a law professor at Georgetown who taught Lieutenant Piette criminal defense, put his photo up in her ethics class as an example of a \u201ccourageous and ethical representation.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s pretty gutsy. This legal train is in motion and he steps out in front to protect his client,\u201d she said in an interview. \u201cI don\u2019t know that all lawyers would do that.\u201d\n\nMr. Kammen said discussions with Lieutenant Piette about staying were \u201ccomplicated\u201d and he was not convinced his most junior lawyer did the right thing.\n\n\u201cIf we are obligated to withdraw, isn\u2019t he?\u201d Mr. Kammen said. \u201cHe\u2019s a fine lawyer, but this is way beyond what he can do.\u201d", "title": "Many Say He\u2019s the Least Qualified Lawyer Ever to Lead a Guant\u00e1namo Case. He Agrees.", "authors": ["Dave Philipps"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "The visual reference \u2014 down to the flat-brimmed black hats worn atop many of the looks (later in the show, dyed-to-match New Wave wigs) \u2014 was Yves Saint Laurent, The Later Years. There was also a pouf skirt, some quilted bags and a watercolor taffeta with a single giant ruffled sleeve. They were asymmetrical and overblown. Bombastic and a bit bomb-tastic.\n\nMr. Jacobs went there. Do we really want to follow?\n\nThese are the kind of effects that can cause fashion people to clutch their chests in delight \u2014 ooh, the pictures! \u2014 yet aside from a few body-con dresses buried amid the cartoon excess and one lovely strapless empire-waisted evening gown, the styles swamped the body, rendering it squatto. When a model appeared in a gray knit body suit and tights beneath a big-shouldered sweater, scarf ends like flying buttresses extending to the floor behind, it was hard not to wince at the extreme contrast between her upper body and her frail legs.", "title": "Marc Jacobs\u2019s 1980s Requiem", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 At the World Cup races late last month, Marcel Hirscher of Austria told his longtime American rival Ted Ligety that he was planning to skip the Alpine combined event at the Winter Olympics.\n\nLigety laughed at Hirscher and told him he would see him at the race\u2019s starting gate.\n\nHirscher, ski racing\u2019s most dominant athlete since 2011, has had a tangled relationship with the Olympics. For all his many accomplishments, which include a record six consecutive World Cup overall titles and 55 World Cup victories, an Olympic gold medal had eluded him, an outcome that vexed him after two previous Olympic appearances.\n\nIt had gotten to the point that Hirscher preferred to make jokes about whether he would ever win a gold medal.", "title": "Marcel Hirscher of Austria Grabs Elusive Gold Medal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Out of the six theme entries, I liked TACO STAND, MORSE CODE and HIT A NERVE the best, especially for the brilliant clues for TACO STAND and MORSE CODE.\n\nIn nontheme news, I would like to have seen better fill in Mr. Collins\u2019s puzzle. I appreciate a theme set that is complete (it is complete, right?), but sometimes you can sacrifice the ability to fill a grid well if you try to pack too much thematic material into a puzzle. I liked the above-mentioned theme entries, as well as RAMRODS and AXL ROSE, but we also have HAD ON and THROW ON, which are, if not dupes, pretty close. We also have the plural LENAS, ON AT, THAN I and HOS, as well as bits of crosswordese.\n\nBut stay tuned, because the cluing is what really boosts this grid.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n21A: I loved this one. \u201cShell station?\u201d for TACO STAND is incredibly clever. And now I want tacos.\n\n32A: I got the answer YDS from the crossings, but who doesn\u2019t love a reference to the wonderfully named football player Y.A. Tittle?\n\n51A: Fabulous wordplay here. \u201cTook out the junk?\u201d is worded to make solvers think about taking out the garbage, but a junk is a classic Chinese sailing ship, so SAILED is the answer here.\n\n52A: Brilliant. It took me a while to get this one. Were you wondering why the clue (\u201cWhere S is \u2026\u201d) just trailed off? Those three dots are not an ellipsis. They are MORSE CODE for the letter S.\n\n10D: More wordplay! \u201cLee side\u201d may make solvers think about nautical terms, where the lee side is the side of a vessel that is sheltered from the wind. Today, however, we\u2019re supposed to be thinking about the Civil War: The answer THE SOUTH refers to General Robert E. Lee.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n54D: I make mayo from egg yolks and oil, and if you\u2019ve never made your own mayonnaise, it is so much better than the jarred stuff. Try this recipe by Melissa Clark. However, in today\u2019s puzzle \u201cMayo parts?\u201d are DIAS, or days, because mayo is Spanish for the month of May.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nYep. I\u2019m a math teacher. I hope the sight of the six trig functions didn\u2019t trigger PTSD (Post Trigonometric Stress Disorder) in any solvers out there. Math seems to be the most visceral subject in the high school curriculum \u2014 even long after high school. When I meet adults for the first time and they find out what I do for a living, I usually get a response like \u201cOh, I really [past tense verb] math!\u201d Your two Mad Lib choices for the past tense verb are \u201cloved\u201d or \u201chated.\u201d I\u2019d say the ratio of those two verbs is about 10 to 1. I\u2019ll let you guess which way. I like that the revealer is LEFT RIGHT, as the trig functions kind of march down the grid in a left-right manner. I even considered constructing the grid so that the trig functions were pushed up against the sides of the grid, but CSC wouldn\u2019t play along. I also considered taking out LEFT RIGHT altogether, as it made the fill in the center a little strained. That triple column of RETOW/VIRNA/ENIAC probably has a favorable/unfavorable rating of 200 to 1. Again, I\u2019ll let you guess which way. After this puzzle was accepted, I found out that AXL ROSE anagrams into a rather salacious phrase. Am I the last person on the planet to learn this? I like that he\u2019s balanced out by YOYO MA in the opposite quadrant, as sort of a musical counterpoint. Also, YOYO MA anagrams into \u201cYo, mayo\u201d, but that\u2019s not nearly as exciting. My favorite clue that made the cut is [Where S is \u2026] for MORSE CODE. I hope some folks interpreted the dot-dot-dot as an ellipsis, and stopped to scratch their heads for a moment. I also like [Took out the junk?] for SAILED, but I have to admit I used essentially the same clue in an Orange County Register puzzle about a year ago. I hope you enjoyed the solve.\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but need just a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Marching Orders", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "But in other matters, Mr. Rubio has taken a more muddled approach. He has castigated the Trump administration for its handling of Russia and threatened to vote down Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson\u2019s nomination, only to back away from the confrontation. After advocating a comprehensive immigration overhaul under the Obama administration, Mr. Rubio opposed a bipartisan immigration deal this month, saying that it did not do enough to bolster enforcement.\n\nMr. Rubio maintains that he has demonstrated independence from the G.O.P. by consistently defending Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating Russian meddling in the presidential election, and been openly critical of the federal government\u2019s initial response to Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico. His reaction to the Parkland shooting, in his view, has built on his longstanding gun policies, now informed by lessons law enforcement and schools officials have learned in the first few days since the massacre at Stoneman Douglas High.\n\nOn the Democratic side, a mood of cynicism tends to pervade discussions of Mr. Rubio: Representative Ted Deutch, a Democrat who joined Mr. Rubio in the Wednesday town hall and whose district includes Stoneman Douglas High, accused Mr. Rubio of favoring only \u201clegislation that the N.R.A. can live with.\u201d\n\nStill, some Democrats welcomed Mr. Rubio\u2019s apparent openness to new legislative options. Representative Charlie Crist of Florida, a Democrat and former Republican who was once Mr. Rubio\u2019s bitter rival in a Senate primary, said Mr. Rubio\u2019s comments offered reason for optimism.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m encouraged by that, to be honest, and I hope that that evolution continues,\u201d Mr. Crist said Thursday. \u201cIn the wake of an event such as this, that can happen.\u201d\n\nMr. Crist, a onetime N.R.A. ally who now supports a ban on assault weapons, said much of Florida had undergone a similar reassessment of gun rights orthodoxy after two massacres in the state that targeted young people.\n\nPushing back on criticism from Mr. Deutch and others, Mr. Rubio fiercely disputed that he operates with great deference to the N.R.A. He countered that he is focused on practical ideas that might stand a chance of becoming law, and said the assault weapons ban favored by Parkland families is not among them.", "title": "Marco Rubio Finds Himself at Center of Gun Debate, Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump and Gov. Rick Scott of Florida, a Republican, both declined invitations to participate in the town hall-style meeting.\n\nThe father of a 14-year-old girl who was killed at Stoneman Douglas angrily lectured Mr. Rubio for his refusal to support gun control legislation.\n\nThe father, Fred Guttenberg, demanded that Mr. Rubio explain his opposition to a ban on the kind of assault weapon that the gunman at the school used to shoot his daughter, Jaime.\n\n\u201cMy daughter, running down the hallway, was shot in the back with an assault weapon, the weapon of choice,\u201d Mr. Guttenberg said during the forum as Mr. Rubio stood stone-faced. \u201cIt is too easy to get. It is a weapon of war. The fact that you can\u2019t stand with everybody else in this room and say that, I\u2019m sorry.\u201d\n\nThe room erupted in applause for Mr. Guttenberg and repeatedly booed as Mr. Rubio sought to explain his opposition to a proposed assault weapons ban. The bill, he said, is riddled with loopholes that would make it easy for criminals to get around.\n\n\u201cFirst, you have to define what it is. It basically bans 220 specific models of gun,\u201d Mr. Rubio said, prompting applause from the audience.\n\nHe continued, saying that the bill also allows for \u201c2,000 other types\u201d of guns that operate the same way but are not classified as assault weapons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Loesch repeatedly deflected questions about restrictions on the availability of guns, insisting instead that keeping guns out of the hands of the mentally ill or people with criminal records would keep students safe.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t believe that this insane monster should have ever been able to obtain a firearm, ever,\u201d Ms. Loesch told Emma Gonz\u00e1lez, a senior at the high school. \u201cNone of us support people who are crazy, who are a danger to themselves, who are a danger to others, getting their hands on a firearm.\u201d\n\nBut her answers prompted angry taunts from the audience. At times, Ms. Loesch struggled to answer, but she steadfastly refused to back down on the N.R.A.\u2019s position opposing new gun restrictions.\n\nShe said the group opposed raising the legal age for purchasing an assault weapon to 21 from 18, an idea that Mr. Trump had earlier signaled support for. Students who are old enough to serve in the military should be allowed to own firearms, she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDiane Wolk Rogers, a history teacher at Stoneman Douglas, confronted Ms. Loesch by asking her to defend the idea that allowing the suspect in the shooting, a 19-year-old, to own an assault rifle represents \u201ca well-regulated militia\u201d as is written in the Second Amendment.\n\nMs. Loesch said the phrase was meant to protect the rights of anyone who \u201ccould operate and service their firearm,\u201d an answer that drew loud yelling and more boos from the audience.\n\nMr. Rubio, for his part, had offered opening remarks that he clearly hoped would deflect criticism during the event. He expressed grief for those who were affected by the shooting, but he said that people in the United States needed to find ways to disagree \u201cwithout accusing one another of being evil people.\u201d\n\nBut the audience, including Mr. Guttenberg, did not hold back in criticizing Mr. Rubio\u2019s position on gun control. Mr. Guttenberg repeatedly asked whether Mr. Rubio believed that \u201cguns were the factor in the hunting of our kids.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe senator said he agreed, but he insisted that other types of laws would better prevent such attacks. He said that he would support a bill to increase the minimum age for the purchase of an assault weapon to 21 from 18. And he said that he backed improvements to background checks and a ban on so-called bump stocks, which can convert semiautomatic weapons to fire automatically.\n\nStudents and teachers at the forum on Wednesday also had questions for Florida\u2019s other politicians, including two Democrats, Senator Bill Nelson and Representative Ted Deutch.\n\nPhoto\n\nOne young student talked about how her best friend was killed in front of her, and she asked Mr. Nelson about background checks, and how to improve them.\n\nAnother student, whose brother died in the shooting, bluntly said to Mr. Deutch that \u201cmy friends and I are worried that we are going to be murdered in our classrooms.\u201d He asked what Mr. Deutch was going to do about it.\n\n\u201cAs a starter,\u201d the congressman said, \u201cI\u2019m going to introduce legislation to make sure that assault weapons are illegal in every part of this country.\u201d\n\nThe audience burst into applause.\n\nBut Mr. Rubio, who ran for president in 2016, was repeatedly challenged on his positions on gun control and his willingness to accept donations from the N.R.A.\n\nThe issue of donations was raised by a junior at Stoneman Douglas who stood just feet from the senator and asked him whether he would renounce money from the gun advocacy group in the future. When Mr. Rubio refused, the audience booed loudly.\n\n\u201cPeople buy into my agenda, and I do support the Second Amendment,\u201d Mr. Rubio said, repeatedly refusing to say he would stop accepting money from the group. \u201cThe influence of these groups comes not from money, the influence comes from the millions of people who support the agenda.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Deutch at one point engaged in a brief debate with Mr. Rubio, saying that a gun allowing someone to fire off 150 rounds in six to seven minutes \u201cshould be banned.\u201d\n\nLater, Chris Grady, a student at the high school, thanked Mr. Rubio for appearing at the forum, unlike Mr. Trump and Mr. Scott.\n\n\u201cA lot more than can be said for our so-called president and governor,\u201d Mr. Grady told Mr. Rubio. \u201cWe need you and your colleagues on both sides to come together with us and find a compromise if we are ever to solve this epidemic.\u201d\n\nMr. Grady asked the senator whether he supported legislation to limit high-capacity magazines that allow weapons to fire many bullets quickly. Mr. Rubio said that he had long opposed such legislation, but was now reconsidering that position.\n\nThe senator said that there could be evidence from the Florida school shooting that suggested the gunman might have killed fewer people if he did not have high-capacity magazines.\n\n\u201cIt wouldn\u2019t have prevented the attack, but it would have made it less lethal,\u201d Mr. Rubio said.", "title": "Marco Rubio and an N.R.A. Official Were Jeered and Lectured on Gun Control", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "The government isn\u2019t required to obtain a warrant before searching people or property at ports of entry. Within what the Justice Department has defined as a \u201creasonable distance,\u201d officers can search people suspected of violating immigration law or smuggling drugs.\n\n\u2022 But many residents and travelers say that authority amounts to an invasion of privacy.\n\nIvanka at the Games\n\n\u2022 When Kim Jong-un\u2019s sister attended the Winter Olympics two weeks ago, the South Korean news media called her \u201cNorth Korea\u2019s Ivanka.\u201d\n\nThey\u2019re about to get the real one.\n\nIvanka Trump will attend the closing ceremony at the Games this weekend, a visit that administration officials say could smooth some of the tensions from Vice President Mike Pence\u2019s trip.\n\n\u2022 For its part, North Korea announced today that it would send a high-level delegation, another sign that the two Koreas are trying to improve ties.\n\nA pastor to millions\n\n\u2022 The Rev. Billy Graham was America\u2019s best-known Christian evangelist for more than 60 years, using satellites to transmit sermons worldwide. He died Wednesday at 99.\n\nA counselor to presidents, Mr. Graham at times filled the role of national clergyman, offering prayers after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks and preaching in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOur video explains how Mr. Graham capitalized on modern communication technologies to give his ministry a global reach.\n\n\u2022 He will lie in repose Monday and Tuesday in Charlotte, N.C., and his funeral will be on March 2.\n\nVideo\n\nA fault line that runs through Poland\n\n\u2022 The European Union has bestowed huge sums on Poland, but the country\u2019s nationalist government has repeatedly bitten the hand that feeds it, with Warsaw accused of undermining democratic values.\n\nPoland will define whether the union\u2019s long effort to integrate the former Soviet bloc succeeds or fails, and the stakes for Europe, many believe, far outweigh those of Britain\u2019s exit.\n\n\u2022 Speaking of Brexit, Britain\u2019s government suggested on Wednesday that the transition period could be longer than two years, a time frame that disappointed hard-line supporters of withdrawal.\n\nThe Daily Listen to \u2018The Daily\u2019: Students Protest Gun Violence Demands for gun restrictions have followed one mass shooting after another, but little has changed. This time, the students who survived are leading the charge. But people can be a bad influence.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Alexa, Amazon\u2019s voice assistant, has a shot at becoming the third great consumer computing platform of the decade, our tech columnist writes.\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks were down on Wednesday. The two countries have dominated the event since women\u2019s hockey was introduced at the Games in 1998.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn the slopes, Mikaela Shiffrin won silver in the Alpine combined event; Lindsey Vonn finished without a medal.\n\nHere are the rest of today\u2019s results from Pyeongchang, South Korea. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t matter what a pistolero you are, or think you are. You don\u2019t need to be in school in charge of protecting children.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Joel Myrick, a former assistant principal who survived a school shooting, on efforts to arm teachers.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nPhoto\n\nBack Story\n\nIt\u2019s easy to spot members of the Dutch delegation at the Winter Olympics because they travel on orange bicycles, 132 of which were shipped to South Korea.\n\nThe bikes are helping athletes feel at home. In the Netherlands, bicycles outnumber people, 22.5 million to 18 million.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the Netherlands wasn\u2019t always a cyclist\u2019s haven. In the 1950s and \u201960s, as people started buying more cars, two-wheelers started to be pushed off the road.\n\nLiterally. Bicycle deaths, like traffic deaths as a whole, increased.\n\nIn 1971, about 3,300 people died in traffic accidents, including 400 children. Activist groups sprang up. Stop de Kindermoord (Stop the Child Murder) was among the most prominent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe number of traffic deaths has dropped since then. In 2016, the Netherlands saw 629 traffic deaths, about a third of which were bike deaths. Twelve were children.\n\nPart of the success story: the country\u2019s bike lanes, a network measuring about 22,000 miles.\n\nClaire Moses contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning.
