Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Marco Rubio, Ivanka Trump, Ice Hockey: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Margaret Brennan, the senior foreign affairs correspondent for CBS News, will be the next moderator of \u201cFace the Nation,\u201d the network\u2019s prestige Sunday morning public affairs show and one of the most influential venues in American politics.\n\nHer new role, announced by CBS on Thursday, makes Ms. Brennan, 37, the only woman currently serving as a solo anchor of a major Sunday political affairs show. She succeeds John Dickerson, who left \u201cFace the Nation\u201d in January after less than three years to replace Charlie Rose on \u201cCBS This Morning.\u201d\n\nAlong with mainstays like NBC\u2019s \u201cMeet the Press\u201d and ABC\u2019s \u201cThis Week,\u201d \u201cFace the Nation\u201d features interviews with prominent lawmakers and White House officials that often make news, and can forge Washington\u2019s political agenda for the week ahead.\n\nFor decades, the hosts of these shows have primarily been men.\n\n\u201cMeet the Press,\u201d which began in 1947, has had only one female moderator, Martha Rountree, its founding host. Lesley Stahl, now of \u201c60 Minutes,\u201d moderated \u201cFace the Nation\u201d from 1983 to 1991. Christiane Amanpour, now of CNN, moderated ABC\u2019s \u201cThis Week\u201d from 2010 to 2011.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMartha Raddatz of ABC News was named a co-anchor of \u201cThis Week\u201d in 2016, although the program\u2019s branding remains focused on the lead host, George Stephanopoulos.", "title": "Margaret Brennan Named Host of \u2018Face the Nation\u2019 on CBS", "authors": ["Michael M. Grynbaum"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "This week, Attorney General Jeff Sessions paused a discussion of the opioid epidemic to, once again, go after marijuana. He suggested that addictive pain medication wasn\u2019t the only problem and that many heroin addicts start out \u201cwith marijuana and other drugs.\u201d\n\nThere is a relationship between cannabis and opioids, but Mr. Sessions has it backward. Marijuana isn\u2019t a gateway drug to opioid addiction; it\u2019s a safer alternative to pain medicines. Mr. Sessions\u2019s vow to crack down on marijuana will only make the opioid epidemic worse.\n\nWe know that 40 percent of all opiate overdose deaths involve a prescription opiate. So having legal access to cannabis as another option for pain relief may actually reduce consumption of opiates.\n\nI know it sounds counterintuitive, but consider the evidence. To start, a large study assessed the effect of medical-marijuana laws on opiate-related deaths between 1999 and 2010 in all 50 states and reported a 25 percent decrease in opiate overdose mortality in states where medical marijuana was legal, compared with those where it wasn\u2019t. The study found that in 2010, medical-marijuana laws resulted in an estimated 1,729 fewer deaths than expected.", "title": "Opinion | Marijuana Can Save Lives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "The achievement of Robinson\u2019s novels has been how elegantly she folds questions of faith, ethics and eschatology into fiction, and presents them to us as human dramas, in language bright and bare as bone. She has been compared to the Dutch masters for her sense of silence and light, for the quality of patient attention that gilds the most modest moments. But she also has a gift for wit and metaphor that turns the ordinary on its head.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn nonfiction, Robinson approaches her quarry directly, with frank combativeness (or ranting, as her critics have it). She worried about this once: \u201cMy writing has perhaps taken too much of the stain of my anger,\u201d she wrote in \u201cMother Country,\u201d her 1989 study of nuclear pollution. No more. She opens the new collection telling us: \u201cI am too old to mince words.\u201d\n\nShe is democratic in her censure, flaying the left for its \u201cslick, unreflecting cynicism,\u201d the right for its \u201cunembarrassed enthusiasm for self-interest.\u201d She upbraids the religious for their fear and willful dismissal of science; scientists for their juvenile understanding and dismissal of faith.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut back to the original question. How did Robinson end up here \u2014 with an orientation so open to the world that it feels less cosmopolitan than cosmic? Was it libraries?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMostly. Robinson came to the habit of self-scrutiny early. As a child, her teachers told her, \u201cYou have to live with your mind your whole life\u201d; they taught her the value of building it, making it worthy. It was, she has said, the most important lesson she ever received. She kept at it, following the publication of \u201cHousekeeping,\u201d with one of the more interesting silences in American letters. She published no new fiction for 24 years, devoting herself instead to deep study of Marx, Darwin and the history of political thought.\n\nIn many ways, \u201cWhat Are We Doing Here?\u201d is a response to those years of study, a repudiation of Marx and Darwin, of powerful ideologies of any stripe that simplify the world. \u201cOur ways of understanding the world now, our systems and ideologies, have an authority for us that leads us to think of them as exhaustive accounts of reality rather than, at best, as instruments of understanding suited to particular uses,\u201d she writes. No argument here. But when she says that ideologies are to be avoided because they come with conclusions baked into them, I begin to fidget. This sounds an awful lot like some of Robinson\u2019s own nonfiction. For a book that so espouses the virtue of mind interrogating mind, there\u2019s not much evidence of it in this book. Her arguments unspool neatly, like silk off a spindle, because they are frequently arguments she has made before.\n\nWhen Robinson warns against historical amnesia, her regular readers will know exactly where she\u2019s heading: to the Puritans \u2014 caricatured as \u201ccankered souls\u201d but actually \u201cthe most progressive population on earth through the 19th century at least.\u201d I was very persuaded by the case she makes for their importance. I was even more persuaded by it when I first encountered it in her 1998 essay collection, \u201cThe Death of Adam.\u201d\n\nMost of the essays in this new book were delivered as speeches, and some repetition is inevitable. But so too is our desire for more \u2014 for the refinement of her ideas instead of the rehashing \u2014 especially since the final essay, which takes an unexpectedly personal turn, delivers like no other.\n\n\u201cSlander\u201d is the story of Robinson\u2019s strained relationship with her mother. \u201cWith a little difficulty we finally reached an accommodation, an adult friendship,\u201d she writes. \u201cThen she started watching Fox News.\u201d Her mother and her fellow retirees began to share \u201csalacious dread over coffee cake,\u201d fretting over the rumored \u201cwar against Christmas.\u201d \u201cMy mother lived out the end of her fortunate life in a state of bitterness and panic, never having had the slightest brush with any experience that would confirm her in these emotions, except, of course, Fox News,\u201d Robinson writes. The essay brings all the abstractions home, makes real and painful the cost of ceding an independence of mind. It\u2019s composed in a rare register: mourning and fury counterpoised by humor and a refusal of despair.\n\nRobinson tells us that old scholars would speak of being \u201cravished\u201d by a text. \u201cI think they were held to their work by a degree of fascination, of sober delight, that we can no longer imagine,\u201d she writes. She\u2019s wrong. I know exactly what she means.", "title": "Marilynne Robinson\u2019s Essays Reflect an Eccentric, Exasperating, Profound and Generous Mind", "authors": ["Parul Sehgal", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 Paris Fashion Week had barely begun before the wind was knocked out of it.\n\nThe culprit was Marine Serre: a surprisingly elfin radical, 5 feet and change tall, soft-spoken in the extreme. At a rehearsal space, on loan from the choreographer Blanca Li, in the 19th Arrondissement, Ms. Serre, 26, staged her first formal show, an assured, spiny debut from a designer who previously had only a few moon-printed jerseys and some historically minded moir\u00e9 skirts to her name. \u201cAt the beginning,\u201d Ms. Serre protested, at the mention of that. Yes, I agreed: six months ago.\n\nMs. Serre has come far, fast, and the guests at the show Tuesday morning took notice. Three collections in, she already has the benediction of LVMH Mo\u00ebt Hennessy Louis Vuitton; she won the 2017 LVMH Prize for young fashion designers, an award worth 300,000 euros, or about $369,000, which is decided by a jury including the designers Nicolas Ghesqui\u00e8re, Karl Lagerfeld and Marc Jacobs.\n\nHer new collection had less of the overt historical references she once leaned on; it was easier to believe, as her notes put it, that she \u201calways keeps the future in sight.\u201d There were still yards of her signature crescent moon prints, but joining them were pieces with a kind of tough glamour: denim jackets cinched and molded after the model of corsets; utility jackets with bottle holders, lipstick caddies and phone pockets to \u201creplace the classic handbag\u201d \u2014 an admirably heresy in an industry carried on the back of accessory sales.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. Sent weekly. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Serre has worked in the studios of Balenciaga, Dior and Margiela, and her work has reflections of that experience, particularly in her willingness to push what fashion people euphemize as a \u201cstrong\u201d look. But she doesn\u2019t sound like a cog of the industry; she sounds more like a revolutionary.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe day of the romantic designer, standing safely in a zone outside of business and production is over,\u201d she wrote in her show notes, by way of explaining her commitment to \u201cupcycling\u201d and working more sustainably \u2014 as in the pi\u00e8ce de r\u00e9sistance, show-closing dresses made of vintage scarves or shirts found, washed and then combined. She is not the only designer to make use of vintage textiles, but in her hands, and in her hybrid sportswear-and-scarf dresses, they looked cool.\n\nShe spoke, as many designers speak nowadays, about the need for protection: the tough jackets, the head wraps, the giant reflective sunglasses that shielded many of the models. \u201cYou want to hide a little bit,\u201d she said. \u201cThat\u2019s the world today.\u201d", "title": "Marine Serre Makes a Runway Debut", "authors": ["Matthew Schneier"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "During those months she worked as a television broadcaster at tennis events, and conducted on-court interviews at the French Open in Paris. People were so taken aback by her weight loss that some speculated she had anorexia, which Bartoli said bothered her because it was untrue.\n\nThe turning point came in 2016 at Wimbledon, where Bartoli hoped to play in an exhibition doubles event. But tournament doctors, fearing for her health, refused to allow her to play. It was then that Bartoli revealed she had contracted the virus and said she would soon be entering a clinic.\n\n\u201cLooking back, I think they took the best decision for me because I would have probably died on that court if I played a tennis match on that weight,\u201d she said. \u201cIt took me a very long period of time to recover, definitely. I went into the hospital for four months after that.\u201d\n\nAs she gradually recovered, Bartoli started to consider playing tennis again. Last October, she assembled a team and began to train. But during her illness she had lost significant muscle mass and virtually all athletic conditioning.", "title": "Marion Bartoli Is Nearly Back", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "During the podcast, Cuban was candid as usual, openly admitting what anyone who has watched the Mavericks this season could see was true.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m probably not supposed to say this,\u201d Cuban said, \u201cbut, like, I just had dinner with a bunch of our guys the other night, and here we are, you know, we weren\u2019t competing for the playoffs. I was like, \u2018Look, losing is our best option.\u2019 \u201d\n\nHe then referred to Silver, saying: \u201cAdam would hate hearing that, but I at least sat down and I explained it to them. And I explained what our plans were going to be this summer, that we\u2019re not going to tank again. This was, like, a year-and-a-half tanking, and that was too brutal for me. But being transparent, I think that\u2019s the key to being kind of a players\u2019 owner and having stability.\u201d\n\nThe Mavericks, at 18-40, have the third-worst record in the N.B.A. despite the presence of Dirk Nowitzki, a likely future Hall of Famer, and a promising rookie, Dennis Smith Jr. If Dallas finishes with the worst record in the N.B.A., it would have a 25 percent chance of landing the top pick in this year\u2019s draft. Starting in 2019, antitanking rules will take away much of that incentive by giving the bottom three teams each a 14 percent chance at the No. 1 pick.\n\nCuban, who stars on the television show \u201cShark Tank\u201d in addition to his role with the Mavericks and various other business interests, has typically played down the effect of fines on the way he discusses his business. But the timing of this fine was particularly bad. On Tuesday, the team announced that it had engaged outside counsel to investigate reports that its former president and chief executive, Terdema Ussery, had engaged in \u201cvarious acts of inappropriate conduct toward women\u201d during his tenure.", "title": "Mark Cuban\u2019s Terrible 24 Hours Now Includes a $600,000 Fine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "THE HEART IS A SHIFTING SEA\n\nLove and Marriage in Mumbai\n\nBy Elizabeth Flock\n\n358 pp. Harper. $27.99.\n\nThe journalist Elizabeth Flock was in her early 20s when she moved to Mumbai. Though she was wary of overromanticizing India, she was immediately taken with what appeared to be an Indian attitude toward romance itself. \u201cIn Mumbai, people seemed to practice a showy, imaginative kind of love,\u201d she writes in \u201cThe Heart Is a Shifting Sea.\u201d She wondered if there was wisdom to this brand of passion: \u201cWhen I arrived in Mumbai after my dad\u2019s third divorce, the city seemed to hold some answers.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Heart Is a Shifting Sea\u201d is the culmination of Flock\u2019s search for those answers: a heavily reported work of nonfiction centered on three couples. There\u2019s Maya and Veer, Marwari Hindus; Sabeena and Shahzad, Sunni Muslims; and Parvati and Ashok, Tamil Brahmin Hindus. Maya pursues Veer brazenly after spotting him at a wedding; Maya\u2019s parents object to the union, so they elope. Sabeena and Shahzad meet just once before their engagement. Parvati and Ashok find each other through a matrimony website with the help of their concerned families.\n\nLike Katharine Boo \u2014 who synthesized hours of research into a cinematic account of slum life in \u201cBehind the Beautiful Forevers\u201d \u2014 Flock writes about her subjects with omniscient authority. But unlike Boo, who was working across formidable economic and linguistic barriers, Flock has embedded herself among educated, English-speaking, middle-class Indians. Flock\u2019s subjects read novels by Chimamanda Adichie and Jeffrey Eugenides, and watch \u201cFriends\u201d reruns.\n\nMarriage is hard for these couples in the ways that it can be hard for couples anywhere. They fight over money and work, overbearing in-laws and traffic stops. They struggle with infidelity, infertility, miscarriages, anxiety and depression, and the trauma of childhood abuse. But their lives are also difficult in culturally specific ways. As writers like Siddhartha Deb and Akash Kapur have explored, the rapid global economic growth of the 21st century has upended nearly all aspects of Indian life. What this looks like is Maya, armed with a master\u2019s degree, cooking elaborate meals for the in-laws who have confiscated her mobile phone. Or Ashok, an aspiring novelist, telling his father that while it\u2019s true his peers have largely abandoned arranged marriage, he\u2019d still like his parents\u2019 help finding a spouse.\n\nPhoto\n\nIndia, like rural America, has the dubious honor of being perpetually discovered anew by wide-eyed journalists. One of Shahzad\u2019s side-hustles entails offering foreigners a tour of Mumbai; its highlights, Flock notes, include a stop at a slum (where they \u201ccould feel a mix of pity and awe at all the poor, resourceful people and take photos\u201d) and a trip to a Bollywood studio (where \u201cthe foreigners laughed at the dance numbers\u201d).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFlock strives mightily to avoid clich\u00e9, with mixed success. (Take her opening line: \u201cIn Mumbai, people say the monsoons make everyone fall in love.\u201d) And for all its sophistication, the book feels compelled to remind readers of the basics: that caste divisions were said to have originated in ancient India, that Gandhi was father of the nation and so on.", "title": "Marriage Can Take Many Forms in India", "authors": ["Mythili G. Rao", "Elizabeth Flock"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m going,\u201d Ma says.\n\nThis was Mom\u2019s medical condition when I got the call from the nursing home doctor: Bronchitis, the chronic obstructive lung disease getting worse, shortness of breath, and of course her longstanding heart disease and diabetes. There was also a discussion about whether hospice or hospital was preferred.\n\n\u201cDo you believe we\u2019re looking at the beginning of a dying situation here?\u201d I had asked.\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d the doctor said. \u201cWe\u2019re just looking at a change of status, and it could go either way.\u201d\n\nI do think it\u2019s the beginning of the end for my mother \u2014 not this week or even this month, but I do see a sharper downward trajectory. My mother is sleepier these days, more likely to zone out, more anxious. We do not discuss her death, but I know she believes in some sort of afterlife. I do not.\n\nStill there seems to be an image associated with death, of an ascension upward, which many people share. I experienced it years ago myself. I had had an abortion, the psychological aftermath of which was not as simple as I thought it would be, and when I got home, sleeping off the anesthesia, I dreamed of a large cinder, a life that had been snuffed out before it had the opportunity to happen, shooting through space.\n\nWhy was that image of a snuffed-out life moving through space? Why wasn\u2019t it buried in the ground? I understand that nobody wants to dwell on the decay and rot that is a certainty, but why does so much death imagery have to do with moving skyward? One could almost believe there was a biological memory dating to the big bang:\n\nWowza! Did you see that magnificent galactic explosion? I can\u2019t help thinking it\u2019s the beginning of something big. My mother the galaxy. From star stuff I came and to star stuff I shall return. But first, I\u2019d like to grow a face and see Paris.\n\nMy mother was active in two synagogues when she lived in Florida, and one of the things she did was prepare bodies for burial. It\u2019s not disturbing, she told me; it\u2019s an honor. You wash them, you dress them in a shroud, you sit with them until they\u2019re buried so they\u2019re not alone. That traditional Jewish burial was what I figured Ma would want for herself.\n\nIt occurs to me now, however, with Ma\u2019s Mars fixation, that she might, when the time comes, enjoy being cremated and shot into space. \u201cEnjoy\u201d probably isn\u2019t the word, but you know what I\u2019m saying.", "title": "Ground Control to Major Mom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "His rapid rise caught the magpie eyes of all of Europe\u2019s grandest teams. Manchester United, Ajax, Bayern Munich and Liverpool all rolled out the red carpet for Odegaard, but in January 2015, Real Madrid snared him. He would be the jewel in the crown as the club set about buying up all of the best young talent available.\n\nHe was registered for Real\u2019s B team, at the time under the oversight of Zinedine Zidane, but trained most often alongside Cristiano Ronaldo, Gareth Bale and the rest of the club\u2019s senior-team stars. In May of that year, Odegaard made his debut for Real\u2019s senior team. It made him the youngest player to play for the European champions, too.\n\nThat buzz has long since abated. All of the noise that surrounded Odegaard for a year has disappeared. Soccer, impatient, has moved on to other prodigies. As Odegaard \u2014 still just 19, still baby-faced \u2014 dutifully signs autographs and poses for pictures on a bitterly cold night in this city in the north of the Netherlands, it is impossible not to think that he is a long way from Real Madrid, a long way from where he was meant to be, and to wonder whether moving to the biggest team in the world was too much, too soon.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt is impossible to answer that question,\u201d Tore Pedersen, a former Norwegian international defender, said when asked whether Odegaard could have found a more direct route to his goals by choosing another of his suitors. Pedersen, now an agent, consulted on Odegaard\u2019s moves to both Madrid and Heerenveen.\n\nOf far more significance \u2014 to Odegaard and to those concerned with his career \u2014 is that he is, now, in the right place to nurture his talent. In two years at Real Madrid, he made only one start for the first team, in the Copa del Rey. Carlo Ancelotti, the club\u2019s former manager, dismissed his signing as a \u201cPR stunt.\u201d\n\nZidane, who coached him on the B team, would not go that far, but he also did not draft Odegaard into the senior team when he was named manager. In January last year, Odegaard decided he needed an \u201cintermediate step,\u201d the chance to play competitive games somewhere.\n\nPhoto\n\nA loan to Heerenveen was deemed the best option. \u201cIt was a good chance to play,\u201d Pedersen said. \u201cThe culture is similar in Holland to Norway, so it easier to settle, and Heerenveen has a good record with Scandinavian players.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt would be a home away from home, the thinking ran, a more natural progression into the senior game. Morten Thorsby, one of several Norwegians on Heerenveen\u2019s roster, contacted Odegaard to persuade him.\n\nThe Netherlands, too, seemed to offer the right environment to allow him to flourish. \u201cThere is a little bit more space, a little bit more time,\u201d said Stijn Schaars, Heerenveen\u2019s captain, of the style of play in the top division, known as the Eredivisie. \u201cIt is good for young players to grow, to develop the game and the body, before moving on to other leagues.\u201d\n\nThat is not to say it was easy. Odegaard\u2019s first day at the club brought more television cameras than Heerenveen\u2019s manager, Jurgen Streppel, had ever seen. \u201cIt\u2019s what you expect for a European Championship final,\u201d he said. Despite the otherworldly vibe that Odegaard seemed to bring, though, he was still just a teenager, unaccustomed to the stresses and strains of elite soccer. By his own admission, he had \u201cmixed feelings\u201d about his first six months. He passed on a request to be interviewed for this article.\n\nHeerenveen kept its faith. Odegaard asked to be given the coveted No. 10 jersey last summer, and his wish was granted. Streppel promised him he was one of the four key players in his plans for this season, but asked that he try to be more decisive in games.\n\n\u201cHe has to be able to make a difference in Holland in game after game,\u201d Streppel told the Norwegian newspaper VG. \u201cOnly that will be good enough if he is to succeed in a really top team.\u201d\n\nThis season has brought an improvement. Odegaard has scored just one Eredivisie goal in 15 league appearances, and created only one other, but nobody at Heerenveen plays more key passes per game. He is learning, too, to be more vocal. \u201cHe is not a guy with a big mouth,\u201d Schaars said. \u201cBut he is a smart player. Smart players have more vision than normal players, so if you see something, say it.\u201d\n\nThat is why Odegaard is here: to mature, on the field and off it. He has passed his driving test \u2014 when he first arrived, the club issued him a bicycle to help him get around \u2014 and he now lives on his own, after his father, who had lived with him for six months, returned to Norway. He intends to go back to the Bernab\u00e9u as a man, rather than a boy.\n\nThat has always been the aim: to win a place at Real Madrid. He has not forgotten why he is here, and his parent club has not forgotten him, either. Real Madrid is in regular contact with Odegaard, his father and Heerenveen, to monitor his progress. Video of his games is regularly sent back to Madrid, and every so often a scout comes to see him in the flesh.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAgainst Sparta, an observer would not have seen a player who looks ready to displace Ronaldo, or Isco, or any of the other superstars on Real\u2019s books. He may have to go out on loan again before he can make that leap; that decision, Pedersen said, will be made in the summer. But as he was swarmed by fans, they would have seen a boy who still shines, even after three years in the shadows.", "title": "Martin Odegaard\u2019s Second Act on a Smaller Stage", "authors": ["Rory Smith", "On Soccer"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Marty Allen, the frizzy-haired, bug-eyed clown who joined forces with the crooner Steve Rossi to form one of the most successful comedy teams of the 1960s, died on Monday in Las Vegas. He was 95.\n\nHis death was announced on his website.\n\nAllen and Rossi\u2019s humor was not sophisticated \u2014 Mr. Allen\u2019s signature phrase was the succinct exclamation \u201cHello dere!\u201d \u2014 but it was effective. Most of their routines took the form of interviews, with Mr. Rossi asking the questions and Mr. Allen typically playing a befuddled and incompetent (but strangely lovable) astronaut, football player, doctor or other character.\n\nIn one of their best-known routines, Mr. Allen was a punch-drunk boxer.\n\n\u201cWould you say you\u2019re the best fighter in the country?\u201d Mr. Rossi asked him.\n\n\u201cYeah,\u201d he replied fuzzily, \u201cbut in the city they murder me.\u201d\n\nThat kind of comedy was as old as vaudeville if not older. But the material worked thanks to the partners\u2019 personalities, and their chemistry.", "title": "Marty Allen, Wild-Eyed Comedy Star, Is Dead at 95", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "One and the same. True, Tetsu specializes in small plates, but then none of Mr. Takayama\u2019s other restaurants are particularly known for supersizing. What Tetsu does differently is to put away the luxury ingredients that are so central to Masa\u2019s experience and image. At last, New York has a chance to see just how good Mr. Takayama is when he isn\u2019t hiding behind truffles and caviar.\n\nHe can, in fact, make less expensive seafood taste as precious as sturgeon roe. During the bay scallop season, which has an annoying habit of ending before I have eaten enough of them, Tetsu seared them with skinny lengths of asparagus and sent them out with garlic-anchovy oil and lime juice, simmering in a hot bowl. I will be marking this on the calendar so I don\u2019t miss it next winter. For now there is a similar dish that operates on the same principle: tender, palm-size whole octopus sizzled in butter and lime with garlic, chopped cilantro and strands of a green Korean chile.\n\nThe biggest surprise was how much I liked the salads. The menu calls them slaws, which goes a long way toward repairing some of the injuries that word has absorbed over the decades. There is a superb one with fresh kale and fried burdock in an unexpectedly Southeast Asian lemongrass dressing, and another of cabbage and roasted duck stirred with, yes, mayonnaise. (No supermarket mayo, it\u2019s flavored with fresh orange juice and sherry vinegar.) If there was yuzu in the yuzu-daikon slaw, though, it had walked off the job the night I tried it.\n\nItems from the robata, supposedly the heart of the restaurant, were more variable than you would hope. My table went quietly wild for the soy-marinated quail eggs and the pink pork sausage with flecks of yellow and green Thai chiles. Skewered coconut shrimp received polite nods.\n\nWhen you get the menu, though, your eyes will automatically go straight to the raw seafood, and they probably should. It appears twice, the first time in chilled appetizers that can share some of Masa\u2019s delicacy and subtle use of spice. Speckles of finely minced jalape\u00f1os dot little pearly pink bites of hamachi; in a more ordinary case, wasabi has been quickly grated over hunks of yellowfin tuna with a spoonful of simple guacamole.\n\nRaw seafood reappears at the end of the menu as hand rolls and nigiri. Here I have a confession to make: Almost all of my outer-stratosphere moments at Masa happened before the barrage of sushi that ends the meal. Near the end of the game comes a mesmerizing hand roll stuffed with meltingly fatty tuna belly, but the nigiri on its own it would probably not land Masa in my top tier of sushi destinations.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat is roughly my feeling about the sushi at Tetsu. Although the contrast there is less extreme, its nigiri can be inconsistent and is best employed as a short and satisfying last stop, not as the main event.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShould you forge on to dessert, you\u2019ll find that the pastry chef (Matthew O\u2019Haver, who doubles as the service director) does outstanding work: a plate-wide slice of grilled olive oil cake next to a thick stripe of tangy mascarpone; a brownielike chocolate cake made with black-sesame paste and topped with a powerfully appealing miso-caramel sauce; a green-peppercorn ice cream that clamps fire and ice together in a single rich scoop.\n\nAt lunch, the menu is snipped from two pages to one. A little bit is subtracted from each category and two new ones are added: burgers and bowls of squiggly yellow ramen. The ramens are a little smaller and more refined than usual, which may not be top priorities for the average ramen fiend. But given how low in salt and fat they were, relatively speaking, I was impressed by how much flavor made its way into the miso ramen with chashu and the shoyu ramen with very, very good braised short rib.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTetsu\u2019s burgers are cooked in a heated metal contraption with spikes that pierce the meat. Mr. Takayama designed it. I have not seen it, but it sounds like an iron maiden for the stovetop. The spikes are supposed to heat the interior, but the two burgers I\u2019ve had were very rare with a notably dark sear. But the results were very different. I had an immediate, lingering, intensely positive reaction to the lamb burger under melted taleggio, but I would not order the underseasoned and pulpy beef burger with Cheddar again.\n\nThe kitchen may also need more practice on the skinny fries \u2014 \u201cTetsu fries\u201d. Once they were gold and cooked to a fine crackle; another time they were ghostly pale and limp.\n\nThe lunch service is new and still fairly quiet. Dinner, though, can be a racket. If it\u2019s just you, or you and a friend, sitting at the long counter made from a single plank of bubinga wood offers the best shot at privacy. Placed at one of the communal tables in back one night, I ended up next to a group that kept rowdily showing off its expensive wines.\n\nViva Manhattan, I guess?\n\n\u2605\u2605", "title": "Masa\u2019s Chef Comes Out From Behind the Truffles, at Tetsu", "authors": ["Pete Wells", "Restaurant Review"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s not clear that access to mental health care would have prevented violence. Elliot O. Rodger saw several therapists before he killed six people in Isla Vista, Calif., in May 2014. His therapists disagreed on the nature of his mental disorders.\n\nAdam Lanza, who killed 20 children and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School in 2012, had received years of counseling from psychiatrists and psychologists. Though he had Asperger\u2019s syndrome, a mild form of autism that does not suggest violent behavior, he had never been found to have any mental illness that would.\n\nDomestic violence\n\nThe factors that would lead someone to domestic violence are similar to those that would lead someone to mass killings, researchers have found.\n\nQuite often, the crimes overlap. Everytown for Gun Safety, a gun control group, found that 57 percent of mass shooting perpetrators from 2009 to 2015 included a spouse, former spouse or other family member among the victims.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAbout 16 percent of the gunmen in mass shootings during that time period had previously been charged with domestic violence, the group said.\n\nDevin P. Kelley had assaulted his wife and stepson five years before he killed 26 people in Sutherland Springs, Tex., in November, according to the authorities. Robert L. Dear Jr. beat his ex-wife\u2019s head against the floor years before he killed three people at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs in 2015. And Omar Mateen, who killed 49 people in Orlando, Fla., in June 2016, had a history of beating his ex-wife, she told the authorities.\n\n\u201cHaving a history of violence might help neutralize the natural barriers to committing violence,\u201d Paul Gill, a senior lecturer in security and crime science at University College London who studies the behavior of lone-actor terrorists, said in 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSense of grievance\n\nMass killers often believe they have been wronged, whether by an individual, a corporation or demographic group.\n\nDylann Roof, who killed nine people at a church in Charleston, S.C., in 2015, said he hoped to incite a race war. Mr. Rodger raged against women and feminism in corners of the internet.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s become clear over the past 30 years of research is that there\u2019s virtually always a personal grievance that will start a person on a pathway to mass murder,\u201d Dr. J. Reid Meloy, a forensic psychologist who consults on threat assessment for universities and corporations, said in 2015.\n\nDesire for notoriety\n\nMany of the killers had expressed hopes for fame, glory or attention, and had researched prior mass killers. Christopher Harper-Mercer, who killed nine people at a college in Oregon in 2015 before killing himself, wrote in a blog post: \u201cSeems the more people you kill, the more you\u2019re in the limelight.\u201d\n\nDylan Klebold, 17, who, along with Eric Harris, 18, a fellow senior at Columbine High School in Colorado, killed 13 people there in 1999 before committing suicide, said in a video before the massacre that \u201cdirectors will be fighting over this story.\u201d\n\nMark Potok, who researched hate groups and their followers for the Southern Poverty Law Center, said in 2015 that many gunmen turned out to be \u201cpeople who are looking for something larger than their own small lives, to be seen as a hero standing up for a cause.\u201d\n\nSome researchers believe killers feed off the publicity from prior killings, using them as inspiration for their own attacks.\n\n\u201cIf you blast the names and faces of shooters on news stations and constantly repeat their names, there may be an inadvertent process of creating a blueprint,\u201d Dr. Deborah Weisbrot, an associate clinical professor of psychiatry at Stony Brook University who has interviewed hundreds of mostly teenage boys who have made threats, said in 2015.", "title": "Mass Shooters Are All Different. Except for One Thing: Most Are Men.", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "The debate was also closely watched within the art world and drew protesters to the steps of the museum.\n\nProfessional organizations have long held that it is improper for museums to sell art for any reason other than to acquire new works or care for existing ones. Last summer the American Alliance of Museums and the Association of Art Museum Directors issued a joint statement regarding the Berkshire Museum\u2019s plans, saying: \u201cOne of the most fundamental and longstanding principles of the museum field is that a collection is held in the public trust and must not be treated as a disposable financial asset.\u201d\n\nOn Friday the groups thanked the attorney general for examining the sale but lamented the result.\n\n\u201cWhile the negotiated agreement with the Berkshire Museum may satisfy legal standards, it falls far short of ethical standards and best practices for museums,\u201d they wrote. \u201cThis is indeed a sad day for the arts community in the Berkshires and the museum community across the country.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe sales, set to be handled by Sotheby\u2019s, are now likely to go forward, though under the agreement they will stop when proceeds to the museum reach $55 million. The museum may use the first $50 million without restrictions. The agreement stipulates that proceeds between $50 million and $55 million will be held in a fund for acquisitions and to support the museum\u2019s collection.\n\n\u201cThis agreement helps secure the future of the Berkshire Museum for years to come, while preserving \u2018Shuffleton\u2019s Barbershop\u2019 for public view, in keeping with the wishes of Norman Rockwell,\u201d the attorney general, Maura Healey, said in a statement.\n\nElizabeth McGraw, president of the museum\u2019s board, said in a statement that \u201cthis agreement is the promise of a long future for our small but extraordinary museum and its collection.\u201d\n\nAfter its sale, \u201cShuffleton\u2019s Barbershop\u201d will be on display in the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., for 18 to 24 months, under the agreement, and then may be displayed in other museums in the state. The work will ultimately be hung \u201cin a place of prominence within the purchasing museum,\u201d the agreement said, and that institution will consider lending the work to museums in Berkshire County and elsewhere, nationally and internationally.\n\nThe attorney general\u2019s office said that one virtue of the agreement was that it limited the sale of the art to a dollar amount that its investigation showed would be needed to bolster the museum\u2019s finances.\n\n\u201cShuffleton\u2019s Barbershop\u201d had an estimated price at auction of $20 million to $30 million, though it is unclear whether the museum that is planning to buy it has agreed to spend that much.", "title": "Massachusetts Agrees to Allow Berkshire Museum to Sell Its Art", "authors": ["Colin Moynihan"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. \u2014 As the Mets were considering ways to upgrade the team in early December, they listened on trade proposals involving Matt Harvey, who was once called the Dark Knight and thought of as one of the best pitchers in baseball. Harvey was potentially expendable; he was one year away from free agency, and his innings pitched and injuries had taken their toll.\n\nMickey Callaway, the Mets\u2019 new manager, and Dave Eiland, the team\u2019s new pitching coach, watched video of Harvey and talked to him, sensing he was in a good frame of mind. So they told General Manager Sandy Alderson that they wanted an opportunity to work with Harvey. Despite Harvey\u2019s career-worst 6.70 earned run average in 2017, Callaway and Eiland still saw enough embers of ability.\n\n\u201cWe really liked how his stuff was coming out at the end of the season,\u201d Callaway said Thursday. \u201cWe want the challenge of helping this guy out. He deserves it. And when he\u2019s good, the upside is very, very high. We knew if we let this guy go, it\u2019s going to be hard to find another guy with the upside that this kid has.\u201d\n\nHarvey is not a kid anymore. He will be 29 by opening day. His tenure with the team began before Mark Cuban purchased the team in 2000, and he held the job for 18 years, during which the team secured funding for a new arena and won an N.B.A. title, in 2011. He resigned in 2015 to take a position with Under Armour, though he held that job for just three months.\n\nAccording to Sports Illustrated, Ussery had been accused of inappropriate behavior as early as 1998.\n\nIn a statement provided to Sports Illustrated, Ussery said he was not aware of any sexual harassment complaints against him. \u201cI am deeply disappointed that anonymous sources have made such outright false and inflammatory accusations against me,\u201d he said in the statement. \u201cDuring my career with the Mavericks, I have strived to conduct myself with character, integrity and empathy for others.\u201d\n\nCuban, who is one of the league\u2019s most prominent and most public-facing owners, retweeted the team\u2019s statement and responded to the article in a short interview with Sports Illustrated. He was 104.\n\nHis death was confirmed by his son, Barry.\n\nMr. Desfor volunteered to cover the Korean War for the news service when the North invaded the South in June 1950. He parachuted into North Korea with United States troops and retreated with them after forces from the North, joined by the Chinese, pushed south.\n\nHe was in a Jeep near the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, when he spotted a bridge along the Taedong River that had been bombed. Thousands of refugees were lined up on the north bank waiting their turn to cross the river.\n\n\u201cWe came across this incredible sight,\u201d Mr. Desfor said in 1997 for an A.P. oral history. \u201cAll of these people who are literally crawling through these broken-down girders of the bridge. They were in and out of it, on top, underneath, and just barely escaping the freezing water.\u201d", "title": "Max Desfor, 104, War Photographer at Midcentury, Is Dead", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "One area that he will not instruct it to examine will be the issue of outside nonprofit groups created to take donations to support an elected official\u2019s policies, like the Campaign for One New York, which was created for Mr. de Blasio, and whose efforts were later examined by state and federal investigators. Mr. Phillips said it was not necessary because the city had already passed a law limiting donations to such groups.\n\nThe path to election reform is somewhat muddled; most rules governing contribution limits and the matching funds program that provides public money to candidates are derived from legislation passed by the City Council. In addition, the Board of Elections is governed by state law, and it was not clear how it might be altered through changes to the City Charter.\n\nVoters would have to decide on any proposals from the commission in a referendum. Mr. de Blasio\u2019s commission will seek to complete its work in time for voters to consider them in November, Mr. Phillips said.\n\nIn calling for a charter revision, Mr. de Blasio is using a tactic beloved by his two most recent predecessors, Michael R. Bloomberg and Rudolph W. Giuliani, who convened charter revision commissions on some six different occasions. Those commissions were often criticized as being too closely controlled by the mayor and too narrowly focused \u2014 sometimes with the goal of pushing pet projects or political initiatives or seeking policy changes that would have been more appropriately handled as legislation by the City Council.\n\nBefore that, a highly respected charter revision commission was created by Mayor Edward I. Koch and passed by voters in 1989. It led to far-reaching changes in the way city government is organized.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFrederick A.O. Schwarz Jr., the chairman of the 1989 commission, said that he was briefed on the mayor\u2019s proposal by a City Hall aide on Monday and approved of the focus on voting and campaign finance changes. \u201cI think it\u2019s an extremely good idea,\u201d Mr. Schwarz said.\n\nHe said that the key to a successful revision was whether the commission is independent of the mayor. \u201cIt\u2019s a good way to say, \u2018Here are subjects I\u2019d like you to look at,\u2019\u201d Mr. Schwarz said. \u201cIt\u2019s a bad way to say, \u2018Here is what you have to do.\u2019\u201d\n\nA spokeswoman for City Council Speaker Corey Johnson, who has vowed to lead a more independent Council, noted that the Council is considering its own legislation to convene a charter review commission.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat charter revision legislation would create a different sort of commission, whose members would be appointed by the Council, the mayor and other elected officials.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re a little upset because we would like to make sure that it\u2019s a real charter revision and not something you get called five minutes before the appointments are made,\u201d said Gale Brewer, the Manhattan borough president who worked with the public advocate, Letitia James, to have the legislation introduced.\n\nShe said that she would like to see consideration of changes that give the City Council more control over the way money is budgeted and spent by city agencies, among other reforms.\n\n\u201cThe issue is, a charter revision commission should be independent, it should be a wide base of appointments from different entities of city government,\u201d Ms. Brewer said.\n\nMr. de Blasio will announce other programs on Tuesday to encourage voting and other types of civic engagement. Those include an effort to encourage people to participate in the 2020 federal census and a program, to be led by a newly created chief democracy officer, to get more people to register to vote. He will expand a program to encourage 17-year-olds to register to vote and he will provide money to enhance computer security at the Board of Elections.\n\nOn Monday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo proposed adding money to the state budget to provide for a statewide early voting system, in which some polling stations would be open during the 12 days before an election.", "title": "Mayor Wants City Charter Revision to Tackle Campaign Finance", "authors": ["William Neuman"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Hoping to accelerate the closing of the Rikers Island jail complex, city officials on Wednesday announced that they have now chosen sites for four new jails, one in each borough except Staten Island.\n\nThe new facilities in Brooklyn and Manhattan would be located at the site of the jails that currently operate in those boroughs, adjacent to the local courthouses, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Corey Johnson, the City Council speaker, said on Wednesday at a news conference. In Queens, the city would use the site of the former jail near the courts in Kew Gardens.\n\nIn the Bronx, Mr. de Blasio said he would locate a new jail at a Police Department tow pound parking lot in Mott Haven, about two miles from the criminal courthouse. The Council members who represent the districts where the new jails would be located have all endorsed the plan.\n\nMr. de Blasio said there would be no new jail in Staten Island.\n\nAfter long resisting calls to close the Rikers Island complex, the mayor announced last March that he supported shuttering the remote facility, which is plagued by violence and other problems, but said that it would take 10 years.", "title": "Mayor and Council Agree on New Jail Sites to Replace Rikers Island", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Vaccination rates across Europe are lower than in the United States. Various longstanding anti-vaccine movements persist there, and some conservative Protestant sects in Europe believe vaccination subverts God\u2019s will.\n\nTwenty years ago this month, a study of eight children published in The Lancet by Dr. Andrew J. Wakefield suggested that the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine triggered intestinal inflammation and autism. The journal later retracted the paper, and Dr. Wakefield lost his British medical license after it was revealed that he was a paid consultant for attorneys suing vaccine companies.\n\nThe controversy nonetheless triggered a wave of anti-vaccine hysteria. A 2016 survey of 67 countries led by the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine found that skepticism about vaccine safety was highest in France. Skepticism was also high in Russia, Ukraine, Greece and Bosnia-Herzegovina.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe measles outbreaks have led some European countries to crack down. Laws were passed in France, Germany and Italy requiring that parents vaccinate their children or at least consult a doctor about doing so. Italy and Germany imposed fines of $600 to $3,000 for failing to comply.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention currently has Level 1 travel watches in effect for Americans thinking of visiting Britain, Greece, Italy, Romania, Serbia and Ukraine. Travelers under age 60 are advised to have two doses of measles vaccine before going. (Everyone born before 1957 is assumed to have had measles as a child and therefore to be immune.)\n\nThe United States eliminated measles transmission in 2000, but since then there have been sporadic outbreaks caused by infected travelers. In 2015, the \u201cDisneyland outbreak\u201d ultimately led to over 150 cases in seven states. Investigators believe it began with a single theme park visitor who infected 39 others.\n\nAs a result, California outlawed \u201cpersonal belief\u201d exemptions from vaccination requirements for schoolchildren, and vaccination rates shot up.\n\nIn the United States, measles causes pneumonia in about one of 20 cases. One to two cases of measles per 1,000 are fatal; some survivors are left blind or deaf. In countries where children are malnourished and health care is rare, the death rate is as high as 6 percent, the World Health Organization said.\n\nDespite setbacks in Europe, measles vaccine has led to a huge drop in global deaths from the disease. In the 1980s, measles killed 2.6 million a year. In 2016, for the first time since records were kept, deaths fell below 100,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the last two decades, philanthropic donors have paid for 5.5 billion doses for poor countries.", "title": "Measles Cases in Europe Quadrupled in 2017", "authors": ["Donald G. Mcneil Jr.", "Global Health"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Some of us in the boonies must rely entirely on cellular Wi-Fi hot spots. As a result, data usage is a very important consideration, as each gigabyte must be paid for. Fortunately, we have 4G speed, but how much data do services like Instagram or Spotify use? How can one tell how much a YouTube video will consume? Obviously, one can go to a free Wi-Fi locale to see some content, but there are the security issues.\n\nA. The amount of data consumed by sharing and streaming photos, audio and video varies with the quality and size of the files, but quick estimates from a data calculator (like the ones on the AT&T or Verizon Wireless sites) offer a rough idea. Your cellular provider may have its own measures. Nationally, both AT&T and Verizon Wireless estimate uploading a good-quality photo to a social media site like Instagram uses 5 megabytes of data. In comparison, streaming video can chew up 500 to 700 megabytes of data an hour \u2014 and that is for files in the lowest \u201cstandard definition\u201d picture quality.\n\nData usage for streaming music depends on the audio fidelity and service, but plan to use at least 51 megabytes an hour. Spotify, the popular streaming music service, can consume a lot of data at the default settings for its mobile and desktop apps, but you can save megabytes by lowering the audio quality of the stream. For instance, switching to \u201cnormal\u201d from the \u201chigh\u201d quality setting in the mobile app can save you around 30 megabytes per hour of listening time.", "title": "Measuring and Managing Your Cellular Data Use", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor a special occasion, your best friend, sweetheart or spouse deserves the finest dinner you can produce. For many people, that means the simple luxury of steak and potatoes. Instead of going to a crowded restaurant, you can easily pull off this meal at home \u2014 and use the money you save by splurging on an expensive, top-quality cut like rib-eye or tenderloin or strip steak.\n\nOf the three choices, I prefer the rib-eye. It makes the most succulent steak, richly marbled and very tasty. (In France, this cut is called c\u00f4te de boeuf, and considered very special.)\n\nNot to dismiss the milder tenderloin, sliced into filets mignon, but to me those are best pan-fried in butter with a lot of pepper. They are delicious, but not as meaty. Strip loin, or New York strip steak, can be quite lean and thus a bit chewy, but some swear by it. I find it makes a good roast beef, cooked whole.\n\nBut we digress. Assuming you\u2019re going for a high-end steak, you\u2019ll want to stop in a real butcher shop if you can. Or, order from a source you trust. It will cost you, but will still be cheaper than dinner out for two. Rather than buying two pieces for two people, get one large steak, about two inches thick. It will produce juicier, more flavorful meat. Cover it with generous dashes of salt and pepper, a little sliced garlic and some roughly chopped rosemary, then leave it for a while to absorb the seasonings. (You\u2019ll remove the garlic before cooking, as it would burn immediately in the hot skillet.)\n\nPhoto\n\nStart the steak in a scorching hot cast-iron pan on the stovetop, to brown one side well. Flip, then proceed by popping the pan in a hot oven to roast until done in the center and the interior reaches 120 degrees, usually 8 to 10 minutes. Let it rest 10 minutes or so before slicing into wide strips, across the grain. The residual heat will get the steak\u2019s interior to medium-rare.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMy favorite simple potato dish right now is made by boiling the tiny ones called pee-wee (even smaller than baby potatoes) in heavily salted water and tossing them with butter, garlic, parsley and lemon zest. They take but 10 minutes to cook and are fragrant and delicious, with extra potato flavor from the skins. You might substitute your own preferred potato, of course: mashed, baked or otherwise.", "title": "Meat and Potatoes Made Magical", "authors": ["David Tanis", "City Kitchen"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhat kind of meatballs are these? It\u2019s a fair question: Meatballs come in countless variations. You could make them every week for a year, never repeating a recipe. It is a culinary common thread that runs through albondigas, polpettini, boulettes, kofte \u2014 all spherical morsels of finely chopped meat.\n\nThe origin of the meatball is hardly a mystery. When an animal is butchered, there are a limited number of primal cuts, the tender parts that are turned into chops, steaks and roasts. The rest of the beast is used for stewing or put through the meat grinder to become burgers, sausages, meatloaf or meatballs. For many cooks and diners, the bite-size meatball is the most appealing.\n\nAll meatballs begin the same way. Freshly ground meat is mixed with seasonings and a bit of bread or rice before being rolled into balls. (Nearly all recipes advise forming them with wet hands.) They are then browned on the stovetop or in the oven, to be eaten as is, simmered in a sauce or added to a soup.\n\nThis recipe, made with ground lamb, has a Turkish feel, spiced with cumin, coriander, cinnamon and a touch of cayenne. The meatballs are browned in olive oil \u2014 though flattening them into patties to be griddled or grilled would be another good choice \u2014 and served with a traditional yogurt sauce.\n\nPhoto\n\nSome cooks braise their meatballs after browning, which renders them exceedingly moist, soft and tender. In this rendition, I like them straight out of the frying pan, crisp on the outside and juicy inside.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe warm, tart yogurt sauce adds tang and richness, especially when made with whole-milk yogurt. It is prepared at the last minute, just before serving. A beaten egg and a little cornstarch are added to prevent the yogurt from curdling when heated.", "title": "Meatballs That Take a Cue From Turkey", "authors": ["David Tanis", "City Kitchen"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA new website from Porter Road, a chef-owned butcher shop in Nashville, sells meat from small farms, delivered fresh, nationally and within two days. James Peisker and Chris Carter opened their store in 2011 after having difficulty finding meat that satisfied them for their fledgling catering company. The meats and poultry are pasture-raised by farmers who do not use antibiotics or hormones on the animals. The Porter Road partners do their own butchering, dry-age meats for 14 days, and offer a range of cuts, though some are limited and wait-listed. Prices and shipping charges are moderate. My Kansas City bone-in strip loin, a little more than a pound, was $21, for example: Porter Road, porterroad.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Meats and Poultry Just a Click Away", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Her death came amid a national debate over police shootings and prompted protests in New York, led by elected leaders.\n\nSergeant Barry\u2019s lawyer, Andrew C. Quinn, said in his opening statement that his client talked in a calm voice to Ms. Danner when he arrived at the apartment and persuaded her to lay down a pair of scissors. But after he could not persuade her to come farther than the doorway of her bedroom, he and other officers tried to subdue her. She retreated into the bedroom and picked up a bat. He drew his gun and told her to drop it. She began to swing it at him and he fired twice, Mr. Quinn said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Ms. Danner insisted that she be allowed to speak to a medical technician rather than the police officers, who had backed off and had let Ms. Mullings take the lead.\n\nMs. Mullings said she entered the apartment and stood a few feet from Ms. Danner, who had nothing in her hands. She tried to explain to the distraught woman why the police had been called. Ms. Danner was no longer screaming, she said, but was still agitated and was talking loudly.\n\n\u201cShe was still trying to figure out who called 911 and why we were there,\u201d Ms. Mullings said.\n\nWhile they were talking, Sergeant Barry arrived and passed behind Ms. Mullings into the living room. Ms. Mullings said that the sergeant conferred with another officer a few feet behind her, but that he did not speak to her or to Ms. Danner.\n\nMs. Mullings said she told Ms. Danner that the medics wanted only to check on her health. \u201cI didn\u2019t really get to finish the conversation with her,\u201d she recalled.\n\nShe said she heard someone behind her say, \u201cAre you ready?\u201d\n\n\u201cReady for what?\u201d Ms. Danner said.\n\nAll at once, Ms. Danner turned and \u201cscurried back\u201d into her bedroom, Ms. Mullings said, followed by the six officers. A minute later, she heard an officer yell, \u201cGet down!\u201d and then two shots.", "title": "Medic Offers Sharply Different Account of Woman\u2019s Death at Hands of Police", "authors": ["James C. Mckinley Jr."]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "The overlapping issues of health care and employment discrimination remain pivotal ones for transgender communities. They became more so last month, when the Trump administration decided to allow states to institute work requirements for Medicaid.\n\nThe unemployment rate for trans people is three times higher than the national average, according to a 2015 survey produced by the National Center for Transgender Equality \u2014 a rate that results, in many cases, from anti-trans job discrimination. These new rules create a double bind for the most vulnerable trans people: Find work amid rampant prejudice and mistreatment, or lose critical medical coverage.\n\nIn Kentucky, the first state to adopt work requirements, one in four transgender people report losing a job, being passed over for a promotion or not being hired because they are trans. The majority of states considering adopting work requirements are among the 30 in which gender identity is not considered a protected category. Of the 10 states currently carrying out or proposing Medicaid work requirements, only two \u2014 Maine and Utah \u2014 have an employment nondiscrimination law in place that protects trans workers. In contrast, Arkansas and North Carolina have state-level bans on local nondiscrimination ordinances that would safeguard the rights of queer and trans communities.\n\nStatistics regarding transgender people who lose their jobs because of their gender identities reveal only the cases in which such bias was blatant. Lost within these numbers are the more ambiguous stories \u2014 of managers who may have rejected a request for a uniform that reflected an employee\u2019s gender, workers terminated for requests to change their names on internal documents or employees whose presence was shown, through the actions of colleagues and superiors, to be unwelcome.", "title": "Opinion | Medicaid Work Requirements Are Yet Another Burden for Trans Workers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "The world\u2019s first transorbital lobotomy was performed in 1946 by Walter Freeman, in his Washington office. Using an ice pick from his own kitchen, he went through the eye sockets into the brain of his patient, a 29-year-old severely depressed housewife, and cut into her frontal lobes. Then he sent her home in a cab.\n\nThe history of mental illness treatments reveals medicine at its most inventive, desperate and disturbing. There have been awe-inspiring discoveries \u2014 of the healing properties of lithium, for example, a soft, silvery metal produced in the first 20 minutes after the Big Bang. But remedies generally seem to have run a narrow gamut from the unpleasant (Cotton Mather\u2019s prescription for depression: \u201cliving swallows, cut in two, and laid hot reeking unto the shaved Head\u201d) to the outright sadistic. Aside from Freeman\u2019s lobotomies, there is a long tradition of poisoning patients or inducing comas to \u201creset\u201d the brain. In one notorious treatment, turpentine was injected into a patient\u2019s abdominal wall in the hope of encouraging a fever high enough to burn away her hallucinations.\n\nWe\u2019re lucky to live in more evidence-based, scientific times. Or do we? In \u201cBlue Dreams,\u201d a capacious and rigorous history of psychopharmacology, the psychologist and writer Lauren Slater looks at the fact that despite our ravenous appetite for psychotropic medications (about 20 percent of Americans take some psychotropic drug or other), doctors don\u2019t really understand how they work or how to assess if a patient needs them. In the case of antidepressants, two-thirds of patients taking an S.S.R.I. (Prozac, Zoloft, Celexa, etc.) would improve on a placebo alone.\n\nStill the misconception that depression is a matter of \u201clow serotonin\u201d persists. \u201cThere is no proof that a depressed person has a chemical imbalance,\u201d Slater writes. \u201cWhen you choose nevertheless to put that person on a medication that will alter neurotransmitter levels in his or her brain, then in effect you are causing a chemical imbalance rather than curing one.\u201d", "title": "Medicine Can Soothe a Troubled Mind, but Not Without Costs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Zinareen Anas, 36, Militia Commander\n\nMs. Anas is the Euphrates Valley commander of the Women\u2019s Protection Forces, a Kurdish militia that is part of the S.D.F. Like many of her fellow commanders, she has been wounded in battle, while fighting in Kobani in 2014. \u201cOur commanders all lead from the front,\u201d she said. Ms. Anas fought alongside the American military in Manbij, Shadade and Al Haul, and last year in Raqqa and Deir al-Zour. The American Special Operations units always had one or two American women, and they were quick to bond with their Kurdish counterparts, she said. Some of them were chagrined, she said, when they realized the Kurds were way ahead of them in battlefield equality. \u201cThey had limited powers compared to us,\u201d she said. \u201cWe can make decisions and everything without a man approving them, and they can\u2019t easily do that. So you could say we\u2019re more advanced than the American military, that way.\u201d During the Raqqa and Manbij fights, the women\u2019s militia could sometimes listen in on Islamic State radio conversations. \u201cIt drove Daesh crazy to think women were fighting against them,\u201d she said. \u201cThey used to say, \u2018Let\u2019s get one of their heads.\u2019 \u201d They never did; no Kurdish woman was captured alive by the extremists, she said. \u201cWith Daesh, we always kept one bullet or one grenade for ourselves, and fought to the last breath.\u201d", "title": "Meet America\u2019s Syrian Allies Who Helped Defeat ISIS", "authors": ["Rod Nordland"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "JOHANNESBURG \u2014 Cyril Ramaphosa, who was sworn in Thursday as South Africa\u2019s president, recently did what many politicians do at pivotal points in their careers.\n\nHe released a book.\n\nThe book told of one of his passions \u2014 his love for a Ugandan breed of royal cattle that he imported to South Africa at great expense. Anticipating criticism of his wealth in a country where millions still live in shacks, Mr. Ramaphosa argued at his book launch that the cattle were not meant as trophies for the elite like him, but to help struggling black farmers in South Africa.\n\nNow, Mr. Ramaphosa, the former labor leader who Nelson Mandela had hoped would succeed him as president, has an even trickier argument to make as the nation\u2019s new leader replacing Jacob Zuma, who was forced to resign this week.", "title": "Meet Cyril Ramaphosa, South Africa\u2019s New President and a Mandela Favorite", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "This triennial \u201cisn\u2019t about making art stars,\u201d said Lisa Phillips, the director of the New Museum, \u201cbut looking at whether there are similarities and affinities across cultures among an emerging generation of artists.\u201d Of course, in years past some stars have risen: Danh Vo, for example, whose survey at the Guggenheim Museum opens on Feb. 9, and Adri\u00e1n Villar Rojas, who transformed the Cantor Roof Garden at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last year, both gained from exposure in the 2012 triennial, \u201cThe Ungovernables.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhen all of us are feeling the fire of youth, young people\u2019s voices have really come to the fore, particularly in the last year,\u201d said Tom Eccles, the executive director at the Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College, who is not affiliated with the New Museum. The challenge of the triennial, compared with surveys like the Whitney Biennial and the Venice Biennale, where most of the participants are already known, is to find \u201cartists we ultimately can believe in,\u201d he said.\n\nThat will be determined by time. Mr. Carrion-Murayari, 37, and Mr. Gartenfeld, 31, the deputy director and chief curator at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Miami, made nearly two dozen trips around the world, to places where artist communities weren\u2019t digitally accessible. \u201cWe really made a focus of looking at artist-run and alternative spaces as ways of questioning how global art markets have been growing,\u201d Mr. Gartenfeld said.\n\nA shared mind-set that emerged among the chosen \u2014 many showing in the United States for the first time \u2014 is \u201cthe recognition that what we\u2019re experiencing today is the continuation of colonialism that has never truly ended,\u201d Mr. Carrion-Murayari said. Artists like Daniela Ortiz from Peru and Cian Dayrit from the Philippines speak in very similar ways about \u201cethnic and racist divisions that were put in place\u201d during the colonial period, the curator said, and they are responding with subversive gestures.", "title": "Meet Six Disrupters at the New Museum\u2019s Triennial", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "With her victory in the snowboarding giant slalom on Saturday Ester Ledecka of the Czech Republic joined the short list of athletes who have won medals in two different disciplines in the same Olympic Games. She also won the gold medal in super-G.\n\nBut no matter how impressive her accomplishments, she has a way to go to surpass Walter Winans, a forgotten American Olympian who was one of the great renaissance men of his time.\n\nWinans won a gold medal in shooting in London in 1908, then won a silver in Stockholm in 1912. But he also won a gold medal that year in a different event entirely. Sculpture. Yes, the Olympics held art competitions from 1912 to 1948. The categories included architecture, literature, music, painting and sculpture.\n\nThe art competitions were no sideshow, but a serious part of the Olympics program. Igor Stravinsky was even recruited as a judge for the 1924 music competition in Paris. (He stingily awarded no gold, silver or bronze medals.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWinans\u2019s winning sculpture, \u201cAn American Trotter,\u201d beat out a strong field of eight that included silver medalist Georges Dubois, a French hurdler, who entered the seemingly more appropriate \u201cModel of the Entrance to a Modern Stadium.\u201d Also in the field was Prince Paolo Trubetskoy of Russia, a friend of Tolstoy, and Rembrandt Bugatti of Italy, younger brother of the car manufacturer.\n\nPhoto\n\nWinans is the only person to win gold in a sport and an art. Alfred Hajos won two gold medals in swimming in 1896, in the 100 and 1,200 meter freestyle, then turned up in 1924 seeking architecture gold. But his design for a sports stadium could only muster a silver.", "title": "Meet Walter Winans, the Ultimate Two-Event Olympic Medalist", "authors": ["Victor Mather"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Megan Kate Josephson and Dr. Ariel Robert Gitlin were married Feb. 24 in Manhattan. In a series of emails, she copied a lawyer from the New York-based law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison and wrote, \u201cThere have been a number of unfair and untrue statements about me and I am reserving all rights.\u201d\n\nMs. Winston Wolkoff made her name planning society galas in New York, including the Costume Institute Gala, also known as the Met Gala, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Over the years, she worked closely on the gala with the Vogue editor Anna Wintour. Mr. Monn also worked on the gala, which embodies an exclusive vibe that is in many ways incongruous with the messaging to blue-collar voters that Mr. Trump projected during the 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nThat discordance attracted notice when Ms. Winston Wolkoff was retained by the inaugural committee, which was led by the California real estate investor Thomas J. Barrack Jr., a longtime friend of Mr. Trump\u2019s.\n\nMrs. Trump had introduced Ms. Winston Wolkoff to Mr. Barrack, according to a person familiar with the connection. But the decision to hire Ms. Winston Wolkoff was Mr. Barrack\u2019s, said an operative who worked with the inaugural committee.\n\nMs. Winston Wolkoff often invoked her friendship with Mrs. Trump when talking with officials on the Trump transition team and then in the East Wing, according to three people with direct knowledge of her interactions.\n\nThe inaugural committee promised that the swearing-in ceremonies and events would be \u201cworkmanlike,\u201d even as it raised a record-shattering $107 million \u2014 about twice as much as former President Barack Obama\u2019s inaugural committee raised for the festivities around his 2009 swearing-in \u2014 largely from wealthy donors and corporations.\n\nThe majority of those funds \u2014 more than $57 million \u2014 went to four event-planning companies. The company that received the biggest payment was Ms. Winston Wolkoff\u2019s firm, which was incorporated in California in December 2016 \u2014 about six weeks before the inauguration.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe operative who worked with the inaugural committee said that Ms. Winston Wolkoff\u2019s firm handled everything from securing venues and table settings to arranging Instagram filters and satellite feeds, as well as the transportation of heavy equipment.\n\nAn inaugural committee official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the official was not authorized to discuss the details publicly, said Ms. Winston Wolkoff\u2019s firm also paid the team used by Mark Burnett, the creator of \u201cThe Apprentice,\u201d whose involvement in the inaugural festivities was requested by Mr. Trump.\n\nMr. Barrack had praised Ms. Winston Wolkoff, saying that she \u201cexecuted her duties well.\u201d\n\nMr. Monn\u2019s $3.7 million payment from the inaugural committee was primarily to plan two events, one of which was billed as a \u201ccandlelight dinner\u201d attended by Mr. and Mrs. Trump and Vice President Mike Pence and his wife, Karen, according to the operative who worked with the committee.\n\nMr. Monn, who had planned a state dinner for Mr. Obama\u2019s White House, said he was \u201cflattered\u201d and \u201chonored\u201d when Ms. Winston Wolkoff asked him to help with the inauguration. He said he \u201creceived some very unpleasant comments\u201d from people when his work on the inauguration was made public, but he said: \u201cI actually consider myself a patriot. I am not a politician.\u201d\n\nMs. Winston Wolkoff said Mr. Monn \u201cis an exceptional event planner who is universally respected for his design and d\u00e9cor expertise.\u201d", "title": "Melania Trump Parts Ways With Adviser Amid Backlash Over Inaugural Contract", "authors": ["Kenneth P. Vogel", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Elizabeth Alexander, whose memoir was a finalist in 2016 for the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award and who wrote and recited an original poem at Barack Obama\u2019s 2009 inaugural, will be the next president of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the country\u2019s largest humanities philanthropy.\n\n\u201cAll of the things that I\u2019ve cared about my whole life and worked toward my whole life Mellon does,\u201d said Ms. Alexander in a telephone interview, citing areas like higher education and scholarship, arts and cultural heritage, and diversity.\n\nShe added that \u201carts and humanities are not the most protected entities right now.\u201d\n\nMs. Alexander succeeds Earl Lewis, who has served since 2013.
