Weiss, whose avalanche of class-action lawsuits made him a pariah to corporate America, a hero to plaintiffs, a catalyst for legal protections of investors and consumers, and finally a felon, died on Friday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 82.\n\nThe cause was amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, his son Stephen A. Weiss, a partner in the law firm Seeger Weiss, said.\n\nMr. Weiss was a pro bono lawyer for terrorism victims and other causes, a fund-raiser for Democrats and a leader of the Israel Policy Forum, which favors a two-state solution to the Palestinian conflict. He and his wife, the former Barbara Joan Kaplan, sponsored a program in public-interest law at his alma mater, New York University Law School.\n\nBut he was best known for building a fledgling law firm into a powerhouse that compelled miscreant and recalcitrant businesses to pay billions of dollars to aggrieved shareholders and customers.", "title": "Melvyn Weiss, Lawyer Who Fought Corporate Fraud, Dies at 82", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cLet\u2019s Ban Porn,\u201d by Ross Douthat (column, Feb. 11):\n\nA populace is better served when legislation aims to support and reflect shared values rather than to enforce and project desired outcomes. In other words, a top-down legislative approach seems destined for failure unless it is supported by what people want.\n\nIn the realm of heterosexual porn, at least, we\u2019re not there yet.\n\nI hope that, through discussion, men might listen to and support women\u2019s concerns about porn, and I hope that women might resist the desire for male approbation gained by \u201cbeing cool\u201d with it.\n\nI hope that discussions about porn might address principles of trust and respect, and, the seemingly old-fashioned idea that these may be connected to libido.\n\nOne of the strongest parts of Mr. Douthat\u2019s column comes near the end: \u201cour larger inability to imagine any escape from the online world\u2019s immersive power, even as we harbor growing doubts about its influence upon our psyches.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Men, Women and Talking About Pornography", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "We\u2019re interested in your feedback on this page. Tell us what you think.", "title": "Men\u2019s Wear, Without Rules", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The German carmaker Daimler publicly apologized on Tuesday after its Mercedes-Benz brand caused an outcry in China by quoting the Dalai Lama in a social media post.\n\nThe move by the automaker is the latest example of a foreign company being cowed by the growing power of a critical, but increasingly nationalistic, consumer market. Many in China view the Dalai Lama as a dangerous voice for separatism in a region, Tibet, that they consider an integral part of their country.\n\nThe post on the Mercedes-Benz Instagram account, which was widely viewed before being deleted, carried the hashtag \u201c#MondayMotivation\u201d and showed a white Mercedes car on a beach. It featured a quote popularly attributed to the Dalai Lama: \u201cLook at the situations from all angles, and you will become more open.\u201d", "title": "Mercedes-Benz Quotes the Dalai Lama. China Notices. Apology Follows.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The special counsel\u2019s team has uncovered a vast organizational operation that the Russians started building in 2014, and accelerated with a budget of over $1.25 million monthly during the 2016 election. The Russians did not just go after Hillary Clinton in the general election. They also undertook efforts primarily intended \u201cto denigrate other candidates such as Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio,\u201d according to the indictment. If it wasn\u2019t clear before today: The threat to our country includes Russia\u2019s attempts to sow discord among Americans in general, and to shape the Republican primaries. We all stand to lose by being robbed of our democratic choices.\n\nTrying to get beyond partisan politics, it was a wise move to have Rod Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, a Republican, publicly announce the indictments by Mr. Mueller, a Republican, for Russian activities not only to hurt Hillary Clinton but also Republican candidates for president. It was also a good symbol to elevate the public\u2019s understanding of the seriousness of Mr. Rosenstein\u2019s charge and why he has such great confidence in Mr. Mueller.\n\nAnd yet Friday\u2019s indictments cover just one part of the multiheaded Russian operation. They detail the Russians\u2019 use of social media platforms to shape preferences and to engineer political rallies. A separate F.B.I. team is investigating Russian agents for hacking the Democratic National Committee during the election. Mr. Mueller is reportedly keenly interested in Russian agents\u2019 offering \u201cdirt\u201d on Mrs. Clinton to campaign associates of Mr. Trump. And then there\u2019s still the issue of Russian collaboration with WikiLeaks. As with his previous indictments, Mr. Mueller kept the rest of his hand closely guarded.\n\nIt is the case that this round of indictments may help build a future case for any Americans who aided and abetted or conspired with the Russians in any of the Kremlin\u2019s different operations to interfere in the election. Mr. Mueller obviously now appears to have not just intelligence information but also sufficient evidence for a criminal trial. And he has that evidence to prove a Russian conspiracy in \u201cimpairing, obstructing, and defeating the lawful functions of the government through fraud and deceit for the purpose of interfering with the U.S. political and electoral processes, including the presidential election of 2016.\u201d That\u2019s a mouthful, but it captures the scope of the criminal case.\n\nThe indictment tells us that some Trump campaign associates, especially at the grass-roots level, cooperated with the Russians \u201cunwittingly.\u201d That makes sense. As Mr. Rosenstein explained, in answer to a reporter\u2019s question, these parts of the operation depended on Russians\u2019 disguising their identities and duping innocent Americans. According to Mr. Mueller\u2019s other criminal court documents, that was certainly not the case when it came to Russian overtures to more senior levels of the Trump campaign, for example, in offering dirt on Mrs. Clinton in the form of \u201cthousands of emails.\u201d\n\nBut let the chips fall where they may. If Americans deliberately assisted the Kremlin\u2019s \u201cinformation warfare against the United States of America,\u201d we need to know about it \u2014 at the very least as part of a counterintelligence investigation. If these Americans were \u201cunwitting,\u201d it is important to know how the Russians exploit such vulnerabilities and for Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation to educate the government and the public.", "title": "Opinion | Message to Trump: Let Mueller Do His Job", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "The art installation on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is always a much-anticipated rite of spring.\n\nThis year, the Pakistani artist Huma Bhabha has been selected to create a site-specific work for the roof garden, the sixth in a series of commissions for the outdoor space, which will be on view from April 17 through Oct. 28.\n\n\u201cHuma Bhabha\u2019s work is powerful and arresting, informed by a deep and sophisticated engagement with art history, architectural space, an interest in popular iconographies and keenly responsive to political narratives, both historic and current,\u201d said Shanay Jhaveri, an assistant curator of South Asian art at the Met, \u201cwhich makes her the right artist at this time for the commission.\u201d\n\nFor the multipart installation, \u201cWe Come in Peace,\u201d Ms. Bhabha has \u201cchoreographed a dramatic mise en scene\u201d of monumental sculptures, Mr. Jhaveri said.", "title": "Met Selects Pakistani Artist for Roof Garden Commission", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "But meth, it turns out, was only on hiatus. When the ingredients became difficult to come by in the United States, Mexican drug cartels stepped in. Now fighting meth often means seizing large quantities of ready-made product in highway stops.\n\nThe cartels have inundated the market with so much pure, low-cost meth that dealers have more of it than they know what to do with. Under pressure from traffickers to unload large quantities, law enforcement officials say, dealers are even offering meth to customers on credit. In Portland, the drug has made inroads in black neighborhoods, something experienced narcotics investigators say was unheard-of five years ago.\n\n\u201cI have been involved with meth for the last 25 years. A wholesale plummet of price per pound, combined with a huge increase of purity, tells me they have perfected the production or manufacturing of methamphetamine,\u201d said Steven Bell, a spokesman for the Drug Enforcement Administration. \u201cThey have figured out the chemical reactions to get the best bang for their bucks.\u201d\n\nNearly 100 percent pure and about $5 a hit, the new meth is all the more difficult for users to resist. \u201cWe\u2019re seeing a lot of longtime addicts who used crack cocaine switch to meth,\u201d said Branden Combs, a Portland officer assigned to the street crimes unit. \u201cYou ask them about it, and they\u2019ll say: \u2018Hey, it\u2019s half the price, and it\u2019s good quality.\u2019\u201d\n\nNationally, nearly 6,000 people died from stimulant use \u2014 mostly meth \u2014 in 2015, a 255 percent increase from 2005, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The percentage of the nation\u2019s drug overdose toll that was attributed to stimulants inched up to 11 percent of the deaths.\n\nUnited States Customs and Border Protection statistics show that in the past five years, the amount of meth seized has tripled, while the seizures for other drugs have declined or had only modest increases.\n\nIn Oregon, 232 people died from meth use in 2016, nearly twice as many as died from heroin \u2014 and three times as many as died from meth 10 years before, according to the state Department of Health.", "title": "Meth, the Forgotten Killer, Is Back. And It\u2019s Everywhere.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The upgrades are meant to enhance the reliability and security of processing debit and credit card transactions, according to the M.T.A. The city\u2019s more than 2,700 MetroCard machines process about 800,000 transactions each day. A spokesman for the M.T.A., Shams Tarek, said the disruption was necessary to make the improvements. \u201cIt is like any computer, right?\u201d he said. \u201cYou can\u2019t operate a computer while you\u2019re replacing the software.\u201d\n\nMetroCard machines were introduced at the turn of the century. In the last 14 years, there have been three major system upgrades, according to information provided by the agency. There are also periodic outages on Saturdays between 2 a.m. and 3 a.m. while the system is backed up.\n\n\u201cThey are trying to extend the life of this equipment that truly should have been replaced by now,\u201d said Richard Barone, the vice president for transportation for the Regional Plan Association, an urban research and policy organization. \u201cWe are working with equipment that is going to need continuing investment to continue to work.\u201d\n\nCorey Johnson, the City Council speaker, said the new schedule was an improvement. But the enraged reaction from riders pointed to the subway\u2019s bigger problems, he said, of endemic delays, crumbling infrastructure and deep unreliability that led Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who controls the M.T.A., to declare a state of emergency and unfurl a $836 million plan last summer to turn around the troubled system.\n\n\u201cIt is emblematic of just complete and total mutiny and unabated anger at the M.T.A. for the daily abuses that riders have to endure,\u201d he said. \u201cIf this was an isolated incident on its own, people may have shrugged and dealt with it, but given everything else, this became a rallying cry.\u201d\n\nBy 2023, MetroCards will be phased out entirely; fares will be paid with contactless readers that can deduct from credit and debit cards, similar to transit payment systems in London and other cities. Mr. Barone said that the new system would not likely need to be taken offline for updates. Unlike the MetroCard machines, which do much of the processing of transactions themselves, the new system will process payments in a back-end computer system.\n\nThe debacle over the upgrade, Mr. Johnson said, underscores the need for that more modern fare collection technology.\n\n\u201cIn the meantime, things might be clunky and unacceptable,\u201d he said. \u201cBut this is an improvement until we get a state-of-the-art technology system.\u201d", "title": "MetroCard Machines Won\u2019t Accept Credit Cards This Weekend (Briefly)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Mets made their long-awaited move to solidify their infield, and they did so with a familiar face in New York. Late Monday, they agreed to a deal with third baseman Todd Frazier for two years and $17 million, according to multiple people familiar with the contract who requested anonymity because the deal was pending a physical examination.\n\nFrazier, a native of Toms River, N.J., who will turn 32 next week, played a crucial role for the Yankees in the second half of last season after they acquired him from the Chicago White Sox in July. With the Mets, he will bring power, a reliable glove at third, a fair amount of strikeouts, and a strong presence in the clubhouse. Between the White Sox and Yankees last season, Frazier hit .213 but posted a career-high .344 on-base percentage along with 27 home runs and 76 R.B.I.\n\nIn his six full major league seasons, Frazier has averaged 28 home runs and 132 strikeouts. His addition will allow the Mets to move Asdrubal Cabrera to second base, where Cabrera is more comfortable.\n\nIn an unusually depressed free agent market, the Mets have spent $72.5 million this winter on five players. At the start of the off-season, the Mets\u2019 payroll was expected to drop, angering some fans. But the Mets have taken advantage of the market and added help to a roster that missed the playoffs and went 70-92 in 2017.", "title": "Mets Sign Todd Frazier to Two-Year Deal", "authors": ["James Wagner"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "What do you do, in broad strokes, to keep your communications secure?\n\nThe least tech-forward thing you can imagine: I meet face to face with people.\n\nI tend to avoid messaging or talking about specific work targets on my main Mexican phone. I\u2019m pretty sure I was sent Pegasus, the spyware purchased by the Mexican government, and though I\u2019ve wiped that phone and replaced it, I\u2019m cautious. I use the typical encrypted apps for communications and maintain several phones, which I use for different purposes. It\u2019s annoying lugging all of them around, and I get funny looks at the airport when I toss three phones into the scanner basket. It\u2019s also a pain keeping them all charged.\n\nHow has the tech landscape changed in Mexico over the years? Is there a lot of tech start-up activity?\n\nLots has been written about the booming tech scene in Mexico, in particular in the city of Guadalajara, which is the latest place to be given some kind of Silicon Valley moniker. There are a bunch of start-ups there, taking advantage of the tens of thousands of engineering graduates coming out of prestigious programs in Mexico every year.\n\nIs it a game-changer? I don\u2019t know, to be honest. The entrepreneurs and officials here were trying to drum up support for recruiting foreign-born Silicon Valley engineers, to take advantage of President Trump\u2019s immigration policies. Not sure that went anywhere past the headlines, though.\n\nWhat are the most popular kinds of websites or apps or gadgets in Mexico?\n\nWaze is especially popular in Mexico. In Mexico City, where I live, traffic is a force of nature. So if you don\u2019t find the best way to get through it, you\u2019re going to spend some nauseating hours stuck in the car. For me, and for a ton of others living here, Waze is essential unless you\u2019re an old-school cabby who happens to know the city.\n\nOutside work, what gadget or software do you currently find yourself using a lot and why?\n\nI live a relatively low-tech existence. I\u2019ve never been an early adopter of the latest tech \u201cit\u201d item; my phones are really the only technology I can\u2019t function without.", "title": "Mexico Has Its Spyware. A Reporter Has a Few Phones to Juggle.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "MEXICO CITY \u2014 Fuel thieves in Mexico drilled 10,363 illegal taps into state-owned pipelines in 2017, or an average of about 28 every day.\n\nThe government-owned oil company Pemex reported Wednesday that illegal taps rose about 50 percent last year, from 6,873 in 2016.\n\nThose are just the taps that have been found. Many others are believed to be still working surreptitiously, drawing off gasoline or diesel that is sold illegally by vendors or even through established gas stations.\n\nPemex said in a statement that the authorities had closed 70 gas stations for selling presumably stolen fuel to drivers. The company said patrols and other surveillance were increased and that almost four million gallons of stolen fuel had been recovered.", "title": "Mexico Reports Record Number of Illegal Taps Into Fuel Pipelines", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "MEXICO CITY \u2014 American officials have rebuffed repeated requests from Mexico to help investigate the use of government spying technology against innocent civilians, wary that Mexico wants to use the United States as cover in a sham inquiry, senior American officials say.\n\nThe Mexican government has been on the defensive for months, battling revelations that surveillance technology it acquired has been used to spy on some of the nation\u2019s most prominent human rights lawyers, academics and journalists.\n\nDays after The New York Times revealed the extensive spying campaign, Mexico\u2019s president, Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto, acknowledged that the government had purchased the spying technology. He quickly ordered a federal investigation into any misuse, and Mexican officials said they would ask the F.B.I. for help.\n\nBut after reviewing the request, American officials decided not to get involved, leery that the Mexican government had little interest in actually solving the case because a serious investigation might implicate some of its most powerful figures, senior American officials said.", "title": "Mexico Spyware Inquiry Bogs Down. Skeptics Aren\u2019t Surprised.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Carvalho grew up poor in Lisbon, Portugal, and was the first in his family to graduate from high school. At the age of 17, he flew to New York on a visa that he then overstayed. In New York, he washed dishes and worked as a busboy in restaurants. He made his way to Florida, where he worked in construction. He has said that at one point he spent a month being homeless, sleeping in a friend\u2019s U-Haul truck. In a restaurant where he worked as a waiter, he met Representative E. Clay Shaw, a Republican congressman from the area, who helped him gain a student visa.\n\nMr. Carvalho has spent his entire career in the Miami-Dade school system, starting as a teacher at Miami Jackson Senior High, where he taught physics, chemistry and calculus. He went on to become an assistant principal, a lobbyist for the district, and an associate superintendent. He took over the district from Rudy Crew, himself a former New York City schools chancellor.\n\nHe has been an outspoken critic of President Trump\u2019s immigration policies and defender of undocumented immigrants.\n\n\u201cOver my dead body will anyone walk into our schools and yank any child from the sanctity and the protection that schools, as sanctuaries of the young, provide,\u201d he said in a speech last November. (This was perhaps more political rhetoric than a practical statement of policy. As a general rule, Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents do not go into schools, which are considered \u201csensitive locations.\u201d)\n\nNew York City\u2019s most prominent chancellor in recent years was Joel I. Klein, whom Mr. Bloomberg appointed in 2002, shortly after he won mayoral control of the schools, and who served until 2010. Mr. Klein was considered a leader in the national education reform movement, and pioneered the practice of closing low-performing schools and replacing them with new schools on a large scale.\n\nThe mayor\u2019s press secretary, Mr. Phillips, said that Ms. Fari\u00f1a would leave in the next month but that Mr. Carvalho did not have an official start date yet. Mr. Phillips said that the mayor and Mr. Carvalho met twice, once in January and once in February. On this day in 2012, Kim Jong-il, who led the country from 1994 until his death in 2011, was posthumously named a \u201cgeneralissimo.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe announcement came two days before what would have been Mr. Kim\u2019s 70th birthday, which is still celebrated in the country as \u201cThe Day of the Shining Star.\u201d\n\nThe only other North Korean generalissimo is Mr. Kim\u2019s father, Kim Il-sung, who began ruling in 1945 and received the title in 1992, two years before his death. The term is a clear cut above the \u201cmarshal\u201d title held by North Korea\u2019s current leader, Kim Jong-un.\n\nThe younger Mr. Kim may stay in power for decades, though, and he already has several titles: \u201cDear respected comrade,\u201d for one, as well as \u201csupreme commander\u201d of the Korean People\u2019s Army.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMike Ives contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Michael Cohen, Syria, Valentine\u2019s Day: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Michael D. Cohen, President Trump\u2019s longtime personal lawyer, said on Tuesday that he had paid $130,000 out of his own pocket to a pornographic-film actress who had once claimed to have had an affair with Mr. Trump.\n\nIn the most detailed explanation of the 2016 payment made to the actress, Stephanie Clifford, Mr. Cohen, who worked as a counsel to the Trump Organization for more than a decade, said he was not reimbursed by the Trump Organization or the campaign for the payment.\n\n\u201cNeither the Trump Organization nor the Trump campaign was a party to the transaction with Ms. Clifford, and neither reimbursed me for the payment, either directly or indirectly,\u201d Mr. Cohen said in a statement to The New York Times. \u201cThe payment to Ms. Clifford was lawful, and was not a campaign contribution or a campaign expenditure by anyone.\u201d\n\nHe declined to answer several follow-up questions, including whether Mr. Trump had been aware that Mr. Cohen made the payment, why he made the payment or whether he had made similar payments to other people over the years.", "title": "Michael D. An outside investigation found her claim credible after interviewing the student and her mother, who both gave the same sequence of events.\n\nMr. Feinberg denies the accusation, his lawyer, Christopher L. Most of Mr. Haneke\u2019s movies are in German and French, although he remade his 1997 German-language film \u201cFunny Games\u201d in English in 2007, and his latest movie, \u201cHappy End,\u201d though primarily in French, featured some dialogue in English.\n\nThe production company working on \u201cKelvin\u2019s Book,\u201d UFA Fiction, was also behind \u201cDeutschland 83\u201d, the German espionage series that aired in 2015.\n\n\u201cNo other director of the present has sharpened and stirred up my perception through his films like Michael Haneke,\u201d Nico Hoffman, the UFA Fiction chief executive, said in a statement. \u201c \u2018Kelvin\u2019s Book\u2019 is an extraordinarily rich, gripping and ambitious story. Not so for Michael Kors. He prefers a juicy mountain of ground sirloin covered in gooey cheese and wedged between two carb-happy hamburger buns served to a room filled with friends.\n\nOh, don\u2019t forget the French fries. And save room for dessert. And, really, can you blame him?\n\nOn Wednesday night, Mr. Kors closed out New York Fashion Week on a relaxed, crowd-pleasing note with a low-key familial dinner at the Greenwich Village outpost of JG Melon, the pub known for its rustic, tasty bar food. \u201cThis is one of my favorite restaurants,\u201d he said. \u201cI love casual. I grew up with JG Melon uptown, but I\u2019m a Village boy so when they opened down here, I was like, \u2018This is the new canteen.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe designer also used the occasion to celebrate a collaboration with the artist and illustrator David Downton, which debuted earlier that day during Mr. Kors\u2019s runway show at Lincoln Center, an eclectic collection of clashing tartans, florals, animal prints and camouflage, meant to reflect the mixed-up, anything-goes way women dress today.\n\nMr. Downton\u2019s elegant sketches of glamorous women decorated dresses, a coat and some ladylike handbags. \u201cWhen I was a kid, growing up, I worshiped all the illustrators,\u201d Mr. Kors said. \u201cWhat I love about David\u2019s work is he really captures the essence of people, but these aren\u2019t photographs. There\u2019s something about them that captures a mood and a spirit.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. But on Thursday, more than over 30 years after his death, Michel Foucault had a new book, \u201cConfessions of the Flesh,\u201d published in France by Gallimard.\n\nFoucault\u2019s unfinished investigation into the topic of sexuality in early Christian thought and practice is the fourth book in his \u201cHistory of Sexuality\u201d project. The three previously published volumes addressed sexuality during the modern period, from the 17th century to the mid-20th century; in ancient Greece; and in the Roman world. In them Foucault hoped to explain how sexuality became an object of scientific study and a subject of moral preoccupation.\n\nFoucault was unable to finish \u201cConfessions of the Flesh\u201d before his death in 1984 from an AIDS-related illness.\n\nThe decision to publish the book was spurred by the sale in 2013 of the Foucault archives, which contained both a handwritten version of \u201cConfessions of the Flesh\u201d and a typed manuscript that Foucault had begun to correct, to the National Library of France by his longtime partner, Daniel Defert. But after more than a year, one of the biggest mysteries of the Trump administration was finally revealed this week.\n\nIt was a picture frame.\n\nThat was the present wrapped in a Tiffany & Company blue box that Melania Trump presented to a befuddled Michelle Obama as the Obamas greeted the soon-to-be first lady and her husband, Donald J. Trump, outside the north portico of the White House on Jan. 20, 2017, Inauguration Day.\n\nMrs. Obama disclosed the box\u2019s contents in a recent appearance on the Ellen DeGeneres Show, breaking her silence on an awkward moment that was broadcast live. \u201cIt was a lovely frame,\u201d Mrs. Obama said on the show, which was broadcast on Thursday.\n\nOn the show, Mrs. Obama recounted the moment she received the surprise gift.\n\nVideo\n\nIt might seem obvious now that it had to be a frame, but on Inauguration Day there were few clues. He was 76.\n\nHis death was announced by his publicist, Cherry Hepburn, who did not specify the cause or say where he died.\n\nMr. Jones was born on June 10, 1941, in Houston to Edward Jones, an officer in the Navy, and the former Frances Marie Vieregge. He became a professional musician as a teenager, working with Trini Lopez, Johnny Rivers, Mr. Rogers\u2019s band the First Edition and, most notably, Mr. Dylan, before leaving music for acting in the mid-1970s.\n\nHe said in an interview with the website cultfilmfreak.com that he had dreamed of being an actor since he was 8 years old but did not pursue acting as a career until he got \u201ctired of going to the airport every day on concert tours.\u201d", "title": "Mickey Jones, Drummer Turned Character Actor, Is Dead at 76", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "A year after \u201cBad and Boujee\u201d helped to cement a moment for digital streaming by hitting No. 1, the rap trio Migos is at it again.\n\nWith 225 million streams in its debut week, the group\u2019s new album, \u201cCulture II\u201d (Quality Control/Motown/Capitol), easily topped the Billboard 200, tallying the best streaming week for an album since Kendrick Lamar\u2019s \u201cDAMN.\u201d last April. The release also counted 38,000 in traditional sales for a total of 199,000 units by the industry\u2019s current metrics, according to Nielsen data.\n\nThat was enough to best the first \u201cCulture\u201d album \u2014 which debuted with 116 million streams and 131,000 total units last year \u2014 despite the lack of another chart-topping single. The song \u201cMotorSport,\u201d featuring Cardi B and Nicki Minaj, has hovered around the Top 10, while its follow-up, \u201cStir Fry,\u201d has lived mostly in the second half of the Hot 100.\n\nBut unlike \u201cCulture,\u201d which came in at an economical 13 tracks, \u201cCulture II\u201d includes 24 songs in all, a savvy streaming-era tactic that gives fans more to engage with and more options for a breakout hit while the album racks up plays that count toward sales. Friday how the brawl started, but the police were searching for a 37-year-old Afghan suspected of having fired first at a group of Eritreans, according to news reports.\n\n\u201cWe stopped everything, the police came quickly, and everyone got scattered amid tear gas,\u201d said Fran\u00e7ois Guennoc of the Migrants\u2019 Hostel charity, describing how more than 100 migrants from Africa, armed with iron rods and sticks, had tried to beat a group of 20 Afghans during a food distribution.\n\nHuman rights workers said that tensions have increased as migrants have seen their chances of reaching Britain from Calais whittled by a tougher stance by the French and British governments.\n\nIn mid-January, Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain agreed during a meeting with France\u2019s president, Emmanuel Macron, that the British government would pay an additional $62 million to step up security measures around Calais.\n\nYet, organizations say, at least 200 more migrants, mostly young men from Eritrea, have reached Calais since that meeting, where Mr. Macron and Ms. May announced an accord that aimed to reduce the time unaccompanied minors spent there.\n\n\u201cThey mistakenly thought that they could reach Britain more easily,\u201d Mr. Guennoc said.\n\nBut the French government has showed no leniency. \u201cThe message I want to get across is that if you want to go to Britain, it\u2019s not here you should come,\u201d Mr. Collomb said on Thursday while visiting local authorities and security forces in Calais.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFrance received a record number of asylum claims last year \u2014 100,000 compared with 85,000 in 2016 \u2014 but no other town has embodied the challenges posed by immigration more than Calais, where a squalid encampment known as the Jungle was once home to more than 10,000 people before it was dismantled in 2016.\n\n\u201cUnder no circumstances will we allow the Jungle to come back,\u201d Mr. Macron said in January, when he visited Calais to explain his policies on immigration.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe government plans to present legislation on immigration and asylum in the spring, and Mr. Macron has vowed to step up deportations against those who come to France for economic reasons and speed up the process for those who are fleeing conflicts and persecution. This approach, he argued, would mix \u201chumanity\u201d with \u201cefficiency.\u201d\n\nMr. Collomb, the interior minister, has become the face of the latter. In Calais, he has expressed support for the police, whose treatment of migrants was criticized by a Human Rights Watch report that denounced their systematic use of pepper spray against migrants.\n\nWhen a report by the Ministry of Interior found \u201cit plausible that there was a breach in security force doctrine and ethics,\u201d Mr. Collomb dismissed some of the accusations.\n\n\u201cIn Calais, the true violence, it is the one of the traffickers who exploit with cynicism the refugees\u2019 misery and fear,\u201d he said in a post on Twitter on Thursday.\n\nMr. Collomb said that the authorities would take over the distribution of food in Calais within the next two weeks, appearing to criticize local groups when he said the process can\u2019t be \u201cwild.\u201d\n\nMs. Millot, whose organization, Salam, distributed lunches from 2002 to 2015 in Calais and now serves 600 breakfasts every morning, as well as soups at night, said that charities had yet to see how public workers would distribute food.\n\n\u201cOn the one hand, the government orders its police forces to dismantle the migrants\u2019 tents, and on the other, it is going to distribute food to those who saw their shelter torn down,\u201d Ms. Millot said. \u201cSeriously?\u201d", "title": "Migrant Clashes in French City Lead to More Police, and Fears of More Violence", "authors": ["Elian Peltier"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 Shiffrin is the reigning Olympic champion, the three-time defending world champion and a four-time World Cup winner in the event. But she does not want to stop at slalom: \u201cI work to become not just the best slalom skier in the world, but the best skier in the world. Period.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Despite being the heavy favorite, Shiffrin is bucking some history. No one, man or woman, has ever defended an Olympic slalom title.\n\n\u2022 Petra Vlhova of Slovakia is the only other woman to win a World Cup slalom event this season.\n\n\u2022 Win or lose her best event, Shiffrin is ambitious for more Olympics glory: She could win the giant slalom and the combined, and maybe even other events.\n\n\u2022 In the first of two runs, Shiffrin will ski third. The combined time of the two runs will determine the medals.\n\n\u2022 Four years ago, Shiffrin said, \u201cRight now I\u2019m dreaming of the next Olympics, winning five gold medals \u2014 which sounds really crazy.\u201d She goes for No. 1 today.", "title": "Mikaela Shiffrin Live Slalom Results: Looking for a Repeat", "authors": ["Victor Mather"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "In the fall of 2014, Shiffrin trained with Ligety in Colorado, not far from her home outside Vail. Afterward, they would watch videotape of that day\u2019s training for an hour to 90 minutes.\n\n\u201cI remember that Mikaela would ask me about 20 questions in every 15-minute span,\u201d Ligety said late last year. \u201cWhen we\u2019d be done, I\u2019d say, \u2018What else do you want to know?\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cAnd she\u2019d answer: \u2018Everything else.\u2019\u201d\n\nIn October that year, Shiffrin won her first World Cup giant slalom. Two months later, she had the first of six straight top 10 finishes in the event and by the winter of 2016-17, she was rarely out of the top five in any giant slalom. This season, she has won two giant slalom races and been second in another.\n\nBut last month, she fell in her last giant slalom race and many in the ski racing community wondered if Shiffrin\u2019s zeal to branch out to other events had left her distracted. Instead, she was convinced she needed to go back and work on the more basic techniques that she had studied and learned in the years since 2014.\n\nIn the two weeks since her tumble in her last giant slalom last month, she sequestered with her team of coaches and her mother. She rested some days and trained by herself in others.\n\n\u201cIt was kind of a restart to the season and my skiing got better and better,\u201d Shiffrin said. \u201cI rediscovered some things during that training, which was important.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLeaving the gate in her first run Thursday morning, Shiffrin was by far the fastest in the opening segment of the racecourse. She lost some time in the middle of the course and rallied a bit at the end but still trailed first the round leader, Manuela M\u00f6lgg of Italy, by 0.20.\n\nShe predicted after the first run that she could go faster in the second run, and she did, especially in the first 40 seconds after she left the gate. She soon opened a lead on the field that was nearly a full second, a stunning margin.\n\nBut within sight of the finish line, she skidded slightly and was knocked off-balance. It appeared she might have given the race away.\n\nAfterward, Shiffrin would disagree. She said she had vowed to ski without fear all the way to the end of the race.\n\n\u201cI was not worried that I gave it away; I had just been a bit too aggressive,\u201d she said, smiling. \u201cBut that\u2019s what I wanted to do.\u201d\n\nSurging past the finish, Shiffrin looked over her shoulder to see her name atop the scoreboard.\n\n\u201cThe most amazing, sweetest feeling,\u201d Shiffrin said. \u201cI was determined to push all the way down and at that moment I really knew where I was.\u201d\n\nIt was four years later, at her next Olympics, and she had not come all this way to finish fifth.", "title": "Mikaela Shiffrin\u2019s Gold Rush Begins With a Bang", "authors": ["Bill Pennington", "Derek Watkins", "Denise Lu"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 Mikaela Shiffrin has yet to win or lose in her pursuit of multiple gold medals at the Pyeongchang Olympics, but that quest became more knotty Wednesday when organizers postponed the slalom event.\n\nHigh winds moved the women\u2019s slalom, which Shiffrin won at the 2014 Sochi Games, to Friday. The women\u2019s giant slalom, also a strength of Shiffrin\u2019s, had already been postponed from Monday to Thursday.\n\nThe revised race program means that Shiffrin now has races on three consecutive days, beginning with Thursday\u2019s giant slalom and concluding with the women\u2019s super-G on Saturday. That\u2019s a grueling schedule in a pressure-filled setting like the Olympics, and it could cause her to change her plans.", "title": "Mikaela Shiffrin\u2019s Quest Gets More Difficult With Another Delay", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "He said he would prefer not to meet Mr. Pence at the informal gathering of American athletes and the official delegation held before the Games.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIf it were before my event, I would absolutely not go out of my way to meet somebody who I felt has gone out of their way to not only show that they aren\u2019t a friend of a gay person but that they think that they\u2019re sick,\u201d Mr. Rippon told the newspaper.\n\nMr. Pence has been dogged by claims that he supports conversion therapy since his 2000 campaign for Congress. After stating his opposition to same-sex marriage and anti-discrimination laws that protect gay people, his campaign website addressed the Ryan White Care Act, which provided federal funding for H.I.V./AIDS patients:\n\nCongress should support the reauthorization of the Ryan White Care Act only after completion of an audit to ensure that federal dollars were no longer being given to organizations that celebrate and encourage the types of behaviors that facilitate the spreading of the HIV virus. Resources should be directed toward those institutions which provide assistance to those seeking to change their sexual behavior.\n\nThat was widely interpreted as signaling his support for conversion therapy. Representatives for Mr. Pence did not respond to emails seeking comment this week. But in January, a spokeswoman, Alyssa Farah, responded to Mr. Rippon, telling USA Today, \u201cThis accusation is totally false and has no basis in fact.\u201d\n\nIn 2016, a spokesman, Marc Lotter, denied that Mr. Pence supported conversion therapy and said his campaign website proposed federal funding for \u201cgroups that promoted safe sexual practices.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Lotter declined to explain what Mr. Pence meant when he referred to groups that \u201ccelebrate and encourage\u201d activity that spreads H.I.V. Gay and transgender groups view that language as directed at their community.\n\nMr. Rippon repeated his criticism of Mr. Pence on Twitter after the USA Today article was published, but he told reporters he had no interest in \u201cpicking a fight\u201d with the vice president.\n\nThat seemed as if it might be the end of it.\n\nAn invitation and a rejection\n\nBut two weeks later, things escalated. On Wednesday, USA Today reported that Mr. Pence\u2019s office was so concerned about Mr. Rippon\u2019s criticism that it had taken the unusual step of asking the United States Olympic Committee to arrange \u201ca conversation between the two.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Rippon, true to his word, would not meet with the vice president, the paper reported.\n\nThat seemed to be too much for Mr. Pence. On Thursday, he lashed out at the paper, tweeting that the report was \u201cfake news\u201d and that the journalist who had written it was bent on dividing Americans. But he was careful not to criticize Mr. Rippon.\n\nMr. Pence\u2019s communications director, Jarrod Agen, denied that he ever requested a meeting with Mr. Rippon, and said that the USA Today report was \u201cjust not accurate.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe USA Today report is false & should be corrected,\u201d Mr. Agen tweeted. \u201cVP\u2019s office did not try to arrange a meeting with Mr. Rippon at Olympics.\u201d\n\nChristine Brennan, the journalist who wrote the USA Today article, defended her work on Twitter, saying the \u201creport is true and therefore will not be corrected.\u201d\n\nMr. Rippon\u2019s agent, David Baden, agreed.\n\n\u201cWe were contacted by his office and I think the objective was to have a conversation with Adam,\u201d he said in an interview. The request did not come directly to him or Mr. Rippon but \u201cwent through the various proper channels and that message was then sent to us,\u201d he said.\n\nHe declined to explain what those channels were. The group has carried out similar attacks in the Indian-administrated portion of Kashmir, particularly along the Line of Control that divides Kashmir into two parts, held by India and Pakistan.\n\nThere was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack this weekend, however.\n\nThe attack began around 4:55 a.m. Saturday as four militants dressed in army uniforms and armed with AK-47 assault rifles and grenades descended on Chenni, a small village on the outskirts of Jammu City, said Abdul Rehman Veeri, the parliamentary affairs minister of the state of Jammu and Kashmir. The village is among those closest to the de facto border with Pakistan.\n\nThe militants entered the family quarters of the army officers, gunning down two soldiers and injuring at least nine other people, including women and children, army officials said.\n\nThe militants were cornered and later killed in a residential complex of the camp when the army deployed Special Forces that engaged in a bloody firefight that lasted more than 24 hours, an army spokesman in Jammu, Lt. Col. Devender Anand, said.\n\n\u201cThe militants entered into the residential quarters where they targeted the family members of the army personnel. A junior commissioned officer and a noncommissioned officer were killed in the attack,\u201d the police said.\n\nThe death toll stood at 10 people: five soldiers, four militants and the father of a soldier, officials said.\n\n\u201cThe operation is still in progress,\u201d Colonel Anand said. \u201cWe are still evacuating the trapped family members of the forces.\u201d\n\nOn Sunday, army helicopters hovered over the Sunjuwan military station, and the Indian Army chief, Gen. Bipin Rawat, arrived in Jammu, the winter capital of Jammu and Kashmir.\n\nIndia\u2019s home minister, Rajnath Singh, said from Delhi that he was monitoring the situation closely.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe latest attack is likely to raise tensions between India and Pakistan, which have fought three wars since independence, two of them over Kashmir. New Delhi has often blamed militant groups in Pakistan for sponsoring militant attacks in the region.\n\nAttacks on army bases have become common in the disputed region after the Indian Army killed a charismatic militant leader, Burhan Muzaffar Wani, in July 2016. Protests in the predominantly Muslim valley have increased since then. And more people have joined the fight against Indian rule.\n\nJammu City is in the southern part of Kashmir Valley, at the heart of the dispute between the two nuclear-armed neighbors.\n\nMore than 200 militants were killed last year, the largest number in seven years, according to the director general of the Jammu and Kashmir police, Shesh Paul Vaid. And the chief minister of the state, Mehbooba Mufti, said last week in the State Assembly that 71 civilians and 49 police officers had been killed over the past two years.\n\nThe police chief for Jammu, Shiv Dev Singh Jamwal, told reporters on Saturday that a sentry had noticed suspicious movement near the camp before the assailants began firing.\n\n\u201cA high alert has been sounded in Jammu, and security beefed up in and around the city,\u201d he said.\n\nThe state government closed schools and several shopping complexes within a three-mile radius of Chenni and the military station.\n\nMohammad Ashraf Mir, whose son was one of the soldiers killed in the attack, said, \u201cHe died serving his nation.\u201d\n\nThe father, a resident of Kupwara, in northern Kashmir, said: \u201cPeople are getting killed every day. India and Pakistan should come together and resolve there differences.\n\n\u201cToday it is my son; tomorrow it will be someone else\u2019s,\u201d he added. \u201cSomething should be done to stop this bloodshed immediately.\u201d", "title": "Militants Storm Indian Army Base, Killing Soldiers and a Civilian", "authors": ["Sameer Yasir"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Morgan: Retirement for me is saving up as much as I can so that by hopefully 60 at the latest, I have enough money to live off for a good 20 years. Maybe somewhere warm.\n\nKirk: It\u2019s not a one-and-done moment in life in my mind at all, it\u2019s going to be more like a slow fade of reaching a point where I\u2019m financially independent enough to make whatever choice I want about how I spend my time.\n\nBrian: I don\u2019t know if it\u2019s just because I\u2019ve been working for a short amount of time, retirement doesn\u2019t seem exciting. I feel like I don\u2019t want to work to just retire.\n\nGarrett: Retirement to me is just not having to work. Not necessarily that you won\u2019t work, but there\u2019s no necessity for it.\n\nEmily: The idea of sitting in a condo in Boca fills me more with dread than anything. Maybe that\u2019s just a foolish millennial dream, thinking you won\u2019t be tired at the end and want to put your feet up for 20 years, but the idea of not working if I have my mind and my health doesn\u2019t feel like me.\n\nZach: What are you doing to save?\n\nAnd does your savings plan affect your life at all?\n\nTravis: I\u2019ve recently been trying to figure out the investing game using some educational apps like Stash \u2014 putting a little away here and there, and learning about what it actually means to invest in the stock market. Learning how it all works so it\u2019s not just magic numbers behind closed doors.\n\nGarrett: I\u2019ve been pretty aggressively investing in mostly index funds since I got out of college.\n\nMorgan: I used to have crazy online shopping binges. I have a Roth I.R.A. and I put the maximum in it annually that I can.\n\nPhoto\n\nTravis: My partner and I consciously chose to live in Maryland in the suburbs because it was just too expensive to live closer to work in D.C.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEmily: I don\u2019t think I\u2019ve ever taken a vacation as an adult \u2014 a real vacation, not driving home or flying home for Thanksgiving to go spend three days in your mother\u2019s house.\n\nKirk: For me the \u201cset it and forget it\u201d type of savings methods have definitely been what helps. I\u2019ve started to cut down on my excess spending.\n\nZach: What\u2019s the best and worst financial advice you\u2019ve received?\n\nEmily: I knew it was going to be bad advice when my mother prefaced it the first time with, \u201cSo, I know I\u2019m a boomer and that means that you think that I don\u2019t know anything but \u2026\u201d and then she started pushing me to start looking for at least a condo to buy, or a house, even saying the classic phrase, \u201cDon\u2019t waste your money paying your landlord\u2019s mortgage.\u201d\n\nI said, \u201cO.K., but then when the laundry machines stop working the same month that the heat goes out and they have to replace everything, it\u2019s also not my checkbook.\u201d\n\nMorgan: The best advice I got was not dumping out my retirement fund to pay for my year living in London, because now I still have that. It would be bad if I had no retirement at all. It\u2019s better to take out student loans than empty your savings.\n\nKirk: I think \u201cnever break the habit\u201d was the best advice I ever got. I think that building habits is so hard to do, and breaking them can be so easy to do.\n\nTravis: I\u2019m going to start telling my younger siblings that they have to start investing because it\u2019s so easy now with these apps like Stash. It invests $5 for you every week. I had $5 when I was 16 and that would be worth so much more now.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nZach: What about retiring hasn\u2019t come up that we should be talking about?\n\nMauricio: I want to question the assumption that to have a decent retirement requires a high amount of literacy right now. It doesn\u2019t have to be that way. I\u2019m playing the game as much as anybody, and I\u2019m doing whatever I can to save as much money for myself, but there are alternative systems that wouldn\u2019t require that every individual be thinking about this and picking the best mutual fund or that sort of thing. The older model of pensions or something like that on a national scale would mean that people can retire without having to be financial gurus by the time they\u2019re 60.\n\nKirk: I\u2019m worried that we\u2019re just not on a good track. And it\u2019s not just about the Social Security rug getting pulled out from under us. It\u2019s about our own personal habits. I don\u2019t know that we\u2019re putting less into our personal savings than previous generations, but we don\u2019t have pensions to fall back on in the way that they did, and if it\u2019s all on our own behavior and our own responsibility, I think a lot of us are going to be in trouble.\n\nEmily: What if you work a 9-to-5 making a decent salary but you\u2019re a contract worker with no access to benefits? A huge percentage of people our age are in contract positions. They\u2019re like internships. You may get to 28, 30, 35 and you\u2019re building up work history, but you\u2019re structurally not given 401(k)s or things like that.\n\nTravis: I think it\u2019s a good idea that we do the work, but I also think it\u2019s a good example of how millennials are being told that we\u2019re lazy because we\u2019re not doing this work that no one else had to do before us. It\u2019s something that people have to get angry about and start organizing around, that all of these systemic protections are being taken apart. At some point, there also has to be systemic support.", "title": "Millennials Are Saving for the Future, if They Can Afford To", "authors": ["Zach Wichter"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "BANJA LUKA, Bosnia and Herzegovina \u2014 Milorad Dodik would like to make two things clear at the outset: that he is the president of a legitimate state, rather than an ethnically cleansed territory in a country with internationally recognized borders; and that, at 58, he can still shoot hoops like a pro.\n\nOn basketball, he has a point. He plays regularly, and although he never played professionally outside the former Yugoslavia, once an international powerhouse in the sport, he showed good game on a court in St. Petersburg last summer when he joined a veterans\u2019 team, led by the Russian former NBA star Andrei Kirilenko, against Moscow old-timers.\n\nHe is wrong on the presidency, though. Despite his determination to break from the Muslim-Croat part of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Mr. Dodik remains the president of the Serb autonomous region, a slice of territory nearly the size of Belgium. The region likes to call itself the Republika Srpska \u2014 a name given to the blood-soaked land by Mr. Dodik\u2019s predecessor, Radovan Karadzic, the convicted war criminal serving a 40-year sentence for genocide against Bosnia\u2019s Muslims.\n\nDuring his two terms as president of the Republika Srpska \u2014 and two more as prime minister \u2014 Mr. Dodik has ruffled more than a few feathers. Despite warnings from the international community, and in violation of a ruling from Bosnia\u2019s highest court, he pressed for a referendum in 2016 on whether to celebrate Jan 9 as a national holiday, the day in 1992 Mr. Karadzic declared a Serb-only state in Bosnia, unleashing a genocidal war.", "title": "Milorad Dodik Wants to Carve Up Bosnia. Peacefully, if Possible", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "If that spoils some of the most savory Milos mythology in circulation, don\u2019t worry: Copious amounts of YouTube footage of his audacious passing is only a click away. A quick internet search will likewise confirm that, for all the fears about how he\u2019d cope with the length and athleticism he\u2019s now seeing daily as the N.B.A.\u2019s oldest rookie \u2014 especially given his well-chronicled defensive shortcomings \u2014 there is no shortage of Teodosic highlights in a Clippers jersey.\n\n\u201cHe still has his razzle-dazzle going,\u201d Dekker said.\n\nNot long after the Clippers saw their All-Star point guard Chris Paul force his way to Houston last June, they signed Teodosic to a two-year deal worth $12.3 million. On a Basketball Without Borders junket in Israel on behalf of the league in August, Dekker found himself being regaled by Israeli reporters with tales about the uncommon vision and flair he was about to be exposed to.\n\n\u201cMy immediate reaction,\u201d Dekker said, \u201cwas that I better go look this guy up.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a true shame that N.B.A. assistant coaches overlooked Teodosic in the voting for the annual Rising Stars game featuring first- and second-year players that gets All-Star Weekend underway in earnest next Friday night. The All-Star festivities are in Los Angeles this season and Teodosic belongs in that game not only as a showman supreme who sports the bonus of local ties but because of his impact for the better-than-expected Clippers, who are 17-8 when he\u2019s in uniform and 11-18 when he\u2019s out. Heading into Monday night\u2019s game in Brooklyn, L.A. is also a meaty plus-5.8 points per 100 possessions better this season when he is on the floor compared to when he sits.\n\nTeodosic, though, doesn\u2019t feel slighted in the least.\n\n\u201cBeing in All-Star any way is something big and good,\u201d he said. \u201cBut I\u2019m 30 years old. Maybe some younger guys should go there and feel this feeling.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen he was 26, Teodosic was courted hard in free agency by the Memphis Grizzlies. He came close to accepting their offer in the summer of 2013, only to decide he couldn\u2019t bear to leave for the United States until he won a Euroleague title. He never expected that it would take another three years, but his European critics were finally hushed when Teodosic led CSKA Moscow to the second-most prestigious club basketball championship in the world in 2016.\n\nThe expiration of his second three-year CSKA contract after the 2016-17 season then set him up, at last, to make the leap to sample N.B.A. life and try to quiet the critics on both sides of the Atlantic who would have branded his r\u00e9sum\u00e9 incomplete without a stint on U.S. shores.\n\nTeodosic said it felt \u201cweird\u201d to be branded a rookie, after winning Euroleague Most Valuable Player honors as far back as 2010 and unexpectedly steering Serbia into the gold medal game against the mighty United States at both the 2014 FIBA World Cup and the 2016 Rio Olympics. \u201cBut I am happy they don\u2019t treat me like a rookie,\u201d Teodosic said of his fellow Clippers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat means no fetching bagels or doughnuts to bring to practice. No transporting of the veterans\u2019 luggage or singing on teammates\u2019 birthdays with the other first-year players. He arrived with too much hoopla to be assigned rookie chores, especially when, as Dekker put it, Teodosic \u201cknows the game better than most of us.\u201d\n\n\u201cI will feel sorry if I didn\u2019t come here,\u201d Teodosic said, admitting that he, too, felt something was missing in his career without an N.B.A. adventure. \u201cI want to show myself I can play here with all these guys. I just feel sorry that I didn\u2019t win Euroleague earlier and came here earlier.\u201d\n\nYet he\u2019s the first to say that they are largely two different games. In Europe, Teodosic capitalized on the smaller court, shorter games and lighter schedule, relying on his pick-and-roll guile to deal with all the bodies in the paint. In the N.B.A., there is more space to cover, far more nuance in the defensive assignments and, most crucially, less time to get shots off.\n\nThe superior quickness he encounters on the perimeter as a Clipper has surely contributed to Teodosic\u2019s shooting struggles (38.2 percent from the floor), but health has been his biggest issue so far. Teodosic has started all 25 games he\u2019s played, earning an unforeseen spot in Coach Doc Rivers\u2019 first five in place of Patrick Beverley, who was his former teammate at Olympiacos in Greece and is not expected back this season after recovering from November knee surgery. But Teodosic, himself, has missed 28 games because of a nagging case of plantar fasciitis in his left foot.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStill, he\u2019s shown enough to vindicate those who have vouched for him over the years. Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski was so entranced by Teodosic\u2019s floor leadership during multiple battles while Krzyzewski was guiding Team USA that he declared during the Rio Games: \u201cI love him. We\u2019re friends.\u201d\n\nEttore Messina, now an assistant coach with the San Antonio Spurs after coaching Teodosic at CSKA Moscow for two seasons, said he used to call the point guard Vincent van Gogh in their CSKA days.\n\n\u201cHe is creativity, he is fantasy, he is an artist,\u201d said Messina, who went on in the same conversation to refer to Teodosic as \u201cthe Pete Maravich of European basketball.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think more like a coach, of course, more rational. So we had our clashes,\u201d Messina said. \u201cBut he can see things most of us don\u2019t see. As a coach, you are used to anticipating the play \u2014 you know where the ball will go most of the time. Teo is one of the few players that can surprise you.\u201d\n\nThe Clippers stunned Teodosic and the rest of the league when they dealt the star forward Blake Griffin to Detroit on Jan. 29, but the departure of the most potent and decorated assist target on the roster came with a consolation prize: Teodosic\u2019s longtime national-team colleague and former roommate, Boban Marjanovic, was one of three Pistons acquired in the trade.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMarjanovic is a fast-talking, 7-foot-3 fan favorite whose hulking presence can only increase his fellow Serbian\u2019s comfort level. Griffin and Teodosic, meanwhile, will always have their memories of that September car ride with Dekker in San Diego, when they pulled into McDonald\u2019s on the way to a team-bonding workout in search of some morning sustenance.\n\nAs Dekker tells it, Teodosic asked for two cheeseburgers when it was their turn in the drive-through and was disconsolate when informed that the full menu wasn\u2019t available at that hour.\n\n\u201cThe person in the speaker was like, \u2018Yeah, we don\u2019t serve those yet,\u2019 \u201d Dekker said. \u201cMilos was so confused. He wanted cheeseburgers so bad.\u201d\n\nTeodosic insists it was \u201clike a joke.\u201d\n\nThe idea of cheeseburgers for breakfast, mind you, fit in well with the narrative of lazy defense and suspect conditioning that dogged Teodosic throughout his European career. But Teodosic, according to Dekker, has never complained once about Dekker\u2019s tweet and how it didn\u2019t exactly enhance his reputation for off-court discipline.\n\n\u201cHe did not care,\u201d Dekker said. \u201cThat\u2019s the type of guy Milos is. He doesn\u2019t care what people think about him. He\u2019s going to go out and do his thing. He\u2019s going to come out with the beard and the floppy hair, looking like a Beatle.\u201d\n\nIt wasn\u2019t always that way. Teodosic said it took him \u201ca long, long time\u201d to learn how to tune out unflattering gossip.\n\n\u201cI used to feel sad,\u201d Teodosic said. \u201cThen you realize that people are there to talk and talk and talk.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think about things people are talking about me outside of the court \u2014 good or bad.\u201d\n\nHe also rarely interacts with the American news media after spending so long in a world in which reporters are never granted locker-room access, which made the opportunity to spend a morning with him even more intriguing. We talked soccer; Teodosic loves A.C. Milan and Liverpool. We talked Serbian basketball history; Dejan Bodiroga, who could never bring himself to give the N.B.A. a shot, is one of his all-time favorites. And we talked about why he\u2019d rather pass than score.\n\n\u201cBecause you make two people happy,\u201d he said.\n\nAnd it should be noted for posterity that Teodosic held up his breakfast sandwich a bit like a trophy when it arrived. \u201cYou see? No cheeseburgers,\u201d he announced with a smile.", "title": "Milos Teodosic Is for Real, Even if That Cheeseburger Story May Not Be", "authors": ["Marc Stein", "On Pro Basketball"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "He said more than 150 submissions came in for the competition, from architects, landscape architects and urban planners. \u201cYou get some incredible stuff, even if it\u2019s not meant to be built,\u201d he said from his office on, naturally, Park Avenue. \u201cYou see that Park Avenue has such potential. It could be one of the most defining landscape architecture projects in the world.\u201d\n\nAnd he went ahead with the competition even though he does not control the medians.\n\n\u201cWe do not,\u201d he said. \u201cCan the city do it? The city can do anything.\u201d\n\nThe eight-person jury included Vishaan Chakrabarti, the founder of the architecture firm Practice for Architecture and Urbanism and a professor at Columbia University, who was also on the jury for the High Line competition.\n\n\u201cThe point is not necessarily to create the practical idea that will get funded and built,\u201d he said. \u201cThe point is to focus our attention on things that are right in front of us and the possibilities there are.\u201d\n\nMr. Fisher said the competition focused on the blocks between 46th and 57th Streets. A few of those blocks would overlap with medians tended by the Fund for Park Avenue, which plants tulips, begonias and mums from 54th Street to 86th Street.\n\nBarbara McLaughlin, the president of the fund, said she looked forward to seeing the finalists in the competition. \u201cThe more attention to the malls, the better,\u201d she said. \u201cSomething needs to be tackled, and it\u2019s bigger than the fund. It\u2019s infrastructure. It needs to be fixed up.\u201d\n\nAs for the minigolf entry, Ms. Schrank said it was not a love of the sport that prompted the design, which includes an 18-hole course, a clubhouse, a restaurant and a virtual driving range. In one case, the sentence was suspension; in the second, expulsion.\n\nLynch played with the Gophers during investigations into the incidents, which dated back more than a year, but he was suspended from play last month when the first decision was made public.\n\nAt a news conference on Thursday, Lynch insisted upon his innocence and blamed a national atmosphere that is unfair to those accused of sexual misdeeds for his downfall. In recent months, accusations of sexual misconduct by powerful men have stirred new interest in combating such behavior.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn today\u2019s climate, people will automatically assume that you are guilty if any accusations have been made,\u201d Lynch said. \u201cI feel scared that in today\u2019s climate, this is the world we live in today. I am angry that there is no real way to defend myself.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. In that case, prosecutors did not charge him and a university investigation cleared him of responsibility.", "title": "Minnesota\u2019s Reggie Lynch Won\u2019t Appeal Sexual Assault Ruling", "authors": ["Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "She added: \u201cThat somehow we should have a hierarchical system whereby touch on the arse is this, tits is this, you know, front bottom, back bottom, over the shirt, rape! That there would be some criteria.\u201d\n\n\u2018Use the model of truth and reconciliation\u2019\n\nAt the same time, she said men needed to be included in the conversation about sexual assault because \u201cthere\u2019s no way to move forward unless we do this together.\u201d Use the \u201cmodel of truth and reconciliation,\u201d she said, referring to courtlike commissions set up after the 1994 genocide in Rwanda or apartheid in South Africa, where the judicial bodies were tasked with revealing wrongdoing in hopes of healing wounds.\n\n\u201cWomen get to be heard,\u201d she said. \u201cYou get to be seen and heard and the accusers get to hear that and get to metabolize that and then there is due process and then there is healing.\u201d\n\nOxfam \u2018needs to clean house\u2019\n\nLast week, the deputy chief executive of Oxfam resigned in the wake of accusations that the British charity had covered up misconduct by its staff members after revelations that aid workers had hired prostitutes in crisis zones in Chad and Haiti.\n\nMs. Driver, who was affiliated with the organization for 20 years \u2014 her \u201clongest relationship with anyone,\u201d she said \u2014 announced last week that she was resigning from her role as a celebrity ambassador. \u201cIt broke my heart in so many ways,\u201d she said, particularly because she had been primarily involved in programs that were helping prostitutes in countries like Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam to retrain and rebuild their lives. \u201cIt cut me to the very heart of what I had been involved with,\u201d she said.", "title": "Minnie Driver Calls for \u2018Truth and Reconciliation\u2019 Model to Combat Sexual Assault", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Just eight women have successfully landed one in competition, including Tonya Harding at Skate America in 1991, a pivotal moment in the Oscar-nominated biopic \u201cI, Tonya,\u201d about the disgraced two-time Olympian. Though it was Harding\u2019s signature move, she never landed one in the Olympics.\n\nNagasu became the third woman to land the triple axel at the Olympics. Two Japanese athletes, Midori Ito, in 1992, and Mao Asada, in 2010 and 2014, were the previous women to land the jump in Olympic competition. The jump has become more common for male skaters since Brian Orser, a Canadian, was the first to land one in 1984 at Sarajevo.\n\nNagasu\u2019s performance on Sunday, set to \u201cMiss Saigon,\u201d included eight other triple jumps and earned her a score of 137.43 points, good for second place in the free skate.\n\nIt was not the first time she has landed the triple axel, having first pulled it off at the U.S. International Figure Skating Classic in September. In an article on Team U.S.A.\u2019s website, she said the rare feat would help to reclaim her spot on the Olympic team.\n\n\u201cThis year I was able to really get a feel for it and so when I started to land it, it was a very satisfactory feeling,\u201d she said in December. \u201cI could always visualize myself doing the jump, it was just getting my muscles to react as they needed to.\u201d", "title": "Mirai Nagasu Lands Triple Axel, a First by an American Woman at an Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "With President Trump\u2019s support, Republican majorities in both chambers of Congress recently enacted an enormous increase in government spending, reversing the only major policy victory of Tea Party insurgents in 2011. Given this blasphemy, where is the conservative revolt?\n\nThe typical conservative cycle runs from backlash to embrace to disappointment \u2014 and we are right on schedule. After opposing government expansion and social change under Democratic presidents, conservatives typically give new Republican presidents the benefit of the doubt. By the time of the next counterattack against a new Democrat, historical revisionism sets in: Republican leaders are seen as part of the problem, being too accommodating to liberalism and selling out their principles.\n\nThe cycle is born of the infeasibility of conservative goals, especially the American right\u2019s attempt to reverse the growth of the welfare and administrative state (which even the world\u2019s most right-wing parties accept) and its tendency to start unwinnable culture wars against inevitable change (a typical conservative foible). The public shares conservatives\u2019 broad desire for limiting government growth and social upheaval, but that does not translate into support for specific policies to achieve those goals. The international and historical norm is that the size and scope of government grow over time and new social changes are codified; conservative resistance slows this liberal policy drift but does not reverse it.\n\nEach conservative cycle begins with a backlash against liberal acceleration. Just as in 2010, the midterm elections of 1966, 1978 and 1994 brought Republican surges reacting to the policies of new Democratic presidents. Each insurgency was more conservative than the previous version, but they lacked realistic and popular proposals to rein in government or reverse social change; they focused mostly on stopping Democratic action.", "title": "Opinion | Missing Conservatism? Just Wait for a Democratic President", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "By Natalie Parletta\n\nThe garden is my husband\u2019s refuge.\n\nWhen he\u2019s not at work there are few things he enjoys more than planting seeds and nurturing them into edible beans, tomatoes, corn, spinach, eggplant; sweat dripping, hands immersed in rich Adelaide foothills soil, left in peace.\n\nSo I was surprised when one evening, a couple of months ago, he left the garden to eat dinner and snapped at me for no apparent reason. \u201cYou\u2019re irritable,\u201d I said.\n\n\u201cYou want to know why?\u201d he retorted. \u201cMy lizard died.\u201d\n\nBlue tongue lizards are one of Australia\u2019s favorite backyard buddies, and it turns out my husband had quietly enjoyed the companionship of one who called our garden home.", "title": "Missing a Blue-Tongued Friend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 State Senator Chris McDaniel, who nearly beat an incumbent senator in 2014, is expected to announce this week that he will challenge Mississippi\u2019s junior United States senator, Roger Wicker, testing the potency of an anti-establishment message in the Trump era.\n\nAfter months of speculation about his intentions, Mr. McDaniel said in a Facebook video Monday night that he would reveal his decision at a hometown rally in Ellisville, Miss., on Wednesday, the day before the filing period to run in 2018 comes to an end.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re looking for a fight, and I can\u2019t wait for you to be on my team again,\u201d he said in the video.\n\nYet even as Republicans familiar with his planning said that Mr. McDaniel would take on Mr. Wicker, there is still uncertainty about which of the two Mississippi Senate seats Mr. McDaniel will ultimately attempt to claim.\n\nMr. McDaniel, 45, a hard-line conservative, nearly unseated Mississippi\u2019s senior senator, Thad Cochran, four years ago in an extraordinarily bitter, racially tinged primary that exposed the depth of hostilities between the party\u2019s Tea Party and establishment wings. But Mr. Trump appears to have found a renewed interest in an agreement that he once described as \u201ca rape of our country.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve met with several of my counterparties and other people, and we\u2019ve begun to have very high-level conversations about T.P.P.,\u201d Mr. Mnuchin said, adding that Mr. Trump would still prefer to do one-on-one trade agreements first. \u201cIt\u2019s not a priority at the moment, but it is something the president will consider.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump opened the door to taking another look at the agreement in January at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, leading to speculation about whether he was upending his \u201cAmerica First\u201d trade policy.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIf we did a substantially better deal, I would be open to T.P.P.,\u201d Mr. Trump said during an interview with CNBC.", "title": "Mnuchin Floats Rejoining Trans-Pacific Partnership, Trade Deal Trump Shelved", "authors": ["Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Laurie Frankel is a novelist living in Seattle.
