Audio\n\nThe author, Bruce Eric Kaplan, is a cartoonist and television writer.\n\nMr. Dafoe is nominated for an Oscar for his role in \u201cThe Florida Project.\u201d", "title": "Modern Love Podcast: Willem Dafoe Reads \u2018Missing a Father I Hardly Knew\u2019", "authors": ["The New York Times", "Modern Love"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGoing makeup-free can be a liberating concept until you\u2019re confronted with bad lighting, skin flare-ups or bouts of redness. In those times, getting by on moisturizer alone can be a challenge. Fortunately, a new breed of hybrid beauty product has emerged to subtly minimize imperfections without requiring layers of foundation or heavy powders.\n\nBehold the modern primer. Of course, these fluids have been around for decades, employed as a first step to even out skin tone, fill in pores and smooth the surface of your face to prep it for foundation. But the formulas of the past were light on any lasting benefits, and often left a white-ish cast on the complexion.\n\nThe latest iterations, however, have smart technology \u2014 soft-focus filters, breathable textures \u2014 and skin-care-level ingredients, making them function as highlighter, serum and moisturizer in one tube. In fact, you might find that they flatter your complexion well enough that you can wear them alone \u2014 as a base, in lieu of makeup \u2014 and not regret that decision later.\n\n\u201cThe new formulas have skin-enhancing qualities, so they give you the most natural of glows,\u201d says New York City-based makeup artist Hannah Murray, who is partial to Dr. Barbara Sturm\u2019s Glow Drops ($145), a milky lotion that contains active natural ingredients (including anti-inflammatory purslane) and mineral pigments to illuminate and hydrate dull skin. Tatcha\u2019s The Silk Canvas ($52) is inspired by the traditional geisha ritual of pressing melted bintsuke (Japanese wax) over the face to protect it from makeup; this modern spin utilizes botanicals to fend off the damaging effects of pollution. Charlotte Tilbury\u2019s Brightening Youth Glow ($55), meanwhile, pairs trendy wellness ingredients, like revitalizing chlorella and nourishing vitamin B, with high-tech pearlized particles for a creamy gel that \u201cinstantly blurs, evens imperfections and corrects redness,\u201d Tilbury explains. When worn on its own, she finds, the primer gives skin a \u201cgorgeous\u201d effect.\n\nRather than quick fixes, many of today\u2019s primers are formulated with long-term anti-aging in mind (and have price tags that rival those of expensive creams). La Prairie\u2019s Cellular Radiance Perfecting Fluide Pure Gold ($550), for example, pairs collagen-boosting peptides with finely milled flecks of gold to scatter light across the face while also firming it over time. Or consider Sisley-Paris\u2019s Instant \u00c9clat ($90): Its plant extracts replenish skin\u2019s natural \u201cwater cushion\u201d for a plumped result that lasts after the soft-pink lotion has melted into your skin.\n\nStill, if dryness is an issue, it\u2019s best to apply these primers over traditional moisturizers. Murray often works them in with a mini-massage technique. \u201cI like to apply with my fingers, smoothing from the center of the face outward and then patting in with the palms of my hands,\u201d she says, adding that this helps \u201cstimulate blood flow and plump the skin.\u201d Will you still need a touch of concealer to cover up under-eye circles or a blemish? Perhaps, but you will need far less. And that can translate into a more realistic radiance. As Murray says, it\u2019s always better to take \u201ca light hand when it comes to the skin.\u201d", "title": "Modern Primers for Naturally Glowing Skin", "authors": ["Kari Molvar", "On Beauty"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Victor Mather: Four years ago, Norway had by all accounts a screamingly successful Winter Olympics, but failed to win the events it treasures the most: the cross country relays. Indeed, Norway failed even to win a medal, placing fourth in the men\u2019s race and fifth in the women\u2019s.\n\nAt the Pyeongchang Games, it appeared all might go wrong again. After one leg of the women\u2019s relay, Norway was third, and after two it was fourth, 30 seconds back.\n\nBut Norway still had two aces to play. The first was Ragnhild Haga, the gold medalist in the 10-kilometer event. She stormed through the course and pulled within three seconds of the leaders.\n\nThen she turned the race over to Marit Bjoergen, one of the century\u2019s greatest athletes in any sport. Already a six-time gold medalist before these Games, Bjoergen had defied her 37 years by picking up a silver and a bronze in individual events in Pyeongchang. (She added an individual gold later.)", "title": "Moments Large and Small in a Memorable Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Forget collaborations, those one-off initiatives where a high-end fashion brand hooks up with a hip underground or mass-market name to the ironically mutual market-opening benefit of both. That\u2019s so last season! Over, pass\u00e9, a dead duck.\n\nRemo Ruffini, the chief executive of Moncler, the Italian puffer coat specialist, has a new idea and it\u2019s, well, genius.\n\nIf he does say so himself. Which he does: \u201cGenius\u201d being the name of his latest fashion project, unveiled Tuesday night at what the brand dubbed the Moncler Genius Building (not to confused with the Apple Genius Bars, although if your mind just unconsciously makes that connection, O.K. then) to kick-start the third leg of the women\u2019s wear collections.\n\nIt was, as the show mission statement read, an entire \u201crepublic of imagination\u201d in which Moncler was interpreted by eight designers in eight mini-collections: the dystopian and cool (Craig Green, Palm Angels); the madly romantic (Simone Rocha, Kei Ninomiya of Noir); the grunge (Fragment by Hiroshi Fujiwara), and the haute (Pierpaolo Piccioli of Valentino), plus the hound (Poldo Dog Couture). The result, which replaces Moncler\u2019s Gamme Rouge and Gamme Bleu high-fashion lines, was part art installation, part political opportunism, and all fashion sleight-of-hand.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEight enormous boxes draped in silver fabric were set up inside a cavernous warehouse, each housing a different scenario: Mr. Green\u2019s monochrome body-swallowing sci-fi spacesuits; Ms. Rocha\u2019s Victorian snow angels in pale pink florals; Mr. Piccioli\u2019s gorgeously austere puffer ball gowns, pale rose and empire-waisted under a floor-length taupe cape with bright green opera gloves, or with a cropped trapeze jacket.\n\nEven the relatively undramatic Moncler Grenoble line was given a conceptual edge: Models in boldly patterned cold-weather gear lay on the floor under a giant tilted mirror that reflected them in a Spider-Man-like way on the vertical wall. Your job is to fill in the people of note who wrote or performed these works.\n\nThe theme entries in Mr. Trudeau\u2019s puzzle happened more than 50 years ago, so consider this one, big \u201cHi, kids!\u201d section. But I will say that these works are important parts of our culture, and even if you are a younger solver, you should know about them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor one thing, if you\u2019ve never read LANGSTON HUGHES\u2019s 1951 book-length poem, \u201cMontage of a Dream Deferred,\u201d you are truly missing out. Mr. Hughes\u2019s life and work were important in shaping the artistic contributions of the Harlem Renaissance of the 1920\u2019s and his connection to the jazz music community heavily influenced his writing. Ms. Elia, 69, a former superintendent of schools in Florida\u2019s Hillsborough County, which includes Tampa, has pursued a modest and conciliatory course, and she gets along well with Ms. Fari\u00f1a. But a person with knowledge of the search said that she was probably a long shot given concerns about her effectiveness in her current job.\n\nA spokeswoman for the state education department said that Ms. Elia \u201chas had no discussions about this.\u201d\n\nKathleen Cashin, a member of the Board of Regents and a former superintendent in New York City, has also been considered, according to the person informed about the search. Dr. Cashin has been a critic of the state\u2019s Common Core-aligned tests and of using test scores to evaluate teachers.\n\nDr. Cashin said she has not been interviewed.\n\nUnder Mr. de Blasio\u2019s predecessor, Michael R. Bloomberg, the city was recognized as a hotbed of education reform, a front-runner in the push to use data, especially test scores, to evaluate schools, principals and teachers. Mr. Bloomberg\u2019s schools chancellor, Joel Klein, began giving schools letter grades and pioneered the practice of closing low-performing schools and replacing them with new schools on a large scale.\n\nUnder Mr. de Blasio and Ms. Fari\u00f1a, New York City\u2019s direction has been symbolic of a larger national retreat from the data-driven approach. \u201cA little bit of the air has gone out of the reform balloon,\u201d said Robert Pondiscio, a senior fellow at the Thomas B. Fordham Institute, a conservative think tank. If the movement\u2019s preferred strategies were \u201cgoing to drive watershed changes in outcomes in American education, we would have seen evidence of it by now, and I just don\u2019t think we have,\u201d he said.\n\nDuring his first campaign, Mr. de Blasio promised to de-emphasize test scores, end the school grading system and put a pause on closures. He has kept those promises. The Bloomberg administration fought with the teachers\u2019 union; Mr. de Blasio was endorsed by it.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Fari\u00f1a has focused on strategies like reforming school discipline, encouraging teacher collaboration and putting social services in schools. Mr. de Blasio\u2019s biggest success has come in expanding prekindergarten for all children, and the education department has used the idea of equity across schools to add algebra in more middle schools and increase access to Advanced Placement courses. It now offers the SAT free to all high school students.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile critics see the de Blasio administration\u2019s efforts as small-bore, supporters say that this work can make a big difference.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s not well understood outside of New York how much this chancellor has emphasized instruction,\u201d said Lynette Guastaferro, the executive director of Teaching Matters, an organization that supports schools in New York City in increasing teacher effectiveness.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor the next chancellor, Ms. Guastaferro said, \u201cThe opportunity is to take the ideas that are in play now and to take them to the next level.\u201d\n\nBut the system remains sharply segregated, with seemingly intractable achievement gaps and little action by the administration to push for integration.\n\nMr. de Blasio\u2019s search committee is made up of insiders from City Hall and the Education Department. Mr. de Blasio has pledged not to choose someone from outside education, as Mr. Bloomberg did twice, and the committee is focusing on people who have previously run urban districts. Given the makeup of the city\u2019s schools, which are nearly 70 percent black and Hispanic, many expect a new chancellor who looks like the student body.\n\nMaking things harder, the job is relatively low paid. Ms. Fari\u00f1a\u2019s current salary is $234,569. The superintendent in Los Angeles, the nation\u2019s second largest district with more than 640,000 students, makes $350,000.\n\nMr. de Blasio\u2019s relationship with the teachers\u2019 union has led some to suggest that Randi Weingarten, the president of the American Federation of Teachers and former president of the city union, will have veto power over the choice. Ms. Weingarten said she had \u201cnot had one conversation with the mayor about this,\u201d though she said some candidates had called to consult with her before being interviewed.\n\nMs. Weingarten said that she was \u201cnot pushing for anybody\u201d but that she believed Kelvin R. Adams, the superintendent of the St. Louis public schools, could do the job. When Dr. Adams was appointed in 2008, the state board of education had revoked the district\u2019s accreditation and given control to an appointed board. Since then, the district, which serves close to 22,000 students, roughly 80 percent of them African-American, has improved significantly, and its accreditation was restored last year.\n\nAsked through a spokeswoman whether he had been interviewed for the job, Dr. Adams declined to comment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Phillips, the mayor\u2019s spokesman, said on Wednesday that Mr. de Blasio would make a decision soon.\n\nPaul Hill, a professor at the University of Washington and the founder of the Center on Reinventing Public Education, said that there was a cyclical nature to the leadership of school systems, where the aggressive innovations of an outsider like Mr. Klein lead to demands for \u201can insider, somebody that educators identify with,\u201d like Ms. Fari\u00f1a, who had been a teacher and principal in New York.\n\nHe said that New York was due now for another outsider, if perhaps one less confrontational than Mr. Klein. What is needed, Dr. Hill said, is \u201csomebody that thinks about the system as a system.\u201d", "title": "Months of Searching Still Hasn\u2019t Found New Schools Chancellor", "authors": ["Kate Taylor"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "This category includes casualties caused by suicide bombers detonating in populated areas and targeted killings, but excludes those caused by ground fighting, airstrikes and explosions aimed principally at military targets, like some roadside bombs.\n\nOver all, the 84-page report notes, the number of civilian casualties declined 9 percent compared with the record numbers seen in 2016, driven primarily by a drop in casualties caused by ground clashes. It was the first decline in overall civilian casualties since 2012.\n\nThe report also says that despite a stepped-up pace of aerial bombardments aimed at the Taliban and Islamic State militants under President Trump\u2019s new strategy for the war, civilian casualties from airstrikes rose only 7 percent. The United Nations credited better targeting in the American-led air campaign, compared with previous years.\n\nThe Taliban\u2019s response to the airstrikes, however, has been ferocious, indicating that what Afghan officials openly call a Pakistani-backed insurgent group is hardly a spent force.\n\nThe report put a spotlight on \u201ccomplex attacks,\u201d a type of suicide assault that is becoming more deadly, United Nations officials say. These involve two or more commandos with suicide vests seizing a building or taking hostages, fighting for hours and detonating their explosives only when security forces close in.\n\nSuch attacks have recently become a hallmark of the war. The ensuing mayhem sends a clear message: that the Taliban can strike at will, even in ostensibly safe cities like Kabul, where the \u201cring of steel\u201d security cordon around the capital has been looking more like a colander.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDeaths from complex attacks and other suicide bombings rose to 605 last year from 398 in 2016, according to the report, with the highest number of civilian casualties in Kabul.\n\nOne of the deadliest single episodes of the war for civilians took place last May, when a gigantic truck bomb estimated to contain two metric tons of high explosives went off on a Kabul street during rush hour, killing 92 and wounding 491 people.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Taliban have also stepped up assassinations in the countryside, targeting doctors delivering polio vaccinations, workers on demining teams and religious leaders who preach against the group, among others, the United Nations said.\n\nThe report blamed the Islamic State\u2019s Afghan branch for 1,000 civilian casualties \u2014 399 killed and 601 wounded.\n\nIn a statement that the United Nations included with the report, the Taliban denied targeting civilians and blamed the United States and its allies for waging war in Afghanistan in the first place. \u201cFor the past 17 years, hundreds of thousands of innocent Afghans were killed after the influx of foreigners, and they are still being killed,\u201d it said.\n\nAtiqullah Amarkhel, a retired general and military analyst based in Kabul, said the report illustrated the failure of peace talks, as both the government and the Taliban were striving now for victory rather than a negotiated settlement. \u201cThe war has intensified. More airstrikes mean more suicide attacks\u201d in retribution, he said.\n\nAirstrikes \u2014 which are carried out only by the United States-led international forces, in an operation now called Resolute Support, and the Afghan Air Force, not by the Taliban and their allies \u2014 killed 295 civilian bystanders and wounded 336 more, the report said. That was the highest toll since the United Nations started counting in 2009, and possibly for the entire war.\n\nBut the casualty rate did not rise as fast as the tempo of air operations, a cornerstone of Mr. Trump\u2019s new strategy. The report said that reflected better targeting. \u201cWhile emphasizing that no civilian casualties are acceptable, the reduced harm ratio suggests improvements,\u201d it said.\n\nStill, the air war continued to take a toll on innocents.\n\nThe report cited an airstrike on Aug. 30 in the eastern province of Logar, apparently targeting a Taliban fighter who was lurking beside a house with a rocket-propelled grenade launcher. The strike killed 10 children and three women in the house, according to witnesses who spoke to United Nations researchers.\n\nThe report quoted a family elder, who was not identified, as saying, \u201cThis was too much for just one Taliban.\u201d", "title": "More Afghan Civilians Being Deliberately Targeted, U.N. Says", "authors": ["Andrew E. Kramer"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Several decades of commercial weight-loss diets, ranging from the Drinking Man\u2019s Diet to the low-carb Atkins Diet, each claiming to be the best way to get rid of unwanted fat with minimal or no sacrifice to taste and satiety, tempted those struggling with rising poundage. Most, however, involved a radical change in people\u2019s eating habits that was rarely sustainable. After a while, dieters returned to their old habits and regained the lost weight, often more than they had lost in the first place.\n\nAs Dr. Livingston stated, \u201cProviding patients with the false hope that if they only reduce one class of foods or another (e.g., carbohydrates or fats) they will lose weight can become frustrating, and may in part explain the failure of most diets.\u201d Even reducing consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages (which provide no nutrients beyond sweet calories), he wrote, \u201cis not likely to influence obesity at the population level,\u201d which has continued to increase even as soda consumption has declined.\n\nRather than a soda tax, Dr. Livingston endorsed taxes based on the calorie content of foods, and using the revenue generated \u201cto subsidize healthy foods to make them more affordable.\u201d Noting that \u201cthe common denominator for all successful diet plans is calorie reduction, irrespective of how that is achieved,\u201d he said that a slimmer American populace can be achieved only if attention is paid to the entire food supply.\n\nThat attention is unlikely to be paid anytime soon by either the processed food industry or government regulatory agencies, so it is up to consumers to take matters into their own hands, eyes and mouths. The goal is not radical change but a reduction in calories of 500 a day and/or an increase in physical activity to achieve a weekly deficit of 3,500 calories, the approximate amount in one pound of body fat.\n\nJust eliminating any of these \u2014 a bagel with cream cheese, one Big Mac, a Belgian waffle with a drizzle of syrup, one cup of H\u00e4agen-Dazs Green Tea ice cream, a Starbucks Venti Caramel Frappuccino with whipped cream, or one serving of a Cheesecake Factory Santa Fe chicken salad \u2014 will create that 500-calorie deficit. (For the sake of comparison, you\u2019d have to eat six apples or seven eggs to get to 500 calories. Or you could choose a two-cup Wegman\u2019s Caesar salad for a mere 200 calories.)\n\nIf you live in a city that mandates calorie listings on menus, pay attention before you order. Also always request dressings and sauces on the side and drizzle them on yourself rather than let the restaurant pour hundreds of calories on a low-calorie salad or chicken breast.", "title": "More Fitness, Less Fatness", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "But as a growing body of research suggests that youth tackle football is harmful to children\u2019s brains, not everyone is cheering.\n\n\u201cWhy bring girls into it? We should be taking the boys out of it,\u201d said Dr. Robert Stern, director of clinical research for Boston University\u2019s C.T.E. Center, which studies chronic traumatic encephalopathy, the degenerative brain disease caused by repeated blows to the head. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t make sense to expose our children to repetitive head impacts during periods of incredible maturation of the most important organ in our body, the brain.\u201d\n\nThe number of girls playing tackle football is still low compared to boys \u2014 of the 225,000 athletes in Pop Warner youth football programs, for example, just 1,100 are girls. According to the Sports and Fitness Industry Association, of the 5.5 million Americans who report playing tackle football, 596,000 \u2014 or 10.9 percent \u2014 are female.\n\nIt is notable that more girls want to play even as annual survey by the National Association of State High School Federations reported that participation in high school football went down 3.5 percent over the past five years.\n\nValerie Palmer-Mehta, a professor of communication at Oakland University whose work focuses on women and rhetoric, said the change is evidence of larger cultural shifts.\n\n\u201cWe can thank a constellation of cultural forces for women\u2019s involvement in football today, from Title IX to the women\u2019s movement, to strong female athletes who have persisted in pursuing their athletic dreams despite a lack of broader cultural support,\u201d Dr. Palmer-Mehta said.\n\nPhoto\n\nTeam sports like football provide well established social, physical and psychological benefits. But a Boston University study released last year found that kids who played tackle football before age 12 may be at higher risk for emotional and behavioral problems later in life. Another study took MRIs of the brains of kids before and after a single season of tackle football, removing from the study anyone who had a diagnosable concussion. Those researchers found that there was a change in the brain\u2019s white matter after just one season of play. And a study published in January in the journal Brain found the kind of changes typical of C.T.E. in the brains of four teenage athletes who had died after impact injuries.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Stern said that it is important to understand that the real danger for C.T.E. is not necessarily concussions, but subconcussive impacts. That is, repeated hitting is damaging \u2014 even if it doesn\u2019t cause a concussion.\n\nCrystal Sacco, league president and co-founder of Utah Girls Tackle Football, which started in 2015 and is expecting about 400 girls this season, said she doesn\u2019t hear many concerns from parents about their daughters playing tackle football.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI think they feel safe because they\u2019re playing against other girls,\u201d she said. And Dr. Stern noted that it is not possible to say whether the research \u2014 which looked only at boys \u2014 can be generalized to include girls because in an all-girls league, the force of the hits could be different.\n\nBut several studies have found that in sports with comparable rules between girls and boys, the rates of concussion are actually higher in women. Not only that, a 2012 statement from the American Medical Society for Sports Medicine highlighted research showing that female athletes sustain more concussions than their male counterparts, report more severe symptoms and have a longer duration of recovery than men.\n\n\u201cWhen it comes to female athletes\u2019 participation \u2014 regardless of age \u2014 we\u2019re lacking in truly understanding their experience around head injury,\u201d said Donna Duffy, co-director of the Female Brain Project, a research team at the University of North Carolina Greensboro studying head injuries in female athletes. \u201cWe\u2019re on the cusp of this; there\u2019s a growing body of literature suggesting that biological sex hormones may be impacted or disrupted when a head injury is sustained.\u201d\n\nBut while Dr. Duffy cautions more research is needed, she agrees with other researchers that prepubescent kids should avoid playing tackle football.\n\nParents whose daughters want to play football may feel they have a difficult decision to make. Several programs suggest flag football as a healthier option for both boys and girls, because they learn the strategy of the game and develop agility skills without risking the injuries of tackling.\n\nLast month, the Concussion Legacy Foundation, composed of doctors and former N.F.L. players, recommended that no children play tackle football before age 14. They\u2019ve created the Flag Football Under 14 program to encourage kids who want to play football to start with flag football until they\u2019re older, and Chris Nowinski, the foundation\u2019s co-founder and chief executive, says those guidelines apply to both boys and girls.\n\nThe N.F.L. has also been promoting its flag football program, which partners with U.S.A. Football to allow kids who play flag football to sport the uniform and logo of an N.F.L. team. The N.F.L. Flag program is open to both girls and boys, and according to Mr. Mumtaz, participation increased 45 percent in the past five years to more than 409,000 in 2017.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGirls varsity flag football has been sanctioned as a high school sport in five states. Jen Welter, the first female coach in the N.F.L., founded Grrridiron Girls, a flag football camp program designed to allow girls of all experience levels to participate. Her most recent camp in Boston had 90 participants.\n\nDr. Welter suggested that if a girl is interested in playing football, rather than shutting down the conversation entirely, parents could discuss what drives her desire to play and consider ways to play safely.\n\n\u201cFlag is one of those ways,\u201d she said, to allow them \u201cto learn about the game and to develop their skills.\u201d", "title": "More Girls Are Playing Football. Is That Progress?", "authors": ["Britni De La Cretaz"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Now a new dimension to this trend is emerging: Even upscale buyers who long favored Lexus, Cadillac, Jaguar and the German luxury brands are gravitating to trucks and S.U.V.s. What they are buying are often special-edition, fully loaded models, like Mr. Victorian\u2019s Raptor, that sell for as much as or more than BMW\u2019s flagship 7 Series sedan.\n\n\u201cWe are seeing it,\u201d said Tom Libby, an auto industry analyst at the research firm IHS Markit. \u201cThere is movement from luxury cars to luxury trucks.\u201d\n\nGeneral Motors\u2019 GMC brand \u2014 which sells only trucks and S.U.V.s \u2014 accounted for 11.3 percent of domestic sales of models with an average price of $60,000 or more in 2017, according to data from Edmunds.com. Five years earlier, the brand made up a mere 0.1 percent of those sales.\n\nFord and Chevrolet saw similar but smaller jumps, driven by increasing high-end truck and S.U.V. sales. At the same time, the portion of over-$60,000 sales for luxury brands including Porsche, Mercedes-Benz, Lexus, Jaguar and Cadillac shrank.\n\nAccelerating, and Sometimes Passing The rapid growth of the luxury truck and sport-utility vehicle segment has substantially increased United States automakers\u2019 share of domestic sales of models with an average price of $60,000 or more. % 20 15 10 5 0 Porsche Mercedes-Benz Lexus GMC Ford Chevrolet 2012 2017 % 20 15 10 5 0 Porsche Mercedes-Benz Lexus GMC Ford Chevrolet 2012 2017 % 20 15 10 5 0 Porsche Mercedes-Benz Lexus GMC Ford Chevrolet 2012 2017\n\nThat is providing a tailwind for the Detroit automakers when overall new-vehicle sales in the United States are slowing. General Motors, Ford and Fiat Chrysler, with its Jeep brand, dominate in trucks and S.U.V.s, and now they\u2019re scrambling to roll out more high-end versions.\n\nIt\u2019s a competitive \u2014 and crucial \u2014 segment. With demand for cars shriveling, the Detroit three and even some foreign manufacturers acknowledge they are now losing money on many of the cars they sell. But a $60,000 truck can generate tens of thousands of dollars in operating profit.\n\nAt a recent investor conference, G.M. outlined a plan to produce more of the pricey Denali versions of GMC S.U.V.s and trucks. The company showed data indicating that the Denali line had an average sale price of $56,000 \u2014 more than the average price of a BMW, a Mercedes-Benz or an Audi.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis thing,\u201d G.M.\u2019s president, Dan Ammann, said of the Denali line, \u201cis a money machine.\u201d\n\nThe other Detroit carmakers are heading in the same direction.\n\nIn October, Ford began making new versions of its eight-passenger Ford Expedition and Lincoln Navigator full-size S.U.V.s, and already has decided to make 25 percent more this year than it originally planned. In January, Navigators sold for an average of $77,000, thanks to strong sales of the top-of-the-line Black Label edition.\n\nFiat Chrysler is preparing to add more Jeep models, including a pickup and a full-size Grand Wagoneer.\n\nIn 2017, S.U.V.s and crossovers made up 41 percent of the market in the United States, up from 30 percent in 2013, according to Autodata. Luxury cars have gone in the opposite direction: They made up 5.4 percent of the market last year, down from 7.5 percent four years earlier.\n\nAnd the priciest S.U.V.s and trucks are selling fastest. The high-end Lariat, King Ranch and Raptor models make up more than half of all F-150 sales, up from one-third a few years ago. Denali editions account for 29 percent of GMC\u2019s sales, up from 21 percent.\n\nLow gasoline prices are one reason that sales of high-end trucks are rising. Years ago, pickups and big S.U.V.s often traveled only 11 or 12 miles on a gallon of gas. Today, their fuel economy is often double that.\n\n\u201cThe complaint that S.U.V.s are horrible on gas is not such a roadblock anymore,\u201d said Mark Scarpelli, owner of two Chevrolet dealerships and a Chrysler-Dodge-Jeep franchise in Illinois.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the same time, automakers have appointed special-edition S.U.V.s and trucks with the same kinds of advanced technologies and comfort features that consumers once found only in luxury cars. Want an interior trimmed in African mahogany? You can get it in the Black Label Navigator. Want an S.U.V. that accelerates like a Porsche (and isn\u2019t a Porsche)? Try the Jeep Grand Cherokee Trackhawk and its 707-horsepower V8.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChuck Ducher, a retired school psychologist in Onsted, Mich., just bought an F-150 Lariat with a bevy of options, including heated rear seats. \u201cI can put my mother back there, and she\u2019s in heaven,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s no doubt in my mind this is a luxury vehicle.\u201d\n\nWes Lutz, owner of a Chrysler-Dodge-Jeep dealership in Jackson, Mich., said he was surprised at the way customers were snapping up the most expensive models on his lot. This month, he had two Trackhawks this month, each with a sticker price of $93,000.\n\n\u201cThey won\u2019t be here more than a few weeks,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s incredible. We never used to play in that price range.\u201d\n\nIncreasing competition from upmarket S.U.V.s and trucks is adding to the struggles of the luxury makers. Most have long relied on cars for the bulk of their sales, and are suffering now that bigger vehicles are in favor. In 2017, for example, BMW\u2019s sales to individual customers at dealerships in the United States fell more than 5 percent, according data shared among automakers. The decline in BMW\u2019s total sales was less because of a big jump in sales to rental car fleets, a type of customer that luxury brands tended to shun in the past.\n\nOut in Tacoma, Wash., Gary Gilchrist sees the trend just about every week at his GMC dealership.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been taking in Lexuses on trade-ins, BMWs,\u201d he said. This month, he said, a customer turned in a 2012 BMW 550i and bought a $71,000 GMC Sierra Denali pickup.\n\n\u201cPeople used to want German cars for the image factor,\u201d Mr. Gilchrist said. \u201cNow, if you have a Denali, you get that. People turn their heads to look.\u201d", "title": "More Luxury Buyers Ditch the Imports and Pick Up a Truck", "authors": ["Neal E. Boudette"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "YAMBIO, South Sudan \u2014 More than 300 child soldiers were released Wednesday by armed groups in South Sudan, the second-largest such release since the country\u2019s civil war began five years ago. All sides in the conflict have recruited more than 19,000 children as fighters.\n\nThe \u201claying down of the guns\u201d ceremony for 87 girls and 224 boys was the first step in a process that should end with at least 700 child soldiers freed in the coming weeks, the United Nations said.\n\nThe United Nations has helped win the release of almost 2,000 child soldiers in the past few years. More than 10 percent of them have been younger than 13.\n\nHuman rights groups say child recruitment continues, even as the government says it has committed to ending the practice.", "title": "More Than 300 Child Soldiers Freed in South Sudan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Tsvangirai proved no match for Mr. Mugabe\u2019s wily political maneuvering, which drew on his record as a leader in the struggle against white minority rule, his often violent intolerance of opposition, and his ability to marshal support from regional and broader African political forces.\n\nMr. Mugabe frequently inveighed against Britain, the former colonial power, and depicted his adversaries, including Mr. Tsvangirai, as puppets of the country\u2019s former imperial overlords.\n\nWhen Mr. Tsvangirai became prime minister in 2009 under a power-sharing agreement brokered by neighboring South Africa after the flawed vote of 2008, the pact and his new job diminished his ability to oppose the president.\n\nEven as he accused Mr. Mugabe of flouting provisions of the so-called unity government, many critics said Mr. Tsvangirai had been outwitted and co-opted by the president, his former sworn enemy. Indeed, Mr. Tsvangirai seemed to settle into a more comfortable relationship with him, built on the privileges of office.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 2012, after Mr. Tsvangirai celebrated his second marriage with a glitzy party attended by guests arriving in Bentleys, Mercedes and BMWs, some of his followers were aghast at the ostentatiousness of the display and questioned who had paid for it.\n\nBy the time elections were held the following year, Mr. Tsvangirai was greatly weakened. He accused Mr. Mugabe of rigging the election and challenged him in the courts. But Mr. Mugabe claimed victory with 61 percent of the vote, compared with 34 percent for Mr. Tsvangirai, and it seemed that Mr. Tsvangirai\u2019s brush with high office was over. That was certainly Mr. Mugabe\u2019s view.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe have thrown the enemy away like garbage,\u201d Mr. Mugabe said. \u201cWe say to them: You are never going to rise again.\u201d\n\nFor all that, Mr. Tsvangirai appeared in recent months to be attempting a comeback, even as he made frequent trips abroad for colon cancer treatment.\n\nIn 2017, he was part of a so-called united front with other opposition groups, including the Zimbabwe People First movement, which is led by Joice Mujuru, a former vice president and onetime guerrilla fighter who was ousted by Mr. Mugabe in 2014.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIn 2013, we don\u2019t know what hit us,\u201d Mr. Tsvangirai said last year, finally conceding that he had been beaten in the polls that year. \u201cWe were defeated. But this time, we will refuse to be defeated.\u201d\n\nThe intention behind the alliance with Ms. Mujuru was to challenge Mr. Mugabe in elections in 2018, but that strategy was eclipsed by the military-backed intervention last November that brought Emmerson Mnangagwa, a former ally of Mr. Mugabe\u2019s, to power.\n\nAfter Mr. Mugabe was overthrown, there was fevered speculation that Mr. Mnangagwa would seek a more inclusive form of rule than that of the leader he had just ousted. Instead, Mr. Mnangagwa lauded Mr. Mugabe and announced a government of his own supporters, including the military.\n\nEven as he fell ill with cancer, however, Mr. Tsvangirai failed to groom a successor, and he left behind a fractured party with no obvious leader to challenge Mr. Mnangagwa in the elections expected this year.\n\nThe eldest in a family of nine, Mr. Tsvangirai was born on March 10, 1952, in the Gutu district of Masvingo Province, in central Zimbabwe. The family was poor, and Mr. Tsvangirai abandoned formal schooling early to start work, first as a textile weaver and then as a plant foreman in a nickel mine.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1978 he married Susan Mhundwa, with whom he had six children before her death in a car accident in 2009. (Mr. Tsvangirai was injured in the crash, with a truck near Harare, as was the car\u2019s driver.) He married Elizabeth Macheka three years later.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis personal life at the time raised eyebrows. While he was planning to marry Ms. Macheka, another woman claimed to be his wife from a traditional ceremony in 2011. A court ruled in her favor.\n\nA third woman also filed court papers claiming that she had been engaged to Mr. Tsvangirai. He eventually apologized publicly to his supporters.\n\n\u201cI had no intention to hurt anyone,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was a genuine search\u201d for a new wife.\n\nLike Mr. Mugabe and Mr. Mnangagwa, Mr. Tsvangirai was a member of the dominant Shona ethnic group. But while they chose armed resistance from exile in the so-called front-line states bordering what was then Rhodesia, Mr. Tsvangirai became a labor union leader, defending workers\u2019 rights and rising through the ranks. He was elected secretary general of the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions in 1988.\n\nHis political roots in the labor movement set him apart from those like Mr. Mugabe and Mr. Mnangagwa, who drew their legitimacy from the seven-year war against white minority rule. Initially an ally, he became a thorn in the side of Mr. Mugabe and his ZANU-PF party.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut as the president\u2019s intolerance became more evident, the gulf between the two men widened.\n\nFamed for his vicious criticism of Mr. Mugabe\u2019s government, Mr. Tsvangirai was twice detained during his time as a labor leader, the first time in 1989 after he voiced concern over rising state repression. Three years later, he was arrested for ignoring a ban on public protests ordered by Mr. Mugabe.\n\nIn 1999, he founded the Movement for Democratic Change as a challenger to Mr. Mugabe\u2019s ZANU-PF Party. He soon discovered that opposition to Mr. Mugabe was a dangerous business.\n\nIn the late 1990s, he went on record in the local news media claiming that assailants had tried to throw him from his office window. In 2001, he narrowly escaped the hangman\u2019s noose when he was tried on charges of plotting to kill Mr. Mugabe before the 2002 presidential election.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2003, Mr. Tsvangirai faced a treason charge for urging his party supporters to topple Mr. Mugabe\u2019s government. The case was thrown out without going to trial.\n\nFour years later, he was among many opposition supporters who were beaten as they tried to stage an antigovernment rally. Mr. Tsvangirai sustained head injuries that drew broad international media attention.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cYes, they brutalized my flesh,\u201d he said in a message from his hospital bed. \u201cBut they will never break my spirit. I will soldier on until Zimbabwe is free.\u201d\n\nMr. Tsvangirai\u2019s party split in two in 2005, when a faction led by Welshman Ncube, the party\u2019s former secretary general, broke away.\n\nThe two sides disagreed on whether they should participate in planned Senate elections. Mr. Ncube thought the opposition should participate; Mr. Tsvangirai did not.\n\nThen came the turmoil and bloodletting of 2008. Mr. Tsvangirai was initially optimistic about the future of the unity government, despite being denied an outright victory in the first round of voting, in which he had trounced Mr. Mugabe, his longtime rival.\n\n\u201cWe will deliver a new Zimbabwe to the people,\u201d he said while announcing his party\u2019s decision to become part of a unity government.\n\nBut events offered a different course.", "title": "Morgan Tsvangirai, Longtime Foe of Mugabe in Zimbabwe, Dies at 65", "authors": ["Jeffrey Moyo", "Alan Cowell"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "STARKVILLE, Miss. \u2014 Morgan William has gotten used to life as a minor celebrity. It\u2019s her jump shot she\u2019s worried about these days.\n\nSo hours before Mississippi State\u2019s shootaround on Monday, a day that ended with the Bulldogs defeating South Carolina, 67-53, in a rematch of last season\u2019s women\u2019s basketball national championship game, William walked into her team\u2019s practice facility and took shot after shot, until she had made 10 attempts from seven spots on the floor. By the time the shootaround actually began for her teammates, William was drenched with sweat and downing a chocolate milk to get her through the next grind.\n\nAt the arena that night, she was out early, too, almost two hours before the game tipped off in front of 10,794 fans. She was still trying in vain to find the rhythm of her shot. Careful jumpers from predetermined angles. Free throws. Anything to rediscover the form that led to the most famous shot of her career: the pull-up jumper she made at the buzzer to beat top-ranked Connecticut in last season\u2019s Final Four.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know why, I feel like this year I\u2019m missing wide open shots,\u201d William said. \u201cIt\u2019s all mental though. When I go shoot in the gym, I make a lot of shots. I get in the game, I just need to take my time.\u201d", "title": "Morgan William Is Still Chasing That Perfect Shot", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMoria Catherine Cappio and Joseph Brian Frederick were married Feb. 24 at St. Helen\u2019s Roman Catholic Church in Westfield, N.J. The Rev. William T. Morris performed the ceremony.\n\nMs. Cappio, 37, is the vice president for early childhood programs at Children\u2019s Aid, an education nonprofit organization in New York. She graduated from Boston College and received a master\u2019s degree in education from Harvard.\n\nMs. Cappio is a daughter of Mary B. Cappio and Philip J. Cappio of Scotch Plains, N.J. The bride\u2019s father is the president of Cappio Landscaping in Scotch Plains. Her mother is the finance director for the Dominican Sisters of Caldwell, a religious organization in Caldwell, N.J.\n\nMr. Frederick, 49, works as a video journalist and producer for The Associated Press in New York. He graduated from Kutztown University in Pennsylvania.\n\nMr. Frederick is a son of Anna V. Frederick of Spring City, Pa., and the late Warren E. Frederick Sr. The groom\u2019s mother retired as a type setter for the Fidelity Mutual Life Insurance Company, which is based in Radnor, Pa. His father worked as a chef at the Spring Ford Country Club in Royersford, Pa. He is also was a technical sergeant in the Air Force from 1949 to 1971. He was last stationed in Berkenfeld, Germany.\n\nThe groom\u2019s first marriage ended in divorce.\n\nThe couple met in 2011 on a New Jersey Transit train bound for Philadelphia.", "title": "Moria Cappio, Joseph Frederick", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "In the years after the American-led invasion, cheaply printed and brazenly pirated books from Pakistan were as dominant as that country\u2019s fruits and vegetables in the markets of Kabul.\n\nAfghanistan\u2019s new government faced the enormous task of rebuilding the educational system, which had been savaged by decades of civil war, followed by five years of a Taliban regime that closed schools and destroyed foreign-language books. That meant millions of new textbooks, which initially were printed in Pakistan. But as relations with that country soured, the government steered those textbook contracts to a few major Afghan publishers.\n\nForeign aid underwrote the school system, so the textbook business jump-started the book publishing industry. Because millions of textbooks had to be printed in a short period of time, Aazem and a few other companies invested in their own presses, which went largely idle once the school publishing season was over. Then the new publishers began translating Western books from English into Dari and Pashto, the country\u2019s two main languages.\n\nOther publishers sprung up, renting the bigger companies\u2019 presses.\n\n\u201cThere was such a curiosity and thirst to know about the world and how people think about Afghanistan,\u201d said Davood Moradian, director general of the Afghan Institute for Strategic Studies, a research organization whose picturesque ancient campus, the Fort of Nine Towers, is a favored venue for book parties. \u201cThe book industry is a growing phenomenon to try to satisfy that thirst.\u201d\n\nThe first locally published books were nonfiction titles about Afghanistan, by Western authors, and they sold so well, there was a rush into the business. Books like \u201cGhost Wars: The Secret History of the C.I.A., Afghanistan and Bin Laden From the Soviet Invasion to September 10, 2001,\u201d by Steve Coll, and \u201cThe Envoy: From Kabul to the White House, My Journey Through a Turbulent World,\u201d by Zalmay Khalilzad, hit the best-seller lists here.\n\n\u201cThere was this huge pent-up demand from so many years without new books,\u201d said Dr. Ajmal Aazem, a pediatrician whose father founded the publishing house that bears their name. The Aazem company is publishing books as fast as it can, limited only by a shortage of qualified translators from English into local languages. Aazem\u2019s 2017-18 goal is to print three new titles a day, 1,100 a year \u2014 a huge number for any publisher.\n\nThe publishing house is festooned with life-size posters of recent book covers, and the bookshop is full of volumes in artfully arranged helical piles or displayed on the walls with English and Persian versions opening from right and left, side by side. The floor in the middle of the sales room has been raised to accommodate the presses on the floor below, making a sort of platform with comfortable armchairs.", "title": "Most Afghans Can\u2019t Read, but Their Book Trade Is Booming", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "In 2002, when the two Koreas were in a reconciliatory mood, North Korea even broadcast the World Cup matches in the South. In 2014, it broadcast daily highlights from the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, although none of its athletes competed there. That makes the absence of Olympic broadcasting in the North all the more conspicuous this year.\n\n\u201cThe last thing the North Korean authorities want is for its people to envy the South,\u201d said Jung Gwang-il, a North Korean defector.\n\nLike its former socialist allies, North Korea has recognized the role of sports in reasserting what it calls the country\u2019s ideological superiority. When its athletes returned home with golds, it honored them with car parades and rewards, like new apartments. The most celebrated example was Jong Song-ok, who won the World Championships marathon in Spain in 1999.\n\nMs. Jong famously said she won because while running, she imagined Kim Jong-il, then North Korea\u2019s leader, \u201cbeckoning me from the finish line.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Kim, the father of the current leader, made her a \u201chero of the republic,\u201d the highest honor in the country, for lifting the morale of his people still, in the grip of a devastating famine. (Defectors from the North later relayed a different story: Ms. Jong, sent to Spain as a pacemaker for another North Korean runner, ran for the life of her father, who was in prison.)\n\nThis year, Kim Jong-un has no athlete who can glorify him as Ms. Jong did his father.\n\nNorth Korea has won only two medals in the Winter Olympics, a silver in speedskating in 1964 and a bronze in short-track speedskating in 1992. The International Olympic Committee granted the 22 North Koreans at the current games last-minute exemptions to compete in five sports in Pyeongchang, including a dozen who joined the South Korean women\u2019s ice hockey squad to create the first inter-Korean Olympic team ever. None is expected to stand on a medal podium.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Mr. Kim had quite a different goal for the Olympics, analysts said.\n\nWhen he used his New Year\u2019s Day speech to propose sending North Korean athletes to the Olympics, it was clear that his interest was not in Olympic golds but in creating a political d\u00e9tente so he could weaken international sanctions imposed on his country. At home, he described his decision as an act of magnanimity.\n\nSouth Koreans \u201care so grateful to us for giving a helping hand to their Winter Games, which were at the risk of becoming the least popular Olympics in history because of the political situation,\u201d the North\u2019s official newspaper, Rodong Sinmun, said last month.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSouth Korea has repeatedly urged North Korea to join the Olympics, hoping that its participation would help ease tensions and help make the games a success. That created an opening for Mr. Kim to engage in what critics called a \u201ccharm offensive.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim sent hundreds of cheerleaders, musicians and singers to the Games to supplement his meager sports contingent. They stole much of the show on the sidelines of the games. He also sent the most unusual Olympic guest: his sister, whose visit to the South, including meetings with President Moon Jae-in, created a media frenzy. Ms. Kim delivered her brother\u2019s invitation for Mr. Moon to visit the North for a summit meeting, raising hopes for a d\u00e9tente, as Mr. Kim intended.\n\n\u201cKim Jong-un didn\u2019t really have anyone to send to the Olympics, except for his cheerleaders and singers,\u201d said Joo Sung-ha, a North Korean defector who works as a reporter for the mass-circulation South Korean daily Dong-A Ilbo. \u201cThey were the best card he had.\u201d\n\nThe state-run North Korean news outlets covering the Olympics focused on these nonsports activities to highlight Mr. Kim\u2019s inter-Korean initiative.\n\nThey carried front-page reports on his sister\u2019s visit. They told North Koreans that their arts troupe performed to \u201cpacked audiences\u201d in the South. They also reported the North Korean cheerleaders rooting for the joint Korean ice hockey team but did not mention that it lost 8-0 to Switzerland and Sweden. The team also lost 4-1 to Japan, the Koreans\u2019 historical enemy, on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cKim Jong-un did not look for Olympic golds in the first place,\u201d said Kim Yong-hyun, a professor of North Korean studies at Dongguk University in Seoul. \u201cHis aim was to use the Olympics to create a mood for dialogue in order to head off sanctions and pressure and to soften his country\u2019s negative image. And he has been more successful there than he hoped for.\u201d", "title": "Most North Koreans Can\u2019t Actually Watch the Olympic Games", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "The coral reefs around the Turks & Caicos Islands are a major tourist attraction, and Mark Parrish is trying to make sure the visitors he takes there don\u2019t kill them with cosmetics.\n\nHe co-owns Big Blue Unlimited, a tour operation that guides snorkeling, kayaking and other adventurous excursions around the islands. The company\u2019s website states that, \u201cBig Blue will ONLY ALLOW the use of 100 percent biodegradable sunscreen on all of our trips. Non-biodegradable sunscreen IS NOT TO BE USED on Big Blue trips.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe make it mandatory, which is easier said than done,\u201d said Mr. Parrish. \u201cThe key is telling people well in advance, putting it on the website and saying this is our policy and giving them a chance to shop at home.\u201d\n\nAfter decades of learning that sunblock is vital to a healthy beach vacation, consumers may wonder what\u2019s wrong with their Coppertone. But recent studies that link the active ingredients in protecting skin from damaging ultraviolet rays to coral bleaching has led to a global push for more reef-safe sunscreens.", "title": "Most Sunscreens Can Harm Coral Reefs. What Should Travelers Do?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "The White Helmets group \u201cdoes serve in opposition areas and its work inherently benefits the forces that Russia opposes,\u201d Mr. Cordesman wrote in an email.\n\nAllegations against the White Helmets have been increasing, with the Russian news site RT accusing the group of having terrorist affiliations and plotting a chemical weapons \u201cprovocation.\u201d Such claims have been discredited by Middle East experts, among them Charles Lister, a senior fellow at the Middle East Institute, a nonpartisan think tank, who said accusations that the White Helmets were linked to ISIS or Al Qaeda were \u201cpatently absurd\u201d and \u201cpuerile.\u201d\n\n\u201cRT-led disinformation campaigns on matters like this operate on another level to reality,\u201d Mr. Lister wrote in an email. \u201cThere\u2019s only one motivation here: to justify the indiscriminate bombing campaigns that have come to exemplify Russia and the Syrian regime\u2019s day-to-day war.\u201d\n\nMr. Fayyad said he had been repeatedly trolled on social media sites. After the film was shown in Davos, Switzerland, one of Google\u2019s top articles about the screening was a hit piece on the Russian news site Sputnik, according to a screenshot taken by his team. It might be a stretch to assume that academy voters are paying much mind to Russian news sites, but Mr. Fayyad believes that detractors, in their fervor to discredit the White Helmets, are also aiming to derail his film\u2019s Oscar chances, something he is trying to offset by sounding the alarm.\n\nMr. Fayyad is from the countryside outside Aleppo and, in March 2011, was working on another film, about the 1982 massacre in the city of Hama, when Syria\u2019s civil uprising began. Mr. Fayyad was arrested \u2014 he was accused of spreading false news, he said \u2014 imprisoned and tortured. (His nails were ripped out, he was shackled and hung by his hands from a ceiling, and sensitive parts of his body were shocked with electricity, he said.)\n\nFor all the horrors he suffered, Mr. Fayyad was struck by his fellow prisoners\u2019 resistance and determination to survive, and how they buoyed each other by singing songs in the lowest of voices. She was in the bedroom with two of the children; one child opened the apartment door to allow the officers inside, the police said.\n\nThe officers entered the apartment and spotted Ms. Baskerville outside of the window before she fell, the police said. But when they do appear in her work, they leave an impression.\n\nIn her first novel, \u201cA Feather on the Breath of God\u201d (1995), which contains extraordinary writing about ballet, a man emigrates from China to Panama. As his boat leaves the dock, his dog, which has been brought to see him off, releases an unearthly howl.\n\nNunez\u2019s novel \u201cMitz\u201d (1998) is the tender biography of a sickly marmoset that was adopted by Leonard Woolf and became a fixture of Bloomsbury society. Nunez described Mitz with her customary \u00e9lan: \u201cHow small she was! A mere scrap of a monkey. You could have balanced her on your palm, like a fur apple. A head no bigger than a walnut, two black pips for eyes, and the tiniest nostrils \u2014 mere pinpricks.\u201d\n\nIn her apocalyptic novel \u201cSalvation City\u201d (2010), about a plague, a family has a basset hound named Sadie. Mr. Gates\u2019s lawyer, Thomas C. Green, who was hired in recent weeks, has refused to discuss the case.\n\nThe investigation has been an unwanted distraction for the White House. After Mr. Gates and Mr. Manafort were indicted, a former national security adviser and a foreign policy aide to Mr. Trump have pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I. about their Russian connections. And 13 Russian operatives were charged with trying to sow chaos in the presidential election and tip the vote toward Mr. Trump.\n\nThe court records paint an unflattering portrait of the man who ran Mr. Trump\u2019s presidential campaign from June to August of 2016, as the candidate secured the Republican nomination and moved into the general election against Hillary Clinton. Prosecutors say he concealed years of lobbying for the pro-Russia government in Ukraine and never properly registered with the United States government for that work. In the process, they say, he laundered millions of dollars in proceeds and misled investigators about how he received those funds.\n\nHe and Mr. Gates shielded millions of dollars from American tax authorities, court papers show, by moving the funds through foreign bank accounts around the world: in Cyprus, the Seychelles, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.\n\n\u201cManafort and Gates hid the existence and ownership of the foreign companies and bank accounts, falsely and repeatedly reporting to their tax preparers and to the United States that they had no foreign bank accounts,\u201d the indictment said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTwo of the largest loans totaled $16 million and were made by one bank. The bank is not identified in the indictment, but the description fits what The New York Times reported last year about loans to a company connected to Mr. Manafort called Summerbreeze L.L.C., which borrowed millions from Federal Savings Bank of Chicago, headed by Stephen M. Calk, an economic adviser to Mr. Trump at the time.\n\nMr. Manafort\u2019s dealings with Federal Savings began in July 2016, when he was running Mr. Trump\u2019s presidential campaign, and continued after he was ousted a month later. In each instance, according to the indictment, Mr. Manafort and Mr. Gates altered financial statements for their consulting business to make it easier for Mr. Manafort to qualify for mortgages.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Mueller also appears to have obtained communications between Mr. Manafort and his son-in-law, Jeffrey Yohai, who ran a real estate investment business in Los Angeles in which Mr. Manafort had invested millions of dollars. The business went bankrupt, and Mr. Yohai himself fell under F.B.I. scrutiny.\n\nIn a message cited in the indictment, Mr. Manafort appears to ask Mr. Yohai to help in a ruse to make it seem that he was living in a building owned by Mr. Manafort, thereby comporting with information Mr. Manafort had put on a mortgage application.\n\nThe original indictment did not explicitly bring tax charges, an omission that experts had predicted that Mr. Mueller would ultimately correct. The first indictment also relied heavily on accusations that Mr. Manafort violated foreign lobbying laws, which have rarely been used at trial. The new indictment gives prosecutors more options.\n\nUnlike the original indictment, which was filed in Washington, the one unsealed on Thursday was brought in a federal court in Alexandria, Va. Prosecutors said they had filed the charges there because the crimes had occurred in the Eastern District of Virginia and Mr. Mueller did not have authority to bring them in Washington. The fact that the two men are now facing similar indictments in two federal courts means that Mr. Manafort\u2019s case will probably be moved to Alexandria.\n\nMr. Manafort joined the campaign in March 2016 to ensure Mr. Trump had enough votes among delegates to the Republican National Convention to clinch the party\u2019s nomination for president. He was elevated to campaign chairman in May, and after Mr. Trump\u2019s first campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, was removed in June, Mr. Manafort took control.\n\nDays earlier, he had attended a meeting at Trump Tower with Russians who had promised incriminating information about Hillary Clinton. Mr. Manafort has maintained that he only briefly attended the meeting, which was arranged by Mr. Trump\u2019s son Donald Trump Jr.\n\nBut just two months later, questions arose about money Mr. Manafort had received from his work in Ukraine, and Mr. Manafort stepped aside. He remained in Mr. Trump\u2019s orbit, often speaking with the candidate.", "title": "Mueller Files New Fraud Charges Against Paul Manafort and Rick Gates", "authors": ["Michael S. Schmidt", "Matt Apuzzo"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump is correct that nothing produced publicly by Mr. Mueller to date has claimed any wrongdoing by the president nor any illegal collaboration with the Russians seeking to influence the 2016 election. The indictment of the Russians \u2014 who are accused of flooding Facebook and other social media with disinformation and propaganda \u2014 cited only contact with \u201cunwitting individuals\u201d connected with Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign.\n\nThe charges against Mr. Manafort and Mr. Gates depict an expansive money-laundering and fraud operation stemming from their work for Ukrainian leaders aligned with Moscow, not from their involvement in the campaign. Michael T. Flynn, the president\u2019s former national security adviser, and George Papadopoulos, a former campaign adviser, pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I. about their contacts with Russians or intermediaries but not to criminal acts related to collusion.\n\nJohn M. Dowd, the president\u2019s private lawyer, pointed to Mr. Trump\u2019s cooperation with the investigation as evidence that he had nothing to hide. He noted that the White House had voluntarily turned over more than 20,000 pages to Mr. Mueller, including documents related to Mr. Flynn and Mr. Comey, and the campaign provided 1.4 million pages.\n\nMore than 20 White House officials, including eight members of the counsel\u2019s office, voluntarily gave interviews to the special counsel or congressional investigators, as did 17 campaign employees and 11 others affiliated with the campaign, he added.\n\n\u201cI give great credit to the president for his extraordinary cooperation with the special counsel,\u201d Mr. Dowd said.\n\nStill, as the pileup at the courthouse indicates, allies of Mr. Trump acknowledged that the investigation had taken a toll.\n\n\u201cThe good news for the White House is that more than 18 months since the F.B.I. probe began, there is still no evidence of Russian collusion,\u201d said Christopher Ruddy, the chief executive of Newsmax and a friend of Mr. Trump. \u201cThe bad news is that the special counsel has a scorched-earth prosecution aimed at crushing the president\u2019s associates.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think the president is worried about the investigation himself,\u201d he added, \u201cbut it clearly bothers him that people are being prosecuted simply because they worked for his campaign.\u201d\n\nInside the White House, officials expressed calm resignation on Friday as Mr. Gates marched into the courthouse. But there was low-grade concern out of recognition that Mr. Gates was in a lot of meetings over a long period of time.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile Mr. Gates joined the campaign with Mr. Manafort, his longtime business partner and mentor, he stayed after Mr. Manafort was fired. He rode on Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign plane and served as liaison to the Republican National Committee. After the election victory, he joined the transition as a right hand to Thomas J. Barrack Jr., the president\u2019s close friend who ran the inaugural operation.\n\nThe fact that Mr. Gates was allowed to plead guilty to just two relatively lower-level charges indicated to legal experts that he must have something of value for Mr. Mueller. The presumption in Mr. Trump\u2019s circle is that Mr. Gates may not have any incriminating information about the president but could be a dangerous witness against Mr. Manafort, who in turn could threaten Mr. Trump.\n\nMr. Manafort participated in a meeting in June 2016 along with Donald Trump Jr., the candidate\u2019s son, and Jared Kushner, his son-in-law, with a Russian lawyer on the promise of receiving incriminating information about Hillary Clinton on behalf of Russia\u2019s government.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Manafort also reportedly offered during the campaign to give \u201cprivate briefings\u201d to Oleg V. Deripaska, a Russian oligarch allied with President Vladimir V. Putin who claimed Mr. Manafort owed him $19 million. Prosecutors are interested in learning how a Republican convention platform plank on Russia\u2019s intervention in Ukraine was watered down.\n\nOn the other hand, Mr. Trump\u2019s defenders said Mr. Gates\u2019s credibility as a witness may be tainted by the fact that one of the charges he pleaded guilty to was lying to the F.B.I. even as he was negotiating his plea deal. Ty Cobb, the White House special counsel, has said that Mr. Manafort has no damaging information against Mr. Trump. Mr. Manafort insisted again on Friday that he was innocent and would fight the \u201cuntrue piled up charges.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s argument that none of this has anything to do with him resonates with many of his supporters, who have echoed his repeated insistence that there was no collusion with Russia. But being surrounded by people who are prosecuted has damaged other presidents even when they were not directly implicated.\n\nJimmy Carter endured significant political damage when his confidant and budget director, Bert Lance, was accused of banking irregularities. Even putting aside the Iran-contra scandal and the Monica S. Lewinsky affair, Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton were besieged by investigations of their aides unrelated to them. In Reagan\u2019s era, it became known as the \u201csleaze factor.\u201d Mr. Clinton\u2019s team drew the scrutiny of six independent counsels other than Kenneth W. Starr.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the current case, the targets so far have included not just a \u201ccoffee boy,\u201d as Mr. Papadopoulos was described by an adviser to Mr. Trump, but the president\u2019s top two campaign officials and national security adviser. While Mr. Trump has dismissed the relevance of allegations against Mr. Manafort because they involved business dealings before the campaign, the latest indictment claims that he was scheming to defraud banks while serving as Mr. Trump\u2019s chairman.\n\nMoreover, it remains unclear why he volunteered to work for Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign without pay at a time when he was experiencing significant financial pressure.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s defenders have focused on questioning the original basis for the investigation, accusing the F.B.I. of misconduct in relying on an unverified dossier assembled by a former British spy hired by investigators working for Mrs. Clinton\u2019s campaign.\n\nTo the extent that Mr. Mueller is exploring whether Mr. Trump obstructed justice by firing Mr. Comey, the president\u2019s defenders contend that under the Constitution, he has the power to dismiss executive branch officials and dictate their work. They also point to testimony by Mr. Comey and other officials who said the investigation was not impeded.\n\nTherefore, they argue, the original order appointing Mr. Mueller was itself invalid and should be revoked.\n\nIn the meantime, they are left to interpret the clues from Mr. Mueller\u2019s actions just like everyone else. David B. Rivkin Jr., a former White House and Justice Department lawyer under Reagan and President George Bush, said the totality of Mr. Mueller\u2019s actions still did not add up to a threat to Mr. Trump.\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t make sense to unfold piecemeal an indictment of Russian entities and Russians if you have any hope of building a collusion case. It makes no logical sense,\u201d he said. \u201cTo me, at least, what he\u2019s done does underscore that there\u2019s no collusion there. That leaves him with the obstruction of justice narrative which I think is constitutionally flawed and isn\u2019t going to go anywhere.\u201d\n\nMr. Wittes said Mr. Mueller\u2019s actions could be seen as building a pyramid \u2014 establishing that there was a Russian influence campaign and assembling a group of cooperating witnesses. But the special counsel has not tipped his hand yet.\n\n\u201cThe basic contours of the puzzle is that he\u2019s constructed his actions in a way that we don\u2019t know where it\u2019s leading,\u201d he said, \u201cand that\u2019s on purpose.\u201d", "title": "Mueller Is Gaining Steam. Should Trump Worry?", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Aboard Air Force One on a flight home from Europe last July, President Trump and his advisers raced to cobble together a news release about a mysterious meeting at Trump Tower the previous summer between Russians and top Trump campaign officials. Rather than acknowledge the meeting\u2019s intended purpose \u2014 to obtain political dirt about Hillary Clinton from the Russian government \u2014 the statement instead described the meeting as being about an obscure Russian adoption policy.\n\nThe statement, released in response to questions from The New York Times about the meeting, has become a focus of the inquiry by Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election. Prosecutors working for Mr. Mueller in recent months have questioned numerous White House officials about how the release came together \u2014 and about how directly Mr. Trump oversaw the process. Mr. Mueller\u2019s team recently notified Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyers that the Air Force One statement is one of about a dozen subjects that prosecutors want to discuss in a face-to-face interview of Mr. Trump that is still being negotiated.\n\nThe revelation of the meeting was striking: It placed the president\u2019s son and his top campaign officials in direct contact with a Russian lawyer who promised damaging information on Mrs. Clinton, and an email to the president\u2019s son emerged saying that the information was part of Russia\u2019s effort to help the Trump campaign. The special counsel is investigating how those revelations were handled in real time in part because the president was involved in his administration\u2019s response.\n\nSome lawyers and witnesses who have sat in or been briefed on the interviews have puzzled over Mr. Mueller\u2019s interest in the episode. Lying to federal investigators is a crime; lying to the news media is not. For that reason, some of Mr. Trump\u2019s advisers argue that Mr. Mueller has no grounds to ask the president about the statement and say he should refuse to discuss it.", "title": "Mueller Zeros In on Story Put Together About Trump Tower Meeting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "And when Donald J. The police surrounded him, eventually bringing him down to the ground and then arresting him.
