If structured like earlier NASA public-private partnerships, like the ones for carrying cargo and crew to the space station, the money would be split between two or more companies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy contrast, the United States has spent close to $100 billion building and operating the International Space Station.\n\nThe end of financing in 2025 does not necessarily mean the station would be discarded then. The Washington Post reported on Sunday that an internal NASA document asserts, \u201cIt is possible that industry could continue to operate certain elements or capabilities of the ISS as part of a future commercial platform.\u201d\n\nBut space experts so far do not see how that would be viable economically because NASA currently spends $3 billion to $4 billion a year.\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t really seen anyone talking about that,\u201d said Tommy Sanford, the executive director of the Commercial Spaceflight Federation, a trade group representing many of the new space companies. \u201cI think that\u2019d be difficult.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Sanford said the federation was concerned about setting a specific end date. He said it would be better to define benchmarks that commercial alternatives would need to achieve before the International Space Station is retired.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn recent years, more companies have started using the station in areas like pharmaceutical research and manufacturing of fiber optical cable.\n\n\u201cIf we abruptly end that, without a smooth transition plan,\u201d John Elbon, vice president and general manager of space exploration at Boeing, said at last week\u2019s conference, \u201call that investment will be for naught.\u201d\n\nFor a greater focus on the moon, the budget plan describes investing in commercial companies to develop and fly robotic landers to carry experiments and other payloads to the moon.\n\nThose companies could include Moon Express and Astrobotic Technology, two companies originally created to compete for a $20 million grand prize in the Google Lunar X Prize. The X Prize Foundation conceded last month that none of the remaining competitors would be able to reach the moon before the prize expires on March 31. Both companies still plan to head to the moon in the next couple of years.\n\nIn addition, Blue Origin, a space company started by Jeff Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon, has proposed a larger lander called Blue Moon that could deliver several tons of cargo to the surface of the moon.\n\nEfforts to increase research and development aimed at next-generation space technologies for a range of human and robotic missions, one of the priorities of the Obama administration\u2019s space policy, would be refocused on nearer-term development on moon missions.\n\nFor astronauts, the goal is still to reach \u201cthe vicinity of the moon\u201d in 2023. That is the current schedule for the first crewed launch of the Space Launch System, which would fly around the moon but not land.\n\nUnder the proposed timeline, work on a lander would not start until that year.", "title": "NASA Budgets for a Trip to the Moon, but Not While Trump Is President", "authors": ["Kenneth Chang"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 The American network NBC has apologized after one of its analysts drew anger for a comment during coverage of the Pyeongchang Olympics that seemed to gloss over South Korea\u2019s painful history with Japan, its former colonial master.\n\nThe analyst, Joshua Cooper Ramo, made the comment while appearing with Katie Couric and Mike Tirico during the opening ceremony on Friday. Noting that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan was in attendance, Mr. Ramo described Japan as \u201ca country which occupied Korea from 1910 to 1945, but every Korean will tell you that Japan is a cultural, technological and economic example that has been so important to their own transformation.\u201d\n\nThe remark immediately ignited outrage in South Korea, the Olympic host nation, where resentment of Japan\u2019s harsh early 20th-century annexation of the Korean Peninsula continues to simmer. Just last month, Mr. Abe\u2019s attendance at the Games was in question after tensions escalated over Japan\u2019s refusal to reissue an apology for the Japanese military\u2019s role in forcing Korean and other women to work in military brothels during World War II.", "title": "NBC Apologizes After Japan Comment Draws Anger in South Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "The NBC Entertainment executive Jennifer Salke was named the new head of Amazon Studios on Friday, ending a nearly four-month search that began when Roy Price was ousted after a sexual harassment allegation.\n\nAmazon had been on the hunt for a new executive, placing a strong emphasis on finding a woman, since October. In that time, streaming rivals like Netflix, Hulu and Apple have continued to gobble up television projects.\n\nAmazon has made the occasional splash at the Golden Globes and the Emmys with shows like \u201cTransparent\u201d and \u201cThe Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,\u201d but it has failed to gain the same kind of standing that Netflix and even Hulu have within Hollywood\u2019s creative community.\n\nIt will be up to Ms. Salke, 53, to essentially hit the reset button.\n\n\u201cWhat stood out about Jen was the deep relationships she has nurtured with creators and talent over her career,\u201d Jeff Blackburn, Amazon\u2019s senior vice president for business development and entertainment, said in a statement.", "title": "NBC Executive Takes Over Amazon Studios", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "NBC is turning to its own bench to replace Jennifer Salke, who announced last week that she was leaving the network to run Amazon Studios.\n\nThe network said on Thursday that Lisa Katz and Tracey Pakosta will become the co-presidents of scripted programming, and both will report to the NBC Entertainment chairman, Robert Greenblatt.\n\nMs. Katz has been running NBC\u2019s drama department for the past year and a half. Before coming to NBC, Ms. Katz worked at Fox, where she helped develop \u201cThis Is Us\u201d (Fox\u2019s TV studio is the production house behind the current NBC hit) and \u201cEmpire.\u201d Those are the two biggest dramas in broadcast television in the last three years.\n\nMs. Pakosta has been running the NBC comedy department since 2015. Ms. Pakosta, who had previously been working at NBC\u2019s corporate cousin, Universal Television, helped develop NBC\u2019s two biggest comedies at the moment, \u201cThe Good Place\u201d and \u201cSuperstore.\u2019\n\nThe two new executives join Paul Telegdy, the network\u2019s reality television chief, in NBC\u2019s entertainment leadership structure. Mr. Telegdy and Ms. Salke were Mr. Greenblatt\u2019s key lieutenants in leading NBC\u2019s surprising turnaround from a moribund network to No. 1 in the ratings.", "title": "NBC Promotes Two Women to Lead Scripted Programming", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "NBC\u2019s prime-time ratings are down 16 percent from the Sochi Games four years ago, though that has been countered by NBCSN\u2019s most-watched week ever. Here in Stamford, the hundreds of employees working on the Pyeongchang Games are too busy putting out most of NBCUniversal\u2019s 2,400 hours of live coverage over 19 days to dwell on the ratings.\n\nNBC rented out 600 rooms at area hotels, so employees don\u2019t have to return home at night.\n\n\u201cMy shift right now is basically 3 in the afternoon to 9 in the morning,\u201d said Dean Walker, a coordinating producer who normally works out of NBC\u2019s facilities in Dry Creek, Colo. Marc Buono, a digital video manager, joked that \u201cyou have to time your final cup of coffee,\u201d or risk missing a precious hour or two of sleep.\n\nPhoto\n\nDays blend into night, and employees lose most sense of time; there are signs reminding everybody which day of the Olympics it is. Ahead of the Games, many shifted their sleeping schedules to match Pyeongchang \u2014 14 hours ahead of the East Coast \u2014 and wake up around 5 p.m. here.\n\nIf they can hold on for \u201cbreakfast\u201d long enough, the on-site commissary is known to serve tasty omelets after midnight.\n\nOn an ordinary day, when the Olympics are not happening, about 750 people work out of the facility, a gleaming 300,000-square-foot structure that formerly was a Clairol factory. NBC Sports took it over in 2012. The facility was designed specifically to handle the load of an Olympics, and during the Games the number of workers swells to about 1,300, in addition to the 2,000 NBC staff members in South Korea.\n\nThe Stamford crew passes the hours monitoring dozens of video and audio feeds that zip across the Pacific Ocean from South Korea on one of four fiber-optic lines before spider-webbing their way across the United States. The journey takes just milliseconds.\n\nThe broadcast operations center also receives satellite feeds from South Korea, a fail-safe to ensure the Games stay on-air no matter what happens. These feeds take a comparatively sluggish two seconds to reach Stamford. \u201cIt\u2019s a speed-of-light problem,\u201d said Tim Canary, the vice president of engineering.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs it has for past Olympics, NBC is calling much of the action stateside in an effort to save money. This takes place in Studio 4, usually used for storage but now filled with eight portable black booths, each about the size of a small bedroom. On one side of each occupied booth are two producers; on the other are two announcers calling an event \u201clive\u201d while watching monitors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast Thursday, the 2006 bronze medalist Pete Fenson, a curling analyst, was commentating on a match from one of the booths. Events can even be called by announcers in both South Korea and Stamford, through a process called \u201ccollaborative off-tube.\u201d\n\nFrom prime time to morning, NBCSN shows the Olympics live. During the day in the United States, and the Korean night, it shows replays or events that were not shown live. For one hour each night, the figure skating preview show \u201cOlympic Ice\u201d is directed from an auxiliary control room, so workers can clean the main control room, which is in use the 23 other hours of the day.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf the \u201cOlympic Ice\u201d set looks familiar, that\u2019s because it is the one used for \u201cFootball Night in America,\u201d with small modifications. There\u2019s an extra desk, and the red and yellow lights of \u201cFootball Night in America\u201d have become the cool blues and purples of the Pyeongchang Games.\n\nThere are also 20 or so operations staffers mostly monitoring digital streams. As more Americans move away from consuming sports on traditional televisions, the streaming operation has become vital.\n\nJust seven days into the Pyeongchang Games, the number of streamed minutes was poised to double the 420 million from Sochi four years ago. NBC has since announced that Pyeongchang streaming has tripled the Sochi numbers. At the lowest point, usually 4 a.m. to 5 a.m. Eastern, the streaming levels are the same as NBC sees for a decent English Premier League game, while at the end of the workday they match those for \u201cSunday Night Football.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou just lose track of time because the audience is so high,\u201d said Eric Black, the digital chief technology officer.\n\nThat is doubly true for those in the highlights factory, a large room full of interns sitting at rows of computers, each decorated with a different country\u2019s flag. Eagle-eyed, the interns each watch a feed in search of something that would make a great highlight.\n\n\u201cThe job is to not miss either of those things, especially those hiding in plain sight,\u201d said Eric Hamilton, the digital video director in charge of the highlights factory.\n\nThe work can be tedious, but gems emerge.\n\nAfter Mikaela Shiffrin won gold in the giant slalom, the highlights factory went back and put together a video of Shiffrin riding the chairlift to the event and preparing for her run. That video did not immediately air on NBC because other skiers were still racing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOther times, the job is more straightforward. A highlight of Shaun White\u2019s gold medal run in the halfpipe has already been viewed 18 million times.", "title": "NBC\u2019s Olympic Nerve Center Is in ... Connecticut", "authors": ["Kevin Draper"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Advertising revenue dropped across the N.F.L., and networks were forced to give away free commercials to advertisers because of missed ratings guarantees. NBC also lost money televising \u201cThursday Night Football\u201d the past two seasons, leading it to submit a low bid to retain the rights. Fox won the bidding to show it for the next five seasons.\n\nNBC said it expected $500 million in advertising revenue from the Super Bowl, where commercials were sold for about $5 million for each 30-second time slot.\n\nBut the importance of this Super Bowl to NBC went beyond ratings and any revenue it took directly from ad sales. The Winter Olympics are coming \u2014 the opening ceremony in Pyeongchang, South Korea, is Friday, and the Games end Feb. 25 \u2014 and NBC is the first network to broadcast the Super Bowl and the Winter Olympics in the same year since CBS did so in 1992.\n\nThe network persuaded many advertisers to buy package deals of commercial time during both the Super Bowl and Olympics, and, as you might have noticed (and then noticed again and again), NBC used the Super Bowl as a giant platform to promote the Games.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe network knows it has to educate many American viewers. Pyeongchang, not exactly a familiar location, is also in an unfavorable time zone for NBC, 14 hours ahead of the East Coast. NBC used its captive Super Bowl audience to try to excite people about some of the athletes and events they will see over the next three weeks.\n\nThe network\u2019s pregame show featured almost as much talk about the Olympics as it did for football, and a 60-second ad featuring the American skier Lindsey Vonn aired during halftime.\n\nOne familiar face will be absent from his usual perch at the Games: Bob Costas, who has been the prime-time host of every NBC Olympic broadcast since the Barcelona Games in 1992. The network lured Mike Tirico away from ESPN in 2016 as Costas\u2019s long-term replacement, and last year decided he would be the face of the Pyeongchang Olympics.\n\nCostas was still expected to host Super Bowl coverage with Tirico already in South Korea, however, but that job instead went to Dan Patrick and Liam McHugh. Costas told SportsBusiness Journal last month that he has \u201clong had ambivalent feelings about football\u201d and that the game should be hosted by someone who is \u201cmore enthusiastic\u201d about the sport.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCostas has indeed been vocal in recent years about his discomfort with the connection between playing football and head trauma. Those concerns were borne out in stark fashion during the Super Bowl, when Patriots wide receiver Brandin Cooks was ruled out of the game after suffering a brutal, but legal, helmet-to-helmet hit in the second quarter.\n\nWhile concerns about concussions are most likely one of the factors that have led to the N.F.L.\u2019s regular season ratings decline, the fact that the Super Bowl viewership drop was less severe than the regular season decrease drives home the fact that the N.F.L.\u2019s problem is the frequency with which hard-core fans watch rather than casual fans turning off the television.\n\nAccording to Mike Mulvihill, Fox Sports\u2019 head of research and planning, while total N.F.L. viewership has dropped 19 percent over the last two seasons, the league\u2019s reach \u2014 meaning the total number of people watching some part of a game \u2014 has declined just 4 percent.\n\nPeople are watching less football, but they still tune in for the big events.", "title": "NBC\u2019s Super Bowl Win (Everyone Knows About the Olympics Now, Right?)", "authors": ["Kevin Draper"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "NPR says it has already taken steps to bolster its workplace culture, including making changes to the complaint process, creating an anti-harassment support group, mandating in-person sexual harassment training and strengthening its human resources department.\n\nThe report suggested further steps, including conducting background checks and asking questions about prior sexual harassment issues during the hiring process, retaining an outside firm to investigate complaints and conducting a study of gender equity in pay and promotions.\n\n\u201cWe are committed to implementing its recommendations to ensure we have a workplace where everyone feels safe and respected,\u201d Isabel Lara, an NPR spokeswoman, said in a statement. \u201cThe past months have shown that sexual harassment is a serious, widespread problem, pervasive in every industry and many organizations; NPR is no exception.\u201d\n\nThe report said that some NPR employees had been warned about Mr. Oreskes\u2019s behavior, but the knowledge stayed within a \u201cwhisper network\u201d that didn\u2019t extend outside the newsroom.\n\n\u201cAs a result, information that many staff members felt was widespread actually was not known to HR or leadership,\u201d the report said.\n\nThe timeline revealed by the investigation shows that NPR executives frequently expressed concern about Mr. Oreskes\u2019s behavior, but repeatedly addressed it through conversations instead of disciplinary action.\n\nWhen NPR hired Mr. Oreskes in March 2015, a search firm delivered \u201coverwhelmingly positive\u201d feedback, with no criticism of his workplace conduct, the report said. But a member of the eight-person hiring committee was aware of one episode and raised it to human resources: A woman said Mr. Oreskes had left her multiple voice mail messages late at night asking to discuss his book while they were at a conference. The woman said that she had heard a similar story about another woman at the conference and that \u201cthe incidents made the conference attendees very uncomfortable,\u201d according to the report. Nonetheless, the committee unanimously voted to hire him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the summer of 2015, two female NPR employees said they had dinners with Mr. Oreskes that turned excessively personal, the report found. He gave one of them a hug after dinner, which \u201cmade her feel uncomfortable,\u201d the report said. They reported the dinners to human resources in October 2015, and the company\u2019s general counsel, Jon Hart, spoke with Mr. Oreskes within a week.\n\n\u201cThis conversation was described as a \u2018stern talking to\u2019 in which Mr. Hart told Mr. Oreskes that sexual comments were not appropriate and warned him that it could not happen again,\u201d the report said. \u201cMr. Oreskes committed to Mr. Hart that it would not happen again.\u201d\n\nBut in the spring of 2016, Mr. Oreskes expensed several dinners with women, including one with a female NPR employee, the report found. In August, Mr. Hart and Deborah A. Cowan, the chief financial officer, met with him and asked for business justifications for his dinners, while cautioning him to make sure he had justifications for dinners going forward.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nExecutives again discussed his behavior in October 2017, and they decided that Jarl Mohn, the chief executive, \u201cwould have an additional counseling session with Mr. Oreskes,\u201d which he did, the report said.\n\n\u201cThey decided not to terminate Mr. Oreskes at that time because there were only two reported incidents of conduct involving NPR employees and both had been addressed two years prior,\u201d the report found.\n\nAfter Mr. Mohn asked the staff to come forward with harassment complaints, an employee said Mr. Oreskes had groped her in the spring of 2017. Around the same time, a woman told NPR\u2019s legal team that Mr. Oreskes had kissed her without her consent when he was employed by The Times.\n\nHe was suspended on Oct. 31 after the Washington Post article was published. Shortly after, an NPR employee said Mr. Oreskes had made an inappropriate comment in 2016 during a conversation about her career, and had invited her to his beach cottage to \u201ccontinue the conversation over wine,\u201d the report found. Mr. Mohn asked for his resignation after hearing her complaint.\n\nMr. Oreskes\u2019s career in journalism stretches back about four decades. He started at The Daily News and joined The Times in 1981, holding many jobs in two decades at the paper, including chief political correspondent and deputy managing editor. He worked at The Associated Press from 2008 to 2015, serving as a vice president and senior managing editor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe newly released report, which was not edited by NPR employees, was based on interviews with 86 current and former employees, 71 of whom were women.\n\nReached by email on Wednesday, Mr. Oreskes said that the law firm that prepared the report did not ask to speak to him, but that he continued to support NPR and its mission.\n\nHe pointed to a statement he made on the day he resigned: \u201cI am deeply sorry to the people I hurt. My behavior was wrong and inexcusable, and I accept full responsibility.\u201d", "title": "NPR Executive Was Warned Repeatedly About Sexual Harassment, Report Finds", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHere\u2019s what to expect in the week ahead:\n\nTRADE\n\nNafta negotiations resume in Mexico City.\n\nThe seventh round of negotiations over the future of the North American Free Trade Agreement will kick off this week in Mexico City, as negotiators from Canada, Mexico and the United States once again meet to try to hammer out their differences over the trade pact. President Trump\u2019s recent statements suggest that the threat of the United States imminently withdrawing from the agreement has receded in recent months. But the countries are still at odds over issues like rules on automobile manufacturing and investment. The countries will face a challenging task as they try to move toward consensus on these issues before the end of the negotiating round on March 5. Ana Swanson\n\nECONOMY\n\nJerome Powell to give his first testimony as Fed chairman.\n\nJerome H. Powell, the new Federal Reserve chairman, who arrived in that role as a relative unknown, will make his public debut on Tuesday morning when he testifies before the House Financial Services Committee. On Thursday, he will reprise the performance before the Senate Banking Committee. Mr. Powell has said that he plans to continue the Fed\u2019s gradual retreat from its economic stimulus campaign, slowly raising interest rates and slowly reducing the Fed\u2019s bond portfolio. While the economy is gaining strength, Mr. Powell is likely to emphasize that so far, stronger growth is increasing the Fed\u2019s confidence in its plans, rather than giving it a reason to move more quickly. Binyamin Appelbaum\n\nBernanke and Yellen to talk about her career and the economy.\n\nSome events sell themselves: On Tuesday afternoon at the Brookings Institution, Janet L. Yellen, the former Federal Reserve chairwoman, will be interviewed by Ben S. Bernanke, her predecessor at the Fed. It will be Ms. Yellen\u2019s first public appearance since she completed her four-year term as Fed chairwoman this month. Both Ms. Yellen and Mr. Bernanke are now fellows at Brookings and so free to speak candidly about their experience leading the Fed through the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis. Brookings says they\u2019ll address Ms. Yellen\u2019s career, \u201cher time at the Fed, her observations about the current state of the economy and the challenges that confront us.\u201d Binyamin Appelbaum\n\nData on income and spending may show impact of bonuses.\n\nAfter passage of the Republican tax overhaul in December, big companies including Apple and Walmart said they would share their tax savings with employees in the form of raises and bonuses. Economists are skeptical of the cause and effect, noting that the low unemployment rate is also putting pressure on companies to raise pay. But whatever the reason, the bonuses are real \u2014 and could show up in data that the Commerce Department will release on Thursday. The report, which covers Americans\u2019 income and spending in January, won\u2019t capture the direct effects of the tax cuts, which mostly didn\u2019t show up in workers\u2019 paychecks until February. But it could show the impact of bonuses and pay increases, as well as any extra spending they might have generated. Don\u2019t expect a big bump, however: Economists surveyed by Bloomberg said both income and spending probably grew more slowly in January. The Federal Reserve, meanwhile, will be watching the report for any signs that inflation is picking up. Ben Casselman\n\nGOVERNMENT\n\nChinese business and political leaders gather for annual meeting.\n\nMore than 3,000 officials from across China will gather in Beijing at the end of the week for the annual twin sessions of the country\u2019s top advisory body and the country\u2019s Legislature. The advisory body, the Chinese People\u2019s Political Consultative Conference, includes many tycoons and other business leaders and will start meeting on Saturday. The Legislature, the National People\u2019s Congress, will start meeting the next Monday and is expected to stay in session for nearly two weeks.\n\nThe congress typically starts with the annual work report of the premier, Li Keqiang. That is followed by the rubber-stamp approval of a long list of government initiatives \u2014 a couple of constitutional amendments are expected this year to cement the primacy of President Xi Jinping. Perhaps most important is that the congress will confirm a new slate of government ministers after the twice-a-decade Communist Party national gathering in Beijing last October. Most of the new lineup is already known, but considerable uncertainty surrounds who might succeed Zhou Xiaochuan, who turns 70 this year and is expected to retire after serving as governor of the central bank since 2002. Keith Bradsher", "title": "Nafta Talks, and Powell\u2019s First Testimony as Fed Chairman", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Pelosi was part of the bipartisan negotiations that led to the budget deal, which included $131 billion for Democratic priorities \u2014 including public works, children\u2019s and veterans\u2019 health programs and opioid abuse prevention \u2014 as well as an infusion of money for hurricane-ravaged areas like Puerto Rico and Texas. She said she understood that, for many in her caucus, the deal was \u201ctoo good\u201d to vote against.\n\nBut the leader had also made personal commitments to the Dreamers, hundreds of thousands of whom have been shielded from deportation under an Obama-era program called DACA, for Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals. Mr. Trump rescinded the program and gave Congress until early March to come up with a replacement. Ms. Pelosi and her fellow Democrats had promised the young immigrants that a measure to help them would be included in any spending deal \u2014 a promise she was not able to keep.\n\nIn staging her marathon monologue \u2014 the longest in more than a century, according to the House historian \u2014 and pressing for no votes on the spending bill, Ms. Pelosi hoped to pressure Speaker Paul D. Ryan into scheduling a free and open debate on immigration, as Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, did in the Senate.\n\nMr. McConnell is giving the Senate a week to debate any immigration issue that senators wish to bring up; rather than put a measure on the floor, he has taken the highly unusual step of introducing a shell bill that senators may amend and shape as they see fit.\n\nIn effect, he is allowing the Senate to build an immigration bill from scratch; no one has any idea how it will turn out.\n\nMr. Ryan has refused to follow suit, though he has pledged to take up an immigration bill at some point, so long as it is one the president supports. And now that the spending bill has been adopted, Democrats in the House may have lost whatever leverage they had to demand protections for the Dreamers.\n\n\u201cWe would like to have had a commitment from the speaker, but we\u2019re not stopping,\u201d Ms. Pelosi said.\n\nThat is unlikely to mollify her critics on the left, who say she did not work hard enough to force Speaker Ryan\u2019s hand. Representative Luis V. Most news organizations, including The Times, do not capitalize the C.\n\nBut confusion persists. In 2014, a Kenyan man trying to attend a United Nations conference in Pyeongchang mistakenly flew to Pyongyang.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInyoung Kang contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Nancy Pelosi, Rob Porter, Winter Olympics: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Fabray nearly gave her life for the show. In 1955, she was hospitalized for almost two weeks after being knocked unconscious by a falling pipe backstage during a broadcast.\n\nThe stage and the small screen turned out to be Ms. Fabray\u2019s m\u00e9tiers, but she started out in film. Her first movie role was as a lady-in-waiting to Elizabeth I (Bette Davis) in \u201cThe Private Lives of Elizabeth and Essex\u201d (1939). In that and the two other film dramas she made that year, she was billed as Nanette Fabares. She changed the spelling of her surname after too many public mispronunciations.\n\nMs. Fabray had one notable film success: the Comden and Green musical \u201cThe Band Wagon\u201d (1953), directed by Vincente Minnelli. The film included the number \u201cTriplets,\u201d in which she, Fred Astaire and Jack Buchanan played infants, with adult-size heads and torsos but short, stubby baby legs.\n\nPhoto\n\nRuby Nanette Bernadette Theresa Fabares was born on Oct. 27, 1920, in San Diego. Her family soon moved to Los Angeles, where Nanette began working in vaudeville at age 4. Her father, Raul, was a train engineer; her mother, the former Lily McGovern, took in boarders. Ms. Fabray recalled that her other childhood job was ironing lodgers\u2019 shirts.\n\nShe attended Los Angeles Junior College and studied acting with the Austrian-born director Max Reinhardt, but she had academic difficulties because of an undiagnosed hearing problem. The problem was eventually corrected by surgery, and she became a spokeswoman and advocate for the hearing-impaired.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Fabray was 21 when she appeared in her first Broadway show, \u201cLet\u2019s Face It,\u201d (1941), a musical comedy, starring Danny Kaye and Eve Arden, about three married women who hire soldiers as escorts. She left the show in 1943 to take a small replacement role in Rodgers and Hart\u2019s \u201cBy Jupiter.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter appearing in two short-lived shows, \u201cMy Dear Public\u201d and \u201cJackpot,\u201d Ms. Fabray replaced Celeste Holm in 1945 as the star of Harold Arlen and Yip Harburg\u2019s \u201cBloomer Girl,\u201d a musical comedy set in the 1860s. Two years later she married one of the show\u2019s publicists, David Tebet. They divorced in 1951, and in 1957 she married Ranald MacDougall, a screenwriter.\n\nMr. MacDougall died in 1973. Besides her son, Ms. Fabray is survived by two grandchildren.\n\nAlthough she continued to work on Broadway after her Tony win, Ms. Fabray began concentrating on television. Her first credited appearance was on \u201cThe Chevrolet Tele-Theater\u201d in 1949, but she had already been involved in demonstrations of the new medium.\n\nAfter the Caesar show, Ms. Fabray attempted a sitcom of her own, but \u201cThe Nanette Fabray Show\u201d (1961), also known as \u201cWestinghouse Playhouse,\u201d lasted less than a season. She went on to four decades of television movies and guest appearances on series, including \u201cLove, American Style,\u201d \u201cThe Mary Tyler Moore Show\u201d (as Ms. Moore\u2019s mother), \u201cOne Day at a Time\u201d (as Bonnie Franklin\u2019s mother) and the 1990s sitcom \u201cCoach,\u201d on which she played the mother of her real-life niece Shelley Fabares.\n\nPhoto\n\nBack on the New York stage in 1963, she received a Tony nomination for her role as a fictional first lady in \u201cMr. President,\u201d Irving Berlin\u2019s last Broadway show. Her final Broadway appearance went less well: \u201cNo Hard Feelings,\u201d a 1973 comedy that also starred Eddie Albert, closed after opening night.\n\nMs. Fabray continued to do stage work (in 2007 she appeared in \u201cThe Damsel Dialogues\u201d in Sherman Oaks, Calif.), but said more than once that live television was her first love. As she told a reporter for The New York Times in 1955, \u201cIt involves a form of insanity that reminds me of make-believe games that you played as a child.\u201d\n\nWhen asked about her career, she declared that comic ability was unteachable but acknowledged one factor in her success. During her third Broadway show, she told the Archive of American Television in 2004, things changed because \u201cI fell in love with the audience, and I fell in love with performing.\u201d", "title": "Nanette Fabray, Star of TV and Stage Comedies, Dies at 97", "authors": ["Anita Gates"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "In statements made to prosecutors after the murders, Ms. Ortega, who is now 55, said that she was angry with the Krims, that they asked her to work too hard and that her skin had been damaged by cleaning products she was forced to use. Did she act out of vengeance or delusion?\n\nIn the years since the murders, little about Ms. Ortega\u2019s life or frame of mind has been illuminated, which is one reason to have imagined that the \u201cThe Perfect Nanny,\u2019\u2019 a French novel inspired by the tragedy, would compel American audiences when it arrived here in translation last month. Ms. Ortega\u2019s avatar in the novel, Louise, a middle-aged widow with huge debts, providing care for the two young children of a Parisian couple, might feed some hunger to know.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOriginally published as \u201cChanson Douce,\u2019\u2019 or \u201cLullaby,\u201d the book was an enormous success in Europe, selling 600,000 copies in its first year, translated into 18 languages and winning the Prix Goncourt, France\u2019s most prestigious literary prize. The author, Leila Slimani, had quickly become a celebrity in France, reportedly pursued by president Emmanuel Macron to become the minister of culture. In advance of the book\u2019s publication in this country, she was profiled in The New Yorker.\n\nSince the arrival of \u201cGone Girl,\u2019\u2019 six years ago, we have been living through a long, peak moment of the domestic thriller, and yet \u201cThe Perfect Nanny\u2019\u2019 has failed to enjoy the reception here that it has had abroad. A.J. Finn\u2019s \u201cWoman in the Window,\u2019\u2019 a novel about a former child psychologist abandoned by her family, who spends her hours drinking wine and staring out of her Harlem brownstone at a mysterious family across the street, made its debut in the No. 1 spot on the New York Times best-seller list. \u201cThe Perfect Nanny,\u2019\u2019 despite the expectations surrounding it and strong reviews, did not achieve similar recognition.\n\nIn the quarters where it might have had created the most commotion, among mothers in Brooklyn for instance, it seems to have made little impact at all. At first I wondered whether this had to do with the book\u2019s exploitative nature, but we consume cultural products that take advantage of real and recent suffering all the time. The 2016 film, \u201cManchester by the Sea,\u2019\u2019 is clearly a work of art inspired by the Christmas Eve fire, a few years earlier, in which a Connecticut mother lost her three daughters and her parents. It was seen and analyzed endlessly.\n\nIn novels like \u201cGone Girl\u201d and its imitators \u2014 \u201cThe Girl on the Train,\u201d among them \u2014 the heroines are drunks and nuts; they are in other words, not like you. Myriam, the mother at the center of \u201cThe Perfect Nanny,\u201d more artfully composed than many of the books in its genre, is an urbane lawyer, knocked off balance by motherhood but only to the point of a very recognizable disturbance. She is in other words, very much like you.\n\n\u201cMila\u2019s tantrums drove her mad, Adam\u2019s first burblings left her indifferent,\u201d Ms. Slimani writes of Myriam\u2019s reaction to her children. \u201cSometimes she wanted to scream in the street like a lunatic. They\u2019re eating me alive, she would think.\u201d The honesty with which Ms. Slimani writes about maternal ambivalence coupled with the fact that Myriam is relieved of the burdens of motherhood in the most horrific way give the novel a darkness that is, perhaps to many tastes, best left unexplored. Some ideas may be better sublimated.", "title": "Nanny Case Is a Parent\u2019s Nightmare, Too Horrifying to See Up Close", "authors": ["Ginia Bellafante", "Big City"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "The case touched a nerve among the growing ranks of China\u2019s urban middle class, many of whom depend on less well-off workers from rural areas for child care, cooking and cleaning.\n\nMr. Lin, a successful entrepreneur, lived in a $3 million apartment in the middle of Hangzhou, a rich technology capital. Ms. Mo, who started working as a live-in nanny for the family in 2016, was a migrant from the southern province of Guangdong.\n\nIn the immediate aftermath of the fire, some expressed sympathy for Ms. Mo, saying she was overburdened by debt and desperate.\n\nBut public opinion turned decidedly against Ms. Mo amid news reports that portrayed her as a gambling addict who had stolen and pawned the family\u2019s jewelry, and squandered money the family had lent her.\n\nThe reaction to the court\u2019s decision on Friday was overwhelmingly positive.\n\n\u201cIf she died 100 times it wouldn\u2019t be enough,\u201d wrote one user on Weibo, a microblogging platform.\n\nMs. Mo was shown in state news media reports standing solemnly in a courtroom. She did not speak at the sentencing, according to reports.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a letter made public during her trial, Ms. Mo expressed remorse, saying, \u201cIf my death will make everything start over again, I\u2019m willing to be sentenced to death.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was unclear if Ms. Mo would appeal the decision. Under Chinese law, the Supreme People\u2019s Court in Beijing must review death sentences.\n\nWhile the Chinese government says it has reduced the use of the death penalty in recent years, it does not release statistics, and China is still believed to execute far more prisoners than any other country. Critics of the legal system argue that the government uses the penalty disproportionately against poorer people.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe case of Ms. Mo also brought attention to shoddy construction and lax safety at many residential buildings in China, another concern of middle-class families.\n\nThe authorities found that a fire hydrant outside the Lin family building, which is managed by Greentown Service Group Company, lacked sufficient water pressure and a place for firefighters to park. Greentown has rejected the accusations.\n\nA lawyer for Ms. Mo, Dang Linshan, said developers should also be held responsible for the tragedy. He accused court officials of bias, saying they had denied his request to hear testimony from dozens of firefighters who responded at the scene, according to news reports.\n\n\u201cJustice isn\u2019t served by simply putting the accused to death,\u201d he told Caixin, a prominent Chinese newsmagazine.\n\nMr. Dang declined to be interviewed on Friday.\n\nThe court said in its decision that Ms. Mo had investigated methods to start fires and searched \u201cWill arson lead to prison?\u201d online before committing the crime. Officials said she had stolen more than $28,000 worth of belongings from the family to pay off debts, including jewelry and watches, and that the family had lent her more than $18,000.\n\nMs. Mo started the fire by lighting books in the living room, officials said. When it grew out of control, she fled the apartment, leaving the children, including two boys and a girl, along with their mother, Zhu Xiaozhen. She then called the police, who took her in for questioning.\n\nRelatives of Mr. Lin said that he was still struggling with the pain of losing his family. Mr. Lin\u2019s online clothing business was named for his children, and they served as models for his brand.\n\nDuring one recent courtroom hearing, according to news reports, he threw a flask at Ms. Mo, hitting a court officer instead.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe can\u2019t go to sleep when he thinks of them,\u201d an uncle, Lin Shengfeng, said by telephone. \u201cHe doesn\u2019t seem to be getting better. He left his marital status blank on several election registration forms when he was chief minister of the state of Gujarat. But under increased scrutiny as a candidate for prime minister in 2014, Mr. Modi revised his official biography to note the relationship.", "title": "Narendra Modi\u2019s Estranged Wife Escapes Unhurt From Car Crash in India", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Those eyes on Wallace, much as they were on Tiger Woods a generation ago, prompted Earnhardt to call him last week. The son of racing legend, Earnhardt knows all about the pressure of expectations.\n\n\u201cHe told me that the next few weeks will basically be hell with all the off-the-track stuff,\u201d Wallace said. \u201cBut he said it\u2019ll all be worth it because I have an opportunity to do things outside the sport that not many other drivers will ever say they\u2019ve had that kind of opportunity to do. So embrace it.\u201d\n\nThe child of a white father and a black mother, Wallace said that he does not quite understand why his skin color makes him newsworthy in 2018. But he knows that stock car racing, with its Southern roots and the Confederate flags that still wave from some fans\u2019 campers and cars, has not attracted an African-American audience.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m just trying to carry that new face, to carry that new image to young people,\u201d Wallace said. \u201cObviously we\u2019ve got to do a lot of work outside of the tracks, stepping out into our local communities. But there\u2019s also venturing out into a different market, into different avenues where the African-American culture lives. We all have to do better at that.\u201d\n\nThere are challenges, of course. On social media, where vulgar epithets can be spewed from faceless and fictitious monikers, Wallace has, at times, had to think twice before responding. He admits he has not always been successful.\n\n\u201cThere is always going to be haters out there, people who don\u2019t want to see you succeed,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve been told that since Day 1 from my parents. Just keep your head down and keep moving, that\u2019s the best you can do.\u201d", "title": "Nascar Waits for Leader of Its Next Generation to Emerge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Already these questions, and others, are rightly the subject of public investigations by the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation and by Nashville\u2019s Metro Council, and there may soon be others. We have no way of knowing whether the investigations will exonerate the mayor or reveal improprieties that are unacceptable in a public servant. Unlike her political opponents, I prefer to wait for their findings before forming an opinion about whether she should resign.\n\n\u201cPlease know that I\u2019m disappointed in myself but also understand that I\u2019m a human and that I made a mistake,\u201d Ms. Barry said in her news conference. Many people here are upset with their mayor and angry about the way she has squandered their hopes for her political future. But I think most Nashvillians heard that statement with real compassion.\n\nThis mayor has been beloved because she\u2019s so human, because she works impossible hours and seems to be everywhere at once, sharing in our happiness and in our heartbreak, wearing her own happiness and her own heartbreak on her sleeve. How shocked should we be to learn that the mayor we love for her humanity is human enough to make this kind of mistake?\n\nI know I sound na\u00efve. In truth, we don\u2019t know if Megan Barry\u2019s affair was only an error of human judgment. We don\u2019t know if it was different in any substantive way from the kind of behavior that has already brought down so many other public servants. All we know for sure is that this is a particularly fraught moment in American history for a person in a position of power \u2014 male or female \u2014 to reveal an affair with a subordinate.\n\nPredictably, Twitter is aflame with outraged conservatives who believe Nashville liberals are giving Ms. Barry a pass simply because we share her politics. That\u2019s a fair point to ponder. When religious conservatives in Alabama had no trouble voting for a credibly accused pedophile during December\u2019s special Senate election, I voiced the same accusation.\n\nPeople here may be keeping an open mind until the official investigations are complete, but that\u2019s not the same thing as giving our mayor a pass. And Ms. Barry is fully cooperating with the inquiries into her behavior. The same cannot be said of, for example, the president of the United States.\n\nIn the wake of the #MeToo tsunami, the conservative coyote pack is howling that liberals would be calling for the mayor\u2019s head if she were a Republican man instead of a Democratic woman. But so far, at least, there is absolutely no evidence that Sergeant Forrest was subject to any form of coercion. Ms. Barry\u2019s affair with her bodyguard was both irresponsible and deeply painful for innocent people, but in all the revelations that have unfolded since the news broke, nothing has come to light to suggest that this is the liberal female version of a #MeToo narrative.", "title": "Opinion | Nashville\u2019s Mayor Has Stumbled. Who Will Cast the First Stone?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Yet traffic deaths could and should have fallen a lot more. We know this because, as my colleague David Leonhardt points out, traffic deaths have fallen much more in other advanced countries, which have used evidence-based policies like lower speed limits and tightened standards for drunken driving to improve their outcomes. Think the French are crazy drivers? Well, they used to be \u2014 but now they\u2019re significantly safer in their cars than we are.\n\nOh, and there\u2019s a lot of variation in car safety among states within the U.S., just as there\u2019s a lot of variation in gun violence. America has a \u201ccar death belt\u201d in the Deep South and the Great Plains; it corresponds quite closely to the firearms death belt defined by age-adjusted gun death rates. It also corresponds pretty closely to the Trump vote \u2014 and also to the states that have refused to expand Medicaid, gratuitously denying health care to millions of their citizens.\n\nWhat I\u2019d argue is that our lethal inaction on guns, but also on cars, reflects the same spirit that\u2019s causing us to neglect infrastructure and privatize prisons, the spirit that wants to dismantle public education and turn Medicare into a voucher system rather than a guarantee of essential care. For whatever reason, there\u2019s a faction in our country that sees public action for the public good, no matter how justified, as part of a conspiracy to destroy our freedom.\n\nThis paranoia strikes both deep and wide. Does anyone remember George Will declaring that liberals like trains, not because they make sense for urban transport, but because they serve the \u201cgoal of diminishing Americans\u2019 individualism in order to make them more amenable to collectivism\u201d? And it goes along with basically infantile fantasies about individual action \u2014 the \u201cgood guy with a gun\u201d \u2014 taking the place of such fundamentally public functions as policing.\n\nAnyway, this political faction is doing all it can to push us toward becoming a society in which individuals can\u2019t count on the community to provide them with even the most basic guarantees of security \u2014 security from crazed gunmen, security from drunken drivers, security from exorbitant medical bills (which every other advanced country treats as a right, and does in fact manage to provide).\n\nIn short, you might want to think of our madness over guns as just one aspect of the drive to turn us into what Thomas Hobbes described long ago: a society \u201cwherein men live without other security than what their own strength and their own invention shall furnish them.\u201d And Hobbes famously told us what life in such a society is like: \u201csolitary, poor, nasty, brutish and short.\u201d\n\nYep, that sounds like Trump\u2019s America.", "title": "Opinion | Nasty, Brutish and Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLOS ANGELES \u2014 New witnesses have emerged in the 1981 drowning of the actress Natalie Wood, prompting investigators to deem it a \u201csuspicious death\u201d and name Robert Wagner, her former husband, a \u201cperson of interest,\u201d Los Angeles County sheriff\u2019s officials said on Thursday.\n\nFor nearly four decades, mystery and speculation have swirled around the death of Ms. Wood, who was nominated for three Academy Awards and starred in the movies \u201cWest Side Story\u201d and \u201cRebel Without a Cause.\u201d\n\nHer death occurred on the weekend after Thanksgiving in 1981 while aboard a yacht with Mr. Wagner, the actor Christopher Walken and the boat\u2019s captain. After a night of drinking, her body was found floating in the waters surrounding Catalina Island, off the coast of Southern California. She was 43.\n\nPhoto\n\nInvestigators initially ruled it an accident but reopened the case in 2011 to see whether Mr. Wagner, now 87, or anyone else played a role after the boat\u2019s captain said he heard the couple arguing the night of her disappearance. The coroner\u2019s office amended Ms. Wood\u2019s death certificate the next year to include \u201cdrowning and other undetermined factors.\u201d\n\nA sheriff\u2019s department spokeswoman, Nicole Nishida, said in a statement on Thursday that new witnesses interviewed since the case was reopened gave statements that \u201cportray a new sequence of events on the boat that night.\u201d\n\nOne of the witnesses described hearing yelling and crashing sounds coming from the couple\u2019s stateroom, she said. Shortly after that, separate witnesses heard a man and a woman arguing on the back of the boat and believe the voices were those of Ms. Wood and Mr. Wagner, Ms. Nishida said.\n\nThe statements differed from the original version of events provided by witnesses, including those who were on the boat, she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
