Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIdaho\u2019s new \u201cstate-based health benefit plans\u201d will have to carry a disclaimer: \u201cThe policy is not fully compliant with federal health insurance requirements.\u201d\n\nInsurers in Idaho could, in some cases, charge different rates based on a person\u2019s health status or claims experience. In addition, insurers would not have to comply with provisions of the federal law limiting out-of-pocket costs, and they could impose caps on the dollar amount of benefits available to consumers.\n\nDean L. Cameron, the director of the Idaho Department of Insurance, said in an interview on Thursday that insurers could start selling the new state-based health plans as early as April.\n\n\u201cWe are trying to salvage the market,\u201d Mr. Cameron said. \u201cThe young and healthy people of all ages have left the market. We are trying to bring them back. Our goal is to help Idaho families.\u201d\n\nBlue Cross of Idaho said this week that it would offer five such plans. \u201cThe Affordable Care Act marketplace has become unaffordable for Idaho\u2019s middle-class uninsured,\u201d the company said, and it told consumers that the new plans could cost \u201cup to 50 percent less\u201d than plans that comply with the federal law.\n\nMr. Azar, a former top executive at Eli Lilly and Company, the drug maker, deftly fielded questions about prescription drugs. He said the president\u2019s budget included \u201ca suite of proposals\u201d that would save Medicare beneficiaries money \u2014 for example, by capping their out-of-pocket costs for many prescription drugs and by giving them the benefit of price concessions negotiated by insurers and prescription drug plans.\n\nDemocrats were not impressed.\n\n\u201cNone of the policies go after the pharmaceutical industry, your former employer,\u201d said Senator Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Azar said Medicaid, the program for more than 70 million low-income people, was full of perverse incentives that tended to drive up drug costs. Under federal law, Medicaid is generally entitled to the best price given to other purchasers of brand-name prescription drugs, with a mandatory discount of at least 23 percent off the list price.\n\nMr. Azar agreed with Senator Bill Cassidy, Republican of Louisiana, who said these discounts led drug makers to raise prices for other customers.\n\n\u201cIf we underpay in Medicaid, it will increase costs elsewhere,\u201d Mr. Azar said.\n\nMembers of both parties expressed concern about Mr. Trump\u2019s proposal to cut $48 billion over 10 years from projected federal payments to teaching hospitals for graduate medical education.\n\nMr. Azar said the administration wanted to direct funds to geographic areas and medical specialties with the greatest need for more doctors.\n\nBut Senator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida, said the proposed cut would \u201cseverely hurt a state like ours, a growth state, that desperately needs residency programs to keep our doctors.\u201d", "title": "New Health Secretary Faces First Test as Idaho Skirts Federal Law", "authors": ["Robert Pear"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 \u201cM laid down his pipe and stared at it tetchily. \u2018We have no choice. We\u2019re just going to bring forward this other chap you\u2019ve been preparing. But you didn\u2019t tell me his name.\u2019 \u2018It\u2019s Bond, sir,\u2019 the Chief of Staff replied. \u2018James Bond.\u2019\u201d\n\nIan Fleming devotees will not recognize this scene. That\u2019s because the author, who died in 1964, didn\u2019t write it. It\u2019s the opening of a new James Bond novel, written by Anthony Horowitz, which offers a prequel to Fleming\u2019s first Bond adventure, \u201cCasino Royale.\u201d The title, which remained a secret until the publishers, Jonathan Cape, and Mr. Horowitz posted it on Twitter on Thursday, is appropriately Bondesque: \u201cForever and a Day.\u201d\n\nThis is Mr. Horowitz\u2019s second venture, authorized by the Fleming estate, into 007 terrain; his first Bond novel, \u201cTrigger Mortis,\u201d was published by Jonathan Cape (Fleming\u2019s original publishers) in 2015 to approving reviews. Both books make use of treatments that Fleming wrote for an American television series that was never made. In an interview with The New York Times in 2015, Mr. Horowitz said that it was inspiring and exciting to have access to writings by Fleming that almost no one had seen. \u201cJames Bond is one of those things identified with this country,\u201d he said.\n\nIn a statement, Mr. Horowitz said that \u201cForever and Day,\u201d which will be published in Britain on May 31, explores \u201cwhat might have been Bond\u2019s first mission,\u201d and imagines \u201csome of the forces that might have turned him into the iconic figure that the whole world knows.\u201d\n\nFleming might have been surprised. Before \u201cCasino Royale\u201d was published in 1953, the author wrote to his publishers, saying \u201cmy own feeling is that the life of a book of this sort is not that long.\u201d", "title": "New James Bond Novel Is a Prequel to Fleming\u2019s First", "authors": ["Roslyn Sulcas"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Delonas, the cartoonist, said that while he sympathized with Ms. Moses, he disagreed with her assessment of the illustration.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s not the way I read it,\u201d said Mr. Delonas, 56, a former cartoonist at The New York Post. \u201cI\u2019ve learned that MS-13 is purposely sending minors over here to commit crimes. I\u2019m pretty sure that the cartels are using minors for a lot of their drug dealing.\u201d\n\nMr. Delonas emphasized that he believed immigrants should come legally to the United States. The cartoon was published after Mr. Trump contended in his State of the Union speech that undocumented immigrants \u201chave caused the loss of innocent lives,\u201d and focused specifically on MS-13, a gang formed in Los Angeles in the 1980s by refugees fleeing El Salvador\u2019s civil war.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Pathetic!\u201d", "title": "New Mexico Newspaper Apologizes for Cartoon Portraying \u2018Dreamers\u2019 as Muggers", "authors": ["Simon Romero"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "At the same time, the performance\u2019s primary features \u2014 physical fragmentation, elusive meaning \u2014 are the strengths of other works on the fourth floor. The young American artist Wilmer Wilson IV enlarges photographic images of figures, most of them African-American, that he finds on fliers for parties and church events in his West Philadelphia neighborhood. He attaches the images to tall wood boards with industrial staples \u2014 not just a few but hundreds of thousands staples, so that the photograph is almost entirely covered, leaving just small sections \u2014 an isolated bottle, or mouth \u2014 clear.\n\nFrom a distance, the effect is gorgeous: an Impressionism of gleaming steel. Up close, though, you zero in on the individual staples and get a sense of the material violation they cause. Whether you see the figures \u2014 the bodies \u2014 underneath, and whether you consider them to have been assaulted or exalted by their metal overlay, will depend on how close to them, in every sense, you stand.\n\nLarge oil-on-canvas paintings by Gresham Tapiwa Nyaude, who lives and works in Harare, Zimbabwe, also lead a double perceptual life. On first view, each is a crazy quilt of lush, fruity colors and abstract shapes. Gradually recognizable forms emerge: patches of military camouflage, detached limbs, headless mouths, grinning or gaping. A wall text \u2014 opaquely written, like most in the show \u2014 tells us that work is an extended commentary on the political corruption and repression that for decades sent fissures of fear through the country under the rule of the recently deposed president, Robert Mugabe. (What may be a portrait of Mr. Mugabe appears in one of the paintings here.)", "title": "New Museum Triennial Looks Great, but Plays It Safe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "JERUSALEM \u2014 Two more serious allegations have surfaced in the metastasizing corruption investigation of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his inner circle: that one of his aides tried to bribe a judge to quash a criminal case involving Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s wife, and that he or his aides traded lucrative regulatory approvals for favorable coverage on a news website owned by Israel\u2019s largest telecommunications company. Mr. Netanyahu denies any wrongdoing.\n\nHere is a rundown of the particulars, according to the police and Israeli news reports.\n\nCase 1270: A Big Job for a Big Favor\n\nTHE BACKDROP In 2015, Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s wife, Sara, was under investigation over allegations that she had misused government funds in managing the prime minister\u2019s official Jerusalem residence.\n\nTHE PLAYERS Nir Hefetz, a veteran journalist and political operative; Eli Kamir, an ex-journalist turned media adviser, paid $40,000 a month by the telecommunications company Bezeq; Judge Hila Gerstel, Israel\u2019s commissioner for prosecutorial oversight.", "title": "New Netanyahu Corruption Allegations: The Details", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Made In, a cookware brand that\u2019s been on the market since September, has developed a new saucier in response to consumer demand. The wide, generous saucepan has a rounded profile to make stirring and whisking a custard, hollandaise or a risotto a breeze. Like the rest of the line, it is produced in the United States and made of five-ply metal: aluminum for conductivity and stainless steel for practicality. The saucier is compatible with induction cooktops, and its long handle stays cool. Made In sells only directly to consumers, so the price-quality ratio is very positive, often half the price of some name brands in stores: Made In, three-quart saucier, $85 without lid, $99 with lid, madeincookware.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "New Pot Has More Room for Hollandaise", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018Everything screwed up about our culture, it all begins right here.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From \u201cA Futile and Stupid Gesture\u201d (Netflix, 2018, directed by David Wain), adapted from the book of the same name by Josh Karp.\n\nThis is not a \u201cnew\u201d sentence; it has surely been said, verbatim, about several thousand aspects of modern society. That\u2019s why it sticks out amid the dialogue in \u201cA Futile and Stupid Gesture,\u201d a biopic about a comedy writer \u2014 Douglas Kenney, who spent the 1970s creating National Lampoon and setting the course for decades of comedy \u2014 that\u2019s possibly the first thing ever directed by David Wain that isn\u2019t impossibly, uproariously funny.\n\nOne obvious problem is that Kenney\u2019s life and work provide a kind of story America has found itself increasingly bored, aggrieved and disgusted by. It\u2019s not just the tale of a Harvard-educated baby boomer who finds great success in doing whatever absurd or juvenile thing he feels like doing, leaving a trail of chaos and disappointment among his intimates. It\u2019s also a snapshot of a moment when comedy\u2019s freshest counterculture impulse was gleefully crass and willfully offensive, built on thumbed noses and middle fingers \u2014 what scanned at the time as a liberating response to a rigid and hypocritical culture, but will appear to a weighty chunk of today\u2019s viewers as the childish dregs of an entire cohort\u2019s glib, bratty chauvinism and coddled, almost toddlerish self-regard.\n\nThe film\u2019s Kenney makes this \u201ceverything screwed up about our culture\u201d observation while considering 1960s high school yearbooks, spotting a comical hollowness and rot in the society he and his peers were trained to join. But today it could be Kenney himself who is a natural symbol of someone else\u2019s rot. It seems nearly impossible to translate the impulses of the one time to the other; the most the film can do is make small apologies for the difference. It might do better to offer a warning to the present: Whatever thrilling, corrective pull your cohort may be having on society right now is very probably, in one way or another, screwing something up for someone later.", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018A Futile and Stupid Gesture\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018When she talks, they accuse her of personalizing.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From \u201cAfter Kathy Acker: A Literary Biography\u201d (Semiotext(e)/Active Agents, 2017, Page 31), by Chris Kraus, author of the increasingly celebrated 1997 novel \u201cI Love Dick.\u201d\n\nKathy Acker, the experimental writer, felt perfectly at home in the wildest bohemian corners of 1970s New York. She saw Patti Smith at CBGB and made radical philosophical sex films and participated in endless dance sessions in capacious old lofts. Her cohort perpetrated some of the era\u2019s defining conceptual art projects, from stockpiling blood samples of eminent poets to filming themselves being shot in the arm.\n\nAnd yet there were other worlds, quite nearby, in which Acker felt deeply out of place. These included political discussions with establishment intellectuals, who argued about current events in abstract, serious, high-minded language and \u2014 according to Chris Kraus\u2019s biography \u201cAfter Kathy Acker\u201d \u2014 accused Acker, when she spoke up, of \u201cpersonalizing.\u201d\n\nIt is a loaded charge, one that our culture is still reckoning with nearly 50 years later. To \u201cpersonalize\u201d means to violate some (often unstated) ideal of disembodied thought \u2014 to fall short of a rationality that transcends all our little lives. Such impersonality, of course, excludes a wide range of human testimony and knowledge: social, emotional, physical. It privileges formal, institutional power. It also, as we\u2019ve discovered, enables all kinds of abuse. The rebuke \u201cbe rational\u201d often carries a threat that is far from rational. Similarly, anyone who tells you not to be personal probably gains a personal advantage from doing so.", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018After Kathy Acker,\u2019 by Chris Kraus", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018When in the course of human events we the people in order to form a more perfect four score and seven years 1492 1517 1776 1865 1914-18 1929 1939-45 1969 1989 1991 2001.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From \u201cFire Sermon\u201d (Grove Press, 2018, Page 127), by Jamie Quatro. \u201cFire Sermon\u201d is Quatro\u2019s first novel, following the short-story collection \u201cI Want to Show You More.\u201d\n\nNothing on Earth has ever not been about the passage of time \u2014 not a film, a poem, a cave painting, a house, a poncho, a comic book, a snowman or a fugue. But some art is particularly obsessed. T.S. Eliot was famously time-drunk in \u201cFour Quartets.\u201d The director Richard Linklater tried to capture time directly in \u201cBoyhood.\u201d\n\nJamie Quatro, in her very sad first novel, \u201cFire Sermon,\u201d squeezes large flows of time into a book as thin as my little finger. Time haunts every sentence. An inventory of objects stored in a grandmother\u2019s basement becomes, very quickly, a still-life about mortality: \u201cLife magazines, Band-Aid tins with Cracker Jack prizes inside, shoe boxes with hardened photographs, all the horrified doomed ancestors.\u201d Another passage sees an unused jogging stroller destroyed, in a kind of verbal time lapse, by mildew.\n\nIn one paragraph, the narrator\u2019s children\u2019s childhoods fly by entirely as a list of the subjects they covered in school. The sentence quoted above is a bouillon cube of American history: Fragments of the Declaration of Independence blur with the Constitution and the Gettysburg Address, and right where we should get Lincoln\u2019s \u201cago,\u201d we get instead an unbroken string of years, spanning Christopher Columbus to Sept. 11, as if all of time is being reduced to a sort of numerical code. The reader is left to intuit all the life those numbers once contained \u2014 the people who lived then, the children who memorized the numbers, the parents who helped them do the memorizing. And then of course we think of our own number, and what it might mean to someone who might memorize it someday, and what it feels like, right now, to be inside of it: 2018.", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018Fire Sermon,\u2019 by Jamie Quatro", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "(If you are reading this story out loud, force a listener to reveal a devastating secret, then open the nearest window to the street and scream it as loudly as you are able.)\n\n\u2014 From \u201cThe Husband Stitch,\u201d a short story in Carmen Maria Machado\u2019s \u201cHer Body and Other Parties\u201d (Graywolf Press, 2017, Page 23).\n\nIt\u2019s a giddy feeling, to be a writer with a reader. An energy flows from you to them, a mental breeze that is capable, almost magically, of moving things in the actual world. Ask a reader to blink three times, and somewhere it will almost certainly happen. \u201cSnap your fingers,\u201d you can write, and fingers will snap. It is an uncanny, almost eerie power. Writers have to be careful not to abuse it.\n\nIn Carmen Maria Machado\u2019s fabulously strange short story \u201cThe Husband Stitch,\u201d the narrator delivers a series of parenthetical instructions that, increasingly, threaten to abuse this power. These asides are, ostensibly, meant to help the reader understand the story more deeply. For instance, after a scene in a clearing, the narrator instructs the reader to reproduce the soundscape \u2014 the stillness, the breeze \u2014 \u201cby taking a deep breath and holding it for a long moment,\u201d then releasing it all at once, over and over again.\n\nAs the story continues, however, the narrator\u2019s commands grow more elaborate and sinister. After describing a difficult birth, she suggests asking someone to cut your hand with a knife and thanking them for it. She tells the reader to shake a soda can full of pennies in the faces of people nearby. \u201cNotice how they never look at you exactly the same way for the rest of your days.\u201d And when she feels she has betrayed someone, she asks the reader to expose someone else\u2019s \u201cdevastating secret\u201d by screaming it from an open window.", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018Her Body and Other Parties,\u2019 by Carmen Maria Machado", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "But several more seconds passed, and I started counting. I got to 90 before I was booted back to the sign-in screen.\n\nI gave it another try. And another. And another still.\n\nThat\u2019s when we told Equifax. About 90 minutes later, a spokeswoman said the company had identified the issue and resolved it.\n\nExcept that it hadn\u2019t. The locking mechanism still wouldn\u2019t lock. A company spokeswoman said Equifax had not experienced widespread issues with the service, but, as with any new product, there had been isolated problems they were working to resolve. She also offered to put me on the phone with a technical support representative.\n\nWhy go to all of this trouble to cut off access to your credit file? Credit-card issuers, mobile phone companies and others generally won\u2019t do business with you without first checking your credit report with at least one of the three major bureaus: Equifax, Experian and TransUnion.\n\nIf companies can\u2019t get to your file, they won\u2019t issue credit. That protects you when thieves get access to your information and then try to open new accounts in your name.\n\nImage Equifax declined to promise that its push toward locks would not cause the loss of legal or regulatory protections.\n\nShutting companies out of your credit files has traditionally meant initiating something called a credit freeze. It often costs a few dollars and you have to use a PIN \u2014 which you may not remember or could lose \u2014 to temporarily lift the freeze when you do want to authorize access to your credit file. Getting a new PIN takes a fair bit of tedious work. (For a longer primer, see our consumer guide to the Equifax breach.) Freezes are also subject to a variety of state laws.\n\nEquifax\u2019s new app offers a lock instead of a freeze. Locks works similarly to freezes \u2014 both restrict access to your credit file \u2014 but it should be easier to unlock your credit file since you can do it from your phone with a swipe, and doesn\u2019t require a 10-digit pin or a fee.", "title": "New Service, Same Old Equifax: Credit Locking App Freezes Up", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Ramaphosa (pronounced rah-mah-POH-sah) had remained largely silent about corruption during the three years he served as Mr. Zuma\u2019s deputy.\n\nIn the two-week-long political crisis that led to Mr. Zuma\u2019s forced resignation on Wednesday, party leaders waved away any suggestion that they wanted Mr. Zuma out because of his scandal-ridden administration and his troubling behavior.\n\nAce Magashule, the party\u2019s secretary general, said emphatically earlier in the week that the former president had \u201cnot been found guilty by any court of law\u201d and had not \u201cdone anything But before that release, there\u2019s \u201cRampage,\u201d based on a popular video game.\n\nThe latest trailer features new footage of George as well as other creatures that swell to Godzilla-like proportions and wreak havoc. It also includes Mr. Johnson\u2019s trademark sly, raised-eyebrow humor: \u201cOf course, the wolf flies,\u201d he deadpans of one monster.\n\nMalin Akerman is introduced as one of the film\u2019s villains, a corporate shark behind Project Rampage, \u201cthe next chapter in genetic selection.\u201d Gigantic crocodiles \u2014 what could possibly go wrong? In 2005, when Mr. Giuca was sentenced to a maximum of life in prison, a group of his supporters showed up in the courtroom wearing T-shirts emblazoned with the words \u201cFree John Giuca.\u201d As the appeal crept forward, his mother, Doreen Giuliano, was caught in an elaborate one-woman sting operation in which she tried to seduce a former juror to root out information that might have helped her son.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe case began on Oct. 11, 2003, when Mark Fisher, a 19-year-old student at Fairfield University in Connecticut, was barhopping on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. At the end of a woozy night of drinking, Mr. Fisher wound up in Prospect Park South in Brooklyn with Mr. Giuca, who was 20 at the time, and a group of other strangers. The next morning, shortly after 6 a.m., Mr. Fisher was found dead on the sidewalk several blocks from Mr. Giuca\u2019s family home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nProsecutors claimed that Mr. Giuca and a co-defendant, Antonio Russo, were members a fledgling gang called the Ghetto Mafia and went after Mr. Fisher for street credibility, seeing him as a rich teenager who was an easy target. They said that Mr. Giuca was jealous about a woman with whom Mr. Fisher had been flirting and was angry at his drunken behavior. Separate juries found both men were guilty, with Mr. Giuca\u2019s jury returning in the brief span of two hours. Mr. Russo was also sentenced to up to life in prison.", "title": "New Trial Ordered in Brooklyn in 2003 Slaying of College Student", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe New York Botanical Garden has named its first female president, Carrie Rebora Barratt, 58, who has spent most of her career as a curator and administrator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She currently serves as the Met\u2019s deputy director for collections and administration.\n\nShe said in an interview that she is looking forward to applying her scholarship and management expertise to the realm of plants and landscapes. Exiting the Met after three decades \u201cfeels weird,\u201d and she was not job hunting when she was asked to apply for the garden job last fall, she said. She had been the subject of art-world speculation that she was a candidate for the Met\u2019s directorship after Thomas P. Campbell resigned under pressure in 2017. (She declined to comment on the Met\u2019s search for a new leader.)\n\nDescribing her enthusiasm about the Botanical Garden, Dr. Barratt said it \u201cis like a magnet\u201d and hard to resist. \u201cYou can\u2019t help but leave feeling more joyful,\u201d she said.\n\nOne highlight of her garden tours so far, she said, was a greenhouse sighting of a Hawaiian orchid, one of the flowers that inspired Georgia O\u2019Keeffe\u2019s luxuriant petal paintings. The garden\u2019s summer show, \u201cGeorgia O\u2019Keeffe: Visions of Hawai\u2019i,\u201d which opens May 19, is part of a series of exhibitions emphasizing connections between plants and art. Previous displays have explored flower beds that served as muses for Claude Monet, Frida Kahlo and American Impressionists.\n\nDr. Barratt, a Chicago native who lives in Manhattan and has two grown daughters, Norma and Anna, volunteers at a Brooklyn community garden and participates in triathlons in her spare time.\n\nMaureen Chilton, the chairwoman of the garden\u2019s board \u2014 and the first woman to serve in that post \u2014 said that naming a woman as president marked \u201ca nice moment\u201d as the gender glass ceiling of top leadership positions at cultural institutions begins to break. Ms. Chilton added that the board appreciated Dr. Barratt\u2019s strengths as a listener and creative facilitator who will be able to build on the accomplishments of Gregory Long, the president since 1989. Among the achievements during his tenure are a billion-dollar fund-raising campaign and the construction of the Edible Academy, which offers lessons in growing and cooking. Expanded academy facilities, including laboratory and demonstration kitchen spaces, will open in June.", "title": "New York Botanical Garden Names Its First Female President", "authors": ["Eve M. Kahn"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019ve seen with the #MeToo movement and the Time\u2019s Up movement that there has been a dark, secretive, dangerous current and epidemic of sexual harassment,\u201d Mr. Johnson said on Friday. \u201cThis is a way to address that and hopefully be on the leading edge of trying to do something legislatively that\u2019s going to protect more people.\u201d\n\nThe measures, which are set for a Wednesday hearing before the committee on women, must still be voted on, and are subject to approval by Mayor Bill de Blasio. \u201cWe\u2019re collaborating with them on this,\u201d Mr. Johnson said of the mayor\u2019s office.\n\n\u201cThe mayor is supportive of the concepts and aim and we look forward to working with the council on the details,\u201d Eric F. Phillips, the mayor\u2019s press secretary, said in a statement. He said the mayor was working on his own proposals.\n\nLikely to be the most contentious aspect of the legislation is the requirement that private employers provide training. More than 30,000 businesses in the city could be affected by the regulation.\n\nThe bill specifies that the training be \u201cinteractive,\u201d either in person, with audiovisual material or some other form approved by the city\u2019s Human Rights Commission; it also requires that employers maintain records of compliance. Enforcement would be handled by the commission as well, and businesses could face penalties up to $500 for their first violation, and up to $2,000 for each one after.\n\nMr. Johnson said he did not expect the legislation would burden employers, but said he looked forward to hearing their concerns next week.\n\nSome in the business community expressed skepticism.\n\n\u201cThanks to the #MeToo movement, any employer who is not asleep understands the importance of strong policies on sexual harassment and relevant training,\u201d said Kathryn Wylde, the president of the Partnership for New York City, a business group, who was briefed on the bills. \u201cWhat more city laws are going to accomplish, aside from legal and compliance headaches, is unclear.\u201d", "title": "New York City May Require Businesses to Conduct Sexual Harassment Training", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Ten of the 11 women on the City Council serve as chairwomen of committees, and the 11th, Laurie Cumbo of Brooklyn, is the majority leader, Mr. Johnson noted. But Ms. Mark-Viverito said she has heard from women on the current Council who are concerned about being stretched too thin because they are being asked to serve on multiple committees because of diversity concerns.\n\nNew York State\u2019s other legislative bodies aren\u2019t faring much better than the City Council. Women make up 32 percent of the Assembly, with 45 women among 141 current members. There are nine vacant seats. Women make up 23 percent of the Senate with 14 women out of 61 senators, with two vacant seats. New York State has never had a female governor and New York City has never had a female mayor.\n\nTwenty-two percent of the United States Senate are women; 19 percent of the House are women. Both figures represent an increase from previous Congresses, and the number seems poised to grow: The number of women considering running for office in the 2018 midterm elections is on pace to break records.\n\nThere are already 50 female candidates for the Senate who have either filed papers or are likely to run, according to the Center for American Women and Politics. That\u2019s more than the record 40 women who filed to run in 2016. There are 396 filed and likely candidates for the House. In 2012, a record 298 women filed to run for the House.", "title": "New York City Women Hoping to Ride Wave of Resistance to Elected Office", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "A New York police detective was arrested on Tuesday on federal perjury charges after prosecutors concluded that he had fabricated evidence in a carjacking case.\n\nThe charges against Michael Foder, 41, who had been assigned to the detective squad in the 70th precinct in central Brooklyn, are the latest sign that perjury remains an ongoing problem within the New York Police Department. Last month another detective, Kevin Desormeau, was convicted in Queens of falsely testifying about having observed a drug deal after a jury found that the detective had made up the story to cover up a dubious arrest.\n\nIn the case on Tuesday, Detective Foder is accused of doctoring a photo lineup to persuade a judge that a victim had been able to identify two suspects in a carjacking. The charges are considered particularly troubling because they involve accusations that a detective tampered with witness identifications.\n\nErroneous identifications by witnesses have been a leading cause of wrongful convictions.\n\nIn the past decade, the New York Police Department has taken steps to try to prevent such misconduct. Among other requirements, detectives are supposed to follow a detailed set of instructions when conducting lineups. They cannot chat with witnesses while showing them photos or lineups, but instead should hew to a script intended to prevent the detectives from improperly influencing the result.", "title": "New York Detective Charged with Faking Lineup Results", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "If this burden is foisted on the counties, some might wheeze under the strain. Localities in New York have long complained, justifiably, about a pattern of \u201cunfunded mandates\u201d \u2014 requirements that come from Albany without so much as a nickel to make them happen. If ever there was an issue of statewide concern, and fiscal obligation, voting is it.\n\nMr. Cuomo\u2019s aides argue that keeping money out of the discussion is a sensible tactic at this point. Don\u2019t let hand-wringing over dollars, no matter how few, get in the way of the principle of electoral reform, they say. But a counterargument can be made that covering the cost now in his budget would demonstrate that the governor is dead serious about this issue.\n\nThere\u2019s no guarantee that the Legislature will go along with any request for change, which in Mr. Cuomo\u2019s formulation would also permit automatic voter registration, Election Day registration, and absentee voting without having to offer an excuse. These ideas have died in the past in Albany, typically at the hands of Republicans, who control the State Senate and worry that anything that enhances voter turnout could work to their disadvantage.\n\nSome of the proposed changes require amending the State Constitution. Early voting is not one of them. All that\u2019s needed is for lawmakers to say yes.\n\nKeeping polling stations open across a stretch of days is hardly a radical system. It exists in varying forms in 37 states of both the red and the blue variety. It is also popular among New Yorkers; a Siena College poll last month showed a support rate of 65 percent.\n\nFor a state that fancies itself a bastion of progressivism, New York remains frozen in electoral practices that amount to an incumbent-protection racket. Take the restrictions on changing party affiliations. As races develop, some registered voters may realize they want to switch allegiances ahead of primaries in June (for federal offices) and September (for state offices). They\u2019re already too late. The deadline expired four months ago \u2014 ridiculously early.", "title": "Opinion | New York Faces an Easy Test on Voting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Today, the fashion flock is off to London for the next round of shows, but let\u2019s not forget the last day of New York Fashion Week. Our photographers captured sublime and dramatic moments from shows by Victoria Beckham, Prabal Gurung, Alexander Wang and more.\n\nJason Wu", "title": "New York Fashion Week: Weekend Rewind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFor the first year, it was what we expected,\u201d said Josh Ripple, the tournament director. \u201cAlready, it\u2019s more than Memphis was for the last 10 years. To think we would get 6,000 people here in the first year is just a bad thought process unless you\u2019re going to have Roger Federer or Rafael Nadal.\u201d\n\nThose stars were not present, but the event offered a striking new look as an attraction: black tennis courts adorned with white lines. The fashionable new surface was making its professional tour debut (it had previously been used in the Laver Cup exhibition last year) and most players seemed to like it.\n\n\u201cI wish more tournaments would use it,\u201d said Artem Sitak of New Zealand, who lost in the doubles final with Wesley Koolhof of the Netherlands. The doubles winners were Philipp Oswald and the veteran Max Mirnyi, who was playing in his 100th ATP final. Mirnyi, a 40-year-old Belarusian, won the United States Open doubles tournament twice and spent time in New York training when he was a teenager. Being back in the region, he said, was a thrill.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI really enjoyed waking up and having a New York bagel,\u201d he said. \u201cSo many great memories.\u201d\n\nAt least one other player did not share\u2019s Mirnyi\u2019s enthusiasm. Adrian Mannarino of France, the No. 4 seed, lost to Querrey in a semifinal and then blasted the suburban isolation.\n\n\u201cHappy my girlfriend was here, otherwise I would have killed myself,\u201d he said with a laugh. \u201cBeing in the middle of nowhere, not doing anything during the day, only playing tennis, is not the thing I really like.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat did not go over well with locals.\n\n\u201cThe Mannarino comments were not appreciated,\u201d Ripple said on Sunday. \u201cI think those were the product of sour grapes. If he doesn\u2019t want to come back, he doesn\u2019t have to. Everyone else seemed to think it was great.\u201d\n\nThe clash between Young and Harrison also marred the event. During the first set of their match Monday night, the two players, who have an acrimonious rivalry, yelled at one another \u2014 including challenges to meet outside and fight \u2014 until they were separated by the chair umpire.\n\nAfter the match, Young told an ATP official that Harrison had made a racially insensitive comment toward him during their altercation, and Young later made a similar, vague accusation on his Twitter account. Harrison denied it and an ATP investigation found no evidence to support Young\u2019s claims. A witness, one of the ball persons on the court at the time, said he had heard the entire exchange and corroborated Harrison\u2019s account.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmong the biggest names to attend were Querrey, John Isner, Kei Nishikori and Anderson, who made it to the U.S. Open final last September before losing to Nadal. His win on Sunday pushed him to No. 9 in the ATP rankings and cemented his affection for the state.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve had two good outings the last two times I\u2019ve been in New York,\u201d he said. \u201cSo I definitely look forward to coming back next year.\u201d\n\nAnother player who enjoys playing in New York is Noah Rubin, the former Wimbledon juniors champion who grew up a 10-minute drive from the coliseum, in Merrick, N.Y. Ranked 234th in the world, Rubin was given a wild-card entry and lost to the fifth-seeded Nishikori in the first round on Tuesday. That match was fairly well attended, once people settled into their seats.\n\n\u201cWhen I first got on court and looked around I was worried,\u201d Rubin said of the crowd, \u201cbut then it filled in and it was pretty cool.\u201d\n\nNot necessarily a jungle, but a decent first-year showing.", "title": "New York Open Stays Out of the Way in Tournament\u2019s First Year", "authors": ["David Waldstein"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "The state prison system, which is directly under the governor\u2019s control, has itself come under fire in recent years for systemic abuses, specifically a pattern of assaults by guards against inmates and a scourge of racism on the part of correction officers. But Rikers, according to the Commission of Correction, remains a particular blight on New York\u2019s criminal justice system.\n\nThe report highlighted \u201csignificant incidents,\u201d including deaths, escapes, fires and group actions, noting that in almost every category, there were more incidents at Rikers Island facilities than at all the county jails, even though the average daily inmate population for Rikers was half that of all county jails in the state combined.\n\nGang and individual assaults involving inmates at Rikers were more than double the corresponding totals at the county jails, and attacks between inmates and personnel were 10 times more frequent. And many categories of serious incidents rose from 2016 to 2017, including fires (up 200 percent) and gang assaults (up 160 percent).\n\nThe report also focused on deficiencies across categories ranging from security and supervision to discipline and visitation, exposing \u201cconditions that are unsecure, unsanitary and dangerous, for staff and inmates alike.\u201d\n\nInvestigators found broken pieces of metal and glass, as well as holes and divots, in the exercise yards at the Anna M. Kross Center, a 40-acre unit at Rikers that houses male detainees. At the Robert N. Davoren Complex, another male detention unit, they found that prisoners requiring constant observation were being supervised by officers of the opposite gender, while inmates were able to \u201cpop open\u201d secured cell doors.\n\nAnd across the complex, there were instances of unmanned security posts, poor record-keeping, papered-over security cameras, rodent infestation, water leaks, sagging floors and expired fire extinguishers. Even the basic requirements for laundry services were not being met, with inmates washing their personal clothes in buckets in their cells and hanging them to dry, obscuring sight lines of correction officers.\n\nJonathan Lippman, the former chief judge of the state\u2019s highest court who is chairman of the independent commission on Rikers, also spoke at the mayor\u2019s news conference, cautioning against a tit for tat between Albany and New York City over the timing of the Rikers closure.", "title": "New York State May Move to Close Rikers Ahead of City\u2019s 10-Year Timeline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "The ATP-sanctioned men\u2019s tournament is making its New York debut after four decades in Memphis, and it is the only tour-level indoor tournament in the United States. Qualifying rounds begin Sunday, and the main draw starts Monday. John Isner, Sam Querrey, Kei Nishikori and Kevin Anderson have committed to compete on the unusual courts, which were manufactured in Germany and carefully laid in place over two days last week.\n\nNormally, hard-surface tennis courts are green or blue. Clay courts can be green or red, though the Madrid Open once tried them in blue. So far natural grass has only one known color, but two weeks of Wimbledon sometimes affect that as well. The New York Open opted for a bold color scheme its organizers say has never been used in a tour event.\n\nVideo\n\nLast September, the Laver Cup, an international team exhibition held in Prague, also used black courts manufactured by Haro, the company that built the ones for the New York Open. Ripple said he had been mulling the idea of using a black court for several years, and when he saw one at the exhibition in Prague, he made the decision to install them in New York.\n\n\u201cIt looked like they were playing on a Broadway stage,\u201d he said.\n\nThere are two perpendicular courts built atop the cement floor of the arena, the former home of the Islanders: a stadium court tucked into one end and a grandstand at the other. The courts are separated by a 26-foot viewing structure; the arena will have room for 6,000 fans.\n\nThe slightly larger stadium court is made up of 460 plywood panels that lay atop a half-inch of foam to create a 10,020-square-foot black court. The surfaces of the wood were pre-painted in Germany with about 230 gallons of gritty black paint, and the cost of each court, including shipping (in 56 crates) and installation, is about $140,000.\n\nAccording to Ripple, the surface is medium to fast, designed to help the top seeds advance into the later rounds. It is common practice for tournaments to customize the court according to its field of players. The amount of grit in the paint determines the speed: the more sand, the slower the surface.\n\nAt the New York Open, the first ATP Tour event in the state since the Hamlet Cup in Commack in 2004, a few of the high seeds \u2014 Isner, Querrey and Anderson \u2014 are big servers who do well with fast courts. But Nishikori, Ripple said, likes it a little slower, so the medium-to-fast finish was chosen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThat should enable everybody to be competitive while at the same time supporting some of the players we would like to see progress through the course of the week,\u201d Ripple said.\n\nFranz Fasold, the president of Ace Surfaces, which installed the courts, said the wooden courts were used frequently in Europe and provided more cushioning for the players.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe wood itself, with the cement-like paint on top, provides a true bounce of the ball. The foam panels underneath help disperse impact.\n\nIn addition to the two courts at the arena, Fasold\u2019s crew installed two more courts at a local club for the players to use for practice.\n\nJared Donaldson, who practiced on the courts on Friday, said he was 0-4 on wooden courts in European competitions, but none were black.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s cool, it\u2019s unique,\u201d he said. \u201cThe ball really stood out against the black. I think it\u2019s good for our sport, not only to have different court surfaces, but also different court colors.\u201d\n\nThe biggest challenge for the black courts, Fasold said, is keeping them black. A combination of dust, foot marks and enhanced lighting (the black surface absorbs light) can make them appear to lighten as the tournament goes on.\n\n\u201cBy the end of the Laver Cup, they looked more of a charcoal shade than straight black,\u201d Fasold said. \u201cBut that is mostly an optical illusion.\u201d\n\nOnce the tournament is over, the courts will be dismantled, packed back into the crates that brought them to New York and then sent out on the road again. One of them will be trucked out to San Jose, Calif., for Roger Federer\u2019s charity exhibition match against Jack Sock in March. The other will be used at Madison Square Garden for a women\u2019s one-day tiebreaker event on March 5.\n\nThen it will be dismantled again and carted back to Nassau Coliseum, for storage until next year\u2019s New York Open.", "title": "New York Tennis Tournament Tries a Distinctive Style: Not-So-Basic Black", "authors": ["David Waldstein"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "In a tough environment for journalism, The New York Times Company continued to post significant subscriber growth, propelling the company to a healthy 2017.\n\nThe company said on Thursday that it added 157,000 net digital-only subscriptions in the fourth quarter of the year, pushing overall subscription revenue to more than $1 billion for the year. Subscription revenue now accounts for 60 percent of the company\u2019s total revenue.\n\nBuoyed by the growth in digital subscriptions, total revenue for the year increased 8 percent, to $1.7 billion, and 10 percent in the fourth quarter, to $484 million.\n\nThe Times Company had more than 2.6 million digital-only subscriptions, which include news, cooking and crossword products, at the end of 2017. Digital-only subscription revenue increased 46 percent last year, to $340 million, and 51 percent in the quarter, to $96 million. Subscription revenue for the year increased 15 percent. For the quarter, it rose 19 percent, to $269 million.", "title": "New York Times Co. Subscription Revenue Surpassed $1 Billion in 2017", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "The awards, which are given out by Long Island University, are named in memory of George Polk, a CBS correspondent murdered while covering the Greek Civil War in 1948.\n\nA special award given for coverage of connections between the Trump campaign and Russia was shared between staffs at The Washington Post and The Times. The national reporting award, given for exposing decades of sexual assault allegations and harassment against Mr. Weinstein, the Hollywood producer, was shared by Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey of The Times and Ronan Farrow of The New Yorker.\n\nStephanie McCrummen, Beth Reinhard and Alice Crites of The Post won the political reporting award after they disclosed that Roy S. Moore, the defeated Alabama Senate candidate, faced allegations of sexual harassment and misconduct with teenagers when he was a district attorney.\n\nThe foreign reporting award was given to Iona Craig of The Intercept for her coverage of casualties and destruction after a Navy SEAL raid on a village in Yemen.\n\nThe local reporting award was given to Melissa Segura of BuzzFeed News, who documented allegations that a Chicago police officer had framed dozens of innocent people for murder.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. "authors": ["Emily Cochrane"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 By 1950, cannabis plants grew as tall as Christmas trees in vacant lots and underpasses in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. But a 1951 eradication effort yanked up 41,000 pounds of the plant.\n\n\u2022 One of the first pro-pot marches took place outside the New York Women\u2019s House of Detention in Greenwich Village in 1965, spearheaded by Allen Ginsberg.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 And in the late \u201980s the underground \u201cgreen aid\u201d movement, a forerunner to legal medical marijuana, supplied ganja to AIDS patients to ease the effects of the harsh drugs given to patients at the time.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no question: New York has played a very important role, historically, as a location for the cannabis phenomenon in the United States,\u201d said Martin A. Lee, the author of \u201cSmoke Signals\u201d and the director of Project CBD, a nonprofit that publicizes research on medical uses of cannabis.\n\n\u2022 The city cracked down again in the 1990s under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose aggressive policing tactics, like stop-and-frisk, disproportionately affected blacks and Latinos and made New York the pot arrest capital of America.\n\n\u2022 Mayor Bill de Blasio \u2014 who toked as an N.Y.U. undergrad \u2014 promised to cut back on marijuana arrests, but they have barely budged and racial disparities persist.\n\n\u201cCulturally, New York has been way out ahead of the law when it comes to cannabis,\u201d Mr. Lee said. \u201cBut politically, New York is certainly not a pioneer or a profile in courage. Now, it\u2019s more toward the caboose instead of the front of the train.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nWelcome to your workweek. The skies will clear this morning, but a cold breeze is blowing and the temperature will drop and hover around freezing.\n\nThings get messy again on Wednesday.\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 Years of investigation into the corruption allegations against Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey unraveled over a two-week span in January. Cuomo is expected to tell all in court, but many say his word can\u2019t be trusted. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Forced to leave Puerto Rico, a man who suffers from anxiety and depression found comfort in sharing his possessions with others who had to flee the island post-Hurricane Maria. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The owner of a vintage clothing store is being forced to move it because of developing high-rises in Long Island City \u2014 the second time residential developments pushed her out. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 A church in New Jersey honored four chaplains who gave their life vests to others as their military transport ship was sinking during World War II. Rangers at Stars, 8:30 p.m. (MSG).\n\n\u2022 Alternate-side parking remains in effect until Feb. 12.\n\n\u2022 For more events, see The New York Times\u2019s Arts & Entertainment guide.\n\nAnd Finally...\n\nPhoto\n\nIn other marijuana news, here are some of your responses to last month\u2019s request for thoughts on legalization:\n\nFor:\n\n\u201cNot only does cannabis have, almost without argument, various medical uses, but the amount of revenue brought in by taxes on cannabis could help pay for things we obviously are having trouble finding money for: maintenance and repair of New York\u2019s fading and failing infrastructure, homelessness issues, affordable housing issues and drug rehabilitation issues.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Jamie Legon, 66, Morningside Heights\n\n\u201cPetty arrests for possession of marijuana have disproportionately targeted low-income communities of color for too long. As a step toward making our justice system more fair and modern, let\u2019s rethink how we criminalize drug use.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Dylan Lee, 22, Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn\n\n\u201cRecreational marijuana should definitely be legal in New York. However, we as a society need to have an honest conversation about the pros and cons of using marijuana \u2014 there are many. We also need to remove any and all barriers into medical research of the drug by unbiased scientists so that we can improve our understanding of the effects of this substance that so many of us consume.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Andr\u00e9 Salerno, 32, Williamsburg, Brooklyn\n\nAgainst:\n\n\u201cI am against legalization simply because it smells bad and New Yorkers live and commute in tight spaces. In New York City the skunky stink seeps into my apartment and I can smell it walking on the sidewalk or lingering on the clothes of subway riders.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Marianne Harmon, 41, Upper West Side\n\n\u201cI am absolutely against America becoming a nation of potheads. We need our critical thinking more than ever now, and marijuana is scientifically documented to slow reaction time and motivation, cause changes in the brain and negatively affect the lungs.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Anne Russell, 80, Wrightsville Beach, N.C.\n\n\u201cI do not support the legalization of marijuana for a simple reason that the cost treating people with potential side effects of the drug is enormous.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Howard Zhang, 26, West New York, N.J.\n\nWait, I\u2019m confused:\n\n\u201cOh, it\u2019s not legal in New York? I walk down the street smelling its pungent aroma just about everywhere in the city. You can get it delivered to your home in an hour. Why on earth don\u2019t we legalize it? Everyone would be way happier and more chill.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Joanne Bernbaum, 59, Williamsburg, Brooklyn\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? The State Senate and Assembly are getting ready to consider everything from tax code rewrites to letting New Yorkers vote early to new sexual harassment rules.\n\nBut wait, there\u2019s more. A big new state park proposed for Brooklyn. A new tax on opioids and e-cigarettes. Here are a few of the proposals large and small to keep an eye on as the session unfolds.\n\n\n\nIf history serves as a guide, it will all get decided behind closed doors, either during budget negotiations or just before the session ends, with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo leading the horse-trading.\n\nCongestion pricing: The idea of charging cars that drive into Manhattan a fee during the busiest hours has been debated for years, but opponents say it would unfairly burden drivers from the outer boroughs. Lawmakers say they\u2019re open to the idea. But the devil is in the details. Watch for sparring over how much to charge, when to charge it and where the money raised should go.", "title": "New York Today: Albany Agenda", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Updated, 11:38 a.m.\n\nGood morning on this energizing Wednesday.\n\nOne day this month, we woke up to an email from a loyal New York Today reader:\n\n\u201cThere has been an outbreak of emotional support animals on airlines, but what\u2019s up with the proliferation of pets in the subway? It\u2019s getting out of control. What are the rules around it?\u201d\n\nHaving recently watched a 70-pound goldendoodle named Augustus leap into a taxi, we, too, were curious.\n\nShams Tarek, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, pointed out the agency\u2019s rules of conduct for the subway:\n\n\u201cNo person may bring any animal on or into any conveyance or facility unless enclosed in a container and carried in a manner which would not annoy other passengers.\u201d\n\n(The word \u201cannoy\u201d is, of course, subjective; a \u201cgood boy\u201d in one rider\u2019s eyes may be a slobbering monster to another.)", "title": "New York Today: Can I Bring My Pet on Public Transit?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "More than a century later, around 1903, New York paid homage to the first first lady with the Martha Washington, a women-only hotel at 30 East 30th Street.\n\nA novel concept at the time, it quickly became a symbol of advancement and independence for female professionals.\n\nIt was declared a city landmark in 2012, and today it\u2019s the site of Danny Meyer\u2019s pizzeria Marta.\n\nYou can learn more about our first ladies on Saturday, Sunday and Monday at the New-York Historical Society on the Upper West Side, where you\u2019ll meet re-enactors playing Martha Washington, Dolley Madison and others.\n\nThat might be a good outing for public school students, who will be kicking off a week without school for midwinter recess.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather", "title": "New York Today: Celebrating Our First Ladies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 \u201cLu Over the Wall,\u201d directed by Masaaki Yuasa, and other animated, live-action and virtual reality films for kids \u2014 and their adults \u2014 at the New York International Children\u2019s Film Festival, at various locations. Through March 18. [Prices vary]\n\n\u2022 Feature, documentary and short films by and about women at the Athena Film Festival at Barnard College in Morningside Heights. Through Sunday. [Prices range from free to $20]\n\n\u2022 Discussion panels and 93 films from emerging filmmakers at the Winter Film Awards at Cinema Village in Greenwich Village and Anthology Film Archives in the East Village. Through March 3. [Prices range from free to $15]\n\n\u2022 And Film Comment magazine will screen some of its favorite movies, like \u201cLife and Nothing More\u201d and \u201cGutland,\u201d at its annual festival at the Film Society of Lincoln Center. Through Feb. 27. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., speaking in Central Park.", "title": "New York Today: Documenting Protest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Thousands of dogs were checked into New York hotels over the weekend ahead of the annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, which begins today.\n\nAround 600 of them \u2014 including four-pound Chihuahuas and 300-pound bull mastiffs \u2014 are staying across from Madison Square Garden, where the pageantry takes place, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.\n\nThis time of year, the hotel is like Vegas for dogs.\n\nThere are dog fashion shows. Dog parties. Dog toy fairs. A dog salon and spa. And a \u201cdoggie concierge\u201d who handles requests specifically from dog owners, coaches and handlers.\n\n\u201cWe have it down to a science,\u201d the canine concierge, Jerry Grymek, said of the hotel, which has been hosting Westminster competitors since the 1990s. \u201cPeople have rituals to make their dogs feel comfortable.\u201d", "title": "New York Today: Dog Concierge Tells All", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Fabscrap\u2019s founder, Jessica Schreiber, is expecting a glut of new stock, \u201cbecause after Fashion Week everyone cleans out.\u201d\n\nWhen we visited this week, volunteers picked fabric from garbage bags piled 12 feet high.\n\nCotton, wool and spandex are separated, and smaller scraps are sent out to be made into fire blankets, insulation and car-door lining. The good pieces are meticulously organized by color and neatly folded in Fabscrap\u2019s retail space.\n\nPhoto\n\nLast year Fabscrap collected 68,000 pounds of fabric \u2014 enough to fill 13,600 shopping bags or create an equal number of head-to-toe looks.\n\nMs. Schreiber, 29, a former senior manager at the city sanitation department and self-described \u201ctrash nerd,\u201d founded the nonprofit after noticing that New York\u2019s clothing recycling program didn\u2019t accept fabric.\n\n\u201cThe city collects reusable clothes and takes it to Goodwill,\u201d she said. \u201cIt didn\u2019t really fit their model.\u201d\n\nShe started driving a U-Haul van around Midtown picking up 50-pound bags of fabric from designers. \u201cI got to know a lot of the freight elevator operators in the garment district,\u201d she said.\n\nShe was often told, \u201cYou work like a man.\u201d She took it as a compliment.\n\nMs. Schreiber\u2019s goal is to one day collect scraps from clothing producers, which generate a lot more waste than designers. \u201cThat\u2019s where you have the potential to make a real impact,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut for now, she\u2019s looking to expand her network of over 600 volunteers, who get free fabric and an important lesson.\n\n\u201cWhen you walk in and see this pile of waste it\u2019s such an educational moment,\u201d she said. \u201cThere\u2019s no better way to change what someone thinks about waste than for them to see it and put their hands on it.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nYesterday\u2019s slush is but a memory.\n\nIt will be sunny and dry, but temperatures might not get above freezing.\n\nWrap a fabric scrap around your neck: The wind could make it feel like 15 on your commute.\n\nIn the News\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Though liberal, Mayor Bill de Blasio says the city should not go easy on turnstile jumpers. I loved the diversity of skills you needed and I love that you get to add your level of personality to your run.\u201d\n\nBy the time she was 15, Ms. Schild was known on the mountain as \u201cWar Paint.\u201d\n\n\u201cOne of my coaches saw how silly I was around the competition but when I stepped into the gate, the war paint came on; I became very focused and serious,\u201d she said. \u201cThe second I finished I was back to my goofy self.\u201d\n\nThe 20-year-old freestyle skier from the Rochester suburb of Pittsford is one of 19 New Yorkers competing at the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, which start today.", "title": "New York Today: From Here to Pyeongchang", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "A bright yellow sign advertises Magid, a handbag company that has survived \u2014 its offices are on Fifth Avenue a few blocks from the sign.\n\n\u201cEvery time I see it, it gives me a little bit of excitement,\u201d said Pinny Rand, whose family bought the rights to the Magid name in the 1990s.\n\nPhoto\n\nLexington Avenue and 32nd Street\n\nA royal blue sign on the back of 192 Lexington Avenue advertises Manning, Bowman & Co., a Connecticut company famous for its metalware: kettles, pots, service kits, fans, toasters, bar goods and the like.\n\n\u201cTheir products represent a beautiful Art Deco style\u201d and are in many museum collections today, Mr. Passikoff said.\n\nPhoto\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\n\u201cMercury Rises to 68, Record for Feb. 21; Holiday Seekers Jam Trains to Resorts.\u201d\n\nThat was the headline in 1930. The bullets knocked him over backward,\u201d The Times reported at the time. He was 39.\n\nAlthough Malcolm was born in Nebraska, he spent much of his life in New York City, where he ascended to the local Harlem spotlight and became a national media figure.\n\nIn the early 1950s, he founded and preached at the Mosque 7, now a Sunni Muslim mosque in Harlem called Masjid Malcolm Shabazz.\n\nMalcolm and his family lived in a house at 23-11 97th Street in East Elmhurst in Queens. The house was firebombed a week before his murder.\n\nHe was assassinated by three members of the Nation of Islam, a religious movement with which he had cut ties a few months earlier.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a marked man,\u201d Malcolm told a Times reporter a week before his death. \u201cNo one can get out without trouble, and this thing with me will be resolved by death and violence.\u201d\n\n\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? Levine", "New York Today"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "In Chicago, politicians were caught on tape discussing the old standbys \u201clettuce\u201d and \u201cCheddar.\u201d\n\nFood makes sense as a cover word for money, said Robert A. Leonard, head of the forensic linguistics program at Hofstra University: Both are desirable, and food often sounds natural in regular conversation.\n\n\u201cThe best code words are language that seem to mean something totally different than what it really means, but seems to fit into the context,\u201d said Mr. Leonard, who testifies as an expert language witness in criminal cases. \u201cFood is good because it\u2019s quotidian.\u201d\n\nThe magic word doesn\u2019t have to be a foodstuff. In a 1995 case, a former New York City transportation official prosaically referred to payoffs as \u201ccommitments.\u201d Farther afield, in South Africa, the code phrase was \u201cEiffel Tower\u201d; in the Democratic Republic of Congo it was \u201cmaking a whiskey\u201d; and in Lebanon a common remedy for unlined pockets is \u201caspirin.\u201d\n\nSecret language often figures in perjury and bribery cases, Mr. Leonard said, because these are crimes that are often \u201ccommitted via the uttering of a word.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather", "title": "New York Today: Hold the Ziti", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "The Patriots\u2019 star tight end, Rob Gronkowski, is from Amherst, N.Y., running back Dion Lewis is from Albany and safety Devin McCourty was born in Nyack.\n\nRoughly 40 of the 300 athletes in the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio, played for New York teams \u2014 not only the Jets and the Giants, but also the now-defunct Staten Island Stapletons, the New York Yankees, the New York Bulldogs, the New York Titans (now known as the Jets) and the Brooklyn Dodgers.\n\nWe were there first.\n\nBoth current New York teams, the Jets and the Giants, won the Super Bowl before the Eagles and the Patriots. The Jets\u2019 win was in 1969; the Giants\u2019 first, in 1987. (The Eagles have yet to win in the Super Bowl era.)\n\nAlso on the list of Giants\u2019 victories: two Super Bowl wins against the Patriots. The first time, in 2008, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City and Mayor Thomas M. Menino of Boston placed a bet on the outcome. After New York prevailed, Mr. Menino sent 100 cups of New England clam chowder, 144 Boston cream pies, and other local delicacies to Mr. Bloomberg. (The food was donated to charity.)\n\nAnd the last time the Patriots lost the Super Bowl, it was also to the Giants.\n\nWhen\u2019s the game?\n\nThe indoor game starts at 6:30 p.m. Eastern time on Sunday on NBC.", "title": "New York Today: New Yorkers in the Super Bowl", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "When Ms. Jennings tried to hop on, the conductor stopped her and told her to wait for a car with her \u201cpeople in it.\u201d\n\n\u201cI then told him that I had no people,\u201d Ms. Jennings wrote, and she boarded the car anyway.\n\nAlthough New York had abolished slavery nearly 30 years before, many restaurants, churches, and schools were still segregated. Public transportation cars were marked with placards announcing whether African-Americans were allowed on board.\n\nGet out, the conductor ordered.\n\n\u201cI answered again that I was a respectable person, born and raised in New York,\u201d Ms. Jennings said, \u201cand that he was a good for nothing impudent fellow for insulting decent persons while on their way to church.\u201d\n\nThe conductor tried to pull Ms. Jennings from the car, but she held onto the window frame.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cYou shall sweat for this,\u201d he said.\n\nHe drove without making stops to a corner on the Bowery and called over a police officer. The officer sided with the conductor and pushed Ms. Jennings onto the street, breaking her bonnet and dirtying her Sunday attire.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe officer \u201ctauntingly told me to get redress if I could,\u201d Ms. Jennings wrote hours later.\n\nShe filed a lawsuit against the Third Avenue Railway Company, the operator of the streetcar, with the help of a lawyer, Chester A. Arthur, who would later become our 21st president.\n\nThe court ruled in her favor, granting her $225 in damages and allowing all African-Americans to use public transit, as long as they were \u201csober, well behaved, and free from disease.\u201d\n\nAs a result of the ruling, within five years, the city\u2019s streetcars were largely integrated.\n\nMs. Jennings went on to found the city\u2019s first kindergarten for African-American children, at her home on West 41st Street. Her story of defiance may not be widely known, but in 2007 a sign reading \u201cElizabeth Jennings Place\u201d went up at the corner of Spruce Street and Park Row \u2014 154 years and a few blocks from where she refused to get off the streetcar.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nYou knew it wouldn\u2019t last.\n\nOur balmy weather is gone. Temperatures will fall into the mid-30s by afternoon, and rain will come and go all day.\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 As the temperature hit a record high by noon, the Bryant Park ice skating rink in Midtown was covered in puddles, but skaters were undeterred. Norman", "New York Today"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "People have been hurt. Last month, Chris Wilson, 39, a software developer, needed eight stitches after slipping on the escalator at the South Ferry station.\n\n\u201cI wasn\u2019t walking down,\u201d he said. \u201cI wasn\u2019t actually doing anything. My foot just sort of slipped out from under me. It was definitely the slickness on the floor.\u201d\n\nTheories have emerged. Some blame ice melt, which can leave an oily residue when tracked in from the street. Others have suggested car exhaust or discarded fried chicken grease.\n\nWe asked the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.\n\nShams Tarek, a spokesman, said the slippery floors are from the combination of rain and snow tracked in from the street, other substances brought in on shoes, and high humidity in stations that traps moisture.\n\nThe buildup on the subway floor \u2014 from shoes, trash, spills and exhaust \u2014 contains substances that dissolve in water, like salt and sugars, along with oily compounds, which don\u2019t, explained Sanat Kumar, a professor of chemical engineering at Columbia University.\n\nYou just don\u2019t notice the oily stuff until it rains or snows because it\u2019s caked together on the subway tile with everything else.\n\n\u201cOnce you add water, whatever didn\u2019t dissolve is going to be oily,\u201d Professor Kumar said. On nonporous subway tiles, where hardly anything is absorbed, the slick stuff just sits on the surface.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs for why floors can seem more slippery on snowy days than on rainy days, Professor Kumar theorized, \u201cIt\u2019s easier to carry snow in on your shoes, so you\u2019ll have more water on the snowy days.\u201d\n\n(Update: Some readers have speculated that the M.T.A. has changed the kind of cleaning fluid it uses. It has not, Mr. Tarek said.)\n\nFor now, the M.T.A. said it would continue to mop aggressively after both snow and rain \u2014 the latter of which is expected to fall for much of the rest of the day.\n\nLook for a high around 42. Tomorrow: clearing but colder.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 The National Transportation Safety Board officially concluded that failure to screen for sleep apnea in engineers has caused train crashes, including one in Hoboken, N.J., in late 2016, and another in Brooklyn last year. 12 shades of red alone.\n\nThe roses were all a little tired-looking from the journey, the florists said, so workers spent the next few days nursing them back to health \u2014 hydrating, cleaning and preening them before arranging them into $100 dozens to be delivered to New Yorkers.\n\nPhoto\n\nPerhaps, to you.\n\nNow, they have about a week before they wilt \u2014 seven days is the typical postsale life expectancy of a rose. \u201cMost flowers, you\u2019re just enjoying the beauty of its death,\u201d Mr. Faitos told us.\n\nStill, they\u2019ve made it this far.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nMild and lovely, with a high of 50.\n\nBut grab an umbrella. The ashes were to be blessed by the priest at 7 o\u2019clock this morning, just before Mass.\n\nAbout 50,000 New Yorkers receive ashes from the cathedral on Fifth Avenue each year, Ms. Lopez-Blanco told us, and the archdiocese is expecting a similar turnout today.\n\nThe message that comes with the cross: \u201cRemember, man, that thou art dust, and into dust thou shalt return.\u201d\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day?
