Norman", "New York Today"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nState financial regulators in New York said Wednesday that they would investigate reports that gay men have been denied insurance policies covering life, disability or long-term care because they were taking medication to protect themselves against H.I.V.\n\nSuch denials would amount to illegal discrimination based on sexual orientation, and the companies doing so could be penalized, said Maria T. Vullo, the state\u2019s superintendent of financial services.\n\nThe investigation was triggered by an article published Tuesday by The New York Times, she said.\n\nThe Times reported that various insurers around the country had denied policies to gay men after learning they took Truvada, a cocktail of two anti-AIDS drugs, to avoid catching H.I.V. through sex. To get insurance, some men even stopped taking the protective drugs.\n\nThe practice \u2014 known as \u201cpre-exposure prophylaxis,\u201d or PrEP \u2014 is recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Studies have shown that people who take the drug every day have nearly a zero chance of becoming infected, even if they are in a long relationship with an H.I.V.-infected person or have sex with many strangers without condoms.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAIDS experts have condemned the insurance denials as both discriminatory and nonsensical, because they deny policies to good risks \u2014 men who protect themselves.", "title": "New York Will Investigate Reports of Gay Men Denied Insurance", "authors": ["Donald G. Mcneil Jr."]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "New Yorkers are accustomed to waiting. They wait, usually with Job-like patience, for a long-overdue train to pull into the station. They wait stoically at home for a store delivery promised for some time between 10 a.m. and never. They waited nearly a century for a Second Avenue subway line \u2014 and even then got only a few stations.\n\nSo it is not surprising that New Yorkers wait calmly for their governor and mayor to move forcefully on two important transportation ideas with a potential to transform travel in the city. One is congestion pricing, the other a streetcar line that would connect Brooklyn and Queens along their shared waterfront. But patience is not infinite. The two leaders would do well to hear a tapping of feet that signals the public\u2019s desire for action.\n\nOn congestion pricing, nearly six weeks have passed since a task force handed Gov. Andrew Cuomo its recommendations to make drivers pay to enter the overcrowded core of Manhattan: $11.52 for cars, $25.34 for trucks, and per-ride surcharges of $2 to $5 for taxis and app-based services like Uber, Lyft and Via. The twofold goal is to ease strangling traffic and raise money for mass transit \u2014 as much as $1.5 billion a year by the task force\u2019s estimates.\n\nGranted, six weeks isn\u2019t an eternity. But the congestion pricing concept is years old, and making it a reality is long overdue. Mr. Cuomo is said to have begun leaning on wary lawmakers, and he has taken a few preliminary steps in his executive budget to get the ball rolling. They amount, however, to dipping toes in the water. Even while recognizing the political delicacy of these proposals, especially in a state election year, we\u2019d like to see him plunge in deeply. If ever an issue cried out for a vigorous exercise of gubernatorial muscle to get lawmakers on board, this one is it.", "title": "Opinion | New Yorkers Deserve Action on Ambitious Transit Plans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWELLINGTON, New Zealand \u2014 In a push to counter the popularity and charisma of Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, New Zealand\u2019s main opposition party elected a young lawmaker as its new leader on Tuesday.\n\nThe vote, held behind closed doors by the lawmakers of the center-right National Party, follows the resignation of the party\u2019s longtime leader, Bill English, after the elections of September 2017. The party failed to win a parliamentary majority, and a coalition led by Ms. Ardern\u2019s center-left Labour Party formed the government.\n\nThe new opposition leader, Simon Bridges, the youngest of the contenders at 41, billed himself as the candidate offering a \u201cgenerational change.\u201d Five lawmakers ran for the post to lead the National Party\u2019s 56 members in Parliament.\n\nPaula Bennett will retain her role as deputy leader.\n\nMr. Bridges, a former prosecutor who cited his \u201cyoung family\u201d in interviews ahead of the vote, will now lead the effort to defeat Ms. Ardern, 37, in New Zealand\u2019s 2020 election.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Bridges was minister for transport and for economic development in the previous National-led government, and has represented the city of Tauranga since 2008. He is part Maori, and said he was the first of New Zealand\u2019s indigenous people to lead the National Party.", "title": "New Zealand\u2019s Opposition Party Selects a New Leader", "authors": ["Charlotte Graham-Mclay"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Like Dieter Rams, Alex Crane, a designer from Brooklyn, believes that it\u2019s important to design as little as possible. \u201cThe simpler the product, the more refined and versatile,\u201d said Mr. Crane, who has been reimagining work wear since 2016. That means comfortable clothing for both work and leisure. Take the Shadows Blanket shirt. It looks like a run-of-the-mill collared dress shirt, but it is made of a Japanese cotton knit that feels as soft as a favorite sweatshirt. \u201cWe spend most of our time working, so we want to make the most of it,\u201d he said.\n\nAlex Crane Shadows Blanket shirt, $145, at alexcrane.co.", "title": "New for Spring: Tie-Dyes, Hawaiian Shirts and Nylon Bags", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Two top editors and a reporter at Newsweek were fired on Monday, and two other reporters left in limbo, in a purge that targeted employees involved in coverage of the company\u2019s financial and legal troubles.\n\nBob Roe, the magazine\u2019s editor in chief; Kenneth Li, its executive news director; and Celeste Katz, a reporter, were dismissed after receiving Google Calendar invitations to meet with executives at Newsweek\u2019s parent company, the Newsweek Media Group, three employees confirmed. Ms. Katz had reported on the company\u2019s affairs, including a raid by the Manhattan district attorney\u2019s office last month, and Mr. Li had overseen the coverage.\n\nTwo other reporters involved in the coverage \u2014 Josh Saul, a Newsweek writer, and Josh Keefe, a writer at the affiliated International Business Times \u2014 were locked out of their computers and email accounts on Monday. They were not fired, but did not know whether they would still have jobs come morning.\n\n\u201cI have not been fired, although that was very clearly the plan,\u201d Mr. Keefe tweeted.\n\nNewsweek\u2019s communications department said in an email on Tuesday that the company does not comment on personnel matters. The magazine\u2019s new acting editor, Nancy Cooper, did not respond to an email sent to her personal address.", "title": "Newsweek Fires Editors and Reporter Who Investigated the Company", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "The luxury hotel market, once concentrated in only the largest cities, has surged over the last decade. Jay Stein, the chief executive at the Dream Hotel Group, has taken advantage of the demand, shining a light on a company that helped cultivate one of the most popular trends in modern upscale lodging.\n\n\u201cWe started the rooftop bar craze,\u201d Mr. Stein said, referring to the 2003 opening of the former Ava Lounge at the Dream Midtown that brought a certain hipness to the usual outdoor drinks scene. \u201cThere were others that started to catch on, but we\u2019ve been an early player with luxury boutique hotels.\u201d\n\nThe company, which includes the Chatwal New York and Time Hotels, currently operates 18 properties. There are plans for 30 additional hotels internationally over the next four years, from a Dream hotel in Belize to boutique-oriented Unscripted hotels in Birmingham, England, and Tulum, Mexico.\n\nBelow are edited excerpts from a conversation with Mr. Stein in Manhattan.\n\nHow has Dream influenced the growth within the New York luxury market? Coach Unai Emery denied reports that Neymar, a star for the Brazilian national team, would have an operation, the club walked back that statement on Wednesday and announced that he would have surgery.\n\n\u201cAfter an initial treatment period of three days in line with a strict medical protocol, a joint decision has been taken between the medical staffs of both Paris Saint-Germain and the Brazil national team,\u201d P.S.G. said in a statement.\n\nP.S.G. broke soccer\u2019s transfer record last year by paying Barcelona 222 million euros ($260 million) to buy Neymar, in part with the hope that he would lead the club to the Champions League title. But those hopes took a massive blow when he was injured on Sunday during P.S.G.\u2019s 3-0 win over Marseille. Tests later revealed he had a cracked fifth metatarsal in his right foot along with an ankle injury.", "title": "Neymar Will Have Surgery on Fractured Foot", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Once hired by The Post, he did not fit into regular news beats. But given the latitude of a column, he became Washington\u2019s enfant terrible, attacking the Nixon administration over the war in Vietnam, violent police crackdowns on protesters at the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago, and President Richard M. Nixon\u2019s taped Oval Office profanities as the Watergate scandal closed in, forcing his resignation in 1974.\n\nMr. Hoffman sounded the political death knell with a bitter irony.\n\n\u201cNixon,\u201d he wrote, \u201cis going into the history books as the president who absent-mindedly didn\u2019t mind having his people drop the Bill of Rights from the Constitution, but who was chased from office for public profanity. You commit treason but they get you for littering.\u201d\n\nHe caricatured subjects with rapier cuts: Nixon \u201clooks like he\u2019s got lip cramps and a Charley horse in the cheek.\u201d Attorney General John N. Mitchell, who helped plan the Watergate break-in, was \u201ca Peeping Tom.\u201d And in the Rev. Billy Graham \u201cwe can see the formal union of state, society and religion, the working partnership between God and Caesar, not rendering to each other so much as washing each other\u2019s hands.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy approach to reporting is nothing new,\u201d Mr. von Hoffman told Newsweek in 1969. \u201cIt\u2019s no different than the methods used by people like Hearst, Pulitzer or Mencken. They certainly didn\u2019t adhere to strict news objectivity. I think you\u2019re mad if you come into journalism with the idea that you\u2019re going to change things for the better. I write because I enjoy it. I sincerely believe in what I write, and I get a kick out of getting those Washington mossbacks angry.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe provoked more outraged letters to the editor than any writer in memory at The Post, said Chalmers M. Roberts, a longtime correspondent.\n\nIn 1970, Mr. von Hoffman raised a storm of protest with a column that referred to American prisoners of war in Vietnam as a political issue involving \u201cjust 1,500 men.\u201d Angry letters from prisoners\u2019 families and support groups flooded in; many were published, along with a Post editorial disagreeing with the column but defending the author\u2019s right to his opinion.\n\n\u201cMy life would have been a lot simpler had Nicholas von Hoffman not appeared in the paper,\u201d the publisher, Katharine Graham, wrote in her 1997 memoir, \u201cPersonal History.\u201d But, she added, \u201cI firmly believed that he belonged at The Post.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. von Hoffman, a thickset man, sometimes let his prematurely gray hair get a bit long. But he hardly looked the part of a radical. He wore spectacles, dressed casually in sports jackets and jeans, smoked a pipe and looked cool, smiling and relaxed, even when caught up in a dispute on national television.\n\nIn the early 1970s, he became a familiar commentator on the CBS program \u201c60 Minutes,\u201d paired on the \u201cPoint/Counterpoint\u201d segment with the conservative James J. Kilpatrick. Don Hewitt, the producer, fired Mr. von Hoffman in 1974 after he called Nixon, on the air, \u201ca dead mouse on the kitchen floor that everyone was afraid to touch and throw in the garbage.\u201d\n\nNicholas von Hoffman was born in New York City on Oct. 16, 1929, to Carl von Hoffman and the former Anna Bruenn. His father was an immigrant Russian cavalry officer. After graduating from Fordham Preparatory School in the Bronx in 1948, Nicholas went to Chicago, intending to enroll at Loyola University. Instead, he took a research job at the University of Chicago, and in 1954 joined Mr. Alinsky as a field organizer in black and Hispanic communities on the South Side.\n\nHis marriage to Ann C. Byrne in 1950 ended in divorce in 1968. She was also a social activist in Chicago and was later a dean at the University of Rhode Island. She died in 2015.\n\nBesides Alexander, Mr. von Hoffman is survived by two other sons from his first marriage, Constantine and Aristo, and two grandchildren. A second marriage, to Patricia Bennett, also ended in divorce.\n\nMr. von Hoffman\u2019s first book, \u201cMississippi Notebook\u201d (1964), grew out of his civil rights coverage for The Sun-Times. Early on at The Post, on the education beat, he wrote a book, \u201cMultiversity\u201d (1966). In cultural affairs, he explored San Francisco\u2019s hippie drug scene and wrote another book, \u201cWe Are the People Our Parents Warned Us Against\u201d (1968).\n\nFinally given latitude as a columnist, he hit his stride. At the 1969 trial of the Chicago Eight , the leftist radicals charged with inciting to riot at the Democratic National Convention the previous summer (they became the Chicago Seven after one defendant\u2019s trial was severed), he depicted a theatrical parody of jurisprudence.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe defendants were portrayed as part of the satire: Abbie Hoffman was the \u201cstreet theater social critic,\u201d David Dellinger was \u201cthe old-line pacifist-socialist who\u2019s only recently dared to grow sideburns,\u201d and Jerry Rubin was \u201ca freelance wild man.\u201d Judge Julius J. Hoffman, presiding at the trial, became \u201can aging Hobbit who never stops talking with the voice of a man reading horror stories to small children.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nReporters for other news organizations could not convey Mr. von Hoffman\u2019s absurdist view of the trial. \u201cHe has caught its tone and flavor in a way that has been almost impossible for those of us operating under tighter editorial restrictions,\u201d said J. Anthony Lukas of The New York Times.\n\nBut even the more objective reporters found rare spectacles to write about: The Black Panther Party activist Bobby Seale, whose case was severed, called the judge \u201ca fascist dog,\u201d \u201ca honky\u201d and \u201ca pig.\u201d When he refused to be silenced, the judge ordered him bound and gagged in court. Two defendants, Mr. Rubin and Mr. Hoffman, appeared in court wearing judicial robes. They complied with an order to remove them, revealing Chicago police uniforms underneath.\n\nAfter leaving The Post, Mr. Hoffman wrote syndicated freelance columns for King Features for decades. He also wrote book reviews and magazine articles for The Times and contributed to The New Republic, Esquire, Vogue, The Nation, Harper\u2019s, The New York Review of Books and other publications.\n\nHe collaborated with the Doonesbury political cartoonist, Garry B. Trudeau, on two books, \u201cThe Fireside Watergate\u201d (1973) and \u201cTales From the Margaret Mead Taproom\u201d (1976). He also wrote two novels, \u201cTwo, Three, Many More\u201d (1969), on the campus disruptions of the 1960s, and \u201cOrganized Crimes\u201d (1984), about gangland Chicago in the Great Depression.\n\nHis most successful book was \u201cCitizen Cohn,\u201d which was on The Times\u2019 best-seller lists for eight weeks in 1988 and inspired a 1992 movie of the same title starring James Woods. Christopher Lehmann-Haupt, in a review for The Times, called the biography a \u201cricher, more rounded, better balanced view\u201d than Sidney Zion\u2019s contemporaneous book, \u201cThe Autobiography of Roy Cohn,\u201d based on interviews with Mr. Cohn, who died in 1986.\n\nMr. von Hoffman broadcast 250 commentaries on public affairs in the 1980s for the syndicated Cato Institute radio program \u201cByline.\u201d From 1993 to 2008, he wrote columns for the weekly newspaper The New York Observer, and from 1996 to 2007 he contributed to Architectural Digest.\n\nHe also wrote for The Huffington Post, and composed the libretto for Deborah Drattell\u2019s 2003 production of \u201cNicholas and Alexandra\u201d by the Los Angeles Opera.\n\nMr. von Hoffman also wrote \u201cHoax: Why Americans Are Suckered by White House Lies,\u201d (2004), and \u201cRadical: A Portrait of Saul Alinsky\u201d (2010), based on his recollections of his years working as a community organizer with Mr. Alinsky.\n\nAnother of his mentors, Benjamin C. Bradlee, the executive editor of The Post, offered perhaps the highest praise for his former reporter and columnist, calling Mr. von Hoffman\u2019s work \u201clandmarks in the early, timid years of the new journalism: personal, pertinent, articulate, vital glimpses of man trying to make it in a more complicated world.\u201d", "title": "Nicholas von Hoffman, Provocative Journalist and Author, Dies at 88", "authors": ["Robert D. Mcfadden"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIn 1962, when I was 18, my best friend, Ted, and I drove from our homes in Colorado to New York for our first visit to the city.\n\nWe stayed at the Y.M.C.A., and over the course of three days managed to visit the Statue of Liberty and the Metropolitan Museum of Art; ride on the Staten Island Ferry; wander around Greenwich Village; take in \u201cMy Fair Lady\u201d on Broadway; and do many other touristy things.\n\nAt the end of our visit, we returned to the parking lot where we had left our car, a 1952 Dodge station wagon with Colorado plates. The attendant, a big guy, told us we owed $4.95 for the three days of parking.\n\nI handed him a $5 bill and prepared to drive away.\n\n\u201cWhoa!\u201d the attendant shouted. He handed me a nickel and, glowering, said, \u201cI don\u2019t take no nickel tips.\u201d\n\nTed and I got flustered. We scrambled to find some more change.\n\nThe attendant laughed.\n\n\u201cYou two have a great time driving back to Colorado.\u201d he said. \u201cAnd don\u2019t forget to come back.\u201d", "title": "Nickel Tip", "authors": ["Peter S. Allen", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "MINNEAPOLIS \u2014 As knowledge about head trauma and concussions has increased over the past decade, a growing number of parents have warned their children about the perils of football. Icons of the sport like Bo Jackson have said they would not have played had they known what we know now, while others have said they would actively discourage their children and grandchildren from playing.\n\nYet here at the home of Sunday\u2019s Super Bowl, the N.F.L. has found a way around those warnings. The league is speaking to children directly.\n\nOn Wednesday, after two hours of sprinting around the booths at a Super Bowl Experience sponsored by the cable network Nickelodeon, about 2,500 children made their way to the N.F.L. Play 60 Field \u2014 everything at the Experience has a branded name \u2014 for a musical performance by JoJo Siwa.\n\nYou might not know Siwa, but your child certainly does. A YouTube star and participant on the reality show \u201cDance Moms,\u201d Siwa, 14, is a familiar face to the millions who watch her videos and sing along to her songs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring a break in her performance on Wednesday, she led the crowd in singing \u201cHappy Birthday\u201d to Play 60 \u2014 the N.F.L. youth fitness campaign that began late in 2007. This was the second track on \u201c\u00c9toile Polaire\u201d that I listened to, and there was just something really beautiful about it. It has all the processes that he was doing in \u201cMusic in 12 Parts,\u201d but it has this luxurious French harmony. It also looks exactly like it sounds: bubbly, ebullient and fun. Philip\u2019s body of work has these forgotten gems. Finding this is like finding a door in your house to a room you never knew existed.\n\nI play it off the manuscript because there\u2019s something about the printed edition I don\u2019t quite get. I really like Philip\u2019s hand. I\u2019m really used to it, and I have a sentimental relationship with looking at it. There are sometimes these ambiguities with his notations, and so much of my life for years was deciphering his manuscripts.\n\nWhat about this music is quintessentially Glass?\n\nYou can see the construction of the rhythmic cycle. You can see how at the beginning each figure contains two units of six notes, each one repeated four times. In Figure 2, interestingly, it\u2019s the same, but each cell of eight notes is repeated four times. Then Figure 3 augments the rhythm and goes eight-six-eight-six. It\u2019s a fake-out: You don\u2019t actually perceive the change until the middle of the figure.", "title": "Nico Muhly on the \u2018Ecstatic Disruption\u2019 of Philip Glass\u2019s Music", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "At the same time, the report notes that Saudi restrictions on imports of civilian goods into Yemen worsened the suffering there. Saudi Arabia is now working to address this through a new Yemen humanitarian aid plan. We welcome its engagement with the United Nations to try to address the humanitarian crisis, and urge it to do more.\n\nBut the report, for all its bad news, should be welcomed by those who wish to prevent the conflict in Yemen from becoming a direct, major confrontation in the Middle East. By confirming that Iran is the source of the missiles and other weaponry fired into Saudi Arabia, the U.N. panel has given the world a chance to act before a missile hits a school or a hospital and leads to a dangerous military escalation that provokes a Saudi military response.\n\nIt is imperative that we seize this opportunity. Iranian missiles have already come close to hitting civilian targets in Saudi Arabia. Last November, Houthi militants fired a missile at a major civilian airport outside Riyadh. Fortunately, the missile fell short of its target. But, as this newspaper reported, it detonated so close to the terminal that it caused people inside to jump out of their seats. And the debris it left scattered around the airport had Iranian fingerprints all over it.\n\nIn December, the United States and our partners took the extraordinary step of declassifying evidence from this missile attack, as well as from other attacks by missiles, conventional arms and explosive boats of Iranian origin \u2014 all used by the rebels in Yemen and all violations of U.N. resolutions.\n\nIn a warehouse in Washington, we put on display recovered pieces of the missile fired at the Riyadh airport, with its telltale nine valves running the length of it and lack of large stabilizing fins, proof of its Iranian manufacture. Some of the missile remnants on display were stamped with the logo of Shahid Bagheri Industries, an Iranian manufacturer. Based on the strength of this and other evidence, our intelligence community concluded unequivocally that the weapons had been supplied by the Tehran regime. As I said at the time, they might as well have had \u201cMade in Iran\u201d all over them.", "title": "Opinion | Nikki Haley: The U.N.\u2019s Uncomfortable Truths About Iran", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor the latest on the Florida school shooting, read our Thursday live updates.\n\nThe man suspected of opening fire inside a Florida high school on Wednesday, killing at least 17 people, is a former student who had been expelled for disciplinary reasons, the authorities said.\n\nSheriff Scott Israel of Broward County, Fla., said that the man, Nikolas Cruz, 19, previously attended Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland but was expelled after getting into trouble. He was enrolled at another Broward County school, officials said.\n\nOn Thursday, the authorities charged Mr. Cruz with 17 counts of premeditated murder.\n\nIn the hours after the shooting, people who knew Mr. Cruz described him as a \u201ctroubled kid\u201d who enjoyed showing off his firearms, bragging about killing animals and whose mother would resort to calling the police to have them come to their home to try to talk some sense into him. At a school with about 3,000 students, Mr. Cruz stayed to himself and had few friends but struck fear in some students with erratic behavior and an affinity for violence.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cHe always had guns on him,\u201d the student, who did not give his name, told WFOR-TV. \u201cThe crazy stuff that he did was not right for school, and he got kicked out of school multiple times for that kind of stuff.\u201d\n\nJim Gard, a math teacher at Stoneman Douglas High School, said in an interview that Mr. Cruz was a student in his class during the first semester of the 2016-17 school year. In the class, he was quiet and not disruptive, Mr. Gard said.\n\nBut he recalled that school administrators became concerned last year about Mr. Cruz\u2019s behavior and alerted the faculty. \u201cWe received emails about him from the administration,\u201d Mr. Gard said in an interview, adding that he did not recall the specific issues.\n\nAfter the shooting on Wednesday, Mr. Gard said that several students told him that Mr. Cruz was taken with a girl at Stoneman Douglas High School \u201cto the point of stalking her.\u201d\n\nIn the interview with the Miami news station, the student said Mr. Cruz was a junior at Stoneman Douglas High School when he was expelled last year. He said that students would joke that if anyone were to open fire inside the school, it would be Mr. Cruz. Because of that, students feared him and mostly stayed away from him, the student said.\n\n\u201cA lot of people were saying that it would be him,\u201d the student told WFOR-TV. \u201cThey would say he would be the one to shoot up the school. Everyone predicted it.\u201d\n\nBrandon Minoff, a student at Stoneman Douglas High School, said in an interview with CNN that a teacher assigned him to work with Mr. Cruz on a group project two years ago. Mr. Cruz was quiet in class but opened up during their project, Mr. Minoff said, telling him that he had been kicked out of two private schools, had been held back twice and aspired to join the military.\n\n\u201cHe was always to himself and never tried to associate himself with anyone,\u201d Mr. Minoff said. \u201cAs far as I know, he didn\u2019t have any friends.\u201d\n\nSchool officials declined to say why Mr. Cruz no longer attended Douglas High School. But Amanda Samaroo, whose daughter, Elizabeth, attended the school while he was a student there, said he had been expelled for bringing knives on campus. \u201cHer friends have said he was known to always be mentally ill and would kill animals,\u201d Ms. Samaroo said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHelen Pasciolla, who is retired, lives on an elegant street in the Pine Tree Estates development in Parkland, three houses down and across from where the Cruz family resided until about a year ago. Ms. Pasciolla said that Mr. Cruz told her that the family had to move out of their one-story beige house and sell it because they could no longer afford it.\n\nShe said that Mr. Cruz has a brother, Zachary, and that both boys were adopted. Their adoptive father died some years ago, she added.\n\nMs. Pasciolla said that the boys\u2019 mother, Lynda Cruz, had regular problems with their behavior. On occasion, she said, the mother would resort to calling the police to have them come over to try to talk some sense into her sons.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think she wanted to scare them a little bit,\u201d Ms. Pasciolla said. \u201cNikolas has behavioral problems, I think, but I never thought he would be violent.\u201d\n\nWhen she saw his picture on TV on Wednesday after the shooting, Ms. Pasciolla said that she thought to herself, \u201cOh, my God, that\u2019s the kid who lived down the street.\u201d\n\nSheriff Israel said that the authorities did not yet know the motive for the killing, but were learning more about Mr. Cruz through his social media pages, which he described as \u201cvery, very concerning.\u201d\n\nScreen shots of an Instagram page said to belong to Mr. Cruz show many photos of a man holding firearms and ammunition used in a semiautomatic AR-15 rifle. One photo shows several guns, including rifles with scopes, lying on a bed. Another appears to show a frog that had been killed.\n\nAfter Mr. Cruz left Douglas High School, he took a job at a Dollar Tree store about a mile and a half from the school. A person who answered the phone at the store on Wednesday evening said that Mr. Cruz worked as a cashier and was well liked by his colleagues.\n\n\u201cHe was a great guy,\u201d the person said.\n\nHe added that he last saw Mr. Cruz about a year ago before he transferred to another Dollar Tree store closer to his home.\n\nAnother student at Douglas High School, Ocean Parodie, told The Daily Beast that he visited the store after Mr. Cruz was expelled to check on him. \u201cHe said he was expelled and was happy that he was thrown out,\u201d Mr. Parodie said. \u201cI felt bad for him.\u201d", "title": "Nikolas Cruz, Florida Shooting Suspect, Described as a \u2018Troubled Kid\u2019", "authors": ["Matthew Haag", "Serge F. Kovaleski"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Pressed repeatedly as to whether he would commit to tightening gun restrictions in his state, Mr. Scott said that he would be \u201cstrong on that,\u201d and that \u201ceverything is on the table.\u201d\n\nBut he also made clear that there were \u201ca lot of things\u201d at play, such as who should have guns, how to make schools safer, and how to make it easier for children to report problems.\n\nMr. Cruz had no criminal history before the shootings, according to state law enforcement records. But his childhood was certainly troubled.\n\nHe spent much of it in a subdivision called Pine Tree Estates, on a lush, narrow street dotted with tropical plants and the occasional driveway basketball hoop. Mr. Cruz and his brother, Zachary, had been adopted, and were raised largely by their mother, Lynda Cruz, especially after their father, Roger P. Cruz, died suddenly in 2004 at the age of 67. Ms. Cruz died in November, and people who knew Nikolas said he had taken the loss hard.\n\nPaul Gold, 45, said he lived next door to the Cruzes in 2009 and 2010 and stayed in touch with Lynda Cruz over the years.\n\n\u201cHe had emotional problems and I believe he was diagnosed with autism,\u201d Mr. Gold said of Nikolas Cruz. \u201cHe had trouble controlling his temper. He broke things. He would do that sometimes at our house when he lost his temper. But he was always very apologetic afterwards.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cHe would sometimes be hitting his head and covering his ears. One time, I sent him home because he was misbehaving at our house and he took a golf club and smashed one of my trailers.\u201d\n\nHe said that Mr. Cruz at one point had gone to a school for students with special needs. \u201cKids were really picking on him and would gang up on him and beat him up a little,\u201d Mr. Gold said. \u201cThey ostracized him. He didn\u2019t have many friends.\u201d\n\nHe said that Mr. Cruz\u2019s mother had done what she could to take care of him, and that the two had an extremely strong bond.\n\n\u201cHis mother was his entire life and when he lost her, I believe that was it for the boy\u2019s peace of mind,\u201d he said.\n\nOther neighbors said Mr. Cruz was a regular source of agitation. Helen Pasciolla said Lynda Cruz had called sheriff\u2019s deputies to the house numerous times in an effort to keep Mr. Cruz in line. Craig Koblitz, 62, a yacht repairman who lives across the street, said some neighbors had suspected him of burglarizing a nearby house a few years ago.\n\nAbout six years ago, Mr. Koblitz returned to his home to find Mr. Cruz scooping the fish from the pond in his palm-shaded front yard. He found it odd that the boy did not seem to express much surprise or guilt over being caught stealing.", "title": "Nikolas Cruz, Florida Shooting Suspect, Showed \u2018Every Red Flag\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Nini Theilade, who won wide acclaim for her dancing in the fabled 1935 film version of \u201cA Midsummer Night\u2019s Dream,\u201d then performed with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo during its tour of the United States as World War II was beginning, died on Feb. 13 in Svendborg, Denmark. She was 102.\n\nHer death was confirmed by a spokesman for the Danish Embassy in Washington.\n\nMs. Theilade (pronounced TAY-laud) was performing solo recitals as young as 14. In an interview for the 2005 documentary \u201cBallets Russes,\u201d she recalled how those recitals opened a big door.\n\n\u201cMax Reinhardt, he discovered me, so to speak,\u201d she said, \u201cbecause he saw one of these recitals, and he said, \u2018Well, I don\u2019t know anything about dancing, but this person doesn\u2019t only dance, she acts.\u2019 \u201d\n\nReinhardt put her in the version of \u201cA Midsummer Night\u2019s Dream\u201d that he staged in England and at the Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles, and then in the film that he and William Dieterle directed. Ms. Theilade was the lead fairy among Titania\u2019s attendants.", "title": "Nini Theilade, Dancer in Reinhardt\u2019s \u2018Dream,\u2019 Dies at 102", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhen Congress determines that the best way to prevent aliens convicted of felonies from repeating their crimes is to lock them up until they can be deported,\u201d he said, \u201clower courts don\u2019t have the authority to second-guess that determination by attempting to rewrite the law.\u201d\n\nThe majority in Tuesday\u2019s case ruled on narrow grounds, saying that the immigration laws do not by their terms authorize the hearings. It sent the case back to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, instructing it to consider whether the Constitution requires the hearings \u2014 but only if various procedural roadblocks could be overcome.\n\nThe Ninth Circuit had ruled that bond hearings are required after six months to determine whether detainees who do not pose flight risks or a danger to public safety may be released while their cases proceed. The court based its ruling on an interpretation of the federal immigration laws, not the Constitution, though it said its reading was required to avoid constitutional difficulties.\n\nJustice Alito, in the majority opinion on Tuesday, said that this interpretive approach, called \u201cconstitutional avoidance,\u201d was unavailable here, as the words of the immigration laws were plain. \u201cThe meaning of the relevant statutory provisions is clear \u2014 and clearly contrary to the decision of the court of appeals,\u201d Justice Alito wrote.\n\nChief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Anthony M. Kennedy joined all of the majority opinion, and Justices Clarence Thomas and Neil M. Gorsuch most of it, though those two justices also wrote that the Supreme Court was powerless to hear the case at all.\n\nIn dissent, Justice Breyer wrote that \u201cwe can, and should, read the relevant statutory provisions to require bail proceedings in instances of prolonged detention without doing violence to the statutory language or to the provisions\u2019 basic purposes.\u201d\n\nJustices Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Sonia Sotomayor joined Justice Breyer\u2019s dissent.\n\nIn response, Justice Alito accused his colleagues of taking extreme liberties with the English language. \u201cThe dissent evidently has a strong stomach when it comes to inflicting linguistic trauma,\u201d Justice Alito wrote. \u201cThe contortions needed to reach these remarkable conclusions are a sight to behold.\u201d", "title": "No Bail Hearings for Detained Immigrants, Supreme Court Rules", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cLast Things First for Patients With Bucket Lists,\u201d by Clyde Haberman (Editorial Notebook, Feb. 14): Since 91 percent of Americans have a bucket list of things they would like to do before they die, you wonder what the other 9 percent are thinking: Are they somehow unaware that there is a 100 percent chance that we will die? I am part of that 9 percent, but I am certainly very aware of my mortality.\n\nI have never been a person who has favorites, because I view picking a favorite movie, book, food or travel destination over all the other possibilities an impossible task of comparing apples and oranges.\n\nI love to travel, so my answer to those who ask where I\u2019d like to go is \u201ceverywhere.\u201d Each time I look to plan a new trip, I simply pick the place that appeals most at the moment.\n\nI am very content in my life, enjoy what I do day to day, and honestly do not think in terms of things I want to do before I die. I will do what I enjoy, what appeals to me at each point in my life, and die when my time comes, simply knowing that I\u2019ve lived a good life.", "title": "Opinion | No Bucket List for Me", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "That has changed, she said \u2014 either because more people are having doubts, or because it has become less taboo to talk about them.\n\nFacing an uncertain future\n\nIf it weren\u2019t for climate change, Allison Guy said, she would go off birth control tomorrow.\n\nBut scientists\u2019 projections, if rapid action isn\u2019t taken, are not \u201ccongruent with a stable society,\u201d said Ms. Guy, 32, who works at a marine conservation nonprofit in Washington. \u201cI don\u2019t want to give birth to a kid wondering if it\u2019s going to live in some kind of \u2018Mad Max\u2019 dystopia.\u201d\n\nParents like Amanda PerryMiller, a Christian youth leader and mother of two in Independence, Ohio, share her fears.\n\n\u201cAnimals are disappearing. The oceans are full of plastic. The human population is so numerous, the planet may not be able to support it indefinitely,\u201d said Ms. PerryMiller, 29. \u201cThis doesn\u2019t paint a very pretty picture for people bringing home a brand-new baby from the hospital.\u201d\n\nThe people thinking about these issues fit no single profile. They are women and men, liberal and conservative. They come from many regions and religions.\n\nPhoto\n\nCate Mumford, 28, is a Mormon, and Mormons believe God has commanded them to \u201cmultiply and replenish the earth.\u201d But even in her teens, she said, she could not get another point of doctrine out of her head: \u201cWe are stewards of the earth.\u201d\n\nMs. Mumford, a graduate student in a joint-degree program at Johns Hopkins and Brigham Young Universities, plans to adopt a child with her husband. Some members of her church have responded aggressively, accusing her of going against God\u2019s plan. But she said she felt vindicated by the worsening projections.\n\nPhoto\n\nA few years ago, she traveled to China, where air pollution is a national crisis. And all she could think was, \u201cI\u2019m so glad I\u2019m not going to bring a brand-new baby into this world to suffer like these kids suffer.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018Some pretty strong cognitive dissonance\u2019\n\nFor many, the drive to reproduce is not easily put aside.\n\n\u201cIf a family is what you want, you\u2019re not just going to be able to make that disappear entirely,\u201d said Jody Mullen, 36, a mother of two in Gillette, N.J. \u201cYou\u2019re not just going to be able to say, \u2018It\u2019s not really good for the environment for humans to keep reproducing, so I\u2019ll just scratch that idea.\u2019\u201d\n\nAnd so compromises emerge. Some parents resolve to raise conscientious citizens who can help tackle climate change. Some who want multiple children decide to have only one.\n\nFor Sara Jackson Shumate, 37, who has a young daughter, having a second child would mean moving to a house farther from her job as a lecturer at the Metropolitan State University of Denver. She is not sure she can justify the environmental impact of a larger home and a longer commute.\n\nBut for Ms. PerryMiller, the Ohio youth leader, the thinking went the opposite way: Once she had her first child, climate change made a second feel more urgent.\n\n\u201cSomeday, my husband and I will be gone,\u201d she said. \u201cIf my daughter has to face the end of the world as we know it, I want her to have her brother there.\u201d\n\nLaura Cornish, 32, a mother of two near Vancouver, said she felt \u201csome pretty strong cognitive dissonance around knowing that the science is really bad but still thinking that their future will be O.K.\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t read the science updates anymore because they\u2019re too awful,\u201d she said. \u201cI just don\u2019t engage with that, because it\u2019s hard to reconcile with my choices.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Climate Fwd: Sign up for our newsletter to get our latest stories about climate change \u2014 along with answers to your questions and tips on how to help. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2018The thing that\u2019s broken is bigger than us\u2019\n\nPeople who choose not to have children are used to being called \u201cselfish.\u201d But many of them see their decision as a sacrifice.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nParenthood is \u201csomething that I want,\u201d said Elizabeth Bogard, 18, a freshman at Northern Illinois University. \u201cBut it\u2019s hard for me to justify my wants over what matters and what\u2019s important for everyone.\u201d\n\nThis attitude seems particularly common among people who have seen the effects of climate change firsthand.\n\nHemanth Kolla is from Hyderabad, in India, where drought and scorching heat waves have been deadly. He lives in California, where the threat of wildfires is increasing and a six-year drought only recently ended. Mr. Kolla, 36, said it felt wrong to have a child when he did not believe the world would be better for him or her.\n\nAnd Maram Kaff, who lives in Cairo, said she had been deeply affected by reports that parts of the Middle East may be too hot for human habitation by 2100.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve seen how Syrian refugees, who are running from a devastating war, are being treated,\u201d Ms. Kaff, 33, said in an email. \u201cImagine how my children will be treated if they have to flee their country due to extreme weather, drought, lack of resources, flooding.\u201d\n\n\u201cI know that humans are hard-wired to procreate,\u201d she said, \u201cbut my instinct now is to shield my children from the horrors of the future by not bringing them to the world.\u201d\n\nMs. Kallman and Josephine Ferorelli, the founders of Conceivable Future, said that the predominant emotion at their gatherings was grief \u2014 and that the very existence of these conversations should spur political action.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThese stories tell you that the thing that\u2019s broken is bigger than us,\u201d Ms. Ferorelli said. \u201cThe fact that people are seriously considering not having children because of climate change is all the reason you need to make the demands.\u201d\n\nMost of the people interviewed, parents and non-parents alike, lamented having to factor climate change into their decisions at all.\n\n\u201cWhat kind of nightmare question is that?\u201d asked Ms. Guy, the Washington nonprofit worker. \u201cThat we have to consider that?\u201d", "title": "No Children Because of Climate Change? "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Four years ago the essayist Helen Andrews wrote a critique, for the religious journal First Things, of what she described as \u201cbloodless moralism\u201d \u2014 meaning the decay of public moral arguments into a kind of a vulgar empiricism, a mode of debate so cringingly utilitarian that it can\u2019t advance the most basic ethical claim (\u201cDo not steal \u2026\u201d) without a regression analysis to back it up (\u201c\u2026 because bicycle thieves were 4 percent less likely to obtain gainful employment within two years of swiping their neighbor\u2019s Schwinn\u201d).\n\nSince Andrews noted in passing that this tendency had infected not only proud utilitarians and explanatory journalists but even reputed conservative moralists like, well, me, I\u2019ve tried to keep her critique in mind ever since. In last week\u2019s column, for instance, which argued that the #MeToo movement should turn its ire against pornography, I decided not to bore my readers with research papers and simply appealed to moral intuition and recent cultural experience, which make as strong a case as any study for the viciousness of porn.\n\nBut now that the massacre in Florida has made mass murder the week\u2019s pressing subject, Andrews\u2019s essay also offers a useful way of thinking about some of the problems with the gun control debate \u2014 on both sides, but particularly among conservatives like myself, who often pick apart specific weaknesses in liberal gun control proposals, relying on studies and experiments that show the limits of prohibition, taking a clinical and somewhat bloodless approach to an issue that rouses liberal zeal.\n\nThere is value in clinical critiques, as there is in the rebuttals to my porn argument that emphasized the problems with enforcing smut restrictions. But technical issues and practical concerns are not the heart of the gun debate. The reason that mass shootings aren\u2019t leading to legislative action is that we have a chasm between two sweeping moral visions, one pro-gun and one anti-gun, that is now too wide to be easily bridged by incrementalism.", "title": "Opinion | No Country for Young Men With AR-15s", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Republicans preached fiscal austerity when the economy needed stimulus, and have turned to fiscal profligacy now that it doesn\u2019t. If this surprises you, either you\u2019ve been completely oblivious to the reality of the modern GOP for the past decade, or you\u2019re a reflexive centrist \u2013 which is pretty much the same thing.\n\nBut how bad a thing is this fiscal profligacy? It\u2019s not good \u2013 it means higher debt, which will in turn reduce the \u201cfiscal space\u201d for responding to the next crisis. It will also crowd out investment, hurting long-run growth. But I\u2019ve been seeing some people suggesting that rising deficits are going to hurt the economy in the short run, perhaps even cause a recession. Will they?\n\nWell, much as I\u2019d like to believe this proposition for political reasons, it doesn\u2019t make sense. The same analysis that told us that austerity was a bad thing in the depths of the slump says that deficit spending now won\u2019t be contractionary. The cases aren\u2019t symmetric \u2013 this deficit will do much less good than austerity did harm. But still, we should be consistent.\n\nRemember, the direct effect of fiscal policy is to change overall spending in the economy: a fiscal expansion means more spending, a fiscal contraction means less spending. When the economy is depressed, as it was for years after the financial crisis, the number of jobs is constrained by the overall level of spending. And because the Fed had limited influence \u2013 short-term interest rates, which the Fed controls, were already zero \u2013 fiscal contraction translated into major job loss.", "title": "Opinion | No Fairy, No Cry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Seventy-eight wins would be one more than last season.\n\n\u201cWhat does that do?\u201d Jeter said, all but stifling a groan. \u201cYou win a championship. You don\u2019t go into a season saying, \u2018Let\u2019s win 78 games this year.\u2019 You don\u2019t do that. Why? It wasn\u2019t acceptable when I was a player, why would it be acceptable now? Yeah, let\u2019s be part of an ownership group and let\u2019s win 78 games. What does that do? Nothing.\u201d\n\nJeter knows this seems strange, asking fans for patience, the very last thing he possessed as a Yankee. He won the World Series as a rookie, in 1996, and then perpetuated the Steinbrenner doctrine more than any other player. If the Yankees did not win the championship, Jeter would say, the season was a failure.\n\nFor owners, though, patience is the magic word. Convince fans of the curative powers of a teardown, and you might buy a few years of good will. Jeter knows he must earn the trust of the skeptical fans in Miami, but he also knows they have not supported the team he broke up. The Marlins have ranked last in N.L. attendance in each of the last five seasons.\n\nJeter has been seeking other investors from the business community, and the trades have chopped some $40 million from the payroll. Yet he insists that propping up an unpopular, losing team simply made no sense. Most of the remaining players seem to understand.\n\n\u201cPeople are freaking out about rebuilding, but I wouldn\u2019t be so worried about it when Jeter is leading the way,\u201d said Martin Prado, a veteran third baseman, who played with Jeter in 2014. \u201cI don\u2019t think he\u2019s going to mess with his reputation just because he wants to be in this position. He\u2019s got a challenge, but I think he knows what he\u2019s doing, and we have to respect that.\u201d\n\nJeter let go of several popular Marlins ambassadors \u2014 Jeff Conine, Andre Dawson, Jack McKeon and Tony Perez \u2014 and does not know if he will keep the whimsical home run sculpture Loria commissioned at Marlins Park. But he did retain Manager Don Mattingly, his friend and former teammate, and Michael Hill, the president of baseball operations. This week he hired Chip Bowers from the Golden State Warriors as president of business operations.\n\n\u201cHe has every intention of hiring the best and the brightest people to come to the Marlins\u2019 organization and work,\u201d said Gary Denbo, the new vice president for scouting and player development, who was Jeter\u2019s first manager in pro ball and later helped oversee the Yankees\u2019 farm system.", "title": "No Golf for Derek Jeter. He\u2019s Back at Spring Training.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe time has come for North Korea to permanently abandon its nuclear and ballistic missile ambitions, to recognize there is no future as a member of the family of nations for a nuclear-empowered North Korea,\u201d Mr. Pence said to reporters after visiting a memorial to the Cheonan, a South Korean Navy warship sunk by North Korea in 2010, killing 46 sailors.\n\nAt the memorial, Mr. Pence also met with four North Korean defectors, along with Fred Warmbier, the father of Otto F. Warmbier, the college student from Cincinnati who fell into an irreversible coma after being detained in Pyongyang, and died soon after being returned to his parents.\n\n\u201cIt was important to be here today to sit with defectors who have escaped the most tyrannical regime on the planet and hear their stories, and see the tears in their eyes and also to see the aftermath of the militarism that was once again on display in Pyongyang yesterday with one more military parade,\u201d Mr. Pence said. (He added, however, that he heartily supported Mr. Trump\u2019s desire for a military parade on the streets of Washington.)\n\nAt the opening ceremony, White House officials said, Mr. Pence was keenly aware of the optics. They said that if he were ducking a meeting with the North Koreans, he could easily have moved to the box where the American delegation, including Mr. Warmbier, was seated. But that would have set up another resonant image: Mr. Moon in his box with Ms. Kim.\n\nWhile Mr. Pence chatted with his Japanese and South Korean counterparts, officials noted that the North Koreans sat by themselves, though Mr. Moon made a point of shaking hands with Ms. Kim.\n\nHandshakes \u2014 or the lack thereof \u2014 have long played an outsize role in diplomacy. In 1954, a year after the end of the Korean War, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles refused to shake the hand of the Chinese premier, Zhou Enlai, at a conference in Geneva. For decades, Mr. Zhou nursed bitterness at the slight \u2014 a breach that was only fully healed when President Richard M. Nixon clasped his hand in Beijing in 1972.\n\nMr. Obama made an art of shaking hands with American rivals: Hugo Chavez of Venezuela and Col. Muammar al-Qaddafi of Libya in 2009; Ra\u00fal Castro of Cuba in 2013, at the funeral of Nelson Mandela in South Africa. In 2013, however, Mr. Obama failed to shake hands with President Hassan Rouhani of Iran at the United Nations General Assembly, in a near miss that carried echoes of Mr. Pence\u2019s nonencounter on Friday.", "title": "No Handshakes as Pence Avoids Kim Jong-un\u2019s Sister at Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "That\u2019s me. [laughs] Whenever we go up to northern Ontario, I go online, look up the local bingo hall and try to sneak in.\n\nDid you and your co-stars do anything to bond before shooting started?\n\nWe did have a game night before we kicked off the film. We\u2019re a very Method ensemble. Billy [Magnussen], he\u2019s an amazing cook, and he had everybody over to his place. We played Clue. And then we played this game called Joking Hazard, have you heard of that one? It\u2019s like Apples to Apples meets Cards Against Humanity. It\u2019s a little intense.\n\nDid people\u2019s competitive streaks start to emerge?\n\nIt is such an interesting social experiment to watch these sides of people come out. And it\u2019s always the person that doesn\u2019t want to play that won\u2019t quit at the end of the night \u2014 the one you drag there, kicking and screaming, that you have to kick out at 3 in the morning.\n\nIs there a day that has gone by since \u201cMean Girls\u201d was released where someone didn\u2019t remind you about Regina George?\n\nDoes Regina George haunt me every day? She does have that quality. [laughs] No, I have to thank Regina George for giving me some longevity. I\u2019m forever grateful to Tina Fey [the \u201cMean Girls\u201d screenwriter] and Mark Waters [the director]. I remember when I read it, I called my agent right away and said, \u201cI will play any part in this, please, please, please.\u201d I was at the beginning of my career, and it was a lofty thing out there, that I really, really, really wanted to do. I\u2019m always looking for larger-than-life characters, which is probably why I like playing villains. They get away with so much.\n\nWas that a time in your career when you felt you had to prove yourself a little harder for the roles you wanted?", "title": "No Matter What Rachel McAdams Plays, She Plays for Keeps", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Their 1-2 finish certainly gave a jolt to the United States\u2019 medal count, which through Thursday\u2019s events stood at 21 medals over all and eight gold. With just a few days left of competition, the Americans seemed on pace to lag behind Sochi\u2019s disappointing total of 28 medals, nine of them gold.\n\nStill, five of the United States\u2019 eight golds have come in halfpipe or slopestyle events. In total, snowboard and freestyle skiing accounts for 10 of the United States\u2019 21 medals.\n\n\u201cHalfpipe really caters to creativity,\u201d Wise said. \u201cIt caters to doing things sort of differently than anybody else does. I think as Americans we have rebel in our blood.\u201d\n\nWise used three different pairs of skis because he had binding problems on the first two runs, leading to wipeouts. He scored 17 on the first and 6.4 on the second before performing a near-perfect run on the third for a 97.20. He landed double corks in all four directions: front left, front right, switch backward left and switch right, which basically means he spun ridiculously high and twirled in nerve-racking succession off the halfpipe banks as if he were on a frosty trampoline.\n\nFerreira had a 96.4, and Porteous a 94.8 after trying a succession of moves he said he had never done before.\n\n\u201cBecause you\u2019re at the Olympics, you just go for it,\u201d Porteous said.\n\nHe took note of the American skiers and the hype about them completely dominating the event.\n\n\u201cIt would have been cool to see the U.S.A. sweep, but I\u2019m a really proud Kiwi right now,\u201d he said.\n\nYater-Wallace, who overcame a hard-luck string of injury and illness to make the team, finished ninth, with a score no higher than a 65.2.", "title": "No Podium Sweep, but David Wise Repeats as Freestyle Ski Halfpipe Champion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, initially blocked that effort, saying Mr. McConnell was starting off on the wrong foot.\n\n\u201cThe majority leader\u2019s desire to vote on an unrelated, partisan immigration bill \u2014 legislation that is not only silent on Dreamers, but is silent on border security as well \u2014 is not a productive way to begin debate,\u201d Mr. Schumer said.\n\nMr. Schumer, instead, wanted to begin with a vote on President Trump\u2019s conservative immigration plan to show that it lacked bipartisan support in an outcome meant to embarrass the president and build momentum for an alternative. Republicans were not interested in the Democratic maneuver.\n\nThe standoff left the Senate right where it has been for years \u2014 frozen by a deep reluctance on the part of leaders of both parties to force vulnerable incumbents to take politically challenging votes. That thinking has dried up floor debate and put tight restrictions on the movement of legislation, making it a central cause of congressional gridlock.\n\nIn 2014, Republicans could not get enough of pointing out that Senator Mark Begich, a first-term Democrat from Alaska, never had a single amendment he wrote voted on by the Senate, a fact they said highlighted a lack of influence. He lost his re-election bid.\n\nThe refusal to battle it out over amendments has frustrated lawmakers in both parties and left some strategists scratching their heads because they see little evidence that such votes are all that damaging in an environment where charges and countercharges fly freely.\n\n\u201cWhat I came here to do is vote,\u201d said Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut. \u201cAnd I am chagrined that we are in a time when both sides seem in trepidation of voting because our political process has become so polarized.\u201d", "title": "No Room for Debate: Senate Floor Fight Over Immigration Is a Bust", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe North Atlantic right whale is already one of the most endangered creatures on earth, and all indications are its situation is rapidly getting worse.\n\nAt last count, the entire population was estimated to include just 458 animals, and at least 17 of them died last year. Now, researchers tracking the right whale\u2019s normal calving grounds, from Georgia to Florida, said they have seen no signs of newborns yet this year, at a time when mothers would normally be birthing and nursing.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates that at least 411 calves were born from 1990 to 2014, an average of about 17 a year. But only five were born in 2017, and if there really are no newborns this year, that would be \u201cunprecedented,\u201d said Charles \u201cStormy\u201d Mayo, director of the Right Whale Ecology Program at the Center for Coastal Studies in Provincetown, Mass.\n\n\u201cI think we\u2019re in a helluva pickle,\u201d he said.\n\nIt\u2019s possible, Dr. Mayo said, that the animals have simply moved elsewhere to give birth, and that at least a few new calves will be found later in the season.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI will not be surprised, though I will be excited, if we see a calf or two in Cape Cod Bay,\u201d said Dr. Mayo, whose research team tracks the animals in the bay.", "title": "No Sign of Newborn North Atlantic Whales This Breeding Season", "authors": ["Karen Weintraub"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 The showdown between Lindsey Vonn and her heir apparent, Mikaela Shiffrin, has been a dominant subplot throughout the Pyeongchang Olympics, and it was in the air again on the final run of the last individual Alpine race of the 2018 Winter Games.\n\nThe moment was, in fact, a scene nearly a year in the making, one whose flash point came last March when Shiffrin, 22, ascended to the title of world\u2019s best women\u2019s skier \u2014 a designation the 33-year-old Vonn had passionately guarded as her own for many years.\n\nVonn and Shiffrin, each an Olympic champion, had rarely raced against each other in any setting, let alone at the Olympics, the biggest stage in ski racing. But late on Thursday afternoon, as an approaching snowstorm cast a shadow over her, Vonn stood in the start house for almost certainly the last time at the Winter Games with a chance to join Shiffrin on the podium \u2014 even, possibly, to grab the gold medal and push Shiffrin, sitting in second place, to the bronze.\n\nIn that instant, Vonn was leading the race, the women\u2019s Alpine combined. There were 52 gates and about 700 yards separating her from the finish line.", "title": "No Storybook Ending for Lindsey Vonn, but Mikaela Shiffrin Wins Silver in Combined", "authors": ["Bill Pennington"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "He was a fixture in Kenya\u2019s wildlife scene, an eccentric American with a mass of white hair, known for meticulous work on the black-market prices of ivory and rhinoceros horn. Now he is the victim in a murder mystery.\n\nThe victim, Esmond Bradley Martin, was found dead in his home in Nairobi, Kenya\u2019s capital, on Sunday, with a stab wound in his neck.\n\nIt is not clear if Mr. Martin, who was 76, was killed in connection to his strident views or his work. No doubt he had made many enemies, writing report after report that exposed the depth of the ivory and rhino horn trade across the world that has killed tens of thousands of endangered animals. His death sent shock waves through East Africa\u2019s wildlife circles.\n\nKenyan police officials said they had yet to identify any suspects. Their leading theory is that Mr. Martin was killed in a robbery.", "title": "No Suspects in Killing of Eccentric American, a Kenyan Wildlife Expert", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "I\u2019ve always believed that pastry chefs are born, not made. They\u2019re patient, methodical, tidy and organized. It\u2019s why I stick to the savory side of the kitchen \u2014 I\u2019m far too messy and impulsive to do all the measuring, timing and rule-following that pastry demands. The temperament of nearly every other cook I\u2019ve met further proves my theory. I know pastry chefs who are overwhelmed by the idea of tasting, rather than measuring, their way to a balanced vinaigrette. And the savory chef who taught me how to cook can\u2019t properly whip an egg white to save his life (though you didn\u2019t hear that from me).\n\nBut there is one notable exception: my friend Amalia Mari\u00f1o, who is both versatile and precise. I\u2019ve watched her confidently grill 100 duck breasts, carefully moving each one as rendering fat threatened to drip into the coals and send up a flare. And I\u2019ve seen her roll out flaky pastry dough, then adorn it with slices of red- and green-fleshed plums in striking patterns only an art-school graduate could conjure.\n\nFor Mari\u00f1o, the choice to straddle both sides of the kitchen is deliberate. \u201cIt\u2019s just the way I was raised,\u201d she said. Her grandfather was obsessed with self-reliance and skillfulness. He taught Mari\u00f1o to use a table saw and to catch, gut and scale a fish by the time she was 6. \u201cHe just wanted me to be capable in every way.\u201d So when Mari\u00f1o decided to pursue cooking, it was natural that she\u2019d learn how to do it all in the kitchen too.", "title": "No Time for a Breakfast Souffl\u00e9? Try a \u2018Soufflazy\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cBuying Online Influence From a Shadowy Market\u201d (front page, Jan. 28): The proliferation of fake social media followers has been fueled by the belief that they help businesses. To the contrary, businesses paying for followers, and giving endorsement deals to people with many fake followers, are wasting their money.\n\nHaving spent years working with businesses of all sizes to harness social media, I\u2019ve found consistently that there is no actual business value in a number of followers. An inflated follower count does not lead to greater sales. It does not increase visits to websites or sign-ups for e-newsletters. It doesn\u2019t build relationships between brands and potential buyers.\n\nBusinesses are much better served using social media to connect directly with consumers. Exchanging tweets, direct messages and Facebook comments with users has real value \u2014 not only helping win them over, but also showing onlookers that the company genuinely wants to engage.\n\nBuyers are also becoming more savvy. Many online tools show how many of a company\u2019s followers are fake, and a large number is a big turnoff.", "title": "Opinion | No Value in Fake Followers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "It is not the first time that Shiffrin has felt uncomfortable on the snow. I just need to ski like myself, and I\u2019ll be fine.\u201d\n\nShiffrin, renowned for needing at least nine hours of sleep a day, said she had gone to bed two hours after her usual bedtime Thursday because she had attended the medal ceremony for the giant slalom.\n\nShiffrin\u2019s mother, Eileen, who is also one of her coaches, said she believed fatigue had contributed substantially to her daughter\u2019s atypical skiing. She won a silver in the world championship in 2015 and a bronze medal in 2013 and 2017.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been skiing well and racing for a long time, and it\u2019s a wonderful accomplishment to have this kind of victory,\u201d Hansdotter, 32, said. \u201cIt will be always be a day to remember.\u201d", "title": "No, Mikaela Shiffrin Can\u2019t Win Them All", "authors": ["Bill Pennington"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "There is good reason a puli needs his coat completely dry. A damp coat leads to mildew, which is never a good look, or smell, for a show dog.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the 142nd Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, which began Monday, two other dogs \u2014 Zoe and Blu \u2014 competed against Rummy in breed judging.\n\nBlu, an 8-year-old competing in his final show, arrived from Tennessee with a compete rain ensemble, bootees and all. \u201cIt took me about 30 minutes to put on his suit for a 10-minute walk,\u201d Blu\u2019s owner, Glen VanDerHart, said.\n\nZoe, who is 4\u00bd, arrived from Maryland looking as if she had a run-in with a cheerleading convention. Cords all over her body were tied up with pink scrunchies to keep her hair from sopping up all of Seventh Avenue\u2019s puddles.\n\nThe absorbency of a puli coat rivals any man-made microfiber. Rummy, when dry, weighs 32 pounds. Give him a long walk in heavy rain, and he returns home topping the scale at 100 pounds.\n\nPuli hair grows into ropelike locks after the puppy stage, and it usually takes about five years for a coat to reach the ground.\n\nIf a dog scratches feverishly or a someone steps on a cord, it can easily detach, leaving five years of work and 13 inches on the ground. Desperate show handlers may look for hair extensions as a quick fix, hoping it goes unnoticed by a judge.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen a puli hovers over a pile of leaves or glides across some dust bunnies, the surface is wiped clean. Items are known to get lost in the thicket.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s the strangest thing that\u2019s ever got lost in one of my puliks?\u201d VanDerHart said, using the plural form of puli. \u201cA judge.\u201d\n\nIn a show ring, smaller dogs are placed on a table and judges meticulously run their hands over their coats and body, evaluating them by the breed standard. At one show, a judge\u2019s arm slipped under Blu\u2019s undercarriage and never came out.\n\n\u201cShe had all this jewelry on and it got tangled in the coat,\u201d VanDerHart said.\n\nAfter several attempts to untether some bracelets, he said, he had to put Blu on his side to extract the judge.\n\nBefore breed judging on Monday, waves of dog lovers gathered around the pulik, snapping pictures and quickly posting them on social media. Though they are still considered a rare breed, they do trend on social media, and not just because Mark Zuckerberg owns a puli named Beast.\n\nLast Halloween, a puli from Kentucky named Keki won the day when her owner plopped her in a bright yellow janitor bucket and pushed her around like a mop. A few years ago, a puli memorably starred in a beer commercial atop a man\u2019s head, accompanied by strains of reggae music.\n\nPulik rank 159th among the 189 dogs listed on the American Kennel Club\u2019s most recent registry, but a puli named Preston won best in show at the A.K.C. National Championship in December 2016. Preston entered Westminster last year as the favorite but was upset in the herding group by Rumor, the German shepherd who won best in show.\n\nWith its roots in Hungary, the puli was first recognized by the A.K.C. in 1936, but it took 80 years for the breed to win top honors at a United States national championship. With Preston now in retirement, the competition was wide open, if thin, on Monday. Rummy and Zoe were Westminster rookies.\n\nPhoto\n\nThough Pessina, 70, has had several best-in-breed winners at Westminster, this is her first time in the ring as her dog\u2019s handler.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat was I thinking bringing such an unseasoned show dog?\u201d she said, stuffing liver cookies into her suit pocket.\n\nThis is only Rummy\u2019s fourth time in the show ring, and Pessina considers him the most willful dog she\u2019s shown.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a wild man,\u201d she said.\n\nIn the ring, she held his leash tightly. \u201cHe just wanted to take off,\u201d she said, showing her hand streaked with red marks.\n\nNevertheless, Rummy won best in breed. Back in the benching area, he climbed into his cage. Pessina picked up a jug of spring water, filled his dish and then took a long chug herself.\n\n\u201cI have no clue what to expect tonight,\u201d she said about Monday night\u2019s group judging at Madison Square Garden. \u201cHe\u2019s never been in front of a crowd like that, noise like that.\u201d\n\nShe took another long gulp of water. \u201cWhat was I thinking?\u201d she said, yet again.", "title": "No, That\u2019s Not a Mop. It\u2019s a Puli.", "authors": ["Kelly Whiteside"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Rachel L. He will take over the job in May, succeeding Jenny Dixon, who retired after 15 years at the helm.\n\nThe museum has expanded both physically and artistically over the years. Ms. Dixon led a renovation of the museum\u2019s building and sculpture garden in 2004, and recent exhibits have focused on the work of other artists besides its founder, the Japanese-American sculptor Isamu Noguchi. (An exhibit currently on display, a retrospective of the Uruguayan-American sculptor Gonzalo Fonseca, was named a Times Critic\u2019s Pick.)\n\nMr. Littman led the Drawing Center for a decade, including through a $10 million renovation and expansion that revamped its portion of a 160-year-old cast-iron building. After switching jobs, he will still curate an exhibition of the work of the German artist Neo Rauch that will open at the Drawing Center in April 2019.\n\nIn a phone interview on Monday, Mr. Littman said one of his main goals was to use his new position to augment the legacy of Noguchi, who died in 1988 at age 84, within the contemporary art world. \u201cMy dream would be to see Noguchi in the next Venice Biennale,\u201d he said.
