I think the development of that program alongside the permanent installation is absolutely essential.\u201d", "title": "Noguchi Museum Hires New Director", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGANGNEUNG, South Korea \u2014 The number of confirmed cases of norovirus at the Winter Games has risen to 86 from 32 in just two days as Olympic officials struggle to track the source of the outbreak on the eve of the opening ceremony.\n\nHong Jeong-ik from South Korea\u2019s Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday that the new cases included staff members of the Pyeongchang Olympics Organizing Committee, venue personnel and even cafeteria workers \u2014 a sign that the highly contagious virus had spread beyond the security personnel who were the first to test positive.\n\nMr. Hong said that because more were still undergoing tests, the number of confirmed cases was likely to rise.\n\nAfter the outbreak was announced on Tuesday, 1,200 security workers were sequestered in their rooms. Mr. Hong said that as of Thursday, more than 1,100 people \u2014 including some nonsecurity staff \u2014 were still in quarantine.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMost of those 1,100, he said, had tested negative for the virus, which causes vomiting and diarrhea, and were expected to return to duty on Thursday afternoon. To make up for the shortfall in security staffing, the government deployed 900 military personnel.", "title": "Norovirus Cases at Olympics More Than Double, Moving Beyond Security Staff", "authors": ["Amy Qin"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The tap water, the food preparation staff and the food itself are being assessed to trace the route of transmission, according to a statement from the Pyeongchang Organizing Committee.\n\n\u201cAs soon as a case, if any more, is identified,\u201d Mr. Dubi said, \u201cof course it is reported, then all the areas get disinfected.\u201d\n\nMr. Dubi added that while officials did not know the exact source of the virus, the food and beverages at the lodging were up to international safety standards. The guards being tested will remain in their quarters until they are deemed to not have the virus, Lee Hee-beom, the chairman of the organizing committee, said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWith thousands of athletes, staff members and spectators housed in close quarters, it is no surprise that outbreaks of the norovirus have emerged at the Olympic Games, and other large-scale sporting events, in the past.\n\nNorovirus is best known in the United States as the \u201ccruise ship virus\u201d and in Europe as \u201cwinter vomiting flu.\u201d\n\nIt is a frequent cause of outbreaks of vomiting and diarrhea on board ships, in nursing homes and in children\u2019s day-care centers, especially in cold weather. The virus is not typically serious for otherwise healthy adults or teenagers, although it can cause several days of misery and dehydration.\n\nSevere dehydration can endanger people unable to take in fluids by themselves, such as young children, the elderly and people with underlying conditions. The most common symptoms of the gastrointestinal disease are nausea, diarrhea and stomach pain, along with fever, headaches and body aches.\n\nIt is spread by touching contaminated surfaces, caring for sick people or eating uncooked food that people with the illness have touched. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, it is the leading cause of outbreaks of food-borne illness in restaurants and salad bars in the United States.\n\nMost of that is from food contaminated by human hands before serving, but fruits and vegetables can be contaminated by sewage in water used to grow them, and oysters or other shellfish can pick it up from sewage. There are many strains of norovirus, so people can catch it more than once in their lives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOfficials said pamphlets detailing the dangers of the virus and ways to avoid contracting the illness would be distributed to those visiting the Olympic sites.", "title": "Norovirus Sidelines Security Staff at Pyeongchang Olympics", "authors": ["Megan Specia", "Donald G. Mcneil Jr."]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "At a news conference on Wednesday night, Dr. Park Kisoo, a spokesman for the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, tried to temper the growing sense of worry here.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t need to go running out of the room if somebody sneezes,\u201d Park said.\n\nPark preached the importance of proactive personal hygiene. So along with wool caps and long underwear, bottles of hand sanitizer in varying shapes and sizes have become this year\u2019s hottest Olympic accessory.\n\nNever mind the studies showing they are largely ineffective in battling norovirus.\n\n\u201cThe U.S.O.C. physician said that the antibacterial spray does not kill the norovirus,\u201d said Matt Hamilton, an American curler competing in the men\u2019s and mixed-doubles events, using the acronym for the United States Olympic Committee. \u201cBut what does do a good job is the Ivory soap. So he\u2019s just like, \u2018Soap up.\u2019 \u201d\n\nThe buses that constitute the Olympics\u2019 internal transportation network have been running smoothly on schedule. The facilities, and the hospitality of those staffing them, have won early raves.\n\nBut the pesky virus has threatened to derail some of the early good vibes.\n\nMore than a thousand people have been quarantined as organizers have rushed to halt the spread of the virus, which can cause bouts of vomiting, diarrhea and abdominal pain. The military was called in to provide additional support to the decimated staff.\n\nSo far 97 of the cases have been at Horeb Youth Centre, a dormitory that housed many local security staff members; 11 were in Pyeongchang; 20 were in Gangneung.\n\nKimani Griffin, an American speed skater and first-time Olympian, said these sorts of outbreaks were always a possibility at major international sporting events, where visitors from around the globe are gathered into tight quarters, day after day.", "title": "Norovirus Spreads at Olympics: Now 128 Confirmed Cases", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Everything came to naught in late 2006 when Pyongyang conducted its first nuclear test. And now North Korea seems closer than ever to becoming a real nuclear power (some say it already is).\n\nNo matter who shoulders the blame for the North\u2019s nuclear status and the tensions that have arisen as a result, the fact remains that Pyongyang is a difficult regime to deal with, one that is quick to take offense and doesn\u2019t hesitate to rain artillery fire on the South. Young South Koreans, who have little sense of connection to the North, tend to see only these current realities.\n\nEnthusiasm for unification is waning. A report last year by the Korea Institute of National Unification, a state-funded think tank, revealed a big gap in how the young and the old approach unification (and North Korea by extension): Nearly 50 percent of respondents under 30 didn\u2019t think being a single people required a single state, while only 20 percent thought unification was necessary. Among those 60 and older, the answers were the other way around, with almost 50 percent saying there should be one state for one nation.\n\nAnd a study published by the institute on Jan. 30 showed that more than 60 percent of respondents in their 20s said \u201cunification is not an immediate goal.\u201d Across all age brackets, respondents greatly prioritized the economy over unification.\n\nMr. Moon\u2019s government has appeared to be blind to this critical shift in popular sentiment, instead promoting the idea, to take a line from a presidential office Facebook post, that \u201cWe are one\u201d with the North.\n\nAs Mr. Moon pushed the one-nation rhetoric, his approval ratings took a dive, falling 10 percentage points in January, which coincided with inter-Korean dialogue on the Olympics (some say his attempt to regulate the cryptocurrency trade, a hot topic in South Korea, is another reason for his decline in favorability).\n\nHis popularity has eroded even more among voters in their 20s \u2014 usually the more progressive segment of the population \u2014 dropping 14 percentage points between the second week of January and the beginning of this month.\n\nEven as a clear majority of South Koreans seem supportive of North Korean participation in the Games, different polls indicate that people are divided about flying the Korean Unification Flag, with one survey putting the public opposition at nearly 50 percent.", "title": "Opinion | North Korea Comes to the Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Vice President Mike Pence had planned to secretly meet with a high-level delegation of North Korean leaders while he was at the Winter Olympics in South Korea this month, but the North Koreans canceled at the last minute, according to the State Department.\n\n\u201cWe regret the failure to seize this opportunity,\u201d Heather Nauert, the department\u2019s spokeswoman, said Tuesday.\n\nThe canceled meeting is the latest twist in the evolving American strategy to persuade North Korea to give up its nuclear and missile programs, which Western intelligence agencies say will soon be able to threaten the continental United States.\n\nIt also adds a remarkable coda to the strange tableau during the opening ceremony of Mr. Pence sitting in a reviewing stand less than 10 feet away from Kim Yo-jong, the sister of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, as the two stared fixedly ahead without acknowledging each other.", "title": "North Korea Dropped Out of Meeting With Pence at Last Minute, U.S. Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe will see if Pyongyang\u2019s message today, that it is willing to hold talks, represents the first steps along the path to denuclearization,\u201d said the statement from the office of the White House press secretary. \u201cThe the maximum pressure campaign must continue until North Korea denuclearizes.\u201d\n\nMr. Moon has been working tirelessly to steer the United States and North Korea away from what he considered a collision course, urging them to open talks.\n\nHis efforts received a boost when he met with Vice President Mike Pence, who led an American delegation to the opening ceremony of the Olympics. United States officials has said that they were open to holding preliminary talks with North Korea \u2014 but only to explain that sanctions \u2014 and that pressure would not let up until the North starts denuclearizing.\n\nEven if talks begin between the two sides, differences remain wide. North Korea insists on being recognized as a nuclear state. It says it will discuss its nuclear weapons programs only if Washington agrees to discuss broader arms reduction around the Korean Peninsula, which analysts say could include a demand for the withdrawal of United States troops from South Korea.\n\nThe statement from Mr. Moon\u2019s office on Sunday indicated that both Mr. Moon and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, were eager to use the diplomatic opening created by the Olympics to improve inter-Korean ties.\n\n\u201cPresident Moon emphasized that South-North Korea relations must be expanded and improved widely,\u201d the statement read. The North Korean delegates had said that Mr. Kim \u201cshared the same desire,\u201d it added.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe statement did not mention a potential inter-Korean summit meeting. Mr. Kim has invited Mr. Moon to Pyongyang, relaying his proposal through his sister, Kim Yo-jong, who attended the Olympics\u2019 opening ceremony.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Moon has said he is willing to meet Mr. Kim to lower tensions further, but he also wanted Washington and Pyongyang to start a dialogue to settle the nuclear dispute. He has faced pressure both at home and from Washington not to improve ties until North Korea made progress in denuclearization.\n\nOn Sunday, conservative activists rallied near the Korean border and later in Pyeongchang to protest the visit from Kim Yong-chol. They waved South Korean and American flags and demanded that Mr. Kim be \u201cpunished.\u201d The country\u2019s main conservative opposition also called him a \u201cmass murderer\u201d and demanded his arrest.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Kim is widely blamed in the South for the sinking of a South Korean warship in 2010, when he was director of the North\u2019s main spy agency. Forty-six South Korean sailors died in the sinking.\n\nThe spy agency, the General Bureau of Reconnaissance, was also widely believed to have launched a cyberattack at Sony Pictures in 2014 as a retaliation against the film \u201cThe Interview,\u201d a comedy based on a fictional plot to assassinate Kim Jong-un. The spy master has also been on sanctions lists in the United States and South Korea for alleged involvement in the North\u2019s nuclear program.\n\nNorth Korea\u2019s reported interest in talks with Washington contrasted with its frosty attitude earlier this month. South Korea had arranged a meeting between Ms. Kim and Mr. Pence while both were in South Korea for the opening ceremony, but the North Koreans pulled out at the last minute, according to United States officials.\n\nAmerican officials and some analysts suspected that North Korea was creating an inter-Korean thaw to soften its image and weaken international sanctions. But Koh Yu-hwan, a professor of North Korean studies at Dongguk University in Seoul, said that North Korea\u2019s primary strategy was not to avoid sanctions but to get the United States to accept it as a nuclear weapons state in return for a freeze on its nuclear program.", "title": "North Korea Is Willing to Talk With U.S., South\u2019s Leader Says", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "And an opinion writer takes issue with the world\u2019s embrace of the North\u2019s tactic of turning pretty young women into aesthetic ambassadors.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 President Trump\u2019s habit of making insensitive remarks is galvanizing opposition against him \u2014 especially from women \u2014 that could smother Republican momentum, our columnist writes.\n\nIn a Twitter post, Mr. Trump appeared to raise doubts about the entire #MeToo movement, writing that lives are being \u201cdestroyed by a mere allegation.\u201d\n\nLast week, Mr. Trump offered sympathy for Rob Porter, the White House staff secretary pictured with him above, who resigned over spousal abuse accusations.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 A Russian plane carrying 71 people crashed shortly after takeoff from Moscow on Sunday, killing all on board.\n\nAn online site that tracks real-time flight information shows the plane lost altitude six minutes after takeoff. Our reporter pondered the question in the latest installment of \u201cThe #MeToo Moment,\u201d our weekly newsletter.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show opens in New York today, an event that bills itself as the World\u2019s Greatest Dog Show. The competition has cultivated a strong following since it opened in 1877 at Gilmore\u2019s Garden, a venue that later became known as Madison Square Garden.\n\nSo where did the \u201cWestminster\u201d come from?\n\nIn the 1870s, a group of men met regularly at the Westminster Hotel near Union Square. They had an extraordinary affinity for the bar, as well as for dogs, and they decided to put on a dog show.\n\nWilliam F. Stifel\u2019s book \u201cThe Dog Show, 125 Years of Westminster\u201d details what happened next.\n\n\u2026 They couldn\u2019t agree on the name for their new club. But finally someone suggested that they name it after their favorite bar. The idea was unanimously selected, we imagine, with the hoisting of a dozen drinking arms.\n\nAfter the Kentucky Derby, the Westminster Dog Show is the second-oldest continuously run sporting event in American history.\n\nThe first show had over 1,200 entries, and the judging took several days to choose a winner. (Here\u2019s our 1877 report on the preparations.)\n\nLast year, the show had close to 3,000 dogs from all 50 states. Judges hold themselves to two days.\n\nHere\u2019s our collection of stories on the show, and we\u2019ll be adding live coverage beginning Tuesday.\n\nClaudio E. Cabrera contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. So if you think that Woody Allen is guilty of sexual abuse, should you stop watching his movies?\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words: Here\u2019s are links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nToday is Groundhog Day, and if you\u2019re unfamiliar with this annual American event \u2014 it\u2019s exactly as strange as it sounds.\n\nThe groundhog, for its part, is a simple creature. A close relative of the squirrel, it digs burrows and can reach a furry 15 pounds. It\u2019s known in some areas as a whistle pig, for its short, sharp cries, but more commonly, as a woodchuck.\n\nThat\u2019s where the day\u2019s simplicities end. The tradition of predicting weather by when animals wake from hibernation goes back centuries. It arrived in the U.S. with European immigrants and \u2014 though there are many Groundhog Day events \u2014 the most celebrated ceremony is in Punxsutawney, Pa.\n\nEach Feb. 2, a groundhog named Punxsutawney Phil emerges from his winter\u2019s nap at a place called Gobbler\u2019s Knob. (In fact, he\u2019s looking for a mate.) Tradition holds that if Phil sees his shadow, it means six more weeks of winter. No shadow, and an early spring is on the way.\n\nIt\u2019s all in fun, of course. And that\u2019s a good thing for the poor groundhog: Since 1887, according to one tally, he\u2019s been right only 39 percent of the time.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Most news organizations, including The Times, decline to capitalize the C.\n\nBut confusion persisted despite the rebranding. In 2014, a Kenyan man trying to attend a United Nations conference in Pyeongchang mistakenly flew to Pyongyang.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInyoung Kang contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "North Korea, Tesla, Taiwan: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": ["Mike Ives", "Charles Mcdermid"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNorth Korea often taps into music to heighten and pronounce the socialist ideology,\u201d said Kang Dong-wan, professor of North Korean culture at Dong-A University in Busan. \u201cSo to then expose the musicians to outside ideologies would be quite a contradiction.\u201d\n\nLeading the Samjiyon art troupe was Hyon Song-wol, the lead singer of the all-female Moranbong Band. Last month, Ms. Hyon ignited a frenzy among local media when she visited South Korea to inspect venues for the performances.\n\nPerhaps because of the buzz surrounding her visit, South Koreans appeared to be more excited about the Samjiyon Orchestra concerts than the actual Olympic events, which so far have had rather lackluster ticket sales. Last week, more than 150,000 people entered a lottery for a chance to win one of more than a thousand free tickets to Samjiyon\u2019s performances in Gangneung and Seoul.\n\nOne of those lucky winners was Keum Sun-hee, 49, who traveled to Gangneung from the eastern province of Gyeonggi with her 18-year-old daughter to see the concert. \u201cI always thought the culture between the North and South had been severed, so it was very moving to see the performance,\u201d said Ms. Keum.\n\nIt is not the first time the North has engaged in so-called music diplomacy. In 2000, when the two Koreas were moving toward reconciliation, North Korea\u2019s State Symphony Orchestra held a joint concert with the South\u2019s Korean Broadcasting System Philharmonic in Seoul.\n\nThen, in 2008, North Korea hosted the New York Philharmonic \u2014 a first for an American cultural organization. More recently, in 2012, the North\u2019s Unhasu Orchestra performed alongside the Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France, in Paris.\n\nBut in recent months, the North has ratcheted up its bellicose rhetoric, effectively undermining much of the good will it has built up through such cultural exchanges. And, despite the temporary d\u00e9tente, the North has shown few signs of slowing down.", "title": "North Korean Orchestra Gives an Emotional Concert in the South", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 A 140-member arts troupe from North Korea plans to travel to South Korea this week by ferry, forcing the South to temporarily lift its ban on all North Korean ships entering its waters, officials said on Monday.\n\nThe arts troupe, comprising orchestra musicians, dancers and singers, will arrive in South Korea on Tuesday on board the ferry Mangyongbong-92, said Baik Tae-hyun, a spokesman at the Unification Ministry, a South Korean government agency in charge of relations with North Korea.\n\nNorth Korea also notified the South that the ship would serve as lodging for the artists, a move apparently designed to keep them from having contact with South Koreans. When North Korea agreed last month to participate in the Winter Olympics in the South Korean city of Pyeongchang, it also agreed to send the troupe as part of Olympic-related cultural events.\n\nThe ferry is expected to dock near Gangneung, on the east coast of South Korea, where the North Korean artists are to perform on Thursday, the eve of the Winter Olympics. Gangneung is hosting Olympic events including women\u2019s ice hockey, in which the two Koreas will compete as a joint team, a first in Olympic history.", "title": "North Korean Troupe Is Cleared to Enter South\u2019s Waters Before Games", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "In fact, the North Korean cheer squad gained international notice only because of South Korea. During a 2006 speech at Pusan University, the South Korean president at the time, Kim Dae-jung, recounted the story: The mayor of Pusan was worried that the 2002 Asian Games, hosted by his city, would be poorly attended. The mayor brought up the possibility of North Korean athletes\u2019 participating as an attention-grabbing ploy; Kim Dae-jung did him one better, sending a special envoy to the North\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-il, to ask him to send not only athletes but cheering fans as well.\n\n\u201cMake sure the cheerleaders are pretty girls,\u201d Kim Dae-jung said. Kim Jong-il complied, sending over 288 just such women. The students broke into applause when Kim Dae-jung concluded his account by saying how pleased he was with the outcome: The girls were pretty, the games were a success, and the city of Pusan made money.\n\nThe South\u2019s fascination with North Korea\u2019s cheerleaders is an extension of its attitude toward North Korean women in general: It views them as exotic, enigmatic, charming in their na\u00efvet\u00e9.\n\nDuring past visits, the South Korean media have showered praise on the women for their \u201cpure, innocent beauty,\u201d as if they were farm girls from the hills and not the elite from their country\u2019s capital. Plastic surgery is among South Korea\u2019s biggest industries; these Northern women are held up, by contrast, as representatives of natural Korean beauty \u2014 despite the presence of plenty of plastic surgery among the North Korean elite as well.\n\nOn Wednesday, within hours of the cheerleaders\u2019 arrival, photos of them had begun appearing on South Korean news. But there are some signs that North Korea\u2019s lipstick diplomacy isn\u2019t as effective as it once was. Thirteen years since the cheerleaders\u2019 last visit to the South in 2005, some of their exoticism has worn off. Over 30,000 defectors now live in South Korea, and they\u2019ve helped remove some of the sense of mystery. At the same time, reality TV shows featuring North Korean women \u2014 called \u201cdefector beauties\u201d \u2014 telling all about their lives back home or participating in \u201cThe Bachelor\u201d-type searches for love have chipped away at the sense of the North as a land of innocents.", "title": "Opinion | North Korea\u2019s Lipstick Diplomacy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cPence, in Tokyo, Threatens Tough Penalties for North Korea\u201d (news article, Feb. 8):\n\nI take great umbrage at Vice President Mike Pence\u2019s statement concerning the Olympic Games: \u201cWe\u2019ll be there to cheer our athletes, but we\u2019ll also be there to stand with our allies, and remind the world that North Korea is the most tyrannical and oppressive regime on the planet.\u201d\n\nDoes this man not know that the Olympic Games are not supposed to be political? That is their beauty. You don\u2019t stand with allies at the Games. There are no allies and enemies. Just athletes. I think there is a beauty in having North Korean athletes stand with those from South Korea. It is the personification of the spirit of the Games.\n\nI deplore the politics of North Korea. Its human rights violations are deplorable. In that I agree with Mr. Pence. But for the 16 days of the Games, politics should be put aside. It is just about these incredibly talented men and women who have come together to vie for the gold.\n\nIt gives me some small hope that, if we could just accept that we have so much more in common than we have differences, we could live together in peace.", "title": "Opinion | North Korea\u2019s Presence at the Olympic Games", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 During the Cold War, the one-upmanship between North and South Korea was so intense that it extended to the height of the flagpoles at their border. So when the South hosted the Summer Olympics in 1988, it was no surprise that the North tried to do it one better in 1989.\n\nWhat followed was one of the biggest boondoggles in North Korean history, one that played a part in the economic catastrophe that soon engulfed the country, according to analysts and North Korean defectors.\n\nBy some estimates, the North spent $4 billion on the World Festival of Youth and Students, a kind of socialist quasi-Olympics and cultural extravaganza. It expanded its airport in Pyongyang, the capital. It laid new streets, built one of the biggest stadiums on Earth and started work on a hotel meant to reach more than 1,000 feet into the sky.\n\nAll of this was done at a time when the North\u2019s centrally planned economy was already shrinking. The spending \u2014 directed by Kim Jong-il, then the country\u2019s leader in waiting \u2014 would leave North Korea even more dismally prepared for the coming collapse of Soviet Communism, which deprived it of economic aid and trading partners, and for a string of droughts and floods that wiped out its agriculture. The famine that followed in the 1990s killed as many as two million people.", "title": "North Korea\u2019s Would-Be Olympics: A Tale of a Cold War Boondoggle", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "For a year, immigration agents have been enforcing the Trump administration\u2019s orders to deport noncitizens at full speed with but one roadblock: the federal courts.\n\nThe immigration activist Ravi Ragbir was scheduled to be deported to Trinidad and Tobago on Saturday, but that was put on hold when his lawyers filed a lawsuit in Manhattan on Thursday. The government agreed to delay his removal until the court can decide whether his rights have been violated.\n\nHis case was one of a growing number in which federal judges have ruled to halt both individual and mass deportations. Last week, a judge in a New Jersey district court temporarily stopped the deportation of Indonesian Christians, longtime community members in Highland Park, N.J., who had been swept up by immigration agents. A day earlier, in Boston, a judge made a similar ruling in the case of 50 Indonesian Christians, and in December, a Miami judge halted the deportation of 92 Somalis. In June, a judge in Detroit halted the deportation of more than a hundred Iraqi Christians, and then expanded the ruling to cover a class of as many as 1,400 people.\n\nThese federal judges are not deciding immigration cases, over which they have no jurisdiction, but rather giving people time to fight in the immigration courts. They are slowing deportations by insisting that undocumented immigrants still have the right of due process, even if in many of these cases, the immigrants had known for years that they could be expelled.", "title": "Not So Fast on Deportations, Judges Tell Immigration Agency", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBlackbarn \u2014 the sprawling home goods store, cafe and bar in Chelsea Market, which is affiliated with Black Barn restaurant in NoMad \u2014 has a new line of packaged foods. They are created by its chef, John Doherty, who founded the company with Mark Zeff, an interior designer. Kristen Zeff, Mr. Zeff\u2019s wife, is also a partner. Highlights include preserves, notably a honeylike craft beer version ($14.95); white chocolate-and-matcha hot chocolate mix ($17); intense black-truffle paste ($55); truffle-and-Parmesan sauce ($13.90); and 72 percent dark chocolate bars ($9.85): Blackbarn Foods for the Home, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), 212-620-3110, blackbarnshop.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest.
