Le Guin, who died in January. In her March 1996 review of \u201cUnlocking the Air and Other Stories,\u201d Francine Prose meditated on the beloved science-fiction writer\u2019s legacy and allure. Below is an excerpt.\n\nMy favorite story by Ursula K. Le Guin purports to be a journal of an all-female expedition to Antarctica, a venture mounted in 1909-10, after Scott\u2019s failure to return from the South Pole and before Amundsen\u2019s success. Along the way, the women run across the filthy, littered bachelor den where Scott\u2019s party stayed. One woman goes into labor. They name the mountain ranges, but \u201cnot very seriously,\u201d because they have agreed to tell no one that they beat \u201cMr. Amundsen\u201d to the pole: \u201cHe would be terribly embarrassed and disappointed. There is no need for him or anyone else outside the family to know. We left no footprints, even.\u201d\n\n\u201cSur,\u201d which appeared in Ms. Le Guin\u2019s 1982 collection, \u201cThe Compass Rose,\u201d typifies what she does best: construct a lightly ironic, playful and more or less fantastic fiction of ideas, with an interest in formal narrative considerations, the nature of female experience and the different methods by which men and women apprehend and respond to the world.\n\nHer work may not move or engage us in conventional ways, yet we stay with it because we trust that by the end it will have delivered a highly particular chill. So, in this new collection, a story called \u201cThe Professor\u2019s Houses\u201d \u2014 about a man who inhabits his daughter\u2019s dollhouse \u2014 ends with a haunting line that echoes back to the very beginning of this fictional investigation of the desire for order, privacy and control.", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "In this week\u2019s issue, Bill McKibben reviews Charles C. Mann\u2019s new double biography of William Vogt and Norman Bourlag. In 1948, Robert C. Cook reviewed Vogt\u2019s \u201cRoad to Survival,\u201d an eloquent treatise on earth\u2019s future that Mann argues birthed modern environmentalism. Read an excerpt below.\n\nAny historian who survives to tell the tale will probably label this the age of the two chain reactions. One of these is no longer news \u2014 if the threat of sudden global extinction can ever cease to be bad news. But only a few experts realize that a biological chain reaction is tearing the soil from the five continents, draining the earth of life-giving groundwater devastating the forests on which our civilization, even our survival, depends. This is the subject of William Vogt\u2019s disturbing \u201cRoad to Survival.\u201d\n\nAs Bernard Baruch points out in his introduction, \u201cThis is no dry-as-dust study. It deals with the raw stuff of living, how more than two billion men and women, including you and me, are to be fed, sheltered, and clothed \u2014 and whether or not we will live in peace tomorrow, and next year, and in the year 1975.\u201d \u201cRoad to Survival\u201d pulls no punches. It is eloquent, sometimes grim, but always vivid. It combines literary excellence with sound scholarship. There are detailed references to the technical literature, and an excellent index. Vogt\u2019s book is essentially an eloquent plea that we start using all of our senses to understand the complex, interrelated forces whose end product he calls \u201chuman ecology.\u201d\n\nRead \u201cRoad to Survival.\u201d It will shock you, and it may infuriate you. But it is a preview of things to come as seen by a courageous, honest, competent scientist. He makes you actually feel the declining fertility of the land, the shrinking of our natural resources equated against that relentless explosive growth in human numbers. There might be room for quibbling as to whether S-day (S for starvation or for salvation \u2014 it all depends!) will fall in 1991 or 2048. But the handwriting is on the wall.", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "This week\u2019s issue is all about pleasure reading \u2014 from the history of sex toys to a roundup of romance novels. In 1947, Margaret Mead reviewed \u201cSex in Our Changing World,\u201d by John McPartland, a blunt meditation on the history of sex in the United States.\n\nThe general thesis of the book is essentially sound, if heavily weighted on the seamy side. This book deals for the most part with wide social pathologies \u2014 the divorce rate, growing sexual inversion and prostitution rather than courtship, marriage and parenthood. Tackling these social pathologies, sometimes with a detail and frankness to which the American reader is only just accustomed, Mr. McPartland illustrates his main theme, that since World War I America has changed drastically from a sex-shy, inhibited people to a hedonistic, cynical people, openly in search of pleasure, and that our old ethics of home and family have rotted away, leaving nothing except a few sporting rules. There are vivid descriptions of the sordid divorce mills, and other institutions which exploit broken lives. But primarily this is not a source book, but a long ethical essay, with considerable gaiety, humor and a refreshing time perspective. ...\n\n\u201cThere have been carnal people before and they were the ancestors of most of us.\u201d\n\nOne of the most illuminating discussions in the book centers around the idea of \u201cadult orphans,\u201d individuals who have lost the capacity to exist as parts of that complementary human group which we call the family and who, if they marry, merely beget and rear other adult orphans. On a different level of social analysis and seriousness is the amusing chapter headed \u201cLove of Women,\u201d which discusses the way some mysterious occult agreement among women changes the styles in men (when the men aren\u2019t looking), so that the poor male who has just got himself finally organized to be a \u201cRaftish character given to black hats, dark looks and contempt for women\u201d finds that the style has shifted and women are giving \u201cthe unpurchasable look to good-natured athletes, broad-shouldered and broad-minded.\u201d\n\nThe book ends by suggesting three alternatives for the future: an America which becomes increasingly degenerate, an America which becomes increasingly over-controlled with science assisting the state in keeping sex in its place, and a more endearing picture of an America which will \u201cprofit by our new careless freedom, use our new understandings of the working of body and mind and will achieve a sexual code that will be free without being careless.\u201d", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Roger Rosenblatt graces this week\u2019s cover with a review of \u201cTime Pieces: A Dublin Memoir,\u201d by John Banville. In a 2004 essay, Banville reflected on his youthful encounters with Dublin and James Joyce\u2019s \u201cUlysses.\u201d Read an excerpt below.\n\nVery many years ago, when I was growing up in the town of Wexford, on the southeast coast of Ireland, I dearly wished to get hold of a copy of James Joyce\u2019s \u201cUlysses.\u201d I had read \u201cDubliners\u201d and \u201cA Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man,\u201d and had even written, on a big black Remington borrowed from my Aunt Sadie, a number of lugubrious short stories in what I thought was the Joycean manner, mainly devoted to the subject of death and all centered on a neurasthenic young hero whom no one truly understood, whose soul was much given to swooning and who went under different names but was always me.\n\nJoyce liked to boast that \u201cUlysses\u201d was so detailed a portrait of Dublin that if the city were to be destroyed \u2014 an eventuality that in his darker moments of Hibernophobia he would probably have welcomed \u2014 it could be rebuilt brick by brick, using his book as a model. In his essay \u201cThe Precession of Simulacra,\u201d the French savant Jean Baudrillard recalls the story by Jorge Luis Borges in which the Empire\u2019s cartographers spend years drawing up a map so detailed that when it is done it covers exactly the territory of the Empire, and imperial decline is plotted by the fraying of the map until only a few shreds remain. If we were to revive the fable today in our media-dominated world, Baudrillard suggests, the map would have engendered the Empire, and \u201cit would be the territory whose shreds are slowly rotting across the map.\u201d\n\nDublin, even well into the 1960\u2019s, when I came to live there, was in many respects still the city that Joyce had known and that he celebrated with maniacal exactitude in \u201cUlysses.\u201d All now is changed. True, most of the streets and many of the buildings through which Joyce\u2019s characters circulate on their way to eternity are still in existence, but the heart of the place is a transplant from Silicon Valley by way of the poppy fields of Afghanistan: Ireland is the world\u2019s largest exporter of computer software, and its capital city is a serious importer of the hardest of hard drugs. Where now is the \u201creal\u201d Dublin?", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Here in the English-speaking world, most of us in the econo-pundit business have been focusing a lot on the US economy post-Trump, and secondarily on the British economy post-Brexit. But once in a while we ought to look further afield. And there\u2019s a pretty big story that isn\u2019t getting much play in the US, at least: the significant recovery finally taking place in Europe.\n\nFor years, the euro area drastically lagged the United States: where America began a sustained recovery in late 2009, Europe, buffeted by debt crises and the problems of misaligned costs among member nations, continued to suffer into 2013. Germany, of course, did well throughout \u2013 largely because its economy was supported by huge trade surpluses, largely at its neighbors\u2019 expense.\n\nSince 2013, however, we\u2019ve seen significant growth in Europe, with the fastest growth occurring in the areas (other than Greece) that were hardest hit by the euro crisis, especially Spain:", "title": "Opinion | Notes on European Recovery (Wonkish)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "McGraw, meanwhile, recalled a conversation with Stevens soon after the 2014 title, which was achieved with a rally against West Texas A&M with less than six minutes to play. Stevens, said McGraw, insisted that the victory was something for every Bentley player she had ever coached to savor.\n\nHer reputation has become a recipe for success, her program a destination for quality high school players who may never have heard of Stevens before someone \u2014 a basketball-coaching uncle in Bakolas\u2019s case \u2014 mentioned this slender Massachusetts native with an easy smile and calm demeanor who has carved a place in women\u2019s basketball history right at home, out of the limelight.\n\n\u201cWe understand who we are, where we are, in the Boston area, not a lot of attention,\u201d Stevens said. \u201cWe don\u2019t even get our Bentley community to pay attention sometimes. But I\u2019m an extremely passionate, competitive person, consumed by what I do. Our resources are different from D-1. Our staffs are smaller. But we recruit really hard.\u201d\n\nAs a Division II program, Bentley can offer scholarships, and it has not been uncommon for players to choose the leafy campus with quick access to Boston over Division I programs, given Bentley\u2019s academic offerings along with Stevens\u2019s record of steering teams deep into March.\n\nBecca Musgrove played three years at Brown before missing her senior season with an injury and applying to Bentley\u2019s graduate school and for a coaching internship. With one season of eligibility left, she has wound up a vital cog in Stevens\u2019s rotation, a 5-9 blur of aggression who scored 20 points in the win over Pace, No. 1,002.\n\n\u201cI never set out to win 1,000 games,\u201d Stevens said. \u201cI only set out to win the next game.\u201d\n\nThe milestone night arrived on Jan. 17, at home against Adelphi, a Northeast-10 Conference rival, with the Bentley community out in full. In the final seconds of a 78-66 victory, the fans chanted Stevens\u2019s name, her players dumped a barrel of confetti on her and she soon stepped to a microphone to talk about sacrifice, about the gatherings with relatives she had to miss over the years to attend to her family of student-athletes.\n\n\u201cI apologized to them for that,\u201d she said, without promising to never be absent again.\n\nA single woman of 63, Stevens looked around and saw her aging mother, out on a frosty New England night, in her wheelchair. She saw reporters from various Massachusetts news media outlets there to finally pay attention. She saw her players, current and former, moved to tears, even a few who went back to her days at Clark and who were no younger than her.\n\nThe countdown to 1,000, after all, had started when Stevens was barely out of college. It was a long road to the limelight, her deserved position and place.", "title": "Now It Can Be Told: Barbara Stevens Has 1,000 Victories to Her Name", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Nearly 18 years have passed since the artist and activist Tania Bruguera first mounted \u2014 or attempted \u2014 \u201cUntitled (Havana, 2000)\u201d at the 7th Havana Biennial. Critical of the post-revolutionary politics of Cuba, it was shut down by censors within hours. Much has changed in the interim. Fidel Castro, the revolutionary turned authoritarian leader whose image is at the center of her installation, which includes black-and-white video images, died in 2016. And art institutions have fully embraced the kind of performance and participatory art Ms. Bruguera makes, which uses live human bodies as a medium.\n\n\u201cVisceral,\u201d \u201csensorial\u201d and \u201cimmersive\u201d are words Ms. Bruguera or MoMA have used to describe \u201cUntitled (Havana, 2000),\u201d which is recreated here. These have become keywords to describe not just art works, but arguments for how art itself should be experienced. Ms. Bruguera also claims that she is \u201cnot representing the political but provoking the political\u201d and that we as viewers need to \u201cstop looking and start thinking.\u201d\n\nTo experience the work you\u2019ll probably start by standing. The wait for viewing is about 45 minutes. Four people at a time are allowed into the dark space. You approach an arch and a faux-cement atrium with rust stains, simulating the old fort in Cuba where \u201cUntitled\u201d was originally mounted. You walk on sugar cane, which crunches underfoot. As your eyes adjust, you see four naked men along the wall, bowing and brushing themselves off, as though brushing off history. A museum guard stands in the corner, like a sentry.", "title": "Now at MoMA, a Work That Fidel Castro Banned 18 Years Ago", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Last week Megan Fairchild, a New York City Ballet principal, posted a photograph on Instagram of herself and Joaquin De Luz with Patricia McBride. \u201cWhat a pleasure and honor to work with this bright spirit on a ballet that is dear to our hearts!!!!,\u201d she wrote. \u201cThanks Pattie for all your nuggets of wisdom! So wonderful to hear what she did in the role, and what Mr. B. asked her to do. We will cherish these last two days forever!!!!\u201d One of the hashtags is #baiserdelafee.\n\nThese happy words require a few layers of explanation for nonspecialists. They also open up one of the biggest issues around City Ballet today. \u201cLe Baiser de la F\u00e9e\u201d (\u201cThe Fairy\u2019s Kiss\u201d) is a four-scene ballet composed by Igor Stravinsky in 1928. And \u201cMr. B\u201d is the choreographer George Balanchine, who first staged \u201cBaiser\u201d in 1937. In 1972, he choreographed the score\u2019s dance suite, \u201cDivertimento From \u2018Le Baiser de la F\u00e9e,\u2019\u201d for New York City Ballet; and in 1974 he added the finale from the complete \u201cBaiser.\u201d This version had no scenery, no fairy and no kiss; it has remained in repertory ever since.\n\nBalanchine made its lead roles for Ms. McBride and Helgi Tomasson, who danced them into the 1980s. Ms. Fairchild and Mr. De Luz, longtime City Ballet principals, have been dancing \u201cDivertimento From \u2018Le Baiser de la F\u00e9e\u2019\u201d for a number of years. And here\u2019s the crucial issue: Why have even senior City Ballet dancers been deprived for so long of interpretive wisdom about this (and many other) Balanchine ballets? When Peter Martins was ballet master in chief (1983-2018), Ms. McBride was among the many creators of Balanchine roles who \u2014 as if in exile \u2014 were seldom if ever invited to coach their roles at City Ballet.\n\nMr. Martins retired under pressure on Jan. 1 after allegations of physical and sexual harassment. Over the decades, no single feature of his artistic policy has caused more grievance than this disinclination to bring in Balanchine alumni.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDancers can learn their roles from various sources: videos, teachers, fellow interpreters of the same repertory. Many testify, though, that real illumination comes from those who studied roles with the choreographer, in particular with those who were part of his or her creative process. With the understanding that these teachers can pass on, steps can be transfigured by motivation, atmosphere, nuance.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Martins\u2019s departure and the recent deaths of the ballerinas Violette Verdy and Karin von Aroldingen, who both, like Mr. Martins, created roles at City Ballet for Balanchine and Jerome Robbins, remind us that direct links to Balanchine\u2019s and Robbins\u2019s foremost dancers are growing fewer. In recent years, there have been multiple occasions when the Balanchine or Robbins flames have burned more brightly and truly with other companies \u2014 Pacific Northwest Ballet, Miami City Ballet, Ballet Arizona, the Suzanne Farrell Ballet \u2014 because the artistic direction kept the style truer, often with coaching from those who helped to bring the ballets into being.", "title": "Nuggets of Ballet Wisdom From Bodies Trained by Balanchine", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Another recent poll, from The Washington Post/ABC News, which reported that more than half of American women had experienced \u201cunwanted sexual advances,\u201d used a broader catchall term rather than the specific behaviors outlined in this survey, and so probably found lower numbers, said Anita Raj, director of the University of California, San Diego, Center on Gender Equity and Health, who analyzed the latest survey data. Researchers have generally found that studies that ask about specific behaviors or that cover longer periods of time tend to report more harassment.\n\nSeveral other recent polls either limited their questions to workplace harassment or assault, or sampled a smaller segment of the population, Professor Raj said.\n\nThis latest survey asked 1,000 women and 1,000 men about verbal harassment, sexual touching, cyber sexual harassment, being followed on the street, genital flashing and sexual assault.\n\nAmong its findings:\n\nSeventy-seven percent of women and 34 percent of men said they had encountered verbal sexual harassment. Fifty-one percent of women and 17 percent of men reported unwelcome sexual touching. Forty-one percent of women and 22 percent of men said they were sexually harassed online. A third of women and one in 10 men reported being physically followed, while 30 percent of women and 12 percent of men experienced genital flashing. Twenty-seven percent of women and 7 percent of men reported sexual assaults.\n\nThe survey deliberately included street harassment as well as other forms of abuse, Ms. Kearl said. \u201cSexual harassment is a human rights violation \u2014 whether it takes place on the sidewalk of a street or in an executive board room \u2014 because it can cause emotional harm and limit and change harassed persons\u2019 lives,\u201d she said.", "title": "Numbers Hint at Why #MeToo Took Off: The Sheer Number Who Can Say Me Too", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Maha Alami, who is from Beirut, Lebanon, learned to make chocolates there from her mother. After a career in banking, she\u2019s now turned to chocolates and is making excellent assortments, many of the pieces nut-based and most enrobed in her own blend of fine 70 percent semisweet. She does her work at Hot Bread Kitchen in East Harlem and sells her treats online and in the Plaza Food Hall and \u00c9picerie Boulud at Lincoln Center. She has some new heart-shaped pieces and boxes for Feb. 14: Maha Chocolate, $16.95 to $62.95, 866-969-6242, mahachocolate.com.", "title": "Nut Clusters and Dark Chocolates by Way of Beirut", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Sherald, in her remarks, paid tribute to Mrs. Obama. \u201cYou exist in our minds and hearts in the way that you do because we can see ourselves in you,\u201d she said. \u201cWhat you represent to this country is an ideal \u2014 a human being with integrity, intellect, confidence and compassion. And the paintings I create aspire to express these attributes.\u201d\n\nAmong the prominent figures who turned out for the ceremony were Steven Spielberg, the filmmaker, and his wife, the actress Kate Capshaw, who helped fund the commission of the portraits. Also in attendance were several former members of Mr. Obama\u2019s administration, including Eric H. Holder Jr., the former attorney general; David Axelrod, the former senior strategist; Jay Carney, the former press secretary; and Sam Kass, Mr. Obama\u2019s senior policy adviser for nutrition (who sat with his baby in his arms). \u201cWe miss you guys,\u201d Mr. Obama told them, in his remarks.\n\nMr. Wiley\u2019s work often features African-Americans in the regal poses of emperors and kings, his own distinctive riff on historic portraiture. The Obama portrait, too, has its own majesty. But the former president is also depicted in a chair, with his hands crossed and elbows on his knees \u2014 a posture of informality and intimacy.\n\nThe two men paged through Mr. Wiley\u2019s collection of art history books and thought about \u201cthe grand tradition of presidential portraits,\u201d Mr. Wiley said, in an interview after the unveiling. \u201cThen we decided very quickly that we were just going to strike out a path of our own and try to create a type of singular narrative surrounding what this picture looks like \u2014 discarding history but also embracing it at once.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe narrative had to do with accessibility, the narrative had to do with a language of openness,\u201d Mr. Wiley added. \u201cThere were no ties, it\u2019s an open collar, it\u2019s a much more relaxed body language \u2014 the sense of repose yet at the same time a kind of radical vigilance in the eyes.\u201d\n\nMs. Sherald\u2019s portrait of Mrs. Obama similarly conveys a certain casualness. But, dressed in a flowing white patterned gown, the former first lady also projects what Ms. Sherald called \u201ca quiet, strong presence,\u201d one in keeping with Ms. Sherald\u2019s own restrained style.", "title": "Obama Portrait Artists Merged the Everyday and the Extraordinary", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "There are, for sure, outstanding things, one being Gilbert Stuart\u2019s so-called \u201cLansdowne\u201d Portrait\u201d of George Washington from 1796, a full-length likeness packed with executive paraphernalia: papers to be signed, multiple quill pens, a sword, and an Imperial Roman-style chair. Even the clothes are an 18th-century version of current POTUS style: basic black suit and fat tie. As for Washington, he stands blank-faced, one arm extended, like a tenor taking a dignified bow.\n\n[Read remarks from the Obamas and the artists. ]\n\nUninflected dignity was the attitude of choice for well over a century, with a few breaks. In an 1836 portrait, Andrew Jackson, a demonstrative bully, sports a floor-length, red-silk-lined Dracula cloak and a kind of topiary bouffant. (A picture of Jackson, one of President Trump\u2019s populist heroes, hangs in the Oval Office.) Abraham Lincoln, seen in several likenesses, is exceptional for looking as if he may actually have weighty matters on his mind. Most of the portraits that precede and follow his are pure P.R.\n\nThis continues well into the 20th century. In a 1980 painting Jimmy Carter trades a black suit for a beige one. How revolutionary is that? And there\u2019s a Casual Fridays vogue: Ronald Reagan and George W. Bush both go tieless for it. Under the circumstances, Elaine de Kooning\u2019s 1963 portrait of John F. Kennedy, a fanfare of green and blue strokes, hits like a boost of adrenaline. Rousing too, though not in a good way, is a big head shot image of Bill Clinton by the artist Chuck Close. Using his signature mosaic-like painting technique, Mr. Close turns the 42nd president into a pixelated clown.\n\nMr. Obama has much better luck with his similarly high-profile portraitist. Mr. Wiley, born in Los Angeles in 1977, gained a following in the early 2000s with his crisp, glossy, life-size paintings of young African-American men dressed in hip-hop styles, but depicted in the old-master manner of European royal portraits. More recently he has expanded his repertoire to include female subjects, as well as models from Brazil, India, Nigeria and Senegal, creating the collective image of a global black aristocracy.\n\nIn an imposingly scaled painting \u2014 just over seven feet tall \u2014 the artist presents Mr. Obama dressed in the regulation black suit and an open-necked white shirt, and seated on a vaguely thronelike chair not so different from the one seen in Stuart\u2019s Washington portrait. But art historical references stop there. So do tonal echoes of past portraits. Whereas Mr. Obama\u2019s predecessors are, to the man, shown expressionless and composed, Mr. Obama sits tensely forward, frowning, elbows on his knees, arms crossed, as if listening hard. No smiles, no Mr. Nice Guy. He\u2019s still troubleshooting, still in the game.\n\nVideo\n\nHis engaged and assertive demeanor contradicts \u2014 and cosmetically corrects \u2014 the impression he often made in office of being philosophically detached from what was going on around him. At some level, all portraits are propaganda, political or personal. And what makes this one distinctive is the personal part. Mr. Wiley has set Mr. Obama against \u2014 really embedded him in \u2014 a bower of what looks like ground cover. From the greenery sprout flowers that have symbolic meaning for the sitter. African blue lilies represent Kenya, his father\u2019s birthplace; jasmine stands for Hawaii, where Mr. Obama himself was born; chrysanthemums, the official flower of Chicago, reference the city where his political career began, and where he met his wife.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMrs. Obama\u2019s choice of Ms. Sherald as an artist was an enterprising one. Ms. Sherald, who was born in Columbus, Ga., in 1973 and lives in Baltimore, is just beginning to move into the national spotlight after putting her career on hold for some years to deal with a family health crisis, and one of her own. (She had a heart transplant at 39.) Production-wise, she and Mr. Wiley operate quite differently. He runs the equivalent of a multinational art factory, with assistants churning out work. Ms. Sherald, who until a few years ago made her living waiting tables, oversees a studio staff of one, herself.\n\nAt the same time, they have much in common. Both focused early on African-American portraiture precisely because it is so little represented in Western art history. And both tend to blend fact and fiction. Mr. Wiley, with photo-realistic precision, casts actual people in fantastically heroic roles. (He modifies his heroizing in the case of Mr. Obama, but it\u2019s still there.) Ms. Sherald also starts with realism, but softens and abstracts it. She gives all her figures gray-toned skin \u2014 a color with ambiguous racial associations \u2014 and reduces bodies to geometric forms silhouetted against single-color fields.\n\nShe shows Mrs. Obama sitting against a field of light blue, wearing a spreading gown. The dress design, by Michelle Smith, is eye-teasingly complicated: mostly white interrupted by black Op Art-ish blips and patches of striped color suggestive of African textiles. The shape of the dress, rising pyramidally upward, mountain-like, feels as if it were the real subject of the portrait. Mrs. Obama\u2019s face forms the composition\u2019s peak, but could be almost anyone\u2019s face, like a model\u2019s face in a fashion spread. To be honest, I was anticipating \u2014 hoping for \u2014 a bolder, more incisive image of the strong-voiced person I imagine this former first lady to be.\n\nAnd while I\u2019m wishing, let me mention something more. Mr. Obama\u2019s portrait will be installed, long-term, among those of his presidential peers, in a dedicated space on the second floor. Mrs. Obama\u2019s will hang in a corridor reserved for temporary displays of new acquisitions \u2014 on the first floor. It will stay there until November, after which there\u2019s no set-aside place for it to land.\n\nIf first men have an acknowledged showcase, first women \u2014 ladies or not \u2014 should too. Better, they should all be together, sharing space, offering a welcoming environment to, among others, a future first female president, and creating a lasting monument to #MeToo.", "title": "Obama Portraits Blend Paint and Politics, and Fact and Fiction", "authors": ["Holland Cotter"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The images are powerful: Michelle, a dark and lovely [woman] comes alive. She is powerful and glamorous, soft and striking. Passionate and peaceful. A woman of grace. Intelligent and observing. Barack, making no apologies. King had the dream. Barack is living the dream. TAI YVONNE\n\nThis drastically new portraiture complements the kind of president that Obama was. Being the first black president in history, he represents a positive change. Some may even see it as a turning point in American history. And, this portrait captures this wonderfully. But, it does more than that by showing Obama as being troubled by something. Given a president\u2019s job, there could be many things that would be troubling him. And this allows me to empathize with him in a way that it\u2019s difficult to do with most other portraits. With the sharp contrast of light and dark colors and the expressive rendition of the president, this portrait is one of a kind. CARSTEN\n\n\u2018Here is the first black president \u2026 and he\u2019s sitting in the bushes.\u2019\n\nI get the symbolism of the flowers in Barack\u2019s portrait, but the busy prints take attention from the subject. It\u2019s the opposite of what a portrait is supposed to do. BELLE CHRISTIAN\n\nI think the paintings are interesting and I like them as thoughtful pieces in and of themselves. But I think that context is important to consider. Here is the first black president, an excellent human being and dignified leader and he\u2019s sitting in the bushes. I definitely want something that shows his poise, integrity and valor. I think something more stately would be more ennobling. JOSE MORENO\n\nFor whatever reason, I was taken aback when I first saw President Obama\u2019s portrait with the floral background. The more I look at it, the more I love it. However, I have to agree with those who say that Michelle\u2019s doesn\u2019t closely resemble her, but does it have to do so. The overall sense of the picture is of peace, elegance and intellect. JENNIE VINSON HLAVACEK\n\nArt definition: the expression or application of human creative skill and imagination, typically in a visual form such as painting or sculpture, producing works to be appreciated primarily for their beauty or emotional power. I love the background of President Obama\u2019s painting because for me it depicts his love of the earth and his love of all living things. JUDITH SALYER\n\nIt\u2019s \u2018all about the dress.\u2019\n\nThe portrait of Michelle appears to be all about the dress. Mrs. Obama, with her caring, strength and true inner beauty, is not there. The picture doesn\u2019t succeed at all with me. DEB HARTOGENSIS GODDEN", "title": "Obama Portraits \u2018Push Us to Think More,\u2019 Readers Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "There are signs that Democrats are starting to get more aggressive. In doing so, they\u2019re running a version of the 2008 Obama strategy. Democratic groups are now running their own ads in Indiana and Missouri, denouncing \u201cout-of-state billionaires\u201d for misleading attacks on \u201cour senator.\u201d The ads explain that Democrats favored a \u201cmiddle-class tax cut\u201d rather than one that overwhelmingly favored the rich and that could lead to cuts in Medicare and Social Security.\n\nThis case is harder to make politically than Obama\u2019s, given that he had a detailed tax-cut plan he could constantly mention. Today\u2019s Democrats do not. Still, they should get more disciplined about making the case against the Trump tax plan. Ultimately, it really is a bad deal for most Americans.\n\nGerrymandering, continued. The initial discussion of Pennsylvania\u2019s new congressional map \u2014 including my analysis \u2014 emphasized \u201cpartisan balance\u201d: the idea that the map would make the partisan split of House seats similar to the split in the popular vote. A party that wins about half the vote will win about half the seats.\n\nEmily Bazelon of The Times argues that this is the wrong point to emphasize. The bigger priorities in the new plan seem to be creating competitive congressional races and keeping existing geographical boundaries (like county lines) intact. That\u2019s no coincidence. Most states require congressional maps to respect geographic boundaries, and the Pennsylvania Supreme Court has specifically said the state\u2019s new map should respect boundaries for the sake of promoting competitiveness.\n\nPartisan balance is a bit different. It\u2019s a perfectly admirable goal. In fact, it should probably be the No. 1 goal in drawing congressional districts. But it\u2019s not a court-approved reason to throw out a current map. Which would explain why Pennsylvania\u2019s new maps focus on keeping counties intact and creating a bunch of close races.\n\nFor more, read Bazelon\u2019s tweets or a piece by Rick Hasen, a law professor who specializes in election law. On the same subject, Sean Trende, an elections analyst for RealClearPolitics, has some good thoughts about the philosophy of gerrymandering.\n\nProgramming note. Congratulations to Gail Collins, winner of this year\u2019s George Polk Award for commentary, \u201cfor her columns of satiric wit and neighborly wisdom that probe the oddities of American politics and social mores.\u201d As Frank Bruni added, Gail is \u201cone of the best colleagues imaginable and an altogether wonderful person.\u201d\n\nThe full Opinion report from The Times follows.", "title": "Opinion | Obama\u2019s Tax Playbook", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nObese men treated for metastatic melanoma may survive longer than their normal-weight peers.\n\nResearchers did a retrospective analysis of 1,918 people, 1,155 of them men, under treatment for metastatic melanoma. The study is in Lancet Oncology.\n\nCompared with men of normal weight, obese men in treatment had nearly double the progression-free survival time and nearly double the overall survival time. The more overweight the man was, the greater the effect. But there was no association of obesity with survival in women.\n\nThe survival benefits were apparent in men undergoing immunotherapy that helps the immune system fight cancer and in those getting targeted therapy that aims to prevent reproduction of cancer cells without attacking healthy cells. But obesity provided no benefits in those taking chemotherapy that attacks healthy and cancer cells alike.\n\nThe mechanism is unknown, but the lead author, Dr. Jennifer L. McQuade, an oncologist at the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, said that obesity causes chronic inflammation that might change the response to therapy.\n\n\u201cThe magnitude of the effect and the dose-response relationship point to there being a biological underpinning to this,\u201d she said. \u201cBut we need to emphasize that obesity is still a risk factor for many diseases, including 13 different types of cancer. The most important thing is still preventing obesity.\u201d", "title": "Obesity Tied to Survival in Men With Melanoma", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNeil LaBute, a prominent American playwright and screenwriter known for his portraits of misanthropic and misogynistic men, has been abruptly cut off by one of New York\u2019s leading nonprofit theaters.\n\nMCC Theater, a prestigious Off Broadway company, announced Thursday that it was canceling an upcoming production of Mr. LaBute\u2019s latest play and terminating his tenure as its playwright-in-residence, effective immediately.\n\nThe theater\u2019s leadership repeatedly declined to explain the reason for its action, but on Friday, Blake West, its executive director, said, \u201cWe\u2019re committed to creating and maintaining a respectful and professional work environment for everyone we work with.\u201d\n\nMr. LaBute did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe action is a startling development in the 15-year relationship between the nonprofit theater and the polarizing playwright: MCC has been a longtime champion of Mr. LaBute\u2019s work, which often raises uncomfortable questions about sex and power and leaves viewers debating whether Mr. LaBute was critiquing or reveling in the bad behavior of some of his protagonists.\n\nMr. LaBute, 54, is best known for \u201cIn the Company of Men,\u201d a 1997 film about men\u2019s cruel treatment of a deaf woman, as well as the play \u201cReasons to Be Pretty,\u201d which was presented on Broadway in 2009 and was nominated for the Tony Award for best new play that year. He is also the showrunner on \u201cVan Helsing,\u201d a series which was recently renewed for a third season by Syfy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe play that MCC canceled, \u201cReasons to Be Pretty Happy,\u201d was the third in a trilogy that included \u201cReasons to Be Pretty\u201d and \u201cReasons to Be Happy\u201d; the new play, about an encounter between two couples who were once friendly, was scheduled to be presented next summer. Leigh Silverman was attached as the director, but she withdrew from the project several weeks ago; she said in an e-mail that \u201cmy departure had nothing to do with this situation and I have absolutely no idea what this situation is.\u201d\n\nOver the years, MCC has presented 10 plays by Mr. LaBute, including \u201cSome Girl(s),\u201d \u201cFat Pig,\u201d \u201cThe Mercy Seat\u201d and, most recently, \u201cAll the Ways to Say I Love You.\u201d\n\nThe split with Mr. LaBute comes at a key moment of transition for MCC, which was founded in 1986 and has presented many much-praised plays on its stages. The company, which currently produces work in a rented theater in the West Village, is building a new theater in Midtown West, and is in the process of trying to raise $35 million for the project.\n\nThe company\u2019s leadership has also been grappling with the national reckoning underway over sexual harassment. Two of the company\u2019s three artistic directors also run a prominent casting office, Telsey and Company, which late last year fired a casting director over accusations of sexual misconduct toward actors.", "title": "Off Broadway Theater Cuts Ties With Neil LaBute", "authors": ["Michael Paulson"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Bill Mason and Sherri Rosen-Mason are credentialed white liberals, having fought for 15 years to increase the diversity of the student body at the New Hampshire boarding school where he is the headmaster and she the director of admissions. But when their college-aged son applies to Yale and is deferred \u2014 and his best friend, whose father is black, gets in \u2014 diversity suddenly becomes discrimination. Misbehavior ensues.\n\nThat\u2019s the setup for \u201cAdmissions,\u201d a new play by Joshua Harmon (\u201cBad Jews,\u201d \u201cSignificant Other\u201d) that he describes as a satire of white privilege and white guilt. The satire is premised on the Masons\u2019 staunch belief in a good education, despite the evidence that their own son, who angrily decides to withdraw all his Ivy applications, may have learned the wrong lessons from his.\n\nAt least five Off Broadway premieres this spring \u2014 \u201cAdmissions\u201d opens at Lincoln Center Theater on March 12 \u2014 take up this theme, from several angles. In the wake of notable recent examples, including Dominique Morisseau\u2019s \u201cPipeline,\u201d Anna Deavere Smith\u2019s \u201cNotes From the Field\u201d and Julia Cho\u2019s \u201cOffice Hour,\u201d these new plays, all set in and around schools, question the idea that an education is universally and always positively transformative, rewarding any sacrifice or subterfuge entailed in getting there.\n\nThat theme is addressed most directly in Lucy Thurber\u2019s \u201cTransfers,\u201d which opens at MCC Theater on April 23. The play concerns two students \u2014 Kristofer, who is Latino, and Clarence, who is black \u2014 studying at a South Bronx community college in hopes of nabbing a scholarship to a top university. Everyone\u2019s assumption is that their efforts will be worth it should they succeed; \u201cTransfers\u201d is partly based on Ms. Thurber\u2019s own experience as a scholarship student at Sarah Lawrence.", "title": "Off Broadway\u2019s Spring Semester: Five New Plays About School", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey put me in the dark until things quiet down, I\u2019m assuming,\u201d he said in a phone interview on Wednesday. A Capitol Police spokesman would not comment on the episode, citing a department policy not to discuss personnel issues.\n\nThe state flag of Mississippi has been a subject of contention for years. Some say it should be changed because it recalls a confederacy that fought to preserve slavery. \u201cI think it\u2019s disgusting that we are the lone state standing with this horrible image,\u201d said Othor Cain, a newspaper editor who was among the first to identify Officer Jackson in the video and contact him.\n\nOthers say the flag represents the state\u2019s history and has the support of its people. Bryant Hargroue, who participated in the parade in Jackson, said the banner should not be associated with slavery and was supported by 65 percent of the population in a 2001 vote.\n\nHe filmed the encounter on Saturday and took issue with Officer Jackson\u2019s behavior. \u201cThis is not a color thing to me,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s the way he was out there acting in front of women and children.\u201d\n\nOfficer Jackson said he was trying to do his job and did not intend to make a political statement about the state flag. But he said he was grateful to the people who supported him, many of whom saw the termination as a sign of systemic racism.\n\n\u201cI thought it just reeked of white supremacy,\u201d Carlos E. Moore, a lawyer based in Grenada, Miss., said in a phone interview on Wednesday. \u201cThere are two sets of rules in Mississippi still, and it\u2019s up to civil rights lawyers like myself to continue to fight the good fight.\u201d\n\nMr. Moore has been criticizing the flag for years; he said the issue became especially urgent after a white supremacist killed nine black churchgoers in Charleston, S.C., in 2015, prompting South Carolina to remove the Confederate battle flag from its statehouse.", "title": "Officer Loses, Then Regains, Job After Conflict Over Confederate and Mississippi Flags", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Sergeant Barry drew his pistol and ordered her to \u201cdrop it, drop the bat please, ma\u2019am,\u201d Officer Rosario said. Then Ms. Danner stood and took a step toward Sergeant Barry with her left leg. He stood four to five feet away from her.\n\n\u201cAt any point did she swing?\u201d the lead prosecutor, Wanda Perez-Maldonado, asked. \u201cNo,\u201d the officer replied. \u201cAt any point did she try to hit Sergeant Barry in the head?\u201d the prosecutor said. \u201cNo,\u201d said Officer Rosario.\n\nThe question of whether Sergeant Barry had reason to fear for his life is at the heart of the defense, and the testimony of Officer Rosario, who is to be cross-examined on Tuesday, contradicted the opening statement from Sergeant Barry\u2019s lawyer, who said Ms. Danner was swinging hard at the sergeant\u2019s head when he fired.\n\nBut Officer Rosario\u2019s testimony was also at odds with some of the testimony of the emergency medical technicians who were in the apartment and who said Sergeant Barry did not try to talk to Ms. Danner before moving in to subdue her.\n\nOfficer Rosario and the other four officers who testified said Sergeant Barry had spent a few minutes calmly trying to persuade Ms. Danner to lay down the scissors before he decided to forcibly take her into custody.\n\nMs. Danner was a paranoid schizophrenic woman who had been hospitalized at least 10 times. The police had been called twice before to her seventh-floor apartment at 630 Pugsley Avenue in the Castle Hill neighborhood to help emergency medical technicians take her to a hospital.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe trial has cast a spotlight on the protocols the police are supposed to follow when dealing with the mentally ill. The shooting of Ms. Danner drew condemnations from Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner James P. O\u2019Neill, who said Sergeant Barry had not followed the department\u2019s protocol for safely containing a distraught, mentally ill person.\n\nOne question facing the State Supreme Court justice trying the case, Robert A. Neary, is whether Sergeant Barry had exhausted other options for safely containing Ms. Danner, or should have waited for specially trained officers from the Emergency Service Unit to arrive. Sergeant Barry waived his right to a jury, opting for a bench trial. A grand jury charged him with murder, manslaughter, involuntary manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, each charge having slightly different elements.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSergeant Barry\u2019s lawyer, Andrew C. Quinn, said in his opening statement that his client had acted in self-defense. He has said Ms. Danner was swinging a bat at Sergeant Barry\u2019s head with enough force to kill him and he was unable to retreat because of the officers behind him. Any mistakes the police made in handling the situation before that moment do not matter, since an officer, or any citizen, has a right to defend his own life with lethal force, Mr. Quinn has said.\n\nTwo emergency medical technicians and five police officers have testified over the last two days of trial, giving differing accounts of what happened. It is not unusual for witnesses to a shooting to remember things differently, though in this trial, some of the inconsistencies have been striking.\n\nThe medics, Britney Mullings and Patrick Moore, both testified that Ms. Mullings had gone into the apartment and was speaking with Ms. Danner, calming her down, when Sergeant Barry and his driver arrived. Both medics said that the sergeant had never spoken to Ms. Danner, and that the police had moved to subdue her while Ms. Mullings was still talking to her. Both remembered one of the officers saying \u201cReady!\u201d before they moved as a group toward Ms. Danner\u2019s bedroom.\n\nBut four of the officers who were present testified that the E.M.T.s had never entered the apartment.\n\nOfficer Rosario, who had initially taken the lead in talking to Ms. Danner, testified that Ms. Mullings did come into the apartment and tried for a time to cajole Ms. Danner into laying down the scissors. He said Ms. Danner had come out of her bedroom and was holding the scissors like a dagger when Ms. Mullings spoke to her.\n\nBut then, he said, the sergeant arrived and Ms. Mullings retreated to the front door of the apartment while Ms. Danner hurried back into her bedroom. Officer Rosario said he had explained to Sergeant Barry that Ms. Danner had the scissors and was refusing to go to the hospital. The sergeant nodded, said \u201cO.K.,\u201d and took over talking to Ms. Danner, who continued to insist that the police leave her apartment, he said.\n\nMinutes later, however, he and Sergeant Barry conferred and decided \u201cwe are just going to have to go cuff her.\u201d Then Sergeant Barry said: \u201cLet\u2019s go into the room.\u201d", "title": "Officer Says Bronx Woman Didn\u2019t Swing Bat Before Being Shot", "authors": ["James C. Mckinley Jr."]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Sergeant Barry faces charges of murder, manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide in the death of Ms. Danner, whom he killed on Oct. 18, 2016, inside her apartment at 630 Pugsley Avenue in the Castle Hill neighborhood.\n\nThe police had been called by a building security guard because Ms. Danner, who was a paranoid schizophrenic, was ranting in the hallways. It was the third time in two years that officers had been called in to help medical technicians take her to a hospital psychiatric ward.\n\nThe shooting prompted protests led by elected leaders and drew condemnation from Mayor Bill de Blasio and James P. O\u2019Neill, the police commissioner, who said Sergeant Barry had failed to follow police guidelines.\n\nWhether Sergeant Barry would testify in his own defense had been a question since the trial began last month. After the prosecution rested its case on Tuesday morning, the sergeant took the witness stand in State Supreme Court in the Bronx. The sergeant had waived his right to a jury trial, electing to have the judge, Robert A. Neary, decide the case.\n\nOn cross-examination, Sergeant Barry, a nine-year veteran, said that he was in the apartment for about five minutes before he shot Ms. Danner. He also conceded he had not followed many of the department\u2019s protocols for handling people with mental illness.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSergeant Barry said Ms. Danner was sitting on her bed angrily cutting up paper with scissors when he arrived at 6:22 p.m. He tried to persuade her to come out and speak to an emergency medical technician. She initially refused, uttering a curse and holding up the scissors like a dagger.\n\nSergeant Barry said he told Ms. Danner the medics just wanted to talk to her. She replied they could come to her bedroom. He explained they could not enter if she had scissors. Then he offered to take a step back if she would come out.\n\nHe said Ms. Danner slammed the scissors down on her nightstand and came just outside her bedroom door, announcing: \u201cThis is as far as I\u2019m going.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA few minutes later, Sergeant Barry said he judged he would not be able to coax her farther. \u201cShe was adamant \u2014 she wasn\u2019t leaving that spot,\u201d he said. He said he nodded to the other officers, signaling he intended to tackle her, then rushed her. But she ran into her bedroom. \u201cShe was much faster than I thought,\u201d he said.\n\nSergeant Barry said that once he stepped into her bedroom and saw her holding the bat, he could not back out, because his fellow officers were crowded close behind him. \u201cIt was like having my back against the wall,\u201d he said.\n\nHe said the Taser on his belt was \u201cnot appropriate\u201d to counter a weapon like a bat.\n\nSergeant Barry\u2019s account differed in many small but significant ways from the testimony of the five other officers and two emergency medical technicians who were there. Some witnesses recalled that Ms. Danner had put down the scissors before Sergeant Barry arrived.\n\nBut the only other officer to see the shooting, Camilo Rosario, confirmed the sergeant\u2019s account on one crucial point: He said Ms. Danner shifted her weight forward and was about to swing the bat when she was shot. Both officers testified she never completed her swing. \u201cShe was in the middle of a swing, and that\u2019s when I shot her,\u201d Sergeant Barry said.\n\nOn cross-examination, the lead prosecutor, Wanda Perez-Maldonado, elicited that Sergeant Barry had not followed his training and appeared to ignore many of the department\u2019s protocols. For instance, he left a shield and restraining straps for dealing with disturbed people in his car.\n\nMs. Perez-Maldonado suggested that Sergeant Barry had rushed to subdue Ms. Danner instead of isolating her and waiting her out. Sergeant Barry repeatedly asserted he was worried she would rearm herself and hurt someone. He said he seized the opening to take her down. \u201cIn situations like this, sometimes you have a split second,\u201d he said. \u201cYou can\u2019t always make a plan.\u201d", "title": "Officer Testifies He Tried to Grab Woman Before Fatal Shooting", "authors": ["James C. Mckinley Jr.", "Joseph Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m laughing about it and at myself because it feels normal,\u201d said Caitlin Patterson, 28, an American skier who finished 34th out of 62 in the 15-kilometer women\u2019s skiathlon. \u201cIt is something we think about a lot of the time,\u201d she said, as she snacked on beef jerky after a workout at the Olympic cross-country center. \u201cIt\u2019s an important part of your job because fueling is so important for your physical performance.\u201d\n\nPatterson, who is 5-foot-9 and about 132 pounds, estimates she takes in up to 3,500 calories a day depending on her training level. Fueling starts with a breakfast of two eggs fried in butter topped with melted Vermont Cheddar, plus two pieces of toast with jam and no guilt. \u201cIt\u2019s a good combination of the nutrients that I need to get through the training,\u201d she said.\n\nAfter morning training she quickly eats about 300 calories in snacks \u2014 beef jerky, almonds, a few Fig Newtons and maybe an orange. She eats lunch when she gets home. A big salad with maple-mustard dressing, a grilled cheese sandwich or quesadillas, followed by a cookie or a bowl of Ben and Jerry\u2019s milk and cookies ice cream. After a few hours rest, it\u2019s time to start thinking about eating again for her afternoon training.\n\nDr. Ola Ronsen, chief medical officer for the Norwegian Ski Federation, said that on many days the athletes simply cannot eat enough. Research has shown some may fall as much as 1,000 calories short of their body\u2019s daily needs. As a result, it is important that they keep up the same eating routine on their days off to make up the deficit.\n\nThe problem, said Ronsen, is that many athletes feel full before they have entirely replaced the energy loss of training. \u201cWhen you train you take a lot of energy from the muscles,\u201d he said. \u201cBut when you are replacing that, you\u2019re using your stomach and gut to process the food before it\u2019s brought back via circulation to your muscles. You\u2019ve filled up your stomach, but feeling full is not always a reliable signal that it\u2019s enough for the muscles to replace the glycogen.\u201d\n\nMoeller says that eating is such a big part of his day that it can sometimes interfere with family time with his sons, ages 6 and 8. \u201cMy kids do say, \u2018Do you have to eat again? Now?\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cWhen you have to go out with the kids, I often say, \u2018We have to wait. I have to eat.\u2019\u201d\n\nMoeller, who is six feet tall and about 176 pounds, says he trains four to five hours a day and takes in about 8,000 calories a day, following a rigorous eating schedule to get it all into his body. In addition to eating a large breakfast (fried eggs, oatmeal and white beans), lunch (pasta with meat sauce, pan-fried fish and salad) and dinner (double servings of whatever his family is eating), he eats two smaller pre-training meals, two small recovery meals and a small extra meal before bedtime (any combination of oatmeal, bread, cheese, ham, honey, sports drinks and sometimes cheesecake or chocolate cake or a doughnut if he wants it.)", "title": "Olympic Cross-Country Skiers Eat 8,000 Calories a Day. It\u2019s Exhausting.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Brian McWilliams, the head trainer for U.S.A. Curling, said that when he joined the organization in 2006, he discovered that he was responsible for conditioning players who were still smoking cigarettes during fifth-end breaks, which is the equivalent of halftime.\n\n\u201cI was like, \u2018What did I just get myself into?\u2019\u201d McWilliams said.\n\nBut curling, the sport that involves using brooms to direct a heavy granite rock down a sheet of ice, has joined the CrossFit age. Phill Drobnick, the coach of the American men, said he suspected that this was the first Olympics in which every team in the field had bought into a fitness program in the run-up to the Games.\n\n\u201cIn the past, if you were a good shot maker, you could be pretty good and still be successful,\u201d said Aileen Geving, who plays for the United States women\u2019s team. \u201cBut the game has gotten so precise: The ice is better, and the players have gotten better. Any bit of edge is going to make a difference. So if fitness is that difference, you\u2019re going to work for it.\u201d\n\nJoanne Courtney, 28, who is competing for Canada and has a reputation as one of the strongest sweepers in the world, has worked with a trainer in Edmonton to add muscle mass to her upper body. The more weight she has over the broom, she said, the more downward pressure she can apply to the ice.", "title": "Olympic Curlers Are Buff Now, and Have the Calendars to Prove It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "But after so many matches and so many throws and so much water damage, the forefoot of his right shoe now has the consistency of a pasta strainer. There are giant rips on both sides. He described them as ventilated. In his defense, he said, his shoes are not the most beat-up pair that he has seen in competition. No, those belonged to a Canadian curler named Blake MacDonald at the world championships in 2010. (MacDonald\u2019s team won.)\n\n\u201cHis shoes made mine look like they\u2019re brand new,\u201d George said. \u201cThose things were horrendous. But if you make enough shots, everyone quiets up pretty quick.\u201d\n\nGeorge had planned to get his Skechers patched up at a shoe shop before he left for the Olympics. But he was worried that he would need to leave them for two or three days, and he did not want to sacrifice practice time, he said. So here in Gangneung, George made a couple of minor repairs using tape \u2014 \u201cI\u2019ve blown a couple tires on these things,\u201d he said \u2014 and jazzed up his look with fancy socks featuring superheroes.\n\n\u201cI knew I had to step up my sock game for the Olympics,\u201d he said.", "title": "Olympic Curler\u2019s Shoes Are Revolting, Other Olympians Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Krushelnytsky stands out because he does not ski, skate or soar off banks of halfpipes seven stories high \u2014 athletic pursuits here that are among the most physically demanding. No, he curls, sweeping a broom to guide a granite rock across a sheet of ice.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn rare occasions, there have been doping violations in curling, since it is, on balance, a taxing feat of endurance to sweep the broom round after round. The sport, however, is not accustomed to being at the center of such a high-profile case, so the news sowed confusion and puzzlement among the curlers here.\n\n\u201cI was a bit shocked this morning,\u201d said Madeleine Dupont, the skip of the Danish women\u2019s team. \u201cI was like, \u2018That cannot be true.\u2019 But then again, people have been taking all sorts of stuff: natural medicine or lip balm or I don\u2019t know what. So I wouldn\u2019t really judge anyone until I knew it was on purpose.\u201d\n\nAsked if she thought the sport\u2019s reputation could be harmed, Dupont said: \u201cI think most people will laugh and be like, \u2018What would you possibly need doping for?\u2019\u201d\n\nKrushelnytsky, in a routine urine check, was found to have traces of meldonium in his system. Use of the drug, a heart medicine that increases blood flow and has been banned from most sports since 2016, has ensnared other Russian athletes in doping cases in the past couple years.\n\nNeither Krushelnytsky, who has left the athletes\u2019 village for Seoul, the South Korean capital, to await the results of the final test, nor his wife, Anastasia Bryzgalova, are competing in the team events.\n\nSergei Belanov, the coach of the Russian women\u2019s team, voiced public support for Krushelnytsky.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t believe that a young man, a clever man, will use the same doping that was so big the last two years,\u201d Belanov said. \u201cIt\u2019s stupid. But Alexander is not stupid. So sorry, I don\u2019t believe it.\u201d\n\nThe drug is thought to enhance endurance and would possibly play a role in curling by increasing the stamina of athletes, who must be accurate with their shots, sometimes down to the centimeter. Hard sweeping can take a toll over the course of a long match. As a result, more curlers than ever, especially at the Olympic level, are training with weights and focusing on fitness to improve their endurance and precision.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like any sport: You need strength,\u201d Nina Roth said after leading the United States women\u2019s team to a narrow win against Denmark. \u201cBut you have to do it on your own merit.\u201d\n\nBrent Laing, who plays for the Canadian men\u2019s team, said he had no idea how meldonium would enhance performance.\n\n\u201cOutside of beer and Advil, that\u2019s the only painkillers I\u2019ve ever heard of for curling,\u201d Laing said. \u201cI imagine it wasn\u2019t that. Hopefully not, or else I\u2019d be in trouble.\u201d\n\nRussia was barred from the Olympics in December after an investigation into a state-backed doping program. The International Olympic Committee, however, later cleared more than 160 Russian athletes to compete here in Pyeongchang as Olympic Athletes From Russia under the Olympic banner.\n\nMoiseeva, whose team lost to Switzerland on Monday morning, said she thought about reaching out to Krushelnytsky and Bryzgalova but decided against it. She would not have known what to say to them, she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week. Curling also has a long tradition of opponents meeting for beers after a good, clean bonspiel (curling lingo for tournament).\n\nBut even before the doping case, curling had experienced its share of controversy here at the Olympics.\n\nLast week, Rachel Homan, the skip of the Canadian women\u2019s team, broke with etiquette by having a curling stone removed from competition when an opponent from Denmark accidentally touched it with her broom. After Denmark came back to win, Dupont, the team\u2019s skip, told a reporter from CBC Sports that it was \u201ckarma.\u201d Even some Canadian fans were bothered by Homan\u2019s decision.\n\nThen, on Sunday, an equipment malfunction appeared to cost the women\u2019s team from Britain in a loss to Sweden. Eve Muirhead, the skip for Britain, had her final throw of the match voided when a red light lit up on her rock, indicating that she had not released the handle in time. But video replays later showed that she had not committed a foul.\n\nIn any case, the biggest scandal was yet to come.", "title": "Olympic Curling Rocked by Russian Doping Case", "authors": ["Scott Cacciola"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think we had a sour taste in our mouth since Sochi (Canada took silver at the 2014 Games),\u201d Moir said. \u201cWe wanted this medal for four years. It feels great.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nWomen: Mirai Nagasu Nails Triple Axel for U.S.\n\nDespite finishing third at the national championships in 2014, Mirai Nagasu was passed over for an Olympic berth. Now, finally back at the Olympics four years later, Nagasu gave a near-perfect performance, starting with a triple axel, a move few women can land. (The Associated Press reported that only Midori Ito and Mao Asada of Japan have done it at the Olympics before.) Before the routine was even over, Nagasu was visibly exulting, and her score reflected the impressive performance.\n\n\u201cFour years ago, when I was left off the team, I wanted to make another Olympic team, and I knew I would really have to be something special,\u201d she said. \u201cSo to become the first American to land a triple axel at the Olympic Games is historical, and no one can take that away from me.\u201d\n\nNagasu placed second to the Russian Alina Zagitova.\n\nPhoto\n\nMen: Canada Tightens Grip on Lead\n\nPatrick Chan of Canada fell, but his lyrical performance to Jeff Buckley\u2019s \u201cHallelujah\u201d was good enough to place first, nearly locking up the gold medal for Canada. NBC\u2019s prime-time ratings are down, too, about 16 percent from four years ago, though according to Total Audience Delivery, NBC\u2019s preferred measuring stick and the one it used to sell ads for the Games, viewership is only down 8 percent over all.\n\nBut another barometer could be telling, too, of the Olympics\u2019 popularity: Most of the viral hits online from the Games, according to data from Twitter, Instagram, Facebook and CrowdTangle, an analytics tool owned by Facebook, have little to do with athletic achievement. These heavily circulated snapshots have focused instead more on the quirky personalities, underdog efforts and curious moments that have always been a part of the Olympics but now spread to a wider audience.\n\nOf the accounts that CrowdTangle tracks, some of the top Facebook posts (those that see lots of likes, comments, shares and clicks) from Feb. 9 to 21 included memes (a spoof of figure skating routines), a look at the synchronized drones from the opening ceremony, a video of a woman \u201cpracticing\u201d the sport of curling with a Roomba and two trailers for \u201cThe Incredibles 2,\u201d which premiered during the Games.", "title": "Olympic Golds Online, if Not in Competition", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Heightened political tension between North Korea and the United States in the buildup to the Games did not help sales. The heavily armed border separating the Koreas is about 40 miles from the Olympic Park.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOccasional ticketing and transportation mix-ups have also caused venues to fill up only after events in them have started.\n\nA women\u2019s hockey game on Wednesday between a joint Korean team and Japan was well into the first period when one ticketholder, Jewell Hatton from Pennsylvania, said an attendant stopped her and told her that her ticket was invalid. I hope that the Pyeongchang Olympics will be remembered as one where we showed the world that we communicated well with North Korea.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPerhaps the most stirring moment of the evening came when the penultimate torch bearers were revealed as Chung Su-hyon, a North Korean player for the unified Korean hockey team, and Park Jong-ah, a South Korean player. The pair carried the torch up the final flight of steps and handed it off to Yuna Kim, the profoundly popular South Korean figure skater who won the gold medal in 2010 and the silver in 2014.\n\nThis event was not the first time that athletes from North and South Korea have marched together under one flag. They did so in 2000 at the Sydney Olympics in Australia, in 2004 in Athens, and in 2006 in Torino, Italy.\n\nBut by doing so in South Korea \u2014 and in Gangwon Province, where North Korea is visible from the peaks of the ski slopes \u2014 the symbolism this time was particularly striking. It also provided a stark contrast to the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, where the North Koreans did not compete after organizing a terrorist attack in which spies blew up a South Korean airliner 10 months before the Games, killing everyone on board.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Seoul Olympics ended up being a turning point for South Korea as it pulled away from North Korea economically, politically and culturally.\n\nIt was also, as it turned out, a turning point for the world. After two previous summer games roiled by political boycotts in Moscow and Los Angeles, the countries that had sat out those games all sent athletes to Seoul, making it the host of the largest number of participating nations during the Cold War era.\n\nA year later, the Berlin Wall fell. The Soviet Union collapsed not long after that.\n\n\u201cIn a sense, the Cold War symbolically ended with the Seoul Olympics,\u201d said Lee O. Young, creative director of the 1988 opening ceremony, in an interview in his library in Seoul this week.\n\nMr. Lee, whose slogan for those ceremonies was \u201cbeyond the wall,\u201d said that he believed in the power of imagination to drive change.\n\n\u201cThe Pyeongchang Olympics, in very surprising ways, could be another turning point in the way the Seoul Olympics was,\u201d Mr. Lee said. \u201cAfter the Seoul Olympics, we have been experiencing a new Cold War, and the Pyeongchang Olympics might set another milestone.\u201d", "title": "Olympics Open With Koreas Marching Together, Offering Hope for Peace", "authors": ["Motoko Rich"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Sung said that the organizers sold 99 percent of 35,000 tickets to the opening ceremony, though viewers noticed many empty seats.\n\nIt is possible the frigid weather kept some away, in addition to technical problems.\n\nMark Adams, a spokesman for the International Olympic Committee, said he hoped to have more information Sunday.\n\nA United States State Department official said the State Department\u2019s Diplomatic Security Service said it was aware of attack reports and continued to work closely with South Korean law enforcement and security agencies, but deferred questions to the International Olympic Committee.\n\nOlympic Games are often targets of cyberattacks and before the opening, the United States Department of Homeland Security warned Americans that cybercriminals would likely try to infiltrate the Games.\n\nNorth Korea has a persistent army of hackers that have attacked central banks and movie studios. Observers had hoped that the fact that North Korean athletes were attending the Games might ease the threat of cyberattacks, while others said that Russian groups might seek to retaliate for a ban on Russian athletes.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn recent weeks, American security researchers at the security firms McAfee and FireEye fired off warnings about an escalating nation-state attack on Olympic organizations. Neither firm has been able to tie the active campaign back to one nation state, but they believe a state is responsible given the resources and organization involved, and the fact that there is little profit incentive to the attacks.\n\nThe attacks began last year with phishing emails to Olympic-related targets. By January, researchers at McAfee said that attackers had successfully compromised several victims, installed malware on their machines and were now actively stealing data off their machines. At the time, attackers\u2019 end goal remained unclear, but security experts across the industry said they have been bracing for what they now describe as an inevitable attack.\n\nIn the days leading up to Friday\u2019s opening ceremony, attackers had moved to Phase 3 of their attack, Ryan Sherstobitoff, a senior analyst at McAfee, said on Saturday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOver the past few days, McAfee\u2019s advanced threat research team discovered that attackers had successfully installed a new, \u201cmore persistent implant\u201d in victims\u2019 servers that may have led to the opening ceremony disruptions, though investigators were still trying to nail down the exact cause on Saturday.\n\n\u201cWe do not have any further information beyond our discovery that would suggest the new implant led to it, but it is highly plausible,\u201d Mr. Sherstobitoff wrote by email.\n\nHe said this new implant would give attackers the ability to do whatever they wished with victims\u2019 machines, including potentially taking them offline.", "title": "Olympics Open and Cyberattacks Begin", "authors": ["Motoko Rich", "Nicole Perlroth"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "2. Above, the two men together.\n\nMr. Porter has been accused of domestic violence by two ex-wives. President Trump defended him, saying that it was a \u201ctough time\u201d and noting that Mr. Porter had denied the accusations.\n\nOn Saturday, Mr. Trump doubled down on those remarks, writing on Twitter that \u201cpeoples lives are being shattered and destroyed by a mere allegation.\u201d\n\n____", "title": "Olympics, Rob Porter, Israel: Your Weekend Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cSave Chicago\u2019s Schools,\u201d by Tamar Manasseh (Op-Ed, Feb. 13):\n\nClosing underperforming public schools is not a panacea, but it offers disaffected parents of all races an opportunity \u2014 not a guarantee \u2014 of a better education for their children. Loyalty to neighborhood schools will always take a back seat to the needs of their own children. That\u2019s why long wait lists exist in all large cities.\n\nWhatever disruption is created by the closings can be ameliorated by a controlled phaseout process and increased support to help the affected make a smoother transition to other schools that provide a quality education.\n\nWALT GARDNER, LOS ANGELES\n\nThe writer\u2019s Reality Check blog is published in Education Week.", "title": "Opinion | On Closing Public Schools", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cState lawmakers know two things: the feds are not going to do something about drug prices anytime soon, and states have to pay the price,\u201d said Trish Riley of the National Academy for State Health Policy.\n\nSo states have embraced their role as laboratories of democracy, a description invoked in a Supreme Court decision by Justice Louis Brandeis, in 1932. Recent precedent for states leading the way in health care include the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program and even the structure of the Affordable Care Act, both of which were rolled out in states before becoming federal law.\n\nHistorically, the federalist philosophy of states taking the policy lead has resonated with political conservatives. And some current drug pricing reforms have a distinctly free-market flavor. More than a decade ago, Massachusetts adopted the health care program that would later influence President Barack Obama\u2019s Affordable Care Act while the state was governed by a Republican, Mitt Romney. Now Massachusetts, governed by another Republican, Charlie Baker, is asking the federal government to allow its state Medicaid program to increase price competition among drugmakers by excluding some high-priced medicines from coverage if an identical cheaper version is available. Last week, Ohio\u2019s Republican governor, John Kasich, urged President Trump to give similar authority \u2014 and the negotiating clout that comes with it \u2014 to all states.\n\nIn Utah, a Republican state representative from Provo, Norman Thurston, is sponsoring legislation to allow the state government to engage in wholesale re-importation of medicines from countries like Canada. \u201cYou have manufacturers who are willing to sell the same drugs we use for far lower prices in other places,\u201d he said. \u201cBut we are their biggest customer, so where is our volume discount? This is a violation of basic free-market principles.\u201d\n\nThurston\u2019s bill passed the Utah House on Feb. 18, and similar proposals are pending in other states. A federal bill that would allow patients to personally import medicines has attracted the support of conservatives like Senators Ted Cruz and Rand Paul.\n\nProposals like these reveal an ideological fault line in the longstanding cozy relationship between the pharmaceutical industry and Republicans. Prescription drug makers are not paragons of the free market.
