While I do understand that the having the right to bear arms is part of the American identity but as a collateral to having that much power in a person\u2019s hand, then there should be strict ways to obtain a gun. I don\u2019t have the slightest idea on how to effectively prevent a school shooting but that is not up to me to decide neither it is my responsibility to do so. But I do know what thing for sure and that is to obviously do something to prevent school shootings.\n\nRonald Zigler from Lansdale, Pa., made an analogy to a myth:\n\nI am reminded of the story of the Minotaur, or of any ritual from ancient legend in which children were sacrificed as a form of tribute. The parallels to our contemporary world are only too clear. For far too many politicians and gun-worshippers, periodic human sacrifice is the necessary tribute that sustains their devotion. As Carl Jung, Aldous Huxley and Joseph Campbell would have each pointed out, our modern civilization is but a veneer, that is often quite transparent.\n\n_________", "title": "On the Shooting in Florida, Student Activism, \u2018Black Panther\u2019 and the Olympics: Our Favorite Student Comments of the Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNo, it\u2019s going to not be O.K.,\u201d Ms. Newman said. \u201cIt\u2019s not. It\u2019s so bad.\u201d\n\nOnce one of Mr. Trump\u2019s most loyal boosters \u2014 she told a \u201cFrontline\u201d documentary crew before the election that \u201cevery critic, every detractor, will have to bow down to President Trump\u201d \u2014 now said she wouldn\u2019t vote for him again, \u201cin a million years, never.\u201d\n\nHer confession was punctuated by the kind of distant-thunder soundtrack that played during boardroom smackdowns on \u201cThe Apprentice.\u201d\n\nIt was a Frost/Nixon interview for the Trump era, when politics and reality TV have become inseparable and indistinguishable. Television, from \u201cFox and Friends\u201d in the morning to \u201cBig Brother\u201d at night, is now a fourth branch of government.\n\nIn a \u201cGood Morning America\u201d interview in December, after she was escorted off the White House grounds after reports of clashes with senior staff, Ms. Newman made only a tepid reference to \u201cuncomfortable\u201d situations on the job.\n\nBut she opened up in the company of her peers. One of them, the actress Keshia Knight-Pulliam of \u201cThe Cosby Show,\u201d was also once a contestant on \u201cThe Celebrity Apprentice,\u201d where she was fired by Mr. Trump for not having called Bill Cosby to help with a challenge.\n\nWhen Ms. Knight-Pulliam criticized Ms. Newman for standing by \u201cthe hate that that campaign kind of incited,\u201d Ms. Newman compared her loyalty with Ms. Knight-Pulliam\u2019s supporting Mr. Cosby through numerous accusations of rape. \u201cOnly you know the inner workings of your relationship with Mr. Cosby,\u201d Ms. Newman said. \u201cThat\u2019s the same thing with me and Mr. Trump.\u201d\n\nI would not have pegged \u201cCelebrity Big Brother\u201d as the show where, in the Trump and #MeToo eras, America would work through the ethics of enabling powerful men accused of abuses. But here we are.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere is a kind of literary symmetry to Ms. Newman\u2019s smiting her former boss with the very tools he taught her to use. Omarosa was the villain of \u201cThe Apprentice,\u201d but she played the game in the most Trumpian way.\n\nShe recognized that the show was a contest not of business acumen but of getting and leveraging attention. She created conflict in the belief that chaos yields opportunity. She denied mistakes even when she\u2019d made them on camera. She didn\u2019t win the season, but she won the greater prize of fame.\n\nShe was so successful that Mr. Trump had her back two more times and also produced, and appeared on, a TV One dating show for her \u2014 \u201cDonald J. Trump Presents the Ultimate Merger\u201d \u2014 all before hiring her for a White House position whose duties few people were able to describe.\n\nA few caveats are in order about Ms. Newman\u2019s \u201cWelcome to the Resistance\u201d moment. Reality shows are edited for maximum sensation. Her warnings were dire but unspecific. As a contestant on \u201cThe Apprentice,\u201d she learned that drama is what saves you from the editing room floor. She might be interested in making a book deal, or simply in repairing her public brand. As Mr. Mathews put it: \u201cI don\u2019t know if it\u2019s real. Would you trust her?\u201d\n\nThose might have been stronger rebuttals to Ms. Newman\u2019s comments than what the deputy White House press secretary, Raj Shah, offered Thursday to a reporter from \u2014 of course \u2014 CBS.\n\n\u201cOmarosa was fired three times on \u2018The Apprentice,\u2019 and this is the fourth time we\u2019ve let her go,\u201d he said. It was a boomerang insult that suggested that the Trump administration is part of the same long-running narrative as \u201cThe Apprentice,\u201d and raised the question of why she was hired in the first place.\n\nBut to suggest that Ms. Newman might have been playing to the cameras would have required the administration of Mr. Trump \u2014 who campaigned on the decisive-leader image that \u201cThe Apprentice\u201d stage-managed for him \u2014 to recognize that reality TV can convey an inaccurate impression of people.\n\nHow much more Ms. Newman has to say, and how much time she\u2019ll have to say it, is yet to be seen. But she\u2019s safe from being voted out of the house for now, having conveniently won immunity from the first ejection.\n\nThe network, if not the White House, must be happy. The Wednesday premiere of the three-week series was the highest-rated show of the night. During the 2016 Republican primary, the CBS chairman Leslie Moonves said of Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign, \u201cIt may not be good for America, but it\u2019s damn good for CBS.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe was more right than he knew.", "title": "On \u2018Big Brother,\u2019 America Gets the Reality-TV Politics It Deserves", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe love the show because it\u2019s distinctive, it has you on the edge of your seat,\u201d Ms. Salke said, speaking by telephone. \u201cWe would never dream in a million years of trying to do anything to push it to the middle.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s wise. Because \u201cGood Girls\u201d suggests that when pushed too far, women push back.\n\nPhoto\n\nJenna Bans, the show\u2019s creator, is a longtime writer and producer on several Shonda Rhimes shows and has also created \u201cThe Family,\u201d a domestic potboiler, and \u201cOff the Map,\u201d a sultry medical drama. Despite \u201cawesome feminist parents,\u201d she has spent most of her life as a self-proclaimed good girl, learning early on \u201cnot to ruffle feathers, not to rock the boat, to do what was expected of you,\u201d she said. (Ms. Bans was speaking by telephone from Los Angeles, where she was busy doing what was expected of her, finalizing the script for the season finale.)\n\nThe impetus for this series came a month or so before the 2016 election, when an \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape surfaced, recording Donald J. Trump\u2019s lewd remarks about women. Surprised by the overt sexism on display, she called her mother, figuring her reaction would be the same. But as Ms. Bans described it, her mother, \u201ca salty, hilarious, practical woman from the Midwest,\u201d just said, \u201cWhere have you been?\u201d\n\nThat conversation made Ms. Bans want to honor women like her mother, who have kept going when the playing field was anything but level. Eventually, that tribute became a compensatory fantasy, showing what might happen if women did rock the boat, if they did ruffle feathers, if they did take what they want. When we meet the characters of \u201cGood Girls,\u201d they\u2019re struggling, they\u2019re powerless, they haven\u2019t reaped the rewards they\u2019ve been promised. A few ski masks, a handful of toy guns, an \u201cAll right, everybody be cool and nobody gets hurt\u201d and those rewards start coming.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s probably not the best choice,\u201d Ms. Bans said. \u201cIt\u2019s not a responsible choice.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s certainly a bold choice to shove a climactic event like the heist into the pilot, rather than build up to it over many weeks, but Ms. Bans seemed unconcerned that viewers won\u2019t stick around. \u201cWe\u2019re never really struggling for lack of a story,\u201d she said. \u201cUsually we\u2019re trying to prune story out of our episodes because they\u2019re too overstuffed.\u201d\n\n\u201cGood Girls\u201d has a punchier, more comedic feel than the Shondaverse of \u201cScandal,\u201d \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy\u201d and \u201cPrivate Practice\u201d (series on which Ms. Bans worked), but shares some of those shows\u2019 D.N.A. As Ms. Bans said, Ms. Rhimes imbued in her \u201ca sense of risk-taking, of not keeping it safe, of pushing your characters to do things that scare them.\u201d\n\nHere, doing things that scare them allows these suburban moms to finally own their smarts, skills and mettle. As Ms. Hendricks\u2019s Beth says in the pilot, \u201cWe have accomplished way harder than this. I once made 300 damn cupcakes in one night and they were both nut- and gluten-free.\u201d So what\u2019s a little crime?\n\nThe crimes on \u201cGood Girls\u201d might not stay little, but they will rarely push the women too far off their moral centers. Last fall, Mike Hale in The New York Times noted that if television seems finally to have entered the age of the antiheroine, showrunners seem reluctant to create a heroine \u201cwho freely practices evil and is, at least in dramatic terms, celebrated for it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s a reluctance \u201cGood Girls\u201d shares and won\u2019t apologize for. \u201cWe really want to protect their sense of right and wrong,\u201d Ms. Bans said. \u201cWhen they make what is a morally gray choice, they really struggle with it.\u201d\n\nTruly amoral women, like Claire Underwood of \u201cHouse of Cards\u201d or Cersei Lannister of \u201cGame of Thrones,\u201d probably don\u2019t get invited out for 2-for-1 margarita night, but as for the women of \u201cGood Girls,\u201d \u201cI really feel like they\u2019re my friends,\u201d Ms. Bans said. She wants viewers to feel the same way.\n\nSo these women won\u2019t break bad. But they will definitely break not nice. And if they were on cable, Ms. Bans thinks they would probably swear a lot more, but she promises that this is the only compromise.\n\nMs. Hendricks said she hopes that the show will encourage viewers to examine their own sense of right and wrong. \u201cFollowing these women around, you ask yourself questions like, \u2018What would you do for your family? What\u2019s the sliding scale in your life? Would you do something a little illegal? Would you do something a lot illegal?\u2019\u201d Beth will commit multiple felonies, but will still slide a coaster underneath a soda can, so that\u2019s her line in the sand.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf the show is asking its audience to rethink its own choices, it\u2019s also encouraging its lead actresses to make some new ones. Ms. Whitman, usually cast as wised-up teenagers on \u201cParenthood\u201d and \u201cArrested Development,\u201d is playing a deeply unwise adult. Retta, a comedian best known as Donna Meagle, the assured office manager and coiner of the phrase \u2018Treat yo self\u201d on \u201cParks and Recreation,\u201d has a dramatic role. Ms. Hendricks, the office femme fatale of \u201cMad Men,\u201d is a neglected mother of four.\n\n(Kathleen Rose Perkins of \u201cEpisodes\u201d played Ms. Hendricks\u2019s character in an earlier pilot, but as the story changed, the role was recast. As Ms. Hendricks, who had her own role on Cameron Crowe\u2019s \u201cRoadies\u201d recast, said, \u201cHappens to everyone.\u201d)\n\nNone of these characters is flawless. None of these characters is simple. As Retta, drinking a La Croix in her trailer between scenes, joked, \u201cI get to have it all \u2014 kids and a husband and an illegal job.\u201d Ms. Whitman, resting in the neighboring trailer, described \u201ca weird sick excitement on my part to play somebody who isn\u2019t perfect.\u201d\n\n\u201cGood Girls\u201d asks what would happen, what could happen if girls and women stopped angling for perfection. \u201cIt\u2019s sad and funny to think about,\u201d Ms. Bans said. If Hillary Clinton had held up a couple of grocery stores, she added, \u201cour lives could all be so different right now.\u201d", "title": "On \u2018Good Girls,\u2019 They\u2019re the Criminal Moms Next Door", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. de Blasio also repeatedly insisted that he would not support any congestion pricing plan that did not include a \u201clockbox\u201d legal guarantee that any revenue generated would go only toward New York City\u2019s subways and buses.\n\n\u201cThat would be a situation that would be very damaging,\u201d he said, \u201cif we all agreed on a revenue vision and then woke up to find the money went elsewhere.\u201d\n\nMr. de Blasio has surely come to expect the verbal manhandling that accompanies these joint budget hearings. In 2016, Ms. Young highlighted the city\u2019s surplus as evidence that Mr. de Blasio did not need any more state support; on Monday, she returned to that theme. In 2017, Senator Simcha Felder of Brooklyn brought a loaf of bread and a carton of eggs to mock the mayor\u2019s proposal to charge a five-cent fee for plastic bags. (Mr. Felder reassured Mr. de Blasio on Monday that he had not brought any props this time.)\n\nLegislators also berated Mr. de Blasio for poor conditions in the city\u2019s public housing complexes and for his refusal to enact a property tax cap to which other municipalities statewide are subject. Assemblywoman Nicole Malliotakis, a Staten Island Republican who ran against Mr. de Blasio in November, made a show of examining her own property tax records against Mr. de Blasio\u2019s, noting that she paid nearly $2,000 more in property taxes each year even though his home was worth nearly three times more.\n\nFor his part, Mr. de Blasio criticized parts of the executive budget that would shift financial responsibility for charter schools to the city, and that would cut funding for special education and affordable housing. The mayor has been open in his criticism of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s proposed budget, even lumping together fiscal threats from Albany with those from Washington.\n\nAfter the hearing, the mayor and the governor, who are famously at loggerheads, met privately for nearly an hour and a half. As he emerged from the governor\u2019s office, Mr. de Blasio said the meeting had been \u201cgood.\u201d\n\nStrained attempts at diplomacy were evident during the hearing, too. While Mr. de Blasio at times could not hide his frustration with the grilling, he tried \u2014 at least in his words if not in his tone of voice \u2014 to maintain a note of optimism.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t buy the conventional wisdom of what is viable here in Albany and what\u2019s not,\u201d he said as he looked at the dozens of state legislators arrayed imposingly above him in the hearing room. \u201cI\u2019m going by what I think is the best outcome.\u201d", "title": "On \u2018Tin Cup Day,\u2019 Mayor de Blasio Sees a Role Reversal of Sorts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "To Democrats, the fact that the N.R.A. is not opposed to the proposal is prima facie evidence that it falls short. They are demanding a more robust debate over a series of gun initiatives, notably what they call a \u201cuniversal\u201d background check system that would cover all gun transactions in the country. That plan is opposed by the gun lobby but was seemingly endorsed by Mr. Trump, putting him at odds not only with the gun advocacy group that strongly backed him, but with many congressional Republicans, as well.\n\nSenator Christopher S. Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut and an author, with Mr. Cornyn, of the more limited background check bill, equated taking up his own legislation without allowing consideration of alternatives to \u201cslamming the door in the face of all these kids who are demanding change.\u201d\n\n\u201cI think it is imperative that we rise to the moment,\u201d Mr. Murphy said.\n\nMr. Trump told lawmakers they should use a broader bipartisan background check measure that failed in 2013 after the school shooting in Newtown, Conn., as the basis for a comprehensive measure that could take in many proposals, including the Cornyn plan, new mental health provisions and added security for schools. He urged backers of a renewed ban on assault weapons to make their case to the authors of the legislation and said he would welcome the opportunity to enact one sweeping bill to combat mass shootings. But Congress has for years been unable to make even incremental headway on new gun buying limits, let alone the type of multifaceted plan called for by the president.\n\nDemocrats would like to persuade Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, to allow votes on major gun control proposals, a plan that could throw the Senate into a full-blown showdown over competing initiatives. But Mr. McConnell is never one to rush into a fight that divides his own party if he can help it. While Mr. McConnell has been quiet about his intentions, Mr. Cornyn opened the door to that possibility of a wider debate provided it could get to passage of his bill at a minimum.\n\n\u201cWe can set up a situation where they can vote on those amendments,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat I don\u2019t want to do is leave here this week and go back home to Texas and say we failed to do anything to try to address these tragedies.\u201d\n\nAs lawmakers quibbled about how to proceed, some of the multiple proposals promoted by Mr. Trump were falling by the wayside.\n\nRepublican lawmakers seem uninterested in plans to raise the age to buy all guns to 21. The idea of arming teachers was also getting a cold reception. Among plans circulating that could draw bipartisan support was a measure that would prevent those on federal no-fly lists from buying guns, though that approach has met Republican resistance in the past.\n\nHoping to skirt a divisive debate, Republicans preferred to focus on other remedies, like improving general school safety, while pointing to law enforcement failures surrounding the Parkland shooting.", "title": "Once Again, Push for Gun Control Collides With Political Reality", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "MIDDLETOWN, N.Y. \u2014 The director of the public library in this Hudson Valley town calls his assistant and security guard \u201cStarsky and Hutch.\u201d They have been trained to spot signs of overdose in library patrons \u2014 paleness and shortness of breath when it is heroin; sudden collapse when it is fentanyl \u2014 and administer the drug naloxone. They patrol the bathrooms and stacks at the Middletown Thrall Library, checking on anyone who is dozing.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s easier to call the police, to wait for E.M.S.,\u201d said the library director, Matt Pfisterer, who had to decide whether to use the overdose-reversing drug himself a few years ago, after he found a woman lying in the grass outside, unconscious and covered with ants.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t know how they\u2019re going to react,\u201d he said. \u201cBut when it comes down to it, you ask, \u2018Do I want to see this person dying in front of me?\u2019 \u2018No.\u2019 So you take the leap.\u201d\n\nThe opioid epidemic is reshaping life in America, including at the local public library, where librarians are considering whether to carry naloxone to battle overdoses. At a time when the public is debating arming teachers, it is another example of an unlikely group being enlisted to fight a national crisis.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPhiladelphia became the poster child for naloxone-toting librarians last year after the Inquirer wrote about a library where one woman had revived several people. Cities including Denver and San Francisco have also started training library staff to use the drug, which comes in the form of a nasal spray and is commonly known by the brand name Narcan.", "title": "Once It Was Overdue Books. Now Librarians Fight Overdoses.", "authors": ["Annie Correal"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nAs a New Yorker, I know to avoid arguments with strangers. Therefore, I apologize whenever I bump into another pedestrian on a crowded sidewalk, whether or not I\u2019m the one at fault.\n\nI knew I had taken this habit to the extreme recently when I apologized to a dog on a leash that bumped into me.", "title": "One Apology Too Many", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "There was a lot to keep an eye on.\n\nBlackRock, which manages $6 trillion overall, is the leading issuer of exchange-traded funds, with $1.3 trillion under management. But as the market fell and trading in BlackRock funds accelerated, there was little sign of panic or emotion among the E.T.F. specialists at the firm.\n\nThey fielded phone calls from clients and let the computers do their work.\n\nMartin Small, who oversees United States-based E.T.F.s at the firm, said the high share of E.T.F. trading was positive for the markets. That is because on days when fearful investors want to sell, large, easy-to-trade E.T.F.s serve as a critical release valve.\n\n\u201cEverything worked,\u201d Mr. Small said. \u201cVolumes were higher and more people were watching, but our funds did what they were supposed to do.\u201d\n\nInvesting on the basis of what machines, as opposed to humans, do has been a trend in financial markets for years. What\u2019s different now is that so much money has poured into a specific type of computer-driven trading.\n\nFrom cost-conscious millennials to the world\u2019s largest pension and sovereign wealth funds, E.T.F.s have become a preferred investment choice. In addition to all the major stock and bond indexes, they enable investors to get a piece of the action in arcane areas like junk bonds, bank loans and stocks in Pakistan. There is even an E.T.F. that tracks companies that make whiskey.\n\nThe popularity of E.T.F.s has concentrated unparalleled financial power in BlackRock and Vanguard, the two biggest providers of index funds and E.T.F.s. Together, they sit on $10.5 trillion in assets and control 65 percent of the 1,700 exchange-traded funds that exist.\n\nRelying on sophisticated computer programs, they funnel investor money into the stocks and bonds that make up indexes around the world. As the flows have grown in volume, much of these funds have gone toward index heavyweights like Amazon, Apple and Facebook, pushing their valuations ever higher.", "title": "One Cause of Market Turbulence: Computer-Driven Index Funds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Syracuse \u2014 Shannon Kennedy, son of Jack, retired military officer, ex-stockbroker, voted twice for Barack Obama (\u201cso poised, a really got-it-together guy\u201d) before his conversion to Donald Trump. Now he\u2019s a true believer, even if he thinks \u201cDonald definitely needs to button it sometimes.\u201d\n\nHis dad, named John but universally known as Jack, \u201cwas such a charmer, he could charm hungry pups from a meat wagon.\u201d Married three times with eight kids, Jack was a Democrat and \u201ca very capable political operative who ran a couple of campaigns here in Syracuse.\u201d For a while he sold used cars at Shamrock Motors, then opened a bar, Kennedy\u2019s Club K, which, his son observes, \u201cwas not a great occupation for an alcoholic.\u201d\n\nJack was dry at the time. He said he\u2019d put tea in the whiskey bottles, nobody would know, and he\u2019d drink from those. That worked, until it didn\u2019t. He was dead at 49.\n\nWe are driving around Syracuse, population 143,000. It\u2019s pretty bleak. Most industry and manufacturers are long gone. Poverty and drugs are scourges, as in countless towns across America. Service industries and Syracuse University are significant providers of jobs now. Kennedy recalls a different town in his youth, a thriving magnet to immigrants. After his parents divorced, and his mother died young in 1961, he was raised by his grandmother.", "title": "Opinion | One Honorable American\u2019s Love of Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Many series for fledgling readers feature mischievous girls and their grade-school exploits: Ramona Quimby, Junie B. Jones and Clementine, to name a few. Others, like the Magic Treehouse books, send children on fantasy adventures. Abby Hanlon\u2019s marvelous Dory Fantasmagory series, featuring the plucky heroine Dory, also known as Rascal, combines the two. As Dory herself puts it: \u201cMy two worlds swirl together like a chocolate and vanilla ice cream cone. Real and unreal get mixed up in one crazy flavor.\u201d On every page, Hanlon\u2019s charming illustrations \u2014 if you squint, they resemble a child\u2019s drawings \u2014 mix things up as well, interweaving layers of visual and narrative storytelling to invite us in to Dory\u2019s active imagination.\n\nThe fourth and latest book in the series, DORY FANTASMAGORY: Head in the Clouds (Dial, $15.99, ages 5 to 8), will have fans rejoicing that Hanlon\u2019s hybrid formula is still going strong. Dory faces obstacles both mundane and enchanted, and surmounts them all. She dumps an objectionable winter coat and devises a pretend game to captivate a weepy friend. After losing her first tooth, she recognizes the Tooth Fairy, shopping incognito, and chases her through a grocery store. And in perhaps her greatest triumph in the series so far, she foils the evil plan of her imaginary nemesis, Mrs. Gobble Gracker, to take over that benevolent spirit\u2019s nightly visits.\n\nThroughout the series, Dory deals with conventional problems \u2014 handling scornful older siblings, starting school, making friends, learning to read \u2014 in unconventional ways. In the first book, she faces her kindergarten fears by inventing Mrs. Gobble Gracker, an even more intimidating foe. With her looming stature and witchy features, she recalls James Marshall\u2019s illustrations of Miss Viola Swamp, \u201cthe meanest substitute teacher in the whole world,\u201d in \u201cMiss Nelson Is Missing,\u201d by Harry G. Allard Jr. Dory\u2019s everyday world is populated with other magical and comic figures, like Mary, her monster, and Mr. Nuggy, her (male) fairy godmother. And while many stories for children send their protagonists back to the real world for good \u2014 Wendy grows up and can\u2019t return to Neverland; Lucy leaves Narnia; Jackie Paper abandons Puff the Magic Dragon \u2014 Hanlon does not champion maturity as the answer to adversity. A former first-grade teacher, she recognizes the value of coping strategies that are particular to children. Rascal becomes resilient, resourceful and adventurous thanks to the permeable boundary between reality and fantasy, not in spite of it. \u201cTry not to imagine things,\u201d Dory\u2019s sister, Violet, tells her when she heads off to kindergarten. But it is Rascal\u2019s imagination that allows her to adapt to new surroundings, practice new skills and make new friends.\n\nIn \u201cHead in the Clouds,\u201d Hanlon once again shows an unerring sense of what distresses children (that \u201cbunchy\u201d winter coat), what excites them (candy canes discovered in pockets), and what they fear (a tooth fairy delivery gone astray). There is, as always, much to laugh over. We see Luke\u2019s and Violet\u2019s frustrated memories of life with infant Dory. We learn the contents of the Tooth Fairy\u2019s purse (like Beyonc\u00e9, she carries a certain condiment). And we get Mrs. Gobble Gracker\u2019s withering assessment of \u201cWhere the Wild Things Are\u201d: \u201cI\u2019ll show them terrible teeth.\u201d When Dory loses her first tooth, her doleful friend Melody sobs, \u201cIt means you are growing up!\u201d The admiring reader earnestly hopes not yet.", "title": "One Part Fantasy, One Part Reality Is a Child\u2019s Perfect Formula", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Well, it\u2019s been a while, but it\u2019s good to be back. This is my fifth New York Times puzzle \u2014 my last one ran a little over four years ago, my first one ran in 2010. At this rate, I\u2019ll have joined the exclusive \u201cTen Club\u201d in 2026.\n\nA lot has happened since my last publication \u2014 I became a father, I made my way on air as a news anchor and sports announcer, and I met Will Shortz.\n\nSince I have more on my plate nowadays, I don\u2019t submit as often as I once did, but if a good idea crosses my mind, I will try to put it to paper.\n\nThis idea just sort of popped into my head one day. I thought it was worth trying it out, but admittedly, I had trouble figuring out theme answers for VISA and DISCOVER. Maybe ELVIS ANDRUS for VISA? Maybe if this were a crossword in \u201cBaseball Digest.\u201d\n\nTruth is, the suggestion box under the Google search bar is what really helped me with these two. I began typing \u201cELVIS A\u201d to see what would come up and did the same for \u201cDISCO VER.\u201d The results I found seemed like legit answers, and Will apparently agreed.\n\nA couple of cool things I realized recently with this puzzle: By total coincidence, the TEX in VORTEX crosses into RITTER, which is neat. Also by total coincidence, PAPI is at 34-Down, and Big Papi\u2019s number was 34 (my favorite jersey number).\n\nOh, and I\u2019m sure there will be nit-pickers out there who will find fault in my lack of MASTER CARD, but that just wasn\u2019t going to happen. As the commercial says, that\u2019s for everything else.", "title": "One With Credit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "La Rochefoucauld was born in September 1923, and was 16 when France surrendered in June 1940. From the beginning he hated the Germans with a deep passion, and he was determined to fight them. Unlike many in France who collaborated with Germans and accepted the collaborationist Vichy government, La Rochefoucauld fled to Spain, taking the dangerous journey to London so he could meet Charles de Gaulle in person. In Spain, he was recruited as a member of the British Special Operations Executive, the S.O.E., Britain\u2019s army of saboteurs, and sent back to France to, in Churchill\u2019s words, \u201cset Europe ablaze.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThis La Rochefoucauld did, winning a Croix de Guerre, made a Chevalier de la L\u00e9gion d\u2019Honneur and awarded other medals. After parachuting into France, he joined a Resistance network and trained r\u00e9sistants in the use of explosives to blow up power plants and railroads, then sabotaged the factory the Germans used to repair them. While guiding two British pilots toward freedom, La Rochefoucauld was arrested by Spanish police agents and sent to a prison camp. In time, he was flown back to London, where he was trained in sabotage and silent killing, and was given arduous physical training. Eventually, he was parachuted back into France and, in 1943, arrested, and sent to Auxerre prison.\n\nA warning: This section of \u201cThe Saboteur\u201d is very explicit in its description of the tortures \u2014 beatings and water boardings among them \u2014 endured by prisoners at Auxerre. In time, he was sentenced to death, but La Rochefoucauld was not prepared to die, and decided to take his chances and escape, jumping off a truck on his way to an execution site, but then he realized he was about to run past Gestapo headquarters: \u201cLa Rochefoucauld decided to continue down the street, despite his heart\u2019s drumming in his rib cage. He walked as casually as a man trying to escape his execution could walk. As he approached the building, he saw a Citro\u00ebn sedan with swastika pennants on the fender, parked nearby. He stole a glance inside the car \u2014 keys in the ignition. He looked around and saw a driver, maybe 30 feet away, pacing back and forth, waiting for someone to emerge from the building. Just then La Rochefoucauld heard distant shouting, The truck! Now \u2014 he had to decide now. He moved closer to the car, swung the door wide and threw himself in.\u201d\n\nThis is first-class adventure writing, which, coupled with a true-life narrative of danger and intrigue, adds up to all-night reading. There are hundreds of books about the French Resistance, some fictional, some based on actual experience. Again and again, one meets heroic people who will not give in to the forces of evil. These works are morality plays about courage and determination. Kix puts it this way: \u201cThe boys talked about how France had lost her honor. \u2018I didn\u2019t have much good sense,\u2019 Robert said, \u2018but honor \u2014 that\u2019s all my friends and I could talk about.\u2019\u201d\n\nThese many narratives, about holding dear to one\u2019s honor in the face of persecution by a powerful enemy, will never go out of style. The reason they remain popular and widely read today is this implicit question: What would you have done? Hard to answer, but it\u2019s a question that, given the political circumstances of the world we live in, sadly needs to be asked. Reading \u201cThe Saboteur,\u201d one understands how a certain person at a certain time answered it. La Rochefoucauld faced torture and death, yet he carried on. There is inspiration in his example, and that makes \u201cThe Saboteur\u201d well worth reading.", "title": "One of the Men Who \u2018Set Europe Ablaze\u2019", "authors": ["Alan Furst", "Paul Kix"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Similarly, at 26A, the clue \u201cMADISON + A = \u2018Me, too!\u2019\u201d refers to President James Madison, and if we anagram his last name along with the letter A, we get the phrase AND SO AM I. It\u2019s a bit awkward as a phrase and as the only non-noun in the theme set, in my opinion, but it was easy enough to get.\n\nThere are five presidents mixed up in Mr. Haight\u2019s puzzle, so go straighten out the other three.\n\nTricky Clues\n\nThe hardest part of today\u2019s puzzle for new solvers will be figuring out the theme. On the other hand, it\u2019s a great way to get a taste of what\u2019s to come in some of the later week puzzles.\n\n29A: I had _YS when I got to \u201cShakespearean cries,\u201d and I so wanted this to be OYS. Alas, forsooth, the answer is AYS.\n\n30A: If you are over the \u201cBounding main,\u201d you are on the SEA, of course. Don\u2019t believe me? Please meet the Shanty Chor Bremerhaven singing the sea shanty \u201cSailing, Sailing.\u201d I don\u2019t think I would be overstating things by saying that this is the most wonderful rendition in the entire history of the universe:\n\n35A: He\u2019s not wrong. PolitiFact does rule on truth and LIES in media. Moving on.\n\n40D: Hi, kids! Back in the 1950s and \u201960s (ask your grandparents), there were these young people called beatniks, partly because they were cool, but mostly because they were into the music scene, man, you dig? If they understood what you were saying, they would say \u201cI DIG!\u201d One of the most famous beatniks on television was a character named Maynard G. Krebs from a show called \u201cThe Many Loves of Dobie Gillis\u201d (ask your grandparents). Coincidentally, Krebs was played by the actor Bob Denver, who went on to even more fame playing the role of Gilligan on the show \u201cGilligan\u2019s Island\u201d (ask your grandparents). Here he is teaching Pat Boone (ask your \u2026 oh, never mind) how to talk hip, beatnik-style:\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nI did an anagrams +1 puzzle on May 16, 2017, with state names, so I decided to try one with presidents\u2019 names. There are some sites online that do this kind of thing, but most of them give you only single-word anagrams \u2014 it took me quite a bit of digging to find multiple-word phrase options. My submitted puzzle had IMPEL at 55-Down and LSTS at 72-Across. I think that latter entry did not sit well with the editors because they were willing to put I.M. PEI in there even on a Monday to get rid of it. I still think every entry in the puzzle is reasonable for a Monday. I remember getting all done, realizing I had FORD in the grid \u2014 ouch \u2014 and finding out that even when you know he needs to go, it\u2019s sometimes not that easy to remove a president. Last time one of the reviewers, Jeff Chen, criticized me for not finding added letters that spelled something interesting. This time I went all out and came up with add-on letters (U, A, V, P, P) that anagram to \u201cV.A. pup,\u201d which is of course closely related to a POLICE DOG. For some reason Will left that piece of info out of the cluing \u2026\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "One to Honor Presidents", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cOnline Courses Fail Those Who Need Help\u201d (Sunday Business, Jan. 21):\n\nI applaud many of the points raised in the article. However, an important segment of online learners not mentioned are adult students looking to advance in their careers who are often juggling a full-time job and family responsibilities. A 2016 survey found that more than two-thirds of students felt time spent in online academic programs was worth it.\n\nPace University was an early adopter of online learning nearly 16 years ago, largely to meet the needs of students who don\u2019t have the ability to attend classes full-time or conform to a schedule. We\u2019ve learned that older students, often beginning studies after many years of work, need more feedback and engagement with professors and classmates.\n\nOnline programs work best when they are part of a university curriculum that is monitored by quality faculty and offers classroom and experiential learning opportunities.\n\nWhile online learning might not be one-size-fits-all, I\u2019ve seen it transform lives for the better.\n\nMARVIN KRISLOV, NEW YORK", "title": "Opinion | Online Learning Successes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "The committee, he said in a Twitter post last week, \u201cdishonorably tossed a coin to decide its 2018 flag bearer.\u201d\n\n\u201cNo problem,\u201d he added. \u201cI can wait until 2022. #BlackHistoryMonth2018 #PyeongChang2018\u201d\n\nDavis has not commented since, and has made his Twitter account private, leaving others to interpret what he meant by the Black History Month reference.\n\nIf Biney is feeling the pressure of paving the way for the next generation of African-American women entering the sport, she is taking it with stride. She was full of laughter on Saturday shortly after securing her spot in the final 16 in the 500 meters. \u201cI\u2019m just ready to get out there on Tuesday and let it rip,\u201d she said.\n\nThirteen athletes from eight African nations will be competing in South Korea, the largest representation of athletes from African nations in any Winter Games. There has yet to be a Winter Olympics medal awarded to any athlete representing an African nation.\n\nThe Nigerian bobsled team has high, perhaps sky high, expectations to change that.\n\nThey make up the first African nation to compete in bobsled at the Olympics, and, win or lose, they said that they hope to make a lasting impression.\n\n\u201cThis could be something that would be really cool, something that we give back, something that people could just be proud of and we could be just kind of low key, get it done, and we could just live in that legacy,\u201d Seun Adigun, the captain and driver of the team, said in Pyeongchang. \u201cOr, people would get really, really excited, and then we\u2019d have to figure out how to manage life that way.\u201d", "title": "Online, a Diverse Winter Olympics. But on the Ground?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "The show is a tour de force. Mr. Prescod tells his story with an agility that seems true to life, and also larger than life. He plays 32 characters, from his mother and father \u2014 on the night they met and fell for each other \u2014 to friends he hung out with, and got in trouble with.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut \u201cA Brooklyn Boy\u201d is about who he was, not who he is, and the who-he-was part of his life ended when he went to CityKids in 2009. \u201cA Brooklyn Boy\u201d stops without examining the transformation that followed or that other high point in his life, the big moment with the royals.\n\nFor someone who tells his life story onstage, Mr. Prescod was the quiet one in a conversation that included Moises Roberto Belizario, who shares a credit for the book, music and lyrics with him and a solo credit as the director. It was Mr. Belizario who did most of the talking, although Laurie Meadoff, the founder of CityKids, chimed in.\n\nMr. Belizario said there was a producer \u201cwe were working with\u201d on a London production who wanted a promise that William and Catherine would attend \u201cA Brooklyn Boy\u201d on opening night. Royals are like presidents, governors or mayors on this side of the Atlantic. They have schedules. The palace handlers would make no such promises, even after so much effusiveness.\n\nMr. Belizario said Mr. Prescod was no angel when he arrived at City Kids \u2014 Mr. Prescod, who was on probation after pleading guilty to armed robbery and assault, was sent there by another nonprofit group, Cases, a clearinghouse that seeks ways to help young offenders pull their lives together. Mr. Prescod said he had told someone at Cases that he loved to dance and rap. \u201cThey said, \u2018We know a great place for you \u2014 CityKids,\u201d he recalled. \u201cI thought it was a day-care center.\u201d\n\nMr. Belizario, 49, said he was no angel, either. He arrived at CityKids after he was arrested at 17 on drug and weapons possession charges \u2014 he was acquitted. Eventually he was hired for its staff and is now its artistic director.\n\nHe said Mr. Prescod made an impression. \u201cIt was like I was looking in the mirror, 10 years before,\u201d Mr. Belizario said, \u201cand he could deliver the message I had wanted to deliver.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Prescod, who had been arrested when he was 16, said more about Mr. Belizario in an article for Essence than he did sitting next to him. Mr. Prescod wrote that he figured Mr. Belizario \u201cwas going to be just like every other man in my life \u2014 a know-it-all that wants to push me to be who he wants me to be.\u201d He said he had been told that he would not have to \u201ctalk about what I did wrong, all I had to do was show up, tell them that I know how to answer phones, file papers and work on the computer. So I was prepared to do just that.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Belizario\u2019s first question was what had Mr. Prescod done wrong.\n\nThey bonded. Mr. Belizario told him to write down stories of his life. Mr. Prescod began constructing scenes like the one in \u201cA Brooklyn Boy\u201d about his appearance in court. He has a flair for details \u2014 the court clerk\u2019s voice, calling his case number; the judge\u2019s voice, offering him five years on probation, later reduced to three years for good behavior; and his own thoughts as he wondered where his life was headed.\n\nHe acknowledged that he was lucky, although he says little in \u201cA Brooklyn Boy\u201d about just how lucky he was \u2014 lucky that the judge sentenced him to probation rather than prison. And lucky later, while on probation, that three police officers did not find a gun he had been holding for a friend.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe saw their patrol car coming down the street. He reached up, hiding the gun just out of sight on a ledge above the front door of his family\u2019s home. The officers stopped, apparently not realizing where he had reached. They apparently assumed he had gone for the mailbox, to hide a drug stash.\n\n\u201cThey kept saying, \u2018Where\u2019d you put it?\u2019\u201d \u2014 without realizing that Mr. Prescod was worried about a different \u201cit\u201d than the one they had in mind. He said the relatives he lived with had not known he had the gun \u2014 \u201cI kept lying about it,\u201d he said.\n\nThe officers went into the house with their guns drawn. His grandfather, an aunt and a young cousin were inside. One of the officers told him, \u201cYou\u2019re lucky I\u2019m a good cop or else I could have shot you.\u201d Or, Mr. Prescod said, if the officers had found the gun, \u201cI\u2019d have gone to prison till I was 22. I was 22 when I met the duke and duchess.\u201d\n\nThat encounter happened because Ms. Meadoff, who founded CityKids in the 1980s and left to work with young people through media, had returned. A friend called her and said the prince and the duchess were coming and asked if they could visit CityKids.\n\nThe next thing Mr. Prescod knew, he was onstage with the prince and duchess in the front row.\n\nAfter the show, he said, \u201cI thought we were just going to say hello.\u201d\n\nBut the prince wanted to talk.\n\nHere Mr. Belizario interrupted. \u201cIt was a validating moment,\u201d he said. \u201cIt let him realize, he matters.\u201d", "title": "Onstage in Manhattan Again, but He Still Has the Prince\u2019s Number", "authors": ["James Barron", "Grace Notes"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "It wasn\u2019t that the actors didn\u2019t wear the usual fashion \u2014 Lupita Nyong\u2019o was in purple Versace with a jewel-studded harness; Chadwick Bozeman in gold and black floral Emporio Armani; Angela Bassett in a fringed yellow jumpsuit by Naeem Khan \u2014 it was that it was such an exuberant version of the usual fashion.\n\nAnd, my guess is, it is also a hint of what is to come. Not just with the film, which officially opens on the 16th, but also with the runway. Every once in a while a movie catches both the public and designer imagination (it happened with \u201cWonder Woman\u201d last year) \u2014 all signs suggest this is going to be one of them.\n\nReviews are not out until next week, but reactions have leaked on social media and they are almost universally ecstatic.\n\nYou know what that means: catwalk influence!\n\nThe question, for me, is what form the influence will take. Most of the clothes at the premiere were abstractly linked to the film\u2019s story and setting \u2014 either royal or primary colored \u2014 but others had more overt African references. That was fine for the purple carpet, since it was connected to the movie, but taken out of context and plunked on a European catwalk could easily prompt charges of cultural appropriation.\n\nIt\u2019s going to be a fine balancing act, and it will be interesting to see how it plays out.\n\nMeanwhile, for your reading pleasure may I suggest this profile of Rande Gerber, the patriarch of modeling\u2019s first family, a sneak peek at Ansel Elgort\u2019s next movie, and the strange story of the controversial Norwegian ski team sweaters. Also a suggestion: Rest up this weekend and drink your green juice. Fashion month starts next Thursday (argh! argh!) and we are all going to need our strength.", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Or spend some time considering how the street became the new runway; whether or not fashion is finally going to address the issue of work/life balance \u2014 and, in the interests of the international aspect of both the Olympics and Fashion month, why young women in Iran are abandoning the head scarf.\n\nHave a good weekend.\n\nYour Style Questions, Answered\n\nEvery week on Open Thread, Vanessa will answer a reader\u2019s fashion-related question, which you can send to her anytime via email or Twitter. Questions are edited and condensed.\n\nQ: In two weeks I\u2019ll be leaving for half a year for a study abroad in Poland. I\u2019m super excited, but what in the world am I going to pack? I\u2019m going in winter but staying until the middle of summer. At home I\u2019m used to my huge Ikea wardrobe, which houses all of my wonderful clothes and shoes and bags, but how do I know what I\u2019m going to need for my various activities without over-packing? \u2014 Lina, Vienna\n\nA: Speaking of parkas, these Olympics may be very useful to you. On a more immediate note, however, I asked our Poland correspondent, Marc Santora, for some actual tips from the front line. Here\u2019s what he said:\n\n\u201cForget layers. A proper winter coat is much better and easier to leave at a coat check. Boots are essential, especially indoor/outdoor boots that are water resistant but not arctic boots. All that said, the malls here have most essentials, so no need to stress. And come spring I am told it is all sundresses and shorts. When the sun arrives they soak up every minute.\u201d\n\nFor the boots I\u2019d check out Sorel if you don\u2019t have some already; throw in a few pairs of pants and some sweaters; make sure your coat is water-resistant (not wool); and then take a few sundresses (which you can also wear over tights and under sweaters in winter), shorts and shirts, sneakers and ballet flats. Plus a transitional jacket, like a pea coat or lightweight trench, and a couple of scarves. Then add a tote bag or backpack, shoulder bag and pochette that can double as an evening clutch, and you should be in good shape.\n\nA final tip: Before you pack, stand in front of your closet and think very carefully about what you actually wear, as opposed to what you have. It can be both enlightening and liberating. \u2014 VANESSA FRIEDMAN", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The 1980s are coming back, at least according to Tom Ford and Marc Jacobs. This did not fill my heart with joy.\n\nRaf Simons trucked 50,000 gallons of popcorn to the old American Stock Exchange building for his Calvin Klein show, and it was most entertaining, even if a lot of guests started complaining about the dry cleaning bills, and there was some social media protest about wasted food.\n\nPolitics and position-taking were largely avoided, except by Kerby Jean-Raymond in a moving Pyer Moss show that was a subtle ode to the black cowboy. Remember his name; he\u2019s one of the most interesting of the NewGen designers in the city.\n\nPeople often ask me how I get ready for fashion month, and the truth is I don\u2019t, really. I wear the same thing almost every season, so packing is easy now, and I stay in the same hotels, so I know where the closest pharmacy and grocery stores are anyway, in case I have an emergency.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor me, the most important prep is really just brain rest. Seven days of skirts can start to blend together in a big blob of ennui.\n\nSo I\u2019ll go to as many trapeze classes I can fit in, since once I get on the plane to Milan all exercise goes out the window, and I\u2019ll spend the weekend with my family getting my Olympic fix, especially of Johnny Weir, who is throwing some serious fashion shade (I actually think his outfits were more interesting than a lot of the shows in New York). I try, in other words, to remind myself of the context in which all these clothes function.\n\nTo that end, check out these \u201cBlack Panther\u201d stories, check in with Leslie Jones\u2019s Olympic fashion criticism, and spend 48 hours with the designer Prabal Gurung to see what Fashion Week is like from the other side. Talk to you from Milan!\n\nYour Style Questions, Answered\n\nEvery week on Open Thread, Vanessa will answer a reader\u2019s fashion-related question, which you can send to her anytime via email or Twitter. Questions are edited and condensed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nQ: Is there such a thing as a fashionable puffer coat? I need something light and warm for the chilly Los Angeles nights and for when I spend five weeks in N.Y. in the fall. I wear a lot of sweaters that come down to my mid thighs. I am a 70-year-old artist and I am looking for something interesting (but no belts, please!) \u2013 Eileen, Santa Monica\n\nA: Take it from this similarly belt-adverse person: yes, absolutely. In fact, fashion has developed something of a thing for puffers. I literally just saw a puffer wrap on the Michael Kors runway, and some pretty great shearling trimmed puffers at Tory Burch.\n\nThose won\u2019t be in stores til August though, so for some more immediate gratification, I asked T\u2019s style director, Malina Joseph Gilchrist, what she would recommend. Here\u2019s what she said: \u201cLook at Moncler and Marques\u2019 Almeida for more fashionable options. Moncler cuts for women where the waist is taken in and gives a more \u2018fashionable\u2019 shape, sans belt. Marques\u2019 Almeida has been incorporating puffer coats on the runway. Other good options are Norma Kamali\u2019s sleeping bag jacket, which was stylish in the \u201880s and is still good today. Or try Uniqlo, and opt for their knee-length quilted thinner down jacket.\u201d\n\nI\u2019d also add another Italian brand that is less expensive than Moncler (though not cheap), as an option. I was standing outside a show the other day and chatting to another critic when I started admiring her puffer \u2014 silky, with a wide turtle neck \u00e0 la Audrey Hepburn \u2014 and asked where it was from: Herno was the answer. You learn a lot waiting for a show to start. \u2014 VANESSA FRIEDMAN", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "(Also, I got a great table-setting tip: tinfoil-covered fruit. Talk to you then.\n\nYour Style Questions, Answered\n\nEvery week on Open Thread, Vanessa will answer a reader\u2019s fashion-related question, which you can send to her anytime via email or Twitter. Questions are edited and condensed.\n\nQ: I am a 28-year-old professional working in construction engineering, and I am extremely petite \u2014 about 4-foot-10 and less than 100 pounds. My office is very informal, daily jeans and a blouse is fine, but I am often mistaken for a college intern. I am already in a male-dominated \u201cold boys\u2019 club\u201d industry, and regularly being assumed to be nearly 10 years younger than I am does not do me any favors when I am trying to be taken seriously. I am at a loss on how to appear fashionable, professional, knowledgeable, and look like I am nearly 30, all at the same time. I can\u2019t realistically wear the high heels I would wear during non-work hours all day long. \u2014 Kaitlin, Boston\n\nA: This is a tough one. I know how frustrating it can be to have people not take you seriously because of how you look (or tell you how happy it will make you when all your peers look their age and you still look young). While we get a lot of complaints about fashion not catering to plus-size or very tall women, very petite women have the same problem.\n\nMy first suggestion would be Brooks Brothers\u2019 boys department, which makes great blazers and button-down shirts (as a bonus, they are the same quality and cut as adult sizes, but at a lower price). I had a friend who used to wear skin-tight pants with boys\u2019 shirts that were a size too small to black tie events, and she pretty much laid those who saw her on the floor. Pair them with girls\u2019 leather riding boots, which should come in all sizes and have the comfort you need, but look chicer than sneakers or ballet flats.\n\nT\u2019s style director, Malina Joseph Gilchrist, also had these ideas: \u201cTry Stitch Fix, a members service where you have the luxury of trying on a style box of goodies in your own home. Reformation also has a special petite department that has cute dresses to wear with a blazer.\u201d Another possible solution: tunics, which you can get tailored down into shift dresses without too much hassle.\n\nMeanwhile, I\u2019ll remind the designers I meet on the road that they are missing a part of the market. And if any other readers have suggestions, please send them in, and I will pass them on. \u2014 VANESSA FRIEDMAN", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "The latest school shooter, Nikolas Cruz, 19, was clearly troubled and making threats, and he was stockpiling weapons. But he had no mental diagnosis. He has been described as angry, possibly depressed, perhaps isolated \u2014 not so different from millions of other teenagers.\n\nWe Want to Hear From You Will arming and training more teachers make schools safer?
