A feared militant commander, he also claimed to have masterminded the 2012 jailbreak in the northwestern town of Bannu that resulted in the escape of nearly 400 inmates, including several high-profile militants.\n\nPakistani officials have been critical of the American drone strikes on the Pakistani soil, arguing that they are a violation of the country\u2019s sovereignty. But last week\u2019s attack that killed Mr. Sayed did not elicit a strong reaction from Pakistan\u2019s Foreign Office.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMuhammad Khurasani, a Taliban spokesman, said in a statement on Monday that Mr. Sayed had been killed in a Feb. 8 drone strike in Growek region of North Waziristan, another tribal area. American missiles struck a vehicle carrying the militant commander and five of his security guards as they were entering Pakistani territory from the Afghan side, Pakistani intelligence officials said; all of the security guards were also killed in the strike.\n\nMr. Sayed had gone into hiding in Khost Province of Afghanistan after the Pakistani Army launched an offensive in 2014 against local and foreign militants in North Waziristan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter the death of the commander Hakimullah Mehsud in a 2013 American drone attack, Mr. Sayed claimed the leadership of the Pakistani Taliban, which consists of several groups. But he then lost out to the current leader, Maulana Fazlullah, who had been responsible for the 2012 attack on Malala Yousafzai, the teenage Pakistani education activist. Differences continued to persist between the two militant commanders.\n\nThe man announced by the Taliban as successor to Mr. Sayed is Mufti Noor Wali Mehsud, who also goes by Abu Mansoor Asim. A 588-page book he published online last month, \u201cInquilab-i-Mehsud,\u201d or \u201cRevolution of the Mehsuds,\u201d chronicles the militant group\u2019s formation and activities, including taking responsibility for the 2007 assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, the first woman to lead a country in the Muslim world.\n\nMr. Mehsud, 40, is also a Shariah court judge.", "title": "Pakistani Taliban Say Deputy Leader Was Killed in U.S. Airstrike", "authors": ["Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud", "Ismail Khan"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "The court, however, disqualified Mr. Sharif for not declaring a salary from one of his son\u2019s companies. He has said he never received that amount and was not bound to declare it on his income returns.\n\nSince the ouster, Mr. Sharif has embarked on a forceful public campaign, claiming that he was removed as a result of political vendetta and on a weak legal argument. He has maintained that he and the ruling party are being singled out by the top court, which he claims is supported by Pakistan\u2019s powerful military establishment. The military and the court\u2019s justices deny the accusations.\n\nMr. Sharif\u2019s messages have resonated in parts of the electorate, chiefly his base in Punjab, the province that traditionally decides the country\u2019s political fortune. The governing party has won several recent polls with a resounding majority.\n\nThe electoral victories, though, have come at a time of increasing clashes with the Supreme Court and a more activist role by Justice Nisar. That, in turn, has raised criticism that the court is overreaching.\n\nOn Tuesday, a day before the panel\u2019s ruling, Justice Nisar lashed out at his critics, saying in a speech that the \u201cConstitution is higher than the Parliament.\u201d That was widely seen as a response to remarks by Prime Minister Shahid Khaqan Abbasi, a Sharif loyalist, that the court was insulting politicians and denying lawmakers the right to legislate.\n\nAnalysts said the court verdict was a setback for Mr. Sharif but one that he could use to his advantage.\n\n\u201cFor Nawaz Sharif, the court ruling has come at a very wrong time procedurally,\u201d said Talat Hussain, a popular talk show host and columnist. \u201cHe was counting on having his candidates in the Senate, and now that is in a state of limbo.\u201d", "title": "Pakistan\u2019s Top Court Rules Ousted Leader Can\u2019t Head Political Party", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Pamela Jean McMurray and Sherry Lynn Christian were married Feb. 10 at the Hausmann Nature Center in Delafield, Wis. Anna Hirt, a Universal Life minister and friend of the couple, officiated.\n\nDr. McMurray (left), 54, is a clinical neuropsychologist in private practice in Waukesha, Wis. She is a former member of the Air Force, having enlisted in 1981, and later serving as a cryptographic maintenance technician from 1982-1988, the year she was honorably discharged from active duty with the rank of sergeant. She was a member of the Missouri Air National Guard at Jefferson Barracks in St. Louis from 1988-1990. She graduated with honors from Southern Illinois University, Edwardsville, and received a Ph.D. in clinical psychology at Washington University in St. Louis. She also completed a post doctoral fellowship in clinical neuropsychology at Baylor.\n\nShe is the daughter of Donna C. McMurray and Robert H. McMurray of Ocala, Fla. Her mother retired as the secretary for the Department of Defense at the Rock Island Arsenal in Rock Island, Ill. Her father retired as a meat cutter at Oscar Mayer in Davenport, Iowa.\n\nMs. Christian, 53 is a Milwaukee-based health and safety manager for the Northern Plains District of the United Parcel Service. She graduated from Ohio State and received an M.B.A. from the University of Phoenix. She is a member of the executive board, and committee chair member of the Salvation Army in Milwaukee. She is a daughter of Delores A. Christian and Donnie R. Christian of Columbus, Ohio.", "title": "Pamela McMurray, Sherry Christian", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Six new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\nTHE IDIOT, by Elif Batuman. (Penguin, $16.) This loosely autobiographical novel \u2014 which our reviewer, Parul Sehgal, called \u201ca hefty, gorgeous, digressive slab of a book\u201d \u2014 charts the college life of Selin, a bookish na\u00eff at Harvard in the mid-1990s. The story borrows from Batuman\u2019s earlier work \u2014 heavy on Russophilia and kooky anecdotes \u2014 but offers a portrait of the intellectual and emotional development of an irresistible narrator.\n\nTHE GAMES: A Global History of the Olympics, by David Goldblatt. (Norton, $17.95.) Goldblatt traces the glories and the stumbles of the modern Games, first held in Athens in 1896. Sexism, anti-Semitism and racism have all plagued the Olympics for decades, as have scandals over worker conditions and concerns about doping. The book delves into the origins of beloved events like the marathon.\n\nSHADOWBAHN, by Steve Erickson. (Blue Rider, $16.) Twenty years after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the twin towers inexplicably crop up in the South Dakota badlands, inhabited by Elvis\u2019s stillborn twin brother. Our reviewer, Fiona Maazel, compared the novel to \u201ca polyphonic dirge for an America that has perhaps never lived anywhere but in the imagination of those of us who keep fighting for it anyway.\u201d\n\nWHITE TEARS, by Hari Kunzru. (Vintage, $16.) Seth and Carter, two 20-something New Yorkers, are music-obsessed and imagine themselves as cutting-edge producers. The pair release a track \u2014 a recent recording from Washington Square \u2014 but pass it off as a relic from Charlie Shaw, a singer of their invention supposedly lost to history. When the hoax gets traction, it sets off a ghost story that touches on appropriation, race and the blues. The novel benefits from Kunzru\u2019s cleareyed and canny view of America\u2019s cultural shifts.", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Six new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\nDEVIL\u2019S BARGAIN: Steve Bannon, Donald Trump, and the Nationalist Uprising, by Joshua Green. (Penguin, $17.) Green\u2019s deeply reported account explores Bannon\u2019s origin story and how he helped pull off a major political upset: the election of Donald J. Trump. Their partnership \u2014 and shared talents for whipping up spectacle and outrage \u2014 ushered in what Bannon saw as the culmination of a global populist uprising.\n\nRUNNING, by Cara Hoffman. (Simon & Schuster, $16.) It\u2019s 1988 in Athens, and a group of hustlers roam the city\u2019s underbelly. Bridley, who has left the United States behind, joins a British couple, Jasper and Milo, and is soon folded into their relationship. Our reviewer, Justin Torres, praised these \u201cmemorable antiheroes,\u201d calling them \u201ctough and resourceful, scarred, feral and sexy.\u201d\n\nSTALIN AND THE SCIENTISTS: A History of Triumph and Tragedy 1905-1953, by Simon Ings. (Grove, $19.) For the founders of the Soviet Union, science was always a pillar of the state. But for scientists, the stakes were higher: If they published research the government did not endorse, they faced jail, exile or death. Ings offers a fascinating look at this establishment, which he calls \u201cthe glory and the laughingstock of the intellectual world.\u201d\n\nNEW BOY, by Tracy Chevalier. (Hogarth, $15.) In Chevalier\u2019s retelling of \u201cOthello,\u201d part of Hogarth\u2019s series of novels revising Shakespeare plays, the events unfold over a single day on a Washington playground. When O, a sixth grader from Ghana, arrives at his new school in the 1970s, Dee, the most popular girl, is immediately drawn to him. As children and teachers alike weigh their unease with a black student in the school, a malicious classmate tries to torpedo the friendship \u2014 with a shocking conclusion.", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSix new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\nTHE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD, by Colson Whitehead. (Anchor, $16.95.) Whitehead\u2019s boldly inventive novel follows Cora, a slave in Georgia making her escape to freedom on a literal underground railroad. As she encounters horror after horror, the story trains an eye on aspects of black history too often co-opted by white narrators. This book, one of the Book Review\u2019s 10 best of 2016, won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 2017.\n\nCANNIBALISM: A Perfectly Natural History, by Bill Schutt. (Algonquin, $16.95.) It wasn\u2019t just the Donner party. Cannibalism is often the rule, not the exception, for many species. Schutt\u2019s breezy tone helps keep disgust at bay, and the book is full of surprising detail: In China, for example, elites during the Yuan dynasty (1271-1368) regularly feasted on humans, and the practice continued well into the late 1960s.\n\nA PIECE OF THE WORLD, by Christina Baker Kline. (William Morrow/HarperCollins, $16.99.) Kline imagines the inner life of the woman with polio crawling across a desolate field in Andrew Wyeth\u2019s iconic painting, \u201cChristina\u2019s World.\u201d \u201cBoth painter and writer have a fine-grained feel for the setting,\u201d our reviewer, Becky Aikman, wrote. \u201cChristina\u2019s yearning, her determination, her will to dream, occupy the emotional center in both the novel and the painting.\u201d\n\nPHENOMENA: The Secret History of the U.S. Government\u2019s Investigation Into Extrasensory Perception and Psychokinesis, by Annie Jacobsen. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $17.99.) For decades, the military has tried to harness the supernatural \u2014 to find hostages, for example, or to read foreign governments\u2019 minds. Jacobsen\u2019s account is full of entertaining anecdotes; she catalogs the seers, the spoon-benders and the researchers who administered ESP tests to plants, all funded in the interest of national security.\n\nILL WILL, by Dan Chaon. (Ballantine, $17.) This dark literary thriller deals with recovered memories, satanistic ritual and childhood trauma. Dustin, a psychologist in his 40s, is grappling with a tragic past: His parents, aunt and uncle were murdered and his adopted brother, Rusty, was convicted of the crime. But new DNA evidence helped overturn the ruling, and Rusty\u2019s exoneration stirs up long-repressed guilt and fear.\n\nMY UTMOST: A Devotional Memoir, by Macy Halford. (Vintage, $17.) \u201cMy Utmost for His Highest,\u201d a book loved by evangelicals, was central to Halford\u2019s faith when she was growing up. Years later, as her beliefs shifted, she investigated the book\u2019s origins and its author, Oswald Chambers. Her memoir is both a mediation on \u201ca complicated nostalgia\u201d for the faith of her childhood and an intellectual biography of Chambers.", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": ["Joumana Khatib"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "THE CRISIS OF THE MIDDLE-CLASS CONSTITUTION: Why Economic Inequality Threatens Our Republic, by Ganesh Sitaraman. (Vintage, $17.) The Constitution was predicated on having a thriving middle class, and today\u2019s widening inequality poses an existential threat. In this call to arms, Sitaraman excels in \u201chelping understand how our forebears handled it and building a platform to think about it today,\u201d Angus Deaton wrote here.\n\nLINCOLN IN THE BARDO, by George Saunders. (Random House, $17.) In 1862, Abraham Lincoln visits the grave of his young son Willie, where he encounters a chorus of ghosts in limbo. Their voices \u2014 of slaves and slavers, doomed soldiers, priests \u2014 narrate the country\u2019s descent into war; as Lincoln mourns he becomes a steward of the nation's tragedies. The novel won the 2017 Man Booker Prize.\n\nBLEAKER HOUSE: Chasing My Novel to the End of the World, by Nell Stevens. (Anchor, $17.) As part of her M.F.A. program, Stevens is awarded a fellowship to travel virtually anywhere; she chooses the remote Falkland Islands to complete a book. Her memoir traces the fits and starts of the writing process and shares some hard-won insight. \u201cSurrounded by people, it is easy to feel alone,\u201d she writes. \u201cSurrounded by penguins, less so.\u201d\n\nA SEPARATION, by Katie Kitamura. (Riverhead, $16.) An unnamed, 30-ish British narrator tracks down her estranged husband, Christopher, in Greece after her mother-in-law intervenes; Christopher is traced to the southern Peloponnese, where he\u2019s supposedly studying mourning rites \u2014 and where marital deception proliferates. Our reviewer, Fernanda Eberstadt, praised the novel\u2019s \u201cradical disbelief \u2014 a disbelief, it appears, even in the power of art \u2014 that makes Kitamura\u2019s accomplished novel such a coolly unsettling work.\u201d", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump used the event to pitch his own ideas about how to prevent such debacles in the future, polling the group about whether they supported allowing teachers and other school employees to carry concealed weapons, an idea he said could have halted the carnage in Parkland.\n\n\u201cThat coach was very brave, saved a lot of lives, I suspect,\u201d Mr. Trump said, apparently referring to Aaron Feis, a coach at Stoneman Douglas who reportedly died using his body as a shield to protect students. \u201cBut if he had a firearm, he wouldn\u2019t have had to run, he would have shot and that would have been the end of it.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nMr. Trump said he would press to strengthen background checks for people buying guns and press for enhanced mental health measures. \u201cWe\u2019re going to go very strongly into age \u2014 age of purchase,\u201d he added, appearing to refer to a proposal to set an age threshold for buying certain weapons, including the AR-15.\n\nBut in a session that began as a subdued conversation and sometimes descended into tears and shouting, policy proposals were overshadowed by raw expressions of fear, anger and sorrow.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re here because my daughter has no voice \u2014 she was murdered last week, and she was taken from us, shot nine times,\u201d said Andrew Pollack, whose daughter Meadow was one of the 17 killed in Parkland. \u201cHow many schools, how many children have to get shot? It stops here, with this administration and me, because I\u2019m not going to sleep until it\u2019s fixed.\u201d\n\nMost of the students and parents invited from the Florida school appeared to support Mr. Trump, many of them prefacing their comments with praise for his leadership. But even fans of the president vented anger and desperation, laying the challenge of responding to the tragedy at his feet.\n\n\u201cIt should have been one school shooting, and we should have fixed it \u2014 and I\u2019m pissed,\u201d said Mr. Pollack, the only parent of a child killed in Parkland who was at the session, raising his voice as he looked at Mr. Trump. \u201cBecause my daughter, I\u2019m not going to see again.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSamuel Zeif, 18, told of texting his parents and brothers from the second floor of Stoneman Douglas, believing that he would be killed, and he dissolved into tears as he begged the president, \u201cLet\u2019s never let this happen again \u2014 please, please.\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t understand why I can still go in a store and buy a weapon of war, an A-R,\u201d Mr. Zeif said, referring to the AR-15 rifle. \u201cHow is it that easy to buy this type of weapon? How do we not stop this after Columbine, after Sandy Hook? I\u2019m sitting with a mother who lost her son. It\u2019s still happening.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Trump, who has often struggled to express empathy in the face of tragedy, appeared moved by the personal stories, even as he asked repeatedly whether anyone in the ornate room at the White House knew how such horrors could be prevented.\n\n\u201cI know you\u2019ve been through a lot \u2014 most of you have been through a lot more than you ever thought possible,\u201d Mr. Trump said, seated in a circle with students and parents. \u201cAll I can say is that we\u2019re fighting hard for you, and we will not stop.\u201d\n\n\u201cI grieve for you,\u201d Mr. Trump added. \u201cTo me, there could be nothing worse than what you\u2019ve gone through.\u201d\n\nDuring the session, Mr. Trump held a card that appeared to remind him of the basics of compassion when dealing with grieving survivors. \u201cWhat would you most want me to know about your experience?\u201d read one handwritten note on the card, captured in photographs of the event. \u201cI hear you,\u201d read another.\n\nMr. Pollack said he did not favor adopting new gun restrictions, but pleaded for Democrats and Republicans to come together to create new school safety measures.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not about gun laws right now \u2014 that\u2019s another fight, another battle,\u201d he said. \u201cWe need our children safe.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet the subtext of the discussion was a contentious debate over gun restrictions and an all-too-familiar cycle of outrage, activism and promises of action, and then the inevitable inertia of Washington because of the opposition by the National Rifle Association and its allies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Trump, a strident defender of gun rights who ran for office with the strong backing of the N.R.A., has come under immense pressure to endorse new gun limits after the Parkland massacre. The mass shooting has prompted a wave of youth activism that has reverberated from South Florida to Washington, where hundreds of students gathered outside the White House gates on Wednesday before the listening session, chanting, \u201cEnough is enough!\u201d and, \u201cHands up! \u2014 Don\u2019t shoot!\u201d\n\nMark Barden, who lost his 7-year-old son Daniel at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., in 2012, said it was futile to believe Congress would act on new policies.\n\n\u201cWe tried this legislative approach,\u201d said Mr. Barden, a founder and managing director of Sandy Hook Promise, a nonprofit advocacy group created after the massacre. \u201cI\u2019ve been in this building before many times, wringing our hands, pleading with legislators \u2014 \u2018What can we do?\u2019 \u2014 until we finally said we have to go home and do this ourselves.\u201d\n\nHe and Nicole Hockley, who lost her 6-year-old son Dylan at Sandy Hook, pressed Mr. Trump to consider prevention programs that train schools and educators to identify students in crisis and intervene before they attempt to harm themselves or others.\n\n\u201cRather than arm them with a firearm,\u201d Ms. Hockley said of teachers, \u201cI would rather arm them with the knowledge of how to prevent these acts from happening in the first place.\u201d\n\nOne of Mr. Pollack\u2019s sons, Hunter, said he would prefer that educators carried weapons, arguing that more firearms on campus would lead to safer schools.\n\nYet it was the emotional appeals that appeared to have more influence on Mr. Trump.\n\nMr. Barden pulled out a photograph of his son showing a gaptoothed grin.\n\nMr. Pollack spoke movingly of \u201cmy beautiful daughter I\u2019m never going to see again.\u201d\n\nMs. Hockley implored the president not to allow another massacre of children on his watch, saying: \u201cConsider your own children. You don\u2019t want to be me \u2014 no parent does.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs he ended the session, Mr. Trump promised their stories would not go unheard or unaddressed.\n\n\u201cThank you for pouring out your hearts,\u201d he said. \u201cBecause the world is watching, and we\u2019re going to come up with a solution.\u201d", "title": "Parents and Students Plead With Trump: \u2018How Many Children Have to Get Shot?\u2019", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "I would like to apologize to all the parents I mocked for taking videos at elementary school performances and soccer games a couple of decades ago when my children \u2014 and theirs \u2014 were young. I can remember exchanging eye-rolls with friends or with my husband when some mommy or daddy with a big state-of-the-art video camera popped up in the row in front of me at a school assembly, or pushed through the crowd to run up and down the soccer sidelines following the ball.\n\nWho on earth would ever watch those videos, we wondered. How sad, we said to one another, to see the big moment through a viewfinder. We didn\u2019t own a video camera, and we were a bit smug about it; we were the parents who actually watched the soccer game, or the play, who participated in the party instead of filming it.\n\nA couple of weeks ago, I was admiring a 6-month-old baby whose mother had brought him to a baby-read-aloud event. The mother told me that her older daughter, who was 3, was always trying to read books to her little brother. Then she took out her phone and showed me a video of the toddler performing for the baby, pointing to the pictures, reciting the story. It was spectacularly adorable; both children were clearly highly entertained by what was going on, you could see the teacherly character of the 3-year-old and the way the baby delighted in her attention.\n\nI said all the right things \u2014 what a great kid your daughter is, and her brother is going to love books so much because of this, and you have such a beautiful family \u2014 but deep inside I was mourning the fact that I cannot reach into my pocket and tap my phone and see my daughter in action when she was 3. I can\u2019t see any of my children as babies or toddlers or preschoolers or elementary school kids. And while I don\u2019t actually crave footage of those eternal soccer games, which, to be honest, bored me even at the time, and while I would still rather watch a performance \u2014 or a graduation \u2014 than film it, I really wish I had videos of a few of those moments.", "title": "Parents, I Was Smug About Your Videos of Your Children. I\u2019m Sorry.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Some who have in the past sought to placate the N.R.A. are now attempting to make amends with the left: In Minnesota, Representative Tim Walz, a Democratic candidate for governor embroiled in a contested primary, posted an apologetic note on Facebook after the Parkland shooting, endorsing an assault weapons ban and acknowledging \u201ccriticisms from those who take issue with my past campaign contributions from the N.R.A.\u201d\n\nMr. Walz, a military veteran from rural southern Minnesota whom the N.R.A. has endorsed in the past, said he is now determined to \u201cget the N.R.A. out of the way, and get us to the common-sense solutions that we all agree on.\u201d\n\nBut his Democratic opponents see an opening.\n\n\u201cIt has become a huge issue,\u201d said Rebecca Otto, the Democratic state auditor. \u201cThe only thing that has changed about Congressman Walz is he\u2019s now running for governor.\u201d\n\nIn South Carolina, State Representative James Smith, the front-runner for the Democratic nomination for governor, has faced attacks in the primary race from a businessman, Phil Noble, for having received an \u201cA\u201d rating from the N.R.A. for several years. In Ohio, Mr. Cordray unveiled a more stringent gun violence platform last week amid criticism from Mr. Kucinich of his past relationship with the N.R.A.\n\nMr. Cordray said in an interview that the Parkland shooting had prompted a reassessment of existing policies even among people who back broader gun rights. He has called for greatly expanded background checks and said lawmakers should \u201crethink\u201d regulation of assault weapons, stopping short of demanding an outright ban. Mr. Cordray also cautioned that there are many voters in rural areas who \u201cfeel strongly about the Second Amendment and their right to have guns for hunting, for self-defense.\u201d\n\nIn Florida, Gwen Graham, whose primary political calling card has been her ability to win over Republican voters, wasted no time calling for new gun regulations after the Parkland shooting, including a suspension on sales of AR-15 rifles. But Ms. Graham, who previously represented a conservative stretch of the state\u2019s panhandle in Congress, will surely face scrutiny in her primary for making more pro-gun comments when she was a congressional candidate facing opposition from the N.R.A.\n\nEven before the Florida shooting, however, the ranks of staunchly N.R.A.-aligned Democrats had dwindled to the point of near-extinction. After the party\u2019s losses in the 2010 and 2014 elections, only a small group of Democrats from rural, solidly Republican areas remain in Congress. Of the five Senate Democrats who voted against a 2013 bill to expand background checks for gun purchasers, just one \u2014 Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota \u2014 is still in office.", "title": "Parkland Massacre Thrusts Guns Into the Midterm Spotlight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "State lawmakers, however, rejected an effort to debate an assault weapons ban, in a party-line vote.\n\n\u2022 The students have emerged as passionate advocates for change, but parts of the right-wing media have portrayed them as pawns and conspiracists. An aide to a Florida legislator was fired on Tuesday after calling the Parkland students actors.\n\nBilly Graham dies at 99\n\n\u2022 The Rev. Billy Graham preached to millions in stadium events he called crusades, becoming a pastor to presidents and America\u2019s best-known Christian evangelist for more than 60 years. He died today at his home in North Carolina.\n\nMr. Graham took the role of evangelist to a new level, lifting it from canvas tents in small towns to packed stadiums in the world\u2019s major cities. He wrote some 30 books and was among the first to use new communication technologies for religious purposes.\n\n\u2022 \u201cThis is not mass evangelism,\u201d Mr. Graham liked to say, \u201cbut personal evangelism on a mass scale.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nRussia investigation broadens\n\n\u2022 The son-in-law of a Russia-based billionaire pleaded guilty on Tuesday to lying to U.S. investigators about his contact with Rick Gates, a former Trump campaign aide.\n\nAlex van der Zwaan, a lawyer, also acknowledged deleting emails sought in the special counsel\u2019s inquiry into Russian election interference. It is the seventh criminal case that the team led by Robert Mueller has brought since October.\n\n\u2022 Separately, Jared Kushner, President Trump\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser, is said to be resisting giving up his high-level security access, as John Kelly, the White House chief of staff, pushes to revamp the clearance process.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHot water gets hotter for Netanyahu\n\n\u2022 Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has already been accused of accepting nearly $300,000 in bribes.\n\nOn Tuesday, one of his top advisers was said to have sought to bribe a judge into dropping an investigation of Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s wife, and several of the leader\u2019s friends and confidants were arrested as part of another inquiry.\n\n\u2022 Mr. Netanyahu denies the new accusations. He and his associates could face charges of obstructing justice.\n\nThe Daily Listen to \u2018The Daily\u2019: Russian Trolls\u2019 Favorite Weapon The indictment secured by the special counsel makes it clear that Facebook was used extensively in the campaign to disrupt the 2016 election. How did Russia do it? Audio\n\nPhoto\n\nBusiness\n\n\u2022 The U.S. could hardly be less prepared for the next recession, our economics columnist writes.\n\n\u2022 Social media companies often fail to enforce their policies against impersonation, an examination by The Times found, enabling the spread of fake news and propaganda \u2014 and allowing a global black market in social identities to thrive.\n\n\u2022 Venezuela has begun selling a virtual currency, backed by its vast petroleum reserves, to try to address one of the most severe economic collapses of modern times.\n\n\u2022 Taking the C out of KFC: The fast-food chain was forced to close about half of its 900 outlets in Britain after a chicken shortage.\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks were down on Tuesday. Here\u2019s a snapshot of global markets today.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\n\u2022 Counting calories is not the key to weight loss, a new study says.\n\n\u2022 Stylists share some practical tips for salvaging dry winter hair. (Treat it like cashmere.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 An easy fish chowder still carries the spirit of the sea.\n\nNoteworthy\n\n\u2022 The price Lindsey Vonn has paid\n\nThe 33-year-old American skier, who has sustained many injuries in her quest for greatness, explained some of them to The Times. She won the third Olympic medal of her career today at the Winter Games, capturing bronze in the downhill.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlso today, Kikkan Randall and Jessie Diggins became the first American cross-country skiers to win a medal at the Games since 1976, one of the longest droughts for the U.S. at the Olympics.\n\nHere are today\u2019s results from Pyeongchang, South Korea. Find all our coverage here.\n\n\u2022 Basketball title is erased\n\nThe Louisville men\u2019s basketball program must forfeit the 2013 N.C.A.A. tournament championship and 122 other victories over four seasons as punishment for a sex scandal involving players.\n\nIt\u2019s the first time the N.C.A.A. has stripped a program of the Division I men\u2019s title.\n\n\u2022 The hunt for produce in Alaska\n\nThe nights are long at this time of year, and Alaskans yearn for fruits and vegetables that shoppers in other states take for granted.\n\n(You\u2019ll never look at a pear the same way again after reading one chef\u2019s description.)\n\nPhoto\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Best of late-night TV\n\nStephen Colbert expressed solidarity with the students who are calling for gun control legislation. \u201cUntil we do something about guns, you can\u2019t vote if you\u2019re over 18.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cI cried when I heard. I am thrilled. I am delighted. And most of all, I want to meet this girl. I want to hear her voice.\u201d\n\n\u2014 David Code, a former member of the Whiffenpoofs at Yale, the nation\u2019s oldest collegiate a cappella chorus, after the group admitted its first female member. In 1987, Mr. Code unsuccessfully lobbied the Whiffenpoofs to admit women, decades after Yale went coed.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\nGerald Holtom, the Briton who designed the peace symbol, was in \u201cdeep despair\u201d when he created it on this day in 1958.\n\n\u201cI drew myself,\u201d wrote Mr. Holtom, a World War II conscientious objector who was alarmed by the nuclear arms race. \u201cThe representative of an individual in despair, with hands palm outstretched outward and downward in the manner of Goya\u2019s peasant before the firing squad.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe symbol also combined the semaphores, or flag-signaling codes, for the letters \u201cN\u201d and \u201cD,\u201d or \u201cNuclear Disarmament.\u201d The circle around it represented the earth.\n\nLater that spring, the symbol appeared on buttons and signs in an antinuclear march to the Atomic Weapons Research Establishment, a warhead factory in Aldermaston, England. (The march became an annual event.)\n\nThe symbol, which isn\u2019t trademarked, was embraced by the broader antiwar movement and disparaged by critics as anti-Christian.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Holtom is said to have later expressed a desire that the symbol be inverted so that it resembled hands reaching to the sky. Such a symbol, in addition to being more celebratory of peace, would also evoke the semaphore for the letter \u201cU\u201d \u2014 as in \u201cUnilateral Disarmament.\u201d\n\nThe Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, which still uses the symbol as its logo, is taking it on an anniversary tour around Britain this year.\n\nJennifer Jett contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Browse past briefings here.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning, or to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights. Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Parkland, Billy Graham, Lindsey Vonn: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Yesterday I was the keynote speaker \u2013 actually keynote have-a-chat-with-Anil Kashyap \u2013 at the U.S. Monetary Policy Forum \u2013 which was both interesting, I thought, and something of an emotional vacation. What I mean by that was that I got to have an extended policy discussion without once mentioning the name T****.\n\nAnyway, one of the issues that came up was the recovery in Europe, which is real and in some ways a bigger story for the world economy than the continuation of the Obama expansion here. An obvious question, which Anil raised, was whether this recovery calls for a reconsideration by Euroskeptics like myself. And my answer is no and yes: No, the economics of the euro look about as bad as we expected. Yes, we underestimated the political cohesion of the single currency, the willingness of political elites to suffer enormous economic pain in order to stay in the monetary union.\n\nI think I can illustrate all of these points with the case of Spain, which is in some ways at the heart of the euro story. During the good years money poured into Spain, fueling a huge housing bubble. This fed inflation that made Spanish industry uncompetitive, leading to a huge trade deficit. When the music stopped, Spain saw unemployment soar; it then went into a painful process of \u201cinternal devaluation,\u201d slowly squeezing down unit labor costs while costs in northern Europe gradually rose. And eventually this worked: Spain resumed fairly rapid growth, boosted by surging exports of autos and other manufactured goods.", "title": "Opinion | Paroling the Spanish Prisoner (Wonkish)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "Tricky Clues\n\nNot only did I find a lot of theme answers difficult, there was also a lot of fiendish fill today that, to put it mildly, discouraged my powers of deduction. I\u2019m referring to, among others, ITLL DO, FT LEE, HOT MIC, IBOOK and IN B. Also of note:\n\n5A: Before you get your 21st-century guff up over this quote, the quotee is Oscar WILDE, and his relationship to women was definitely too complex for one tweet.\n\n53A: I took the clue (\u201cStick for breaking things\u201d) too seriously and the grid not seriously enough, and figured maybe we were supposed to squish \u201ccudgels\u201d in there but the answer is CUES, which \u201cbreak\u201d the racked-up balls to start every game in pool.\n\n61A: Mizzen rang a bell, and it does sound pretty nautical (part of either a ship or a loom, I always say, and people don\u2019t cry from the tops of looms). So I figured \u201cland ho\u201d was instant filler. Instead it\u2019s SAIL HO, the opposite and a puzzle debut. Just as the former means that land was in view, \u201cSail ho!\u201d means that someone else at sea is somewhere in sight. Shiver me timbers.\n\n99A: Two very early writing systems, Cretan hieroglyphics and LINEAR A, are still considered undeciphered \u201cmissing links\u201d to European language systems. There are profuse writings available from ruins in Crete, but no Rosetta Stone with known languages to compare Linear A to, and the wide array of symbols that make it up create a complex mystery. There are references to commerce, religion and possibly puns.\n\n118A: Looking for a \u201cTrix alternative\u201d had me thinking about cereals; what Mr. Ginsberg wanted was another feminizing suffix, ETTE. One of my favorite terms is from \u201cThe Crying of Lot 49,\u201d by Thomas Pynchon, when the protagonist Oedipa Maas becomes the executrix of the Inverarity estate and the whole thing spins out from there. What a word! And it\u2019s been in the puzzle, but just once.\n\n39D: \u201cWack\u201d is not the same as \u201cwhack,\u201d even though we\u2019re doing these homophonic puns today. We usually think of it as \u201cbad,\u201d as in one of the \u201980s seminal phrases, \u201cCrack is wack\u201d. But it also helps make a wackjob, and has also been occasionally clued to mean crazy, or NUTSO. Confusingly enough, so has whackjob, meaning both \u201cnut\u201d (in 2010) and \u201chit man\u2019s hit\u201d (in 2003).\n\n102D: I suppose that there are space fans who already knew this (and how could it really have been anything but TANG?) \u2014 but I was surprised to learn that Buzz Aldrin didn\u2019t like it and that he even said so, as it seems like such a minor thing to notice in zero gravity. It turns out this gripe is one Mr. Aldrin didn\u2019t mention until very recently and then just as an unfavorable comparison to delicious Red Bull (I kid).\n\nConstructor Notes (with bonus puns!)\n\nThis was such a fun puzzle to make; I hope it was as much fun to solve! Since everything is a word, Dr. Fill rips through it with no mistakes in a few seconds. Will was very kind to my clues this time, using the vast majority of them and, as always, I found some of his changes interesting. I had gone with the slightly edgier [Bridgegate locale] for 19D and with [Death of a telethon host?] for 35A. Not sure what people will think of those. Will also removed my slightly political [Company that recalled 18 million products after outsourcing production to China in 2002] for 40A. I had clued 9D as [Start of something big] and was sorry to see that changed. I never know where to clue fill as an abbreviation. So, for example, my clue for 100D involved a couple of actresses. 110D was [Am partner] and 106A was [Baby / pigeon commonality]. I\u2019d love to hear what people think of these changes and I\u2019ll hopefully learn something! Mostly, though, I had a great time finding the ever-so-painful puns and then subjecting everyone where I work to them. Hopefully all of you groaned as much as they did. I guess I\u2019d be remiss not to include some of the words that wound up on the cutting room floor. Here are the clues; the answers are below in a random order. What a wild stallion may do Asked for help Like \u201cgo fly a kite\u201d Plain ol\u2019 spud Drag Karl around Passover celebration for the staff COMMENTATOR SAUTEED CRUSADER BUXOM HALLMARKS FORWARD\n\nWhat did you think?", "title": "Paronomasia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "When Teva Pharmaceuticals announced recently that it would begin selling a copycat version of Syprine \u2014 an expensive drug invented in the 1960s \u2014 the news seemed like a welcome development for people taking old drugs that have skyrocketed in price.\n\nSyprine, which treats a rare condition known as Wilson disease, gained notoriety after Valeant Pharmaceuticals International raised the price of the drug to $21,267 in 2015 from $652 just five years earlier. Along with similar practices by pharmaceutical executives like Martin Shkreli of Turing Pharmaceuticals and Heather Bresch of Mylan (the maker of the EpiPen), the story helped spark a national conversation about the high cost of prescription drugs, not to mention Congressional inquiries and federal investigations.\n\nIn promoting its \u201clower-cost\u201d alternative to Syprine, a Teva executive boasted in a news release that the product \u201cillustrates Teva\u2019s commitment to serving patient populations in need.\u201d\n\nWhat the release didn\u2019t mention was the price: Teva\u2019s new generic will cost $18,375 for a bottle of 100 pills, according to Elsevier\u2019s Gold Standard Drug Database. That\u2019s 28 times what Syprine cost in 2010, and hardly the discount many patients were waiting for.", "title": "Patients Eagerly Awaited a Generic Drug. Then They Saw the Price.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The Frustacis resolved to have the babies, despite the medical risks. On May 21, 1985, Ms. Frustaci delivered four boys and three girls by cesarean section, about 12 weeks premature. Intense news coverage ensued, with many outlets calling the birth the largest in the United States, even though the seventh child, a girl named Christina, was stillborn.\n\nThe six surviving children all had heart problems, jaundice and hyaline membrane disease, a respiratory ailment. They were whisked into intensive care, where a team of neonatal doctors struggled to save them. One of the babies, a boy named David, died about three days after he was born.\n\nMs. Frustaci spent more than a week in the hospital recovering. She got to hold her surviving children in the neonatal intensive care unit before she left the hospital in early June. The children remained in intensive care.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re beautiful,\u201d she told reporters when she left. \u201cI just hope they live.\u201d\n\nTwo others, a daughter named Bonnie and a son named James, died before the three remaining children \u2014 Stephen, Richard and Patricia \u2014 went home.\n\nAll three of the surviving septuplets faced grave health concerns that initially required near-constant care.\n\nIn October 1985, the couple sued the Tyler Medical Clinic, the fertility center in Los Angeles that had overseen Ms. Frustaci\u2019s treatment, and Dr. Jaroslav Marik, a fertility specialist there, alleging malpractice.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe suit contended that Ms. Frustaci had not been properly monitored early in her pregnancy and that the dose of Perganol she had received was too high. Dr. Marik contended that Ms. Frustaci had been negligent in failing to obtain the ultrasound treatments he had recommended.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe suit was settled in 1990 for a one-time payment of $450,000 and a monthly care payment for each of the three surviving septuplets, who needed extensive physical therapy and medical treatment. The Frustacis\u2019 son Joseph said that the family still received the payments, and that the total amount paid so far had exceeded $1.5 million.\n\nThe difficulties of raising her family did not dissuade Ms. Frustaci from adding to it. In 1990, after undergoing further fertility treatments, she gave birth to healthy twins, Jordan and Jaclyn.\n\nShe was born Patricia Ann Jorgensen on Nov. 19, 1954, at Hill Air Force Base in Utah. Her father, Richard, was in the Air Force and later ran an advertising agency; her mother, the former Bonnie Palfreyman, was a homemaker.\n\nMs. Frustaci received a bachelor\u2019s degree in English from Brigham Young University in the mid-1970s and went on to earn a master\u2019s from California State University, Fullerton. She married Mr. Frustaci in 1981, and they soon tried to start a family.\n\nThe news media coverage of the septuplets opened the Frustacis to some criticism. \u201cOne baby is excellent,\u201d Dr. Heather Irwin, a gynecologist and fertility specialist, told The Miami Herald in late May 1985. \u201cTwo is acceptable. Anything more than twins is bad medicine.\u201d\n\nThe Frustacis felt compelled to defend themselves. \u201cBy no means did we set out to have twins or triplets or more than one child,\u201d Mr. Frustaci told The Times, adding, \u201cWe were not out to set any records.\u201d\n\nIn an interview, Joseph Frustaci said that the media attention, and the criticism, had made it even harder for his mother to deal with the loss of her children.\n\n\u201cReally, all she wanted was to be a mother, and I think the media got in the way, for a time, of her being able to be a loving and nurturing mother,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe ordeal took a toll on the family, and particularly on Ms. Frustaci, who had bipolar disorder. She and Mr. Frustaci, an industrial equipment salesman, were divorced in the mid-1990s.\n\nIn addition to her son Joseph, she is survived by her other children; her mother; three sisters, Julie Lindahl, Susan Ahlman and Joyce Wilson; three brothers, Richard, David and Scott; and five grandchildren.\n\nJoseph Frustaci said that even through the difficult years his mother \u201cwas really the strength of the family.\u201d All three of the surviving septuplets are doing well, he said. Her daughter Patti Carpenter is married with two children; her son Richard lives independently; and her son Stephen is cared for by his father.", "title": "Patricia Frustaci, 63, Dies; Septuplets Put Her in Spotlight", "authors": ["Daniel E. Slotnik"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif. \u2014 Patrick Cantlay and Tony Finau each carded a five-under-par 66 on Thursday to share the overnight lead in the Genesis Open.\n\nPlay was suspended by darkness at Riviera Country Club with 12 golfers yet to complete the first round. The opening round will conclude Friday morning, ahead of the second round.\n\nTiger Woods, in his second tournament of the year after a layoff for spinal surgery, was tied for 63rd after a one-over 72. Woods\u2019s playing partners both fared better, with Justin Thomas shooting 69 and Northern Ireland\u2019s Rory McIlroy shooting 71.\n\nWoods, who had a difficult time off the tee at Torrey Pines three weeks ago, turned to a driver like one he used in the past. He said he was happy with it, despite wayward tee shots early, including his first using the driver. It was on his second hole, and the ball disappeared into some eucalyptus trees; Woods ended up with a double bogey.", "title": "Patrick Cantlay and Tony Finau Share Lead in a Suspended First Round at Riviera", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "A.I. \u201crecognizes objects, but can\u2019t explain what it sees. It can\u2019t read a textbook and understand the questions in the back of the book,\u201d said Oren Etzioni, a former University of Washington professor who oversees the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence. \u201cIt is devoid of common sense.\u201d\n\nSuccess may require years or even decades of work \u2014 if it comes at all. Others have tried to digitize common sense, and the task has always proved too large.\n\nIn the mid-1980s, Doug Lenat, a former Stanford University professor, with backing from the government and several of the country\u2019s largest tech companies, started a project called Cyc. He and his team of researchers worked to codify all the simple truths that we learn as children, from \u201cyou can\u2019t be in two places at the same time\u201d to \u201cwhen drinking from a cup, hold the open end up.\u201d\n\nThirty years later, Mr. Lenat and his team are still at work on this \u201ccommon sense engine\u201d \u2014 with no end in sight.", "title": "Paul Allen Wants to Teach Machines Common Sense", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Speaker Paul D. Ryan faced a backlash on Saturday after he pointed to a secretary\u2019s $1.50 weekly increase in take-home pay as a sign of the Republican tax plan\u2019s success.\n\n\u201cA secretary at a public high school in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, said she was pleasantly surprised her pay went up $1.50 a week ... she said [that] will more than cover her Costco membership for the year,\u201d Mr. Ryan posted on Twitter, sharing an Associated Press report about paycheck increases under the $1.5 trillion tax overhaul.\n\nMr. Ryan deleted the Twitter post in hours, however, after lawmakers and social media users criticized him for appearing out of touch.\n\n\u201cThat tweet about the $1.50 a week is not a PR mistake,\u201d Senator Brian Schatz, Democrat of Hawaii, wrote on Twitter. \u201cIt is really what they think.\u201d", "title": "Paul Ryan Deletes Tweet Lauding a $1.50 Benefit From the New Tax Law", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Chicago still has a long way to go. Its math and reading scores remain below the national average, for example. But its recent progress is exciting, especially given the city\u2019s diverse population and relatively high poverty rate.\n\nThe city\u2019s students \u201cappear to be learning faster than those in almost every other school system in the country, according to new data from researchers at Stanford,\u201d Emily Badger and Kevin Quealy of The Times recently wrote.\n\nIn The Washington Post last week, Karin Chenoweth wrote, \u201cIf we as a country are really serious about wanting to improve schools and education, we should be studying Chicago.\u201d\n\nThe gains haven\u2019t come easily, though. They have involved, among other things, greater accountability for school leaders and the closure of some underperforming schools. In a Times op-ed today, Tamar Manasseh makes the case against the next round of Chicago\u2019s school closures, calling previous ones \u201ca fiasco.\u201d\n\nI disagree. For too long, school systems have been unwilling to crack down on failing schools. As traumatic as closures can be, they can lead to real progress, as has happened in Chicago. In most other parts of society, after all, institutions aren\u2019t allowed to fail year after year, without consequence.\n\nFor more on Chicago, I wrote about its schools last year, focusing on the role that principals have played. You can also read the Stanford University study. And The Chicago Tribune explained the latest development yesterday: a three-year phaseout, rather than a 2018 closing, for three high schools.\n\nAs usual, I encourage you to read both sides of the debate.\n\nFollow up. Lucas Dolan of American University responded to my column about Trumpism-for-thee-and-not-for-me by noting on Twitter that populist demagogues in other countries have followed a similar pattern. They\u2019ve exempted their own supporters from their policy agenda.\n\nIn a follow-up email exchange, Dolan credited the political scientists Kurt Weyland and Jan-Werner M\u00fcller with introducing the term \u201cdiscriminatory legalism.\u201d They used it to describe the actions of demagogues like Venezuela\u2019s Hugo Ch\u00e1vez, who use the law to punish political opponents and give benefits to supporters.", "title": "Opinion | Paul Ryan and the Dreamers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "By Tacey Rychter\n\nWhen my fianc\u00e9 was a teenager growing up in the southeastern suburbs of Melbourne, he started taking guitar lessons from a new teacher in Collingwood. At the end of the lesson, he realized he didn\u2019t have any cash on him, but asked, \u201cHow much do I owe you for the lesson?\u201d\n\nThe guy said, \u201cJust a pineapple, but you can bring it next week.\u201d\n\nSo the next week Will came back with an actual pineapple, and said, \u201cWell, here\u2019s your pineapple.\u201d\n\nThe guy very politely explained that a \u201cpineapple\u201d is Aussie slang for the yellow $50 note (i.e. a $5 is a \u201cprawn,\u201d a $20 is a \u201clobster\u201d), and as hilarious as this was, asked if he could please bring the actual money next time.", "title": "Pay Me a Pineapple", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "And yet, as Mr. Bernstein acknowledges, tight labor markets are only part of the solution. For starters, they eventually end when the cycle turns \u2014 and wages can get stuck for a long time. And tight labor markets don\u2019t carry the power they used to.\n\nA 1999 study by the economists Lawrence Katz of Harvard University and Alan B. Krueger of Princeton University estimated how far the unemployment rate needed to decline to prevent wages from falling. From the mid-1970s to the late \u201980s, they found, an unemployment rate of 6.2 percent or lower would keep wages at the bottom tenth of the pay scale from declining. By the 1990s, however, unemployment had to dip to 5.7 percent to prevent wage losses at the bottom.\n\nJosh Bivens of the Economic Policy Institute replicated the exercise for the economic expansion that ended with the demise of the housing bubble in 2007: Unemployment, he found, had to fall below 4.6 percent to keep workers in the bottom 10 percent from losing ground.\n\nAt this pace, unemployment will soon have to hit zero for workers at the bottom to get a raise.\n\nSo what else can be done? There is obviously a role for training and education to help workers meet employers\u2019 rising demand for skills, especially at the beginning of their career. Fatih Guvenen of the University of Minnesota notes that the income of 25-year-old men starting their careers has declined sharply since the early 1970s and is now about where it was in the late \u201950s.\n\nBut a strategy focused on education will not tip the balance. As Heidi Shierholz of the Economic Policy Institute points out, the list of remedies is long. It includes raising the minimum wage, increasing unionization, banning mandatory arbitration for employment claims, ending arbitrary and unpredictable scheduling, and ensuring that companies that subcontract their low-wage work remain in some way accountable for the workers.\n\nOr how about restoring competition to labor markets? Mr. Krueger and Eric Posner of the University of Chicago write that the government could stop companies from forcing low-pay workers to sign noncompete covenants, which bar them from better-paid jobs elsewhere. It should also ban no-poaching arrangements of dubious legality among franchisees of the same company, which also close off workers\u2019 options.\n\nOver the last 50 years, employers have been allowed to exercise ever more sway over their workers. The share of private-sector workers covered by unions has dwindled to a sliver. Businesses have grown to imposing heft. All along, executives and policymakers have sold this rebalancing of power as a boon for competitiveness, efficiency and economic growth.", "title": "Paychecks Are Getting Bigger. Don\u2019t Get Too Used to It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which was born out of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act, immediately seized on the payday lending industry as one of its first targets, opening a complaint database, initiating investigations, filing lawsuits and formulating rules to prevent lenders from preying on consumers. According to the consumer agency, it has pursued more than 20 public enforcement actions against small-dollar lenders, many of which have resulted in large settlements.\n\nThe crackdown has had an effect. According to data from the Center for Financial Services Information, annual payday lending revenue dropped to $5.3 billion in 2017, from $9.2 billion in 2012. The number of payday loan stores dropped from a peak of 24,043 in 2007, to 16,480 in 2015, according to a recent report published by the consumer bureau.\n\nThe industry has long been a presence on Capitol Hill, but it spied an opening after Mr. Trump\u2019s election and the Republican takeover of Congress. The industry pushed lawmakers to repeal the consumer bureau\u2019s 2017 payday lending rule by using the Congressional Review Act to essentially kill it. A bipartisan group of lawmakers has sponsored such a resolution, though its viability remains uncertain. Since Mr. Trump\u2019s election, the payday lending lobby has also made its voice heard at the consumer bureau, flooding the agency with comments expressing opposition to the payday rule.\n\nAnd lenders have poured money into the coffers of influential Republican lawmakers. Lobbying donations peaked in 2012, when the bureau began to make payday lending a priority and have leveled off in the last year. Among the biggest recipients have been Representative Jeb Hensarling of Texas, the Republican chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, and Senator Mike Crapo of Idaho, the Republican chairman of the Senate Banking Committee.\n\nIn December, Mr. Hensarling, who has long accused the consumer bureau of overreach, said that \u201cno unelected Washington bureaucrat\u201d should be able to stop Americans from taking out the short-term loan that they wanted.\n\nPayday lenders have also looked for inroads with the president. A lender based in Ohio, Community Choice Financial, was one of the first clients of Corey Lewandowski, Mr. Trump\u2019s first campaign manager, who started a Washington consulting business last year. Over the summer, Mr. Lewandowski called on Mr. Trump in a television interview to fire Mr. Cordray.\n\nIn the spring, the industry will spend four days networking at the Trump National Doral Golf Club, which has event spaces like the Donald J. Trump Grand Ballroom and the Ivanka Trump Ballroom. Mr. Shaul said his group began looking at the Trump property as a potential site for its spring meeting well before the 2016 presidential election and ultimately chose it because it was cheaper than other East Coast resorts.", "title": "Payday Rules Relax on Trump\u2019s Watch After Lobbying by Lenders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHer idea of what it meant to be a collector also meant investing in the artist as a human being,\u201d Ms. Bumbray said. \u201cShe had a relationship with each individual. She didn\u2019t take it lightly. She practiced a radical kind of love, and we see that love truly manifest in the success of the artists she collected and nurtured so deeply.\u201d\n\nSimone Leigh, a multimedia artist whose work exploring African-American tropes and female identity was also championed by Ms. Cooper Cafritz, said of her: \u201cShe had a lot of faith that we could do well. She made you feel like the most important artist in the world. She saw that\u2019s what was needed.\u201d\n\nIn 2009, more than 300 pieces of art that she had spent years collecting were destroyed in a fire that ravaged the gabled and columned eight-bedroom estate Ms. Cooper Cafritz had built in 1986 with her husband at the time, Conrad Cafritz, a wealthy developer, in the Kent neighborhood of northwest Washington. Firefighters said there had not been adequate water pressure in the neighborhood\u2019s hydrants. In 2014, Ms. Cooper Cafritz settled a lawsuit with Washington\u2019s water authority for an undisclosed amount.\n\nAfter months of investigation, fire officials classified the cause of the fire as \u201cundetermined.\u201d\n\nThe house had long been a vibrant social hub for Washington\u2019s elites. There were political fund-raisers, including one for the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson\u2019s presidential campaign in 1988. When John F. Kennedy Jr. was looking for a place for a party in the capital to introduce his new magazine, George, Ms. Cooper Cafritz opened her doors to him.\n\nResilient and gruffly beguiling, Ms. Cooper seemed to juggle fame and catastrophe, much of it health-related. She once had emergency gallbladder surgery in Croatia during a doctor\u2019s strike, which put her in a coma; more recently there were two failed back surgeries and bouts of pneumonia, the last one putting her in Medstar Georgetown University Hospital, where she died.\n\nMs. Cooper Cafritz had been a fellow of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars and president of the District of Columbia Board of Education.", "title": "Peggy Cooper Cafritz, Patron of Black Artists, Dies at 70", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "At one point, perhaps running out of stories, Ms. Pelosi suggested she might turn to the Bible. \u201cPerhaps I should bring my rosary, blessed by the pope,\u201d she said.\n\nAn estimated 690,000 young undocumented immigrants have been protected under DACA, and roughly 1.1 million more are eligible but did not apply. When Mr. Trump suspended the program in September, he gave Congress six months to come up with a replacement. Democrats and their allies had hoped to use the must-pass spending bill to carry legislation to protect the Dreamers.\n\nSenator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, has promised an open debate in the Senate on immigration legislation, with senators of both parties allowed to offer amendments, if a deal is not reached by Thursday. Ms. Pelosi is calling on Speaker Paul D. Ryan to make a similar commitment in the House.\n\n\u201cOur basic request is to honor the House of Representatives, give us a chance to have a vote on the floor,\u201d she said as she wound down her talk on Wednesday night.\n\nBut a spokeswoman for Mr. Ryan, choosing her words carefully, suggested he had no intention of conducting a freewheeling House debate. \u201cSpeaker Ryan has already repeatedly stated we intend to do a DACA and immigration reform bill \u2014 one that the president supports,\u201d she said.\n\nImmigrants\u2019 rights advocates, meanwhile, are furious \u2014 not only with Republicans but also with Democrats for failing to exercise their leverage to ensure that the Dreamers would not be left behind.\n\n\u201cWe want a negotiated solution that\u2019s part of this spending bill, not a vague promise of floor action after it,\u201d said Frank Sharry, the executive director of America\u2019s Voice, an immigrants\u2019 rights group. \u201cWe\u2019re disappointed that a deal was cut without us, and we\u2019re on the outside looking in, and we\u2019re going to ask Democrats and Republicans who care about Dreamers to vote no.\u201d", "title": "Pelosi Held House Floor in Advocacy of \u2018Dreamers\u2019 for More Than 8 Hours", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, last week gave a marathon eight-hour speech on the floor of the House about the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers.\n\nDuring the majority of her remarks, Ms. Pelosi read testimonies and letters from Dreamers who had written to their representatives about their lives. But amid her nearly 75,000 words that are now part of the Congressional Record, Ms. Pelosi also cited some facts and figures about immigration policy and history. Below is an assessment of the veracity of those claims.\n\nMs. Pelosi cited imprecise poll numbers about American support for Dreamers.\n\nMs. Pelosi claimed that \u201c84 percent of Americans support a path to citizenship or permanent status for Dreamers; 88 percent of independents back the path of citizenship or permanent status; and 70 percent of Republicans back either citizenship or permanent status.\u201d\n\nHer numbers are slightly off.\n\nWhen reached by The Times, a spokesman for Ms. Pelosi cited a December poll from Quinnipiac University in which 77 percent of all respondents, 57 percent of Republicans and 81 percent of independents supported giving Dreamers a pathway to citizenship.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe poll also found that 7 percent of all respondents, 13 percent of Republicans and 7 percent of independents said Dreamers should be allowed to remain in the United States, but should not be allowed to apply for citizenship. That\u2019s not quite the same thing as supporting \u201cpermanent status.\u201d A Republican bill in the House, for example, would give Dreamers a three-year renewable legal status rather than permanent legal residency.", "title": "Pelosi Spoke for Eight Hours on Dreamers. Among them is Kim Yong-nam, the president of the Presidium of North Korea\u2019s Parliament, who serves as a nominal head of state and will lead a 22-member delegation of its officials making a rare visit to the South.\n\nSpeaking to reporters in Alaska during a stopover on his way to Japan and South Korea, Mr. Pence reiterated the administration\u2019s stance that \u201call options are on the table\u201d in confronting North Korea about its nuclear weapons and missile programs. He said part of the purpose of his visit was to tell \u201cthe truth about North Korea at every stop.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re traveling to the Olympics to make sure that North Korea doesn\u2019t use the powerful symbolism and the backdrop of the Winter Olympics to paper over the truth about their regime,\u201d he said, calling it \u201ca regime that oppresses its own people, a regime that threatens nations around the world, a regime that continues its headlong rush to develop nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles.\u201d", "title": "Pence Doesn\u2019t Rule Out Meeting North Koreans at Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "On Friday, North Korea announced it would send the only sister of its leader, Kim Jong-un, to South Korea as a member of its official delegation. That sets up at least the possibility of a landmark meeting with Mr. Pence, though Mr. Kim\u2019s sister, Kim Yo-jong, is under Treasury Department sanctions for her role in North Korea\u2019s human rights abuses, which would make a meeting highly unlikely.\n\nIndeed, Mr. Pence is drawing attention to abuses in North Korea at every stop of his Asia trip. He is bringing as a guest to the Games the father of Otto F. Warmbier, the Ohio college student who was imprisoned in Pyongyang and fell into an irreversible coma. Mr. Warmbier died soon after being returned to his parents, Fred and Cindy, in Cincinnati.\n\n\u201cWe will not allow North Korean propaganda to hijack the message and imagery of the Olympic Games,\u201d Mr. Pence said. \u201cWe will not allow North Korea to hide behind the Olympic banner the reality that they enslave their people and threaten the wider region.\u201d\n\nLast week, Mr. Trump paid tribute to Mr. Warmbier\u2019s parents, as well as a North Korean defector, Ji Seong-ho, during his State of the Union address. He later gathered Mr. Ji and other defectors in the White House, where they shared harrowing tales of imprisonment, abuse and escape from the North.\n\n\u201cThe human rights issue is creeping into their strategy,\u201d said Evan S. Prosecutors have accused Mr. Percoco, the governor\u2019s former executive deputy secretary, of trading his vast influence in New York State government for more than $300,000 in bribes.\n\nMr. Bohrer\u2019s description was markedly different from the one Mr. Percoco had cultivated during his time as the governor\u2019s \u201cenforcer,\u201d \u201chammer\u201d and top lieutenant in Albany.
