Blechman\n\nSign up for our newsletter to get the best of The New York Times Magazine delivered to your inbox every week.", "title": "Poem: Mommy\u2019s Acquaintance, a 90-Year-Old Tree", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "The woodland, a United Nations World Heritage site in northeast Poland along its border with Belarus, is a relic of ancient forests, with some of the largest and oldest trees in Europe. Scientists have long argued that they can use the forest \u2014 a mix of deciduous and evergreen trees towering over thick undergrowth \u2014 to study how natural processes worked for thousands of years, before humans deforested most of the Continent.\n\nThe forest, part of it contained within a national park, is also home to the largest colony of European bison, or wisent, as well as to species that are rare or even extinct elsewhere.\n\nPoland has argued that its widely criticized operations in the primeval forest have complied with European law. It says they have been aimed at combating an invasion of bark beetles.\n\nStill, Poland\u2019s environment minister said the government would study Mr. Bot\u2019s opinion closely and respect the court\u2019s final ruling.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cPoland is a state of law that respects the opinion of the spokesman of the European Court of Justice,\u201d the minister, Henryk Kowalczyk, said in a statement published on Tuesday morning. \u201cThe Bialowieza Forest is an exceptionally valuable area for Poland, and all of the past actions had been undertaken in the interest of maintaining it in the best possible condition for the present and future generations.\u201d\n\nThe clash over the forest is just part of a larger dispute between the conservative Polish government and Brussels, which has accused the governing Law and Justice Party of undermining democracy and the rule of law. The government has tightened its control of the judiciary and imposed new restrictions on speech and demonstrations.\n\nThis month, it enacted a law making it a crime to say that Poland bore any blame for Nazi atrocities, and specifically banning the use of the phrase \u201cPolish death camps.\u201d That measure has put a great strain on Warsaw\u2019s relations with Israel and the United States.\n\nThe final ruling of the European Court of Justice in the Bialowieza Forest case is expected in several weeks, said Krzysztof Cibor, an official from the Polish branch of Greenpeace.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe European Court of Justice has been moving exceptionally swiftly here, probably recognizing the urgency of the problem,\u201d Mr. Cibor said in a telephone interview. \u201cIt usually takes years to resolve such disputes.\u201d\n\nHe said he did not expect or want the court to penalize Poland financially in its final ruling, only to halt the logging.\n\n\u201cThe money, even if it\u2019s millions of euros, wouldn\u2019t be the biggest loss,\u201d Mr. Cibor said. \u201cThe last time Poland logged so many trees in Bialowieza as it did in 2017 was 30 years ago. That\u2019s our biggest loss.\u201d", "title": "Poland Broke Law by Logging Ancient Forest, E.U. Court Official Says", "authors": ["Joanna Berendt"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "In 1938, 24-year-old Jakub Piekarz left the small town of Jedwabne in eastern Poland for the United States. Three years later, just after the Red Army had withdrawn and the Wehrmacht had invaded the town, Jedwabne\u2019s Jews, including Mr. Piekarz\u2019s parents, were murdered by their Polish neighbors. In 2000, the historian Jan Tomasz Gross published a book about the massacre; what followed was the most important debate on the Holocaust to take place in post-Communist Europe. Mr. Piekarz (by then Rabbi Baker) died in 2006. In 2013 Ms. Muller visited his daughter in New York; she gave Ms. Muller her father\u2019s letters, photographs and the passport with which he had left Poland in 1938.\n\nThe museum now has over 13,000 donated artifacts like Father Sklodowski\u2019s medallion and Rabbi Baker\u2019s passport. The government believes that the museum insufficiently expresses \u201cthe Polish point of view.\u201d The museum\u2019s original director, Pawel Machewicz, has been dismissed.\n\nFor now, the original main exhibition remains, but the five-minute concluding film has been removed. The censored documentary moves chronologically from the Nuremberg trials through the Korean War, the Ku Klux Klan, Stalin\u2019s death, Martin Luther King\u2019s \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d speech, John F. Kennedy\u2019s assassination, the testing of an atomic bomb, the Polish \u201canti-Zionist\u201d campaign of 1968, Nelson Mandela, Polish Solidarity, Ronald Reagan\u2019s meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev, Sept. 11, the Iraq war, the recent hell of Aleppo and refugees drowned in the Mediterranean. It is set to the music of \u201cHouse of the Rising Sun.\u201d\n\nIt is not at all anti-Polish. It is cosmopolitan \u2014 and peculiarly devastating because it forces us to question what is particular and what is universal, which horrors we have left behind, and which remain with us.\n\nThe rejection of the universal \u2014 the insistence on Polish exceptionalism \u2014 is at the heart of Poland\u2019s \u201chistorical policy,\u201d which aims to control the narrative of the 20th century in such a way as to glorify and exonerate Poles. The underlying principles are simple: a trope of Christ-like martyrdom; a Manichaean division between innocence and guilt, and an assurance that everything bad came from outside.\n\nIt was the publication of Mr. Gross\u2019s \u201cNeighbors\u201d that motivated the first attempts, in 2006 during the first Law and Justice government, to enshrine historical policy by criminalizing the denial that Poles were innocent of any Nazi or Communist crimes. At that time, the Polish historian Dariusz Stola protested against the abdication of responsibility: \u201cIf neither groups of nor individual Polish citizens had anything to do with these crimes, then why all the ado about the iniquities of the Communist regime?\u201d he asked. \u201cAfter all, everything bad was done by some alien creatures, most likely Martians.\u201d\n\nSeveral years ago, the Polish courts declared the original law unconstitutional on technical grounds. But on Jan. 26, the Sejm renewed the project, approving an article stipulating a punishment of up to three years in prison for those who \u201cpublicly and against the facts attribute to the Polish nation or the Polish state responsibility or co-responsibility for Nazi crimes committed by the German Third Reich\u201d or for \u201cother crimes against peace, humanity or war crimes.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Poland Digs Itself a Memory Hole", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "The current measure passed the lower house of Parliament on Friday. The move, on the eve of Holocaust Remembrance Day, seemed planned to provoke a reaction.\n\nIt got one.\n\n\u201cThe law is baseless; I strongly oppose it,\u201d Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a statement released on Saturday. \u201cOne cannot change history, and the Holocaust cannot be denied.\u201d\n\nOn Thursday, the Israeli Foreign Ministry said Israel would seek to postpone a planned visit by a top Polish national security official.\n\n\u201cOn the backdrop of the approval of the bill by the Polish Senate,\u201d the ministry said in a statement, \u201cIsrael has requested the postponement of the planned visit of the head of the Polish National Security Council.\u201d\n\nYair Lapid, leader of a centrist opposition party in Israel and the son of a Holocaust survivor, wrote on Twitter, \u201cThere were Polish death camps and no law can ever change that.\u201d\n\nThe Israeli journalist Lahav Harkov wrote a tweet simply repeating \u201cPolish death camps\u201d 14 times.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPoland was invaded and occupied by Germany in 1939, but unlike in neighboring countries, there was no collaborationist government in Warsaw. Roughly three million Polish Jews were killed in the Holocaust, and another three million Polish citizens died.\n\nSeveral international organizations have been quick to condemn the law, including Yad Vashem, Israel\u2019s official Holocaust memorial; the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum; and the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United States has asked Polish officials to rethink plans to enact the bill, arguing that it is a threat to freedom of speech and to Poland\u2019s international relationships.\n\nBut even as international condemnation poured in, the Polish Senate, took up the measure for debate late Wednesday. The body, controlled by the governing Law and Justice party, moved swiftly, ignoring all of the opposition\u2019s amendments. The legislation passed 57 to 23, with two abstentions.\n\nBut even some Law and Justice lawmakers thought it was reckless.\n\n\u201cHow is it that nobody had foreseen that it was a terrible idea to accept this bill on the eve of the anniversary of International Holocaust Remembrance Day?\u201d Senator Anna Maria Anders, the daughter of a Polish war hero, asked during the debate.\n\n\u201cWe could have done it a week, two weeks later,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd now we have a terrible, terrible international crisis. The crisis is not just in Poland and Israel. The American Congress has begged Poland not to pass this bill. This is so unnecessary. Why didn\u2019t anyone predict that this would be the reaction?\u201d\n\nThe deputy justice minister, Patryk Jaki, responded that Poland \u201ccould not have predicted this reaction because the Israelis had never expressed any criticism in regard to this bill.\u201d\n\nDonald Tusk, the president of the European Council and a former Polish prime minister, suggested in a Twitter post on Thursday that the Polish government was guilty of the very thing the law was intended to fight.\n\n\u201cWho spreads false accusations about the \u2018Polish camps\u2019 damages Poland\u2019s good name and interests,\u201d he wrote. \u201cThe authors of this bill have promoted this slander all over the world, and have been successful in it as no one before them.\u201d", "title": "Poland Tries to Curb Holocaust Speech, and Israel Puts Up a Fight", "authors": ["Marc Santora", "Joanna Berendt"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cPoland\u2019s Holocaust Blame Bill\u201d (editorial, Jan. 30):\n\nPoland is one of the principal guardians of the memory of the victims of the Holocaust and protector of sites sanctified by the blood of innocent Jewish and Polish victims of Nazi German terror.\n\nIt is a great injustice that Poland, the first country to resist German aggression during World War II, and a country that suffered dearly at the hands of the sinister German occupier, has been accused of being responsible in part for the Holocaust. Let me be clear: There was no systematic complicity in the Holocaust, not by the Polish nation or by the Polish state.\n\nIndividuals all throughout German-occupied Europe \u2014 guided by coercion, fear, anti-Semitism, opportunism and greed \u2014 collaborated in one way or another with the German occupiers and committed heinous acts, and in occupied Poland as well.\n\nBut the Polish underground state and resistance carried out death sentences against collaborators and blackmailers, and Poland never formed a collaborationist government.", "title": "Opinion | Poland and the Holocaust: The Ambassador\u2019s View", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "The party has risen from almost 38 percent of the vote in the 2015 election to about 47 percent in recent opinion polls. Much of that success is attributed to its investment in the poorer countryside, and much of the money for that investment is attributed to European Union support and access to its markets and jobs.\n\nBut more than money, Law and Justice thrives on cultural and identity politics. It has contrasted a conservative, Catholic Poland and its family values with a godless, freethinking, gender-bending Western Europe.\n\nIt accuses past governments, the opposition and the urban elites of hankering after European approval and acceptance to the detriment of Polish interests.\n\nSniadowo district, a collection of villages northeast of Warsaw with roughly 5,500 people, reflects that support. While the pre-World War II population was about 40 percent Jewish, today it is Kaczynski country.\n\nThe area is profoundly Roman Catholic and deeply affected by its proximity to Belarus and the memories of the Soviet occupation of World War II. In 2015, roughly 70 percent of voters in the region supported Law and Justice.\n\nPhoto\n\nPeople go to church several times a week, priests tend to give passionate, political sermons, and state and church media give a partisan version of events.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPromoting same-sex marriage will not go down well here,\u201d said Marek Adam Komorowski, 58, a local councilman in nearby Lomza. \u201cIf you are in Europe, you can\u2019t speak against it, but it is not a norm here. Here, family means something else.\u201d\n\nRafal Pstragowski, the 37-year-old mayor of Sniadowo, an independent in his seventh year in office, echoed the sentiments. \u201cPoland is a traditional Christian country and Poland respects other religions,\u201d he said, \u201cbut we want our culture to be respected, too.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere is a fear among people that Western secularism is a threat to our traditional culture,\u201d he added. \u201cIf things in Europe keep going in the same direction, people think that the migration crisis and terrorist attacks could start here, too.\u2019\u2019\n\nSlawomir Zgrzywa, 55, a local historian, said that Poland\u2019s long history of conflict with Russia had made it skeptical of \u201cany sort of left-wing or liberal politics,\u201d and had enhanced the standing of a deeply conservative and politicized Roman Catholic priesthood.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs for the fight with the European Union over the government\u2019s control of the judiciary, that \u201cseems abstract,\u201d said Agnieszka Walczuk, 45, the director of the town\u2019s elementary school. \u201cThe people here are poor, and they feel they have been helped by a government seen as protecting them,\u201d she said.\n\nThe recent squabble over Poland\u2019s new law about history and the Holocaust is another example of the government\u2019s offending Western European sensibilities about free speech for domestic gain. It is seen at home as an effort to protect Poland against all those angry, upset foreigners \u2014 including Jews and Western Europeans. It was telling that the opposition abstained on the vote, rather than voting against.\n\nWhile firmly in favor of membership, Law and Justice has a vision of the European Union similar to the British one \u2014 a union of nation states trading freely with one another but not interfering in domestic politics or national culture.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the same time, Poland sees an emerging vision for Europe, under the proposals of France\u2019s president, Emmanuel Macron, as reviving French-German domination of the bloc, which would leave Poland more sidelined.\n\nIn Poland\u2019s view, talk of restricting the rights of foreign workers in France is protectionist and aimed at the new member states, but wrapped in pro-European language. Poland rejects a \u201cmultilevel\u201d or \u201ctwo-speed\u201d Europe, with an inner core of eurozone states and an outer ring of lesser members. But it sees Brussels heading that way regardless.", "title": "Poland\u2019s Nationalism Threatens Europe\u2019s Values, and Cohesion", "authors": ["Steven Erlanger", "Marc Santora"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "WARSAW \u2014 President Andrzej Duda said on Tuesday that he would sign into law a bill making it illegal to accuse \u201cthe Polish nation\u201d of complicity in the Holocaust and other Nazi atrocities, a measure that has roiled relations with Israel and the United States, and spurred claims that the nationalist government is trying to whitewash one of the bloodiest chapters in Poland\u2019s history.\n\nOpponents have predicted that the law \u2014 which prohibits, among other things, the phrase \u201cPolish death camp\u201d \u2014 would stifle free speech and put questions of historical accuracy into the hands of judges and prosecutors who may be more motivated by politics than scholarship. Despite weeks of ferocious criticism from other nations and from independent scholars, Mr. Duda\u2019s right-wing Law and Justice Party pressed ahead with the bill.\n\nMr. Duda said in a speech broadcast on Polish television and radio that he would sign the measure, while asking the Constitutional Court to determine whether the law violated free-speech protections and to make clear specifically what kinds of speech could be prosecuted. He said that the government wanted to be sure that survivors of war crimes felt free to tell their stories without fear.\n\nBut a judicial review is unlikely to placate those who have accused the Law and Justice Party of dangerous revisionism. It is unclear when the high court, which is controlled by judges appointed by Mr. Duda\u2019s party, might act; the law would remain in effect at least until then.", "title": "Poland\u2019s President Supports Making Some Holocaust Statements a Crime", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "On Tuesday, Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson criticized the law, saying that it \u201cadversely affects freedom of speech and academic inquiry.\u201d Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has gone further, likening the law to Holocaust denial.\n\nPoland\u2019s government on Monday canceled a planned visit by Israel\u2019s education minister, Naftali Bennett, after he criticized the law. \u201cThe blood of Polish Jews cries from the ground, and no law will silence it,\u201d Mr. Bennett said in response.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe law is the latest controversial act by a government that has curbed media and judicial independence, while pushing a populist narrative that casts Poland in a bitter battle with the European Union to regain its sovereignty.\n\nGermany is the dominant power in the bloc, and analysts say it is no coincidence that Poland\u2019s nationalist government talks regularly about the crimes of World War II. For instance, it routinely brings up the idea of Germany paying war reparations, an issue that nearly all of the authorities consider settled as a matter of international law.\n\nCritics say the new law pits two narratives of immense suffering against each other.\n\n\u201cIt is understandable that Poles want people to know their story,\u201d said Timothy Snyder, a Yale historian who lamented that few people know that the death toll in the failed 1944 Warsaw Uprising was higher than in the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, Japan.\n\n\u201cBut the worst thing about a law like this is that it convinces you that you understand yourself,\u201d Mr. Snyder added. \u201cYour confidence in yourself grows as your knowledge of yourself goes down.\u201d\n\nThere is a widespread feeling among many Poles \u2014 even those who oppose the governing Law and Justice Party \u2014 that the nation\u2019s wartime experience, as victim and resister, has not been properly told and is not adequately understood. Invaded first by the Nazis and then by the Soviets, Poland and its people, gentiles and Jews alike, suffered immensely.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPrime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki has compared the Nazis to bandits invading a home shared by two families: If the bandits slaughtered one family and killed several members of the other, he suggested, how could the second family bear any culpability in the bandits\u2019 crimes?\n\nBut nearly all scholars who have weighed in call that analogy dangerously simplistic.\n\nAlthough many Poles risked their lives to save Jews, others energetically took part in pogroms, murdering at least 340 Jews in the town of Jedwabne in 1941 and 42 in the city of Kielce in 1946, after the war ended, to take two notorious examples. Still others extorted or betrayed their Jewish neighbors.\n\nPhoto\n\nYad Vashem, the Holocaust remembrance center in Jerusalem, formally recognizes more than 6,700 gentiles in Poland as \u201crighteous among the nations\u201d because they risked their lives during the war to save Jews \u2014 more than from any other country in Europe. It estimates that 30,000 to 35,000 Polish Jews were saved because of such efforts.\n\nIn a statement last week, the center said that the term \u201cPolish death camps\u201d was undoubtedly a historical misrepresentation, but that it was a mistake to restrict what scholars can say about the \u201cdirect or indirect complicity\u201d of Poles in the Holocaust.\n\nPoland\u2019s president, Andrzej Duda, said he would ask a Constitutional Court to review the legislation to determine whether the law violates freedom of speech and is clear about what kind of speech could be prosecuted.\n\n\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut the court is controlled by people appointed by the governing party, and it is unclear when the review would be conducted.\n\nHistorians say Poland has generally been a responsible steward for the six main Nazi extermination camps in Poland, including Auschwitz-Birkenau. Here, visitors learn about suffering by Poles, Soviet soldiers, Roma and Jews, largely without politics getting in the way. There are no audio tours; artifacts like the vault of human hair that is slowly turning to dust make interpretation seem unnecessary.\n\nBut how to refer to places like Auschwitz is a matter of contention. Poles have long chafed at the term \u201cPolish death camps.\u201d For years, one of the tasks of interns in Polish embassies across Europe was to scour news media accounts for the phrase so that complaints could be filed, said Jagoda Walorek, who worked in the Berlin Embassy in 2007.\n\nEven presidents are not spared. The White House apologized after President Barack Obama used the phrase in 2012, when posthumously honoring a war hero, Jan Karski. On Tuesday, the State Department called the phrase \u201cpainful and misleading,\u201d but added: \u201cWe believe that open debate, scholarship and education are the best means of countering misleading speech.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJonathan Ornstein, the executive director of the Jewish Community Center in Krakow, said one of the sad side effects of the dispute has been that it obscured the \u201cmiracle\u201d of the rebirth of Jewish life in Poland. \u201cWhat is happening here is real and strong and will survive,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast week, the prime minister flew with a group of foreign journalists to visit a museum dedicated to a Polish family who were killed for sheltering Jews. On March 24, 1944, Jozef and Wiktoria Ulma were executed along with their six young children and the eight Jews the family had been harboring.\n\nThe aim of the new law, Mr. Morawiecki said, was to ensure the telling of \u201ctrue history,\u201d adding that it simply needed to be explained better.\n\nJan T. Gross, a Polish-born historian at Princeton, was not reassured, saying that the law was an attempt \u201cto falsify the history of the Holocaust.\u201d\n\nIn an opinion piece for The Financial Times, he said it could even put Holocaust survivors at risk of prosecution. \u201cI\u2019ve read hundreds of survivors\u2019 testimonies, yet I do not recall a single one where the writer has not described an episode of betrayal, blackmail or denunciation on the part of their fellow Polish citizens,\u201d he wrote.\n\nMr. Snyder, the historian, said the new law was strikingly similar to legislation adopted in Russia a few years ago that made it a crime to speak of Russia as an aggressor in 1939, when Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union carved up Poland. The Russian law also made it illegal to talk about any war crime not covered at the Nuremberg trials. Since the Soviets were among the victors, Soviet crimes were not discussed at the trials.\n\nMr. Snyder also said the new Polish law was an attempt to distance the country from the European Union. \u201cThe folks in power now in Poland tend to identify the E.U. with Germany,\u201d he said. \u201cThe notion of wartime victimhood at the hand of Germans follows pretty easily into one of sovereignty.\u201d\n\n\u201cSovereignty,\u201d he said, \u201cis the right to define yourself as innocent.\u201d", "title": "Poland\u2019s \u2018Death Camp\u2019 Law Tears at Shared Bonds of Suffering With Jews", "authors": ["Marc Santora"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "For allegations of criminal sexual conduct, the board\u2019s memo called for a new policy allowing the board to notify the appropriate district attorney\u2019s office \u2014 a step beyond its current practice of only notifying the Internal Affairs Bureau \u2014 though it said the high burden of proof in such cases means prosecutors often cannot or will not pursue them.\n\nAndrew Case, a lawyer who was a spokesman for the review board, said he worries \u201cthat if these cases, particularly forcible assaults, fall to C.C.R.B., then that would be a sign that D.A.s are not doing all they can to investigate truly criminal acts.\u201d\n\nNew York state law does not explicitly forbid sexual contact between police officers and people in their custody, though it forbids such conduct by correction and parole officers. The New York State Assembly last week passed legislation to prevent police officers from escaping legal consequences of an alleged sexual assault by saying arrestees consented, and the State Senate is now considering the same measure. The New York City Council is also considering legislation that would make it a misdemeanor crime for police officers to have sexual contact with people in custody.\n\nThe 117 allegations of sexual misconduct the board referred to the Internal Affairs Bureau between January 2016 and June \u201cincluded a variety of allegations, from catcalls and sexual propositions to unwanted touching and rape,\u201d the memo said. It summarized three of them to provide a range of cases the board receives.\n\nIn one, a woman questioned by a Bronx detective in 2014, at a shooting scene, went on to repeatedly encounter the same man around the neighborhood \u201cand recalled that he would regularly lick his lips and make lewd expressions toward her,\u201d the board\u2019s memo said. In 2016, as she was held in a station house jail cell on a driving charge, the same detective entered her cell and made a profane gesture and a reference to oral sex.\n\nIn another, a man alleged that an officer twice squeezed his genitals during a frisk last year that followed a street stop for jaywalking.\n\nThe Police Department declined to answer questions about any discipline handed down to officers in the 117 complaints referred to its Internal Affairs Bureau, how the cases were decided or what the complaints alleged. It said it would work with the review board to implement the new procedure.\n\nFor all review board referrals to the Internal Affairs Bureau, \u201ca huge issue\u201d is that the police \u201cdon\u2019t tell us what happens with any of them,\u201d Mr. Case said. \u201cOne of the things this speaks to, a broader issue, is reporting from I.A.B. to C.C.R.B. about all referrals.\u201d", "title": "Police Complaint Board to Investigate Charges of Sexual Misconduct", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "The stabbing deaths of a Brooklyn couple may have been related to a dispute at their religious supply store of candles and scented oils in a nearby section of Brownsville, the police said on Thursday.\n\nNo arrests have been made in the deaths of Hazel Brown and Stephenson Bonaparte, both from Trinidad, who were stabbed Wednesday night in and outside their home on the 200 block of Winthrop Street near Prospect Park in Prospect Lefferts Gardens.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not saying it\u2019s a robbery, a robbery gone bad, a home invasion; it\u2019s not the issue,\u201d said Robert K. Boyce, the chief of detectives for the New York Police Department. \u201cWe think it\u2019s something else,\u201d he said without elaborating.\n\nHe said detectives were looking into an argument the couple had with a customer earlier in the day at their store, King Soloman Religious Store on Rutland Road, which the couple had operated for years and where Mr. Bonaparte was known as a pastor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe believe it\u2019s something to do with their business; they own a religious store,\u201d Chief Boyce said. \u201cWe\u2019re going to do a search warrant on the store to see exactly what\u2019s going on. So we\u2019re a long way away from where we need to be on this case, but we have a lot of people speaking to us in the neighborhood because everybody liked them; they were nice people.\u201d", "title": "Police Seek Motive in Stabbings at Brooklyn Home", "authors": ["Michael Wilson", "Al Baker"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "A New York City police sergeant was acquitted Thursday of murder in the fatal 2016 shooting of a bat-wielding, mentally ill 66-year-old woman in the bedroom of her Bronx apartment.\n\nThe death of the woman, Deborah Danner, became a flash point in the national, racially charged debate over whether police officers are too quick to shoot people and whether they are adequately trained and sufficiently conscientious in their dealings with people suffering from severe mental illness.\n\nThe sergeant, Hugh Barry, 32, had also been charged with manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide and chose to have his case decided by a judge instead of a jury; he was acquitted on all counts by Justice Robert A. Neary of State Supreme Court.\n\nBecause the sergeant claimed self-defense, Justice Neary said that the prosecution needed to prove that he was \u201cnot justified in the use of deadly physical force.\u201d", "title": "Police Sergeant Acquitted in Killing of Mentally Ill Woman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "SYDNEY \u2014 Australia\u2019s deputy prime minister, Barnaby Joyce, has spent most of his career advocating for rural voters and strong families, and shouting down welfare cheats.\n\nBut on Wednesday in Parliament, he offered a full-throated defense for remaining in office despite an affair with a former staff member who is now pregnant, and with whom he lived rent-free in an apartment owned by a wealthy supporter.\n\nSuch is the scandal known as #barnababy, which in just one week has gone from a debate about privacy, sex and tabloids to an indictment of Australia\u2019s crony politics.\n\n\u201cThis whole incident is absolutely tailor-made to undercut people\u2019s faith in the Parliament, which is already at an all-time low,\u201d said Susan Harris Rimmer, a law professor at Griffith University in Queensland.", "title": "Politician\u2019s Affair Puts Spotlight on Australia\u2019s Crony Culture", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Should celebrities wear all-black to the Oscars? Ever since the Golden Globes, when they did exactly that (or most of them did) in support of Time\u2019s Up, the movement to combat sexual harassment and gender inequality, this has been a question. Especially after the white-rose moment at the Grammys; especially since a similar all-black call has gone out to attendees of the British Academy Film Awards (the Baftas) this weekend.\n\nFashion has been largely avoiding the issue, but on Sunday night, Prabal Gurung addressed it head-on.", "title": "Politics Comes to the New York Runways", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "While Pomerol is often a wonderful wine, it is usually expensive. If money is no object, go right ahead and track down classic labels like Vieux Ch\u00e2teau Certan and Ch\u00e2teau Trotanoy, which will run around $175 to $250 a bottle, to say nothing of rare objects of desire like Ch\u00e2teau Lafleur ($600 and up) and P\u00e9trus (if you have to ask \u2026).\n\nMore down-to-earth bottles exist, though they are almost never inexpensive. Here are five producers worth seeking out, in alphabetical order. (Prices are estimates for recent vintages.)\n\nCh\u00e2teau Bellegrave Structured and minerally (Weygandt-Metzler, Unionville, Pa., $55).\n\nCh\u00e2teau Bourgneuf Pomerol for the people. Precise, floral and nuanced (Maisons Marques & Domaines USA, Oakland, Calif., $45).\n\nCh\u00e2teau Clinet Rich and opulent (Monsieur Touton, New York, $80).\n\nCh\u00e2teau Gombaude-Guillot Sumptuous and pure, needs time to age (Kermit Lynch Wine Merchant, Berkeley, Calif., $80).", "title": "Pomerol, From a Little Expensive on Up", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "I spent my entire childhood in poverty, reliant on public assistance from the day I was born until my high school graduation and with a few brief sporadic returns after that. Some of my most vivid childhood memories involve accompanying my mother to the store, where she exchanged food stamps for the groceries our family needed. In those days, food stamps came in paper form, so she had to perform a ritual at the checkout counter, tearing each voucher from its booklet.\n\nThese days, electronic cards called E.B.T.s, which can be used like credit cards at checkout, eliminate the awkward process of fumbling with booklets. But that doesn\u2019t make it any less painful to be so poor that you need help paying for food. Being poor means getting shamed and criticized for each minor decision you make, both by politicians and your neighbors standing in line behind you at the grocery store.\n\nFederal guidelines already dictate what can and cannot be purchased with food stamps, yet poor people are subjected to endless commentary and condemnation from cable news pundits to Facebook friends over their grocery selections. Are they picking items with enough nutrition? Are they choosing products that are more expensive, or more enjoyable, than they deserve?\n\nAmericans of all income levels occasionally make food choices that aren\u2019t the healthiest or most economical, but it\u2019s the poor \u2014 who often have few other ways to indulge themselves and their children \u2014 who are judged most harshly when they do so.\n\nAs a result, poor people are constantly required to explain their circumstances, and justify their every choice. This is especially true for parents who must rely on social programs to feed their children. The proposed Harvest Box further reinforces the notion that low-income parents can\u2019t be trusted to determine what\u2019s best for their own children. The implication is that wiser authority figures should dictate what these families should and can eat.", "title": "Opinion | Poor People Deserve Better Than Food in a Box", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.\n\nPop\n\nBLACK REBEL MOTORCYCLE CLUB at Brooklyn Steel (Feb. 2, 9 p.m.). Named for the leather-clad toughs from the 1953 film \u201cThe Wild One,\u201d this California band started making heavy, heady rock around the turn of the millennium \u2014 its 2001 debut, \u201cB.R.M.C.,\u201d is a minor classic of that time \u2014 and never stopped. The eighth Black Rebel Motorcycle Club album, \u201cWrong Creatures,\u201d arrived in January. The group\u2019s sound may no longer reflect the latest fashions, but it\u2019s somehow comforting to find it unchanged after all these years.\n\nbowerypresents.com/brooklyn-steel\n\nBROCKHAMPTON at Irving Plaza (Feb. 2-4, 9 p.m.). This freewheeling crew of rappers and producers, which traces its origins to a popular online forum for fans of Kanye West, has energy and charisma to spare. Brockhampton released its first, second and third full-length studio albums in 2017 \u2014 \u201cSaturation II,\u201d from August, is the one to try if you\u2019re short on time, although they\u2019re all solid listens \u2014 and has a fourth on the way. The group sold out three nights at Irving Plaza \u2014 capacity 1,000 \u2014 this week, and while that fact suggests there will be opportunities to see Brockhampton at bigger venues soon enough, the resale market is there for those who can\u2019t wait that long.\n\n212-777-6817, irvingplaza.com\n\nJOOLS HOLLAND at Blue Note (through Feb. 4, 8 p.m. and 10:30 p.m.). If you\u2019ve ever hummed along to \u201cPulling Mussels (From the Shell)\u201d or another of the new-wave classics Squeeze released between 1978 and 1980, you\u2019ve likely enjoyed Jools Holland\u2019s genial piano and keyboard work. Mr. Holland, who left that band in 1981, is better known today as the host of a long-running BBC2 show, but he continues to record music that falls somewhere between supper-club jazz and smooth R&B. These twice-nightly engagements in the West Village are his first performances in the United States in well over a decade.\n\n212-475-8592, bluenotejazz.com/newyork\n\nNADINE at Baby\u2019s All Right (Feb. 8, 8 p.m.). Nadine\u2019s recent single \u201cUltra Pink\u201d is the kind of song that makes one wonder why its creators aren\u2019t more famous yet: light as a feather, cryptic and cool in just the right proportions to inspire repeat listening. There\u2019s more where that came from on this indie-pop trio\u2019s just-released debut LP, \u201cOh My.\u201d Lexie, a side project of the singer-songwriter Greta Kline (of Frankie Cosmos), will be among the opening acts on Thursday night.\n\n877-987-6487, babysallright.com", "title": "Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "PALM at Market Hotel (Feb. 9, 9 p.m.). Palm\u2019s 2015 full-length debut, \u201cTrading Basics,\u201d and 2017 EP, \u201cShadow Expert,\u201d shared a remarkable commitment to resisting the obvious. Songs started off on unsettling tones, then torqued in even stranger directions. The Philadelphia-based art-rock band\u2019s second album, \u201cRock Island,\u201d is out this Friday, and it\u2019s even more inventive, with highlights that suggest a curious hybrid of Beach Boys melodies and Chicago footwork rhythms. Palm will celebrate the LP with a show at this beloved D.I.Y. space in Bushwick, Brooklyn.\n\n877-987-6487, ticketfly.com\n\nVILLAGE OF LOVE at Music Hall of Williamsburg (Feb. 14, 8 p.m.). Bush Tetras\u2019 classic post-punk dart \u201cToo Many Creeps\u201d diagnosed a fundamental societal problem circa 1980 and continues to ring all too true today. That group is one of several acts performing at this annual Valentine\u2019s Day fund-raiser for Planned Parenthood\u2019s New York chapter, along with Kid Congo Powers (of the Cramps), Shilpa Ray and others. The Lemon Twigs, young 1960s-pop revivalists from Long Island, will headline the night.\n\n888-929-7849, musichallofwilliamsburg.com\n\nSIMON VOZICK-LEVINSON\n\nPhoto\n\nJazz\n\nDAVELL CRAWFORD AND PEDRITO MARTINEZ at the Blue Note (Feb. 13, 8 and 10:30 p.m.). A New Orleans pianist and a Havana-born percussionist, Mr. Crawford and Mr. Martinez are two former prodigies who hail from opposite sides of the Gulf of Mexico. Both have high, enchanting singing voices, and each of them upholds a traditional style while drawing broad connections. Mr. Crawford inherited the robust piano acrobatics of Professor Longhair and Henry Butler, pulling it into contact with the broader American R&B tradition. Mr. Martinez built his musical backbone in Santeria ceremonies and Havana watering holes, and his svelte playing on the congas and the sacred bat\u00e1 drum has made him a sought-after side musician, as well as a bandleader of growing renown.\n\n212-475-8592, bluenote.net\n\nAMIR ELSAFFAR AND RIVERS OF SOUND at N.Y.U. Skirball Center (Feb. 10, 7:30 p.m.). Balancing cool forbearance and sauntering grace, the 17-piece ensemble Rivers of Sound represent an exceptional gathering of instrumentalists from musical traditions across Asia and the Americas. On the group\u2019s beguiling debut album, \u201cNot Two,\u201d released last year, Mr. ElSaffar\u2019s trumpet flutters above a weave of plucked strings and assorted percussion (the American drum kit, the Indian mridangam, the Egyptian dumbek), creating an illusion of endless development and broad traversal.\n\n212-998-4941, nyuskirball.org\n\nBILLY HART QUARTET at Jazz Standard (through Feb. 11, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Mr. Hart developed a reputation in the 1970s as one of the most adaptive and sympathetic drummers in jazz, adding subtle shading and suspense-building mobility to Herbie Hancock\u2019s electric fusion, Pharoah Sanders\u2019s avant-garde spiritualism and Billy Harper\u2019s Afrocentric postbop. Mr. Hart is a slow burner with no particular interest in clean resolution, and he\u2019s long produced engrossing work as a bandleader who lives by those principles. In the past dozen years, he has led this esteemed quartet, performing his own dusky compositions and those of his younger band mates: the tenor saxophonist Mark Turner, the pianist Ethan Iverson and the bassist Ben Street.\n\n212-576-2232, jazzstandard.com\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSHEILA JORDAN at Mezzrow (Feb. 14, 8 and 9:30 p.m.). Cheeky, importunate and canny, Ms. Jordan\u2019s voice is one of the great standard-bearing instruments of midcentury jazz. Now 89 and a National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Master, she still has that mix of sagacity and ingenuous charm that endeared her to discerning listeners in the 1960s. For this Valentine\u2019s Day show, Ms. Jordan appears with two well-traveled accompanists, the pianist John DiMartino and the bassist Harvie S.\n\n646-476-4346, mezzrow.com\n\nGREGORY PORTER at Carnegie Hall (Feb. 14, 8 p.m.). Last year the stout-voiced Mr. Porter released \u201cNat King Cole & Me,\u201d a tribute album featuring some of Cole\u2019s best-known songs, rendered with resplendent backing from the London Symphony Orchestra. (You might say the record was bound to happen: In 2004, before he was a big name, Mr. Porter presented an autobiographical musical of a similar name.) This Valentine\u2019s Day concert marks Mr. Porter\u2019s debut at Carnegie Hall, where Cole gave some of the most momentous performances of his career.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nLIZZ WRIGHT at Lincoln Center (Feb. 14, 8:30 p.m.). \u201cGrace,\u201d Ms. Wright\u2019s sixth album, finds her planted ankle-deep in the Southern soil, while sending her ample, burgundy voice aloft. The album \u2014 one of last year\u2019s finest \u2014 feels remarkably personal, despite featuring just one original tune. Instead Ms. Wright bridges a wide tradition of American song, from gospel (\u201cSinging in My Soul\u201d) to New Orleanian balladry (\u201cSouthern Nights\u201d) to seminal Christian rock (\u201cEvery Grain of Sand\u201d). Ms. Wright will draw from that record at this concert, in the Appel Room at Jazz at Lincoln Center.\n\n212-721-6500, jazz.org\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "The first, three-year mandate of the commission ended in December, and its lapsing coincided with growing criticism of the pope\u2019s commitment to addressing sexual abuse in the church. The group plans to begin its work in April by hearing the testimony of abuse victims.\n\nThe Vatican statement said the commission\u2019s goal \u201cand greatest challenge\u201d remained embedding \u201cabuse prevention and protection into the life and action of local churches.\u201d\n\nThe announcement about the commission came on the same day that the pope\u2019s most experienced sex crimes investigator, Archbishop Charles Scicluna of Malta, was expected to take testimony in New York from Juan Carlos Cruz, who says that he was sexually abused when he was a teenager in Chile by a priest and that Bishop Juan Barros Madrid had witnessed the abuse.\n\nWhile visiting Chile last month, the pope initially defended Bishop Barros as a victim of \u201ccalumny,\u201d saying that the Vatican had received no concrete evidence against the bishop.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe day someone brings me proof against Bishop Barros, then I will talk,\u201d Francis said at the time. \u201cBut there is not one single piece of evidence. It is all slander.\u201d\n\nThe comments caused outrage in Chile, and Francis, amid intense pressure, dispatched Archbishop Scicluna to investigate.\n\nOn Thursday, the Civilt\u00e0 Cattolica, a Jesuit journal, published the private remarks the pope made during a visit to Peru last month, in which he disclosed that he regularly met with victims of sexual abuse.\n\n\u201cThe Holy Father meets victims of sexual abuse, either individually or in groups, several times a month,\u201d Greg Burke, the Vatican spokesman, confirmed in a statement. He added that the pope \u201ctries to help them heal the grave wounds caused by the abuses they suffered.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany advocates for abuse survivors accused the pope of opening up a wound by saying there was no evidence that Bishop Barros had covered up abuse. It then emerged that the pope had personally received an eight-page letter in 2015 containing testimony against the bishop, and that Cardinal O\u2019Malley had delivered it.\n\nEight members of the commission were reappointed, and nine others are new to the panel. Its experts, which include lay academics and psychologists, priests and nuns, come from several countries, including Brazil, Ethiopia, India and Tonga. Ten are non-clerics and eight are women, including three nuns.\n\nTwo abuse survivors previously left the commission in frustration. And the pope did not reappoint six lay members who advocates for the abused considered among the commission\u2019s most active leaders.", "title": "Pope Revives Sexual Abuse Commission Amid Criticism of Vatican", "authors": ["Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nName Naomi Watanabe\n\nAge 30\n\nHometown Ibaraki Prefecture, about two hours northeast of Tokyo.\n\nNow Lives Tokyo\n\nClaim to Fame With more than 7.6 million followers on Instagram, Ms. Watanabe is one of the most popular social media celebrities in Japan. She is an actress, comedian and fashion designer who is perhaps best known for her skits imitating Beyonc\u00e9, Lady Gaga and other pop stars, in which she exaggerates their dance moves while lip-syncing their songs on TV variety shows.\n\nBig Break A lifelong comedian who enrolled in a Tokyo comedy school when she was 18, Ms. Watanabe made her television debut in 2007 on \u201cWaratte Iitomo!\u201d (\u201cIt\u2019s O.K. to Laugh\u201d), a daily hourlong variety show that ran for 32 years before ending in 2014. The show, which was broadcast live, featured a roster of regular performers including, at one point, Ms. Watanabe, who did impersonations. Fun facts: Ms. Watanabe was once called the Japanese Beyonc\u00e9, and the show set the Guinness Book of World Record title for the longest running live TV variety show on the same channel (8,054 episodes).\n\nPhoto\n\nLatest Project In addition to comedy, Ms. Watanabe was always interested in fashion but had a hard time finding plus-size clothes in Japan. As a teenager she would improvise by shopping in men\u2019s stores, or by buying a dress and wearing it as a T-shirt. In 2014, Ms. Watanabe started a clothing line called Punyus (it means \u201cchubby\u201d in Japanese) that includes plus-size pieces for women like herself. Twice a year she introduces a new collection with a stadium-size runway show. She modeled the show after Victoria\u2019s Secret, but instead of big-name artists like the Weeknd performing, she is the main attraction. \u201cI\u2019m like a fake musician,\u201d she said through a translator.\n\nNext Thing Ms. Watanabe plans to spend more time in New York this year, with ambitions to open a Punyus store. She won\u2019t be a total stranger in the city: She was recently featured in a Gap Logo Remix ad, dancing alongside MetroBoomin, SZA and Bria Vinaite, an actress from \u201cThe Florida Project.\u201d\n\nClass Clown As a child, Ms. Watanabe would study television skits with Ken Shimura, a Japanese comedian known for his expressive faces. She would, in turn, practice her own funny faces whenever she could, including in the school cafeteria. \u201cAs soon as my classmates would take a sip of their milk, I would make a crazy facial expression and see if they would squirt out milk,\u201d she said.", "title": "Popular Japanese Comedian Wants to Bring Her Plus-Size Fashion to the U.S.", "authors": ["Joanna Nikas", "Up Next"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I live in a co-op in Midtown West. My living room wall abuts the wall of a new building. My wall was damaged during its construction, and mold keeps growing on it. Because of a licensing agreement between my co-op board and the new development, the developer\u2019s contractors have cleaned the mold and replaced the dry wall three times in two years. But, they do not share the mold test results with me, nor have they provided me with remediation paperwork; they say that verbal confirmation is enough. My co-op board and managing agent are not helping me get the paperwork either, ignoring my written requests. What can I do?\n\nAsk Real Estate Submit your questions, share your stories and tell us what topics interest you most. Post a comment or email us at realestateqa@nytimes.com.\n\nA. Mold is serious and needs to be taken care of. Although black mold is toxic, common molds can be harmful to your health, too. If you are allergic to mold, it could cause a reaction or exacerbate asthma, and if your immune system is compromised from an illness like HIV or AIDS, such exposure could pose a serious health threat, said Dr. Louis DePalo, a pulmonology professor at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai.\n\nEven if the mold does not bother you now, you should still insist on removing it because \u201cif you continue to live in that space, you might develop an allergy\u201d to mold eventually, Dr. DePalo said. So how do you make sure the mold is really gone? You need the board to step up because fixing this is the board\u2019s responsibility. The licensing agreement is between the board and the developer, and the board is responsible for problems within the walls, according to Robert J. Braverman, a real estate lawyer. \u201cIt is the board, not you, that is in a position to enforce the terms of the agreement\u201d with the developer, Mr. Braverman said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBecause mold was discovered in your walls, there is a good chance that reports exist identifying the type of mold and the extent of the problem. Keep pressing the board to get hold of those reports, and any remediation reports, too, reminding the board that this is its responsibility.\n\nIf you cannot make any progress, you may want to hire an environmental consultant to test your apartment for hazardous levels of mold. If your consultant finds that the damage has not been adequately addressed, then the board must fix the problem on your behalf, Mr. Braverman said, and then go after the developer for compensation.", "title": "Possible Mold in the Walls and an Unresponsive Board", "authors": ["Ronda Kaysen", "Ask Real Estate"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Powell has the calm and unassuming manner of a person confident in his abilities. Mr. Carpenter said the only time that he had seen Mr. Powell show irritation was when he persisted in addressing Mr. Powell as \u201cGovernor Powell\u201d rather than \u201cJay.\u201d\n\nJohn Dugan, a longtime friend who worked for Mr. Powell at Treasury, said Mr. Powell\u2019s success owed much to playing well with others. \u201cHe has a tremendous sense of humor, but not an unkind one,\u201d said Mr. Dugan, a former comptroller of the currency.\n\nThe Salomon scandal began with a routine phone call. At the time, Wall Street firms wrote bids on scraps of paper stuffed into a wooden box. The New York Fed policed the process by calling a small selection of buyers to verify bids. In the spring of 1991, a staff member reached a surprised supposed bidder. A quiet investigation found that Salomon was bidding in other peoples\u2019 names. No firm was allowed to buy more than 35 percent of a given debt issue; at one auction in May 1991, Salomon bought 94 percent, allowing the firm to resell at a premium.\n\nMr. Powell oversaw the government\u2019s borrowing program, so he led the repairs, including the negotiations over a long weekend in August that resulted in the departure of Salomon\u2019s top management and the installation of Warren E. Buffett as chairman. The bond trader went to prison.\n\nMr. Powell \u201cwas impressive to me because he thought clearly and he didn\u2019t jump to conclusions,\u201d said Deborah A. Perelmuter, then the head of the domestic trading desk at the New York Fed, who watched Mr. Powell hammer together a consensus on the necessary changes \u2014 including the replacement of paper slips with electronic bidding. \u201cHe seemed to have his head on straight.\u201d\n\nHis views about regulation remain substantially unchanged. He supports the stronger rules imposed on financial companies after the 2008 crisis, but he has said he sees room for streamlining and he favors measures that encourage the industry to take responsibility for its conduct, where possible.\n\nAfter leaving Treasury, Mr. Powell remained in Washington and made a fortune as a private-equity investor at the Carlyle Group. By 2010, he was looking for a new challenge, and he joined the Bipartisan Policy Center for an eight-week project simulating a state\u2019s insolvency. He was not paid.", "title": "Powell Takes Over as Fed Chief as Economy Starts to Show Strain", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "Researchers have found that such children often bounce around among relatives, suffer in school and display self-destructive behaviors, such as cutting themselves.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s insane,\u201d said Marci Leuschen, a high school biology teacher and friend of the Jamal family who has helped organize a campaign in Lawrence to support the family. Some 500 people showed up at a local church to write letters in support of Jamal, and Leuschen said some were Trump supporters who were aghast that the immigration crackdown meant locking up their friend.\n\nOn Change.org, more than 66,000 have signed a petition calling for Jamal to be freed. A GoFundMe campaign has raised more than $39,000 for legal and other expenses.\n\nThank you, President Trump, for defending us from such \u201cbad hombres\u201d \u2014 even if Professor Jamal hasn\u2019t been accused of any violence, in contrast to your (recently ousted) staff secretary.\n\nNaheen said that the outpouring of community support has overwhelmed her. \u201cIt\u2019s what keeps me going,\u201d she told me. \u201cEveryone in my community, I feel so grateful to them.\u201d\n\nJamal earned a graduate degree in pharmaceutical sciences, worked as a researcher in cancer and genetics and became renowned for helping others. He even assisted elderly neighbors with their weekly shopping and checked on their medicines.\n\n\u201cThe truth is, the country needs more neighbors like Syed,\u201d wrote a local pastor, Eleanor McCormick, whose Plymouth Congregational Church in Lawrence has helped lead the grass-roots effort to support him.\n\nJamal has had a tortuous series of interactions with the impossibly complex immigration system. Several years ago, immigration authorities ruled that he had overstayed his visa, but the Obama administration exercised discretion, and (like countless others) he was allowed to stay if he reported in regularly. So Jamal had a temporary work permit and checked in with the immigration authorities, most recently on Jan. 7. Everything seemed to be fine \u2014 until the immigration officers decided for some reason to blow up his family\u2019s life.", "title": "Opinion | President Trump, How Is This Man a Danger?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump and Devin Nunes have been muddying the waters of the Russia investigation, so let\u2019s try to clarify those waters so that they\u2019re as clear as vodka.\n\nHere are a dozen things we know.\n\n1. Russia interfered in the U.S. election. The U.S. intelligence community concluded that President Vladimir Putin had \u201ca clear preference\u201d for Trump and \u201cordered an influence campaign\u201d to hurt Hillary Clinton. The Department of Homeland Security notified 21 states that Russian hackers (mostly unsuccessfully) had targeted their election systems before the 2016 election.\n\nRussia oversaw an online campaign using fake American accounts to spread anti-Clinton messages. Twitter found that 50,000 Russian accounts fired off 2.1 million election-related tweets in the fall of 2016, and in the final weeks around the election accounted for 4.25 percent of retweets of Trump\u2019s own account.\n\n2. Trump has longstanding business interests in Russia. The Times has explored these, beginning with a trip to Moscow in 1987 to try to build a hotel there. The prospect that he will rule for years to come has raised concerns about oppression at home and potential truculence abroad.\n\nMr. Xi, the son of Communist Party elite, came to power with a long history of working his way up the ranks of officialdom, deftly sidelining rivals and rolling over dissent as he cultivated alliances and strengthened his control over the government, the economy and the military.\n\nHere is a guide to The New York Times\u2019s coverage of the key moments of his life and political career.", "title": "President Xi Jinping\u2019s Rise in China, as Covered by The Times", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "The party\u2019s move comes as Mr. Xi has proclaimed an era of China\u2019s greatness, when the country, he says, will take what he sees as its rightful place as a top global power. Already, it is establishing military bases in the Western Pacific and Africa, building infrastructure across Asia, parts of Europe and Africa, and running what Mr. Xi hopes will be the world\u2019s No. 1 economy within two decades or sooner.\n\n\u201cChina feels it is on the road to great power status and they want to perpetuate the trajectory they are on,\u201d said David Finkelstein, director of China Studies at CNA, a research institute in Arlington, Va.\n\nSome analysts outside China said they worried that allowing Mr. Xi one-man rule might worsen an increasingly tense relationship between the United States and China.\n\nAfter years of efforts by the United States to engage China on issues from market reform to climate change to human rights, the Trump administration turned on Beijing last December and called China a strategic competitor in its first national security document.\n\nWashington policy makers are preparing plans to impose tariffs on some Chinese imports, limit Chinese investments in the United States, particularly in technology, and spend more on the United States military to sustain its big advantage over the People\u2019s Liberation Army.\n\nIn congressional testimony earlier this month, the director of the F.B.I., Christopher Wray, described China as \u201cnot just a whole of government threat but a whole of society threat.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump may well see Mr. Xi\u2019s consolidation of power as part of a global trend toward increasingly influential leaders, in which he might include himself along with Mr. Xi and Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian leader, said James Mann, the author of \u201cThe China Fantasy,\u201d which contradicted the popular view that increasing prosperity would lead to political liberalization in China.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m guessing he will not deplore the lack of democracy in China, because that\u2019s the sort of thing he rarely if ever does,\u201d Mr. Mann said of Mr. Trump.\n\nMr. Mann also said Mr. Trump might not have much problem with what Mr. Xi had accomplished.\n\n\u201cOver the past 14 months in office, Trump has almost never voiced the sort of support for our constitutional system that has been a staple in the statements of past presidents,\u201d Mr. Mann said. \u201cHe does not respect the dignity or integrity of political opponents. He does not express support for the independence of the courts or the freedom of the press.\u201d\n\nSo if anything, he said, \u201cI think Trump is probably jealous.\u201d\n\nFrom Clinton to Bush to Obama, the prevailing belief was engagement with China would make China more like the West.\n\nPhoto\n\nInstead, as Mr. Mann predicted, China has gone in the opposite direction.\n\nShi Yinhong, professor of international relations at Renmin University in Beijing, said Mr. Xi most likely did not care how the world would interpret his designation as a potential ruler in perpetuity.\n\nWith an unlimited term in office, Mr. Xi would almost certainly be in office beyond 2024, the year Mr. Trump would leave the White House if he won a second term.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. And nationalists cheered the decision, describing Mr. Xi as a singular force who could restore the glory of the nation.\n\nBut as the news spread, readings of Hannah Arendt, who wrote about the evils of totalitarian rule, and passages from George Washington, who retired after two terms as president, were discussed on social media in Chinese legal circles.\n\nDouglas H. Paal, a China expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said the sudden move, before Mr. Xi even starts his second term next month, suggested that things were not \u201cnormal\u201d within the Communist Party.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis looks like forced marching, not normal order, so something is going on,\u201d Mr. Paal said. \u201cXi is winning, but it will take sleuthing to find out what. These are not ordinary times.\u201d\n\nA series of visits by senior Chinese officials to Washington in the past month to try and persuade the Trump administration to slow down plans to introduce punitive measures that could result in a trade war had failed, Mr. Paal said.\n\n\u201cThis could get complicated when controversial U.S. initiatives meet unconventional times in China,\u201d he said.\n\nStill, Mr. Xi is popular in many areas \u2014 his fans affectionately call him \u201cUncle Xi\u201d \u2014 and his brand of folksy nationalism wins accolades, especially in rural areas. Experts said Mr. Xi would probably benefit from the perception in China that the rest of the world is chaotic.\n\n\u201cWith a population amazed at the incompetent mess in much of the rest of the world, and intoxicated by nationalism, for Xi to effect this change will be seen as reasonable,\u201d said Kerry Brown, a professor of Chinese politics at King\u2019s College, London.\n\nBut Mr. Xi\u2019s assumption of unfettered power may not work out the way he thinks, said Peter Jennings, executive director of the Australian Strategic Policy Institute, and a former senior Australian defense official.\n\n\u201cThe risks to his personal fortunes are huge,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat if the People\u2019s Liberation Army decides he should be cut loose?\u201d And, he added, \u201cWhat if growth slows more than expected?\u201d\n\nIf Mr. Xi comes under pressure at home or abroad, he could become unpredictable, and even dangerous, Mr. Jennings said. The reach for more personal power could be the start of his downfall.\n\n\u201cThe West can take no comfort in that because Xi\u2019s situation means he may take more risks in the South China Sea or over Taiwan,\u201d he said. \u201cHe has nothing to lose and everything to gain by engaging in more Putin-like brinkmanship.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMoreover, he added, \u201cWhere does one ever see the \u2018president for life\u2019 model end well?\u201d", "title": "President Xi\u2019s Strongman Rule Raises New Fears of Hostility and Repression", "authors": ["Jane Perlez", "Javier C. Hern\u00e1ndez"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Every year since the end of apartheid in 1994, South Africa\u2019s annual state of the nation address has been given by the president in Parliament. But on Tuesday, two days before this year\u2019s address, parliamentary leaders abruptly announced that it would be postponed.\n\n\u201cWe believe it is in the best interest of Parliament, and in the best interest of our country, for us to give time for whatever political matters that need to be resolved,\u201d Jackson Mthembu, chief whip of the A.N.C. and a Ramaphosa ally, said of the postponement.\n\nIt was not clear when the address would take place. Or whether the embattled Mr. Zuma would deliver it. Or who might do so if he were to resign unexpectedly.\n\nAt a news conference earlier on Tuesday, party leaders had said that they hoped to break the deadlock between the two factions at a meeting of the national executive committee on Wednesday. The meeting had been hastily scheduled after party leaders had failed to come to a resolution in meetings earlier in the week.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cLet the N.E.C. provide us with a decision,\u201d Jessie Duarte, the deputy secretary general and a longtime Zuma ally, said, referring to the committee. \u201cUp to this point, there has been no decision.\u201d\n\nMr. Zuma, a survivor who has defied political gravity for years, had told supporters that it was his right to give the speech, though on Tuesday his office said that he had agreed to the postponement. According to the news media, he has given no indication of stepping down, saying that the \u201cpeople still love him.\u201d\n\nIn South Africa, the president is appointed by Parliament, which is dominated by the A.N.C. If the party\u2019s executive committee turns against Mr. Zuma, he would most likely resign, or face a humiliating fate in Parliament.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe annual address has produced dramatic political theater in recent years. While A.N.C. lawmakers have visibly supported Mr. Zuma during past speeches, opposition lawmakers have used what amounts to the president\u2019s most important speech of the year to humiliate him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Economic Freedom Fighters, the nation\u2019s second largest opposition party, whose members dress in red overalls, have delayed the start of Mr. Zuma\u2019s previous speeches, heckled him and demanded his resignation before walking out en masse. Should Mr. Zuma deliver the address, the Economic Freedom Fighters have promised similar actions.\n\nBut an address by Mr. Zuma would leave some A.N.C. lawmakers in a difficult situation \u2014 whether to visibly support him, adopt a critical pose, remain neutral or even boycott the address.\n\nThe Economic Freedom Fighters and other opposition parties are also pushing for Mr. Zuma\u2019s resignation. A motion of no-confidence called by the Economic Freedom Fighters has been scheduled for a vote in Parliament on Feb. 22.\n\nThat, too, would put A.N.C. lawmakers critical of Mr. Zuma in a difficult situation. The party has helped Mr. Zuma survive previous opposition-led votes of no confidence. While many members of the governing party want Mr. Zuma to step down, some have said that they do not want the opposition to lead the effort.\n\nMr. Ramaphosa, who has been nudging Mr. Zuma to resign without deepening the party split, has said that Mr. Zuma should not be humiliated. His supporters say that reflects Mr. Ramaphosa\u2019s skillful negotiating style and his view of the big picture.\n\nBut others interpret Mr. Ramaphosa\u2019s attitude as a sign of weakness. Julius Malema, the leader of the Economic Freedom Fighters, said in a television interview that Mr. Ramaphosa was \u201ca coward\u201d and that the A.N.C. was paralyzed.", "title": "President Zuma\u2019s Speech Postponed as South African Power Struggle Intensifies", "authors": ["Norimitsu Onishi"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "GURGAON, India \u2014 When the Trump family jet lands in India this week, the family member taking a tour of the world\u2019s largest democracy \u2014 with a Secret Service detail in tow \u2014 won\u2019t be the president on a diplomatic mission.
