Mr. Himes noted that the president had declassified the contents of a rival Republican memo, based on the same underlying documents, that criticized the F.B.I.\u2019s behavior despite vigorous objections from both the bureau and the Justice Department.\n\n\u201cThere is just no way that man will allow the release of information that shows that the Nunes memo is just plain wrong,\u201d Mr. Himes said in an interview, referring to the Republican memo drafted by aides to Devin Nunes, Republican of California and the committee\u2019s chairman.\n\nBoth memos address the F.B.I.\u2019s justification for seeking a secret court warrant in October 2016 to eavesdrop on the former Trump campaign aide, Carter Page, who was suspected of being an agent of Russia.", "title": "Pressure From Trump May Lead to Revision of Democratic Memo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Regarding Mr. Blackmun, Mr. Probst said, \u201cHe has served the U.S.O.C. with distinction\u201d since becoming its chief executive in 2010. \u201cWe think that he did what he was supposed to do and did the right thing at every turn.\u201d\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Probst said that after the results of the investigation are made public, \u201cwhatever actions are required and are appropriate, based upon on that investigation, will be taken by our board.\u201d\n\nTo the hundreds of girls and women who have said they were sexually abused by Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar, the gymnastics team doctor who has been convicted of multiple sex crimes, Mr. Probst said, \u201cThe Olympic system failed you and we are so incredibly sorry.\u201d\n\nHe did not say specifically that the U.S.O.C. had failed the athletes, seeming to choose his words carefully, perhaps attempting to shield the Olympic committee\u2019s liability in several lawsuits that have been filed. Asked to clarify, Mr. Probst noted that the U.S.O.C. was part of the Olympic system.\n\nMore than 260 athletes, several of them Olympic medalists, have accused Dr. Nassar, who has been sentenced to decades in prison, of abusing them, often in the guise of medical treatment.\n\nThe appearance of scores of the athletes at his sentencing hearings last month threw the Olympic committee into crisis as several publicly accused it of not doing enough to protect them.\n\nThrough his tenure as chief executive, Mr. Blackmun has been highly regarded and viewed as a stabilizing force in an organization previously troubled by chaotic leadership. He has served in a number of roles at the U.S.O.C., including general counsel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Blackmun\u2019s diligent efforts to repair a damaged relationship between United States Olympic officials and the International Olympic Committee resulted in Los Angeles being named as the host city for the 2028 Summer Games.\n\nBut criticism of the U.S.O.C.\u2019s handling of the gymnastics abuse scandal \u2014 one of the largest in sports history \u2014 has led two United States senators and a group of about 30 former Olympians, athletes\u2019 representatives and child-advocacy experts to call for Mr. Blackmun to step down.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s done,\u201d said Edward G. Williams, a lawyer in New York who competed in the biathlon in the 1968 Winter Olympics and is a prominent advocate for athletes\u2019 rights. \u201cScott\u2019s leadership flaw was that he forgot who he serves. He serves the athletes; he doesn\u2019t serve the N.G.B.s,\u201d parlance for national sports governing bodies.\n\nMr. Williams is a chief organizer of a group of athletes, coaches and lawyers called the Committee to Restore Integrity to the U.S.O.C. This week, the group called for Mr. Blackmun\u2019s ouster, after similar demands made recently by Senators Jeanne Shaheen, a Democrat from New Hampshire, and Joni Ernst, a Republican from Iowa.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe senators called for Mr. Blackmun to step down after a report in The Wall Street Journal that the U.S.O.C. did not intervene despite learning in 2015 from U.S.A. Gymnastics that gymnasts were victims of possible sexual misconduct by Dr. Nassar, a year before accusations became public in an investigation by The Indianapolis Star.\n\nThe U.S.O.C. has said it followed proper procedures and was told that the authorities were being contacted. But The New York Times has reported that as an F.B.I. investigation plodded along between July 2015 and September 2016, at least 40 girls and women say Dr. Nassar molested them during that period.\n\nThe Olympic reform group has sent a 13-page report to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, which is investigating the sexual abuse of gymnasts.\n\nIn its letter, the reform group described what it said was a failure by Mr. Blackmun and the Olympic committee to sufficiently protect athletes from sexual abuse over the past three decades in various sports such as gymnastics, taekwondo, swimming and speedskating.\n\nAthletes who complained of sexual abuse were left to fend for themselves in arbitration instead of being able to rely on the U.S.O.C. for safety, the group said in its report. As a result, it said, Mr. Blackmun and the Olympic committee \u201ccreated the underlying conditions for sexual abuse to thrive by cutting athletes off from institutional support.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne of the reform group members is Nancy Hogshead-Makar, a three-time gold medalist in swimming at the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles and a lawyer who said she was serving as an expert on sexual abuse on behalf of some gymnasts in civil litigation.\n\nIn a statement, Ms. Hogshead-Makar said that Mr. Blackmun \u201callowed one of the country\u2019s largest youth-serving organizations to avoid basic child protection measures, such as prohibitions on adults being alone with children.\u201d\n\nShe added: \u201cHe has instructed the U.S.O.C. to sit on the sidelines when athletes have been sexually abused. He has ignored the pleas of athletes, all in order to serve the U.S.O.C.\u2019s corporate interests of limited civil liability. He does not deserve to lead our Olympic team.\u201d\n\nMark Jones, a spokesman for the U.S.O.C., said Friday: \u201cWe\u2019ve seen the letter and obviously fundamentally disagree on a number of points. There are some instances in the letter that are flat-out untrue, and we look forward to further discussing it with the House Energy and Commerce Committee.\u201d\n\nSteven Ungerleider, a sports psychologist in Eugene, Ore., who said that his consulting team had interviewed 18 of Dr. Nassar\u2019s accusers, provided The Times with an email copy of a letter he said he had recently sent to Mr. Blackmun, urging him to resign.\n\nMr. Ungerleider, who has been affiliated with the U.S.O.C. for three decades, wrote that he urged Mr. Blackmun more than a year ago to intervene with U.S.A. Gymnastics and to say something public about the abuse scandal.\n\nMr. Blackmun\u2019s reply, according to Mr. Ungerleider\u2019s letter, was that lawyers representing the Olympic committee recommended that officials \u201ckeep our heads low and our mouths shut.\u201d\n\nThe athletes abused by Dr. Nassar needed the U.S.O.C.\u2019s support, but instead received a \u201cdeathly silent\u201d response from Mr. Blackmun, Mr. Ungerleider wrote. He added, \u201cYour lack of oversight, fiduciary duty and moral compass has been despicable.\u201d\n\nMr. Jones said he had not yet seen Mr. Ungerleider\u2019s letter and would not comment until he had read it.", "title": "Pressure Grows for U.S. Olympic Committee Chief to Step Down", "authors": ["Jer\u00e9 Longman"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced the Excelsior scholarship program offering free tuition to New York\u2019s public colleges and universities last year, many of New York\u2019s private colleges worried that they would lose prospective students. And, indeed, in November, a survey released by the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities, which represents private nonprofit colleges in the state, found that freshmen enrollment at the schools by New York residents slipped 6 percent in the fall of 2017.\n\nBut in the middle of admissions season, the state\u2019s private schools say their numbers are up, despite the price competition from Excelsior, which the governor last week credited with increasing applications to State University of New York and City University of New York affiliated schools by 10 percent. The growth, he said, was \u201cproof positive that students are seizing this unprecedented opportunity.\u201d\n\nSUNY and CUNY\u2019S increases actually pale in comparison to some of the private colleges, including smaller ones that mostly draw from within the state. At Hartwick College, less than a mile from SUNY Oneonta in the Catskills, freshman applications for the fall of 2018 are up by 43 percent over all, and 41 percent among New York state residents. At St. Lawrence University, located about 20 miles from the Canadian border, applications have climbed 12 percent, reversing a drop from the previous year. And at Alfred University in southwestern New York, near the Pennsylvania border, applications have risen 14 percent to a record high, while deposits have increased 30 percent.\n\nIn response to Excelsior, many of the schools have begun new scholarships, or are making efforts to highlight their advantages over the public institutions and target prospective students.", "title": "Private College Applications Rise Despite Cuomo Tuition Plan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMINNEAPOLIS \u2014 The hard-hitting linebackers Ray Lewis and Brian Urlacher and the big-play receiver Randy Moss each made the Pro Football Hall of Fame on his first try, while the receiver Terrell Owens got in on his third time on the ballot.\n\nSafety Brian Dawkins, in his second year of eligibility, also was chosen by the Hall of Fame voters on Saturday.\n\nThose five were the modern-day player selections in an eight-person class that also included the executive Bobby Beathard and two nominees chosen by the Seniors Committee, the former Green Bay Packers lineman Jerry Kramer and the former Houston Oilers linebacker Robert Brazile.\n\nLewis and Urlacher helped define the middle linebacker position in their era. Lewis won two Associated Press Defensive Player of the Year awards and one Super Bowl Most Valuable Player Award for the Baltimore Ravens, and Urlacher won a Defensive Player of the Year award, too.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMoss and Owens were two of the most dynamic receivers of their time, but also lightning rods because of a periodic inability to get along well with teammates and coaches. For me \u2014 and your mileage may vary \u2014 solving each one was very satisfying, but didn\u2019t necessarily reveal what the next one should be, and I enjoyed that. When I got to the revealer at 51A, I had a moment of \u201cawww \u2026\u201d because I have friends who do this for a living and it seemed to me to be a nice tip of the hat to them.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nWe\u2019re celebrating LEXICOGRAPHERS, the people who write and compile dictionaries. My dictionary of choice is Merriam-Webster, and one of my favorite editors there is Kory Stamper, who wrote a book \u201cWord by Word: The Secret Life of Dictionaries.\u201d She also has a hilarious Twitter feed:\n\nPhoto\n\nToday our clues are definitions, right out of the dictionary, more or less. Your first hint is that the first word of each theme clue is not only not capitalized, but is also the part of speech of part of the answer. For example, at 20A, the clue is \u201cadj. under the influence of a drug,\u201d and the answer is HIGH DEFINITION. This is not the HIGH DEFINITION you see on television; this is the DEFINITION of what it is to be HIGH.\n\nClever, right? There are only three theme entries beside the revealer, so I\u2019ll leave the others to you. They\u2019re fun, and even if the format of 45A is a bit different than the others, I\u2019m willing to give that a pass because I think the theme as a whole is a neat find. In addition, all three theme entries and their revealer are unique entries.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd remember, if you need extra help, you can peek at the answer key in the link below.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n10D: Wordplay alert! \u201cMakes the rounds?\u201d could mean that you are getting around, or even a doctor on rounds, but today the answer is BARTENDS, which is what you do when you make rounds of drinks.", "title": "Producing the Clues", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "When Merlijn and Sils, Dutch boys who are 11 and 10, meet Afghan and Syrian youths while visiting a refugee camp in Greece, the children seem to have nothing in common. But using cellphone translation apps and a knowledge of English words, they begin to connect \u2014 over childhood games, a snowball fight, their mutual curiosity. By the time the Dutch leave \u2014 the boys\u2019 mothers are camp volunteers \u2014 the two groups have forged a surprisingly trusting and tender bond.\n\nSound more like a movie than real life? This story is both, unfolding in Kim Brand\u2019s \u201cHello Salaam,\u201d a Dutch documentary short in the New York International Children\u2019s Film Festival, which arrives on Friday with Masaaki Yuasa\u2019s exuberant anime feature \u201cLu Over the Wall\u201d and continues through March 18 in six venues, with more than 100 works from over 30 countries. But the medication has one disadvantage: it turns urine a vivid blue.\n\n\u201cThis is something we need to solve, because it could stop people from using it,\u201d said Teun Bousema, a microbiologist at Radboud University Medical Center in the Netherlands and an author of the study, which was published Tuesday in The Lancet Infectious Diseases.\n\nModern malaria treatments, based on the drug artemisinin, are still effective in Africa and save hundreds of thousands of lives each year. But scientists fear the parasites will develop resistance, as they have in Southeast Asia, and are seeking ways to kill them faster using cocktails of several drugs.\n\nMethylene blue, a dye used to stain tissues viewed under a microscope, can be taken by tablet or injection, and is sometimes used to treat urethral infections and a hemoglobin disorder.", "title": "Promising Malaria Drug Has a Striking Drawback: Blue Urine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "JERUSALEM \u2014 Israel\u2019s attorney general, Avichai Mandelblit, was Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu\u2019s favored candidate for the country\u2019s top legal job. Admirers say the law is Mr. Mandelblit\u2019s only agenda and his moral compass.\n\nEither way, Mr. Mandelblit, who rose from relative obscurity as a military prosecutor, is likely to become the most scrutinized person in Israel in the coming months.\n\nAfter the Israeli police on Tuesday recommended that Mr. Netanyahu be charged with bribery, fraud and breach of trust in two corruption cases, Mr. Mandelblit became the one who will ultimately decide, in consultation with state prosecutors, whether the evidence warrants taking Mr. Netanyahu to court.", "title": "Promoted by Netanyahu, Israel\u2019s Attorney General Must Now Scrutinize Him", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "When police officers respond to vehicle collisions in New York City, they often call a tow truck from a rotating list to help clean up.\n\nThe list is intended to make sure that the towing is fairly distributed among the companies licensed to perform the work. But in reality, according to four indictments unsealed Wednesday in Manhattan, nearly a dozen of the companies on the list were illegally controlled by a single enterprise.\n\nThe enterprise involved at least 17 people and 10 companies that were indicted on charges that included corruption and conspiracy in connection with what the district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., described as a classic scheme to enrich themselves and maintain \u201ca violent, corrupt and nearly complete monopoly\u201d on the towing business.\n\n\u201cIf you were involved in a collision between June 2015 and December 2017 and received assistance from a towing company,\u201d he said at a news conference, \u201cyou were most likely an unwitting customer of an illegal enterprise that dominated New York City\u2019s towing business.\u201d", "title": "Prosecutor Says a Ring Tried to Monopolize Towing in New York", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "The idea reflects a recognition that no swatch of the Western landscape can be separated from the larger whole, and it may provide one path to pay for conservation of wildlife and working lands \u2014 the ranches and adjacent public lands they lease \u2014 around Yellowstone. The proposal lacks detail and will be complicated by an important debate about fee increases at national parks, but it deserves a close look from federal officials and conservationists.\n\nDespite this progress, the threats to migrations are still outpacing conservation. This is why leadership from the federal government, with its immense reach across hundreds of millions of acres, could be so important.\n\nBut gaps and questions linger. Many migrations cross Forest Service lands, which are administered by the Department of Agriculture and beyond the reach of Mr. Zinke\u2019s order. Most also cross private lands where funding is needed for conservation easements and incentives to accommodate wildlife. By joining with Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue, Mr. Zinke could engage not only the Forest Service but also conservation programs authorized by the last farm bill that can be used to help ranchers and farmers conserve habitats of migratory herds.\n\nSecretaries Zinke and Perdue would need assistance from Congress, which controls the purse strings on farm bill conservation programs as well as the Land and Water Conservation Fund\u2014 another potentially crucial funding tool in the conservation of migrations.\n\nTo be sure, Mr. Zinke\u2019s Interior Department has accelerated oil and gas leasing significantly in the past year, and some industry groups and Western stakeholders will push back on any new land protections whatsoever. That\u2019s why the ultimate test of the new policy may come when a new gas field or wind farm is proposed in the middle of a migration corridor or a winter range.\n\nMr. Zinke\u2019s order states that \u201cthe best available science\u201d will be used to inform \u201cplanning and developing energy\u201d and \u201cother relevant projects to avoid or minimize potential negative impacts on wildlife.\u201d If that\u2019s really the case, these migratory herds should receive much new attention in federal decision-making on public lands.\n\nCommon ground is hard to come by in America right now. At kitchen tables and diners all across the West, conservationists, ranchers and sportsmen talk more and more about the so-called 80/20 rule here: If we are definitely going to disagree about 20 percent of whatever we take up together, we should try to focus on the 80 percent we can agree on. It\u2019s a principle that could help us find a path to saving America\u2019s last great wildlife migrations, and maybe much more.", "title": "Opinion | Protecting America\u2019s Last Great Animal Migrations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "We need a new story about the Earth that isn\u2019t just a litany of alarming statistics about crashing wildlife populations, polluted air and water, and climate chaos. We need a story that reminds us that the continuing degradation of landscapes and the seas is not necessarily a one-way street toward irreversible destruction.\n\nOn Monday we began to write such a story with the government of Chile. Under the wide skies of the new Patagonia National Park, President Michelle Bachelet and I formalized the largest-ever expansion of a national park system prompted by a donation of private land.\n\nOur organization, Tompkins Conservation, has donated roughly one million acres of privately assembled conservation land to Chile for national parks. Also included were lodging, campground and dining facilities, and trails, bridges and roads. In accepting the gift, the Chilean government is creating five new parks and expanding three others. With roughly nine million acres of federal land from Chile, these new parks add 10.3 million acres to Chile\u2019s excellent park system. This is more than three times the size of Yosemite and Yellowstone National Parks combined.\n\nFor more than two decades, my husband, Douglas Tompkins, and I worked alongside our team and through the Tompkins Conservation family of foundations to acquire and aggregate wildlife habitat and then donate it to the park systems of Chile and Argentina. In partnership with other like-minded philanthropists, conservation activists and leaders of various political parties in those countries, with this latest donation, more than 13 million acres have been conserved in the two countries.", "title": "Opinion | Protecting Wilderness as an Act of Democracy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.\n\nI\u2019m the founding director of a nonprofit that works with local government on legal policy matters. Everyone on my small staff is competent, but all are tied in to political forces in the region. My board of directors is packed with elected officials, as well as a couple of community members. The political influence causes a lot of dysfunction, and I\u2019m happily on my way to another position in a different field. The agency has successfully grown under my direction, but I\u2019m worried that my colleagues will not keep the place functioning smoothly \u2014 and that their poor performance will somehow be blamed on me. Is there a checklist or some sort of parting document I can prepare to protect my reputation? LIZ\n\nHere\u2019s one (admittedly rude) thought: Get over yourself. That\u2019s a churlish thing to say, but I mean it in the most reassuring way possible. We\u2019ve all had the feeling that our workplace would completely crumble in our absence. It\u2019s rarely true. So at least consider the possibility that the organization will muddle along happily without you.\n\nMore seriously, the best thing you can do is worry less about your reputation than about the organization itself.\n\n\u201cWhen I think of making a checklist,\u201d says Rebecca Zucker, a partner in the leadership development firm Next Step Partners, \u201cI think, \u2018What do I need to make sure is in place before I leave?\u2019\u201d\n\nMake sure you\u2019re giving your people the information and guidance you believe they need \u2014 and responding to whatever they believe they need. In short, leave the agency \u201cin a good position to continue on the trajectory that you\u2019ve set it on,\u201d Ms. Zucker adds.", "title": "Protecting Your Reputation When You\u2019re Ready to Go", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "But there are still suspicions about the North\u2019s intentions.\n\n\u201cNorth Korea will cause trouble one way or another in order to interrupt the successful completion of the Games,\u201d said Yoo Dong-ryul, the head of the Korea Institute of Liberal Democracy in Seoul. \u201cIn all the years the Kim dynasty has been in power, North Korea has never once properly cooperated with South Korea.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn November 1987, 10 months before Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games, North Korean agents detonated a bomb on a South Korean airliner, killing all 104 passengers and 11 crew members. The goal, one of the agents later told investigators, was to frighten international athletes and visitors out of attending the Games.\n\nWhen South Korea was co-host of the soccer World Cup in 2002, a naval clash with North Korea in disputed waters killed six South Korean sailors just hours before the South played in the third-place match.\n\nBut the North did not take part in those sporting events. When North Korea has participated in events hosted by the South \u2014 the 2002 Asian Games in Busan and the 2014 Asian Games in Incheon, for example \u2014 there have been no major disruptions.\n\nThat is why South Korean officials and analysts argue that the risk of a military provocation during these Olympics \u2014 nuclear or otherwise \u2014 has been significantly reduced.\n\nStill, South Korea plans to field up to 60,000 security personnel each day of the Games, including the 50,000 soldiers \u2014 more than twice the number of military personnel deployed during the 2016 Summer Olympics in Brazil.\n\n\u201cThe possibility of a missile or nuclear test is extremely low,\u201d said Shin Beom-chul, an expert on North Korea at the government-run Korea National Diplomatic Academy in Seoul. \u201cThe North may use the Games as a political propaganda opportunity to show that while they may be a nuclear power, they also want to have peace with their neighbors.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSince North Korea agreed to attend the Games, organizers have scrambled to coordinate security and logistics for its delegation, which includes a cheerleading squad.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJeong Se-yun, a provincial police official involved in the planning, said the North\u2019s decision was a tremendous relief. \u201cBut it also created a lot more work for us,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve barely slept in the last month. That\u2019s why my eyes are always red now.\u201d\n\nOne fear is that something might happen during the Games that could prompt North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, to recall its athletes and retaliate in some way.\n\nA small group of right-wing protesters burned an image of Mr. Kim as a North Korean delegation traveled through Seoul last month. The police quickly extinguished the fire to avoid angering the visitors, who accord Mr. Kim an almost godlike status.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe state media in North Korea condemned the act as a \u201chideous crime\u201d committed by \u201chuman rejects,\u201d and warned that only South Korea would be to blame if the North withdrew from the Games.\n\nThere is also concern that a North Korean athlete or another member of the delegation might try to defect, putting the South Korean government in the difficult position of deciding whether to return the defector or anger the North.\n\nAnalysts said a defection during the Olympics would be highly unlikely because the North has almost certainly vetted its delegation carefully and would keep its people under close watch.\n\nThe authorities are also on alert against a cyberattack, either by the North or by Russia, whose delegation was banned from participating under the Russian flag in the Pyeongchang Games after revelations of systematic government-sponsored doping.\n\nNorth Korea has developed sophisticated hacking capabilities and launched a series of damaging attacks around the world, including one in 2013 that temporarily knocked out three banks and two television networks in South Korea.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo combat more conventional threats, organizers said the security forces intended to deploy both old-fashioned checkpoints and new technologies such as facial recognition systems, smart cameras and drones. A tactical surveillance blimp will hover above.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSouth Korea is considered one of the world\u2019s safest tourist destinations, with low crime rates and essentially no history of terrorist activity other than by the North. Nevertheless, the immigration authorities said last month that they had deported 17 foreign nationals believed to pose a terror risk, according to the Korea Times newspaper. Some of the deportees were said to be from Central Asia and Southeast Asia.\n\n\u201cBroadly, we consider the event low-risk,\u201d the London-based Risk Advisory Group wrote in a recent analysis of the Pyeongchang Games. \u201cCompared with the host cities of the most recent Winter and Summer Games in 2014 and 2016 respectively, Pyeongchang is a benign environment in terms of terrorism, crime and unrest.\u201d\n\nIn the rural areas around Pyeongchang, the most commonly reported crime is drunken fighting.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany residents shrugged off the idea that the North might attempt to disrupt the Games, which may reflect the fact that South Koreans have grown accustomed to living within range of its artillery and rockets. Even security officials sounded nonchalant, as if surprised by the world\u2019s anxiety.\n\n\u201cWe are well aware of the international community\u2019s concerns about the safety of the Olympics due to threat of North Korean nuclear test and missile launches,\u201d the interagency body established to handle Olympic security said in a statement in response to written questions. \u201cSigns of North Korean provocation are monitored 24/7 through various means every day, regardless of the Olympics.\u201d\n\nThe interagency body added that underground evacuation centers for up to 30,000 people had been prepared at an undisclosed site near Pyeongchang for use in the event of any sort of attack.\n\nOther security measures include an emergency alert system that can send messages to all cellphones in the area, though it is unclear whether its operators are prepared for the tens of thousands of foreign visitors en route to Pyeongchang.\n\nOne recent morning an alert flashed on cellphones written only in Korean, causing a moment of panic among some non-Korean speakers, who immediately assumed the worst.\n\nIt turned out to be a warning to beware of fires because of dry weather.", "title": "Protecting an Olympics Held in North Korea\u2019s Nuclear Shadow", "authors": ["Amy Qin"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "JUBA, South Sudan \u2014 Demonstrations in South Sudan\u2019s capital turned violent on Tuesday as people took to the streets to protest the United States\u2019 new ban on supplying weapons to the country.\n\nOn Friday, the United States imposed a unilateral arms embargo on South Sudan, which is embroiled in a civil war. The State Department said it was \u201cappalled\u201d by the continuing violence perpetrated by both sides in the conflict.\n\nThe civil war has killed tens of thousands of people and displaced millions.\n\nOn Tuesday, hundreds of people gathered outside the United States Embassy in the capital, Juba, and the nearby United Nations base to show their anger.\n\nDemonstrators held up posters that included the slogans \u201cDown Down Mr. Trump\u201d and \u201cDon\u2019t weaken our nation Mr. Trump.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe protesters delivered a petition to the embassy, an embassy spokesman confirmed. None were seriously injured.", "title": "Protesters in South Sudan Denounce U.S. Arms Embargo", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSAN JUAN, P.R. \u2014 An explosion and fire at an electric substation threw much of northern Puerto Rico into darkness late Sunday in a setback for the territory\u2019s efforts to fully restore power more than five months after Hurricane Maria started one of the longest blackouts in United States history.\n\nThe island\u2019s Electric Power Authority said several municipalities were without power, including parts of the capital, San Juan, but officials were optimistic it could be restored within a day as they worked to repair a substation that controls voltage.\n\nThe blast illustrated the challenges of restoring a power grid that was already crumbling before it was devastated by Maria, a Category 4 hurricane.\n\nIn many cases, power workers are repairing equipment that should have long been replaced but remained online because of the power authority\u2019s yearslong financial crisis. The power authority is worth roughly $4 billion, carries $9 billion in debt and has long been criticized for political patronage and inefficiency. It also struggled with frequent blackouts, including an island-wide outage in September 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was not immediately known what caused Sunday\u2019s fire, which was quickly extinguished. Officials said the explosion knocked two other substations offline and caused a total loss of 400 megawatts worth of generation.\n\nHeavy black smoke billowed from the substation as neighbors in the area described on social media seeing the sky turn orange following a loud explosion. San Juan Mayor Carmen Cruz posted on Twitter that no injuries had been reported and that power had been restored in some areas of the city.", "title": "Puerto Rico Hit by Blackouts After Power Station Blast", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Four months after Puerto Rico was battered by Hurricane Maria, Congress last week approved more badly needed emergency assistance, including $2 billion to repair the island\u2019s severely damaged power grid. An additional $9 billion will be directed to recovery and restoration projects in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.\n\nThe expectation is that this aid will help provide relief not only to the hundreds of thousands of utility customers in Puerto Rico who are still without power but also to the more than three million islanders as a whole, who are still being warned to boil water before drinking it. But the money from Washington falls far short of the island\u2019s requirements.\n\nPuerto Rico needs more than bandages. It needs to rethink and redesign its electric, water and wastewater systems, both to protect them against the next big storm and to provide the dependable service they were failing to give residents before Hurricane Maria. To accomplish that and other rebuilding needs, Puerto Rico had sought $94.4 billion in total disaster aid in November. That included nearly $18 billion to rebuild the power grid \u2014 nine times what Congress has provided.\n\nAchieving resiliency in the face of powerful storms will require the wholesale rebuilding of the island\u2019s utilities. Simply patching them up will not be enough. If that\u2019s the extent of the fix, the island is likely to find itself back in the same place after the next big storm, with taxpayers asked to spend new billions on more life preservers.", "title": "Opinion | Puerto Rico Needs More Than Bandages", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 Puns and Anagrams are two ingredients in a cryptic puzzle, also called a \u201cBritish puzzle\u201d after its popularity in England (and much of Europe). They\u2019re pretty fiendish! Every clue has at least one form of trickery, you\u2019re rarely able to completely solve any clues with crosses, and the misdirections can be creative, frankly, to the point of mild lunacy. Tempting, right? If you\u2019re interested in getting into cryptic crosswords, today\u2019s variety is a great gateway drug. If the idea makes you shudder, you should try this puzzle by Sam Ezersky anyway; it draws from a different set of skills than a regular crossword puzzle, requires and rewards a sense of humor, and is very gratifying (and possible!) to solve.\n\nFirst of all, there are usually a ton of anagrams, which are the equivalent of multiple-choice questions on a very difficult exam, although they\u2019re not labeled such. The thing is, the answer is in front of you; you just need to scramble up some letters. A nice, approachable example of this would be 6D, \u201cSteals electric cars.\u201d One word, reordered, defines the rest of the clue; so S-T-E-A-L-S becomes TESLAS, \u201celectric cars.\u201d Other straightforward clues like this are 20A, 34A, 59A, 57D.\n\nThe next step, putting together longer words, or anagramming two words in a clue or an entry, appears at 10A, 17A, 32A, 38A, 10D, 14D, 31D and 44A, among others. 32A, for example, is a common crossword entry that reads pretty funny, but HELP COIN \u2014> PINOCHLE.\n\nSometimes the clue will scramble one name into another, which is a little tricky: 16A, Maori woman, for example, anagrams Maori to Moira. Have you seen Catherine O\u2019Hara as Moira Rose in \u201cSchitt\u2019s Creek\u201d? Hilarious.\n\nThere are also clues with some misdirection \u2014 like numbers that need to be simply spelled out (1A) or converted to letter(s) by the Roman numeral system (1D). A couple don\u2019t use every last speck of a clue, which is permitted. 13D, for example, \u201cDepot near Las Vegas,\u201d leaves the Vegas out to solve to ARSENAL. A few clues have a side of pun with their anagram; don\u2019t be surprised to need to know a bit of both for a clue like 41D, where an \u201cex\u201d can become an X, or 45D, where \u201cwell-head\u201d tells you to use the \u201chead\u201d of the word \u201cwell\u201d in your answer \u2014 W.\n\nThat segues us into puns. Puns are infinite, one hopes, as language evolves and we grow (hopefully?) ever cleverer. I was completely delighted by Mr. Ezersky\u2019s punny jokes, and had to mumble and mull over several to get them. If it weren\u2019t for another accessible trait of Puns and Anagrams, their configuration as a standard crossword, I probably wouldn\u2019t have been able to solve them altogether. A few flavors included here were visual puns, like 64A: G W G, or a W in two Gs \u2014> WINGS; an original-looking fill-in-the-blanks thing at 33D and 49D : _ _ ds dec _ _ atio _ _? becomes \u201cadds decorations?\u201d \u2014> ADORNS, the missing letters; and \u201cgrammagrams,\u201d where you need to sound out letters to make words or vice versa, the most fiendish example here being 23D: \u201cSeaside, by the sound of it.\u201d That would be C side; or B and D \u2014 BEADY.\n\nWhat did you think?!", "title": "Puns and Anagrams", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "UFA, Russia \u2014 As President Vladimir V. Putin was about to step out onto the gleaming white cement floor of the Ufa Engine Industrial Association, where motors are assembled for military helicopters, Alyona V. Popova was busy organizing her work station, more out of nerves than necessity.\n\nHis predetermined path would lead him right past her spot in the government-owned plant, erected six months ago as part of the president\u2019s program for military hardware once built in the now-hostile territory of Ukraine.\n\nMs. Popova, 26, was grateful to the president for helping her finally land a factory job with a future. She allowed, however, that she might express a few qualms if he stopped to chat.\n\n\u201cOur salaries are low,\u201d she said, under $500 a month, and Russia spent excessive rubles on foreign adventures. \u201cWhen will that money flow into Russia instead of flowing out?\u201d she added, echoing remarks made by other workers. \u201cWe need roads built according to modern standards.\u201d", "title": "Putin the Campaigner: Scripted and Awkward, Save One Big Hug", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "What\u2019s more, she contends that embracing clean energy affirms the populist beliefs the Tea Party espouses. The monopoly control of utilities over energy supplies stands in contrast to the free market, she said, while solar and wind power represent energy freedom.\n\nPhoto\n\nOver the last five years, she has unabashedly linked arms with environmental groups championed by the left, like the Sierra Club. And on Thursday, she is set to appear at an event in San Francisco with a member of the Democratic National Committee\u2019s executive committee \u2014 Christine Pelosi, daughter of Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader vilified by the right.\n\n\u201cYou can have success if you have environmentalists look at saving the environment as an ethic, and evangelicals as saving God\u2019s creation,\u201d Christine Pelosi said. \u201cYou don\u2019t have to agree on everything.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile Ms. Dooley\u2019s efforts are still an anomaly in conservative circles, she has formed a group called the Green Tea Coalition to rally more conservatives around renewable energy.\n\n\u201cDebbie is being a little bit of a trailblazer on the climate issue, but she was always a trailblazer on clean energy,\u201d said Stephen Smith, executive director of the Southern Alliance for Clean Energy, an environmental advocacy group based in Knoxville, Tenn.\n\nMs. Dooley sees the Trump administration\u2019s tariffs on solar-panel imports as the latest in a series of impediments to clean energy. A former information technology systems analyst \u2014 \u201cprobably why I am so drawn to innovative energy technology\u201d \u2014 she is particularly critical of policies that make it more difficult for consumers to become more self-reliant for their energy.\n\nAt 59, from her rental home here in the Atlanta suburbs, she works full time on utility, clean energy and climate issues with a total budget of $90,000 a year, using funds from the San Francisco-based Energy Foundation and other donors. She has worked to persuade legislators and regulators in her state to embrace measures that would foster greater use of solar power.\n\nBut it wasn\u2019t easy. \u201cI didn\u2019t just put my head in the sand like an ostrich,\u201d Ms. Dooley said. \u201cLet\u2019s face it: They had to come kicking and screaming.\u201d\n\nShe is also having a wider impact, taking on some of the nation\u2019s largest utilities.\n\nProponents of residential solar power like Ms. Dooley accuse utility companies and the energy industry at large of waging war on efforts to free consumers from their power companies, even if only for a slightly lower electric bill.\n\nFor the utilities, which are facing flat or declining consumption, residential solar power threatens the bottom line. They have responded by spending tens of millions of dollars to combat consumers\u2019 efforts to untether themselves from the electric grid.\n\nA new study by the Sustainable Investments Institute, a nonprofit group that conducts research on efforts to influence corporate boards, found that utilities had spent $50 million between 2011 and 2016 to block clean energy in seven states: Alaska, California, Florida, Michigan, Ohio, Oregon and Washington.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite calling itself the Sunshine State, Florida lags behind states like New York and New Jersey in residential solar installations. But a 2016 campaign resulted in overwhelming voter approval of a constitutional amendment to provide a property tax exemption for solar installations. In a referendum months later, voters rejected a utility-backed measure, presented as pro-solar, that would have actually allowed new fees on home solar users.\n\nDifferent Directions on Solar Energy Republican-leaning states lag in residential solar capacity, though some of those states are among the leaders in large solar-power projects by utility companies. New Mexico 0.6 10. Colorado 0.5\n\nFlorida Power & Light and Duke Energy spent a combined $14.8 million on the referendum campaign. Ms. Dooley worked to counter their efforts, standing with environmentalists and business groups and helping win support from the Christian Coalition and self-identified libertarians.\n\nHer side prevailed. And aided by the property-tax break and lower solar-panel prices, Florida more than doubled the number of residential solar projects in 2016 compared with the previous year, according to the Southern Alliance for Clean Energy.\n\nClean-energy proponents are determined to build on such successes. According to research by the University of California, Irvine, the California Institute of Technology and the Carnegie Institution for Science, 80 percent of the nation\u2019s power needs can be met by solar and wind.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlthough she backed the Florida tax break, Ms. Dooley said she was convinced that alternative energy sources could hold their own without government intervention. \u201cI think solar and wind have progressed to the point that they don\u2019t need subsidies,\u201d she said. \u201cThe government shouldn\u2019t pick winners and losers.\u201d\n\nThat conservative shading to her argument might appeal to Republicans. Still, red states \u2014 particularly in the South \u2014 have been resistant to residential solar power, a review of data from the solar industry organization has found. If they support solar power at all, their utilities tend to want to produce it themselves.\n\nOf the 10 states with the most residential solar power, eight voted for Hillary Clinton in 2016. Of the 10 with the most solar capacity at utility scale, six voted for Mr. Trump.\n\nRandy Wheeless, a spokesman for Duke Energy, insists that utilities are embracing cleaner technologies, noting that a decision by the company to forgo building a nuclear plant in Florida included plans for new solar farms. He said Duke was one of the few utilities in the country to file comments opposing the solar-panel tariff.\n\nMr. Wheeless also said Duke had recently been adding 300 residential solar customers in Florida each month.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Lauren McDonald Jr., a member of the Georgia Public Service Commission who led efforts to bring more solar to his state, said the utilities simply didn\u2019t want to depart from the business model they had operated under for a century, despite the changing world of energy.\n\n\u201cTheir business is to generate electricity, transport it and to sell it,\u201d Mr. McDonald said. \u201cAnything that might come into play that might derail that agenda, they don\u2019t give up easily.\u201d\n\nNeither, it seems, does Ms. Dooley.\n\nWhen she talks about clean energy and climate change, she clutches her cellphone and pulls up a picture of her grandson, Ayden Sides.\n\n\u201cI fully believe we should be good stewards of what God gave us,\u201d Ms. Dooley said.", "title": "A Gun-Owning Trump Fan\u2019s New Crusade: Clean Energy", "authors": ["Ivan Penn"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "The Legal Aid Society has threatened to take the New York City Housing Authority to court unless the agency agrees to refund up to $15 million in rent to tenants who were left without heat or hot water during this winter\u2019s cold snap.\n\n\u201cUnless Nycha grants abatements, the Legal Aid Society will take necessary legal action to enforce our clients\u2019 rights,\u201d Lucy Newman, a staff lawyer for the Legal Aid Society, wrote in a letter sent to Nycha on Friday. The group gave Nycha until Feb. 21 to resolve the issue.\n\nNew York City has seen the most days below freezing this winter since 1961. The frigid temperatures have taken a toll on Nycha\u2019s aging boilers, leaving 323,098 residents without heat or hot water at some point during the heating season. Nycha officials have said that between Oct. 1, 2017, and Jan. 22, 143,000 apartments were without heat and hot water for an average of 48 hours.\n\nUsing this information, Legal Aid Society lawyers argue that anywhere from $2.5 million to $15 million in rent payments should be rebated based on the average monthly rent of $509, or $17 per day.", "title": "Putting a Price on Heat, Legal Aid Threatens to Sue Housing Authority", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Pyeongchang\u2019s obstacles were both economic and physical. It is one of the poorest places in Gangwon, South Korea\u2019s most isolated and least developed province, which shares a long border with the North. And though it is just 80 miles from Seoul, getting to Pyeongchang from the capital used to take hours on mountain roads that twist like \u201ca sheep\u2019s intestines,\u201d as the locals say.\n\nThe provincial governor, Choi Moon-soon, called it \u201cthe last place the government thought of when it thought of investment,\u201d adding, \u201cWe hoped an Olympics would change that.\u201d\n\nEven the town\u2019s name was a problem. Originally spelled \u201cPyongchang\u201d in English, it was often confused with Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea. So in 2000, the town added a letter, capitalized another and changed its name to \u201cPyeongChang,\u201d though most foreign news agencies declined to use the capital C.\n\nDespite the rebranding, a Kenyan man registered to attend a United Nations meeting in Pyeongchang in 2014 made headlines after he flew to Pyongyang by mistake.", "title": "Pyeongchang\u2019s Winding Path From Obscurity to Olympics Fame", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Qualcomm said on Thursday that its board had unanimously rejected a revised $121 billion buyout offer from Broadcom, a rival chip maker.\n\nThe board had determined that Broadcom\u2019s proposal \u201cmaterially undervalues\u201d Qualcomm and fell short of the firm regulatory commitment the deal would demand, given the significant downside risk of a failed transaction, the company said.\n\nQualcomm, based in San Diego, also said it had offered to meet with Broadcom, which has headquarters in Singapore and Irvine, Calif., to see if it could address the serious deficiencies in value and certainty in its proposal.\n\nBroadcom increased its offer on Monday to $82 a share from $70 a share, saying it was its \u201cbest and final\u201d offer. By doing so, Broadcom raised the stakes a month before Qualcomm\u2019s annual shareholder meeting, at which Broadcom hopes to unseat the entire board.", "title": "Qualcomm Rejects Broadcom\u2019s Revised Buyout Offer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQualcomm on Tuesday increased its takeover bid for rival chip maker NXP Semiconductors to about $44 billion in hopes of shoring up support for the deal, and to potentially fend off its own unwanted suitor, Broadcom.\n\nUnder the new terms, Qualcomm would pay $127.50 for each NXP share, 16 percent more than originally proposed, and the threshold for how many NXP shareholders must agree to tender their shares would be lowered to 70 percent from 80 percent.\n\nIn statements, Qualcomm officials said NXP technology would bolster their company\u2019s products for the next-generation 5G wireless standard.\n\n\u201cThe acquisition of NXP will enable us to accelerate our growth strategy,\u201d Tom Horton, Qualcomm\u2019s presiding director, said. \u201cThe board unanimously believes this is an attractive acquisition at this price for Qualcomm stockholders.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe revised bid was enough to win over investors controlling roughly 28 percent of NXP\u2019s shares, including Elliott Management, the activist hedge fund that had opposed Qualcomm\u2019s initial offer as too low. Elliott had argued that NXP, whose chips are used in cars, payment terminals and other products, was worth at least $135 a share.", "title": "Qualcomm, Moving to Fend Off Broadcom, Raises Bid for NXP to $44 Billion", "authors": ["Michael J. De La Merced"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "An 11-year-old Queens boy playing with a friend on an icy pond near his home died after he fell through the thin sheet of ice and into the frigid water on Tuesday afternoon, the authorities said.\n\nThe boy, Anthony Perez, had walked about 50 feet onto Strack Pond inside Forest Park when the ice suddenly gave way around 4 p.m. The boy plunged into the water, and his friend ran to get help. The Fire Department arrived within four minutes of a 911 call, and three firefighters began a frantic effort to rescue the submerged boy, the authorities said.\n\nThe firefighters jumped into the pond in their regular uniforms and broke up chunks of ice with their hands wading through chilly, chest-high water toward the hole where the boy fell. They pulled Anthony out of the water, holding him as firefighters on the shore reeled them back to safety with a rope.", "title": "Queens Boy Dies After Falling Into Icy Pond", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "The report also discusses a 2017 book, \u201cAssuming Boycott,\u201d that Ms. Raicovich edited with Kareem Estefan and Carin Kuoni. The museum said it received this payment on Tuesday.\n\nThe report also said that Ms. Raicovich allowed the museum to serve as a \u201cfiscal sponsor\u201d of a Kickstarter campaign for a new cultural center in the West Bank \u201cwithout the approval of or disclosure to the board, and without putting into place proper controls for the solicitation or use of such funds.\u201d The center on its Kickstarter site gives \u201cspecial thanks to the Queens Museum\u201d for its support.\n\nIn response to the report\u2019s findings, Councilman Lancman said in a telephone interview: \u201cThe leader of this museum is supposed to represent the values of Queens but also represent to the world our values. I didn\u2019t go barging into Uma\u2019s trailer, screaming at her to get into the car.\u201d\n\nHe said that he had tested the course, a one-lane strip of road in Mexico, before encouraging Ms. Thurman to perform the stunt, but then he decided to change the direction in which she would drive.\n\nThe change of direction \u201cwas the beginning of where the crash happened,\u201d he said.\n\nIn an Instagram post on Monday, Ms. Thurman praised Mr. Tarantino for helping her obtain the footage when he knew it could do him personal harm. I can only answer to the best of my conviction,\u201d the man answered. \u201cI can only imagine what it would be like to come home and find,\u201d he said, stopping in midsentence. \u201cI don\u2019t know if I can be fair. Some people can compartmentalize these things, I\u2019m maybe not as capable as others.\u201d\n\nStuart Silberg, a senior assistant district attorney, handled the questioning for the prosecution that day. He asked the jurors whether they had relatives who suffered from mental illness, had been victims of a crime and what their experience with the criminal justice system was. Then he went on: \u201cChildcare,\u201d he said pointedly.\n\n\u201cYou know in this case the judge told you the defendant murdered two children,\u201d he said. \u201cShe was responsible, in part, for their care. The people will prove to you that while they were in her care she murdered them. I\u2019d like to know from each one of you if you\u2019ve had any experience hiring anyone to help you with your children?\u201d\n\nA potential juror seated on a crowded courtroom bench whispered: \u201cDamn.\u201d Mr. Silberg went on to question each of the jurors who had hired or worked as a nanny about their experience.\n\nBefore posing her own questions to the potential jurors, the defense lawyer, Valerie Van Leer-Greenberg, laid out the difficult nature of the case. \u201cWe find ourselves dropped into unusual circumstances and as grown-ups we have to deal with them. It may not be pleasant for us, it may be emotionally charged, publicly regarded, despicable, unacceptable, irrefutable. But they\u2019re the circumstances,\u201d she said.\n\nShe explained that the case is about \u201ctwo beautiful kids that were killed, horribly killed.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhen this mother, Marina Krim comes in here, I mean, all of us will be affected, not just you, all of you, the world,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Van Leer-Greenberg asked potential Juror No. 9 if he was up to the task of being on the jury.
